Anon!: This cannot anger him.
Goodbye!: This can’t anger him.

Anon!: Nay, I bear it on my shoulders as a beggar wont her brat, and I think when he hath lamed me, I shall beg with it from door to door.
Goodbye!: I’ll beg it from door to door when he has lamed me.

Anon!: To what base uses we may return, Horatio.
Goodbye!: We can return to what base we use, Horatio.

Anon!: Come hither, sir.
Goodbye!: Come here, sir.

Anon!: Come to me, that of this I may speak more.
Goodbye!: Come to me, so I can speak more about this.

Anon!: Fair Beatrice, I thank you for your pains.
Goodbye!: Fair Beatrice, thank you for your efforts.

Anon!: Folded the writ up in form of th' other, Subscribed it, gave ’t th' impression, placed it safely, The changeling never known.
Goodbye!: Folded the writ up in the form of the other, signed it, gave it a safe impression, and placed it safely, the changeling never known.

Anon!: If he were dead, you’d weep for him.
Goodbye!: If he were dead, you’d cry for him.

Anon!: How?
Goodbye!: How?

Anon!: I am sure I am none such.
Goodbye!: I’m sure I’m not such a person.

Anon!: As I did sleep under this yew tree here, I dreamt my master and another fought, And that my master slew him.
Goodbye!: As I slept under this yew tree here, I dreamed my master and another fighter had fought, and that my master slew him.

Anon!: He is at hand, and Pindarus is come To do you salutation from his master.
Goodbye!: He’s at hand, and Pindarus’s coming to greet you from his master.

Anon!: I tell thee, Kate, ’twas burnt and dried away.
Goodbye!: I tell you, Kate, it was burnt and dried away.

Anon!: Indeed, it is a strange-disposèd time.
Goodbye!: It’s a strange time.

Anon!: Do not doubt, Cassio, But I will have my lord and you again As friendly as you were.
Goodbye!: I’ll have my lord and you again as friendly as you were.

Anon!: I would exult, man.
Goodbye!: I’d like to go, man.

Anon!: Captain Macmorris, when there is more better opportunity to be required, look you, I will be so bold as to tell you I know the disciplines of war, and there is an end.
Goodbye!: Captain Macmorris, when there’s more opportunity to be required, look, I’ll be so bold as to tell you I know the rules of war, and there’s an end.

Anon!: Lucius, who’s that knocking?
Goodbye!: Lucius, who’s that knocking?

Anon!: Yield, cur.
Goodbye!: Yield, curt.

Anon!: For my Lord Lackbeard there, he and I shall meet, and till then peace be with him.
Goodbye!: For my Lord Lackbeard there, he and I will meet, and until then we’ll be in peace with him.

Anon!: Macduff is missing, and your noble son.
Goodbye!: Macduff is missing, and your noble son.

Anon!: Your wrongs do set a scandal on my sex.
Goodbye!: Your wrongs have ruined my sexuality.

Anon!: Since the youth will not be entreated, his own peril on his forwardness.
Goodbye!: Since the youth won’t be able to get out of here, he’s putting his own risk on his future.

Anon!: I will bring you thither.
Goodbye!: I’ll bring you there.

Anon!: Indeed, he hath an excellent good name.
Goodbye!: Indeed, he has an excellent reputation.

Anon!: Angels are bright still, though the brightest fell.
Goodbye!: Angels are still bright, even though the brightest fell.

Anon!: O Cassio, whence came this?
Goodbye!: Oh Cassio, when did this come from?

Anon!: To me, sir?
Goodbye!: To me, sir?

Anon!: He is composed and framed of treachery, And fled he is upon this villainy.
Goodbye!: He’s a man who’s a man of treachery, and he’s fled from this evil.

Anon!: Fulvia thy wife first came into the field.
Goodbye!: Your wife Fulvia came first to the field.

Anon!: And if I cannot, I’ll find those that shall.
Goodbye!: And if I can’t, I’ll find those who can.

Anon!: I will assume thy part in some disguise And tell fair Hero I am Claudio, And in her bosom I’ll unclasp my heart And take her hearing prisoner with the force And strong encounter of my amorous tale.
Goodbye!: I’ll disguise your role and tell her that I’m Claudio, and I’ll unclasp my heart and take her prisoner with the force and strength of my amorous tale.

Anon!: Her eye in heaven Would through the airy region stream so bright That birds would sing and think it were not night.
Goodbye!: Her eyes would be so bright in the air that birds would sing and think it wasn’t night.

Anon!: The weary way hath made you melancholy.
Goodbye!: The weary way has made you melancholy.

Anon!: Tis the last service that I shall command you.
Goodbye!: It’s the last service I’ll command you.

Anon!: But fathers that bear bags  Shall see their children kind.
Goodbye!: But fathers who carry bags will see their children kind.

Anon!: I marvel what kin thou and thy daughters are.
Goodbye!: I marvel at how close you and your daughters are.

Anon!: Twere good you do so much for charity.
Goodbye!: You’d be good to do so much for charity.

Anon!: Come.
Goodbye!: Come on.

Anon!: I am sure of that.
Goodbye!: I’m sure of that.

Anon!: Alas, and woe!
Goodbye!: Oh, and I’m so sorry!

Anon!: The more fool you for laying on my duty.
Goodbye!: The more fool you are for laying on my duty.

Anon!: Farewell, thou lob of spirits.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, you lob of spirits.

Anon!: Our reasons are so full of good regard That were you, Antony, the son of Caesar, You should be satisfied.
Goodbye!: Our reasons are so good that if you were Antony, the son of Caesar, you would be satisfied.

Anon!: Now, Charmian!
Goodbye!: Now, Charmian!

Anon!: This fellow I remember Since once he played a farmer’s eldest son.
Goodbye!: This man I remember remembering once he played a farmer’s eldest son.

Anon!: What need one?
Goodbye!: What do you need?

Anon!: Call my sister so.
Goodbye!: Call my sister like that.

Anon!: Their malady convinces The great assay of art, but at his touch— Such sanctity hath heaven given his hand— They presently amend.
Goodbye!: Their malady convinces the great ass of art, but at his touch—that sanctity has given heaven his hand—they’re now changing.

Anon!: Caliban!
Goodbye!: Caliban!

Anon!: Ay, and that thou and the proudest of you all shall find when he comes home.
Goodbye!: Yes, and you and the most proud of you all will find when he comes home.

Anon!: Be bloody, bold, and resolute.
Goodbye!: Be bloody, bold, and resolute.

Anon!: He calls me “boy” and chides as he had power To beat me out of Egypt.
Goodbye!: He calls me “boy” and chides me as if he had power to beat me out of Egypt.

Anon!: Well, sir, in brief, the gown is not for me.
Goodbye!: Well, sir, I’m not sure the gown is for me.

Anon!: Pray you do not, sir.
Goodbye!: Don’t be shy, sir.

Anon!: Then hie you hence to Friar Lawrence’s cell.
Goodbye!: Then go to Friar Lawrence’s cell.

Anon!: Out of doubt he is transported.
Goodbye!: He’s not yet transported.

Anon!: Thou most lying slave, Whom stripes may move, not kindness!
Goodbye!: You lying slave, who can’t move, not kindness!

Anon!: This servitude makes you to keep unwed.
Goodbye!: This servitude makes you want to stay unwed.

Anon!: And then, as we have ta'en the sacrament, We will unite the white rose and the red.
Goodbye!: And then, as we’ve sat in the sacrament, we’ll unite the white rose and the red.

Anon!: Two of the fairest stars in all the heaven, Having some business, do entreat her eyes To twinkle in their spheres till they return.
Goodbye!: Two of the fairest stars in all the heavens, who have some business, are begging her eyes to twinkle in their spheres until they return.

Anon!: thieves!
Goodbye!: thieves!

Anon!: By so much the more shall I tomorrow be at the height of heart-heaviness, by how much I shall think my brother happy in having what he wishes for.
Goodbye!: I’ll be at the height of heart-heaviness tomorrow, and I’ll think my brother is happy with what he wants.

Anon!: Let’s follow, Gertrude.
Goodbye!: Let’s follow him, Gertrude.

Anon!: But what talk we of fathers when there is such a man as Orlando?
Goodbye!: But what do we talk about fathers when there’s such a man as Orlando?

Anon!: Let all the rest give place.
Goodbye!: Let all the rest of us give place.

Anon!: Never believe it.
Goodbye!: Don’t believe it.

Anon!: I pray you tell your brother how well I counterfeited.
Goodbye!: Please tell your brother how well I’ve faked.

Anon!: I have no exquisite reason for ’t, but I have reason good enough.
Goodbye!: I have no excellent reason for it, but I have good reason.

Anon!: Behold!
Goodbye!: Look!

Anon!: Well may you prosper.
Goodbye!: Good luck.

Anon!: Nay, he reserved a blanket, else we had been all shamed.
Goodbye!: No, he reserved a blanket, and we’d all be shamed.

Anon!: I perceive these lords At this encounter do so much admire That they devour their reason and scarce think Their eyes do offices of truth, their words Are natural breath.—But howsoev'r you have Been justled from your senses, know for certain That I am Prospero and that very duke Which was thrust forth of Milan, who most strangely Upon this shore where you were wracked, was landed, To be the lord on ’t.
Goodbye!: I see these lords at this encounter so much that they devour their reason and scarce think their eyes are a source of truth.—But you’ve been justled from your senses, know for sure that I’m

Anon!: Oh, help, ho!
Goodbye!: Help!

Anon!: He was disposed to mirth, but on the sudden A Roman thought hath struck him.—Enobarbus!
Goodbye!: He was tempted to scold him, but suddenly a Roman thought struck him.—Enobarbus!

Anon!: Well, peace be with you, sir.
Goodbye!: Well, please be calm, sir.

Anon!: Sir, a whole history.
Goodbye!: I have a whole history, sir.

Anon!: Your grace hath laid the odds o' th' weaker side.
Goodbye!: Your grace has put the odds on the weaker side.

Anon!: What wouldst thou, fellow?
Goodbye!: What do you want, fellow?

Anon!: I care not for my spirits, if my legs were not weary.
Goodbye!: I don’t care about my spirits, if my legs weren’t tired.

Anon!: O Caesar, read mine first, for mine’s a suit That touches Caesar nearer.
Goodbye!: Oh, Caesar, read mine first, because mine’s a suit that touches Caesar closer.

Anon!: More light and light it grows.
Goodbye!: More and more light.

Anon!: Here were the servants of your adversary, And yours, close fighting ere I did approach.
Goodbye!: Here were the servants of your adversary, and yours, I was fighting close to you.

Anon!: Sirrah, go see what trumpet ’tis that sounds.
Goodbye!: Sirrah, go see what trumpet sounds like.

Anon!: But if the cause be not good, the king himself hath a heavy reckoning to make, when all those legs and arms and heads, chopped off in a battle, shall join together at the latter day, and cry all, “We died at such a place,” some swearing, some crying for a surgeon, some upon their wives left poor behind them, some upon the debts they owe, some upon their children rawly left.
Goodbye!: But if the cause is not good, the king himself has a heavy reckoning to make when all those legs and arms and heads, chopped off in a battle, will join together at the latter day and cry all, “

Anon!: I’ll tell thee ere thou ask it me again.
Goodbye!: I’ll tell you before you ask me again.

Anon!: I have nothing to do with thee.
Goodbye!: I have nothing to do with you.

Anon!: I’ll join with black despair against my soul And to myself become an enemy.
Goodbye!: I’ll join with black despair against my soul and become an enemy.

Anon!: Come, I’ll dispose of thee Among a sisterhood of holy nuns.
Goodbye!: Come on, I’ll leave you with a sisterhood of holy nuns.

Anon!: So it appears by that I have to say.
Goodbye!: I’m going to say that.

Anon!: I am not such an ass, but I can keep my hand dry.
Goodbye!: I’m not such an ass, but I can keep my hand dry.

Anon!: My Lady Grey his wife, Clarence, ’tis she That tempers him to this extremity.
Goodbye!: My Lady Grey’s wife, Clarence, is the one who tempers him to this extreme.

Anon!: I never hurt you.
Goodbye!: I never hurt you.

Anon!: Borrow Cupid’s wings And soar with them above a common bound.
Goodbye!: Borrow Cupid’s wings and soar with them above a common bound.

Anon!: It is more worthy to leap in ourselves Than tarry till they push us.
Goodbye!: It’s more worthy to leap in ourselves than to tarry until they push us.

Anon!: Therefore in my presence still smile, dear my sweet, I prithee.”
Goodbye!: So I congratulate you in my presence.”

Anon!: Twas told me you were rough and coy and sullen, And now I find report a very liar.
Goodbye!: I was told you were rough and coy and sullen, and now I find a report a very liar.

Anon!: The heart is sorely charged.
Goodbye!: The heart is so intense.

Anon!: I will have such revenges on you both That all the world shall—I will do such things— What they are yet I know not, but they shall be The terrors of the earth.
Goodbye!: I’ll revenge you both so that all the world will—I’ll do such things—what they are still I don’t know, but they will be the terrors of the earth.

Anon!: What, i' th' storm, i' th' night?
Goodbye!: What, the storm, the night?

Anon!: Take up my mistress' gown to his master’s use!
Goodbye!: Take up my mistress’s gown to his master’s use!

Anon!: I’ll bury thee in a triumphant grave.
Goodbye!: I’ll bury you in a triumphant grave.

Anon!: Within this three hours will fair Juliet wake.
Goodbye!: Within three hours Juliet will wake up.

Anon!: Sir, in my heart there was a kind of fighting That would not let me sleep.
Goodbye!: Sir, there was a kind of fighting that wouldn’t let me sleep.

Anon!: I can tell thee where that saying was born, of “I fear no colors.”  Where, good Mistress Mary?
Goodbye!: I can tell you where that saying was born, “I don’t fear colors.” Where, good Mistress Mary?

Anon!: What less than doomsday is the Prince’s doom?
Goodbye!: What less is the Prince’s doom than doomsday?

Anon!: I must be idle.
Goodbye!: I must be idle.

Anon!: I had rather have a fool to make me merry than experience to make me sad— and to travel for it, too.
Goodbye!: I’d rather have a fool to make me sad than experience to travel for it too.

Anon!: What news among the merchants?
Goodbye!: What news do the merchants have?

Anon!: When he returns from hunting, I will not speak with him.
Goodbye!: When he returns from hunting, I won’t speak to him.

Anon!: I’ll have an action of battery against him if there be any law in Illyria.
Goodbye!: I’ll have an action against him if there’s any law in Illyria.

Anon!: Then if he lose he makes a swanlike end, Fading in music.
Goodbye!: Then if he loses, he’ll end up swaning, screaming in music.

Anon!: One, gentlewoman, that God hath made, himself to mar.
Goodbye!: God has made himself a man, gentlewoman, to be a martyr.

Anon!: I’ll mark the play.
Goodbye!: I’ll watch the play.

Anon!: I will confess it to all the 'orld.
Goodbye!: I’ll confess it to all the lord.

Anon!: A friend.
Goodbye!: A friend.

Anon!: Fair Leda’s daughter had a thousand wooers; Then well one more may fair Bianca have.
Goodbye!: Then there may be a more beautiful girl like Bianca.

Anon!: Not life, but love in death.
Goodbye!: Not life, but love in death.

Anon!: I hope she will be brief.
Goodbye!: I hope she’ll be brief.

Anon!: I thank you.
Goodbye!: Thank you.

Anon!: Fool, of thyself speak well.
Goodbye!: Fool, speak well of yourself.

Anon!: A great suspicion.
Goodbye!: A great suspicion.

Anon!: Draw that thy honest sword, which thou hast worn Most useful for thy country.
Goodbye!: Draw your honest sword, which you have worn most usefully for your country.

Anon!: The noble Brutus Hath told you Caesar was ambitious.
Goodbye!: The noble Brutus told you Caesar was ambitious.

Anon!: Under Sir Thomas Erpingham.
Goodbye!: Sir Thomas Erpingham.

Anon!: No more that thane of Cawdor shall deceive Our bosom interest: go pronounce his present death, And with his former title greet Macbeth.
Goodbye!: No more than the one of Cawdor’s will fool our interest in the king’s death: go declare his death, and greet Macbeth with his former title.

Anon!: A turn or two I’ll walk To still my beating mind.
Goodbye!: A few minutes later I’ll walk to my heart.

Anon!: Art thou gone so, love, lord?
Goodbye!: Are you gone, love, lord?

Anon!: Hymen from heaven brought her, Yea, brought her hither, That thou mightst join her hand with his Whose heart within his bosom is.
Goodbye!: Hymen brought her from heaven, Yea, brought her here so you could join her hand with his whose heart within his bosom.

Anon!: There lay he, stretched along like a wounded knight.
Goodbye!: He lay there, stretched along like a wounded knight.

Anon!: Death, that hath ta'en her hence to make me wail, Ties up my tongue and will not let me speak.
Goodbye!: Death, who has sent her to make me cry, ties up my tongue and won’t let me speak.

Anon!: The noise they make Will cause Demetrius to awake.
Goodbye!: The noise they make will wake Demetrius up.

Anon!: Madam, not yet.
Goodbye!: Madam, not yet.

Anon!: Tis done by me, and ends in “Margaret.”   Thus have you breathed your curse against yourself.
Goodbye!: It’s done by me, and ends in “Margaret.” You’ve ruined yourself.

Anon!: Good e'en, brother.
Goodbye!: Good morning, brother.

Anon!: My liege, They are not yet come back.
Goodbye!: My liege, they’re not yet coming back.

Anon!: Come, Charmian.
Goodbye!: Come on, Charmian.

Anon!: That by proscription and bills of outlawry, Octavius, Antony, and Lepidus Have put to death an hundred senators.
Goodbye!: Octavius, Antony, and Lepidus have killed an hundred senators by proscription and law.

Anon!: He that parts us shall bring a brand from heaven And fire us hence like foxes.
Goodbye!: The one who’s dividing us will bring a brand from heaven and fire us away like foxes.

Anon!: If you be pleased, retire into my cell And there repose.
Goodbye!: If you’re happy, go back to my cell and go back there.

Anon!: Being holiday, the beggar’s shop is shut.
Goodbye!: Being a holiday, the beggar’s shop is shut.

Anon!: O sir, content you.
Goodbye!: Oh, sir, please.

Anon!: He came too late.
Goodbye!: He came too late.

Anon!: What stay had I but Edward?
Goodbye!: What time did I have except Edward?

Anon!: Plucking the entrails of an offering forth, They could not find a heart within the beast.
Goodbye!: When they shook the entrails of an offer, they couldn’t find a heart inside the beast.

Anon!: Will you be patient?
Goodbye!: Will you be patient?

Anon!: So ho!
Goodbye!: That’s true!

Anon!: Ha!
Goodbye!: Ha!

Anon!: I will then give it you soundly.
Goodbye!: I’ll give it to you then.

Anon!: A very mean meaning.
Goodbye!: That’s a very mean meaning.

Anon!: Nay, not sound, I pray you.
Goodbye!: No, don’t sound, please.

Anon!: Therefore, most gracious duke, with thy command Let him be brought forth and borne hence for help.
Goodbye!: So, most gracious duke, let him be brought out and borne here for help.

Anon!: O villain, villain, smiling, damnèd villain!
Goodbye!: Oh, villain, villain, smiling, damned villain!

Anon!: Call you me daughter?
Goodbye!: Are you calling me daughter?

Anon!: But though my cates be mean, take them in good part.
Goodbye!: But even if my words are mean, take them seriously.

Anon!: He is descried.
Goodbye!: He’s been screamed.

Anon!: Dost thou not suspect my years?
Goodbye!: Don’t you suspect my years?

Anon!: And yet I do thee wrong to mind thee of it, For thou art framed of the firm truth of valor.
Goodbye!: But I’m wrong to think about it, because you’re framed by the truth of valor.

Anon!: I would your grace would constrain me to tell.
Goodbye!: I wish you had to tell me.

Anon!: Upon what sickness?
Goodbye!: What sickness did you suffer?

Anon!: Ay, my good lord.
Goodbye!: Yes, my good lord.

Anon!: I know it well, sir.
Goodbye!: I know it well, sir.

Anon!: This letter from Bellario doth commend A young and learnèd doctor to our court.
Goodbye!: This letter from Bellario gives a young and educated doctor a call to our court.

Anon!: Not yet, my cousin.
Goodbye!: Not yet, cousin.

Anon!: It is a massy wheel Fixed on the summit of the highest mount, To whose huge spokes ten thousand lesser things Are mortised and adjoined, which, when it falls, Each small annexment, petty consequence, Attends the boisterous ruin.
Goodbye!: It’s a wheel fixed on the summit of the highest mountain, to which ten thousand lesser things are buried and buried.

Anon!: He ran this way and leapt this orchard wall.
Goodbye!: He ran this way and leapt over this orchard wall.

Anon!: Hark, Tranio!
Goodbye!: Listen, Tranio!

Anon!: What’s to do?
Goodbye!: What’s going on?

Anon!: And what wilt thou do—beg when that is spent?
Goodbye!: And what will you do—beg when that’s spent?

Anon!: You do remember all the circumstance?
Goodbye!: You remember all the circumstances?

Anon!: Peace, peace!
Goodbye!: Quiet, quiet!

Anon!: Be silent.
Goodbye!: Be quiet.

Anon!: Pardon, dear father.
Goodbye!: Pardon me, dear father.

Anon!: I might do ’t as well i' th' dark.
Goodbye!: I could do it as well in the dark.

Anon!: I little thought You would have followed.
Goodbye!: I didn’t think you would have followed me.

Anon!: Say, is your tardy master now at hand?
Goodbye!: Is your tardy master now at hand?

Anon!: O dear Ophelia, I am ill at these numbers.
Goodbye!: Oh, Ophelia, I’m ill at these numbers.

Anon!: Pray now, rest yourself.
Goodbye!: Now please rest yourself.

Anon!: How shall I answer you?
Goodbye!: How should I answer you?

Anon!: He thinks, being twenty times of better fortune, He is twenty men to one.
Goodbye!: He thinks that twenty times better than a man, he’s twenty men to one.

Anon!: How many then should cover that stand bare!
Goodbye!: How many people should cover that stand bare?

Anon!: I saw Mark Antony offer him a crown (yet ’twas not a crown neither, ’twas one of these coronets) and, as I told you, he put it by once—but, for all that, to my thinking, he would fain have had it.
Goodbye!: I saw Mark Antony offer him a crown (it wasn’t a crown, it wasn’t one of these coronets) and, as I told you, he put it by once—but for all that

Anon!: Thou didst prevent me.
Goodbye!: You stopped me.

Anon!: Or if thou hast not sat as I do now, Wearying thy hearer in thy mistress’s praise, Thou hast not loved.
Goodbye!: Or if you haven’t sat as I do now, you’ve been scolded by your mistress’s praise, you haven’t loved.

Anon!: Saw you no more?
Goodbye!: Didn’t you see anything else?

Anon!: The devil damn thee black, thou cream-faced loon!
Goodbye!: The devil damne you black, you cream-faced loon!

Anon!: Tell me.
Goodbye!: Tell me.

Anon!: Come, Kate, we’ll to bed.
Goodbye!: Come on, Kate, we’ll go to bed.

Anon!: Emilia, run you to the citadel And tell my lord and lady what hath happed.— Will you go on afore?
Goodbye!: Emilia, run to the citadel and tell my lord and lady what’s happened.—Do you want to go on this journey?

Anon!: But thou with mildness entertain’st thy wooers, With gentle conference, soft and affable.
Goodbye!: But you entertain your wooers with a gentle conference, soft and affable.

Anon!: This is the day wherein I wished to fall By the false faith of him who most I trusted.
Goodbye!: This is the day I wished to fall in love with the man I trusted most.

Anon!: Three and three, We’ll hold a feast in great solemnity.
Goodbye!: Three and three, we’ll feast in great solemnity.

Anon!: Those linen cheeks of thine Are counselors to fear.

Anon!: I pray you, one of you question yond man, if he for gold will give us any food.
Goodbye!: Please, one of you asks another, if he gives us any food.

Anon!: I do repent The tedious minutes I with her have spent.
Goodbye!: I’m sorry I spent the tedious minutes with her.

Anon!: Get horses for your mistress.
Goodbye!: Get horses for your mistress.

Anon!: Lucentio is your name.
Goodbye!: Lucentio is your name.

Anon!: And welcome, welcome!
Goodbye!: And welcome, welcome!

Anon!: Romeo!
Goodbye!: Romeo!

Anon!: Fare ye well.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: By the hour of nine.
Goodbye!: By nine o'clock.

Anon!: She is too fair, too wise, wisely too fair, To merit bliss by making me despair.
Goodbye!: She’s too fair, too wise, too fair to merit bliss by making me despair.

Anon!: Cast it off!
Goodbye!: Get it out of here!

Anon!: Oh, here Will I set up my everlasting rest, And shake the yoke of inauspicious stars From this world-wearied flesh.
Goodbye!: Oh, I’ll rest here forever and shake the yoke of savage stars from this world-wearied flesh.

Anon!: Swoons rather, for so bad a prayer as his Was never yet for sleep.
Goodbye!: It’s a sigh, for a so bad prayer as his prayer was never for sleep yet.

Anon!: O ceremony, show me but thy worth!
Goodbye!: Oh, ceremony, show me your worth!

Anon!: But if thou diest before I come, thou art a mocker of my labor.
Goodbye!: But if you die before I come, you’re a mocker of my work.

Anon!: O Sisters three, Come, come to me With hands as pale as milk.
Goodbye!: Oh, sisters three, come to me with hands as pale as milk.

Anon!: I heard it not.
Goodbye!: I didn’t hear it.

Anon!: So, so, so, so!
Goodbye!: So, so, so, so!

Anon!: Now by my George, my Garter, and my crown— Profaned, dishonored, and the third usurped.
Goodbye!: Now by my George, my Garter, and my crown— Profaned, dishonored, and the third usurped.

Anon!: Now, my friendly knave, I thank thee.
Goodbye!: Now, my friendly king, I thank you.

Anon!: To save her life, I’ll say she is not so.
Goodbye!: I’ll say she’s not so.

Anon!: She that would alter services with thee,  The Fortunate Unhappy”  Daylight and champaign discovers not more.
Goodbye!: The man who would alter your services with you, The Fortunate Unhappy” Daylight and champaign don’t discover anything more.

Anon!: A challenge, on my life.
Goodbye!: I’m facing a challenge.

Anon!: Let every eye nogetiate for itself And trust no agent, for beauty is a witch Against whose charms faith melteth into blood.
Goodbye!: Let every eye nogulate for itself and don’t trust any agent, because beauty is a witch whose charms melt into blood.

Anon!: O most unhappy strumpet!
Goodbye!: Oh, what a terrible strumpet!

Anon!: If you be well pleased with this And hold your fortune for your bliss, Turn you where your lady is And claim her with a loving kiss.”
Goodbye!: If you’re happy with this and hold your fortune for your bliss, turn you to where your lady is and claim her with a loving kiss.”

Anon!: The Prince’s fool!
Goodbye!: The Prince’s fool!

Anon!: Then leave him out.
Goodbye!: Then leave him out.

Anon!: I would thou hadst told me of another father.
Goodbye!: I wish you had told me about another father.

Anon!: Lie thou there.
Goodbye!: Go there.

Anon!: If I could pray to move, prayers would move me.
Goodbye!: If I could pray to move, then prayers would move me.

Anon!: Truly, my name is Cinna.
Goodbye!: I’m Cinna.

Anon!: Madam, I will.
Goodbye!: Madam, I will.

Anon!: That’s mercy, but too much security.
Goodbye!: That’s mercy, but it’s too much security.

Anon!: No more!
Goodbye!: Don’t worry about it anymore!

Anon!: Here, madam, at your service.
Goodbye!: Here, madam, at your service.

Anon!: Ay, if you dare do yourself a profit and a right.
Goodbye!: Yes, if you dare to make a profit and a right.

Anon!: Whose hand soever launched their tender hearts, Thy head, all indirectly, gave direction.
Goodbye!: Whoever hand opened their tender hearts so quickly, your head, all indirectly, gave direction.

Anon!: Where is my lord the duke of Gloucester?
Goodbye!: Where is my lord the duke of Gloucester?

Anon!: And so adieu, sir.
Goodbye!: And so, sir.

Anon!: What sayest thou now?
Goodbye!: What do you say now?

Anon!: A golden mind stoops not to shows of dross.
Goodbye!: A golden mind doesn’t stooped to show of dross.

Anon!: Myself am Naples, Who with mine eyes, never since at ebb, beheld The king my father wracked.
Goodbye!: Myself is Naples, who, with my eyes, never seen the king my father wracked.

Anon!: Good morrow to you both.
Goodbye!: Good morning to you both.

Anon!: Take to you no hard thoughts.
Goodbye!: Don’t take any hard thoughts.

Anon!: Masters, masters—   warrant you.
Goodbye!: Master, masters— I’m sure you’re right.

Anon!: I am informèd thoroughly of the cause.
Goodbye!: I’ve been informed of the cause.

Anon!: Yond same black cloud, yond huge one, looks like a foul bombard that would shed his liquor.
Goodbye!: The same cloud, besides the huge cloud, looks like a foul bombardment that would shed his liquor.

Anon!: I know my hour is come.
Goodbye!: I know my hour is here.

Anon!: You sent me for a rope’s end as soon.
Goodbye!: You sent me for a rope’s end as soon as you got it.

Anon!: I never got him.— Hark, the duke’s trumpets.
Goodbye!: I never got him.—Speak, the duke’s trumpets.

Anon!: He is attended with a desperate train.
Goodbye!: He’s waiting for a desperate train.

Anon!: I know his trumpet.
Goodbye!: I know his trumpet.

Anon!: There’s no offense, my lord.
Goodbye!: There’s no offense, my lord.

Anon!: Which be the malefactors?
Goodbye!: Which are the malefactors?

Anon!: Go to, charm your tongue.
Goodbye!: Go to, speak your tongue.

Anon!: What is “t o”clock?
Goodbye!: What time is it?

Anon!: Tomorrow, my lord.
Goodbye!: Tomorrow, my lord.

Anon!: Fairy King, attend, and mark.
Goodbye!: Fairy King, come and see.

Anon!: Ay, do.
Goodbye!: Yes, do.

Anon!: Yet I cannot choose but laugh To think it should leave crying and say “ay.” And yet, I warrant, it had upon its brow A bump as big as a young cockerel’s stone, A perilous knock, and it cried bitterly.
Goodbye!: But I can’t help laughing to think it should leave crying and say “yes.” And yet, I’m sure it had a bump on its forehead as big as a young cockerel’s stone, a

Anon!: I have lived long enough.
Goodbye!: I’ve lived long enough.

Anon!: I come to thee for charitable license, That we may wander o'er this bloody field To book our dead and then to bury them; To sort our nobles from our common men, For many of our princes—woe the while!— Lie drowned and soaked in mercenary blood.
Goodbye!: I’m coming to you for charitable licenses, so we can wander through this bloody field to find our dead and then to bury them; to sort our nobles from our common men, because many of our princes—w

Anon!: How say you to that, Malvolio?
Goodbye!: What do you say to that, Malvolio?

Anon!: There’s enough.
Goodbye!: There’s enough.

Anon!: What would my potent master?
Goodbye!: What would my powerful master do?

Anon!: How is it with her?
Goodbye!: How is she?

Anon!: God keep you from them, and from such false friends.
Goodbye!: God keep you from them and from such false friends.

Anon!: I shall remember.
Goodbye!: I’ll remember.

Anon!: If thou would have such a one, take me.
Goodbye!: If you want to have such a man, take me.

Anon!: Now I will believe That there are unicorns, that in Arabia There is one tree, the phoenix' throne, one phoenix At this hour reigning there.
Goodbye!: Now I’ll believe that unicorns exist, that in Arabia there is one tree, the phoenix’s throne, and one phoenix reigning there at this hour.

Anon!: That last is true.
Goodbye!: That last one is true.

Anon!: Ah, welladay!
Goodbye!: Ah, goodbye!

Anon!: With no less religion than if thou wert indeed my Rosalind.
Goodbye!: With no less religion than if you were my Rosalind.

Anon!: Oh, lay me by my mistress' side.
Goodbye!: Oh, lay me on my mistress’s side.

Anon!: Tom will throw his head at them.—Avaunt, you curs!
Goodbye!: Tom will throw his head at them.—Avail, you curs!

Anon!: Saints do not move, though grant for prayers' sake.
Goodbye!: Saints don’t move, even if they grant for prayers’ sake.

Anon!: The gods best know— Oh never was there queen So mightily betrayed!
Goodbye!: The gods know— Oh, never was there queen so sanely betrayed!

Anon!: Thou art a soul in bliss, but I am bound Upon a wheel of fire, that mine own tears Do scald like molten lead.
Goodbye!: You’re a soul in bliss, but I’m bound on a wheel of fire, that my tears scald like molten lead.

Anon!: You stand.
Goodbye!: You’re standing.

Anon!: I know the good king and queen have sent for you.
Goodbye!: I know the king and queen sent for you.

Anon!: I wish mine eyes Would with themselves shut up my thoughts.
Goodbye!: I wish my eyes could shut up my thoughts.

Anon!: If you prick us, do we not bleed?
Goodbye!: If you prick us, don’t we bleed?

Anon!: Calphurnia’s cheek is pale, and Cicero Looks with such ferret and such fiery eyes As we have seen him in the Capitol Being crossed in conference by some senators.
Goodbye!: Calphurnia’s cheek is pale, and Cicero looks like a ferret and a fiery face as we saw him in the Capitol being crossed in a meeting by some senators.

Anon!: Thou need’st not to be gone.
Goodbye!: You don’t need to go.

Anon!: Sblood, but you’ll not hear me!
Goodbye!: But you won’t hear me!

Anon!: I’ll know his humor when he knows his time.
Goodbye!: I’ll know his humor when he knows his time.

Anon!: When it concerns the fool or coward.
Goodbye!: When it comes to the fool or the coward.

Anon!: This is the very false gallop of verses.
Goodbye!: This is the false saga of verses.

Anon!: That done, repair to Pompey’s theatre.
Goodbye!: That’s done, restore to Pompey’s theatre.

Anon!: Good my sovereign, Take up the English short, and let them know Of what a monarchy you are the head.
Goodbye!: My sovereign, take up the English short and tell them what a monarch you’re the head.

Anon!: Ass, I doubt not.
Goodbye!: I don’t doubt it.

Anon!: What ring gave you my lord?
Goodbye!: What ring did you give me, my lord?

Anon!: What, my dear Lady Disdain!
Goodbye!: What, my dear Lady Disdain!

Anon!: Mine would, sir, were I human.
Goodbye!: I wish I were human, sir.

Anon!: Woo’t tear thyself?
Goodbye!: Do you want to tear yourself?

Anon!: Is it even so?
Goodbye!: Is that true?

Anon!: Oh, do but think You stand upon the rivage and behold A city on th' inconstant billows dancing, For so appears this fleet majestical Holding due course to Harfleur.
Goodbye!: Oh, don’t think you’re standing on the rivage and seeing a city dancing in the sand, because this majestically fleet is holding its course to Harfleur.

Anon!: The day is spent.
Goodbye!: The day is over.

Anon!: I know you.
Goodbye!: I know you.

Anon!: My lord?
Goodbye!: My lord?

Anon!: Well, we’ll see ’t.
Goodbye!: Well, we’ll see it.

Anon!: Nay, let me alone for swearing.
Goodbye!: No, let me be alone for swearing.

Anon!: Get your apparel together, good strings to your beards, new ribbons to your pumps.
Goodbye!: Get your clothes together, good strings to your beards, and new ribbons to your pumps.

Anon!: Very good orators, when they are out, they will spit; and for lovers lacking—God warn us—matter, the cleanliest shift is to kiss.
Goodbye!: Very good orators, when they’re out, they’ll spit.

Anon!: When thou wakest, if she be by, Beg of her for remedy.
Goodbye!: When you wake up, if she’s coming, go ahead and ask for help.

Anon!: With the help of a surgeon he might yet recover and prove an ass.
Goodbye!: With the help of a surgeon, he could recover and prove an ass.

Anon!: Must there no more be done?
Goodbye!: Isn’t there any more work to be done?

Anon!: Well, you have made a simple choice.
Goodbye!: Well, you’ve made a simple choice.

Anon!: That he hath usèd thee.
Goodbye!: He’s sworn in you.

Anon!: But if we fail, We then can do ’t at land.
Goodbye!: But if we fail, we can do it on land.

Anon!: Give me some help.
Goodbye!: Give me some help.

Anon!: Our troops set forth tomorrow.
Goodbye!: Our troops are going tomorrow.

Anon!: What means this jest?
Goodbye!: What’s this nonsense?

Anon!: Out, out, brief candle!
Goodbye!: Out, out, a brief candle!

Anon!: Wherefore to Dover, sir?
Goodbye!: Why Dover?

Anon!: I warrant something from Venice.
Goodbye!: I’m sure I’ll get something from Venice.

Anon!: A challenge, on my life.
Goodbye!: I’m facing a challenge.

Anon!: To thee I do commend my watchful soul, Ere I let fall the windows of mine eyes.
Goodbye!: I’m recommending my sane soul, and I’ll let fall my eyes.

Anon!: Yet if thou say Antony lives, is well, Or friends with Caesar, or not captive to him, I’ll set thee in a shower of gold and hail Rich pearls upon thee.
Goodbye!: But if you say Antony is alive, is well, or is friends with Caesar, or not captive to him, I’ll put you in a shower of gold and hail rich pearls on you.

Anon!: Tis no matter.
Goodbye!: It doesn’t matter.

Anon!: Even he.
Goodbye!: He’s just that.

Anon!: I have heard more since.
Goodbye!: I’ve heard more since.

Anon!: When I presented Ceres, I thought to have told thee of it, but I feared Lest I might anger thee.
Goodbye!: When I presented Ceres, I thought I’d tell you about it, but I feared I’d be tempted to anger you.

Anon!: Angels and ministers of grace defend us!
Goodbye!: Angels and ministers of grace defend us!

Anon!: This is some minx’s token, and I must take out the work?
Goodbye!: This is some minx’s token, and I have to take out the work?

Anon!: His father was called Philip of Macedon, as I take it.
Goodbye!: His father was called Philip of Macedon, as I say.

Anon!: Sir, there she stands.
Goodbye!: She’s standing there, sir.

Anon!: Death, in guerdon of her wrongs, Gives her fame which never dies.
Goodbye!: Death, in a guerdon of her wrongs, gives her fame that never dies.

Anon!: Inquire me out some mean poor gentleman, Whom I will marry straight to Clarence' daughter.
Goodbye!: Ask me some poor gentleman who I’ll marry straight to Clarence’s daughter.

Anon!: Your sister is the better soldier.
Goodbye!: Your sister is the better soldier.

Anon!: I will help you to ’t.
Goodbye!: I’ll help you.

Anon!: What’s to say?
Goodbye!: What’s to say?

Anon!: My Regan counsels well.
Goodbye!: My Regan is very helpful.

Anon!: You are early stirring.
Goodbye!: You’re a bit upset.

Anon!: I ne'er saw this before.
Goodbye!: I hadn’t seen this before.

Anon!: I had as lief be a Brownist as a politician.
Goodbye!: I’d be as a Brownist as a politician.

Anon!: Hast thou the pretty worm of Nilus there, That kills and pains not?
Goodbye!: Are you the pretty worm of Nilus there, who doesn’t kill and pain?

Anon!: O, lady, lady, shame would have it hid.
Goodbye!: Oh, lady, lady, shame would have it hidden.

Anon!: I shall attend you presently at your tent.
Goodbye!: I’ll be at your tent.

Anon!: How now, Shylock?
Goodbye!: What’s going on, Shylock?

Anon!: You mock me, madam.
Goodbye!: You mock me, madam.

Anon!: I must confess your offer is the best, And, let your father make her the assurance, She is your own; else, you must pardon me.
Goodbye!: I must admit your offer is the best, and let your father make her the assurance that she is your own.

Anon!: I have no words.
Goodbye!: I don’t have any words.

Anon!: Come, seek the conspirators.
Goodbye!: Come, find out the conspirators.

Anon!: Nay, weep not, gentle Eros.
Goodbye!: No, don’t cry, gentle Eros.

Anon!: Tis no matter.— Go to the fellow, good Alexas.
Goodbye!: It doesn’t matter.—Go to the fellow, good Alexas.

Anon!: That were a kind of bastard hope indeed.
Goodbye!: That’s a kind of hope for you.

Anon!: A privilege never to see me more.
Goodbye!: It’s a privilege to never see me again.

Anon!: But when I tell him he hates flatterers, He says he does, being then most flatterèd.
Goodbye!: But when I tell him he hates flatterers, he says he does, being flattered.

Anon!: Brother, I’ll go and bring it thee.
Goodbye!: Brother, I’ll go and bring it to you.

Anon!: What is her mother?
Goodbye!: Who is her mother?

Anon!: Will you come presently?
Goodbye!: Will you come here?

Anon!: Moreover, he hath left you all his walks, His private arbors and new-planted orchards, On this side Tiber.
Goodbye!: Moreover, he has left you all his walks, his private arbors and his new-planted orchards, on this side of Tiber.

Anon!: And thither will I straight to visit him.
Goodbye!: And I’ll go straight to visit him.

Anon!: Would I were able to load him with his desert!
Goodbye!: I wish I could load him with his desert!

Anon!: Speak you so gently?
Goodbye!: Do you speak so gently?

Anon!: Who’s there?
Goodbye!: Who’s there?

Anon!: It wearies me; you say it wearies you.
Goodbye!: It’s weary me, you say it’s weary you.

Anon!: What, what, good cheer!
Goodbye!: What, what, good cheer!

Anon!: I do but keep the peace.
Goodbye!: I’m only keeping the peace.

Anon!: Thou naughty knave, what trade?
Goodbye!: You naughty king, what trade?

Anon!: If this letter move him not, his legs cannot.
Goodbye!: If this letter doesn’t move him, his legs can’t.

Anon!: A coward, a most devout coward, religious in it.
Goodbye!: A coward, a very devout coward, religious in it.

Anon!: Here, here!
Goodbye!: Here, here!

Anon!: Fellows, let’s be gone.
Goodbye!: Let’s go.

Anon!: Yea,” quoth he, “Dost thou fall upon thy face?
Goodbye!: Yes,” he said, “Do you fall on your face?

Anon!: What if I had said I had seen him do you wrong?
Goodbye!: What if I had said I saw him do you wrong?

Anon!: How fondly dost thou reason!
Goodbye!: How fondly do you reason?

Anon!: Should I not say, “Hath a dog money?
Goodbye!: Shouldn’t I say, “Is a dog worth money?

Anon!: Hie thee, slave.
Goodbye!: Hie, slave.

Anon!: Weary sev'nnights nine times nine Shall he dwindle, peak and pine.
Goodbye!: Weary nights nine times nine will dwindle, peak and pine.

Anon!: I pray you, look upon her.
Goodbye!: Please, look at her.

Anon!: No, cousin, I’ll to Fife.
Goodbye!: No, cousin, I’ll go to Fife.

Anon!: Where is my Romeo?
Goodbye!: Where is my Romeo?

Anon!: Now, ere the sun advance his burning eye, The day to cheer and night’s dank dew to dry, I must upfill this osier cage of ours With baleful weeds and precious-juicèd flowers.
Goodbye!: Now, if the sun advances his burning eye, the day to cheer and the night’s dew to dry, I must fill this osier cage of ours with baleful weeds and precious-ju

Anon!: Caesar sends greeting to the Queen of Egypt, And bids thee study on what fair demands Thou mean’st to have him grant thee.
Goodbye!: Caesar sends greetings to the Queen of Egypt and asks you to study what you want to do to get him to you.

Anon!: All take hands.
Goodbye!: All of us take their hands.

Anon!: Their bloody sign of battle is hung out, And something to be done immediately.
Goodbye!: Their bloody sign of battle is hanging out, and something to be done immediately.

Anon!: Before and apace.
Goodbye!: Now, I’m ready.

Anon!: Why, I am glad on ’t.
Goodbye!: Well, I’m glad about it.

Anon!: Rescue, my lord of Norfolk, rescue, rescue!
Goodbye!: Rescue, my lord of Norfolk, rescue, rescue!

Anon!: Then I defy you, stars!
Goodbye!: Then I’m afraid of you, stars!

Anon!: The music, ho!
Goodbye!: The music!

Anon!: Pray you now, forget and forgive.
Goodbye!: Please, forget and forgive me.

Anon!: Hark, what noise is this?
Goodbye!: What’s this noise?

Anon!: Go back again and be new beaten home?
Goodbye!: Go back again and be beaten home again?

Anon!: Maid’s mild behavior and sobriety.
Goodbye!: Maid’s mild behavior and sobriety.

Anon!: A right good markman!
Goodbye!: A good markman!

Anon!: Stayed it long?
Goodbye!: Did it stay long?

Anon!: And all the better is it for the maid.
Goodbye!: And it’s all better for the maid.

Anon!: Come, come with me, and we will make short work.
Goodbye!: Come with me, and we’ll make a short work.

Anon!: Perchance he will not mind me.
Goodbye!: He’ll never mind me.

Anon!: Nor I.
Goodbye!: I’m not.

Anon!: I do arrest you, sir.
Goodbye!: I’m arresting you, sir.

Anon!: Welcome, Publius.
Goodbye!: Welcome, Publius.

Anon!: Now, fellows, you are welcome.
Goodbye!: Now, fellows, you’re welcome.

Anon!: Then say at once what thou dost know in this.
Goodbye!: Then tell me immediately what you know about this.

Anon!: In the way of argument, look you, and friendly communication, partly to satisfy my opinion, and partly for the satisfaction, look you, of my mind, as touching the direction of the military discipline, that is the point.
Goodbye!: I’m going to say that, and that’s the point, I’ll say that you’re talking about the military discipline.

Anon!: All hail, great master!
Goodbye!: All hail, great master!

Anon!: She was the wife of Caius Marcellus.
Goodbye!: She was Caius Marcellus’s wife.

Anon!: Tom’s a-cold.
Goodbye!: Tom’s a cold.

Anon!: Do you not know me, Father?
Goodbye!: Don’t you know me, Father?

Anon!: Nor I.
Goodbye!: I’m not.

Anon!: Nay, come, I prithee.
Goodbye!: No, come, please.

Anon!: What he will do with it Heaven knows, not I. I nothing but to please his fantasy.
Goodbye!: I’m not a fan of him, but I’m just trying to please his fantasy.

Anon!: Consent to swear.
Goodbye!: Accept to swear.

Anon!: Your commission’s ready.
Goodbye!: Your commission is ready.

Anon!: In wisdom I should ask thy name.
Goodbye!: I’d like to ask you your name.

Anon!: Now, infidel, I have you on the hip.
Goodbye!: Now, infidel, I have you on the hip.

Anon!: Some friendship will it lend you 'gainst the tempest.
Goodbye!: It’ll give you some friendship against the tempest.

Anon!: Tell him, so please him come unto this place, He shall be satisfied and, by my honor, Depart untouched.
Goodbye!: Tell him, if he come to this place, he’ll be satisfied and, by my honor, he’ll leave unattended.

Anon!: Am I your bird?
Goodbye!: Am I your bird?

Anon!: Come forth, I say!
Goodbye!: Come out, I say.

Anon!: To eat us hungerly, and when they are full, They belch us.
Goodbye!: They’re begging us to eat them hungry, and when they’re full, they’ll belch us.

Anon!: I see, lady, the gentleman is not in your books.
Goodbye!: I see, lady, the gentleman isn’t in your books.

Anon!: This is the place.
Goodbye!: This is the place.

Anon!: What if it come to thee again?
Goodbye!: What if it’s come to you again?

Anon!: I hope my noble lord esteems me honest.
Goodbye!: I hope my noble lord is esteeming me as honest.

Anon!: Out o' your wits and hearing too?
Goodbye!: Are you out of your wits and hearing too?

Anon!: Yea, sir, we hope.
Goodbye!: Yes, sir, we hope so.

Anon!: Neighbors and friends, though bride and bridegroom wants For to supply the places at the table, You know there wants no junkets at the feast.
Goodbye!: Neighbors and friends, even though bride and bridegroom want to bring the tablecloths, you know there are no junkets at the feast.

Anon!: A most high miracle!
Goodbye!: What a great miracle!

Anon!: Let him come in.
Goodbye!: Let him come in.

Anon!: This is more strange Than such a murder is.
Goodbye!: This is more strange than a murder like that.

Anon!: Foul shame upon you, you have all moved mine.
Goodbye!: Shame on you, you’ve all moved me.

Anon!: I pray you do.
Goodbye!: Please do.

Anon!: Well, officer, arrest him at my suit.
Goodbye!: Well, officer, arrest him at my trial.

Anon!: I know his gait, ’tis he.—Villain, thou diest!
Goodbye!: I know his gait, it’s him.—Villain, you die!

Anon!: Most certain, if you are she, you do usurp yourself, for what is yours to bestow is not yours to reserve.
Goodbye!: If you’re her, you’re a usurp yourself, because what you’re going to give you is not yours to reserve.

Anon!: Repent but you that you shall lose your friend, And he repents not that he pays your debt.
Goodbye!: Repent that you’ll lose your friend, and he doesn’t repent that he’s paying your debt.

Anon!: My young remembrance cannot parallel A fellow to it.
Goodbye!: My young memory can’t parallel a fellow to it.

Anon!: My fair Bianca, bid my father welcome, While I with selfsame kindness welcome thine.
Goodbye!: My fair Bianca, welcome my father, while I welcome you with the same kindness as you.

Anon!: Do not think, gentlemen, I am drunk.
Goodbye!: Don’t think I’m drunk, gentlemen.

Anon!: You will answer, “The slaves are ours.” So do I answer you.
Goodbye!: You’ll answer, “The slaves are ours.” I’ll answer you.

Anon!: In all these circumstances I’ll instruct you.
Goodbye!: In all these circumstances I’ll instruct you.

Anon!: My banquet is to close our stomachs up, After our great good cheer.
Goodbye!: My banquet is to close our stomachs up after our great good cheer.

Anon!: You shall be a woodmonger and buy nothing of me but cudgels.
Goodbye!: You’ll be a woodmonger and buy nothing but cudgels from me.

Anon!: Good madam, keep yourself within yourself.
Goodbye!: Good madam, keep yourself inside.

Anon!: Was ’t not to this end That thou began’st to twist so fine a story?
Goodbye!: Wasn’t it to this purpose that you began to tell such a fine story?

Anon!: Behind the abbey wall Within this hour my man shall be with thee And bring thee cords made like a tackled stair, Which to the high top-gallant of my joy Must be my convoy in the secret night.
Goodbye!: I’ll be with you behind the abbey wall within an hour and bring you cords made like a stair, which must be my convoy in the secret night.

Anon!: I thank it.
Goodbye!: Thank you.

Anon!: Give us the place alone.
Goodbye!: Give us the place alone.

Anon!: Ay, but the feet were lame and could not bear themselves without the verse, and therefore stood lamely in the verse.
Goodbye!: Yes, but the feet were lame and couldn’t bear themselves without the verse, and therefore stood lamely in the verse.

Anon!: Happy is Hermia, wheresoe'er she lies, For she hath blessèd and attractive eyes.
Goodbye!: Hermia is happy, where she lies, because she has beautiful eyes.

Anon!: What is my offense?
Goodbye!: What’s my offense?

Anon!: I could make as true a boast as that if I had a sow to my mistress.
Goodbye!: I could make as true a joke as that if I had a sow to my mistress.

Anon!: Am I like such a fellow?
Goodbye!: Am I like such a man?

Anon!: I am heartily glad I came hither to you.
Goodbye!: I’m very glad I came here to you.

Anon!: I thank thee, good Sir John, with all my heart.
Goodbye!: Thank you, Sir John, with all my heart.

Anon!: Then move not, while my prayer’s effect I take.
Goodbye!: Then don’t move while I pray.

Anon!: Statilius showed the torchlight but, my lord, He came not back.
Goodbye!: Statilius showed the torchlight, but he didn’t come back, my lord.

Anon!: What, says the married woman you may go?
Goodbye!: What, is the married woman you want to go?

Anon!: O, good sir, I do.
Goodbye!: Oh, good sir, I do.

Anon!: It is your music, madam, of the house.
Goodbye!: It’s your music, madam, of the house.

Anon!: A plague o' both your houses!
Goodbye!: A plague kills both your houses!

Anon!: O Goneril, You are not worth the dust which the rude wind Blows in your face.
Goodbye!: Oh Goneril, you’re not worth the dust that the rude wind blows in your face.

Anon!: If I could add a lie unto a fault I would deny it.
Goodbye!: If I could add a lie to a fault, I would deny it.

Anon!: That?
Goodbye!: That?

Anon!: His wits are gone.
Goodbye!: His wits are gone.

Anon!: Sweetest nut hath sourest rind; Such a nut is Rosalind.
Goodbye!: Sweetest nut has a rind of sourest; Rosalind is such a nut.

Anon!: Nor will you tender less.
Goodbye!: You won’t be tempted to tender less.

Anon!: Get you to church, and have a good priest that can tell you what marriage is.
Goodbye!: Get to church and have a good priest who can tell you what marriage is.

Anon!: I cannot draw a cart, nor eat dried oats.
Goodbye!: I can’t draw a cart or eat dried oats.

Anon!: A night is but small breath and little pause To answer matters of this consequence.
Goodbye!: A night is only a small breath and a little pause to answer questions of this consequence.

Anon!: Thou hast taken against me a most just exception, but yet I protest I have dealt most directly in thy affair.
Goodbye!: You’ve taken against me a very just exception, but I’m not saying I’ve dealt with your affair most directly.

Anon!: Two such opposèd kings encamp them still, In man as well as herbs—grace and rude will.
Goodbye!: Two such opposing kings still encamp them in man as well as in herbs—grace and rude will.

Anon!: Who, queasy with his insolence already, Will their good thoughts call from him.
Goodbye!: Who, who’s already angry with his insolence, will give their good thoughts to him.

Anon!: Where are the vile beginners of this fray?
Goodbye!: Where are the vile men who are starting this fight?

Anon!: Well, sir.
Goodbye!: Well, sir.

Anon!: Oh, no, good Kate.
Goodbye!: Oh no, good Kate.

Anon!: Therefore he that cannot lick his fingers goes not with me.
Goodbye!: So anyone who can’t lick his fingers doesn’t go with me.

Anon!: Spit, fire!
Goodbye!: Spit, fire!

Anon!: His coward lips did from their color fly, And that same eye whose bend doth awe the world Did lose his luster.
Goodbye!: His coward lips were flying from their color, and the same eye whose bends awe the world lost his luster.

Anon!: The gentleness of all the gods go with thee!
Goodbye!: The gentleness of all the gods will go with you!

Anon!: He’s almost slain, and Roderigo dead.
Goodbye!: He’s almost killed, and Roderigo’s dead.

Anon!: I must obey.
Goodbye!: I have to obey.

Anon!: Take it in what sense thou wilt.
Goodbye!: Take it in what sense you want.

Anon!: If I say sooth, I must report they were As cannons overcharged with double cracks, So they doubly redoubled strokes upon the foe.
Goodbye!: If I say sooth, I must tell you they were like cannons overcharged with double cracks, so they doubled strokes on the enemy.

Anon!: I will not trouble thee, my child.
Goodbye!: I won’t bother you, my child.

Anon!: But it was—as I received it, and others, whose judgments in such matters cried in the top of mine—an excellent play, well digested in the scenes, set down with as much modesty as cunning.
Goodbye!: But it was—as I received it, and others, who cried in the top of me—an excellent play, well digested in the scenes, set down with as much modesty as cunning.

Anon!: What, are you mad?
Goodbye!: Are you crazy?

Anon!: What, lamb!
Goodbye!: What, lamb!

Anon!: She’s cold.
Goodbye!: She’s cold.

Anon!: The worm that’s fled Hath nature that in time will venom breed; No teeth for th' present.
Goodbye!: The worm that’s fled has a nature that will breed in time, and no teeth for the moment.

Anon!: Juliet!—Fast, I warrant her, she.— Why, lamb!
Goodbye!: Juliet!—Fast, I assure her, she.—Why, lamb!

Anon!: God be wi' you.
Goodbye!: God bless you.

Anon!: May I be bold To think these spirits?
Goodbye!: Can I be bold to think of these spirits?

Anon!: I will show myself a tyrant.
Goodbye!: I’ll be a tyrant.

Anon!: Methinks it is like a weasel.
Goodbye!: I think it’s like a weasel.

Anon!: Art thou wise?
Goodbye!: Are you wise?

Anon!: I know where I will wear this dagger then.
Goodbye!: I know where I’ll wear this dagger then.

Anon!: Give him a halter.
Goodbye!: Give him a halter.

Anon!: At your request!
Goodbye!: At your request!

Anon!: What would you with me, honest neighbor?
Goodbye!: What do you want with me, my honest neighbor?

Anon!: Go release them, Ariel.
Goodbye!: Go release them, Ariel.

Anon!: Aroint thee, witch!” the rump-fed runnion cries.
Goodbye!: Aroint you, witch!” the rump-fed runnion cries.

Anon!: A match!
Goodbye!: A match!

Anon!: No, my lord.
Goodbye!: No, my lord.

Anon!: Which, when I saw rehearsed, I must confess, Made mine eyes water—but more merry tears The passion of loud laughter never shed.
Goodbye!: When I saw the rehearse, I must confess, I made my eyes water—but more merry tears never shed the passion of loud laughter.

Anon!: You are a fool.—You, niece, provide yourself.
Goodbye!: You’re a fool.—You, niece, give yourself.

Anon!: I’ll call upon you straight.
Goodbye!: I’ll call you straight away.

Anon!: O ye immortal gods!
Goodbye!: Oh immortal gods!

Anon!: You know me well, and herein spend but time To wind about my love with circumstance.
Goodbye!: You know me well, and here I am, just to wind up on my love for the situation.

Anon!: Which is Sebastian?
Goodbye!: Which one is Sebastian?

Anon!: Away, go away!
Goodbye!: Go away!

Anon!: Therein, ye gods, you tyrants do defeat.
Goodbye!: You tyrants are defeated here, gods.

Anon!: He would be crowned.
Goodbye!: He would be crowned.

Anon!: Of the king’s ship, The mariners, say how thou hast disposed, And all the rest o' th' fleet.
Goodbye!: The mariners, the king’s ship, tell us how you’ve landed, and all the rest of your fleet.

Anon!: Notable pirate!
Goodbye!: Notable pirate!

Anon!: Hold, then.
Goodbye!: Stop, then.

Anon!: Ingratitude, thou marble-hearted fiend, More hideous when thou show’st thee in a child Than the sea monster.
Goodbye!: You’re more hideous when you show you in a child than the sea monster.

Anon!: You say well.
Goodbye!: You’re right.

Anon!: How now, my lord?
Goodbye!: What’s going on, my lord?

Anon!: To take the widow Exasperates, makes mad her sister Goneril, And hardly shall I carry out my side, Her husband being alive.
Goodbye!: I’ll never be able to take the widow out of her house, making her mad sister Goneril, and I’ll never be able to take her husband out of her house.

Anon!: Shall I do that which all the Parthian darts, Though enemy, lost aim and could not?
Goodbye!: Should I do what the Parthian darts, even though they were enemy, lost their aim and couldn’t do?

Anon!: What paper were you reading?
Goodbye!: What paper were you reading?

Anon!: What hast thou been?
Goodbye!: What have you been?

Anon!: You have made me offer Of Sicily, Sardinia.
Goodbye!: You’ve made me offer Sicily, Sardinia.

Anon!: Why, what’s the matter?
Goodbye!: What’s the matter?

Anon!: Bring it to that, The gold I give thee will I melt and pour Down thy ill-uttering throat.
Goodbye!: Bring it to that, the gold I give you will melt and pour down your ill-looking throat.

Anon!: We waste our lights in vain, like lights by day.
Goodbye!: We’re going to waste our lights in vain, like lights by day.

Anon!: There’s mine.
Goodbye!: Here’s mine.

Anon!: And sometime comes she with a tithe-pig’s tail Tickling a parson’s nose as he lies asleep, Then he dreams of another benefice.
Goodbye!: And sometimes she’s tickling a pig’s tail, tickling a parson’s nose as he sleeps, and then he dreams of another good.

Anon!: The king falls from bias of nature—there’s father against child.
Goodbye!: The king is a man who isn’t a child.

Anon!: Benedicite.
Goodbye!: Benedicite.

Anon!: I would my horse had the speed of your tongue and so good a continuer.
Goodbye!: I wish my horse had the speed of your tongue and a good savage.

Anon!: Warrant thee, my man’s as true as steel.
Goodbye!: Yes, my man’s as true as steel.

Anon!: We Have used to conquer standing on the earth And fighting foot to foot.
Goodbye!: We’ve used to conquer standing on the earth and fighting foot to foot.

Anon!: Of your complexion.
Goodbye!: Of your complexion.

Anon!: Tell me that.
Goodbye!: Tell me that.

Anon!: You appeared to me but as a common man.
Goodbye!: You appeared to me only as a common man.

Anon!: Be pleased to tell us— For this is from the present—how you take The offers we have sent you.
Goodbye!: Please tell us how we’ve sent you the offers.

Anon!: He has heard that word of some great man and now applies it to a fool.
Goodbye!: He heard that word from some great man and now he’s a fool.

Anon!: Live thou, I live.
Goodbye!: You, I live.

Anon!: To her, my lord, Was I betrothed ere I saw Hermia.
Goodbye!: I was beaten to her, my lord, when I saw Hermia.

Anon!: How looked he?
Goodbye!: How did he look?

Anon!: The king hath granted every article, His daughter first, and, in sequel, all, According to their firm proposed natures.
Goodbye!: The king has given every article, his daughter first, and, in the sequel, all, according to their firm proposed nature.

Anon!: Dost thou love me?
Goodbye!: Do you love me?

Anon!: Men’s eyes were made to look and let them gaze.
Goodbye!: Men’s eyes were made to look and let them see.

Anon!: There was no link to color Peter’s hat, And Walter’s dagger was not come from sheathing.
Goodbye!: There was no link to Peter’s hat, and Walter’s dagger was not a result of squeezing.

Anon!: Thou, why, thou wilt quarrel with a man that hath a hair more or a hair less in his beard than thou hast.
Goodbye!: You’re going to fight with a man who has a more or a less beard than you have.

Anon!: O deadly sin!
Goodbye!: Oh, deadly sin!

Anon!: May a man do it?
Goodbye!: Can a man do it?

Anon!: So the spirit is eased.
Goodbye!: So the spirit is calm.

Anon!: Sing it.
Goodbye!: Sing it.

Anon!: Give me excess of it that, surfeiting, The appetite may sicken, and so die.
Goodbye!: Give me excess of it so that, if I’m snoring, the appetite may sicken and so die.

Anon!: Your honor is most welcome.
Goodbye!: Your honor is very welcome.

Anon!: I grant you, friends, if you should fright the ladies out of their wits, they would have no more discretion but to hang us.
Goodbye!: I swear, friends, if you frighten the ladies out of their wits, they’d have no choice but to hang us.

Anon!: Let me go with you.
Goodbye!: Let me go with you.

Anon!: Why, I said nothing.
Goodbye!: I didn’t say anything.

Anon!: I can stay with Regan, I and my hundred knights.
Goodbye!: I can stay with Regan, I and my hundred knights.

Anon!: A thousand thanks, Signior Gremio.
Goodbye!: A thousand thanks, Signior Gremio.

Anon!: Hob, nob, is his word.
Goodbye!: Hob, nob, is his word.

Anon!: If she be a traitor, Why so am I.
Goodbye!: If she’s a traitor, why so am I.

Anon!: Now I see, I see, In Fulvia’s death how mine received shall be.
Goodbye!: Now I see, I see, in Fulvia’s death how my death will be.

Anon!: Or who pronounced The bitter sentence of poor Clarence' death Before I be convict by course of law?
Goodbye!: Or who pronounced the bitter sentence of poor Clarence’s death before I could be sentenced by law?

Anon!: Do as thou wilt, for I have done with thee.
Goodbye!: Do as you want, because I’ve done with you.

Anon!: When he is best he is a little worse than a man, and when he is worst he is little better than a beast.
Goodbye!: When he is best, he’s a little worse than a man, and when he’s worst, he’s little better than a beast.

Anon!: How, my pretty York?
Goodbye!: How, my pretty York?

Anon!: Now sir, be judge yourself, Whether I in any just term am affined To love the Moor.
Goodbye!: Now, sir, judge yourself whether I’m a good man to love the Moor.

Anon!: We’ll lead you thither.
Goodbye!: We’ll lead you there.

Anon!: That which hath made them drunk hath made me bold.
Goodbye!: The fact that they were drunk has made me bold.

Anon!: Give me your hand, And let me all your fortunes understand.
Goodbye!: Give me your hand, and let me understand your fortunes.

Anon!: Or did I dream it so?
Goodbye!: Or did I dream about it?

Anon!: Just, just; and the men do sympathize with the mastiffs in robustious and rough coming on, leaving their wits with their wives.
Goodbye!: Just, just; and the men sympathize with the mastiffs in their brutal and brutal coming on, leaving their wits with their wives.

Anon!: She is spherical, like a globe.
Goodbye!: She’s spherical, like a globe.

Anon!: Have you not spoken 'gainst the Duke of Cornwall aught?
Goodbye!: Have you not spoken to the Duke of Cornwall about this?

Anon!: Desire him to go in.
Goodbye!: I’d like him to go in.

Anon!: That’s all one: has hurt me, and there’s the end on ’t.
Goodbye!: That’s all one thing: I’ve hurt myself, and it’s the end.

Anon!: Too old to be engaged to young.
Goodbye!: Too old to be engaged to young people.

Anon!: Let me have your hand.
Goodbye!: Let me have your hand.

Anon!: You shall close prisoner rest Till that the nature of your fault be known To the Venetian state.—Come, bring him away.
Goodbye!: You’ll keep the prisoner quiet until the Venetian state knows the nature of your crime.—Come, bring him away.

Anon!: I’ll write straight to my sister To hold my very course.
Goodbye!: I’ll write to my sister immediately to keep my course.

Anon!: I love her ten times more than e'er I did.
Goodbye!: I love her ten times more than I did before.

Anon!: If the cat will after kind, So, be sure, will Rosalind.
Goodbye!: If the cat is kind, then Rosalind will.

Anon!: Well, you are a rare parrot-teacher.
Goodbye!: Well, you’re a rare parrot-teacher.

Anon!: Then say at once what thou dost know in this.
Goodbye!: Then tell me immediately what you know about this.

Anon!: Who meets us here?
Goodbye!: Who’s this?

Anon!: Let him come, and kindly.
Goodbye!: Let him come, and please.

Anon!: How malicious is my fortune, that I must repent to be just!
Goodbye!: How malicious I am, that I have to repent to be just!

Anon!: Is not that neighborly?
Goodbye!: Isn’t that neighborly?

Anon!: God 'i' good e'en.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: He hath rid his prologue like a rough colt.
Goodbye!: He’s ridding his prologue like a rough colt.

Anon!: Nay, but how dearly he adores Mark Antony!
Goodbye!: No, but he loves Mark Antony so much!

Anon!: But is there any else longs to see this broken music in his sides?
Goodbye!: But is there anything else that wants to see this broken music in his sides?

Anon!: Where should she be?
Goodbye!: Where should she be?

Anon!: Know’st thou Gower?
Goodbye!: Do you know Gower?

Anon!: With all my heart.
Goodbye!: With all my heart.

Anon!: Which is that adversary?
Goodbye!: Which one of you is that adversary?

Anon!: Your lordship is right welcome back to Denmark.
Goodbye!: Your lordship is welcome back to Denmark.

Anon!: But give me your hand, Menas.
Goodbye!: But give me your hand, Menas.

Anon!: And you too, gentle Hero?
Goodbye!: And you too, gentle Hero?

Anon!: You are gentlemen of brave mettle.
Goodbye!: You’re brave men.

Anon!: So quick bright things come to confusion.
Goodbye!: So bright things get confused.

Anon!: Oh, let us hence.
Goodbye!: Let’s go.

Anon!: Long love doth so.
Goodbye!: Love does that.

Anon!: I think the sun where he was born Drew all such humors from him.
Goodbye!: I think the sun where he was born is all about humor.

Anon!: To our house.
Goodbye!: To our house.

Anon!: Where he arrives he moves All hearts against us.
Goodbye!: Where he arrives, he’s bringing all his hearts against us.

Anon!: If I find a hole in his coat, I will tell him my mind.
Goodbye!: If I find a hole in his coat, I’ll tell him my thoughts.

Anon!: The one, to save the money that he spends in tiring; the other, that at dinner they should not drop in his porridge.
Goodbye!: One, to save the money he spends on tiring, the other, to ensure that they don’t drop in his porridge at dinner.

Anon!: Now, good sweet Nurse— O Lord, why look’st thou sad?
Goodbye!: Now, good sweet Nurse— Oh Lord, why are you looking so sad?

Anon!: Tomorrow, soldier, By sea and land I’ll fight.
Goodbye!: Tomorrow, soldier, I’ll fight by sea and land.

Anon!: She told her, while she kept it 'Twould make her amiable and subdue my father Entirely to her love, but if she lost it Or made gift of it, my father’s eye Should hold her loathèd and his spirits should hunt After new fancies.
Goodbye!: She told her that while she kept it, it would make her amiable and subdue my father to her love, but if she lost it or gave it to her, my father’s eyes should keep her from being lo

Anon!: Sir, by your patience: if I heard you rightly, The duke hath put on a religious life And thrown into neglect the pompous court.
Goodbye!: Sir, if I heard you rightly, the duke has put on a religious life and thrown the pompous court into neglect.

Anon!: Speed him hence.
Goodbye!: Get him out of here.

Anon!: I’ll back to the duke of Gloucester and tell him so.
Goodbye!: I’ll go back to the duke of Gloucester and tell him that.

Anon!: Pray you, sit down, For now we sit to chat as well as eat.
Goodbye!: Please sit down, because now we sit down to chat as well as eat.

Anon!: Good Enobarbus, make yourself my guest Whilst you abide here.
Goodbye!: Good Enobarbus, make yourself my guest while you’re here.

Anon!: I learned it in England where indeed they are most potent in potting.
Goodbye!: I learned it in England, where they are really very capable of potting.

Anon!: Canst thou remember A time before we came unto this cell?
Goodbye!: Can you remember a time before we came to this cell?

Anon!: I will leave you now to your gossip-like humor.
Goodbye!: I’ll leave you to your gossip-like humor.

Anon!: How many cowards whose hearts are all as false As stairs of sand wear yet upon their chins The beards of Hercules and frowning Mars, Who, inward searched, have livers white as milk, And these assume but valor’s excrement To render them redoubted.
Goodbye!: How many cowards whose hearts are as false as the sand sand sand sand sand sand sand sand sand sand sand sand

Anon!: Go, make money.
Goodbye!: Go, make money.

Anon!: I have an exposition of sleep come upon me.
Goodbye!: I’ve come to sleep with a glimpse of sleep.

Anon!: Please ’t your highness To grace us with your royal company?
Goodbye!: Would you like your highness to grace us with your royal company?

Anon!: This is most certain that I shall deliver: Mark Antony is every hour in Rome Expected.
Goodbye!: I’ll deliver this one.

Anon!: His affections do not that way tend.
Goodbye!: His affections don’t tend to go that way.

Anon!: Worthy Othello, I am hurt to danger.
Goodbye!: Oh, Othello, I’m hurt to be in danger.

Anon!: Twelve year since, Miranda, twelve year since, Thy father was the Duke of Milan and A prince of power.
Goodbye!: Twelve years ago, Miranda, twelve years ago, your father was the Duke of Milan and a prince of power.

Anon!: Why, I am sorry for thee, gentle Silvius.
Goodbye!: I’m sorry for you, gentle Silvius.

Anon!: He hath left them you And to your heirs forever—common pleasures, To walk abroad and recreate yourselves.
Goodbye!: He’s left them to you forever and to your heirs—common pleasures, to walk abroad and recreate yourself.

Anon!: I am for the air.
Goodbye!: I’m for the air.

Anon!: But, sirrah, not for my sake, but your master’s, I advise You use your manners discreetly in all kind of companies.
Goodbye!: But, sir, not for my sake, but for your master’s sake, I advise you to use your manners discreetly in any kind of company.

Anon!: Let us now stay and see it.
Goodbye!: Let’s stay and see it now.

Anon!: So it should be, that none but Antony Should conquer Antony, but woe ’tis so!
Goodbye!: It should be, that none except Antony should conquer Antony, but it’s so bad!

Anon!: Now, by the world—      'Tis full of thy foul wrongs.
Goodbye!: Now, by the world— It’s full of your evil evils.

Anon!: Tis pitiful, but yet Iago knows That she with Cassio hath the act of shame A thousand times committed.
Goodbye!: It’s a terrible thing, but Iago knows that she has sex with Cassio a thousand times.

Anon!: And how cam’st thou hither?
Goodbye!: And how are you going here?

Anon!: Villain am I none.
Goodbye!: I’m no one.

Anon!: How am I false?
Goodbye!: How am I false?

Anon!: Ay, with a twink.
Goodbye!: Yes, with a twinkling.

Anon!: Tell me, Othello.
Goodbye!: Tell me, Othello.

Anon!: Which is the villain?
Goodbye!: Which one of you is the villain?

Anon!: Our friends all stay for you.
Goodbye!: Our friends are all waiting for you.

Anon!: You should hear reason.
Goodbye!: You should hear why.

Anon!: Yet this I will not do, do how I can.
Goodbye!: But I won’t do this, and I’ll do what I can.

Anon!: Tis a brave army, and full of purpose.
Goodbye!: It’s a brave army, and it’s full of purpose.

Anon!: Say that the last I spoke was “Antony,” And word it, prithee, piteously.
Goodbye!: Say that the last I spoke was “Antony,” and say it, prit, in a pitiful way.

Anon!: Where they feared the death, they have borne life away; and where they would be safe, they perish.
Goodbye!: Where they feared the death, they have borne their life away, and where they would be safe, they perish.

Anon!: Most savage and unnatural!
Goodbye!: Most savage and unnatural!

Anon!: Alack, ’tis he.
Goodbye!: Oh, that’s him.

Anon!: And sometime comes she with a tithe-pig’s tail Tickling a parson’s nose as he lies asleep, Then he dreams of another benefice.
Goodbye!: And sometimes she’s tickling a pig’s tail, tickling a parson’s nose as he sleeps, and then he dreams of another good.

Anon!: Miranda.—O my father, I have broke your hest to say so!
Goodbye!: Miranda.—Oh, my father, I’ve broken your heart to say that!

Anon!: Now, then, we’ll use His countenance for the battle, which being done, Let her who would be rid of him devise His speedy taking off.
Goodbye!: Now, we’ll use his countenance for the battle, which is done, and let her who would be rid of him devise his rapid take off.

Anon!: Upon record, my gracious lord.
Goodbye!: On record, my gracious lord.

Anon!: Your serpent of Egypt is bred now of your mud by the operation of your sun.
Goodbye!: The sun turns your serpent into a snake in Egypt.

Anon!: I shall, my lord.
Goodbye!: I will, my lord.

Anon!: Ha!
Goodbye!: Ha!

Anon!: The Duke in council?
Goodbye!: The Duke in council?

Anon!: There is no woman’s sides Can bide the beating of so strong a passion As love doth give my heart.
Goodbye!: There is no woman’s side that can tell me to beat a woman as strong as love gives me.

Anon!: Bid Gloucester think of this, and he will weep.
Goodbye!: Tell Gloucester to think about this, and he’ll cry.

Anon!: In his own grace he doth exalt himself More than in your addition.
Goodbye!: He’s exalting himself more than you’re adding.

Anon!: I tell you what you shall do.
Goodbye!: I tell you what you’ll do.

Anon!: Antonio, O my dear Antonio!
Goodbye!: Antonio, Oh my dear Antonio!

Anon!: As sweet as balm, as soft as air, as gentle— O Antony!—Nay, I will take thee too.
Goodbye!: As sweet as balm, as soft as air, as gentle— Oh Antony!—No, I’ll take you too.

Anon!: Give me thy hand.
Goodbye!: Give me your hand.

Anon!: An honest mind and plain, he must speak truth.
Goodbye!: He’s honest and clear, and he’s going to speak truthfully.

Anon!: Let me comply with you in this garb—lest my extent to the players, which, I tell you, must show fairly outwards, should more appear like entertainment than yours.
Goodbye!: Let me follow you in this slur—I’ll give you my slur to the players, which, I tell you, must show a fair amount of respect for, should be more like entertainment than yours

Anon!: Therefore, farewell.
Goodbye!: So goodbye.

Anon!: Alas the day, it did.
Goodbye!: It did.

Anon!: For with throwing thus my head,  Dogs leap the hatch, and all are fled.
Goodbye!: With my head throwing, dogs leap the hatch and all are fleeing.

Anon!: The ingratitude of this Seleucus does Even make me wild.
Goodbye!: The ingratitude of this Seleucus makes me wild.

Anon!: Proceed, proceed.
Goodbye!: Go ahead, go ahead.

Anon!: Labio and Flavio, set our battles on.
Goodbye!: Labio and Flavio, set our battles on.

Anon!: You are there followed by a faithful shepherd.
Goodbye!: You’re followed by a faithful shepherd.

Anon!: Quick, quick!
Goodbye!: Quick, quick!

Anon!: And so, God be with him!
Goodbye!: And so, God be with him!

Anon!: This is some priory.
Goodbye!: This is some priory.

Anon!: Amen.
Goodbye!: Amen.

Anon!: O weary night, O long and tedious night, Abate thy hours.
Goodbye!: Oh, weary night, Oh, long and tedious night, and leave your hours.

Anon!: Of what, lady?
Goodbye!: What, lady?

Anon!: But one, poor one, one poor and loving child, But one thing to rejoice and solace in, And cruel death hath catched it from my sight!
Goodbye!: But one, one poor one, one poor and loving child, but one thing to rejoice and solace in, and cruel death has catched it out of my sight!

Anon!: The fiend gives the more friendly counsel.
Goodbye!: The fiend gives the more friendly advice.

Anon!: Oh, I am out of breath in this fond chase.
Goodbye!: Oh, I’m out of breath in this sane chase.

Anon!: Where is my mother?
Goodbye!: Where is my mother?

Anon!: Muffle me, night, awhile.
Goodbye!: Muffle me, night, for a while.

Anon!: Seek to know no more.
Goodbye!: Don’t seek to know more.

Anon!: Your tale, sir, would cure deafness.
Goodbye!: Your story would cure deafness, sir.

Anon!: Nay, if an oily palm be not a fruitful prognostication, I cannot scratch mine ear.—Prithee, tell her but a workaday fortune.
Goodbye!: No, if an oily palm isn’t a good idea, I can’t scratch my ear.—Pride, tell her a good fortune.

Anon!: I wrote to you When rioting in Alexandria.
Goodbye!: I wrote to you when I rioted in Alexandria.

Anon!: Because their business still lies out o' door.
Goodbye!: Because their business is still out of the door.

Anon!: Who’s there, besides foul weather?
Goodbye!: Who’s there, out of the rain?

Anon!: Bottom!
Goodbye!: Bottom!

Anon!: O serpent heart hid with a flowering face!
Goodbye!: Oh, serpent heart hid with a flowering face!

Anon!: Farewell, sweet playfellow.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, sweet playfellow.

Anon!: Romeo can, Though heaven cannot.
Goodbye!: Romeo can, even though heaven can.

Anon!: But since he stands obdurate And that no lawful means can carry me Out of his envy’s reach, I do oppose My patience to his fury, and am armed To suffer with a quietness of spirit The very tyranny and rage of his.
Goodbye!: But since he’s obscene and has no legal means to carry me out of his envy, I’m opposing my patience to his fury, and I’m armed to suffer with a quiet spirit the

Anon!: I shall offend, either to detain or give it.
Goodbye!: I’ll offend you either to detention or give it to you.

Anon!: Dear lad, believe it.
Goodbye!: Dear lad, believe it.

Anon!: I pray you, go Along with me.
Goodbye!: Please, go with me.

Anon!: Stop her there!
Goodbye!: Stop her there!

Anon!: Ah, welladay!
Goodbye!: Ah, goodbye!

Anon!: Remember our reward when the deed’s done.
Goodbye!: Remember our reward when the deed’s done.

Anon!: Two deep enemies, Foes to my rest, and my sweet sleep’s disturbers, Are they that I would have thee deal upon.
Goodbye!: Two deep enemies, who are begging me to rest, and my sweet sleep disturbers, are those who I wish you could deal with.

Anon!: Oh, but I fear.
Goodbye!: Oh, but I’m afraid.

Anon!: Shall I go win my daughter to thy will?
Goodbye!: Should I go win my daughter to your will?

Anon!: Give me thy hand.
Goodbye!: Give me your hand.

Anon!: There’s money for thee.
Goodbye!: There’s money for you.

Anon!: Do you not jest?
Goodbye!: Don’t you scolde?

Anon!: Is not that he?
Goodbye!: Isn’t that him?

Anon!: What ish my nation?
Goodbye!: What’s my nation?

Anon!: Gentle cousin, Let us go thank him and encourage him.
Goodbye!: Gentle cousin, let’s go thank him and encourage him.

Anon!: Ratcliffe, come hither.
Goodbye!: Ratcliffe, come here.

Anon!: From our brother England?
Goodbye!: From our brother England?

Anon!: Are your doors locked?
Goodbye!: Are your doors locked?

Anon!: Why art thou here, Come from the farthest step of India?
Goodbye!: Why are you here, come from the farthest step of India?

Anon!: O, they did urge it still unto the king.
Goodbye!: Oh, they did urge the king to do it.

Anon!: I am content, so the maiden cities you talk of may wait on her.
Goodbye!: I’m happy, so the maiden cities you’re talking about can wait on her.

Anon!: Do you hear, Cassio?
Goodbye!: Do you hear that, Cassio?

Anon!: Thrice he walked By their oppressed and fear-surprisèd eyes Within his truncheon’s length, whilst they, distilled Almost to jelly with the act of fear, Stand dumb and speak not to him.
Goodbye!: Then he walked by their oppressed and fear-surprising eyes within his truncheon’s length, while they distilled almost to jelly with the act of fear, stand dumb and don’t

Anon!: Well struck!
Goodbye!: Well struck!

Anon!: Let your highness Command upon me, to the which my duties Are with a most indissoluble tie Forever knit.
Goodbye!: Let your highness command me to the level of duty I’m able to do with a sleeve that never ends.

Anon!: Believe me, King of Shadows, I mistook.
Goodbye!: Believe me, King of Shadows, I mistook it.
