Anon!: O Juliet, I already know thy grief.
Goodbye!: Oh Juliet, I know your grief already.

Anon!: That’s fouler.
Goodbye!: That’s worse.

Anon!: You have done that you should be sorry for.
Goodbye!: You’ve done something you should be sorry for.

Anon!: Run, run, O, run!
Goodbye!: Run, run, Oh, run!

Anon!: Tis exactly valued, Not petty things admitted.
Goodbye!: It’s absolutely valued, not petty things.

Anon!: I doubt not that, since we are well-persuaded We carry not a heart with us from hence That grows not in a fair consent with ours, Nor leave not one behind that doth not wish Success and conquest to attend on us.
Goodbye!: I don’t doubt that, since we’re well-persuaded, we don’t carry a heart with us from here, and we don’t have a heart with us, and we don’t leave any

Anon!: Is he not honest?
Goodbye!: Isn’t he honest?

Anon!: Bring me word how tall she is.
Goodbye!: Tell me how tall she is.

Anon!: A laughter.
Goodbye!: A laugh.

Anon!: Regan, I have good hope Thou didst not know on ’t.—Who comes here?
Goodbye!: Regan, I hope you didn’t know about it.—Who’s this?

Anon!: Do as I bid thee, go.
Goodbye!: Go, as I told you.

Anon!: Oh, then, what graces in my love do dwell, That he hath turned a heaven unto a hell!
Goodbye!: Oh, then, what graces in my love dwell, that he has turned a heaven into a hell!

Anon!: I’ll mend it and then play— Where’s the Queen?
Goodbye!: I’ll try to get it back and then play— Where’s the Queen?

Anon!: To a rope’s end, sir, and to that end am I returned.
Goodbye!: I’m back to the ropes, sir.

Anon!: You are too hot.
Goodbye!: You’re too hot.

Anon!: Tedious it were to tell and harsh to hear.
Goodbye!: It’s too bad to tell and too harsh to hear.

Anon!: I must needs tell thee all.
Goodbye!: I have to tell you everything.

Anon!: All disconsolate, With Pindarus his bondman on this hill.
Goodbye!: All the gossip, with Pindarus his bondman on this hill.

Anon!: You have been factious one against the other.— Wife, love Lord Hastings.
Goodbye!: You’ve been a factious one against the other.—Wife, love Lord Hastings.

Anon!: How now, sir?
Goodbye!: What’s going on, sir?

Anon!: Bring me no more reports.
Goodbye!: Don’t bring me any more reports.

Anon!: Therefore, good Brutus, be prepared to hear.
Goodbye!: So be prepared to hear, good Brutus.

Anon!: And when shalt thou see him again?
Goodbye!: And when will you see him again?

Anon!: Mistress, how mean you that?
Goodbye!: Mistress, what do you mean by that?

Anon!: What says the silver with her virgin hue?
Goodbye!: What does the silver say with her virgin hue?

Anon!: Did ever dragon keep so fair a cave?
Goodbye!: Did a dragon ever keep such a beautiful cave?

Anon!: Mistake me not.
Goodbye!: Don’t misunderstand me.

Anon!: Call up the right Master Constable.
Goodbye!: Call up the Master Constable.

Anon!: Remember First to possess his books, for without them He’s but a sot, as I am, nor hath not One spirit to command.
Goodbye!: Remember to possess his books first, because without them he’s just a savage, as I am, and he’s not a single spirit to command.

Anon!: Your eyes are lodestars, and your tongue’s sweet air More tunable than lark to shepherd’s ear When wheat is green, when hawthorn buds appear.
Goodbye!: Your eyes are lodestars, and your tongue’s sweet air is more tunable than lark to shepherd’s ear when wheat is green, and hawthorn buds appear.

Anon!: When beggars die there are no comets seen.
Goodbye!: When beggars die there are no comets seen.

Anon!: Amen.
Goodbye!: Amen.

Anon!: Mustardseed.
Goodbye!: Mustardseed.

Anon!: Hold, sir, for God’s sake!
Goodbye!: Hold on, sir, for God’s sake!

Anon!: I will, my lord.
Goodbye!: I will, my lord.

Anon!: Anon!
Goodbye!: Goodbye!

Anon!: And badest me bury love.
Goodbye!: And I’m bad enough to bury my love.

Anon!: Away, get thee away.
Goodbye!: Go away, get away.

Anon!: Go.
Goodbye!: Go.

Anon!: I protest I take these wise men that crow so at these set kind of fools no better than the fools' zanies.
Goodbye!: I’m angry that these wise men who crow at these set kind of fools are no better than the fools’ zanies.

Anon!: Go to.
Goodbye!: Go on.

Anon!: Romeo!— Alack, alack, what blood is this, which stains The stony entrance of the sepulcher?
Goodbye!: Romeo!—Oh, what’s this blood that stains the stony entrance of the sepulcher?

Anon!: And therefore is Love said to be a child, Because in choice he is so oft beguiled.
Goodbye!: So, love is said to be a child, because he chooses to be so ill.

Anon!: As strange as the thing I know not.
Goodbye!: I’m as strange as the thing I don’t know.

Anon!: An he speak any thing against me, I’ll take him down, an he were lustier than he is, and twenty such Jacks.
Goodbye!: If he says anything against me, I’ll take him down, if he were lustier than he is, and twenty such Jacks.

Anon!: To Ireland, I.
Goodbye!: I’ll go to Ireland.

Anon!: Moved,” in good time.
Goodbye!: Moved,” in good time.

Anon!: To, to, to— To murder me?
Goodbye!: To, to, to— To murder me?

Anon!: Look how he makes to Caesar.
Goodbye!: Look at how he’s going to Caesar.

Anon!: I will omit no opportunity That may convey my greetings, love, to thee.
Goodbye!: I won’t give you any opportunity to express my love, my love.

Anon!: Come.
Goodbye!: Come on.

Anon!: We shall be much unfurnished for this time.
Goodbye!: We’ll be unprepared for this time.

Anon!: Bring me but to the very brim of it, And I’ll repair the misery thou dost bear With something rich about me.
Goodbye!: Bring me to the brim of it, and I’ll help you get something rich about me.

Anon!: Where is the horse that doth untread again His tedious measures with the unbated fire That he did pace them first?
Goodbye!: Where is the horse who tries to scold him again with the unbated fire he pushed them first?

Anon!: Well, get thee gone.
Goodbye!: Well, go away.

Anon!: A good moral, my lord: it is not enough to speak, but to speak true.
Goodbye!: A good moral statement, my lord: it’s not enough to speak, but to speak true.

Anon!: The spirit torments me.
Goodbye!: The spirit has tormented me.

Anon!: Fair youth, I would I could make thee believe I love.
Goodbye!: Young man, I wish I could make you believe I love you.

Anon!: My lord, his throat is cut.
Goodbye!: My lord, his throat is cut.

Anon!: A mighty man of Pisa.
Goodbye!: A mighty man from Pisa.

Anon!: And it is marvel he outdwells his hour, For lovers ever run before the clock.
Goodbye!: And it’s marveling he’s out of his hour, because lovers run before the clock.

Anon!: You may relish him more in the soldier than in the scholar.
Goodbye!: You can relish him more in the soldier than in the scholar.

Anon!: Your royal preparation Makes us hear something.
Goodbye!: Your royal preparation makes us hear something.

Anon!: Shall I be tempted of the devil thus?
Goodbye!: Should I be tempted by the devil like this?

Anon!: With much, much more dismay I view the fight than thou that makest the fray.
Goodbye!: I’m much more upset about the fight than you are.

Anon!: Bid every noise be still.
Goodbye!: Tell me that every noise is still.

Anon!: Tomorrow shall you bear our full intent Back to our brother England.
Goodbye!: Tomorrow we’ll go back to our brother England.

Anon!: But then the mind much sufferance doth o'erskip When grief hath mates and bearing fellowship.
Goodbye!: But then the mind is suffering when grief has mates and a good relationship.

Anon!: I fear he will.
Goodbye!: I’m afraid he will.

Anon!: Tarry, sweet soul, for mine; then fly abreast, As in this glorious and well-foughten field We kept together in our chivalry.” Upon these words I came and cheered him up.
Goodbye!: I’ll go, sweet soul, for mine.

Anon!: I protest I love thee.
Goodbye!: I swear I love you.

Anon!: Farewell.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: We know thy charge, Brakenbury, and will obey.
Goodbye!: We know your charges, Brakenbury, and we’ll obey them.

Anon!: She had a prophesying fear Of what hath come to pass.
Goodbye!: She had a fear of what has happened.

Anon!: It will be short.
Goodbye!: It’ll be short.

Anon!: Fare you well.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: I understand moreover, upon the Rialto, he hath a third at Mexico, a fourth for England, and other ventures he hath squandered abroad.
Goodbye!: I know, he’s a third at Mexico, a fourth for England, and other ventures he’s squandered abroad.

Anon!: I thank your lordship, you have got me one.
Goodbye!: Thank you, you’ve got me one.

Anon!: The cry is still “They come!” Our castle’s strength Will laugh a siege to scorn.
Goodbye!: The cry is still “They come!” Our castle’s strength will laugh a siege to scorn.

Anon!: I serve you, madam.
Goodbye!: I’ll serve you, madam.

Anon!: God and our innocence defend and guard us!
Goodbye!: God and our innocence protect and protect us!

Anon!: No, sooth, sir.
Goodbye!: No, sooth, sir.

Anon!: What needed, then, that terrible dispatch of it into your pocket?
Goodbye!: So what did you need that terrible sneeze into your pocket?

Anon!: Within a month, Ere yet the salt of most unrighteous tears Had left the flushing in her gallèd eyes, She married.
Goodbye!: Within a month, she had left the tears in her galled eyes, and she married.

Anon!: All the East, Say thou, shall call her mistress.” So he nodded, And soberly did mount an arm-gaunt steed, Who neighed so high that what I would have spoke Was beastly dumbed by him.
Goodbye!: The whole East, say you will call her mistress.” He nodded, and soberly mounted an arm-gaunt steed, who neighed so high that what I would have said was beastly dumb

Anon!: Let no fair be kept in mind But the fair of Rosalind.
Goodbye!: It’s not fair to think about Rosalind.

Anon!: What trumpet is that same?
Goodbye!: What trumpet is that?

Anon!: His father, though I say ’t, is an honest exceeding poor man and, God be thanked, well to live.
Goodbye!: His father, even though I say it, is an honest, exceedingly poor man, and, God be thanked, he’s well to live.

Anon!: Benedick, didst thou note the daughter of Signior Leonato?
Goodbye!: Benedick, did you notice Signior Leonato’s daughter?

Anon!: Adieu.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: I will not budge for no man’s pleasure, I.
Goodbye!: I won’t budge for anyone’s pleasure, I swear.

Anon!: What, are there masques?
Goodbye!: Are there masks?

Anon!: Is ’t possible?
Goodbye!: Is it possible?

Anon!: Dry sorrow drinks our blood.
Goodbye!: We drink our blood with dry sorrow.

Anon!: If they will fight with us, bid them come down, Or void the field.
Goodbye!: If they’re fighting with us, ask them to come down or leave the field.

Anon!: God restore you to health!
Goodbye!: God restore you to health!

Anon!: He speaks home, madam.
Goodbye!: He’s speaking home, madam.

Anon!: Twas where you wooed the gentlewoman so well.
Goodbye!: That was where you wooed the gentlewoman so well.

Anon!: Go, borrow me a crow.
Goodbye!: Go borrow me a crow.

Anon!: To you I am bound for life and education.
Goodbye!: I’m bound to live and teach you.

Anon!: Brutus shall lead, and we will grace his heels With the most boldest and best hearts of Rome.
Goodbye!: Brutus will lead, and we’ll grace his heels with the boldest and best hearts of Rome.

Anon!: Tis twenty year till then.
Goodbye!: It’s twenty years until then.

Anon!: I prithee, recount some of them.
Goodbye!: Please, tell me some of them.

Anon!: Swear priests and cowards and men cautelous, Old feeble carrions and such suffering souls That welcome wrongs.
Goodbye!: Swear priests and cowards and men cautelous, old feeble carrions and such suffering souls that welcome wrongs.

Anon!: A mighty strength they carry.
Goodbye!: They’re a powerful force.

Anon!: Proceed.
Goodbye!: Go ahead.

Anon!: She says enough, yet she’s a simple bawd That cannot say as much.
Goodbye!: She’s a simple bawd who can’t say as much.

Anon!: Oh, where is Romeo?
Goodbye!: Oh, where is Romeo?

Anon!: You have broken The article of your oath, which you shall never Have tongue to charge me with.
Goodbye!: You’ve broken the law of your oath, which you won’t have any tongue to charge me with.

Anon!: Let me see.
Goodbye!: Let me see.

Anon!: He sent me word if I said his beard was not cut well, he was in the mind it was.
Goodbye!: He sent me a word if I said his beard wasn’t cut well, but he knew it was.

Anon!: My charms I’ll break, their senses I’ll restore, And they shall be themselves.
Goodbye!: I’ll break my charms, my senses will be restored, and they’ll be themselves.

Anon!: The food that to him now is as luscious as locusts shall be to him shortly as bitter as coloquintida.
Goodbye!: The food that’s being given to him now is as luscious as the sour food, and will soon be as bitter as coloquintida.

Anon!: Why, we shall make him mad indeed.
Goodbye!: Well, we’ll make him crazy.

Anon!: Though Cassio did some little wrong to him, As men in rage strike those that wish them best, Yet surely Cassio, I believe, received From him that fled some strange indignity Which patience could not pass.
Goodbye!: Although Cassio did some little wrong to him, as men in rage strike those who wish them best, I believe Cassio received from him who fled some strange indignity that couldn’t pass.

Anon!: Romeo!
Goodbye!: Romeo!

Anon!: It shall advantage thee more than ever the bearing of letter did.
Goodbye!: It will benefit you more than ever, as the letter was written.

Anon!: You have dancing shoes With nimble soles.
Goodbye!: You’re wearing dancing shoes with nimble soles.

Anon!: I protest, in the sincerity of love and honest kindness.
Goodbye!: I’m protesting, in the sincerity of love and honest kindness.

Anon!: Thy mistress' marks?
Goodbye!: What are your mistress’s marks?

Anon!: The more I love, the more he hateth me.
Goodbye!: The more I love him, the more he hates me.

Anon!: Come, where’s the chain?
Goodbye!: Where’s the chain?

Anon!: O my brother’s child!
Goodbye!: Oh, my brother’s child!

Anon!: Have you the lion’s part written?
Goodbye!: Have you written the lion’s part?

Anon!: That “may be” must be, love, on Thursday next.
Goodbye!: That “may be” must be, love, on Thursday.

Anon!: Give me Bianca for my patrimony.
Goodbye!: Give me Bianca for my patrimony.

Anon!: By this hand, Claudio shall render me a dear account.
Goodbye!: By this hand, Claudio will give me a very good account.

Anon!: Peace, ho!
Goodbye!: Quiet!

Anon!: But they’ll nor pinch, Fright me with urchin-shows, pitch me i' th' mire, Nor lead me like a firebrand in the dark Out of my way, unless he bid 'em.
Goodbye!: But they’ll not pinch me, frighten me with urchin-shows, pitch me in the dark, and not lead me like a firebrand in the dark out of my way, unless he bid

Anon!: For what reason?
Goodbye!: Why?

Anon!: It is a reeling world indeed, my lord, And I believe will never stand upright Till Richard wear the garland of the realm.
Goodbye!: It’s a witty world, my lord, and I believe it won’t stand upright until Richard wears the garland of the realm.

Anon!: My lord.
Goodbye!: My lord.

Anon!: Gentle Mercutio, put thy rapier up.
Goodbye!: Gentle Mercutio, put your rapier up.

Anon!: Feed and sleep.
Goodbye!: Feed and sleep.

Anon!: There is no harm intended to your person, Nor to no Roman else.
Goodbye!: You don’t want to harm anyone, and you don’t want to harm anyone else.

Anon!: I’ll stay no longer question.
Goodbye!: I won’t be able to answer any more questions.

Anon!: How with mine honor may I give him that Which I have given to you?
Goodbye!: How can I honor him for the one I’ve given you?

Anon!: An thou make minstrels of us, look to hear nothing but discords.
Goodbye!: If you make a bunch of jokes about us, you’ll hear nothing but discords.

Anon!: If ever he have wife, let her be made More miserable by the death of him Than I am made by my poor lord and thee.— Come now towards Chertsey with your holy load, Taken from Paul’s to be interrèd there.
Goodbye!: If he ever has wife, let her be made miserable by the death of him more than I am made by my poor lord and you.—Come on to Chertsey with your holy load, taken from Paul

Anon!: Now, my Lord Constable?
Goodbye!: Now, my Lord Constable?

Anon!: But leave it all to God.
Goodbye!: But let it go to God.

Anon!: This kindness will I show.
Goodbye!: I’ll show you this kindness.

Anon!: We please them not by land.
Goodbye!: We don’t please them by land.

Anon!: Yes, that you did, sir, and forswore it too.
Goodbye!: Yes, you did, sir, and you forswore it too.

Anon!: It was about to speak when the cock crew.
Goodbye!: It was about to speak when the cock crew arrived.

Anon!: Go you to him from me.
Goodbye!: Go to him from me.

Anon!: Alas, poor Romeo!
Goodbye!: Oh, poor Romeo!

Anon!: What hour now?
Goodbye!: What hour is it?

Anon!: My lord and you were then at Mantua.— Nay, I do bear a brain.—But, as I said, When it did taste the wormwood on the nipple Of my dug and felt it bitter, pretty fool, To see it tetchy and fall out with the dug!
Goodbye!: My lord and you were at Mantua.—No, I have a brain.—But I said that when it tasted the wormwood on the nipple of my dug and felt it

Anon!: O, then, dear saint, let lips do what hands do.
Goodbye!: Oh, then, dear saint, let lips do what hands do.

Anon!: No place will please me so, no mean of death, As here by Caesar, and by you cut off, The choice and master spirits of this age.
Goodbye!: No place will please me, no death penalty will be imposed, as Caesar and you will cut off the choice and master spirits of this age.

Anon!: Call, good Mercutio.
Goodbye!: Call me, good Mercutio.

Anon!: Why, what is Tybalt?
Goodbye!: Why, what’s Tybalt?

Anon!: Where is he?
Goodbye!: Where is he?

Anon!: God keep your Ladyship still in that mind, so some gentle- man or other shall ’scape a predestinate scratched face.
Goodbye!: God keep your Ladyship in that mind, so that some gentle man or other will leave a scratched face.

Anon!: Pluck up thy spirits.
Goodbye!: Pluck up your spirits.

Anon!: Her eye discourses.
Goodbye!: Her eyes are talking.

Anon!: Does’t not go well?
Goodbye!: Doesn’t it go well?

Anon!: Is ’t come to this?
Goodbye!: Is it coming to this?

Anon!: If it be true that good wine needs no bush, ’tis true that a good play needs no epilogue.
Goodbye!: If it’s true that good wine doesn’t need a bush, it’s true that a good play doesn’t need a epilogue.

Anon!: You’re welcome hither.
Goodbye!: You’re welcome here.

Anon!: Ay, on my life, and hopes to find you forward Upon his party for the gain thereof; And thereupon he sends you this good news, That this same very day your enemies, The kindred of the queen, must die at Pomfret.
Goodbye!: Yes, I’m going to find you on his side, and then he sends you this good news, that your enemies, the kindred queen, must die at Pomfret on the same day.

Anon!: Bear with him, Brutus.
Goodbye!: Bear with him, Brutus.

Anon!: I have it here about me.
Goodbye!: I have it about me here.

Anon!: Why, why is this?
Goodbye!: Why, why is this?

Anon!: Why, she is within.
Goodbye!: She’s inside.

Anon!: How idly do they talk!
Goodbye!: How idly they talk!

Anon!: I pray thee, Rosalind, sweet my coz, be merry.
Goodbye!: Please, Rosalind, my sweet coz, be a good man.

Anon!: Tis strange, my Theseus, that these lovers speak of.
Goodbye!: It’s strange, My Theseus, that these lovers speak of.

Anon!: Thou know’st not gold’s effect.
Goodbye!: You don’t know gold’s effect.

Anon!: But I have none.
Goodbye!: But I don’t have any.

Anon!: O thou dull Moor!
Goodbye!: Oh, you dull Moor!

Anon!: Happily met, my lady and my wife.
Goodbye!: I’m happy to have you, my lady and my wife.

Anon!: Well, go thy way.
Goodbye!: Well, go on your way.

Anon!: O, fie, fie, fie!
Goodbye!: Oh, I’m a savage, I’m a savage!

Anon!: God be wi' you, princes all.
Goodbye!: God be wise, princes all.

Anon!: He longs to see your head.
Goodbye!: He’s eager to see your head.

Anon!: Good morrow to thee.
Goodbye!: Good morning to you.

Anon!: I see that thou art poor.
Goodbye!: I see that you’re poor.

Anon!: Seven of my people, with an obedient start, make out for him.
Goodbye!: Seven of my people make up for him with a obedient start.

Anon!: Did I not, fellow?
Goodbye!: Didn’t I, fellow?

Anon!: Where is your servant Caius?
Goodbye!: Where is your servant Caius?

Anon!: It sounds no more, and sure, it waits upon Some god o' th' island.
Goodbye!: It’s not a more sane thing, and it’s sure it’s waiting on some god on the island.

Anon!: The noblest deer hath them as huge as the rascal.
Goodbye!: The noblest deer has them as huge as the rascal.

Anon!: Would not they speak?
Goodbye!: They wouldn’t say anything?

Anon!: I stand on sudden haste.
Goodbye!: I’m ready to go.

Anon!: Help, ho!
Goodbye!: Help!

Anon!: You are too indulgent.
Goodbye!: You’re too indulgent.

Anon!: He would not?
Goodbye!: He wouldn’t?

Anon!: Let it not, Brutus.
Goodbye!: Don’t let it go, Brutus.

Anon!: Within this roof The enemy of all your graces lives.
Goodbye!: In this roof, the enemy of all your graces lives.

Anon!: If thou wert my fool, nuncle, I’d have thee beaten for being old before thy time.
Goodbye!: If you were my fool, my nuncle, I’d have you beaten for being old before you.

Anon!: If you do stir abroad, go armed.
Goodbye!: If you’re going abroad, go armed.

Anon!: Yet what can it when one can not repent?
Goodbye!: But what can I do when I can’t repent?

Anon!: Stand from the body.
Goodbye!: Stand out of the body.

Anon!: What says the golden chest?
Goodbye!: What does the golden chest say?

Anon!: Pretty soul!
Goodbye!: Pretty soul!

Anon!: Is there more toil?
Goodbye!: Is there more work to do?

Anon!: Never—O fault!—revealed myself unto him Until some half-hour past, when I was armed.
Goodbye!: I never resisted myself to him until half an hour ago, when I was armed.

Anon!: Thy head is as full of quarrels as an egg is full of meat, and yet thy head hath been beaten as addle as an egg for quarreling.
Goodbye!: Your head is as full of fights as an egg is full of meat, and yet your head has been beaten as much as an egg for fighting.

Anon!: God bless your Grace with health and happy days.
Goodbye!: God bless your Grace with health and happy days.

Anon!: I say unto thee, I bid thy master cutout the gown, but I did not bid him cut it to pieces.
Goodbye!: I say to you, I asked your master to cut out the gown, but I didn’t ask him to cut it to pieces.

Anon!: We are arrant knaves, all.
Goodbye!: We’re arrant knaves, all of them.

Anon!: I dare swear this is the right Vincentio.
Goodbye!: I swear this is the right Vincentio.

Anon!: Nay, good Sir Toby.
Goodbye!: No, good Sir Toby.

Anon!: We’ll answer.
Goodbye!: We’ll answer.

Anon!: I will speak daggers to her but use none.
Goodbye!: I’ll speak daggers to her, but I’ll use none.

Anon!: Nor I.
Goodbye!: I’m not.

Anon!: Ha, ha, ha!
Goodbye!: Ha, ha, ha!

Anon!: To whom, my lord?
Goodbye!: To whom, my lord?

Anon!: He is very busy about it.
Goodbye!: He’s very busy about it.

Anon!: You may do then in time.
Goodbye!: You can do that then in time.

Anon!: Make it a word and a blow.
Goodbye!: Make it a word and a blow.

Anon!: So hath my lord dared him to single fight.
Goodbye!: So my lord has urged him to fight single.

Anon!: That methinks is strange.
Goodbye!: That’s strange.

Anon!: He hath made me a Christian.
Goodbye!: He’s made me a Christian.

Anon!: Madam, there is at the gate a young gentleman much desires to speak with you.
Goodbye!: Madam, there is a young gentleman at the gate wanting to speak with you.

Anon!: And yet it is not: it is but so-so.
Goodbye!: But it isn’t, it is.

Anon!: Couple it with something.
Goodbye!: Add it to something.

Anon!: I have been with your father and given him notice that the Duke of Cornwall and Regan his duchess will be here with him this night.
Goodbye!: I’ve been with your father and told him that the Duke of Cornwall and Regan’s duchess will be here with him tonight.

Anon!: You cloudy princes and heart-sorrowing peers That bear this heavy mutual load of moan, Now cheer each other in each other’s love.
Goodbye!: You cloudy princes and heart-sorrowing peers who bear this heavy mutually heavy burden of moan, cheer each other up in each other’s love.

Anon!: It is a most sharp sauce.
Goodbye!: It’s a very sharp sauce.

Anon!: With what I get, I mean, and so do they.
Goodbye!: I mean, with what I get, and so do they.

Anon!: Passion, I see, is catching, for mine eyes, Seeing those beads of sorrow stand in thine, Began to water.
Goodbye!: I see, passion is getting caught, because my eyes, seeing those sorrowful beads stand in yours, poured into water.

Anon!: But yet I’ll go in hate to feed upon The prodigal Christian.—Jessica, my girl, Look to my house.
Goodbye!: But I’ll go in hate to feed the prodigal Christian.—Jessica, my girl, go to my house.

Anon!: I would I had thy inches.
Goodbye!: I wish I had your inches.

Anon!: Niggard of question, but of our demands Most free in his reply.
Goodbye!: He’s free of any question, but he’s free of any questions.

Anon!: Go, one, and call the Jew into the court.
Goodbye!: Go one, and call the Jew into the court.

Anon!: Or he that slew her brothers and her uncles?
Goodbye!: Or the man who killed her brothers and her uncles?

Anon!: Are you fair?
Goodbye!: Are you fair?

Anon!: I hate it as an unfilled can.
Goodbye!: I hate it as much as a void.

Anon!: Let this fellow Be nothing of our strife.
Goodbye!: Let this fellow be nothing from our fight.

Anon!: He plies the duke at morning and at night, And doth impeach the freedom of the state If they deny him justice.
Goodbye!: He’s pleading the duke at morning and night, and he’ll impeach the state’s freedom if they deny him justice.

Anon!: Shall I say to Caesar What you require of him?
Goodbye!: Should I tell Caesar what you want from him?

Anon!: Gods and goddesses, All the whole synod of them!
Goodbye!: Gods and goddesses, all the whole thing of them!

Anon!: I do remember.
Goodbye!: I remember.

Anon!: I am sure, sweet Kate, this kindness merits thanks.
Goodbye!: I’m sure, sweet Kate, this kindness deserves thanks.

Anon!: Call her forth, brother.
Goodbye!: Call her out, brother.

Anon!: But lest my liking might too sudden seem, I would have salved it with a longer treatise.
Goodbye!: But if I could seem too sudden, I would have smashed it with a longer treatise.

Anon!: Any bar, any cross, any impediment will be med'cinable to me.
Goodbye!: Any bar, any cross, any obstacle will be cured to me.

Anon!: Traverse, go, provide thy money.
Goodbye!: Go, give me your money.

Anon!: I will not.
Goodbye!: I won’t.

Anon!: Wilt thou at Ninny’s tomb meet me straightway?
Goodbye!: Do you want to meet me at Ninny’s tomb straight away?

Anon!: Go, sirrah, trudge about Through fair Verona.
Goodbye!: Go, sir, trudge around through fair Verona.

Anon!: Pray you, leave your courtesy, good monsieur.
Goodbye!: Please, let’s go, good monsieur.

Anon!: Dolabella!
Goodbye!: Dolabella!

Anon!: Close by, my master.
Goodbye!: Close by, my master.

Anon!: I have been up this hour, awake all night.
Goodbye!: I’ve been awake all night for a while.

Anon!: Is she not apt?
Goodbye!: Isn’t she right?

Anon!: He is a dreamer.
Goodbye!: He’s a dreamer.

Anon!: Her head’s declined, and death will seize her but Your comfort makes the rescue.
Goodbye!: Her head has declined, and death will save her, but you’ll help her.

Anon!: All things are ready if our minds be so.
Goodbye!: Everything is ready if our minds are so.

Anon!: Give me mine armor.
Goodbye!: Give me my armor.

Anon!: My cousin tells him in his ear that he is in her heart.
Goodbye!: My cousin tells him in his ear that he’s in her heart.

Anon!: Thy Clarence he is dead that stabbed my Edward, And the beholders of this frantic play, Th' adulterate Hastings, Rivers, Vaughan, Grey, Untimely smothered in their dusky graves.
Goodbye!: Your Clarence is dead, who stabbed my Edward, and the beholders of this frantic play, your adulterate Hastings, Rivers, Vaughan, Grey, smothered in their

Anon!: Your face, my thane, is as a book where men May read strange matters.
Goodbye!: Your face is like a book where men can read strange things.

Anon!: Farewell.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: And false.
Goodbye!: And false.

Anon!: No, I do not know you, nor I am not sent to you by my lady, to bid you come speak with her, nor your name is not Master Cesario, nor this is not my nose neither.
Goodbye!: No, I don’t know you, and I’m not sent to you by my lady to tell you to speak with her, and your name is not Master Cesario, and this is not my nose either.

Anon!: Alack, poor gentleman!
Goodbye!: Oh, poor gentleman!

Anon!: If you love her then, tomorrow wed her.
Goodbye!: If you love her then, tomorrow wed her.

Anon!: His grace hath made the match, and all grace say “Amen” to it.
Goodbye!: His grace made the match, and all of his grace said “Amen” to it.

Anon!: If haply you my father do suspect An instrument of this your calling back, Lay not your blame on me.
Goodbye!: If you, my father, suspect that this is the way you call back, don’t blame me.

Anon!: A grave?
Goodbye!: A grave?

Anon!: We’ll mutiny.
Goodbye!: We’ll mutiny.

Anon!: His son is thirty.
Goodbye!: His son is thirty.

Anon!: Yes, ’tis Emilia.— 'Tis like she comes to speak of Cassio’s death, The noise was high.
Goodbye!: Yes, it’s Emilia.—It’s like she’s coming to speak about Cassio’s death, the noise was high.

Anon!: Well, you may fear too far.
Goodbye!: Well, you may be afraid to go too far.

Anon!: Poor prattler, how thou talk’st!
Goodbye!: Poor prattler, how do you talk?

Anon!: Right, as snow in harvest.
Goodbye!: Right, as snow is in the harvest.

Anon!: Away with him!
Goodbye!: Get out of here!

Anon!: Let me endure your wrath, if ’t be not so.
Goodbye!: Let me endure your wrath if it’s not true.

Anon!: Let me see her.
Goodbye!: Let me see her.

Anon!: I could interpret between you and your love, if I could see the puppets dallying.
Goodbye!: I could interpret the relationship between you and your love if I saw the puppets dallying.

Anon!: I understand not, madam.
Goodbye!: I don’t understand, madam.

Anon!: And do still, by these pickers and stealers.
Goodbye!: And still do, by these pickers and stealers.

Anon!: You all do know this mantle.
Goodbye!: You all know this mantle.

Anon!: Now, by heaven, My blood begins my safer guides to rule, And passion, having my best judgment collied, Assays to lead the way.
Goodbye!: Now, by heaven, my blood begins to guide me to rule, and my passion, after my best judgment collied, is as strong as I can lead the way.

Anon!: Hail to thee, lady, and the grace of heaven, Before, behind thee, and on every hand, Enwheel thee round!
Goodbye!: Please, lady, and the grace of heaven, please, go ahead, behind you, and on every hand, turn around!

Anon!: For three months, well.
Goodbye!: For three months, well.

Anon!: This is as uncivil as strange.
Goodbye!: This is as uncivil as strange.

Anon!: If the English had any apprehension, they would run away.
Goodbye!: If the English had any misunderstanding, they would run away.

Anon!: Faith, some certain dregs of conscience are yet within me.
Goodbye!: Yes, some dregs of conscience are still in me.

Anon!: At mine own house, good lady.
Goodbye!: I’m at my own house, good lady.

Anon!: But I, who never knew how to entreat, Nor never needed that I should entreat, Am starved for meat, giddy for lack of sleep, With oaths kept waking and with brawling fed.
Goodbye!: But I, who never knew how to eat, and never needed to eat, am starved for meat, giddy for lack of sleep, with oaths kept waking and fed with brawling

Anon!: Sir, she can turn, and turn, and yet go on, And turn again.
Goodbye!: Sir, she can turn, turn, and turn, and yet go on, and turn again.

Anon!: Belike for want of rain, which I could well Beteem them from the tempest of my eyes.
Goodbye!: I could bet they’re not a good thing to betray my eyes.

Anon!: What things are these, my lord Antonio?
Goodbye!: What are these things, my lord Antonio?

Anon!: Let that suffice you.
Goodbye!: Let that suffice you.

Anon!: Methinks I could not die anywhere so contented as in the king’s company, his cause being just and his quarrel honorable.
Goodbye!: I think I could not die anywhere as happy as in the king’s company, his cause being just and honorable.

Anon!: I am not bid for love.
Goodbye!: I’m not asking for love.

Anon!: What will you give us?
Goodbye!: What will you give us?

Anon!: He seeks my life.
Goodbye!: He’s looking for my life.

Anon!: Take that of me, my friend, who have the power  To seal th' accuser’s lips.
Goodbye!: Take that of me, my friend, who have the power to seal the accuser’s lips.

Anon!: By your patience, no.
Goodbye!: No, you’re patient.

Anon!: Let their beds Be made as soft as yours and let their palates Be seasoned with such viands”?
Goodbye!: Let their beds be as soft as yours and let their palates be seasoned with such a sour cream”?

Anon!: Perchance he is not drown’d.—What think you, sailors?
Goodbye!: What do you think, sailors?

Anon!: The day is yours.
Goodbye!: The day is yours.

Anon!: Look you, if you take the matter otherwise than is meant, Captain Macmorris, peradventure I shall think you do not use me with that affability as, in discretion, you ought to use me, look you, being as good a man as yourself, both in the disciplines of war and in the derivation of my birth and in other particularities.
Goodbye!: If you take the matter out of the way it is meant, Captain Macmorris, I’ll think you don’t use me with that affability as you should use me, look at me, as good a man

Anon!: Caesar, I will.
Goodbye!: Caesar, I will.

Anon!: Good my lord, what is your cause of distemper?
Goodbye!: My lord, what’s your cause for distemperation?

Anon!: Nor stony tower, nor walls of beaten brass, Nor airless dungeon, nor strong links of iron Can be retentive to the strength of spirit.
Goodbye!: A stony tower, beaten walls, a dungeon, or a strong iron ring can be retracted to the strength of spirit.

Anon!: Why, sir, I trust I may have leave to speak, And speak I will.
Goodbye!: I hope I have the right to speak, and I will.

Anon!: Methinks I should know you, and know this man.
Goodbye!: I think I should know you and know this man.

Anon!: Good morrow, brother Bedford.
Goodbye!: Good morning, brother Bedford.

Anon!: Thy woes will make them sharp and pierce like mine.
Goodbye!: Your sorrows will make them sharp and pierce like mine.

Anon!: Set you down this,
Goodbye!: Write this down.

Anon!: I will owe thee an answer for that.
Goodbye!: I’ll give you a reply for that.

Anon!: Speak, my fair, and fairly, I pray thee.
Goodbye!: Speak, my fair, and fair, I beg you.

Anon!: Give him this letter.
Goodbye!: Give him this letter.

Anon!: By heaven, I do not, I do not, gentlemen.—   O murderous coxcomb!
Goodbye!: I swear by heaven, I don’t, I don’t, gentlemen.—Oh, murderous coxcomb!

Anon!: Take from them now The sense of reck'ning ere th' opposèd numbers Pluck their hearts from them.
Goodbye!: Take away the sense of reckning from the opposing numbers and take away their hearts.

Anon!: Will you have her?
Goodbye!: Will you have her?

Anon!: I was the more deceived.
Goodbye!: I was the more deceived.

Anon!: And to that end, sir, I will welcome you.
Goodbye!: And to that end, sir, I’ll welcome you.

Anon!: She’s full of most blessed condition.
Goodbye!: She’s in a very blessed condition.

Anon!: Speakest thou from thy heart?
Goodbye!: Do you speak from your heart?

Anon!: Truly, sir, all that I live by is with the awl.
Goodbye!: I’m a wll.

Anon!: If I can recover him and keep him tame and get to Naples with him, he’s a present for any emperor that ever trod on neat’s leather.
Goodbye!: If I can recover him and keep him tame and get to Naples with him, he’s a present for any emperor who ever threw his leather on a neat leather jacket.

Anon!: If in Naples I should report this now, would they believe me?
Goodbye!: If I’m going to Naples now, would they believe me?

Anon!: To the vales, And hold our best advantage.
Goodbye!: To the vales, and have our best advantage.

Anon!: It is no shame.
Goodbye!: It’s not shameful.

Anon!: I do not, till you practice them on me.
Goodbye!: I don’t, until you’ve done them on me.

Anon!: I shall entreat him To answer like himself.
Goodbye!: I’ll ask him to answer like himself.

Anon!: Come, sir, away.
Goodbye!: Come, sir, get out of here.

Anon!: She must change for youth.
Goodbye!: She must change for youth.

Anon!: Good morrow, sweet Hero.
Goodbye!: Good morning, sweet Hero.

Anon!: It doth appear you are a worthy judge.
Goodbye!: It seems you’re a worthy judge.

Anon!: Let me go with him.
Goodbye!: Let me go with him.

Anon!: But canst thou guess that he doth aim at it?
Goodbye!: But can you guess that he’s trying to do it?

Anon!: Take your time.
Goodbye!: Take your time.

Anon!: Turn thee back, And tell thy king I do not seek him now But could be willing to march on to Calais Without impeachment, for, to say the sooth, Though ’tis no wisdom to confess so much Unto an enemy of craft and vantage, My people are with sickness much enfeebled, My numbers lessened, and those few I have Almost no better than so many French, Who when they were in health, I tell thee, herald, I thought upon one pair of English legs Did march three Frenchmen.
Goodbye!: Turn your back and tell your king I don’t want him now, but I could be willing to march on to Calais without impeachment.

Anon!: Thou seest we are not all alone unhappy.
Goodbye!: You see, we’re not all alone unhappy.

Anon!: Humh!
Goodbye!: Humh!

Anon!: Tis not yet near day.
Goodbye!: It’s not yet day.

Anon!: By what?
Goodbye!: What?

Anon!: Madam, in happy time, what day is that?
Goodbye!: Madam, what day is that?

Anon!: Adieu, good neighbor.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, good neighbor.

Anon!: Is not the leaf turned down Where I left reading?
Goodbye!: Isn’t the leaf turned down where I left reading?

Anon!: O knight, thou lackest a cup of canary.
Goodbye!: Oh, knight, you don’t have a cup of canary.

Anon!: Thou shalt be loggerhead.—Good faith, ’tis day.
Goodbye!: You’ll be a loggerhead.—Good faith, it’s day.

Anon!: I am sorry.
Goodbye!: I’m sorry.

Anon!: I am content, so thou wilt have it so.
Goodbye!: I’m happy, you’ll get it.

Anon!: Has he, masters?
Goodbye!: Has he, masters?

Anon!: But where the greater malady is fixed The lesser is scarce felt.
Goodbye!: But where the greater the malady is fixed, the less the less the problem is.

Anon!: But with a rearward following Tybalt’s death, “Romeo is banishèd.” To speak that word, Is father, mother, Tybalt, Romeo, Juliet, All slain, all dead.
Goodbye!: But with a rearward following Tybalt’s death, “Romeo is banned.” To speak that word, Tybalt, Romeo, Juliet, are all dead, all dead.

Anon!: The man that once did sell the lion’s skin While the beast lived was killed with hunting him.
Goodbye!: The man who once sold the lion’s skin while the beast lived was killed by hunting him.

Anon!: What, did he marry me to famish me?
Goodbye!: What, did he marry me to famish me?

Anon!: Why then, God’s soldier be he!
Goodbye!: Well then, God’s soldier will be him!

Anon!: For my part, I care not.
Goodbye!: For my part, I don’t care.

Anon!: But, sirrah, mark, we use To say the dead are well.
Goodbye!: But, sir, mark, we’re using this phrase to say the dead are well.

Anon!: I’ll tell my husband, Launcelot, what you say.
Goodbye!: I’ll tell my husband what you’re saying, Launcelot.

Anon!: Murder!
Goodbye!: Murder!

Anon!: For no kind of traffic Would I admit.
Goodbye!: I wouldn’t admit any kind of traffic.

Anon!: That island of England breeds very valiant creatures.
Goodbye!: That island of England breeds very valiant creatures.

Anon!: I will praise any man that will praise me, though it cannot be denied what I have done by land.
Goodbye!: I’ll praise any man who will praise me, even though it can’t be denied what I’ve done on land.

Anon!: Is the day so young?
Goodbye!: Is the day so young?

Anon!: An apple, cleft in two, is not more twin Than these two creatures.
Goodbye!: An apple, cleft in two, is not more twin than these two creatures.

Anon!: Nurse?
Goodbye!: Nurse?

Anon!: I will do so.
Goodbye!: I’ll do so.

Anon!: The king hath note of all that they intend, By interception which they dream not of.
Goodbye!: The king has taken note of everything they intend to do, by interpreting what they don’t dream of.

Anon!: Where is my page?—Go, villain, fetch a surgeon.
Goodbye!: Where is my page?—Go, villain, get a surgeon.

Anon!: If he break the peace, he ought to enter into a quarrel with fear and trembling.
Goodbye!: If he breaks the peace, he’ll have to fight with fear and trembling.

Anon!: In faith, my hand meant nothing to my sword.
Goodbye!: I swear, my hand didn’t mean anything to my sword.

Anon!: My best endeavours shall be done herein.
Goodbye!: I’ll do my best to do this.

Anon!: But for all this thou shalt have as many dolors for thy daughters as thou canst tell in a year.
Goodbye!: But for all this you’ll have as many dolors for your daughters as you can tell in a year.

Anon!: Against my soul’s pure truth why labour you To make it wander in an unknown field?
Goodbye!: Why are you trying to make my soul wander in an unknown field?

Anon!: My most exquisite Sir Topas!
Goodbye!: My most exquisite Sir Topas!

Anon!: I’ll make him find him.
Goodbye!: I’ll find him.

Anon!: It is the east, and Juliet is the sun.
Goodbye!: It’s the east, and Juliet’s the sun.

Anon!: Here lies your way.
Goodbye!: Here you go.

Anon!: Not sick, my lord, unless it be in mind, Nor well, unless in mind.
Goodbye!: I’m not sick, my lord, unless I’m thinking about it, or well, unless I’m thinking about it.

Anon!: Oh, farewell!
Goodbye!: Goodbye!

Anon!: My lord, I cannot.
Goodbye!: My lord, I can’t.

Anon!: Why Romeo, art thou mad?
Goodbye!: Why Romeo, are you crazy?

Anon!: Bid her have good heart.
Goodbye!: Tell her to have a good heart.

Anon!: Here comes my man.
Goodbye!: Here comes my man.

Anon!: I had it of him.
Goodbye!: I had it from him.

Anon!: That is, to watch her, as we watch these kites That bate and beat and will not be obedient.
Goodbye!: That’s, watch her, as we watch these kites that bate and beat and won’t be obedient.

Anon!: You were the word of war.
Goodbye!: You were the word of war.

Anon!: Oh, she is lame!
Goodbye!: Oh, she’s lame!

Anon!: I know him to be valiant.
Goodbye!: I know him as brave.

Anon!: Good beauties, let me sustain no scorn.
Goodbye!: Good beauties, don’t be angry.

Anon!: And take good note What Caesar doth, what suitors press to him.
Goodbye!: And take good note of what Caesar does, what suitors press to him.

Anon!: Why, so I do.
Goodbye!: I do.

Anon!: They never meet but there’s a skirmish of wit between them.
Goodbye!: They never meet but there’s a skirmish of wit between them.

Anon!: O sir, you are old.
Goodbye!: Oh sir, you’re old.

Anon!: But oh, how vile an idol proves this god!
Goodbye!: But oh, how vile an idol proves this god!

Anon!: Yet must not we put the strong law on him.
Goodbye!: But we shouldn’t put the law on him.

Anon!: Pour in sow’s blood, that hath eaten Her nine farrow; grease that’s sweaten From the murderer’s gibbet throw Into the flame.
Goodbye!: Pour in her blood that has eaten nine farrows.

Anon!: There is occasions and causes why and wherefore in all things.
Goodbye!: There are occasions and causes for all things.

Anon!: There is no world without Verona walls But purgatory, torture, hell itself.
Goodbye!: There is no world without walls in Verona, but purgatory, torture, and hell itself.

Anon!: I bear no hatred, blessèd man, for, lo, My intercession likewise steads my foe.
Goodbye!: I don’t have hatred, blessed man, because my intercession is like a foe.

Anon!: Nay, you must name his name, and half his face must be seen through the lion’s neck.
Goodbye!: No, you have to name his name, and half his face must be seen through the lion’s neck.

Anon!: Many a morning hath he there been seen, With tears augmenting the fresh morning’s dew, Adding to clouds more clouds with his deep sighs.
Goodbye!: He’s been seen there many times a morning, with tears sighing over the dew, adding to clouds more clouds.

Anon!: Who now the price of his dear blood doth owe?
Goodbye!: Who owes the price of his dear blood now?

Anon!: What with a torch!
Goodbye!: What with a torch!

Anon!: I did hear The galloping of horse.
Goodbye!: I heard the galloping of a horse.

Anon!: Call Claudio and some other of my men.
Goodbye!: Call Claudio and some of my men.

Anon!: Come hither, fellow.
Goodbye!: Come here, fellow.

Anon!: Delay not, Caesar.
Goodbye!: Don’t delay, Caesar.

Anon!: What malice was between you?
Goodbye!: What was the trouble between you and me?

Anon!: I will not stay behind.
Goodbye!: I won’t stay behind.

Anon!: Your reproof is something too round.
Goodbye!: Your reproof is something too round.

Anon!: There is means, madam.
Goodbye!: There are some means, madam.

Anon!: She stood and spake.
Goodbye!: She stood and said something.

Anon!: I shall answer for her.
Goodbye!: I’ll answer for her.

Anon!: A daughter?
Goodbye!: A daughter?

Anon!: I will tell you.
Goodbye!: I’ll tell you.

Anon!: O Pyramus, arise!
Goodbye!: Oh, Pyramus, come on!

Anon!: Calphurnia!
Goodbye!: Calphurnia!

Anon!: Horrible steep.
Goodbye!: It’s a cliff.

Anon!: The skin is good for your broken coxcomb.
Goodbye!: The skin is good for your broken coxcomb.

Anon!: A calendar, a calendar!
Goodbye!: A calendar, a calendar!

Anon!: Conrade, I say!
Goodbye!: Conrade, I say!

Anon!: Not dead?
Goodbye!: Are you dead?

Anon!: I pray you, master, tell me?
Goodbye!: Please tell me, master?

Anon!: Thus I do escape the sorrow Of Antony’s death.
Goodbye!: So I’m free from the sorrow of Antony’s death.

Anon!: Their course of love, the tidings of her death.
Goodbye!: Their love course, the tidal of her death.

Anon!: Now, ere the sun advance his burning eye, The day to cheer and night’s dank dew to dry, I must upfill this osier cage of ours With baleful weeds and precious-juicèd flowers.
Goodbye!: Now, if the sun advances his burning eye, the day to cheer and the night’s dew to dry, I must fill this osier cage of ours with baleful weeds and precious-ju

Anon!: There!
Goodbye!: There!

Anon!: Do so.
Goodbye!: Do so.

Anon!: Well, more anon.—Comes the king forth, I pray you?
Goodbye!: Well, more on that.—Come on, I ask you, is the king coming?

Anon!: Michael, good night.
Goodbye!: Michael, good night.

Anon!: O God of battles, steel my soldiers' hearts.
Goodbye!: Oh God of battles, steel my soldiers' hearts.

Anon!: On, on, you noblest English, Whose blood is fet from fathers of war-proof, Fathers that, like so many Alexanders, Have in these parts from morn till even fought And sheathed their swords for lack of argument.
Goodbye!: On, on, on, on, on, on, on, on, on, on, on, on, on, on, on, on, on, on, on, on, on, on, on, on, on

Anon!: Tell him, when that our princely father York Blessed his three sons with his victorious arm, He little thought of this divided friendship.
Goodbye!: Tell him, when our princely father York blessed his three sons with his victorious arm, he didn’t think about this split friendship.

Anon!: Out of my sight!
Goodbye!: Out of my sight!

Anon!: The question of his death is enrolled in the Capitol.
Goodbye!: The question of his death is a question that’s being answered in the Capitol.

Anon!: Do, good friend.
Goodbye!: Do it, my friend.

Anon!: Ere he take ship for France, and in Southampton.
Goodbye!: He’s going to take ship for France and Southampton.

Anon!: And so no doubt he is, my gracious madam.
Goodbye!: And so he is, my gracious madam.

Anon!: See where she comes from shrift with merry look.
Goodbye!: Look, she’s coming from shrift with a merry look.

Anon!: Look what is done cannot be now amended.
Goodbye!: Look, what’s been done can’t be changed now.

Anon!: But, O grief, Where hast thou led me?
Goodbye!: But, oh, grief, where have you led me?

Anon!: The former Hero!
Goodbye!: The former Hero!

Anon!: I hope we have reformed that indifferently with us, sir.
Goodbye!: I hope we’ve reformed that indifferently, sir.

Anon!: Answer me directly.
Goodbye!: Answer me directly.

Anon!: Dear love, adieu.— Anon, good Nurse!—Sweet Montague, be true.
Goodbye!: Dear love, adieu.—Aon, good Nurse!—Sweet Montague, be true.

Anon!: I am not of your element.
Goodbye!: I’m not yours.

Anon!: Brother Anthony—
Goodbye!: Brother Anthony—

Anon!: If thou canst love me for this, take me.
Goodbye!: If you can love me for this, take me.

Anon!: Is he pursued?
Goodbye!: Is he going to be arrested?

Anon!: Challenge me the count’s youth to fight with him.
Goodbye!: Challenge me the count’s youth to fight with him.

Anon!: Therefore our everlasting farewell take.
Goodbye!: So let’s take our everlasting farewell.

Anon!: I think so too.
Goodbye!: I think so too.

Anon!: I’ll be with thee straight.
Goodbye!: I’ll be with you straight away.

Anon!: Go softly on.
Goodbye!: Go on.

Anon!: The sister to my wife, this gentlewoman, Thy son by this hath married.
Goodbye!: My wife’s sister, this lady, your son has been married by this.

Anon!: O woeful time.
Goodbye!: Oh, what a sad time.

Anon!: Where be thy brothers?
Goodbye!: Where are your brothers?

Anon!: He shall do this, or else I do recant The pardon that I late pronouncèd here.
Goodbye!: He’ll do this, or I’ll recant the pardon I pronouncéd here late.

Anon!: The poison of that lies in you to temper.
Goodbye!: You’re going to be poisoned by that.

Anon!: We cannot be here and there too.
Goodbye!: We can’t be both here and there.

Anon!: It is both he and she: Your son and daughter.
Goodbye!: It’s both him and her: your son and daughter.

Anon!: Why dost thou ask?
Goodbye!: Why do you ask?

Anon!: Why, the honest men.
Goodbye!: The honest men.

Anon!: This naughty man Shall face to face be brought to Margaret, Who I believe was packed in all this wrong, Hired to it by your brother.
Goodbye!: This naughty man will face to face with Margaret, who I believe was thrown in all this wrong, hired by your brother.

Anon!: Why, whither shall we go?
Goodbye!: Why, where will we go?

Anon!: Then ’tis most like The sovereignty will fall upon Macbeth.
Goodbye!: Then it’s almost like Macbeth’s sovereignty will fall on him.

Anon!: What, go you toward the Tower?
Goodbye!: What, are you going to the Tower?

Anon!: How now, Roderigo!
Goodbye!: What’s going on, Roderigo?

Anon!: We’ll whisper o'er a couplet or two of most sage saws.
Goodbye!: We’ll whisper about a couple of or two of most sage saws.

Anon!: I almost die for food, and let me have it.
Goodbye!: I’m almost dying for food, and let me have it.

Anon!: Ha, ha, ha!
Goodbye!: Ha, ha, ha!

Anon!: The French ambassador upon that instant Craved audience.
Goodbye!: The French ambassador was greeted by a crowd.

Anon!: I hear his trumpet.
Goodbye!: I hear his trumpet.

Anon!: I do not now fool myself, to let imagination jade me, for every reason excites to this, that my lady loves me.
Goodbye!: I don’t fool myself, because I’m afraid I’m letting my imagination fool me, for every reason, that my lady loves me.

Anon!: The wager?
Goodbye!: What’s the wager?

Anon!: Truly, sir, the better for my foes and the worse for my friends.
Goodbye!: The better for my enemies and the worse for my friends.

Anon!: Alas, then she is drowned.
Goodbye!: Well, then she’s drowned.

Anon!: I shall not sleep in quiet at the Tower.
Goodbye!: I won’t sleep in the quiet at the Tower.

Anon!: Captain, I thee beseech to do me favors.
Goodbye!: Captain, I beg you to do me good.

Anon!: Is there a murderer here?
Goodbye!: Is there a murderer here?

Anon!: A madness most discreet, A choking gall, and a preserving sweet.
Goodbye!: A sour, choking gall, and a sweet treat.

Anon!: Fare you well, boy.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, boy.

Anon!: By my head, here comes the Capulets.
Goodbye!: I swear, here come the Capulets.

Anon!: What beast was ’t, then, That made you break this enterprise to me?
Goodbye!: What beast did you think you were breaking this deal with me?

Anon!: And you, good yeoman, Whose limbs were made in England, show us here The mettle of your pasture.
Goodbye!: And you, good yeoman, who made limbs in England, show us the mud of your pasture.

Anon!: O sir, such a life with such a wife were strange!
Goodbye!: Oh sir, such a life with such a wife was strange!

Anon!: What may she not?
Goodbye!: What can’t she do?

Anon!: Old I do wax, and from my weary limbs Honor is cudgeled.
Goodbye!: I’m old, and honor is cudgeled from my limbs.

Anon!: Go, leave me.
Goodbye!: Go, leave me.

Anon!: He knows not the stop.
Goodbye!: He doesn’t know where to stop.

Anon!: Wilt thou set thy foot o' my neck?
Goodbye!: Do you want to put your foot on my neck?

Anon!: Ay, every man away.
Goodbye!: Yes, every man is away.

Anon!: You look not well, Signor Antonio.
Goodbye!: You don’t look well, Antonio.

Anon!: No blown ambition doth our arms incite, But love—dear love!—and our aged father’s right.
Goodbye!: No ambition is enough to inspire our arms, but love—dear love!—and our father’s right.

Anon!: Helena, adieu.
Goodbye!: Helena, goodbye.

Anon!: And twenty of these puny lies I’ll tell, That men shall swear I have discontinued school Above a twelvemonth.
Goodbye!: And twenty of these lies I’ll tell you, that men will swear I’ve been deprived of school for more than a twelve month period.

Anon!: Wert thou not banishèd on pain of death?
Goodbye!: Don’t you want to be banned from dying?

Anon!: What three things does drink especially provoke?
Goodbye!: What three things does drink make you angry?

Anon!: Here, noble lord.
Goodbye!: Here, noble lord.

Anon!: Sweet friends, your patience for my long abode.
Goodbye!: Dear friends, please, I’m waiting for you.

Anon!: Therefore thou sleep’st so sound.
Goodbye!: So you’re sleeping so soundly.

Anon!: Let’s talk.
Goodbye!: Let’s talk.

Anon!: Give me your hand.
Goodbye!: Give me your hand.

Anon!: At sea, I think.
Goodbye!: At sea, I think.

Anon!: Do, young sir.
Goodbye!: Do it, young sir.

Anon!: Sink Rome!
Goodbye!: Sink Rome!

Anon!: It is a most sharp sauce.
Goodbye!: It’s a very sharp sauce.

Anon!: I thought thou hadst been resolute.
Goodbye!: I thought you’d been resolute.

Anon!: Press near and second him.
Goodbye!: Press near him and second him.

Anon!: What rein can hold licentious wickedness When down the hill he holds his fierce career?
Goodbye!: What kind of wickedness can he hold when he climbs down the hill with his fierce career?

Anon!: Why dost thou stay?
Goodbye!: Why are you waiting?

Anon!: Gratiano!
Goodbye!: Gratiano!

Anon!: Come hither, Proculeius.
Goodbye!: Come here, Proculeius.

Anon!: Therefore we’ll have some half a dozen friends, And there an end.
Goodbye!: So we’ll have about half a dozen friends, and that’s the end.

Anon!: I do not, sir.
Goodbye!: I don’t, sir.

Anon!: Will you go, sister?—Shepherd, ply her hard.
Goodbye!: Will you go, sister?—Shepherd, ply her hard.

Anon!: He did, from first to last.
Goodbye!: He did, from first to last.

Anon!: If more, the more thou’st wronged me.
Goodbye!: If you’re more serious, the more you’ve wronged me.

Anon!: Their shadows seem A canopy most fatal, under which Our army lies, ready to give up the ghost.
Goodbye!: Their shadows seem to be the most fatal canopy in our army, ready to give up the ghost.

Anon!: No, Caesar shall not.
Goodbye!: No, Caesar won’t.

Anon!: I am sorry that your leisure serves you not.— Antonio, gratify this gentleman, For in my mind you are much bound to him.
Goodbye!: I’m sorry you don’t enjoy your leisure.— Antonio, please, this gentleman, because you’re very much bound to him.

Anon!: And do it with all thy heart.
Goodbye!: And do it with all your heart.

Anon!: Will she go now to bed?
Goodbye!: Will she go to bed now?

Anon!: Little” again?
Goodbye!: “No, no,” again?

Anon!: Past the mid season.
Goodbye!: Past mid season.

Anon!: Wilt thou, O God, fly from such gentle lambs And throw them in the entrails of the wolf?
Goodbye!: Do you want to fly from such gentle lambs and throw them in the wolf’s entrails?

Anon!: I had my father’s signet in my purse, Which was the model of that Danish seal.
Goodbye!: I had my father’s signet in my purse, which was the model of that Danish seal.

Anon!: I’ll apprehend him.
Goodbye!: I’ll arrest him.

Anon!: Well, Juliet, I will lie with thee tonight.
Goodbye!: Well, Juliet, I’ll lie with you tonight.

Anon!: Not here in presence.
Goodbye!: Not here in presence.

Anon!: The next, our ship— Which, but three glasses since, we gave out split— Is tight and yare and bravely rigged as when We first put out to sea.
Goodbye!: The next, our ship—which we gave out three glasses since we gave it out—is tight and yare and bravely rigged as when we first put out to sea.

Anon!: But for his purpose in the coronation, I have not sounded him, nor he delivered His gracious pleasure any way therein.
Goodbye!: But I haven’t sounded him for his purpose in the coronation, and he hasn’t delivered his gracious pleasure anywhere there.

Anon!: She dies for ’t.—Eros, ho!
Goodbye!: She dies for it.—Eros, ho!

Anon!: But, come what may, I do adore thee so That danger shall seem sport, and I will go.
Goodbye!: But, whatever you want, I love you so much that danger will seem sporty, and I’ll go.

Anon!: I say I love thee more than he can do.
Goodbye!: I say I love you more than he can do.

Anon!: Fair lady, do you think you have fools in hand?
Goodbye!: Do you think you’re a fool?

Anon!: Some of them will fall tomorrow, I hope.
Goodbye!: Some of them will fall tomorrow, I hope.

Anon!: This blue-eyed hag was hither brought with child And here was left by th' sailors.
Goodbye!: This blue-eyed hag was brought here with a child and left here by the sailors.

Anon!: His life was gentle, and the elements So mixed in him that Nature might stand up And say to all the world, “This was a man.” According to his virtue let us use him, With all respect and rites of burial.
Goodbye!: His life was gentle, and the elements were so mixed in him that Nature could stand up and say to the world, “This was a man.” According to his virtue, let’s use him with all respect and rites of

Anon!: Oh, I have suffered With those that I saw suffer.
Goodbye!: Oh, I’ve suffered with those who I saw suffer.

Anon!: O dear son Edgar, The food of thy abusèd father’s wrath, Might I but live to see thee in my touch, I’d say I had eyes again!
Goodbye!: Oh, son Edgar, I’d say I had eyes again.

Anon!: Take heed you fall not.
Goodbye!: Be careful not to fall.

Anon!: Will not the ladies be afeard of the lion?
Goodbye!: Willn’t the ladies be afealed by the lion?

Anon!: Well demanded, wench.
Goodbye!: Well demanded, wench.

Anon!: Say you have wronged her, sir.
Goodbye!: Say you’ve wronged her, sir.

Anon!: By my troth, I speak my thought.
Goodbye!: I swear by my lord, I’m talking about my thoughts.

Anon!: How canst thou urge God’s dreadful law to us When thou hast broke it in such dear degree?
Goodbye!: How can you tell us to obey God’s dreadful law when you’ve broken it in such a high fashion?

Anon!: So shall he waste his means, weary his soldiers, Doing himself offense, whilst we, lying still, Are full of rest, defense, and nimbleness.
Goodbye!: He’ll waste his money, weary his soldiers, and punish himself while we’re still nimble and reliant.

Anon!: Is in his retirement marvelous distempered.
Goodbye!: He’s in his retirement and is a wonderful man.

Anon!: I see that thou art poor.
Goodbye!: I see that you’re poor.

Anon!: Tell me, daughter Juliet, How stands your disposition to be married?
Goodbye!: Tell me, daughter Juliet, how are you going to be married?

Anon!: Enough to purchase what you have made known.
Goodbye!: Enough to buy what you’ve made known.

Anon!: I pray thee, bear my former answer back.
Goodbye!: Please, bring my previous answer back.

Anon!: Why have you left the chamber?
Goodbye!: Why have you left the room?

Anon!: Ay, madam, well, for I was bred and born Not three hours' travel from this very place.
Goodbye!: Yes, madam, well, because I was born and raised not three hours from here.

Anon!: About it!
Goodbye!: About it!

Anon!: I think the duke will not be spoke withal.
Goodbye!: I don’t think the duke will be spoken with.

Anon!: There was never counterfeit of passion came so near the life of passion as she discovers it.
Goodbye!: There was never a counterfeit of passion that came near the life of passion as she discovers it.

Anon!: Anon!
Goodbye!: Goodbye!

Anon!: Most miserable hour that e'er time saw In lasting labor of his pilgrimage.
Goodbye!: It was the most miserable hour of his life that he had ever seen in his pilgrimage.

Anon!: Things growing are not ripe until their season.
Goodbye!: Things aren’t ready until the end of the season.

Anon!: Ariel, thy charge Exactly is performed.
Goodbye!: Ariel, your job is exactly what you’re doing.

Anon!: I am a gentleman of a company.
Goodbye!: I’m a gentleman of a company.

Anon!: To suckle fools and chronicle small beer.
Goodbye!: To suckle fools and chronicle small beer.

Anon!: A false conclusion.
Goodbye!: A false conclusion.

Anon!: Patience, I say.
Goodbye!: Be patient, I say.

Anon!: Well then, take a good heart and counterfeit to be a man.
Goodbye!: Well then, take a good heart and be fooled to be a man.

Anon!: What say you?
Goodbye!: What do you say?

Anon!: I’ll tell thee what, Prince: a college of wit-crackers cannot flout me out of my humor.
Goodbye!: I’ll tell you what, Prince: a college of witcrackers can’t fool me out of my humor.

Anon!: Your Majesty, hear now, saving your Majesty’s manhood, what an arrant, rascally, beggarly, lousy knave it is.
Goodbye!: Your Majesty, listen now, saving your Majesty’s life, what an arrant, rascally, beggarly, lousy king it is.

Anon!: Still you keep o' the windy side of the law.
Goodbye!: You’re still on the windy side of the law.

Anon!: Decius, well urged.
Goodbye!: Decius, well urged.

Anon!: I do not think thou canst, for then thou wast not Out three years old.
Goodbye!: I don’t think you can, because you were not three years old.

Anon!: If it be not to come, it will be now.
Goodbye!: If it doesn’t come, it will come now.

Anon!: You are a saucy boy.
Goodbye!: You’re a savage boy.

Anon!: What, are you mad that you do reason so?
Goodbye!: Are you crazy about why you do so?

Anon!: And when she weeps, weeps every little flower, Lamenting some enforcèd chastity.
Goodbye!: And when she weeps, she weeps every little flower, blaming some chastity.

Anon!: The flat transgression of a schoolboy who, being overjoyed with finding a birds' nest, shows it his companion, and he steals it.
Goodbye!: The flat transgression of a schoolboy who, being overjoyed with finding a bird nest, shows it to his companion, and he steals it.

Anon!: A carrion death, within whose empty eye There is a written scroll.
Goodbye!: A carrion death, within which there’s a written scroll.

Anon!: This is the latest parle we will admit.
Goodbye!: This is the latest talk we’ll admit.

Anon!: Tis here.
Goodbye!: It’s here.

Anon!: Rarely, rarely.
Goodbye!: Rarely, rarely.

Anon!: When shall he come?
Goodbye!: When will he come?

Anon!: And Caesar shall go forth.
Goodbye!: And Caesar will go out.

Anon!: He is hid at Lawrence' cell.
Goodbye!: He’s hid in Lawrence’s cell.

Anon!: Whither are they vanished?
Goodbye!: Where are they going?

Anon!: With the same 'havior that your passion bears Goes on my master’s grief.
Goodbye!: I’m a master, and you’re a master.

Anon!: Come.
Goodbye!: Come on.

Anon!: Away, and mock the time with fairest show.
Goodbye!: Go away, and mock the time with the fairest show.

Anon!: And earthly power doth then show likest God’s When mercy seasons justice.
Goodbye!: And earthly power is like God’s grace when mercy seasons justice.

Anon!: Whoever bound him, I will loose his bonds And gain a husband by his liberty.— Speak, old Egeon, if thou be’st the man That hadst a wife once called Emilia, That bore thee at a burden two fair sons.
Goodbye!: If you’re the man who had a wife called Emilia once, who bore you two fair sons.

Anon!: Stay the friar too.
Goodbye!: Stay the friar too.

Anon!: No, fair princess.
Goodbye!: No, fair princess.

Anon!: Hark you, sir.
Goodbye!: Listen, sir.

Anon!: Mass, and my elbow itched, I thought there would a scab follow.
Goodbye!: I thought I’d follow a scab, and my elbow slid.

Anon!: Convey her to my tent.
Goodbye!: Go get her to my tent.

Anon!: Have I not reason, beldams as you are?
Goodbye!: Don’t I have any reason to be angry, beldams like you are?

Anon!: Within this half hour will he be asleep.
Goodbye!: Within a half hour he’ll be asleep.

Anon!: Oh, strange!
Goodbye!: Oh, strange!

Anon!: He’s speaking now, Or murmuring “Where’s my serpent of old Nile?” For so he calls me.
Goodbye!: He’s talking now, or murmuring, “Where’s my serpent from the old Nile?” Because he’s calling me.

Anon!: Take you assurance of her cum privilegio ad imprimendum solum.
Goodbye!: Take care of her pranks and pranks.

Anon!: And time is at his period.
Goodbye!: And time is at his peak.

Anon!: Oh, that she knew she were!
Goodbye!: Oh, she knew she were!

Anon!: Ha!
Goodbye!: Ha!

Anon!: Why, he’s a devil, a devil, a very fiend.
Goodbye!: Why, he’s a devil, a devil, a very fiend.

Anon!: Go, get thee gone, I say.
Goodbye!: Go, get out of here, I say.

Anon!: It is the prince of palfreys.
Goodbye!: It’s the prince of palfreys.

Anon!: Tomorrow is the day.
Goodbye!: Tomorrow is the day.

Anon!: Look what I have.
Goodbye!: Look what I have.

Anon!: So said, so done, is well.
Goodbye!: That’s right, done.

Anon!: And shall, sir.
Goodbye!: And will, sir.

Anon!: I met this man with my glove in his cap, and I have been as good as my word.
Goodbye!: I met this man with my glove in his cap, and I’ve been as good as my word.

Anon!: Then I will come to my mother by and by.
Goodbye!: Then I’ll come to my mother by and by.

Anon!: Upon his brow shame is ashamed to sit, For ’tis a throne where honor may be crowned.
Goodbye!: He’s ashamed to sit on his forehead, because it’s a throne where honor can be crowned.

Anon!: But are they, Ariel, safe?
Goodbye!: But are they safe, Ariel?

Anon!: Help, help, help!
Goodbye!: Help, help, help!

Anon!: Sooth, madam, I hear nothing.
Goodbye!: I don’t hear anything, madam.

Anon!: Yea, and the best person too.
Goodbye!: Yes, and the best person too.

Anon!: O Scotland, Scotland!
Goodbye!: Oh Scotland, Scotland!

Anon!: Nay, let’s follow him.
Goodbye!: No, let’s follow him.

Anon!: Excellent, i' faith, of the chameleon’s dish.
Goodbye!: I’m sure it’s excellent for the chameleon’s dish.

Anon!: I’ll have the work ta'en out And give ’t Iago.
Goodbye!: I’ll get the work done and give it to Iago.

Anon!: The fiend is strong within him.
Goodbye!: The fiend is strong inside him.

Anon!: They are incensed.
Goodbye!: They’re incensed.

Anon!: Nay, like enough, for I stay dinner there.
Goodbye!: No, I’m not sure, because I’m staying there for dinner.

Anon!: I forget, But these sweet thoughts do even refresh my labors, Most busiest when I do it.
Goodbye!: I forget, but these sweet thoughts refresh my work, most busy when I do it.

Anon!: The ground is bloody.—Search about the churchyard.
Goodbye!: The ground is bloody.—Search about the churchyard.

Anon!: I must stay with the lackeys with the luggage of our camp.
Goodbye!: I have to stay with the kings and carry the luggage of our camp.

Anon!: Tell Antony Brutus is ta'en.
Goodbye!: Tell Antony Brutus is a king.

Anon!: I did not think he had been acquainted with her.
Goodbye!: I didn’t think he knew her.

Anon!: Your brother—no, no brother—yet the son— Yet not the son, I will not call him son— Of him I was about to call his father Hath heard your praises, and this night he means To burn the lodging where you use to lie, And you within it.
Goodbye!: Your brother—no brother—yet the son—But not the son, I won’t call him son—I was about to call his father, and this night he’s going to burn the lodging where you use

Anon!: My ever-gentle cousin, welcome hither.
Goodbye!: My gentle cousin, welcome here.

Anon!: I and my bosom must debate awhile, And then I would no other company.
Goodbye!: I and my wife must debate for a while, and then I wouldn’t have any other company.

Anon!: What will become of this?
Goodbye!: What will happen from this?

Anon!: Twill be a storm.
Goodbye!: It’ll be a storm.

Anon!: And therefore as a stranger give it welcome.
Goodbye!: So give it a welcome as a stranger.

Anon!: What do you mean?
Goodbye!: What do you mean?

Anon!: Good Master Fabian, grant me another request.
Goodbye!: Good Master Fabian, please give me another request.

Anon!: And what of him, Tranio?
Goodbye!: And what about him, Tranio?

Anon!: We’ll to th’ river.
Goodbye!: We’ll go to the river.

Anon!: Do as I bid thee.
Goodbye!: Do what I told you.

Anon!: Art thou so hasty?
Goodbye!: Are you so hurrying?

Anon!: What say the augurers?
Goodbye!: What do the snoring men say?

Anon!: I know him well.
Goodbye!: I know him well.

Anon!: Experience, manhood, honor, ne’er before Did violate so itself.
Goodbye!: Experience, manhood, honor, never before did it.

Anon!: I would have her learn, my fair cousin, how perfectly I love her, and that is good English.
Goodbye!: I want her to learn how much I love her, my fair cousin, and that’s good English.

Anon!: A contract of true love to celebrate, And some donation freely to estate On the blessed lovers.
Goodbye!: A contract of true love to celebrate, and some generous donation to the estate of the blessed lovers.

Anon!: Adieu, adieu, adieu.
Goodbye!: Adieu, adieu, adieu.

Anon!: Avaunt!
Goodbye!: Avail!

Anon!: But for your private satisfaction, Because I love you, I will let you know.
Goodbye!: But for your private satisfaction, because I love you, I’ll tell you.

Anon!: So do I, my lord.
Goodbye!: I do, my lord.

Anon!: Come, death, and welcome!
Goodbye!: Come, death, and welcome!

Anon!: Hark you, sir.
Goodbye!: Listen, sir.

Anon!: Go to, mum, you are he.
Goodbye!: Go to him, mum.

Anon!: Art thou his friend?
Goodbye!: Are you his friend?

Anon!: The king, the king’s to blame.
Goodbye!: The king, the king’s to blame.

Anon!: But did you think the Prince would have served you thus?
Goodbye!: But did you think the Prince would have served you like that?

Anon!: I say, there is no darkness but ignorance, in which thou art more puzzled than the Egyptians in their fog.
Goodbye!: I say, there’s no darkness except ignorance, in which you’re more puzzled than the Egyptians in their fog.

Anon!: Thou art as wise as thou art beautiful.
Goodbye!: You’re as wise as you are beautiful.

Anon!: And yet she’ll kneel and pray, I have seen her do ’t.
Goodbye!: And yet she’ll kneel and pray, I’ve seen her do it.

Anon!: Who’s gone this morning?
Goodbye!: Who’s gone this morning?

Anon!: I have made it for you.
Goodbye!: I’ve made it for you.

Anon!: There is a kind of merry war betwixt Signor Benedick and her.
Goodbye!: There’s a kind of merry war between Signor Benedick and her.

Anon!: As great to me as late.
Goodbye!: As good to me as late.

Anon!: News, madam.
Goodbye!: News, madam.

Anon!: Signor Benedick!
Goodbye!: Signor Benedick!

Anon!: I’ll be with thee betimes.
Goodbye!: I’ll be with you soon.

Anon!: Fie, how impatience loureth in your face.
Goodbye!: I’m sorry, how impatience you feel.

Anon!: How does thy honor?
Goodbye!: How is your honor?

Anon!: Instance, briefly.
Goodbye!: Let’s talk briefly.

Anon!: From forth the fatal loins of these two foes A pair of star-crossed lovers take their life, Whose misadventured piteous overthrows Doth with their death bury their parents' strife.
Goodbye!: Then a pair of star-crossed lovers take their lives from the fare of these two foes.

Anon!: Casca, you are the first that rears your hand.
Goodbye!: Casca, you’re the first person to raise your hand.

Anon!: Doth not Brutus bootless kneel?
Goodbye!: Don’t Brutus kneel without a boot?

Anon!: That may be, sir, when I may be a wife.
Goodbye!: That may be true, sir, when I’m a wife.

Anon!: O dear discretion, how his words are suited!
Goodbye!: Oh, what a good choice he’s doing!

Anon!: When was it she last walked?
Goodbye!: When was she last walking?

Anon!: Sure it is hers.
Goodbye!: It’s hers.

Anon!: All there is thine.
Goodbye!: You’re all right.

Anon!: Jove bless thee, master Parson.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, master Parson.

Anon!: Doubtful it stood, As two spent swimmers that do cling together And choke their art.
Goodbye!: It’s not true, as two spent swimmers clinging together and choking their art.

Anon!: Sir, his chests and treasure He has not with him.
Goodbye!: Sir, his chests and treasure aren’t with him.

Anon!: You are very welcome, sir.
Goodbye!: You are very welcome, sir.

Anon!: Canst thou bring me to th' party?
Goodbye!: Can you bring me to the party?

Anon!: Are there no stones in heaven But what serve for the thunder?—Precious villain!
Goodbye!: Aren’t there any stones in heaven but what is the thunder?—Precious villain!

Anon!: Why ever wast thou lovely in my eyes?
Goodbye!: Why were you always lovely in my eyes?

Anon!: Thou dost conspire against thy friend, Iago, If thou but think’st him wronged and mak’st his ear A stranger to thy thoughts.
Goodbye!: You conspire against your friend, Iago, if you only think he’s wronged and scolded his ear with your thoughts.

Anon!: Within our files there are, Of those that served Mark Antony but late, Enough to fetch him in.
Goodbye!: We have a lot of people in our archives, including those who served Mark Antony but were late, and enough to get him in.

Anon!: Though for myself alone I would not be ambitious in my wish To wish myself much better, yet for you I would be trebled twenty times myself— A thousand times more fair, ten thousand times more rich— That only to stand high in your account I might in virtue, beauties, livings, friends Exceed account.
Goodbye!: I wish I could be much better for myself alone, but I wish I could be trebled twenty times myself—a thousand times more fair, ten thousand times richer—that only to stand high in your account I could be

Anon!: My falcon now is sharp and passing empty, And, till she stoop, she must not be full-gorged, For then she never looks upon her lure.
Goodbye!: My falcon is now sharp and empty, and until she stoops, she won’t be full-gorged, because she never looks at her lure.

Anon!: If the balance of our lives had not one scale of reason to poise another of sensuality, the blood and baseness of our natures would conduct us to most prepost'rous conclusions.
Goodbye!: If we had no reason to be able to make a different sense of our lives, we would have to make our own conclusions.

Anon!: He hath been in unusual pleasure, and Sent forth great largess to your offices.
Goodbye!: He’s been a pleasure to work with you, and he’s sent a great largess to your offices.

Anon!: And when was he wont to wash his face?
Goodbye!: And when did he want to wash his face?

Anon!: Nor I, my lord.
Goodbye!: I’m not, my lord.

Anon!: Off with his son George’s head!
Goodbye!: Off with his son George’s head!

Anon!: You kiss by th' book.
Goodbye!: You kiss by the book.

Anon!: Approach thou like the rugged Russian bear, The armed rhinoceros, or th' Hyrcan tiger; Take any shape but that, and my firm nerves Shall never tremble.
Goodbye!: Take any shape except that, and my sane nerves won’t tremble.

Anon!: I remember thine eyes well enough.
Goodbye!: I remember your eyes well enough.

Anon!: There is a litter ready.
Goodbye!: There’s a litter ready.

Anon!: Romeo, away, be gone!
Goodbye!: Romeo, go away!

Anon!: Here comes the fool, i' faith.
Goodbye!: Here comes the fool, I’m sure.

Anon!: I think he will carry this island home in his pocket and give it his son for an apple.
Goodbye!: I think he’ll carry this island home in his pocket and give it to his son for an apple.

Anon!: At last, a little shaking of mine arm And thrice his head thus waving up and down, He raised a sigh so piteous and profound As it did seem to shatter all his bulk And end his being.
Goodbye!: I shook my arm with a little shaking and his head waving so far up and down, he raised a sigh so pitiful and profound that it seemed to shatter his entire body and end his being

Anon!: Oh, now, who will behold The royal captain of this ruined band
Goodbye!: Oh, now, who will see the royal captain of this ruined band

Anon!: Nothing that can be can come between me and the full prospect of my hopes.
Goodbye!: Nothing can be done between me and the full potential of my hopes.

Anon!: The king, sir— Ay, sir, what of him?
Goodbye!: The king, sir— Yes, sir, what about him?

Anon!: Why, as I told thee, ’tis a custom with him, I' th' afternoon to sleep.
Goodbye!: I told you that he’s a custom to sleep in the afternoon.

Anon!: And thought they Margaret was Hero?
Goodbye!: And they thought Margaret was Hero?

Anon!: Come, is the bride ready to go to church?
Goodbye!: Come on, is the bride ready to go to church?

Anon!: Thy drugs are quick.
Goodbye!: Your drugs are quick.

Anon!: Why, to put ’s head in—not to give it away to his daughters and leave his horns without a case.
Goodbye!: Why, put your head in—not give it away to his daughters and leave his horns without a case.

Anon!: I know not how to pray your patience, Yet I must speak.
Goodbye!: I don’t know how to pray for your patience, but I have to speak.

Anon!: Be not so.
Goodbye!: Don’t be so.

Anon!: The April’s in her eyes; it is love’s spring, And these the showers to bring it on.
Goodbye!: April is in her eyes, it’s love’s spring, and these showers are the way to bring it on.

Anon!: Of princes in this number And nobles bearing banners, there lie dead One hundred twenty-six.
Goodbye!: There are twenty-six princes in this number and nobles with banners.

Anon!: That’s sides and heart.
Goodbye!: That’s sides and heart.

Anon!: Thou torturest me, Tubal.
Goodbye!: You torture me, Tubal.

Anon!: What might you think?
Goodbye!: What do you think?

Anon!: Ay, sir.
Goodbye!: Yes, sir.

Anon!: The power of Caesar, and His power unto Octavia.
Goodbye!: The power of Caesar and his power to Octavia.

Anon!: Good fool, some ink, paper, and light, and convey what I will set down to my lady.
Goodbye!: Good fool, some ink, paper, and light, and tell my lady what I’ll put down.

Anon!: Stay not, be gone.
Goodbye!: Don’t stay, go away.

Anon!: Macbeth!— Had I three ears, I’d hear thee.
Goodbye!: Macbeth!—If I had three ears, I’d hear you.

Anon!: My Lord of Oxford, you, Sir William Brandon, And you, Sir Walter Herbert, stay with me.
Goodbye!: My Lord of Oxford, you, Sir William Brandon, and you, Sir Walter Herbert, stay with me.

Anon!: By any other house or person?
Goodbye!: By any other house or person?

Anon!: Yes, by Saint Anne, and ginger shall be hot i' the mouth too.
Goodbye!: Yes, by Saint Anne, and ginger will be hot in the mouth too.

Anon!: Music, ho!
Goodbye!: Music!

Anon!: Methinks you are my glass, and not my brother: I see by you I am a sweet-faced youth.
Goodbye!: I think you’re my glass, not my brother.

Anon!: She is stirring, sir.
Goodbye!: She’s stirring, sir.

Anon!: Braved in mine own house with a skein of thread?
Goodbye!: I’ve been robbed in my own house with a skein of thread?

Anon!: Back you shall not to the house, unless you undertake that with me which with as much safety you might answer him.
Goodbye!: You can’t go back to the house unless you’re able to do something with me, which you can do with as much security as you can.

Anon!: An honest tale speeds best being plainly told.
