Goodbye!: It’s best to tell a truth.

Anon!: What’s the matter, lieutenant?
Goodbye!: What’s the matter, lieutenant?

Anon!: Therefore, great King, We yield our town and lives to thy soft mercy.
Goodbye!: So, great King, we give our town and lives to your mercy.

Anon!: Even such delight Among fresh fennel buds shall you this night Inherit at my house.
Goodbye!: You’ll be here tonight at my house.

Anon!: Arms, take your last embrace.
Goodbye!: Arms, take your last embrace.

Anon!: Marry, God forbid!
Goodbye!: God forbid!

Anon!: I go; and towards three or four o'clock Look for the news that the Guildhall affords.
Goodbye!: I’ll go, and at three or four o'clock look for the news that the Guildhall offers.

Anon!: O, let me kiss that hand!
Goodbye!: Oh, let me kiss that hand!

Anon!: We have none such, sir.
Goodbye!: We don’t have any such thing, sir.

Anon!: You shall hear more by midnight.
Goodbye!: You’ll hear more by midnight.

Anon!: Urge me no more, I shall forget myself.
Goodbye!: Don’t ask me to do anything else, I’ll forget myself.

Anon!: What dogs are these!
Goodbye!: What dogs are these!

Anon!: Will you walk, sir?—O Desdemona— My lord?
Goodbye!: Will you walk, sir?—O Desdemona— My lord?

Anon!: O serpent heart hid with a flowering face!
Goodbye!: Oh, serpent heart hid with a flowering face!

Anon!: Stand, an you be a man.
Goodbye!: Stand up, if you’re a man.

Anon!: Die for adultery?
Goodbye!: Die for adultery?

Anon!: I might call him A thing divine, for nothing natural I ever saw so noble.
Goodbye!: I could call him a divine man, because nothing natural I ever saw so noble.

Anon!: Gentlewoman, my lady calls.
Goodbye!: Gentlewoman, my lady calls me.

Anon!: Well, I’ll be revenged as I may.
Goodbye!: Well, I’ll be revenged as I can.

Anon!: Pass.
Goodbye!: Pass.

Anon!: You are looked for and called for, asked for and sought for, in the great chamber.
Goodbye!: You’re in the great chamber looking for and called for, asked and sought for.

Anon!: God give me joy to wear it, for my heart is exceeding heavy.
Goodbye!: God give me joy in wearing it, because my heart is exceedingly heavy.

Anon!: Ay, lord.
Goodbye!: Yes, lord.

Anon!: The old man and his people Cannot be well bestowed.
Goodbye!: The old man and his people can’t be well rewarded.

Anon!: Tis a fair young man, and well attended.
Goodbye!: He’s a good young man, and he’s well attended.

Anon!: And too soon marred are those so early made.
Goodbye!: And too soon are those who made it so early.

Anon!: I charge you, get you home.
Goodbye!: I’ll get you home.

Anon!: But who was this?
Goodbye!: But who was this?

Anon!: My master hath appointed me to go to Saint Luke’s to bid the priest be ready to come against you come with your appendix.
Goodbye!: My master has appointed me to go to Saint Luke’s to ask the priest to come against you with your appendix.

Anon!: That is the way to make her scorn you still.
Goodbye!: That’s the way to make her slander you.

Anon!: Why then, good night indeed.
Goodbye!: Well then, good night.

Anon!: Now, forward with your tale.—Prithee, stand farther off.
Goodbye!: Now, get ahead of your story.—Prince, stand farther away.

Anon!: Madam, I am here.
Goodbye!: Madam, I’m here.

Anon!: Came he not home tonight?
Goodbye!: Didn’t he come home tonight?

Anon!: Ay me, it is my husband.
Goodbye!: Yes, it’s my husband.

Anon!: I pray, weep not.
Goodbye!: Please don’t cry.

Anon!: I am Grumio’s pledge.
Goodbye!: I’m Grumio’s pledge.

Anon!: What likelihood of his amendment, lords?
Goodbye!: What is his amendment likely, lords?

Anon!: I protest unto thee— Good heart, and i' faith, I will tell her as much.
Goodbye!: I’m telling her that I’m good, and I’m sure she’ll tell her as much.

Anon!: You have an excellent armor, but let my horse have his due.
Goodbye!: You have an excellent armor, but let my horse have his due.

Anon!: And we will hear it.
Goodbye!: And we’ll hear it.

Anon!: Oh, ’tis foul in her.
Goodbye!: Oh, it’s foul in her.

Anon!: I remember him well, and I remember him worthy of thy praise.
Goodbye!: I remember him well, and I remember him worthy of your praise.

Anon!: They lack retention.
Goodbye!: They’re not able to keep their spirits.

Anon!: Not I.
Goodbye!: Not me.

Anon!: Even as a flatt'ring dream or worthless fancy.
Goodbye!: It’s just like a flattened dream or a useless fancy.

Anon!: Come, sir, to dinner.—Dromio, keep the gate.
Goodbye!: Come to dinner, sir.—Dromio, keep the gate.

Anon!: Hence, Mardian, And bring me how he takes my death.
Goodbye!: Go, Mardian, and bring me the way he takes my death.

Anon!: And let my liver rather heat with wine Than my heart cool with mortifying groans.
Goodbye!: And let my liver heat with wine rather than my heart cool with mortifying groans.

Anon!: Then how can it be said I am alone When all the world is here to look on me?
Goodbye!: Then how can I say I’m alone when the whole world is here to look at me?

Anon!: Look to ’t, I charge you.
Goodbye!: Look at it, I’m telling you.

Anon!: But let them measure us by what they will.
Goodbye!: But let them measure us by what they want.

Anon!: You could never do him so ill-well unless you were the very man.
Goodbye!: You could never do him so badly if you were the man you were.

Anon!: But nature should bring forth Of its own kind all foison, all abundance, To feed my innocent people.
Goodbye!: But nature should bring forth its own kind, all abundance, to feed my innocent people.

Anon!: Stephano!
Goodbye!: Stephano!

Anon!: Lurk, lurk.
Goodbye!: Lurk, lurk.

Anon!: Love me or love me not, I like the cap, And it I will have, or I will have none.
Goodbye!: I’ll have it, or I’ll have none.

Anon!: Caesar, my lord.
Goodbye!: Caesar, my lord.

Anon!: And I beseech you come again tomorrow.
Goodbye!: And I beg you to come back tomorrow.

Anon!: I must tell you then.
Goodbye!: I’ll tell you then.

Anon!: Sola, sola!
Goodbye!: Oh, yes!

Anon!: Is Claudio thine enemy?
Goodbye!: Is Claudio your enemy?

Anon!: Is now become a god, and Cassius is A wretched creature and must bend his body If Caesar carelessly but nod on him.
Goodbye!: It’s become a god, and Cassius is a wretched creature and must bend his body if Caesar scolded him.

Anon!: Farewell, great chief.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, great chief.

Anon!: Call you this railing?
Goodbye!: Do you call this a slur?

Anon!: And if your love Can labor ought in sad invention, Hang her an epitaph upon her tomb And sing it to her bones.
Goodbye!: And if your love can work in a sad way, hang her an epitaph on her tomb and sing it to her bones.

Anon!: Faith, like enough.
Goodbye!: Yes, that’s enough.

Anon!: Very brief, and to exceeding good sense—less.
Goodbye!: Very brief, and to exceeding good sense—less.

Anon!: This only is the witchcraft I have used.
Goodbye!: This is only the witchcraft I’ve used.

Anon!: Shall I say to you, “Let them be free!
Goodbye!: Shall I say to you, “Let them be free!

Anon!: How is it with her?
Goodbye!: How is she?

Anon!: We must not.
Goodbye!: We shouldn’t.

Anon!: I would I were invisible, to catch the strong fellow by the leg.
Goodbye!: I wish I were invisible, to catch the strong fellow by the leg.

Anon!: Give me my sin again.
Goodbye!: Give me my sin back.

Anon!: The king has killed his heart.
Goodbye!: The king has killed his heart.

Anon!: They did so, to th' amazement of mine eyes That looked upon ’t.
Goodbye!: They did so, to amaze me how I looked at it.

Anon!: Do you know me, sir?
Goodbye!: Do you know me, sir?

Anon!: Think what thou wilt, I am thy lover’s grace.
Goodbye!: Think what you want, I’m your lover’s grace.

Anon!: Saw you him today?
Goodbye!: Did you see him today?

Anon!: If she do, he’ll smile and take ’t for a great favor.
Goodbye!: If she does, he’ll smile and take it for a great favor.

Anon!: I know it pleaseth neither of us well.
Goodbye!: I know it doesn’t please any of us.

Anon!: Go with me to the duchess.
Goodbye!: Go with me to the duchess.

Anon!: Shake!” quoth the dovehouse.
Goodbye!: Shake!” quoth the dovehouse.

Anon!: Thou flea, thou nit, thou winter cricket thou!
Goodbye!: You flea, you nit, you winter cricket!

Anon!: Ay, sir, the sergeant of the band; he that brings any man to answer it that breaks his band; one that thinks a man always going to bed and says “God give you good rest.”  Well, sir, there rest in your foolery.
Goodbye!: Yes, sir, the sergeant of the band; the one who brings any man to answer the question that breaks his band; the one who thinks a man always goes to bed and says, “God give you good

Anon!: The Prince will doom thee death If thou art taken.
Goodbye!: The Prince will punish you for death if you’re taken.

Anon!: The cords That Romeo bid thee fetch?
Goodbye!: The cords Romeo told you to get?

Anon!: I will be heard.
Goodbye!: I’ll be heard.

Anon!: For, I am sure, you have your hands full all In this so sudden business.
Goodbye!: I’m sure you’re all in the right mood for this sudden business.

Anon!: Mark Antony I served, who best was worthy Best to be served.
Goodbye!: I served Mark Antony, who was the best person to be served.

Anon!: My worthy lord, Your noble friends do lack you.
Goodbye!: My noble lord, your noble friends don’t have you.

Anon!: Why then, your ambition makes it one.
Goodbye!: Well then, your ambition makes it one of them.

Anon!: You look wearily.
Goodbye!: You look tired.

Anon!: To no more Will I give place or notice.
Goodbye!: I won’t give any more notice or place.

Anon!: Pray God, I say, I prove a needless coward!
Goodbye!: Please, I say, I’m a useless coward!

Anon!: Marry, heaven forbid!
Goodbye!: God forbid!

Anon!: Some light-foot friend post to the duke of Norfolk— Ratcliffe, thyself, or Catesby.
Goodbye!: Some light-foot friend will go to the duke of Norfolk— Ratcliffe, yourself, or Catesby.

Anon!: Are we all met?
Goodbye!: Are we all here?

Anon!: Have we devils here?
Goodbye!: Are we devils here?

Anon!: Heaven and earth!
Goodbye!: Heaven and earth!

Anon!: Is ’t possible?
Goodbye!: Is it possible?

Anon!: As I have life and honor, there shall he sit till noon.
Goodbye!: As long as I have life and honor, he’ll sit there until noon.

Anon!: As you shall prove us, praise us.
Goodbye!: As you’ll tell us, praise us.

Anon!: Nay, but Beatrice— Sweet Hero, she is wronged, she is slandered, she is undone.
Goodbye!: No, but Beatrice— Sweet Hero, she’s wronged, she’s slandered, and she’s gone.

Anon!: What, sir, not yet at rest?
Goodbye!: What, sir, are you still sleeping?

Anon!: It is well.
Goodbye!: It’s good.

Anon!: Not to kill him, having a warrant, but to be damned for killing him, from the which no warrant can defend me.
Goodbye!: Not to kill him, but to be damned for killing him, from which no warrant can defend me.

Anon!: But Antonio is certainly undone.
Goodbye!: But Antonio has certainly been wiped out.

Anon!: Then must thou needs find out new heaven, new earth.
Goodbye!: Then you have to find out new heaven, new earth.

Anon!: Hence, saucy eunuch!
Goodbye!: So, sane eunuch!

Anon!: Who cannot want the thought how monstrous It was for Malcolm and for Donalbain To kill their gracious father?
Goodbye!: Who can’t imagine how monstrous it was for Malcolm and Donalbain to kill their gracious father?

Anon!: Ceres, most bounteous lady, thy rich leas Of wheat, rye, barley, vetches, oats, and peas; Thy turfy mountains, where live nibbling sheep, And flat meads thatched with stover, them to keep; Thy banks with pionèd and twillèd brims,
Goodbye!: You’re a sane, most blustery lady, your rich leas of wheat, rye, barley, vetches, oats, and peas; your turfy mountains

Anon!: Now Margaret’s curse is fall'n upon our heads, When she exclaimed on Hastings, you, and I, For standing by when Richard stabbed her son.
Goodbye!: Now Margaret’s curse has fallen on our heads when she exclaimed on Hastings, you, and I, for standing by when Richard stabbed her son.

Anon!: No more but so?
Goodbye!: No more than that?

Anon!: Nay, come, I pray you, sir, give me the chain.
Goodbye!: No, come, please, sir, give me the necklace.

Anon!: But there’s a saying very old and true: “If that you will France win, Then with Scotland first begin.” For once the eagle England being in prey, To her unguarded nest the weasel Scot Comes sneaking and so sucks her princely eggs, Playing the mouse in absence of the cat, To ’tame and havoc more than she can eat.
Goodbye!: But there’s a saying very old and true: “If you win France, then with Scotland first begin.” For once the eagle England being in prey, the weasel Scot comes sneaking and

Anon!: What are thy comings in?
Goodbye!: What are your comings?

Anon!: Where is he?
Goodbye!: Where is he?

Anon!: Come, uncle Exeter, Go you and enter Harfleur.
Goodbye!: Come, uncle Exeter, go and enter Harfleur.

Anon!: That handkerchief thou speak’st of I found by fortune and did give my husband.
Goodbye!: I found that handkerchief by fortune and gave my husband that handkerchief.

Anon!: Mark Antony, here, take you Caesar’s body.
Goodbye!: Mark Antony, take Caesar’s body here.

Anon!: And yonder, Caesar.
Goodbye!: And then, Caesar.

Anon!: The orchard walls are high and hard to climb, And the place death, considering who thou art, If any of my kinsmen find thee here.
Goodbye!: The orchard walls are high and hard to climb, and death is the place, considering who you are, if any of my relatives find you here.

Anon!: This will so fright them both that they will kill one another by the look, like cockatrices.
Goodbye!: This will scare them both so that they’ll kill each other by looking at them like cockatrices.

Anon!: I warrant you, madam.
Goodbye!: I’ll tell you, madam.

Anon!: Most wonderful!
Goodbye!: What a wonderful thing!

Anon!: If all else fail, myself have power to die.
Goodbye!: If everything else fails, I’ll have the power to die.

Anon!: Marry, thou dost wrong me, thou dissembler, thou.
Goodbye!: You’re wrong, you dissembler, you.

Anon!: Let us take the law of our sides.
Goodbye!: Let’s take the law of our sides.

Anon!: But one, poor one, one poor and loving child, But one thing to rejoice and solace in, And cruel death hath catched it from my sight!
Goodbye!: But one, one poor one, one poor and loving child, but one thing to rejoice and solace in, and cruel death has catched it out of my sight!

Anon!: So full of shapes is fancy That it alone is high fantastical.
Goodbye!: It’s so full of shapes that it’s fantastical.

Anon!: Say, have I thy consent that they shall die?
Goodbye!: Do you agree that they will die?

Anon!: Hie you to church.
Goodbye!: Go to the church.

Anon!: Believe me, I am not.
Goodbye!: Believe me, I am not.

Anon!: I’ll read the writing.
Goodbye!: I’ll read the story.

Anon!: Now she holds me not.
Goodbye!: Now she’s not holding me.

Anon!: Here comes my lady.
Goodbye!: Here comes my lady.

Anon!: I would not change this hue Except to steal your thoughts, my gentle queen.
Goodbye!: I wouldn’t change this color except to steal your thoughts, my gentle queen.

Anon!: My news I might have told hereafter.
Goodbye!: I could have told you my news later.

Anon!: Now know you, Casca, I have moved already Some certain of the noblest-minded Romans To undergo with me an enterprise Of honorable-dangerous consequence.
Goodbye!: Now know you, Casca, I’ve already moved some of the noblest Romans to take me to a dangerous and honorable event.

Anon!: My resolution’s placed, and I have nothing Of woman in me.
Goodbye!: I’ve been told to do my job, and I have nothing of a woman in me.

Anon!: For, since the mortal and intestine jars 'Twixt thy seditious countrymen and us, It hath in solemn synods been decreed Both by the Syracusians and ourselves, To admit no traffic to our adverse towns.
Goodbye!: Since the intestines and the mortals of your countrymen and us have been thrown out of the mud, both the Syracusians and ours have decreed to admit no traffic to our towns.

Anon!: Was ever man so weary?
Goodbye!: Was a man ever so tired?

Anon!: He shall stay my leisure.
Goodbye!: He’ll stay with me.

Anon!: Dost thou call me fool, boy?
Goodbye!: Are you calling me a fool, boy?

Anon!: I do not know.
Goodbye!: I don’t know.

Anon!: How many gentlemen have you lost in this action?
Goodbye!: How many gentlemen have you lost in this action?

Anon!: I’ll catch it ere it come to ground.
Goodbye!: I’ll catch it before it comes to ground.

Anon!: No, sir, no jot.
Goodbye!: No, sir, no jot.

Anon!: A jealous hood, a jealous hood!
Goodbye!: A jealous hood, a jealous hood!

Anon!: Is all things ready for the royal time?
Goodbye!: Is everything ready for the royal time?

Anon!: Stay, Tybalt, stay!
Goodbye!: Stay, Tybalt, stay!

Anon!: Do as I bid thee, go.
Goodbye!: Go, as I told you.

Anon!: Let’s then determine with the ancient of war On our proceedings.
Goodbye!: Let’s decide on our actions with the ancient of war.

Anon!: With this, my lord, myself have naught to do.
Goodbye!: I have a lot to do with this, my lord.

Anon!: Have you any commission from your lord to negotiate with my face?
Goodbye!: Have you ever asked your lord to negotiate with me?

Anon!: He hath known you but three days, and already you are no stranger.
Goodbye!: He has only known you for three days, and you’re already no stranger.

Anon!: There are some shrewd contents in yond same paper That steals the color from Bassanio’s cheek.
Goodbye!: There are some shrewd contents in the same paper that steals the color from Bassanio’s cheek.

Anon!: Gone she is.
Goodbye!: She’s gone.

Anon!: In weightier things you’ll say a beggar nay.
Goodbye!: You’ll say a beggar nay.

Anon!: Tis two or three, my lord, that bring you word Macduff is fled to England.
Goodbye!: It’s two or three, my lord, who bring you the word Macduff has fled to England.

Anon!: O sinful thought!
Goodbye!: Oh, what a sinful thought!

Anon!: Well, well, thou hast a careful father, child.
Goodbye!: Well, well, you have a careful father, child.

Anon!: I could munch your good dry oats.
Goodbye!: I could munch your good oats.

Anon!: Come, come, you froward and unable worms!
Goodbye!: Come on, you froward and unable worms!

Anon!: I dare abide no longer.
Goodbye!: I’m not going to do anything else.

Anon!: I am a villain.
Goodbye!: I’m a villain.

Anon!: He’s coming, madam.
Goodbye!: He’s coming, madam.

Anon!: Twill bring you gain or perish on the seas.
Goodbye!: You’ll gain or perish on the seas.

Anon!: What’s the matter?
Goodbye!: What’s the matter?

Anon!: So, of his gentleness, Knowing I loved my books, he furnished me From mine own library with volumes that I prize above my dukedom.
Goodbye!: So, because he knew I loved my books, he gave me a book from my own library with volumes that I’m a big prize over my dukedom.

Anon!: Honest, ay, honest.
Goodbye!: Yes, I’m honest.

Anon!: Ill luck, ill luck?
Goodbye!: Ill luck, ill luck?

Anon!: Let her not walk i' th' sun.
Goodbye!: Don’t let her walk in the sun.

Anon!: Oh, fie upon thee, slanderer!
Goodbye!: Oh, be merciful on you, slanderer!

Anon!: And what say’st thou then to my love?
Goodbye!: And what do you say to my love?

Anon!: What is thy soul of adoration?
Goodbye!: What is your soul of adoration?

Anon!: Did you see Master Lorenzo?
Goodbye!: Did you see Master Lorenzo?

Anon!: I dare not, sir.
Goodbye!: I don’t dare, sir.

Anon!: And I am Brutus, Marcus Brutus, I!
Goodbye!: And I am Brutus, Marcus Brutus, I!

Anon!: Well then, it now appears you need my help.
Goodbye!: Well then, it seems you’re getting my help.

Anon!: Will you deny me now?
Goodbye!: Will you deny me now?

Anon!: Will you to Scone?
Goodbye!: Will you go to Scone?

Anon!: Thy husband in thy bosom there lies dead, And Paris too.
Goodbye!: Your husband is dead in your house, and Paris too.

Anon!: Therefore the winds, piping to us in vain, As in revenge, have sucked up from the sea Contagious fogs, which falling in the land Have every pelting river made so proud That they have overborne their continents.
Goodbye!: So the winds, piping to us in vain, as well as in revenge, have sucked up from the sea, and the fogs that have fallen in the land have made every river so proud that they have overborne their

Anon!: Yes, faith.
Goodbye!: Yes, yes.

Anon!: You English princes all, I do salute you.
Goodbye!: You English princes, I salute you.

Anon!: For certainly thou art so near the gulf Thou needs must be englutted.
Goodbye!: You’re certainly so near the gulf that you have to be englutted.

Anon!: Father, in.
Goodbye!: Father, come in.

Anon!: Worthy Montano, you were wont be civil.
Goodbye!: You were worthy of Montano, you were not civil.

Anon!: That shall be by and by.
Goodbye!: That’s all.

Anon!: A second Daniel!—A Daniel, Jew!
Goodbye!: A second Daniel!—A Daniel, Jew!

Anon!: Let them be hunted soundly.
Goodbye!: Let them be hunted well.

Anon!: Night’s candles are burnt out, and jocund day Stands tiptoe on the misty mountain tops.
Goodbye!: Night’s candles are burned out, and day is a slut on the misty mountain tops.

Anon!: You take your pennyworths now.
Goodbye!: You’re taking your pennyworths now.

Anon!: I have o'ershot myself to tell you of it.
Goodbye!: I’ve o'ershot myself to tell you about it.

Anon!: It is now high suppertime, and the night grows to waste.
Goodbye!: It’s now high suppertime, and the night has turned into a waste.

Anon!: Oh, well-a-day, Lady!
Goodbye!: Oh, good-bye, Lady!

Anon!: Before the eyes of both our armies here, Which should perceive nothing but love from us, Let us not wrangle.
Goodbye!: Let’s not wrangle before the eyes of both our army here, who should see nothing but love from us.

Anon!: Where is my father and my mother, Nurse?
Goodbye!: Where are my father and my mother, Nurse?

Anon!: God ye good morrow, gentlemen.
Goodbye!: Good morning, gentlemen.

Anon!: When they shall see The face of Caesar, they are vanishèd.
Goodbye!: When they see Caesar’s face, they’re gone.

Anon!: I long to know the truth hereof at large.
Goodbye!: I’m eager to know the truth about this.

Anon!: Untimely storms make men expect a dearth.
Goodbye!: Storms make men expect a dearth.

Anon!: Who could be out, being before his beloved mistress?
Goodbye!: Who could be out, being in front of his beloved mistress?

Anon!: Caesar, and that, having in Sicily Sextus Pompeius spoiled, we had not rated him His part o’ th’ isle.
Goodbye!: Caesar, and since Sextus Pompeius was spoiled in Sicily, we had not rated him his part in the island.

Anon!: But I do see you’re moved.
Goodbye!: But I see you’re moving.

Anon!: Come on.
Goodbye!: Come on.

Anon!: I am not Barbason; you cannot conjure me.
Goodbye!: I’m not a barbason, you can’t conjure me.

Anon!: And be not easily won to our requests.
Goodbye!: And don’t be fooled to our demands.

Anon!: Is not marriage honorable in a beggar?
Goodbye!: Isn’t marriage honorable in a beggar?

Anon!: O Charmian, I will never go from hence.
Goodbye!: Oh Charmian, I’ll never go out of here.

Anon!: So he served the second, and so the third.
Goodbye!: He served the second, and the third.

Anon!: O sir, you are too sure an augurer.
Goodbye!: Oh, sir, you’re too sure you’re an augurer.

Anon!: If he do fear God, he must necessarily keep peace.
Goodbye!: If he fears God, he must always keep peace.

Anon!: A pack of blessings light upon thy back, Happiness courts thee in her best array,
Goodbye!: A pack of blessings is shining on your back, and Happiness is the best thing for you.

Anon!: This note doth tell me of ten thousand French That in the field lie slain.
Goodbye!: This note tells me about ten thousand French soldiers who were killed on the field.

Anon!: As love is, my lord, before it loves.
Goodbye!: As love is, my lord, before it loves.

Anon!: While that the armèd hand doth fight abroad, Th' advisèd head defends itself at home.
Goodbye!: While the armowed hand fights abroad, the advised head defends itself at home.

Anon!: Oh, this false soul of Egypt!
Goodbye!: Oh, this false soul of Egypt!

Anon!: Not that we love words better, as you do.
Goodbye!: Not that we love words better than you do.

Anon!: Ha, ha, ha!
Goodbye!: Ha, ha, ha!

Anon!: Heaven keep the monster from Othello’s mind!
Goodbye!: Heaven keep the monster from Othello’s mind!

Anon!: Upon a lie seven times removed.—Bear your body more seeming, Audrey.—As thus, sir: I did dislike the cut of a certain courtier’s beard.
Goodbye!: I was a bit upset with the cut of a courtier’s beard.

Anon!: One that old Frederick, your father, loves.
Goodbye!: One old Frederick, your father, loves.

Anon!: Will you pleasure me?
Goodbye!: Will you please me?

Anon!: But lest myself be guilty to self wrong, I’ll stop mine ears against the mermaid’s song.
Goodbye!: But if I’m guilty of self-destructiveness, I’ll stop my ears against the mermaid’s song.

Anon!: Sleep a little.
Goodbye!: Sleep a little.

Anon!: Mass, and well said.
Goodbye!: Well, and well said.

Anon!: Dear lady, welcome home.
Goodbye!: Hello, dear lady.

Anon!: Now, by the faith of my love, I will.
Goodbye!: Now I will, if I believe in my love.

Anon!: Thanks, dear my lord.
Goodbye!: Thanks, my dear lord.

Anon!: Fathers commonly Do get their children.
Goodbye!: Fathers get their children often.

Anon!: On Thursday, sir?
Goodbye!: On Thursday, sir?

Anon!: So every bondman in his own hand bears The power to cancel his captivity.
Goodbye!: So every bondman in his own hand has the power to cancel his captivity.

Anon!: God will revenge it.
Goodbye!: God will revenge it.

Anon!: A lover is more condoling.
Goodbye!: A lover is more angry.

Anon!: Love?
Goodbye!: Love?

Anon!: I am his brother, and I love him well.
Goodbye!: I am his brother, and I love him very much.

Anon!: To the seaside straightway!
Goodbye!: To the seaside right away!

Anon!: I am glad of it.
Goodbye!: I’m glad about it.

Anon!: Know him?
Goodbye!: Do you know him?

Anon!: My life upon her faith!—Honest Iago, My Desdemona must I leave to thee.
Goodbye!: I’ll leave my life on her faith!—Iago, my Desdemona must I leave to you.

Anon!: The concavities of it is not sufficient, for, look you, th' athversary, you may discuss unto the duke, look you, is digt himself four yard under the countermines.
Goodbye!: The concavities of it aren’t enough, because you can talk to the duke, you can talk to him, and he’s digging himself four yards under the countermines.

Anon!: But thou art not quickly moved to strike.
Goodbye!: But you’ve not been able to strike quickly.

Anon!: I marvel our mild husband Not met us on the way.
Goodbye!: I’m amazed our mild husband didn’t meet us on the way.

Anon!: For we will fetters put upon this fear, Which now goes too free-footed.
Goodbye!: We’ll scold this fear, which now goes too free-footed.

Anon!: It shines everywhere.
Goodbye!: It’s everywhere.

Anon!: You are to blame, my lord, to rate her so.
Goodbye!: You’re to blame for not telling her to.

Anon!: He does.
Goodbye!: He does.

Anon!: This is the very painting of your fear.
Goodbye!: This is the painting of your fear.

Anon!: What kind of god art thou, that suffer’st more Of mortal griefs than do thy worshippers?
Goodbye!: What kind of god are you, who suffer more of mortal grief than your worshippers?

Anon!: O coward conscience, how dost thou afflict me!
Goodbye!: Oh, coward conscience, how do you affect me?

Anon!: God save the foundation!
Goodbye!: God save the foundation!

Anon!: God witness with me, I have wept for thine.
Goodbye!: God witness, I’ve wept for you.

Anon!: Oh, that I were a glove upon that hand That I might touch that cheek!
Goodbye!: Oh, I wish I were a glove on that hand so I could touch that cheek!

Anon!: This rudeness is a sauce to his good wit, Which gives men stomach to digest his words With better appetite.
Goodbye!: This rudeness is a sauce to his good wit, which gives men stomach to digest his words with better appetite.

Anon!: He was not born to shame.
Goodbye!: He was not born to be shameful.

Anon!: A pox o' your bottle!
Goodbye!: A pox on your bottle!

Anon!: I cannot tell what you and other men Think of this life, but, for my single self, I had as lief not be as live to be In awe of such a thing as I myself.
Goodbye!: I can’t tell what you and other men think about this life, but I’d be as miserable as myself to be in awe of something like myself.

Anon!: We all stand up against the spirit of Caesar, And in the spirit of men there is no blood.
Goodbye!: We all stand up against the spirit of Caesar, and there is no blood in the spirit of men.

Anon!: What says that fool of Hagar’s offspring, ha?
Goodbye!: What does that fool of Hagar’s descendants say, ha?

Anon!: So, This is to horse.
Goodbye!: That’s what I’m saying.

Anon!: If I live to see it, I will never trust his word after.
Goodbye!: If I live to see it, I’ll never trust his word again.

Anon!: Tubal, a wealthy Hebrew of my tribe, Will furnish me.
Goodbye!: Tubal, a wealthy Hebrew of my tribe, will furnish me with a bed.

Anon!: I will only be bold with Benedick for his company, for from the crown of his head to the sole of his foot he is all mirth.
Goodbye!: I’ll only be bold with Benedick for his company, because he’s all a savage from the crown of his head to the sole of his foot.

Anon!: There is no other way.
Goodbye!: There’s no other way.

Anon!: What, from myself?
Goodbye!: What, from myself?

Anon!: And you are come in very happy time To bear my greeting to the senators And tell them that I will not come today.
Goodbye!: And you’re coming in very happy time to bear my greeting to the senators and tell them that I won’t come today.

Anon!: Then never man was man true.
Goodbye!: Then never was a man true.

Anon!: And squabble?
Goodbye!: And squabbling?

Anon!: If we be not relieved within this hour, We must return to th’ court of guard.
Goodbye!: If we’re not relieved within an hour, we’ll have to return to the guard’s court.

Anon!: This was the noblest Roman of them all.
Goodbye!: This was the noblest Roman of them all.

Anon!: Hear me, for I will speak.
Goodbye!: Listen to me, because I’ll speak.

Anon!: Speak yet.
Goodbye!: Tell me.

Anon!: Nurse, will you go with me into my closet To help me sort such needful ornaments As you think fit to furnish me tomorrow?
Goodbye!: Nurse, will you go with me into my closet to help me sort out the needy ornaments you think I’ll need tomorrow?

Anon!: He says so, Tranio?
Goodbye!: He says that, Tranio?

Anon!: The general speaks to you.
Goodbye!: The general speaks to you.

Anon!: What is a traitor?
Goodbye!: What is a traitor?

Anon!: Sit i' th' middle.
Goodbye!: Sit in the middle of the house.

Anon!: It will make you melancholy, Monsieur Jaques.
Goodbye!: It will make you mad, Monsieur Jaques.

Anon!: Or be alive again, And dare me to the desert with thy sword.
Goodbye!: Or be alive again, and dare me to the desert with your sword.

Anon!: If what he might he is not, I would to heaven he were!
Goodbye!: If he isn’t what he might be, I wish he were in heaven!

Anon!: So turns she every man the wrong side out And never gives to truth and virtue that Which simpleness and merit purchaseth.
Goodbye!: She turns every man out of the wrong side and never gives it to the truth and virtue that simpleness and merit are worth.

Anon!: If I let him go, The debt he owes will be required of me.
Goodbye!: If I let him go, I’ll have to pay him the debt.

Anon!: Who’s there?
Goodbye!: Who’s there?

Anon!: I did not, gentle husband, lock thee forth.
Goodbye!: I didn’t lock you out, husband.

Anon!: Even so?
Goodbye!: And so?

Anon!: Oh, villain that I am!
Goodbye!: Oh, I’m a villain!

Anon!: My visor is Philemon’s roof; within the house is Jove.
Goodbye!: My visor is the roof of Philemon, and inside the house is Jove.

Anon!: I am not well.
Goodbye!: I’m not well.

Anon!: If I speak like myself in this, let him be whipped that first finds it so.
Goodbye!: If I’m speaking like myself, let him be whipped, who first finds it.

Anon!: To that end, As matching to his youth and vanity, I did present him with the Paris balls.
Goodbye!: To that end, as he was matched to his youth and vanity, I presented him with the Paris balls.

Anon!: Ay, there’s the villany.
Goodbye!: Yes, there’s the villany.

Anon!: Avoid, and leave him.
Goodbye!: Leave him alone.

Anon!: What you have said I will consider, what you have to say I will with patience hear, and find a time Both meet to hear and answer such high things.
Goodbye!: I’ll consider what you’ve said, what you have to say, and find a time to meet and answer such high questions.

Anon!: Had I your tongues and eyes, I’d use them so That heaven’s vault should crack.
Goodbye!: If I had your tongues and eyes, I’d use them so that heaven’s vault would crack.

Anon!: Therefore, have done.
Goodbye!: So, have done it.

Anon!: A braggart, a rogue, a villain that fights by the book of arithmetic!
Goodbye!: A braggart, a rogue, a villain who fights by the book of arithmetic!

Anon!: Bless thy five wits.
Goodbye!: Give your five wits a hug.

Anon!: As ’tis said, the bastard son of Gloucester.
Goodbye!: As it’s said, the bastard son of Gloucester.

Anon!: By my troth, Nerissa, my little body is aweary of this great world.
Goodbye!: My little body is tired of this great world, Nerissa.

Anon!: On their sustaining garments not a blemish, But fresher than before.
Goodbye!: It’s not a blemish on their clothes, but a fresher one than before.

Anon!: Twas I, but ’tis not I. I do not shame To tell you what I was, since my conversion So sweetly tastes, being the thing I am.
Goodbye!: I was, but it’s not me.

Anon!: Ay, leeks is good.
Goodbye!: Yes, leeks are good.

Anon!: The Mayor and all his brethren in best sort, Like to the senators of th' antique Rome, With the plebeians swarming at their heels, Go forth and fetch their conquering Caesar in— As, by a lower but loving likelihood,
Goodbye!: The Mayor and all his brethren are in the best form, like the senators of Rome, with the plebeians swarming at their heels, and go forth and fetch their conquering Caesar in—like,

Anon!: Ay, by my life, And never did desire to see thee more.
Goodbye!: Yes, I’m still alive, and I never wanted to see you more.

Anon!: So ’tis to thee.
Goodbye!: That’s what’s going on to you.

Anon!: Ay, sir, we are some of her trappings.
Goodbye!: Yes, sir, we’re some of her trappings.

Anon!: Not a whit.
Goodbye!: Not a moment.

Anon!: Nor send you out o' th' way?
Goodbye!: Or send you out of your way?

Anon!: Good thou, save me a piece of marchpane, and, as thou loves me, let the porter let in Susan Grindstone and Nell.—Antony and Potpan!
Goodbye!: You, save me a piece of sand, and, as you love me, let the porter let in Susan Grindstone and Nell.—Antony and Potpan!

Anon!: Good night.
Goodbye!: Good night.

Anon!: Get me ink and paper, And hire post horses.
Goodbye!: Get me ink and paper, and hire horses to ride.

Anon!: The duke is humorous.
Goodbye!: The duke is funny.

Anon!: Where will the old duke live?
Goodbye!: Where will the old duke live?

Anon!: O excellent young man!
Goodbye!: Oh, a great young man!

Anon!: Talk not to me.
Goodbye!: Don’t talk to me.

Anon!: You look angerly.
Goodbye!: You look angry.

Anon!: For those that mingle reason with your passion Must be content to think you old, and so— But she knows what she does.
Goodbye!: For those who love to think about you must be content to think you’re old, and so— But she knows what she does.

Anon!: You know my mind.
Goodbye!: You know what I’m thinking.

Anon!: Till that, I’ll view the manners of the town, Peruse the traders, gaze upon the buildings, And then return and sleep within mine inn, For with long travel I am stiff and weary.
Goodbye!: I’ll go see the way the town is, see the traders, look at the buildings, and then return and sleep in my inn, because I’m tired and tired.

Anon!: Tis done already, and the messenger gone.
Goodbye!: It’s already done, and the messenger is gone.

Anon!: I do not bid thee call.
Goodbye!: I don’t want you to call me.

Anon!: Methinks his words do from such passion fly, That he believes himself.
Goodbye!: I think his words are so passionate that he believes himself.

Anon!: So let it be with Caesar.
Goodbye!: Let it be Caesar.

Anon!: I weigh it lightly, were it heavier.
Goodbye!: I would weigh it lightly, if it were heavier.

Anon!: My mistress and her sister stays for you.
Goodbye!: My mistress and her sister are waiting for you.

Anon!: O upright, just, and true-disposing God, How do I thank thee that this carnal cur Preys on the issue of his mother’s body And makes her pew-fellow with others' moan!
Goodbye!: Oh, upright, just, and true-to-be God, how do I thank you for the fact that this savage savage is a savage savage who treats his mother’s

Anon!: There’s rosemary, that’s for remembrance.
Goodbye!: There’s rosemary, that’s for remembrance.

Anon!: Sister, content you in my discontent.— Sir, to your pleasure humbly I subscribe.
Goodbye!: Sister, please, I’m content with my discontent.—Sir, I’m humbly subscribe to your pleasure.

Anon!: The town sounds a parley.
Goodbye!: The town is a parley.

Anon!: That must we also.
Goodbye!: That’s what we have to do.

Anon!: Ah me!
Goodbye!: Ah, me!

Anon!: But come, I’ll tell thee all my whole device When I am in my coach, which stays for us At the park gate.
Goodbye!: But come on, I’ll tell you my entire device when I’m in my coach, which stays for us at the gate.

Anon!: But he has promised me, as he is a gentleman and a soldier, he will not hurt you.
Goodbye!: But he has promised me that he won’t hurt you as a gentleman and a soldier.

Anon!: Besides, they have burned and carried away all that was in the king’s tent, wherefore the king, most worthily, hath caused every soldier to cut his prisoner’s throat.
Goodbye!: Besides, they’ve burned and carried away all that was in the king’s tent, so the king, most worthily, has caused every soldier to cut his prisoner’s throat.

Anon!: What a strange drowsiness possesses them!
Goodbye!: What a strange drowsiness they have!

Anon!: Sweet Sir Toby, be patient for tonight.
Goodbye!: Sweet Sir Toby, be patient tonight.

Anon!: I’ll find Romeo To comfort you.
Goodbye!: I’ll find Romeo to comfort you.

Anon!: I wonder of their being here together.
Goodbye!: I wonder how they’re here together.

Anon!: Thou shalt be pinched As thick as honeycomb, each pinch more stinging Than bees that made 'em.
Goodbye!: You’ll be as thick as honeycomb, and each one will be stingier than bees that made it.

Anon!: Seigneur Martino and his wife and daughters; County Anselme and his beauteous sisters; The lady widow of Vitruvio; Seigneur Placentio and his lovely nieces; Mercutio and his brother Valentine; Mine uncle Capulet, his wife and daughters; My fair niece Rosaline and Livia;
Goodbye!: Seigneur Martino and his wife and daughters; County Anselme and his beauteous sisters; the lady widow of Vitruvio; Seigneur Placentio and his lovely nieces; Mercuti

Anon!: Rather approach’d too late!
Goodbye!: I’d rather go to bed early than be late!

Anon!: Your friends are up and buckle on their armor.
Goodbye!: Your friends are up and buckle on their armor.

Anon!: Love’s heralds should be thoughts, Which ten times faster glide than the sun’s beams, Driving back shadows over louring hills.
Goodbye!: Love’s heroes should be thoughts, which glide ten times faster than sun’s beams, driving back shadows over louring hills.

Anon!: Either my eyesight fails, or thou look’st pale.
Goodbye!: Either my eyesight fails, or you look pale.

Anon!: This is the place.
Goodbye!: This is the place.

Anon!: Whither am I going?
Goodbye!: Where am I going?

Anon!: Think, my lord?
Goodbye!: Think, my lord?

Anon!: I think you set nothing by a bloody coxcomb.
Goodbye!: I think you’re not a bloody savage.

Anon!: I know that we shall have him well to friend.
Goodbye!: I know that we’ll have him to be a friend.

Anon!: I remember The first time ever Caesar put it on.
Goodbye!: I remember the first time Caesar put it on.

Anon!: I was sure your lordship did not give it me.
Goodbye!: I was sure your lord didn’t give it to me.

Anon!: Was the crown offered him thrice?
Goodbye!: Was the crown offered to him three times?

Anon!: And for their sake, In your fair minds let this acceptance take.
Goodbye!: And for their sake, let this acceptance take place in your fair minds.

Anon!: I have made strong proof of my constancy, Giving myself a voluntary wound Here in the thigh.
Goodbye!: I’ve made a strong proof of my perseverance, giving myself a voluntary wound in the thigh.

Anon!: Husband, I’ll dine above with you today, And shrive you of a thousand idle pranks.
Goodbye!: Husband, I’ll dine above with you today and shrive you of a thousand idle pranks.

Anon!: Jailer, look to him.
Goodbye!: Jailer, look at him.

Anon!: For your coming in to dinner, sir, why, let it be as humours and conceits shall govern.
Goodbye!: If you come in to dinner, sir, let it be as humours and conceits will govern.

Anon!: But this rough magic I here abjure, and when I have required Some heavenly music, which even now I do, To work mine end upon their senses that This airy charm is for, I’ll break my staff, Bury it certain fathoms in the earth, And deeper than did ever plummet sound I’ll drown my book.
Goodbye!: But I’ll break my staff, and I’ll drown my book deeper than ever.

Anon!: How do you, Cassio?—Oh, a chair, a chair!
Goodbye!: How are you, Cassio?—Oh, a chair, a chair!

Anon!: But passion lends them power, time means, to meet, Tempering extremities with extreme sweet.
Goodbye!: But passion gives them power, and time gives them the opportunity to meet, tying extremities with sweetness.

Anon!: My royal cousin, teach you our princess English?
Goodbye!: My royal cousin, do you teach our princess English?

Anon!: The prince my brother hath outgrown me far.
Goodbye!: My brother’s prince has outgrown me.

Anon!: Take me up.
Goodbye!: Take me up.

Anon!: Regan, I think you are.
Goodbye!: Regan, I think you are.

Anon!: I would not spare my brother in this case If he should scorn me so apparently.
Goodbye!: I wouldn’t spare my brother in this case if he would scorn me so a little.

Anon!: Either my eyesight fails, or thou look’st pale.
Goodbye!: Either my eyesight fails, or you look pale.

Anon!: O you mighty gods,  This world I do renounce, and in your sights Shake patiently my great affliction off.
Goodbye!: Oh, you mighty gods, I renounce this world, and in your eyes I’ll leave my great affliction.

Anon!: In each thing give him way.
Goodbye!: Give him the way to each other.

Anon!: Good sister, wrong me not nor wrong yourself, To make a bondmaid and a slave of me.
Goodbye!: My sister, you’re not wrong to make me a slave and a bondmaid.

Anon!: Thou shalt not choose but go.
Goodbye!: You’ll not have to go.

Anon!: Not that I love you not.
Goodbye!: Not that I don’t love you.

Anon!: Proculeius, What thou hast done thy master Caesar knows, And he hath sent for thee.
Goodbye!: Proculeius, what your master Caesar knows, and he sent for you.

Anon!: What shall I do?
Goodbye!: What should I do?

Anon!: Fare thee well!
Goodbye!: Goodbye!

Anon!: Make haste, I say.
Goodbye!: Hurry up, I say.

Anon!: What, in my sight?—Bianca, get thee in.
Goodbye!: What, in my sight?—Bianca, get in.

Anon!: Death’s the end of all.
Goodbye!: Death is the end of all.

Anon!: They will scarcely believe this without trial.
Goodbye!: They’ll be tempted to believe this without trial.

Anon!: How prove you that in the great heap of your knowledge?
Goodbye!: How do you prove that in the vast amount of your knowledge?

Anon!: Is the sword unswayed?
Goodbye!: Is the sword unwayed?

Anon!: They bleed on both sides.—How is it, my lord?
Goodbye!: They’re bleeding on both sides.—How is it, my lord?

Anon!: But indeed an old religious uncle of mine taught me to speak, who was in his youth an inland man, one that knew courtship too well, for there he fell in love.
Goodbye!: But my uncle taught me to speak, who was a man in his youth who knew too well about courtship, because there he fell in love.

Anon!: But we will draw the curtain and show you the picture.
Goodbye!: But we’ll draw the curtain and show you the picture.

Anon!: When we our betters see bearing our woes, We scarcely think our miseries our foes.
Goodbye!: When we see our betters bear our sorrows, we don’t think our misfortunes are our foes.

Anon!: Speak, I’ll go no further.
Goodbye!: Speak, I won’t go any further.

Anon!: Here comes the herald of the French, my liege.
Goodbye!: Here comes the herald of the French, my liege.

Anon!: My duty hushes me.
Goodbye!: My duty is hushed.

Anon!: I will give you the minstrel.
Goodbye!: I’ll give you the minstrel.

Anon!: Foolish curs, that run winking into the mouth of a Russian bear and have their heads crushed like rotten apples.
Goodbye!: Foolish slurs that run into a Russian bear’s mouth and have their heads crushed like rotten apples.

Anon!: I never gave him any.
Goodbye!: I never gave him any.

Anon!: We have engaged ourselves too far.
Goodbye!: We’ve been too far.

Anon!: And how like you this shepherd’s life, Master Touchstone?
Goodbye!: And how are you, Master Touchstone, living this shepherd?

Anon!: Which in his dearest need will fly from him.
Goodbye!: Which in his most precious need will fly from him.

Anon!: The death of Antony Is not a single doom.
Goodbye!: Antony’s death isn’t a single crime.

Anon!: But art thou not advised, he took some care To get her cunning schoolmasters to instruct her?
Goodbye!: But you didn’t advise him, but he took care of getting her to be taught by the sane schoolmasters?

Anon!: Tis fittest.
Goodbye!: It’s the best thing to do.

Anon!: But thou art not quickly moved to strike.
Goodbye!: But you’ve not been able to strike quickly.

Anon!: Pray, have you not a daughter Called Katherina, fair and virtuous?
Goodbye!: Do you have a daughter named Katherina, fair and virtuous?

Anon!: Switch and spurs, switch and spurs, or I’ll cry a match.
Goodbye!: Switch and spurs, switch and spurs, or I’ll cry a match.

Anon!: If you will take a homely man’s advice, Be not found here.
Goodbye!: If you want to take a homely man’s advice, don’t be found here.

Anon!: Good day to both of you.
Goodbye!: Good day to both of you.

Anon!: God’s will and His pleasure, Captain, I beseech you now, come apace to the king.
Goodbye!: God’s will and pleasure, Captain, I beg you now to come to the king.

Anon!: Hence, prating peasant!
Goodbye!: Go on, scolding peasant!

Anon!: Yet say I, he is in love.
Goodbye!: But say I, he’s in love.

Anon!: Not black in my mind, though yellow in my legs.
Goodbye!: I’m not black, even though my legs are yellow.

Anon!: Oh!
Goodbye!: Oh!

Anon!: Do not break off so, For we may pity though not pardon thee.
Goodbye!: Don’t break it off, because we can pity you, even if we don’t pardon you.

Anon!: Sure, it was the roar Of a whole herd of lions.
Goodbye!: It was the roar of a whole herd of lions.

Anon!: Why, by making him uncapable of Othello’s place: knocking out his brains.
Goodbye!: Why, by making him uncapable of Othello’s place, knocking out his brains.

Anon!: How old art thou?
Goodbye!: How old are you?

Anon!: Peter, didst ever see the like?
Goodbye!: Peter, did you see the same thing ever?

Anon!: They vanished strangely.
Goodbye!: They vanished strangely.

Anon!: My industrious servant, Ariel!
Goodbye!: My devoted servant, Ariel!

Anon!: No, lady.
Goodbye!: No, lady.

Anon!: By my sword, Beatrice, thou lovest me.
Goodbye!: By my sword, Beatrice, you love me.

Anon!: Oh, it offends me to the soul to hear a robustious periwig-pated fellow tear a passion to tatters, to very rags, to split the ears of the groundlings, who for the most part are capable of nothing but inexplicable dumb-shows and noise.
Goodbye!: Oh, it offends me to hear a prank-pated fellow tear a passion to tatters, to very rags, to split the ears of the groundlings, who are capable of nothing

Anon!: I will desire you to live in the meantime and eat your victuals.
Goodbye!: I’d like you to live in the meantime and eat your victuals.

Anon!: Lesser than Macbeth and greater.
Goodbye!: Less than Macbeth and greater.

Anon!: Why, art thou mad, old fellow?
Goodbye!: Why, are you crazy, old fellow?

Anon!: First, of my word!
Goodbye!: First of all, my word!

Anon!: Thy loving father, Hamlet.
Goodbye!: Hamlet, your loving father.

Anon!: I’ll ask them.
Goodbye!: I’ll ask them.

Anon!: After a little time, I’ll beat him too.
Goodbye!: After a little time, I’ll beat him too.

Anon!: Mark the music.
Goodbye!: Listen to the music.

Anon!: Whom should I knock?
Goodbye!: Whom should I knock?

Anon!: All the pictures fairest lined Are but black to Rosalind.
Goodbye!: All the pictures that are the most beautiful are black to Rosalind.

Anon!: Hoo!
Goodbye!: Hooray!

Anon!: O, rejoice Beyond a common joy, and set it down With gold on lasting pillars.
Goodbye!: Oh, rejoice beyond a common joy, and set it down with gold on long pillars.

Anon!: Good morrow, friends.
Goodbye!: Good morning, friends.

Anon!: And thy father Was Duke of Milan, and thou his only heir And princess no worse issued.
Goodbye!: And your father was Duke of Milan, and you were his only heir and princess.

Anon!: Come, civil night, Thou sober-suited matron, all in black, And learn me how to lose a winning match Played for a pair of stainless maidenhoods.
Goodbye!: Come, civil night, you handsome matron, all in black, and learn how to lose a winning match played for a pair of stainless-steel-trained women.

Anon!: Romeo, he cries aloud, “Hold, friends!
Goodbye!: Romeo, he cries, “Hold, friends!

Anon!: Come one more.
Goodbye!: Come on, one more.

Anon!: Ay, are you thereabouts?
Goodbye!: Yes, are you there?

Anon!: If it will not, what remedy?
Goodbye!: If it doesn’t, what remedy?

Anon!: No more than from my soul I mourn for yours.
Goodbye!: I’m not mourning yours more than I mourn from my soul.

Anon!: Sister, where thou?
Goodbye!: Sister, where are you?

Anon!: I was killed i' th' Capitol.
Goodbye!: I was killed in the Capitol.

Anon!: Were you by when it began?
Goodbye!: Did you come here when it started?

Anon!: What, are Ancient Pistol and you friends yet?
Goodbye!: Are you and Pistol friends yet?

Anon!: Zounds, who is there?
Goodbye!: Zounds, who’s there?

Anon!: These be the Christian husbands.
Goodbye!: These are the Christian husbands.

Anon!: O momentary grace of mortal men, Which we more hunt for than the grace of God!
Goodbye!: Oh, the precious grace of mortal men, which we’re more searching for than the grace of God!

Anon!: O happy horse, to bear the weight of Antony!
Goodbye!: Oh, happy horse, to bear the weight of Antony!

Anon!: Do you not hear me speak?
Goodbye!: Don’t you hear me speak?

Anon!: O brave touch!
Goodbye!: Oh, what a brave touch!

Anon!: You know not how to choose a man.
Goodbye!: You don’t know how to choose a man.

Anon!: Hearty thanks.
Goodbye!: Thank you very much.

Anon!: I grant I am a woman, but withal A woman well-reputed, Cato’s daughter.
Goodbye!: I’m sure I’m a woman, but I’m a woman well-known, Cato’s daughter.

Anon!: Ten masts at each make not the altitude Which thou hast perpendicularly fell.
Goodbye!: Each of the ten masts is different from the altitude you have fallen perpendiculairely.

Anon!: I do not desire he should answer for me, and yet I determine to fight lustily for him.
Goodbye!: I don’t want him to answer for me, and yet I’m determined to fight lustfully for him.

Anon!: What need’st thou run so many mile about When thou mayst tell thy tale the nearest way?
Goodbye!: What should you run so many miles about when you can tell your story the nearest way?

Anon!: All that glisters is not gold— Often have you heard that told.
Goodbye!: All that glisters are not gold— You’ve heard that often.

Anon!: My liege, your highness now may do me good.
Goodbye!: My liege, your highness may help me now.

Anon!: But yet It is our trick.
Goodbye!: But it’s not our trick.

Anon!: A fiend like thee might bear my soul to hell.
Goodbye!: A fiend like you could bring my soul to hell.

Anon!: I mean, my head upon your lap?
Goodbye!: I mean, my head is on your lap?

Anon!: But are not some whole that we must make sick?
Goodbye!: But aren’t there some whole thing we have to make sick?

Anon!: His better doth not breathe upon the earth.
Goodbye!: He’s better off not breathing on the earth.

Anon!: Fare thee well.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: My suit to her Is that she will to virtuous Desdemona Procure me some access.
Goodbye!: I’m asking her to get some access to Desdemona.

Anon!: Here is a rural fellow That will not be denied your Highness’ presence.
Goodbye!: Here’s a rural fellow who won’t be denied the presence of your Highness.

Anon!: Oh!
Goodbye!: Oh!

Anon!: When this advice is free I give and honest, Probal to thinking and indeed the course To win the Moor again?
Goodbye!: When I give this advice and give it to you, Probal to think about the way to win the Moor again?

Anon!: Was he not here?
Goodbye!: Wasn’t he here?

Anon!: Let’s withdraw, my lord.
Goodbye!: Let’s go, my lord.

Anon!: If our father would sleep till I waked him, you should enjoy half his revenue forever, and live the beloved of your brother,       Edgar.”  Hum, conspiracy?
Goodbye!: If our father would sleep until I wake him up, you’d enjoy half his income forever, and live the beloved of your brother, Edgar.” Hum, conspiracy?

Anon!: Therefore I have entreated him along With us to watch the minutes of this night, That if again this apparition come He may approve our eyes and speak to it.
Goodbye!: So I have urged him along with us to watch the night before, so if this apparition comes again, he can see our eyes and speak to it.

Anon!: They say he parted well and paid his score.
Goodbye!: They say he was well offended and paid his score.

Anon!: If you do love Rosalind so near the heart as your gesture cries it out, when your brother marries Aliena shall you marry her.
Goodbye!: If you love Rosalind as much as you cry out, when your brother marries Aliena, you’ll marry her.

Anon!: This for him.
Goodbye!: That’s for him.

Anon!: Is ’t possible?
Goodbye!: Is it possible?

Anon!: When that’s gone, He shall drink naught but brine, for I’ll not show him Where the quick freshes are.
Goodbye!: When that’s gone, he’ll drink naughty brine, because I won’t show him where the quick freshness is.

Anon!: Dost thou not suspect my place?
Goodbye!: Don’t you suspect my place?

Anon!: But is there no sequel at the heels of this mother’s admiration?
Goodbye!: But isn’t there any sequel to this mother’s admiration?

Anon!: And these does she apply for warnings and portents And evils imminent, and on her knee Hath begged that I will stay at home today.
Goodbye!: She’s asking for warnings and threats and imminent evils, and on her knee she’s begged me to stay at home today.

Anon!: Gallus, go you along.
Goodbye!: Gallus, go along.

Anon!: How will you live?
Goodbye!: How will you live?

Anon!: And I do know by this they stay for me In Pompey’s porch.
Goodbye!: And I know that they’re waiting for me in Pompey’s porch.

Anon!: Let him that loves me strike me dead.
Goodbye!: Let the man who loves me strike me dead.

Anon!: The story is extant, and writ in choice Italian.
Goodbye!: The story is still alive, and it’s a choice of Italian.

Anon!: But if you fail, without more speech, my lord, You must be gone from hence immediately.
Goodbye!: But if you fail, you have to go away immediately, my lord.

Anon!: We will, fair queen, up to the mountain’s top, And mark the musical confusion Of hounds and echo in conjunction.
Goodbye!: We’ll climb up to the top of the mountain, fair queen, and see the confusion of hounds and hear them in conjunction.

Anon!: Who comes here?
Goodbye!: Who’s coming?

Anon!: Indeed, that is out of the air.
Goodbye!: That’s true, it’s out of the air.

Anon!: I will frown as I pass by, and let them take it as they list.
Goodbye!: I’ll frown as I pass by, and let them take it as they list it.

Anon!: Then make a ring about the corpse of Caesar, And let me show you him that made the will.
Goodbye!: Then make a ring about Caesar’s corpse, and let me show you the man who made the will.

Anon!: Holla!
Goodbye!: Holla!

Anon!: Let him approach.
Goodbye!: Let him come.

Anon!: Well, let it strike.
Goodbye!: Well, let it strike.

Anon!: Bid them move away.
Goodbye!: Ask them to move away.

Anon!: Therein the patient Must minister to himself.
Goodbye!: Therein the patient must minister to himself.

Anon!: Where should she be?
Goodbye!: Where should she be?

Anon!: I do begin to have bloody thoughts.
Goodbye!: I’m starting to have bloody thoughts.

Anon!: Sir, I do know you, And dare upon the warrant of my note Commend a dear thing to you.
Goodbye!: Sir, I know you, and I’ll dare to thank you for a dear thing.

Anon!: A certain aim he took At a fair vestal thronèd by the west, And loosed his love shaft smartly from his bow As it should pierce a hundred thousand hearts.
Goodbye!: He took a certain aim at a fair throne throned by the west and loosed his love shaft smartly from his bow, as it would pierce a hundred thousand hearts.

Anon!: Is he gone and hath nothing?
Goodbye!: Is he gone and has nothing to do with?

Anon!: Why then, to thee, thou silver treasure house.
Goodbye!: Well then, you silver treasure house.

Anon!: You’ll pay me the eight shillings I won of you at betting?
Goodbye!: You’ll pay me the eight shillings I won from you at betting?

Anon!: And why not the swift foot of time?
Goodbye!: Why not wait a minute?

Anon!: Ah, that good Kent— He said it would be thus, poor banished man.
Goodbye!: Ah, that good Kent— He said it would be like that, poor banished man.

Anon!: The several messengers From hence attend dispatch.
Goodbye!: The messengers from here are ready to go.

Anon!: I was told that by one that knows him better than you.
Goodbye!: I was told that by someone who knows him better than you.

Anon!: Then have at thee, boy!
Goodbye!: Then have at you, boy!

Anon!: To th’ monument!
Goodbye!: To the monument!

Anon!: I doubt it is no other but the main: His father’s death and our o'erhasty marriage.
Goodbye!: I doubt it’s nothing but the main reason: his father’s death and our obnoxious marriage.

Anon!: All men call thee fickle.
Goodbye!: All men call you a fickle man.

Anon!: Yet I profess curing it by counsel.
Goodbye!: But I swear to you that I’m a man who’s cured it.

Anon!: Petruchio, patience.
Goodbye!: Petruchio, patience.

Anon!: You all did see that on the Lupercal I thrice presented him a kingly crown, Which he did thrice refuse.
Goodbye!: You all saw that I presented him a kingly crown on the Lupercal, which he refused to accept.

Anon!: And did they bid you tell her of it, madam?
Goodbye!: And did they ask you to tell her about it, madam?

Anon!: Ratcliffe!
Goodbye!: Ratcliffe!

Anon!: What did you enact?
Goodbye!: What did you do to make it happen?

Anon!: O God, did Romeo’s hand shed Tybalt’s blood?
Goodbye!: Oh God, did Romeo’s hand shed Tybalt’s blood?

Anon!: Was not that letter from fair Jessica?
Goodbye!: Wasn’t that a letter from a good Jessica?

Anon!: Her dotage now I do begin to pity.
Goodbye!: I’m starting to pity her.

Anon!: I did not think you could have been so angry.
Goodbye!: I didn’t think you could have been so angry.

Anon!: Why Romeo, art thou mad?
Goodbye!: Why Romeo, are you crazy?

Anon!: Ah, Rosencrantz!
Goodbye!: Ah, Rosencrantz!

Anon!: The ladies, her attendants of her chamber Saw her abed, and in the morning early They found the bed untreasured of their mistress.
Goodbye!: The ladies, her servants in her room saw her abed, and early morning they found the bed of their mistress untreasured.

Anon!: Take the hint Which my despair proclaims.
Goodbye!: Take the hint I’m saying.

Anon!: Sad, lady!
Goodbye!: Sad, lady!

Anon!: Tis well you offer it behind her back.
Goodbye!: It’s good you’re offering it behind her back.

Anon!: Nay, certainly, I have heard the Ptolemies’ pyramises are very goodly things.
Goodbye!: No, I’ve heard that the Ptolemies’ pyramises are very good.

Anon!: Speak, man.
Goodbye!: Speak, man.

Anon!: She swoons to see them bleed.
Goodbye!: She’s swooning to see them bleed.

Anon!: If thy greatness will Revenge it on him—for I know thou darest, But this thing dare not— That’s most certain.
Goodbye!: If your greatness will revenge it on him—for I know you dare, but this thing doesn’t dare—that’s certainly true.

Anon!: Well, come, my Kate.
Goodbye!: Well, come, my Kate.

Anon!: Oh, give us leave, great king, To view the field in safety and dispose Of their dead bodies.
Goodbye!: Oh, let’s go, great king, to see the field safely and dispose of their dead bodies.

Anon!: If love be blind, love cannot hit the mark.
Goodbye!: If love is blind, love can’t hit the mark.

Anon!: And here I stand, both to impeach and purge, Myself condemnèd and myself excused.
Goodbye!: And here I stand, both to impeach and purge, condemning myself and excused myself.

Anon!: For his valor cannot carry his discretion, and the fox carries the goose.
Goodbye!: He can’t carry his discretion, and the fox has the goose.

Anon!: Ay, or any show that you will show him.
Goodbye!: Yes, or any show you’ll show him.

Anon!: For Brutus, as you know, was Caesar’s angel.
Goodbye!: For Brutus, as you know, was Caesar’s angel.

Anon!: Dost thou love pictures?
Goodbye!: Do you love pictures?

Anon!: Boatswain!
Goodbye!: Boatswain!

Anon!: It is not for you.
Goodbye!: It’s not for you.

Anon!: He has a little galled me, I confess.
Goodbye!: He’s slammed me a little bit.

Anon!: But ere we could arrive the point proposed, Caesar cried, “Help me, Cassius, or I sink!” I, as Aeneas, our great ancestor, Did from the flames of Troy upon his shoulder The old Anchises bear, so from the waves of Tiber Did I the tired Caesar.
Goodbye!: But if we could reach the point proposed, Caesar cried, “Help me, Cassius, or I sink!” I, as Aeneas, our great ancestor, did from the flames of Troy on his

Anon!: The messengers of Venice stays the meat.
Goodbye!: The messengers of Venice keep the meat.

Anon!: Good, speak to th' mariners.
Goodbye!: Good, speak to the mariners.

Anon!: This, this.
Goodbye!: That’s it.

Anon!: Fair sir, and you, my merry mistress, That with your strange encounter much amazed me, My name is called Vincentio, my dwelling Pisa, And bound I am to Padua, there to visit A son of mine which long I have not seen.
Goodbye!: I’m called Vincentio, my residence Pisa, and I’m bound to Padua to visit a son of mine that I’ve never seen for a long time.

Anon!: But, as I said, On Lammas Eve at night shall she be fourteen.
Goodbye!: But I said, on Lammas Eve she’ll be fourteen.

Anon!: What is here?
Goodbye!: What’s this?

Anon!: O, make them joyful.
Goodbye!: Oh, make them joyful.

Anon!: What cheer, my love?— Demetrius and Egeus, go along.
Goodbye!: What cheer, my love?—Demetrius and Egeus, go along.

Anon!: Both, both, my girl.
Goodbye!: Both, both, my girl.

Anon!: Of whence, I pray?
Goodbye!: Of when, please?

Anon!: Was that my father that went hence so fast?
Goodbye!: Was that my father who left here so fast?

Anon!: Look, here comes Helena.
Goodbye!: Look, here comes Helena.

Anon!: Let’s see for means.
Goodbye!: Let’s see what’s going on.

Anon!: Fie, fie!
Goodbye!: Oh, sir!

Anon!: Why so, being gone,      Why so, being gone, I am a man again.
Goodbye!: Why so, being gone, why so, being gone, I’m a man again.

Anon!: Who knows not that?
Goodbye!: Who doesn’t know that?

Anon!: That hath made him mad.
Goodbye!: That’s made him mad.

Anon!: Have I thought long to see this morning’s face, And doth it give me such a sight as this?
Goodbye!: Have I thought I’d be watching this morning for a long time, and does it give me such a sight as this?

Anon!: Faith, once or twice she heaved the name of “father” Pantingly forth as if it pressed her heart, Cried, “Sisters, sisters!
Goodbye!: She heaved the name of “father” once or twice, as if it pressed her heart, Cried, “Sisters, sisters!

Anon!: Is not that strange?
Goodbye!: Isn’t that strange?

Anon!: Fair and noble hostess, We are your guest tonight.
Goodbye!: Fair and noble hostess, we’re your guest tonight.

Anon!: Have you not hurt your head?
Goodbye!: Didn’t you hurt your head?

Anon!: Many a man would take you at your word And go indeed, having so good a mean.
Goodbye!: Many men would take you at your word and go, even if you were so good.

Anon!: Go you down that way towards the Capitol.
Goodbye!: Go down that way towards the Capitol.

Anon!: How now, Roderigo!
Goodbye!: What’s going on, Roderigo?

Anon!: No, I will be the pattern of all patience.
Goodbye!: No, I’ll be the model of all patience.

Anon!: Be comforted, dear madam.
Goodbye!: Be calm, dear madam.

Anon!: Dost thou not bring me letters from the friar?
Goodbye!: Don’t you bring me letters from the friar?

Anon!: Think’st thou the fiery fever will go out With titles blown from adulation?
Goodbye!: Do you think the fiery fever will go out with titles blown out of adulation?

Anon!: That’s not so good now.
Goodbye!: That’s not good now.

Anon!: Mistress!
Goodbye!: Mistress!

Anon!: Striving to better, oft we mar what’s well.
Goodbye!: We’re always trying to better things, and we’re always trying to get better.

Anon!: O, sir, upon her nose, all o'er-embellished with rubies, carbuncles, sapphires, declining their rich aspect to the hot breath of Spain, who sent whole armadas of caracks to be ballast at her nose.
Goodbye!: Oh, sir, on her nose, all o'clock, surrounded by rubies, carbuncles, sapphires, reducing their richness to the hot breath of Spain, who sent whole armadas

Anon!: What would my lord?
Goodbye!: What would I do, my lord?

Anon!: Friends, part!” and, swifter than his tongue, His agile arm beats down their fatal points, And ’twixt them rushes—underneath whose arm An envious thrust from Tybalt hit the life Of stout Mercutio, and then Tybalt fled.
Goodbye!: Friends, part!” and, faster than his tongue, his agile arm beat down their fatal points and swam them into the rush—and whose arm was thrown from Tybalt and hit Mercutio’s life

Anon!: He hath given his empire Up to a whore; who now are levying The kings o’ th’ earth for war.
Goodbye!: He has given his empire to a whore, who now imposes the kings on earth for war.

Anon!: Our separated fortune Shall keep us both the safer.
Goodbye!: Our separated fortune will keep us both safe.

Anon!: Are you a man?
Goodbye!: Are you a man?

Anon!: He could not have ’scaped sixpence a day.
Goodbye!: He couldn’t have escaped sixpence a day.

Anon!: Do not swear at all.
Goodbye!: Don’t swear at all.

Anon!: I shall miss thee, But yet thou shalt have freedom.—So, so, so.— To the king’s ship, invisible as thou art.
Goodbye!: I’ll miss you, but you’ll have freedom.—So, so, so.—To the king’s ship, invisible as you are.

Anon!: Oh, I could play the woman with mine eyes And braggart with my tongue!
Goodbye!: Oh, I could play the woman with my eyes and braggart with my tongue!

Anon!: Now heaven hath all,
Goodbye!: Now heaven has all.

Anon!: Ay, mine own fortune in my misery.
Goodbye!: Yes, I’m a good man in my mistress.

Anon!: Can heaven be so envious?
Goodbye!: Can heaven be so envious?

Anon!: Good gentle one, give me modest assurance if you be the lady of the house, that I may proceed in my speech.
Goodbye!: Good gentleman, give me modest assurance if you’re the lady of the house, that I can proceed with my speech.

Anon!: Death’s the end of all.
Goodbye!: Death is the end of all.

Anon!: God knows I loved my niece, And she is dead, slandered to death by villains That dare as well answer a man indeed As I dare take a serpent by the tongue.— Boys, apes, braggarts, jacks, milksops!
Goodbye!: God knows I loved my niece, and she is dead, slandered to death by villains that dare as well answer a man as I dare take a serpent by the tongue.— Boys, apes

Anon!: You take pleasure then in the message?
Goodbye!: You’re enjoying the message then?

Anon!: Hence, and stand aloof.
Goodbye!: Go away and stay away from me.

Anon!: What, mistress!
Goodbye!: What, mistress!

Anon!: But, as you say, sir, let your bounty take a nap, I will awake it anon.
Goodbye!: But as you say, sir, let your bounty take a nap, I’ll wake it up.

Anon!: By'r Lady, thirty years.
Goodbye!: By'r Lady, thirty years.

Anon!: Here, Fluellen, wear thou this favor for me and stick it in thy cap.
Goodbye!: Here, Fluellen, wear this favor for me and stick it in your cap.

Anon!: Nothing could have subdued nature To such a lowness but his unkind daughters.
Goodbye!: Nothing could have subdued nature to such a lowness, except his unkind daughters.

Anon!: Why, then, let them alone till they are sober.
Goodbye!: So let them go alone until they’re sober.

Anon!: I did not think, sir, to have met you here.
Goodbye!: I didn’t think I had met you here, sir.

Anon!: Is yonder the man?
Goodbye!: Is he over here?

Anon!: Let me see her.
Goodbye!: Let me see her.

Anon!: Retire!
Goodbye!: Retire!

Anon!: Let four captains Bear Hamlet like a soldier to the stage, For he was likely, had he been put on, To have proved most royally.
Goodbye!: Let four captains take Hamlet to the stage like a soldier, because he was likely to have been a royal king if he were put on.

Anon!: I am not Cinna the conspirator.
Goodbye!: I’m not Cinna the conspirator.

Anon!: Are there balance here to weigh The flesh?
Goodbye!: Are there balances here to weigh the flesh?

Anon!: Petruchio, stand by a while.
Goodbye!: Petruchio, let’s go.

Anon!: But tell us, do you hear whether Antonio have had any loss at sea or no?
Goodbye!: But tell us, do you hear whether Antonio has lost his life on the sea or not?

Anon!: Are you so hasty now?
Goodbye!: Are you so hurrying now?

Anon!: Titinius, if thou lovest me, Mount thou my horse, and hide thy spurs in him Till he have brought thee up to yonder troops And here again, that I may rest assured Whether yond troops are friend or enemy.
Goodbye!: Titinius, if you love me, mount my horse and hide your snore until he’s brought you up to troops and here again, so I can rest assured whether troops are friends or enemies.

Anon!: Good my lord.
Goodbye!: Good, my lord.

Anon!: What misadventure is so early up That calls our person from our morning rest?
Goodbye!: What misadventure is that early in the morning that calls our person out of our morning sleep?

Anon!: Where’s Peaseblossom?
Goodbye!: Where’s Peaseblossom?

Anon!: O heavens!
Goodbye!: Oh heavens!

Anon!: At our synagogue, Tubal.
Goodbye!: At our synagogue, Tubal.

Anon!: If our sport had gone forward, we had all been made men.
Goodbye!: If we had a sport going forward, we would have all been men.

Anon!: By heaven, it is the same I gave the doctor!
Goodbye!: I swear, I gave it to the doctor!

Anon!: Cambio.
Goodbye!: Cambio.

Anon!: Your Worship is deceived.
Goodbye!: Your Worship is wrong.

Anon!: I am sorry to hear this.
Goodbye!: I’m sorry to hear this.

Anon!: They will steal anything and call it purchase.
Goodbye!: They’ll steal anything and call it a purchase.

Anon!: With the earl, sir, here within.
Goodbye!: With the earl, sir, here inside.

Anon!: I pray you watch about Signior Leonato’s door, for the wedding being there tomorrow, there is a great coil tonight.
Goodbye!: Please watch Signior Leonato’s door, because the wedding is going tomorrow, there’s a great ring tonight.

Anon!: Draw thy sword and give me Sufficing strokes for death.
Goodbye!: Draw your sword and give me a stroke of death.

Anon!: My worthy Cawdor!
Goodbye!: My worthy Cawdor!

Anon!: These letters give, Iago, to the pilot, And by him do my duties to the senate.
Goodbye!: Iago, Iago, I’ll send these letters to the pilot, and I’ll do my duties to the senate.

Anon!: She hath, and in that sparing makes huge waste, For beauty, starved with her severity, Cuts beauty off from all posterity.
Goodbye!: She has, and in that way she’s making huge wastes, because she’s starved with her severity, she’s cutting her beauty off from all the posterity.

Anon!: No, by this heavenly light!
Goodbye!: No, by this heavenly light!

Anon!: Nay, I hope.
Goodbye!: No, I hope so.

Anon!: Here comes the Prince and Claudio.
Goodbye!: Here comes the Prince and Claudio.

Anon!: Where are they?
Goodbye!: Where are they?

Anon!: Good morrow, Lieutenant Bardolph.
Goodbye!: Good morning, Lieutenant Bardolph.

Anon!: The lieutenant is to be saved before the ancient.
Goodbye!: The lieutenant will be saved before the ancient.

Anon!: Tell me, how fares our loving mother?
Goodbye!: Tell me, how is our loving mother?

Anon!: A plague upon this howling!
Goodbye!: This wrath is plagued!

Anon!: Merciful powers, Restrain in me the cursèd thoughts that nature Gives way to in repose.
Goodbye!: Merciful powers, restrain me from the slurding thoughts that nature gives way to repose.

Anon!: Can you do it?
Goodbye!: Can you do it?

Anon!: Now I’ll tell you without asking.
Goodbye!: Now I’ll tell you without asking.

Anon!: Well said.
Goodbye!: That’s right.

Anon!: I’ll wear none but this.
Goodbye!: I’ll wear nothing but this.

Anon!: Farewell to you.—And you.—And you, Volumnius.
Goodbye!: Goodbye to you.—And you.—And you, Volumnius.

Anon!: Pardon the frankness of my mirth if I answer you for that.
Goodbye!: Pardon my frankness if I answer you for that.

Anon!: What says your Highness to my just request?
Goodbye!: What does your Highness say to my just request?

Anon!: I’ll hold my mind were she an Ethiope.
Goodbye!: I’d like to think of her if she were an Ethiope.

Anon!: Not i' th' stocks, fool.
Goodbye!: Not in the stocks, fool.

Anon!: I pray thee, sing, and let me woo no more.
Goodbye!: Please sing, and let me woo no more.

Anon!: My little spirit, see, Sits in a foggy cloud and stays for me.
Goodbye!: My little spirit, see, sits in a cloud of frighten clouds and stays for me.

Anon!: Unless he have a fancy to this foolery, as it appears he hath, he is no fool for fancy, as you would have it appear he is.
Goodbye!: If he doesn’t have a fancy for this foolery, as it appears he has, he’s not a fool for fancy, as you would have it appear he is.

Anon!: Ready, my lord.
Goodbye!: Get ready, my lord.

Anon!: Enjoy the honey-heavy dew of slumber.
Goodbye!: Enjoy the honey-heavy dew of slumber.

Anon!: I am a soldier, I, Older in practice, abler than yourself To make conditions.
Goodbye!: I’m a soldier, and I’m older in practice, and more capable than you to make the right decisions.

Anon!: I heard him swear his affection.
Goodbye!: I heard him swear he’s affectionate.

Anon!: Go, Sir Andrew.
Goodbye!: Go, Sir Andrew.

Anon!: Romeo slew Tybalt.
Goodbye!: Romeo killed Tybalt.

Anon!: Oh, is ’t come to this?
Goodbye!: Oh, is it coming to this?

Anon!: Will they not say afterwards, if they should grow themselves to common players (as it is most like if their means are no better), their writers do them wrong to make them exclaim against their own succession?
Goodbye!: Willn’t they say that if they grow up to a common audience (as it’s most like if their means aren’t better), their writers do them wrong to make them claim against their own succession?

Anon!: Now all the plagues that in the pendulous air Hang fated o'er men’s faults light on thy daughters!
Goodbye!: Now all the plagues that plagues your daughters have blown away by men’s faults are now a threat!

Anon!: The villain is much lighter-heeled than I. I followed fast, but faster he did fly, That fallen am I in dark uneven way,
Goodbye!: I followed him fast, but he did fly faster, and I’m falling in a dark uneven way.

Anon!: Even for that I thank you.
Goodbye!: Thank you for that.

Anon!: What say you sir?
Goodbye!: What do you say, sir?

Anon!: Hang thou there upon the tomb, Praising her when I am dumb.
Goodbye!: Hang on the tomb, praising her when I’m dumb.

Anon!: Therefore then, thou gaudy gold, Hard food for Midas, I will none of thee.
Goodbye!: So, if you’re gaudy gold, I won’t be able to eat anything for Midas.

Anon!: Tis meet I should be used so, very meet.
Goodbye!: I’d be able to do that, very often.

Anon!: Where is our usual manager of mirth?
Goodbye!: Where is our usual manager of sex?

Anon!: Brutus and Caesar—what should be in that “Caesar”?
Goodbye!: Brutus and Caesar—what should be that “Caesar”?

Anon!: We will be married o' Sunday.
Goodbye!: We’ll be married on Sunday.

Anon!: Nothing, but this is so.
Goodbye!: Nothing, but this is true.

Anon!: Sit down and feed, and welcome to our table.
Goodbye!: Sit down and feed, and welcome to our table.

Anon!: But what though?
Goodbye!: But what?

Anon!: Groan!
Goodbye!: Groan!

Anon!: I confess the cape.
Goodbye!: I confess the cape.

Anon!: Ay, madam, from the reach of these my hands.
Goodbye!: Yes, madam, I’m out of my reach.

Anon!: Therefore, put money in thy purse.
Goodbye!: So, put your money in your purse.

Anon!: Part them!
Goodbye!: Part them!

Anon!: Ay, sir, they be ready.
Goodbye!: Yes, sir, they’re ready.

Anon!: Know you before whom, sir?
Goodbye!: Do you know whom, sir?

Anon!: I’ll none of it.
Goodbye!: I won’t do anything about it.

Anon!: Thou canst not.
Goodbye!: You can’t.

Anon!: As thou'rt a man, Give me the cup.
Goodbye!: As a man, give me the cup.

Anon!: How now?
Goodbye!: What’s going on?

Anon!: That she brought me up, I likewise give her most humble thanks.
Goodbye!: I thank her for bringing me up, and I thank her very humblely.

Anon!: So do I ever  For had I cursed now, I had cursed myself.
Goodbye!: I’d never cursed myself, because if I had cursed myself.

Anon!: How now, Lorenzo?
Goodbye!: What’s going on, Lorenzo?

Anon!: Wilt thou not, Jule?” It stinted and said “ay.” And stint thou too, I pray thee, Nurse, say I.
Goodbye!: I’m praying you, Nurse, say I.

Anon!: The gods forbid!
Goodbye!: The gods forbid!

Anon!: Is ’t not your trick?
Goodbye!: Isn’t that your trick?

Anon!: By Jove that thunders!
Goodbye!: By Jove that’s thundering!

Anon!: Hang him, foul collier!
Goodbye!: Hang him, foul collier!

Anon!: Gloucester’s eyes?
Goodbye!: Gloucester’s eyes?

Anon!: Helen, it is not so.
Goodbye!: Helena, it’s not true.

Anon!: In which array, brave soldier, doth he lie, Larding the plain, and by his bloody side, Yoke-fellow to his honor-owing wounds, The noble earl of Suffolk also lies.
Goodbye!: In which array, brave soldier, lies he lying, larding the plain, and by his bloody side, he spits his honorable wounds, and the noble earl of Suffolk lies.

Anon!: What is the course and drift of your compact?
Goodbye!: What’s the course and the direction of your pact?

Anon!: Let your epilogue alone.
Goodbye!: Leave your epilogue alone.

Anon!: If a man do not erect in this age his own tomb ere he dies, he shall live no longer in monument than the bell rings and the widow weeps.
Goodbye!: If a man doesn’t erect his own tomb in this age before he dies, he will not live in a monument more than the bell rings and the widow weeps.

Anon!: No, it is not possible you should love the enemy of France, Kate.
Goodbye!: No, it’s not possible you should love the enemy of France, Kate.

Anon!: I should be wise, for honesty’s a fool And loses that it works for.
Goodbye!: I should be wise, because honesty is a fool and it’s lost.

Anon!: Let her not say ’tis I that keep you here.
Goodbye!: Don’t let her say I’m keeping you here.

Anon!: O bosom black as death!
Goodbye!: Oh, death is black!

Anon!: Oh, fie upon them!
Goodbye!: Oh, be careful about them!

Anon!: What, is the jay more precious than the lark Because his feathers are more beautiful?
Goodbye!: What, is the jay more precious than the lark because his feathers are beautifulr?

Anon!: Thou an Egyptian puppet shalt be shown In Rome, as well as I.
