Goodbye!: You’ll be shown an Egyptian puppet in Rome, as well as I.

Anon!: To prison, eyes, ne'er look on liberty.
Goodbye!: Go to prison, eyes, and never look at liberty.

Anon!: But if all aim but this be leveled false, The supposition of the lady’s death Will quench the wonder of her infamy.
Goodbye!: But if all the aims are false, the supposition of the lady’s death will stop the wonder of her infamy.

Anon!: What makes him here?
Goodbye!: What makes him here?

Anon!: What should I do I do not?
Goodbye!: What should I do I do not do?

Anon!: Had I been any god of power, I would Have sunk the sea within the earth or ere It should the good ship so have swallowed and The fraughting souls within her.
Goodbye!: If I were any power god, I would have sunk the sea within the earth or sunk it if the good ship swallowed it and the fraught souls inside her.

Anon!: And so he goes to heaven.
Goodbye!: And so he goes to heaven.

Anon!: More, Domitius: My lord desires you presently.
Goodbye!: More, Domitius: My lord wants you now.

Anon!: I would be sorry, sir, but the fool should be as oft with your master as with my mistress: I think I saw your wisdom there.
Goodbye!: I’d be sorry, sir, but the fool should be as often as I am with my mistress: I think I saw your wisdom there.

Anon!: Ay, my good lord.
Goodbye!: Yes, my good lord.

Anon!: But now the duke of Buckingham and I Are come from visiting his majesty.
Goodbye!: But now the duke of Buckingham and I have come from visiting his majesty.

Anon!: If he fail of that, He will have other means to cut you off.
Goodbye!: If he fails to do that, he’ll have other means to cut you off.

Anon!: The reason that I gather he is mad, Besides this present instance of his rage, Is a mad tale he told today at dinner Of his own doors being shut against his entrance.
Goodbye!: I’m sure he’s insane, and besides this actual example of his rage, he told me a mad story of his own being shut against his entrance.

Anon!: A pound of man’s flesh taken from a man Is not so estimable, profitable neither, As flesh of muttons, beefs, or goats.
Goodbye!: A pound of man’s flesh taken from a man is not as valuable and profitable as meat from muttons, beefs, or goats.

Anon!: More, more, I prithee, more.
Goodbye!: More, more, please, more.

Anon!: If they deny to come, Swinge me them soundly forth unto their husbands.
Goodbye!: If they refuse to come, then go to my husbands.

Anon!: Hold you still.
Goodbye!: Hold your breath.

Anon!: I’ll go along, no such sight to be shown, But to rejoice in splendor of mine own.
Goodbye!: I’ll go along, no one can see that, but I’ll rejoice in my own splendor.

Anon!: I’ll teach you how to flow.
Goodbye!: I’ll teach you how to flow.

Anon!: Twas I that killed her.
Goodbye!: I was the one who killed her.

Anon!: Gentlemen both, we will not wake your patience.
Goodbye!: Gentlemen, we won’t wake up your patience.

Anon!: Your goods that lay at host, sir, in the Centaur.
Goodbye!: Your goods were the ones that were buried in the Centaur, sir.

Anon!: Then, you conclude, my grandam, he is dead.
Goodbye!: Then you conclude, my grandma, he’s dead.

Anon!: I am none of his skains-mates.
Goodbye!: I’m not one of his sains-mates.

Anon!: Truly, shepherd, in respect of itself, it is a good life; but in respect that it is a shepherd’s life, it is naught.
Goodbye!: It’s a good life, but it’s a good life, and it’s naughty.

Anon!: What in the contrary?
Goodbye!: What’s wrong?

Anon!: Where it seems best unto your royal self.
Goodbye!: Where it seems to you that you’re the best royal.

Anon!: No, and swears she never will.
Goodbye!: No, and she swears she never will.

Anon!: You think none but your sheets are privy to your wishes.
Goodbye!: You think nothing but your sheets are suited to your wishes.

Anon!: She shall be buried by her Antony.
Goodbye!: She will be buried by her Antony.

Anon!: What comfortable hour canst thou name, That ever graced me in thy company?
Goodbye!: What time can you name, who ever graced me in your company?

Anon!: Go, you cot-quean, go.
Goodbye!: Go, you cot-quean, go.

Anon!: And why, sir, must they so?
Goodbye!: And why, sir, do they have to?

Anon!: Whither is he going?
Goodbye!: Where is he going?

Anon!: Dost thou lie still?
Goodbye!: Do you lie still?

Anon!: It is a beast for Perseus.
Goodbye!: It’s a beast for Perseus.

Anon!: Your ladyship were best to have some guard about you if he come, for sure the man is tainted in ’s wits.
Goodbye!: If your ladyship was good to have some guard around you, you’d be sure the man is tainted by his wits.

Anon!: I’ll to my rest.
Goodbye!: I’ll go to sleep.

Anon!: Where is thy husband now?
Goodbye!: Where’s your husband now?

Anon!: Come, Vaughan.
Goodbye!: Come on, Vaughan.

Anon!: Dead.
Goodbye!: Dead.

Anon!: How came we ashore?
Goodbye!: How did we get ashore?

Anon!: We two alone will sing like birds i' th' cage.
Goodbye!: We two will sing like birds in the cage.

Anon!: Which they will make an obedient father.
Goodbye!: They’ll make you obedient father.

Anon!: My lord, your nobles, jealous of your absence, Seek through your camp to find you.
Goodbye!: My lord, your nobles, jealous of your absence, look for you in your camp.

Anon!: Go you with me, uncle of Exeter.
Goodbye!: Go with me, uncle of Exeter.

Anon!: Thou say’st the king grows mad.
Goodbye!: You say the king is getting mad.

Anon!: Ay, sir, in Pisa have I often been, Pisa renownèd for grave citizens.
Goodbye!: Yes, sir, I’ve often been in Pisa, and I’ve been redeemed for grave citizens.

Anon!: Now near enough.
Goodbye!: Now it’s near enough.

Anon!: You embrace your charge too willingly.
Goodbye!: You’re willing to take your charge too.

Anon!: His nurse?
Goodbye!: His nurse?

Anon!: My brother Gloucester’s voice.—Ay, I know thy errand.
Goodbye!: My brother Gloucester’s voice.—Yes, I know your errand.

Anon!: If my lady have not called up her steward Malvolio and bid him turn you out of doors, never trust me.
Goodbye!: If my lady hasn’t called up her steward Malvolio and told him to turn you out of the door, don’t trust me.

Anon!: Show me briefly how.
Goodbye!: Show me how.

Anon!: Thy adversary’s wife doth pray for thee.
Goodbye!: Your adversary’s wife is praying for you.

Anon!: Proof enough to misuse the Prince, to vex Claudio, to undo Hero, and kill Leonato.
Goodbye!: Proof enough to misuse the Prince, vex Claudio, undo Hero, and kill Leonato.

Anon!: We have seen the best of our time.
Goodbye!: We’ve seen the best of our time.

Anon!: When we have matched our rackets to these balls, We will in France, by God’s grace, play a set Shall strike his father’s crown into the hazard.
Goodbye!: When we’ve matched our rackets to these balls, we’ll play a set in France, by God’s grace, that will strike his father’s crown into the danger.

Anon!: Now, afore God, I am so vexed that every part about me quivers.
Goodbye!: Now, God, I’m so angry that every part of me is a slander.

Anon!: They say this town is full of cozenage, As nimble jugglers that deceive the eye, Dark-working sorcerers that change the mind, Soul-killing witches that deform the body, Disguised cheaters, prating mountebanks, And many suchlike liberties of sin.
Goodbye!: They say this town is full of sex, as nimble jugglers who deceive the eye, dark-working sorcerers who change the mind, soul-killing witches that de

Anon!: We will haste us.
Goodbye!: We’ll hurry.

Anon!: O ye gods, Render me worthy of this noble wife!
Goodbye!: Oh gods, make me worthy of this noble wife!

Anon!: I know that voice.
Goodbye!: I know that voice.

Anon!: Yet my heart Throbs to know one thing.
Goodbye!: But I’m afraid I can tell you one thing.

Anon!: No, good mother.
Goodbye!: No, good mother.

Anon!: He is a proper man’s picture, but alas, who can converse with a dumb show?
Goodbye!: He’s a good man’s picture, but who can converse with a dumb show?

Anon!: The Lord in heaven bless thee, noble Harry!
Goodbye!: The Lord in heaven bless you, noble Harry!

Anon!: What, art thou drawn among these heartless hinds?
Goodbye!: What, are you drawn from these heartless men?

Anon!: Lady, you come hither to be married to this count?
Goodbye!: Lady, you’ve come here to be married to this count?

Anon!: My daughter!
Goodbye!: My daughter!

Anon!: Where shall we dine?—O me!
Goodbye!: Where should we eat?—Oh, I’m!

Anon!: Wo, ha, ho!
Goodbye!: Oh, ha, ha!

Anon!: Why, sir, I gave the money for the rope.
Goodbye!: Why, sir, I gave the money for the rope.

Anon!: Where art thou now?
Goodbye!: Where are you now?

Anon!: Dear sir, forbear!
Goodbye!: Dear sir, stop!

Anon!: Oh, they take the part of a better wrestler than myself.
Goodbye!: Oh, they’re taking the role of a better wrestler than myself.

Anon!: Tomorrow, Caesar, I shall be furnished to inform you rightly Both what by sea and land I can be able To front this present time.
Goodbye!: Tomorrow, Caesar, I’ll be able to tell you rightly what I can do on land and sea at this moment.

Anon!: you know me well.
Goodbye!: you know me well.

Anon!: I hope so.
Goodbye!: I hope so.

Anon!: Stay!
Goodbye!: Stay!

Anon!: I will tell you everything, right as it fell out.
Goodbye!: I’ll tell you everything, right as it fell out.

Anon!: In the street I met him, And in his company that gentleman.
Goodbye!: I met him in the street, and he was that gentleman.

Anon!: What are you then determinèd to do?
Goodbye!: What are you going to do then?

Anon!: That a woman conceived me, I thank her.
Goodbye!: I thank her for having a woman who conceived me.

Anon!: You’re much deceived.
Goodbye!: You’re wrong.

Anon!: And here am I, and wood within this wood, Because I cannot meet my Hermia.
Goodbye!: And here are I, and wood in this wood, because I can’t meet my Hermia.

Anon!: It is a nipping and an eager air.
Goodbye!: It’s a nipping and an eager air.

Anon!: What, ho?
Goodbye!: What, you?

Anon!: I bade the rascal knock upon your gate And could not get him for my heart to do it.
Goodbye!: I told the rascal to knock on your gate and I couldn’t get him to do it.

Anon!: We’ll burn his body in the holy place, And with the brands fire the traitors' houses.
Goodbye!: We’ll burn his body in the holy place, and with the brands we’ll burn the traitors' houses.

Anon!: I am now from home, and out of that provision Which shall be needful for your entertainment.
Goodbye!: I’m now from home, and I’m out of that provision that will be necessary for your entertainment.

Anon!: Welcome.
Goodbye!: Welcome.

Anon!: Why, if thou never wast at court, thou never saw’st good manners; if thou never saw’st good manners, then thy manners must be wicked, and wickedness is sin, and sin is damnation.
Goodbye!: If you never was at court, you never saw good manners.

Anon!: He begins at curfew and walks till the first cock.
Goodbye!: He starts at the supper and walks up to the first cock.

Anon!: Something he left imperfect in the state which, since his coming forth, is thought of; which imports to the kingdom so much fear and danger that his personal return was most required and necessary.
Goodbye!: He left something in the state that, since he came out, is thought of.

Anon!: Both wind and tide stays for this gentleman, And I, to blame, have held him here too long.
Goodbye!: Wind and tide are the main reasons for this gentleman, and I’ve been here too long, to blame.

Anon!: Ha?
Goodbye!: Ha?

Anon!: These growing feathers plucked from Caesar’s wing Will make him fly an ordinary pitch, Who else would soar above the view of men And keep us all in servile fearfulness.
Goodbye!: These feathers that are growing from Caesar’s wing will make him fly like a normal pitch, who else would soar above the men’s view and keep us all in a hostile fear.

Anon!: Take you, as ’twere, some distant knowledge of him, As thus: “I know his father and his friends, And, in part, him.” Do you mark this, Reynaldo?
Goodbye!: Take you, as you were before, some distant knowledge of him, as if you were: “I know his father and his friends, and in part, he.” Do you remember this, Reynaldo?

Anon!: This is a man—old, wrinkled, faded, withered— And not a maiden, as thou say’st he is.
Goodbye!: This is a man—old, wrinkled, faded, withered—and not a maiden, as you say.

Anon!: But I know to be up late is to be up late.
Goodbye!: But I know that being up late is being up late.

Anon!: Be assured We go to use our hands and not our tongues.
Goodbye!: We’re going to use our hands and not our tongues.

Anon!: He’s fat, and scant of breath.— Here, Hamlet, take my napkin, rub thy brows.
Goodbye!: He’s fat, and has a little breath.— Here, Hamlet, take my napkin, rub your brows.

Anon!: We judge no less.—Uncle of Exeter, Enlarge the man committed yesterday That railed against our person.
Goodbye!: We’re not judged less.—Uncle of Exeter, please, add the man who railed against us yesterday.

Anon!: Lo thee!
Goodbye!: Oh, you!

Anon!: Tis a pageant, To keep us in false gaze.
Goodbye!: It’s a pageant to keep us in a false view.

Anon!: A friend should bear his friend’s infirmities, But Brutus makes mine greater than they are.
Goodbye!: A friend should bear his friend’s infirmities, but Brutus makes mine more powerful than they are.

Anon!: Be as ourself in Denmark.—Madam, come.
Goodbye!: Come on, sir.

Anon!: Into a thousand that I have forgotten.
Goodbye!: I’ve forgotten a thousand.

Anon!: If that be to care for nothing, sir, I would it would make you invisible.
Goodbye!: If that’s enough to care for nothing, I’d make you invisible.

Anon!: Titinius' face is upward.
Goodbye!: Titinius’s face is upward.

Anon!: I’ll pull thee by the lesser legs.
Goodbye!: I’ll pull you by the lesser legs.

Anon!: I shall take it, sir.
Goodbye!: I’ll take it, sir.

Anon!: Here comes the Countess.
Goodbye!: Here comes the Countess.

Anon!: How dost thou feel thyself now?
Goodbye!: How are you feeling now?

Anon!: I know my remedy.
Goodbye!: I know my remedy.

Anon!: Let me know.
Goodbye!: Let me know.

Anon!: Three proper young men of excellent growth and presence.
Goodbye!: Three good young men are excellent at achieving their goals.

Anon!: But have I fall'n, or no?
Goodbye!: But have I fallen, or not?

Anon!: I hear thou must, and nothing may prorogue it, On Thursday next be married to this county.
Goodbye!: I hear that you must marry this county on Thursday, and nothing can ruin it.

Anon!: Lo, here I lie, Never to rise again.
Goodbye!: Oh, I lie here, never to rise again.

Anon!: Ay, and a kind one too.
Goodbye!: Yes, and a kind one too.

Anon!: Commend me to thy lady, And bid her hasten all the house to bed, Which heavy sorrow makes them apt unto.
Goodbye!: Give my praise to your lady, and ask her to hurry up to bed, which makes them apt to do.

Anon!: We are the queen’s abjects and must obey.— Brother, farewell.
Goodbye!: We’re the queen’s abjects and we must obey.— Brother, goodbye.

Anon!: Not a whit.
Goodbye!: Not a moment.

Anon!: No, I warrant you.
Goodbye!: No, I’m sure you.

Anon!: I think the best grace of wit will shortly turn into silence, and discourse grow commendable in none only but parrots.
Goodbye!: I think the best wit will soon turn into silence, and discourse will be commended only by parrots.

Anon!: I’ll humbly signify what in his name, That magical word of war, we have effected: How with his banners and his well-paid ranks The ne’er-yet-beaten horse of Parthia We have jaded out o’ th’ field.
Goodbye!: I’ll tell you what we’ve done in his name, that magical word of war, and how we’ve jaded out of the field with his banners and his well-paid ranks.

Anon!: Go with me to the vault.
Goodbye!: Go with me to the vault.

Anon!: Portia is dead.
Goodbye!: Portia is dead.

Anon!: I have fled myself, and have instructed cowards To run and show their shoulders.
Goodbye!: I’ve fled myself and instructed cowards to run and show their shoulders.

Anon!: What is he for a fool that betroths himself to unquietness?
Goodbye!: What’s the reason for a fool who’s prone to a bad mood?

Anon!: One knocks.
Goodbye!: One knocks.

Anon!: Thou chid’st me oft for loving Rosaline.
Goodbye!: You’re always chiddling me for loving Rosaline.

Anon!: Thou chid’st me oft for loving Rosaline.
Goodbye!: You’re always chiddling me for loving Rosaline.

Anon!: Here is more news.
Goodbye!: Here’s more news.

Anon!: Well, Jove, not I, is the doer of this, and he is to be thanked.
Goodbye!: Well, Jove, not me, is the one who does this, and he deserves a thank you.

Anon!: Why may not imagination trace the noble dust of Alexander till he find it stopping a bunghole?
Goodbye!: Why can’t imagination trace the noble dust of Alexander until he finds it stopping a bunghole?

Anon!: Tooth that poisons if it bite, Mastiff, greyhound, mongrel grim,
Goodbye!: Tooth that poisons if it bites, Mastiff, greyhound, mongrel grim

Anon!: O Antony, Antony, Antony!
Goodbye!: Oh, Antony, Antony, Antony!

Anon!: The heavens do lour upon you for some ill. Move them no more by crossing their high will.
Goodbye!: The heavens are lurching on you for some ill, and you’ll never move them again by crossing their high will.

Anon!: I hear thou must, and nothing may prorogue it, On Thursday next be married to this county.
Goodbye!: I hear that you must marry this county on Thursday, and nothing can ruin it.

Anon!: With all my heart, and it doth much content me To hear him so inclined.
Goodbye!: I’m very happy to hear him so much.

Anon!: I desire you of more acquaintance, good Master Mustardseed.
Goodbye!: I want you to be more familiar, good Master Mustardseed.

Anon!: There the grown serpent lies.
Goodbye!: There lies the grown serpent.

Anon!: Let go my hand.
Goodbye!: Let go of my hand.

Anon!: Not I, unless the breath of heartsick groans, Mistlike, infold me from the search of eyes.
Goodbye!: I won’t, unless the groans’ breath is a mist that screams me away from the search of eyes.

Anon!: Fly further off, my lord, fly further off.
Goodbye!: Fly further off, my lord, fly further off.

Anon!: A thousand thousand!
Goodbye!: A thousand thousand!

Anon!: Fool, do not flatter.
Goodbye!: Fool, don’t flatter yourself.

Anon!: Now will I question Cassio of Bianca, A huswife that by selling her desires Buys herself bread and clothes.
Goodbye!: Now I’ll ask Cassio of Bianca, a huswife who sells her desires to buy bread and clothes.

Anon!: In happy time here comes the duke himself.
Goodbye!: Here comes the duke himself in a happy time.

Anon!: The shame itself doth speak For instant remedy.
Goodbye!: The shame itself is saying something to remedy it immediately.

Anon!: I defy lechery.
Goodbye!: I’m afraid of lechery.

Anon!: How, the nonpareil!
Goodbye!: How, the nonpareil!

Anon!: This is the truth, or let Benvolio die.
Goodbye!: This is the truth, or let Benvolio die.

Anon!: Thursday is near.
Goodbye!: Thursday is near.

Anon!: Friar, it cannot be.
Goodbye!: Friar, it can’t be.

Anon!: Lysander, whereto tends all this?
Goodbye!: Lysander, where do you do all this?

Anon!: He is all the mother’s, from the top to toe.
Goodbye!: He’s all the mother’s, from top to toe.

Anon!: And did not they Put on my brows this wreath of victory And bid me give it thee?
Goodbye!: And didn’t they put on my brows this wreath of victory and asked me to give it to you?

Anon!: To her, widow!
Goodbye!: To her, widow!

Anon!: I’ll bring thee word Straight how ’tis like to go.
Goodbye!: I’ll tell you exactly how it’s going to be.

Anon!: What news from her?
Goodbye!: What’s the news from her?

Anon!: I dare assure you, sir, ’tis almost two, And ’twill be supper time ere you come there.
Goodbye!: I’m sure it’s almost two, and it’ll be dinner time before you come here.

Anon!: I had a pass with him, rapier, scabbard, and all, and he gives me the stuck-in with such a mortal motion, that it is inevitable.
Goodbye!: I had a pass with him, rapier, scabbard, and all, and he gives me the slapstick with such a mortal motion that it’s inevitable.

Anon!: My name is Pistol called.
Goodbye!: My name is Pistol.

Anon!: Therefore play, music.—Prince, thou art sad.
Goodbye!: So play music, then.—Prince, you’re sad.

Anon!: Yet Caesar shall go forth, for these predictions Are to the world in general as to Caesar.
Goodbye!: But Caesar will go out, because these predictions are to the general world as to Caesar.

Anon!: Against all rules of nature, and must be driven To find out practices of cunning hell Why this should be.
Goodbye!: It’s not natural, and it’s not necessary to find out why this is so stupid.

Anon!: Lucius!
Goodbye!: Lucius!

Anon!: A love song, a love song.
Goodbye!: A love song, a love song.

Anon!: Has here writ a letter to you.
Goodbye!: Here’s a letter to you.

Anon!: I wonder none of you have thought of him.
Goodbye!: I wonder that none of you have thought of him.

Anon!: Come, come.
Goodbye!: Come on, come on.

Anon!: Marry, sir, we say we are none.
Goodbye!: We say we’re not.

Anon!: Who hath he left behind him general?
Goodbye!: Who left behind him general?

Anon!: Ay me, detested!
Goodbye!: Yes, I’m detested!

Anon!: His son was but a ward two years ago.
Goodbye!: His son was only a ward two years ago.

Anon!: I think it well, my lord.
Goodbye!: I think it’s good, my lord.

Anon!: Oh, the good gods!
Goodbye!: Oh, the good gods!

Anon!: Tis evermore the prologue to his sleep.
Goodbye!: He’s always a prologue to sleep.

Anon!: Tush, I may as well say the fool’s the fool.
Goodbye!: I’d rather say the fool’s the fool.

Anon!: Or what are you?
Goodbye!: Or what are you?

Anon!: Still be kind And eke out our performance with your mind.
Goodbye!: Be kind and make sure to make sure we’re all done with your mind.

Anon!: If we grow all to be pork-eaters, we shall not shortly have a rasher on the coals for money.
Goodbye!: If we all grow to be pork-eaters, we’ll have a rasher on the coals in the coming days for money.

Anon!: How now, Oswald?
Goodbye!: What’s going on, Oswald?

Anon!: Indeed, sweet love, I was coming to your house.
Goodbye!: Yes, sweet love, I was coming to your house.

Anon!: He’ll watch the horologe a double set If drink rock not his cradle.
Goodbye!: He’ll watch the horologe a double set if he doesn’t drink his cradle.

Anon!: He, upon some action, Is now in durance at Malvolio’s suit, A gentleman and follower of my lady’s.
Goodbye!: He’s in a durance now, after some action, at Malvolio’s suit, a gentleman and follower of my lady’s.

Anon!: Pour on, I will endure.
Goodbye!: I’ll endure.

Anon!: And yet no further than a wanton’s bird, That lets it hop a little from his hand Like a poor prisoner in his twisted gyves, And with a silken thread plucks it back again, So loving-jealous of his liberty.
Goodbye!: And yet it’s not far from a bird, who lets it hop a little from his hand like a poor prisoner in his twisted gyves, and plucks it back with a silky

Anon!: Thy grace shall have it.
Goodbye!: Your grace will have it.

Anon!: We therefore have great cause of thankfulness And shall forget the office of our hand Sooner than quittance of desert and merit According to the weight and worthiness.
Goodbye!: We’ll forget the handwriting of our hands sooner than the rebirth of desert and merit, according to the weight and worthiness.

Anon!: Lead away.
Goodbye!: Lead away.

Anon!: Will you pluck your sword out of his pilcher by the ears?
Goodbye!: Will you pluck your sword out of his pilcher by the ears?

Anon!: Let not the Nurse lie with thee in thy chamber.
Goodbye!: Don’t let the Nurse lie with you in your room.

Anon!: My lord, from head to foot.
Goodbye!: My lord, from head to foot.

Anon!: If e'er thou wast thyself and these woes thine, Thou and these woes were all for Rosaline.
Goodbye!: If you were yourself and your pains were yours, you and your pain were all for Rosaline.

Anon!: Let them not live to taste this land’s increase, That would with treason wound this fair land’s peace.
Goodbye!: Don’t let them live to taste this land’s growth, which would wound this fair land’s peace with treason.

Anon!: The noble Brutus is ascended.
Goodbye!: The noble Brutus is ascended.

Anon!: Go to thy cold bed and warm thee.
Goodbye!: Go to your cold bed and warm yourself up.

Anon!: My learnèd lord, we pray you to proceed And justly and religiously unfold Why the law Salic that they have in France Or should or should not bar us in our claim.
Goodbye!: My learned lord, we ask you to proceed and explain why the law that they have in France or should or shouldn’t stop us from defending us.

Anon!: I prithee, peace.
Goodbye!: Please, calm down.

Anon!: Cassio!
Goodbye!: Cassio!

Anon!: Our fortune lies Upon this jump.
Goodbye!: Our fortune lies on this jump.

Anon!: At a word, I am not.
Goodbye!: I’m not.

Anon!: Be patient.
Goodbye!: Be patient.

Anon!: Out of their saddles into the dirt, and thereby hangs a tale.
Goodbye!: They’re dragging their saddles out of the dirt, and then a story is hung.

Anon!: I mean, in a sort.
Goodbye!: I mean, in a way.

Anon!: And the creature run from the cur?
Goodbye!: And the creature ran away from the curfew?

Anon!: The same indeed, a very valiant fellow.
Goodbye!: That’s true, a very valiant fellow.

Anon!: Anon!
Goodbye!: Goodbye!

Anon!: Tie up my love’s tongue.
Goodbye!: Tie up my love’s tongue.

Anon!: But for your husband, He is noble, wise, judicious, and best knows The fits o' th' season.
Goodbye!: But for your husband, he’s noble, wise, judicious, and knows the best season.

Anon!: Let’s have the tongs and the bones.
Goodbye!: Let’s have the tongs and the bones.

Anon!: Why, then, tomorrow night, or Tuesday morn.
Goodbye!: Well then, tomorrow night, or Tuesday morning.

Anon!: Thy father hath his life.
Goodbye!: Your father has his life.

Anon!: And so am I for no woman.
Goodbye!: And I am for no woman.

Anon!: As a walled town is more worthier than a village, so is the forehead of a married man more honorable than the bare brow of a bachelor.
Goodbye!: As a walled town is more worthless than a village, the forehead of a married man is honorable than the bare brow of a bachelor.

Anon!: I once did lend my body for his wealth, Which but for him that had your husband’s ring Had quite miscarried.
Goodbye!: I gave my body once for his wealth, which was quite miscarried for him who had your husband’s ring.

Anon!: But I with blowing the fire shall warm myself.
Goodbye!: But I’ll warm myself up with blowing the fire.

Anon!: Sweet bodements!
Goodbye!: Sweet bodements!

Anon!: But if you be remembered, I did not bid you mar it to the time.
Goodbye!: But if you remember, I didn’t ask you to go ahead.

Anon!: Good night, good doctor.
Goodbye!: Good night, good doctor.

Anon!: He wonders to what end you have assembled Such troops of citizens to come to him, His grace not being warned thereof before.
Goodbye!: He wonders how many troops you’ve assembled to come to him, without being warned of it before.

Anon!: But he comes armed in his fortune and prevents the slander of his wife.
Goodbye!: But he’s armed with his fortune and is not responsible for the slander of his wife.

Anon!: How if they will not?
Goodbye!: What if they don’t want to?

Anon!: Were not my doors locked up and I shut out?
Goodbye!: Didn’t my doors lock up and I’ve shut out?

Anon!: I see, sir, you have found the goldsmith now.
Goodbye!: I see, sir, you’ve found the goldsmith now.

Anon!: Read it, Mark Antony!
Goodbye!: Read it, Mark Antony!

Anon!: Who bare my letter, then, to Romeo?
Goodbye!: Who bared my letter to Romeo?

Anon!: We are glad the Dauphin is so pleasant with us.
Goodbye!: We’re glad the Dauphin is so friendly with us.

Anon!: I am not here.
Goodbye!: I’m not here.

Anon!: By this hand, they are scoundrels and substractors that say so of him.
Goodbye!: By this hand, they’re scoundrels and substractors who say so about him.

Anon!: Is he alone?
Goodbye!: Is he alone?

Anon!: Leave it to his discretion, and let us listen to the moon.
Goodbye!: Leave it to his discretion, and let’s listen to the moon.

Anon!: If either of you know any inward impediment why you should not be conjoined, charge you on your souls to utter it.
Goodbye!: If either of you knows any obstacle in the way you should not be accompanied, then you’ll have to ask your souls to tell me.

Anon!: Ay, marry, am I, sir; and now ’tis plotted!
Goodbye!: Yes, I am, sir.

Anon!: So please your grace, the Prologue is addressed.
Goodbye!: Please, please, I’m going to talk about the Prologue.

Anon!: Then let the trumpets sound The tucket sonance and the note to mount, For our approach shall so much dare the field That England shall couch down in fear and yield.
Goodbye!: Then let the trumpets sound the tucket sonance and the note to mount, because our approach will so dare the field that England will be afraid and yield.

Anon!: Well mayst thou woo, and happy be thy speed.
Goodbye!: Well, you can woo and be happy to be your speed.

Anon!: Is love a tender thing?
Goodbye!: Is love a tender thing?

Anon!: It cannot be.
Goodbye!: It can’t be.

Anon!: And I in all unwillingness will go.
Goodbye!: And I’m not ready to go.

Anon!: When the butt is out, we will drink water.
Goodbye!: When the butt is out, we’ll drink water.

Anon!: Thou mightst have done this without thy beard and gown.
Goodbye!: You could have done this without your beard and gown.

Anon!: Go, hang yourselves all!
Goodbye!: Go hang yourself all!

Anon!: Thou shalt serve me.
Goodbye!: You’ll serve me.

Anon!: No, ’tis not so deep as a well nor so wide as a church-door, but ’tis enough, ’twill serve.
Goodbye!: No, it’s not as deep as a well or as wide as a church door, but it’s enough, it’ll serve.

Anon!: He might have chid me so, for, in good faith, I am a child to chiding.
Goodbye!: He might have chidled me like that, because I’m a child who’s chiding.

Anon!: Then call we this the field of Agincourt, Fought on the day of Crispin Crispianus.
Goodbye!: Then we call this the field of Agincourt, a land that was ruined by Crispin Crispianus.

Anon!: We here attend you.
Goodbye!: We’re here to help you.

Anon!: I am a spirit of no common rate.
Goodbye!: I’m not a common man.

Anon!: Now all the youth of England are on fire, And silken dalliance in the wardrobe lies.
Goodbye!: Now all the young men of England are on fire, and there’s a silky dalliance in the wardrobe.

Anon!: I scorn you not.
Goodbye!: I don’t scorn you.

Anon!: Virtue?
Goodbye!: Virtue?

Anon!: This I made good to you In our last conference, passed in probation with you, How you were borne in hand, how crossed, the instruments, Who wrought with them, and all things else that might To half a soul and to a notion crazed Say, “Thus did Banquo.”      You made it known to us.
Goodbye!: I made this good to you in our last conference, passed it to you in probation, how you were borne in hand, how crossed, the instruments, who wrought with them, and all other things that could be a half-

Anon!: Here is my bed.
Goodbye!: Here is my bed.

Anon!: That is where we dined, Where Dowsabel did claim me for her husband.
Goodbye!: That’s where we ate, where Dowsabel claimed me for her husband.

Anon!: This weaves itself perforce into my business.
Goodbye!: This is what I’m doing.

Anon!: Here comes his Majesty.
Goodbye!: Here comes his Majesty.

Anon!: Never in your life, I think, unless you see canary put me down.
Goodbye!: I think you’ll never be alive unless you see a canary put me down.

Anon!: For I am sick when I do look on thee.
Goodbye!: I’m sick when I look at you.

Anon!: There it goes, Silver!
Goodbye!: Here it goes, Silver!

Anon!: I do consent—    Prick him down, Antony.
Goodbye!: I agree— Prick him down, Antony.

Anon!: But, too unruly deer, he breaks the pale And feeds from home.
Goodbye!: But he’s a too unruly deer, and he’s breaking the pale bones and snucks away from home.

Anon!: Wherefore?
Goodbye!: Why?

Anon!: My good friends, hark!
Goodbye!: My good friends, listen!

Anon!: But he protests he loves you And needs no other suitor but his likings To take the safest occasion by the front To bring you in again.
Goodbye!: But he says he loves you and doesn’t need any other suitor except his liking to take the safest occasion by the front to bring you back in.

Anon!: I will acquit you.
Goodbye!: I’ll acquit you.

Anon!: If I see anything tonight why I should not marry her, tomorrow in the congregation, where I should wed, there will I shame her.
Goodbye!: If I see anything tonight why I shouldn’t marry her, tomorrow I’ll shame her in the congregation where I should marry her.

Anon!: That’s my good son.
Goodbye!: That’s my good son.

Anon!: These clothes are good enough to drink in, and so be these boots too.
Goodbye!: These clothes are good enough to drink in, and so are these boots too.

Anon!: I did not see him since.
Goodbye!: I didn’t see him since.

Anon!: I pray you, fail me not.
Goodbye!: Please, don’t fail me.

Anon!: Away, Tybalt.
Goodbye!: Go away, Tybalt.

Anon!: But are my brother’s powers set forth?
Goodbye!: But are my brother’s powers set up?

Anon!: How the moon sleeps with Endymion And would not be awaked.
Goodbye!: How the moon sleeps with Endymion and doesn’t want to be awake.

Anon!: I beseech thee, youth, Put not another sin upon my head By urging me to fury.
Goodbye!: I beg you, young man, don’t put another sin on my head by telling me to fury.

Anon!: I am all the daughters of my father’s house, And all the brothers too—and yet I know not.
Goodbye!: I’m all the daughters of my father’s house, and all the brothers too—and yet I don’t know.

Anon!: Too late, good Diomed.
Goodbye!: Too late, good Diomed.

Anon!: Call him.
Goodbye!: Call him.

Anon!: They are about the court, And, as I think, they have already order This night to play before him.
Goodbye!: They’re on the court, and I think they’ve already ordered this night to play with him.

Anon!: I dreamt tonight that I did feast with Caesar, And things unlucky charge my fantasy.
Goodbye!: I dreamed tonight that I feasted with Caesar, and things unlucky are causing my fantasy.

Anon!: I have no food for thee.
Goodbye!: I don’t have food for you.

Anon!: Mine ache to think on ’t.
Goodbye!: I’m sorry to think about it.

Anon!: Would they had stayed.
Goodbye!: They wish they had stayed.

Anon!: My master’s.
Goodbye!: My master’s house.

Anon!: Why, this is a more exquisite song than the other.
Goodbye!: This is a more exquisite song than the other one.

Anon!: I am for you.
Goodbye!: I’m for you.

Anon!: A bridegroom, say you?
Goodbye!: A bridegroom, what do you say?

Anon!: Eyes, look your last.
Goodbye!: Eyes, look at your last sight.

Anon!: Dove-feathered raven, wolvish-ravening lamb!
Goodbye!: A raven, ravening lamb, feathered by doves!

Anon!: And yours of Helena to me bequeath, Whom I do love and will do till my death.
Goodbye!: And you give Helena to me, who I love and will do until my death.

Anon!: Whither should they come?
Goodbye!: Where should they come?

Anon!: But died thy sister of her love, my boy?
Goodbye!: But did your sister die of her love, my boy?

Anon!: Both one and other he denies me now.
Goodbye!: Both of us denies me any further.

Anon!: Here’s drink.
Goodbye!: Here’s a drink.

Anon!: We have two hours To furnish us.
Goodbye!: We have two hours to get out of here.

Anon!: No, I will go seek Some ditch wherein to die.
Goodbye!: No, I’ll go find some ditch where I’ll die.

Anon!: Kindness in women, not their beauteous looks, Shall win my love, and so I take my leave, In resolution as I swore before.
Goodbye!: I’ll leave my mind to be as kind as I swore before.

Anon!: Right glad I am he was not at this fray.
Goodbye!: I’m glad he wasn’t in this fight.

Anon!: You amaze me.
Goodbye!: You’re surprised by me.

Anon!: How now, how now?
Goodbye!: What’s going on, what’s going on?

Anon!: How tartly that gentleman looks!
Goodbye!: How tartly that gentleman looks!

Anon!: Sir, he answered me in the roundest manner he would not.
Goodbye!: Sir, he answered me in the roundest manner he wouldn’t.

Anon!: I humbly thank your ladyship.
Goodbye!: Thank you very much.

Anon!: Think on me, That am with Phoebus’ amorous pinches black And wrinkled deep in time.
Goodbye!: Think about me, that Phoebus’ amorous pinches black and wrinkled deep in time.

Anon!: Lucius, awake.
Goodbye!: Lucius, awake.

Anon!: Shall we part, sweet girl?
Goodbye!: Shall we play, sweet girl?

Anon!: Farewell, kind Charmian.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, kind Charmian.

Anon!: That a monster should be such a natural!
Goodbye!: That a monster should be so natural!

Anon!: I will be free from thee.
Goodbye!: I’ll be free from you.

Anon!: Why “with some little train,” my Lord of Buckingham?
Goodbye!: Why “with some little train,” my Lord of Buckingham?

Anon!: And I, my lord.
Goodbye!: And I, my lord.

Anon!: Therefore know I have earned of Don John a thousand ducats.
Goodbye!: So I know that Don John has earned a thousand ducats.

Anon!: I met the youthful lord at Lawrence' cell, And gave him what becomèd love I might, Not stepping o'er the bounds of modesty.
Goodbye!: I met the young lord at Lawrence’s cell and gave him what I could be like, not stepping beyond the limits of modesty.

Anon!: The king doth love you well.
Goodbye!: The king loves you very much.

Anon!: O Cassius, Far from this country Pindarus shall run, Where never Roman shall take note of him.
Goodbye!: Oh Cassius, Pindarus will run away from this country, where never Romans will take notice of him.

Anon!: Stanley, he is your wife’s son.
Goodbye!: Stanley, he’s your wife’s son.

Anon!: Our enemies have beat us to the pit.
Goodbye!: Our enemies have beat us to the pit.

Anon!: Sometime am I All wound with adders who with cloven tongues Do hiss me into madness.
Goodbye!: Sometime I’ve been wound with adders who have cloven tongues to make me mad.

Anon!: I am not furnished with the present money.
Goodbye!: I don’t have the money to pay for it.

Anon!: The thought whereof Doth, like a poisonous mineral, gnaw my inwards, And nothing can or shall content my soul Till I am evened with him, wife for wife.
Goodbye!: The thought of gnawing my soul is like a poisonous mineral, and nothing can or will be a good thing for me until I’m reunited with him, wife for wife.

Anon!: Her hair, what color?
Goodbye!: What color is her hair?

Anon!: Antonio, I am married to a wife Which is as dear to me as life itself.
Goodbye!: Antonio, I’m married to a wife as dear to me as life itself.

Anon!: Look, sir, I bleed.
Goodbye!: Look, sir, I’m bleeding.

Anon!: Go with me to the vault.
Goodbye!: Go with me to the vault.

Anon!: Nay, an you will not, sir, I’ll take my heels.
Goodbye!: No, if you don’t want me to, sir, I’ll take my heels.

Anon!: Out upon it, old carrion!
Goodbye!: Get out of here, old carrion!

Anon!: Let them affright thee.
Goodbye!: Let them scolde you.

Anon!: Master Constable, you go not the way to examine.
Goodbye!: Master Constable, you’re not going to go the way to examine.

Anon!: What mean’st thou, that thou help’st me not?
Goodbye!: What do you mean, that you don’t help me?

Anon!: And I know, my lord, If law, authority, and power deny not, It will go hard with poor Antonio.
Goodbye!: And I know, my lord, if law, authority, and power don’t deny it, it’ll go hard with poor Antonio.

Anon!: But notwithstanding, haste.
Goodbye!: But hurry up.

Anon!: You are very sensible, and yet you miss my sense: I mean, Hortensio is afeard of you.
Goodbye!: You’re very sensible, but you’re not aware of me.

Anon!: Sir, shall I to this lady?
Goodbye!: Sir, should I go to this lady?

Anon!: We’ll visit Caliban, my slave who never Yields us kind answer.
Goodbye!: We’ll visit Caliban, my slave who never gives us a kind answer.

Anon!: He made you for a highway to my bed, But I, a maid, die maiden-widowèd.
Goodbye!: He made you to go on a highway to my bed, but I die as a maiden.

Anon!: Bless thee from whirlwinds, star-blasting, and taking!
Goodbye!: Help you avoid whirlwinds, star-blasting, and taking!

Anon!: What is this That rises like the issue of a king, And wears upon his baby-brow the round And top of sovereignty?
Goodbye!: What’s this that looks like a king, and wears on his baby-brow the round and top of his sovereignty?

Anon!: Signior Hortensio, ’twixt such friends as we Few words suffice.
Goodbye!: Signior Hortensio, we’re two hundred friends like you.

Anon!: A pleasing cordial, princely Buckingham, Is this thy vow unto my sickly heart.
Goodbye!: A pleasing cordial, princely Buckingham, you’re sending this vow to my sick heart.

Anon!: Give you good night.
Goodbye!: Good night.

Anon!: Ay, noble lord.
Goodbye!: Yes, noble lord.

Anon!: Go with me, Silvius.
Goodbye!: Go with me, Silvius.

Anon!: And let his knights have colder looks among you.
Goodbye!: And let his knights have colder eyes among you.

Anon!: Never, my lord.
Goodbye!: Never, my lord.

Anon!: Dorset, embrace him.—Hastings, love Lord Marquess.
Goodbye!: Dorset, embrace him.—Hastings, love Lord Marquess.

Anon!: Be large in mirth.
Goodbye!: Be big in the mud.

Anon!: Draw together.
Goodbye!: Draw together.

Anon!: If he be not in love with some woman, there is no believing old signs.
Goodbye!: If he doesn’t love a woman, there’s no way to believe old signs.

Anon!: I will deny thee nothing!
Goodbye!: I won’t deny you anything!

Anon!: Tis a good silling, I warrant you, or I will change it.
Goodbye!: It’s a good silling, I assure you, or I’ll change it.

Anon!: Tomorrow or next day they will be here.
Goodbye!: Tomorrow or the next day they’ll be here.

Anon!: But these cannot I command to any utterance of harmony.
Goodbye!: But I can’t command these to a semblance of harmony.

Anon!: Prithee, no more.
Goodbye!: Please, don’t worry.

Anon!: Mad call I it, for, to define true madness, What is ’t but to be nothing else but mad?
Goodbye!: I’m calling it mad, because I’m trying to define true madness, what is it that I’m only going to be insane?

Anon!: No.
Goodbye!: No.

Anon!: This found I on my tent this morning.
Goodbye!: This was my first time in my tent this morning.

Anon!: It is well done and fitting for a princess Descended of so many royal kings.
Goodbye!: It’s well done and fitting for a princess who’s been ruled by so many royal kings.

Anon!: Come on, come on.
Goodbye!: Come on, come on.

Anon!: What does he say of Brutus?
Goodbye!: What does he say about Brutus?

Anon!: Not th’ imperious show Of the full-fortuned Caesar ever shall Be brooched with me.
Goodbye!: I won’t be able to talk about the imperious show of the full-fortuned Caesar ever.

Anon!: Give us kind keepers, heavens!
Goodbye!: Give us kind keepers, heavens!

Anon!: We will.
Goodbye!: We will.

Anon!: Good morrow, Brutus.
Goodbye!: Good morning, Brutus.

Anon!: Fore heaven, an excellent song.
Goodbye!: Fore heaven, this is an excellent song.

Anon!: Oh, he is even in my mistress' case, Just in her case.
Goodbye!: Oh, he’s just in my mistress’s case, just in her case.

Anon!: All my pretty ones?
Goodbye!: All my pretty ones?

Anon!: Ay, with Cassio.
Goodbye!: Yes, with Cassio.

Anon!: Nay, but say true, does it work upon him?
Goodbye!: No, but I’m sure he’s doing it?

Anon!: But, my good lord, this boy is forest-born And hath been tutored in the rudiments Of many desperate studies by his uncle, Whom he reports to be a great magician Obscurèd in the circle of this forest.
Goodbye!: But, my good lord, this boy is born in the forest and has been tutored in the rudiments of many desperate studies by his uncle, who he claims to be a great magician.

Anon!: Do you see yonder cloud that’s almost in shape of a camel?
Goodbye!: Do you see a cloud that’s almost like a camel?

Anon!: As from a bear a man would run for life, So fly I from her that would be my wife.
Goodbye!: As far as a man would run for life from a bear, I would run away from her that would be my wife.

Anon!: Lepidus is high-colored.
Goodbye!: Lepidus is high-colored.

Anon!: It is his hand, my lord, but I hope his heart is not in the contents.
Goodbye!: It’s his handwriting, my lord, but I hope his heart doesn’t matter.

Anon!: Besides, our hands are hard.
Goodbye!: Besides, our hands are hard.

Anon!: But yet methinks it is very sultry and hot for my complexion.
Goodbye!: But I think it’s very hot and sultry for my complexion.

Anon!: What is that noise?
Goodbye!: What’s that noise?

Anon!: But it is certain I am loved of all ladies, only you excepted.
Goodbye!: But it’s certain that I’m all ladies, except you.

Anon!: Patience unmoved!
Goodbye!: Be calm!

Anon!: Come, come, thou art as hot a Jack in thy mood as any in Italy, and as soon moved to be moody, and as soon moody to be moved.
Goodbye!: Come on, you’re as hot a Jack in your mood as any other in Italy, and you’re as soon as you’re feeling moody, and so soon as you’re feeling moody.

Anon!: Two o'clock is your hour?
Goodbye!: You’re at two o'clock?

Anon!: Caesar speaks.
Goodbye!: Caesar speaks.

Anon!: When Caesar says, “do this,” it is performed.
Goodbye!: When Caesar says “do this,” it’s performed.

Anon!: Prove true, imagination, oh, prove true, That I, dear brother, be now ta'en for you!
Goodbye!: I’m going to be for you now, brother.

Anon!: Strike, I say!
Goodbye!: Strike, I say!

Anon!: Ay, widow Dido.
Goodbye!: Yes, widow Dido.

Anon!: You can fool no more money out of me at this throw.
Goodbye!: You can’t fool me out of money at this throw.

Anon!: No, sir, the worse.
Goodbye!: No, sir, the worse.

Anon!: Abhorrèd slave, Which any print of goodness wilt not take, Being capable of all ill!
Goodbye!: A savage slave, which any kind of goodness you can’t take, capable of all evil!

Anon!: Let it be a quarrel between us, if you live.
Goodbye!: Let it be a fight between us, if you live.

Anon!: Lives he, good uncle?
Goodbye!: Is he alive, uncle?

Anon!: Good morrow, Richmond.
Goodbye!: Good morning, Richmond.

Anon!: And till the tears that she hath shed for thee Like envious floods o'errun her lovely face, She was the fairest creature in the world— And yet she is inferior to none.
Goodbye!: And until she shed tears for you like a flood ruined her beautiful face, she was the fairest creature in the world—and yet she is inferior to none.

Anon!: Why then, alas, Do I put up that womanly defense, To say I have done no harm?
Goodbye!: Why then, alas, do I put up that womanly defense to say I’ve done nothing wrong?

Anon!: What, drawn, and talk of peace?
Goodbye!: What, drawn, and talk about peace?

Anon!: I remember.
Goodbye!: I remember.

Anon!: Your constancy Hath left you unattended.
Goodbye!: Your constant presence has left you unattended.

Anon!: Nor shalt not till necessity be served.
Goodbye!: And he won’t wait until the need is met.

Anon!: Our size of sorrow, Proportioned to our cause, must be as great As that which makes it.
Goodbye!: Our sorrow, proportioned to our cause, must be as great as the one that makes it.

Anon!: Come, sir, what letters had you late from France?
Goodbye!: Come, sir, what letters did you have from France late?

Anon!: Yes, and shall do till the pangs of death shake him.
Goodbye!: Yes, and he’ll do it until death shakes him.

Anon!: Go, coward as thou art.
Goodbye!: Go, coward as you are.

Anon!: Octavius, lead your battle softly on, Upon the left hand of the even field.
Goodbye!: Octavius, lead your battle softly on the left side of the field.

Anon!: Yet let me weep for such a feeling loss.
Goodbye!: But let me cry for such a loss.

Anon!: And weep ye now, seeing she is advanced Above the clouds, as high as heaven itself?
Goodbye!: And now you cry, seeing she’s up above the clouds, as high as heaven itself?

Anon!: What of that?
Goodbye!: What about that?

Anon!: By my troth, a pleasant-spirited lady.
Goodbye!: I swear, a pleasant-spirited lady.

Anon!: Am I your man?
Goodbye!: Am I your man?

Anon!: I will do so.
Goodbye!: I’ll do so.

Anon!: Where souls do couch on flowers, we’ll hand in hand, And with our sprightly port make the ghosts gaze.
Goodbye!: Where souls sleep on flowers, we’ll hand in hand, and with our sprightly port, we’ll see the ghosts.

Anon!: I would thou hadst my bones and I thy news.
Goodbye!: I wish you had my bones and I had your news.

Anon!: O, you give me ill counsel.
Goodbye!: Oh, you’re giving me a bad advice.

Anon!: You will compel me, then, to read the will?
Goodbye!: You’ll have to convince me to read the will?

Anon!: Sir, sir, sir—
Goodbye!: Sir, sir, sir—

Anon!: D'elbow.”      “D'elbow,”    “De nick,”  “De nick.”  “De chin.” “De sin.”
Goodbye!: D'elbow.” “D'elbow,” “De nick,” “De nick.” “De chin.” “De sin.”

Anon!: Why art thou angry?
Goodbye!: Why are you angry?

Anon!: I’ll be at thy elbow.
Goodbye!: I’ll be at your elbow.

Anon!: Take thy fair hour, Laertes.
Goodbye!: Take your fair hour, Laertes.

Anon!: I shall, my lord.
Goodbye!: I will, my lord.

Anon!: Confined together In the same fashion as you gave in charge, Just as you left them, all prisoners, sir, In the line grove which weather-fends your cell.
Goodbye!: They were arranged in the same manner you gave them in charge, as you left them, all prisoners, sir, in the grove which protects your cell.

Anon!: Coming from Sardis, on our former ensign Two mighty eagles fell, and there they perched, Gorging and feeding from our soldiers' hands, Who to Philippi here consorted us.
Goodbye!: Coming from Sardis, two mighty eagles fell on our former ship, and they perched there, sanding and feeding from our soldiers' hands, who brought Philippi here to rescue us.

Anon!: You know I gave it you even now.
Goodbye!: You know I gave it to you right now.

Anon!: Reputation, reputation, reputation!
Goodbye!: Reputation, reputation, reputation!

Anon!: Fie, fie, thou shamest thy shape, thy love, thy wit, Which, like a usurer, abound’st in all And usest none in that true use indeed Which should bedeck thy shape, thy love, thy wit.
Goodbye!: You shame your shape, your love, your wit, which, like a usurer, is all over there and doesn’t use any of those true uses that should bedecked by your shape, your love, your

Anon!: O' Thursday be it, then.— Go you to Juliet ere you go to bed.
Goodbye!: Oh, Thursday will be it, then.—Go to Juliet before you go to bed.

Anon!: Vouchsafe to those that have not read the story That I may prompt them; and of such as have, I humbly pray them to admit th' excuse Of time, of numbers, and due course of things, Which cannot in their huge and proper life Be here presented.
Goodbye!: I hope to those who haven’t read the story that I can tell them to tell them, and I humbly ask them to admit the excuse of time, numbers, and course of things that can’t be presented here

Anon!: What was th' impediment that broke this off?
Goodbye!: What was the obstacle that broke this off?

Anon!: Let me alone.
Goodbye!: Let me go.

Anon!: I think I had.
Goodbye!: I think I had.

Anon!: Oh, villainous!
Goodbye!: Oh, you’re villainous!

Anon!: And golden Phoebus never be beheld Of eyes again so royal!
Goodbye!: And golden Phoebus will never be seen from the eyes so royal again!

Anon!: Here comes one o' the parings.
Goodbye!: Here comes one of the parings.

Anon!: Adieu.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: Hold, there’s half my coffer.
Goodbye!: Hold on, there’s half my money.

Anon!: Take it thankfully.
Goodbye!: Take it thankfully.

Anon!: An if thou couldst, thou couldst not make him live.
Goodbye!: If you could, you couldn’t make him live.

Anon!: He is hid at Lawrence' cell.
Goodbye!: He’s hid in Lawrence’s cell.

Anon!: Is it so, countrymen?
Goodbye!: Is that true, countrymen?

Anon!: To be now a sensible man, by and by a fool, and presently a beast!
Goodbye!: To be a sensible man, by and by a fool, and now a beast!

Anon!: Lysander and myself will fly this place.
Goodbye!: Lysander and I will fly this place.

Anon!: Upon such sacrifices, my Cordelia, The gods themselves throw incense.
Goodbye!: My Cordelia, the gods themselves throw incense on such sacrifices.

Anon!: Have you got leave to go to shrift today?
Goodbye!: Have you got permission to go to shrift today?

Anon!: Now is the sun upon the highmost hill Of this day’s journey, and from nine till twelve Is three long hours, yet she is not come.
Goodbye!: Now the sun is shining on the highest hill of this day’s journey, and from nine to twelve she’s three hours long, but she’s not coming.

Anon!: I’ll make her come, I warrant you, presently.
Goodbye!: I’ll make her come, I assure you, now.

Anon!: Go make thee ready; Our letters are prepared.
Goodbye!: Go ahead, we’ll send you our letters.

Anon!: Tis true.
Goodbye!: That’s true.

Anon!: A very forward March-chick!
Goodbye!: A very forward March-chick!

Anon!: Well are you welcome to the open air.
Goodbye!: Well, welcome to the open air.

Anon!: He misses not much.
Goodbye!: He doesn’t miss anything.

Anon!: What makes that frontlet on?
Goodbye!: What’s the frontline on that?

Anon!: If any, speak—for him have I offended.
Goodbye!: If there are any, speak—for he has offended me.

Anon!: She took the ring of me.
Goodbye!: She took the ring of me.

Anon!: For two, and sound ones too.
Goodbye!: For two, and sound ones too.

Anon!: I will not do thee so much wrong to wake thee.
Goodbye!: I won’t do you so much wrong to wake you up.

Anon!: Give him this deed, And let him sign it.
Goodbye!: Give him this deed and let him sign it.

Anon!: O blessèd, blessèd night!
Goodbye!: Oh, blessed, blessed night!

Anon!: He brings great news.
Goodbye!: He’s got great news.

Anon!: Alas, the storm is come again!
Goodbye!: Oh, the storm is coming again!

Anon!: What is it ye would see?
Goodbye!: What do you want?

Anon!: How dost thou, Guildenstern?
Goodbye!: How are you, Guildenstern?

Anon!: I know it is the sun that shines so bright.
Goodbye!: I know that the sun is shining so bright.

Anon!: Old lord, I cannot blame thee, Who am myself attached with weariness To th' dulling of my spirits.
Goodbye!: Old lord, I can’t blame you, who is attached to my sanity to dulling my spirits.

Anon!: Hie you to church.
Goodbye!: Go to the church.

Anon!: Ay.
Goodbye!: Yes.

Anon!: But better service have I never done you Than now to bid you hold.
Goodbye!: But I’ve never done you better than now to offer you a better service.

Anon!: Here comes Kent.
Goodbye!: Here comes Kent.

Anon!: I never saw a better-fashioned gown, More quaint, more pleasing, nor more commendable.
Goodbye!: I never saw a better-fashioned gown, more beautiful, and more commended.

Anon!: If God will be avengèd for this deed, O, know you yet He doth it publicly!
Goodbye!: If God is avenged for this deed, then you know that he does it publicly!

Anon!: You beastly knave, know you no reverence?
Goodbye!: You beastly knave, don’t you know what you’re saying?

Anon!: Am I a coward?
Goodbye!: Am I a coward?

Anon!: March gently on to meet him.
Goodbye!: March on to meet him gently.

Anon!: Here’s Lucentio, right son to the right Vincentio, That have by marriage made thy daughter mine While counterfeit supposes bleared thine eyne.
Goodbye!: Here’s Lucentio, right son to the right Vincentio, who have made your daughter mine by marriage while counterfeits suppose you’ve bleared your eyne.

Anon!: Good morrow, good Lieutenant.
Goodbye!: Good morning, good Lieutenant.

Anon!: It is written, that the shoemaker should meddle with his yard and the tailor with his last, the fisher with his pencil and the painter with his nets.
Goodbye!: It’s written that shoemaker should go with his yard and tailor with his last, the fisherman with his pencil and the painter with his nets.

Anon!: He’s a friend of the Duke Alençon’s.
Goodbye!: He’s a friend of the Duke Alençon’s.

Anon!: By your most gracious pardon, I sing but after you.
Goodbye!: I swear by your gracious pardon, I’m only singing after you.

Anon!: There lock yourself and send him word you are dead.
Goodbye!: Lock yourself and send him the word you’re dead.

Anon!: If thou hadst feared to break an oath by Him, Th' imperial metal circling now thy head Had graced the tender temples of my child, And both the princes had been breathing here, Which now, two tender bedfellows for dust, Thy broken faith hath made the prey for worms.
Goodbye!: If you had feared to break an oath by Him, your imperial metal circling your head had graced my child’s tender temples, and both the princes had been breathing here.

Anon!: If sight and shape be true, Why then, my love adieu.
Goodbye!: If sight and shape are true, then my love will die.

Anon!: Tis hatched, and shall be so.
Goodbye!: It’s been hatched, and it’ll be.

Anon!: He threw his eye aside— And mark what object did present itself: Under an old oak, whose boughs were mossed with age And high top bald with dry antiquity, A wretched, ragged man, o'ergrown with hair, Lay sleeping on his back.
Goodbye!: He threw his eyes aside—and he threw the object away—and it was the object of a tree, whose boughs were mossed with age and bald with dry antiquity, and

Anon!: You had musty victual, and he hath holp to eat it.
Goodbye!: You had a musty victual, and he has holp to eat it.

Anon!: Sweet Beatrice, wouldst thou come when I called thee?
Goodbye!: Sweet Beatrice, are you going to come when I called you?

Anon!: I’ll see it done.
Goodbye!: I’ll see it done.

Anon!: How is ’t with you?
Goodbye!: How are you?

Anon!: Grim death, how foul and loathsome is thine image!
Goodbye!: Grim death, how foul and loathsome your image is!

Anon!: Your part in her you could not keep from death, But heaven keeps his part in eternal life.
Goodbye!: You could not keep your part in her from dying, but heaven keeps his part in eternal life.

Anon!: Tis not a time for private stomaching.
Goodbye!: It’s not time for private stomaching.

Anon!: Even so lies she, Blubbering and weeping, weeping and blubbering.
Goodbye!: She lies in that she’s Blubbering and weeping, weeping and blubbering.

Anon!: Ay, his breast.
Goodbye!: Yes, his breast.

Anon!: Our worser thoughts heavens mend.
Goodbye!: Then heavens will change our worse thoughts.

Anon!: Yet Brutus says he was ambitious, And Brutus is an honorable man.
Goodbye!: But Brutus says he was ambitious, and Brutus is an honorable man.

Anon!: Peace, ho!
Goodbye!: Quiet!

Anon!: But, in good sooth, are you he that hangs the verses on the trees wherein Rosalind is so admired?
Goodbye!: But are you the one who hangs the verses on the trees where Rosalind is so famous?

Anon!: Tonight in Harfleur will we be your guest; Tomorrow for the march are we addressed.
Goodbye!: Tonight in Harfleur we’ll be your guest; tomorrow we’ll be heading for the march.

Anon!: But I’ll not chide thee.
Goodbye!: But I won’t chide you.

Anon!: Tell me, thou unknown power—      He knows thy thought.
Goodbye!: Tell me, you unknown power— He knows what you thought.

Anon!: They are louder than the weather or our office.
Goodbye!: They’re louder than the weather or our office.

Anon!: We must not now displease him.
Goodbye!: We can’t displease him now.

Anon!: He gives you upon his knees a thousand thanks, and he esteems himself happy that he hath fall'n into the hands of one, as he thinks, the most brave, valorous, and thrice- worthy seigneur of England.
Goodbye!: He gives you a thousand thanks on his knees, and he’s happy he’s fallen into the hands of one of England’s brave, valorous, and most worthy seigneur.

Anon!: Of what nature the wrongs are thou hast done him, I know not, but thy intercepter, full of despite, bloody as the hunter, attends thee at the orchard end.
Goodbye!: I don’t know what you’ve done, but you’re a hunter, as bloody as you are, who’s waiting at the orchard end.

Anon!: One would think his mother’s milk were scarce out of him.
Goodbye!: One would think his mother’s milk was scarce from him.

Anon!: Why is this reasoned?
Goodbye!: Why are you saying that?

Anon!: The king’s a-bed.
Goodbye!: The king’s a bed.

Anon!: Persuade me rather to be slave and sumpter To this detested groom.
Goodbye!: I’d rather be a slave and a sumpter to this detested groom.

Anon!: Thou drunken slave, I sent thee for a rope And told thee to what purpose and what end.
Goodbye!: You drunken slave, I sent you for a rope and told you what purpose and what purpose you’re going to achieve.

Anon!: Your mind may change.
Goodbye!: Your mind may change.

Anon!: They are coming to the play.
Goodbye!: They’re coming to the play.

Anon!: No words.
Goodbye!: No words.

Anon!: And yet thou wilt tutor me from quarreling!
Goodbye!: And yet you’ll help me out of fighting!

Anon!: He’s as tall a man as any ’s in Illyria.
Goodbye!: He’s as tall as any man in Illyria.

Anon!: Look, love, what envious streaks Do lace the severing clouds in yonder east.
Goodbye!: Look, love, what envious streaks make the clouds severing in the east.

Anon!: Look thou but sweet, And I am proof against their enmity.
Goodbye!: Look, you’re sweet, and I’m proof against their enmity.

Anon!: Othello, leave some officer behind And he shall our commission bring to you, And such things else of quality and respect As doth import you.
Goodbye!: Oh, let some of you leave behind, and he’ll bring you to our commission, and all the things that are worthy of your respect and quality are important to you.

Anon!: Master, some show to welcome us to town.
Goodbye!: Master, some show to welcome us to town.

Anon!: To tell thee thou shalt see me at Philippi.
Goodbye!: Tell me you’ll see me at Philippi.

Anon!: Stay not, be gone.
Goodbye!: Don’t stay, go away.

Anon!: But yet, madam— I do not like “But yet.” It does allay The good precedence.
Goodbye!: But yet, madam— I don’t like “But yet.” It’s all about the good news.

Anon!: And I must be from thence!
Goodbye!: And I must be away from here!

Anon!: Take a trumpet, herald.
Goodbye!: Take a trumpet, herald.

Anon!: O Pomfret, Pomfret!
Goodbye!: Oh, Pomfret, Pomfret!

Anon!: Show ’s the way, sir.
Goodbye!: Show the way, sir.

Anon!: Till then, enough.
Goodbye!: That’s enough.

Anon!: For every minute is expectancy Of more arrivance.
Goodbye!: Every minute there’s a chance of more arrivance.

Anon!: You will be whipped.
Goodbye!: You’ll be whipped.

Anon!: Dost thou in conscience think—tell me, Emilia— That there be women do abuse their husbands In such gross kind?
Goodbye!: Do you think, in conscience—tell me, Emilia—there are women who abuse their husbands in such a cruel manner?

Anon!: I pitied thee, Took pains to make thee speak, taught thee each hour One thing or other.
Goodbye!: I pitied you, made it hard to make you speak, and taught you one thing or two at a time.

Anon!: I sent you money, sir, to be your bail By Dromio, but I think he brought it not.
Goodbye!: I sent Dromio to you to be your bail, but I don’t think he brought it.

Anon!: What dost thou think?
Goodbye!: What do you think?

Anon!: Yet words do well When he that speaks them pleases those that hear.
Goodbye!: But words are good when the person who speaks them pleases the people who hear them.

Anon!: Tear him, tear him!
Goodbye!: Tear him, tear him!

Anon!: Go to.
Goodbye!: Go on.

Anon!: I should not then ask Casca what had chanced.
Goodbye!: I wouldn’t ask Casca what happened.

Anon!: I will go along.
Goodbye!: I’ll go with you.

Anon!: Had I great Juno’s power, The strong-winged Mercury should fetch thee up And set thee by Jove’s side.
Goodbye!: If I had great Juno’s power, the strong-winged Mercury would get you up and set you up by Jove’s side.

Anon!: Besides, they are our outward consciences And preachers to us all, admonishing That we should dress us fairly for our end.
Goodbye!: Besides, they are our outward consciences and preachers to us all, admonising that we should dress up fairly for our purposes.

Anon!: The moblèd queen”?
Goodbye!: The moblèd queen”?

Anon!: I tax not you, you elements, with unkindness.
Goodbye!: I don’t punish you, you elements, with unkindness.

Anon!: But who comes here?
Goodbye!: But who’s coming?

Anon!: Come, night.
Goodbye!: Come, night.

Anon!: He cannot be heard of.
Goodbye!: He can’t be heard of.

Anon!: Why, here’s no crab, and therefore look not sour.
Goodbye!: Why, here’s no crab, and therefore don’t look sour.

Anon!: But, hark thee, Charmian.
Goodbye!: But listen, Charmian.

Anon!: Did you send to him, sir?
Goodbye!: Did you send to him, sir?

Anon!: There is further compliment of leave-taking between France and him.
Goodbye!: There’s more compliment on the leave-taking between France and him.

Anon!: Cure her of that.
Goodbye!: Cure her of that.

Anon!: O young and noble Cato, art thou down?
Goodbye!: Oh, young and noble Cato, are you down?

Anon!: What is the matter, lady?
Goodbye!: What’s the matter, lady?

Anon!: Give me leave awhile.
Goodbye!: Give me permission for a while.

Anon!: There was, for a while, no money bid for argument unless the poet and the player went to cuffs in the question.
Goodbye!: There was no money to be used for argument until the poet and the player were cuffed in the question.

Anon!: The strings, my lord, are false.
Goodbye!: The strings, my lord, are false.

Anon!: Not once, nor twice, but twenty times you have.
Goodbye!: Not once, or twice, but twenty times you have.

Anon!: Wilt thou not answer, man?
Goodbye!: Don’t you answer me, man?

Anon!: This fortification, gentlemen, shall we see ’t?
Goodbye!: Will we see this fortification, gentlemen?

Anon!: Is thy news good, or bad?
Goodbye!: Is your news good or bad?

Anon!: Art thou afeard To be the same in thine own act and valor As thou art in desire?
Goodbye!: Are you afraid to be the same in your own act and in your own valor as you want?

Anon!: No.
Goodbye!: No.

Anon!: Thou look’st cheerly, and I’ll be with thee quickly.
Goodbye!: You look cheery, and I’ll be with you quickly.

Anon!: They shall, Nerissa, but in such a habit That they shall think we are accomplishèd With that we lack.
Goodbye!: They will, Nerissa, but they’ll think we’re getting better with the ones we don’t have.

Anon!: Gentle Mercutio, put thy rapier up.
Goodbye!: Gentle Mercutio, put your rapier up.

Anon!: What news?
Goodbye!: What news do you have?

Anon!: Upon my sword.
Goodbye!: On my sword.

Anon!: I am cut to th' brains.
Goodbye!: I’m cut to the brains.

Anon!: Fare thee well.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: What bastard doth not?
Goodbye!: What kind of savage isn’t he?

Anon!: Villain, thou know’st not law of God nor man.
Goodbye!: Villain, you don’t know the law of God or man.

Anon!: But thou must needs be sure My spirits and my place have in their power To make this bitter to thee.
Goodbye!: But you have to be sure my spirits and my place are in their power to make this bitter to you.

Anon!: We’ll overreach the graybeard, Gremio, The narrow-prying father, Minola, The quaint musician, amorous Litio, All for my master’s sake, Lucentio.
Goodbye!: We’ll overreach the graybeard, Gremio, the narrow-prying father, Minola, the charming musician, amorous Litio, all for my master’s sake, Lucent

Anon!: Thou shalt find That I’ll resume the shape which thou dost think I have cast off for ever.
Goodbye!: You’ll find that I’ll resume the shape you think I’ve been cast off for forever.

Anon!: Keep promise, love.
Goodbye!: Keep your promise, love.

Anon!: I will not stay to offend you.
Goodbye!: I won’t stay here to offend you.

Anon!: Not today, O Lord, Oh, not today, think not upon the fault My father made in compassing the crown.
Goodbye!: Oh, Lord, don’t think about the fault my father made in compassing the crown.

Anon!: Why then, let fall Your horrible pleasure.
Goodbye!: So let’s fall in your horrible pleasure.

Anon!: He is very well-favored, and he speaks very shrewishly.
Goodbye!: He’s very well-favored, and he’s very shrewd.

Anon!: I shall be much bound to you for ’t.
Goodbye!: I’ll be a big fan of you.

Anon!: For I had then laid wormwood to my dug, Sitting in the sun under the dovehouse wall.
Goodbye!: I had then laid wormwood to my dug, sitting in the sun under the wall of the dovehouse.

Anon!: Are you not a strumpet?
Goodbye!: Aren’t you a strumpet?

Anon!: For charitable prayers Shards, flints and pebbles should be thrown on her.
Goodbye!: For charitable prayers, she should throw a sword, flints and pebbles on her.

Anon!: Now, by my holidam, here comes Katherina!
Goodbye!: Now, by my holidam, here comes Katherina!

Anon!: Ay.
Goodbye!: Yes.

Anon!: I will forestall their repair hither and say you are not fit.
Goodbye!: I’ll stop them from getting back on the ground and say you’re not fit.

Anon!: From the dread summit of this chalky bourn.
Goodbye!: From the dreadful summit of this chalky bourn.

Anon!: No, he’s in Tartar limbo, worse than hell.
Goodbye!: No, he’s in a terrible situation, worse than hell.

Anon!: She says you have some goodly jest in hand.
Goodbye!: She says you have some good sneezing in hand.

Anon!: Pray, write down, “Borachio.”—Yours, sirrah?
Goodbye!: Please write down, “Borachio.”—Yours, sir?

Anon!: Why, now I see there’s mettle in thee, and even from this instant to build on thee a better opinion than ever before.
Goodbye!: Now I see you’re getting a better opinion than ever before.

Anon!: I say a husband.
Goodbye!: I say a husband.

Anon!: Last thing he did, dear Queen, He kissed—the last of many doubled kisses— This orient pearl.
Goodbye!: The last thing he did, dear Queen, was kissing—the last of many double kisses—this orient pearl.

Anon!: Come, talk not of her.
Goodbye!: Come on, don’t talk about her.

Anon!: Why do you make such faces?
Goodbye!: Why do you make such faces?

Anon!: What, art thou hurt?
Goodbye!: What, are you hurt?

Anon!: Why no, boy.
Goodbye!: No, boy.

Anon!: Sweet lady, ho, ho.
Goodbye!: Sweet lady, ho, ho.

Anon!: He’ll make a proper man.
Goodbye!: He’ll be a good man.

Anon!: Hortensio, peace.
Goodbye!: Hortensio, calm down.

Anon!: What manner o’ thing is your crocodile?
Goodbye!: What’s your crocodile doing?

Anon!: O, then by day Where wilt thou find a cavern dark enough To mask thy monstrous visage?
Goodbye!: Oh, then by day, where will you find a cavern dark enough to mask your monstrous face?

Anon!: Talk you of killing?
Goodbye!: Are you talking about killing?

Anon!: Peace, peace!
Goodbye!: Quiet, quiet!

Anon!: In faith, hath not the world one man but he will wear his cap with suspicion?
Goodbye!: Isn’t there a man in the world who will wear his cap with suspicion?

Anon!: Why, farewell, Portia.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, Portia.

Anon!: Well, gentlemen, I am thus resolved: On Sunday next, you know My daughter Katherina is to be married.
Goodbye!: Well, gentlemen, I’m so happy: On Sunday next week, you know that my daughter Katherina is going to be married.

Anon!: Thou canst compel no more than she entreat.
Goodbye!: You can’t compel any more than she can.

Anon!: If it pass against us, We lose the better half of our possession, For all the temporal lands which men devout By testament have given to the Church Would they strip from us, being valued thus: “As much as would maintain, to the King’s honor, Full fifteen earls and fifteen hundred knights, Six thousand and two hundred good esquires; And, to relief of lazars and weak age Of indigent faint souls past corporal toil, A hundred almshouses right well supplied; And to the coffers of the King besides, A thousand pounds by th' year.” Thus runs the bill.
Goodbye!: If it passes against us, we lose the better half of our possession, because all the lands that men have given to the Church would be stripped of us, as valued as so: “As much as the King’s honor would

Anon!: Go get him surgeons.
Goodbye!: Go get him surgeons.

Anon!: If thou kill’st me, boy, thou shalt kill a man.
Goodbye!: If you kill me, boy, you’ll kill a man.

Anon!: I will not say you shall see a masque, but if you do then it was not for nothing that my nose fell a-bleeding on Black Monday last at six o'clock i' th' morning falling out that year on Ash Wednesday was four year in th' afternoon.
Goodbye!: I won’t say you’ll see a mask, but if you do, it wasn’t for nothing that my nose fell a-bleeding on Black Monday last night at six o'clock in the morning,

Anon!: Is he gone?
Goodbye!: Is he gone?

Anon!: So dear I loved the man that I must weep.
Goodbye!: I loved the man so much that I have to cry.

Anon!: Oh, farewell!
Goodbye!: Goodbye!

Anon!: Tut, fear not me.
Goodbye!: Don’t worry about me.

Anon!: Oh, but she is wise.
Goodbye!: Oh, but she is wise.

Anon!: The perdition of th' athversary hath been very great, reasonable great.
Goodbye!: The perdition of the athversary has been very great, reasonable great.

Anon!: Hear you aught of her in yours?
Goodbye!: Do you hear her in yours?

Anon!: Now, by Saint Peter’s Church and Peter too, He shall not make me there a joyful bride.
Goodbye!: Now, by Saint Peter’s Church and Peter too, he won’t make me a joyful bride here.

Anon!: Go we to him.
Goodbye!: Go to him.

Anon!: The hour steals on.
Goodbye!: The hour is over.

Anon!: Rage, blow!
Goodbye!: Rage, blow!

Anon!: I found him under a tree like a dropped acorn.
Goodbye!: I found him under a tree like a dropped acorn.

Anon!: Pray ye, sir?
Goodbye!: Please, sir?

Anon!: Macbeth!
Goodbye!: Macbeth!

Anon!: What, are they children?
Goodbye!: Are they children?

Anon!: When spake I such a word?
Goodbye!: When did I say such a word?

Anon!: He says so.
Goodbye!: He says that.

Anon!: Poor men alone?
Goodbye!: Poor men alone?

Anon!: I have no will to wander forth of doors, Yet something leads me forth.
Goodbye!: I don’t want to wander out of the door, but something leads me out.

Anon!: Look to the lady.
Goodbye!: Look at the lady.

Anon!: It seems that you scorn me.
Goodbye!: It seems you’re insulting me.

Anon!: But to Orlando: did he leave him there, Food to the sucked and hungry lioness?
Goodbye!: But to Orlando: did he leave him there, and eat food to the hungry lioness?

Anon!: All things that are, Are with more spirit chasèd than enjoyed.
Goodbye!: Everything that is, is more chastized than enjoyed.

Anon!: I am none of his flirt-gills.
Goodbye!: I’m not one of his flirty gills.

Anon!: I will go along.
Goodbye!: I’ll go with you.

Anon!: Come, sirs.
Goodbye!: Come on, sirs.

Anon!: Put money in thy purse.
Goodbye!: Put money in your purse.

Anon!: Why, but there’s many a man hath more hair than wit.
Goodbye!: But many men have more hair than wit.

Anon!: The interim’s mine.
Goodbye!: The interim’s mine.

Anon!: No, thy words are too precious to be cast away upon curs.
Goodbye!: No, your words are too precious to be cast away on a cursor.

Anon!: He shall spurn fate, scorn death, and bear His hopes 'bove wisdom, grace, and fear.
Goodbye!: He will scold fate, scorn death, and bear his hopes to scold wisdom, grace, and fear.

Anon!: If I could bid the fifth welcome with so good a heart as I can bid the other four farewell, I should be glad of his approach.
Goodbye!: If I could give the fifth welcome with so good a heart as I can give the other four farewell, I’d be glad of his approach.

Anon!: It becomes The thronèd monarch better than his crown.
Goodbye!: It’s better to be the throned monarch than his crown.

Anon!: God help thee, shallow man.
Goodbye!: God help you, shallow man.

Anon!: Marry, at the very next turning turn of no hand, but turn down indirectly to the Jew’s house.
Goodbye!: Then turn down directly to the Jew’s house.

Anon!: If I be waspish, best beware my sting.
Goodbye!: If I’m a savage, beware of my sting.

Anon!: Let him answer me.— Come, follow me, boy.
Goodbye!: Let him answer me.—Come on, follow me, boy.

Anon!: Thy wit is a very bitter sweeting.
Goodbye!: Your wit is a very bitter sweetener.

Anon!: Thou shalt not be the worse for me: there’s gold.
Goodbye!: You’re not going to be the worse for me, there’s gold.

Anon!: Thou worms' meat in respect of a good piece of flesh, indeed.
Goodbye!: You’re worms' meat when it comes to a good piece of flesh.

Anon!: All, all.
Goodbye!: All, all.

Anon!: You have seen nothing then?
Goodbye!: You didn’t see anything then?

Anon!: You have displaced the mirth, broke the good meeting, With most admired disorder.
Goodbye!: You’ve displaced the sand, broke the good meeting, and ruined the best of the best.

Anon!: No grave upon the earth shall clip in it A pair so famous.
Goodbye!: No grave on earth will have a pair of graves that is so famous.

Anon!: O hated potion, hence!
Goodbye!: Oh, hated potion, come on!

Anon!: Wast thou not charged at peril— Wherefore to Dover?—Let him first answer that.
Goodbye!: Didn’t you be charged with peril— Why Dover?—Let him answer that first.

Anon!: He shall not go to prison.
Goodbye!: He won’t go to prison.

Anon!: Rumble thy bellyful!
Goodbye!: Rumble your bellyful!

Anon!: Be warned by me, then: they that ride so, and ride not warily, fall into foul bogs.
Goodbye!: Well, then, be warned: those who ride so well, and don’t ride so carefully, fall into foul bogs.

Anon!: All offices are open, and there is full liberty of feasting from this present hour of five till the bell have told eleven.
Goodbye!: All the offices are open, and there’s a full freedom to feast from five to eleven o'clock.

Anon!: Then slip I from her bum, down topples she, And “Tailor!” cries, and falls into a cough, And then the whole quire hold their hips and laugh, And waxen in their mirth, and neeze, and swear A merrier hour was never wasted there.
Goodbye!: Then I slip from her bum, down topples her, and “Tailor!” cries, and falls into a cough, and then the whole quire holds their hips and laughs, waxes

Anon!: Caesar gets money where He loses hearts.
Goodbye!: Caesar gets money where he loses his hearts.

Anon!: What is decreed must be, and be this so.
Goodbye!: What’s been decreed must be, and that’s the way it is.

Anon!: I have a thing for you.
Goodbye!: I have something for you.

Anon!: Now, Balthazar, As I have ever found thee honest true, So let me find thee still.
Goodbye!: Now, Balthazar, as I’ve ever found you true, let me find you still.

Anon!: Her lord is come.
Goodbye!: Her lord is here.

Anon!: Is that any thing now?
Goodbye!: Is that something?

Anon!: Now go to the door and stay there till we call.
Goodbye!: Now go to the door and stay there until we call.

Anon!: They’ll be in scarlet straight at any news.
Goodbye!: They’ll be in a slew of news immediately.

Anon!: Answer me like men.
Goodbye!: Answer me like men.

Anon!: For me, that I may surely keep mine oath, I will be married to a wealthy widow, Ere three days pass, which hath as long loved me As I have loved this proud disdainful haggard.
Goodbye!: I’ll marry a wealthy widow for three days, which has loved me as long as I have loved this disdainful haggard.

Anon!: Now I feed myself With most delicious poison.
Goodbye!: Now I’m feeding myself with the most delicious poison.

Anon!: That, being mad herself, she’s madly mated.
Goodbye!: That she’s mad herself, and she’s madly mated.

Anon!: I speak to thee plain soldier.
Goodbye!: I’m talking to you as a plain soldier.

Anon!: Oh, my daughter!
Goodbye!: Oh, my daughter!

Anon!: Behold the threaden sails, Borne with th' invisible and creeping wind, Draw the huge bottoms through the furrowed sea, Breasting the lofty surge.
Goodbye!: Look, the sails, born with the invisible and creeping wind, draw the huge bottoms through the furrowed sea, breasting the high surge.

Anon!: Wherefore throng you hither?
Goodbye!: Why are you going here?

Anon!: Dear my lord, Make me acquainted with your cause of grief.
Goodbye!: Dear lord, tell me what you’re saying.

Anon!: One fairer than my love?
Goodbye!: One more fair man than my love?

Anon!: But, as I said, On Lammas Eve at night shall she be fourteen.
Goodbye!: But I said, on Lammas Eve she’ll be fourteen.

Anon!: Come, down into the boat.
Goodbye!: Come down into the boat.
