Anon!: Seigneur Martino and his wife and daughters; County Anselme and his beauteous sisters; The lady widow of Vitruvio; Seigneur Placentio and his lovely nieces; Mercutio and his brother Valentine; Mine uncle Capulet, his wife and daughters; My fair niece Rosaline and Livia;
Goodbye!: Seigneur Martino and his wife and daughters; County Anselme and his beauteous sisters; the lady widow of Vitruvio; Seigneur Placentio and his lovely nieces; Mercuti

Anon!: Nay, heaven doth know.
Goodbye!: No, heaven knows.

Anon!: What cursèd foot wanders this way tonight To cross my obsequies and true love’s rite?
Goodbye!: What foot is wandering this way tonight to cross my rite of love and obsequies?

Anon!: I have no hope That he’s undrowned.
Goodbye!: I don’t think he’s ruined.

Anon!: Why, that was he.
Goodbye!: That was him.

Anon!: I frown upon him, yet he loves me still.
Goodbye!: I frown on him, but he loves me still.

Anon!: What is ’t thou canst demand?
Goodbye!: What do you want?

Anon!: Who then shall blame His pestered senses to recoil and start, When all that is within him does condemn Itself for being there?
Goodbye!: Who will blame his sane senses for recoiling and starting, when all that is inside him condemns himself for being there?

Anon!: I think he would not wish himself anywhere but where he is.
Goodbye!: I think he wouldn’t wish himself anywhere but where he is.

Anon!: Know you what Caesar means to do with me?
Goodbye!: Do you know what Caesar wants to do with me?

Anon!: What counterfeit did I give you?
Goodbye!: What counterfeit did I give you?

Anon!: Tis Cinna.
Goodbye!: It’s Cinna.

Anon!: I dare swear he is no hypocrite but prays from his heart.
Goodbye!: I swear he’s not a hypocrite, but I’m praying from his heart.

Anon!: What, have you dined at home?
Goodbye!: Have you eaten at home?

Anon!: Your grandfather of famous memory, an’t please your Majesty, and your great-uncle Edward the Plack Prince of Wales, as I have read in the chronicles, fought a most prave pattle here in France.
Goodbye!: Your grandfather of famous memory, who is not please your Majesty, and your great-uncle Edward the Plack Prince of Wales, as I’ve read in the chronicles, fought a prave pattle here

Anon!: If thou consider rightly of the matter, Caesar has had great wrong.
Goodbye!: If you think about the matter rightly, Caesar has had great wrong.

Anon!: Fie, now you run this humor out of breath.
Goodbye!: You’re running out of breath.

Anon!: You have not called me so, nor have you cause.
Goodbye!: You’ve not called me so, and you’ve not made any reason to.

Anon!: This dagger hath mista'en—for, lo, his house Is empty on the back of Montague, And it mis-sheathèd in my daughter’s bosom.
Goodbye!: This dagger has mista’en—for his house is empty on the back of Montague, and it’s misheathed in my daughter’s bosom.

Anon!: Didst thou dream, Lucius, that thou so criedst out?
Goodbye!: Did you dream, Lucius, that you cried out so loud?

Anon!: Do you amend it then.
Goodbye!: Do you change it then.

Anon!: O Lorenzo, If thou keep promise, I shall end this strife, Become a Christian and thy loving wife.
Goodbye!: Oh Lorenzo, if you keep your promise, I’ll end this fight, become a Christian and your loving wife.

Anon!: Sola!
Goodbye!: Sola!

Anon!: Your betters, sir.
Goodbye!: Your betters, sir.

Anon!: Nothing.
Goodbye!: Nothing.

Anon!: What if my house be troubled with a rat And I be pleased to give ten thousand ducats To have it baned?
Goodbye!: What if my house is ruined by a rat and I’m happy to give ten thousand ducats to have it baned?

Anon!: It now draws toward night.
Goodbye!: It’s coming to night now.

Anon!: And, for his passage, The soldiers' music and the rites of war Speak loudly for him.
Goodbye!: And for his passage, the soldiers' music and the rites of war speak loudly for him.

Anon!: Even a toy in hand here, sir.
Goodbye!: There’s a toy in hand here, sir.

Anon!: With duty and desire we follow you.
Goodbye!: We follow you with our duty and desire.

Anon!: Their villainy goes against my weak stomach, and therefore I must cast it up.
Goodbye!: Their villainy is against my weak stomach, and I have to cast it up.

Anon!: No harm.
Goodbye!: No harm.

Anon!: Go comfort your cousin.
Goodbye!: Go comfort your cousin.

Anon!: But this is trifling, And all the more it seeks to hide itself The bigger bulk it shows.
Goodbye!: But this is a tastier thing, and the more it seeks to hide itself, the bigger it is.

Anon!: My fan, Peter.
Goodbye!: My fan, Peter.

Anon!: Note him, Note him, good Charmian, ’tis the man, but note him.
Goodbye!: Take note of him, good Charmian, it’s the man, but take note of him.

Anon!: He comes, my lord.
Goodbye!: He’s coming, my lord.

Anon!: This day I breathed first.
Goodbye!: I breathed first this day.

Anon!: If thou rememberest aught ere thou camest here, How thou camest here thou mayst.
Goodbye!: If you remember what happened before you came here, you may remember how you came here.

Anon!: Macbeth shall never vanquished be until Great Birnam Wood to high Dunsinane Hill Shall come against him.
Goodbye!: Macbeth will never be beaten until Birnam Wood’s return to Dunsinane Hill will come against him.

Anon!: Happy, in that we are not overhappy.
Goodbye!: Happy, because we’re not too happy.

Anon!: Come, the recorders!
Goodbye!: Come on, the recorders!

Anon!: Turn, hellhound, turn!
Goodbye!: Turn, hellhound, turn!

Anon!: Caesar is touched.
Goodbye!: Caesar is touched.

Anon!: So please your Lordship to accept our duty.
Goodbye!: Please, your Lord, accept our duty.

Anon!: Why, all these should be in the lanthorn, for all these are in the moon.—But silence!
Goodbye!: All these are in the moon.—But silence!

Anon!: I may not leave it so.
Goodbye!: I can’t leave it.

Anon!: If love be blind, love cannot hit the mark.
Goodbye!: If love is blind, love can’t hit the mark.

Anon!: Oh, my lord, wisdom and blood combating in so tender a body, we have ten proofs to one that blood hath the victory.
Goodbye!: Oh, my lord, we have ten proofs to prove that blood has won.

Anon!: Not that, I hope, which you received of me.
Goodbye!: Not the one you received from me, I hope.

Anon!: Dost thou hear, lady?
Goodbye!: Do you hear anything, lady?

Anon!: Poor living corse, closed in a dead man’s tomb!
Goodbye!: Poor living corse, closed in a dead man’s tomb!

Anon!: The crows and choughs that wing the midway air Show scarce so gross as beetles.
Goodbye!: The crows and choughs that wing the midway air are scarce as beetles.

Anon!: Marry, they say my uncle grew so fast That he could gnaw a crust at two hours old.
Goodbye!: They say my uncle grew so fast that he could gnaw a crust at two hours old.

Anon!: As I learned, The night before there was no purpose in them Of this remove.
Goodbye!: I learned that the night before they were leaving were empty.

Anon!: Thou dost, and think’st it much to tread the ooze Of the salt deep, To run upon the sharp wind of the north, To do me business in the veins o' th' earth When it is baked with frost.
Goodbye!: You do, and you think it’s important to tread the sand deep, to run on the north wind, to do my business in the veins of the earth when it’s baked with frost.

Anon!: Where is the gold I gave in charge to thee?
Goodbye!: Where is the gold I gave you?

Anon!: How vexest thou this man!
Goodbye!: How vexist you are!

Anon!: Trow you whither I am going?
Goodbye!: Do you know where I’m going?

Anon!: O, cleave, my sides!
Goodbye!: Oh, cleave my sides!

Anon!: Pitchers have ears.
Goodbye!: Pitchers have ears.

Anon!: Here come the lovers, full of joy and mirth.— Joy, gentle friends!
Goodbye!: Here come the lovers, full of joy and joy.—Stress, gentle friends!

Anon!: What said my man, when my betossèd soul Did not attend him as we rode?
Goodbye!: What did my man say when my sane soul didn’t attend him as we rode?

Anon!: I warrant thee.
Goodbye!: I’m sure you’re right.

Anon!: While grace is saying, hood mine eyes Thus with my hat, and sigh and say, “Amen”— Use all the observance of civility Like one well studied in a sad ostent To please his grandam, never trust me more.
Goodbye!: While I’m saying grace, I’ll hood my eyes with my hat and sigh and say “Amen”— Use all the respect of civility, like one well studied man in a sad omen

Anon!: If she be black, and thereto have a wit, She’ll find a white that shall her blackness fit.
Goodbye!: If she’s black, and she’ll find a white that will fit her blackness.

Anon!: I hope he be in love.
Goodbye!: I hope he’s in love.

Anon!: If I stand here, I saw him.
Goodbye!: If I stand here, I saw him.

Anon!: Is not their climate foggy, raw, and dull, On whom, as in despite, the sun looks pale, Killing their fruit with frowns?
Goodbye!: Isn’t the sun pale, killing their fruit with frowns?

Anon!: Nurse, commend me to thy lady and mistress.
Goodbye!: Nurse, please give my praise to your lady and mistress.

Anon!: Let’s meet as little as we can.
Goodbye!: Let’s meet as little as we can.

Anon!: From the Count Orsino, is it?
Goodbye!: Is it from the Count Orsino?

Anon!: My nyas?
Goodbye!: My nyas?

Anon!: Sir, she is mortal.
Goodbye!: Sir, she’s mortal.

Anon!: I do remember in this shepherd boy Some lively touches of my daughter’s favor.
Goodbye!: I remember in this shepherd boy some lively touches of my daughter’s favor.

Anon!: None that I more love than myself.
Goodbye!: I don’t love anything more than myself.

Anon!: Who else should be?
Goodbye!: Who else should be?

Anon!: Who is most inward with the noble duke?
Goodbye!: Who’s most inward with the noble duke?

Anon!: Only foul words, and thereupon I will kiss thee.
Goodbye!: I’ll kiss you soon.

Anon!: Inform her full of my particular fear, And thereto add such reasons of your own As may compact it more.
Goodbye!: Tell her all about my particular fears, and add those that might make her feel as if you’re a bit more worried.

Anon!: I see thou know’st me not.
Goodbye!: I see you don’t know me.

Anon!: Tongue, not a word.
Goodbye!: No, don’t say a word.

Anon!: Before me, she’s a good wench.
Goodbye!: She’s a good wench.

Anon!: Judge, O you gods, how dearly Caesar loved him!
Goodbye!: Oh gods, how much Caesar loved him!

Anon!: Have you that holy feeling in your souls To counsel me to make my peace with God, And art you yet to your own souls so blind That thou will war with God by murd'ring me?
Goodbye!: Are you still in your own souls so blind that you’ll fight with God by murding me?

Anon!: My soul, and not my child!
Goodbye!: My soul, not my child!

Anon!: I have sent after him.
Goodbye!: I’ve sent him back.

Anon!: Most excellent accomplished lady, the heavens rain odors on you!
Goodbye!: The best accomplished lady, the heavens rain odors on you!

Anon!: Then show it me.
Goodbye!: Then show it to me.

Anon!: Of one whose hand, Like the base Indian, threw a pearl away Richer than all his tribe.
Goodbye!: Of one who, like the Indian, threw a pearl away Richer than all his tribe.

Anon!: To be acknowledged, madam, is o'erpaid.
Goodbye!: I’m sorry, madam.

Anon!: O, know, my name is lost.
Goodbye!: Oh, I know, my name has been lost.

Anon!: Good night.
Goodbye!: Good night.

Anon!: Not one, my lord.
Goodbye!: Not one, my lord.

Anon!: Revenge his foul and most unnatural murder.
Goodbye!: Revenge his horrible and unnatural murder.

Anon!: Even so.—Cover their faces.
Goodbye!: That’s true.—Cover their faces.

Anon!: I will weep for thee, For this revolt of thine methinks is like Another fall of man.—Their faults are open.
Goodbye!: I’ll cry for you, because this revolt of yours is like another fall of man.—They’re open.

Anon!: You see how simple and how fond I am.
Goodbye!: You see how simple and fond I am.

Anon!: Why, then you must.
Goodbye!: Well, then you have to.

Anon!: By my life, I do.
Goodbye!: I swear by my life, I do.

Anon!: His leg is but so-so—and yet ’tis well.
Goodbye!: He’s only so stiff—and yet he’s well.

Anon!: And wished to see thee cross-gartered.” Cross-gartered?
Goodbye!: And wished to see you cross-gartered.” Cross-gartered?

Anon!: I have great comfort from this fellow.
Goodbye!: I’m very happy with this fellow.

Anon!: I have but with a cursitory eye O'erglanced the articles.
Goodbye!: I’ve only seen the articles with a cursory eye.

Anon!: Then belike my children shall have no names.
Goodbye!: Then my children will never have names.

Anon!: I will, my lord.
Goodbye!: I will, my lord.

Anon!: Will money buy 'em?
Goodbye!: Will money buy them?

Anon!: Even now a tailor called me in his shop And showed me silks that he had bought for me, And therewithal took measure of my body.
Goodbye!: Now a tailor called me in his shop and showed me silks he had bought for me, and then took my body measurements.

Anon!: Their defeat Does by their own insinuation grow.
Goodbye!: Their defeat is growing by their own insinuation.

Anon!: No.
Goodbye!: No.

Anon!: My brother he is in Elysium.
Goodbye!: My brother is in Elysium.

Anon!: Fortune and victory sit on thy helm!
Goodbye!: You’re helming a battle with luck and victory!

Anon!: But I had rather fast from all four days Than drink so much in one.
Goodbye!: But I had rather fast from all four days than drink so much in one.

Anon!: Give ’s your hand.
Goodbye!: Give it your hand.

Anon!: Dissemble not your hatred.
Goodbye!: Don’t dissemble your hatred.

Anon!: Is the king stirring, worthy thane?
Goodbye!: Is the king a good man?

Anon!: But for the seventh cause.
Goodbye!: But for the seventh reason.

Anon!: Men shall deal unadvisedly sometimes, Which after-hours give leisure to repent.
Goodbye!: Men will behave unadvisedly sometimes, which after hours gives them the opportunity to repent.

Anon!: Despised, distressèd, hated, martyred, killed!
Goodbye!: Despised, distressed, hated, martyred, killed!

Anon!: So befall my soul As this is false he burdens me withal.
Goodbye!: I’m so sick, as this is false, he’s burdening me with a burden.

Anon!: Age, thou art shamed!
Goodbye!: Age, you’re shamed!

Anon!: Where’s Monsieur Mustardseed?
Goodbye!: Where’s Monsieur Mustardseed?

Anon!: It is a letter from my brother that I have not all o'er-read.
Goodbye!: It’s a letter from my brother that I haven’t read all the time.

Anon!: Claribel.
Goodbye!: Claribel.

Anon!: He doth nothing but frown, as who should say, “An you will not have me, choose.” He hears merry tales and smiles not.
Goodbye!: He’s not smiling, frowning like who should say, “An you won’t have me.” He’s heard merry stories and not smiling.

Anon!: All blessed secrets, All you unpublished virtues of the earth, Spring with my tears.
Goodbye!: All your blessed secrets, all your unpublished virtues of the earth, come back with my tears.

Anon!: Therefore, as I am bound, Receive it from me.
Goodbye!: So get it from me, as I am bound.

Anon!: Are these, I pray you, wind instruments?
Goodbye!: Are these wind instruments, please,?

Anon!: Call them forth.
Goodbye!: Call them out.

Anon!: Foul deeds will rise, Though all the earth o'erwhelm them, to men’s eyes.
Goodbye!: The frightened deeds will rise, even though the earth has ruined them, to men’s eyes.

Anon!: Can it be possible that no man saw them?
Goodbye!: Can it be possible that no man saw them?

Anon!: Set it down.
Goodbye!: Set it down.

Anon!: But either it was different in blood—
Goodbye!: But either it was different in blood—

Anon!: We’ll enter all together.
Goodbye!: We’ll go all together.

Anon!: Now sit we close about this taper here And call in question our necessities.
Goodbye!: Now sit close to this taper and ask for our necessities.

Anon!: Royal Queen!
Goodbye!: Royal Queen!

Anon!: I wot well where he is.
Goodbye!: I’m glad he’s here.

Anon!: Well, I conceive.
Goodbye!: Well, I think so.

Anon!: No.
Goodbye!: No.

Anon!: Sweet now, silence.
Goodbye!: Now, quiet.

Anon!: No, he hath simply the best wit of any handicraft man in Athens.
Goodbye!: No, he’s just the best man in Athens.

Anon!: I see him rouse himself To praise my noble act.
Goodbye!: I see him rouse himself to praise my noble act.

Anon!: Thus do I ever make my fool my purse.
Goodbye!: I’m always making my fool’s purse.

Anon!: I delight in masques and revels sometimes altogether.
Goodbye!: Sometimes I’m a bit snoring.

Anon!: Oh, speak of that.
Goodbye!: Oh, speak about that.

Anon!: Halfway down Hangs one that gathers samphire—dreadful trade!
Goodbye!: Halfway down there’s a man who’s gathering samphire—dreadful trade!

Anon!: That’s the next to do.
Goodbye!: That’s the next thing to do.

Anon!: Oh, ominous!
Goodbye!: Oh, ominous!

Anon!: O, do not do your cousin such a wrong!
Goodbye!: Oh, don’t do your cousin such a wrong!

Anon!: There is no tarrying here.
Goodbye!: There’s no tarrying here.

Anon!: I do beseech you, sir, have patience.
Goodbye!: Please, sir, have patience.

Anon!: We’ll ha ’t tomorrow night.
Goodbye!: We’ll do it tomorrow night.

Anon!: I thank you, gentle uncle.
Goodbye!: Thank you, uncle.

Anon!: Good husband, come home presently.
Goodbye!: Good husband, come home now.

Anon!: Let me go, I say.
Goodbye!: Let me go, I say.

Anon!: Good morrow, old Sir Thomas Erpingham.
Goodbye!: Good morning, old Sir Thomas Erpingham.

Anon!: Say ’tis not so, a province I will give thee And make thy fortunes proud.
Goodbye!: If it’s not true, I’ll give you a province and make your fortunes proud.

Anon!: You’ll “never trust his word after.” Come, ’tis a foolish saying.
Goodbye!: You’ll “never trust his word afterward.” Come on, it’s a foolish saying.

Anon!: Nobody.
Goodbye!: Nobody.

Anon!: Monster, come, put some lime upon your fingers, and away with the rest.
Goodbye!: Monster, come, put some lime on your fingers and get the rest of it out.

Anon!: His daughter is to be brought by you to the supper.
Goodbye!: His daughter will be brought to the supper by you.

Anon!: When saw you my father last?
Goodbye!: When did you see my father last time?

Anon!: And I was going to your lodging, Cassio.
Goodbye!: And I was going to your house, Cassio.

Anon!: You can do better yet, but this is meetly.
Goodbye!: You can do better, but this is a good thing.

Anon!: Nothing at all.
Goodbye!: Nothing at all.

Anon!: Warm, o' my troth.
Goodbye!: Warm, oh my.

Anon!: Say that she rail; why then I’ll tell her plain She sings as sweetly as a nightingale.
Goodbye!: Say she’s a railing; then I’ll tell her that she sings as sweetly as a nightingale.

Anon!: Yet they are not joined.
Goodbye!: But they’re not joined.

Anon!: What a wretched and peevish fellow is this king of England to mope with his fat-brained followers so far out of his knowledge.
Goodbye!: What a wretched and peevish fellow this king of England is to mope with his fat-brained followers so far out of his knowledge.

Anon!: Barnardo?
Goodbye!: Barnardo?

Anon!: Ere I would say I would drown myself for the love of a guinea hen, I would change my humanity with a baboon.
Goodbye!: I’d say I would drown myself for the love of a guinea hen, and I would change my humanity with a baboon.

Anon!: The sea, with such a storm as his bare head In hell-black night endured, would have buoyed up, And quenched the stellèd fires.
Goodbye!: The sea would have flooded the sea with such a storm as his bare head endured in hell-black night.

Anon!: Saints do not move, though grant for prayers' sake.
Goodbye!: Saints don’t move, even if they grant for prayers’ sake.

Anon!: Hanging and wiving goes by destiny.
Goodbye!: Then you’re going to be hanging and wiving.

Anon!: I’ll never see ’t!
Goodbye!: I’ll never see it!

Anon!: None at all.
Goodbye!: No, no.

Anon!: Go with my brothers to my lords of England.
Goodbye!: Go with my brothers to my lords of England.

Anon!: Spare not for the cost.
Goodbye!: Don’t worry about the cost.

Anon!: Had all his hairs been lives My great revenge had stomach for them all.
Goodbye!: If all his hairs were life-threatening, I would have ruined them all.

Anon!: Ay, if the devil tempt you to do good.
Goodbye!: Yes, if the devil tempts you to do good.

Anon!: Behold it stained With his most noble blood.
Goodbye!: Look, it’s stained with his most noble blood.

Anon!: Peace, ho!
Goodbye!: Quiet!

Anon!: And ’tis great pity that the noble Moor Should hazard such a place as his own second With one of an ingraft infirmity.
Goodbye!: And it’s great pity that the noble Moor could be a danger to his own life with a sanity.

Anon!: Give me my robe.
Goodbye!: Give me my robe.

Anon!: So that by my foes, sir I profit in the knowledge of myself, and by my friends, I am abused.
Goodbye!: I swear by my enemies, I’m abused by my friends, and by my friends.

Anon!: He came to me, and I delivered it.
Goodbye!: He came to me, and I delivered it.

Anon!: This gentleman will out-talk us all.
Goodbye!: This gentleman will out-talk us all.

Anon!: That same villain, Romeo.
Goodbye!: That villain, Romeo.

Anon!: What is he that shall buy his flock and pasture?
Goodbye!: Who will buy his flock and his pasture?

Anon!: But what’s your jest?
Goodbye!: But what’s your slur?

Anon!: I’ll halt after.
Goodbye!: I’ll stop after that.

Anon!: Were you a woman, as the rest goes even, I should my tears let fall upon your cheek And say “Thrice-welcome, drownèd Viola!” My father had a mole upon his brow.
Goodbye!: If you were a woman, as long as the rest of you go, I’d let my tears fall on your cheek and say, “Three-welcome, drowned Viola!” My father had a

Anon!: Make your best use of this.
Goodbye!: Make sure you use this word best.

Anon!: Where lodges he?
Goodbye!: Where is he sleeping?

Anon!: Hark!
Goodbye!: Listen!

Anon!: I have noted it well.
Goodbye!: I’ve read it well.

Anon!: You’ll have your nephews neigh to you.
Goodbye!: You’ll see your nephews neighing to you.

Anon!: Be bold, and take thy stand.
Goodbye!: Be bold and take your stand.

Anon!: Come hither, Catesby.
Goodbye!: Come here, Catesby.

Anon!: Taurus!
Goodbye!: Taurus!

Anon!: You are very well met.
Goodbye!: You’re very well met.

Anon!: We have store to do ’t, And they have earned the waste.
Goodbye!: We have a store to do it, and they’ve earned the money.

Anon!: Would I had two coxcombs and two daughters.
Goodbye!: I wish I had two coxcombs and two daughters.

Anon!: Run hence, proclaim, cry it about the streets.
Goodbye!: Run away, proclaim, cry about the streets.

Anon!: With meditating that she must die once, I have the patience to endure it now.
Goodbye!: I’m ready to endure it now.

Anon!: My lord, he doth deny to come.
Goodbye!: My lord, he refuses to come.

Anon!: My name is Thidias.
Goodbye!: My name is Thidias.

Anon!: Antony, Leave thy lascivious wassails.
Goodbye!: Antony, leave your savage wassails.

Anon!: And therefore is he idle?
Goodbye!: So is he idle?

Anon!: Would you would bear your fortune like a man!
Goodbye!: You’d like to bear your fortune like a man!

Anon!: We follow thee.—Juliet, the county stays.
Goodbye!: We follow you.—Juliet, the county is still alive.

Anon!: Go thither, and with unattainted eye Compare her face with some that I shall show, And I will make thee think thy swan a crow.
Goodbye!: Go on, and with an unattractive eye, compare her face to some that I’ll show you, and I’ll make you think your swan is a crow.

Anon!: No, he doth but mistake the truth totally.
Goodbye!: No, he’s only mistaken the truth completely.

Anon!: If it be, sir, I pray you, eat none of it.
Goodbye!: If it’s true, please, don’t eat it.

Anon!: He raised the house with loud and coward cries.
Goodbye!: He raised the house with loud and cowardly cries.

Anon!: O madam, madam, madam!
Goodbye!: Oh, madam, madam, madam!

Anon!: Lie—   With her?
Goodbye!: Lie— With her?

Anon!: I prithee let me hear it.
Goodbye!: Please let me hear it.

Anon!: What he hath uttered I have writ my sister.
Goodbye!: I’ve written my sister’s letter.

Anon!: Your heart is burst, you have lost half your soul.
Goodbye!: Your heart is bursting, you’ve lost half your soul.

Anon!: And is he a man to encounter Tybalt?
Goodbye!: And is he a man who wants to meet Tybalt?

Anon!: Cesario, come, For so you shall be, while you are a man.
Goodbye!: Cesario, come, because you’ll be as good as you are, while you’re a man.

Anon!: The crowner hath sat on her and finds it Christian burial.
Goodbye!: The crowner has sat on her and finds it Christian burial.

Anon!: Nothing, madam.
Goodbye!: Nothing, madam.

Anon!: Yet I love thee too.
Goodbye!: But I love you too.

Anon!: Thou wast provokèd by thy bloody mind, That never dream’st on aught but butcheries.
Goodbye!: You were beaten by your bloody mind, who never dreamed of killing butchers.

Anon!: Yes, sir, but anger hath a privilege.
Goodbye!: Yes, sir, but anger has a privilege.

Anon!: Why did you so cry out, sirs, in your sleep?
Goodbye!: Why did you cry out in your sleep, sirs?

Anon!: Ay, that’s the way.
Goodbye!: Yes, that’s the way.

Anon!: For when she saw— Which never shall be found—you did suspect She had disposed with Caesar, and that your rage Would not be purged, she sent you word she was dead.
Goodbye!: When she saw—which never will be found—you suspect she had sex with Caesar and that your anger wouldn’t be purged, she sent you the word she was dead.

Anon!: Ay, my lord.
Goodbye!: Yes, my lord.

Anon!: Tybalt, the reason that I have to love thee Doth much excuse the appertaining rage To such a greeting.
Goodbye!: Tybalt, the reason I have to love you is to excuse the rage that comes with such a greeting.

Anon!: Under Captain Gower, my liege.
Goodbye!: Under Captain Gower, my liege.

Anon!: It must be by his death, and for my part I know no personal cause to spurn at him But for the general.
Goodbye!: It must be by his death, and I don’t know any reason to insult him, but for the general.

Anon!: Tis brief, my lord.
Goodbye!: It’s short, my lord.

Anon!: But I am shepherd to another man And do not shear the fleeces that I graze.
Goodbye!: But I’m a shepherd to another man and don’t shear the fleeces I graze.

Anon!: I have a soul of lead So stakes me to the ground I cannot move.
Goodbye!: I have a soul of lead that can’t move.

Anon!: Meantime forbear, And let mischance be slave to patience.— Bring forth the parties of suspicion.
Goodbye!: In the meantime, stop, and let mischance be slave to patience.—Let’s talk about suspicion.

Anon!: What ho, Horatio!
Goodbye!: Horatio!

Anon!: But is he often thus?
Goodbye!: But is he often so?

Anon!: Good my lord, enter here.
Goodbye!: Please, my lord, come here.

Anon!: Amen, amen.
Goodbye!: Amen, amen.

Anon!: First resolve me that.
Goodbye!: First, resolve that.

Anon!: And all the better is it for the maid.
Goodbye!: And it’s all better for the maid.

Anon!: I know his soul is in heaven, fool.
Goodbye!: I know his soul is in heaven, fool.

Anon!: Drunk?
Goodbye!: Drunk?

Anon!: O earth, which this blood drink’st revenge his death!
Goodbye!: Oh, earth, which this blood drink revenges his death!

Anon!: Yea, an ’twere a thousand pound more than ’tis, for I hear as good exclamation on your Worship as of any man in the city, and though I be but a poor man, I am glad to hear it.
Goodbye!: Yes, it’s been a thousand pound more than it is, because I hear as good a word on your Worship as any man in the city, and even though I’m a poor man, I’m

Anon!: Who is ’t that hinders you?
Goodbye!: Who’s behind you?

Anon!: You were best knock louder.
Goodbye!: You’d better knock louder.

Anon!: Look then to be well edified when the fool delivers the madman.
Goodbye!: Look for a good example when the fool delivers the madman.

Anon!: I told him you were asleep.
Goodbye!: I told him you were asleep.

Anon!: Shylock is my name.
Goodbye!: Shylock is my name.

Anon!: You need not tell us what Lord Hamlet said.
Goodbye!: You don’t need to tell us what Lord Hamlet said.

Anon!: Ha!
Goodbye!: Ha!

Anon!: Well, for your favor, sir, why, give God thanks, and make no boast of it, and for your writing and reading, let that appear when there is no need of such vanity.
Goodbye!: Well, for your favor, sir, please thank God, and don’t boast about it, and for your writing and reading, let that appear when there’s no need for such vanity.

Anon!: Why comest thou?
Goodbye!: Why are you coming?

Anon!: Come your ways.
Goodbye!: Come on.

Anon!: Mine honor was not yielded, But conquered merely.
Goodbye!: I didn’t give my honor, but I was conquered.

Anon!: I go, sir, but I would not have you to think that my desire of having is the sin of covetousness.
Goodbye!: I’m going, sir, but I wouldn’t want you to think that my desire to have is the sin of covet.

Anon!: He, he, ’tis he.
Goodbye!: He, he, he is.

Anon!: Ay, madam, twenty several messengers.
Goodbye!: Yes, madam, twenty messengers.

Anon!: Master, mean you so?
Goodbye!: Master, do you mean that?

Anon!: One, Kate, that you must kiss and be acquainted with.— Where are my slippers?
Goodbye!: One of you, Kate, you must kiss and be familiar with.—Where are my slippers?

Anon!: I fear he will prove the weeping philosopher when he grows old, being so full of unmannerly sadness in his youth.
Goodbye!: I’m afraid he’ll be the weeping philosopher when he grows old, despite his unmannered sadness in his youth.

Anon!: I’ll to the mart, and there for Dromio stay.
Goodbye!: I’ll go to the martin, and then go there for Dromio to stay.

Anon!: Very well, my lord.
Goodbye!: Very well, my lord.

Anon!: Your lady mother is coming to your chamber.
Goodbye!: Your mother is coming to your room.

Anon!: Begone!
Goodbye!: Start!

Anon!: Ancient, what makes he here?
Goodbye!: What’s this man doing?

Anon!: Royal Egypt, Empress!
Goodbye!: Royal Egypt, Empress!

Anon!: The treacherous instrument is in thy hand, Unbated and envenomed.
Goodbye!: The treacherous instrument is in your hand, unbated and envenomed.

Anon!: In Orsino’s bosom.
Goodbye!: In Orsino’s bosom.

Anon!: It shall be said his judgment ruled our hands.
Goodbye!: It’s been said that his judgment ruled our hands.

Anon!: Get you to bed, faith.
Goodbye!: Go to bed, I swear.

Anon!: Iago, who began ’t?
Goodbye!: Iago, who started it?

Anon!: In mine eye she is the sweetest lady that ever I looked on.
Goodbye!: I’m sure she’s the sweetest lady I’ve ever looked at.

Anon!: I frown the while, and perchance wind up watch, or play with my—some rich jewel.
Goodbye!: I frown the time, and I’ll watch or play with my rich jewel.

Anon!: But where is Kate?
Goodbye!: But where is Kate?

Anon!: Write me a prologue, and let the prologue seem to say we will do no harm with our swords, and that Pyramus is not killed indeed.
Goodbye!: Write me a prologue, and let the prologue seem to say we won’t do harm with our swords, and that Pyramus is not killed.

Anon!: See where she comes and brings your froward wives As prisoners to her womanly persuasion.— Katherine, that cap of yours becomes you not.
Goodbye!: See where she comes and brings your froward wives as prisoners to her womanly persuasion.—Kathleen, that cap of yours won’t be you.

Anon!: But let it be.
Goodbye!: But let it be.

Anon!: He is the general challenger.
Goodbye!: He’s the general challenger.

Anon!: Yea, yea, my lord.
Goodbye!: Yes, yes, my lord.

Anon!: Wilt break my heart?
Goodbye!: Will I break my heart?

Anon!: It did, it did.
Goodbye!: It did, it did.

Anon!: Well, I will call Beatrice to you, who I think hath legs.
Goodbye!: Well, I’ll call Beatrice to you, who I think has legs.

Anon!: What have you done?
Goodbye!: What have you done?

Anon!: I say “thy husband”—dost understand the word?
Goodbye!: I say “your husband”—can you understand the word?

Anon!: Bloody, bawdy villain!
Goodbye!: Bloody, bawdy villain!

Anon!: Mistress!
Goodbye!: Mistress!

Anon!: I met the youthful lord at Lawrence' cell, And gave him what becomèd love I might, Not stepping o'er the bounds of modesty.
Goodbye!: I met the young lord at Lawrence’s cell and gave him what I could be like, not stepping beyond the limits of modesty.

Anon!: For himself to mar,” quoth he?
Goodbye!: For himself to be a savage,” he said.

Anon!: A cup, closed in my true love’s hand?
Goodbye!: A cup, closed in my true love’s hand?

Anon!: And thus a while the fit will work on him.
Goodbye!: So he’ll be able to do it for a while.

Anon!: For shame, bring Juliet forth.
Goodbye!: For shame, bring Juliet out.

Anon!: Here you may roast your goose.
Goodbye!: Here you can roast your goose.

Anon!: That ever holds.
Goodbye!: That’s always true.

Anon!: All which we pine for now.
Goodbye!: All that we’re pineing for now.

Anon!: I know not, sir.
Goodbye!: I don’t know, sir.

Anon!: Of Albany’s and Cornwall’s powers you heard not?
Goodbye!: You’ve never heard of Albany’s and Cornwall’s powers?

Anon!: Tis partly my own fault, Which death or absence soon shall remedy.
Goodbye!: It’s partly my own fault, which will be fixed soon.

Anon!: Bear hence this body and attend our will.
Goodbye!: Take this body away and take care of our will.

Anon!: And O you mortal engines, whose rude throats The immortal Jove’s dead clamors counterfeit, Farewell!
Goodbye!: Oh, you mortal engines, whose rude throats the immortal Jove’s dead clamors are counterfeit, goodbye!

Anon!: Petruchio, go thy ways; the field is won.
Goodbye!: Petruchio, go on your way; the field is won.

Anon!: Go then, find me a meet hour to draw Don Pedro and the Count Claudio alone.
Goodbye!: Go find me a meeting hour to draw Don Pedro and Claudio alone.

Anon!: Run to the Capulets.
Goodbye!: Run to the Capulets.

Anon!: And mine a hundred and forty.
Goodbye!: And mine a hundred and forty.

Anon!: How now, Malvolio!
Goodbye!: What’s going on, Malvolio?

Anon!: Pray thee, take pain To allay with some cold drops of modesty Thy skipping spirit, lest through thy wild behavior I be misconst’red in the place I go to, And lose my hopes.
Goodbye!: Please, take pain to allay your snoring spirit with some cold drops of modesty, so I can’t be fooled into the place I go to, and lose my hopes.

Anon!: Troth, I think your other rebato were better.
Goodbye!: I think your other rebato would be better.

Anon!: I will hear Brutus speak.
Goodbye!: I’ll hear Brutus speak.

Anon!: He left behind him myself and a sister, both born in an hour.
Goodbye!: He left behind myself and a sister, both born in an hour.

Anon!: I therefore vouch again That with some mixtures powerful o'er the blood Or with some dram, conjured to this effect, He wrought upon her.
Goodbye!: So I’ll say again that he wrought on her with some powerful mixtures of blood or some dram, conjured to this effect.

Anon!: Fare you well.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: Oh, that your Highness knew my heart in this: I never loved my brother in my life.
Goodbye!: Oh, your Highness knew my heart in this: I never loved my brother in my life.

Anon!: Will you go to them?
Goodbye!: Will you go to them?

Anon!: With his mouth full of news.
Goodbye!: With his mouth full of news.

Anon!: I shall desire you of more acquaintance, good Master Cobweb.
Goodbye!: I’ll want you to be more familiar with me, Master Cobweb.

Anon!: I’ll set her on.
Goodbye!: I’ll put her on.

Anon!: Here in the tent.
Goodbye!: Here in the tent.

Anon!: O nature, what hadst thou to do in hell When thou didst bower the spirit of a fiend In moral paradise of such sweet flesh?
Goodbye!: Oh nature, what did you do in hell when you bowed to the spirit of a fiend in such a sweet flesh?

Anon!: Away!
Goodbye!: Go away!

Anon!: The sun not yet thy sighs from heaven clears, Thy old groans ring yet in my ancient ears.
Goodbye!: The sun still doesn’t clear your sighs from heaven, and your old groans still ring in my old ears.

Anon!: Strange things I have in head, that will to hand, Which must be acted ere they may be scanned.
Goodbye!: I have strange things in my head, that I’ll hand, and that must be done before they can be scanned.

Anon!: I will have my revenge ere I depart his house.
Goodbye!: I’ll get revenge if I leave his house.

Anon!: Madam, I will.
Goodbye!: Madam, I will.

Anon!: Did you say with Cassio?
Goodbye!: Did you say Cassio?

Anon!: Good master, take it not unkindly, pray, That I have been thus pleasant with you both.
Goodbye!: Good master, don’t take it unkindly, please, that I’ve been so pleasant with you both.

Anon!: This is kind I offer.
Goodbye!: I’m offering this kind of offer.

Anon!: I see thy age and dangers make thee dote.
Goodbye!: I see your age and your dangers make you dot.

Anon!: Who is it that complains unto the king That I, forsooth, am stern and love them not?
Goodbye!: Who complains to the king that I am stern and don’t love them?

Anon!: Tis truly so.
Goodbye!: That’s true.

Anon!: What conquest brings he home?
Goodbye!: What conquest brings him home?

Anon!: A most unhappy one.
Goodbye!: A very unhappy one.

Anon!: You will not then?
Goodbye!: You won’t, then?

Anon!: What, still in tears, Evermore showering?
Goodbye!: What, still in tears, evermore showering?

Anon!: An they will take it, so.
Goodbye!: If they take it, then.

Anon!: Th' exchange of thy love’s faithful vow for mine.
Goodbye!: I’m glad to hear your love’s faithful vow for me.

Anon!: For doting, not for loving, pupil mine.
Goodbye!: I’m a pupil for doing things, not loving it.

Anon!: Speak the word along.
Goodbye!: Speak the word along.

Anon!: Hail!
Goodbye!: Hail!

Anon!: But it is no matter.
Goodbye!: But it doesn’t matter.

Anon!: When a wise man gives thee better counsel, give me mine again.
Goodbye!: When a wise man gives you better advice, give me my advice again.

Anon!: Knock, knock!
Goodbye!: Knock, knock!

Anon!: Here, Peter Quince.
Goodbye!: Here, Peter Quince.

Anon!: I know a lady in Venice would have walked barefoot to Palestine for a touch of his nether lip.
Goodbye!: I know a lady in Venice would have walked barefoot to Palestine for a touch of his nether lip.

Anon!: Ghastly looks Are at my service, like enforcèd smiles, And both are ready in their offices, At any time to grace my stratagems.
Goodbye!: I’m at my service with ghastly looks like a smile, and both are ready in their offices at any time to grace my slums.

Anon!: I’ll to my rest.
Goodbye!: I’ll go to sleep.

Anon!: It is a wise father that knows his own child.
Goodbye!: It’s a wise father who knows his own child.

Anon!: Stay, give me drink.—Hamlet, this pearl is thine.
Goodbye!: Stay, drink.—Hamlet, this pearl is yours.

Anon!: Yes, madam.
Goodbye!: Yes, madam.

Anon!: The duke of Exeter doth love thee well.
Goodbye!: The duke of Exeter loves you.

Anon!: The basest horn of his hoof is more musical than the pipe of Hermes.
Goodbye!: The horn of his hoof is more musical than the pipe of Hermes.

Anon!: What will you do?
Goodbye!: What are you going to do?

Anon!: But he that tempered thee bade thee stand up, Gave thee no instance why thou shouldst do treason, Unless to dub thee with the name of traitor.
Goodbye!: But the man who tempered you told you to stand up, won’t give you any reason why you should do treason unless you dub you with the name of the traitor.

Anon!: Thou, wretched boy, that didst consort him here Shalt with him hence.
Goodbye!: You, wretched boy, who consorted him here will go with him.

Anon!: Yet Count Claudio may hear, for what I would speak of concerns him.
Goodbye!: But Count Claudio may hear it, because what I’d like to say concerns him.

Anon!: Well, girl, thou weep’st not so much for his death, As that the villain lives which slaughtered him.
Goodbye!: Well, girl, you’re not crying for his death, as much as for the life of the villain who killed him.

Anon!: These ears of mine, thou know’st did hear thee.
Goodbye!: I’ve heard these ears of mine, you know you heard them.

Anon!: Commend me to thy lady.
Goodbye!: Give my praises to your lady.

Anon!: Her vestal livery is but sick and green, And none but fools do wear it.
Goodbye!: Her robes are sick and green, and no fools wear it.

Anon!: Roundly replied.
Goodbye!: I answered quickly.

Anon!: Why then I think Cassio’s an honest man.
Goodbye!: So I think Cassio’s an honest man.

Anon!: Your virtue is my privilege.
Goodbye!: Your virtue is my privilege.

Anon!: His name’s Cinna.
Goodbye!: His name’s Cinna.

Anon!: For your life you durst not.
Goodbye!: You won’t be able to live for long.

Anon!: Where is Malvolio?
Goodbye!: Where’s Malvolio?

Anon!: Consent to pay thee that I never had?— Arrest me, foolish fellow, if thou dar’st.
Goodbye!: If you’re willing to pay you that I never had?—Arror me, foolish man, if you dare.

Anon!: I noted her not, but I looked on her.
Goodbye!: I didn’t notice her, but I looked at her.

Anon!: The Duke himself, Or any of my brothers of the state, Cannot but feel this wrong as ’twere their own.
Goodbye!: The Duke himself, or any of my brothers of the state, can’t only feel this wrong as if it were their own.

Anon!: O Banquo, Banquo, Our royal master’s murdered!
Goodbye!: Oh Banquo, Banquo, our royal master’s murdered!

Anon!: Do so, good Messala.
Goodbye!: Do so, Messala.

Anon!: Oh, by this count I shall be much in years Ere I again behold my Romeo.
Goodbye!: Oh, by this count I’ll be much older than I’ve been before.

Anon!: I, by attorney, bless thee from thy mother, Who prays continually for Richmond’s good.
Goodbye!: I swear by your mother, who always prays for Richmond’s good.

Anon!: Why wither not the leaves that want their sap?
Goodbye!: Why don’t you get the leaves that want their sap?

Anon!: Within this three hours will fair Juliet wake.
Goodbye!: Within three hours Juliet will wake up.

Anon!: I do not bid the thunder-bearer shoot, Nor tell tales of thee to high-judging Jove.
Goodbye!: I don’t want the thunder-bearer to shoot, and I don’t tell you anything about you to judge Jove.

Anon!: Beshrew my very heart, I think you are happy in this second match, For it excels your first.
Goodbye!: I think you’re happy in this second match, because it’s your first match.

Anon!: Fine apparition!
Goodbye!: A beautiful apparition!

Anon!: Since they did plot The means that dusky Dis my daughter got, Her and her blind boy’s scandaled company I have forsworn.
Goodbye!: Since they plotted the way my daughter was able to get rid of the dusky Dis, I’ve been sworn to have her and her blind boy’s slander.

Anon!: You mar our labor.
Goodbye!: You’re causing us to work.

Anon!: You durst not so have tempted him.
Goodbye!: You wouldn’t have tempted him like that.

Anon!: My lord, that would dishonor him!
Goodbye!: My lord, that would dishonor him!

Anon!: Ay, he.
Goodbye!: Yes, he.

Anon!: Wherein hath Caesar thus deserved your loves?
Goodbye!: Where has Caesar deserved your love?

Anon!: Yes, sooth, and so do you.
Goodbye!: Yes, sooth, and so do you.

Anon!: I’ll follow this good man, and go with you; And, having sworn truth, ever will be true.
Goodbye!: I’ll follow this good man and go with you.

Anon!: Did you?
Goodbye!: Did you?

Anon!: Why then, the devil give him good of it!
Goodbye!: Then the devil will give him good advice!

Anon!: We may as bootless spend our vain command Upon th' enragèd soldiers in their spoil As send precepts to the Leviathan To come ashore.
Goodbye!: We can as sanely spend our vain command on the enragèd soldiers in their armor as send precepts to the Leviathan to come ashore.

Anon!: My husband is on earth, my faith in heaven.
Goodbye!: My husband is on earth, and I’m in heaven.

Anon!: Ah, cut my lace asunder, That my pent heart may have some scope to beat, Or else I swoon with this dead-killing news!
Goodbye!: Oh, cut my lace asunder so my pent heart can have some room to beat, or else I’ll swoon with this dead-killing news!

Anon!: I cannot live to hear the news from England.
Goodbye!: I can’t live to hear the news from England.

Anon!: I think his soul is in hell, madonna.
Goodbye!: I think his soul is in hell, madonna.

Anon!: Dined at home”?
Goodbye!: I’ve been drank at home”?

Anon!: Murder!
Goodbye!: Murder!

Anon!: O damned Iago!
Goodbye!: Oh damned Iago!

Anon!: Finish, good lady.
Goodbye!: Finish, good lady.

Anon!: What is the matter, ho?
Goodbye!: What’s the matter, hmmm?

Anon!: Let me love him for that, and do you love him because I do.
Goodbye!: Let me love him for that, and you love him because I do.

Anon!: Who calls so loud?
Goodbye!: Who’s calling so loud?

Anon!: Tis too bad, too bad.
Goodbye!: It’s too bad, too bad.

Anon!: You shall hear more.
Goodbye!: You’ll hear more.

Anon!: They are free men, but I am banishèd.
Goodbye!: They’re free men, but I’m not.

Anon!: Where are his eyes?
Goodbye!: Where are his eyes?

Anon!: Do you intend it?
Goodbye!: Do you want it?

Anon!: Sport?
Goodbye!: Sport?

Anon!: Here’s our chief guest.
Goodbye!: Here’s our chief guest.

Anon!: How silver-sweet sound lovers' tongues by night, Like softest music to attending ears!
Goodbye!: The sound of lovers’ tongues by night is silver-sweet, like the softest music to listen to!

Anon!: Since I am crept in favor with myself, I will maintain it with some little cost.
Goodbye!: Since I’m a favorer, I’ll keep it with some little money.

Anon!: I will say so.
Goodbye!: I’ll say that.

Anon!: Our solemn hymns to sullen dirges change, Our bridal flowers serve for a buried corse, And all things change them to the contrary.
Goodbye!: Our solemn hymns to sullen dirges change, our bridal flowers serve as a burial corse, and everything changes them to the contrary.

Anon!: Killing swine.
Goodbye!: Killing swine.

Anon!: Younger than she are happy mothers made.
Goodbye!: Younger than she is, happy mothers.

Anon!: He was wont to call me usurer; let him look to his bond.
Goodbye!: He was wont call me usurer; let him look at his contract.

Anon!: A gentleman.
Goodbye!: A gentleman.

Anon!: Sirrah, I’ll teach thee a speech.
Goodbye!: Sirrah, I’ll give you a speech.

Anon!: Came you from Padua, from Bellario?
Goodbye!: Have you come from Padua, from Bellario?

Anon!: And I, delivering you, am satisfied, And therein do account myself well paid.
Goodbye!: And I’m satisfied, and I’m well paid.

Anon!: O Antony, O thou Arabian bird!
Goodbye!: Oh, Antony, Oh, you Arabian bird!

Anon!: Go fetch them hither.
Goodbye!: Go get them here.

Anon!: Help me, help me!
Goodbye!: Help me, help me!

Anon!: Where is the thousand marks thou hadst of me?
Goodbye!: Where are the thousand marks you had of me?

Anon!: Hath not a Jew eyes?
Goodbye!: Doesn’t a Jew have eyes?

Anon!: So in the world.
Goodbye!: That’s true in the world.

Anon!: By my count, I was your mother much upon these years That you are now a maid.
Goodbye!: I swear, I was your mother in the years you have been a maid.

Anon!: Nay, an there were two such, we should have none shortly, for one would kill the other.
Goodbye!: If there were two such people, we’d have none soon, because one would kill the other.

Anon!: Who saw Cesario, ho?
Goodbye!: Who saw Cesario?

Anon!: O hell-kite!
Goodbye!: Oh, hell-kite!

Anon!: Mistress!
Goodbye!: Mistress!

Anon!: Marry, that, I think, be young Petruchio.
Goodbye!: I think that’s young Petruchio.

Anon!: Why, Dromio?
Goodbye!: Why, Dromio?

Anon!: She’s not well married that lives married long, But she’s best married that dies married young.
Goodbye!: She’s not well married, who lives married long, but she’s best married, who dies young.

Anon!: And there the snake throws her enameled skin, Weed wide enough to wrap a fairy in.
Goodbye!: And there the snake throws her skin out, weed enough wide to wrap a fairy in.

Anon!: I like not that.
Goodbye!: I don’t like that.

Anon!: My life is run his compass.
Goodbye!: My life is run by his compass.

Anon!: She was too good for me.
Goodbye!: She was too good for me.

Anon!: Art thou thus boldened, man, by thy distress Or else a rude despiser of good manners, That in civility thou seem’st so empty?
Goodbye!: Are you so bold, man, by your distress or else a rude despiser of good manners, that you seem so empty in civility?

Anon!: Tybalt is dead, and Romeo banishèd.”
Goodbye!: Tybalt is dead, and Romeo has been banned.”

Anon!: Go thou.
Goodbye!: Go.

Anon!: Why, this is not Lear.
Goodbye!: Why, this is not Lear.

Anon!: Why, anything.
Goodbye!: No, anything.

Anon!: What’s your will?
Goodbye!: What do you want?

Anon!: Is ’t possible?
Goodbye!: Is it possible?

Anon!: Give me my sword.
Goodbye!: Give me my sword.

Anon!: I Beyond all limit of what else i' th' world Do love, prize, honor you.
Goodbye!: I’m beyond all the limits of what else I’m doing to love you, honor you.

Anon!: And sometime lurk I in a gossip’s bowl In very likeness of a roasted crab, And when she drinks, against her lips I bob And on her withered dewlap pour the ale.
Goodbye!: And when she drinks, I bob her lips and pour the ale on her withered dewlap.

Anon!: A blessèd labor, my most sovereign lord.
Goodbye!: A blessed labor, my sovereign lord.

Anon!: It was ourself thou didst abuse.
Goodbye!: It was ours, you did abuse.

Anon!: Well, stand aside.—'Fore God, they are both in a ale.
Goodbye!: Well, stand aside.—God, they’re both in a beer.

Anon!: Gone, sir.
Goodbye!: Gone, sir.

Anon!: I do defy thy commination And apprehend thee for a felon here.
Goodbye!: I’m a fool and apprehend you for a felon here.

Anon!: I must needs report the truth.
Goodbye!: I have to tell you the truth.

Anon!: Mooncalf, speak once in thy life, if thou beest a good mooncalf.
Goodbye!: Mooncalf, speak once in your life, if you’re a good mooncalf.

Anon!: Look, look.
Goodbye!: Look, look.

Anon!: I take ’t ’tis later, sir.
Goodbye!: I think it’s later, sir.

Anon!: Name Cleopatra as she is called in Rome.
Goodbye!: Name Cleopatra, as she is called in Rome.

Anon!: Alas the day!
Goodbye!: Oh, that’s the day!

Anon!: I stumbled when I saw.
Goodbye!: I stumbled when I saw it.

Anon!: Oh, how I long to have some chat with her!
Goodbye!: Oh, how long I’ve been to chat with her!

Anon!: I am sure he is in the fleet.
Goodbye!: I’m sure he’s in the fleet.

Anon!: I am tame, sir.
Goodbye!: I’m tame, sir.

Anon!: What hath quenched them hath given me fire.
Goodbye!: What has shattered them has given me fire.

Anon!: Peace, children, peace.
Goodbye!: Quiet, children, quiet.

Anon!: It will be rain tonight.
Goodbye!: It will rain tonight.

Anon!: Bring him before us.
Goodbye!: Bring him to us.

Anon!: God give him joy!
Goodbye!: God give him joy!

Anon!: We’ll have thee to a couch Softer and sweeter than the lustful bed On purpose trimmed up for Semiramis.
Goodbye!: We’ll have you trimmed up to a softer and sweeter couch than the lustful bed on purpose for Semiramis.

Anon!: Help me hence, ho!
Goodbye!: Help me out of here, ho!

Anon!: Find thou the means, and I’ll find such a man.
Goodbye!: Find out the way, and I’ll find a man like that.

Anon!: What means this shouting?
Goodbye!: What’s this shouting?

Anon!: So do not I.
Goodbye!: I don’t.

Anon!: The passages of alleys, creeks, and narrow lands; A hound that runs counter and yet draws dryfoot well, One that before the judgment carries poor souls to hell.
Goodbye!: The passages of rivers, creeks, and narrow lands; a hound who runs against the ground and draws dryfoot well, one who, before judgment, brings poor souls to hell.

Anon!: But here they come.
Goodbye!: But here they come.

Anon!: Look, where he comes.
Goodbye!: Look, where he comes.

Anon!: I would I were thy bird.
Goodbye!: I wish I were your bird.

Anon!: This a dull sight.
Goodbye!: This is a dull sight.

Anon!: This torture should be roared in dismal hell.
Goodbye!: This torture should be roared in terrible hell.

Anon!: I cannot blame thee now to weep, For such an injury would vex a very saint, Much more a shrew of thy impatient humor.
Goodbye!: I can’t blame you for crying now, because such a traumatic injury would vex a very saint, much more a shrew of your unpatient humor.

Anon!: Are you now going to dispatch this thing?
Goodbye!: Are you going to do this now?

Anon!: I’ll help you to a horse.
Goodbye!: I’ll help you get a horse.

Anon!: Behold how like a maid she blushes here!
Goodbye!: Look, how she blushes like a maid here!

Anon!: Do you confess so much?
Goodbye!: Do you confess so much?

Anon!: But I’ll amerce you with so strong a fine That you shall all repent the loss of mine.
Goodbye!: But I’ll punish you so harshly that you’ll all regret the loss of mine.

Anon!: Why, if two gods should play some heavenly match And on the wager lay two earthly women, And Portia one, there must be something else Pawned with the other, for the poor rude world Hath not her fellow.
Goodbye!: If two gods could play some heavenly match and put on the wager two earthly women, Portia one, there must be something else to be done with the other, because the poor poor world doesn’t have her fellow.

Anon!: He, sir, that must marry this woman.
Goodbye!: He, sir, who must marry this woman.

Anon!: Freedom!
Goodbye!: Freedom!

Anon!: Now, Signior Petruchio, how speed you with my daughter?
Goodbye!: Now, Signior Petruchio, how are you going with my daughter?

Anon!: Come between us, good Benvolio.
Goodbye!: Come between us, Benvolio.

Anon!: The strangers all are gone.
Goodbye!: The strangers are all gone.

Anon!: We have not yet set down this day of triumph.
Goodbye!: We haven’t yet set the day of triumph.

Anon!: No occupation.
Goodbye!: No job.

Anon!: He will not know what all but he do know.
Goodbye!: He won’t know what all except he knows.

Anon!: Go take this shape And hither come in ’t.
Goodbye!: Go take this shape and come here.

Anon!: Jove’s lightning, the precursors O' th' dreadful thunderclaps, more momentary And sight-outrunning were not.
Goodbye!: The lightning, the precursors of dreadful thunderclaps, were more momentary and sight-outrunning.

Anon!: Now sits the wind fair, and we will aboard.
Goodbye!: Now the wind is shining, and we’ll be on board.

Anon!: Said he not so?
Goodbye!: Didn’t he say that?

Anon!: I will deliver you or else lie for you.
Goodbye!: I’ll either deliver you or lie for you.

Anon!: Last night of all, When yond same star that’s westward from the pole Had made his course t' illume that part of heaven Where now it burns, Marcellus and myself, The bell then beating one— Peace, break thee off.
Goodbye!: Last night, when the same star who’s westward from the pole had made his way to the heavens where it’s burning, Marcellus and I, the bell beating one— Peace, break you off.

Anon!: This is a most majestic vision, and Harmonious charmingly.
Goodbye!: This is a majestic vision, and it’s charming.

Anon!: If thou didst ever thy dear father love— O God!
Goodbye!: If you ever loved your dear father— Oh God!

Anon!: Sit, worthy friends.
Goodbye!: Sit down, worthy friends.

Anon!: Well, do your discretion.
Goodbye!: Well, do your discretion.

Anon!: Iago is most honest.
Goodbye!: Iago is very honest.

Anon!: Oh, that record is lively in my soul!
Goodbye!: Oh, that record is lively in my soul!

Anon!: I cannot tell wat is dat.
Goodbye!: I can’t tell if it’s dat.

Anon!: Why, he is the Prince’s jester, a very dull fool, only his gift is in devising impossible slanders.
Goodbye!: He’s the Prince’s fool, a very dull fool, and his gift is to create impossible slanders.

Anon!: I’ll put it on.
Goodbye!: I’ll put it on.

Anon!: Did he live now,
Goodbye!: He was alive now.

Anon!: Tis like the howling of Irish wolves against the moon.
Goodbye!: It’s like the howling of Irish wolves against the moon.

Anon!: I will be angry.
Goodbye!: I’ll be angry.

Anon!: How easy is it, then!
Goodbye!: That’s how easy it is, then!

Anon!: Hence.
Goodbye!: Go on.

Anon!: I will not trouble you As yet to question you about your fortunes.— Give us some music, and, good cousin, sing.
Goodbye!: I’ll not bother you to ask about your fortunes.—Come on, listen to some music, and, good cousin, sing.

Anon!: I would not change it.
Goodbye!: I wouldn’t change it.

Anon!: O Juliet, I already know thy grief.
Goodbye!: Oh Juliet, I know your grief already.

Anon!: A thousand times the worse to want thy light.
Goodbye!: A thousand times worse to want your light.

Anon!: Not Hermia but Helena I love.
Goodbye!: I love Hermia, but Helena.

Anon!: You say you do not know the lady’s mind.
Goodbye!: You say you don’t know the lady’s mind.

Anon!: Now.
Goodbye!: Now.

Anon!: And so falls it out With Rivers, Vaughan, Grey; and so ’twill do With some men else that think themselves as safe As thou and I, who, as thou know’st, are dear To princely Richard and to Buckingham.
Goodbye!: And so will Rivers, Vaughan, Grey, and so will happen to some men who think themselves as safe as you and I, who, as you know, are dear to princely Richard and Buckingham.

Anon!: Signior Hortensio, come you to part the fray?
Goodbye!: Signior Hortensio, are you coming to join the fight?

Anon!: I am an ass, indeed; you may prove it by my long ears.—I have served him from the hour of my nativity to this instant, and have nothing at his hands for my service but blows.
Goodbye!: I’m an ass, indeed.

Anon!: Prithee, say on.
Goodbye!: Please, tell me.

Anon!: O heavy day!
Goodbye!: Oh, what a sad day!

Anon!: Is ’t like that lead contains her?
Goodbye!: Is that the lead contained in her?

Anon!: Let them go.
Goodbye!: Let them go.

Anon!: Better I were distract— So should my thoughts be severed from my griefs, And woes by wrong imaginations lose The knowledge of themselves.
Goodbye!: I wish I could distract myself— I should be able to shake my thoughts off my grief and lose the knowledge of myself.

Anon!: Tis as arrant a piece of knavery, mark you now, as can be offert, in your conscience now, is it not?
Goodbye!: It’s as arrant as a piece of knavery, you can tell, as you can offer, in your conscience now, isn’t it?

Anon!: I will answer you with gait and entrance.
Goodbye!: I’ll answer you with a gait and a ring.

Anon!: Whate’er becomes of me, This is a soldier’s kiss.
Goodbye!: What’s going on from me is a soldier’s kiss.

Anon!: Help me into some house, Benvolio, Or I shall faint.
Goodbye!: Help me get some house, Benvolio, or I’ll faint.

Anon!: He’s fortified against any denial.
Goodbye!: He’s fortified against any denial.

Anon!: He will come straight.
Goodbye!: He’ll come straight.

Anon!: Tis but a peevish boy—yet he talks well— But what care I for words?
Goodbye!: But what do I care about words?

Anon!: Thither will I invite the duke and all’s contented followers.
Goodbye!: I’ll invite the duke and all his contented followers.

Anon!: His lecture will be done ere you have tuned.
Goodbye!: He’ll be done if you’ve tuned in.

Anon!: And what to?
Goodbye!: And what do you mean?

Anon!: And let our hearts, as subtle masters do, Stir up their servants to an act of rage And after seem to chide 'em.
Goodbye!: And let our hearts, like subtle masters, stir up their servants to a rage and then appear to chide them.

Anon!: Is ’t frailty that thus errs?
Goodbye!: Is it a stale story that tries to get worse?

Anon!: Thou must be patient.
Goodbye!: You have to be patient.

Anon!: He is called Aunchient Pistol.
Goodbye!: He’s called Aunchient Pistol.

Anon!: Live, live!
Goodbye!: Live, live!

Anon!: How now, my metal of India?
Goodbye!: What’s going on, my metal from India?

Anon!: O excellent device— and make a sop of him.
Goodbye!: Oh, what an excellent device— and make a sop of him.

Anon!: Then lead the way, good father; and heavens so shine That they may fairly note this act of mine.
Goodbye!: Then lead the way, good father; and heavens so shine that they can see how I am.

Anon!: Brother John Bates, is not that the morning which breaks yonder?
Goodbye!: Brother John Bates, isn’t that morning that breaks?

Anon!: Let some of my people have a special care of him.
Goodbye!: Some of my people should care about him.

Anon!: God help the noble Claudio!
Goodbye!: God help Claudio!

Anon!: By th' way we met My wife, her sister, and a rabble more Of vile confederates.
Goodbye!: We met my wife, her sister, and a rabble of vile confederates.

Anon!: My lord, they stay for you to give your daughter to her husband.
Goodbye!: My lord, they’re waiting for you to give your daughter to her husband.

Anon!: Believe then, if you please, that I can do strange things.
Goodbye!: If you want, then I’ll do something strange.

Anon!: Is it a true thing?
Goodbye!: Is it true?

Anon!: Brother, I’ll go and bring it thee.
Goodbye!: Brother, I’ll go and bring it to you.

Anon!: Shylock, there’s thrice thy money offered thee.
Goodbye!: Shylock, you’ve got three of your money.

Anon!: I am not mad.
Goodbye!: I’m not insane.

Anon!: You shall know more hereafter.
Goodbye!: You’ll know more later.

Anon!: You must needs yield your reason, Sir Andrew.
Goodbye!: You’re going to need to give me your reason, Sir Andrew.

Anon!: I am unfit for state and majesty.
Goodbye!: I’m not in the mood for state and majesty.

Anon!: Dear lady— Give me leave, beseech you.
Goodbye!: Dear lady— Please leave me alone.

Anon!: How dost thou and thy master agree?
Goodbye!: How are you and your master agree?

Anon!: Celerity is never more admired Than by the negligent.
Goodbye!: The lust of the king is never more admired than the lustful.

Anon!: This shall determine that.
Goodbye!: This will determine that.

Anon!: There’s my cap.
Goodbye!: Here’s my cap.

Anon!: It’s nine o'clock.
Goodbye!: It’s nine o'clock.

Anon!: Sweet-heart!
Goodbye!: Sweetheart!

Anon!: There’s two or three of us have seen strange sights.
Goodbye!: There’s two or three of us who’ve seen strange sights.

Anon!: If he have never drunk wine afore, it will go near to remove his fit.
Goodbye!: If he’s never drunk wine before, it’ll go away to remove his fit.

Anon!: Bless you, fair dame!
Goodbye!: Bless you, fair dame!

Anon!: Why, then, we kill all our women.
Goodbye!: So we kill all our women.

Anon!: An you part so, mistress, I would I might never draw sword again.
Goodbye!: If you part of that, my mistress, I’d never draw a sword again.

Anon!: Nay, good Lysander.
Goodbye!: No, Lysander.

Anon!: Come, wait upon him.
Goodbye!: Come on, wait on him.

Anon!: And here’s a marvelous convenient place for our rehearsal.
Goodbye!: And here’s a wonderful place for our rehearsal.

Anon!: Doth Fortune play the huswife with me now?
Goodbye!: Is Fortune playing the huswife with me now?

Anon!: Was my father a traitor, Mother?
Goodbye!: Was my father a traitor, Mother?

Anon!: But, sith I am entered in this cause so far, Pricked to ’t by foolish honesty and love, I will go on.
Goodbye!: But if I’ve been beaten up in this fight so far, I’ll go on.

Anon!: Ay, I thank God, my father, and yourself.
Goodbye!: Yes, I thank God, my father, and yourself.

Anon!: Retire thee, go where thou art billeted.
Goodbye!: Go to the place where you’re seated.

Anon!: Watch me like Argus.
Goodbye!: Watch me like a pig.

Anon!: Faith, no, as you may season it in the charge.
Goodbye!: No, you can’t, as you can.

Anon!: But since the affairs of men rest still incertain, Let’s reason with the worst that may befall.
Goodbye!: But since the men’s affairs are still uncertain, let’s go with the worst that could happen.

Anon!: I like the work well.
Goodbye!: I like the work.

Anon!: Rescue, fair lord, or else the day is lost!
Goodbye!: Rescue, dear lord, or the day is lost!

Anon!: You laugh when boys or women tell their dreams.
Goodbye!: You laugh when boys or women tell their dreams.

Anon!: You must not look so sour.
Goodbye!: You can’t look so sour.

Anon!: Take up the sword again, or take up me.
Goodbye!: Take the sword back, or take me up.

Anon!: Ay, my lord.
Goodbye!: Yes, my lord.

Anon!: Follow, I pray you.
Goodbye!: Follow me, please.

Anon!: I’ll never care what wickedness I do, If this man come to good.
Goodbye!: I’ll never care what wickedness I do, if this man comes to good.

Anon!: Poor and content is rich, and rich enough, But riches fineless is as poor as winter To him that ever fears he shall be poor.
Goodbye!: Poor and content is rich, and rich enough, but riches are as poor as winter to him that ever fears he will be poor.

Anon!: Right glad I am he was not at this fray.
Goodbye!: I’m glad he wasn’t in this fight.

Anon!: Zounds, hold your peace.
Goodbye!: Go ahead, calm down.

Anon!: What satisfaction canst thou have tonight?
Goodbye!: What satisfaction can you have tonight?

Anon!: I will the banner from a trumpet take And use it for my haste.
Goodbye!: I’ll take the banner from a trumpet and use it to grab it.

Anon!: Stir with the lark tomorrow, gentle Norfolk.
Goodbye!: Stir with the lark tomorrow, gentle Norfolk.

Anon!: Here’s Romeo’s man.
Goodbye!: Here’s Romeo’s man.

Anon!: Oh, my dear Cassio!
Goodbye!: Oh, my dear Cassio!

Anon!: Thou hast my love.
Goodbye!: You have my love.

Anon!: I say thy husband.
Goodbye!: I say your husband.

Anon!: Then patiently hear my impatience.
Goodbye!: Then listen to my impatience patiently.

Anon!: Horrible sight!
Goodbye!: A horrible sight!

Anon!: I’ll have grounds More relative than this.
Goodbye!: I’ll have more reason to do that than this.

Anon!: Did my father strike my gentleman For chiding of his fool?
Goodbye!: Did my father strike my gentleman for chiding at him?

Anon!: Very good.
Goodbye!: Very good.

Anon!: Most meet That first we come to words, and therefore have we Our written purposes before us sent, Which, if thou hast considered, let us know If ’twill tie up thy discontented sword And carry back to Sicily much tall youth That else must perish here.
Goodbye!: Most people agree that we first come to words, and therefore we have our written purposes before us sent.

Anon!: Get thee away.
Goodbye!: Get away from me.

Anon!: Thou liest, thou thread, thou thimble, Thou yard, three-quarters, half-yard, quarter, nail!
Goodbye!: You liar, you thread, you thimble, you yard, three-quarters, half-yard, quarter, nail!

Anon!: What thou wouldst do Is done unto thy hand.
Goodbye!: What you want to do is to get your hand.

Anon!: I have offended reputation, A most unnoble swerving.
Goodbye!: I’ve offended reputation, a very unnoble swerving.

Anon!: That I’ll try.
Goodbye!: I’ll try that.

Anon!: Tis said, man, and farewell.
Goodbye!: It’s said, man, and goodbye.

Anon!: I prithee, who doth he trot withal?
Goodbye!: Please, who’s he trotting with?

Anon!: Never till this day Saw I him touched with anger so distempered.
Goodbye!: I never saw him touch with so much anger until today.

Anon!: Base is the slave that pays.
Goodbye!: Base is the slave who pays.

Anon!: I’ll rather dwell in my necessity.
Goodbye!: I’d rather dwell on my need.

Anon!: Be ’t so.
Goodbye!: Be it.

Anon!: Farewell.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: Before you hazard, for in choosing wrong I lose your company.
Goodbye!: Before you risk, because I’m losing your company.

Anon!: None, my lord.
Goodbye!: No, my lord.

Anon!: Tell him so yourself, And see how he will take it at your hands.
Goodbye!: Tell him so yourself, and see how he’ll take it to you.

Anon!: O mischief strangely thwarting!
Goodbye!: Oh, mischief is causing a strange blow!

Anon!: Put off your maiden blushes, avouch the thoughts of your heart with the looks of an empress, take me by the hand, and say “Harry of England, I am thine,” which word thou shalt no sooner bless mine ear withal, but I will tell
Goodbye!: Put off your maiden blushes, avouch the thoughts of your heart with the look of an empress, take me by the hand and say “Harry of England, I am yours,” which you’

Anon!: True, my good boy.—Come, bring us to this hovel.
Goodbye!: Yes, my good boy.—Come, bring us to this hovel.

Anon!: If you thrive well, bring them to Baynard’s Castle, Where you shall find me well accompanied With reverend fathers and well-learnèd bishops.
Goodbye!: If you’re well-behaved, bring them to Baynard’s Castle, where you’ll find me accompanied with reverend fathers and well-learned bishops.

Anon!: That last is true.
Goodbye!: That last one is true.

Anon!: Uncle, I must come forth.
Goodbye!: Uncle, I have to come out.

Anon!: Much will be seen in that.
Goodbye!: That’s what I’ll see.

Anon!: Hers you are.
Goodbye!: You are hers.

Anon!: Here lies the county slain, And Juliet bleeding, warm and newly dead, Who here hath lain these two days buried.— Go, tell the Prince.
Goodbye!: Here lies the slain county, and Juliet is bleeding, warm and newly dead, who has been buried here for two days.—Go, tell the Prince.

Anon!: And too soon marred are those so early made.
Goodbye!: And too soon are those who made it so early.

Anon!: As well as I can, madam.
Goodbye!: As well as I can, madam.

Anon!: What are they, beseech your ladyship?
Goodbye!: What are they, please ask your ladyship?

Anon!: Crowns in my purse I have and goods at home, And so am come abroad to see the world.
Goodbye!: I have crowns in my purse and goods at home, and so I’m coming abroad to see the world.

Anon!: The night has been unruly.
Goodbye!: The night has been unruly.

Anon!: Why, what did I?
Goodbye!: What did I do?

Anon!: Hail to your lordship.
Goodbye!: Go to your lordship.

Anon!: Come, tailor, let us see these ornaments.
Goodbye!: Come on, tailor, let’s see these ornaments.

Anon!: If thou hast nature in thee, bear it not.
Goodbye!: If you have nature in you, don’t bear it.

Anon!: Ay, marry, what is he?
Goodbye!: Yes, what is he?

Anon!: Good signors both, when shall we laugh?
Goodbye!: Good signors both, when should we laugh?

Anon!: If thou the next night following enjoy not Desdemona, take me from this world with treachery and devise engines for my life.
Goodbye!: If you’re not going to Desdemona the next night, take me out of this world with treachery and devise my life plans.

Anon!: Bring forth men-children only, For thy undaunted mettle should compose Nothing but males.
Goodbye!: Bring out men-children only, because your unreliable sanity should compose nothing but men.

Anon!: His glory not extenuated wherein he was worthy, nor his offenses enforced for which he suffered death.
Goodbye!: His glory wasn’t attenuated when he was worthy, nor his crimes for which he died.

Anon!: Wake Duncan with thy knocking.
Goodbye!: Wake Duncan with your knocking.

Anon!: Come, Casca, you and I will yet ere day See Brutus at his house.
Goodbye!: Come on, Casca, you and I will see Brutus at his house on the day.

Anon!: That is because the traitor murderer lives.
Goodbye!: That’s because the murderer of the traitors lives.

Anon!: Why are you drawn?
Goodbye!: Why are you getting drawn?

Anon!: My lord it shall be done.
Goodbye!: My lord, it’s time to do it.

Anon!: I will be satisfied.
Goodbye!: I’ll be satisfied.

Anon!: Wherefore is that?
Goodbye!: Why?

Anon!: Can he that deny?
Goodbye!: Can he deny that?

Anon!: Tis said they eat each other.
Goodbye!: They said they eat each other.

Anon!: Tis better as it is.
Goodbye!: It’s better than that.

Anon!: It hath been taught us from the primal state That he which is was wished until he were, And the ebbed man, ne’er loved till ne’er worth love, Comes deared by being lacked.
Goodbye!: It’s been taught from the primal state that the man who was wished until he were, and the ebbed man who never loved until he was worth love, has come to be deared by being

Anon!: Besides—I ha' not since put up my sword— Against the Capitol I met a lion, Who glared upon me and went surly by, Without annoying me.
Goodbye!: Besides—I’ve never put up my sword since—I met a lion on the Capitol, who glared on me and went by a lion, without bothering me.

Anon!: Let it work, For ’tis the sport to have the engineer Hoist with his own petard.
Goodbye!: It’s the sport to have the engineer Hoist with his own petard.

Anon!: Oh, ’twill be admirable!
Goodbye!: Oh, it’ll be admirable!

Anon!: Will it not be?
Goodbye!: Willn’t it be?

Anon!: Ay, marry, is ’t.
Goodbye!: Yes, it’s marriage.

Anon!: What is ’t o'clock?
Goodbye!: What time is it?

Anon!: I am not here.
Goodbye!: I’m not here.

Anon!: What other bond Than secret Romans that have spoke the word And will not palter?
Goodbye!: What other bond do you have than secret Romans who have spoken the word and won’t be able to scold?

Anon!: By heaven, I’ll make a ghost of him that lets me.
Goodbye!: I swear by heaven, I’ll make a ghost of him that lets me.

Anon!: Nothing but “low” and “little”!— Why will you suffer her to flout me thus?
Goodbye!: You’re going to suffer her to slander me like this?

Anon!: Look, when I vow, I weep.
Goodbye!: Look, when I promise, I weep.

Anon!: My lord, my lord— I will not hear you.
Goodbye!: My lord, my lord— I won’t hear you.

Anon!: I have brought him a present.
Goodbye!: I’ve brought him a present.

Anon!: O, one too much by thee!
Goodbye!: Oh, one of you is too much!

Anon!: A friend?
Goodbye!: A friend?

Anon!: Now let’s have a catch.
Goodbye!: Let’s catch it.

Anon!: For a little Follow, and do me service.
Goodbye!: For a little while, follow me and help me.

Anon!: He were an excellent man that were made just in the midway between him and Benedick.
Goodbye!: He was an excellent man who was made just midway between him and Benedick.

Anon!: Of what color?
Goodbye!: Of what color?

Anon!: An abominable monster!
Goodbye!: An abominable monster!

Anon!: We should have met you By sea and land, supplying every stage With an augmented greeting.
Goodbye!: We should have met you on land and sea, supplying everyone on the stage with a special greeting.

Anon!: Why that’s with watching, ’twill away again.
Goodbye!: That’s because you’re watching, and it’ll go away again.

Anon!: And now about the cauldron sing, Like elves and fairies in a ring, Enchanting all that you put in.
Goodbye!: And now sing about the cauldron like elves and fairies in a ring, enchanting everything you put in.

Anon!: The clock struck nine when I did send the Nurse.
Goodbye!: The clock struck nine when I sent the Nurse.

Anon!: The best I can, my lord.
Goodbye!: I’ll do the best I can, my lord.

Anon!: Less in your knowledge and your grace you show not Than our earth’s wonder, more than earth divine.
Goodbye!: You’re less than a wonder of our earth, more than a divine earth.

Anon!: Here come two noble beasts in, a man and a lion.
Goodbye!: Here come two noble beasts, a man and a lion.

Anon!: Happier than this— She is not bred so dull but she can learn.
Goodbye!: She’s not so dull, but she can learn.

Anon!: He is not here.
Goodbye!: He’s not here.

Anon!: Ay, by heaven, my lord.
Goodbye!: Yes, by heaven, my lord.

Anon!: Let me speak a little.
Goodbye!: Let me speak a little.

Anon!: I would not see ’t.
Goodbye!: I wouldn’t see it.

Anon!: The players cannot keep counsel.
Goodbye!: The players can’t keep their counsel.

Anon!: Youngling, thou canst not love so dear as I.   Graybeard, thy love doth freeze.
Goodbye!: Youngling, you can’t love as much as I am.

Anon!: Is this the noble Moor whom our full senate Call all in all sufficient?
Goodbye!: Is this the noble Moor whom our full senate calls sufficient?

Anon!: The castle’s gently rendered.
Goodbye!: The castle’s redesigned with a gentle twist.

Anon!: Do not abuse me.
Goodbye!: Don’t abuse me.

Anon!: My countryman, but yet I know him not.
Goodbye!: My countryman, but I don’t know him.

Anon!: I will hear further reason for this.
Goodbye!: I’ll hear more about this.

Anon!: I am no more mad than you are.
Goodbye!: I’m no more mad than you are.

Anon!: Let it be written in eight and eight.
Goodbye!: Let it be written in eight and eight.

Anon!: Oh, mickle is the powerful grace that lies In herbs, plants, stones, and their true qualities.
Goodbye!: Oh, mickle is the powerful grace that lies in herbs, plants, stones, and their true qualities.

Anon!: Nor doth this wood lack worlds of company, For you in my respect are all the world.
Goodbye!: This forest doesn’t have any worlds of business, because you are all the world.

Anon!: Ay, but I know— What dost thou know?
Goodbye!: Yes, but I know— What do you know?

Anon!: Now, my co-mates and brothers in exile, Hath not old custom made this life more sweet Than that of painted pomp?
Goodbye!: Now, my friends and brothers in exile, hasn’t old tradition made this life sweeter than the one of painted pomp?

Anon!: Be better suited.
Goodbye!: Be more comfortable.

Anon!: Alas, I rather hate myself For hateful deeds committed by myself.
Goodbye!: Alas, I hate myself more than hate myself for hateful deeds committed by myself.

Anon!: With another, for tying his new shoes with old ribbon?
Goodbye!: With another, for tying his new shoes with old ribbon?

Anon!: But I pray you, tell me, is my boy, God rest his soul, alive or dead?
Goodbye!: But please tell me, is my boy, God rest his soul, alive or dead?

Anon!: Maria once told me she did affect me, and I have heard herself come thus near, that, should she fancy, it should be one of my complexion.
Goodbye!: Maria told me she was affecting me, and I’ve heard herself come near me, that if she wants to, it should be one of my complexions.

Anon!: We have no friend But resolution, and the briefest end.
Goodbye!: We have no friend except a friend, and we have the best outcome.

Anon!: Though the nature of our quarrel yet never brooked parle, know now upon advice, it toucheth us both, that we may yet again have access to our fair mistress and be happy rivals in Bianca’s love, to labor and effect one thing specially.
Goodbye!: Even though we’ve never been in a fight, we know that now, on our advice, it’s a good idea to have access to our mistress and to be happy rivals in Bianca’s love,

Anon!: Safely stowed.
Goodbye!: Safely stowed.

Anon!: I’ll make you quiet.—What, cheerly, my hearts!
Goodbye!: I’ll make you quiet.—Oh, cheery, my hearts!

Anon!: Grumio, my horse.
Goodbye!: Grumio, my horse.

Anon!: My father loved Sir Rowland as his soul, And all the world was of my father’s mind.
Goodbye!: My father loved Sir Rowland as much as his soul loved him, and my father loved everything in the world.

Anon!: Ay, I praise God, and I have merited some love at his hands.
Goodbye!: Yes, I praise God, and I’ve got some love for him.

Anon!: That I have labored With all my wits, my pains, and strong endeavors, To bring your most imperial Majesties Unto this bar and royal interview, Your mightiness on both parts best can witness.
Goodbye!: I’ve fought hard and hard to bring your imperial Majesties to this bar and royal interview, and I can see how you can see how you can do it.

Anon!: Why, uncle, ’tis a shame.
Goodbye!: Oh, uncle, it’s a shame.

Anon!: Yes, I know thee to be Signior Lucentio.
Goodbye!: Yes, I know you’re Signior Lucentio.

Anon!: Here at the door.
Goodbye!: Here at the door.

Anon!: So, again, good night.
Goodbye!: So, again, good night.

Anon!: I will leave him.
Goodbye!: I’ll leave him.

Anon!: I think so too.
Goodbye!: I think so too.

Anon!: Talkers are no good doers.
Goodbye!: Talkers are not good doers.

Anon!: It shall be done, my lord.
Goodbye!: It will be done, my lord.

Anon!: And are not you my husband?
Goodbye!: And aren’t you my husband?

Anon!: Because that, like a jack, thou keep’st the stroke Betwixt thy begging and my meditation.
Goodbye!: Because you keep the stroke of your begging and my meditation.

Anon!: I am none of his flirt-gills.
Goodbye!: I’m not one of his flirty gills.

Anon!: I will not hold thee long.
Goodbye!: I won’t wait long.

Anon!: By report I know him well.
Goodbye!: I know him well.

Anon!: Go and importune her.
Goodbye!: Go and importune her.

Anon!: Women’s gentle brain Could not drop forth such giant-rude invention, Such Ethiop words, blacker in their effect Than in their countenance.
Goodbye!: Women’s gentle brain couldn’t pull out such a sluggish invention, such a sluggish word that is blacker in their effect than in their countenance.

Anon!: It must be so, for miracles are ceased, And therefore we must needs admit the means How things are perfected.
Goodbye!: It must be, because miracles have been stopped, and therefore we have to admit the way things are perfected.

Anon!: I’ll take my leave.
