Goodbye!: I’ll leave.

Anon!: If you can separate yourself and your misdemeanors, you are welcome to the house.
Goodbye!: If you can separate yourself from your misdemeanors, you’re welcome to the house.

Anon!: And on that vice in him will my revenge find notable cause to work.
Goodbye!: And I’ll find some reason to do that.

Anon!: No more of that.
Goodbye!: Don’t worry about that.

Anon!: Romeo.
Goodbye!: Romeo.

Anon!: Look I so pale, Lord Dorset, as the rest?
Goodbye!: Look, Lord Dorset, as pale as the rest?

Anon!: And came I not at last to comfort you?
Goodbye!: And didn’t I come to comfort you last night?

Anon!: I' faith, coz, ’tis he.
Goodbye!: I’m sure he’s right, coz.

Anon!: Go to the gate.
Goodbye!: Go to the gate.

Anon!: For who would bear the whips and scorns of time, Th' oppressor’s wrong, the proud man’s contumely, The pangs of despised love, the law’s delay, The insolence of office, and the spurns That patient merit of th' unworthy takes, When he himself might his quietus make With a bare bodkin?
Goodbye!: Who would be the whips and scorns of time, the oppressor’s wrong, the proud man’s sane, the sane love of despised people, the delay in the law, the

Anon!: Why, here is the note of the fashion to testify.
Goodbye!: Here’s the note of the fashion to testify.

Anon!: You are as well provided of both as any prince in the world.
Goodbye!: You’re as good as any prince in the world.

Anon!: I know his eye doth homage otherwhere, Or else what lets it but he would be here?
Goodbye!: I know his eyes are homages elsewhere, or else what does it mean he would be here?

Anon!: Tell me not, Friar, that thou hear’st of this, Unless thou tell me how I may prevent it.
Goodbye!: Don’t tell me that you hear about this, Friar, unless you tell me how I can prevent it.

Anon!: Today the lords you talked of are beheaded.
Goodbye!: Today the lords you talked about are beheaded.

Anon!: Where was she born?
Goodbye!: Where was she born?

Anon!: Arrest him, officer.
Goodbye!: Arrest him, officer.

Anon!: Lo, here’s the chain.
Goodbye!: Oh, here’s the necklace.

Anon!: My cousin means Signor Benedick of Padua.
Goodbye!: My cousin is Signor Benedick of Padua.

Anon!: My lord, upon the platform where we watch.
Goodbye!: My lord, we’re on the platform where we’re watching.

Anon!: A good sharp fellow.
Goodbye!: A good sharp man.

Anon!: By mine honor, in true English, I love thee, Kate.
Goodbye!: By my honor, I love you, Kate.

Anon!: A very handsome man.
Goodbye!: A very handsome man.

Anon!: He.
Goodbye!: He.

Anon!: Tell him I’ll knock his leek about his pate Upon Saint Davy’s day.
Goodbye!: Tell him I’ll knock his leek over his pate on Saint Davy’s day.

Anon!: So let high-sighted tyranny range on Till each man drop by lottery.
Goodbye!: So let the tyranny run away until each man drops by lottery.

Anon!: When devils will the blackest sins put on They do suggest at first with heavenly shows As I do now.
Goodbye!: When devils will put on the blackest sins, they’ll suggest at first with heavenly shows like I do now.

Anon!: Prithee, peace.
Goodbye!: Please, calm down.

Anon!: Those that do teach young babes Do it with gentle means and easy tasks.
Goodbye!: The people who teach young babies do it with gentle means and easy tasks.

Anon!: A king, perhaps— My lord— How chance the prophet could not at that time Have told me, I being by, that I should kill him?
Goodbye!: A king, perhaps— my lord— How could the prophet not have told me at that time that I should kill him?

Anon!: Give you good morrow, sir.
Goodbye!: Good morning, sir.

Anon!: Methinks I see my cousin’s ghost Seeking out Romeo, that did spit his body Upon a rapier’s point.
Goodbye!: I think I see my cousin’s ghost looking for Romeo, who spit his body on a rapier’s point.

Anon!: Well, I cannot tell.
Goodbye!: Well, I can’t tell.

Anon!: It is too late.
Goodbye!: It’s too late.

Anon!: Why, no.
Goodbye!: No.

Anon!: Prove that ever I lose more blood with love than I will get again with drinking, pick out mine eyes with a ballad-maker’s pen and hang me up at the door of a brothel house for the sign of blind Cupid.
Goodbye!: If you prove that I’ve lost more blood with love than I’ll get again with drinking, pick out my eyes with a ballad maker’s pen and hang me up at the door of a brothel house

Anon!: Twere best he speak no harm of Brutus here.
Goodbye!: He’d better not say anything wrong about Brutus here.

Anon!: Come on, i' God’s name, once more toward our father’s.
Goodbye!: Come on, God’s name, and go back to our father’s house.

Anon!: Will ’t please your highness walk?
Goodbye!: Will your highness walk?

Anon!: Is that the law?
Goodbye!: Is that the law?

Anon!: Stay, fellow.
Goodbye!: Stay, fellow.

Anon!: O, be gone!
Goodbye!: Oh, go away!

Anon!: Come hither, knight.
Goodbye!: Come here, knight.

Anon!: I cannot speak Any beginning to this peevish odds, And would in action glorious I had lost Those legs that brought me to a part of it.
Goodbye!: I can’t speak any beginning to this sluggish odds, and I wish I had lost those legs that brought me to a part of it.

Anon!: Heaven and thy thoughts are witness that thou art.
Goodbye!: Heaven and your thoughts are witnessing that you are.

Anon!: Thou art too wild, too rude and bold of voice— Parts that become thee happily enough And in such eyes as ours appear not faults.
Goodbye!: You’re too wild, too rude and bold to speak—parts that become you happy enough and don’t appear to be faultless in our eyes.

Anon!: Her name is Portia, nothing undervalued To Cato’s daughter, Brutus' Portia.
Goodbye!: Her name is Portia, and Cato’s daughter, Portia, has nothing to do with her name.

Anon!: I' faith, I am sorry that thou art not well.
Goodbye!: I’m sorry you’re not well.

Anon!: Thyself shalt see the act.
Goodbye!: You’ll see the act yourself.

Anon!: Nay, when I have a suit Wherein I mean to touch your love indeed It shall be full of poise and difficult weight And fearful to be granted.
Goodbye!: No, when I have a case where I want to touch your love, it will be difficult and difficult to get granted.

Anon!: Speak, Count, ’tis your cue.
Goodbye!: Speak, count, it’s your cue.

Anon!: Is it come to this?
Goodbye!: Is it coming to this?

Anon!: O fortune, fortune!
Goodbye!: Oh luck, luck!

Anon!: O braggart vile and damnèd furious wight, The grave doth gape, and doting death is near.
Goodbye!: Oh, vile and damned furious wight, the grave is gaping, and death is near.

Anon!: Let him not pass, But kill him rather.
Goodbye!: Don’t let him pass, but kill him.

Anon!: Go, some of you, And bring these gentlemen where Hamlet is.
Goodbye!: Go, some of you, and bring these gentlemen to Hamlet.

Anon!: His present and your pains we thank you for.
Goodbye!: We thank you for his present and your pains.

Anon!: Thou dost infect mine eyes.
Goodbye!: You’re infecting my eyes.

Anon!: Fore heaven, they have given me a rouse already.
Goodbye!: Fore heaven, they’ve given me a rouse already.

Anon!: Give me answer to it.
Goodbye!: Give me a reply.

Anon!: When it is paid according to the tenor.
Goodbye!: When it’s paid according to the tenor.

Anon!: Do you bite your thumb at us, sir?
Goodbye!: Do you bite your thumb at us?

Anon!: There is so much that thou wilt kill me straight.
Goodbye!: There’s so much that you’ll kill me straight away.

Anon!: I dare be sworn for him he would not leave it Nor pluck it from his finger for the wealth That the world masters.
Goodbye!: I’d be sworn he wouldn’t leave it, and he wouldn’t pluck it off his finger for the wealth that the world has.

Anon!: Speak to her, Hamlet.
Goodbye!: Speak to her, Hamlet.

Anon!: Thou art to die.
Goodbye!: You’re going to die.

Anon!: Speak.
Goodbye!: Speak.

Anon!: But as ’tis, We cannot miss him.
Goodbye!: But as it is, we can’t miss him.

Anon!: Tonight she is mewed up to her heaviness.
Goodbye!: Tonight she’s mewed up to her heaviness.

Anon!: What do they in the north When they should serve their sovereign in the west?
Goodbye!: What do they do in the north when they should serve their sovereign in the west?

Anon!: And what your Highness suffered under that shape, I beseech you take it for your own fault and not mine, for, had you been as I took you for, I made no offense.
Goodbye!: And what your Highness suffered under that shape, I beg you to take it for your own fault and not mine, because if you were as I took you for, I wouldn’t have made any offense.

Anon!: God bless your Grace!
Goodbye!: God bless your Grace!

Anon!: At such a time I’ll loose my daughter to him.
Goodbye!: At such a time, I’ll leave my daughter to him.

Anon!: Tyrant, show thy face!
Goodbye!: Tyrant, show your face!

Anon!: Noble Antony, not sickness should detain me.
Goodbye!: Noble Antony, not sickness should stop me.

Anon!: What do I fear?
Goodbye!: What do I fear?

Anon!: My noble lords and cousins all, good morrow.
Goodbye!: My noble lords and cousins, good morning.

Anon!: Madam, his majesty doth call for you,— And for your Grace, —and yours, my gracious lords.
Goodbye!: Madam, his majesty wants you—and your Grace—and yours, my gracious lords.

Anon!: Pray you, let’s sit together.
Goodbye!: Please, let’s sit together.

Anon!: I cannot speak enough of this content.
Goodbye!: I can’t speak enough about this.

Anon!: Alas, their love may be called appetite, No motion of the liver, but the palate, That suffer surfeit, cloyment, and revolt; But mine is all as hungry as the sea, And can digest as much.
Goodbye!: But my love may be called appetite, no motion of the liver, but the palate, who suffers from cloyment, and revolt.

Anon!: Will you pluck your sword out of his pilcher by the ears?
Goodbye!: Will you pluck your sword out of his pilcher by the ears?

Anon!: Dost fall?
Goodbye!: Do you fall?

Anon!: Hast thou not a word of joy?
Goodbye!: Don’t you have a word of joy?

Anon!: Come away, away.
Goodbye!: Come away, go away.

Anon!: O day and night, but this is wondrous strange!
Goodbye!: Oh, day and night, but this is a strange thing!

Anon!: How now, gentleman?
Goodbye!: What’s going on, gentleman?

Anon!: O, thou didst prophesy the time would come That I should wish for thee to help me curse That bottled spider, that foul bunch-backed toad!
Goodbye!: Oh, you prophesied that the time would come when I’d like you to help me curse that rotten spider, that foul bunch-backed toad!

Anon!: Spakest thou of Juliet?
Goodbye!: Are you complaining about Juliet?

Anon!: Madam, I go with all convenient speed.
Goodbye!: Madam, I’m going fast.

Anon!: He’s gone, but his wife’s killed.
Goodbye!: He’s gone, but his wife’s killed.

Anon!: The soul and body rive not more in parting Than greatness going off.
Goodbye!: The soul and body aren’t more involved in parting than the greatness going off.

Anon!: For, as I am a soldier, A name that in my thoughts becomes me best, If I begin the batt'ry once again, I will not leave the half-achieved Harfleur Till in her ashes she lie burièd.
Goodbye!: As a soldier, I’ll give you the best name for the soldier.

Anon!: You ever gentle gods, take my breath from me.
Goodbye!: You always gentle gods, take my breath away from me.

Anon!: Will either of you bear me a challenge to him?
Goodbye!: Will either of you challenge him?

Anon!: Ah me!
Goodbye!: Ah, me!

Anon!: I have forgot why I did call thee back.
Goodbye!: I’ve forgotten why I called you back.

Anon!: Do they hold the same estimation they did when I was in the city?
Goodbye!: Do they think they did the same thing when I was in the city?

Anon!: What a thrice-double ass Was I, to take this drunkard for a god And worship this dull fool!
Goodbye!: What a triple ass I was, to take this drunk man for a god and worship this dull fool!

Anon!: Harp on it still shall I till heart-strings break.
Goodbye!: I’ll keep it from squeezing until my heartstrings break.

Anon!: What’s the matter?
Goodbye!: What’s the matter?

Anon!: This is no place, this house is but a butchery.
Goodbye!: This is no place, this house is just a butchery.

Anon!: It is the lady that Pyramus must love.
Goodbye!: It’s the lady Pyramus must love.

Anon!: O eastern star!
Goodbye!: Oh, eastern star!

Anon!: A madness most discreet, A choking gall, and a preserving sweet.
Goodbye!: A sour, choking gall, and a sweet treat.

Anon!: Along with them They brought one Pinch, a hungry, lean-faced villain, A mere anatomy, a mountebank, A threadbare juggler, and a fortune-teller, A needy, hollow-eyed, sharp-looking wretch, A living dead man.
Goodbye!: Along with them they brought one Pinch, a hungry, lean-faced villain, a mere anatomy, a mountebank, a juggler, and a fortune-teller, a needy

Anon!: Pray heaven it be State matters, as you think, and no conception Nor no jealous toy concerning you.
Goodbye!: Please, heaven, it’s the state that matters, as you think, and no conception or jealous toy about you.

Anon!: And come you now with “knocking at the gate”?
Goodbye!: And are you coming with “knocking at the gate”?

Anon!: Be you constant in the accusation, and my cunning shall not shame me.
Goodbye!: Be calm in the accusation, and my sanity will not shame me.

Anon!: If it shall please you to make me a wholesome answer, I will do your mother’s commandment.
Goodbye!: If you want me to be a good answer, I’ll do your mother’s commandment.

Anon!: Not honestly, my lord, but so covertly that no dishonesty shall appear in me.
Goodbye!: I’m not so honest, my lord, but so secretly that I won’t be dishonest.

Anon!: Thou art on thy deathbed.
Goodbye!: You’re on your deathbed.

Anon!: She is not well.
Goodbye!: She’s not well.

Anon!: But let it rest.—Now, Litio, to you.
Goodbye!: But let it rest.—Now, Litio, let’s go to you.

Anon!: But now in the division of the kingdom, it appears not which of the dukes he values most, for equalities are so weighed that curiosity in neither can make choice of either’s moiety.
Goodbye!: But now in the division of the kingdom, it doesn’t seem to be the dukes he values most, because equalities are so heavily weighed that curiosity can’t make choice of either of them.

Anon!: Here comes the Emperor.
Goodbye!: Here comes the Emperor.

Anon!: Come, thou mortal wretch, With thy sharp teeth this knot intrinsicate Of life at once untie.
Goodbye!: Come, you mortal wretch, with your sharp teeth this knot is intrinsic to life once again.

Anon!: He is most in the company of the right noble Claudio.
Goodbye!: He’s most in the company of the right noble Claudio.

Anon!: I mean, she is the list of my voyage.
Goodbye!: I mean, she’s the list of my journey.

Anon!: O flesh, flesh, how art thou fishified!
Goodbye!: Oh flesh, flesh, how you’ve sprayed!

Anon!: Peace!
Goodbye!: Quiet!

Anon!: You say he dined at home; the goldsmith here Denies that saying.
Goodbye!: You say he ate at home, and the goldsmith here denies that saying.

Anon!: Katherine the curst!” A title for a maid of all titles the worst.
Goodbye!: Katherine the curse!” That’s the worst title for a maid of all titles.

Anon!: He did bespeak a chain for me but had it not.
Goodbye!: He said he had a necklace for me, but he didn’t have it.

Anon!: Be by, good madam, when we do awake him.
Goodbye!: Be there, madam, when we wake him up.

Anon!: I would kiss before I spoke.
Goodbye!: I’d kiss before I spoke.

Anon!: But, sir, here comes your boy.
Goodbye!: But here comes your boy, sir.

Anon!: O me, my heart, my rising heart!
Goodbye!: Oh, my heart, my rising heart!

Anon!: Oh, brave Iago, honest and just, That hast such noble sense of thy friend’s wrong!
Goodbye!: Oh, brave Iago, honest and just, that’s a noble sense of your friend’s wrong!

Anon!: Sir, know you this glove?
Goodbye!: Sir, do you know this glove?

Anon!: As she is mine, I may dispose of her— Which shall be either to this gentleman Or to her death—according to our law Immediately provided in that case.
Goodbye!: I can dispose of her immediately, as she is mine.

Anon!: Which of you trembles not that looks on me?
Goodbye!: Which of you doesn’t tremble with me?

Anon!: Had it th' ability of life to thank you.
Goodbye!: If you could thank you, you would have a good life.

Anon!: Sweetly in force unto her fair life’s end.
Goodbye!: She’s in force until her life’s end.

Anon!: A merry whoreson, ha!
Goodbye!: A merry whoreson, ha!

Anon!: Then weigh what loss your honor may sustain If with too credent ear you list his songs, Or lose your heart, or your chaste treasure open To his unmastered importunity.
Goodbye!: Then weigh what loss your honor may sustain if you list his songs with a savage ear, or lose your heart, or your treasure is open to his unmastered importunity.

Anon!: Scout me for him at the corner the orchard like a bum-baily.
Goodbye!: Scout me for him at the corner of the orchard like a bum-baily.

Anon!: I am not sorry neither.
Goodbye!: I’m not sorry, either.

Anon!: My lord, my lord!
Goodbye!: My lord, my lord!

Anon!: Name what part I am for and proceed.
Goodbye!: Tell me what part I’m going to do and proceed.

Anon!: Your love says, like an honest gentleman, 'Where is your mother?
Goodbye!: Your love says, like an honest gentleman, 'Where is your mother?

Anon!: Thou dost not mark me.
Goodbye!: You don’t mark me.

Anon!: And till she come, as truly as to heaven I do confess the vices of my blood So justly to your grave ears I’ll present How I did thrive in this fair lady’s love And she in mine.
Goodbye!: And until she comes, as true as I am to heaven I confess the slanders of my blood to your grave ears so justly I’ll tell you how I did thrive in this fair lady’s love and in my love

Anon!: Then move not, while my prayer’s effect I take.
Goodbye!: Then don’t move while I pray.

Anon!: Let me beseech your grace not to do so.
Goodbye!: Please don’t do so.

Anon!: That he was never trainèd up in arms.
Goodbye!: He never was trained up in arms.

Anon!: Come now, your promise.
Goodbye!: Come on, let’s talk about your promise.

Anon!: Is he not able to discharge the money?
Goodbye!: Isn’t he able to pay the money?

Anon!: A little water clears us of this deed.
Goodbye!: A little water clears us of this deed.

Anon!: Give me thy hand.
Goodbye!: Give me your hand.

Anon!: This shall end without the perdition of souls.
Goodbye!: This will end without the perdition of souls.

Anon!: Threescore and ten I can remember well, Within the volume of which time I have seen Hours dreadful and things strange, but this sore night Hath trifled former knowings.

Anon!: Madam, your mother craves a word with you.
Goodbye!: Madam, your mother wants to speak with you.

Goodbye!: I’m going to tell you: many things, if you have full consent, can work against each other, as many arrows have been loosened to one point, as many ways meet in one town, as many fresh

Anon!: Go, you wild bedfellow, you cannot soothsay.
Goodbye!: Go, you wild bedfellow, you can’t soothsay.

Anon!: Now, good sir, what are you?
Goodbye!: Now, good sir, what are you doing?

Anon!: Lucius!—Fast asleep?
Goodbye!: Lucius!—Fast asleep?

Goodbye!: But as all is mortal in nature, all nature in love is mortal in folly.

Anon!: Why, so didst thou.
Goodbye!: Why, so did you.

Anon!: Wednesday is tomorrow.
Goodbye!: Wednesday is tomorrow.

Anon!: Go thy ways to a nunnery.
Goodbye!: Go to a nunnery.

Anon!: Whose house?
Goodbye!: Whose house?

Anon!: Nay, I will do so.
Goodbye!: No, I’ll do so.

Anon!: Amen, amen.
Goodbye!: Amen, amen.

Goodbye!: Why the King of France is suddenly gone back know you’re wrong?

Goodbye!: The first question I’ll ask my Nerissa is whether she’d rather stay until the next night or go to bed now, two hours to day.

Anon!: Oh, God 'i' good e'en.
Goodbye!: Oh, God 'i’m good.

Anon!: Slanders, sir.
Goodbye!: Slanders, sir.

Anon!: Fare you well.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: Set on thy wife to observe.
Goodbye!: Tell your wife to watch.

Anon!: Come, Let’s have one other gaudy night.
Goodbye!: Come on, let’s have one other gaudy night.

Anon!: Is ’t possible?
Goodbye!: Is it possible?

Anon!: There came divers of Antonio’s creditors in my company to Venice that swear he cannot choose but break.
Goodbye!: There came a group of Antonio’s creditors in my company to Venice, who swear he can’t choose but break.

Anon!: The weight of this sad time we must obey.
Goodbye!: We have to obey the weight of this sad time.

Anon!: For you must understand he goes but to see a noise that he heard, and is to come again.
Goodbye!: You must understand that he only goes to see a noise he heard, and is coming back.

Anon!: None in the world, nor do I know the man.
Goodbye!: I don’t know him in the world, and I don’t know him.

Anon!: O simple!
Goodbye!: Oh, that’s simple!

Anon!: Poor Tom’s a-cold.
Goodbye!: Poor Tom’s a cold.

Anon!: His daughter and I will be king and queen—save our graces!—and Trinculo and thyself shall be viceroys.—Dost thou like the plot, Trinculo?
Goodbye!: His daughter and I will be king and queen—save our graces!—and Trinculo and yourself will be viceroys.—Do you like the plot, Trinculo?

Anon!: If you say, I hope you will not kill me.
Goodbye!: If you say something, I hope you won’t kill me.

Anon!: He kills her in her own humor.
Goodbye!: He kills her in her own way.

Anon!: An please your Majesty, let his neck answer for it, if there is any martial law in the world.
Goodbye!: If you want your Majesty, let his neck answer for it, if there is any martial law in the world.

Anon!: This approves her letter That she would soon be here.
Goodbye!: This is the reason she wrote that she’ll be here soon.

Anon!: Know’st thou the way to Dover?
Goodbye!: Do you know the way to Dover?

Anon!: I do beseech ye, if you bear me hard, Now, whilst your purpled hands do reek and smoke, Fulfill your pleasure.
Goodbye!: I beg you, if you bear me hard, then you’ll enjoy it.

Anon!: Who comes here?
Goodbye!: Who’s coming?

Anon!: Therefore be merry, Cassio, For thy solicitor shall rather die Than give thy cause away.
Goodbye!: So be happy, Cassio, because your lawyer will rather die than give you your cause.

Anon!: I have no power upon you.
Goodbye!: I have no power over you.

Anon!: Uncouple in the western valley.
Goodbye!: Unwind in the western valley.

Anon!: Answer to that.
Goodbye!: Answer that question.

Anon!: How now, Cassio!
Goodbye!: What’s going on, Cassio?

Anon!: A halter gratis, nothing else, for God’s sake.
Goodbye!: A halter is free, nothing else, for God’s sake.

Anon!: There be land rats and water rats, water thieves and land thieves—I mean pirates—and then there is the peril of waters, winds, and rocks.
Goodbye!: There are rats and water rats, thieves and pirates, and then there are dangers of water, winds, and rocks.

Anon!: I think we are too bold upon your rest.
Goodbye!: I think we’re too bold to rest.

Anon!: My leisure serves me, pensive daughter, now.— My lord, we must entreat the time alone.
Goodbye!: My leisure is for me now, my pensive daughter.—My lord, we have to wait for the time alone.

Goodbye!: I tell you, Captain, if you look at the maps of the Orld, I assure you that you’ll find in the comparisons between Macedon and Monmouth that the situation, look at, is both different.

Anon!: Why, what would you?
Goodbye!: What do you want?

Anon!: Why, doth not every earthly thing Cry shame upon her?
Goodbye!: Why, doesn’t every thing on earth cry shame on her?

Anon!: You see me, Lord Bassanio, where I stand Such as I am.
Goodbye!: You see me, Lord Bassanio, where I am.

Anon!: Our gracious brother, I will go with them.
Goodbye!: Our gracious brother, I’ll go with them.

Anon!: No more of drowning, do you hear?
Goodbye!: Don’t you hear any more about drowning?

Anon!: What shall I call thee when thou art a man?
Goodbye!: What should I call you when you’re a man?

Anon!: Are all thy conquests, glories, triumphs, spoils, Shrunk to this little measure?
Goodbye!: Are all your conquests, glories, triumphs, spoils, shrunk to this little measure?

Anon!: Well, may you see things well done there.
Goodbye!: Well, I hope you see what’s going on there.

Anon!: Let us not burden our remembrances with A heaviness that’s gone.
Goodbye!: Don’t burden our memories with a heaviness that’s gone.

Goodbye!: Nine or ten times I thought he’d snuck him here under the ribs.

Anon!: Prithee, how many boys and wenches must I have?
Goodbye!: Please, how many boys and wenches should I have?

Anon!: I beseech you, follow straight.
Goodbye!: Please, follow straight.

Anon!: The skies, the fountains, every region near Seemed all one mutual cry.
Goodbye!: The skies, the fountains, and every area near me were all a cry.

Anon!: Would you, the supervisor, grossly gape on, Behold her topped?
Goodbye!: You would, the supervisor, beg yourself to be a sluggish man, and see her topped?

Anon!: Who’s within?
Goodbye!: Who’s inside?

Anon!: I will proclaim my name about the field.
Goodbye!: I’ll proclaim my name on the field.

Anon!: Enobarbus, welcome.
Goodbye!: Enobarbus, welcome.

Anon!: Young fry of treachery!
Goodbye!: Young fry of treachery!

Goodbye!: What did Northumberland say about Richmond?

Goodbye!: But she, your subject, refuses such sovereignty.

Goodbye!: Should I keep your hogs and eat husks with them?

Anon!: Tis so.

Goodbye!: Sue to him again, and he’s yours.

Goodbye!: Look, here’s the usurper’s swollen head.

Goodbye!: Hound or spaniel, brach or him, Bobtail tyke or trundle-tail— Tom will make them weep and wail.

Anon!: Perhaps you have learned it without book.
Goodbye!: Maybe you’ve learned it without a book.

Anon!: Pardon not that.
Goodbye!: Don’t pardon that.

Goodbye!: My brother has a daughter, almost the copy of my child who’s dead, and she is heir to both of us.

Anon!: Let us see.

Goodbye!: You’ve been beaten up for such a wish!

Anon!: Or keep it as a cistern for foul toads To knot and gender in!
Goodbye!: Or keep it as a cistern for foul toads to knot and marry!

Anon!: Madam.
Goodbye!: Madam.

Goodbye!: Is this well done?

Anon!: Tis nine o'clock.
Goodbye!: It’s nine o'clock.

Anon!: Ay, a thousand times.—Peter!
Goodbye!: Yes, a thousand times.—Peter!

Goodbye!: I’ll do it.

Goodbye!: What color, madam?

Anon!: Assist, good friends.
Goodbye!: Help, good friends.

Anon!: Here’s to thy health.
Goodbye!: Here’s to your health.

Anon!: I do not set my life in a pin’s fee, And for my soul—what can it do to that, Being a thing immortal as itself?
Goodbye!: I don’t set my life in a pin’s fee, and for my soul—what can it do to that, being as immortal as itself?

Anon!: Do you withdraw yourself a little while,
Goodbye!: Take a moment to get out of here.

Anon!: For my part, the sea cannot drown me.
Goodbye!: For my part, the sea can’t drown me.

Anon!: As from your graves rise up, and walk like sprites, To countenance this horror!
Goodbye!: As you rise up from your graves and walk like sprites, to countenance this horror!

Anon!: I see the ruin of my house.
Goodbye!: I see the ruin of my house.

Anon!: But soft, I pray you.
Goodbye!: But please, I beg you.

Anon!: From the four corners of the earth they come To kiss this shrine, this mortal breathing saint.
Goodbye!: They come from the four corners of the earth to kiss this shrine, this mortal breathing saint.

Anon!: What complexion is she of?
Goodbye!: What color is she?

Anon!: O sweet mistress, speak!
Goodbye!: Oh sweet mistress, speak!

Anon!: Oh, what a goodly outside falsehood hath!
Goodbye!: Oh, what a falsehood that’s good for you!

Anon!: Now boast thee, Death, in thy possession lies A lass unparalleled.
Goodbye!: Now boast you, Death, that you have a lass that’s unparalleled.

Anon!: Casca will tell us what the matter is.
Goodbye!: Casca will tell us what’s going on.

Goodbye!: I’m not made of stones, but I’m able to find your kind love, against my conscience and my soul.

Anon!: I am feared in field and town.
Goodbye!: I’m afraid in the field and in the town.

Anon!: I rest much bounden to you.
Goodbye!: I’m very close to you.

Anon!: He is my prisoner, and you shall not have him.
Goodbye!: He’s my prisoner, and you won’t have him.

Anon!: Moblèd queen” is good.
Goodbye!: The moblèd queen” is good.

Anon!: Tis the infirmity of his age.
Goodbye!: It’s the infirmity of his age.

Anon!: The sky doth frown and lour upon our army.
Goodbye!: The sky frowns and lours our army.

Anon!: Betrayed I am.
Goodbye!: I’ve been trayed.

Anon!: Can you deny all this?
Goodbye!: Can you deny all this?

Anon!: In the name lay A moiety of the world.
Goodbye!: In the name of the world there is a moiety.

Anon!: Wherefore?
Goodbye!: Why?

Anon!: Either send the chain, or send me by some token.
Goodbye!: Either send the necklace, or send me some token.

Anon!: This was well done, my bird.
Goodbye!: This was well done, my bird.

Anon!: She was of Carthage, not of Tunis.
Goodbye!: She was from Carthage, not Tunis.

Anon!: Tis a good hearing when children are toward.
Goodbye!: It’s a good thing to hear when children are coming.

Anon!: So they do nothing, ’tis a venial slip.
Goodbye!: They’re not doing anything, it’s a jolly slip.

Anon!: Therefore I will depart unkissed.
Goodbye!: So I’ll leave unkissed.

Anon!: Hoyday, a riddle!
Goodbye!: Hoyday, a riddle!

Anon!: Hold off your hands.
Goodbye!: Hold off your hands.

Anon!: A crow without feather?
Goodbye!: A crow without feathers?

Anon!: His roguish madness Allows itself to any thing.
Goodbye!: His roguish madness allows itself to do anything.

Anon!: The worm of conscience still begnaw thy soul.
Goodbye!: The worm of conscience still begnaws your soul.

Anon!: Small cheer and great welcome makes a merry feast.
Goodbye!: A small feast of cheer and great welcome makes a merry feast.

Anon!: Oh, thou didst then ne'er love so heartily.
Goodbye!: Oh, you never loved so much.

Anon!: Had I as many mouths as Hydra, such an answer would stop them all.
Goodbye!: If I had as many mouths as Hydra, that would stop them all.

Anon!: Let them play it.
Goodbye!: Let them play it.

Goodbye!: Come on, good Athenian.

Goodbye!: Goodbye!

Anon!: Here, Peter Quince.
Goodbye!: Here, Peter Quince.

Anon!: Now spurs the lated traveler apace To gain the timely inn, and near approaches The subject of our watch.
Goodbye!: Now the late traveler is rushing to get the inn and is approaching the subject of our watch.

Anon!: But shall ’t be shortly?
Goodbye!: But will it be soon?

Anon!: Mere prattle without practice Is all his soldiership.
Goodbye!: He’s a soldier.

Anon!: Why sinks that cauldron?
Goodbye!: Why is that cauldron sinking?

Goodbye!: What, keep a week away?

Goodbye!: No, his mouth has stopped.

Goodbye!: Go to bed, Francisco.

Anon!: Shall they see us?
Goodbye!: Shall they see us?

Anon!: It is now two o'clock.
Goodbye!: It’s two o'clock now.

Anon!: Sister, welcome.
Goodbye!: Hello, sister.

Anon!: Come ho, and wake Diana with a hymn!
Goodbye!: Come on, and wake Diana with a hymn!

Anon!: You know not what you do.
Goodbye!: You don’t know what you’re doing.

Anon!: In Syracusa was I born, and wed Unto a woman happy but for me, And by me, had not our hap been bad.
Goodbye!: I was born in Syracusa, and wed a woman happy for me, and by me, we would have not had a bad day.

Anon!: And find I am alone felicitate In your dear highness' love.
Goodbye!: And I’m sure I’m alone to be a felicitate for your dear highness’s love.

Anon!: Ah, Tranio, what a cruel father’s he!
Goodbye!: Oh, Tranio, what a cruel father he is!

Anon!: How satisfied, my lord?

Anon!: Why, give it to my wife, and fetch your money.
Goodbye!: Give it to my wife and get your money.

Anon!: What is between you?
Goodbye!: What’s between you?

Anon!: Then every soldier kill his prisoners.
Goodbye!: Then every soldier kills his prisoners.

Goodbye!: I spoke to his man.

Anon!: But tell me, is young George Stanley living?
Goodbye!: But tell me, is young George Stanley alive?

Anon!: And thereof came it that the man was mad.
Goodbye!: And it came to that man that he was insane.

Anon!: I hope now thou art not drowned.
Goodbye!: I hope you’re not drowned.

Anon!: How can it be?
Goodbye!: How can it be?

Anon!: Till then sit still, my soul.
Goodbye!: So sit still, my soul.

Anon!: O, sir, the conceit is deeper than you think for.
Goodbye!: Oh, sir, the conceit is deeper than you think.

Anon!: If I do so, it will be of more price Being spoke behind your back than to your face.
Goodbye!: If I do so, it’ll be more expensive to be slammed behind your back than to your face.

Anon!: Is it new and old too?
Goodbye!: Is it old and new?

Anon!: I pray you, tell it.
Goodbye!: Please tell me.

Anon!: What, must I come to you With five and twenty, Regan?
Goodbye!: What, should I come to you with five and twenty, Regan?

Anon!: Nay, I think it is scurvy, and begin to find myself fopped in it.
Goodbye!: No, I think it’s scurvy, and I’m starting to get thrown in it.

Anon!: Prithee, who is ’t that thou mean’st?
Goodbye!: Please, who are you talking about?

Anon!: If it be a suit from the count, I am sick, or not at home.
Goodbye!: If it’s a suit from the count, I’m sick or not at home.

Anon!: Thou hast harped my fear aright.
Goodbye!: You’ve ruined my fear.

Anon!: But ’tis gone.
Goodbye!: But it’s gone.

Anon!: The date is out of such prolixity.
Goodbye!: The date is out of such a bad mood.

Anon!: I would I had your bond, for I perceive A weak bond holds you.
Goodbye!: I wish I had your contract, because I think a weak contract holds you.

Anon!: Tis he.
Goodbye!: That’s him.

Anon!: Would ’twere done.
Goodbye!: I wish it were done.

Anon!: Come, bring us, bring us where he is.
Goodbye!: Come, bring us, bring us where he is.

Anon!: For my dinner.
Goodbye!: For my dinner.

Anon!: Let’s to billiards.
Goodbye!: Let’s go to billiards.

Anon!: I speak no treason.
Goodbye!: I’m not saying anything wrong.

Anon!: It proves not so.
Goodbye!: It’s not true.

Anon!: Now welcome, Kate, and bear me witness all That here I kiss her as my sovereign queen.
Goodbye!: Now welcome, Kate, and bear me witness that I kiss her as my sovereign queen.

Anon!: My leg is cut in two.
Goodbye!: My leg is cut in two.

Anon!: Hamlet.” This in obedience hath my daughter shown me, And more above, hath his solicitings, As they fell out by time, by means, and place, All given to mine ear.
Goodbye!: Hamlet.” This obedience has shown my daughter, and more above, has given me his invitations, as they fell out by time, by means, and by place, all given to me.

Anon!: Who would fardels bear, To grunt and sweat under a weary life, But that the dread of something after death, The undiscovered country from whose bourn No traveler returns, puzzles the will And makes us rather bear those ills we have Than fly to others that we know not of?
Goodbye!: Who would be able to bear the burden of a weary life, to grunt and sweat, but that the dread of something after death, the undiscovered country from which no traveler returns, puzzles the will

Anon!: Go charge Agrippa Plant those that have revolted in the vant, That Antony may seem to spend his fury Upon himself.
Goodbye!: Go charge Agrippa to plant those who revolted in the vant so that Antony could seem to spend his fury on himself.

Anon!: Let him do his spite.
Goodbye!: Let him do his job.

Anon!: I’ll find out your man, And he shall signify from time to time Every good hap to you that chances here.
Goodbye!: I’ll find your man, and he’ll tell you from time to time that you’re lucky.

Anon!: He speaks nothing but madman.
Goodbye!: He’s only a madman.

Anon!: Oh, on my soul, my cousin is belied!
Goodbye!: Oh, on my soul, my cousin is belied!

Anon!: Let it come down.
Goodbye!: Let it come down.

Anon!: Hie to your chamber.
Goodbye!: Go to your room.

Anon!: The time has been That, when the brains were out, the man would die, And there an end.
Goodbye!: The time has come when the brains were out, and the man would die, and that’s the end.

Anon!: If so, be patient, sister.
Goodbye!: If that’s true, please, sister.

Anon!: Twas the boy that stole your meat, and you’ll beat the post.
Goodbye!: You were the boy who stole your meat, and you’ll beat the post.

Anon!: He, woman.
Goodbye!: He, woman.

Anon!: Why, sweet Othello—   I have not deserved this.
Goodbye!: Oh, Othello— I haven’t deserved this.

Anon!: If thou pleasest not, I yield thee up my life.
Goodbye!: If you don’t like me, I’ll give you my life.

Anon!: Therefore my son i' th' ooze is bedded, and I’ll seek him deeper than e'er plummet sounded And with him there lie mudded.
Goodbye!: So my son is bedded, and I’ll seek him deeper than he’s ever sounded, and with him there’s a smuggling.

Anon!: Thou speak’st aright.
Goodbye!: You’re right.

Anon!: Tis now the very witching time of night, When churchyards yawn and hell itself breathes out Contagion to this world.
Goodbye!: It’s the time of night for witching, when churchyards are yawn and hell itself breathes out the world.

Anon!: O God!
Goodbye!: Oh God!

Anon!: Oh, rarely base!
Goodbye!: Oh, you’re rarely a base!

Anon!: Oh, what learning is!
Goodbye!: What a good idea!

Anon!: We waste our lights in vain, like lights by day.
Goodbye!: We’re going to waste our lights in vain, like lights by day.

Anon!: I will speak to this fellow.—Whose grave’s this, sirrah?
Goodbye!: I’ll speak to this fellow.—Would this grave be this, sir?

Anon!: Not to his father’s.
Goodbye!: Not to his father’s house.

Anon!: No, you shall paint when you are old.
Goodbye!: No, you’ll paint when you’re old.

Anon!: Here, sweet lord, at your service.
Goodbye!: Here, sir, at your service.

Anon!: What’s the boy Malcolm?
Goodbye!: What’s the boy Malcolm?

Anon!: And that is Claudio.
Goodbye!: And that’s Claudio.

Anon!: Marry, now I let go your hand, I am barren.
Goodbye!: Now I let go of your hand, I’m barren.

Anon!: Speak what we feel, not what we ought to say.
Goodbye!: Speak what we feel, not what we should say.

Anon!: O hell, what have we here?
Goodbye!: Oh hell, what are we doing here?

Anon!: He hath every month a new sworn brother.
Goodbye!: Every month he has a new sworn brother.

Anon!: Now, banished Kent, If thou canst serve where thou dost stand condemned, So may it come thy master, whom thou lovest, Shall find thee full of labors.
Goodbye!: Now, banished Kent, if you can serve where you’re condemned, then you can come to your master, whom you love, who will find you full of labor.

Anon!: One knocks.
Goodbye!: One knocks.

Anon!: See, see, here comes the man we went to seek.
Goodbye!: Look, here comes the man we went to seek.

Anon!: Say that I lingered with you at your shop To see the making of her carcanet, And that tomorrow you will bring it home.
Goodbye!: Say that I waited with you at your shop to see the making of her carcanet, and that you’ll bring it home tomorrow.

Anon!: Swords out, and tilting one at other’s breasts In opposition bloody.
Goodbye!: Swords out, and tilting one at another’s breasts in opposition bloody.

Anon!: Yet, when I saw it last, it was besmeared As black as Vulcan in the smoke of war.
Goodbye!: But when I saw it last time, it was smeared as black as Vulcan in the smoke of war.

Anon!: He shall have nothing but the penalty.
Goodbye!: He’ll have nothing but the penalty.

Anon!: Why should he follow?
Goodbye!: Why should he follow him?

Anon!: How many months Do you desire?
Goodbye!: How many months do you want?

Anon!: So haply are they friends to Antony.
Goodbye!: They’re friends to Antony.

Anon!: Give me some light, away!
Goodbye!: Give me some light away!

Anon!: Let’s briefly put on manly readiness, And meet i' th' hall together.
Goodbye!: Let’s get ready for a quick meeting and meet up in the hall.

Anon!: You, uncivil lady, To whose ingrate and unauspicious altars My soul the faithfull’st off'rings have breathed out That e'er devotion tendered—what shall I do?
Goodbye!: You, uncivil lady, have breathed out my ingrate and unauspicious altars that have been poured out by the faithful, whose devotion has been redeemed—what should I do?

Anon!: That’s a fault that water will mend.
Goodbye!: That’s a fault that water will repair.

Anon!: Hood my unmanned blood bating in my cheeks, With thy black mantle, till strange love, grow bold, Think true love acted simple modesty.
Goodbye!: Hood my unmanned blood batting in my cheeks, with your black mantle, until strange love grows bold, think true love acted simple modesty.

Anon!: I like it not.
Goodbye!: I don’t like it.

Anon!: Fear you the boar, and go so unprovided?
Goodbye!: Do you fear the boar, and go so unprepared?

Anon!: How, in one house, Should many people under two commands Hold amity?
Goodbye!: How, in one house, should many people under two command have a good life?

Anon!: What though I be not so in grace as you— So hung upon with love, so fortunate— But miserable most, to love unloved?
Goodbye!: What if I’m not as blessed as you—so blessed, so fortunate—but I’m miserable to love unloved?

Anon!: That goldsmith there, were he not packed with her, Could witness it, for he was with me then, Who parted with me to go fetch a chain, Promising to bring it to the Porpentine, Where Balthasar and I did dine together.
Goodbye!: That goldsmith, if he weren’t packed with her, could see it, because he was with me, who parted with me to go fetch a chain, and then he promised to bring it to the Por

Anon!: Ay, Casca.
Goodbye!: Yes, Casca.

Anon!: But where unbruisèd youth with unstuffed brain Doth couch his limbs, there golden sleep doth reign.
Goodbye!: But when unloved young men with unstuffed brains sleep in their arms, there’s golden sleep.

Anon!: Lord,” quoth he?
Goodbye!: Lord,” he said?

Anon!: Or rather bottomless, that as fast as you pour affection in, it runs out.
Goodbye!: Or rather bottomless, that as fast as you pour affection in, it’s out.

Anon!: It is not possible.
Goodbye!: It’s not possible.

Anon!: My sweet Cassio!
Goodbye!: My sweet Cassio!

Anon!: If you do sweat to put a tyrant down, You sleep in peace, the tyrant being slain.
Goodbye!: If you sweat to put down a tyrant, you’ll sleep peacefully, the tyrant being killed.

Anon!: Therefore Make space enough between you.
Goodbye!: So make space between you.

Anon!: I am he that is so love-shaked.
Goodbye!: I’m the one who’s so love-shaken.

Anon!: What says my lord?
Goodbye!: What do you say, my lord?

Anon!: You, you, ay, you!
Goodbye!: You, you, yes, you!

Anon!: Marry, that can Hero!
Goodbye!: That’s Hero!

Anon!: That’s very true, my lord.
Goodbye!: That’s very true, my lord.

Anon!: In my chamber window lies a book.
Goodbye!: In my room there’s a book.

Anon!: Say that thou overheardst us, And bid her steal into the pleachèd bower Where honeysuckles ripened by the sun Forbid the sun to enter, like favorites Made proud by princes, that advance their pride Against that power that bred it.
Goodbye!: Say you’ve overheard us, and bid her to steal into the sand where honeysuckles ripened by the sun forbid the sun to enter, like favorites made by princes, who advance their pride against

Anon!: I know the boy will well usurp the grace, Voice, gait, and action of a gentlewoman.
Goodbye!: I know the boy will give a gentlewoman the grace, voice, gait, and action.

Anon!: Thou praisest the worst best.
Goodbye!: You’re the worst person you’ve ever met.

Anon!: Intend a kind of zeal both to the Prince and Claudio, as in love of your brother’s honor, who hath made this match, and his friend’s reputation, who is thus like to be cozened with the semblance of a maid, that you have discovered thus.
Goodbye!: Give the Prince and Claudio a kind of zeal, as in love with your brother’s honor, who made this match, and his friend’s reputation, who is like a semblance of a mai

Anon!: From helmet to the spur, all blood he was.
Goodbye!: From helmet to spur, he was all blood.

Anon!: The hurt cannot be much.
Goodbye!: The hurt can’t be anything.

Anon!: The residue of your fortune Go to my cave and tell me.—Good old man, Thou art right welcome as thy master is.
Goodbye!: You’re welcome as welcome as your master is.

Anon!: Marcus Octavius, Marcus Justeius, Publicola, and Caelius, are for sea; But we keep whole by land.
Goodbye!: Marcus Octavius, Marcus Justeius, Publicola, and Caelius are for sea; but we’re all on land.

Anon!: As much to him, else is his thanks too much.
Goodbye!: As much to him as I do, and his thanks are too much.

Anon!: Have you a soul or sense?
Goodbye!: Have you a sense of soul?

Anon!: How goes the night, boy?
Goodbye!: How is the night going, boy?

Anon!: Make haste, I say.
Goodbye!: Hurry up, I say.

Anon!: I never shall endure her.
Goodbye!: I won’t endure her.

Anon!: Mistress, that you know.
Goodbye!: Mistress, you know.

Anon!: It nothing ill becomes thee.— Aboard my galley I invite you all.
Goodbye!: I invite you all to join me in my galley.

Anon!: What trumpet’s that?
Goodbye!: What’s that trumpet?

Anon!: Awake remembrance of these valiant dead And with your puissant arm renew their feats.
Goodbye!: Remind these brave men of war and renew their feats with your powerful arm.

Anon!: Prithee, dispatch.
Goodbye!: Please, hurry up.

Anon!: Nay, but the devil take mocking.
Goodbye!: No, but the devil is mocking me.

Anon!: Let’s see.
Goodbye!: Let’s see.

Anon!: And did you leave him in this contemplation?
Goodbye!: And did you leave him in this contemplation?

Anon!: He knows not yet of his honorable fortune.
Goodbye!: He hasn’t yet learned about his honorable fortune.

Anon!: She was a vixen when she went to school.
Goodbye!: She was a vixen when she went to school.

Anon!: My lord of Gloucester hath conveyed him hence.
Goodbye!: My lord of Gloucester has sent him to the country.

Anon!: Pardon this fault, and by my soul I swear I never more will break an oath with thee.
Goodbye!: Pardon this fault, and I swear I’ll never break an oath with you again.

Anon!: Cousins, you know what you have to do.—O, I cry you mercy, friend.
Goodbye!: Cousins, you know what you have to do.—Oh, I cry you mercy, friend.

Anon!: God has given you one face and you make yourselves another.
Goodbye!: God has given you one face and you’re making another.

Anon!: wherefore sink you down?
Goodbye!: Why are you sinking down?

Anon!: I have heard her swear ’t.
Goodbye!: I’ve heard her swear.

Anon!: The potent poison quite o'ercrows my spirit.
Goodbye!: The poison is poisoning my spirit.

Anon!: We know each other’s faces; for our hearts, He knows no more of mine than I of yours, Or I of his, my lord, than you of mine.— Lord Hastings, you and he are near in love.
Goodbye!: We know each other’s faces; for our hearts, he doesn’t know more about mine than I’m about yours, or I’m about his, my lord, than you are about to love.

Anon!: The Prince of Arragon hath ta'en his oath And comes to his election presently.
Goodbye!: The Prince of Arragon has oath and comes to his election now.

Anon!: So should a murderer look, so dead, so grim.
Goodbye!: That’s what a murderer should look like, so dead, so grim.

Anon!: How do you, madam?
Goodbye!: How are you, madam?

Anon!: For hear me, Hero, wooing, wedding, and repenting is as a Scotch jig, a measure, and a cinquepace.
Goodbye!: Hero, wooing, wedding, and repenting is as a Scotch jig, a measure, and a fiveuepace.

Anon!: And leave us, Publius, lest that the people, Rushing on us, should do your age some mischief.
Goodbye!: And leave us, Publius, so that the people who rush on us should do some mischief in your age.

Anon!: These ducats pawn I for my father here.
Goodbye!: I’m pawning these ducats for my father here.

Anon!: The citizens are up, and Tybalt slain.
Goodbye!: The citizens are up, and Tybalt has been killed.

Anon!: What, will you murder me?—Thou jailer, thou, I am thy prisoner.
Goodbye!: What, will you murder me?—You jailer, you, I’m your prisoner.

Anon!: It ish give over.
Goodbye!: It’s going to give over.

Anon!: I will not.
Goodbye!: I won’t.

Anon!: I’ll do ’t.
Goodbye!: I’ll do it.

Anon!: Put up your sword.
Goodbye!: Put your sword on the sword.

Anon!: Speak to us.
Goodbye!: Tell us.

Anon!: Be kind and courteous to this gentleman.
Goodbye!: Be kind and courteous to this gentleman.

Anon!: I knew a wench married in an afternoon as she went to the garden for parsley to stuff a rabbit, and so may you, sir.
Goodbye!: I knew a wench married in an afternoon as she went to the garden for parsley to stuff a rabbit, and so may you, sir.

Anon!: First, rehearse your song by rote, To each word a warbling note.
Goodbye!: First, listen to your song by rote, and make sure to listen to each word a warbling note.

Anon!: Say, “the brave Antony.” The valiant Caesar!
Goodbye!: Say, “the brave Antony.” The valiant Caesar!

Anon!: Oh, that I were a fool!
Goodbye!: Oh, I wish I were a fool!

Anon!: Ay, ay, the cords.
Goodbye!: Yes, yes, the cords.

Anon!: Is ’t possible that on so little acquaintance you should like her?
Goodbye!: Is it possible that you would like her if you were so young?

Anon!: Here’s a madman will murder me.
Goodbye!: Here’s a madman who will murder me.

Anon!: But, sirrah, you shall buy this sport as dear As all the metal in your shop will answer.
Goodbye!: But you’ll pay for this sport as much as the metal in your shop will pay.

Anon!: I’ll fume with them!” And with that word she struck me on the head, And through the instrument my pate made way,
Goodbye!: I’ll fume with them!” And with that word she struck me on the head, and my slurped way through the instrument.

Anon!: We will hear Caesar’s will.
Goodbye!: We’ll hear Caesar’s will.

Anon!: What a life is this That your poor friends must woo your company?
Goodbye!: What a life is this that your poor friends must woo your company?

Anon!: No, I went round to work, And my young mistress thus I did bespeak: “Lord Hamlet is a prince out of thy star.
Goodbye!: No, I went round to work, and my young mistress said that so: “Lord Hamlet is a prince out of your star.

Anon!: O, let her live, And I’ll corrupt her manners, stain her beauty, Slander myself as false to Edward’s bed, Throw over her the veil of infamy.
Goodbye!: Oh, let her live, and I’ll corrupt her manners, stain her beauty, slander myself as false to Edward’s bed, throw over her the veil of infamy.

Anon!: Brutus, my lord.
Goodbye!: Brutus, my lord.

Anon!: Be patient, for the world is broad and wide.
Goodbye!: Be patient, because the world is wide and wide.

Anon!: What eye but such an eye would spy out such a quarrel?
Goodbye!: What eye would spy out such a fight?

Anon!: I say “amen.”
Goodbye!: I say “amen.”

Anon!: Ay.
Goodbye!: Yes.

Anon!: Heavens make our presence and our practices Pleasant and helpful to him!
Goodbye!: Heavens make our presence and our practices pleasant and helpful to him!

Anon!: And now I do bethink me, it was she First told me thou wast mad, then camest in smiling, And in such forms which here were presupposed Upon thee in the letter.
Goodbye!: And now I think about it, she first told me you were insane, then came smiling, and in such forms that were presupposed here in the letter.

Anon!: What news with you, sir?
Goodbye!: What news do you have, sir?

Anon!: You hear him all night.
Goodbye!: You hear him all night.

Anon!: Who talks within there?
Goodbye!: Who’s there talking?

Anon!: And yet thou wilt tutor me from quarreling!
Goodbye!: And yet you’ll help me out of fighting!

Anon!: Tell me why.
Goodbye!: Tell me why.

Anon!: So much for him.
Goodbye!: That’s what he’s doing.

Anon!: Ratcliffe, about the mid of night come to my tent And help to arm me.
Goodbye!: Ratcliffe, come to my tent around midnight and help me arm me.

Anon!: Do not rise yet.
Goodbye!: Don’t rise yet.

Anon!: If good, thou shamest the music of sweet news By playing it to me with so sour a face.
Goodbye!: If it’s good, you’re shameful of the sweet news by playing it to me with so sour a face.

Anon!: As they pass by, pluck Casca by the sleeve, And he will, after his sour fashion, tell you What hath proceeded worthy note today.
Goodbye!: As they pass by, pluck Casca by the sleeve, and he will tell you what’s been done today.

Anon!: No, sir, ’tis in grain; Noah’s flood could not do it.
Goodbye!: No, sir, it’s a grainy thing, but Noah’s flood didn’t do it.

Anon!: Hath she forgot already that brave prince, Edward, her lord, whom I some three months since Stabbed in my angry mood at Tewkesbury?
Goodbye!: Has she already forgotten that brave prince, Edward, her lord, whom I’ve been slain three months ago at Tewkesbury?

Anon!: Your husband being troubled with a shrew Measures my husband’s sorrow by his woe.
Goodbye!: Your husband is upset with a shrew, which is what makes my husband sad by his suffering.

Anon!: Is ’t long or round?
Goodbye!: Is it long or round?

Anon!: Avaunt, you cullions!
Goodbye!: You scolded me!

Anon!: Looked he or red or pale, or sad or merrily?
Goodbye!: Is he red or pale, or sad or merrily?

Anon!: No, Caesar hath it not.
Goodbye!: No, Caesar hasn’t.

Anon!: Dromio—thou, Dromio—thou snail, thou slug, thou sot.
Goodbye!: Dromio—you, Dromio—you snail, you slug, you sot.

Anon!: Stand not amazed.
Goodbye!: Don’t stand up surprised.

Anon!: Alas the day!
Goodbye!: Oh, that’s the day!

Anon!: Out upon you!
Goodbye!: Come on!

Anon!: What have you, my good friends, deserved at the hands of fortune that she sends you to prison hither?
Goodbye!: What have you, my good friends, deserved from the fortune she sent you to prison here?

Anon!: O, then I see you will part but with light gifts.
Goodbye!: Oh, then I see you’ll only be part of the party with light gifts.

Anon!: All ready.
Goodbye!: All right.

Anon!: Without his roe, like a dried herring.
Goodbye!: Without his roe, like a dried herring.

Anon!: Why the wrong is but a wrong i' th' world, and having the world for your labor, ’tis a wrong in your own world, and you might quickly make it right.
Goodbye!: Why the wrong is only a wrong in the world, and having the world for your work is a wrong in your own world, and you might make it right quickly.

Anon!: O wise and upright judge!
Goodbye!: Oh wise and upright judge!

Anon!: So stood the state when Henry the Sixth Was crowned in Paris but at nine months old.
Goodbye!: That’s the way Henry the Sixth was crowned in Paris, but at nine months old.

Anon!: In the great hand of God I stand, and thence Against the undivulged pretense I fight Of treasonous malice.
Goodbye!: I stand in the great hand of God, and then I fight against the unintended pretense of treasonous malice.

Anon!: She cannot endure to hear tell of a husband.
Goodbye!: She can’t wait to hear about a husband.

Anon!: We’ll leave you, Brutus.
Goodbye!: We’ll leave you, Brutus.

Anon!: I could find in my heart to beat him—   But that the poor monster’s in drink.
Goodbye!: I could find in my heart to beat him— But the poor monster’s drinking.

Anon!: Let me entreat you.
Goodbye!: Let me ask you.

Anon!: Well have you heard, but something hard of hearing.
Goodbye!: Well, you’ve heard something hard about it.

Anon!: Faith, I saw it not, but I felt it hot in her breath.
Goodbye!: I didn’t see it, but I felt it hot in her breath.

Anon!: Therefore, Lord Constable, haste on Montjoy And let him say to England that we send To know what willing ransom he will give.
Goodbye!: So hurry up Montjoy, Lord Constable, and tell him to England that we send to know what he will give.

Anon!: Oh that I knew this husband, which, you say, must charge his horns with garlands!
Goodbye!: Oh, I knew this husband, who, you say, must charge his horns with a sand!

Anon!: Come on.
Goodbye!: Come on.

Anon!: I attend them with all respect and duty.
Goodbye!: I’m going to attend them with all respect and duty.

Anon!: Thou wast the prettiest babe that e'er I nursed.
Goodbye!: You were the prettiest baby I ever nursed.

Anon!: Pray, do not mock me.
Goodbye!: Please don’t mock me.

Anon!: Was this before the king returned?
Goodbye!: Was this before the king returned?

Anon!: The sight whereof I think you had from me, From Claudio and the Prince.
Goodbye!: I think you had a sight from me, from Claudio and the Prince.

Anon!: Come, bird, come.
Goodbye!: Come, bird, come.

Anon!: To prison, eyes, ne'er look on liberty.
Goodbye!: Go to prison, eyes, and never look at liberty.

Anon!: Good sir, this ring was given me by my wife.
Goodbye!: Good sir, my wife gave me this ring.

Anon!: Shut up your doors.
Goodbye!: Shut up your doors.

Anon!: To business that we love we rise betimes And go to ’t with delight.
Goodbye!: We’ll go to it with delight.

Anon!: For Juliet’s sake, for her sake, rise and stand.
Goodbye!: For Juliet’s sake, for her sake, rise and stand.

Anon!: Yet keep the French the field.
Goodbye!: But keep the French on the field.

Anon!: What news abroad?
Goodbye!: What news are you getting out of here?

Anon!: Let him write down the Prince’s officer “coxcomb.” Come, bind them.—Thou naughty varlet!
Goodbye!: Let him write down the Prince’s officer’s “coxcomb.” Come, tie them up.—You naughty varlet!

Anon!: Why?
Goodbye!: Why?

Anon!: What would my lord?
Goodbye!: What would I do, my lord?

Anon!: Nay, I’ll conjure too!
Goodbye!: No, I’ll conjure it too!

Anon!: You are welcome.
Goodbye!: You are welcome.

Anon!: Think it no more.
Goodbye!: Don’t think about it anymore.

Anon!: Go, bring them in.—And take your places, ladies.
Goodbye!: Go, bring them in.—And take your places, ladies.

Anon!: Look how thy servants do attend on thee, Each in his office ready at thy beck.
Goodbye!: Look how your servants are preparing you, each in his office ready to beckon.

Anon!: Triple-turned whore!
Goodbye!: The king is a triple-turned whore!

Anon!: And supportable To make the dear loss have I means much weaker Than you may call to comfort you, for I Have lost my daughter.
Goodbye!: And to make the loss so dear that I can make it much weaker than you can comfort me, because I’ve lost my daughter.

Anon!: No.
Goodbye!: No.

Anon!: Every one that does so is a traitor and must be hanged.
Goodbye!: Every one who does that is a traitor and must be hanged.

Anon!: An oath, an oath, I have an oath in heaven.
Goodbye!: An oath, an oath, I have an oath in heaven.

Anon!: Speak, speak.
Goodbye!: Speak, speak.

Anon!: O good Sir Toby, hold!
Goodbye!: Oh, Sir Toby, stop!

Anon!: For the Queen, I’ll take her to my guard.
Goodbye!: For the Queen, I’ll take her to my guard.

Anon!: Have you heard any imputation to the contrary?
Goodbye!: Have you heard any imputation to the contrary?

Anon!: I cannot be a man with wishing, therefore I will die a woman with grieving.
Goodbye!: I can’t be a man with wishing, so I’ll die a woman with grieving.

Anon!: Why, but you are now well enough.
Goodbye!: But you’re well enough now.

Anon!: No king of England if not king of France.
Goodbye!: No king of England, if not king of France.

Anon!: They stumble that run fast.
Goodbye!: They’re scolded when they run fast.

Anon!: Curse not thyself, fair creature; thou art both.
Goodbye!: Don’t curse yourself, fair creature; you’re both.

Anon!: What would you say to me now, an I were your very, very Rosalind?
Goodbye!: What do you want to say to me now, if I were your very, very Rosalind?

Anon!: Master, here’s The gold you sent me for.
Goodbye!: Master, here’s the gold you sent me for.

Anon!: But yet—   Which, of he or Adrian, for a good wager, first begins to crow?
Goodbye!: But yet— Which, he or Adrian, for a good wager, begins to crow first?

Anon!: Can I bear that with patience, And not my husband’s secrets?
Goodbye!: Can I bear that with patience, and not my husband’s secrets?

Anon!: Thrice the brinded cat hath mewed.
Goodbye!: The brinded cat has mewed three times.

Anon!: I do but keep the peace.
Goodbye!: I’m only keeping the peace.

Anon!: I will read it.— How much unlike art thou to Portia!
Goodbye!: I’ll read it.—How much unlike Portia!

Anon!: Will ’t please you taste of what is here?
Goodbye!: Will you like what’s here?

Anon!: Cassius, be constant.
Goodbye!: Cassius, be calm.

Anon!: What, has his daughters brought him to this pass?— Couldst thou save nothing?
Goodbye!: What, have his daughters brought him to this pass?—Can you save nothing?

Anon!: My father’s death—      Thy life hath it dishonored.
Goodbye!: My father’s death— Your life has been dishonored.

Anon!: Humbly on my knee I crave your blessing.
Goodbye!: I’m humbly on my knee asking for your blessing.

Anon!: Were it good, think you?
Goodbye!: Did it be good, do you think?

Anon!: They are not near my conscience.
Goodbye!: They’re not near my conscience.

Anon!: I’ll pluck thee berries.
Goodbye!: I’ll pluck you berries.

Anon!: Or to be naked with her friend in bed An hour or more, not meaning any harm?
Goodbye!: Or to be naked with her friend in bed for an hour or more, without any harm?

Anon!: Why, that the Moor first gave to Desdemona, That which so often you did bid me steal.
Goodbye!: Why, that the Moor gave to Desdemona, something you asked me to steal so often.

Anon!: And that were much he should, for he is given To sports, to wildness and much company.
Goodbye!: And if he were so much, he would, because he was given to sports, wildness and company.

Anon!: As I do live, my honored lord, ’tis true.
Goodbye!: As I live, my honorable lord, it’s true.

Anon!: Wondrous heavy.
Goodbye!: It’s a witty thing.

Anon!: I do desire it with all my heart, and I hope it is no dishonest desire to desire to be a woman of the world.
Goodbye!: I want it with all my heart, and I hope it doesn’t make me want to be a woman of the world.

Anon!: I see a woman may be made a fool If she had not a spirit to resist.
Goodbye!: I see a woman can be made a fool if she didn’t have a spirit to resist.

Anon!: The juice of it on sleeping eyelids laid Will make or man or woman madly dote Upon the next live creature that it sees.
Goodbye!: The juice of it on the sleeping eyelids will make or make a man or woman madly dote on the next live creature that it sees.

Anon!: It is too true an evil.
Goodbye!: It’s too true.

Anon!: We are no tyrant, but a Christian king, Unto whose grace our passion is as subject As is our wretches fettered in our prisons.
Goodbye!: We’re not a tyrant, but a Christian king, whose grace is as subject to our passion as our wretches are in our prisons.

Anon!: If this prove A vision of the Island, one dear son Shall I twice lose.
Goodbye!: If this is a vision of the Island, I’ll lose one dear son twice.

Anon!: Within these ten days if that thou beest found So near our public court as twenty miles, Thou diest for it.
Goodbye!: Within ten days, if you’re found near our court as twenty miles away as twenty miles, you die for it.

Anon!: Marry, sir, they praise me and make an ass of me, now my foes tell me plainly I am an ass.
Goodbye!: They praise me and make an ass of me, and now my enemies tell me I’m an ass.

Anon!: Is it your own inclining?
Goodbye!: Is it your own inclination?

Anon!: Not so, neither.
Goodbye!: Not true, neither.

Anon!: Are you sure of that?
Goodbye!: Are you sure of that?

Anon!: And if on earth he do not merit it, In reason he should never come to heaven.
Goodbye!: And if he doesn’t deserve it on earth, he shouldn’t come to heaven.

Anon!: Bind fast his corky arms.
Goodbye!: Bind his corky arms.

Anon!: Here therefore for a while I will remain.
Goodbye!: So I’ll stay here for a while.

Anon!: Follow me, lady.— Turn out that eyeless villain.
Goodbye!: Follow me, lady.—Look at that pathetic villain.

Anon!: An if they live, I hope I need not fear.
Goodbye!: If they live, I hope I don’t need to worry.

Anon!: Indeed, he plied them both with excellent praises.
Goodbye!: He plied them both with excellent praise.

Anon!: No, faith, my coz, wish not a man from England.
Goodbye!: No, I don’t wish a man from England.

Anon!: By heaven, that should be my handkerchief!
Goodbye!: I swear, that should be my handkerchief!

Anon!: Away!
Goodbye!: Go away!

Anon!: What, have you forgot me?
Goodbye!: Have you forgotten me?

Anon!: Alack the day, I know you not, young gentleman.
Goodbye!: I don’t know you, young gentleman.

Anon!: Come, bustle, bustle.
Goodbye!: Come on, hurry up, hurry up.

Anon!: I do assure thee, father, so it is.
Goodbye!: I assure you, father, that it is.

Anon!: Come then and take the last warmth of my lips.
Goodbye!: Come on, take the last warmth of my lips.

Anon!: Where is she?
Goodbye!: Where is she?

Anon!: I had forgot the reward.
Goodbye!: I had forgotten the reward.

Anon!: Therefore, have done.
Goodbye!: So, have done it.

Anon!: Goes the king hence today?
Goodbye!: Is the king leaving today?

Anon!: Very many, men and women too.
Goodbye!: Very many, men and women too.

Anon!: What, not a word?
Goodbye!: What, not a word?

Anon!: Is it not like the king?
Goodbye!: Isn’t it like the king?

Anon!: No, uncle, I’ll none.
Goodbye!: No, uncle, I won’t.

Anon!: I had myself notice of my brother’s purpose herein and have by underhand means labored to dissuade him from it; but he is resolute.
Goodbye!: I had my brother’s purpose in this article and have sworn in to dissuade him from it by hand, but he’s resolute.

Anon!: If she be false, heaven mocked itself.
Goodbye!: If she’s false, heaven mocked itself.

Anon!: Tell me, daughter Juliet, How stands your disposition to be married?
Goodbye!: Tell me, daughter Juliet, how are you going to be married?

Anon!: Now, by this hand, I swear, I scorn the term, Nor shall my Nell keep lodgers.
Goodbye!: I swear, I swear, I’m not referring to the term, and I’ll never keep a lodger.

Anon!: Do not desire to see this letter.
Goodbye!: Don’t want to see this letter.

Anon!: And she’s fair I love.
Goodbye!: And she’s fair, I love her.

Anon!: And, honest company, I thank you all, That have beheld me give away myself To this most patient, sweet and virtuous wife.
Goodbye!: And, honest company, thank you all, who have given me away to this patient, sweet and virtuous wife.

Anon!: Give me now leave to leave thee.
Goodbye!: Now let me leave you.

Anon!: Very well, madam.
Goodbye!: Very well, madam.

Anon!: Yea, even I alone.
Goodbye!: Yes, I’m alone.

Anon!: They’ll tell the clock to any business that We say befits the hour.
Goodbye!: They’ll tell the clock to any business that we say is right for the hour.

Anon!: Need and oppression starveth in thine eyes.
Goodbye!: You’re starving in your eyes.

Anon!: My liege and madam, to expostulate What majesty should be, what duty is, Why day is day, night night, and time is time, Were nothing but to waste night, day, and time.
Goodbye!: My liege and madam, to expostulate what majesty should be, what duty is, why day is day, night is night, and time is time, would be nothing but waste night, day, and time.

Anon!: Affection is not rated from the heart.
Goodbye!: Affection doesn’t come from the heart.

Anon!: Why, then Othello and Desdemona return again to Venice.
Goodbye!: Well, then Othello and Desdemona return to Venice.

Anon!: Shall I play my freedom at tray-trip, and become thy bondslave?
Goodbye!: Shall I play my freedom at the shack and become your slave?

Anon!: Why then, your uncle and the Prince and Claudio Have been deceived.
Goodbye!: Well then, your uncle and the Prince and Claudio have been deceived.

Anon!: Say to me whose fortunes shall rise higher, Caesar’s or mine?
Goodbye!: Tell me whose fortunes will rise, Caesar’s or mine?

Anon!: No evil lost is wailed when it is gone.
Goodbye!: No evil is lost when it’s gone.

Anon!: A greater gift?
Goodbye!: A greater gift?

Anon!: I assure my good liege, I hold my duty as I hold my soul, Both to my God and to my gracious king.
Goodbye!: I assure my good liege that I’m as good as I am, both to my God and to my gracious king.

Anon!: Oh, beware, my lord, of jealousy!
Goodbye!: Oh, beware of jealousy, my lord!

Anon!: That’s as much as to say, the sweet youth’s in love.
Goodbye!: That’s as much as to say, the sweet boy’s in love.

Anon!: Her worth being mounted on the wind, Through all the world bears Rosalind.
Goodbye!: Her worth is mounted on the wind, and through the whole world she bears Rosalind.

Anon!: Wilt thou make a trust a transgression?
Goodbye!: Do you think trust is a fraud?

Anon!: The wonder is he hath endured so long.
Goodbye!: He’s been so long ago.

Anon!: Let wantons light of heart Tickle the senseless rushes with their heels.
Goodbye!: Let the sane rushes get a little sane.

Anon!: Your daughter here the princes left for dead.
Goodbye!: The princes left your daughter here for dead.

Anon!: Content.
Goodbye!: Content.

Anon!: Wherein, my friends, have I offended you?
Goodbye!: Where did I offended you, my friends?

Anon!: Romeo slew him; he slew Mercutio.
Goodbye!: Romeo killed him, and Mercutio killed him.

Anon!: Our masquing mates by this time for us stay.
Goodbye!: Our masquing mates will stay here at this time.

Anon!: Come, some music!
Goodbye!: Come on, listen to some music!

Anon!: Stand thee close, then, under this penthouse, for it drizzles rain, and I will, like a true drunkard, utter all to thee.
Goodbye!: So stand close to you under this penthouse, because it’s raining, and I’ll tell you everything, like a true drunken.

Anon!: Things have fall'n out, sir, so unluckily, That we have had no time to move our daughter.
Goodbye!: It’s so bad, sir, that we haven’t had time to move our daughter.

Anon!: But yet I’ll make assurance double sure, And take a bond of fate.
Goodbye!: But I’ll make sure I’m sure I’m going to be able to make sure I’m safe and have a chance.

Anon!: A mellifluous voice, as I am true knight.
Goodbye!: A savage voice, as I am a true knight.

Anon!: Or shall we on without apology?
Goodbye!: Or should we go on without apology?

Anon!: So is he now in execution Of any bold or noble enterprise, However he puts on this tardy form.
Goodbye!: He’s in the process of any bold or noble enterprise, even if he’s in this late stage.

Anon!: Never.
Goodbye!: Never.

Anon!: To Dover.
Goodbye!: To Dover.

Anon!: Oh, that she knew she were!
Goodbye!: Oh, she knew she were!

Anon!: A monster, a very monster in apparel, and not like a Christian footboy or a gentleman’s lackey.
Goodbye!: A monster, a very monster in clothing, and not like a Christian footboy or a gentleman’s lackey.

Anon!: My lord, I claim the gift, my due by promise, For which your honor and your faith is pawned— Th' earldom of Hereford and the movables Which you promisèd I shall possess.
Goodbye!: My lord, I claim the gift, my due by promise, for which your honor and your faith are pawned—your earldom of Hereford and the movables that I’ll possess.

Anon!: Come you to make confession to this Father?
Goodbye!: Do you come to make confession to this Father?

Anon!: Oh, where is Romeo?
Goodbye!: Oh, where is Romeo?

Anon!: I know no ways to mince it in love, but directly to say, “I love you.” Then if you urge me farther than to say, “Do you, in faith?” I wear out my suit.
Goodbye!: I don’t know how to make it into love, but I’m telling you directly, “I love you.” Then if you tell me more than to say, “Do you, in faith?” I wear out my suit

Anon!: Whiles I threat, he lives.
Goodbye!: I’m afraid he’s alive.

Anon!: My gracious sovereign, now in Devonshire, As I by friends am well advertisèd, Sir Edward Courtney and the haughty prelate, Bishop of Exeter, his elder brother, With many more confederates are in arms.
Goodbye!: My gracious sovereign, now in Devonshire, as I am a good friend, Sir Edward Courtney and the haughty prelate, Bishop of Exeter, his elder brother, with many more confederates in arms.

Anon!: Quickly send— Be brief in it—to th' castle, for my writ Is on the life of Lear and on Cordelia.
Goodbye!: Send—be brief in it—to the castle, because my writ is about Lear and Cordelia.

Anon!: News from Verona!—How now, Balthasar?
Goodbye!: News from Verona!—How are you, Balthasar?

Anon!: I know I cannot please you.
Goodbye!: I know I can’t please you.

Anon!: Oh, she knew well Thy love did read by rote, that could not spell.
Goodbye!: Oh, she knew well that your love was written by a man who couldn’t spell it.

Anon!: Unhappy fortune!
Goodbye!: Unhappy fortune!

Anon!: Richard of York, how fares our loving brother?
Goodbye!: Richard of York, how is our loving brother?

Anon!: I will not take her on gift of any man.
Goodbye!: I won’t take her on any man’s gift.

Anon!: Madam, it so fell out, that certain players We o'erraught on the way.
Goodbye!: Madam, it fell out so quickly that certain players we o'ered on the way.

Anon!: This week he hath been heavy, sour, sad, And much different from the man he was.
Goodbye!: This week he’s been heavy, sour, sad, and much different from the man he was.

Anon!: A third cannot be matched unless the devil himself turn Jew.
Goodbye!: A third of the king’s screams can’t be matched unless the devil himself turns a Jew.

Anon!: Shame come to Romeo!
Goodbye!: Shame on Romeo!

Anon!: Fetch the will hither, and we shall determine How to cut off some charge in legacies.
Goodbye!: Let’s go, and we’ll decide how to cut off some legacies.

Anon!: Nay, the man hath no wit that cannot, from the rising of the lark to the lodging of the lamb, vary deserved praise on my palfrey.
Goodbye!: No, the man who can’t be a good man, from the lark to the lamb, deserves praise for my pity.

Anon!: How can that be, unless she drowned herself in her own defense?
Goodbye!: How can that be, unless she drowned herself in her own defense?

Anon!: This is the truth, or let Benvolio die.
Goodbye!: This is the truth, or let Benvolio die.

Anon!: Is ’t possible?
Goodbye!: Is it possible?

Anon!: And what confederacy have you with the traitors Late footed in the kingdom?
Goodbye!: And what do you have with the traitors who have been snuck into the kingdom?

Anon!: Romeo is coming.
Goodbye!: Romeo is coming.

Anon!: To the jail with him!
Goodbye!: Go to jail with him!

Anon!: How now, brother Edmund?
Goodbye!: What’s going on, brother Edmund?

Anon!: Why, ’tis not possible.
Goodbye!: It’s not possible.

Anon!: But ’tis all one; ’tis alike as my fingers is to my fingers, and there is salmons in both.
Goodbye!: But it’s all one thing, it’s as good as my fingers are to my fingers, and there’s salmon in both of them.

Anon!: I come to fetch you to the senate house.
Goodbye!: I’m coming to fetch you to the senate house.

Anon!: E'en at hand, alighted by this.
Goodbye!: I’m not sure what’s going on.

Anon!: Nor ever heard, nor ever did suspect.
Goodbye!: I didn’t hear anything, or suspect anything.

Anon!: Yes, certainly, and out of doubt and out of question, too, and ambiguities.
Goodbye!: Yes, certainly, and out of doubt and out of question, too, and out of ambiguity.

Anon!: Both sides are even.
Goodbye!: Both sides are equally right.

Anon!: Why I should fear I know not, Since guiltiness I know not.
Goodbye!: Why I shouldn’t fear myself, since I don’t know what guilt I’m doing.

Anon!: How have I offended?
Goodbye!: How have I offended me?

Anon!: The wife of Antony Should have an army for an usher and The neighs of horse to tell of her approach Long ere she did appear.
Goodbye!: The wife of Antony should have an army for an usher and the neighs of horse to tell her about her approach long before she appeared.

Anon!: Mistress, we have.
Goodbye!: Mistress, we have.

Anon!: Coraggio, bully-monster,  If these be true spies which I wear in my head, here’s a goodly sight.
Goodbye!: Coraggio, bully-monster, if these are true spies I wear in my head, here’s a good sight.

Anon!: Then the whining schoolboy with his satchel And shining morning face, creeping like snail Unwillingly to school.
Goodbye!: Then the whining schoolboy with his satchel and shining morning face, creeping like a snail unwillingly to school.

Anon!: With Cassio, mistress.
Goodbye!: With Cassio, my mistress.

Anon!: Nor have I seen More that I may call men than you, good friend, And my dear father.
Goodbye!: I’ve never seen anything more men than you, my dear father, my friend.

Anon!: Seven days and nights?
Goodbye!: Seven days and seven nights?

Anon!: She cannot love Nor take no shape nor project of affection She is so self-endeared.
Goodbye!: She can’t love, and she can’t take any shape or project of affection.

Anon!: Peace be with Burgundy.
Goodbye!: Let’s go with Burgundy.

Anon!: The time ’twixt six and now Must by us both be spent most preciously.
Goodbye!: We’ll spend the time between us two and six.

Anon!: Only myself stood out; For which, if I be lapsèd in this place, I shall pay dear.
Goodbye!: I stood out, and if I’m thrown in this place, I’ll pay dear.

Anon!: If I had, my weapon should quickly have been out, I warrant you.
Goodbye!: If I had, my weapon would have been out quickly, I assure you.

Anon!: Gentlemen all, I do suspect this trash To be a party in this injury.— Patience awhile, good Cassio.—Come, come, Lend me a light.
Goodbye!: Gentlemen, I suspect this trash is a party to this injury.—Past up, Cassio.—Come, come, let me light up.

Anon!: Such comfort as do lusty young men feel When well-appareled April on the heel Of limping winter treads.
Goodbye!: As comforting as lusty young men feel when they’re snoring in April on the heel of limping winter treads.

Anon!: Orlando?
Goodbye!: Orlando?

Anon!: Oh, heaven, how got she out?
Goodbye!: Oh heaven, how did she get out?

Anon!: An interlude!
Goodbye!: An interlude!

Anon!: But I’ll be hanged, sir, if he wear your livery.
Goodbye!: But I’ll be hanged if he wears your livery.

Anon!: Hath Leonato any son, my lord?
Goodbye!: Is Leonato any son, my lord?

Anon!: Well, I am glad that all things sort so well.
Goodbye!: Well, I’m glad everything works out so well.

Anon!: This is practice, Gloucester.
Goodbye!: This is a practice, Gloucester.

Anon!: I never was nor never will be false.
Goodbye!: I never was, and I won’t be false.

Anon!: Sir, he dined with her there, at the Porpentine.
Goodbye!: Sir, he ate with her at the Porpentine.

Anon!: Hail.
Goodbye!: Hail.

Anon!: Some others search.
Goodbye!: Some others are searching.

Anon!: Nay, never lay thy hand upon thy sword.
Goodbye!: No, don’t lay your hand on your sword.

Anon!: His forward voice now is to speak well of his friend.
Goodbye!: He’s speaking well about his friend.

Anon!: And thence from Athens turn away our eyes To seek new friends and stranger companies.
Goodbye!: And then we’ll go away from Athens to find new friends and strangers.

Anon!: I’ll be sworn, if thou be Launcelot, thou art mine own flesh and blood.
Goodbye!: If you’re Launcelot, you’re my own flesh and blood.

Anon!: I marvel Cambio comes not all this while.
Goodbye!: I’m amazed Cambio doesn’t come all this time.

Anon!: How now?
Goodbye!: What’s going on?

Anon!: And though she be but little, she is fierce.
Goodbye!: And even though she’s only little, she’s fierce.

Anon!: I am the youngest of that name, for fault of a worse.
Goodbye!: I’m the youngest person in that name, because I’m a worse person.

Anon!: Towards him I made, but he was 'ware of me And stole into the covert of the wood.
Goodbye!: I made him to him, but he was ware of me and stole into the woods.

Anon!: Swear by her foot, that she may tread out the oath.
Goodbye!: Swear by her foot so she can tread out the oath.

Anon!: Something we will determine.
Goodbye!: Something we’ll decide on.

Anon!: Oh!
Goodbye!: Oh!

Anon!: That you should think we come not to offend, But with good will.
Goodbye!: You should think we’re not going to offend you, but with good will.

Anon!: Look, Lucius, here’s the book I sought for so.
Goodbye!: Look, Lucius, here’s the book I wanted to read.

Anon!: An you be mine, I’ll give you to my friend.
Goodbye!: If you’re mine, I’ll give you to my friend.

Anon!: Why, shall we turn to men?
Goodbye!: Why, should we turn to men?

Anon!: Courteous lord, one word.
Goodbye!: Good lord, let’s say one thing.

Anon!: Our dinner done and he not coming thither, I went to seek him.
