Goodbye!: I went to find him, and he didn’t come here.

Anon!: I say, it is not lost.
Goodbye!: I say, it’s not lost.

Anon!: What a caterwauling do you keep here!
Goodbye!: What a savage you keep here!

Anon!: Before you can say “Come” and “Go,” And breathe twice and cry “So, so!” Each one, tripping on his toe,
Goodbye!: Before you can say “Come” and “Go,” breathe twice and cry “So, so!” Each one of you, tripping on his toe,

Anon!: The Queen approaches.
Goodbye!: The Queen is approaching.

Anon!: It is no matter.
Goodbye!: It doesn’t matter.

Anon!: The king my father?!
Goodbye!: The king my father?!

Anon!: May it be done?
Goodbye!: Can it be done?

Anon!: I talked with no man at that hour, my lord.
Goodbye!: I didn’t talk to any man at that time, my lord.

Anon!: Here comes his body, mourned by Mark Antony, who, though he had no hand in his death, shall receive the benefit of his dying—a place in the commonwealth—as which of you shall not?
Goodbye!: Here comes his body, mourned by Mark Antony, who, even though he had no hand in his death, will receive the benefit of his dying—a place in the commonwealth—a place that you won’

Anon!: Thy smiles become thee well.
Goodbye!: Your smiles make you happy.

Anon!: Go thither, and with unattainted eye Compare her face with some that I shall show, And I will make thee think thy swan a crow.
Goodbye!: Go on, and with an unattractive eye, compare her face to some that I’ll show you, and I’ll make you think your swan is a crow.

Anon!: I’ll to dinner.
Goodbye!: I’ll go to dinner.

Anon!: I beseech you, sir, pardon me.
Goodbye!: Please, pardon me.

Anon!: Each new morn New widows howl, new orphans cry, new sorrows Strike heaven on the face, that it resounds As if it felt with Scotland and yelled out Like syllable of dolor.
Goodbye!: Every new day, new widows howl, new orphans cry, new sorrows Strike heaven on the face so that it resounds like it felt with Scotland and yelled out like a sy

Anon!: Here comes Oberon.
Goodbye!: Here comes Oberon.

Anon!: It may well be called Jove’s tree when it drops forth such fruit.
Goodbye!: It may well be called Jove’s tree when it drops such fruit out.

Anon!: Tweaks me by the nose?
Goodbye!: Is it weak by the nose?

Anon!: I gave him no order.
Goodbye!: I didn’t give him any order.

Anon!: Here is the head of that ignoble traitor, The dangerous and unsuspected Hastings.
Goodbye!: Here is the head of that ignoble traitor, the dangerous and unsuspected Hastings.

Anon!: They say, one Taurus.
Goodbye!: They say one Taurus.

Anon!: Ha!
Goodbye!: Ha!

Anon!: Will you hoist sail, sir?
Goodbye!: Will you hoist sail, sir?

Anon!: Tis three o'clock, and, Romans, yet ere night We shall try fortune in a second fight.
Goodbye!: It’s three o'clock, and, Romans, we’ll fight for luck in a second night.

Anon!: Nay, gentle Romeo, we must have you dance.
Goodbye!: No, gentle Romeo, we have to dance.

Anon!: Fie, how my bones ache!
Goodbye!: Oh, how my bones ache!

Anon!: They have made him drink alms-drink.
Goodbye!: They made him drink alms-drink.

Anon!: Did heaven look on, And would not take their part?
Goodbye!: Did heaven look on and don’t want to take part?

Anon!: A plague o' both your houses!
Goodbye!: A plague kills both your houses!

Anon!: I do remember now.
Goodbye!: I remember now.

Anon!: He breathes, my lord.
Goodbye!: He’s breathing, my lord.

Anon!: We never valued this poor seat of England And therefore, living hence, did give ourself To barbarous license, as ’tis ever common That men are merriest when they are from home.
Goodbye!: We never valued this poor place in England and therefore, living here, gave ourselves a barbarous license, as it’s always common that men are the most merry when they’re away from home.

Anon!: Oh, I am undone, I am undone!
Goodbye!: Oh, I’m gone, I’m gone!

Anon!: And I remember the wooing of a peascod instead of her, from whom I took two cods and, giving her them again, said with weeping tears, “Wear these for my sake.” We that are true lovers run into strange capers.
Goodbye!: And I remember the wooing of a peascod instead of her, from whom I took two cods and gave her them again, crying, “Wear these for my sake.” We who are true lovers run into strange

Anon!: I will, sir.
Goodbye!: I will, sir.

Anon!: Dost thou affect her, Claudio?
Goodbye!: Do you affect her, Claudio?

Anon!: Though now this grainèd face of mine be hid In sap-consuming winter’s drizzled snow, And all the conduits of my blood froze up, Yet hath my night of life some memory, My wasting lamps some fading glimmer left, My dull deaf ears a little use to hear.
Goodbye!: Even though my face is now buried in the drizzled snow, and all the conduits of my blood froze up, I’ve lost some memory for my night of life, my wasting lamps left some fading g

Anon!: Tybalt, that murderer, which way ran he?
Goodbye!: Tybalt, that murderer, which way did he run?

Anon!: No man must know.” What follows?
Goodbye!: No man must know.” What follows?

Anon!: She is banished.
Goodbye!: She’s been banished.

Anon!: Go get it ready.
Goodbye!: Go get it ready.

Anon!: Companion, hence!
Goodbye!: Come on, come on!

Anon!: All that I have to say is to tell you that the lanthorn is the moon; I, the man in the moon; this thornbush, my thornbush; and this dog, my dog.
Goodbye!: I have to tell you that the lanthorn is the moon, I, the man in the moon, this thornbush, my thornbush, and this dog, my dog.

Anon!: As freely, son, as God did give her me.
Goodbye!: As freely, son, as God gave her me.

Anon!: M”—why, that begins my name.
Goodbye!: M”—why, that’s what begins my name?

Anon!: Go to, go to.
Goodbye!: Go to, go to.

Anon!: There, take you that, sir knave.
Goodbye!: Take that, sir knave.

Anon!: Signior Montano, Your trusty and most valiant servitor, With his free duty recommends you thus, And prays you to believe him.
Goodbye!: Signior Montano, your trusty and valiant servitor, recommends you with his free duty, and asks you to believe him.

Anon!: When I desire their leave that I might pity him, they took from me the use of mine own house, charged me on pain of their perpetual displeasure neither to speak of him, entreat for him, nor any way sustain him.
Goodbye!: When I want their permission to pity him, they took my own house from me, charged me with pain because they didn’t want to speak of him, say no way to support him.

Anon!: I say, but mark his gesture.
Goodbye!: I say, but please remember his gesture.

Anon!: But that thy strange mutations make us hate thee, Life would not yield to age.
Goodbye!: But if you’re making us hate you, you’d never be able to live longer.

Anon!: And hath challenged thee?
Goodbye!: And have you challenged me?

Anon!: Art thou afeard?
Goodbye!: Are you afeard?

Anon!: I did, my lord.
Goodbye!: I did, my lord.

Anon!: Tomorrow is the joyful day, Audrey.
Goodbye!: Tomorrow is the joyful day, Audrey.

Anon!: Death of thy soul!
Goodbye!: Death of your soul!

Anon!: Why, then, build me thy fortunes upon the basis of valor.
Goodbye!: So, then, build me your fortunes on the basis of my valor.

Anon!: Buzz, buzz.
Goodbye!: Buzz, buzz.

Anon!: But this is most falliable, the worm’s an odd worm.
Goodbye!: But this is a worm that’s odd.

Anon!: God be wi' you.
Goodbye!: God bless you.

Anon!: Ay, boy.
Goodbye!: Yes, boy.

Anon!: I am too sore enpiercèd with his shaft To soar with his light feathers, and so bound, I cannot bound a pitch above dull woe.
Goodbye!: I’m too sore enpiercé with his shaft to soar with his light feathers, and I can’t get a pitch above dull sorrow.

Anon!: I have them ready.
Goodbye!: I have them ready.

Anon!: Or if not so, then here I hit it right: Our Romeo hath not been in bed tonight.
Goodbye!: If not, then I’ll hit it right here: Romeo hasn’t been in bed tonight.

Anon!: What handkerchief?
Goodbye!: What handkerchief?

Anon!: This speech of yours hath moved me, And shall perchance do good.
Goodbye!: Your speech has moved me, and will do good.

Anon!: Where learned you this, Fool?
Goodbye!: Where did you learn this, Fool?

Anon!: All torment, trouble, wonder, and amazement Inhabits here.
Goodbye!: All this trouble, wonder, and amazement is in here.

Anon!: Will you go with me?
Goodbye!: Will you go with me?

Anon!: Though others have the arm, show us the sleeve; We in your motion turn, and you may move us.
Goodbye!: Even though others have the arm, show us the sleeve; you can turn in your motion, and you can move us.

Anon!: Have you a mind to sink?
Goodbye!: Have you ever thought about sinking?

Anon!: Your names?
Goodbye!: Your names?

Anon!: The Dauphin, whom of succors we entreated, Returns us that his powers are yet not ready To raise so great a siege.
Goodbye!: The Dauphin, whom we fought with, returns to tell us that his powers aren’t ready to raise such a siege.

Anon!: I doubt some foul play.
Goodbye!: I doubt some foul play.

Anon!: Nym, thou hast spoke the right.
Goodbye!: Nym, you’ve said the right.

Anon!: Are you drawn forth among a world of men To slay the innocent?
Goodbye!: Are you drawn out of a world of men to kill the innocent?

Anon!: This damned witch Sycorax, For mischiefs manifold and sorceries terrible To enter human hearing, from Argier, Thou know’st, was banished.
Goodbye!: This damned witch Sycorax, for mischiefs and sorceries terrible to hear from Argier, you know, was banished.

Anon!: I am the son of Marcus Cato, ho!
Goodbye!: I’m Marcus Cato’s son!

Anon!: He is of a very melancholy disposition.
Goodbye!: He’s very apathetic.

Anon!: Pompey doth this day laugh away his fortune.
Goodbye!: Pompey is laughing away his fortune today.

Anon!: By two o'clock I will be with thee again.
Goodbye!: By two o'clock I’ll be with you again.

Anon!: How “strangely”?
Goodbye!: How “strangely”?

Anon!: He is married?
Goodbye!: He’s married?

Anon!: Too familiar Is my dear son with such sour company.
Goodbye!: My dear son is too familiar with such sour company.

Anon!: Oh, wretched villain!
Goodbye!: Oh, wretched villain!

Anon!: There’s my key.
Goodbye!: Here’s my key.

Anon!: You spurn me hence, and he will spurn me hither.
Goodbye!: You’re begging me to leave, and he’ll push me here.

Anon!: Oh, then belike she was old and gentle, and you rode, like a kern of Ireland, your French hose off and in your straight strossers.
Goodbye!: Oh, then she was old and gentle, and you rode, like a kern of Ireland, off your French hose and in your straight strossers.

Anon!: And, as he fell, did Romeo turn and fly.
Goodbye!: And as he fell, Romeo turned and flew.

Anon!: She hath betrayed me and shall die the death.
Goodbye!: She has betrayed me and will die.

Anon!: How does my wife?
Goodbye!: How is my wife?

Anon!: The Emperor calls Canidius.
Goodbye!: The Emperor calls Canidius.

Anon!: Now, fellow, What is there?
Goodbye!: Now, fellow, what’s there?

Anon!: How do you all at Verona?
Goodbye!: How are you all at Verona?

Anon!: Thank you.
Goodbye!: Thank you.

Anon!: A credulous father, and a brother noble— Whose nature is so far from doing harms That he suspects none, on whose foolish honesty My practices ride easy.
Goodbye!: A credulous father and a brother noble—whose nature is so far from doing harms that he doesn’t suspect any of them, and whose foolishness is easy.

Anon!: I’ll call thee “Hamlet,” “King,” “Father,” “royal Dane.” O, answer me!
Goodbye!: I’ll call you “Hamlet,” “King,” “Father,” “royal Dane.” Oh, answer me!

Anon!: There’s matter in ’t indeed, if he be angry.
Goodbye!: It’s true, if he’s angry.

Anon!: Both?
Goodbye!: Both?

Anon!: Tell the constable.
Goodbye!: Tell the constable.

Anon!: Are you his brother?
Goodbye!: Are you his brother?

Anon!: They are winged.
Goodbye!: They’re beaten.

Anon!: Our whole city is much bound to him.
Goodbye!: Our whole city is bound to him.

Anon!: If not, shun me, and I will spare your haunts.
Goodbye!: If not, stop me, and I’ll spare you.

Anon!: Tis well, sir, that you hunted for yourself.
Goodbye!: It’s good that you’ve hunted for yourself, sir.

Anon!: Stanley did dream the boar did raze his helm, And I did scorn it and disdain to fly.
Goodbye!: Stanley dreamed that the boar razed his helm, and I swore it and disdain it to fly.

Anon!: Your royal father’s murdered.
Goodbye!: Your royal father’s been murdered.

Anon!: Somebody knocks.
Goodbye!: Somebody’s knocking.

Anon!: My lord?
Goodbye!: My lord?

Anon!: What, for a counter, would I do but good?
Goodbye!: What, for a counter, would I do just good?

Anon!: I see, sir, you are liberal in offers.
Goodbye!: I see, sir, you’re liberal in offering.

Anon!: Thou hast frighted the word out of his right sense, so forcible is thy wit.
Goodbye!: You’ve scolded the word out of his right sense, and your wit is so forcible.

Anon!: Who can blot that name With any just reproach?
Goodbye!: Who can blot that name with any just reproach?

Anon!: Oh yes, my lord.
Goodbye!: Oh yes, my lord.

Anon!: You a man?
Goodbye!: Are you a man?

Anon!: If my heart’s dear love— Well, do not swear.
Goodbye!: If my heart’s dear love— Well, don’t swear.

Anon!: Go with me.
Goodbye!: Go with me.

Anon!: I fear I wrong the honorable men Whose daggers have stabbed Caesar.
Goodbye!: I’m afraid I’m wronging the honorable men who have stabbed Caesar.

Anon!: When it appears to you where this begins, Turn your displeasure that way, for our faults Can never be so equal that your love Can equally move with them.
Goodbye!: When it comes to you where this begins, turn your dissatisfaction into a way, because our faults can never be as equal as your love can be.

Anon!: Enough, I am engaged.
Goodbye!: Enough, I’m engaged.

Anon!: Upon my life, by some device or other The villain is o'erraught of all my money.
Goodbye!: I swear by some means, I’m obnoxious of all my money.

Anon!: O, pardon me for bringing these ill news, Since you did leave it for my office, sir.
Goodbye!: Oh, pardon me for bringing these bad news, since you left it for my job, sir.

Anon!: Yet if you there Did practice on my state, your being in Egypt Might be my question.
Goodbye!: But if you were there to practice my state, then you could be my question.

Anon!: You are welcome.
Goodbye!: You are welcome.

Anon!: But let us rear The higher our opinion, that our stirring Can from the lap of Egypt’s widow pluck The ne’er lust-wearied Antony.
Goodbye!: But let’s get the higher our opinion, that our lust-wearing lord can pluck Antony from the lap of the Egyptian widow.

Anon!: But what, is Catesby gone?
Goodbye!: But what, is Catesby gone?

Anon!: The messengers!
Goodbye!: The messengers!

Anon!: Why,       Am I not i' th' right, old Jephthah?
Goodbye!: Why, am I not right, old Jephthah?

Anon!: Out, fool.
Goodbye!: Out, fool.

Anon!: Mark how the tyrant writes.
Goodbye!: Listen to how the tyrant writes.

Anon!: Put out the light, and then put out the light.
Goodbye!: Put out the light, and then put out the light.

Anon!: She Is daughter to this famous Duke of Milan, Of whom so often I have heard renown But never saw before, of whom I have Received a second life.
Goodbye!: She’s the daughter of this famous Duke of Milan, whom I’ve heard so often, but never saw before, and whom I’ve received a second life.

Anon!: I’ll slit the villain’s nose that would have sent me to the jail.
Goodbye!: I’ll slit the villain’s nose that would have sent me to jail.

Anon!: Good madam, let me see your face.
Goodbye!: Good madam, let me see your face.

Anon!: Much good do you, scald knave, heartily.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, scald king, heartily.

Anon!: Oh, coward that I am, to live so long To see my best friend ta'en before my face!
Goodbye!: Oh, coward I am, to live so long to see my best friend ta’en before my face!

Anon!: He hath brought many captives home to Rome Whose ransoms did the general coffers fill.
Goodbye!: He brought many captives home to Rome, who ransoms filled the general sacraments.

Anon!: That’s certain—if the devil may be her judge.
Goodbye!: That’s true—if the devil can judge her.

Anon!: I have it not about me.
Goodbye!: I don’t have it about me.

Anon!: I have promised to make all this matter even.
Goodbye!: I’ve promised to make everything even more sense.

Anon!: Should I lie, madam?
Goodbye!: Should I lie, madam?

Anon!: Give me your answer, i' faith, do; and so clap hands and a bargain.
Goodbye!: Give me your answer, I swear.

Anon!: Caesar, thou art revenged, Even with the sword that killed thee.
Goodbye!: Caesar, you’re revenged, even with the sword that killed you.

Anon!: For Juliet’s sake, for her sake, rise and stand.
Goodbye!: For Juliet’s sake, for her sake, rise and stand.

Anon!: Ay.
Goodbye!: Yes.

Anon!: Speak not so grossly.—You are all amazed.
Goodbye!: Don’t say anything so grossly.—You’re all amazed.

Anon!: Watch you tonight for the command, I’ll lay ’t upon you.
Goodbye!: Watch you for the command tonight, I’ll lay it on you.

Anon!: Do not say “banishment.” Hence from Verona art thou banishèd.
Goodbye!: Don’t say “banishment.” From now on, you’re banned from Verona.

Anon!: Here’s a maze trod indeed Through forthrights and meanders.
Goodbye!: Here’s a maze thrown through slanders and meanders.

Anon!: A blank, my lord.
Goodbye!: A blank, my lord.

Anon!: I am a king, my masters, know you that?
Goodbye!: I’m a king, my masters, do you know that?

Anon!: I prithee, let thy wife attend on her, And bring them after in the best advantage.
Goodbye!: Please, let your wife take her to her, and bring them to her.

Anon!: In me ’tis villainy, In thee ’t had been good service.
Goodbye!: It’s bad in me, in you it’s been good service.

Anon!: I was the other day talking on the sea-bank with certain Venetians, and thither comes the bauble and, by this hand, she falls me thus about my neck— Crying “O dear Cassio!” as it were.
Goodbye!: I was talking the other day on the sea-bank with certain Venetians, and she comes out of the mud, and by this hand she falls me like this around my neck— Crying “Oh Cassio!” as it

Anon!: What news?
Goodbye!: What news do you have?

Anon!: And patches will I get unto these cudgeled scars, And swear I got them in the Gallia wars.
Goodbye!: And I’ll get patches to these cudgeled scars, and I swear I got them in the Gallia wars.

Anon!: What horrible fancy’s this?
Goodbye!: What horrible thing is this?

Anon!: Howling attends it.
Goodbye!: I’m a howling.

Anon!: You have trained me like a peasant, obscuring and hiding from me all gentlemanlike qualities.
Goodbye!: You’ve trained me like a peasant, hiding from me all gentlemanlike qualities.

Anon!: If ’twere not she, I cannot tell who told me.
Goodbye!: If she wasn’t, I can’t tell who told me.

Anon!: Wert thou as young as I, Juliet thy love, An hour but married, Tybalt murderèd, Doting like me, and like me banishèd, Then mightst thou speak, then mightst thou tear thy hair And fall upon the ground, as I do now, Taking the measure of an unmade grave.
Goodbye!: You’re as young as I am, Juliet, your love, you’ve only been married an hour, Tybalt was murdered, you’re like me, and you’re banished, then you’re

Anon!: I am more proud to be Sir Rowland’s son, His youngest son, and would not change that calling To be adopted heir to Frederick.
Goodbye!: I’m prouder to be Sir Rowland’s son, his youngest son, and I wouldn’t change that calling to be Frederick’s adopted heir.

Anon!: Touched you the bastardy of Edward’s children?
Goodbye!: Have you touched the bastardy of Edward’s children?

Anon!: I do beseech your Grace, Let me the knowledge of my fault bear with me.
Goodbye!: Please, your Grace, let me know my fault.

Anon!: O Stephano, two Neapolitans ’scaped!
Goodbye!: Oh Stephano, two Neapolitans have escaped!

Anon!: Peace, sirrah!
Goodbye!: Quiet, sir!

Anon!: I thank it, poor fool, it keeps on the windy side of care.
Goodbye!: I thank it, poor fool, it keeps on the windy side of care.

Anon!: Did you ne'er hear say, “Two may keep counsel, putting one away”?
Goodbye!: Did you hear someone say, “Two can keep a good friend, putting one away”?

Anon!: One kiss, and I’ll descend.
Goodbye!: I’ll kiss you, and I’ll descend.

Anon!: Tell us the manner of it, gentle Casca.
Goodbye!: Tell us what it is, gentle Casca.

Anon!: Death, that hath sucked the honey of thy breath, Hath had no power yet upon thy beauty.
Goodbye!: Death, who sucked the honey of your breath, has yet had no power on your beauty.

Anon!: There’s some conceit or other likes him well When that he bids good morrow with such spirit.
Goodbye!: He’s a good man when he wants to be good morning with such a spirit.

Anon!: Alack the day!
Goodbye!: Let’s go!

Anon!: Then let us both be sudden.
Goodbye!: Then let’s both be sudden.

Anon!: Is he well shipped?
Goodbye!: Is he well shipped?

Anon!: Tarry, Jew.
Goodbye!: Hurry, Jew.

Anon!: The town is beseeched, and the trumpet call us to the breach, and we talk and, be Chrish, do nothing, ’tis shame for us all.
Goodbye!: The town is besieged, and the trumpets call us to the breach, and we talk and, be Chrish, don’t do anything, it’s shame for us all.

Anon!: Dighton and Forrest, whom I did suborn To do this piece of ruthless butchery, Albeit they were fleshed villains, bloody dogs, Melted with tenderness and mild compassion, Wept like two children in their deaths' sad story.
Goodbye!: Dighton and Forrest, whom I swore to do this ruthless butchery, were fleshed villains, bloody dogs, melted with tenderness and mild compassion, and wept like

Anon!: My lord, I came to see your father’s funeral.
Goodbye!: My lord, I came to see your father’s funeral.

Anon!: Some must go off.
Goodbye!: Some must go off.

Anon!: They swore that you were well-nigh dead for me.
Goodbye!: They swore that you were almost dead for me.

Anon!: Hath the fellow any wit that told you this?
Goodbye!: Is the man any wit who told you this?

Anon!: What’s your highness’ pleasure?
Goodbye!: What’s your highness’s pleasure?

Anon!: I will not desire that.
Goodbye!: I won’t want that.

Anon!: Othello?
Goodbye!: Oh, what?

Anon!: Let me see now,
Goodbye!: Let me see,

Anon!: Then you do not love me?
Goodbye!: Then you don’t love me?

Anon!: How green!
Goodbye!: How green!

Anon!: Good Cinna, take this paper, And look you lay it in the praetor’s chair Where Brutus may but find it.
Goodbye!: Good Cinna, take this paper and look at it in the praetor’s chair where Brutus can only find it.

Anon!: Of a snail?
Goodbye!: Of a snail?

Anon!: A fig!
Goodbye!: A fig!

Anon!: My curses on her!
Goodbye!: I curse her!

Anon!: How does my bounteous sister?
Goodbye!: How is my baffling sister?

Anon!: Portia, art thou gone?
Goodbye!: Portia, are you gone?

Anon!: Come.
Goodbye!: Come on.

Anon!: Romeo’s a dishclout to him.
Goodbye!: Romeo’s a dishclout to him.

Anon!: Now in faith, Gratiano, You give your wife too unkind a cause of grief.
Goodbye!: Now, Gratiano, you give your wife a reason for grief to be too unkind.

Anon!: Let me come to her.
Goodbye!: Let me come to her.

Anon!: Nor go neither.
Goodbye!: And don’t go either.

Anon!: I’ll tell you in your ear.
Goodbye!: I’ll tell you in your ear.

Anon!: And here’s another, Writ in my cousin’s hand, stol'n from her pocket, Containing her affection unto Benedick.
Goodbye!: And here’s another, write in my cousin’s hand, stol'n from her pocket, containing her affection for Benedick.

Anon!: Let each man render me his bloody hand.
Goodbye!: Let each of you give me his bloody hand.

Anon!: Why do you speak so startingly and rash?
Goodbye!: Why are you talking so rashly and a bit scolding?

Anon!: May I never To this good purpose, that so fairly shows, Dream of impediment!
Goodbye!: I’ll never dream of a sanity, which is so fair, but I’ll never dream of a sanity!

Anon!: My soul, and not my child!
Goodbye!: My soul, not my child!

Anon!: Madam?
Goodbye!: Madam?

Anon!: Why, that he did—I know not what he did.
Goodbye!: That’s what he did—I don’t know what he did.

Anon!: It must be  Nay, but hear you, Goodman Delver— Give me leave.
Goodbye!: It must be Nay, but listen to me, Goodman Delver— Give me permission.

Anon!: Is it his use?
Goodbye!: Is it his use?

Anon!: Who does me this?
Goodbye!: Who does this mean?

Anon!: The sun is high, and we outwear the day.
Goodbye!: The sun is high, and we’re out of the day.

Anon!: Who’s here?
Goodbye!: Who’s this?

Anon!: Hey, Mountain, hey!
Goodbye!: Hey, Mountain, hey!

Anon!: I thank thee for that gird, good Tranio.
Goodbye!: Thank you for that gird, Tranio.

Anon!: That you have wronged me doth appear in this: You have condemned and noted Lucius Pella For taking bribes here of the Sardians, Wherein my letters, praying on his side Because I knew the man, were slighted off.
Goodbye!: You’ve condemned and noted Lucius Pella for taking bribes here of the Sardians, wherein my letters, praying on his side because I knew the man, were slighted off.

Anon!: Alack the day.
Goodbye!: Let’s go.

Anon!: My lord, I have news to tell you.
Goodbye!: My lord, I have news to tell you.

Anon!: It might have since been answered in repaying What we took from them, which, for traffic’s sake, Most of our city did.
Goodbye!: It might have been a good idea that we’d repay what we took from them, which, for traffic’s sake, most of our city did.

Anon!: That they lack, for if their heads had any intellectual armor, they could never wear such heavy head-pieces.
Goodbye!: They don’t have any armor, because if their heads were armed with any armor, they wouldn’t wear such heavy headpieces.

Anon!: Their papers is more lawful.
Goodbye!: Their papers are more legal.

Anon!: Therefore my age is as a lusty winter, Frosty but kindly.
Goodbye!: So my age is as lusty as winter, but it’s frosty.

Anon!: Get thee to a nunnery, go.
Goodbye!: Go to a nunnery.

Anon!: I must be gone.
Goodbye!: I have to go.

Anon!: I was provokèd by her sland'rous tongue, That laid their guilt upon my guiltless shoulders.
Goodbye!: I was slandish, and she gave me guilt on my guiltless shoulders.

Anon!: Pardon me, sweet one, even for the vows We made each other but so late ago.
Goodbye!: Pardon me, sweet man, for the vows we made each other only so late ago.

Anon!: I pray you, uncle, give me this dagger.
Goodbye!: Please, uncle, give me this dagger.

Anon!: Officers, what offense have these men done?
Goodbye!: Officers, what offense have these men committed?

Anon!: Dost thou hold there still?
Goodbye!: Do you still live there?

Anon!: The people love me, and the sea is mine.
Goodbye!: The people love me, and the sea is mine.

Anon!: Good madam, be not angry with the child.
Goodbye!: Good madam, don’t be angry with the child.

Anon!: Think upon these gone.
Goodbye!: Think about the ones who have died.

Anon!: What think you of the Scottish lord, his neighbor?
Goodbye!: What do you think of the Scottish lord, his neighbor?

Anon!: Why do you cross me in this exigent?
Goodbye!: Why are you crossing me in this sane situation?

Anon!: What woman, then?
Goodbye!: What woman, then?

Anon!: You must not think then that I am drunk.
Goodbye!: You shouldn’t think that I’m drunk.

Anon!: If thou beest Stephano, touch me and speak to me.
Goodbye!: If you’re Stephano, touch me and speak to me.

Anon!: The gown is made Just as my master had direction.
Goodbye!: The gown is made as if my master had a direction.

Anon!: Hail!
Goodbye!: Hail!

Anon!: Oh, ho!
Goodbye!: Oh, ho!

Anon!: I commend my duty to your lordship.
Goodbye!: I’m recommending my duty to your lord.

Anon!: Out of these convertites There is much matter to be heard and learned.
Goodbye!: Out of these convertites there is much to be learned and heard.

Anon!: Not a word.
Goodbye!: Not a word.

Anon!: Fie, fie, ’tis lewd and filthy!
Goodbye!: Oh, it’s rotten and filthy!

Anon!: No, heavens forfend, I would not kill thy soul!
Goodbye!: No, heavens forbid, I wouldn’t kill your soul!

Anon!: Where, where?
Goodbye!: Where, where?

Anon!: Not now to hear thee sing.
Goodbye!: Don’t listen to you anymore.

Anon!: Who comes here?
Goodbye!: Who’s coming?

Anon!: But what’s your will?
Goodbye!: But what do you want?

Anon!: Let’s stay and hear the will.
Goodbye!: Let’s stay and hear the will.

Anon!: What can he say in this?
Goodbye!: What does he say in this?

Anon!: If they do this, As, if God please, they shall, my ransom then Will soon be levied.
Goodbye!: If they do this, as if God pleases, then my ransom will be refunded soon.

Anon!: The fee simple?
Goodbye!: The fee is simple?

Anon!: If you have any music that may not be heard, to ’t again.
Goodbye!: If you have any music that can’t be heard, then go back.

Anon!: Peace.—Who comes here?
Goodbye!: Quiet.—Who’s this?

Anon!: Things base and vile, holding no quantity, Love can transpose to form and dignity.
Goodbye!: Everything is vile and vile, and it’s not worthless.

Anon!: What, in the midst of the street?
Goodbye!: What, in the middle of the street?

Anon!: Go, my dread lord, to your great-grandsire’s tomb, From whom you claim.
Goodbye!: Go to your great-grandmother’s tomb, from whom you claim to be.

Anon!: I’ll fish for thee and get thee wood enough.
Goodbye!: I’ll fish for you and get you enough wood.

Anon!: But seven years since, in Syracusa, boy, Thou know’st we parted.
Goodbye!: But seven years ago, in Syracusa, boy, you know we’ve split.

Anon!: Of my kind uncle, that I know will give, And being but a toy, which is no grief to give.
Goodbye!: I know that my uncle will give me a toy, and that’s not a sad thing to do.

Anon!: Ophelia, walk you here.
Goodbye!: Ophelia, walk here.

Anon!: The messengers from our sister and the king.
Goodbye!: The messengers from our sister and the king.

Anon!: Here comes the king, The queen, the courtiers—who is this they follow, And with such maimèd rites?
Goodbye!: Here comes the king, the queen, the courtiers—who are the men they follow, and with such a rite?

Anon!: Your man and you are marvelous merry, sir.
Goodbye!: Your man and you are wonderful, sir.

Anon!: I had else been perfect, Whole as the marble, founded as the rock, As broad and general as the casing air.
Goodbye!: I had been as full as the marble, founded as the rock, as broad and general as the air.

Anon!: Ay, sir.
Goodbye!: Yes, sir.

Anon!: What’s your gracious pleasure?
Goodbye!: What’s your pleasure?

Anon!: The King will be gone from Southampton.
Goodbye!: The King will be gone from Southampton.

Anon!: I nursed her daughter that you talked withal.
Goodbye!: I nursed her daughter, whom you talked to.

Anon!: Still be ’t yours.
Goodbye!: It’s still yours.

Anon!: I looked her in the face, and saw her led Between her brother and Mark Antony.
Goodbye!: I looked at her in the face and saw her lead between her brother and Mark Antony.

Anon!: The foul fiend haunts Poor Tom in the voice of a nightingale.
Goodbye!: The foul fiend haunts Poor Tom in the voice of a nightingale.

Anon!: May I know?
Goodbye!: Can I know?

Anon!: If you meet the Prince in the night, you may stay him.
Goodbye!: If you meet the Prince in the night, you can stay with him.

Anon!: Had I not Four or five women once that tended me?
Goodbye!: Didn’t I have four or five women who tended to me once?

Anon!: They’ll mar my counterfeiting.
Goodbye!: They’ll ruin my counterfeiting.

Anon!: I shall laugh myself to death at this puppy-headed monster.
Goodbye!: I’ll laugh myself to death at this puppy-headed monster.

Anon!: Done.
Goodbye!: Don’t.

Anon!: Therefore prepare thyself.
Goodbye!: So prepare yourself.

Anon!: What a plague means my niece, to take the death of her brother thus?
Goodbye!: What a plague means, my niece, to take the death of her brother like this?

Anon!: If thou dost play with him at any game, Thou art sure to lose, and of that natural luck He beats thee ’gainst the odds.
Goodbye!: If you play with him at any game, you’ll lose, and he beat you by beating you.

Anon!: Some achieve greatness—” What sayest thou?
Goodbye!: Some achieve greatness—” What do you say?

Anon!: And therefore tell me, most fair Katherine, will you have me?
Goodbye!: So tell me, dear Katherine, will you have me?

Anon!: Put up thy sword, Or manage it to part these men with me.
Goodbye!: Put up your sword or take it to take these men with me.

Anon!: But, good Kate, mock me mercifully, the rather, gentle princess, because I love thee cruelly.
Goodbye!: But, good Kate, mock me mercifully, the rather gentle princess, because I love you cruelly.

Anon!: What is it that you would impart to me?
Goodbye!: What do you want to tell me?

Anon!: He will, an if he live to be a man.
Goodbye!: He will, if he lives to be a man.

Anon!: Their residence, both in reputation and profit, was better both ways.
Goodbye!: Their reputation and their profit were better both ways.

Anon!: Come on, to ’t.
Goodbye!: Come on, come on.

Anon!: I think their inhibition comes by the means of the late innovation.
Goodbye!: I think they’re being punished by the late innovation.

Anon!: O Antony, Thou mine of bounty, how wouldst thou have paid My better service, when my turpitude Thou dost so crown with gold!
Goodbye!: Oh, Antony, you’re mine of bounty, how would you have paid my better service, when you’re crowning my throne with gold!

Anon!: He forbids it, Being free from vainness and self-glorious pride, Giving full trophy, signal, and ostent Quite from himself, to God.
Goodbye!: He forbids it, because he is free from vainness and self-glorious pride, giving full trophy, signal, and ostentative to God.

Anon!: Upon the stroke of ten.
Goodbye!: At ten.

Anon!: We’ll to dinner, thither.
Goodbye!: We’ll go to dinner.

Anon!: Here comes young Master Ganymede, my new mistress’s brother.
Goodbye!: Here comes young Master Ganymede, my new mistress’s brother.

Anon!: Of a strange nature is the suit you follow, Yet in such rule that the Venetian law Cannot impugn you as you do proceed.—   Ay, so he says.
Goodbye!: You’re a strange person, but you can’t be pushed by the Venetian law as you do.—Yes, he says.

Anon!: If you outstay the time, upon mine honor And in the greatness of my word, you die.
Goodbye!: If you’re out of my honor and in my greatness, you’ll die.

Anon!: No, rather I will go to Benedick And counsel him to fight against his passion; And truly I’ll devise some honest slanders To stain my cousin with.
Goodbye!: No, I’ll go to Benedick and advise him to fight against his passion.

Anon!: What is your pleasure?
Goodbye!: What do you want?

Anon!: Master, go on, and I will follow thee To the last gasp, with truth and loyalty.
Goodbye!: Master, go on, and I’ll follow you to the last gasp with truth and loyalty.

Anon!: But I must tell thee plainly, Claudio undergoes my challenge, and either I must shortly hear from him, or I will subscribe him a coward.
Goodbye!: But I have to tell you clearly that Claudio is facing my challenge, and either I have to hear from him soon, or I’ll be a coward.

Anon!: Howl, howl, howl, howl!
Goodbye!: Howl, howl, howl, howl!

Anon!: Death, that hath ta'en her hence to make me wail, Ties up my tongue and will not let me speak.
Goodbye!: Death, who has sent her to make me cry, ties up my tongue and won’t let me speak.

Anon!: Sovereign of Egypt, hail!
Goodbye!: Sovereign of Egypt, hail!

Anon!: No more.
Goodbye!: Don’t worry.

Anon!: Oh, then, I see Queen Mab hath been with you.
Goodbye!: Oh, then, I see that Queen Mab has been with you.

Anon!: Why, wherefore ask you this?
Goodbye!: Why, why do you ask this?

Anon!: What, An advocate for an imposter?
Goodbye!: What, an advocate for an imposter?

Anon!: He comes to kill my heart.
Goodbye!: He’s coming to kill my heart.

Anon!: Tis a wonder, by your leave, she will be tamed so.
Goodbye!: It’s a wonder that, if you leave, she’ll be tamed like that.

Anon!: Two thousand ducats by the year of land!
Goodbye!: Two thousand ducats by the year of land!

Anon!: I took no more pains for those thanks than you took pains to thank me.” That’s as much as to say, “Any pains that I take for you is as easy as thanks.” If I do not take pity of her, I am a villain.
Goodbye!: I took no more pains for those thanks than you took pains to thank me.” That’s as easy as to say, “Any pain I take for you is as easy as thanks.” If I don’t take pity

Anon!: Have you sent to Bottom’s house?
Goodbye!: Have you sent to Bottom’s house?

Anon!: Stephano is my name, and I bring word My mistress will before the break of day Be here at Belmont.
Goodbye!: Stephano is my name, and I’ll be here at Belmont before daybreak.

Anon!: But that you do not love me.
Goodbye!: But you don’t love me.

Anon!: But old folks, many feign as they were dead, Unwieldy, slow, heavy, and pale as lead.
Goodbye!: But old people, many feign as they were dead, unwieldy, slow, heavy, and pale as lead.

Anon!: Why, she hath a face of her own.
Goodbye!: She has a face like her own.

Anon!: Myself have letters of the selfsame tenor.
Goodbye!: I have letters of the same tenor.

Anon!: Alas, you know not.
Goodbye!: You don’t know.

Anon!: Madam, O good Empress!
Goodbye!: Madam, oh good Empress!

Anon!: Into my grave.
Goodbye!: I’ll go to my grave.

Anon!: Your gentleness shall force More than your force move us to gentleness.
Goodbye!: Your gentleness will force us more than your force will force us to gentleness.

Anon!: I am a gentleman.
Goodbye!: I’m a gentleman.

Anon!: What’s he?
Goodbye!: What’s he?

Anon!: I looked not for you yet, nor am provided For your fit welcome.
Goodbye!: I didn’t look for you yet, and I’m not sure you’re welcome.

Anon!: No seconds?
Goodbye!: No seconds?

Anon!: Now I perceive they have conjoined all three To fashion this false sport, in spite of me.— Injurious Hermia!
Goodbye!: Now I see that all three of them have teamed up to make this false sport, in spite of me.—Injurious Hermia!

Anon!: Thou runaway, thou coward, art thou fled?
Goodbye!: You run away, you coward, are you leaving?

Anon!: Set me where you stand.
Goodbye!: Tell me where you stand.

Anon!: Out of my sight!— Be not offended, dear Cesario.— Rudesby, be gone!
Goodbye!: Out of my sight!—Don’t be offended, dear Cesario.—Rudesby, go away!

Anon!: Spake you not these words plain: “Sirrah, knock me here, rap me here, knock me well, and knock me soundly”?
Goodbye!: Don’t you say these words plainly: “Sirrah, knock me here, rap me here, knock me well, and knock me soundly”?

Anon!: What is his name?
Goodbye!: What’s his name?

Anon!: Well met, well met, Master Antipholus.
Goodbye!: Good-bye, good-bye, Master Antipholus.

Anon!: Nay, do not quarrel with us, good old man.
Goodbye!: No, don’t fight with us, good old man.

Anon!: Good words are better than bad strokes, Octavius.
Goodbye!: Good words are better than bad strokes, Octavius.

Anon!: And thus thy fall hath left a kind of blot To mark the full-fraught man and best endued With some suspicion.
Goodbye!: And so your fall has left a blot to mark the frightened man and bestowed with some suspicion.

Anon!: Your answer, sir, is enigmatical.
Goodbye!: Your answer is enigmatical, sir.

Anon!: Follow me.
Goodbye!: Follow me.

Anon!: Hast thou, spirit, Performed to point the tempest that I bade thee?
Goodbye!: Have you been able to tell me the time I’ve been badeing you?

Anon!: The all-seeing sun Ne'er saw her match since first the world begun.
Goodbye!: The sun in the sky has been watching her match since the world began.

Anon!: My father’s loss, the weakness which I feel, The wrack of all my friends, nor this man’s threats, To whom I am subdued, are but light to me, Might I but through my prison once a day Behold this maid.
Goodbye!: My father’s loss, my weakness, all my friends’ wracks, and all the threats to this man, whom I’m subdued, are only light to me.

Anon!: Sweet mistress—what your name is else I know not, Nor by what wonder you do hit of mine,—
Goodbye!: Sweet mistress—what else you’re not known, and what you’re surprised by my surprise—

Anon!: Do you not remember he saw a flea stick upon Bardolph’s nose, and he said it was a black soul burning in hell?
Goodbye!: Don’t you remember that Bardolph saw a flea stick on Bardolph’s nose, and he said it was a black soul burning in hell?

Anon!: Tis her command.
Goodbye!: That’s her command.

Anon!: Fie, fie!
Goodbye!: Oh, sir!

Anon!: So the poor third is up, till death enlarge his confine.
Goodbye!: So the poor third is up, until death enlarges his confinement.

Anon!: Ay—but not yet to die!
Goodbye!: Yes—but not yet to die!

Anon!: For the poor wren, The most diminutive of birds, will fight, Her young ones in her nest, against the owl.
Goodbye!: The poor wren, the most swollen of birds, will fight against the owl, her young ones in her nest.

Anon!: I think she’ll sooner prove a soldier.
Goodbye!: I think she’ll be a better soldier.

Anon!: Upon them!
Goodbye!: Have them!

Anon!: Thou wouldst make a good fool.
Goodbye!: You’d be a good fool.

Anon!: Come now, keep thine oath.
Goodbye!: Come now, keep your oath.

Anon!: Tis but a man gone.
Goodbye!: It’s only a man who’s gone.

Anon!: By my heel, I care not.
Goodbye!: I don’t care.

Anon!: Ay, my good lord.
Goodbye!: Yes, my good lord.

Anon!: Say this becomes him— As his composure must be rare indeed Whom these things cannot blemish—yet must Antony No way excuse his foils when we do bear So great weight in his lightness.
Goodbye!: If this becomes him—as he’s very brave, he’s not blemishing—you can’t excuse Antony’s slurds when we bear so much lightness.

Anon!: Laertes, I must commune with your grief, Or you deny me right.
Goodbye!: Laertes, I have to commune with your grief, or you deny me right.

Anon!: Who you are and what you would are out of my welkin, I might say “element,” but the word is overworn.
Goodbye!: I might say “element,” but the word is overworn.

Anon!: Ay, gentle cousin, were it light enough.
Goodbye!: Yes, gentle cousin, if it were light enough.

Anon!: Such comfort as do lusty young men feel When well-appareled April on the heel Of limping winter treads.
Goodbye!: As comforting as lusty young men feel when they’re snoring in April on the heel of limping winter treads.

Anon!: Have you delivered to her our decree?
Goodbye!: Have you given her our decree?

Anon!: It was he That made the overture of thy treasons to us, Who is too good to pity thee.
Goodbye!: It was the man who made us treasonous, who is too good to pity you.

Anon!: There lies your way.
Goodbye!: You’re on your way.

Anon!: Alas, who knows?
Goodbye!: Who knows?

Anon!: Would she had never given you leave to come!
Goodbye!: She never gave you permission to come!

Anon!: You’ll be sick tomorrow For this night’s watching.
Goodbye!: You’ll be sick tomorrow because you’re watching this night.

Anon!: Why appear you with this ridiculous boldness before my lady?
Goodbye!: Why are you appearing with this ridiculous boldness before my lady?

Anon!: This is Trebonius.
Goodbye!: This is Trebonius.

Anon!: Come, wherefore should you be so pashful?
Goodbye!: Come on, why should you be so sane?

Anon!: Tis almost fairy time.
Goodbye!: It’s almost fairy time.

Anon!: I serve as good a man as you.
Goodbye!: I’m as good a man as you are.

Anon!: The Count’s gentleman, one Cesario.
Goodbye!: The Count’s gentleman, Cesario.

Anon!: Draw, you rogue, or I’ll so carbonado your shanks.
Goodbye!: Draw your sword, or I’ll make you so rogue.

Anon!: Not when I saw ’t.
Goodbye!: Not when I saw it.

Anon!: Let’s alone, And do the murder first.
Goodbye!: Let’s go alone and do the murder first.

Anon!: Treason and murder ever kept together As two yoke-devils sworn to either’s purpose, Working so grossly in a natural cause That admiration did not whoop at them.
Goodbye!: Treason and murder were always kept together as two yoke-devils swore to either of them, working so grossly in a natural way that admiration didn’t scold them.

Anon!: Make me not offended In your distrust.
Goodbye!: Don’t offended me by your distrust.

Anon!: Virtue is no hornmaker, and my Rosalind is virtuous.
Goodbye!: Virtue isn’t a hornmaker, and my Rosalind is virtuous.

Anon!: Come, begin.
Goodbye!: Come on, start.

Anon!: Hark!
Goodbye!: Listen!

Anon!: Let me live here ever.
Goodbye!: Let me live here forever.

Anon!: Thou know’st the mask of night is on my face, Else would a maiden blush bepaint my cheek For that which thou hast heard me speak tonight.
Goodbye!: You know that the night mask is on my face, and you would be a maiden blushing on my cheek for the one you heard me say tonight.

Anon!: Get him to say his prayers, good Sir Toby, get him to pray.
Goodbye!: Get him to say his prayers, Sir Toby, get him to pray.

Anon!: Deny me this, And an eternal curse fall on you!
Goodbye!: Don’t give me this, and you’ll be cursed forever!

Anon!: Is ’t so, my lords of England?
Goodbye!: Is that true, my lords of England?

Anon!: And so far am I glad it so did sort, As this their jangling I esteem a sport.
Goodbye!: And so far I’m glad it did, as I’m a sport like this.

Anon!: Confess yourself freely to her, importune her help to put you in your place again.
Goodbye!: Give her your help to put you back in your place.

Anon!: This a good block.
Goodbye!: This is a good block.

Anon!: As I remember, this should be the house.
Goodbye!: As I remember, this should be the house.

Anon!: There sleeps Titania sometime of the night, Lulled in these flowers with dances and delight.
Goodbye!: Titania sleeps sometime in the night, lulled in these flowers with dances and delight.

Anon!: They are of Norway, sir.
Goodbye!: They’re from Norway, sir.

Anon!: I never gave him token.
Goodbye!: I never gave him tokens.

Anon!: Tis he, that villain Romeo.
Goodbye!: He’s the villain Romeo.

Anon!: If we walk not in the trodden paths our very petticoats will catch them.
Goodbye!: If we don’t walk in the mud, our petticoats will catch them.

Anon!: Thine eyes, sweet lady, have infected mine.
Goodbye!: My eyes have infected me, sweet lady.

Anon!: O mischief, thou art swift To enter in the thoughts of desperate men!
Goodbye!: Oh mischief, you’re rushing to enter into the thoughts of desperate men!

Anon!: I had a son, Now outlawed from my blood.
Goodbye!: I had a son, now outlawed from my blood.

Anon!: Sextus Pompeius Makes his approaches to the port of Rome.
Goodbye!: Sextus Pompeius is approaching the port of Rome.

Anon!: We found him in the churchyard.
Goodbye!: We found him in the churchyard.

Anon!: The table’s full.
Goodbye!: The table’s full.

Anon!: If I know this, know all the world besides, That part of tyranny that I do bear I can shake off at pleasure.
Goodbye!: If I know this, I know the whole world, I can shake off the part of tyranny I’m carrying.

Anon!: I would I were thy bird.
Goodbye!: I wish I were your bird.

Anon!: Shall I descend?
Goodbye!: Shall I go down?

Anon!: Bad is the world, and all will come to naught When such ill dealing must be seen in thought.
Goodbye!: The world is bad, and all will be naughty when such a bad situation is seen in the mind.

Anon!: What said my man, when my betossèd soul Did not attend him as we rode?
Goodbye!: What did my man say when my sane soul didn’t attend him as we rode?

Anon!: You have her father’s love, Demetrius.
Goodbye!: You have her father’s love, Demetrius.

Anon!: Bear them from hence.
Goodbye!: Keep them away from here.

Anon!: Now Jove, in his next commodity of hair, send thee a beard!
Goodbye!: Now, in his next piece of hair, send a beard to you!

Anon!: I, sir?
Goodbye!: I, sir?

Anon!: Farewell.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: Our force by land Hath nobly held.
Goodbye!: Our forces are on land, and they’re nobility.

Anon!: And in their ship I am sure Lorenzo is not.
Goodbye!: And I’m sure Lorenzo isn’t aboard their ship.

Anon!: Here is the money.
Goodbye!: Here’s the money.

Anon!: Here is a place reserved, sir.
Goodbye!: Here’s a place reserved, sir.

Anon!: Now, by my sword— And target.
Goodbye!: Now, by my sword— And target.

Anon!: Well, forward, forward!
Goodbye!: Well, go ahead, go ahead!

Anon!: If it be not for some purpose of import, Give ’t me again.
Goodbye!: If it doesn’t have some purpose to be imported, give it to me again.

Anon!: Is it honest in deed and word?
Goodbye!: Is it honest in word and deed?

Anon!: Come, come, thou art as hot a Jack in thy mood as any in Italy, and as soon moved to be moody, and as soon moody to be moved.
Goodbye!: Come on, you’re as hot a Jack in your mood as any other in Italy, and you’re as soon as you’re feeling moody, and so soon as you’re feeling moody.

Anon!: Go tell him of this.
Goodbye!: Tell him about this.

Anon!: My wit’s diseased.
Goodbye!: My wit’s deteriorated.

Anon!: Confess and love” Had been the very sum of my confession.
Goodbye!: I’d have been a part of my confession.

Anon!: For my part, I had rather bear with you than bear you.
Goodbye!: For my part, I’d rather bear with you than bear with you.

Anon!: Come, away.
Goodbye!: Come on, go away.

Anon!: Shall I have the thought To think on this, and shall I lack the thought That such a thing bechanced would make me sad?
Goodbye!: Should I have the thought to think about this, and should I have the thought that such a thing that’s been ruined would make me sad?

Anon!: Let copulation thrive, for Gloucester’s bastard son Was kinder to his father than my daughters got ’tween the lawful sheets.
Goodbye!: Let the copulation thrive, because Gloucester’s bastard son was kinder to his father than my daughters were tweening the lawful sheets.

Anon!: I pray thee, good Mercutio, let’s retire.
Goodbye!: Please, Mercutio, let’s go away.

Anon!: Tis more, ’tis more.
Goodbye!: It’s more, it’s more.

Anon!: For God’s sake, send some other messenger.
Goodbye!: For God’s sake, send some other messenger.

Anon!: Therefore, O Antony, stay not by his side.
Goodbye!: So don’t stay by his side, Antony.

Anon!: Still in this fashion, color, ornament, For him I imitate.
Goodbye!: I’m still in this mood, with color, ornament, for him.

Anon!: I would be loath to have you overflown with a honey bag, signor.
Goodbye!: I’d be foolish to have you overflowed with a honey bag, signor.

Anon!: Indeed, the French may lay twenty French crowns to one they will beat us, for they bear them on their shoulders.
Goodbye!: The French can give twenty French crowns to one of them, because they bear them on their shoulders.

Anon!: Peace, I say!
Goodbye!: Quiet, I say!

Anon!: Art thou not Romeo, and a Montague?
Goodbye!: Aren’t you Romeo, and a Montague?

Anon!: Let them set on at once, for I perceive But cold demeanor in Octavius' wing, And sudden push gives them the overthrow.
Goodbye!: Let them start a fight, because I see Octavius’s wing is a cold one, and a sudden push gives them the overthrow.

Anon!: Your reason.
Goodbye!: You’re right.

Anon!: Have patience, sir.
Goodbye!: Have patience, sir.

Anon!: And for Cassio, let me be his undertaker.
Goodbye!: And for Cassio, let me be his spokesman.

Anon!: Oh, the people in the street cry “Romeo,” Some “Juliet,” and some “Paris,” and all run With open outcry toward our monument.
Goodbye!: Oh, the people in the street cry “Romeo,” some “Juliet,” and some “Paris,” and all run out of anger toward our monument.

Anon!: I have, since I was three year old, conversed with a magician, most profound in his art and yet not damnable.
Goodbye!: I’ve been talking to a magician since I was three years old, who is very powerful in his art, and yet is not damnable.

Anon!: Fetch Desdemona hither.
Goodbye!: Take Desdemona here.

Anon!: One woe doth tread upon another’s heel, So fast they follow.—Your sister’s drowned, Laertes.
Goodbye!: One of the worst things is treading on another’s heel so fast they follow.—Your sister’s drowned, Laertes.

Anon!: Be patient, for you shall remain with us.
Goodbye!: Be patient, because you’ll stay with us.

Anon!: Gracious my lord, I should report that which I say I saw, But know not how to do ’t.
Goodbye!: My lord, I should tell you what I said I saw, but I don’t know how to do it.

Anon!: A foolish thought, to say a sorry sight.
Goodbye!: It’s a foolish thought to say a sorry sight.

Anon!: There to meet with Macbeth.
Goodbye!: There to meet Macbeth.

Anon!: I charge thee, hence, and do not haunt me thus.
Goodbye!: I’ll take you there, and I’ll never be able to haunt me like that.

Anon!: Cousin, thou wast not wont to be so dull.
Goodbye!: Cousin, you weren’t going to be so dull.

Anon!: Now all is well.
Goodbye!: Now everything is fine.

Anon!: I will fall prostrate at his feet And never rise until my tears and prayers Have won his grace to come in person hither And take perforce my husband from the Abbess.
Goodbye!: I’ll fall prostrate at his feet and never rise until my tears and prayers have won his grace to come here and take my husband away from the Abbess.

Anon!: These are the forgeries of jealousy.
Goodbye!: These are the forgeries of jealousy.

Anon!: Tis a fearful odds.
Goodbye!: It’s a fearful situation.

Anon!: How does my old acquaintance of this isle?— Honey, you shall be well desired in Cyprus, I have found great love amongst them.
Goodbye!: How did my old acquaintance of this island be?—House, you’ll be well desired in Cyprus, I have found great love among them.

Anon!: She died, my lord, but whiles her slander lived.
Goodbye!: She died, my lord, but she lived while her slander was alive.

Anon!: That may be, sir, when I may be a wife.
Goodbye!: That may be true, sir, when I’m a wife.

Anon!: He supped at my house, but I therefore shake not.
Goodbye!: He supped at my house, but I don’t shake him.

Anon!: Soft, soft!
Goodbye!: Soft, soft!

Anon!: Fathers, from hence trust not your daughters' minds By what you see them act.
Goodbye!: Fathers, don’t trust your daughters’ minds by what you see them act.

Anon!: And I will purge thy mortal grossness so That thou shalt like an airy spirit go.— Peaseblossom, Cobweb, Moth, and Mustardseed!
Goodbye!: And I’ll purge your mortal grossness so that you’ll go like a sane spirit.—Peaseblossom, Cobweb, Moth, and Mustardseed!

Anon!: Yes, being kept together and put to use.
Goodbye!: Yes, being kept together and put to use.

Anon!: I conjure you by that which you profess— Howe'er you come to know it—answer me.
Goodbye!: I’ll conjure you by the words you profess—however you come to know it—that you’re asking me.

Anon!: We’ll burn the house of Brutus.
Goodbye!: We’ll burn the house of Brutus.

Anon!: Madam, if you could find out but a man To bear a poison, I would temper it, That Romeo should, upon receipt thereof, Soon sleep in quiet.
Goodbye!: Madam, if you could find a man who bears a poison, I’d temper it so that Romeo should sleep quietly soon.

Anon!: Our preparation stands In expectation of them.
Goodbye!: We’re ready to get them.

Anon!: You mock me, sir.
Goodbye!: You mock me, sir.

Anon!: Now, my Titania, wake you, my sweet queen.
Goodbye!: Now, Titania, wake up, my sweet queen.

Anon!: Thou liest, malignant thing!
Goodbye!: You’re a liar, a malignant thing!

Anon!: Come.
Goodbye!: Come on.

Anon!: Go show your slaves how choleric you are And make your bondmen tremble.
Goodbye!: Show your slaves how choleric you are, and make your bondmen tremble.

Anon!: Ay, madam.
Goodbye!: Yes, madam.

Anon!: Twas never merry world Since lowly feigning was call’d compliment.
Goodbye!: It was never a happy world, since low-feigning was a compliment.

Anon!: I will, my lord.
Goodbye!: I will, my lord.

Anon!: The more the pity that some honest neighbors will not make them friends.
Goodbye!: The more it’s pity that some honest neighbors won’t make them friends.

Anon!: As wit and fortune will.
Goodbye!: As wit and fortune will.

Anon!: What mean your graces?
Goodbye!: What are you doing?

Anon!: What lawful quest have given their verdict up Unto the frowning judge?
Goodbye!: What lawful quest did the judge give their verdict?

Anon!: Th’ art an honest man.
Goodbye!: You’re an honest man.

Anon!: I’ll fight at sea.
Goodbye!: I’ll fight at sea.

Anon!: What mean you, Caesar?
Goodbye!: What do you mean, Caesar?

Anon!: He that conceals him, death.
Goodbye!: The one who conceals him, death.

Anon!: And wast thou fain, poor father, To hovel thee with swine and rogues forlorn In short and musty straw?
Goodbye!: And were you trying to scold you with a swine and rogues forlorn in a short and musty straw?

Anon!: The world esteemed thy father honorable, But I did find him still mine enemy.
Goodbye!: The world respected your father honorably, but I found him my enemy.

Anon!: Sir, sir, I will have law in Ephesus, To your notorious shame, I doubt it not.
Goodbye!: Sir, sir, I’ll have law in Ephesus, I don’t doubt it.

Anon!: I’ll give you a verse to this note that I made yesterday in despite of my invention.
Goodbye!: I’ll give you a verse to this note I made yesterday, despite my invention.

Anon!: What wilt thou tell her, Nurse?
Goodbye!: What will you tell her, Nurse?

Anon!: But now I’ll tell thee joyful tidings, girl.
Goodbye!: But now I’ll tell you joyous stories, girl.

Anon!: A poor unfortunate beggar.
Goodbye!: A poor, unfortunate beggar.

Anon!: Gold, silver, and base lead.
Goodbye!: Gold, silver, and base lead.

Anon!: God make incision in thee; thou art raw.
Goodbye!: God make you a bit more sane.

Anon!: Marry, patience, Or I shall say you are all in all in spleen, And nothing of a man.
Goodbye!: Please, patience, or I’ll say you’re all in spleen, and nothing of a man.

Anon!: Master, is this Mistress Satan?
Goodbye!: Master, is this Mistress Satan?

Anon!: To be honest, as this world goes, is to be one man picked out of ten thousand.
Goodbye!: To be honest, as this world goes, is to be one man picked out of ten thousand.

Anon!: Please, let me stay.
Goodbye!: Please, let me stay.

Anon!: Hie to high fortune!
Goodbye!: Go to high fortune!

Anon!: All is not well.
Goodbye!: It’s not good.

Anon!: Your eldest daughters have fordone themselves, And desperately are dead.
Goodbye!: Your eldest daughters have forgiven themselves, and are desperately dead.

Anon!: I gave my love a ring and made him swear Never to part with it.
Goodbye!: I gave my love a ring and made him swear never to wear it.

Anon!: Firm and irrevocable is my doom Which I have passed upon her.
Goodbye!: I’ve passed on her to be a sane woman.

Anon!: You take my life When you do take the means whereby I live.
Goodbye!: You take my life when you take the means where I live.

Anon!: Come forth, thou fearful man.
Goodbye!: Come out, you fearful man.

Anon!: Why, that’s my dainty Ariel.
Goodbye!: That’s my dainty Ariel.

Anon!: To feed my humor, wish thyself no harm.
Goodbye!: To feed my humor, don’t wish yourself harm.

Anon!: I give them with this ring, Which when you part from, lose, or give away, Let it presage the ruin of your love
Goodbye!: I give them this ring, which when you break from, lose, or give away, will be a sign of your love.

Anon!: Tongue nor heart cannot conceive nor name thee!
Goodbye!: No one can understand or name you!

Anon!: Fortune is merry, And in this mood will give us anything.
Goodbye!: Fortune is a good man, and in this mood, he’ll give us anything.

Anon!: What, man?
Goodbye!: What, man?

Anon!: Yet thou liest in the bleak air.
Goodbye!: But you’re lying in the bleak air.

Anon!: when ’twas a little prating thing.—Oh, there is a nobleman in town, one Paris, that would fain lay knife aboard, but she, good soul, had as lief see a toad, a very toad, as see him.
Goodbye!: When it was a little bit of a prating thing.—Oh, there’s a nobleman in town, one Paris, who would fain lay knife on the ship, but she, good soul, had

Anon!: I shall devise something.
Goodbye!: I’ll do something.

Anon!: Death is my son-in-law.
Goodbye!: Death is my son-in-law.

Anon!: What news, what news in this our tott'ring state?
Goodbye!: What news, what news do you have in this stumbling state?

Anon!: What, not one hit?
Goodbye!: What, not one hit?

Anon!: But soft, behold!
Goodbye!: But wait, see!

Anon!: Nor anyone.
Goodbye!: No one.

Anon!: Tis with cares.
Goodbye!: It’s a good thing.

Anon!: Then there’s life in ’t.
Goodbye!: Then there’s life in it.

Anon!: We are blessèd in the change.
Goodbye!: We’re blessed by the change.

Anon!: Why, well.
Goodbye!: Well, well.

Anon!: I pray God he be not, I say.
Goodbye!: I beg God he isn’t, I say.

Anon!: So kind a father!—Be my horses ready?
Goodbye!: I’m so kind a father!—Be my horses ready?

Anon!: Care keeps his watch in every old man’s eye, And where care lodges, sleep will never lie.
Goodbye!: He’s always in the eye of every old man, and when he’s in the mood, he’ll never lie.

Anon!: For your part, To you our swords have leaden points, Mark Antony.
Goodbye!: For your part, our swords have lead points, Mark Antony.

Anon!: Good nuncle, in, and ask thy daughters blessing.
Goodbye!: Come in, good nuncle, and ask your daughters to give them blessing.

Anon!: I dare say you love him not so ill to wish him here alone, howsoever you speak this to feel other men’s minds.
Goodbye!: I’d rather say you love him than wish him alone, so you’re telling other men to think about him.

Anon!: I have a journey, sir, shortly to go.
Goodbye!: I’ll have a long journey to go, sir.

Anon!: You are welcome, masters, welcome, all!—I am glad to see thee well.—Welcome, good friends.—O old friend?
Goodbye!: You are welcome, masters, welcome, all!—I’m glad to see you well.—Welcome, good friends.—O old friend?

Anon!: Is it good e'en?
Goodbye!: Is it good?

Anon!: I’ll call Sir Toby the whilst.
Goodbye!: I’ll call Sir Toby the next time.

Anon!: But I’ll go in.
Goodbye!: But I’ll go in.

Anon!: Nay, that’s not so.
Goodbye!: No, that’s not true.

Anon!: A pair of stocks, you rogue!
Goodbye!: A pair of stocks, you rogue!

Anon!: Save thee, Curan.
Goodbye!: Save you, Curan.

Anon!: Yet I beseech you, If you think fit, or that it may be done, Give me advantage of some brief discourse With Desdemona alone.
Goodbye!: But please, if you think it’s appropriate or that it’s possible, give me some brief talk with Desdemona alone.

Anon!: Let it appear so.
Goodbye!: Let it appear.

Anon!: I am hers.
Goodbye!: I’m hers.

Anon!: Thou art a villain!
Goodbye!: You’re a villain!

Anon!: What, have you writ that letter to my sister?
Goodbye!: Have you written that letter to my sister?

Anon!: The citizens are up, and Tybalt slain.
Goodbye!: The citizens are up, and Tybalt has been killed.

Anon!: Good, good, the justice of it pleases!
Goodbye!: Good, good, it’s fair to you!

Anon!: Who comes with her?
Goodbye!: Who’s coming with her?

Anon!: When think you that the sword goes up again?
Goodbye!: When do you think the sword is going up again?

Anon!: Hail, King of Scotland!
Goodbye!: Hail, King of Scotland!

Anon!: If all else fail, myself have power to die.
Goodbye!: If everything else fails, I’ll have the power to die.

Anon!: There’s none but witches do inhabit here, And therefore ’tis high time that I were hence.
Goodbye!: There’s no one except witches here, and it’s high time for me to leave.

Anon!: Was ever man so beaten?
Goodbye!: Was a man ever so beaten?

Anon!: Well aimed of such a young one.
Goodbye!: I’m hoping for a young man like that.

Anon!: Not so happy, yet much happier.
Goodbye!: Not so happy, but much happier.

Anon!: Tranio hits you now.
Goodbye!: Tranio’s hitting you now.

Anon!: I did send, After the last enchantment you did here, A ring in chase of you.
Goodbye!: I sent you a ring after the last enchantment you had here.

Anon!: Antony will use his affection where it is.
Goodbye!: Antony will use his affection wherever it is.

Anon!: Will it not be received, When we have marked with blood those sleepy two Of his own chamber and used their very daggers, That they have done ’t?
Goodbye!: Willn’t we see that when we’ve marked with blood those two sleepy men in his own chamber and used their daggers to do it?

Anon!: It lies in you.
Goodbye!: It’s in you.

Anon!: Nay, let me praise you while I have a stomach.
Goodbye!: No, let me praise you while I’m eating.

Anon!: Farewell, father.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, father.

Anon!: Our house is hell, and thou, a merry devil, Didst rob it of some taste of tediousness.
Goodbye!: Our house is hell, and you, a merry devil, robbed it of some tediousness.

Anon!: Plantagenet.
Goodbye!: Plantagenet.

Anon!: Oh, I am spoiled, undone by villains!
Goodbye!: Oh, I’m spoiled, and wiped out by villains!

Anon!: You are a royal one, and we obey you.
Goodbye!: You’re a royal, and we’re obeying you.

Anon!: Why, the night gone by.
Goodbye!: The night has passed.

Anon!: I prithee speak to me as to thy thinkings, As thou dost ruminate, and give thy worst of thoughts The worst of words.
Goodbye!: Please tell me what you think, as you ruminate, and give your worst thoughts the worst of words.

Anon!: Now heaven hath all,
Goodbye!: Now heaven has all.

Anon!: The generals would have some words.
Goodbye!: The generals would like to say some words.

Anon!: Who has done this, Sir Andrew?
Goodbye!: Who did this, Sir Andrew?

Anon!: We looked not for Mark Antony here.
Goodbye!: We didn’t look for Mark Antony here.

Anon!: I shall not look upon his like again.
Goodbye!: I won’t look at his likeness again.

Anon!: I’ll die for ’t but some woman had the ring.
Goodbye!: I’ll die for it only if some woman had the ring.

Anon!: Never anger Made good guard for itself.
Goodbye!: Never made anger a good guard for itself.

Anon!: What, wilt thou wash him from his grave with tears?
Goodbye!: Do you want to wash him out of his grave with tears?

Anon!: You have said, sir.
Goodbye!: You’ve said what you’re saying, sir.

Anon!: I am no fee’d post, lady.
Goodbye!: I’m not a fee-free person, lady.

Anon!: A howling monster, a drunken monster.
Goodbye!: A drunken monster.

Anon!: You sent me to the bay, sir, for a bark.
Goodbye!: You sent me to the bay for a bark.

Anon!: Go, sirrah, take them to the buttery And give them friendly welcome every one.
Goodbye!: Go, sir, take them to the buttery place and welcome them to everyone.

Anon!: Yes, other men have ill luck too.
Goodbye!: Yes, other men have bad luck too.

Anon!: Is it not hard, Nerissa, that I cannot choose one nor refuse none?
Goodbye!: Isn’t it hard, Nerissa, that I can’t choose one or refuse none?

Anon!: O Cassio, Cassio, Cassio!
Goodbye!: Oh, Cassio, Cassio, Cassio!

Anon!: All this amazement can I qualify When after that the holy rites are ended I’ll tell you largely of fair Hero’s death.
Goodbye!: I can’t believe all this amazement until I’ll tell you a lot about Hero’s death.

Anon!: He has my dying voice.
Goodbye!: He has my dying voice.

Anon!: Save means to live.
Goodbye!: Save the means to live.

Anon!: Thou know’st ’tis common.
Goodbye!: You know that it’s common.

Anon!: Whence come you?
Goodbye!: When are you coming?

Anon!: Talk not to me, for I’ll not speak a word.
Goodbye!: Don’t talk to me, because I won’t say a word.

Anon!: Calls your Worship?
Goodbye!: Are you calling your Worship?

Anon!: At your noble pleasure.
Goodbye!: At your noble pleasure.

Anon!: Why then, the mustard without the beef.
Goodbye!: Well then, the mustard without the beef.

Anon!: Well then, confess and live.
Goodbye!: Well then, confess and live.

Anon!: Who sent you hither?
Goodbye!: Who sent you here?

Anon!: But this most foul, strange and unnatural.
Goodbye!: But this is very bad, strange and unnatural.

Anon!: Come you from old Bellario?
Goodbye!: Are you coming from old Bellario?

Anon!: I pray you, let it stand.
Goodbye!: Please, let it stand.

Anon!: Name the day of marriage, and God give thee joy.
Goodbye!: Name the day of marriage, and God give you joy.

Anon!: Farewell the neighing steed and the shrill trump, The spirit-stirring drum, th' ear-piercing fife, The royal banner, and all quality, Pride, pomp, and circumstance of glorious war!
Goodbye!: Farewell to the neighing steed and the shrill trump, the spirit-stirring drum, the ear-piercing fife, the royal banner, and all the quality

Anon!: Signior Baptista, you are happily met.— Sir, this is the gentleman I told you of.
Goodbye!: Signior Baptista, you’re happy to be here.—Sir, this is the gentleman I told you about.

Anon!: I am sure no man hath any quarrel to me.
Goodbye!: I’m sure no one has any fight with me.

Anon!: Cassio, may you suspect Who they should be that have thus mangled you?
Goodbye!: Cassio, do you think they should be the ones who have mangled you?

Anon!: Your vessels and your spells provide, Your charms and everything beside.
Goodbye!: Your vessels and your spells provide, your charms and everything else.

Anon!: But art not thou thyself giddy with the fashion too, that thou hast shifted out of thy tale into telling me of the fashion?
Goodbye!: But you’re not giddy with the fashion too, so that you’ve shifted out of your story to tell me about the fashion?

Anon!: What’s this for?
Goodbye!: What’s this for?

Anon!: Tremblingly she stood And on the sudden dropped.
Goodbye!: She stood tremblingly and suddenly dropped.

Anon!: Did Michael Cassio, when you wooed my lady, Know of your love?
Goodbye!: Did Michael Cassio know when you wooed my lady, about your love?

Anon!: Nay, not sure, in a thing falsing.
Goodbye!: No, not sure, in a thing that’s falsing.

Anon!: If it be you that stir these daughters' hearts Against their father, fool me not so much To bear it tamely.
Goodbye!: If you’re the ones who stir these daughters' hearts against their father, don’t fool me so much to bear it tamely.

Anon!: Mine shall be spent When theirs are dry, for Romeo’s banishment.
Goodbye!: I’ll be spent on my own when they’re dry, for Romeo’s banishment.

Anon!: Speak thou now.
Goodbye!: Tell me now.

Anon!: My lord, you once did love me.
Goodbye!: My lord, you once loved me.

Anon!: I wonder at this haste, that I must wed Ere he, that should be husband, comes to woo.
Goodbye!: I wonder at this moment that I have to marry him, who should be husband, and come to woo me.

Anon!: Here, my lord.
Goodbye!: Here, my lord.

Anon!: He says they can do nothing in this kind.
Goodbye!: He says they can’t do anything in this way.

Anon!: Till night, my lord, and all night too.
Goodbye!: I’ll go to bed until night, my lord, and all night too.

Anon!: Doth not my wit become me rarely?
Goodbye!: Doesn’t my wit become me very rarely?

Anon!: Away with him.
Goodbye!: Go with him.

Anon!: I have.
Goodbye!: I have.

Anon!: I anger her sometimes and tell her that Paris is the properer man.
Goodbye!: I anger her sometimes and tell her that Paris is the better man.

Anon!: Let go, slave, or thou diest!
Goodbye!: Let go of it, slave, or you die!

Anon!: I am one, my liege, Whom the vile blows and buffets of the world Have so incensed that I am reckless what I do to spite the world.
Goodbye!: I’m one of those people who have been so angry and angry that I’m reckless in doing what I do to spite the world.

Anon!: How have you known the miseries of your father?
Goodbye!: How have you known the misfortunes of your father?

Anon!: Here, at thy hand.
Goodbye!: Here, at your hand.

Anon!: Can any of your neighbors tell, Kate?
Goodbye!: Can any of your neighbors tell you, Kate?

Anon!: He left this ring behind him, Would I or not.
Goodbye!: He left this ring behind him, either I or not.

Anon!: That did I never hear.
Goodbye!: I never heard that.

Anon!: I had as lief have my mistress a jade.
Goodbye!: I had as much as a mistress a jade.

Anon!: Possess them not with fear.
Goodbye!: Don’t fear them.

Anon!: Made you no more offense but what you speak of?
Goodbye!: Did you have any more offense than what you’re talking about?

Anon!: Anything that’s mended is but patched.
Goodbye!: Anything that’s been mended is only patched.

Anon!: Saw who?
Goodbye!: Saw who?

Anon!: If not, elsewhere they meet with charity.
Goodbye!: If not, they’ll meet with the lord.

Anon!: Well.
Goodbye!: Well, that’s right.

Anon!: Truly, madam, he holds Beelzebub at the staves' end as well as a man in his case may do.
Goodbye!: Yes, madam, he holds Beelzebub at the end of the staves as a man in his case can.

Anon!: But wherefore, villain, didst thou kill my cousin?
Goodbye!: But why did you kill my cousin?

Anon!: There my Lysander and myself shall meet.
Goodbye!: I’ll meet Lysander and myself there.

Anon!: As I am an honest man, he looks pale.—Art thou sick, or angry?
Goodbye!: As honest as I am, he looks pale.—Are you sick or angry?

Anon!: O heavy day!
Goodbye!: Oh, what a sad day!

Anon!: Lend thy hand And pluck my magic garment from me.
Goodbye!: Lend your hand and pluck my magic garment from me.

Anon!: For you see, it is already in snuff.
Goodbye!: You see, it’s already in a snuff.

Anon!: The urging of that word “judgment” hath bred a kind of remorse in me.
Goodbye!: I’ve been remorsed by the words “judgment.”

Anon!: Hold, there is forty ducats.
Goodbye!: There are forty ducats.

Anon!: You have forgot the will I told you of.
Goodbye!: You’ve forgotten the will I told you about.

Anon!: Bring me to Antony.
Goodbye!: Bring me to Antony.

Anon!: If Cleopatra heard you, your reproof Were well deserved of rashness.
Goodbye!: If Cleopatra heard you, you’d be well deserved for your rashness.

Anon!: Nay, as they dare.
Goodbye!: No, they dare.

Anon!: Thy spirits are most tall.
Goodbye!: Your spirits are taller than you are.

Anon!: And when she is froward, peevish, sullen, sour, And not obedient to his honest will, What is she but a foul contending rebel And graceless traitor to her loving lord?
Goodbye!: And when she’s froward, peevish, sullen, sour, and not obedient to his honest will, what is she like to be a rebel and a graceless traitor

Anon!: Be ruled.
Goodbye!: Be ruled.

Anon!: Here, my lord.
Goodbye!: Here, my lord.

Anon!: Why, what’s a moveable?
Goodbye!: What’s a moveable thing?

Anon!: Is ’t possible?
Goodbye!: Is it possible?

Anon!: We will speak further.
Goodbye!: We’ll speak further.

Anon!: A good knave.
Goodbye!: A good knave.

Anon!: Oh, they are our friends.
Goodbye!: Oh, they’re our friends.

Anon!: On, on, on, on, on!
Goodbye!: On, on, on, on, on!

Anon!: Worse and worse!
Goodbye!: Worse and worse!

Anon!: Foul, wrinkled witch, what mak’st thou in my sight?
Goodbye!: What’s the mak in my eyes?

Anon!: I' th' air or th' earth?
Goodbye!: Is it in the air or the earth?

Anon!: Thou bleed’st apace.
Goodbye!: You’re bleeding quickly.

Anon!: He is knight, dubbed with unhatched rapier and on carpet consideration, but he is a devil in private brawl.
Goodbye!: He’s a knight, dubbed with a rapier and a carpet, but he’s a devil in a private brawl.

Anon!: O noble English, that could entertain With half their forces the full pride of France And let another half stand laughing by, All out of work and cold for action!
Goodbye!: Oh, noble English, who could entertain with half their forces the full pride of France and let another half stand laughing by, all out of work and cold for action!

Anon!: Most sure and vulgar.
Goodbye!: It’s true and vulgar.

Anon!: Under what captain serve you?
Goodbye!: What captain do you serve?

Anon!: To who?
Goodbye!: Who?

Anon!: We shall be the more marketable.—Bonjour, Monsieur Le Beau.
Goodbye!: We’ll be the more attractive.—Bonjour, Monsieur Le Beau.

Anon!: There, take it; and much thanks for my good cheer.
Goodbye!: Here, take it, and thank you for my good cheer.

Anon!: And so he fell.
Goodbye!: And so he fell.

Anon!: Yes, the fashion is the fashion.
Goodbye!: Yes, fashion is fashion.

Anon!: Fear me not.
Goodbye!: Don’t worry about me.

Anon!: Yea, noise?
Goodbye!: Oh, noise?

Anon!: I warrant thou art a merry fellow and carest for nothing.
Goodbye!: I assure you’re a good fellow and don’t care about anything.

Anon!: Tis but one cast away, and so, come, death.
Goodbye!: It’s only one cast away, and so come, death.

Anon!: Never, Iago.
Goodbye!: Never, Iago.

Anon!: Lives, sir.
Goodbye!: Lives, sir.

Anon!: The leisure and the fearful time Cuts off the ceremonious vows of love And ample interchange of sweet discourse, Which so-long-sundered friends should dwell upon.
Goodbye!: The time and the time of the day cut off the ceremonious vows of love and the endless exchange of sweet words, which so long-sundered friends should be able to speak with.

Anon!: As I am an honest man, I thought you had received some bodily wound.
Goodbye!: As an honest man, I thought you had suffered some bodily wound.

Anon!: I will look him and privily relieve him.
Goodbye!: I’ll look at him and relieve him.

Anon!: Commend me to Lord William.
Goodbye!: Give my praises to Lord William.

Anon!: Did you ne'er hear say, “Two may keep counsel, putting one away”?
Goodbye!: Did you hear someone say, “Two can keep a good friend, putting one away”?

Anon!: In God’s name, what art thou?
Goodbye!: What are you doing in God’s name?

Anon!: Before the time I did Lysander see Seemed Athens as a paradise to me.
Goodbye!: Before I saw Lysander, Athens was a paradise for me.

Anon!: I beseech you, do me this courteous office, as to know of the knight what my offense to him is.
Goodbye!: Please, do me this courteous job, so I can know what my offense against him is.

Anon!: Will your grace command me any service to the world’s end?
Goodbye!: Will you command me any service to the end of the world?

Anon!: Your loves, as mine to you.
Goodbye!: Your love, as mine to you.

Anon!: I would have you.
Goodbye!: I want you.

Anon!: Neither can be enjoyed If both remain alive.
Goodbye!: Both of us can enjoy neither of them if they remain alive.

Anon!: Tis no less, I tell you, for the bawdy hand of the dial is now upon the prick of noon.
Goodbye!: It’s no less, I tell you, because the sluggish hand of the dial is now on the prick of noon.

Anon!: The rest will comfort, for thy counsel’s sound.
Goodbye!: The rest of you will comfort you, because your advice is sound.

Anon!: Oh, this is it that makes your servants droop!
Goodbye!: Oh, this is the thing that makes your servants droop!

Anon!: This morning are they fled away and gone, And in their steads do ravens, crows, and kites Fly o'er our heads and downward look on us As we were sickly prey.
Goodbye!: They’ve fled this morning and gone, and in their steads are ravens, crows, and kites flying over our heads and looking downward on us as we were sickly prey.

Anon!: Thou'ld’st have, great Glamis, That which cries, “Thus thou must do,” if thou have it, And that which rather thou dost fear to do, Than wishest should be undone.
Goodbye!: You have, great Glamis, what you’re saying, “Thus you have to do,” if you have it, and what you’re afraid to do, than your wishes should be wiped out.

Anon!: Alas for both, both mine, Edward and Clarence!
Goodbye!: Oh, for both of you, Edward and Clarence!

Anon!: But, mistress, know yourself.
Goodbye!: But, mistress, you know.

Anon!: But look to it: Find out thy brother, wheresoe'er he is.
Goodbye!: But look at it: find out your brother, where he is.

Anon!: Where yond pine does stand I shall discover all.
Goodbye!: Where pine stands, I’ll find everything.

Anon!: Amen, say we.
Goodbye!: Amen, let’s go.

Anon!: Thus I let you go And give you to the gods.
Goodbye!: So I let you go and give you to the gods.

Anon!: I will.
Goodbye!: I will.

Anon!: Be merciful, great duke, to men of mold.
Goodbye!: Be merciful, great duke, to men who are moldy.

Anon!: Clubs, bills, and partisans!
Goodbye!: Clubs, bills, and partisans!

Anon!: Do, good William.
Goodbye!: Do, good William.

Anon!: He did command me to call timely on him.
Goodbye!: He told me to call him promptly.

Anon!: Arise.
Goodbye!: Get up.

Anon!: Come, sister.—Shepherdess, look on him better, And be not proud.
Goodbye!: Come, sister.—Shepherdess, look at him better and be not proud.

Anon!: It is his.
Goodbye!: It’s his job.

Anon!: Not in my husband’s nose.
Goodbye!: Not in my husband’s nose.

Anon!: Shall we their fond pageant see?
Goodbye!: Will we see their sane pageant?
