Anon!: Yet this is your harmless fairy, monster.
Goodbye!: But this is your harmless fairy, monster.

Anon!: I Richard’s body have interrèd anew, And on it have bestowed more contrite tears Than from it issued forcèd drops of blood.
Goodbye!: I Richard’s body has been reborn, and on it has given more tears than it has given forcibly poured blood.

Anon!: At Crosby Place, there shall you find us both.
Goodbye!: At Crosby Place, you’ll find us both.

Anon!: Know, my long lord, The marquess Dorset, as I hear, is fled To Richmond, in the parts where he abides.
Goodbye!: My long lord, the marquess Dorset, as I hear, has fled to Richmond, in the areas where he is.

Anon!: Ay, but the mustard is too hot a little.
Goodbye!: Yes, but the mustard is too hot a little.

Anon!: Messala, I have here receivèd letters That young Octavius and Mark Antony Come down upon us with a mighty power, Bending their expedition toward Philippi.
Goodbye!: Messala, I’ve received letters that young Octavius and Mark Antony come down upon us with a powerful power, bending their expedition toward Philippi.

Anon!: Come, be a man.
Goodbye!: Come on, be a man.

Anon!: Which way hast thou been?
Goodbye!: Which way did you go?

Anon!: The quality of nothing hath not such need to hide itself.
Goodbye!: Nothing hasn’t been hidden.

Anon!: What traitor hears me and says not “Amen?” England hath long been mad and scarred herself.
Goodbye!: What traitor hears me and doesn’t say “Amen?” England has long been mad and scarred herself.

Anon!: Come, come, you’re drunk.
Goodbye!: Come on, you’re drunk.

Anon!: But I can tell why a snail has a house.
Goodbye!: But I can tell you why a snail has a house.

Anon!: God keep me from false friends, but they were none.
Goodbye!: God keep me from false friends, but they weren’t false friends.

Anon!: I would I were senseless, sir, that I might not feel your blows.
Goodbye!: I wish I were so foolish, sir, that I wouldn’t feel your blows.

Anon!: I have fair meanings, sir.
Goodbye!: I have a good meaning, sir.

Anon!: For Brutus' sake, I am beholding to you.
Goodbye!: For Brutus’s sake, I’m holding you.

Anon!: I think you are all mated or stark mad.
Goodbye!: I think you’re all mated or insane.

Anon!: If we do meet again, why, we shall smile.
Goodbye!: If we meet again, then we’ll smile.

Anon!: The taper burneth in your closet, sir.
Goodbye!: The taper is burning in your closet, sir.

Anon!: Since thou dost give me pains, Let me remember thee what thou hast promised, Which is not yet performed me.
Goodbye!: Since you give me pains, let me remember what you’ve promised me, which hasn’t yet been done.

Anon!: Be angry when you will, it shall have scope.
Goodbye!: If you want to be angry, it will be a good thing.

Anon!: My father watches.
Goodbye!: My father is watching.

Anon!: This, and Saint George to boot—What think’st thou, Norfolk?
Goodbye!: This, and Saint George to boot—What do you think, Norfolk?

Anon!: Wilt thou have music?
Goodbye!: Do you want to have music?

Anon!: But say, sir, is it dinnertime?
Goodbye!: But say, sir, is it dinnertime?

Anon!: Five hundred poor I have in yearly pay, Who twice a day their withered hands hold up Toward heaven to pardon blood.
Goodbye!: Five hundred poor people I pay annually, who have their hands slammed twice a day to heaven to pardon blood.

Anon!: Thy slander hath gone through and through her heart, And she lies buried with her ancestors, Oh, in a tomb where never scandal slept Save this of hers, framed by thy villainy.
Goodbye!: Your slander has gone through and through her heart, and she lies buried with her ancestors, Oh, in a tomb where never slept in a scandal except this of hers, framed by your villain

Anon!: Let pride, which she calls plainness, marry her.
Goodbye!: Let pride, which she calls plainness, marry her.

Anon!: Down from the waist they are centaurs, though women all above.
Goodbye!: They’re centaurs, though women are all above.

Anon!: With her, on her, what you will.
Goodbye!: With her, on her, what you want.

Anon!: Out o' tune, sir.
Goodbye!: Out of tune, sir.

Anon!: And of the heat of the ginger.
Goodbye!: And of the heat of ginger.

Anon!: I thank you, sir.
Goodbye!: Thank you, sir.

Anon!: Light!
Goodbye!: Light!

Anon!: We are haunted.
Goodbye!: We’re haunted.

Anon!: Or, if his mind be writ, give me his letter.
Goodbye!: Or, if his mind is written, give me his letter.

Anon!: Do you sing it, and I’ll dance it.
Goodbye!: Do you sing it, and I’ll dance it.

Anon!: Here.
Goodbye!: Here.

Anon!: Thanks to your majesty.
Goodbye!: Thanks to your majesty.

Anon!: The matter?
Goodbye!: What’s the matter?

Anon!: I will be brief, for my short date of breath Is not so long as is a tedious tale.
Goodbye!: I’ll be brief, because my short time of breath is not as long as a tedious tale.

Anon!: You speak all your part at once, cues and all.—Pyramus, enter.
Goodbye!: You’re talking all your parts together, cues and everything.—Pyramus, enter.

Anon!: And a goose for his discretion.
Goodbye!: And a goose for his discretion.

Anon!: This same should be the voice of Friar John.
Goodbye!: That’s the voice of Friar John.

Anon!: If I last in this service, you must case me in leather.
Goodbye!: If I’m in this service, you’ll have to wear me in leather.

Anon!: If he be absent, bring his brother to me.
Goodbye!: If he’s absent, bring his brother to me.

Anon!: You praise yourself By laying defects of judgment to me, but You patched up your excuses.
Goodbye!: You praise yourself by putting my judgment to the test, but you’ve snuck up your excuses.

Anon!: For but a month ago I went from hence, And then ’twas fresh in murmur—as, you know, What great ones do the less will prattle of— That he did seek the love of fair Olivia.
Goodbye!: I just went from here a month ago, and then it was a fresh day of murmur—as you know, what great ones do the less will prattle of—that he did seek the love of fair Olivia

Anon!: Ay, sir, for three months.
Goodbye!: Yes, sir, for three months.

Anon!: Come hither, gentlemen, And lay your hands again upon my sword.
Goodbye!: Come here, gentlemen, and lay your hands on my sword again.

Anon!: My precious Queen, forbear, And give true evidence to his love which stands An honorable trial.
Goodbye!: Please, my precious Queen, and give evidence to his love, which is an honorable trial.

Anon!: We have not made good preparation.
Goodbye!: We haven’t made any preparations.

Anon!: O this learning, what a thing it is!
Goodbye!: Oh, this learning is what it is!

Anon!: Who stays it still withal?
Goodbye!: Who’s still waiting for it?

Anon!: The devil take order now!
Goodbye!: The devil is in order!

Anon!: Thy master is a wise and valiant Roman.
Goodbye!: Your master is a wise and valiant Roman.

Anon!: My cousin’s a fool, and thou art another.
Goodbye!: My cousin’s a fool, and you’re another.

Anon!: My friends told me as much, and I thought no less.
Goodbye!: My friends told me as much, and I didn’t think so.

Anon!: It’s the wind.
Goodbye!: It’s the wind.

Anon!: None, but your beauty.
Goodbye!: No, but your beauty.

Anon!: O, that once more you knew but what you are!
Goodbye!: Oh, you knew once more what you are!

Anon!: But, if you were the devil, you are fair.
Goodbye!: But if you were the devil, you would be fair.

Anon!: I will piece out the comfort with what addition I can.
Goodbye!: I’ll give you the comfort I need with all the additions I can.

Anon!: Say it is done, And I will love thee and prefer thee for it.
Goodbye!: Say it’s done, and I’ll love you and prefer you for it.

Anon!: The rate— Well, Shylock, shall we be beholding to you?
Goodbye!: The rate— Well, Shylock, should we beholding your vows?

Anon!: Nay, the dust Should have ascended to the roof of heaven, Raised by your populous troops.
Goodbye!: No, the dust would have risen to the roof of heaven, raised by your powerful troops.

Anon!: And private in his chamber pens himself, Shuts up his windows, locks fair daylight out, And makes himself an artificial night.
Goodbye!: He’s locked himself in his room, shuts up his windows, locks out the daylight, and makes himself an artificial night.

Anon!: I did enact Julius Caesar.
Goodbye!: I enacted Julius Caesar.

Anon!: I never knew woman love man so.
Goodbye!: I never knew that woman love man so much.

Anon!: Come, death, and welcome!
Goodbye!: Come, death, and welcome!

Anon!: The king mine uncle is to blame for it.
Goodbye!: My uncle is to blame for it.

Anon!: In respect that it is solitary, I like it very well; but in respect that it is private, it is a very vile life.
Goodbye!: I like it very much, but I like it very much, because it’s private, and it’s a very vile life.

Anon!: I embrace it.
Goodbye!: I embrace it.

Anon!: And yet I wish but for the thing I have.
Goodbye!: And yet I only wish for what I have.

Anon!: Tis late.
Goodbye!: It’s late.

Anon!: My lord, you know I love you.
Goodbye!: My lord, you know I love you.

Anon!: She Phoebes me.
Goodbye!: She’s stealing me.

Anon!: The Jew shall have all justice.
Goodbye!: The Jew will have justice.

Anon!: Keep close, I thee command.
Goodbye!: Keep your eyes closed, I command you.

Anon!: I do not know, my lord, what I should think.
Goodbye!: I don’t know what I should think, my lord.

Anon!: Pray, give me that.
Goodbye!: Please give me that.

Anon!: Macbeth!
Goodbye!: Macbeth!

Anon!: Where’s Antony?
Goodbye!: Where’s Antony?

Anon!: I’ll signify so much unto him straight.
Goodbye!: I’ll signify that to him right away.

Anon!: Tush, I will stir about, And all things shall be well, I warrant thee, wife.
Goodbye!: I’ll be scolded, and everything will be good, I assure you, wife.

Anon!: You’ll find it otherwise, I assure you.
Goodbye!: You’ll find it wrong, I assure you.

Anon!: Now, sweet lord, You know the goodness I intend upon you.
Goodbye!: Now, sweet lord, you know what I’m going to do.

Anon!: Speak low if you speak love.
Goodbye!: Speak low if you’re talking about love.

Anon!: Lucillius and Titinius, bid the commanders Prepare to lodge their companies tonight.
Goodbye!: Lucillius and Titinius, ask the commanders to prepare for their meetings tonight.

Anon!: She’s dead as earth.
Goodbye!: She’s dead as much as earth.

Anon!: Ay, sir, it is too true, God help the while.
Goodbye!: Yes, sir, it’s too true, God help you.

Anon!: That’s not the tune.
Goodbye!: That’s not the tune.

Anon!: William, sir.
Goodbye!: William, sir.

Anon!: There would this monster make a man.
Goodbye!: There would be a monster like this to make a man.

Anon!: Why, no, sir.
Goodbye!: No, sir.

Anon!: We shall obey, were she ten times our mother.
Goodbye!: We’d obey if she were ten times our mother.

Anon!: Not a dump, we.
Goodbye!: Not a dump, we’re not.

Anon!: For I had then laid wormwood to my dug, Sitting in the sun under the dovehouse wall.
Goodbye!: I had then laid wormwood to my dug, sitting in the sun under the wall of the dovehouse.

Anon!: Comes his army on?
Goodbye!: Is his army on the way?

Anon!: If you can, your reason?
Goodbye!: If you can, what do you think?

Anon!: Could not a worm, an adder, do so much?
Goodbye!: Can’t a worm, an adder, do that?

Anon!: Where is he gone?
Goodbye!: Where is he going?

Anon!: I cannot wish the fault undone, the issue of it being so proper.
Goodbye!: I can’t wish the fault was wiped out, because it’s so good.

Anon!: What, shall I stab him as he sleeps?
Goodbye!: What, should I stab him as he sleeps?

Anon!: I might ask you for your commission, but I do take thee, Orlando, for my husband.
Goodbye!: I might ask you for your commission, but I take you, Orlando, for my husband.

Anon!: My bond to the Jew is forfeit.
Goodbye!: My bond to the Jew is forfeited.

Anon!: This will I also wear in my cap.
Goodbye!: I’ll wear this in my cap.

Anon!: When I know the gentleman, I’ll tell him what you say.
Goodbye!: When I know the gentleman, I’ll tell him what you’re saying.

Anon!: And I do hope good days and long to see.
Goodbye!: And I hope good days and long to see.

Anon!: Then hear me, gracious sovereign, and you peers That owe yourselves, your lives, and services To this imperial throne.
Goodbye!: Then listen to me, gracious sovereign, and you peers who owe yourselves, your lives, and your services to this imperial throne.

Anon!: You are a councilor.
Goodbye!: You’re a councilor.

Anon!: I pray you tell me.
Goodbye!: Please tell me.

Anon!: Now attest That those whom you called fathers did beget you.
Goodbye!: Now, tell me that those who you called fathers were getting you.

Anon!: I am hurt.
Goodbye!: I’m hurt.

Anon!: But what of Cicero?
Goodbye!: But what about Cicero?

Anon!: All strange and terrible events are welcome, But comforts we despise.
Goodbye!: All strange and terrible events are welcome, but we’re afraid.

Anon!: I think he brings the money.
Goodbye!: I think he’s getting the money.

Anon!: Prithee, Emilia, Go know of Cassio where he supped tonight.—
Goodbye!: Let’s go know Cassio where he supped tonight.—

Anon!: I say my prayers aloud.
Goodbye!: I’m telling you my prayers.

Anon!: I would not for the wealth of all the town Here in my house do him disparagement.
Goodbye!: I wouldn’t punish him for the wealth of the whole town here in my house.

Anon!: The limit of your lives is out.
Goodbye!: You’re out of your control.

Anon!: Have you no modesty, no maiden shame, No touch of bashfulness?
Goodbye!: Are you a modesty, a woman’s shame, a touch of sex?

Anon!: I am the king himself.
Goodbye!: I’m the king himself.

Anon!: Even when you please, since you will have it so.
Goodbye!: Even if you want, since you’ll have it.

Anon!: For the which, as I told you, Antonio shall be bound.
Goodbye!: For the one I told you, Antonio will be bound.

Anon!: Or I have no observance.
Goodbye!: Or I don’t have any respect for it.

Anon!: Haply some poison yet doth hang on them, To make me die with a restorative.
Goodbye!: They’re still hanging some poison, to make me die with a restorative.

Anon!: Come with my lady hither.
Goodbye!: Come with my lady here.

Anon!: Trinculo, run into no further danger.
Goodbye!: Trinculo, don’t run into any further danger.

Anon!: I will say for you.
Goodbye!: I’ll say for you.

Anon!: And I am your Rosalind.
Goodbye!: And I’m your Rosalind.

Anon!: Learn it, learn it, marquess.
Goodbye!: Learn it, learn it, marquess.

Anon!: I wonder that you will still be talking, Signor Benedick.
Goodbye!: I’m wondering that you’ll be talking, Signor Benedick.

Anon!: My lord of Burgundy.
Goodbye!: My lord of Burgundy.

Anon!: It is so too.
Goodbye!: It’s true too.

Anon!: My cake is dough, but I’ll in among the rest, Out of hope of all but my share of the feast.
Goodbye!: I’ll go among the rest of the party, out of hope for all except my part.

Anon!: An thou let part so, Sir Andrew, would thou mightst never draw sword again.
Goodbye!: If you let it go, Sir Andrew, you’d never draw a sword again.

Anon!: It is my arm.
Goodbye!: It’s my arm.

Anon!: So please you— What says the fellow there?
Goodbye!: So please— What does the fellow say?

Anon!: To the gates of Tartar, thou most excellent devil of wit!
Goodbye!: To the gates of Tartar, you excellent devil of wit!

Anon!: What, a prisoner?
Goodbye!: What, a prisoner?

Anon!: I had rather be a dog and bay the moon Than such a Roman.
Goodbye!: I’d rather be a dog and a bay the moon than a Roman.

Anon!: What must be shall be.
Goodbye!: What must be will be.

Anon!: Bear welcome in your eye, Your hand, your tongue.
Goodbye!: Keep your eyes, your hand, your tongue warm.

Anon!: But here’s a parchment with the seal of Caesar.
Goodbye!: But here’s a parchment with Caesar’s seal.

Anon!: Now do you know the reason of this haste.
Goodbye!: Now you know the reason for this rush.

Anon!: I am your wife if you will marry me.
Goodbye!: I’m your wife if you want to marry me.

Anon!: An ’t be any way, it must be with valor, for policy I hate.
Goodbye!: It must be brave, because I hate politics.

Anon!: Here is better than the open air.
Goodbye!: Here is better than in the air.

Anon!: How have you slept, my lord?
Goodbye!: How have you slept, my lord?

Anon!: I’ll do my best To woo your lady— Whoe'er I woo, myself would be his wife.
Goodbye!: I’ll do my best to get your lady— If I’m going to get her, I’d be his wife.

Anon!: That which is now a horse, even with a thought The rack dislimns and makes it indistinct As water is in water.
Goodbye!: The horse is now a horse, even though it’s thought it’s a horse, and it’s not as distinct as water is in water.

Anon!: Say to the king the knowledge of the broil As thou didst leave it.
Goodbye!: Tell the king the truth about the king’s story, as long as you left it.

Anon!: Nor for yours neither.
Goodbye!: And you can’t do it for you.

Anon!: All will be well.
Goodbye!: Everything will be good.

Anon!: Stirred up by Dorset, Buckingham, and Morton, He makes for England, here to claim the crown.
Goodbye!: Stirred up by Dorset, Buckingham, and Morton, he’s heading for England to claim the crown.

Anon!: Are they so followed?
Goodbye!: Are they followed so closely?

Anon!: Come hither, come!
Goodbye!: Come here, come!

Anon!: Adieu, good Queen.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, good Queen.

Anon!: The king hath heard them, to the which as yet There is no answer made.
Goodbye!: The king has heard them, and there’s no answer yet.

Anon!: Go to, thou art made, if thou desirest to be so—” Am I made?
Goodbye!: Go to, are you making it, if you want to be—” Am I making it?

Anon!: My lord, his majesty bade me signify to you that he has laid a great wager on your head.
Goodbye!: My lord, his majesty told me to signify to you that he has put a great wager on your head.

Anon!: I pray thee, hold thy peace.
Goodbye!: Please, keep your peace.

Anon!: They shout for joy.
Goodbye!: They shout for joy.

Anon!: I mean that my heart unto yours is knit So that but one heart we can make of it.
Goodbye!: I mean that my heart is knit so that we can only make one heart from it.

Anon!: In love?
Goodbye!: In love?

Anon!: Here I kneel: If e'er my will did trespass 'gainst his love, Either in discourse of thought or actual deed, Or that mine eyes, mine ears, or any sense, Delighted them, or any other form, Or that I do not yet, and ever did,
Goodbye!: I kneel here: If my will trespassed his love, either in a discourse of thought or actual deed, or that my eyes, my ears, or any sense, delighted them, or any other

Anon!: How shall that faith return again to earth, Unless that husband send it me from heaven By leaving earth?
Goodbye!: How will that faith return to earth unless my husband sends it to me by leaving the earth?

Anon!: When I have plucked thy rose I cannot give it vital growth again, It must needs wither.
Goodbye!: When I’ve plucked your rose, I can’t give it a vital growth back again, and it must have gotten worse.

Anon!: Tis not fit thus to obey him.
Goodbye!: It’s not appropriate to obey him like that.

Anon!: Do so.
Goodbye!: Do so.

Anon!: A conduit, girl?
Goodbye!: A conduit, girl?

Anon!: By this scimitar That slew the Sophy and a Persian prince That won three fields of Sultan Solyman, I would o'erstare the sternest eyes that look, Outbrave the heart most daring on the earth, Pluck the young sucking cubs from the she-bear, Yea, mock the lion when he roars for prey, To win the lady.
Goodbye!: I would slam the sternest eyes that look, outbrave the heart most daring on earth, pluck the young sucking cubs from the she-bear, Yea, mock the lion

Anon!: How now, what’s the matter?
Goodbye!: What’s the matter?

Anon!: The King of Naples, being an enemy To me inveterate, hearkens my brother’s suit, Which was that he, in lieu o' th' premises Of homage and I know not how much tribute, Should presently extirpate me and mine Out of the dukedom, and confer fair Milan With all the honors on my brother.
Goodbye!: The King of Naples, who is an enemy to me, hears my brother’s suit, which was that he, in lieu of homage, and I don’t know how much I’m paying for, should ext

Anon!: But she as far surpasseth Sycorax As great’st does least.
Goodbye!: But she’s as far away from Sycorax as great as she does least.

Anon!: Old Montague is come, And flourishes his blade in spite of me.
Goodbye!: Old Montague is coming, and he’s thriving in spite of me.

Anon!: Welcome hither.
Goodbye!: Welcome here.

Anon!: There, take my coxcomb.
Goodbye!: Take my coxcomb.

Anon!: Make no noise, make no noise.
Goodbye!: Don’t make noise, don’t make noise.

Anon!: We’ll know all our fortunes.
Goodbye!: We’ll know all about our fortunes.

Anon!: She shows a body rather than a life, A statue than a breather.
Goodbye!: She shows a body rather than a life, a statue than a breather.

Anon!: Go thou to Juliet, help to deck up her.
Goodbye!: Go to Juliet and help her get dressed.

Anon!: I’ll assure you, he uttered as prave words at the pridge as you shall see in a summer’s day.
Goodbye!: I’ll tell you, he uttered as prave words at the pridge as you’ll see on a summer’s day.

Anon!: I know not, gentlemen, what you intend, Who else must be let blood, who else is rank.
Goodbye!: I don’t know what you want, gentlemen, who else must be let blood, who else is rank.

Anon!: Who brought it?
Goodbye!: Who brought it?

Anon!: Be lion-mettled, proud, and take no care Who chafes, who frets, or where conspirers are.
Goodbye!: Be lion-mettled, proud, and don’t care who chafes, who’s angry, or where conspirers are.

Anon!: How do you, pretty lady?
Goodbye!: How are you, pretty lady?

Anon!: So thou, that hast no unkind mate to grieve thee, With urging helpless patience would relieve me; But, if thou live to see like right bereft, This fool-begged patience in thee will be left.
Goodbye!: You, who has no unkind mate to grieve you, would relieve me with urging you to be patient, but if you live to see like a right-winger, this fool-begged patience will be left

Anon!: I’ll none now.
Goodbye!: I won’t.

Anon!: I humbly do beseech you of your pardon For too much loving you.
Goodbye!: I beg you to forgive me for loving you too much.

Anon!: Commend me to thy mistress.
Goodbye!: Give my praise to your mistress.

Anon!: Tis all one.
Goodbye!: It’s all one thing.

Anon!: So that, as clear as is the summer’s sun, King Pepin’s title and Hugh Capet’s claim, King Lewis his satisfaction, all appear To hold in right and title of the female.
Goodbye!: That, as clear as the sun is, King Pepin’s title and Hugh Capet’s claim, King Lewis’s satisfaction, all appear to hold the title and title of the female.

Anon!: Tis a world to see, How tame, when men and women are alone, A meacock wretch can make the curstest shrew.— Give me thy hand, Kate.
Goodbye!: It’s a world to see how tame, when men and women are alone, a meacock wretch can make the curstest shrew.— Give me your hand, Kate.

Anon!: So fare you well till we shall meet again.
Goodbye!: So farewell until we meet again.

Anon!: Prince John is this morning secretly stolen away.
Goodbye!: Prince John has been stolen this morning secretly.

Anon!: For me, the gold of France did not seduce, Although I did admit it as a motive The sooner to effect what I intended; But God be thankèd for prevention, Which I in sufferance heartily will rejoice, Beseeching God and you to pardon me.
Goodbye!: For me, the French gold did not seduce me, even though I admitted it as a motive the sooner I wanted to do what I intended.

Anon!: When I told you My state was nothing, I should then have told you That I was worse than nothing, for indeed I have engaged myself to a dear friend, Engaged my friend to his mere enemy To feed my means.
Goodbye!: When I told you my state was nothing, I would have told you that I was worse than nothing, because I’ve actually engaged myself to a dear friend, and engaged my friend to his enemy to feed me.

Anon!: Perchance she cannot meet him.
Goodbye!: She can’t meet him.

Anon!: Our Italy Shines o’er with civil swords.
Goodbye!: Our Italy is shattered with civil swords.

Anon!: Boy, this shall not excuse the injuries That thou hast done me.
Goodbye!: Boy, this will not excuse the injuries you’ve caused me.

Anon!: Bear it coldly but till midnight and let the issue show itself.
Goodbye!: Keep it cold until midnight and let the issue show itself.

Anon!: Oh, a good wish upon you.
Goodbye!: Oh, I wish you a good wish.

Anon!: He meant he did me none; the more my spite.
Goodbye!: He meant he didn’t do anything for me, the more I did.

Anon!: Nay, but I know who loves him.
Goodbye!: No, but I know who loves him.

Anon!: As sure, my liege, as I do see your Grace.
Goodbye!: As sure, my liege, as I see your Grace.

Anon!: And what will you do now?
Goodbye!: And what will you do now?

Anon!: Liar and slave!
Goodbye!: Liar and slave!

Anon!: To bed?
Goodbye!: To bed?

Anon!: See, and then speak yourselves.
Goodbye!: Look, and then speak yourself.

Anon!: Coldhearted toward me?
Goodbye!: Is it coldhearted toward me?

Anon!: Let me see—what think you of falling in love?
Goodbye!: Let me see—what do you think of falling in love?

Anon!: Hazard for lead?
Goodbye!: What’s the danger for lead?

Anon!: I pray you, sir, what is he?
Goodbye!: Please, sir, what is he?

Anon!: Where, my lord?
Goodbye!: Where, my lord?

Anon!: Fool!
Goodbye!: Fool!

Anon!: And my trust, Like a good parent, did beget of him A falsehood in its contrary as great As my trust was, which had indeed no limit, A confidence sans bound.
Goodbye!: And my trust, like a good parent, was a falsely false in its contrary, as great as my trust was, which had no limit, and no bound.

Anon!: I speak not like a dotard nor a fool, As under privilege of age to brag What I have done being young, or what would do Were I not old.
Goodbye!: I’m not talking like a dotard or a fool, as young as I am to brag about what I’ve done when I’m young, or what I’d do if I weren’t old

Anon!: Do you like me, Kate?
Goodbye!: Do you like me, Kate?

Anon!: And were the king on ’t, what would I do?
Goodbye!: And if the king were on it, what would I do?

Anon!: The younger rises when the old doth fall.
Goodbye!: The younger ones rise when the older ones fall.

Anon!: When we shall meet at compt This look of thine will hurl my soul from heaven And fiends will snatch at it.
Goodbye!: When we meet at compt, this look of yours will hurl my soul from heaven and fiends will snatch it.

Anon!: For, by this heaven, now at our sorrows pale, Say what thou canst, I’ll go along with thee.
Goodbye!: By this heaven, now at our sorrows pale, say what you can, I’ll go with you.

Anon!: I’ll tarry no longer with you.
Goodbye!: I’ll go away with you.

Anon!: Well, again.
Goodbye!: Well, again.

Anon!: Sir boy, I’ll whip you from your foining fence, Nay, as I am a gentleman, I will.
Goodbye!: I’ll whip you out of your fence, sir, I will.

Anon!: Will you tell me that?
Goodbye!: Will you tell me that?

Anon!: Thou villain Capulet!
Goodbye!: Capulet, you villain!

Anon!: What, will you walk with me about the town And then go to my inn and dine with me?
Goodbye!: What, will you walk with me around the town and then go to my inn and dine with me?

Anon!: So get you hence in peace.
Goodbye!: So go away in peace.

Anon!: Ay, he spoke Greek.
Goodbye!: Yes, he said Greek.

Anon!: Bid farewell to your sisters.
Goodbye!: Goodbye to your sisters.

Anon!: Came he not home tonight?
Goodbye!: Didn’t he come home tonight?

Anon!: How may we try it further?
Goodbye!: How can we try it further?

Anon!: Farewell, good Charles.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, good Charles.

Anon!: I stay too long.
Goodbye!: I’m staying too long.

Anon!: Never make known what you have seen tonight.
Goodbye!: Don’t tell me what you’ve seen tonight.

Anon!: Murder, murder!
Goodbye!: Murder, murder!

Anon!: Worthy Macbeth, we stay upon your leisure.
Goodbye!: Good Macbeth, we’ll stay at your leisure.

Anon!: I must, she’ll rail in the street else.
Goodbye!: I must, she’ll walk in the street and get out of here.

Anon!: After her, after her.
Goodbye!: After her, after her.

Anon!: What’s that good for?
Goodbye!: What’s that good for?

Anon!: Shall I believe That unsubstantial death is amorous, And that the lean abhorrèd monster keeps Thee here in dark to be his paramour?
Goodbye!: Shall I believe that death is amorous, and that the evil monster keeps you here in dark to be his paramour?

Anon!: So were their daggers, which unwiped we found Upon their pillows.
Goodbye!: They were the daggers, which we found on their pillows unwiped.

Anon!: There’s part of a power already footed.
Goodbye!: There’s already a part of a power.

Anon!: There lies your way, due west.
Goodbye!: You’re on your way, right west.

Anon!: If so, then be not tongue-tied.
Goodbye!: If that’s true, then don’t be a bit tongue-tied.

Anon!: A pestilent gall to me!
Goodbye!: A pestilent gall to me!

Anon!: Thou hotly lust’st to use her in that kind  For which thou whipp’st her.
Goodbye!: You’re lusting to use her in whatever kind of way you whip her up.

Anon!: If fortune be not ours today, it is Because we brave her.
Goodbye!: If we don’t have fortune today, it’s because we brave her.

Anon!: He only in a general honest thought And common good to all, made one of them.
Goodbye!: He only made one of them in a general, honest and common sense.

Anon!: Nay, their endeavor keeps in the wonted pace.
Goodbye!: No, their efforts are in the works.

Anon!: To cut the forfeiture from that bankrupt there.
Goodbye!: To cut the forfeiture from that bankrupt man there.

Anon!: Let wantons light of heart Tickle the senseless rushes with their heels.
Goodbye!: Let the sane rushes get a little sane.

Anon!: Or stole it, rather.
Goodbye!: Or stole it, rather.

Anon!: Will you enforce me to a world of cares?
Goodbye!: Will you force me to a world of cares?

Anon!: No, by no means.
Goodbye!: No, no.

Anon!: My pretty cousins, you mistake me both.
Goodbye!: My pretty cousins, you’re mistaken for me both.

Anon!: Hear me, hear me what I say: he that strikes the first stroke, I’ll run him up to the hilts, as I am a soldier.
Goodbye!: Listen, listen to what I say: whoever strikes the first stroke, I’ll run him up to the hilts, as I’m a soldier.

Anon!: Wilt thou be gone?
Goodbye!: Are you going?

Anon!: I’ll show thee the best springs.
Goodbye!: I’ll show you the best springs.

Anon!: For do but stand upon the foaming shore, The chidden billow seems to pelt the clouds, The wind-shaked surge, with high and monstrous mane, Seems to cast water on the burning bear, And quench the guards of th' ever-fixèd pole.
Goodbye!: The wind-shaked surge, with high and monstrous mane, looks to cast water on the bear and quench the guards of the ever-fixed pole.

Anon!: Adieu, adieu!
Goodbye!: Goodbye, goodbye!

Anon!: We’ll so begin these rites As we do trust they’ll end, in true delights.
Goodbye!: We’ll begin these rituals as soon as we trust them to end, in true delights.

Anon!: Never so rich a gem Was set in worse than gold.
Goodbye!: Never was a gem that was so rich in gold that it was worse than gold.

Anon!: We’ll not run, Monsieur Monster.
Goodbye!: We’re not going to run, Monsieur Monster.

Anon!: The boy gives warning something doth approach.
Goodbye!: The boy warns that something is approaching.

Anon!: What’s the news?
Goodbye!: What’s the news?

Anon!: He holds me well.
Goodbye!: He’s good at keeping me.

Anon!: He does smile his face into more lines than is in the new map with the augmentation of the Indies.
Goodbye!: He smiles on his face more than he is on the map with the rise of the Indies.

Anon!: Do it not with poison.
Goodbye!: Don’t do it with poison.

Anon!: I stand dishonored, that have gone about To link my dear friend to a common stale.
Goodbye!: I’m dishonored, who have gone about to link my dear friend to a common stale.

Anon!: Why, man, I saw Bassanio under sail.
Goodbye!: Well, man, I saw Bassanio under sail.

Anon!: I take it much unkindly That thou, Iago, who hast had my purse As if the strings were thine, shouldst know of this.
Goodbye!: I’m not sure that you, Iago, who has had my purse as if the strings were yours, should know about this.

Anon!: O, he is mad, Laertes.
Goodbye!: Oh, he’s insane, Laertes.

Anon!: And look you get a prayer book in your hand And stand between two churchmen, good my lord, For on that ground I’ll make a holy descant.
Goodbye!: And look at a prayer book in your hand and stand between two churchmen, my lord, because I’ll make a holy descant on that ground.

Anon!: I will not sleep, my lord, till I have delivered your letter.
Goodbye!: I won’t sleep until I’ve delivered your letter, my lord.

Anon!: I thank thee, master.
Goodbye!: Thank you, master.

Anon!: Get you therefore hence, Poor miserable wretches, to your death, The taste whereof God of His mercy give You patience to endure, and true repentance Of all your dear offences.—Bear them hence.
Goodbye!: So get out of here, poor miserable wretches, to your death, to the point where God gives you patience to endure, and to repentance of all your dear crimes.—Bear them out of here.

Anon!: Never come such division ’tween our souls.
Goodbye!: We’ve never seen such a division in our souls.

Anon!: Have you not set Lysander, as in scorn, To follow me and praise my eyes and face?
Goodbye!: Didn’t you set Lysander to follow me, like a scorn, and praise my eyes and my face?

Anon!: Let be.
Goodbye!: Let’s go.

Anon!: Fulvia?
Goodbye!: Fulvia?

Anon!: He cannot speak, my lord.
Goodbye!: He can’t speak, my lord.

Anon!: There must be conclusions.
Goodbye!: There must be conclusions.

Anon!: What is his name?
Goodbye!: What’s his name?

Anon!: Go, vanish into air, away!
Goodbye!: Go, disappear into the air, away!

Anon!: Well, well, put up your sword.
Goodbye!: Well, well, put your sword on your sword.

Anon!: And in the morn I’ll bring you to your ship and so to Naples, Where I have hope to see the nuptial Of these our dear-belovèd solemnized, And thence retire me to my Milan, where Every third thought shall be my grave.
Goodbye!: And I’ll bring you to your ship and so to Naples, where I hope to see the wedding of these dearly loved ones, and then I’ll go back to Milan, where every third thought will be my grave.

Anon!: What do you mean?
Goodbye!: What do you mean?

Anon!: Let her know ’t.—  And he will fill thy wishes to the brim With principalities.
Goodbye!: Tell her.—And he’ll fill your wishes with a lot of sanity.

Anon!: No, since.
Goodbye!: No, since then.

Anon!: No, none by me.
Goodbye!: No, no.

Anon!: You must not think I am so simple but I know the devil himself will not eat a woman.
Goodbye!: You can’t think I’m so simple, but I know that the devil himself won’t eat a woman.

Anon!: I am constant to my purpose.
Goodbye!: I’m always devoted to my purpose.

Anon!: I am not bound to please thee with my answers.
Goodbye!: I’m not going to please you with my answers.

Anon!: I am too sore enpiercèd with his shaft To soar with his light feathers, and so bound, I cannot bound a pitch above dull woe.
Goodbye!: I’m too sore enpiercé with his shaft to soar with his light feathers, and I can’t get a pitch above dull sorrow.

Anon!: It cannot be.
Goodbye!: It can’t be.

Anon!: Tis bargained ’twixt us twain, being alone, That she shall still be curst in company.
Goodbye!: It’s been a deal that shook us up, alone, so that she’ll still be scolded.

Anon!: Hast thou no letters to me from the friar?
Goodbye!: Don’t you have any letters from the friar to me?

Anon!: Are you wise?
Goodbye!: Are you wise?

Anon!: But if I give my wife a handkerchief— What then?
Goodbye!: But if I give my wife a handkerchief— What then?

Anon!: Your sword upon a woman?
Goodbye!: Your sword is on a woman?

Anon!: Fare you well.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: Fall not a tear, I say.
Goodbye!: Don’t fall a tear, I say.

Anon!: We will have no telling.
Goodbye!: We won’t have any telling.

Anon!: I shall, King Harry.
Goodbye!: I will, King Harry.

Anon!: Heaven would that she these gifts should have And I to live and die her slave.
Goodbye!: Heaven would wish she had these gifts, and I would live and die her slave.

Anon!: Tell her my love, more noble than the world, Prizes not quantity of dirty lands; The parts that fortune hath bestowed upon her, Tell her, I hold as giddily as fortune; But ’tis that miracle and queen of gems That nature pranks her in attracts my soul.
Goodbye!: Tell her my love, more noble than the world, doesn’t give me any dirty lands.

Anon!: Is it concluded that he shall be Protector?
Goodbye!: Is it possible that he will be Protector?

Anon!: An inviting eye, and yet methinks right modest.
Goodbye!: I’m a very welcoming person, but I think it’s right modest.

Anon!: A wreck past hope he was.
Goodbye!: He was a wreck past the hope he was.

Anon!: Use me but as your spaniel—spurn me, strike me, Neglect me, lose me.
Goodbye!: Use me as a spaniel—spurn me, strike me, Neglect me, lose me.

Anon!: Where is this rash and most unfortunate man?
Goodbye!: Where is this rash and unfortunate man?

Anon!: Thou, why, thou wilt quarrel with a man that hath a hair more or a hair less in his beard than thou hast.
Goodbye!: You’re going to fight with a man who has a more or a less beard than you have.

Anon!: Adultery?
Goodbye!: Adultery?

Anon!: That’s as we list to grace him.
Goodbye!: That’s what we’re going to do to make him happy.

Anon!: Yet poor old heart, he holp the heavens to rain.
Goodbye!: But he’s old and poor, and he’s holping the heavens to rain.

Anon!: It did come to his hands, and commands shall be executed.
Goodbye!: He did come to his hands, and commands will be executed.

Anon!: Pray you lead on.
Goodbye!: Please lead me on.

Anon!: I think not so, my lord.
Goodbye!: I don’t think so, my lord.

Anon!: It is the right butter-women’s rank to market.
Goodbye!: It’s the right woman’s rank to sell.

Anon!: If thou takest more Or less than a just pound, be it but so much As makes it light or heavy in the substance Or the division of the twentieth part Of one poor scruple—nay, if the scale do turn But in the estimation of a hair, Thou diest and all thy goods are confiscate.
Goodbye!: If you take more or less than a pound, be it just as light or heavy in the substance or the division of the twentieth part of one poor scruple—if you turn the scale only in the estimation of a hair

Anon!: Serve God.
Goodbye!: Serve God.

Anon!: Regard Titinius, And tell me what thou notest about the field.
Goodbye!: Titinius, tell me what you’re not aware of on the field.

Anon!: I would sing my song without a burden.
Goodbye!: I wish I could sing my song without a burden.

Anon!: My master’s mind.
Goodbye!: My master’s mind.

Anon!: Why?
Goodbye!: Why?

Anon!: Go, rascals, go, and fetch my supper in.
Goodbye!: Go, rascals, go and get my supper.

Anon!: Fortune is an excellent moral.
Goodbye!: Fortune is an excellent moral.

Anon!: What should the wars do with these jigging fools?
Goodbye!: What should the war do with these jigging fools?

Anon!: Why, is not this better now than groaning for love?
Goodbye!: Why, isn’t this better now than groaning for love?

Anon!: I’ll not endure it.
Goodbye!: I won’t endure it.

Anon!: Most miserable hour that e'er time saw In lasting labor of his pilgrimage.
Goodbye!: It was the most miserable hour of his life that he had ever seen in his pilgrimage.

Anon!: He cannot like her long.
Goodbye!: He can’t like her long.

Anon!: I have been told so of many.
Goodbye!: I’ve heard so many of these things.

Anon!: Rosalind lacks then the love Which teacheth thee that thou and I am one.
Goodbye!: So Rosalind has no love for you, and I’m one.

Anon!: If you poison us, do we not die?
Goodbye!: If you poison us, don’t we die?

Anon!: And so will I.
Goodbye!: And so will I.

Anon!: Therefore speak softly.
Goodbye!: So speak softly.

Anon!: It is my promise, And they expect it from me.
Goodbye!: It’s my promise, and they expect it from me.

Anon!: And we will mend thy wages.
Goodbye!: And we’ll change your wages.

Anon!: O, let me speak!
Goodbye!: Oh, let me speak!

Anon!: Pray heaven I be deceived in you.
Goodbye!: Please, I’m sorry I’m wrong about you.

Anon!: Love cools, friendship falls off, brothers divide, in cities
Goodbye!: Love cools, friendships break up, brothers break up in cities

Anon!: To what effect?
Goodbye!: What do you think?

Anon!: Marry, sir, for this something that you gave me for nothing.
Goodbye!: You gave me this gift for nothing.

Anon!: So will it, madam till I lie with you.
Goodbye!: And it will, madam, until I lie with you.

Anon!: No, I will weep no more.
Goodbye!: No, I won’t cry anymore.

Anon!: That which ordinary men are fit for, I am qualified in.
Goodbye!: I’m qualified for what ordinary men are looking for.

Anon!: To what end, my lord?
Goodbye!: What do you want, my lord?

Anon!: An your ladyship will have it as it ought to be, you must allow  Prithee, read i' thy right wits.
Goodbye!: If your ladyship wants it to be as good as it should be, you have to give a pity, read your right thoughts.

Anon!: Why, what make you here?
Goodbye!: What are you doing here?

Anon!: Royal Lear, Whom I have ever honored as my king, Loved as my father, as my master followed, As my great patron thought on in my prayers— The bow is bent and drawn.
Goodbye!: Royal Lear, who I’ve ever honored as my king, loved as my father, followed as my master, as my great patron thought on my prayers— The bow is bent and drawn.

Anon!: O Romeo, Romeo!
Goodbye!: Oh, Romeo, Romeo!

Anon!: Oh, heavy ignorance!
Goodbye!: Oh, I’m a big man!

Anon!: If so, my eyes are oftener washed than hers.
Goodbye!: If that’s true, my eyes are often more washed than hers.

Anon!: This cannot be, By no assay of reason.
Goodbye!: That can’t be, without a reasonable argument.

Anon!: Fetch thy master home.
Goodbye!: Bring your master home.

Anon!: And for the more better assurance, tell them that I, Pyramus, am not Pyramus, but Bottom the weaver.
Goodbye!: And for the better assurance, tell them that I, Pyramus, am not Pyramus, but Bottom the weaver.

Anon!: Then in my tent, Cassius, enlarge your griefs, And I will give you audience.
Goodbye!: Then, in my tent, Cassius, you’ll be engrossed in my grief, and I’ll give you a speech.

Anon!: A devil, a born devil on whose nature Nurture can never stick, on whom my pains, Humanely taken, all, all lost, quite lost.
Goodbye!: A devil, a born devil who can’t stick to nature, and who I’ve taken my pains, humanly taken, all, all lost, quite lost.

Anon!: Thus I’ll visit her.
Goodbye!: So I’ll visit her.

Anon!: My Queen and Eros Have by their brave instruction got upon me A nobleness in record.
Goodbye!: My Queen and Eros have given me a nobleness in their brave instruction.

Anon!: Why, man, he doth bestride the narrow world Like a Colossus, and we petty men Walk under his huge legs and peep about To find ourselves dishonorable graves.
Goodbye!: He’s a man who’s a bit like a Colossus, and we petty men walk under his huge legs and peep around to find our unhonorable graves.

Anon!: Your statue spouting blood in many pipes, In which so many smiling Romans bathed, Signifies that from you great Rome shall suck Reviving blood, and that great men shall press For tinctures, stains, relics, and cognizance.
Goodbye!: Your statue spouting blood in many pipes, in which so many smiling Romans bathed, shows that from you great Rome will suck blood from you, and that great men will press for tinctures,

Anon!: Well, my dread lord—so must I call you now.
Goodbye!: Well, my dreadful lord—I have to call you now.

Anon!: Let’s take leave of him.
Goodbye!: Let’s leave him alone.

Anon!: To fright you thus methinks I am too savage; To do worse to you were fell cruelty, Which is too nigh your person.
Goodbye!: You’re afraid to think I’m too savage, and you’re worse off if you were beaten with cruelty, which is too bad for you.

Anon!: No, sir, God forbid, but ashamed to kiss.
Goodbye!: No, sir, God forbid, but be ashamed to kiss.

Anon!: Your friends at Pomfret, they do need the priest; Your Honor hath no shriving work in hand.
Goodbye!: Your friends at Pomfret, they need the priest.

Anon!: Milan and Naples have More widows in them of this business' making Than we bring men to comfort them.
Goodbye!: Milan and Naples have more widows in them than we bring men to comfort them.

Anon!: Upon this hint I spake.
Goodbye!: I said that on this hint.

Anon!: I say my daughter is my flesh and blood.
Goodbye!: I say my daughter is my flesh and blood.

Anon!: What two crowns shall they be?
Goodbye!: What two crowns should they be?

Anon!: Now set the teeth and stretch the nostril wide, Hold hard the breath and bend up every spirit To his full height.
Goodbye!: Now set the teeth and stretch the nostril wide, hold the breath hard and bend every spirit to his height.

Anon!: Will you tell me that?
Goodbye!: Will you tell me that?

Anon!: Give me that mattock and the wrenching iron.
Goodbye!: Give me that sleeve and the wrenching iron.

Anon!: No boasting like a fool.
Goodbye!: No, you’re not a fool.

Anon!: Go to, say you nothing.
Goodbye!: Don’t say anything.

Anon!: For Lord Hamlet, Believe so much in him that he is young, And with a larger tether may he walk Than may be given you.
Goodbye!: For Lord Hamlet, believe in him so much that he’s young, and he can walk with a larger tether than you can give him.

Anon!: Buy food, and get thyself in flesh.— Come, cordial and not poison, go with me To Juliet’s grave, for there must I use thee.
Goodbye!: Get food and get yourself in flesh.—Come with me, cordial and not poison, to Juliet’s grave, because I have to use you there.

Anon!: Was never widow had so dear a loss.
Goodbye!: Never had a widow so much to lose.

Anon!: I urge this childhood proof Because what follows is pure innocence.
Goodbye!: I urge this child to prove that it is pure innocence.

Anon!: Help, ho!
Goodbye!: Help!

Anon!: Thou know’st where I will tarry.
Goodbye!: You know where I’ll tarry.

Anon!: Spake you with him?
Goodbye!: Have you spoken to him?

Anon!: This murderous shaft that’s shot Hath not yet lighted, and our safest way Is to avoid the aim.
Goodbye!: This murderous shaft that’s been shot hasn’t been lighted yet, and our safest way is to avoid the aim.

Anon!: I had rather hear my dog bark at a crow than a man swear he loves me.
Goodbye!: I’d rather hear my dog bark at a crow than a man swearing he loves me.

Anon!: No.
Goodbye!: No.

Anon!: Uncle, this is a Montague, our foe, A villain that is hither come in spite To scorn at our solemnity this night.
Goodbye!: Uncle, this is a Montague, our enemy, a villain who has come here to scorn our solemnity this night.

Anon!: Ay, every inch a king.
Goodbye!: Yes, every inch king.

Anon!: To see no pastime I.
Goodbye!: I don’t see any moment.

Anon!: I will not fail you.
Goodbye!: I’ll never fail you.

Anon!: Sister, have comfort.
Goodbye!: Sister, be quiet.

Anon!: Let’s do so.
Goodbye!: Let’s do that.

Anon!: How shall I know thee again?
Goodbye!: How can I see you again?

Anon!: Caesar should be a beast without a heart If he should stay at home today for fear.
Goodbye!: Caesar should be a beast without a heart if he stays at home today for fear.

Anon!: But, gentle heavens, Cut short all intermission.
Goodbye!: But, gentle heavens, stop all intermissions.

Anon!: O my follies!
Goodbye!: Oh my follies!

Anon!: These deeds must not be thought After these ways.
Goodbye!: I’m not going to think about these things.

Anon!: A piece of ice.
Goodbye!: A piece of ice.

Anon!: Well, I will do it, though I take thee in the king’s company.
Goodbye!: Well, I’ll do it, even if I take you in the king’s company.

Anon!: I must perforce.
Goodbye!: I have to be adamant.

Anon!: Oh, If you but knew how you the purpose cherish Whiles thus you mock it!
Goodbye!: Oh, if you only knew how to do it, you’d be a fool!

Anon!: Nay, come again, Good Kate.
Goodbye!: No, come back, good Kate.

Anon!: Away, make haste.
Goodbye!: Go ahead, hurry up.

Anon!: I like him not, nor stands it safe with us To let his madness range.
Goodbye!: I don’t like him, and I’m not safe with him to let his madness go.

Anon!: Well, that is the dowry of his wife; ’tis none of his own getting.
Goodbye!: Well, that’s the dowry of his wife, and it’s not his own.

Anon!: I must embrace thee.
Goodbye!: I must embrace you.

Anon!: What early tongue so sweet saluteth me?
Goodbye!: What early tongue is that sweet salute for me?

Anon!: The law that threatened death becomes thy friend And turns it to exile—there art thou happy.
Goodbye!: The law that threatened death becomes your friend and turns it into exile—there are you happy.

Anon!: Then pleaded I for you.
Goodbye!: Then I pleaded for you.

Anon!: Five summers have I spent in farthest Greece, Roaming clean through the bounds of Asia, And, coasting homeward, came to Ephesus, Hopeless to find, yet loath to leave unsought Or that or any place that harbors men.
Goodbye!: I’ve spent five summers in farthest Greece, cruising through the borders of Asia, and cruising homeward, came to Ephesus, hoping to find something unhelpful, yet loath to leave the

Anon!: I dare damnation.
Goodbye!: I dare damnation.

Anon!: Go to, then.
Goodbye!: Go on, then.

Anon!: But, till the king come forth, and not till then, Unto Southampton do we shift our scene.
Goodbye!: But until the king comes out, and not until then, we’ll move to Southampton.

Anon!: The jewels you have had from me to deliver Desdemona would half have corrupted a votaress.
Goodbye!: The jewels you had from me to deliver Desdemona would have corrupted a votaress half of the time.

Anon!: Hadst thou done so, The kings that have revolted, and the soldier That has this morning left thee, would have still Followed thy heels.
Goodbye!: If you did that, the kings who revolted and the soldier who left you today would have followed your heels.

Anon!: There is a lord will hear you play tonight; But I am doubtful of your modesties, Lest over-eyeing of his odd behavior— For yet his Honor never heard a play— You break into some merry passion And so offend him.
Goodbye!: There’s a lord who will listen to you tonight; but I’m doubtful of your modesty, so you’re breaking into some merry passion and so offend him.

Anon!: Oh, behold, The riches of the ship is come on shore!
Goodbye!: Oh, see, the riches of the ship are coming on shore!

Anon!: Thy false uncle— Dost thou attend me?
Goodbye!: Your false uncle— Are you attracted to me?

Anon!: Why, how now, Kate!
Goodbye!: What’s going on, Kate?

Anon!: What wouldst thou?
Goodbye!: What do you want?

Anon!: Tell your piteous heart There’s no harm done.
Goodbye!: Tell your pathetic heart that there’s no harm done.

Anon!: Let them come before Master Constable.
Goodbye!: Let them come before Master Constable.

Anon!: You slave, you cur!
Goodbye!: You slave, you curled!

Anon!: An if the wind blow any way from shore, I will not harbor in this town tonight.
Goodbye!: If the wind blows any way from shore, I won’t harbor tonight in this town.

Anon!: Marry, do I, sir, and I came to acquaint you with a matter.
Goodbye!: I do, sir, and I came to tell you something.

Anon!: Hark, come hither, Tyrrel.
Goodbye!: Listen, come here, Tyrrel.

Anon!: Where’s your father?
Goodbye!: Where’s your father?

Anon!: Did you see him?
Goodbye!: Did you see him?

Anon!: I had rather be married to a death’s-head with a bone in his mouth than to either of these.
Goodbye!: I’d rather be married to a death’s head with a bone in his mouth than to either of these.

Anon!: Hark.
Goodbye!: Listen.

Anon!: Stand there!
Goodbye!: Stand there!

Anon!: But as yet, I swear, I cannot truly say how I came here.
Goodbye!: But I swear I can’t tell you how I came here.

Anon!: Be not afraid of greatness.” 'Twas well writ.
Goodbye!: Don’t be afraid of greatness.” It was a good idea.

Anon!: Nothing that is so is so.
Goodbye!: Nothing is that.

Anon!: Roderigo!
Goodbye!: Roderigo!

Anon!: The pig, or the great, or the mighty, or the huge, or the magnanimous are all one reckonings, save the phrase is a little variations.
Goodbye!: The pig, or the great, or the mighty, or the huge, or the magnanimous are all one thing, except the phrase is a little different.

Anon!: My bones would rest, That have but labored to attain this hour.
Goodbye!: My bones would rest, who only worked to get to this hour.

Anon!: Whereat grieved— That so his sickness, age, and impotence Was falsely borne in hand—sends out arrests On Fortinbras, which he, in brief, obeys, Receives rebuke from Norway, and in fine Makes vow before his uncle never more To give th' assay of arms against your majesty.
Goodbye!: Whereas grieved—that his sickness, age, and impotence were falsely borne in hand—he’s sending out arrests on Fortinbras, which he obeys in brief, receives

Anon!: And in part him, but,” you may say, “not well.
Goodbye!: And in part he, but,” you may say, “not well.

Anon!: I will talk further with you.
Goodbye!: I’ll talk to you more.

Anon!: Is there not charms By which the property of youth and maidhood May be abused?
Goodbye!: Isn’t there any charm that can be used to steal the property of youth and motherhood?

Anon!: Would you were not sick!
Goodbye!: You wish you were not sick!

Anon!: Yet touch this sparingly, as ’twere far off, Because, my lord, you know my mother lives.
Goodbye!: But touch this sparingly, as if it were far away, because you know my mother lives.

Anon!: Stand from the hearse.
Goodbye!: Stand away from the hearse.

Anon!: Have you delivered to her our decree?
Goodbye!: Have you given her our decree?

Anon!: Or if thou hast uphoarded in thy life Extorted treasure in the womb of earth, For which, they say, you spirits oft walk in death, Speak of it.
Goodbye!: Or if you’ve ruined your life by destroying your treasure in the earth’s womb, for which you’re often killed, tell me about it.

Anon!: He dies that strikes again.
Goodbye!: He dies, and he’s again fighting.

Anon!: Boy, this shall not excuse the injuries That thou hast done me.
Goodbye!: Boy, this will not excuse the injuries you’ve caused me.

Anon!: Or is he on his horse?
Goodbye!: Or is he on his horse?

Anon!: Observe her, stand close.
Goodbye!: Watch her, stand close.

Anon!: O, wilt thou darkling leave me?
Goodbye!: Oh, will you leave me with a dark spell?

Anon!: Oh, I followed that I blush to look upon!
Goodbye!: Oh, I followed the one I’m blushing to look at!

Anon!: Go after her.
Goodbye!: Go after her.

Anon!: Let him greet England with our sharp defiance.
Goodbye!: Let him greet England with our sharp defiance.

Anon!: Now do you know the reason of this haste.
Goodbye!: Now you know the reason for this rush.

Anon!: Then keep thy vow, sirrah, when thou meet’st the fellow.
Goodbye!: Then keep your vow, sir, when you meet the fellow.

Anon!: I’ll look to like if looking liking move.
Goodbye!: I’ll look at it if I’m looking for something to like.

Anon!: Hie you to the cell.
Goodbye!: Go to the cell.

Anon!: I prithee, call him back.
Goodbye!: Please, call him back.

Anon!: You are not wood, you are not stones, but men.
Goodbye!: You’re not wood, you’re not stones, but men.

Anon!: This tune goes manly.
Goodbye!: This song is manly.

Anon!: Now will he sit under a medlar tree And wish his mistress were that kind of fruit As maids call medlars when they laugh alone.— O Romeo, that she were!
Goodbye!: Now he’ll sit under a medlar tree and wish his mistress were the kind of fruit that maids call medlars when they laugh alone.—Oh Romeo, that she were!

Anon!: Lovers, to bed.
Goodbye!: Lovers, go to bed.

Anon!: How do you, women?
Goodbye!: How are you, women?

Anon!: Where should they be set else?
Goodbye!: Where should they be set and other things?

Anon!: You speak this to fetch me in, my lord.
Goodbye!: You’re talking about this to get me in, my lord.

Anon!: O my brave Emperor, this is fought indeed!
Goodbye!: Oh, my brave Emperor, this is really a battle!

Anon!: Speak!
Goodbye!: Speak!

Anon!: Pray you, is he married to Cleopatra?
Goodbye!: Is he married to Cleopatra?

Anon!: Why, is not this better now than groaning for love?
Goodbye!: Why, isn’t this better now than groaning for love?

Anon!: Were not you even now with the Countess Olivia?
Goodbye!: Didn’t you even get with the Countess Olivia?

Anon!: Juliet!—Fast, I warrant her, she.— Why, lamb!
Goodbye!: Juliet!—Fast, I assure her, she.—Why, lamb!

Anon!: Peace, fool.
Goodbye!: Be quiet, fool.

Anon!: I’ll make the motion.
Goodbye!: I’ll make the motion.

Anon!: I do remember well where I should be, And there I am.
Goodbye!: I remember where I should be, and I am here.

Anon!: That most ingrateful boy there by your side From the rude sea’s enraged and foamy mouth Did I redeem.
Goodbye!: I was the most ill-looking boy there by your side from the rude sea’s enraged and foamy mouth.

Anon!: Arm, arm, my lord.
Goodbye!: Arm, arm, my lord.

Anon!: You are welcome.
Goodbye!: You are welcome.

Anon!: But thou'rt too much my friend, And I’ll not wish thee to her.
Goodbye!: But you’re too much, my friend, and I won’t wish you to her.

Anon!: The next Caesarion smite, Till by degrees the memory of my womb, Together with my brave Egyptians all, By the discandying of this pelleted storm Lie graveless till the flies and gnats of Nile Have buried them for prey!
Goodbye!: The next Caesarion smite, until the womb’s memory is passed, and my brave Egyptians all, by the destruction of this storm, Lie dead until the flies and gnats of

Anon!: I’ll find out your man, And he shall signify from time to time Every good hap to you that chances here.
Goodbye!: I’ll find your man, and he’ll tell you from time to time that you’re lucky.

Anon!: God quit you in His mercy.
Goodbye!: God forgive you in His mercy.

Anon!: No, faith, not a jot.
Goodbye!: No, I’m not a joke.

Anon!: Stand to ’t.
Goodbye!: Stand up.

Anon!: What offense, sweet Beatrice?
Goodbye!: What offense, sweet Beatrice?

Anon!: Edmund I think is gone In pity of his misery to dispatch His nighted life; moreover to descry The strength o' th' enemy.
Goodbye!: Edmund is gone, I think, in pity of his misfortune to dispatch his night life, and to descry the strength of the enemy.

Anon!: I have it, And soundly too.
Goodbye!: I have it, and it’s sound too.

Anon!: There’s the respect That makes calamity of so long life.
Goodbye!: There’s the respect that makes life so long.

Anon!: O insupportable and touching loss!
Goodbye!: Oh, what a terrible and touching loss!

Anon!: Lay breath so bitter on your bitter foe.
Goodbye!: Give your bitter foe so bitterly.

Anon!: Thou wast never with me for anything when thou wast not there for the goose.
Goodbye!: You were never with me for anything when you weren’t there for the goose.

Anon!: I choose her for myself.
Goodbye!: I choose her for myself.

Anon!: Sebastian was my father; Such a Sebastian was my brother too, So went he suited to his watery tomb.
Goodbye!: Sebastian was my father, and such a Sebastian was my brother too, so he went to his watery tomb.

Anon!: No “master,” sir, but a poor man’s son.
Goodbye!: No “master,” sir, but a poor man’s son.

Anon!: Tell me for more certainty, Albeit I’ll swear that I do know your tongue.
Goodbye!: Tell me for more certainty, I swear I know your tongue.

Anon!: Come, shall we hear this music?
Goodbye!: Come on, should we hear this music?

Anon!: My husband is on earth, my faith in heaven.
Goodbye!: My husband is on earth, and I’m in heaven.

Anon!: This, this All Souls' Day to my fearful soul Is the determined respite of my wrongs.
Goodbye!: This, this All Souls' Day is the perfect excuse for my wrongdoing.

Anon!: Stand!
Goodbye!: Stand!

Anon!: We have kissed away Kingdoms and provinces.
Goodbye!: We’ve kissed away Kingdoms and provinces.

Anon!: After my death, the one half of my lands, And, in possession, twenty thousand crowns.
Goodbye!: After my death, the one half of my land was destroyed, and twenty thousand crowns were destroyed.

Anon!: Send for the man and ask him.
Goodbye!: Send for the man and ask him.

Anon!: I am a tainted wether of the flock, Meetest for death.
Goodbye!: I’m a tainted wether of the flock, the most ill for death.

Anon!: Whither should I fly?
Goodbye!: Where should I go?

Anon!: Beware the thane of Fife.
Goodbye!: Beware of Fife’s thane.

Anon!: Behind the arras I’ll convey myself To hear the process.
Goodbye!: I’ll tell myself to listen to the process behind the scenes.

Anon!: Fear it, Ophelia.
Goodbye!: Fear it, Ophelia.

Anon!: They are weary?
Goodbye!: They’re tired?

Anon!: Here is the number of the slaughtered French.
Goodbye!: Here’s the number of the slaughtered French.

Anon!: Thou art a traitor— Off with his head.
Goodbye!: You’re a traitor— Off with his head.

Anon!: Sweet soul, let’s in, and there expect their coming.
Goodbye!: Let’s go in, and there’s a chance to see them.

Anon!: Why do you stay so long, my lords of France?
Goodbye!: Why are you staying so long, my lords of France?

Anon!: Why, I can buy me twenty at any market.
Goodbye!: Why, I can buy twenty at any market.

Anon!: For him, I think not on him.
Goodbye!: I don’t think about him.

Anon!: Fear you not my part of the dialogue.
Goodbye!: Don’t worry about my part in the dialogue.

Anon!: I’ll be with thee straight.
Goodbye!: I’ll be with you straight away.

Anon!: Therefore use thy discretion.
Goodbye!: So use your discretion.

Anon!: Repent that e’er thy tongue Hath so betrayed thine act.
Goodbye!: Repent that you’ve been so trampled by your tongue.

Anon!: Well said.
Goodbye!: That’s right.

Anon!: What, is Antonio here?
Goodbye!: Is Antonio here?

Anon!: Lord of his fortunes he salutes thee, and Requires to live in Egypt; which not granted, He lessens his requests, and to thee sues To let him breathe between the heavens and earth A private man in Athens.
Goodbye!: Lord of his fortunes, he salutes you, and he’s required to live in Egypt, which he hasn’t granted, and he’s begging you to let him breathe between the heavens

Anon!: What shall you ask of me that I’ll deny, That honor, saved, may upon asking give?
Goodbye!: What should you ask about me that I’ll deny, that honor, saved, you may give after you asked me to give?

Anon!: Let us not break with him, For he will never follow anything That other men begin.
Goodbye!: Don’t break with him, because he’ll never follow anything that other men start.

Anon!: He’s in his fit now and does not talk after the wisest.
Goodbye!: He’s in his right mood now and doesn’t talk like the wisest.

Anon!: Is ’t not well done?
Goodbye!: Isn’t it well done?

Anon!: When the wind is southerly, I know a hawk from a handsaw.
Goodbye!: When the wind is southerly, I know a hawk from a handsaw.

Anon!: A good man’s fortune may grow out at heels.
Goodbye!: A good man’s fortune may grow out of heels.

Anon!: Give me particulars.
Goodbye!: Give me details.

Anon!: Dark night, that from the eye his function takes, The ear more quick of apprehension makes.
Goodbye!: The dark night, that takes the eye, makes the ear more panicy.

Anon!: You do love my lord.
Goodbye!: You love me, my lord.

Anon!: Aha!
Goodbye!: Aha!

Anon!: I must with haste from hence.
Goodbye!: I have to hurry up.

Anon!: I thank you, sir.
Goodbye!: Thank you, sir.

Anon!: Yea, is the worst well?
Goodbye!: Is the worst well?

Anon!: It did, it did.
Goodbye!: It did, it did.

Anon!: What, I say?
Goodbye!: What, I say?

Anon!: Would you not swear, All you that see her, that she were a maid By these exterior shows?
Goodbye!: You wouldn’t swear, all those who see her, that she was a maid by these exterior shows?

Anon!: Brother, ho!
Goodbye!: Brother, ho!

Anon!: Where?
Goodbye!: Where?

Anon!: Two, two—a shirt and a smock.
Goodbye!: Two, two—a shirt and a smock.

Anon!: O sir, I do, and will repute you ever The patron of my life and liberty.
Goodbye!: Oh sir, I do, and I will repute you as my patron of my life and my liberty.

Anon!: One of my fellows had the speed of him, Who, almost dead for breath, had scarcely more Than would make up his message.
Goodbye!: One of my fellows had the speed of him, who, almost dead for breath, had barely more than to make up his message.

Anon!: Come, throw it o'er my face.
Goodbye!: Come on, throw it out of my face.

Anon!: Now, if you are a maid, answer to this.
Goodbye!: If you’re a woman, answer this question.

Anon!: Thriftless ambition, that will raven up Thine own lives' means!
Goodbye!: The ambition that will be a king of your own lives will be a king!

Anon!: No better.
Goodbye!: No better.

Anon!: One of these three contains her heavenly picture.
Goodbye!: One of these three is a picture of her.

Anon!: O Iago!
Goodbye!: Oh, Iago!

Anon!: Didst thou not kill this king?
Goodbye!: Didn’t you kill this king?

Anon!: Someone take order Buckingham be brought To Salisbury.
Goodbye!: Someone take orders to bring Buckingham to Salisbury.

Anon!: You shall not choose but drink before you go.
Goodbye!: You can’t choose but drink before you go.

Anon!: When I came back— For this was brief— I found them close together At blow and thrust, even as again they were When you yourself did part them.
Goodbye!: When I came back—because this was brief— I found them close together at blow and thrust, even as they were again when you sat down.

Anon!: And, as I am an honest Puck,  If we have unearnèd luck  Now to ’scape the serpent’s tongue,  We will make amends ere long.
Goodbye!: And, as I am an honest Puck, if we have unarned luck now to escape the serpent’s tongue, we’ll make some changes a long time later.

Anon!: Nor heaven nor earth have been at peace tonight.
Goodbye!: Heaven and earth have never been peaceful tonight.

Anon!: Let him thank me, that holp to send him thither, For he was fitter for that place than earth.
Goodbye!: Let him thank me for sending him to the holp, because he was fitter for that place than the earth.

Anon!: You are welcome, sir.
Goodbye!: You are welcome, sir.

Anon!: I thank you most for him.
Goodbye!: Thank you very much for him.

Anon!: Tis she must do ’t, And, lo, the happiness!
Goodbye!: She’s going to do it, and, lo, she’ll do the happiness!

Anon!: My purpose is, indeed, a horse of that color.
Goodbye!: I’m a horse of that color.

Anon!: All the better.
Goodbye!: All the better.

Anon!: A Cornish name.
Goodbye!: A Cornish name.

Anon!: Go by, Saint Jeronimy.
Goodbye!: Go ahead, Saint Jeronimy.

Anon!: If they suffer our departure, death’s the word.
Goodbye!: If they suffer our departure, then death is the word.

Anon!: He did receive his letters and is coming.
Goodbye!: He received his letters and is coming.

Anon!: Tut, a toy!
Goodbye!: Oh, a toy!

Anon!: And must she die for this?
Goodbye!: And must she die for this?

Anon!: I am ashamèd I did yield to them.
Goodbye!: I’m ashamed I gave them the money.

Anon!: I cannot love him.
Goodbye!: I can’t love him.

Anon!: Prescribe not us our duty.
Goodbye!: Don’t tell us what we’re doing.

Anon!: Nor rain, wind, thunder, fire are my daughters.
Goodbye!: I’m not my daughters.

Anon!: You know not Whether it was his wisdom or his fear.
Goodbye!: You don’t know whether it was his wisdom or his fear.

Anon!: To tell you true, I counterfeit him.
Goodbye!: I’m trying to tell you true truth.

Anon!: Lorenzo and Salerio, welcome hither, If that the youth of my new interest here Have power to bid you welcome.
Goodbye!: Lorenzo and Salerio, welcome here, if the young man who is interested in me here has the power to welcome you.

Anon!: Better Macbeth Than such an one to reign.
Goodbye!: I’m better Macbeth than a man like that to reign.

Anon!: Haply in private.
Goodbye!: Haply in private.

Anon!: Stay but a little.
Goodbye!: Stay a little longer.

Anon!: Yea, from the table of my memory I’ll wipe away all trivial fond records, All saws of books, all forms, all pressures past That youth and observation copied there, And thy commandment all alone shall live Within the book and volume of my brain, Unmixed with baser matter.
Goodbye!: Yes, from the table of my memory I’ll wipe away all trivial and fond records, all books, all forms, all the pressures that have been copied there, and your commandment will live alone in the book and volume of

Anon!: I’ll unhair thy head!
Goodbye!: I’ll unhair your head!

Anon!: Therefore be o' good cheer, for truly I think you are damned.
Goodbye!: So be a good cheer, because I think you’re damned.

Anon!: Untimely comes this hurt.
Goodbye!: It’s too late to get this hurt.

Anon!: This not to do, So grace and mercy at your most need help you, Swear.
Goodbye!: You don’t need to do this, so you can be a better person, Swear.

Anon!: If you like upon report The soil, the profit, and this kind of life, I will your very faithful feeder be And buy it with your gold right suddenly.
Goodbye!: If you like to report the soil, the profit, and this kind of life, I’ll be your faithful servant and buy it with your gold right now.

Anon!: I will not disclose 'em.
Goodbye!: I won’t disclose them.

Anon!: Ay, Caesar, but not gone.
Goodbye!: Yes, Caesar, but not gone.

Anon!: Yet have I left a daughter.
Goodbye!: But I’ve left a daughter.

Anon!: Haste me to know ’t, that I, with wings as swift As meditation or the thoughts of love, May sweep to my revenge.
Goodbye!: I’ll tell you, that I can go to my revenge with wings as swift as meditation or love thoughts.

Anon!: Keep thee warm.
Goodbye!: Keep your spirits warm.

Anon!: Yes, Cassius.
Goodbye!: Yes, Cassius.

Anon!: This moral ties me over to time and a hot summer.
Goodbye!: This morality is tied to me in time and a hot summer.

Anon!: To Caesar will I render My legions and my horse.
Goodbye!: I’ll give Caesar my legions and my horse.

Anon!: Throw my heart Against the flint and hardness of my fault, Which, being dried with grief, will break to powder And finish all foul thoughts.
Goodbye!: Throw my heart against the flint and hardness of my fault, which, being dried with grief, will break to powder and finish all foul thoughts.

Anon!: Twas on a summer’s evening in his tent, That day he overcame the Nervii.
Goodbye!: He was in his tent on a summer evening, and that day he overcame the Nervii.

Anon!: Take not her part.
Goodbye!: Don’t take her part.

Anon!: Such as she says my lord did say I was.
Goodbye!: She said that my lord said I was.

Anon!: Whoe'er he be that in this foul proceeding Hath thus beguiled your daughter of herself And you of her, the bloody book of law You shall yourself read in the bitter letter, After your own sense, yea, though our proper son Stood in your action.
Goodbye!: If he is the one who has slain your daughter and you of her, you’ll read the bloody law book in the bitter letter, after your own sense, you know, even though our son Stood was

Anon!: Why, get you gone!
Goodbye!: Go away!

Anon!: Young budding virgin, fair and fresh and sweet, Whither away, or where is thy abode?
Goodbye!: Young budding virgin, fair and fresh and sweet, or where is your home?

Anon!: I know not by what power I am made bold Nor how it may concern my modesty In such a presence here to plead my thoughts, But I beseech your grace that I may know The worst that may befall me in this case, If I refuse to wed Demetrius.
Goodbye!: I don’t know what power I’ve been given, and how it may affect my modesty in such a presence here to plead my thoughts.

Anon!: Why had I one?
Goodbye!: Why did I have one?

Anon!: O lamentable day!
Goodbye!: Oh, sad day!

Anon!: Do not so.
Goodbye!: Don’t do that.

Anon!: Where had he wine?
Goodbye!: Where did he drink?

Anon!: My lord, I hold my life as dear as you do yours, And never in my days, I do protest, Was it so precious to me as ’tis now.
Goodbye!: My lord, I hold my life as dear as you do yours, and I never protested in my days, that I was so precious to me as it is now.

Anon!: What should this mean?
Goodbye!: What should this mean?

Anon!: My strange and self-abuse Is the initiate fear that wants hard use.
Goodbye!: My strange and self-abuse is the trigger for fear that wants to be used hard.

Anon!: Worthy prince, I know ’t.
Goodbye!: I know it, prince.

Anon!: And most chirurgeonly.
Goodbye!: And most chirurgeonly.

Anon!: Sweet marjoram.
Goodbye!: Sweet marjoram.

Anon!: Where the devil should this Romeo be?
Goodbye!: Where the devil should Romeo be?

Anon!: I do, Mark Antony.
Goodbye!: I do, Mark Antony.

Anon!: The gods confound thee!
Goodbye!: The gods have ruined you!

Anon!: Do you hear aught, sir, of a battle toward?
Goodbye!: Do you hear a battle about it, sir?

Anon!: It was not brought me, my lord.
Goodbye!: It wasn’t brought to me, my lord.

Anon!: Let’s hear him, for the things he speaks may concern Caesar.
Goodbye!: Let’s hear him, because the things he says may concern Caesar.

Anon!: Away!
Goodbye!: Go away!

Anon!: Is the king dead, the empire unpossessed?
Goodbye!: Is the king dead, the empire unpossessed?

Anon!: What is Thisbe?
Goodbye!: What is Thisbe?

Anon!: So many miseries have crazed my voice That my woe-wearied tongue is still and mute.
Goodbye!: I’ve been so crazed by so many mishaps that my tongue is still mute and irritated.

Anon!: Poor Tom, thy horn is dry.
Goodbye!: Poor Tom, your horn is dry.

Anon!: Two of my brother’s men bound!
Goodbye!: Two of my brother’s men were bound!

Anon!: What love could press Lysander from my side?
Goodbye!: What love could force Lysander out of my side?

Anon!: How far that little candle throws his beams!
Goodbye!: How far that little candle throws his beams!

Anon!: Come, let us go.
Goodbye!: Let’s go.

Anon!: Machinations, hollowness, treachery, and all ruinous disorders follow us disquietly to our graves.
Goodbye!: We’re going to die in our graves with a squeak machination, hollowness, treachery, and all the ruined things.

Anon!: With any strong or vehement importunity.
Goodbye!: With any strong or vehement importunity.

Anon!: You will take little delight in it, I can tell you, there is such odds in the man.
Goodbye!: You won’t delight in it, I can tell you, because he’s so oddsy.

Anon!: Come, you are too severe a moraler.
Goodbye!: Come on, you’re too serious to be moraler.

Anon!: What’s she?
Goodbye!: What’s she?

Anon!: There will we rehearse, for if we meet in the city we shall be dogged with company, and our devices known.
Goodbye!: We’ll rehearse there, because if we meet in the city we’ll be scolded with company and know our secrets.

Anon!: So out went the candle and we were left darkling.
Goodbye!: So we went out and we were left dark.

Anon!: And why should Caesar be a tyrant then?
Goodbye!: Why should Caesar be a tyrant then?

Anon!: A velvet dish!
Goodbye!: A velvet dish!

Anon!: He was but a fool that brought My answer back.
Goodbye!: He was a fool who brought my answer back.

Anon!: Then shall I swear to Kate, and you to me, And may our oaths well kept and prosp'rous be.
Goodbye!: Then I’ll swear to Kate and you to me, and I’ll be able to keep our oaths well maintained and sane.

Anon!: Have you the chain about you?
Goodbye!: Have you seen the necklace around you?

Anon!: I cannot tell.
Goodbye!: I don’t know.

Anon!: Now I change my mind, And partly credit things that do presage.
Goodbye!: Now I’m changing my mind and partly credit things that aren’t a good idea.

Anon!: Why,
Goodbye!: Why,

Anon!: When I think, I must speak.
Goodbye!: When I think, I have to speak.

Anon!: Let’s carve him as a dish fit for the gods, Not hew him as a carcass fit for hounds.
Goodbye!: Let’s make him a dish that’s right for the gods, not hew him as a carcass that’s right for hounds.

Anon!: I oft delivered from his forfeitures Many that have at times made moan to me.
Goodbye!: I’ve often given him the money I’ve lost for many of them.

Anon!: If that this simple syllogism will serve, so.
Goodbye!: If this simple syllogism will serve you, then.

Anon!: Good my lord, enter.
Goodbye!: Good, my lord, go inside.

Anon!: What day is this?
Goodbye!: What day is this?

Anon!: Where shall we meet i' th' morning?
Goodbye!: Where will we meet in the morning?

Anon!: I bring thee tidings of the Prince’s doom.
Goodbye!: I’ll bring you a story about the Prince’s death.

Anon!: I would fain learn to lie.
Goodbye!: I’d rather learn to lie.

Anon!: I thank your Honor.
Goodbye!: Thank you, Honor.

Anon!: Murellus and Flavius, for pulling scarfs off Caesar’s images, are put to silence.
Goodbye!: Murellus and Flavius, for pulling scarfs off Caesar’s images, are put to silence.

Anon!: What, no more?
Goodbye!: What, no more?

Anon!: Let us take the law of our sides.
Goodbye!: Let’s take the law of our sides.

Anon!: We have lost best half of our affair.
Goodbye!: We’ve lost the best half of our affair.

Anon!: Say it, Othello.
Goodbye!: Say it, Othello.

Anon!: Shame, and eternal shame, nothing but shame!
Goodbye!: Shame, eternal shame, nothing but shame!

Anon!: The son is fled.
Goodbye!: The son has fled.

Anon!: Methinks I have a great desire to a bottle of hay.
Goodbye!: I think I’m a great desire to drink a bottle of hay.

Anon!: Three of the carriages, in faith, are very dear to fancy, very responsive to the hilts, most delicate carriages, and of very liberal conceit.
Goodbye!: Three of the carriages are very expensive, very responsive to the hilts, most delicate carriages, and very liberal.

Anon!: What is the matter, masters?— Honest Iago, that looks dead with grieving, Speak, who began this?
Goodbye!: What’s the matter, masters?—Honest Iago, who looks dead with grief, Speak, who started this?

Anon!: Stay, madam.
Goodbye!: Stay, madam.

Anon!: Yes, Shylock, I will seal unto this bond.
Goodbye!: Yes, Shylock, I’ll give you this bond.

Anon!: But now, Baptista, to your younger daughter.
Goodbye!: But now, Baptista, I’ll go to your younger daughter.

Anon!: And she is exceeding wise.
Goodbye!: And she’s exceedingly wise.

Anon!: What’s he that now is going out of door?
Goodbye!: Who’s going out of the door now?

Anon!: An I were so apt to quarrel as thou art, any man should buy the fee simple of my life for an hour and a quarter.
Goodbye!: If I were so apt to fight like you, anyone would buy the basic wage of my life for an hour and a quarter.

Anon!: Mine ear, I thank it, brought me to thy sound But why unkindly didst thou leave me so?
Goodbye!: I thank you, and I brought my ear to your sound.

Anon!: I find here that Don Pedro hath bestowed much honor on a young Florentine called Claudio.
Goodbye!: I find that Don Pedro has given a young Florentine named Claudio much honor.

Anon!: I prithee, turn aside and weep for her.
Goodbye!: Please, turn aside and weep for her.

Anon!: An it had not fallen flat-long.
Goodbye!: If it hadn’t fallen flat long.

Anon!: Now Mercury endue thee with leasing, for thou speakest well of fools!
Goodbye!: Now Mercury will end up with a lease, because you’re talking well about fools!

Anon!: I am sorry that with better heed and judgment I had not quoted him.
Goodbye!: I’m sorry I didn’t mention him with better judgment.

Anon!: She’s cold.
Goodbye!: She’s cold.

Anon!: I here take my oath before this honorable assembly, she kicked the poor king her father.
Goodbye!: I swear to this honorable assembly that she kicked the poor king her father.

Anon!: Thanks to your Highness.
Goodbye!: Thanks to your Highness.

Anon!: She hath not seen the change of fourteen years.
Goodbye!: She hasn’t seen the change of fourteen years.

Anon!: And when I told thee he was of my counsel Of my whole course of wooing, thou cried’st “Indeed?” And didst contract and purse thy brow together As if thou then hadst shut up in thy brain Some horrible conceit.
Goodbye!: And when I told you he was a good man, you cried “Indeed?” And you sat and pursed your brow together as if you had shut up your brain with some horrible conceit.
