Anon!: To seek my uncle in the Forest of Arden.
Goodbye!: To find my uncle in the Forest of Arden.

Anon!: I have nothing with this answer, Hamlet.
Goodbye!: I don’t have any answer with this, Hamlet.

Anon!: Let th’ Egyptians And the Phoenicians go a-ducking.
Goodbye!: Let the Egyptians and the Phoenicians go a-ducking.

Anon!: Alack, what trouble Was I then to you!
Goodbye!: Oh, what trouble did I have for you?

Anon!: Thou need’st not to be gone.
Goodbye!: You don’t need to go.

Anon!: I know thee well.
Goodbye!: I know you.

Anon!: Be trusty, and I’ll quit thy pains.
Goodbye!: Be confident, and I’ll leave you alone.

Anon!: Now heaven help him!
Goodbye!: Now heaven help him!

Anon!: My wife is coming yonder.
Goodbye!: My wife is coming soon.

Anon!: Speak.
Goodbye!: Speak.

Anon!: By heaven, you do me wrong!
Goodbye!: By heaven, you’re wrong!

Anon!: Again!
Goodbye!: Again!

Anon!: God in heaven bless her!
Goodbye!: God in heaven bless her!

Anon!: Come, I will have thee, but, by this light, I take thee for pity.
Goodbye!: Come on, I’ll have you, but I’ll take you for pity.

Anon!: And you shall be satisfied.
Goodbye!: And you’ll be satisfied.

Anon!: You will have Gremio to keep you fair.
Goodbye!: You’ll have Gremio to keep you fair.

Anon!: Follow him, friends.
Goodbye!: Follow him, friends.

Anon!: The foe vaunts in the field.
Goodbye!: The enemy is on the field.

Anon!: But beshrew my jealousy!
Goodbye!: But beshrew my jealousy!

Anon!: For I ne'er saw true beauty till this night.
Goodbye!: I’ve never seen true beauty until tonight.

Anon!: Therefore speak no more.
Goodbye!: So don’t speak more.

Anon!: False to me?
Goodbye!: False to me?

Anon!: What is a man If his chief good and market of his time Be but to sleep and feed?
Goodbye!: What is a man if his chief good and market of time are only to sleep and feed?

Anon!: Know, my hearts, I hope well of tomorrow, and will lead you Where rather I’ll expect victorious life Than death and honor.
Goodbye!: I hope I’ll live well tomorrow, and I’ll lead you where I’ll expect victorious life rather than death and honor.

Anon!: And where the worser is predominant, Full soon the canker death eats up that plant.
Goodbye!: And where the worser is predominant, death soon kills that plant.

Anon!: Farewell, farewell.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, goodbye.

Anon!: Then must we look from his age to receive not alone the imperfections of long-engrafted condition, but therewithal the unruly waywardness that infirm and choleric years bring with them.
Goodbye!: Then we must look at his age to see not only the imperfections of long-lasting condition, but also the unruly waywardness that infirm and choleric years bring with them.

Anon!: I deny it not.
Goodbye!: I don’t deny it.

Anon!: But come, my lord, let’s away.
Goodbye!: But let’s go, my lord.

Anon!: If trembling I inhabit then, protest me The baby of a girl.
Goodbye!: If I’m trembling then, protest me to the baby of a girl.

Anon!: Do you wish then that the gods had made me poetical?
Goodbye!: Do you wish the gods had made me poetical?

Anon!: Poison, I see, hath been his timeless end.— O churl, drunk all, and left no friendly drop To help me after?
Goodbye!: I see, it’s been his lifelong end.—Oh, if you’re drunk, you’re drunk, and you’ve left no friendly drop to help me after that?

Anon!: Will you shog off?
Goodbye!: Will you shog off?

Anon!: Now, if you love me, stay.
Goodbye!: Now, if you love me, stay.

Anon!: Sirrah, naked fellow— Poor Tom’s a-cold.
Goodbye!: Sirrah, naked fellow— Poor Tom’s a cold.

Anon!: I think we do know the sweet Roman hand.
Goodbye!: I think we know the sweet Roman hand.

Anon!: Where lies he?
Goodbye!: Where is he?

Anon!: The Duke’s in council and your noble self, I am sure, is sent for.
Goodbye!: The Duke’s in council and your noble self, I’m sure, are sent for.

Anon!: You are thought here to be the most senseless and fit man for the constable of the watch; therefore bear you the lantern.
Goodbye!: You’re thought to be the most intelligent and fit man for the constable of the watch; therefore, bear the lantern.

Anon!: I cannot blame her.
Goodbye!: I can’t blame her.

Anon!: I warrant your honor.
Goodbye!: I’m sure you’re right.

Anon!: In pity of the challenger’s youth, I would fain dissuade him, but he will not be entreated.
Goodbye!: I’d rather dissuade him, but he won’t be beaten.

Anon!: More pity that the eagle should be mewed While kites and buzzards prey at liberty.
Goodbye!: It’s a little sad that the eagle is mewed while kites and buzzards are free to kill.

Anon!: Take in your love, and then let me alone.
Goodbye!: Take in your love, and then let me alone.

Anon!: Impatient of my absence, And grief that young Octavius with Mark Antony Have made themselves so strong—for with her death That tidings came—with this she fell distract And, her attendants absent, swallowed fire.
Goodbye!: I’m anxious about my absence, and I’m sad that young Octavius and Mark Antony have made themselves so strong—for with her death that tidbits came—with this she fell away and,

Anon!: Oh, she is Ten times more gentle than her father’s crabbed, And he’s composed of harshness.
Goodbye!: Oh, she’s ten times more gentle than her father’s crabbed, and he’s composed of harshness.

Anon!: Say that I wish he never find more cause To change a master.
Goodbye!: Say that I wish he never had more reason to become a master.

Anon!: An angel is like you, Kate, and you are like an angel.
Goodbye!: An angel is like you, Kate, and you are like an angel.

Anon!: Let it be who it is.
Goodbye!: Let it be who it is.

Anon!: O calm dishonourable, vile submission!
Goodbye!: Oh, calm submission!

Anon!: Mend your speech a little, Lest you may mar your fortunes.
Goodbye!: Mend your speech a little, so you don’t have to worry about your fortune.

Anon!: Hold you, there is a groat to heal your pate.
Goodbye!: Hold on, there’s a groat to heal your wounds.

Anon!: News have I that my Nell is dead i' th' spital Of a malady of France, And there my rendezvous is quite cut off.
Goodbye!: I’ve heard that my Nell is dead in the hospital of a French malady, and that my rendezvous is completely cut off.

Anon!: Poor soul, thy face is much abused with tears.
Goodbye!: Poor soul, your face is abused with tears.

Anon!: So I charmed their ears That, calflike, they my lowing followed through Toothed briers, sharp furzes, pricking gorse, and thorns, Which entered their frail shins.
Goodbye!: I charmed their ears so that, like calf, they walked through toothed briers, sharp furzes, pricking gorse, and thorns, which entered their fra

Anon!: What, art thou ashamed of me?
Goodbye!: What, are you ashamed of me?

Anon!: We’ll see 'em starve first.
Goodbye!: We’ll see if they die first.

Anon!: Will you speak well of him that killed your cousin?
Goodbye!: Will you speak well about the man who killed your cousin?

Anon!: So fare you well at once, for Brutus' tongue Hath almost ended his life’s history.
Goodbye!: So farewell, because Brutus’s tongue has almost ended his life.

Anon!: Why, what wouldst thou do there before I go?
Goodbye!: Why, what are you going to do there before I go?

Anon!: That can I.
Goodbye!: I can do that.

Anon!: I should have given ’t you today morning, but as a madman’s epistles are no gospels, so it skills not much when they are delivered.
Goodbye!: I would have given you the morning, but as a madman’s epistles are no gospels, it doesn’t really make sense when they’re delivered.

Anon!: No hope that way is Another way so high a hope that even Ambition cannot pierce a wink beyond, But doubt discovery there.
Goodbye!: No hope in that way is another hope so high that even Ambition can’t wink beyond the sky, but there’s no doubt that there’s something to doubt.

Anon!: Music such as charmeth sleep!
Goodbye!: Music like this makes you sleep!

Anon!: Why, what’s the matter?
Goodbye!: What’s the matter?

Anon!: So do not I.
Goodbye!: I don’t.

Anon!: Good madonna, give me leave to prove you a fool.
Goodbye!: Good madonna, let me prove you’re a fool.

Anon!: You know the law.
Goodbye!: You know the law.

Anon!: Where did you leave him?
Goodbye!: Where did you leave him?

Anon!: Whip me such honest knaves.
Goodbye!: Whip me such honest knaves.

Anon!: What men have you lost, Fluellen?
Goodbye!: What men have you lost, Fluellen?

Anon!: Welcome, good Robin.
Goodbye!: Welcome, good Robin.

Anon!: Thus I conceive by him.
Goodbye!: I think so by him.

Anon!: Which of these is he?
Goodbye!: Which one of these is he?

Anon!: For mine own part, I shall be glad to learn of noble men.
Goodbye!: For my own part, I’ll be glad to learn about noble men.

Anon!: She robs thee of thy name, And thou wilt show more bright and seem more virtuous When she is gone.
Goodbye!: She robs you of your name, and you’ll show more bright and virtuous when she’s gone.

Anon!: What’s your name?
Goodbye!: What’s your name?

Anon!: Is it not past two o'clock?
Goodbye!: Isn’t it past two o'clock?

Anon!: The Queen Of audience nor desire shall fail, so she From Egypt drive her all-disgracèd friend Or take his life there.
Goodbye!: The Queen of audience and desire will fail, so she’ll drive her all-disgracing friend out of Egypt or take his life there.

Anon!: By Dromio?
Goodbye!: By Dromio?

Anon!: I would be friends with you and have your love, Forget the shames that you have stained me with, Supply your present wants and take no doit Of usance for my moneys—and you’ll not hear me!
Goodbye!: I wish I could be friends with you and have your love, but don’t forget the shames you’ve stained me with, give me your present wishes and don’t take any sanity for my money—and you

Anon!: May she give that?
Goodbye!: Can she give that?

Anon!: Cheer your heart.
Goodbye!: Cheer your heart.

Anon!: There is a fat friend at your master’s house That kitchened me for you today at dinner.
Goodbye!: There’s a fat friend at your master’s house who cooked me for you today at dinner.

Anon!: Good hay, sweet hay, hath no fellow.
Goodbye!: Good hay, sweet hay, there’s no one else.

Anon!: How came you, Cassio, by that handkerchief That was my wife’s?
Goodbye!: How did you come, Cassio, by that handkerchief that was my wife’s handkerchief?

Anon!: That you must teach me.
Goodbye!: That’s what you have to teach me.

Anon!: Now he tells how she plucked him to my chamber.
Goodbye!: Now he tells me how she plucked him to my room.

Anon!: Nothing but sit and sit, and eat and eat!
Goodbye!: Nothing but sit and sit and eat and eat!

Anon!: When have I injured thee?
Goodbye!: When did I hurt you?

Anon!: Switch and spurs, switch and spurs, or I’ll cry a match.
Goodbye!: Switch and spurs, switch and spurs, or I’ll cry a match.

Anon!: What shall I know of thee?
Goodbye!: What should I know of you?

Anon!: What, may it please you, shall I do at Salisbury?
Goodbye!: What, please, should I do at Salisbury?

Anon!: Thy reason, dear venom, give thy reason.
Goodbye!: Your reason, dear venom, give your reason.

Anon!: Is it not as this mouth should tear this hand For lifting food to ’t?
Goodbye!: Isn’t it as if this mouth should tear this hand for lifting food to it?

Anon!: Oh, the people in the street cry “Romeo,” Some “Juliet,” and some “Paris,” and all run With open outcry toward our monument.
Goodbye!: Oh, the people in the street cry “Romeo,” some “Juliet,” and some “Paris,” and all run out of anger toward our monument.

Anon!: Be not afeard.
Goodbye!: Don’t be afraid.

Anon!: Oh, is that all?
Goodbye!: Oh, is that all?

Anon!: Decius Brutus loves thee not.
Goodbye!: Decius Brutus doesn’t love you.

Anon!: Right well, dear madam.
Goodbye!: Good, dear madam.

Anon!: Fie!
Goodbye!: I’m sorry!

Anon!: Oh, that we now had here But one ten thousand of those men in England That do no work today.
Goodbye!: Oh, we had only one ten thousand of those men in England who don’t work today.

Anon!: A kind good night to all!
Goodbye!: A kind good night to everyone!

Anon!: Nay, I dare not swear it.
Goodbye!: No, I don’t dare swear it.

Anon!: He’s not thy kinsman.
Goodbye!: He’s not your father.

Anon!: My son Came then into my mind, and yet my mind Was then scarce friends with him.
Goodbye!: My son came then into my mind, and yet my mind was scarce friends with him.

Anon!: More villain thou.—Well, push him out of doors And let my officers of such a nature Make an extent upon his house and lands.
Goodbye!: You’re more villain than you.—Well, push him out of the doors and let my officers of such a nature make a large impact on his house and land.

Anon!: Dost thou think so, spirit?
Goodbye!: Do you think so, spirit?

Anon!: Assume a virtue if you have it not.
Goodbye!: If you don’t have it, assume a virtue.

Anon!: Methinks thy voice is altered, and thou speak’st In better phrase and matter than thou didst.
Goodbye!: I think your voice is altered, and you’re speaking better than you did.

Anon!: Indeed?
Goodbye!: Yes, really?

Anon!: That were the most if he should   husband you.
Goodbye!: That would be the most if he married you.

Anon!: Let me see his face.
Goodbye!: Let me see his face.

Anon!: Oh, falsely, falsely murdered!
Goodbye!: Oh, I’m wrongly murdered!

Anon!: Remember thee!
Goodbye!: Remember you!

Anon!: A grave?
Goodbye!: A grave?

Anon!: What thou seest when thou dost wake, Do it for thy true love take.
Goodbye!: What you see when you wake up, do it for your true love.

Anon!: Now will I go to take some privy order To draw the brats of Clarence out of sight, And to give order that no manner of person Have any time recourse unto the princes.
Goodbye!: Now I’ll go take some order to get Clarence’s brats out of sight and to give the order that no one can ever take any time to get the princes.

Anon!: Nothing.
Goodbye!: Nothing.

Anon!: Certainly my conscience will serve me to run from this Jew, my master.
Goodbye!: I’ll bet my conscience will help me run away from this Jew, my master.

Anon!: Is it so long?— Call forth the holy father.
Goodbye!: Is it so long?— Call out the holy father.

Anon!: Good Romeo, hide thyself.
Goodbye!: Good Romeo, hide yourself.

Anon!: Ha, ha.
Goodbye!: Ha, ha.

Anon!: Come hither, herald.—Let the trumpet sound,— And read out this.
Goodbye!: Come here, herald.—Let the trumpet sound,— And read this.

Anon!: First, I must tell thee this: Desdemona is directly in love with him.
Goodbye!: First, I must tell you that Desdemona is in love with him.

Anon!: Their preparation is today by sea.
Goodbye!: They’re ready today by sea.

Anon!: Now, as I am a Christian, answer me In what safe place you have bestowed my money, Or I shall break that merry sconce of yours That stands on tricks when I am undisposed.
Goodbye!: Now, as I am a Christian, tell me what safe place you’ve given me my money, or I’ll break that merry sconce of yours that is a sconce of yours when I

Anon!: Himself.
Goodbye!: Himself.

Anon!: Who comes so fast in silence of the night?
Goodbye!: Who’s coming so fast in the silence of the night?

Anon!: Even for the blood That then I lost for thee, now grant me justice.
Goodbye!: Now, even for the blood I lost for you, I’ll get justice.

Anon!: There’s more depends on this than on the value.
Goodbye!: There’s more to this than to the value.

Anon!: I’ll play the housewife for this once.
Goodbye!: I’ll play the housewife for this once.

Anon!: He had, my lord, and when he ran in here, These people saw the chain about his neck.
Goodbye!: He had, my lord, and when he ran in here, these people saw the chain around his neck.

Anon!: He said once the devil would have him about women.
Goodbye!: He said once the devil would have him talk about women.

Anon!: Am I that name, Iago?
Goodbye!: Am I that name, Iago?

Anon!: Marry, heaven forbid!
Goodbye!: God forbid!

Anon!: You should ask me what time o' day.
Goodbye!: You should ask me what time o'clock.

Anon!: And now I have the boy, I will undo This hateful imperfection of her eyes.
Goodbye!: Now I have the boy, I’ll undo this hateful imperfection of her eyes.

Anon!: We have lost your son, I fear, forever.
Goodbye!: We’ve lost your son forever, I’m afraid.

Anon!: Heavenly powers, restore him!
Goodbye!: Heavenly powers, restore him!

Anon!: Let me be clear of thee.
Goodbye!: Let me be clear of you.

Anon!: If they have done this deed, my noble lord— If?
Goodbye!: If they’ve done this deed, my noble lord— If?

Anon!: I know she is an irksome brawling scold.
Goodbye!: I know she’s a scolding.

Anon!: Hence.
Goodbye!: Go on.

Anon!: Never did I know A creature that did bear the shape of man So keen and greedy to confound a man.
Goodbye!: I never knew a creature that had the shape of a man so keen and greedy to ruin a man.

Anon!: No cock of mine.
Goodbye!: I’m not a cocky man.

Anon!: Give me my armor.
Goodbye!: Give me my armor.

Anon!: You mistake, sir, you mistake, sir.
Goodbye!: You’re wrong, sir, you’re wrong, sir.

Anon!: He is of note.
Goodbye!: He’s very important.

Anon!: Plague on ’t, an I thought he had been valiant and so cunning in fence, I’d have seen him damned ere I’d have challenged him.
Goodbye!: I thought he’d be so brave and sane, I’d have seen him damned if I had challenged him.

Anon!: Wilt thou suffer them To make a rescue?
Goodbye!: Do you want them to help you?

Anon!: Thou teachest me.
Goodbye!: You teach me.

Anon!: The phrase would be more germane to the matter if we could carry cannon by our sides.
Goodbye!: The phrase would be more logical to the matter if we could carry a cannon by our sides.

Anon!: Sweet lord, if your lordship were at leisure, I should impart a thing to you from His Majesty.
Goodbye!: If your lordship were at leisure, I would give you something from His Majesty.

Anon!: What revels are in hand?
Goodbye!: What’s going on?

Anon!: I’ll make you quiet.—What, cheerly, my hearts!
Goodbye!: I’ll make you quiet.—Oh, cheery, my hearts!

Anon!: All may be well; but if God sort it so, 'Tis more than we deserve or I expect.
Goodbye!: All may be good, but if God sorts it out, it’s more than we deserve or I expect.

Anon!: You did.
Goodbye!: You did.

Anon!: Nay, ’tis most certain, Iras.
Goodbye!: No, it’s very certain, Iras.

Anon!: Yes, sir, I have indeed.
Goodbye!: Yes, sir, I have.

Anon!: What do you call the play?
Goodbye!: What do you call the play?

Anon!: But it becomes me well enough, does ’t not?
Goodbye!: But it’s getting me right, doesn’t it?

Anon!: I set him there, sir, but his own disorders Deserved much less advancement.
Goodbye!: I set him there, sir, but his own troubles merited much less advancement.

Anon!: You do assist the storm.
Goodbye!: You’re helping the storm.

Anon!: Play with your fancies and in them behold, Upon the hempen tackle, shipboys climbing.
Goodbye!: Play with your fancies and see, on the cliffs, shipboys climb.

Anon!: The earl of Pembroke keeps his regiment— Good Captain Blunt, bear my goodnight to him, And by the second hour in the morning Desire the earl to see me in my tent.
Goodbye!: The earl of Pembroke keeps his regiment— Good Captain Blunt, give him my goodnight, and by the second hour in the morning, I’ll see him in my tent.

Anon!: I marvel why I answered not again.
Goodbye!: I’m amazed why I didn’t answer again.

Anon!: Tis well for thee That, being unseminared, thy freer thoughts May not fly forth of Egypt.
Goodbye!: It’s good for you to think that you can’t escape Egypt without your freer thoughts.

Anon!: This business is well ended.
Goodbye!: This business has been well ended.

Anon!: And Launcelot, soon at supper shalt thou see Lorenzo, who is thy new master’s guest.
Goodbye!: And Launcelot, you’ll see Lorenzo soon at supper.

Anon!: He lies to th' heart.
Goodbye!: He’s lying to your heart.

Anon!: To go out of my dialect, which you discommend so much.
Goodbye!: To go out of my dialect, which you’re so talking about.

Anon!: Some twenty of them fought in this black strife, And all those twenty could but kill one life.
Goodbye!: Some twenty of them fought in this black conflict, and all those twenty could only kill one person.

Anon!: She did commend my yellow stockings of late, she did praise my leg being cross-gartered, and in this she manifests herself to my love, and with a kind of injunction, drives me to these habits of her liking.
Goodbye!: She praised my yellow stockings of late, she praised my leg being cross-gartered, and in this she manifests herself to my love, and drives me to these habits of her liking.

Anon!: Here comes other reck'nings.
Goodbye!: Here comes other snorings.

Anon!: That thou shalt see the difference of our spirit, I pardon thee thy life before thou ask it.
Goodbye!: I pardon you before you ask for it.

Anon!: Tis very good.
Goodbye!: It’s very good.

Anon!: Ha!
Goodbye!: Ha!

Anon!: What speech, my good lord?
Goodbye!: What’s the speech, my good lord?

Anon!: Nor nothing in your letters writ of her?
Goodbye!: And you don’t have any word for her in your letters?

Anon!: I was adored once too.
Goodbye!: I was adored once too.

Anon!: Do you question me as an honest man should do, for my simple true judgment?
Goodbye!: Do you think I should be a good man, because I’m a simple, honest man?

Anon!: What think you on ’t?
Goodbye!: What do you think about it?

Anon!: No, faith, I’ll not stay a jot longer.
Goodbye!: No, I won’t stay a jot longer.

Anon!: Alas, I sent you money to redeem you By Dromio here, who came in haste for it.
Goodbye!: I sent Dromio to redeem you, who came in grabs for it.

Anon!: The curfew bell hath rung.
Goodbye!: The bell has rung.

Anon!: Antonio shall become bound, well.
Goodbye!: Antonio will be bound, well.

Anon!: Over hill, over dale,  Thorough bush, thorough brier,  Over park, over pale,  Thorough flood, thorough fire.
Goodbye!: Over hill, over dale, Thorough bush, thorough brier, over park, over pale, Thorough flood, thorough fire.

Anon!: Like aqua vitae with a midwife.
Goodbye!: Like a baby with a midwife.

Anon!: I have ’t in my nose too.
Goodbye!: I have it in my nose too.

Anon!: Is this a holiday?
Goodbye!: Is this a holiday?

Anon!: Was ’t you he rescued?
Goodbye!: Was he saved you?

Anon!: But with a rearward following Tybalt’s death, “Romeo is banishèd.” To speak that word, Is father, mother, Tybalt, Romeo, Juliet, All slain, all dead.
Goodbye!: But with a rearward following Tybalt’s death, “Romeo is banned.” To speak that word, Tybalt, Romeo, Juliet, are all dead, all dead.

Anon!: My noble uncle, do you know the cause?
Goodbye!: My uncle, do you know the cause?

Anon!: What is my name?
Goodbye!: What’s my name?

Anon!: You have prevailed.
Goodbye!: You’ve won.

Anon!: The one I’ll stay, the other stayeth me.
Goodbye!: The one I’ll stay, the other keeps me.

Anon!: I know our country disposition well.
Goodbye!: I know the country well.

Anon!: How much unlike art thou Mark Antony!
Goodbye!: How much unlike Mark Antony!

Anon!: Well, go thy way.
Goodbye!: Well, go on your way.

Anon!: Nay, I pray you let me go.
Goodbye!: No, please let me go.

Anon!: So Guildenstern and Rosencrantz go to ’t.
Goodbye!: Guildenstern and Rosencrantz are going to do it.

Anon!: Good majesty, Herod of Jewry dare not look upon you But when you are well pleased.
Goodbye!: Good majesty, Herod of Jewry doesn’t dare look at you, but when you’re happy.

Anon!: There’s ne'er a villain dwelling in all Denmark But he’s an arrant knave.
Goodbye!: There’s no villain in Denmark, but he’s an arrant king.

Anon!: If he love Caesar, all that he can do Is to himself: take thought and die for Caesar.
Goodbye!: If he loves Caesar, all he can do is to himself: think and die for Caesar.

Anon!: Go to, you’re a dry fool.
Goodbye!: Go on, you’re a dry fool.

Anon!: Could I repair what she will wear in me As I can change these poor accoutrements, 'Twere well for Kate and better for myself.
Goodbye!: I could repair what she will wear in me as I can change these poor adversities, and it would be better for Kate and better for myself.

Anon!: I stand here for law.
Goodbye!: I’m standing here for law.

Anon!: Fare you well.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: Some villain hath done me wrong.
Goodbye!: Some villain has done me wrong.

Anon!: Nay, that’s certain.
Goodbye!: No, that’s true.

Anon!: What will you give us?
Goodbye!: What will you give us?

Anon!: For a fish without a fin, there’s a fowl without a feather.—   Go, get thee gone.
Goodbye!: For a fish without a fin, there’s a fowl without a feather.—Go, get out of here.

Anon!: O thou weed, Who art so lovely fair and smell’st so sweet That the sense aches at thee, would thou hadst ne'er been born!
Goodbye!: Oh, you weed, who is so lovely and smells so sweet that the sense aches at you, would never have been born!

Anon!: Therefore thy earliness doth me assure Thou art uproused by some distemperature.
Goodbye!: So I assure you’re a bit sane.

Anon!: Come, Balthasar, we’ll hear that song again.
Goodbye!: Come on, Balthasar, we’ll hear that song again.

Anon!: Good e'en, good e'en.
Goodbye!: Good e'en, good e'en.

Anon!: My father’s love is enough to honor him.
Goodbye!: My father’s love is enough to honor him.

Anon!: How doth my lady?
Goodbye!: How is my lady?

Anon!: Mistress and master, you have oft inquired After the shepherd that complained of love, Who you saw sitting by me on the turf, Praising the proud disdainful shepherdess That was his mistress.
Goodbye!: Mistress and master, you’ve often asked the shepherd who complained of love who you saw sitting by me on the turf, praising the proud disdainful shepherdess who was his mistress.

Anon!: Get thee gone, And hire those horses.
Goodbye!: Get out of here, and hire those horses.

Anon!: He bears too great a mind.
Goodbye!: He’s too good at thinking.

Anon!: God’s bread!
Goodbye!: God’s bread!

Anon!: I will this night, In several hands, in at his windows throw, As if they came from several citizens, Writings all tending to the great opinion That Rome holds of his name, wherein obscurely Caesar’s ambition shall be glancèd at.
Goodbye!: I’ll throw this night, in several hands, at his windows, as if they were from several citizens, writing all the great opinions Rome holds about his name, wherein Caesar’s ambition will be glancéd

Anon!: Do thy worst.
Goodbye!: Do your worst.

Anon!: Chastisement!
Goodbye!: Chastisement!

Anon!: Sir Topas, Sir Topas!
Goodbye!: Sir Topas, Sir Topas!

Anon!: To thee a woman’s services are due.
Goodbye!: You’re due to receive a woman’s services.

Anon!: Let us therefore eat and drink.
Goodbye!: So let’s eat and drink.

Anon!: Be comforted, good madam.
Goodbye!: Be calm, madam.

Anon!: Let him approach.
Goodbye!: Let him come.

Anon!: She’s framed as fruitful As the free elements.
Goodbye!: She’s as fruitful as the free elements.

Anon!: So are you, princes English, every one.
Goodbye!: You are all the same, princes English.

Anon!: But say, I prithee, is he coming home?
Goodbye!: But tell me, please, is he coming home?

Anon!: Farewell.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: How have the hours racked and tortured me Since I have lost thee!
Goodbye!: How have the hours racked and tortured me since I lost you!

Anon!: Attend the lords of France and Burgundy, Gloucester.
Goodbye!: Come with the lords of France and Burgundy, Gloucester.

Anon!: Lend me a looking-glass.
Goodbye!: Give me a look-glass.

Anon!: Methinks he looks as though he were in love.
Goodbye!: I think he looks like he’s in love.

Anon!: The queen desires you to use some gentle entertainment to Laertes before you fall to play.
Goodbye!: The queen wants you to enjoy some fun with Laertes before you fall to play.

Anon!: Here’s that, I warrant you, will pay them all.
Goodbye!: Here’s a payment that will pay them all, I assure you.

Anon!: This looks not like a nuptial.
Goodbye!: This isn’t like a wedding.

Anon!: He is addressed.
Goodbye!: He’s been addressed.

Anon!: Far off methinks I hear the beaten drum.
Goodbye!: I think I hear the beat drum.

Anon!: And so did I.
Goodbye!: And so did I.

Anon!: Fall and cease.
Goodbye!: Let’s go.

Anon!: Thus says my king: “Say thou to Harry of England, though we seemed dead, we did but sleep.
Goodbye!: That’s what my king says: “Say to Harry of England, even though we seemed dead, we only did sleep.

Anon!: I will play the swan.
Goodbye!: I’ll play the swan.

Anon!: Good sirs, take heart.
Goodbye!: Good sirs, take heart.

Anon!: Rise, and lend thine ear.
Goodbye!: Rise and lend your ear.

Anon!: Some kinds of baseness Are nobly undergone.
Goodbye!: Some kinds of sanity are under way.

Anon!: What is he, Biondello?
Goodbye!: What is he, Biondello?

Anon!: A dire induction am I witness to, And will to France, hoping the consequence Will prove as bitter, black, and tragical.
Goodbye!: I’m witnessing a terrible induction, and I’ll go to France hoping the consequences will be bitter, black, and tragic.

Anon!: We are bound to the like.
Goodbye!: We’re bound to the same.

Anon!: This same should be the voice of Friar John.
Goodbye!: That’s the voice of Friar John.

Anon!: Above my fortunes, yet my state is well.
Goodbye!: I’m above my fortunes, but my state is well.

Anon!: Younger than you Here in Verona, ladies of esteem Are made already mothers.
Goodbye!: Younger than you here in Verona, women of esteem are already mothers.

Anon!: His daughters seek his death.
Goodbye!: His daughters are seeking his death.

Anon!: Then have my lips the sin that they have took.
Goodbye!: Then have my lips sinned about the sin they took.

Anon!: Your praise is come too swiftly home before you.
Goodbye!: Your praise has come to you too quickly.

Anon!: And if you wrong us, shall we not revenge?
Goodbye!: And if you wronged us, shouldn’t we be revenge?

Anon!: Therefore they thought it good you hear a play And frame your mind to mirth and merriment, Which bars a thousand harms and lengthens life.
Goodbye!: So they thought it was good to hear a play and to scold you with a merriment and a merriment that could cause a thousand deaths and prolongs life.

Anon!: She now shall be my sister, not my wife.
Goodbye!: She’ll be my sister, not my wife.

Anon!: The gallants desire it.
Goodbye!: The gallants want it.

Anon!: No, not tonight.
Goodbye!: No, not tonight.

Anon!: Your servant shall do so.
Goodbye!: Your servant will do so.

Anon!: And, as he fell, did Romeo turn and fly.
Goodbye!: And as he fell, Romeo turned and flew.

Anon!: Did you ever cure any so?
Goodbye!: Did you ever cure anything like that?

Anon!: None.
Goodbye!: No.

Anon!: I loved you not.
Goodbye!: I didn’t love you.

Anon!: Why then, resolve me whether you will or no.
Goodbye!: So, tell me whether you want to or not.

Anon!: Now, in good sadness, son Petruchio, I think thou hast the veriest shrew of all.
Goodbye!: Now, in good sadness, son Petruchio, I think you have the shrewdest of all.

Anon!: Go and tell them so.
Goodbye!: Go and tell them that.

Anon!: He hath commission from thy wife and me To hang Cordelia in the prison and To lay the blame upon her own despair, That she fordid herself.
Goodbye!: He has ordered your wife and me to hang Cordelia in the prison and to blame her for her own despair, that she fordid herself.

Anon!: Your mother.
Goodbye!: Your mother.

Anon!: That she was false to wedlock?
Goodbye!: That she was wrong to marry?

Anon!: What is this?
Goodbye!: What’s this?

Anon!: Let Rome be thus informed.
Goodbye!: Let Rome be informed of that.

Anon!: And she as much in love, her means much less To meet her new beloved anywhere.
Goodbye!: And she’s as much in love as she is, and she’s less likely to meet her new lover anywhere.

Anon!: Oh my fair warrior!
Goodbye!: Oh, my fair warrior!

Anon!: This, Cinna.
Goodbye!: This is Cinna.

Anon!: I have a health for you.
Goodbye!: I have a health for you.

Anon!: Good Grumio, fetch it me.
Goodbye!: Good Grumio, get it to me.

Anon!: By a name I know not how to tell thee who I am.
Goodbye!: I don’t know who I am.

Anon!: Go waken Juliet.
Goodbye!: Go wake Juliet.

Anon!: Why do we wrap the gentleman in our more rawer breath?
Goodbye!: Why do we wrap the gentleman in our rawer breath?

Anon!: He hath.
Goodbye!: He has.

Anon!: Is it my lady mother?
Goodbye!: Is it my mother?

Anon!: Say she shall be a high and mighty queen.
Goodbye!: Say she will be a high and mighty queen.

Anon!: Peace!
Goodbye!: Quiet!

Anon!: No, great king.
Goodbye!: No, great king.

Anon!: I cannot think my sister in the least Would fail her obligation.
Goodbye!: I can’t think my sister would fail her obligation.

Anon!: I tell thee, I am as well in my wits as any man in Illyria.
Goodbye!: I tell you, I’m as good in my mind as any man in Illyria.

Anon!: She will not.
Goodbye!: She won’t.

Anon!: Alack, our terrene moon is now eclipsed, And it portends alone the fall of Antony.
Goodbye!: Oh, our moon is now eclipsed, and it’s only about the fall of Antony.

Anon!: Ah ha!
Goodbye!: Ah ha!

Anon!: No, but the barber’s man hath been seen with him, and the old ornament of his cheek hath already stuffed tennis balls.
Goodbye!: No, but the barber’s man has been seen with him, and the old ornament of his cheek has already stuffed tennis balls.

Anon!: What warlike noise is this?
Goodbye!: What’s this warlike noise?

Anon!: Tis fit we understand them.
Goodbye!: It’s good to understand them.

Anon!: By 'r lady, I think it be so.
Goodbye!: I think it’s true, lady.

Anon!: My lord, your promise for the earldom— Richmond!
Goodbye!: My lord, your promise for the earldom— Richmond!

Anon!: Some tardy cripple bear the countermand, That came too lag to see him burièd.
Goodbye!: Some tardy cripple will bear the countermand, who came too late to see him burièd.

Anon!: His son is elder, sir.
Goodbye!: His son is older than that, sir.

Anon!: Now, the next day Was our sea fight, and what to this was sequent Thou know’st already.
Goodbye!: The next day was our sea fight, and you know what happened to this.

Anon!: Approach, my Ariel, come.
Goodbye!: Come on, my Ariel.

Anon!: I do desire we may be better strangers.
Goodbye!: I’m hoping we can be better strangers.

Anon!: That with this little arm and this good sword I have made my way through more impediments Than twenty times your stop.
Goodbye!: I’ve made my way through obstacles more difficult than twenty times your stop.

Anon!: Why, how now, Juliet?
Goodbye!: What’s going on, Juliet?

Anon!: Alack, why thus?
Goodbye!: Why?

Anon!: I do never use it.
Goodbye!: I don’t use it.

Anon!: Tis not so sweet now as it was before.
Goodbye!: It’s not as sweet now as it was before.

Anon!: What heir of York is there alive but we?
Goodbye!: What heir of York is there alive but we?

Anon!: Tell me your counsels.
Goodbye!: Tell me your advice.

Anon!: What, bear her in hand until they come to take hands and then, with public accusation, uncovered slander, unmitigated rancor—O God, that I were a man!
Goodbye!: What, keep her in hand until they come to take hands and then, with public accusation, uncovered slander, unmitigated rancor—Oh God, I wish I were a man!

Anon!: Is ’t not the king?
Goodbye!: Isn’t the king?

Anon!: Why should their liberty than ours be more?
Goodbye!: Why should their freedom be more than ours?

Anon!: Yes, they have.
Goodbye!: Yes, they have.

Anon!: Now, good sweet Nurse— O Lord, why look’st thou sad?
Goodbye!: Now, good sweet Nurse— Oh Lord, why are you looking so sad?

Anon!: No, no.
Goodbye!: No, no.

Anon!: This blows my heart.
Goodbye!: This blows my heart.

Anon!: Sweet, so would I.
Goodbye!: Sweet, so would I.

Anon!: It is a common thing— Ha?
Goodbye!: It’s a common thing— Ha?

Anon!: I was enforced to send it after him.
Goodbye!: I was forced to send it to him.

Anon!: I tell thee, churlish priest, A ministering angel shall my sister be When thou liest howling.
Goodbye!: I tell you, churlish priest, a ministering angel will my sister be when you’re a howling.

Anon!: I’ll rhyme you so eight years together, dinners and suppers and sleeping hours excepted.
Goodbye!: I’ll rhyme you so well for eight years, except dinners and suppers and sleeping hours.

Anon!: So I to her and so she yields to me, For I am rough and woo not like a babe.
Goodbye!: I’m wooing her, and she’s giving me, because I’m rough and don’t woo like a baby.

Anon!: Or else she could not have the wit to do this.
Goodbye!: Or else she couldn’t have the wit to do this.

Anon!: I have not seen such a firago.
Goodbye!: I haven’t seen such a firago.

Anon!: And be assured you’ll find a difference, As we his subjects have in wonder found, Between the promise of his greener days And these he masters now.
Goodbye!: And be assured you’ll find a difference, as we’ve found out about his sanity, between the promises of his greener days and the ones he masters now.

Anon!: Ay, and for that thou diest.
Goodbye!: Yes, and you die for that.

Anon!: O slanderous world!
Goodbye!: Oh, a slanderous world!

Anon!: I am no villain.
Goodbye!: I’m not a villain.

Anon!: I pray you, see him presently discharged, For he is bound to sea, and stays but for it.
Goodbye!: Please, see him discharged now, because he’s bound to sea and stays only for it.

Anon!: Thy head is as full of quarrels as an egg is full of meat, and yet thy head hath been beaten as addle as an egg for quarreling.
Goodbye!: Your head is as full of fights as an egg is full of meat, and yet your head has been beaten as much as an egg for fighting.

Anon!: Cold friends to me.
Goodbye!: I’m cold friends to me.

Anon!: Here was he merry, hearing of a song.
Goodbye!: Here he was a good man, hearing a song.

Anon!: Let me dispute with thee of thy estate.
Goodbye!: Let me dispute your fate.

Anon!: This dagger hath mista'en—for, lo, his house Is empty on the back of Montague, And it mis-sheathèd in my daughter’s bosom.
Goodbye!: This dagger has mista’en—for his house is empty on the back of Montague, and it’s misheathed in my daughter’s bosom.

Anon!: How came her eyes so bright?
Goodbye!: How did she see such a bright eye?

Anon!: Yea, marry, dost thou hear, Balthasar?
Goodbye!: Yes, do you hear that, Balthasar?

Anon!: It is so.
Goodbye!: It is.

Anon!: Play the men.
Goodbye!: Play the men.

Anon!: Thou art like one of those fellows that, when he enters the confines of a tavern, claps me his sword upon the table and says “God send me no need of thee!” and, by the operation of the second cup, draws it on the drawer when indeed there is no need.
Goodbye!: You’re like one of those men who, when he enters the confines of a tavern, claps me his sword on the table and says, “God send me no need of you

Anon!: Peace, you mumbling fool!
Goodbye!: Quiet, you mumbling fool!

Anon!: Oh, I am slain!—My lord, you have one eye left To see some mischief on him.
Goodbye!: Oh, I’m dead!—My lord, you have one eye left to see some mischief on him.

Anon!: Saint Valentine is past.
Goodbye!: Saint Valentine is past.

Anon!: You would say so, master, if your garments were thin.
Goodbye!: You would say that, master, if your clothes were thin.

Anon!: Peace!
Goodbye!: Quiet!

Anon!: Repays he my deep service With such deep contempt?
Goodbye!: Is he paying for my deep service with such a deep contempt?

Anon!: Scorn and defiance, slight regard, contempt, And anything that may not misbecome The mighty sender, doth he prize you at.
Goodbye!: Scorn and defiance, slight regard, contempt, and anything that doesn’t make him a mighty sender, are the things he rewards you.

Anon!: Who calls?
Goodbye!: Who’s calling me?

Anon!: Are yet two Romans living such as these?
Goodbye!: Are there two Romans still alive as these?

Anon!: My lord, Mark Antony, Hearing that you prepared for war, acquainted My grievèd ear withal, whereon I begged His pardon for return.
Goodbye!: My lord, Mark Antony, hearing that you were prepared for war, I heard my grieving ear, and I asked his pardon for returning.

Anon!: By my troth, Sir Toby, you must come in earlier o' nights.
Goodbye!: Sir Toby, you have to come in early o'clock.

Anon!: To him will I.
Goodbye!: I will.

Anon!: My good friends, I’ll leave you till night.
Goodbye!: My good friends, I’ll leave you until nighttime.

Anon!: Why, thou silly gentleman!
Goodbye!: Why, you silly gentleman!

Anon!: For what good turn?
Goodbye!: What’s the good turn?

Anon!: Farewell.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: The foul’st best fits My latter part of life.
Goodbye!: The worst thing I’ve ever done is to get my second life.

Anon!: I do defy thy commination And apprehend thee for a felon here.
Goodbye!: I’m a fool and apprehend you for a felon here.

Anon!: I wish you all joy of the worm.
Goodbye!: I wish you all joy in the worm.

Anon!: Ay, more.
Goodbye!: Yes, more.

Anon!: Nobody marks you.
Goodbye!: Nobody’s talking about you.

Anon!: You, Nick Bottom, are set down for Pyramus.
Goodbye!: Nick Bottom, you’re set for Pyramus.

Anon!: I have almost forgot the taste of fears.
Goodbye!: I’ve almost forgotten the taste of fears.

Anon!: O God, Horatio, what a wounded name, Things standing thus unknown, shall live behind me!
Goodbye!: Oh God, Horatio, what a wounded name I’ll have to live behind me, and the unknown things that are still alive.

Anon!: Why, that’s the way To fool their preparation and to conquer Their most absurd intents.
Goodbye!: That’s the way to fool their preparations and conquer their absurd intentions.

Anon!: I’ll have them sleep on cushions in my tent.
Goodbye!: I’ll have them sleep on cushions in my tent.

Anon!: His fault is much, and the good king his master Will check him for ’t.
Goodbye!: His fault is very bad, and the good king’s master will check him out.

Anon!: In what part of her body stands Ireland?
Goodbye!: In what part of her body is Ireland?

Anon!: Not know my voice!
Goodbye!: Don’t know my voice!

Anon!: Bid the players make haste.
Goodbye!: Ask the players to hurry.

Anon!: Gramercy!
Goodbye!: Gramercy!

Anon!: Where is he?
Goodbye!: Where is he?

Anon!: What Conrade!
Goodbye!: What’s Conrade?

Anon!: I will then give it you soundly.
Goodbye!: I’ll give it to you then.

Anon!: Can you not conceive?
Goodbye!: Can’t you imagine?

Anon!: Not mad, but bound more than a madman is, Shut up in prison, kept without my food, Whipped and tormented and—Good e'en, good fellow.
Goodbye!: Not insane, but bound more than a madman is, Shut up in prison, kept without food, whipped and tormented and—Good e'en, good fellow.

Anon!: So I will, my liege, as I live.
Goodbye!: I will, my liege, as I live.

Anon!: Let him alone.
Goodbye!: Leave him alone.

Anon!: I am to blame.
Goodbye!: I’m to blame.

Anon!: Shall we go seek Benedick and tell him of her love?
Goodbye!: Should we go find Benedick and tell him about her love?

Anon!: Ready.
Goodbye!: Ready.

Anon!: The chaplain of the Tower hath buried them, But where, to say the truth, I do not know.
Goodbye!: The chaplain of the Tower has buried them, but I don’t know where, to say the truth, I’m not sure.

Anon!: Primo, secundo, tertio is a good play, and the old saying is, the third pays for all.
Goodbye!: Primo, secundo, tertio is a good play, and the old saying is, the third is paying for everything.

Anon!: I mean, the matter that you read, my lord.
Goodbye!: I mean, what you read, my lord.

Anon!: There could I have him now—and there—and there again—and there.
Goodbye!: I could have him here—and there—and there again—and there.

Anon!: Why dost thou lead these men about the streets?
Goodbye!: Why are you leading these men around the streets?

Anon!: Nay, take my life and all.
Goodbye!: No, take my life and everything.

Anon!: Great and increasing.
Goodbye!: Great and increasing.

Anon!: How dost, my lord?
Goodbye!: How are you, my lord?

Anon!: See how beastly she doth court him!
Goodbye!: See how beastly she is defending him!

Anon!: Take some remembrance of us as a tribute, Not as a fee.
Goodbye!: Take some remembrance of us as a tribute, not as a fee.

Anon!: We must be patient, but I cannot choose but weep, to think they should lay him i' th' cold ground.
Goodbye!: We must be patient, but I can’t choose but cry, to think they should lay him in the cold ground.

Anon!: I’ll do ’t, my lord.
Goodbye!: I’ll do it, my lord.

Anon!: Unfought withal, but I will sell my dukedom To buy a slobb'ry and a dirty farm In that nook-shotten isle of Albion.
Goodbye!: I’ll sell my dukedom to buy a slobb'ry and a dirty farm in that nook-shotten isle of Albion.

Anon!: They flatter me.
Goodbye!: They flatter me.

Anon!: Thou seest these lovers seek a place to fight.
Goodbye!: You’re looking for a place to fight.

Anon!: We have scorched the snake, not killed it.
Goodbye!: We’ve scorched the snake, not killed it.

Anon!: Most gracious Duke, To my unfolding lend your prosperous ear And let me find a charter in your voice, T' assist my simpleness.
Goodbye!: Most gracious Duke, give me a letter to my lord and let me find a letter in your voice, which will help me to be simple.

Anon!: Tush, fear not, man.
Goodbye!: Don’t worry, man.

Anon!: I am pale, Charmian.
Goodbye!: I’m pale, Charmian.

Anon!: On what compulsion must I?
Goodbye!: What do I have to do to do?

Anon!: Though their injunction be to bar my doors And let this tyrannous night take hold upon you, Yet have I ventured to come seek you out And bring you where both fire and food is ready.
Goodbye!: Even though they’re urging me to shut my doors and let this tyrannous night take hold of you, I’ve ventured to come find you and bring you where fire and food are ready.

Anon!: I will stand, and so shall Trinculo.
Goodbye!: I’ll stand, and so will Trinculo.

Anon!: Your dinner, and the generous islanders By you invited, do attend your presence.
Goodbye!: Your dinner and the generous islanders invited to join you are at your service.

Anon!: What many men desire”—that “many” may be meant By the fool multitude that choose by show, Not learning more than the fond eye doth teach; Which pries not to th' interior, but like the martlet Builds in the weather on the outward wall, Even in the force and road of casualty.
Goodbye!: What many men want”—that “many” may be meant by the fools who choose by show, not learning more than the fond eye does teach; which pries not to the interior, but like the martlet builds

Anon!: What we will do, we do upon command.
Goodbye!: We’ll do what we want, and we’ll do what we want.

Anon!: Yes, faith, will I, Fridays and Saturdays and all.
Goodbye!: Yes, I will, Fridays and Saturdays and all.

Anon!: Why thou, loss upon loss!
Goodbye!: Why, loss upon loss!

Anon!: I will see them.
Goodbye!: I’ll see them.

Anon!: Marry, I’ll teach you.
Goodbye!: I’ll teach you.

Anon!: Yet I should kill thee with much cherishing.
Goodbye!: But I’d kill you with a lot of love.

Anon!: His counsel now might do me golden service.
Goodbye!: He’s going to do my best to do my best.

Anon!: The most you sought was her promotion, For ’twas your heaven she should be advanced.
Goodbye!: The most you wanted was her promotion, because it was your heaven that she should be promoted.

Anon!: Do not learn of him, Emilia, though he be thy husband.
Goodbye!: Don’t learn about him, Emilia, even if he’s your husband.

Anon!: I will withdraw To furnish me with some swift means of death For the fair devil.
Goodbye!: I’ll go back to get some swift death for the wicked devil.

Anon!: A tomb Must cover thy sweet eyes.
Goodbye!: A tomb must cover your sweet eyes.

Anon!: The sooner, sweet, for you.
Goodbye!: The sooner, sweet, for you.

Anon!: Which of you—if you were a prince’s son Being pent from liberty, as I am now— If two such murderers as yourselves came to you, Would not entreat for life?
Goodbye!: Which of you—if you were a prince’s son, you were freed from liberty, as I am now—if two such murderers as you came to you, wouldn’t you want to live?

Anon!: Excellent.
Goodbye!: Excellent.

Anon!: I am the duke That loved your father.
Goodbye!: I’m the duke who loved your father.

Anon!: Bring me a father that so loved his child, Whose joy of her is overwhelmed like mine, And bid him speak of patience.
Goodbye!: Bring me a father who loved his child so much, who is overwhelmed with joy like mine, and ask him to speak of patience.

Anon!: Lay hand on heart, advise.
Goodbye!: Give me a hand on heart and advise me.

Anon!: She is cunning past man’s thought.
Goodbye!: She’s scolded past man’s thought.

Anon!: Charmian, hark.
Goodbye!: Charmian, listen.

Anon!: Get you to bed again.
Goodbye!: Go back to bed.

Anon!: Alas, my liege, my wife is dead tonight.
Goodbye!: Oh, my liege, my wife is dead tonight.

Anon!: Take you some company, and away to horse.
Goodbye!: Take some company and go to horse.

Anon!: Farewell, my dearest sister, fare thee well.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, my dearest sister, goodbye.

Anon!: His countenance likes me not.
Goodbye!: He doesn’t like me.

Anon!: Nay, good goose, bite not.
Goodbye!: No, good goose, don’t bite me.

Anon!: Was Milan thrust from Milan, that his issue Should become kings of Naples?
Goodbye!: Was Milan thrust out of Milan, so that his issue should become kings of Naples?

Anon!: Is this true?
Goodbye!: Is this true?

Anon!: Therefore let Benedick, like covered fire, Consume away in sighs, waste inwardly.
Goodbye!: So let Benedick, like a covered fire, go away in sighs and go outward.

Anon!: It is impossible they bear it out.
Goodbye!: It’s impossible they’re going to bear it out.

Anon!: Oh, then we bring forth weeds When our quick minds lie still, and our ills told us Is as our earing.
Goodbye!: Oh, then we’re bringing out weeds when our quick minds lie still, and our ills told us that is as our earing.

Anon!: If you’ll sit down, I’ll bear your logs the while.
Goodbye!: If you sit down, I’ll keep your logs.

Anon!: So are the Prince and Claudio, who accused her Upon the error that you heard debated.
Goodbye!: The Prince and Claudio, who accused her of a wrong, are the ones who said you heard the news.

Anon!: But let me hear the letter of your friend.
Goodbye!: But let me hear the letter from your friend.

Anon!: As mine on hers, so hers is set on mine, And all combined, save what thou must combine By holy marriage.
Goodbye!: As mine on her, as mine on her, as mine on hers, and all together, except what you must combine by holy marriage.

Anon!: I will make myself known to Desdemona.
Goodbye!: I’ll tell Desdemona what I’m doing.

Anon!: Well I know the man.
Goodbye!: I know the man well.

Anon!: And so had mine.
Goodbye!: Mine did.

Anon!: Haste thee for thy life.
Goodbye!: Haste you for your life.

Anon!: But in this kind, wanting your father’s voice, The other must be held the worthier.
Goodbye!: But in this case, if you want your father’s voice, the other must be a better man.

Anon!: If you do fight against your country’s foes, Your country’s fat shall pay your pains the hire.
Goodbye!: If you fight against your country’s enemies, your country’s fat will pay you the hire.

Anon!: I pray, sir, tell me, is it possible That love should of a sudden take such hold?
Goodbye!: Please tell me, sir, is it possible that love suddenly takes such a hold?

Anon!: But those that understood him smiled at one another and shook their heads.
Goodbye!: But those who understood him smiled at each other and shook their heads.

Anon!: To his conveyance I assign my wife, With what else needful your good grace shall think To be sent after me.
Goodbye!: I’ll send my wife to him, with whatever else you need to think of being sent after me.

Anon!: Why, what a monstrous fellow art thou, thus to rail on one that is neither known of thee nor knows thee!
Goodbye!: What a monstrous fellow you are, to be a man who doesn’t know you or knows you!

Anon!: Have the pioneers given o'er?
Goodbye!: Have the pioneers given up?

Anon!: Ay, if your self’s remembrance wrong yourself.
Goodbye!: Yes, if you’re wrong in your memory.

Anon!: No more amazement.
Goodbye!: No more amazement.

Anon!: Sir, this is the matter—  I beseech you, remember— Nay, good my lord, for mine ease, in good faith.
Goodbye!: Sir, this is the matter—please, remember—No, my lord, for my ease, in good faith.

Anon!: Go after.
Goodbye!: Go ahead.

Anon!: Ho, now you strike like the blind man.
Goodbye!: Now you’re hitting like a blind man.

Anon!: A horse, a horse, my kingdom for a horse!
Goodbye!: A horse, a horse, my kingdom for a horse!

Anon!: Madam, you have done me wrong, Notorious wrong.
Goodbye!: Madam, you’ve done me wrong, notorious wrong.

Anon!: Give me a kiss.
Goodbye!: Give me a kiss.

Anon!: Now let it work.
Goodbye!: Now let it work.

Anon!: Thou didst it excellent.
Goodbye!: You did it excellently.

Anon!: They’ll be in scarlet straight at any news.
Goodbye!: They’ll be in a slew of news immediately.

Anon!: Let it be so.
Goodbye!: Let it be.

Anon!: Stay, Tybalt, stay!
Goodbye!: Stay, Tybalt, stay!

Anon!: That ever I should call thee castaway!
Goodbye!: I’m always going to call you castaway!

Anon!: I should be angry with you if the time were convenient.
Goodbye!: I’d be angry with you if it were time.

Anon!: What are they that do play it?
Goodbye!: Who are the actors?

Anon!: What didst not like?
Goodbye!: What did you like?

Anon!: What, Nurse, I say!
Goodbye!: Nurse, I say what!

Anon!: Who calls?
Goodbye!: Who’s calling me?

Anon!: Away, and let me die.
Goodbye!: Go away, and let me die.

Anon!: I think it be.
Goodbye!: I think it is.

Anon!: Serve God.
Goodbye!: Serve God.

Anon!: No, truly, but in friendly recompense.
Goodbye!: No, really, but in a friendly recompense.

Anon!: Now, sir, what make you here?
Goodbye!: What are you doing here, sir?

Anon!: No matter whither, so you come not here.
Goodbye!: No matter how you’re talking, you’re not coming here.

Anon!: Therefore be patient.
Goodbye!: So be patient.

Anon!: I have done my duty.
Goodbye!: I’ve done my duty.

Anon!: And yet, to say the truth, reason and love keep little company together nowadays.
Goodbye!: But to say the truth, reason and love keep little company together today.

Anon!: Stand fast, Titinius.
Goodbye!: Stand fast, Titinius.

Anon!: Ay, and Wall too.
Goodbye!: Yes, and Wall too.

Anon!: Speak not against it.
Goodbye!: Don’t say anything against it.

Anon!: I bespoke it not.
Goodbye!: I didn’t tailor it to my needs.

Anon!: If you have any pity, grace, or manners, You would not make me such an argument.
Goodbye!: If you have any pity, grace, or manners, you wouldn’t want to make me argue that.

Anon!: It is no hidden virtue in him.
Goodbye!: He has no hidden virtue.

Anon!: He knows me as the blind man knows the cuckoo— By the bad voice.
Goodbye!: He knows me as the blind man knows the cuckoo— By the bad voice.

Anon!: Therefore be deaf to my unpitied folly, And all the gods go with you!
Goodbye!: So be deaf to my unpitied folly, and all the gods go with you!

Anon!: Here, mighty Theseus.
Goodbye!: Here, mighty Theseus.

Anon!: Good morrow, worthy Caesar.
Goodbye!: Good morning, worthy Caesar.

Anon!: Now, Ursula, when Beatrice doth come, As we do trace this alley up and down, Our talk must only be of Benedick.
Goodbye!: Now, Ursula, when Beatrice comes, as we look at this alley up and down, we must only talk about Benedick.

Anon!: Dromio, what stuff of mine hast thou embarked?
Goodbye!: Dromio, what stuff did you have to do with mine?

Anon!: Friends, part!” and, swifter than his tongue, His agile arm beats down their fatal points, And ’twixt them rushes—underneath whose arm An envious thrust from Tybalt hit the life Of stout Mercutio, and then Tybalt fled.
Goodbye!: Friends, part!” and, faster than his tongue, his agile arm beat down their fatal points and swam them into the rush—and whose arm was thrown from Tybalt and hit Mercutio’s life

Anon!: Let the garden door be shut, and leave me to my hearing.
Goodbye!: Let the garden door be closed, and leave me to my hearing.

Anon!: Your son, my lord, has paid a soldier’s debt.
Goodbye!: Your son, my lord, has paid a soldier’s debt.

Anon!: If you deny them, all the land will rue it.
Goodbye!: If you deny them, all the land will ruin it.

Anon!: Holy Saint Francis, what a change is here!
Goodbye!: Holy Saint Francis, what a change this is!

Anon!: But did you not request to have it cut?
Goodbye!: But didn’t you ask to cut it?

Anon!: The spring, the head, the fountain of your blood Is stopped; the very source of it is stopped.
Goodbye!: The spring, the head, the fountain of your blood is stopped.

Anon!: This sight of death is as a bell, That warns my old age to a sepulcher.
Goodbye!: This sight of death is like a bell, which warns me to be a sepulcher.

Anon!: What means this lady?
Goodbye!: What’s this lady?

Anon!: Thanks, good my countryman.
Goodbye!: Thanks, my good countryman.

Anon!: Fare you well, my liege.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, my liege.

Anon!: That death’s unnatural that kills for loving.
Goodbye!: That death is unnatural, because it’s a loving thing.

Anon!: You understand me?
Goodbye!: You understand me?

Anon!: Romeo!
Goodbye!: Romeo!

Anon!: Doth not  Ay, Nurse, what of that?
Goodbye!: Don’t you say yes, Nurse, what about that?

Anon!: I must take out the work?
Goodbye!: I have to take out the work?

Anon!: If your master Would have a queen his beggar, you must tell him, That majesty, to keep decorum, must No less beg than a kingdom.
Goodbye!: If your master wants a queen to beg him, you have to tell him that a queen must beg no less than a kingdom.

Anon!: I cry you mercy, then, I took you for that cunning whore of Venice That married with Othello.—You, mistress, That have the office opposite to Saint Peter And keep the gate of hell!
Goodbye!: I’ll cry you mercy, then, I took you for that sane whore of Venice, who married with Othello.—You, mistress, who have the office opposite to Saint Peter and keep the gate of

Anon!: No, my lord, I saw nothing.
Goodbye!: No, my lord, I didn’t see anything.

Anon!: Why, tell me, is not this my Cambio?
Goodbye!: Why, tell me, isn’t this my Cambio?

Anon!: Sir?
Goodbye!: Sir?

Anon!: Whiles we stood here securing your repose, Even now, we heard a hollow burst of bellowing Like bulls, or rather lions.
Goodbye!: While we stood here to secure your repose, even now we heard a hollow burst of bellowing like bulls, or rather lions.

Anon!: If it please you.
Goodbye!: If you like.

Anon!: Not where he eats, but where he is eaten.
Goodbye!: Not where he eats, but where he eats.

Anon!: The words expressly are “a pound of flesh.” Take then thy bond, take thou thy pound of flesh, But in the cutting it if thou dost shed One drop of Christian blood, thy lands and goods Are by the laws of Venice confiscate Unto the state of Venice.
Goodbye!: The words expressly are “a pound of flesh.” Take your bond, take your pound of flesh, but if you shed one drop of Christian blood, your lands and goods are confiscated by the laws of Venice to the

Anon!: Which else were shame, that then necessity Will call discreet proceeding.
Goodbye!: Which else would be shame, that would be a sex act.

Anon!: The ship was under sail.
Goodbye!: The ship was under sail.

Anon!: Good bawcock, 'bate thy rage.
Goodbye!: Good bawcock, scold your rage.

Anon!: And so doth mine.
Goodbye!: And mine.

Anon!: Follow, and see there be no harm between them.
Goodbye!: Follow them and see that they won’t suffer.

Anon!: Good my friends, consider You are my guests.
Goodbye!: My friends, please consider you are my guests.

Anon!: sits.—I did never think that lady would have loved any man.
Goodbye!: I never thought that lady would have loved any man.

Anon!: To plainness honor’s bound When majesty falls to folly.
Goodbye!: Honor is bound to the truth when majesty falls to a wickedness.

Anon!: No, I pray thee speak in sober judgment.
Goodbye!: No, please, speak soberly.

Anon!: Vouchsafe, defused infection of a man, Of these known evils but to give me leave By circumstance to curse thy cursèd self.
Goodbye!: I’m not going to curse your self by circumstance.

Anon!: Let the trumpet sound.
Goodbye!: Let the trumpet sound.

Anon!: The lunatic, the lover, and the poet Are of imagination all compact.
Goodbye!: The lunatic, the lover, and the poet are all sane.

Anon!: Smile heaven upon this fair conjunction, That long have frowned upon their enmity.
Goodbye!: Smile heaven on this fair relationship, who have frowned on their enmity for a long time.

Anon!: Yet put it out, for I would not be seen.
Goodbye!: Put it out, because I wouldn’t be seen.

Anon!: What news?
Goodbye!: What news do you have?

Anon!: Well roared, Lion!
Goodbye!: Well roared, Lion!

Anon!: Now is he for the numbers that Petrarch flowed in.
Goodbye!: Now he’s a man for the numbers Petrarch flies in.

Anon!: What dost thou mean?
Goodbye!: What do you mean?

Anon!: That will I.
Goodbye!: I will.

Anon!: If I should take a displeasure against you, look you—  Thou wert but a lost monster.
Goodbye!: If I’d take a displeasure against you, look— You’re only a lost monster.

Anon!: Tis clean out of the way.
Goodbye!: It’s clean out of the way.

Anon!: I have a device to make all well.
Goodbye!: I have a way to make everything work.

Anon!: He needs not.
Goodbye!: He doesn’t need to.

Anon!: Thou hast quarreled with a man for coughing in the street because he hath wakened thy dog that hath lain asleep in the sun.
Goodbye!: You have fought with a man for coughing in the street because he woke up your dog who slept in the sun.

Anon!: And how you may be converted I know not, but methinks you look with your eyes as other women do.
Goodbye!: I don’t know how you can be transformed, but I think you look like other women.

Anon!: It eats and sleeps and hath such senses As we have, such.
Goodbye!: It eats and sleeps and has the same senses as we have, such.

Anon!: Soldiers, sir.
Goodbye!: Soldiers, sir.

Anon!: You have too courtly a wit for me.
Goodbye!: You’re too clever to be a fool for me.

Anon!: Which way ran he that killed Mercutio?
Goodbye!: Which way did he kill Mercutio?

Anon!: Bid me farewell.
Goodbye!: Give me farewell.

Anon!: I know no news, my lord.
Goodbye!: I don’t know anything, my lord.

Anon!: A very dishonest paltry boy, and more a coward than a hare.
Goodbye!: A very dishonest, paltry boy, and more cowardly than a hare.

Anon!: How durst you, villains, bring it from the dresser And serve it thus to me that love it not?
Goodbye!: How do you, villains, bring it out of the dresser and serve it to me who don’t love it?

Anon!: No.
Goodbye!: No.

Anon!: O, he was gentle, mild, and virtuous.
Goodbye!: Oh, he was gentle, mild, and virtuous.

Anon!: If a Jew wrong a Christian, what is his humility?
Goodbye!: If a Jew is wrong with a Christian, what’s his humility?

Anon!: I am glad to see your highness.
Goodbye!: I’m glad to see you.

Anon!: And must they all be hanged that swear and lie?
Goodbye!: And must they all be hanged, who swear and lie?

Anon!: That “banishèd,” that one word “banishèd” Hath slain ten thousand Tybalts.
Goodbye!: That banishment, that one word banishment, has killed ten thousand Tybalts.

Anon!: Oh, ’tis treason!
Goodbye!: Oh, it’s treason!

Anon!: At least I’m sure it may be so in Denmark.
Goodbye!: I’m sure it may be in Denmark.

Anon!: Despair and die!
Goodbye!: Despair and die!

Anon!: None does offend—none, I say, none.
Goodbye!: None of them is offending—no, I say, no.

Anon!: This doth betoken The corse they follow did with desperate hand Fordo its own life.
Goodbye!: This is the way the corse they follow did with a desperate hand for Fordo to live.

Anon!: I have heard too much, and your words and performances are no kin together.
Goodbye!: I’ve heard too much, and your words and performances aren’t akin to each other.

Anon!: She speaks poniards, and every word stabs.
Goodbye!: She’s talking poniards, and every word stabs.

Anon!: Shall we hear from you, Catesby, ere we sleep?
Goodbye!: Should we hear from you, Catesby, if we sleep?

Anon!: Do you mark that, my lord?
Goodbye!: Do you remember that, my lord?

Anon!: And you are well met, Signior Hortensio.
Goodbye!: And you’re well met, Signior Hortensio.

Anon!: Faith, that was not so well.
Goodbye!: Yes, that was not so good.

Anon!: He may recover yet.
Goodbye!: He may recover yet.

Anon!: Ay, madam, from the reach of these my hands.
Goodbye!: Yes, madam, I’m out of my reach.

Anon!: At thy request, monster, I will do reason, any reason.— Come on, Trinculo, let us sing.
Goodbye!: I’ll do whatever I want, monster.—Come on, Trinculo, let’s sing.

Anon!: Gallants, I am not as I have been.
Goodbye!: Gallants, I’m not as old as I am.

Anon!: By this hand, I am.
Goodbye!: I swear by this hand.

Anon!: Excellent.
Goodbye!: Excellent.

Anon!: I am afeard you make a wanton of me.
Goodbye!: I’m afraid you’re making a wish for me.

Anon!: What stay had we but Clarence?
Goodbye!: What time did we have except Clarence?

Anon!: Romeo, away, be gone!
Goodbye!: Romeo, go away!

Anon!: Villain am I none.
Goodbye!: I’m no one.

Anon!: I will do any modest office, my lord, to help my cousin to a good husband.
Goodbye!: I’ll do any modest job to help my cousin get a good husband.

Anon!: Or wilt thou hunt?
Goodbye!: Or are you planning to hunt?

Anon!: O Iras, Charmian!
Goodbye!: Oh, Iras, Charmian!

Anon!: You are pictures out of door, bells in your parlors, wild-cats in your kitchens, saints in your injuries, devils being offended, players in your housewifery, and housewives in your beds.
Goodbye!: You’re out of the door, you’re ringing bells in your parlors, wild-cats in your kitchens, saints in your injuries, devils being offended, housewifes playing with

Anon!: What’s to be done?
Goodbye!: What’s going on?

Anon!: No more, no more.
Goodbye!: No more, no more.

Anon!: For these two hours, Rosalind, I will leave thee.
Goodbye!: For these two hours, Rosalind, I’ll leave you.

Anon!: And this way have you well expounded it.
Goodbye!: And you’ve done well in this way.

Anon!: He will keep that good name still.
Goodbye!: He’ll keep that good name still.

Anon!: Nor I know not Where I did lodge last night.
Goodbye!: I don’t know where I stayed last night.

Anon!: It is much that the Moor should be more than reason.
Goodbye!: It’s much that the Moor should be more than just reason.

Anon!: He is not here, so please your lordship, that should sing it.
Goodbye!: He’s not here, please, your lord, who should sing it.

Anon!: Will not he?
Goodbye!: Willn’t he?

Anon!: Call the clotpoll back.
Goodbye!: Call the clotpoll back.

Anon!: A friend of Antony’s.
Goodbye!: A friend of Antony’s.

Anon!: And we mean well in going to this mask, But ’tis no wit to go.
Goodbye!: And we mean well in going to this mask, but it’s not a good idea to go.

Anon!: The bounty and the benison of heaven To boot and boot.
Goodbye!: The bounty and the benison of heaven to boot and boot.

Anon!: How heavy weighs my lord!
Goodbye!: How much is my lord?

Anon!: Yea, marry, let them come before me.
Goodbye!: Yes, let them come before me.

Anon!: Ay, let the county take you in your bed.
Goodbye!: Yes, let the Count take you in your bed.

Anon!: Let her be round with him, And I’ll be placed, so please you, in the ear Of all their conference.
Goodbye!: Let her be round with him, and I’ll be placed, please, in the ear of all their meetings.

Anon!: Tomorrow night when Phoebe doth behold Her silver visage in the watery glass, Decking with liquid pearl the bladed grass (A time that lovers' flights doth still conceal), Through Athens' gates have we devised to steal.
Goodbye!: Tomorrow night, when Phoebe sees her silver face in the watery glass, a grass covered with pearls, and the sand that’s still hiding in the air.

Anon!: List a brief tale, And when ’tis told, oh, that my heart would burst!
Goodbye!: Listen to a brief story, and when it’s told, oh, my heart will burst!

Anon!: Do me right, or I will protest your cowardice.
Goodbye!: Do me right, or I’ll protest your cowardice.

Anon!: Well, I will be so much a sinner, to be a double-dealer.
Goodbye!: Well, I’ll be a sinner, to be a double-dealer.

Anon!: I’ll court his favors.
Goodbye!: I’ll court his favors.

Anon!: So take her to thee, shepherd.
Goodbye!: Take her to you, shepherd.

Anon!: How does lieutenant Cassio?
Goodbye!: How is lieutenant Cassio?

Anon!: Who is here so rude that would not be a Roman?
Goodbye!: Who is here so rude that he doesn’t want to be a Roman?

Anon!: Now will I to the chink, To spy an I can hear my Thisbe’s face.
Goodbye!: Now I’ll go to the chink to spy on me so I can hear my Thisbe’s face.

Anon!: Three words, dear Romeo, and good night indeed.
Goodbye!: Three words, dear Romeo, and good night indeed.

Anon!: So do all thoughts.
Goodbye!: So do all the thoughts.

Anon!: Let thy blood and spirit embrace them.
Goodbye!: Let your blood and spirit embrace them.

Anon!: Madam, not now.
Goodbye!: Madam, not now.

Anon!: Seigneur Valentio and his cousin Tybalt; Lucio and the lively Helena.” A fair assembly.
Goodbye!: Seigneur Valentio and his cousin Tybalt, Lucio and the lively Helena.” A fair assembly.

Anon!: Is the storm overblown?
Goodbye!: Is the storm overblown?

Anon!: He had a thousand noses, Horns whelked and waved like the enragèd sea.
Goodbye!: He had a thousand noses, and he waved like a sea.

Anon!: If ’twere no other— 'Tis but so, I warrant.
Goodbye!: If it weren’t the other— it’s just that, I’m sure.

Anon!: What raiment will your Honor wear today?
Goodbye!: What raiment will your Honor wear today?

Anon!: Marry, he told me so himself; and he said he cared not who knew it.
Goodbye!: He told me so himself, and he said he didn’t care who knew it.

Anon!: Judge me the world if ’tis not gross in sense That thou hast practiced on her with foul charms, Abused her delicate youth with drugs or minerals That weakens motion.
Goodbye!: Judge me the world if it’s not gross in sense that you have abused her with foul charms, and abused her delicate youth with drugs or minerals that weakens her mood.

Anon!: Bear hence this body and attend our will.
Goodbye!: Take this body away and take care of our will.

Anon!: Nay, that’s true, that’s very true.
Goodbye!: That’s true, that’s very true.

Anon!: For this reason, if you’ll know: That she’s the choice love of Signior Gremio.
Goodbye!: If you know, then she’s Signior Gremio’s choice love.

Anon!: Look how he laughs already!
Goodbye!: Look how he laughs already!

Anon!: The mighty dukes, Gloucester and Buckingham.
Goodbye!: The mighty dukes Gloucester and Buckingham.

Anon!: You must call forth the watch that are their accusers.
Goodbye!: You have to call out the watch that’s accused of it.

Anon!: Make good room.
Goodbye!: Make good room.

Anon!: O brother Montague, give me thy hand.
Goodbye!: Oh, brother Montague, give me your hand.

Anon!: Let’s see once more this saying graved in gold, “Who chooseth me shall gain what many men desire.” Why, that’s the lady.
Goodbye!: Let’s see this saying, graved in gold, “Who chooses me will get what many men want.” That’s the lady.

Anon!: My quaint Ariel, Hark in thine ear.
Goodbye!: My quaint Ariel, listen to your ear.

Anon!: Say, Voltemand, what from our brother Norway?
Goodbye!: Say, Voltemand, what’s the news from our brother Norway?

Anon!: The time of universal peace is near.
Goodbye!: The time of universal peace is approaching.

Anon!: And I remember the kissing of her batler, and the cow’s dugs that her pretty chopped hands had milked.
Goodbye!: And I remember the kissing of her batler, and the cow’s dugs that her pretty chopped hands had milked.

Anon!: My maid Nerissa and myself meantime Will live as maids and widows.
Goodbye!: My maid Nerissa and I will live as maids and widows.

Anon!: Ay, pilgrim, lips that they must use in prayer.
Goodbye!: Yes, pilgrim, they have lips that they need to pray for.

Anon!: I will employ thee back again; I find thee Most fit for business.
Goodbye!: I’ll hire you back again, and I find you the most suitable for business.

Anon!: He shall think, by the letters that thou wilt drop, that they come from my niece, and that she’s in love with him.
Goodbye!: He’ll think, if you drop the letters, that they’re coming from my niece and that she’s in love with him.

Anon!: What misadventure is so early up That calls our person from our morning rest?
Goodbye!: What misadventure is that early in the morning that calls our person out of our morning sleep?

Anon!: No, truly, unless thou wert hard-favored, for honesty coupled to beauty is to have honey a sauce to sugar.
Goodbye!: No, unless you’re hard-favored, because honesty coupled to beauty is to have honey a sauce to sugar.

Anon!: Hark, hark!
Goodbye!: Listen, listen!

Anon!: Is it e'en so?
Goodbye!: Is it true?

Anon!: I’ll have some proof.
Goodbye!: I’ll have some proof.

Anon!: The ground is bloody.—Search about the churchyard.
Goodbye!: The ground is bloody.—Search about the churchyard.

Anon!: Some o’ their plants are ill-rooted already.
Goodbye!: Some of their plants are already rotten.

Anon!: Here’s goodly gear.
Goodbye!: Here’s a good gear.

Anon!: I have very poor and unhappy brains for drinking.
Goodbye!: I have very poor and unhappy brains for drinking.

Anon!: Faith, he is posted hence on serious matter.
Goodbye!: Yes, he’s been arrested for serious matters.

Anon!: You bring me out.
Goodbye!: You’re taking me out.

Anon!: I will, and know her mind early tomorrow.
Goodbye!: I will, and I know her mind early tomorrow.

Anon!: Sweet saint, for charity, be not so curst.
Goodbye!: Sweet saint, for good reason, don’t be so scolded.

Anon!: And how doth she?
Goodbye!: And how is she?

Anon!: Virtue that transgresses is but patched with sin, and sin that amends is but patched with virtue.
Goodbye!: Virtue that is a slander is only patched with sin, and sin that is only patched with virtue.

Anon!: They are so still, Or thou, the greatest soldier of the world, Art turned the greatest liar.
Goodbye!: They’re still so, or you, the greatest soldier of the world, have turned the greatest liar.

Anon!: You the like loss?
Goodbye!: You’re losing something like that?

Anon!: Good morrow, Casca.—Caius Ligarius, Caesar was ne'er so much your enemy As that same ague which hath made you lean.
Goodbye!: Good morning, Casca.—Caius Ligarius, Caesar was no enemy of any kind as you were in that ague that made you lean.

Anon!: Hie you to horse.
Goodbye!: Go on horse.

Anon!: He is not very tall—yet for his years he’s tall.
Goodbye!: He’s not very tall—for his years he’s tall.

Anon!: You may, sir.
Goodbye!: You can, sir.

Anon!: There, my lord.
Goodbye!: Here, my lord.

Anon!: Oh, come apace, dispatch!
Goodbye!: Oh, come quickly, dispatch!

Anon!: Such an exploit have I in hand, Ligarius, Had you a healthful ear to hear of it.
Goodbye!: I’d be in the right hands for such a thing, Ligarius, if you had a good ear to hear about it.

Anon!: One doth not know How much an ill word may empoison liking.
Goodbye!: One doesn’t know how much a bad word can affect liking.

Anon!: Were such things here as we do speak about?
Goodbye!: Were things like that here?

Anon!: Nay, but, Ophelia— Pray you, mark.
Goodbye!: No, but Ophelia— Please, mark.

Anon!: I am in your debt for your last exercise.
Goodbye!: I’m in debt for your last job.

Anon!: Tell me, if your art Can tell so much: shall Banquo’s issue ever Reign in this kingdom?
Goodbye!: Tell me, if your art can tell you so much: will Banquo’s issue ever return to this kingdom?

Anon!: What follows, then, my lord?
Goodbye!: What’s going on, then, my lord?

Anon!: But, like the owner of a foul disease, To keep it from divulging, let it feed Even on the pith of life.
Goodbye!: But to keep it from being divulged, let it feed even the smallest part of life.

Anon!: That she may long live here, God say amen.
Goodbye!: I hope she can live here for a long time, God say amen.

Anon!: Tybalt is dead, and Romeo banishèd.”
Goodbye!: Tybalt is dead, and Romeo has been banned.”

Anon!: Why did you bring these daggers from the place?
Goodbye!: Why did you bring these daggers out of the place?

Anon!: I hold your dainties cheap, sir, and your welcome dear.
Goodbye!: I’m a big fan of your dainties, sir, and you’re dear to me.

Anon!: Thou art not conquered.
Goodbye!: You’ve never been conquered.

Anon!: An I might live to see thee married once, I have my wish.
Goodbye!: If I could live to see you marry once, I have my wish.

Anon!: Infirm of purpose!
Goodbye!: I’m not sure what to do!

Anon!: Therefore let’s follow.
Goodbye!: So let’s follow them.

Anon!: So God sa' me, ’tis shame to stand still.
Goodbye!: That’s shame to stand still.

Anon!: The good years shall devour them, flesh and fell, Ere they shall make us weep.
Goodbye!: The good years will devour them, flesh and fall, and they will make us cry.

Anon!: Talk not to me, for I’ll not speak a word.
Goodbye!: Don’t talk to me, because I won’t say a word.

Anon!: What, will our mother come?
Goodbye!: What, will my mother come?

Anon!: Hath put himself from rest, And must needs taste his folly.
Goodbye!: He’s been thrown away from sleep and must taste his foolishness.

Anon!: No way but gentleness, gently, gently.
Goodbye!: No way but gentleness, gentleness, gentleness.

Anon!: You are a senator!
Goodbye!: You’re a senator!

Anon!: That skull had a tongue in it and could sing once.
Goodbye!: That skull had a tongue in it and could sing once.

Anon!: Descend, for you must be my torchbearer.
Goodbye!: Descend, because you have to be my torchbearer.

Anon!: I dare not, sir.
Goodbye!: I don’t dare, sir.

Anon!: I have an interest in your hearts' proceeding.
Goodbye!: I’m interested in your actions.

Anon!: We are the makers of manners, Kate, and the liberty that follows our places stops the mouth of all find- faults, as I will do yours for upholding the nice fashion of your country in denying me a kiss.
Goodbye!: We’re the makers of manners, Kate, and the freedom that follows us stops the mouth of all the slanders, as I’ll do yours for defending your country’s nice style by refusing me

Anon!: I have no long spoon.
Goodbye!: I have no long spoon.

Anon!: His neigh is like the bidding of a monarch, and his countenance enforces homage.
Goodbye!: His neigh is like a monarch’s bid, and his countenance is a homage to him.

Anon!: My dismal scene I needs must act alone.
Goodbye!: I have to act alone in my terrible situation.

Anon!: Raise up the Montagues.
Goodbye!: Raise up the Montagues.

Anon!: And I am such a tender ass, if my hair do but tickle me, I must scratch.
Goodbye!: And if my hair tickles me, I’ll scratch.

Anon!: The throng that follows Caesar at the heels, Of senators, of praetors, common suitors, Will crowd a feeble man almost to death.
Goodbye!: The throng that follows Caesar at the heels of senators, praetors, common suitors, will turn a poor man almost to death.

Anon!: Verona, for a while I take my leave, To see my friends in Padua, but of all My best belovèd and approvèd friend, Hortensio.
Goodbye!: Verona, I’m leaving for a while to see my friends in Padua, but of all my best beloved and approved friend, Hortensio.

Anon!: Tell him we could have rebuked him at Harfleur, but that we thought not good to bruise an injury till it were full ripe.
Goodbye!: Tell him we could have rebuked him at Harfleur, but we didn’t think it was good to bruise an injury until it was full ripe.

Anon!: Not being Fortune, he’s but Fortune’s knave, A minister of her will.
Goodbye!: Not being Fortune, he’s just Fortune’s king, a minister of her will.

Anon!: Last night she slept not, nor tonight she shall not.
Goodbye!: Last night she slept, and tonight she will not.

Anon!: Art thou of Cornish crew?
Goodbye!: Are you a Cornish crew?

Anon!: Upon the corner of the moon There hangs a vap'rous drop profound.
Goodbye!: On the moon’s edge there’s a huge drop.

Anon!: Or did the letters work upon his blood And new-create his fault?
Goodbye!: Or did the letters work on his blood and create his fault?

Anon!: Hold, for shame!
