Goodbye!: Stop, for shame!

Anon!: Nay, I am for all waters.
Goodbye!: No, I’m for all waters.

Anon!: I see you all are bent To set against me for your merriment.
Goodbye!: I see you all are bent to fight against me for your merriment.

Anon!: Or sleep I now and think I hear all this?
Goodbye!: Or do I sleep now and think I hear all this?

Anon!: Phoebe, with all my heart.
Goodbye!: Phoebe, with all my heart.

Anon!: Go to, go to.
Goodbye!: Go to, go to.

Anon!: Within these two months—that’s a month before This bond expires—I do expect return Of thrice three times the value of this bond.
Goodbye!: Within two months—that’s a month before this bond expires—I expect three times the value of this bond.

Anon!: I would not be cured, youth.
Goodbye!: I wouldn’t be cured, young man.

Anon!: There is one within, Besides the things that we have heard and seen, Recounts most horrid sights seen by the watch.
Goodbye!: There’s one inside, out of all the things we’ve heard and seen, that’s what the watch has seen.

Anon!: Oh, damn her, damn her!
Goodbye!: Oh, damn her, damn her!

Anon!: A commodity in question, I warrant you.—Come, we’ll obey you.
Goodbye!: I’m sure it’s a commodity.—Come on, we’ll obey you.

Anon!: I say it is the moon that shines so bright.
Goodbye!: I say the moon is shining so bright.

Anon!: Full of vexation come I with complaint Against my child, my daughter Hermia.— Stand forth, Demetrius.—My noble lord, This man hath my consent to marry her.— Stand forth, Lysander.—And my gracious duke, This man hath bewitched the bosom of my child.— Thou, thou, Lysander, thou hast given her rhymes, And interchanged love tokens with my child.
Goodbye!: I’ve been vexing my child with complaints against her, my daughter Hermia.—Stop, Demetrius.—My noble lord, this man has my consent to marry her.—Stop

Anon!: You stayed well by ’t in Egypt.
Goodbye!: You stayed well in Egypt.

Anon!: What need the bridge much broader than the flood?
Goodbye!: What’s the need for a bridge much larger than the flood?

Anon!: This way, my lord.
Goodbye!: This way, my lord.

Anon!: I will meditate the while upon some horrid message for a challenge.
Goodbye!: I’ll meditate on some horrid message for a challenge.

Anon!: She shall not harm thee, Helena.
Goodbye!: She won’t harm you, Helena.

Anon!: And turns the sun to shade.
Goodbye!: And the sun turns to the shade.

Anon!: Tomorrow will we be married.
Goodbye!: Tomorrow we’ll be married.

Anon!: In him your comfort lives.
Goodbye!: You’re in your comfort.

Anon!: I urged you further, then you scratched your head And too impatiently stamped with your foot.
Goodbye!: I urged you to go further, then you scratched your head and stamped your foot too unpatiently.

Anon!: I know not if ’t be true, But I, for mere suspicion in that kind, Will do as if for surety.
Goodbye!: I don’t know if it’s true, but I’ll do as if I’m a fool.

Anon!: So humbly take my leave.
Goodbye!: So take my leave.

Anon!: As I!
Goodbye!: As I am!

Anon!: You draw me, you hard-hearted adamant.
Goodbye!: You draw me, you hard-hearted adamant.

Anon!: O Cicero, I have seen tempests when the scolding winds Have rived the knotty oaks, and I have seen Th' ambitious ocean swell and rage and foam To be exalted with the threatening clouds, But never till tonight, never till now, Did I go through a tempest dropping fire.
Goodbye!: Oh, Cicero, I’ve seen the storms when the storms rived the knotty oaks, and I’ve seen the rage and rage of the oceans being exalted with the

Anon!: O time’s extremity, Hast thou so crack’d and splitted my poor tongue In seven short years that here my only son Knows not my feeble key of untuned cares?
Goodbye!: Oh, the extreme times, have you cracked and split my poor tongue in seven short years so that my only son doesn’t know my sluggish ear?

Anon!: All things shall be well.
Goodbye!: Everything will be good.

Anon!: No, indeed, my lord.
Goodbye!: No, my lord.

Anon!: Look, love, what envious streaks Do lace the severing clouds in yonder east.
Goodbye!: Look, love, what envious streaks make the clouds severing in the east.

Anon!: Besides, Antonio certified the Duke They were not with Bassanio in his ship.
Goodbye!: Besides, Antonio told the Duke they weren’t with Bassanio aboard his ship.

Anon!: Can I go forward when my heart is here?
Goodbye!: Can I go forward when my heart is here?

Anon!: Carried to Colmekill, The sacred storehouse of his predecessors, And guardian of their bones.
Goodbye!: Then he was transported to Colmekill, the sacred storehouse of his predecessors, and guardians of their bones.

Anon!: Shall we go, coz?
Goodbye!: Shall we go, coz?

Anon!: I once writ a sonnet in his praise and began thus: “Wonder of nature—”  I have heard a sonnet begin so to one’s mistress.
Goodbye!: I once wrote a sonnet in his praise and began like this: “Wonder of nature—” I’ve heard a sonnet start so quickly to his mistress.

Anon!: That’s a degree to love.
Goodbye!: That’s a degree of love.

Anon!: Here comes Ancient Pistol and his wife.
Goodbye!: Here comes Ancient Pistol and his wife.

Anon!: Hark how our steeds for present service neigh.
Goodbye!: Listen to how our steeds are neighing for the moment.

Anon!: But there the Duke was given to understand That in a gondola were seen together Lorenzo and his amorous Jessica.
Goodbye!: But the Duke was given the chance to understand that Lorenzo and his wife Jessica were seen together in a gondola.

Anon!: I have a mind to strike thee ere thou speak’st.
Goodbye!: I’m going to strike you when you speak.

Anon!: I hope you do not mean to cheat me so.
Goodbye!: I hope you don’t want to cheat me like that.

Anon!: Villain, I say, knock me at this gate And rap me well, or I’ll knock your knave’s pate.
Goodbye!: I say, I’ll knock me at this gate and rap me well, or I’ll knock your knave’s slap.

Anon!: That I love her, I feel.
Goodbye!: I feel that I love her.

Anon!: You, sir?
Goodbye!: You, sir?

Anon!: My nyas?
Goodbye!: My nyas?

Anon!: No, my lord.
Goodbye!: No, my lord.

Anon!: I should have been a sore one then.
Goodbye!: I would have been a sore one then.

Anon!: When they are gone, then must I count my gains.
Goodbye!: When they’re gone, then I have to count my gains.

Anon!: We’ll to dinner, thither.
Goodbye!: We’ll go to dinner.

Anon!: O, that thou wert not, poor distressèd soul!
Goodbye!: Oh, you don’t deserve, poor soul!

Anon!: As woman’s love.
Goodbye!: As woman’s love.

Anon!: Soldiers, have careful watch.
Goodbye!: Soldiers, watch carefully.

Anon!: No, nor more fearful.
Goodbye!: No, and I’m not afraid.

Anon!: The ground indeed is tawny.
Goodbye!: The ground is really tawny.

Anon!: O Regan, wilt thou take her by the hand?
Goodbye!: Oh Regan, will you take her by the hand?

Anon!: Your eyes do menace me.
Goodbye!: Your eyes are threatening me.

Anon!: Why?
Goodbye!: Why?

Anon!: Would all were well—but that will never be.
Goodbye!: It would be good to all—but that will never happen.

Anon!: Thou hast by moonlight at her window sung With feigning voice verses of feigning love, And stol'n the impression of her fantasy With bracelets of thy hair, rings, gauds, conceits, Knacks, trifles, nosegays, sweetmeats—messengers Of strong prevailment in unhardened youth.
Goodbye!: You’ve sung by moonlight at her window with feigning voice verses of feigning love, and you’ve stolped the impression of her fantasy with bracelets of your hair

Anon!: Poor painted queen, vain flourish of my fortune, Why strew’st thou sugar on that bottled spider, Whose deadly web ensnareth thee about?
Goodbye!: Poor painted queen, I’m a vain king, why do you strew on that bottled spider, who’s a deadly web that’s ensnatching you?

Anon!: Therefore exhale.
Goodbye!: So go out.

Anon!: Wrong I mine enemies?
Goodbye!: Wrong I’m my enemies?

Anon!: So she may live unscarred of bleeding slaughter, I will confess she was not Edward’s daughter.
Goodbye!: So she can live without being slaughtered, I’ll admit she was not Edward’s daughter.

Anon!: Now lies he there, And none so poor to do him reverence.
Goodbye!: Now he’s there, and none of those poor who can do him reverence are so poor.

Anon!: We’ll draw cuts for the signior.
Goodbye!: We’ll cut the signior’s hair.

Anon!: For Pyramus is a sweet-faced man, a proper man as one shall see in a summer’s day, a most lovely, gentlemanlike man.
Goodbye!: Pyramus is a sweet-faced man, a good man as he can see in a summer’s day, a lovely gentlemanlike man.

Anon!: Doth the moon shine that night we play our play?
Goodbye!: Is the moon shining that night?

Anon!: Now have I done a good day’s work.
Goodbye!: Now I’ve done a good day’s work.

Anon!: A very gentle beast, of a good conscience.
Goodbye!: A very gentle beast, with a good conscience.

Anon!: We shall ne'er be younger.
Goodbye!: We’ll never be younger.

Anon!: This is Signor Antonio.
Goodbye!: This is Signor Antonio.

Anon!: Right joyous are we to behold your face, Most worthy brother England.
Goodbye!: We’re so happy to see your face, most worthy brother England.

Anon!: Holy Franciscan Friar!
Goodbye!: Holy Franciscan Friar!

Anon!: All this is comfort.
Goodbye!: All this is comforting news.

Anon!: The Moor himself at sea And is in full commission here for Cyprus.
Goodbye!: The Moor himself is on the sea and is in full service here for Cyprus.

Anon!: Go to him, madam, speak to him.
Goodbye!: Go to him, madam, speak to him.

Anon!: Shame of ladies, sisters!
Goodbye!: Shame on ladies, sisters!

Anon!: I am old and foolish.
Goodbye!: I’m old and foolish.

Anon!: Do, I prithee, but yet have the grace to consider that tears do not become a man.
Goodbye!: Please, I’m sorry, but I’ll admit that tears don’t become a man.

Anon!: Go with me, And in the breath of bitter words let’s smother My damnèd son that thy two sweet sons smothered.
Goodbye!: Go with me, and let’s smother my damned son, whose two sweet sons smothered you.

Anon!: Let me shake thy hand.
Goodbye!: Let me shake your hand.

Anon!: Why, he drinks you with facility your Dane dead drunk; he sweats not to overthrow your Almain.
Goodbye!: He drinks you with a drink of a sour drink, your Dane dead drunk, and he doesn’t sweat to overthrow your Almain.

Anon!: Conscience and grace, to the profoundest pit!
Goodbye!: Conscience and grace, to the deepest pit!

Anon!: Where are they?
Goodbye!: Where are they?

Anon!: Is the duke of Exeter safe?
Goodbye!: Is the duke of Exeter safe?

Anon!: Stay, Jaques, stay.
Goodbye!: Stay, Jaques, stay.

Anon!: Ay, boy, ready.
Goodbye!: Yes, boy, ready.

Anon!: Yet would not so have been, Durst I have done my will.
Goodbye!: But I wouldn’t have done that, even if I had done my will.

Anon!: Madam, good night.
Goodbye!: Madam, good night.

Anon!: And to sink in it, should you burthen love— Too great oppression for a tender thing.
Goodbye!: And to sink in it, should you burst in love— Too much oppression for a tender thing.

Anon!: Tis no time to play now.
Goodbye!: It’s not time to play.

Anon!: Know you not the cause?
Goodbye!: Don’t you know the cause?

Anon!: Good night.
Goodbye!: Good night.

Anon!: Show his eyes and grieve his heart.
Goodbye!: Show his eyes and grieve his heart.

Anon!: You saw my master wink and laugh upon you?
Goodbye!: You saw my master wink and laugh at you?

Anon!: Not proud you have, but thankful that you have.
Goodbye!: You’re not proud of me, but you’re thankful for you.

Anon!: Be better at thy leisure.
Goodbye!: Be better at your leisure.

Anon!: My lord of Orléans, and my Lord High Constable, you talk of horse and armor?
Goodbye!: You’re talking about horse and armor, my lord of Orléans, and my Lord High Constable.

Anon!: O, my fair cousin, I must not say so.
Goodbye!: Oh, my fair cousin, I can’t say that.

Anon!: O royal Caesar!
Goodbye!: Oh, royal Caesar!

Anon!: Come, Dolabella, see High order in this great solemnity.
Goodbye!: Come, Dolabella, see the high order in this great honor.

Anon!: Hear me, you wrangling pirates, that fall out In sharing that which you have pilled from me!
Goodbye!: Listen to me, you wrangling pirates, who fall out of sharing what you’ve pilled from me!

Anon!: I will go seek the king.
Goodbye!: I’ll go find the king.

Anon!: Farewell.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: Tis too late to go to bed now.
Goodbye!: It’s too late to go to bed now.

Anon!: Thy reason, man?
Goodbye!: What’s your reason, man?

Anon!: I was forbid it.
Goodbye!: I was forbid.

Anon!: I cannot tell.
Goodbye!: I don’t know.

Anon!: Let us go, For it is after midnight, and ere day We will awake him and be sure of him.
Goodbye!: Let’s go, because it’s after midnight, and if day comes, we’ll wake him up and be sure of him.

Anon!: Would that fault were mine!
Goodbye!: I wish I could do that!

Anon!: Didst thou not say he lied?
Goodbye!: Didn’t you say he lied?

Anon!: I know not, sir.
Goodbye!: I don’t know, sir.

Anon!: What noise is that?
Goodbye!: What’s that noise?

Anon!: And trust me, love, in my eye so do you.
Goodbye!: And trust me, love, you do.

Anon!: We came hither to fight with you.
Goodbye!: We came here to fight with you.

Anon!: To feed were best at home; From thence, the sauce to meat is ceremony; Meeting were bare without it.
Goodbye!: The best way to feed were at home; from there, the sauce to meat is a ceremony; the meeting was bare without it.

Anon!: Ay, let the county take you in your bed.
Goodbye!: Yes, let the Count take you in your bed.

Anon!: Thus far with rough and all-unable pen Our bending author hath pursued the story, In little room confining mighty men, Mangling by starts the full course of their glory.
Goodbye!: Our bending author has sat down with a rough and unable pen to tell the story, in a little room surrounded by mighty men, and sneezing by their glory.

Anon!: Thou didst promise To bate me a full year.
Goodbye!: You promised to give me a full year.

Anon!: And that distilled by magic sleights Shall raise such artificial sprites As by the strength of their illusion Shall draw him on to his confusion.
Goodbye!: And those distilled by magic sleights will raise such artificial sprites as they will draw him to confusion.

Anon!: They told me I was everything.
Goodbye!: They told me I was everything.

Anon!: I thank God, I thank God!
Goodbye!: Thank God, thank God!

Anon!: Give me your hand first.
Goodbye!: Give me your hand first.

Anon!: I know that, but I would have thee hence and here again.
Goodbye!: I know that, but I want you to go back and forth.

Anon!: As far, my lord, as will fill up the time 'Twixt this and supper.
Goodbye!: As far as I can go, my lord, as I’ll fill up the time for this and supper.

Anon!: Did he take interest?
Goodbye!: Did he take interest?

Anon!: Ay, you have been a mouse-hunt in your time, But I will watch you from such watching now.
Goodbye!: Yes, you’ve been a mouse hunter in your time, but I’ll watch you out now.

Anon!: Th' abuse of greatness is when it disjoins Remorse from power.
Goodbye!: Your greatness is abused when it disintegrates Remorse from power.

Anon!: Despise me If I do not.
Goodbye!: Don’t shame me if I don’t.

Anon!: Do you hear?
Goodbye!: Do you hear that?

Anon!: Yet he looks successfully.
Goodbye!: But he looks good.

Anon!: Whence came you, sir?
Goodbye!: When did you come, sir?

Anon!: Sweet, sweet, sweet Nurse, tell me, what says my love?
Goodbye!: Sweet, sweet, sweet Nurse, tell me, what does my love say?

Anon!: And she’s obedient, as you say, obedient, Very obedient.—Proceed you in your tears.— Concerning this, sir—Oh, well-painted passion!— I am commanded home.—Get you away, I’ll send for you anon.—Sir, I obey the mandate And will return to Venice.—Hence, avaunt!
Goodbye!: And she’s obedient, as you say, obedient, very obedient.—Proceed you in your tears.—I’m commanded home to do this.—Get away, I

Anon!: Romeo slew Tybalt.
Goodbye!: Romeo killed Tybalt.

Anon!: Casca, by your voice.
Goodbye!: Casca, by your voice.

Anon!: You have not seen such a thing as ’tis.
Goodbye!: You haven’t seen anything like that.

Anon!: Call him hither to me, soldier.
Goodbye!: Call him here to me, soldier.

Anon!: What’s your pleasure, sir?
Goodbye!: What do you want, sir?

Anon!: Tis he that sends us to destroy you here.
Goodbye!: It’s the man who sends us to destroy you here.

Anon!: Their names are pricked.
Goodbye!: Their names are snuck.

Anon!: Come, come away.
Goodbye!: Come on, come away.

Anon!: Out on thee, seeming!
Goodbye!: Look out at you, look!

Anon!: And so am I, being else by faith enforced To call young Claudio to a reckoning for it.
Goodbye!: And I am, because I’m obligated to call young Claudio to a reckoning for it.

Anon!: Follow me not.
Goodbye!: Don’t follow me.

Anon!: Madam, if you could find out but a man To bear a poison, I would temper it, That Romeo should, upon receipt thereof, Soon sleep in quiet.
Goodbye!: Madam, if you could find a man who bears a poison, I’d temper it so that Romeo should sleep quietly soon.

Anon!: God buy you, take mine office.
Goodbye!: Please, take my job.

Anon!: Name them.
Goodbye!: Name them.

Anon!: Then will I lay the serving creature’s dagger on your pate.
Goodbye!: Then I’ll lay the servant creature’s dagger on your pate.

Anon!: The clock struck nine when I did send the Nurse.
Goodbye!: The clock struck nine when I sent the Nurse.

Anon!: If you do fight in safeguard of your wives, Your wives shall welcome home the conquerors.
Goodbye!: If you fight to protect your wives, your wives will welcome home the conquerors.

Anon!: Did not you speak?
Goodbye!: Didn’t you speak?

Anon!: Holds it true, sir, that the Duke of Cornwall was so slain?
Goodbye!: Is it true, sir, that the Duke of Cornwall was killed so badly?

Anon!: Self-harming jealousy, fie, beat it hence.
Goodbye!: I’m jealous of you, savage, beat it down.

Anon!: Treason!
Goodbye!: Treason!

Anon!: Tis no time to play now.
Goodbye!: It’s not time to play.

Anon!: But wherefore did you so much tempt the heavens?
Goodbye!: But why did you tempt the heavens so much?

Anon!: Why then, the beef, and let the mustard rest.
Goodbye!: Then let the beef rest and let the mustard rest.

Anon!: Your houses!
Goodbye!: Your houses!

Anon!: He’s that he is.
Goodbye!: He’s the one he is.

Anon!: I did never know so full a voice issue from so empty a heart.
Goodbye!: I never knew so much about a voice issue from such a empty heart.

Anon!: Be thou my witness that against my will, As Pompey was, am I compelled to set Upon one battle all our liberties.
Goodbye!: You’re my witness that I’m compelled to fight all our freedoms against my will, as Pompey was.

Anon!: Troth, no, no more than reason.
Goodbye!: No, no more than reason.

Anon!: Canidius, Our nineteen legions thou shalt hold by land, And our twelve thousand horse.
Goodbye!: Canidius, our nineteen legions will be held by land, and our twelve thousand horse.

Anon!: Wherefore weep I then?
Goodbye!: Why do you cry then?

Anon!: I know what reason I have to think so: if thou shouldst not be glad, I would divorce me from thy mother’s tomb, Sepulchring an adultress.
Goodbye!: I know what reason I think so.

Anon!: Romeo, Romeo, Romeo!
Goodbye!: Romeo, Romeo, Romeo!

Anon!: What did you mean by that same handkerchief you gave me even now?
Goodbye!: What did you mean by that handkerchief you gave me now?

Anon!: Open, locks, Whoever knocks.
Goodbye!: Open the door, locks, whoever knocks.

Anon!: What would you, Desdemona?
Goodbye!: What do you want, Desdemona?

Anon!: Yet I should kill thee with much cherishing.
Goodbye!: But I’d kill you with a lot of love.

Anon!: Where is thy luster now?
Goodbye!: Where’s your luster now?

Anon!: Make peace with God, for you must die, my lord.
Goodbye!: Be quiet with God, because you have to die, my lord.

Anon!: Wherefore?
Goodbye!: Why?

Anon!: Let no such man be trusted.
Goodbye!: Don’t trust any man like that.

Anon!: This is the indictment of the good Lord Hastings, Which in a set hand fairly is engrossed, That it may be today read o'er in Paul’s.
Goodbye!: This is the indictment of the good Lord Hastings, which is engrossed in a fair way, so that it can be read in Paul’s today.

Anon!: If it will please Caesar To be so good to Caesar as to hear me, I shall beseech him to befriend himself.
Goodbye!: If it will please Caesar to be so good to Caesar as to hear me, I’ll ask him to befriend himself.

Anon!: He that is giddy thinks the world turns round”— I pray you, tell me what you meant by that.
Goodbye!: I beg you, tell me what you mean by that.

Anon!: If I gave them all my living, I’d keep my coxcombs myself.
Goodbye!: If I gave them all my life, I’d keep my coxcombs myself.

Anon!: I was of late as petty to his ends As is the morn-dew on the myrtle leaf To his grand sea.
Goodbye!: I was as petty to his ends as the morn-dew on the myrtle leaf to his grand sea.

Anon!: I see two husbands, or mine eyes deceive me.
Goodbye!: I see two husbands, or my eyes fool me.

Anon!: Rogue, thou hast lived too long.
Goodbye!: Rogue, you’ve lived too long.

Anon!: Nay, that he did not.
Goodbye!: No, he didn’t.

Anon!: Come on.
Goodbye!: Come on.

Anon!: No, no, they would not.
Goodbye!: No, no, they wouldn’t.

Anon!: He, that Caliban Whom now I keep in service.
Goodbye!: He, Caliban, who’s now in service.

Anon!: Why, here he comes, swelling like a turkey-cock.
Goodbye!: Here he comes, swelling like a turkey-cock.

Anon!: The king hath strictly charged the contrary.
Goodbye!: The king has strictly accused the contrary.

Anon!: So indeed he did.
Goodbye!: That’s true.

Anon!: Her eyes are fierce, but thine Do comfort and not burn.
Goodbye!: Her eyes are fierce, but you’re comforting and not burning.

Anon!: O Margaret, Margaret, now thy heavy curse Is lighted on poor Hastings' wretched head.
Goodbye!: Oh Margaret, Margaret, now your curse is lighted on the poor Hastings wretched head.

Anon!: But while I say one prayer!
Goodbye!: But while I say one prayer!

Anon!: Let the great gods That keep this dreadful pudder o'er our heads Find out their enemies now.
Goodbye!: Let the great gods who keep this terrible pudder on our heads find out their enemies now.

Anon!: I pray you, husband, be not so disquiet.
Goodbye!: Please, husband, don’t be so upset.

Anon!: Where is my lord of Gloucester?
Goodbye!: Where is Gloucester?

Anon!: But I perceive in you so excellent a touch of modesty that you will not extort from me what I am willing to keep in.
Goodbye!: But I see you as so modest that you won’t get anything from me that I’m willing to keep in.

Anon!: Tis strange.
Goodbye!: It’s strange.

Anon!: Desist, and drink.
Goodbye!: Stop, and drink.

Anon!: What a pied ninny’s this!—Thou scurvy patch!— I do beseech thy greatness, give him blows And take his bottle from him.
Goodbye!: What a ninny this is!—You scurvy patch!—I beg your greatness, give him blows and take his bottle from him.

Anon!: And they are gone.
Goodbye!: And they’re gone.

Anon!: Good sooth, even thus.
Goodbye!: Good sooth, even so.

Anon!: Lead me to my chamber.
Goodbye!: Lead me to my room.

Anon!: She thanked me And bade me, if I had a friend that loved her, I should but teach him how to tell my story And that would woo her.
Goodbye!: She thanked me and told me that if I had a friend who loved her, I would only teach him how to tell my story and that would woo her.

Anon!: Where is my Romeo?
Goodbye!: Where is my Romeo?

Anon!: O, what a fall was there, my countrymen!
Goodbye!: Oh, what a fall there was, my countrymen!

Anon!: And cross-gartered?
Goodbye!: And cross-gartered?

Anon!: How comes it?
Goodbye!: How is it?

Anon!: Now, Roderigo, Where didst thou see her?—Oh, unhappy girl!— With the Moor, say’st thou?—Who would be a father?— How didst thou know ’twas she?—Oh, she deceives me Past thought!—What said she to you?—Get more tapers, Raise all my kindred.
Goodbye!: Now, Roderigo, where did you see her?—Oh, unhappy girl!—With the Moor, say you?—Who would be a father?—How did you know she was?—Oh, she de

Anon!: Fare thee well.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: Do you confess the bond?
Goodbye!: Do you confess the contract?

Anon!: It is very hot.
Goodbye!: It’s very hot.

Anon!: Holy Saint Francis, what a change is here!
Goodbye!: Holy Saint Francis, what a change this is!

Anon!: Should you do so, my lord, My speech should fall into such vile success Which my thoughts aimed not at.
Goodbye!: If you do that, my lord, my speech should be so bad that I didn’t think about it.

Anon!: Slid, I’ll after him again and beat him.
Goodbye!: Slid, I’ll follow him again and beat him.

Anon!: No, dear Queen, For we intend so to dispose you as Yourself shall give us counsel.
Goodbye!: No, dear Queen, because we intend to dispose of you as you will advise us.

Anon!: Strike not by land; keep whole.
Goodbye!: Don’t fight by land; keep whole.

Anon!: O me!
Goodbye!: Oh, my!

Anon!: Yet thou didst kill my children.
Goodbye!: But you killed my children.

Anon!: Ay.
Goodbye!: Yes.

Anon!: tis a lost fear.
Goodbye!: It’s a lost fear.

Anon!: The curfew bell hath rung.
Goodbye!: The bell has rung.

Anon!: He had one yesterday.
Goodbye!: He had one yesterday.

Anon!: They shouted thrice.
Goodbye!: They shouted three times.

Anon!: Masters, let him go.
Goodbye!: Go ahead, my lord.

Anon!: It is no matter.
Goodbye!: It doesn’t matter.

Anon!: Where is the king?
Goodbye!: Where is the king?

Anon!: Will he bring his power?
Goodbye!: Will he bring his power?

Anon!: Welcome, my lord.
Goodbye!: Welcome, my lord.

Anon!: Even now we housed him in the abbey here, And now he’s there, past thought of human reason.
Goodbye!: We’ve housed him in the abbey here, and now he’s there, thinking about human reason.

Anon!: I’ll follow it.
Goodbye!: I’ll follow it.

Anon!: Is that the meaning of “accost”?
Goodbye!: Is that the meaning of “accost”?

Anon!: But oh, how oddly will it sound that I Must ask my child forgiveness!
Goodbye!: But oh, how odd it will sound that I have to ask my child forgiveness!

Anon!: God in heaven bless her!
Goodbye!: God in heaven bless her!

Anon!: I am sorry for thee.
Goodbye!: I’m sorry for you.

Anon!: Oh, make an end Of what I have begun!
Goodbye!: Oh, let’s end what I’ve begun!

Anon!: I am he.
Goodbye!: I’m him.

Anon!: I have an interest in your hearts' proceeding.
Goodbye!: I’m interested in your actions.

Anon!: Up, my lords.
Goodbye!: Up, my lords.

Anon!: If thou wilt lend this money, lend it not As to thy friends, for when did friendship take A breed for barren metal of his friend?
Goodbye!: If you want to lend this money, don’t lend it to your friends, because when did friendship take a breed for a barren metal from his friend?

Anon!: Faith, the priest was good enough, for all the old gentleman’s saying.
Goodbye!: Yes, the priest was good enough for all the old gentleman’s saying.

Anon!: No.
Goodbye!: No.

Anon!: Oh, here it is.
Goodbye!: Oh, here it is.

Anon!: Go you before, and I will follow you.
Goodbye!: Go ahead, and I’ll follow you.

Anon!: Our course will seem too bloody, Caius Cassius, To cut the head off and then hack the limbs, Like wrath in death and envy afterwards, For Antony is but a limb of Caesar.
Goodbye!: Caius Cassius, we’ll seem too bloody to cut off the head and then hack the limbs, like death and envy, because Antony is only a limb of Caesar.

Anon!: Find thou the means, and I’ll find such a man.
Goodbye!: Find out the way, and I’ll find a man like that.

Anon!: Come, what says Romeo?
Goodbye!: Come on, what does Romeo say?

Anon!: I will discharge thee ere I go from thee.
Goodbye!: I’ll leave you before I leave you.

Anon!: Say either, and I’ll stay the circumstance.
Goodbye!: Say either, and I’ll keep the situation.

Anon!: Let me see, let me see.
Goodbye!: Let me see, let me see.

Anon!: Is she not a modest young lady?
Goodbye!: Isn’t she a modest young lady?

Anon!: Nothing, good monsieur, but to help Cavalery Cobweb to scratch.
Goodbye!: Nothing, good monsieur, but to help Cavalery Cobweb to scratch.

Anon!: By mine honor I will, and when I break that oath, let me turn monster.
Goodbye!: I will, and when I break that oath, let me turn into a monster.

Anon!: What is yond gentleman?
Goodbye!: What do you mean by gentleman?

Anon!: His speech was like a tangled chain.
Goodbye!: His speech was like a tangled chain.

Anon!: An if your wife be not a madwoman, And know how well I have deserved the ring, She would not hold out enemy forever For giving it to me.
Goodbye!: If your wife isn’t a madwoman, and you know how well I deserve the ring, she wouldn’t hold out the enemy forever for giving it to me.

Anon!: That’s not an office for a friend, my lord.
Goodbye!: That’s not a job for a friend, my lord.

Anon!: But shall we wear these glories for a day, Or shall they last and we rejoice in them?
Goodbye!: But should we wear these glories for a day, or should they last and we rejoice in them?

Anon!: He will to his Egyptian dish again.
Goodbye!: He’ll go back to his Egyptian dish.

Anon!: I hear none, madam.
Goodbye!: I don’t hear anything, madam.

Anon!: I would thou wert so happy by thy stay To hear true shrift.—Come, madam, let’s away.
Goodbye!: I wish you were so happy by your stay to hear true shrift.—Come, madam, let’s go.

Anon!: Take him hence.
Goodbye!: Take him away.

Anon!: Why, or for what, the nobles were committed Is all unknown to me, my gracious lord.
Goodbye!: Why, or what, the nobles were committed is not my fault, my gracious lord.

Anon!: Couch we a while and mark.
Goodbye!: We’ll be back for a while.

Anon!: Why, there’s more gold.
Goodbye!: There’s more gold.

Anon!: I pray you tell me your remedy.
Goodbye!: Please tell me your remedy.

Anon!: Said he not so?
Goodbye!: Didn’t he say that?

Anon!: And, gentle master, I received no gold.
Goodbye!: And, gentle master, I didn’t receive any gold.

Anon!: Why, every day, tomorrow.
Goodbye!: Every day, tomorrow.

Anon!: Go, bind this man, for he is frantic too.
Goodbye!: Go, bind this man, because he’s frantic too.

Anon!: Nay, he rubs himself with civet.
Goodbye!: No, he’s rubbing himself with civet.

Anon!: O Kate, nice customs curtsy to great kings.
Goodbye!: Oh Kate, nice customs are a slur for great kings.

Anon!: And if you leave me so, you do me wrong.
Goodbye!: And if you leave me like that, you’re wrong.

Anon!: Sir Topas!
Goodbye!: Sir Topas!

Anon!: Tranio, let’s go.
Goodbye!: Tranio, let’s go.

Anon!: Her husband, sirrah?
Goodbye!: Her husband, sir?

Anon!: Thou art a boil, A plague-sore or embossèd carbuncle In my corrupted blood.
Goodbye!: You’re a boil, a plague-sore or embossing carbuncle in my corrupted blood.

Anon!: Th' occasion speaks thee, and My strong imagination sees a crown Dropping upon thy head.
Goodbye!: It’s a good occasion, and my imagination sees a crown dropping on your head.

Anon!: She’s dead, she’s dead, she’s dead!
Goodbye!: She’s dead, she’s dead, she’s dead!

Anon!: Contemning Rome, he has done all this and more In Alexandria.
Goodbye!: Contemning Rome, he’s done all this and more in Alexandria.

Anon!: Tyranny is dead!
Goodbye!: Tyranny is dead!

Anon!: Oh, let us yet be merciful.
Goodbye!: Oh, let’s be merciful.

Anon!: Lay on, Macduff, And damned be him that first cries, “Hold, enough!” I would the friends we miss were safe arrived.
Goodbye!: Lay on, Macduff, and damn him who first cried, “Hold, enough!” I wish the friends we miss were safe.

Anon!: I think it is not meet Mark Antony, so well beloved of Caesar, Should outlive Caesar.
Goodbye!: I think Mark Antony, so beloved by Caesar, shouldn’t be able to survive Caesar.

Anon!: O woeful day, O woeful day!
Goodbye!: Oh, sad day, sad day!

Anon!: Didst perceive?
Goodbye!: Did you see?

Anon!: I meddle with no tradesman’s matters nor women’s matters, but withal I am indeed, sir, a surgeon to old shoes.
Goodbye!: I’m not a tradesman or a woman, but I’m a surgeon to old shoes, sir.

Anon!: Tis certain, every man that dies ill, the ill upon his own head.
Goodbye!: It’s certain that every man dies ill, the ill on his own head.

Anon!: I will.
Goodbye!: I will.

Anon!: But in this case of wooing, A child shall get a sire, if I fail not of my cunning.
Goodbye!: But in this case of wooing, a child will get a sire if I don’t fail to do my cunning.

Anon!: Yet his means are in supposition.
Goodbye!: But his plans are in the works.

Anon!: Do not bid me speak.
Goodbye!: Don’t ask me to speak.

Anon!: Why, thou sayst well.
Goodbye!: Well, you’re right.

Anon!: By th' clock ’tis day, And yet dark night strangles the travelling lamp.
Goodbye!: By the clock it’s day, and dark night still strangles the lamp.

Anon!: Nay, then, good night our part.
Goodbye!: No, then, good night for us.

Anon!: A marvelous witty fellow, I assure you, but I will go about with him.—Come you hither, sirrah, a word in your ear.
Goodbye!: I’ll go with him.—Come here, sir, and let me say a word in your ear.

Anon!: Was ’t not the way?
Goodbye!: Wasn’t it the way?

Anon!: Then the liars and swearers are fools, for there are liars and swearers enough to beat the honest men and hang up them.
Goodbye!: Then the liars and swearers are fools, because there are enough liars and swearers to beat the honest men and hang them up.

Anon!: Brother, ho!
Goodbye!: Brother, ho!

Anon!: And will you rent our ancient love asunder To join with men in scorning your poor friend?
Goodbye!: And will you rent our ancient love asunder to join men in slandering your poor friend?

Anon!: Let them curtsy with their left legs, and not presume to touch a hair of my master’s horse-tail till they kiss their hands.
Goodbye!: Let them curl with their left legs, and don’t presume to touch a hair from my master’s horse-tail until they kiss their hands.

Anon!: This man said, sir, that Don John, the Prince’s brother, was a villain.
Goodbye!: This man said, sir, that Don John, the Prince’s brother, was a villain.

Anon!: Well, in that hit you miss.
Goodbye!: Well, you’re missing out on that hit.

Anon!: Though news be sad, yet tell them merrily.
Goodbye!: Even though news is sad, tell them merrily.

Anon!: If I do die before thee, prithee, shroud me In one of these same sheets.
Goodbye!: If I die before you, please, shroude me in one of these same sheets.

Anon!: What, a feast, a feast?
Goodbye!: What, a feast, a feast?

Anon!: Knock, I say.
Goodbye!: Knock, I say.

Anon!: How answer you for yourselves?
Goodbye!: How do you answer for yourself?

Anon!: I beseech you, follow straight.
Goodbye!: Please, follow straight.

Anon!: No doubt, my liege, if each man do his best.
Goodbye!: No doubt, my liege, if each man does his best.

Anon!: My lord is often thus And hath been from his youth.
Goodbye!: My lord is often so, and he’s been from his youth.

Anon!: You say you are a better soldier.
Goodbye!: You say you’re a better soldier.

Anon!: I do not know dat.
Goodbye!: I don’t know dat.

Anon!: The round world Should have shook lions into civil streets And citizens to their dens.
Goodbye!: The round world would have shook lions into civil streets and shook citizens to their dens.

Anon!: I warrant you, sir, The white cold virgin snow upon my heart Abates the ardor of my liver.
Goodbye!: I assure you, sir, that the cold, virgin snow on my heart is a slander on my liver.

Anon!: My lord and lady, it is now our time, That have stood by and seen our wishes prosper, To cry, “Good joy, good joy, my lord and lady!” My Lord Bassanio and my gentle lady, I wish you all the joy that you can wish, For I am sure you can wish none from me.
Goodbye!: My lord and lady, it’s now our time to cry, “Good joy, good joy, my lord and lady!” My Lord Bassanio and my gentle lady, I wish you all the joy that you can

Anon!: I will kiss thy lips.
Goodbye!: I’ll kiss your lips.

Anon!: I think the policy of that purpose made more in the marriage than the love of the parties.
Goodbye!: I think the purpose of that marriage is more important than the love of the parties.

Anon!: But yet thou art my flesh, my blood, my daughter— Or rather a disease that’s in my flesh, Which I must needs call mine.
Goodbye!: But you’re my flesh, my blood, my daughter— Or rather a disease that’s in my flesh, which I must call mine.

Anon!: Our separation so abides and flies That thou, residing here, goes yet with me, And I, hence fleeting, here remain with thee.
Goodbye!: Our separation is so long and flies that you, who live here, are still with me, and I, hence fleeting, here remain with you.

Anon!: Yet I have not seen So likely an ambassador of love.
Goodbye!: But I haven’t seen a ambassador of love so likely.

Anon!: I promise you I scarcely know myself.
Goodbye!: I promise you I don’t know myself.

Anon!: Soft stillness and the night Become the touches of sweet harmony.
Goodbye!: Stillness and nighttime are the touches of sweet harmony.

Anon!: Honest Nurse, farewell.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, Nurse.

Anon!: I have a daughter, sir, called Katherina.
Goodbye!: I have a daughter called Katherina, sir.

Anon!: Drown thyself?
Goodbye!: Drown yourself?

Anon!: I did not think to draw my sword ’gainst Pompey, For he hath laid strange courtesies and great Of late upon me.
Goodbye!: I didn’t think I would draw my sword against Pompey, because he has snorely defended me and defended me.

Anon!: Hail, brave friend!
Goodbye!: Hail, brave friend!

Anon!: Is Cassius near?
Goodbye!: Is Cassius near?

Anon!: Had we fought, I doubt we should have been too young for them.
Goodbye!: If we had fought, I’d have thought we’d be too young for them.

Anon!: I have a wife, whom I protest I love.
Goodbye!: I have a wife I’m angry I love.

Anon!: Nay, an you be so tardy, come no more in my sight.
Goodbye!: If you’re so late, don’t come to see me again.

Anon!: Mark Antony— Pardon me, Caius Cassius.
Goodbye!: Mark Antony— Pardon me, Caius Cassius.

Anon!: It was, so please your highness.
Goodbye!: It was, please your highness.

Anon!: What is this same?
Goodbye!: What’s this?

Anon!: Is it two days ago since I tripped up thy heels and beat thee before the king?
Goodbye!: Is it two days ago that I tripped your heels up and beat you before the king?

Anon!: By my troth, I am sick.
Goodbye!: I swear, I’m sick.

Anon!: I could well wish courtesy would invent some other custom of entertainment.
Goodbye!: I wish I could have a good friend to create some other entertainment style.

Anon!: The glove which I have given him for a favor May haply purchase him a box o' th' ear.
Goodbye!: I’ve given him a glove that I’ve given him to do a favor, and I’ll give him a box with a ear.

Anon!: But his flawed heart— Alack, too weak the conflict to support— 'Twixt two extremes of passion, joy and grief, Burst smilingly.
Goodbye!: But his flawed heart—alack, the conflict is too weak to support—twixt two extremes of passion, joy and grief, burst smiling.

Anon!: A contagious breath.
Goodbye!: A contagious breath.

Anon!: I have sent for these strawberries.
Goodbye!: I’ve sent for these strawberries.

Anon!: It goes not forward.
Goodbye!: It’s not going forward.

Anon!: God ye good e'en, fair gentlewoman.
Goodbye!: Good-bye, fair lady.

Anon!: How now, spirit?
Goodbye!: What’s going on, spirit?

Anon!: Wilt thou lift up Olympus?
Goodbye!: Will you lift Olympus up?

Anon!: Excellent good, i' faith.
Goodbye!: Good, I’m sure.

Anon!: None good, my liege, to please you with the hearing, Nor none so bad but well may be reported.
Goodbye!: No good, my liege, to please you with the hearing, and no bad news can be reported.

Anon!: Wherefore did they not That hour destroy us?
Goodbye!: Why didn’t they destroy us at that hour?

Anon!: What man art thou that, thus bescreened in night, So stumblest on my counsel?
Goodbye!: What man are you, who stumbles on my advice, so be screened in the night?

Anon!: What?
Goodbye!: What?

Anon!: For our bad neighbor makes us early stirrers, Which is both healthful and good husbandry.
Goodbye!: Our bad neighbor makes us early stirrers, which is both healthy and good for our husbands.

Anon!: Let me play the lion too.
Goodbye!: Let me play the lion too.

Anon!: There I shall see mine own figure.
Goodbye!: I’ll see my own figure there.

Anon!: Wherein went he?
Goodbye!: Where did he go?

Anon!: This, Casca.
Goodbye!: This is Casca.

Anon!: If any, speak—for him have I offended.
Goodbye!: If there are any, speak—for he has offended me.

Anon!: I will bite thee by the ear for that jest.
Goodbye!: I’ll bite you by the ear for that sneezing.

Anon!: But new struck nine.
Goodbye!: But new things have struck nine.

Anon!: He married but his occasion here.
Goodbye!: He only married here.

Anon!: Chid I for that at frugal Nature’s frame?
Goodbye!: Is that the nature’s frame frugal?

Anon!: Thou hast braved many men; brave not me.
Goodbye!: You’ve braved many men, but not me.

Anon!: What news?
Goodbye!: What news do you have?

Anon!: You have not been abed, then?
Goodbye!: You’ve been beaten up, then?

Anon!: It is a monster Begot upon itself, born on itself.
Goodbye!: It’s a monster that’s born on itself.

Anon!: I will die, And leave him all.
Goodbye!: I’ll die and leave him all.

Anon!: Hath Romeo slain himself?
Goodbye!: Has Romeo killed himself?

Anon!: Vex not his prescience.
Goodbye!: Don’t ignore his prescience.

Anon!: I was a fine fool to take it.
Goodbye!: I was a fine fool to take it.

Anon!: Most certain.
Goodbye!: Yes, I’m sure.

Anon!: Ha, ha!
Goodbye!: Ha, ha!

Anon!: That “may be” must be, love, on Thursday next.
Goodbye!: That “may be” must be, love, on Thursday.

Anon!: Their great guilt, Like poison given to work a great time after, Now 'gins to bite the spirits.
Goodbye!: Their great guilt, like poison given to work a great time afterward, has begun to bite the spirits.

Anon!: In Venice they do let God see the pranks They dare not show their husbands.
Goodbye!: In Venice, they let God see the pranks they dare not show their husbands.

Anon!: She is of so free, so kind, so apt, so blessed a disposition, she holds it a vice in her goodness not to do more than she is requested.
Goodbye!: She’s so kind, so kind, so apt, so blessed, she’s a good man, and she doesn’t want to do anything more than she wants.

Anon!: If you will live, lament.
Goodbye!: If you want to live, be sorry.

Anon!: Call not your stocks for me.
Goodbye!: Don’t call me your stocks.

Anon!: What a man are you?
Goodbye!: What kind of man are you?

Anon!: Enjoy thy plainness.
Goodbye!: Enjoy your plainness.

Anon!: Fare-well.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: Pray thee, corporal, stay.
Goodbye!: Please, corporal, stay.

Anon!: Give welcome to my friend.
Goodbye!: Please welcome my friend.

Anon!: And for the Jew’s bond which he hath of me, Let it not enter in your mind of love.
Goodbye!: And for the Jew’s bond he has with me, don’t let it be your love.

Anon!: They have said their prayers, and they stay for death.
Goodbye!: They’ve said their prayers, and they’re waiting for death.

Anon!: I do now let loose my opinion, hold it no longer: this is no fish, but an islander that hath lately suffered by a thunderbolt.
Goodbye!: I’m not saying anything anymore.

Anon!: Where is gentle Rivers, Vaughan, Grey?
Goodbye!: Where are gentle Rivers, Vaughan, Grey?

Anon!: Throw physic to the dogs; I’ll none of it.
Goodbye!: Throw physic to the dogs, I won’t do anything.

Anon!: Therefore let every man now task his thought, That this fair action may on foot be brought.
Goodbye!: So let every man think about it now so that he can take action on foot.

Anon!: Come, Dromio, come, these jests are out of season.
Goodbye!: Come, Dromio, come, these sneezes are out of season.

Anon!: First, I ask thee what they have done; thirdly, I ask thee what’s their offense; sixth and lastly, why they are committed; and, to conclude, what you lay to their charge.
Goodbye!: First, I ask you what they’ve done, thirdly, I ask you what they’ve done, sixth and lastly, why they’ve committed it, and, to conclude, what you’re doing to their charge.

Anon!: I thank you, madam.
Goodbye!: Thank you, madam.

Anon!: He, for his father’s sake, so loves the prince That he will not be won to aught against him.
Goodbye!: He loves the prince so much for his father’s sake that he won’t be won to fight him.

Anon!: His hour is almost past.
Goodbye!: He’s almost finished.

Anon!: Wednesday is tomorrow.
Goodbye!: Wednesday is tomorrow.

Anon!: What cheer?
Goodbye!: What cheer?

Anon!: Let us on heaps go offer up our lives.
Goodbye!: Let’s go offer up our lives on heaps.

Anon!: Some of my shame, if you will know of me What man I am, and how, and why, and where This handkercher was stained.
Goodbye!: I’ll be ashamed, if you know what I am, how, why, and where this handkerchief was stained.

Anon!: Humbly, sir, I thank you.
Goodbye!: Dear, sir, thank you.

Anon!: I will not stay tonight for all the town.
Goodbye!: I won’t stay tonight for all the town.

Anon!: Do so.
Goodbye!: Do so.

Anon!: Thou dost talk nothing to me.
Goodbye!: You don’t talk to me.

Anon!: But, Roderigo, if thou hast that in thee indeed, which I have greater reason to believe now than ever—I mean purpose, courage and valor—this night show it.
Goodbye!: But Roderigo, if you have something in you, I have more reason to believe than ever—I mean purpose, courage and valor—this night will show it.

Anon!: Love news, in faith?
Goodbye!: Love news, in faith?

Anon!: I mean, the Lord Protector.
Goodbye!: I mean, the Lord Protector.

Anon!: I know you not.
Goodbye!: I don’t know you.

Anon!: An they be not, let them hang themselves in their own straps.
Goodbye!: If they aren’t, let them hang themselves in their own straps.

Anon!: Hail, most dear Caesar!
Goodbye!: Hail, dear Caesar!

Anon!: You know me by my habit.
Goodbye!: You know me by my habit.

Anon!: Ay.
Goodbye!: Yes.

Anon!: O, yet defend me, friends.
Goodbye!: Oh, defend me, friends.

Anon!: Ay, marry, now unmuzzle your wisdom.
Goodbye!: Yes, you’re a fool.

Anon!: What o'clock tomorrow Shall I send to thee?
Goodbye!: What time tomorrow will I send you?

Anon!: Montjoy.
Goodbye!: Montjoy.

Anon!: How now, my pretty knave?
Goodbye!: What’s going on, my pretty king?

Anon!: Within this hour it will be dinnertime.
Goodbye!: Within an hour it’ll be dinnertime.

Anon!: The time was once when thou unurged wouldst vow That never words were music to thine ear, That never object pleasing in thine eye, That never touch well welcome to thy hand, That never meat sweet-savored in thy taste, Unless I spake, or looked, or touched, or carved to thee.
Goodbye!: It was once when you would vow that never words were music to your ear, that never object pleasing to your eye, that never touch well to your hand, that never meat sweet-savored in your taste, unless I

Anon!: Where is Lucentio?
Goodbye!: Where is Lucentio?

Anon!: You would all this time have proved there is no time for all things.
Goodbye!: You would have been able to prove that there isn’t time for everything.

Anon!: Speak not of Helena.
Goodbye!: Don’t speak of Helena.

Anon!: For the best turn i’ th’ bed.
Goodbye!: For the best time, turn your bed.

Anon!: I will discharge it in either your straw-color beard, your orange-tawny beard, your purple-in-grain beard, or your French crown-color beard, your perfect yellow.
Goodbye!: I’ll leave it in either your straw-colored beard, your orange-tawny beard, your purple-in-grain beard, or your French crown-colored beard, your perfect yellow beard

Anon!: Soft!
Goodbye!: Get out of here!

Anon!: Crown him that, And then I grant we put a sting in him That at his will he may do danger with.
Goodbye!: Tell him that, and then I grant we put a sting on him so he can be in danger.

Anon!: Ay, marry, is ’t.
Goodbye!: Yes, it’s marriage.

Anon!: Why, this that I speak of.
Goodbye!: Why, I’m talking about this.

Anon!: Well-a-day that you were, sir.
Goodbye!: You were well-a-day, sir.

Anon!: It may be, these apparent prodigies, The unaccustomed terror of this night, And the persuasion of his augurers May hold him from the Capitol today.
Goodbye!: It may be that these apparent prodigies, the unaccustomed terror of this night, and the persuasion of his augurers may hold him out of the Capitol today.

Anon!: Where have you this?
Goodbye!: Where are you?

Anon!: See where they come.
Goodbye!: See where they come.

Anon!: O woeful, woeful, woeful day!
Goodbye!: Oh, sad, sad day!

Anon!: Think not, thou noble Roman, That ever Brutus will go bound to Rome.
Goodbye!: Don’t think that Brutus will ever go to Rome.

Anon!: Here’s sport indeed!
Goodbye!: Yes, here’s a sport!

Anon!: Here is everything advantageous to life.
Goodbye!: Here’s everything that’s beneficial to life.

Anon!: It is too hard a knot for me to untie!
Goodbye!: It’s too hard for me to knot a knot!

Anon!: Look, here it is.
Goodbye!: Look, here it is.

Anon!: Yet again?
Goodbye!: And again?

Anon!: His captain’s heart, Which in the scuffles of great fights hath burst The buckles on his breast, reneges all temper And is become the bellows and the fan To cool a gypsy’s lust.
Goodbye!: His captain’s heart has burst in the scuffles of great fights, reneges all temper and becomes the bellows and fan to cool a gypsy’s lust.

Anon!: Some men there are love not a gaping pig, Some that are mad if they behold a cat, And others, when the bagpipe sings i' th' nose, Cannot contain their urine.
Goodbye!: Some men there are not lovers of a gaping pig, some who are crazy if they see a cat, and others, when the bagpipe sings in the nose, can’t contain their urine.

Anon!: From top to toe?
Goodbye!: From top to toe?

Anon!: If I dream not, thou art Emilia.
Goodbye!: If I don’t dream, you’re Emilia.

Anon!: If you do sorrow at my grief in love, By giving love your sorrow and my grief Were both extermined.
Goodbye!: If you’re sad about my grief in love, you’re both exterminated by giving love.

Anon!: Of all the wonders that I yet have heard, It seems to me most strange that men should fear, Seeing that death, a necessary end, Will come when it will come.
Goodbye!: I’m very strange that men fear death, a necessary end, when it comes.

Anon!: Yare, yare, good Iras, quick.
Goodbye!: Yare, yare, good Iras, quick.

Anon!: What’s your will?
Goodbye!: What do you want?

Anon!: Do you not hear, fellows?
Goodbye!: Don’t you hear anything, fellows?

Anon!: I have as much of my father in me as you, albeit, I confess, your coming before me is nearer to his reverence.
Goodbye!: I have as much of my father in me as you, though I admit you’re closer to his reverence.

Anon!: Welcome, my lord.
Goodbye!: Welcome, my lord.

Anon!: Ay, but when?
Goodbye!: Yes, but when?

Anon!: This casket threatens.
Goodbye!: This casecase is in danger.

Anon!: A grandam’s name is little less in love Than is the doting title of a mother.
Goodbye!: A grandam’s name is little less in love than a mother’s title.

Anon!: I know, sir, I am no flatterer.
Goodbye!: I know, sir, I’m not flattering.

Anon!: Alack, I love myself.
Goodbye!: Oh, I love myself.

Anon!: Give me some music.
Goodbye!: Give me some music.

Anon!: Grandam, his nurse.
Goodbye!: Grandam, his nurse.

Anon!: In this slumbery agitation, besides her walking and other actual performances, what, at any time, have you heard her say?
Goodbye!: What have you heard her say in this slumbery, out of walking and other real performances, at any time?

Anon!: Madam, your mother craves a word with you.
Goodbye!: Madam, your mother wants to speak with you.

Anon!: How am I then a villain To counsel Cassio to this parallel course, Directly to his good?
Goodbye!: How am I a villain to counsel Cassio on this parallel course, directly to his good?

Anon!: I pray you and beseech you that you will.
Goodbye!: Please, and please, that you will.

Anon!: Now am I Dromio, and his man, unbound.
Goodbye!: Now I’m Dromio and his man, unbound.

Anon!: And I for Ganymede.
Goodbye!: And I for Ganymede.

Anon!: I did love you once.
Goodbye!: I loved you once.

Anon!: Henceforth I’ll bear Affliction till it do cry out itself, “Enough, enough,” and die.
Goodbye!: I’ll be afffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffff

Anon!: Do you bite your thumb at us, sir?
Goodbye!: Do you bite your thumb at us?

Anon!: How may that be?
Goodbye!: How can that be?

Anon!: Caesar, thou canst not die by traitors' hands Unless thou bring’st them with thee.
Goodbye!: Caesar, you can’t die by traitors’ hands unless you bring them with you.

Anon!: Are you crept hither to see the wrestling?
Goodbye!: Are you crept here to see the wrestling?

Anon!: I never did her any, to my knowledge.
Goodbye!: I never did anything to her, I know.

Anon!: Still through the hawthorn blows the cold wind, says, “Suum, mun, nonny.” Dauphin my boy, my boy, cessez.
Goodbye!: The wind still blows through the hawthorn, saying, “Suum, mun, nonny.” Dauphin my boy, my boy, cessez.

Anon!: If this uncouth forest yield anything savage, I will either be food for it or bring it for food to thee.
Goodbye!: If this unnatural forest gives you anything savage, I’ll either be food for it or bring it to you.

Anon!: Then you are mad indeed, if you be no better in your wits than a fool.
Goodbye!: Then you’re insane, if you’re no better in your mind than a fool.

Anon!: I will fetch him.
Goodbye!: I’ll get him.

Anon!: Oh, fie!
Goodbye!: Oh, fie!

Anon!: O Romeo, Romeo!
Goodbye!: Oh, Romeo, Romeo!

Anon!: He says for Brutus' sake He finds himself beholding to us all.
Goodbye!: He says for Brutus’s sake he’s begging us all.

Anon!: Oh, behold How pomp is followed!
Goodbye!: Oh, see how pomp is followed!

Anon!: Thou hast described A hot friend cooling.
Goodbye!: You’ve described a hot friend cooling.

Anon!: This was a merry message.
Goodbye!: This was a merry message.

Anon!: Like one of two contending in a prize That thinks he hath done well in people’s eyes, Hearing applause and universal shout, Giddy in spirit, still gazing in a doubt Whether these pearls of praise be his or no— So, thrice fair lady, stand I even so, As doubtful whether what I see be true Until confirmed, signed, ratified by you.
Goodbye!: I’m standing as if I’m a good lady, as I’m doubtful whether anything I see is true until you’ve confirmed, signed, ratified.

Anon!: I’ll to dinner.
Goodbye!: I’ll go to dinner.

Anon!: Obey thy parents, keep thy word’s justice, swear not, commit not with man’s sworn spouse, set not thy sweet heart on proud array.
Goodbye!: Don’t swear, don’t commit with your spouse, don’t put your sweet heart on the table.

Anon!: Romeo, he cries aloud, “Hold, friends!
Goodbye!: Romeo, he cries, “Hold, friends!

Anon!: Kind sister, thanks.
Goodbye!: Dear sister, thanks.

Anon!: I know it is the moon.
Goodbye!: I know it’s the moon.

Anon!: peace, this piece of toasted cheese will do ’t.
Goodbye!: Peace, this piece of toasted cheese will do it.

Anon!: Once more, good night, kind lords and gentlemen.
Goodbye!: Again, good night, kind lords and gentlemen.

Anon!: But oh, poor Gloucester— Lost he his other eye?
Goodbye!: But oh, poor Gloucester— Did he lose his other eye?

Anon!: Fie!
Goodbye!: I’m sorry!

Anon!: Sir, you and I must part, but that’s not it.
Goodbye!: Sir, you and I must be part of the group, but that’s not it.

Anon!: Ay, good my lord.
Goodbye!: Yes, my lord.

Anon!: I hear some noise within.
Goodbye!: I hear some noise inside.

Anon!: O happy dagger, This is thy sheath.
Goodbye!: Oh, happy dagger, this is your sheath.

Anon!: Thus may we gather honey from the weed And make a moral of the devil himself.
Goodbye!: So we can get honey from the weed and make a moral decision of the devil himself.

Anon!: What though I killed her husband and her father?
Goodbye!: What if I killed her husband and her father?

Anon!: O villain!
Goodbye!: Oh, villain!

Anon!: Slay!
Goodbye!: Slay!

Anon!: Hop in his walks and gambol in his eyes.
Goodbye!: Hop in his walks and gambol in his eyes.

Anon!: I am a Jew.
Goodbye!: I’m a Jew.

Anon!: And the best of me is diligence.
Goodbye!: And the best thing about me is diligence.

Anon!: Stay, gentle Helena.
Goodbye!: Stay, gentle Helena.

Anon!: Fellow, come from the throng.
Goodbye!: Come from the throng, sir.

Anon!: What, my gracious lord?
Goodbye!: What, my gracious lord?

Anon!: Muffle me, night, awhile.
Goodbye!: Muffle me, night, for a while.

Anon!: Would that he were gone!
Goodbye!: I wish he were gone!

Anon!: My salad days, When I was green in judgment, cold in blood, To say as I said then.
Goodbye!: I was a green man, cold in blood, and a cold man.

Anon!: If that you were the good Sir Rowland’s son, As you have whispered faithfully you were, And as mine eye doth his effigies witness Most truly limned and living in your face, Be truly welcome hither.
Goodbye!: If you were Sir Rowland’s son, as you’ve whispered faithfully, and as my eyes see his effigies live in your face, be truly welcome here.

Anon!: Ay, boy, ready.
Goodbye!: Yes, boy, ready.

Anon!: Rebels it at these years?
Goodbye!: Is it a rebellion at these years?

Anon!: How many fond fools serve mad jealousy!
Goodbye!: How many fond fools serve mad jealousy!

Anon!: Peace!
Goodbye!: Quiet!

Anon!: I never saw a woman, But only Sycorax my dam and she.
Goodbye!: I never saw a woman, but I only saw Sycorax my dam and she.

Anon!: Yes.
Goodbye!: Yes.

Anon!: Tis well.
Goodbye!: It’s good.

Anon!: Soft, no haste.
Goodbye!: No, hurry.

Anon!: Friend Launcelot, what’s the news?
Goodbye!: Friend Launcelot, what’s the news?

Anon!: You kiss by th' book.
Goodbye!: You kiss by the book.

Anon!: The ox hath therefore stretched his yoke in vain, The ploughman lost his sweat, and the green corn Hath rotted ere his youth attained a beard.
Goodbye!: The ox has therefore stretched his yoke in vain, the sluggish man has lost his sweat, and the green corn has rotted before his youth has a beard.

Anon!: Be’st thou sad or merry, The violence of either thee becomes, So does it no man else.—Mett’st thou my posts?
Goodbye!: Are you sad or merry, either you’re being violent or no one else.—Do you have my posts?

Anon!: Certain, men should be what they seem.
Goodbye!: Certain, men should be what they seem.

Anon!: Tis a fault I will not change for your best virtue.
Goodbye!: I’ll never change your virtue for you.

Anon!: Farewell, farewell.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, goodbye.

Anon!: You are dull, Casca, and those sparks of life That should be in a Roman you do want, Or else you use not.
Goodbye!: You’re dull, Casca, and you’re wasting your life on the sparks of a Roman you want, or you don’t use them.

Anon!: No more.
Goodbye!: Don’t worry.

Anon!: All this is comfort.
Goodbye!: All this is comforting news.

Anon!: I do not like the office.
Goodbye!: I don’t like the job.

Anon!: Tis death for anyone in Mantua To come to Padua.
Goodbye!: It’s time for anyone in Mantua to come to Padua.

Anon!: That I beheld.
Goodbye!: I saw that.

Anon!: Woe, alas!
Goodbye!: Oh, sorry!

Anon!: Had you rather Caesar were living and die all slaves, than that Caesar were dead, to live all free men?
Goodbye!: If you wish you were all free men, and that Caesar were dead, and living free men?

Anon!: Ourself will mingle with society And play the humble host.
Goodbye!: We’ll mingle with the society and play the humble host.

Anon!: I would they’d fight i’ th’ fire or i’ th’ air, We’d fight there too.
Goodbye!: I wish they’d fight in the fire or in the air, we’d fight there too.

Anon!: If I can fasten but one cup upon him, With that which he hath drunk tonight already, He’ll be as full of quarrel and offense As my young mistress' dog.
Goodbye!: If I can only hold one cup on him, with the one he’s drunk tonight already, he’ll be as sane and offensive as my young mistress’s dog.

Anon!: Alas, I am the mother of these griefs.
Goodbye!: Alas, I’m the mother of these griefs.

Anon!: Remember’st thou any that have died on ’t?
Goodbye!: Do you remember anyone who died on it?

Anon!: The images of revolt and flying off.
Goodbye!: The images of rebellion and flying off.

Anon!: Either there is a civil strife in heaven, Or else the world, too saucy with the gods, Incenses them to send destruction.
Goodbye!: Either there’s a civil battle in heaven, or the world, too sane with the gods, encourages them to send destruction.

Anon!: Edward’s unhappy sons do bid thee flourish.
Goodbye!: Edward’s unhappy sons want you to flourish.

Anon!: Such have but a shadow’s bliss.
Goodbye!: Such a thing has a shadow’s bliss.

Anon!: Sweet Phoebe, pity me.
Goodbye!: Sweet Phoebe, please.

Anon!: Seest not?
Goodbye!: Don’t you see it?

Anon!: Nay, faith, let me not play a woman.
Goodbye!: No, please, don’t let me play a woman.

Anon!: But I will write again to Mantua, And keep her at my cell till Romeo come.
Goodbye!: But I’ll write again to Mantua, and keep her in my cell until Romeo comes.

Anon!: Good Enobarbus, ’tis a worthy deed, And shall become you well, to entreat your captain To soft and gentle speech.
Goodbye!: Good Enobarbus, it’s a worthy deed, and it’ll become you well, to encourage your captain to speak softly and quietly.

Anon!: Thou canst not fear us, Pompey, with thy sails.
Goodbye!: Pompey, you can’t fear us with your sails.

Anon!: News, friends!
Goodbye!: News, friends!

Anon!: Where they most breed and haunt, I have observed, The air is delicate.
Goodbye!: The air is delicate, I’ve seen.

Anon!: Ah, poor heart, he is so shaked of a burning quotidian tertian that it is most lamentable to behold.
Goodbye!: Ah, poor heart, he’s so shaken by a burning tertian that it’s terribly sad to see him.

Anon!: Well, God-'a'-mercy.
Goodbye!: Well, God bless you.

Anon!: You have little cause to say so.
Goodbye!: You don’t have any reason to say that.

Anon!: Very sweet and contagious, i' faith.
Goodbye!: Very sweet and contagious, I’m sure.

Anon!: Why, sir, give the gods a thankful sacrifice.
Goodbye!: Why, sir, give the gods a thankful sacrifice.

Anon!: But I have heard him oft maintain it to be fit that, sons at perfect age and fathers declined, the father should be as ward to the son, and the son manage his revenue.
Goodbye!: But I’ve heard him say it’s always appropriate that sons at perfect age and fathers declined, the father should be as ward to the son, and the son should manage his income.

Anon!: It shall lose thee nothing.
Goodbye!: It won’t lose you anything.

Anon!: Thou know’st the first time that we smell the air We wawl and cry.
Goodbye!: You know the first time we smell the air we hear and cry.

Anon!: I do the wrong, and first begin to brawl.
Goodbye!: I’m wrong, and I’ll start to fight.

Anon!: Some comfort, Nurse.
Goodbye!: I’m feeling a little better, Nurse.

Anon!: Tis with him in standing water, between boy and man.
Goodbye!: He’s standing in the water between boy and man.

Anon!: He has been yonder i' the sun practising behavior to his own shadow this half hour.
Goodbye!: He’s been practicing his behavior to his own shadows over the last half hour.

Anon!: Let specialties be therefore drawn between us, That covenants may be kept on either hand.
Goodbye!: So we need to draw specialties between us so that we can keep both sides of the agreement.

Anon!: His folly, Helena, is no fault of mine.
Goodbye!: Helena, he’s not my fault.

Anon!: Therefore to our best mercy give yourselves Or, like to men proud of destruction, Defy us to our worst.
Goodbye!: So give yourself to our best mercy or, like men who are proud of our destruction, Defy us to our worst.

Anon!: Know the glove!
Goodbye!: Know the glove!

Anon!: would you create me new?
Goodbye!: Would you like to create me new?

Anon!: I am thus bold to put your Grace in mind Of what you promised me.
Goodbye!: I’m so bold to think about what you promised me.

Anon!: There was blow for blow.
Goodbye!: There was blow for blow.

Anon!: From me he got it.
Goodbye!: He got it from me.

Anon!: Come, go.
Goodbye!: Come on, go.

Anon!: Now is the sun upon the highmost hill Of this day’s journey, and from nine till twelve Is three long hours, yet she is not come.
Goodbye!: Now the sun is shining on the highest hill of this day’s journey, and from nine to twelve she’s three hours long, but she’s not coming.

Anon!: He sups tonight with a harlotry, and thither will I go to him.
Goodbye!: He’s sups tonight with a harlotry, and I’ll go to him.

Anon!: Why, uncle, ’tis a shame.
Goodbye!: Oh, uncle, it’s a shame.

Anon!: I’ll seal to such a bond, And say there is much kindness in the Jew.
Goodbye!: I’ll give you a bond, and I’ll say that the Jew is kind.

Anon!: The fault’s your own.
Goodbye!: It’s your fault.

Anon!: I will prove it legitimate, sir, upon the oaths of judgment and reason.
Goodbye!: I’ll prove it to you, sir, on your oaths of judgment and reason.

Anon!: But thine doth fry.
Goodbye!: But you’re frying.

Anon!: Who heard me to deny it or forswear it?
Goodbye!: Who heard me say I’m wrong?

Anon!: Oh , stay but till then!
Goodbye!: Oh, wait until then!

Anon!: We must bear all.
Goodbye!: We have to bear everything.

Anon!: Wert thou as young as I, Juliet thy love, An hour but married, Tybalt murderèd, Doting like me, and like me banishèd, Then mightst thou speak, then mightst thou tear thy hair And fall upon the ground, as I do now, Taking the measure of an unmade grave.
Goodbye!: You’re as young as I am, Juliet, your love, you’ve only been married an hour, Tybalt was murdered, you’re like me, and you’re banished, then you’re

Anon!: Come not near Casca.
Goodbye!: Don’t come near Casca.

Anon!: Thus answer I in the name of Benedick, But hear these ill news with the ears of Claudio.
Goodbye!: So answer me in the name of Benedick, but hear these bad news with Claudio’s ears.

Anon!: For I am almost ready to dissolve, Hearing of this.
Goodbye!: I’m almost ready to dissolve, hearing about this.

Anon!: Bondage is hoarse, and may not speak aloud, Else would I tear the cave where Echo lies, And make her airy tongue more hoarse than mine, With repetition of “My Romeo!” It is my soul that calls upon my name.
Goodbye!: I’d tear the cave where Echo lies, and make her airy tongue more hoarse than mine, with the repetition of “My Romeo!” I’m the soul who calls upon my name.

Anon!: Oh, then belike you fancy riches more.
Goodbye!: Oh, then you’ll get more riches.

Anon!: There’s five to one.
Goodbye!: There’s five to one.

Anon!: The world is not thy friend nor the world’s law.
Goodbye!: The world is not your friend, and neither is the law.

Anon!: If you deny me, fie upon your law— There is no force in the decrees of Venice.
Goodbye!: If you deny me, please obey your law— Venice has no force in its decrees.

Anon!: Fly, therefore, noble Cassius, fly far off.
Goodbye!: So fly, noble Cassius, fly far away.

Anon!: Can you remember any of the principal evils that he laid to the charge of women?
Goodbye!: Can you remember any of the principal evils he committed to women?

Anon!: And now, good friends, As you are friends, scholars and soldiers, Give me one poor request.
Goodbye!: Now, good friends, as you are friends, scholars and soldiers, give me one poor request.

Anon!: Now comes the wanton blood up in your cheeks.
Goodbye!: Now you’re getting the blood out of your cheeks.

Anon!: Ho, ho, ho!
Goodbye!: Oh, ho, ho!

Anon!: Hear it apart.
Goodbye!: Listen to it.

Anon!: Thou call’st on him that hates thee.
Goodbye!: You’re calling on someone who hates you.

Anon!: Here, catch this casket.
Goodbye!: Here, catch this casecase.

Anon!: Be certain, nothing truer.
Goodbye!: Yes, nothing truer.

Anon!: Remember who commended thy yellow stockings—” Thy yellow stockings?
Goodbye!: Remember who commended your yellow stockings—” Your yellow stockings?

Anon!: O Cassius, if you could But win the noble Brutus to our party— Be you content.
Goodbye!: Oh Cassius, if you could only win the noble Brutus to our party— Be content.

Anon!: He named Sebastian.
Goodbye!: He named Sebastian.

Anon!: Why, know’st thou any harm’s intended towards him?
Goodbye!: Why, do you know any harm is intended for him?

Anon!: I pray thee, good Mercutio, let’s retire.
Goodbye!: Please, Mercutio, let’s go away.

Anon!: Oh!
Goodbye!: Oh!

Anon!: Fare thee well.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: Why, thou didst conclude hairy men plain dealers without wit.
Goodbye!: Why, you sat down with hairy men who were a fool.

Anon!: Grumio gave order how it should be done.
Goodbye!: Grumio gave instructions on how to do it.

Anon!: God’s peace, I would not lose so great an honor As one man more, methinks, would share from me, For the best hope I have.
Goodbye!: God’s peace, I wouldn’t lose such an honor as one more man, I think, would share from me, for the best hope I have.

Anon!: Nay, good, be patient.
Goodbye!: No, good, be patient.

Anon!: The king, sir, hath laid that in a dozen passes between yourself and him, he shall not exceed you three hits.
Goodbye!: The king has said that he will not exceed you three times in a dozen passes.

Anon!: Tell them that you know that Hero loves me.
Goodbye!: Tell them that you know that Hero loves me.

Anon!: Who does i’ th’ wars more than his captain can Becomes his captain’s captain; and ambition, The soldier’s virtue, rather makes choice of loss Than gain which darkens him.
Goodbye!: Who does more in war than his captain can become his captain’s captain; and ambition, the soldier’s virtue, rather than loses.

Anon!: You are welcome to Elsinore.
Goodbye!: You’re welcome to Elsinore.

Anon!: You have it full, Benedick.
Goodbye!: You’re full of it, Benedick.

Anon!: What you would work me to, I have some aim.
Goodbye!: I’m trying to figure out what you want me to do.

Anon!: Then be ’t so, my good lord.— How does the king?
Goodbye!: Then be so, my good lord.—How is the king?

Anon!: I have a soul of lead So stakes me to the ground I cannot move.
Goodbye!: I have a soul of lead that can’t move.

Anon!: Now he’ll outstare the lightning.
Goodbye!: Now he’ll outseat the lightning.

Anon!: Wilt thou destroy him then?
Goodbye!: Will you destroy him then?

Anon!: Know’st thou his mind?
Goodbye!: Do you know his mind?

Anon!: Do me no foul play, friends.
Goodbye!: Don’t play me foul, friends.

Anon!: What was thy cause?
Goodbye!: What was your cause?

Anon!: That which I gave you.
Goodbye!: I gave you the same thing.

Anon!: Oh, he is even in my mistress' case, Just in her case.
Goodbye!: Oh, he’s just in my mistress’s case, just in her case.

Anon!: I grant you.
Goodbye!: I grant you.

Anon!: I have a widow aunt, a dowager Of great revenue, and she hath no child.
Goodbye!: I have a widow aunt, a king of great income, and she has no child.

Anon!: Is this a prologue or the posy of a ring?
Goodbye!: Is this a prologue or a ring?

Anon!: Good even to my ghostly confessor.
Goodbye!: Good to my ghostly confessor.

Anon!: What, lamb!
Goodbye!: What, lamb!

Anon!: As it determines, so Dissolve my life!
Goodbye!: As it determines, I’ll die.

Anon!: Whither wander you?
Goodbye!: Where are you going?

Anon!: Why came not the slave back to me when I called him.
Goodbye!: Why didn’t the slave come back to me when I called him?

Anon!: Come down.
Goodbye!: Come down.

Anon!: So much for praising myself, who, I myself will bear witness, is praiseworthy.
Goodbye!: I’ll bet that I’m worthy of praise.

Anon!: And your experience makes you sad.
Goodbye!: And your experience makes you sad.

Anon!: He were no lion were not Romans hinds.
Goodbye!: He were no lion, but Romans weren’t hinds.

Anon!: More to know Did never meddle with my thoughts.
Goodbye!: More to know was never a part of my thoughts.

Anon!: We would not die in that man’s company That fears his fellowship to die with us.
Goodbye!: We wouldn’t die in that man’s company, who fears his fellowship with us.

Anon!: Here comes another troop to seek for you.
Goodbye!: Here comes another army to search for you.

Anon!: Naughty lady, These hairs which thou dost ravish from my chin Will quicken and accuse thee.
Goodbye!: No, a naughty lady, these hairs you ravish from my chin will quicken and accuse you.

Anon!: Come, Hamlet, come, and take this hand from me.
Goodbye!: Come, Hamlet, come and take this hand from me.

Anon!: Are you content to stay?
Goodbye!: Are you happy to stay?

Anon!: Thine, Claudio, thine, I say.
Goodbye!: You, Claudio, you, I say.

Anon!: But down.
Goodbye!: But down.

Anon!: She haunts me in every place.
Goodbye!: She’s haunting me in every place.

Anon!: Thy lands and all things that thou dost call thine Worth seizure, do we seize into our hands Till thou canst quit thee by thy brother’s mouth Of what we think against thee.
Goodbye!: Your land and all the things you call your worth-sale, we’re taking your hands until you can stop you by your brother’s mouth of what we think against you.

Anon!: Some to Decius' house and some to Casca’s.
Goodbye!: Some to Decius’s house and some to Casca’s.

Anon!: Oh, yes, I heard them all, and more too, for some of them had in them more feet than the verses would bear.
Goodbye!: Oh yes, I heard them all, and more, because some of them had more feet in them than the verses would bear.

Anon!: Therefore, merchant, I’ll limit thee this day To seek thy life by beneficial help.
Goodbye!: Therefore, merchant, I’ll limit you to seeking your life by getting help.

Anon!: He does well to commend it himself.
Goodbye!: He’s good at recommending it himself.

Anon!: Would I were so too.
Goodbye!: I wish I were so too.

Anon!: O Regan, she hath tied Sharp-toothed unkindness, like a vulture, here.
Goodbye!: Oh, Regan, she has tied her wits with a sharp-toothed unkindness, like a vulture, here.

Anon!: Then pardon him, sweet father, for my sake.
Goodbye!: Then pardon him, sweet father, for my sake.

Anon!: The trumpery in my house, go bring it hither For stale to catch these thieves.
Goodbye!: The trumpery in my house, go bring it here for stale capture of these thieves.

Anon!: Softly and swiftly, sir, for the priest is ready.
Goodbye!: The priest is ready.

Anon!: What noise is this?
Goodbye!: What’s this noise?

Anon!: In his tongue.
Goodbye!: In his tongue.

Anon!: Here is more of us.
Goodbye!: Here are more of us.

Anon!: Lo, she is one of this confederacy!
Goodbye!: Oh, she’s one of this confederacy!

Anon!: He fell down in the marketplace, and foamed at mouth, and was speechless.
Goodbye!: He fell down in the marketplace and foamed at mouth, and was speechless.

Anon!: Never at quiet.
Goodbye!: Never quiet.

Anon!: Signor Antonio?
Goodbye!: Signor Antonio?

Anon!: It might, my lord.
Goodbye!: It might, my lord.

Anon!: She is drowned already, sir, with salt water, though I seem to drown her remembrance again with more.
Goodbye!: She’s already drowned in salt, though I’m attempting to drown her memory with more.

Anon!: Most learnèd judge, a sentence!
Goodbye!: A judge who’s learned a sentence!

Anon!: Then forth, dear countrymen.
Goodbye!: Then go out, dear countrymen.

Anon!: Within the infant rind of this small flower Poison hath residence and medicine power.
Goodbye!: The small flower is ripe and has medicinal power.

Anon!: An eagle, madam, Hath not so green, so quick, so fair an eye As Paris hath.
Goodbye!: An eagle, madam, is not as green, as quick, as a man is.

Anon!: If thou darest tempt me further, draw thy sword.
Goodbye!: If you dare to tempt me further, draw your sword.

Anon!: Were never orphans had so dear a loss.
Goodbye!: Were never orphans so much lost.

Anon!: Here, stand behind this bulk, straight will he come.
Goodbye!: Here, stand behind this bulk, he’ll come straight away.

Anon!: Most villanously, like a pedant that keeps a school i' the church.
Goodbye!: Most vilely, like a pedant who keeps a school in the church.

Anon!: Welcome from Mantua.
Goodbye!: Welcome back from Mantua.

Anon!: Learn of the wise and perpend: civet is of a baser birth than tar, the very uncleanly flux of a cat.
Goodbye!: Learn about the wise and wise: a cat is a baser birth than a cat, a cat that is very unclean.

Anon!: No, indeed, sir; the Lady Olivia has no folly.
Goodbye!: No, indeed, sir.

Anon!: I know you are my eldest brother, and in the gentle condition of blood you should so know me.
Goodbye!: I know you’re my eldest brother, and you’d be able to know me in the gentle condition of blood.

Anon!: Approach.
Goodbye!: Take it.

Anon!: Most heathenish and most gross!
Goodbye!: The heat is so hot and gross!

Anon!: He will bear you easily and reins well.
Goodbye!: He’ll bear you easily and will be able to keep your reins well.

Anon!: What think’st thou then of Stanley?
Goodbye!: What do you think of Stanley then?

Anon!: It was his bidding.
Goodbye!: It was his bid.

Anon!: It is not day.
Goodbye!: It’s not daybreak.

Anon!: Enobarbus?
Goodbye!: Enobarbus?

Anon!: She’s dead, my Queen.
Goodbye!: She’s dead, my Queen.

Anon!: when ’twas a little prating thing.—Oh, there is a nobleman in town, one Paris, that would fain lay knife aboard, but she, good soul, had as lief see a toad, a very toad, as see him.
Goodbye!: When it was a little bit of a prating thing.—Oh, there’s a nobleman in town, one Paris, who would fain lay knife on the ship, but she, good soul, had

Anon!: Leonato, stand I here?
Goodbye!: Leonato, am I standing here?

Anon!: Being holiday, the beggar’s shop is shut.
Goodbye!: Being a holiday, the beggar’s shop is shut.

Anon!: A drum, a drum!
Goodbye!: A drum, a drum!

Anon!: To answer by the method, in the first of his heart.
Goodbye!: To answer by the method, in the first of his heart.

Anon!: Marry, on Hero, the daughter and heir of Leonato.
Goodbye!: Hero, the daughter and heir of Leonato.

Anon!: What should I say to you?
Goodbye!: What should I say to you?

Anon!: Day, night, hour, tide, time, work, play, Alone, in company, still my care hath been To have her matched.
Goodbye!: Day, night, hour, tide, time, work, play, alone, in company, I’ve always been a good friend to have her matched.

Anon!: The chain!
Goodbye!: The chain!

Anon!: She’s dead, she’s dead, she’s dead!
Goodbye!: She’s dead, she’s dead, she’s dead!

Anon!: My news shall be the fruit to that great feast.
Goodbye!: I’ll give you the fruit of that great feast.

Anon!: No, madam.
Goodbye!: No, madam.

Anon!: To our shores Throng many doubtful hollow-hearted friends, Unarmed and unresolved to beat them back.
Goodbye!: To our shores, take many doubtful hollow-hearted friends, unarmed and unresolved to beat them back.

Anon!: Hath Romeo slain himself?
Goodbye!: Has Romeo killed himself?

Anon!: Sayest thou that house is dark?
Goodbye!: Do you say that the house is dark?

Anon!: Breathe Merriman, the poor cur is embossed, And couple Clowder with the deep-mouthed brach.
Goodbye!: Breathe Merriman, the poor curfew is embossed, and couple Clowder with the deep-mouthed brach.

Anon!: Therefore I pray you That to our sister you do make return.
Goodbye!: So please, please, make your return to our sister.

Anon!: Heard you this, Gonzalo?
Goodbye!: Did you hear this, Gonzalo?

Anon!: Hast thou slain Tybalt?
Goodbye!: Have you killed Tybalt?

Anon!: My servant, sir!
Goodbye!: My servant, sir!

Anon!: But mark, poor knight, What dreadful dole is here!
Goodbye!: But mark, poor knight, what a terrible thing this is!

Anon!: Prithee, keep up thy quillets.
Goodbye!: Please keep up your quillets.

Anon!: Let him send no more— Unless perchance you come to me again To tell me how he takes it.
Goodbye!: Don’t send him any more—unless you come back to tell me how he takes it.

Anon!: It is a man’s office, but not yours.
Goodbye!: It’s a man’s job, but not yours.

Anon!: An he speak any thing against me, I’ll take him down, an he were lustier than he is, and twenty such Jacks.
Goodbye!: If he says anything against me, I’ll take him down, if he were lustier than he is, and twenty such Jacks.

Anon!: Take up my mistress' gown for thy master’s use!
Goodbye!: Take up my mistress’ gown for your master’s use!
