Anon!: But this good comfort bring I to your Highness: The Breton navy is dispersed by tempest.
Goodbye!: But I’ll bring this good comfort to your Highness: The Breton navy is dispersed by the storm.

Anon!: Madam, I’ll take my leave.
Goodbye!: Madam, I’ll leave.

Anon!: Your Grace is too costly to wear every day.
Goodbye!: Your Grace is too expensive to wear every day.

Anon!: Ay, indeed!
Goodbye!: Yes, indeed!

Anon!: The king’s a bawcock, and a heart of gold, A lad of life, an imp of fame, Of parents good, of fist most valiant.
Goodbye!: The king’s a savage, a heart of gold, a lad of life, a savage of fame, of parents good, and a valiant fist.

Anon!: I pray thee tell me truly how thou lik’st her.
Goodbye!: Please tell me how you love her.

Anon!: Come hither, sirrah.
Goodbye!: Come here, sir.

Anon!: Therefore prepare to die.
Goodbye!: So prepare to die.

Anon!: Not now.
Goodbye!: Not now.

Anon!: If the ill spirit have so fair a house, Good things will strive to dwell with ’t.
Goodbye!: If the poor spirit has such a good house, good things will be able to live with it.

Anon!: Ay, sir, I have a pretty wit.
Goodbye!: Yes, sir, I have a pretty wit.

Anon!: An I had been a man of any occupation, if I would not have taken him at a word, I would I might go to hell among the rogues.
Goodbye!: If I had been a man of any occupation, if I hadn’t taken him at a word, I’d go to hell among the rogues.

Anon!: Slave!
Goodbye!: Slave!

Anon!: How well my comfort is revived by this!
Goodbye!: How good I feel about this!

Anon!: I thank you for your pains and courtesy.
Goodbye!: Thank you for your pains and courtesy.

Anon!: Tis bitter cold, And I am sick at heart.
Goodbye!: It’s bitter cold, and I’m sick at heart.

Anon!: Here’s a spirit.
Goodbye!: Here’s a spirit.

Anon!: God shield I should disturb devotion!— Juliet, on Thursday early will I rouse ye.
Goodbye!: I’ll bet I’ll disturb devotion!— Juliet, I’ll rouse you on Thursday.

Anon!: Will it give place to flexure and low bending?
Goodbye!: Will it give place to bending and bending?

Anon!: Here’s such a coil.
Goodbye!: Here’s a slew of sleeves.

Anon!: But you, O you, So perfect and so peerless, are created Of every creature’s best.
Goodbye!: But you, too, are perfect and so sane, and are created from every creature’s best.

Anon!: Are you not Kent?
Goodbye!: Aren’t you Kent?

Anon!: That eyeless head of thine was first framed flesh To raise my fortunes.
Goodbye!: That eyeless head of yours was first framed in flesh to raise my fortune.

Anon!: You shall have ransom.
Goodbye!: You’ll get a ransom.

Anon!: Is it fit, The threefold world divided, he should stand One of the three to share it?
Goodbye!: Is it appropriate, the three-dimensional world divided, that he should stand one of the three to share it?

Anon!: Besides, in mercy, The constable desires thee thou wilt mind Thy followers of repentance, that their souls May make a peaceful and a sweet retire From off these fields where, wretches, their poor bodies Must lie and fester.
Goodbye!: Besides, the constable wants you to be punished, so that your followers can be resentful and a sweet man to come off these fields where, wretches, their poor bodies must lie and fester.

Anon!: Ha!
Goodbye!: Ha!

Anon!: Not so hot.
Goodbye!: Not so hot.

Anon!: Shall we be sundered?
Goodbye!: Should we be sundered?

Anon!: Thus losers part.
Goodbye!: Then the losers are part of the equation.

Anon!: Now, my lord, what shall we do, if we perceive Lord Hastings will not yield to our complots?
Goodbye!: Now, my lord, what should we do if we think Lord Hastings won’t give up on our lords?

Anon!: Here’s metal more attractive.
Goodbye!: Here’s more attractive metal.

Anon!: Heard you of nothing strange about the streets?
Goodbye!: Have you heard of anything strange about the streets?

Anon!: Was he not companion with the riotous knights That tend upon my father?
Goodbye!: Wasn’t he companion with the riotous knights who are chasing my father?

Anon!: Here come the officers.
Goodbye!: Here come the officers.

Anon!: But he that will believe all that they say shall never be saved by half that they do.
Goodbye!: But anyone who believes everything they say will never be saved by half of what they do.

Anon!: And so will I.
Goodbye!: And so will I.

Anon!: I know ’t—my sister’s.
Goodbye!: I know it—my sister’s.

Anon!: I’ll make you amends next, to give you nothing for something.
Goodbye!: I’ll make you amends next, to give you nothing for something.

Anon!: I overheard him and his practices.
Goodbye!: I’ve overheard him and his practices.

Anon!: Be patient, gentlemen.
Goodbye!: Be patient, gentlemen.

Anon!: Conclude, conclude, he is in love.
Goodbye!: Let’s conclude that he’s in love.

Anon!: Well, good night.
Goodbye!: Good night.

Anon!: Let his shames quickly Drive him to Rome.
Goodbye!: Let his shame drive him quickly to Rome.

Anon!: I was with Hercules and Cadmus once, When in a wood of Crete they bayed the bear With hounds of Sparta.
Goodbye!: I was with Hercules and Cadmus once, when they sat in a wood in Crete with hounds of Sparta.

Anon!: In, or we are spoiled.
Goodbye!: We’re in, or we’re spoiled.

Anon!: How think you of it?
Goodbye!: What do you think of it?

Anon!: There is one goat for you.
Goodbye!: There’s one goat for you.

Anon!: Orlando, my liege, the youngest son of Sir Rowland de Boys.
Goodbye!: Orlando, my liege, is the youngest son of Sir Rowland de Boys.

Anon!: Not so, my lord.
Goodbye!: Not true, my lord.

Anon!: We being strangers here, how dar’st thou trust So great a charge from thine own custody?
Goodbye!: We’re strangers here, how do you trust such a large charge from your own custody?

Anon!: I cross me for a sinner.
Goodbye!: I’m a sinner.

Anon!: Since my young lady’s going into France, sir, the fool hath much pined away.
Goodbye!: Since my young lady’s going into France, sir, the fool has been scolded.

Anon!: Counterfeit?
Goodbye!: Counterfeit?

Anon!: Thou fond mad man, hear me a little speak.
Goodbye!: You fond madman, listen to me a little bit.

Anon!: What, wouldst thou have a serpent sting thee twice?
Goodbye!: What, would you have a serpent sting you twice?

Anon!: The news is true, my lord.
Goodbye!: The news is true, my lord.

Anon!: O, my old master.—Who hath bound him here?
Goodbye!: Oh, my old master.—Who has bound him here?

Anon!: Retire we to our chamber.
Goodbye!: Retire to our room.

Anon!: Is thy name Tyrrel?
Goodbye!: Is your name Tyrrel?

Anon!: My lord?
Goodbye!: My lord?

Anon!: Thou 'rt mad to say it.
Goodbye!: You’re crazy to say it.

Anon!: I strike quickly, being moved.
Goodbye!: I’m stricken, being moved.

Anon!: It is the blessèd sun.
Goodbye!: It’s the sun that’s blessed.

Anon!: You were sent for, and there is a kind of confession in your looks which your modesties have not craft enough to color.
Goodbye!: You were sent for, and you’ve got a confession in your looks that you don’t have enough to color.

Anon!: Thy luster thickens When he shines by.
Goodbye!: Your luster will thicken when he shines.

Anon!: So shines a good deed in a naughty world.
Goodbye!: That’s a good thing in a naughty world.

Anon!: My fan, Peter.
Goodbye!: My fan, Peter.

Anon!: He shall live a man forbid.
Goodbye!: He’ll live a man forbid.

Anon!: One stroke Shall free thee from the tribute which thou payest.
Goodbye!: You’ll be freed by one stroke from the tribute you pay.

Anon!: You shall not find, Though you be therein curious, the least cause For what you seem to fear.
Goodbye!: You won’t find the least reason for what you’re afraid of, even if you’re curious.

Anon!: But hast thou yet latched the Athenian’s eyes With the love juice, as I did bid thee do?
Goodbye!: But have you snuck the Athenian’s eyes with the love juice, as I asked you to?

Anon!: What wood is this before us?
Goodbye!: What’s this wood in the woods?

Anon!: Face not me.
Goodbye!: Don’t face me.

Anon!: Let go!
Goodbye!: Let go of it!

Anon!: Where is my page?—Go, villain, fetch a surgeon.
Goodbye!: Where is my page?—Go, villain, get a surgeon.

Anon!: Now, as thou lovest me, let me see his letter.
Goodbye!: Now, as you love me, let me see his letter.

Anon!: Tis he.
Goodbye!: That’s him.

Anon!: I am alone the villain of the earth, And feel I am so most.
Goodbye!: I’m alone the villain of the earth, and I feel like I’m so much.

Anon!: True is it that we have seen better days And have with holy bell been knolled to church, And sat at good men’s feasts and wiped our eyes Of drops that sacred pity hath engendered.
Goodbye!: It’s true that we’ve seen better days and have been knolled to church with a holy bell, sat at good men’s feasts and wiped our eyes off the drops that have sparked

Anon!: Tis so; and that self chain about his neck Which he forswore most monstrously to have.
Goodbye!: It’s so, and he’s wearing a self-chain around his neck that he’s forsaid monstrously.

Anon!: Therefore be cheered.
Goodbye!: So cheer up.

Anon!: You tallow face!
Goodbye!: You tallow face!

Anon!: Where is thy master, Dromio?
Goodbye!: Where is your master, Dromio?

Anon!: Lady!
Goodbye!: Lady!

Anon!: A plague o' both your houses!
Goodbye!: A plague kills both your houses!

Anon!: I hear some noise.
Goodbye!: I hear some noise.

Anon!: I will die bravely, like a smug bridegroom.
Goodbye!: I’ll die bravely, like a smug bridegroom.

Anon!: Very foul.
Goodbye!: Very bad.

Anon!: Can anything be made of this?
Goodbye!: Can anything be done about this?

Anon!: When it is lighted, come and call me here.
Goodbye!: When it’s lighted, come and call me here.

Anon!: I know not that, when he knows what I know.
Goodbye!: I don’t know that, when he knows what I know.

Anon!: On me, whose all not equals Edward’s moiety?
Goodbye!: On me, whose all that’s not Edward’s?

Anon!: Hear the shrill whistle, which doth order give To sounds confused.
Goodbye!: Listen to the shrill whistle, which is what order gives to sounds confused.

Anon!: I with the morning’s love have oft made sport, And like a forester the groves may tread Even till the eastern gate, all fiery red, Opening on Neptune with fair blessèd beams, Turns into yellow gold his salt green streams.
Goodbye!: I’ve always made sports with the morning’s love, and like a forester, the groves can tread even till the eastern gate, all fiery red, opening on Neptune with fair blessed beams

Anon!: Who chooseth me must give and hazard all he hath.” Must give—for what?
Goodbye!: Who chooses me must give and risk all he has.” Must give—for what?

Anon!: Oh, treble woe Fall ten times treble on that cursèd head, Whose wicked deed thy most ingenious sense Deprived thee of!
Goodbye!: Oh, treble pain is ten times more painful on that slurdy head, who your wicked sense has deprived you of!

Anon!: Good Signior Angelo, you must excuse us all; My wife is shrewish when I keep not hours.
Goodbye!: Good Signior Angelo, you must excuse us all.

Anon!: The villain Jew with outcries raised the Duke, Who went with him to search Bassanio’s ship.
Goodbye!: The villain Jew with outcries raised the Duke, who went with him to search Bassanio’s ship.

Anon!: That’s more to me than my wetting.
Goodbye!: That’s more to me than my wetness.

Anon!: By my soul I swear There is no power in the tongue of man To alter me.
Goodbye!: I swear by my soul that man has no power to change me.

Anon!: And in the morning early will we both Fly toward Belmont.
Goodbye!: And we’ll both fly to Belmont early in the morning.

Anon!: What is thy name?
Goodbye!: What’s your name?

Anon!: Leave me, I pray, a little.
Goodbye!: Leave me, please, a little.

Anon!: And she is mine, and all my right of her I do estate unto Demetrius.
Goodbye!: And she is mine, and I’m giving her all my right to do to Demetrius.

Anon!: Go shake your ears!
Goodbye!: Go shake your ears!

Anon!: The one of them contains my picture, Prince.
Goodbye!: The one of them contains my picture, Prince.

Anon!: Would he deny his letter, said he?
Goodbye!: Would he deny his letter, said he?

Anon!: My wits begin to turn.—   Come on, my boy.
Goodbye!: I’m starting to turn my wits around.—Come on, my boy.

Anon!: There thou mightst behold the great image of authority: a dog’s obeyed in office.
Goodbye!: You might see the great image of authority: a dog is obeyed in his office.

Anon!: Soft, here follows prose.
Goodbye!: Here’s the prose.

Anon!: So be it.
Goodbye!: That’s it.

Anon!: Marry, I fare well, For here is cheer enough.
Goodbye!: I’m farewell, because here’s cheering enough.

Anon!: How!
Goodbye!: How!

Anon!: This wretch hath part confessed his villainy.
Goodbye!: This wretch has confessed his crimes.

Anon!: At your choice, sir.
Goodbye!: At your choice, sir.

Anon!: Oh, villainy, villainy!
Goodbye!: Oh, villainy, villainy!

Anon!: Sir Walter Herbert, a renownèd soldier; Sir Gilbert Talbot, Sir William Stanley, Oxford, redoubted Pembroke, Sir James Blunt, And Rice ap Thomas, with a valiant crew, And many other of great name and worth; And towards London they do bend their power, If by the way they be not fought withal.
Goodbye!: Sir Walter Herbert, a renowned soldier; Sir Gilbert Talbot, Sir William Stanley, Oxford, redoubted Pembroke, Sir James Blunt, and Rice ap Thomas, with a valiant crew

Anon!: The funeral baked meats Did coldly furnish forth the marriage tables.
Goodbye!: The funeral baked meats were preparing the marriage tables for the cold weather.

Anon!: I will go call the watch.
Goodbye!: I’ll go call the watch.

Anon!: Besides, their writers say, King Pepin, which deposèd Childeric, Did, as heir general, being descended Of Blithild, which was daughter to King Clothair, Make claim and title to the crown of France.
Goodbye!: Besides, their writers say, King Pepin, who deposed Childeric, was heir general, born of Blithild, who was daughter of King Clothair, and claimed the crown of France.

Anon!: If he may be conveniently delivered, I would he were, for I am now so far in offense with my niece that I cannot pursue with any safety this sport to the upshot.
Goodbye!: If he could be delivered quickly, I would he be, because I’m so far indebted to my niece that I can’t pursue this sport with any safety.

Anon!: A tailor make a man?
Goodbye!: A tailor makes a man?

Anon!: Woe to the hand that shed this costly blood!
Goodbye!: I’m sorry to the hand that shed this costly blood!

Anon!: He is the brooch indeed And gem of all the nation.
Goodbye!: He’s the treasure of all nations.

Anon!: Caesar.
Goodbye!: Caesar.

Anon!: Is thy master stirring?
Goodbye!: Is your master stirring?

Anon!: But where’s the money?
Goodbye!: But where’s the money?

Anon!: Enough.
Goodbye!: Enough.

Anon!: Out upon you!
Goodbye!: Come on!

Anon!: Good even to my ghostly confessor.
Goodbye!: Good to my ghostly confessor.

Anon!: Still so constant, lord.
Goodbye!: That’s still so constant, lord.

Anon!: I will fetch you light, and paper, and ink.
Goodbye!: I’ll get you light, paper, and ink.

Anon!: How long hath this possession held the man?
Goodbye!: How long has this possession held the man?

Anon!: Stay, fellow.
Goodbye!: Stay, fellow.

Anon!: Do not you meddle.
Goodbye!: Don’t interfere.

Anon!: March to the bridge.
Goodbye!: March to the bridge.

Anon!: This is all.
Goodbye!: That’s all.

Anon!: Stanley, what news with you?
Goodbye!: Stanley, what’s the news?

Anon!: A joint stool.
Goodbye!: A joint stool.

Anon!: What news?
Goodbye!: What news do you have?

Anon!: You are welcome.
Goodbye!: You are welcome.

Anon!: And we, like friends, will straightway go together.
Goodbye!: And we’ll go straight away, like friends.

Anon!: He had none.
Goodbye!: He didn’t have any.

Anon!: Bear it straight, And bring thy master home immediately.
Goodbye!: Take it straight, and bring your master home immediately.

Anon!: Here’s to Caesar.
Goodbye!: Here’s to Caesar.

Anon!: Widow Dido” said you?
Goodbye!: Widow Dido” said you?

Anon!: What to him from England?
Goodbye!: What to him from England?

Anon!: Or, if sour woe delights in fellowship And needly will be ranked with other griefs, Why followed not, when she said “Tybalt’s dead,” “Thy father” or “thy mother,” nay, or both, Which modern lamentations might have moved?
Goodbye!: Or, if sour sorrows are in fellowship and are ranked with other griefs, why not, when she said “Tybalt’s dead,” “your father” or “your mother,” no, or both

Anon!: Such welcome and unwelcome things at once 'Tis hard to reconcile.
Goodbye!: It’s hard to reconcile such welcome and unwelcome things together.

Anon!: Out on her, hilding!
Goodbye!: She’s out of here, hilding!

Anon!: She shall be buried with her face upwards.
Goodbye!: She will be buried with her face upwards.

Anon!: I speak no treason.
Goodbye!: I’m not saying anything wrong.

Anon!: I charge you by the law, Whereof you are a well-deserving pillar, Proceed to judgment.
Goodbye!: I’ll tell you by law that you’re a worthy pillar of justice.

Anon!: Good guard Until their greater pleasures first be known That are to censure them.
Goodbye!: Be careful until they know what they’re doing to censure them.

Anon!: Thou art the thing itself.
Goodbye!: You’re doing the same thing.

Anon!: Pardon me, dear Rosalind.
Goodbye!: Pardon me, dear Rosalind.

Anon!: I’ll torture him.
Goodbye!: I’ll torture him.

Anon!: If they make you not then the better answer, you may say they are not the men you took them for.
Goodbye!: If they don’t make you the better answer, you can say they’re not the men you took them for.

Anon!: I follow him to serve my turn upon him.
Goodbye!: I follow him to serve my turn on him.

Anon!: Who knocks so hard?
Goodbye!: Who’s knocking so hard?

Anon!: About the ninth hour, lady.
Goodbye!: About ninth hour, lady.

Anon!: Why, lady!
Goodbye!: Why, lady!

Anon!: Who is ’t that can inform me?
Goodbye!: Who can tell me?

Anon!: Naught’s had, all’s spent, Where our desire is got without content.
Goodbye!: It’s been a long time since we’ve been able to get everything we wanted.

Anon!: If you have tears, prepare to shed them now.
Goodbye!: If you have tears, prepare to shed them now.

Anon!: It is “music with her silver sound” because musicians have no gold for sounding.
Goodbye!: It’s “music with her silver sound,” because musicians don’t have gold to sound.

Anon!: Against my will, I am sent to bid you come in to dinner.
Goodbye!: I’ve been sent to ask you to come in to dinner.

Anon!: My lord, for aught I know.
Goodbye!: My lord, I know what to do.

Anon!: Tomorrow then I will expect your coming.
Goodbye!: Tomorrow I’ll expect you to come.

Anon!: What needs more words?
Goodbye!: What are you waiting for?

Anon!: By your patience, I may not suffer you to visit them.
Goodbye!: I can’t help you visit them.

Anon!: Why, that’s all one.
Goodbye!: That’s all one thing.

Anon!: I can as well be hanged as tell the manner of it.
Goodbye!: I can be hanged as well as tell the story.

Anon!: I thank thee, Ariel.
Goodbye!: Thank you, Ariel.

Anon!: Good morrow, neighbor Gremio.—God save you, gentlemen!
Goodbye!: Good morning, neighbor Gremio.—God save you, gentlemen!

Anon!: I will give him some relief if it be but for that.
Goodbye!: I’ll give him some relief if it’s just for that.

Anon!: Gentle lady, When I did first impart my love to you, I freely told you, all the wealth I had Ran in my veins.
Goodbye!: Gentle lady, when I first told you my love, I told you that all the wealth I had accumulated in my veins.

Anon!: I pray you, sir, dispatch.
Goodbye!: Please, sir, get out of here.

Anon!: Hark ye, your Romeo will be here at night.
Goodbye!: Listen, your Romeo will be here at night.

Anon!: Come, brother; away!
Goodbye!: Come, brother; let’s go!

Anon!: I have brought you from Venice.
Goodbye!: I’ve brought you from Venice.

Anon!: I’ll have no speaking.
Goodbye!: I won’t speak.

Anon!: Tybalt, that murderer, which way ran he?
Goodbye!: Tybalt, that murderer, which way did he run?

Anon!: Most noble Empress, you have heard of me?
Goodbye!: Most noble Empress, have you heard of me?

Anon!: I never saw her till this time.
Goodbye!: I never saw her until this time.

Anon!: Kill me tomorrow—let me live tonight!
Goodbye!: Kill me tomorrow—let me live tonight!

Anon!: Why then, lead on.
Goodbye!: So lead on.

Anon!: Belike you slew great number of his people?
Goodbye!: You’re like you slew a lot of his people?

Anon!: And, for thou wast a spirit too delicate To act her earthy and abhorred commands, Refusing her grand hests, she did confine thee, By help of her more potent ministers And in her most unmitigable rage, Into a cloven pine, within which rift Imprisoned thou didst painfully remain A dozen years; within which space she died And left thee there, where thou didst vent thy groans As fast as mill wheels strike.
Goodbye!: And, because you were too delicate to act her sane and affluent command, she confined you to a cloven pine, with her more powerful ministers and her unmitigable rage,

Anon!: Tis a good hand, A frank one.
Goodbye!: It’s a good hand, a frank one.

Anon!: What, have you lost your wits?
Goodbye!: Have you lost your wits?

Anon!: I do serve you in this business.
Goodbye!: I’m helping you out.

Anon!: What should I speak?
Goodbye!: What should I say?

Anon!: Blind is his love and best befits the dark.
Goodbye!: He’s blind and is best in the dark.

Anon!: May ’t please your highness sit.
Goodbye!: May your highness sit down.

Anon!: We doubt it nothing.
Goodbye!: We don’t doubt it.

Anon!: Fie upon “But yet.” “But yet” is as a jailer to bring forth Some monstrous malefactor.
Goodbye!: “But yet.” “But yet” is like a jailer to bring out some monstrous malefactor.

Anon!: If thou read this, O Caesar, thou mayst live.
Goodbye!: If you read this, Caesar, you can live.

Anon!: Go bring the rabble, O'er whom I give thee power, here to this place.
Goodbye!: Go bring the rabble, whom I give you power, here to this place.

Anon!: Good now, some excellent fortune!
Goodbye!: Good luck now!

Anon!: That nature, which contemns its origin Cannot be bordered certain in itself.
Goodbye!: That nature, which confounds its origin, can’t be ruled by itself.

Anon!: The Prince and Monsieur Love!
Goodbye!: The Prince and Monsieur Love!

Anon!: Do you perceive in all this noble company Where most you owe obedience?
Goodbye!: Do you see in all this noble company where you owe most obedience?

Anon!: Strike alarum, drums!
Goodbye!: Beat the drums!

Anon!: Good gentle youth, tempt not a desperate man.
Goodbye!: Good gentle young man, don’t tempt a desperate man.

Anon!: Thou seest that all the grace that she hath left Is that she will not add to her damnation A sin of perjury.
Goodbye!: You’re sure that all the grace she left is that she won’t add to her damnation a sin of perjury.

Anon!: My Lord of Gloucester, I have too long borne Your blunt upbraidings and your bitter scoffs.
Goodbye!: My Lord of Gloucester, I’ve been putting your blunt upbraidings and your bitter scoffs too long.

Anon!: Thou dost belie her, and thou art a devil.
Goodbye!: You beg her, and you’re a devil.

Anon!: But what a fool am I to chat with you, When I should bid good morrow to my bride And seal the title with a lovely kiss!
Goodbye!: But what a fool I am to chat with you when I should give my bride a good morning and seal the title with a lovely kiss!

Anon!: O valiant cousin!
Goodbye!: Oh, my valiant cousin!

Anon!: And most poor matters Point to rich ends.
Goodbye!: And most poor matters are about to reach rich ends.

Anon!: But new struck nine.
Goodbye!: But new things have struck nine.

Anon!: Oh, look!
Goodbye!: Oh, look!

Anon!: I can tell you, but young Romeo will be older when you have found him than he was when you sought him.
Goodbye!: I can tell you, but young Romeo will be older when you find him than he was when you found him.

Anon!: My most dear Gloucester!
Goodbye!: My dear Gloucester!

Anon!: Do you come near me now?
Goodbye!: Are you coming near me now?

Anon!: Wilt thou be lord of the whole world?
Goodbye!: Will you be the king of the whole world?

Anon!: And then, I hope, thou wilt be satisfied.
Goodbye!: And then, I hope, you’ll be satisfied.

Anon!: Most certain.
Goodbye!: Yes, I’m sure.

Anon!: She will sit you—you heard my daughter tell you how.
Goodbye!: She’ll sit with you—you heard my daughter tell you how.

Anon!: Faith, we met and found the quarrel was upon the seventh cause.
Goodbye!: We met and found the fight was on the seventh cause.

Anon!: I will plague them all, Even to roaring.
Goodbye!: I’ll plague them all, even roaring.

Anon!: Know him I shall, I am well sure of it.
Goodbye!: I will know him, I’m sure of it.

Anon!: I think he thinks upon the savage bull.
Goodbye!: I think he’s thinking about the savage bull.

Anon!: Poor souls, they perished.
Goodbye!: Poor souls, they died.

Anon!: Come to what is important in ’t.
Goodbye!: Come to what matters.

Anon!: As for my wife, I would you had her spirit in such another.
Goodbye!: As for my wife, I wish you had her spirit in such another.

Anon!: He that sweetest rose will find Must find love’s prick, and Rosalind.
Goodbye!: The sweetest rose will find Rosalind and love.

Anon!: Pray you, hasten Your generals after.
Goodbye!: Please hurry up your generals.

Anon!: Why?
Goodbye!: Why?

Anon!: Yon light is not daylight, I know it, I.
Goodbye!: I know that light is not daylight, I know.

Anon!: Nay, come, again.
Goodbye!: No, come, again.

Anon!: We had much more monstrous matter of feast, which worthily deserved noting.
Goodbye!: We had a much more monstrous feast than that, which was worth noting.

Anon!: Do you quarrel, sir?
Goodbye!: Do you have a fight, sir?

Anon!: A lean cheek, which you have not; a blue eye and sunken, which you have not; an unquestionable spirit, which you have not; a beard neglected, which you have not—but I pardon you for that, for simply your having in beard is a younger brother’s revenue.
Goodbye!: A lean cheek, which you haven’t, a blue eye and sunken eye, which you haven’t; an unquestionable spirit, which you haven’t; a beard neglected, which

Anon!: Make that good.
Goodbye!: Make that good.

Anon!: Then, gentle brother, get you in again.
Goodbye!: Then, gentle brother, come back in.

Anon!: Away, Tybalt.
Goodbye!: Go away, Tybalt.

Anon!: But you’ll be secret?
Goodbye!: But you’ll be secret?

Anon!: Cry but “Ay me!” Pronounce but “love” and “dove.” Speak to my gossip Venus one fair word, One nickname for her purblind son and heir, Young Abraham Cupid, he that shot so true When King Cophetua loved the beggar maid.— He heareth not, he stirreth not, he moveth not.

Goodbye!: Bassanio told him he’d make some speed of his return.

Goodbye!: I will, my lord.

Goodbye!: Will you come to bed, my lord?

Goodbye!: Oh, the duke of Gloucester is a dangerous man, and the queen’s sons and brothers are proud and proud, and if they were ruled and not ruled, this sickly land could solace up as before

Anon!: Would it were day!
Goodbye!: I wish it were day!

Anon!: Yet could I bear that too, well, very well.
Goodbye!: But I could bear that too, well, very well.

Goodbye!: Then tell me, who’s the next heir of Naples?

Goodbye!: My brave spirit!

Anon!: Tis strange that they should so depart from home, And not send back my messenger.
Goodbye!: It’s strange that they’re leaving home so quickly and not sending back my messenger.

Anon!: Pray you now, Nay, do so, for indeed I have lost command.
Goodbye!: Please do so now, no, because I’ve lost command.

Anon!: Treason!
Goodbye!: Treason!

Anon!: Behold: it is the privilege of mine honors, My oath, and my profession.
Goodbye!: Look: it’s my privilege to honor my oath, my oath, and my profession.

Anon!: All that is spoke is marred.
Goodbye!: All the word is spoken is ruined.

Anon!: All’s well.
Goodbye!: All’s well.

Anon!: Tarry, sweet Beatrice.
Goodbye!: Be sorry, sweet Beatrice.

Anon!: I’ll go farther off.
Goodbye!: I’ll go farther away.

Anon!: We talk here in the public haunt of men.
Goodbye!: We’re talking here in the public haunt of men.

Anon!: Death, that hath sucked the honey of thy breath, Hath had no power yet upon thy beauty.
Goodbye!: Death, who sucked the honey of your breath, has yet had no power on your beauty.

Anon!: Will you walk towards him?
Goodbye!: Will you walk towards him?

Anon!: Marry, you may partly hope that your father got you not, that you are not the Jew’s daughter.
Goodbye!: You may hope your father doesn’t get you, and you’re not the Jew’s daughter.

Anon!: Ay, truly, for the power of beauty will sooner transform honesty from what it is to a bawd than the force of honesty can translate beauty into his likeness.
Goodbye!: Yes, really, because the power of beauty will transform honesty sooner from what it is to a baddened man than the power of honesty can transform beauty into his likeness.

Anon!: Fair sir, I pity her And wish, for her sake more than for mine own, My fortunes were more able to relieve her.
Goodbye!: I pity her, sir, and I wish I could help her more than I do myself.

Anon!: How shalt thou hope for mercy, rendering none?
Goodbye!: How will you hope for mercy, without a doubt?

Anon!: A little, by your favor.
Goodbye!: A little bit, by your favor.

Anon!: Would I might But ever see that man!
Goodbye!: I wish I could see that man ever!

Anon!: What hast thou to do?— Father, be quiet.
Goodbye!: What are you going to do?—Sister, be quiet.

Anon!: I will follow you.
Goodbye!: I’ll follow you.

Anon!: I knew what you would prove.
Goodbye!: I knew what you wanted.

Anon!: Let us deal justly.
Goodbye!: Let’s deal with it justly.

Anon!: Very well.
Goodbye!: Very well.

Anon!: There lies the man, slain by young Romeo, That slew thy kinsman, brave Mercutio.
Goodbye!: There’s the man, killed by young Romeo, who killed your kinsman, brave Mercutio.

Anon!: Good my lord, How does your honor for this many a day?
Goodbye!: My lord, how are you honoring this many days?

Anon!: Why are you grown so rude?
Goodbye!: Why are you getting so rude?

Anon!: You told me you salute not at the court but you kiss your hands.
Goodbye!: You told me you don’t salute the court, but you kiss your hands.

Anon!: But this place is too cold for hell.
Goodbye!: But this place is too cold for hell.

Anon!: O, quicken them with thine!
Goodbye!: Oh, quicken them with yours!

Anon!: Swum ashore, man, like a duck.
Goodbye!: Swum ashore, man, like a duck.

Anon!: But i' faith, I should have been a woman by right.
Goodbye!: But I wish I had been a woman.

Anon!: There is but one mind in all these men, and it is bent against Caesar.
Goodbye!: All these men have a mind that’s bent against Caesar.

Anon!: I cannot speak to her, yet she urged conference.
Goodbye!: I can’t speak to her, but she urged her to speak.

Anon!: Not I, my lord.
Goodbye!: Not me, my lord.

Anon!: Thou know’st my daughter’s of a pretty age.
Goodbye!: You know my daughter’s pretty old.

Anon!: Was never mother had so dear a loss.
Goodbye!: I never had a mother so much to lose.

Anon!: Will you go to them?
Goodbye!: Will you go to them?

Anon!: Therefore thy kinsmen are no stop to me.
Goodbye!: Therefore, your parents aren’t stopping me.

Anon!: I’ll warrant she’ll tax him home.
Goodbye!: I’ll tell her she’ll pay him home.

Anon!: A dream itself is but a shadow.
Goodbye!: A dream itself is only a shadow.

Anon!: Thy voice is thunder, but thy looks are humble.
Goodbye!: Your voice is thunder, but your looks are humble.

Anon!: Most happy!
Goodbye!: Very happy!

Anon!: We have cause to be glad that matters are so well digested.
Goodbye!: We’re glad that matters are so well understood.

Anon!: But, on: six Barbary horses against six French swords, their assigns, and three liberal-conceited carriages—that’s the French bet against the Danish.
Goodbye!: But, on: six barbary horses against six French swords, their assigns, and three liberal-conceited carriages—that’s the French betting against the Danish.

Anon!: O heavens, that they were living both in Naples, The king and queen there!
Goodbye!: Oh heavens, they were both living in Naples, the king and queen there!

Anon!: That’s twice.
Goodbye!: That’s twice.

Anon!: I do wander everywhere  Swifter than the moon’s sphere.
Goodbye!: I wander everywhere, more swift than the moon’s sphere.

Anon!: Gifts that God gives.
Goodbye!: God gives you the gifts.

Anon!: We must to the watch.
Goodbye!: We have to watch.

Anon!: I have this present evening from my sister Been well informed of them—and with such cautions That if they come to sojourn at my house I’ll not be there.
Goodbye!: I’ve been informed of them from my sister this evening—and I’m sure they’ll stay at my house if they come.

Anon!: Twere damnation To think so base a thought.
Goodbye!: It’s damning to think so, but I’m not sure what to say.

Anon!: I thought so then, I’ll kill myself for grief.
Goodbye!: I thought that I’d kill myself for grief.

Anon!: There I have another bad match!—a bankrupt, a prodigal who dare scarce show his head on the Rialto, a beggar that was used to come so smug upon the mart.
Goodbye!: I have another bad match!—a bankrupt, a prodigal who dares to show his head on the Rialto, a beggar who was used to come so smug on the mart.

Anon!: Who are you?
Goodbye!: Who are you?

Anon!: As I did sleep under this yew tree here, I dreamt my master and another fought, And that my master slew him.
Goodbye!: As I slept under this yew tree here, I dreamed my master and another fighter had fought, and that my master slew him.

Anon!: His grace looks cheerfully and smooth this morning.
Goodbye!: His grace looks cheerful and smooth this morning.

Anon!: I’ll stay a month longer.
Goodbye!: I’ll stay for a month.

Anon!: I beg for justice, which thou, Prince, must give.
Goodbye!: I beg for justice, which you, Prince, must give.

Anon!: Who is it?
Goodbye!: Who is it?

Anon!: This foul Egyptian hath betrayèd me.
Goodbye!: This evil Egyptian has betrayed me.

Anon!: Say not so.
Goodbye!: Don’t say that.

Anon!: Forever and forever farewell, Cassius.
Goodbye!: Goodbye forever and forever, Cassius.

Anon!: Go, get thee to thy love, as was decreed.
Goodbye!: Go, get to your love, as was decreed.

Anon!: Why then, he is alive.
Goodbye!: Well, then, he’s alive.

Anon!: Twill endure wind and weather.
Goodbye!: Wind and weather will keep you warm.

Anon!: Till then, my noble friend, chew upon this: Brutus had rather be a villager Than to repute himself a son of Rome Under these hard conditions as this time Is like to lay upon us.
Goodbye!: But Brutus would rather be a villager than to be a son of Rome under these hard conditions as this time is like to lay on us.

Anon!: Tis most convenient.
Goodbye!: It’s most convenient.

Anon!: I have seen thee fight When I have envied thy behavior.
Goodbye!: I’ve seen you fight when I’ve envied your behavior.

Anon!: Mercy but murders, pardoning those that kill.
Goodbye!: Mercy is only about murders, pardoning those who kill.

Anon!: What is it thou didst say?
Goodbye!: What did you say?

Anon!: Say that you love me not, but say not so In bitterness.
Goodbye!: Say that you don’t love me, but don’t say that in bitterness.

Anon!: That which you are, my thoughts cannot transpose.
Goodbye!: I can’t tell you what you’re doing.

Anon!: Wilt thou, Silvius?
Goodbye!: Do you want to, Silvius?

Anon!: You’ll win two days upon me.
Goodbye!: You’ll win two days for me.

Anon!: And when she put it on, she made me vow That I should neither sell nor give nor lose it.
Goodbye!: And when she put it on, she made me vow that I won’t sell it, give it, or lose it.

Anon!: I’ll write thee a challenge.
Goodbye!: I’ll write you a challenge.

Anon!: The time is very short.
Goodbye!: The time is very short.

Anon!: Hail to thee, thane of Glamis!
Goodbye!: Hail to you, thane of Glamis!

Anon!: O Lord, my lord, if they were but a week married, they would talk themselves mad.
Goodbye!: Oh Lord, my lord, if they were only a week old, they’d talk themselves crazy.

Anon!: Himself in person there?
Goodbye!: He’s there in person?

Anon!: Is she as tall as me?
Goodbye!: Is she as tall as me?

Anon!: Madam, I have a touch of your condition, Which cannot brook the accent of reproof.
Goodbye!: Madam, I have a touch of your condition, which can’t be reproofed.

Anon!: How?
Goodbye!: How?

Anon!: I leave an arrant knave with your Worship, which I beseech your Worship to correct yourself, for the example of others.
Goodbye!: I leave an arrant knave with your Worship, which I ask your Worship to correct yourself, for example.

Anon!: Damned as thou art, thou hast enchanted her!
Goodbye!: Damned as you are, you’ve enchanted her!

Anon!: Hear me with patience.
Goodbye!: Listen to me with patience.

Anon!: But if it be a sin to covet honor, I am the most offending soul alive.
Goodbye!: But if it’s a sin to covet honor, I’m the most offending soul alive.

Anon!: Our brother is imprisoned by your means, Myself disgraced, and the nobility Held in contempt, while great promotions Are daily given to ennoble those That scarce some two days since were worth a noble.
Goodbye!: Our brother is imprisoned by your means, myself disgraced, and the noblest is held in contempt, while great promotions are given daily to ennoble those who scarcely survived two days of

Anon!: I' th' mire.
Goodbye!: I’m in the mire.

Anon!: No marrying ’mong his subjects?
Goodbye!: Isn’t he marrying his subjects?

Anon!: Nay then, let the devil wear black, for I’ll have a suit of sables.
Goodbye!: No, then, let the devil wear black, because I’ll have a suit of sables.

Anon!: All this done Upon the gad?—Edmund, how now?
Goodbye!: All this is done on the day?—Edmund, what’s going on?

Anon!: My lord, I would that Thursday were tomorrow.
Goodbye!: My lord, I wish Thursday were tomorrow.

Anon!: Let us go.
Goodbye!: Let’s go.

Anon!: Ay, sir.
Goodbye!: Yes, sir.

Anon!: Thou shalt not back till I have borne this corse Into the marketplace.
Goodbye!: You won’t go back until I’ve brought this corse into the marketplace.

Anon!: Well, but to my choice.
Goodbye!: Well, I’m not sure.

Anon!: Balm his foul head in warm distilled waters And burn sweet wood to make the lodging sweet.
Goodbye!: Balm his foul head in warm, distilled water and burn sweet wood to make the lodging sweet.

Anon!: This must crave— An if this be at all—a most strange story.
Goodbye!: This is a strange story—if it’s all about it.

Anon!: A fair name.
Goodbye!: A good name.

Anon!: I, as I may—that which I would I cannot,— With best advantage will deceive the time, And aid thee in this doubtful shock of arms.
Goodbye!: I’ll do whatever I can—which I can’t do.

Anon!: O bloody Richard!
Goodbye!: Oh bloody Richard!

Anon!: An if I be, sir, is it any offense?
Goodbye!: Is it any offense, sir?

Anon!: There’s fire ready.
Goodbye!: There’s a fire ready.

Anon!: She will not come.
Goodbye!: She won’t come.

Anon!: Dost thou understand me, man?
Goodbye!: Do you understand me, man?

Anon!: Good my lord.
Goodbye!: Good, my lord.

Anon!: What noise is that?
Goodbye!: What’s that noise?

Anon!: Full many a lady I have eyed with best regard and many a time
Goodbye!: I’ve seen many women with the best regard and many times

Anon!: If thou dost I shall never love thee after.
Goodbye!: If you do, I’ll never love you again.

Anon!: If you did wear a beard upon your chin, I’d shake it on this quarrel.
Goodbye!: If you wore a beard on your chin, I’d shake it on this fight.

Anon!: Do you find Your patience so predominant in your nature That you can let this go?
Goodbye!: Do you feel so dreadful that you can let this go?

Anon!: Yet ’tis the plague to great ones, Prerogatived are they less than the base.
Goodbye!: But it’s the plague to great people, and the king’s rights are less than the base.

Anon!: To England will I steal, and there I’ll steal.
Goodbye!: I’ll go to England, and I’ll go there.

Anon!: They have not been commanded, mighty king.
Goodbye!: They haven’t been commanded, mighty king.

Anon!: Monster, I will kill this man.
Goodbye!: Monster, I’ll kill this man.

Anon!: Why, horns, which such as you are fain to be beholding to your wives for.
Goodbye!: Why, horns, which you’re faking to beholding to your wives for.

Anon!: I long to hear him call the drunkard “husband,” And how my men will stay themselves from laughter When they do homage to this simple peasant.
Goodbye!: I’m waiting to hear him call the drunkard “husband” and how my men will keep themselves from laughing when they honor this simple peasant.

Anon!: Thus hath he lost sixpence a day during his life.
Goodbye!: So he lost sixpence a day during his life.

Anon!: She false with Cassio!
Goodbye!: She’s false with Cassio!

Anon!: I serve as good a man as you.
Goodbye!: I’m as good a man as you are.

Anon!: Why, thou hast put him in such a dream that when the image of it leaves him he must run mad.
Goodbye!: Why, you’ve put him in such a dream that when the image of it leaves him, he’ll run crazy.

Anon!: But come what sorrow can, It cannot countervail the exchange of joy That one short minute gives me in her sight.
Goodbye!: But if you come to see what sorrow can do, it can’t counteract the joy I’ve had in her sight for a minute.

Anon!: Lady, come from that nest Of death, contagion, and unnatural sleep.
Goodbye!: Lady, come from that nest of death, contagion, and unnatural sleep.

Anon!: But If thou dost break her virgin knot before All sanctimonious ceremonies may With full and holy rite be ministered, No sweet aspersion shall the heavens let fall To make this contract grow, but barren hate, Sour-eyed disdain, and discord shall bestrew The union of your bed with weeds so loathly That you shall hate it both.
Goodbye!: But if you break her virgin knot before all holy ceremonies can be celebrated, the heavens won’t let fall to make this contract grow, but barren hate, sane disdain, and discord will best

Anon!: Most shallow man.
Goodbye!: The most shallow man.

Anon!: I will omit no opportunity That may convey my greetings, love, to thee.
Goodbye!: I won’t give you any opportunity to express my love, my love.

Anon!: I grant indeed it hath not appeared, and your suspicion is not without wit and judgment.
Goodbye!: I’m sure it hasn’t appeared, and your suspicion isn’t without wit and judgment.

Anon!: Look thou but sweet, And I am proof against their enmity.
Goodbye!: Look, you’re sweet, and I’m proof against their enmity.

Anon!: Yet, in reason, no man should possess him with any appearance of fear, lest he, by showing it, should dishearten his army.
Goodbye!: But if he shows it, he’ll dishearten his army.

Anon!: Caesar, beware of Brutus.
Goodbye!: Caesar, beware of Brutus.

Anon!: But stay awhile.
Goodbye!: But stay for a while.

Anon!: I think our father will hence tonight.
Goodbye!: I think our father will leave here tonight.

Anon!: Do not think it so unwholesome.
Goodbye!: Don’t think it’s so unwholesome.

Anon!: A bitter fool.
Goodbye!: A bitter fool.

Anon!: He is my prisoner.
Goodbye!: He’s my prisoner.

Anon!: Come, we burn daylight, ho!
Goodbye!: Come on, we’re burning daylight!

Anon!: Get him to bed, and let his hurt be looked to.
Goodbye!: Get him to bed and let his hurt be treated.

Anon!: Call, good Mercutio.
Goodbye!: Call me, good Mercutio.

Anon!: See, here he comes.
Goodbye!: Here he comes.

Anon!: You must be father to your brother’s daughter, And give her to young Claudio.
Goodbye!: You must be your brother’s father and give her to Claudio.

Anon!: What is the matter?
Goodbye!: What’s the matter?

Anon!: Near and on speedy foot.
Goodbye!: Very close and on a fast foot.

Anon!: How low am I?
Goodbye!: How low am I?

Anon!: Come, sire, no more.—What, Oswald, ho!
Goodbye!: Come on, sire, no more.—Oh, Oswald, ho!

Anon!: Nor is he dead, for aught that I can tell.
Goodbye!: He’s not dead, for what I can tell.

Anon!: His highness is not well.
Goodbye!: His highness is not well.

Anon!: Still it cried, “Sleep no more!” to all the house.
Goodbye!: It cried, “Sleep no more!” to all the house.

Anon!: All men I hope live so.
Goodbye!: I hope all men live as they do.

Anon!: I must be gone.
Goodbye!: I have to go.

Anon!: If any such there be, heaven pardon him!
Goodbye!: If there’s anything like that, heaven pardon him!

Anon!: Farewell.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: Well, God give them wisdom that have it.
Goodbye!: Well, God give them wisdom.

Anon!: Antony Did tell me of you, bade me trust you, but I do not greatly care to be deceived, That have no use for trusting.
Goodbye!: Antony told me of you, tell me to trust you, but I don’t care to be deceived, who don’t have any use for trusting.

Anon!: Words before blows.
Goodbye!: Words before blows.

Anon!: Caesar doth bear me hard, but he loves Brutus.
Goodbye!: Caesar is hard on me, but he loves Brutus.

Anon!: It is not honesty in me to speak What I have seen and known.
Goodbye!: I don’t have the honesty to speak about what I’ve seen and heard.

Anon!: Fire and brimstone!
Goodbye!: Fire and brimstone!

Anon!: Nothing, unless you render her again.
Goodbye!: Nothing, unless you render her again.

Anon!: Yet Benedick was such another, and now is he become a man.
Goodbye!: But Benedick was such a man, and now he’s become a man.

Anon!: First, know my horse is tired, my master and mistress fallen out.
Goodbye!: First, know my horse is tired, my master and mistress have fallen out.

Anon!: How, how, how, how?
Goodbye!: How, how, how, how?

Anon!: Oh, who hath done this deed?
Goodbye!: Who did this deed?

Anon!: Well, I’ll break in.
Goodbye!: Well, I’ll break in.

Anon!: We, at the height, are ready to decline.
Goodbye!: We’re ready to decline at the height of this country.

Anon!: Iago?
Goodbye!: Iago?

Anon!: Had I a glass, I would.
Goodbye!: If I had a glass, I would.

Anon!: Therefore thy earliness doth me assure Thou art uproused by some distemperature.
Goodbye!: So I assure you’re a bit sane.

Anon!: Sweet Hero, now thy image doth appear In the rare semblance that I loved it first.
Goodbye!: Sweet Hero, now your image is like a rare semblance that I loved it first.

Anon!: Caesar shall forth.
Goodbye!: Caesar will go.

Anon!: She is our capital demand, comprised Within the forerank of our articles.
Goodbye!: She’s the capital demand, which is comprised of the relics of our articles.

Anon!: And so farewell, Signior Lucentio.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, Signior Lucentio.

Anon!: True,” said she, “a fine little one.” “No,” said I, “a great wit.” “Right,” says she, “a great gross one.” “Nay,” said I, “a good wit.” “Just,” said she, “it hurts nobody.” “Nay,” said I, “the gentleman is wise.” “Certain,” said she, “a wise gentleman.” “Nay,” said I, “he hath the tongues.” “That I believe,” said she, “for he swore a thing to me on Monday night, which he forswore on Tuesday morning; there’s a double tongue, there’s two tongues.” Thus did she an hour together transshape thy particular virtues.
Goodbye!: “No,” said she, “a fine little man.” “No,” said I, “a great wit.” “Right,” says she, “a great gross one.” “No,” said I, “a good wit.”

Anon!: Ev'n as your horse bears your praises—who would trot as well were some of your brags dismounted.
Goodbye!: You’d trot as well if some of your brags were dismounted.

Anon!: Why, friends, you go to do you know not what.
Goodbye!: Friends, you’re going to do you don’t know what.

Anon!: Well, sir, good night.
Goodbye!: Well, sir, good night.

Anon!: What though he love your Hermia?
Goodbye!: What if he love your Hermia?

Anon!: I am not to you known, Though in your state of honor I am perfect.
Goodbye!: I’m not known to you, even though I’m perfect in your honor.

Anon!: Letters, my lord, from Hamlet.
Goodbye!: Letters from Hamlet, my lord.

Anon!: That will I, should I die the hour after.
Goodbye!: I will, if I die the hour afterward.

Anon!: My lord, you shall o'errule my mind for once.— Come on, Lord Hastings, will you go with me?
Goodbye!: My lord, you’ll be able to rule my mind for a moment.—Come on, Lord Hastings, will you go with me?

Anon!: No, coz, I rather weep.
Goodbye!: No, coz, I’d rather cry.

Anon!: The mercy that was quick in us but late By your own counsel is suppressed and killed.
Goodbye!: The mercy that was quick in us but late by your own counsel was suppressed and killed.

Anon!: I’ll leave you.
Goodbye!: I’ll leave you.

Anon!: Nay, an I tell you that, I’ll ne'er look you i' th' face again.
Goodbye!: No, if I tell you that, I’ll never look at you again.

Anon!: He’s safe for these three hours.
Goodbye!: He’s safe for these three hours.

Anon!: Did you say all?
Goodbye!: Did you say everything?

Anon!: O woeful day!
Goodbye!: Oh, what a sad day!

Anon!: And a chain, that you once wore, about his neck.
Goodbye!: And a necklace, you wore one time, about his neck.

Anon!: I’ll follow him no more with bootless prayers.
Goodbye!: I won’t follow him again with scolding prayers.

Anon!: Since his majesty went into the field, I have seen her rise from her bed, throw her nightgown upon her, unlock her closet, take forth paper, fold it, write upon ’t, read it, afterwards seal it, and again return to bed; yet all this while in a most fast sleep.
Goodbye!: Since his majesty went into the field, I’ve seen her rise from her bed, throw her nightgown on her, unlock her closet, take out paper, fold it, write it on it, read it, then

Anon!: Seal up the mouth of outrage for a while, Till we can clear these ambiguities And know their spring, their head, their true descent, And then will I be general of your woes, And lead you even to death.
Goodbye!: Wait a while until we can clear these ambiguities and know their origin, their head, their true descent.

Anon!: Pronounce.
Goodbye!: Pronounce.

Anon!: Long live the king!
Goodbye!: Long live the king!

Anon!: No money, on my faith, but the gleek.
Goodbye!: No money, I swear.

Anon!: Why should he not?
Goodbye!: Why shouldn’t he?

Anon!: Is Rosaline, whom thou didst love so dear, So soon forsaken?
Goodbye!: Is Rosaline, whom you loved so much, so soon forsaken?

Anon!: Do you put tricks upon ’s with savages and men of Ind, ha?
Goodbye!: Do you put tricks on a bunch of savages and men of Ind, ha?

Anon!: I speak not as in absolute fear of you.
Goodbye!: I’m not saying anything in fear about you.

Anon!: Marry, I will, and this is wisely done.
Goodbye!: I will, and this is wisely done.

Anon!: Go call him hither.
Goodbye!: Go call him here.

Anon!: But how hath she received his love?
Goodbye!: But how did she receive his love?

Anon!: Let housewifery appear.
Goodbye!: Let housewifery appear.

Anon!: When in that moment so it came to pass, Titania waked and straightway loved an ass.
Goodbye!: When it came to pass, Titania woke up and sat straight away in love with an ass.

Anon!: This will put them out of fear.
Goodbye!: This will put them out of fear.

Anon!: Arms, arms, sword, fire, corruption in the place!
Goodbye!: Arms, arms, sword, fire, corruption in the place!

Anon!: Tis almost morning.
Goodbye!: It’s almost morning.

Anon!: Yes, sir.
Goodbye!: Yes, sir.

Anon!: The adventurous knight shall use his foil and target, the lover shall not sigh gratis, the humorous man shall end his part in peace, the clown shall make those laugh whose lungs are tickle o' th' sear, and the lady shall say her mind freely, or the blank verse shall halt for ’t.
Goodbye!: The adventurous knight will use his foil and target, the lover won’t sigh gratis, the funny man will end his life in peace, the clown will make those who laugh with their lungs tickle, and the lady will say

Anon!: This falls out better than I could devise.
Goodbye!: This is better than I could imagine.

Anon!: My dear Othello!
Goodbye!: My dear Othello!

Anon!: Then let your servants bring my husband forth.
Goodbye!: Then let your servants bring my husband out.

Anon!: It is, it is.
Goodbye!: It is, it is.

Anon!: Turning th' accomplishment of many years Into an hour-glass; for the which supply, Admit me chorus to this history; Who, prologue-like, your humble patience pray Gently to hear, kindly to judge our play.
Goodbye!: I’ll give you a chorus to this history.

Anon!: And I for Rosalind.
Goodbye!: And I for Rosalind.

Anon!: And if it stand, as you yourself still do, Within the eye of honor, be assured My purse, my person, my extremest means Lie all unlocked to your occasions.
Goodbye!: And if it’s true, as you do, please, keep me in my purse, my person, my extremest means, and Lie all over your days.

Anon!: I love your majesty According to my bond, no more nor less.
Goodbye!: I love your majesty, according to my contract, neither more nor less.

Anon!: I am transformèd, master, am I not?
Goodbye!: I’ve been transformed, master, am I?

Anon!: Therefore, farewell.
Goodbye!: So goodbye.

Anon!: I will go with thee.
Goodbye!: I’ll go with you.

Anon!: Then weep no more.
Goodbye!: Then don’t cry.

Anon!: Let not the royal bed of Denmark be A couch for luxury and damnèd incest.
Goodbye!: Don’t let the royal bed of Denmark be a couch for luxury and damned incest.

Anon!: I have not breathed almost since I did see it.
Goodbye!: I’ve not breathed since I saw it.

Anon!: Brutus is wise, and were he not in health, He would embrace the means to come by it.
Goodbye!: Brutus is wise, and if he weren’t in good health, he’d embrace the means to come by it.

Anon!: What is the matter?
Goodbye!: What’s the matter?

Anon!: This if she perform, She shall not sue unheard.
Goodbye!: If she performs, she won’t be able to sue anyone.

Anon!: But after many ceremonies done, He calls for wine.
Goodbye!: But after many ceremonies, he calls for wine.

Anon!: Then, lest he may, prevent.
Goodbye!: Then, if he can, stop.

Anon!: No, faith, lords and great men will not let me.
Goodbye!: No, please, lords and great men will not let me.

Anon!: Not proud you have, but thankful that you have.
Goodbye!: You’re not proud of me, but you’re thankful for you.

Anon!: He hath twice or thrice cut Cupid’s bow-string, and the little hangman dare not shoot at him.
Goodbye!: He’s cut Cupid’s bow twice or twice, and the little hangman doesn’t dare shoot at him.

Anon!: Oh, ’tish ill done, ’tish ill done, by my hand, ’tish ill done.
Goodbye!: Oh, it’s ill done, it’s ill done, by my hand, it’s ill done.

Anon!: I’ll fetch them, sir.
Goodbye!: I’ll get them, sir.

Anon!: Come, Romeo.
Goodbye!: Come, Romeo.

Anon!: Now, fellow, What is there?
Goodbye!: Now, fellow, what’s there?

Anon!: Many will swoon when they do look on blood.
Goodbye!: Many people will swoon when they look at blood.

Anon!: Think you my uncle did dissemble, grandam?
Goodbye!: Do you think my uncle was dissembling you, grandam?

Anon!: Tybalt’s death Was woe enough, if it had ended there.
Goodbye!: Tybalt’s death was a terrible one if it had ended there.

Anon!: So please you, we will stand and watch your pleasure.
Goodbye!: Please, we’ll stand and watch you enjoy.

Anon!: The wolves have preyed, and look, the gentle day, Before the wheels of Phoebus, round about Dapples the drowsy east with spots of grey.
Goodbye!: The wolves have preyed on the drowsy east, and look at the gentle day, before the wheels of Phoebus, around the corner.

Anon!: Farewell.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: Is it within reason and compass?
Goodbye!: Is it reasonable and compassable?

Anon!: Hood my unmanned blood bating in my cheeks, With thy black mantle, till strange love, grow bold, Think true love acted simple modesty.
Goodbye!: Hood my unmanned blood batting in my cheeks, with your black mantle, until strange love grows bold, think true love acted simple modesty.

Anon!: A piece of him.
Goodbye!: A piece of him.

Anon!: Dead, then?
Goodbye!: That’s dead, then?

Anon!: How otherwise?— Will you be ruled by me?
Goodbye!: How would you be ruled by me?

Anon!: We shall know by this fellow.
Goodbye!: We’ll know by this fellow.

Anon!: Thus with a kiss I die.
Goodbye!: So I die with a kiss.

Anon!: I will construe to them whence you come.
Goodbye!: I’ll tell them when you come.

Anon!: Tis certain then for Cyprus.
Goodbye!: That’s true for Cyprus.

Anon!: If that the Turkish fleet Be not ensheltered and embayed, they are drowned.
Goodbye!: If the Turkish fleet isn’t protected and embayed, they’re drowned.

Anon!: Would I were sleep and peace, so sweet to rest.
Goodbye!: I wish I were sleep and quiet, so I could rest.

Anon!: And, as thou badest me, In troops I have dispersed them 'bout the isle.
Goodbye!: And, as you are, I’ve dispersed them in troops to keep them in the island.

Anon!: For he is, sure, i' th' island.
Goodbye!: He’s certainly on the island.

Anon!: Is my father well?
Goodbye!: Is my father well?

Anon!: Sleep thou, and I will wind thee in my arms.
Goodbye!: Sleep, and I’ll wind you in my arms.

Anon!: Bade him anon return and here speak with me, The which he promised.
Goodbye!: Tell him to come back and speak with me, the one he promised.

Anon!: Give him no breath, but now Make boot of his distraction.
Goodbye!: Don’t give him breath, but now take advantage of his distraction.

Anon!: I prithee, tell me who is it quickly, and speak apace.
Goodbye!: Please tell me who it is quickly, and speak quickly.

Anon!: Call her forth to me.
Goodbye!: Call her out to me.

Anon!: That shall she.
Goodbye!: That will be her.

Anon!: Tis a match.
Goodbye!: It’s a match.

Anon!: Go, be gone.
Goodbye!: Go, go away.

Anon!: Prepare the body then, and follow us.
Goodbye!: Prepare the body then and follow us.

Anon!: Then to the wood will he tomorrow night Pursue her.
Goodbye!: Then he’ll go to the wood tomorrow night.

Anon!: Ha?
Goodbye!: Ha?

Anon!: Mark him.
Goodbye!: Mark him.

Anon!: I fear me you’ll be in till then.
Goodbye!: I’m afraid you’ll be in until then.

Anon!: Why, whose is it?
Goodbye!: Why, whose name is it?

Anon!: Or is the adder better than the eel Because his painted skin contents the eye?
Goodbye!: Or is the eal better than the eal because his painted skin is full of eyes?

Anon!: His name is Balthazar.
Goodbye!: His name is Balthazar.

Anon!: Is not your husband mad?
Goodbye!: Isn’t your husband crazy?

Anon!: Make thee a fortune from me.
Goodbye!: Make yourself a fortune from me.

Anon!: Ay, is ’t, I warrant him.
Goodbye!: Yes, is it, I assure him.

Anon!: For shame, bring Juliet forth.
Goodbye!: For shame, bring Juliet out.

Anon!: And is it not well served into a sweet goose?
Goodbye!: And isn’t it good served as a sweet goose?

Anon!: How now?
Goodbye!: What’s going on?

Anon!: I am aweary.
Goodbye!: I’m tired.

Anon!: What ceremony else?
Goodbye!: What else?

Anon!: And therefore is winged Cupid painted blind.
Goodbye!: So Cupid is painted blind.

Anon!: My mistress with a monster is in love.
Goodbye!: My mistress is in love with a monster.

Anon!: And when he saw my best alarumed spirits, Bold in the quarrel’s right, roused to the encounter, Or whether ghasted by the noise I made, Full suddenly he fled.
Goodbye!: And when he saw my best spirits, scolded in the fight’s right, roused to the encounter, or ghasted by the noise I made, he suddenly fled.

Anon!: I can no more.
Goodbye!: I can’t do anything else.

Anon!: Was this ambition?
Goodbye!: Was this ambition?

Anon!: They are beaten, sir, and our advantage serves For a fair victory.
Goodbye!: They’re beaten, sir, and our advantage is a good victory.

Anon!: I meant plain holy thistle.
Goodbye!: I meant a holy thistle.

Anon!: I am sorry I beat thee.
Goodbye!: I’m sorry I beat you.

Anon!: I am not for this ambling.
Goodbye!: I’m not for this ambling.

Anon!: Be not ta'en tardy by unwise delay.
Goodbye!: Don’t delay yourself in a hurry.

Anon!: Where is my love?
Goodbye!: Where is my love?

Anon!: I am gone, though I am here.
Goodbye!: I’m gone, even though I’m here.

Anon!: But though thou art adjudgèd to the death, And passèd sentence may not be recalled But to our honour’s great disparagement, Yet will I favor thee in what I can.
Goodbye!: But even though you’re adjudgmented to death, and you’re not recalled to our honour for the slander, I’ll favor you in all my possible efforts.

Anon!: Go, go, good countrymen, and for this fault, Assemble all the poor men of your sort, Draw them to Tiber banks, and weep your tears Into the channel till the lowest stream Do kiss the most exalted shores of all.
Goodbye!: Go, good countrymen, and for this reason, assemble all the poor men of your kind, draw them to Tiber banks, and weep your tears into the channel until the lowest stream kisses the most ex

Anon!: No?
Goodbye!: No?

Anon!: Mars’s hot minion is returned again.
Goodbye!: Mars’s hot minion is back again.

Anon!: My husband lost his life to get the crown, And often up and down my sons were tossed For me to joy, and weep, their gain and loss.
Goodbye!: My husband lost his life to get the crown, and often my sons were tossed for me to joy and weep about their losses.

Anon!: I prithee, pretty York, who told thee this?
Goodbye!: Please, pretty York, who told you this?

Anon!: If from the field I shall return once more To kiss these lips, I will appear in blood.
Goodbye!: If I’m back from the field again to kiss these lips, I’ll appear in blood.

Anon!: In your dumps?
Goodbye!: Are you in your dumps?

Anon!: Get you to bed, faith.
Goodbye!: Go to bed, I swear.

Anon!: And discourse fustian with one’s own shadow?
Goodbye!: And what’s the sex of a man?

Anon!: I will but spend a word here in the house And go with you.
Goodbye!: I’ll only spend a word here in the house and go with you.

Anon!: Then away she started To deal with grief alone.
Goodbye!: Then she started to deal with grief alone.

Anon!: No, Kate?
Goodbye!: No, Kate?

Anon!: Call me what instrument you will, though you can fret me, yet you cannot play upon me.
Goodbye!: Call me what instrument you want, even if you can’t fret me, but you can’t play on me.

Anon!: An honest man he is, and hates the slime That sticks on filthy deeds.
Goodbye!: He’s an honest man, and he hates the slime that sticks to filthy deeds.

Anon!: And then came Pyramus.
Goodbye!: And then came Pyramus.

Anon!: Why, such is love’s transgression.
Goodbye!: Why, love is transgressing.

Anon!: Mass, and well said.
Goodbye!: Well, and well said.

Anon!: Her eye in heaven Would through the airy region stream so bright That birds would sing and think it were not night.
Goodbye!: Her eyes would be so bright in the air that birds would sing and think it wasn’t night.

Anon!: I am peppered, I warrant, for this world.
Goodbye!: I’m scolded for this world, I swear.

Anon!: Lysander’s love, that would not let him bide, Fair Helena, who more engilds the night Than all yon fiery oes and eyes of light.
Goodbye!: Lysander’s love, who wouldn’t let him bide, is more a savage night than all the fiery oes and light.

Anon!: Oh, now forever Farewell the tranquil mind!
Goodbye!: Oh, goodbye to the calm mind now.

Anon!: My lord?
Goodbye!: My lord?

Anon!: I do I know not what and fear to find Mine eye too great a flatterer for my mind.
Goodbye!: I don’t know what I’m thinking, and I’m afraid to find my eye too flattering for me.

Anon!: Trinculo, if you trouble him any more in ’s tale, by this hand, I will supplant some of your teeth.
Goodbye!: Trinculo, if you bother him more in the story, I’ll supplant some of your teeth with this hand.

Anon!: If you are so fond over her iniquity, give her patent to offend, for if it touch not you it comes near nobody.
Goodbye!: If you’re so fond of her iniquity, give her permission to offend her, because if it doesn’t touch you, it’s close to nobody.

Anon!: If any ship put out, then straight away.
Goodbye!: If any ship is out, then you’ll get out of here immediately.

Anon!: He’ll speak with you, will you or no.
Goodbye!: He’ll speak with you, will you or not.

Anon!: Shake it off.
Goodbye!: Shake it off.

Anon!: Kill men i' th' dark!
Goodbye!: Kill men in the dark!

Anon!: I am to blame to be thus waited for.
Goodbye!: I’m to blame for waiting for it.

Anon!: A worthy pioneer!
Goodbye!: A worthy pioneer!

Anon!: I pray thee, chide not.
Goodbye!: Please don’t chide me.

Anon!: He’ll make your Paris Louvre shake for it, Were it the mistress court of mighty Europe.
Goodbye!: He’ll shake your Paris Louvre for it, if it were the mistress court of mighty Europe.

Anon!: I must go with you to Belmont.
Goodbye!: I have to go with you to Belmont.

Anon!: For shame, put on your gown.
Goodbye!: For shame, put on your gown.

Anon!: For my part, I am sorry it is turned to a drinking.
Goodbye!: I’m sorry it’s turned into a drink.

Anon!: Take thou that.
Goodbye!: Take that.

Anon!: Sure, I shall never marry like my sisters, To love my father all.
Goodbye!: I’ll never marry like my sisters, to love my father all.

Anon!: Where is the evidence that doth accuse me?
Goodbye!: Where’s the evidence that accuses me?

Anon!: But I’ll be hanged, sir, if he wear your livery.
Goodbye!: But I’ll be hanged if he wears your livery.

Anon!: When didst thou sleep when such a deed was done?
Goodbye!: When did you sleep when such a deed was done?

Anon!: Come they of noble family?
Goodbye!: Are they from a noble family?

Anon!: There’s comfort yet; they are assailable.
Goodbye!: There’s still comfort, they’re assailable.

Anon!: I will go on the slightest errand now to the Antipodes that you can devise to send me on.
Goodbye!: I’ll go on the slightest errand to the Antipodes, which you can devise to send me on.

Anon!: Heavens, I am the best of them that speak this speech, Were I but where ’tis spoken.
Goodbye!: Heavens, I’m the best of them to speak this, if I were only where it was spoken.

Anon!: O sir, to wilful men, The injuries that they themselves procure Must be their schoolmasters.
Goodbye!: Oh, sir, to wilful men, the injuries they themselves get must be their schoolmasters.

Anon!: The star is fall’n.
Goodbye!: The star is falling.

Anon!: Never, my lord.
Goodbye!: Never, my lord.

Anon!: Thy life’s a miracle.
Goodbye!: Your life is a miracle.

Anon!: My necessaries are embarked.
Goodbye!: My lords are on their way.

Anon!: It is not seen enough; you should wear it in your cap.
Goodbye!: It’s not seen enough, but you should wear it in your cap.

Anon!: Thank God.” A good answer.
Goodbye!: Thank God.” That’s a good answer.

Anon!: O noble sir!
Goodbye!: Oh, noble sir!

Anon!: I found you as a morsel cold upon Dead Caesar’s trencher.
Goodbye!: I found you as a morsel cold on Dead Caesar’s trencher.

Anon!: Raise up the Montagues.
Goodbye!: Raise up the Montagues.

Anon!: In God’s name, speak.
Goodbye!: In God’s name, speak.

Anon!: Let us be conjunctive in our revenge against him.
Goodbye!: Let’s be conjunctive in our revenge against him.

Anon!: These things, come thus to light, Smother her spirits up.
Goodbye!: These things, come to light, smother her spirits.

Anon!: Were he not warmed with ale, This were a bed but cold to sleep so soundly.
Goodbye!: If he weren’t warmed with ale, this would be a bed but a cold place to sleep so well.

Anon!: I never hated thee.
Goodbye!: I never hated you.

Anon!: Turn the sands into eloquent tongues, and my horse is argument for them all.
Goodbye!: Turn the sands into eloquent tongues, and my horse is a good argument for them all.

Anon!: A maiden never bold, Of spirit so still and quiet that her motion Blushed at herself.
Goodbye!: A woman never bold, so quiet and still alive that her motion shook her head.

Anon!: And the hour, I think, is come To give him hearing.
Goodbye!: And I think the hour is coming to give him a hearing.

Anon!: My charity is outrage, life my shame, And in that shame still live my sorrows' rage.
Goodbye!: My charity is outrage, my life is my shame, and in that shame I’m still in rage.

Anon!: Upon my life, my lord, I’ll undertake it.
Goodbye!: I’ll do it on my life, my lord.

Anon!: Hath she forsook so many noble matches, Her father and her country, and her friends, To be called “whore”?
Goodbye!: Has she forsooped so many noble matches, her father and her country, and her friends, to be called “whore”?

Anon!: I would not follow him then.
Goodbye!: I wouldn’t follow him then.

Anon!: Those being all my study, The government I cast upon my brother And to my state grew stranger, being transported And rapt in secret studies.
Goodbye!: I was a stranger to my brother, and I was rapting them in secret.

Anon!: I do not think it good.
Goodbye!: I don’t think it’s good.

Anon!: Why, therefore fire, for I have caught extreme cold.
Goodbye!: So fire, because I’ve caught extreme cold.

Anon!: Lorenzo, I commit into your hands The husbandry and manage of my house Until my lord’s return.
Goodbye!: Lorenzo, I’ll be able to handle my house until my lord returns.

Anon!: But for my daughter Katherine, this I know, She is not for your turn, the more my grief.
Goodbye!: But for my daughter Katherine, I know that she isn’t for you, the more I’m grieving.

Anon!: They must take it in sense that feel it.
Goodbye!: They must take it in the sense that they feel it.

Anon!: What, not a word?
Goodbye!: What, not a word?

Anon!: Faith, we may put up our pipes and be gone.
Goodbye!: Yes, we can put up our pipes and go away.

Anon!: He is afeard to come.
Goodbye!: He’s afraid to come.

Anon!: Yes, as sparrows eagles, or the hare the lion.
Goodbye!: Yes, as sparrows eagles, or the hare the lion.

Anon!: Yet do I not use my horse for my mistress, or any such proverb so little kin to the purpose.
Goodbye!: But I don’t use my horse for my mistress, or any other proverb that’s so little about it.

Anon!: Demand me nothing.
Goodbye!: Don’t ask me anything.

Anon!: O limèd soul that, struggling to be free, Art more engaged!
Goodbye!: Oh, a limod soul who’s struggling to be free, and is more engaged!

Anon!: You should be ruled and led By some discretion that discerns your state Better than you yourself.
Goodbye!: You should be ruled and led by some discernment that makes you better than you yourself.

Anon!: She is too fair, too wise, wisely too fair, To merit bliss by making me despair.
Goodbye!: She’s too fair, too wise, too fair to merit bliss by making me despair.

Anon!: Why, that same pale hard-hearted wench, that Rosaline, Torments him so, that he will sure run mad.
Goodbye!: That pale, hard-hearted wench, Rosaline, Torture him so much that he’ll run insane.

Anon!: O thou invisible spirit of wine, if thou hast no name to be known by, let us call thee devil!
Goodbye!: Oh, you invisible spirit of wine, if you have no name to be known by, let’s call you the devil!

Anon!: I bring thee tidings of the Prince’s doom.
Goodbye!: I’ll bring you a story about the Prince’s death.

Anon!: So good night unto you all.
Goodbye!: Good night to you all.

Anon!: First, good Peter Quince, say what the play treats on, then read the names of the actors, and so grow to a point.
Goodbye!: First, good Peter Quince, tell me what the play is about, then read the names of the actors, and so get to a point.

Anon!: Here’s one comes in his shirt, with light and weapons.
Goodbye!: Here’s one who comes in his shirt with light and weapons.

Anon!: Farewell, my lord.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, my lord.

Anon!: I’ll no more of you.
Goodbye!: I won’t see any more of you.

Anon!: You always end with a jade’s trick.
Goodbye!: You’re always going to end with a jade’s trick.

Anon!: Soft, Caesar.
Goodbye!: Soft, Caesar.

Anon!: The Duke does greet you, general, And he requires your haste-post-haste appearance, Even on the instant.
Goodbye!: The Duke greets you, general, and he’ll have to wait for you to get your appearance ready.

Anon!: Never alone Did the king sigh, but with a general groan.
Goodbye!: The king never sighed alone, but with a general groan.

Anon!: Do not deny to him that you love me.
Goodbye!: Don’t deny to him that you love me.

Anon!: Therefore speak.
Goodbye!: So speak.

Anon!: O plague right well prevented!
Goodbye!: Oh, plague has been prevented!

Anon!: A gentle riddance.—Draw the curtains, go.— Let all of his complexion choose me so.
Goodbye!: A gentle riddance.—Draw the curtains, go.—Let all his skin choose me like that.

Anon!: Fair daylight?
Goodbye!: Good daylight?

Anon!: Wherefore?
Goodbye!: Why?

Anon!: O heavens, that such companions thou’dst unfold, And put in every honest hand a whip To lash the rascals naked through the world Even from the east to th' west!
Goodbye!: Oh heavens, that such companions you’d be able to escape, and put in every hand a whip to lash the rascals naked through the world, from the east to the west!

Anon!: Fetch forth the stocks!
Goodbye!: Get out of here!

Anon!: Well, say, sir.
Goodbye!: Well, sir.

Anon!: Say from whence You owe this strange intelligence, or why Upon this blasted heath you stop our way With such prophetic greeting.
Goodbye!: Tell me from the time you owe this strange intelligence, or why you’re stopping our way on this blasted heat with such prophetic greetings.

Anon!: Have you that I sent you for?
Goodbye!: Have you been sent for?

Anon!: Chill not let go, zir, without vurther 'casion.
Goodbye!: Don’t let go of it, sir, without a sigh of a sigh.

Anon!: I must go seek some dewdrops here  And hang a pearl in every cowslip’s ear.
Goodbye!: I have to go find some dewdrops here and hang a pearl in every cowslip’s ear.

Anon!: Is he dead?
Goodbye!: Is he dead?

Anon!: My dearest coz, I pray you school yourself.
Goodbye!: My dearest coz, please, you’re going to school yourself.

Anon!: Now does my project gather to a head.
Goodbye!: Now I’m going to a head.

Anon!: Shall not be long but I’ll be here again.
Goodbye!: It won’t be long, but I’ll be here again.

Anon!: I will return again into the house and desire some conduct of the lady.
Goodbye!: I’ll go back into the house again and ask the lady to do some work.

Anon!: Here on her breast There is a vent of blood, and something blown.
Goodbye!: Here on her breast there’s a vent of blood, and something has been blown.

Anon!: Marry, beshrew my hand If it should give your age such cause of fear.
Goodbye!: I’ll bet my hand if it’s a reason to be afraid of you.

Anon!: This is her very guise; and, upon my life, fast asleep.
Goodbye!: This is her very guise, and I’m asleep fast.

Anon!: I feel this pinprick.
Goodbye!: I feel this pinprick.

Anon!: He hath been out nine years, and away he shall again.
Goodbye!: He’s been out for nine years, and he’ll be out again.

Anon!: When the mind’s free, The body’s delicate.
Goodbye!: When the mind is free, the body’s delicate.

Anon!: How canst thou try them so?
Goodbye!: How can you try them like that?

Anon!: The bridegroom he is come already.
Goodbye!: He’s already coming to the bridegroom.

Anon!: Do, do.
Goodbye!: Do it.

Anon!: Who’s his lieutenant, hear you?
Goodbye!: Who’s his lieutenant, can you hear him?

Anon!: Beguiled, divorcèd, wrongèd, spited, slain!
Goodbye!: Beguiled, divorced, wronged, spited, killed!

Anon!: Young Edward lives; think now what I would speak.
Goodbye!: Young Edward lives; think about what I want to say.

Anon!: When, without stratagem, But in plain shock and even play of battle, Was ever known so great and little loss On one part and on th' other?
Goodbye!: When, without a slur, but in a slur and even a battle, was ever so much and little loss on the one and the other part?

Anon!: Not stingless too?
Goodbye!: Not stingy too?

Anon!: The greater therefore should our courage be.
Goodbye!: The greater we should be, therefore.

Anon!: My charms crack not, my spirits obey, and time Goes upright with his carriage.
Goodbye!: My charms don’t crack, my spirits obey, and time goes upright with his carriage.

Anon!: They are not ever jealous for the cause, But jealous for they’re jealous.
Goodbye!: They’re not always jealous for the reason, but jealous for they’re jealous.

Anon!: Alas!
Goodbye!: Oh, no!

Anon!: If I may trust the flattering truth of sleep, My dreams presage some joyful news at hand.
Goodbye!: If I can trust the flattering truth of sleep, my dreams are a good sign of joy.

Anon!: Ay, so I thought.
Goodbye!: Yes, I thought so.

Anon!: No marvel then, though he were ill affected.
Goodbye!: No surprise, even if he were badly affected.

Anon!: What is she?
Goodbye!: What is she?

Anon!: When he came to himself again, he said, if he had done or said anything amiss, he desired their worships to think it was his infirmity.
Goodbye!: When he came back to himself, he said, if he had done or said anything wrong, he wanted their worships to think it was his infirmity.

Anon!: Fate, show thy force.
Goodbye!: Fate, show your force.

Anon!: If you will come to me— For now I spy a danger—I entreat you To bring but five and twenty.
Goodbye!: If you come to me—for now I’m spying on a danger—I ask you to bring only five and twenty.

Anon!: Did I deserve no more than a fool’s head?
Goodbye!: Did I deserve nothing more than a fool’s head?

Anon!: Here thought they to have done Some wanton charm upon this man and maid, Whose vows are that no bed-right shall be paid Till Hymen’s torch be lighted—but in vain.
Goodbye!: Here they thought they had done some charm on this man and her husband, who vows that no bed-right will be paid until Hymen’s torch is lighted—but in vain.

Anon!: Fie, what a slug is Hastings that he comes not To tell us whether they will come or no!
Goodbye!: Hastings is such a slug that he doesn’t come to tell us whether they’ll come or not!

Anon!: The day is broke.
Goodbye!: The day has broken.

Anon!: So foolish sorrows bids your stones farewell.
Goodbye!: Your foolish sorrows send your stones farewell.

Anon!: My spirits, as in a dream, are all bound up.
Goodbye!: I’m all bound up in my spirits, as in a dream.

Anon!: Why is Time such a niggard of hair, being, as it is, so plentiful an excrement?
Goodbye!: Why is time such a naughty nut of hair, as plentiful as it is?

Anon!: Here all eyes gaze on us.
Goodbye!: Here all eyes are on us.

Anon!: Yet, when we can entreat an hour to serve, We would spend it in some words upon that business, If you would grant the time.
Goodbye!: But when we can wait an hour to serve, we’d say some words about that business if you were to.

Anon!: I hear a tongue, shriller than all the music, Cry “Caesar!”—Speak.
Goodbye!: I hear a tongue, a shriller than all the music, cry “Caesar!”—Speak.

Anon!: Skipper, stand back.
Goodbye!: Skip, stand back.

Anon!: The best in this kind are but shadows, and the worst are no worse if imagination amend them.
Goodbye!: The best of this kind are shadows, and the worst aren’t worse if you’re thinking about it.

Anon!: What is your difference?
Goodbye!: What’s your difference?

Anon!: Who’s there?
Goodbye!: Who’s there?

Anon!: What dost thou say?
Goodbye!: What do you say?

Anon!: Cast thy humble slough,” says she.
Goodbye!: Cast your humble slough,” says she.

Anon!: Rather a ditch in Egypt Be gentle grave unto me.
Goodbye!: Instead, a ditch in Egypt should be a gentle grave to me.

Anon!: Portia, adieu.
Goodbye!: Portia, goodbye.

Anon!: And from henceforth When you are over-earnest with your Brutus, He’ll think your mother chides and leave you so.
Goodbye!: And from now on, when you’re over-earning with your Brutus, he’ll think your mother’s a scolding and leave you so.

Anon!: I have said.
Goodbye!: I’ve said what I’ve said.

Anon!: Dead art thou!
Goodbye!: You’re dead!

Anon!: It were a delicate stratagem to shoe A troop of horse with felt.
Goodbye!: It was a delicate way to shoe a horse with felt.

Anon!: Young gentleman, your spirits are too bold for your years.
Goodbye!: Young gentleman, your spirits are too bold for your years.

Anon!: I must go in.
Goodbye!: I have to go in.

Anon!: Thy mother was a piece of virtue and She said thou wast my daughter.
Goodbye!: Your mother was a piece of virtue, and she said you were my daughter.
