Goodbye!: Our tongue is rough, coz, and my condition isn’t smooth, so that, having neither the voice nor the heart of flattery about me, I can’t conjure up the spirit of love in her so that

Anon!: My sovereign lord, I do beseech your Highness To take our brother Clarence to your grace.
Goodbye!: My sovereign lord, I beg your Highness to take our brother Clarence to your grace.

Anon!: Take that, and that.
Goodbye!: Take that, and that.

Anon!: By this light, a most perfidious and drunken monster.
Goodbye!: By this light, a perfidious and drunken monster.

Anon!: Look, Don Pedro is returned to seek you.
Goodbye!: Look, Don Pedro is back to seek you.

Anon!: I know you of old.
Goodbye!: I know you’re old.

Anon!: Turn from me then that noble countenance Wherein the worship of the whole world lies.
Goodbye!: Turn from me, then, to the noble countenance where the whole world worships.

Anon!: Stephano!
Goodbye!: Stephano!

Anon!: Here let them lie Till famine and the ague eat them up.
Goodbye!: Let them lie here until the famine and the ague eat them up.

Anon!: I pray thee, give it me.
Goodbye!: Please, give it to me.

Anon!: I will be mild and gentle in my words.
Goodbye!: I’ll be gentle and mild.

Anon!: Give me your hand.
Goodbye!: Give me your hand.

Anon!: Hearts, tongues, figures, scribes, bards, poets, cannot Think, speak, cast, write, sing, number—hoo!— His love to Antony.
Goodbye!: Hearts, tongues, figures, scribes, bards, poets, can’t think, speak, cast, write, sing, number—hoo!—He’s love for Antony.

Anon!: Dear Kate, you and I cannot be confined within the weak list of a country’s fashion.
Goodbye!: Dear Kate, you and I can’t be confined to the poor list of country’s fashion.

Anon!: What, was I married to her in my dream?
Goodbye!: Was I married to her in my dream?

Anon!: It doth not fit me.
Goodbye!: It doesn’t fit me.

Anon!: That’s most certain, and with you.
Goodbye!: That’s true, and with you.

Anon!: Alas now, pray you, Work not so hard.
Goodbye!: Please, don’t work so hard now.

Anon!: What, master, read you?
Goodbye!: What, master, have you read?

Anon!: To fetch my poor distracted husband hence.
Goodbye!: To get my poor, distracted husband to leave.

Anon!: Thou canst not frown, thou canst not look askance, Nor bite the lip as angry wenches will, Nor hast thou pleasure to be cross in talk.
Goodbye!: You can’t frown, you can’t look a bit sane, or bite the lip as angry wenches will, or you’re not willing to be cross in talk.

Anon!: What friend?
Goodbye!: What friend?

Anon!: What are you?
Goodbye!: Who are you?

Anon!: So that in these ten thousand they have lost, There are but sixteen hundred mercenaries.
Goodbye!: So that in these ten thousand they’ve lost, there are only sixteen hundred mercenaries.

Anon!: I know not which is which.
Goodbye!: I don’t know which one is.

Anon!: Had you not been their father, these white flakes Did challenge pity of them.
Goodbye!: If you weren’t their father, these white flakes would challenge pity of them.

Anon!: While one with moderate haste might tell a hundred.
Goodbye!: While one who’s hurrying might tell a hundred.

Anon!: I do assure you, ’tis against my will.
Goodbye!: I assure you, it’s against my will.

Anon!: Good lads, how do you both?
Goodbye!: Good guys, how are you both?

Anon!: Then I defy you, stars!
Goodbye!: Then I’m afraid of you, stars!

Anon!: Peace, peace, Iras.
Goodbye!: Peace, peace, Iras.

Anon!: He made you for a highway to my bed, But I, a maid, die maiden-widowèd.
Goodbye!: He made you to go on a highway to my bed, but I die as a maiden.

Anon!: At a word, I am not.
Goodbye!: I’m not.

Anon!: Run one before And let the Queen know of our gests.
Goodbye!: Run one before the Queen and tell the Queen about our actions.

Anon!: I am doubtful that you have been conjunct And bosomed with her as far as we call hers.
Goodbye!: I’m sure you’ve been scolded and scolded by her as far as we call hers.

Anon!: We are two lions littered in one day, And I the elder and more terrible.
Goodbye!: We’re two lions littered in one day, and I’m the older and more terrible.

Anon!: Scant not my cups, and make as much of me As when mine empire was your fellow too, And suffered my command.
Goodbye!: Don’t scold my cups and make as much of me as when my empire was yours too, and suffered my command.

Anon!: She speaks, yet she says nothing.
Goodbye!: She’s talking, but she’s not saying anything.

Anon!: I’ll end my exhortation after dinner.
Goodbye!: I’ll end my exhortation after dinner.

Anon!: Show me, my women, like a queen.
Goodbye!: Show me, my women, like a queen.

Anon!: Is Signior Lucentio within, sir?
Goodbye!: Is Signior Lucentio inside, sir?

Anon!: Those are the raisèd father and his friends.
Goodbye!: That’s the raisind father and his friends.

Anon!: I’ll strike and cry, “Take all.” Well said.
Goodbye!: I’ll strike and cry, “Take everything.” Well said.

Anon!: And mine shall.
Goodbye!: And I will.

Anon!: See, my women, Against the blown rose may they stop their nose, That kneeled unto the buds.—Admit him, sir.
Goodbye!: Look, my women, if they can’t stop their nose against the rose that kneeled to the buds.—Admit him, sir.

Anon!: Men may sleep, and they may have their throats about them at that time, and some say knives have edges.
Goodbye!: Men can sleep, and they can have their throats about them at that time, and some say knives have edges.

Anon!: A hornèd man’s a monster and a beast.
Goodbye!: A horned man is a monster and a beast.

Anon!: If one should be a prey, how much the better To fall before the lion than the wolf!
Goodbye!: If one is a prey, how much better to fall before the lion than the wolf!

Anon!: I prithee, pretty youth, let me be better acquainted with thee.
Goodbye!: Please, pretty young man, let me be more familiar with you.

Anon!: Who offered him the crown?
Goodbye!: Who offered him the crown?

Anon!: Supper is done, and we shall come too late.
Goodbye!: Supper is over, and we’ll come too late.

Anon!: But then I saw no harm, and then I heard Each syllable that breath made up between them.
Goodbye!: But then I didn’t see any harm, and then I heard each syllable that sounded like a breath.

Anon!: You are the lord of duty.
Goodbye!: You’re the lord of duty.

Anon!: Then is Caesar and he forever knit together.
Goodbye!: Then Caesar and he’ll be forever together.

Anon!: It is to be all made of faith and service, And so am I for Phoebe.
Goodbye!: It’s to be made of faith and service, and so am I for Phoebe.

Anon!: And he that will not follow Bourbon now, Let him go hence, and with his cap in hand Like a base pander hold the chamber door, Whilst by a slave, no gentler than my dog, His fairest daughter is contaminate.
Goodbye!: And if he doesn’t follow Bourbon now, let him go, and with his cap in hand, like a base pander, hold the door, while he’s contaminated by a slave, no

Anon!: My lord, the army of great Buckingham— Out on you, owls!
Goodbye!: My lord, the army of great Buckingham— Out on you, owls!

Anon!: Clubs, bills, and partisans!
Goodbye!: Clubs, bills, and partisans!

Anon!: No more, I pray you.
Goodbye!: Don’t wait, please.

Anon!: I prithee—and I’ll pay thee bounteously— Conceal me what I am, and be my aid For such disguise as haply shall become The form of my intent.
Goodbye!: I’ll pay you for it—and I’ll give you my help—to get me what I am, because I’ll disguise myself as a disguise.

Anon!: But it is no English treason to cut French crowns, and tomorrow the king himself will be a clipper.
Goodbye!: But it’s not a treason for English to cut French crowns, and tomorrow the king himself will be a clipper.

Anon!: Give me those flowers.
Goodbye!: Give me those flowers.

Anon!: Those that do die of it do seldom or never recover.
Goodbye!: People who die of it rarely or never recover.

Anon!: Delay this marriage for a month, a week.
Goodbye!: Wait for a month, a week.

Anon!: Go and commend me to my brother Cassius.
Goodbye!: Go and give my praise to my brother Cassius.

Anon!: The sound is going away.
Goodbye!: The sound is going away.

Anon!: I would know that.
Goodbye!: I’d like to know that.

Anon!: The time will bring it out.
Goodbye!: The time will bring it out.

Anon!: Perforce I must confess I thought you lord of more true gentleness.
Goodbye!: I must admit I thought you were a gentleman who was more gentle.

Anon!: The rest march on with me.
Goodbye!: The rest of the day are marching on with me.

Anon!: I can see a church by daylight.
Goodbye!: I can see a church in daylight.

Anon!: I’ll to the friar to know his remedy.
Goodbye!: I’ll go to the friar to find out his remedy.

Anon!: If he will not stand when he is bidden, he is none of the Prince’s subjects.
Goodbye!: If he doesn’t stand when he’s offered, he won’t be one of the Prince’s subjects.

Anon!: I will neither be faced nor braved.
Goodbye!: I won’t be faced or be braved.

Anon!: Most kind messenger, Say to great Caesar this in deputation: I kiss his conqu’ring hand.
Goodbye!: Most kind messenger, tell the great Caesar this in deputation: I kiss his conqu’ring hand.

Anon!: How say you, sir?
Goodbye!: What do you say, sir?

Anon!: How oft tonight Have my old feet stumbled at graves!—Who’s there?
Goodbye!: How often tonight have my old feet stumbled at graves!—Who’s there?

Anon!: And thus she means, videlicet— Asleep, my love?
Goodbye!: And so she says, videlicet— What do you mean, my love?

Anon!: Grant their lawful suit.
Goodbye!: Give them their legal action.

Anon!: I will be gone, sir, and not trouble you.
Goodbye!: I’ll go, sir, and I won’t bother you.

Anon!: Am I not wise?
Goodbye!: Am I not wise?

Anon!: That I might sleep out this great gap of time My Antony is away.
Goodbye!: I wish I could sleep out this time when my Antony is away.

Anon!: Perform ’t, or else we damn thee.”  How, my love?
Goodbye!: Do it, or else we’ll damn you.” How, my love?

Anon!: Shall I entreat a word?
Goodbye!: Should I say a word?

Anon!: It is my lady.
Goodbye!: It’s my lady.

Anon!: Who shall bar me from them?
Goodbye!: Who will stop me from them?

Anon!: Let me, if not by birth, have lands by wit.
Goodbye!: If I don’t have lands by birth, I’ll have lands by wit.

Anon!: Have you heard of no likely wars toward ’twixt the two Dukes of Cornwall and Albany?
Goodbye!: Have you heard of any wars between the two Dukes of Cornwall and Albany?

Anon!: The soldier’s pole is fall’n!
Goodbye!: The soldier’s pole is falling!

Anon!: I mean, to go, sir, to enter.
Goodbye!: I mean to go, sir, to enter.

Anon!: It sorts well with your fierceness.
Goodbye!: It’s good for you to fight.

Anon!: And I.
Goodbye!: And I.

Anon!: O, wilt thou leave me so unsatisfied?
Goodbye!: Oh, will you leave me so unsatisfied?

Anon!: Sheathe your dagger.
Goodbye!: Sheathe your dagger.

Anon!: Stay, countrymen.
Goodbye!: Stay, countrymen.

Anon!: Good Lord, how bright and goodly shines the moon!
Goodbye!: Good Lord, how bright and good the moon shines!

Anon!: Make those that do offend you suffer too.
Goodbye!: Make those who are wrong to you suffer too.

Anon!: Bleed, bleed, poor country!
Goodbye!: Bleed, bleeding, poor country!

Anon!: O Kate, content thee.
Goodbye!: Oh, Kate, please.

Anon!: Thy wild acts denote The unreasonable fury of a beast.
Goodbye!: Your wild actions are like the fury of a beast.

Anon!: Good morrow to this fair assembly.
Goodbye!: Good morning to this fair assembly.

Anon!: To Adriana.
Goodbye!: To Adriana.

Anon!: Twill be ill taken.
Goodbye!: You’ll be wrong.

Anon!: Madam my interpreter, what says she?
Goodbye!: My interpreter, what does she say?

Anon!: All the conspirators save only he Did that they did in envy of great Caesar.
Goodbye!: All the conspirators, except he did, were jealous of great Caesar.

Anon!: I come to bury Caesar, not to praise him.
Goodbye!: I’m going to bury Caesar, not to praise him.

Anon!: When will he be here?
Goodbye!: When will he be here?

Anon!: No medicine in the world can do thee good.
Goodbye!: No medicine in the world can do your good.

Anon!: Why have you stol’n upon us thus?
Goodbye!: Why have you stolen on us like this?

Anon!: My lady has a white hand, and the Myrmidons are no bottle-ale houses.
Goodbye!: My lady has a white hand, and the Myrmidons are no bottle-ale houses.

Anon!: Is ’t possible?
Goodbye!: Is it possible?

Anon!: Hail, gentle sir.
Goodbye!: Hail, gentle sir.

Anon!: It cannot be.
Goodbye!: It can’t be.

Anon!: I pray you, turn the key and keep our counsel.
Goodbye!: Please turn the key and keep our counsel.

Anon!: Why, I have eat none yet.
Goodbye!: I haven’t eaten anything yet.

Anon!: I would have made it short, for I was come to the whole depth of my tale, and meant, indeed, to occupy the argument no longer.
Goodbye!: I would have made it short, since I was able to tell the whole story and to stop the argument.

Anon!: Menas, I’ll not on shore.
Goodbye!: Menas, I won’t be on shore.

Anon!: I am paid for ’t now.
Goodbye!: I’m paid for it now.

Anon!: Accursed, unhappy, wretched, hateful day!
Goodbye!: Accursed, unhappy, wretched, hateful day!

Anon!: Would they were basilisks to strike thee dead.
Goodbye!: They would be basilisks to strike you dead.

Anon!: Thus then in brief: The valiant Paris seeks you for his love.
Goodbye!: So, in short, the valiant Paris wants you to marry him.

Anon!: You mistake, sir.
Goodbye!: You’re wrong, sir.

Anon!: Life, living, all is Death’s.
Goodbye!: Life, living, everything is Death’s.

Anon!: I go.
Goodbye!: I’m going.

Anon!: The poop was beaten gold, Purple the sails, and so perfumèd that The winds were lovesick with them.
Goodbye!: The poop was beaten with gold, purple sails, and so perfumed that the winds were like loveicks.

Anon!: But yet I feel I fear.
Goodbye!: But I’m still afraid.

Anon!: Thou hast mettle enough in thee to kill care.
Goodbye!: You’ve been sane enough to kill you.

Anon!: Young son, it argues a distempered head So soon to bid good morrow to thy bed.
Goodbye!: Young son, it’s a slur of a distempered head so soon to give you a good morning to your bed.

Anon!: Be you his eunuch, and your mute I’ll be.
Goodbye!: I’ll be your eunuch, and I’ll be your mute.

Anon!: I one, my lord.
Goodbye!: I’m one, my lord.

Anon!: The name of Cassius honors this corruption, And chastisement doth therefore hide his head.
Goodbye!: Cassius’s name honors this corruption, and chastisement hides his head.

Anon!: Come, come, let us thither.
Goodbye!: Come, come, let’s go.

Anon!: No news of them?
Goodbye!: No news about them?

Anon!: No jutty, frieze, Buttress, nor coign of vantage, but this bird Hath made his pendant bed and procreant cradle.
Goodbye!: No jutty, frieze, buttress, no sluggish vantage, but this bird has made his pendant bed and cradle.

Anon!: Misery acquaints a man with strange bedfellows.
Goodbye!: Misery is familiar to a man with strange bedfellows.

Anon!: Good night.
Goodbye!: Good night.

Anon!: Thou hast quarreled with a man for coughing in the street because he hath wakened thy dog that hath lain asleep in the sun.
Goodbye!: You have fought with a man for coughing in the street because he woke up your dog who slept in the sun.

Anon!: Let me but bind it hard, within this hour It will be well.
Goodbye!: I’ll be able to fix it hard, but it will be good within an hour.

Anon!: As I intend to prosper and repent, So thrive I in my dangerous affairs Of hostile arms!
Goodbye!: As I intend to prosper and repent, I’m so happy in my hostile affairs!

Anon!: They are friends, Ratcliffe and Lovell.
Goodbye!: They’re friends, Ratcliffe and Lovell.

Anon!: Tybalt is gone, and Romeo banishèd.
Goodbye!: Tybalt is gone, and Romeo has been banned.

Anon!: I will deal in poison with thee, or in bastinado, or in steel.
Goodbye!: I’ll poison you, or in a savage, or in steel.

Anon!: Antonio, as I heard in Genoa— What, what, what?
Goodbye!: Antonio, as I heard in Genoa— What, what, what?

Anon!: There attend my coming.
Goodbye!: I’ll be there.

Anon!: So I hope.
Goodbye!: I hope so.

Anon!: He that keeps nor crust nor crumb,  Weary of all, shall want some.
Goodbye!: He who keeps or eats a crust or a crumb, tired of all, will want some.

Anon!: Till which encounter It is my business too.
Goodbye!: I’m doing my job until I see you.

Anon!: Come, come, no longer will I be a fool, To put the finger in the eye and weep Whilst man and master laugh my woes to scorn.
Goodbye!: Come on, I won’t be a fool anymore, to put the finger in the eye and weep while man and master laugh my sorrows to shame.

Anon!: I saw ’t i' the orchard.
Goodbye!: I saw it in the orchard.

Anon!: I am th' unhappy subject of these quarrels.
Goodbye!: I’m the unhappy subject of these quarrels.

Anon!: And when I do, I swear It shall be Romeo, whom you know I hate, Rather than Paris.
Goodbye!: And when I do, I swear it will be Romeo, whom you know I hate, rather than Paris.

Anon!: Ha, let me see.
Goodbye!: Ha, let me see.

Anon!: Shake off this downy sleep, death’s counterfeit, And look on death itself!
Goodbye!: Shake off this sleepy sleep, which is fake, and look at death itself!

Anon!: Provoke him that he may.
Goodbye!: Provoke him that he can.

Anon!: Sweet Portia, If you did know to whom I gave the ring, If you did know for whom I gave the ring, And would conceive for what I gave the ring, And how unwillingly I left the ring When naught would be accepted but the ring, You would abate the strength of your displeasure.
Goodbye!: Sweet Portia, if you knew who gave the ring, if you knew who gave it, and if you knew who gave it, and if you knew what I gave it, and if I left it when

Anon!: Do not laugh at me, For as I am a man, I think this lady To be my child Cordelia.
Goodbye!: Don’t laugh at me, because I think this lady is my child Cordelia.

Anon!: Look down, you gods, And on this couple drop a blessèd crown, For it is you that have chalked forth the way Which brought us hither.
Goodbye!: Look down, you gods, and on this couple drop a blessed crown, because you’ve sewed the way that brought us here.

Anon!: For, hark you, Tybalt being slain so late, It may be thought we held him carelessly, Being our kinsman, if we revel much.
Goodbye!: If you’re a king, you can think that Tybalt was killed so late that we thought we held him a sane man, as our kinsman.

Anon!: Know you not he has?
Goodbye!: Don’t you know he has?

Anon!: Let music sound while he doth make his choice.
Goodbye!: Listen to music while he chooses.

Anon!: I shall be there before thee.
Goodbye!: I’ll be there before you.

Anon!: The business she hath broached in the state Cannot endure my absence.
Goodbye!: I can’t stand my absence.

Anon!: Will it not be?
Goodbye!: Willn’t it be?

Anon!: If e'er thou wast thyself and these woes thine, Thou and these woes were all for Rosaline.
Goodbye!: If you were yourself and your pains were yours, you and your pain were all for Rosaline.

Anon!: It is called Wye at Monmouth, but it is out of my prains what is the name of the other river.
Goodbye!: It’s called Wye at Monmouth, but it’s out of my pranks, the name of the other river.

Anon!: Bear free and patient thoughts.
Goodbye!: Be patient and free.

Anon!: Romeo, will you come to your father’s?
Goodbye!: Romeo, will you come to your father’s house?

Anon!: Youth to itself rebels, though none else near.
Goodbye!: Youth rebels, even if none else is near.

Anon!: Good morrow, Caesar.
Goodbye!: Good morning, Caesar.

Anon!: Take thee that too.
Goodbye!: Take that too.

Anon!: We came crying hither.
Goodbye!: We came here crying.

Anon!: Pray you, let’s have no more fooling about it, but give me your blessing.
Goodbye!: Please, let’s not have any more fooling about it, but give me your blessing.

Anon!: And then?
Goodbye!: And then?

Anon!: That dreamers often lie.
Goodbye!: Dreamers often lie.

Anon!: Thy husband in thy bosom there lies dead, And Paris too.
Goodbye!: Your husband is dead in your house, and Paris too.

Anon!: God be with you.
Goodbye!: God be with you.

Anon!: And Benedick is not the unhopefulest husband that I know.
Goodbye!: And Benedick is not the unhopefulest husband I know.

Anon!: Some grief shows much of love, But much of grief shows still some want of wit.
Goodbye!: Some grief shows much of love, but some grief shows some desire for wit.

Anon!: Would you had never seen him!
Goodbye!: You wish you had never seen him!

Anon!: Tis now struck twelve.
Goodbye!: It’s twelve.

Anon!: Methinks I see thee now, thou art so low As one dead in the bottom of a tomb.
Goodbye!: I think I see you now, you’re so low as one dead in the bottom of a tomb.

Anon!: You will lose this wager, my lord.
Goodbye!: You’ll lose this wager, my lord.

Anon!: Or say, sweet love, what thou desirest to eat.
Goodbye!: Or say sweet love, what you want to eat.

Anon!: Go, girl, seek happy nights to happy days.
Goodbye!: Go, girl, look for happy nights to happy days.

Anon!: Know we this face or no?
Goodbye!: Do we know this face or not?

Anon!: She was too fond of her most filthy bargain.
Goodbye!: She was too fond of her most filthy bargain.

Anon!: I am not I if there be such an  Or those eyes shut that makes thee answer “ay.” If he be slain, say “ay,” or if not, “no.” Brief sounds determine of my weal or woe.
Goodbye!: I don’t know if there’s a man like that or those eyes shut that make you answer “yes.” If he’s killed, say “yes,” or if not, “no.” Brief sounds determine

Anon!: Monster, your fairy, which you say is a harmless fairy, has done little better than played the jack with us.
Goodbye!: Monster, your fairy, which you say is harmless, has done little better than played the jack with us.

Anon!: I see the jewel best enamelèd Will lose his beauty.
Goodbye!: I see that the jewel that is best etched will lose his beauty.

Anon!: Are you my wife and will not call me “husband”?
Goodbye!: Are you my wife and won’t call me “husband”?

Anon!: Indeed, they say the senators tomorrow Mean to establish Caesar as a king, And he shall wear his crown by sea and land In every place save here in Italy.
Goodbye!: The senators will decide tomorrow to establish Caesar as a king, and he will wear his crown on sea and land in every place except here in Italy.

Anon!: Where’s my fool, ho?
Goodbye!: Where’s my fool, ho?

Anon!: I do not like thy look, I promise thee.
Goodbye!: I don’t like your look, I promise you.

Anon!: For whose sake did I that ill deed?
Goodbye!: For whose sake did I do that bad deed?

Anon!: And we mean well in going to this mask, But ’tis no wit to go.
Goodbye!: And we mean well in going to this mask, but it’s not a good idea to go.

Anon!: Call it my fear That keeps you in the house, and not your own.
Goodbye!: Call it my fear that keeps you in the house, not your own.

Anon!: That shall you know hereafter.
Goodbye!: That’s what you’ll know later.

Anon!: Tis a day Such as the day is when the sun is hid.
Goodbye!: It’s a day like the day when the sun is hiding.

Anon!: No, Corin, being old, thou canst not guess, Though in thy youth thou wast as true a lover As ever sighed upon a midnight pillow.
Goodbye!: No, Corin, you can’t guess, even though you were as true a lover in your youth as ever sighed on a midnight pillow.

Anon!: Those that are married already, all but one, shall live.
Goodbye!: All those who are already married, except one, will live.

Anon!: You did know How much you were my conqueror, and that My sword, made weak by my affection, would Obey it on all cause.
Goodbye!: You knew how much you were my conqueror, and that my sword, made weak by my affection, would kill it for all reasons.

Anon!: Are they “informed” of this?
Goodbye!: Are they “informed” of this?

Anon!: Unless I have mista'en his colors much, Which well I am assured I have not done, His regiment lies half a mile, at least, South from the mighty power of the king.
Goodbye!: If I haven’t mista’d his colors much, which I’m sure I haven’t done, his regiment is at least half a mile south of the king’s power.

Anon!: Go therefore, tell thy master: here I am.
Goodbye!: So tell your master: here I am.

Anon!: Most radiant, exquisite and unmatchable beauty—I pray you, tell me if this be the lady of the house, for I never saw her.
Goodbye!: What a beautiful, exquisite and unmatchable beauty—Please tell me if this is the lady of the house, because I never saw her.

Anon!: Cleopatra, catching but the least noise of this, dies instantly.
Goodbye!: Cleopatra, who only caught the least noise of this, dies instantly.

Anon!: He says he’ll come.
Goodbye!: He says he’ll come.

Anon!: For not alone The death of Fulvia, with more urgent touches, Do strongly speak to us, but the letters too Of many our contriving friends in Rome Petition us at home.
Goodbye!: For not only the death of Fulvia, with more urgent touches, will speak to us strongly, but the letters of many of our heirs in Rome will ask us at home.

Anon!: You tremble and look pale.
Goodbye!: You tremble and look pale.

Anon!: The things that threatened me Ne'er looked but on my back.
Goodbye!: The things that threatened me were on my back.

Anon!: They shall be married tomorrow, and I will bid the duke to the nuptial.
Goodbye!: They’ll be married tomorrow, and I’ll ask the duke to attend the wedding.

Anon!: Go not my horse the better, I must become a borrower of the night For a dark hour or twain.
Goodbye!: Don’t go my horse the better, I have to be a borrower of the night for a dark hour or two.

Anon!: Exceedingly, my lord.
Goodbye!: Excuse me, my lord.

Anon!: Tis yours, and we, Your scutcheons and your signs of conquest, shall Hang in what place you please.
Goodbye!: It’s yours, and we, your scutcheons and your signs of conquest, will hang in whatever place you want.

Anon!: A many of our bodies shall no doubt Find native graves, upon the which, I trust, Shall witness live in brass of this day’s work.
Goodbye!: A number of our bodies will certainly find native graves, on which, I trust, we’ll witness the work of this day.

Anon!: What wilt thou tell her, Nurse?
Goodbye!: What will you tell her, Nurse?

Anon!: And now they do re-stem Their backward course, bearing with frank appearance Their purposes toward Cyprus.
Goodbye!: Now they’re re-strouting their backward path, bearing with frank appearance their intentions toward Cyprus.

Anon!: Good Lord!
Goodbye!: Good Lord!

Anon!: My liege, this was my glove; here is the fellow of it.
Goodbye!: My liege, this was my glove; here is the man of it.

Anon!: But when we in our viciousness grow hard— Oh, misery on ’t!—the wise gods seel our eyes, In our own filth drop our clear judgments, make us Adore our errors, laugh at ’s while we strut To our confusion.
Goodbye!: But when we grow in our viciousness— Oh, misfortune on it!—the wise gods see our eyes, drop our clear judgments in our own filth, make us adamant our mistakes, laugh at

Anon!: Thus do all traitors.
Goodbye!: So do all traitors.

Anon!: Nay, that you shall not.
Goodbye!: No, you won’t.

Anon!: You shall have time to wrangle in when you have nothing else to do.
Goodbye!: You’ll have time to wrangle in when you have nothing else to do.

Anon!: Sir, amen.
Goodbye!: Sir, amen.

Anon!: You dare easier be friends with me than fight with mine enemy.
Goodbye!: You’re more likely to be friends with me than to fight with my enemy.

Anon!: Haply some poison yet doth hang on them, To make me die with a restorative.
Goodbye!: They’re still hanging some poison, to make me die with a restorative.

Anon!: Look you, she loved her kinsman Tybalt dearly, And so did I.
Goodbye!: Look, she loved her father Tybalt very much, and so did I.

Anon!: Light is an effect of fire, and fire will burn: ergo, light wenches will burn.
Goodbye!: Light is a result of fire, and fire will burn: ergo, light wenches will burn.

Anon!: Of what personage and years is he?
Goodbye!: What age and years is he?

Anon!: Then thou art damned.
Goodbye!: Then you’re damned.

Anon!: And yet for aught I see, they are as sick that surfeit with too much as they that starve with nothing.
Goodbye!: And yet I see, they’re as sick as they are that they’re suffering from too much, and that they’re not hungry enough to survive.

Anon!: Do we all holy rites.
Goodbye!: We all have holy rites.

Anon!: It is.
Goodbye!: It is.

Anon!: What news?
Goodbye!: What news do you have?

Anon!: He hath refused it in the open court.
Goodbye!: He refused it in the open court.

Anon!: On him I lay what you would lay on me, The right and fortune of his happy stars, Which God defend that I should wring from him.
Goodbye!: I’ll lay on him what you want on me, the right and fortune of his happy stars, which God defends that I should wring from him.

Anon!: And now to our French causes.
Goodbye!: Now we’re talking about our French causes.

Anon!: My wits faints.
Goodbye!: My wits are faint.

Anon!: But how did you desire it should be made?
Goodbye!: But how did you want it to be made?

Anon!: Thy bed, lust-stained, shall with lust’s blood be spotted.
Goodbye!: Your bed will be lust-stained, and it will be spotted with lust’s blood.

Anon!: My lord?
Goodbye!: My lord?

Anon!: Parting is such sweet sorrow That I shall say good night till it be morrow.
Goodbye!: Parting is such sweet sorrow that I’ll say good night until it’s morrow.

Anon!: I did not kill your husband.
Goodbye!: I didn’t kill your husband.

Anon!: I would not marry her, though she were endowed with all that Adam had left him before he transgressed.
Goodbye!: I wouldn’t marry her, even if she were given all the money Adam had left him before he transgressed.

Anon!: Farewell, my coz.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, my coz.

Anon!: O sir, very well: here in your orchard.
Goodbye!: Oh, sir, very well: here in your orchard.

Anon!: The drink, the drink!
Goodbye!: The drink, the drink!

Anon!: My lord, in Athens.
Goodbye!: My lord, in Athens.

Anon!: How’s the day?
Goodbye!: How’s the day?

Anon!: Well, peace be with you, sir.
Goodbye!: Well, please be calm, sir.

Anon!: And art thou changed?
Goodbye!: And you’ve changed?

Anon!: Take him on the costard with the hilts of thy sword, and then throw him into the malmsey butt in the next room.
Goodbye!: Take him on the costard with the hilts of your sword, and then throw him into the malmsey butt in the next room.

Anon!: But speak you this with a sad brow?
Goodbye!: But do you speak this with a sad brow?

Anon!: No.
Goodbye!: No.

Anon!: Tush, I will stir about, And all things shall be well, I warrant thee, wife.
Goodbye!: I’ll be scolded, and everything will be good, I assure you, wife.

Anon!: Why look you pale?
Goodbye!: Why are you looking pale?

Anon!: Commend me to your daughter.
Goodbye!: Give my praises to your daughter.

Anon!: Why, let her except, before excepted.
Goodbye!: Let her go, before she’s gone.

Anon!: Let us to the great supper.
Goodbye!: Let’s go to the great supper.

Anon!: He fears, my lord, you mean no good to him.
Goodbye!: He fears you’re not good enough to him, my lord.

Anon!: I’ll have no bigger.
Goodbye!: I won’t have any bigger.

Anon!: Why, ’tis a cockle or a walnut shell, A knack, a toy, a trick, a baby’s cap.
Goodbye!: It’s a cockle or a walnut shell, a knack, a toy, a trick, a baby’s cap.

Anon!: Nay, then I must have an ounce or two of this malapert blood from you.
Goodbye!: No, then I have to get an ounce or two of this malapert blood from you.

Anon!: O, grief hath changed me since you saw me last, And careful hours with time’s deformèd hand Have written strange defeatures in my face.
Goodbye!: Oh, grief has changed me since you saw me last time, and careful hours with time’s deformified hand have written strange deformities in my face.

Anon!: This is the fruits of rashness.
Goodbye!: This is the fruit of rashness.

Anon!: Dull thing, I say so.
Goodbye!: I’m saying that.

Anon!: Young Romeo is it?
Goodbye!: Is it young Romeo?

Anon!: Give me my robe, for I will go.
Goodbye!: Give me my robe, because I’ll go.

Anon!: That Petruchio came?
Goodbye!: Petruchio?

Anon!: We have, sir.
Goodbye!: We have, sir.

Anon!: I pray you.
Goodbye!: Please.

Anon!: I pray you sir, go forth And give us truth who ’tis that is arrived.
Goodbye!: Please go out and tell us who’s coming.

Anon!: Here’s another More potent than the first.
Goodbye!: Here’s another more powerful than the first.

Anon!: O, wilt thou leave me so unsatisfied?
Goodbye!: Oh, will you leave me so unsatisfied?

Anon!: Farewell.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: O, help him, you sweet heavens!
Goodbye!: Oh, help him, you sweet heavens!

Anon!: Oh, my fortunes have Corrupted honest men!
Goodbye!: Oh, my fortune has corrupted honest men!

Anon!: Alas, good Kate, I will not burden thee, For knowing thee to be but young and light— Too light for such a swain as you to catch, And yet as heavy as my weight should be.
Goodbye!: I’ll not burden you, good Kate, because I know you’re young and light— Too light for a swain as you can catch, and yet as heavy as my weight should be.

Anon!: What effects, my lord?
Goodbye!: What effects, my lord?

Anon!: I would I were as sure of a good dinner.
Goodbye!: I wish I were as sure of a good dinner.

Anon!: He shall tell them so.
Goodbye!: He’ll tell them so.

Anon!: Upon the platform, ’twixt eleven and twelve, I’ll visit you.
Goodbye!: On the platform, eleven and twelve, I’ll visit you.

Anon!: Bless thee, Bottom, bless thee.
Goodbye!: Bless you, Bottom, bless you.

Anon!: And indeed it takes From our achievements, though performed at height, The pith and marrow of our attribute.
Goodbye!: And indeed, from our achievements, even if they were performed at height, it’s the marrow and the sleeve of our reputation.

Anon!: If thou wilt needs damn thyself, do it a more delicate way than drowning.
Goodbye!: If you’re going to need to do it yourself, do it a more delicate way than drowning.

Anon!: And died that day when Viola from her birth Had numbered thirteen years.
Goodbye!: And died that day, when Viola died from her birth thirteen years ago.

Anon!: Will you go hunt, my lord?
Goodbye!: Will you go hunt, my lord?

Anon!: Good night.
Goodbye!: Good night.

Anon!: I met her deity Cutting the clouds towards Paphos, and her son Dove-drawn with her.
Goodbye!: I met her deity, cutting the clouds towards Paphos, and her son Dove-drawn with her.

Anon!: Call him hither, good Monsieur Le Beau.
Goodbye!: Call him here, good Monsieur Le Beau.

Anon!: What a foolish duty call you this?
Goodbye!: What a foolish duty do you call this?

Anon!: Orsino, this is that Antonio That took the  And this is he that did the  When your young nephew Titus lost his leg.
Goodbye!: Orsino, this is Antonio who took the king, and this is the one who took the king when your young nephew Titus lost his leg.

Anon!: If he do blench, I know my course.
Goodbye!: If he’s bleak, I know what to do.

Anon!: And let us swear our resolution.
Goodbye!: Let’s swear we’ve got our resolution.

Anon!: And so we will, provided that he win her.
Goodbye!: And so we will, if he wins her.

Anon!: Now, afore God, I am so vexed that every part about me quivers.
Goodbye!: Now, God, I’m so angry that every part of me is a slander.

Anon!: Beat them down!
Goodbye!: Beat them down!

Anon!: Uncharitably with me have you dealt, And shamefully my hopes by you are butchered.
Goodbye!: You’ve dealt with me uncharitably, and my hopes are ruined.

Anon!: How far into the morning is it, lords?
Goodbye!: How far is it, lords?

Anon!: There is none but he Whose being I do fear, and under him My genius is rebuked, as it is said Mark Antony’s was by Caesar.
Goodbye!: There’s no one except him, who is afraid of me, and under him my genius is rebuked, as it’s said Mark Antony’s was by Caesar.

Anon!: Are you there, wife?
Goodbye!: Are you there, wife?

Anon!: For in all the play There is not one word apt, one player fitted.
Goodbye!: In all the play, there’s no one word, no one.

Anon!: Heart, once be stronger than thy continent.
Goodbye!: Heart, be stronger once than your continent.

Anon!: No, some of it is for my child’s father.
Goodbye!: No, some of it is for my child’s father.

Anon!: A good note, that keeps you from the blow of the law.
Goodbye!: A good note, that keeps you from being beaten by the law.

Anon!: But were the day come, I should wish it dark, That I were couching with the doctor’s clerk.
Goodbye!: But if the day came, I’d rather be darkened than that I was couching with the doctor’s clerk.

Anon!: Now my charms are all o'erthrown, And what strength I have’s mine own, Which is most faint.
Goodbye!: Now my charms are all gone, and what strength I have is my own, which is most faint.

Anon!: Why, what effects of passion shows she?
Goodbye!: Why, what effects of passion are she showing?

Anon!: Thou speak’st with all thy wit; and yet, i' faith, With wit enough for thee.
Goodbye!: You speak with all your wit, and yet, i’m sure, with enough wit for you.

Anon!: My services which I have done the signiory Shall out-tongue his complaints.
Goodbye!: I’ll out-tongue his complaints.

Anon!: Leave him to my displeasure.—Edmund, keep you our sister company.
Goodbye!: Leave him to my displeasure.—Edmund, keep your sister company.

Anon!: Murder?
Goodbye!: Murder?

Anon!: But, hark, I hear the footing of a man.
Goodbye!: But listen, I hear the footing of a man.

Anon!: That was in thy rage.
Goodbye!: That was in your rage.

Anon!: Dost thou think If I would stand against thee, would the reposal Of any trust, virtue, or worth in thee Make thy words faithed?
Goodbye!: Do you think if I stood against you, would the retribution of any trust, virtue, or worth in you give you your words?

Anon!: First kiss me, Kate, and we will.
Goodbye!: First kiss me, Kate, and we will.

Anon!: True, madam.
Goodbye!: True, madam.

Anon!: But good lieutenant, is your general wived?
Goodbye!: But good lieutenant, is your general wived?

Anon!: I am not mad, Sir Topas.
Goodbye!: I’m not insane, Sir Topas.

Anon!: Dear general, I never gave you cause.
Goodbye!: Dear general, I never gave you any reason to say anything.

Anon!: There is no world without Verona walls But purgatory, torture, hell itself.
Goodbye!: There is no world without walls in Verona, but purgatory, torture, and hell itself.

Anon!: I will hear Cassius and compare their reasons When severally we hear them renderèd.
Goodbye!: I’ll hear Cassius and compare their reasons when we hear them.

Anon!: How now, Fluellen, cam’st thou from the bridge?
Goodbye!: How are you coming from the bridge, Fluellen?

Anon!: Under this conjuration, speak, my lord, For we will hear, note, and believe in heart That what you speak is in your conscience washed As pure as sin with baptism.
Goodbye!: Under this conjuration, speak, my lord, because we’ll hear, note, and believe in your heart that what you say is sprayed as pure as sin with baptism.

Anon!: How canst thou thus for shame, Titania, Knowing I know thy love to Theseus?
Goodbye!: How can you do that, Titania, because I know you love You?

Anon!: Look, with a spot I damn him.
Goodbye!: Look, I’m damning him with a spot.

Anon!: Had you not come upon your cue, my lord, William Lord Hastings had pronounced your part— I mean your voice for crowning of the king.
Goodbye!: If you hadn’t come upon your cue, my lord, William Lord Hastings would have said your part— I mean your voice for crowning the king.

Anon!: We are friends.
Goodbye!: We’re friends.

Anon!: You go to seek the Lord Hamlet.
Goodbye!: You’re going to find the Lord Hamlet.

Anon!: Some officers take them away.
Goodbye!: Some officers take them away.

Anon!: I pray you, hear her speak.
Goodbye!: Please, listen to her.

Anon!: Eight score eight hours?
Goodbye!: Eight score eight hours?

Anon!: How long hath he been there?
Goodbye!: How long has he been there?

Anon!: Hie, make haste, Make haste.
Goodbye!: Hurry up, hurry up.

Anon!: Tis thought that Richmond is their admiral; And there they hull, expecting but the aid Of Buckingham to welcome them ashore.
Goodbye!: It’s thought Richmond is their admiral, and there they hull, expecting Buckingham’s help to welcome them to shore.

Anon!: We shall find a time, Audrey.
Goodbye!: We’ll find a time, Audrey.

Anon!: Nay, but this dotage of our general’s O’erflows the measure.
Goodbye!: No, but this slander of our general’s slanders is the measure.

Anon!: Make thy two eyes, like stars, start from their spheres, Thy knotted and combinèd locks to part And each particular hair to stand on end, Like quills upon the fearful porpentine.
Goodbye!: Make your two eyes start from their spheres, your knotted and twisted locks to part and each particular hair to stand on end, like quills on the fearful porpentine.

Anon!: Is it e'en so?
Goodbye!: Is it true?

Anon!: It must appear in other ways than words, Therefore I scant this breathing courtesy.
Goodbye!: It must appear in other ways than words, so I’ve snuck up this courtesy.

Anon!: Feeling so the loss, Cannot choose but ever weep the friend.
Goodbye!: If you feel the loss, you can’t choose but weep the friend ever.

Anon!: Why, this is not a boon, 'Tis as I should entreat you wear your gloves, Or feed on nourishing dishes, or keep you warm, Or sue to you to do a peculiar profit To your own person.
Goodbye!: This is not a good idea, it’s as if I’d wear your gloves, or feed on nourishing dishes, or keep you warm, or sue you to do a peculiar profit to your own person.

Anon!: Well then, if ever I thank any man, I’ll thank you.
Goodbye!: Well then, if I ever thank any man, I’ll thank you.

Anon!: Well, you have made a simple choice.
Goodbye!: Well, you’ve made a simple choice.

Anon!: Then must I think you would not have it so.
Goodbye!: Then I must think you wouldn’t want it.

Anon!: He is about the house.
Goodbye!: He’s about to go to the house.

Anon!: This shall make Our purpose necessary and not envious, Which so appearing to the common eyes, We shall be called purgers, not murderers.
Goodbye!: This will make our purpose necessary and not envious, which will appear to the common eye so often, we’ll be called purgers, not murderers.

Anon!: I thank you, doctor.
Goodbye!: Thank you, doctor.

Anon!: Why, good sir?
Goodbye!: Why, good sir?

Anon!: Nay, I care not for their names.
Goodbye!: No, I don’t care about their names.

Anon!: It did always seem so to us.
Goodbye!: It always seemed so to us.

Anon!: You whoreson malt-horse drudge!
Goodbye!: You whoreson malt-horse drudge!

Anon!: Come, go along.
Goodbye!: Come on, go with me.

Anon!: Ratcliffe, my lord, ’tis I.
Goodbye!: Ratcliffe, my lord, it’s me.

Anon!: Quite dumb?
Goodbye!: Is that dumb?

Anon!: They met so near with their lips that their breaths embraced together.
Goodbye!: They met so close with their lips that their breaths embraced.

Anon!: Sweet, say on.
Goodbye!: Sweet, say on.

Anon!: I know I can do it.
Goodbye!: I know I can do it.

Anon!: Why, there’s no remedy.
Goodbye!: There’s no remedy.

Anon!: The god of Jupiter.
Goodbye!: The god of Jupiter.

Anon!: Methinks I hear Antony call.
Goodbye!: I think I hear Antony call me.

Anon!: Your worship speaks like a most thankful and reverent youth, and I praise God for you.
Goodbye!: Your worship speaks like a very thankful and reverent youth, and I praise God for you.

Anon!: To cry “Amen” to that, thus we appear.
Goodbye!: We’re going to cry “Amen” to that.

Anon!: Farewell.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: Yes, by heaven!
Goodbye!: Yes, by heaven!

Anon!: What noise is here?
Goodbye!: What’s this noise?

Anon!: And all my children?
Goodbye!: And all my children?

Anon!: Tis time to look about.
Goodbye!: It’s time to look around.

Anon!: Send the deed after me, And I will sign it.
Goodbye!: Send the deed to me, and I’ll sign it.

Anon!: You are in the right.
Goodbye!: You’re right.

Anon!: Sleep dwell upon thine eyes, peace in thy breast.
Goodbye!: Sleep on your eyes, and you’ll feel peace in your breast.

Anon!: Who hath sent thee now?
Goodbye!: Who sent you now?

Anon!: I have more care to stay than will to go.
Goodbye!: I’m more concerned about staying than I want to go.

Anon!: Both of you Know Banquo was your enemy.
Goodbye!: Both of you know Banquo was your enemy.

Anon!: And that I am he Let me a little show it even in this: That I was constant Cimber should be banished, And constant do remain to keep him so.
Goodbye!: And that I am he, let me show it in this way: that I was constant Cimber should be banished, and that he’s still alive.

Anon!: I mean, sir, for his weapon.
Goodbye!: I mean, sir, for his weapon.

Anon!: I would you were as I would have you be!
Goodbye!: I wish you were as I wish you were!

Anon!: But I will wed thee in another key, With pomp, with triumph, and with reveling.
Goodbye!: But I’ll wed you in another key, with pomp, with triumph, and with reveling.

Anon!: See how she leans her cheek upon her hand.
Goodbye!: See how she leans her cheeks on her hand.

Anon!: For the love of God, a surgeon!
Goodbye!: For the love of God, a surgeon!

Anon!: He is sad and civil And suits well for a servant with my fortunes.
Goodbye!: He’s sad and civil and suits me well for a servant with my fortunes.

Anon!: I am sped.
Goodbye!: I’m sped.

Anon!: Fall to.
Goodbye!: Fall to it.

Anon!: Behold this man.
Goodbye!: Look at this man.

Anon!: What is your will, sir, that you send for me?
Goodbye!: What will you send me?

Anon!: Then, God grant me too Thou mayst be damnèd for that wicked deed.
Goodbye!: Then, God grant me that you may be damned for that wicked deed.

Anon!: Sir, I say to you we are none.
Goodbye!: Sir, I tell you that we’re not.

Anon!: Now, music, sound, and sing your solemn hymn.
Goodbye!: Now listen to music, sound, and sing your solemn hymn.

Anon!: Marry, well remembered.
Goodbye!: Good luck.

Anon!: I know thee well.
Goodbye!: I know you.

Anon!: Here are enemies.
Goodbye!: Here are enemies.

Anon!: Now, I prithee, daughter, do not make me mad.
Goodbye!: Now, please, daughter, don’t make me mad.

Anon!: What were these?
Goodbye!: What were these?

Anon!: So to them both.
Goodbye!: So to them both.

Anon!: Good faith, good faith, the saying did not hold In him that did object the same to thee!
Goodbye!: Good faith, good faith, the saying didn’t hold in him who objected to you!

Anon!: So will you wish on me when the rash mood is on.
Goodbye!: You’ll wish you luck to me when I’m in a rash mood.

Anon!: We, Hermia, like two artificial gods, Have with our needles created both one flower, Both on one sampler, sitting on one cushion, Both warbling of one song, both in one key, As if our hands, our sides, voices, and minds, Had been incorporate.
Goodbye!: We, Hermia, have created both one flower, both on one sampler, sitting on one cushion, and both singing in one key, as if our hands, our sides, our voices, and our minds had been

Anon!: Let witchcraft join with beauty, lust with both.
Goodbye!: Witchcraft will join beauty, lust with both.

Anon!: For ’tis most easy Th' inclining Desdemona to subdue In any honest suit.
Goodbye!: It’s very easy for Desdemona to subdue in any honest case.

Anon!: Yea, noise?
Goodbye!: Oh, noise?

Anon!: Where is he?
Goodbye!: Where is he?

Anon!: Therefore stay yet.
Goodbye!: So stay for a while.

Anon!: By your leave, hostess.
Goodbye!: By your way, hostess.

Anon!: Hath not a Jew hands, organs, dimensions, senses, affections, passions?
Goodbye!: Doesn’t a Jew have hands, organs, dimensions, senses, affections, passions?

Anon!: If you do free your children from the sword, Your children’s children quits it in your age.
Goodbye!: If you free your children from the sword, your children’s children will leave it in your age.

Anon!: I forgive you the praise.
Goodbye!: I’ll forgive you for the praise.

Anon!: You could, for a need, study a speech of some dozen or sixteen lines which I would set down and insert in ’t, could you not?
Goodbye!: You could, for a need, write a speech of about twelve or sixteen lines I’d set down and insert in it, wouldn’t you?

Anon!: I would not have him miscarry for the half of my dowry.
Goodbye!: I wouldn’t want him to be a miscarry for half of my dowry.

Anon!: What wouldst thou with us?
Goodbye!: What are you going to do with us?

Anon!: Open your gates.
Goodbye!: Open your gates.

Anon!: You shall find me apt enough to that, sir, an you will give me occasion.
Goodbye!: You’ll find me apt enough to do that, sir, so you can give me some opportunity.

Anon!: Let us die.
Goodbye!: Let’s die.

Anon!: It is determined, not concluded yet; But so it must be if the king miscarry.
Goodbye!: It’s determined, not yet concluded, but it must be if the king’s miscarrying.

Anon!: His fault concludes but what the law should end, The life of Tybalt.
Goodbye!: He’s only guilty of what the law should end, Tybalt’s life.

Anon!: No, you shall pardon me.
Goodbye!: No, you’ll pardon me.

Anon!: There lies your love.
Goodbye!: There lies your love.

Anon!: Briefness and fortune, work!— Brother, a word.
Goodbye!: Briefness and fortune, work!—French, a word.

Anon!: As wicked dew as e'er my mother brushed With raven’s feather from unwholesome fen Drop on you both!
Goodbye!: I’ve brushed my mother with a feather of raven’s feathers, and I’ll drop you both!

Anon!: How now, Grumio?
Goodbye!: What’s going on, Grumio?

Anon!: Never was seen so black a day as this.
Goodbye!: Never was this black day as this.

Anon!: Hath there been such a time—I would fain know that— That I have positively said, “'Tis so,” When it proved otherwise?
Goodbye!: Has there been such a time—I would fain know that—when I said positively, “I’m so,” when it proved otherwise?

Anon!: O Lord, they fight!
Goodbye!: Oh Lord, they’re fighting!

Anon!: Let that be left Which leaves itself.
Goodbye!: Let’s leave that that leaves itself.

Anon!: Now gods that we adore, whereof comes this?
Goodbye!: Now gods that we love, where’s this coming from?

Anon!: This would drink deep.
Goodbye!: This would make you drink deep.

Anon!: Pray God, he keep his oath!
Goodbye!: Please, he’s still oath!

Anon!: How!
Goodbye!: How!

Anon!: Are not you he?
Goodbye!: Aren’t you him?

Anon!: What is he that you ask for, niece?
Goodbye!: What do you want, niece?

Anon!: I have well approved it, sir.
Goodbye!: I’ve a good opinion on it, sir.

Anon!: How oddly thou repliest!
Goodbye!: How oddly you respond!

Anon!: Macbeth!
Goodbye!: Macbeth!

Anon!: You shall find me apt enough to that, sir, an you will give me occasion.
Goodbye!: You’ll find me apt enough to do that, sir, so you can give me some opportunity.

Anon!: O Friar, the damnèd use that word in hell.
Goodbye!: Oh Friar, damned men use that word in hell.

Anon!: I had rather be a toad And live upon the vapor of a dungeon Than keep a corner in the thing I love For others' uses.
Goodbye!: I’d rather be a toad and live on the vapor of a dungeon than keep a corner in the thing I love for others.

Anon!: Tis true, my liege; this ring I had of her.
Goodbye!: It’s true, my liege, I had this ring from her.

Anon!: Go you with me and I will use your skill.— Good cousin, have a care this busy time.
Goodbye!: Go with me and I’ll use your skills.—Good cousin, take care of this busy time.

Anon!: How now, who calls?
Goodbye!: Who’s calling me?

Anon!: What call you the carriages?
Goodbye!: What do you call the carriages?

Anon!: I will weary you then no longer with idle talking.
Goodbye!: I’ll weary you then, not with idle talking.

Anon!: And know it now: the senate have concluded To give this day a crown to mighty Caesar.
Goodbye!: And now you know it: the senate has decided to give the mighty Caesar a crown today.

Anon!: O life!
Goodbye!: Oh life!

Anon!: Yours by this hand.
Goodbye!: You’re yours by this hand.

Anon!: Ride you this afternoon?
Goodbye!: Do you ride this afternoon?

Anon!: This is mere madness.
Goodbye!: This is pure madness.

Anon!: Why, that were covetousness.
Goodbye!: That’s a slander.

Anon!: How is ’t with you?
Goodbye!: How are you?

Anon!: Madam, good night.
Goodbye!: Madam, good night.

Anon!: If it be love indeed, tell me how much.
Goodbye!: If it’s true love, tell me how much.

Anon!: Most mighty duke, vouchsafe me speak a word.
Goodbye!: Most mighty duke, please tell me to speak a word.

Anon!: I promise you your kindred hath made my eyes water ere now.
Goodbye!: I promise you’ve made my eyes water now.

Anon!: This disturbèd sky Is not to walk in.
Goodbye!: This disturbed sky isn’t a way to walk in.

Anon!: Make a short shrift.
Goodbye!: Make a short break.

Anon!: By my life I do, which I tender dearly, though I say I am a magician.
Goodbye!: I swear I do, which I love most, even though I say I’m a magician.

Anon!: But do not so.
Goodbye!: But don’t.

Anon!: Orsino.
Goodbye!: Orsino.

Anon!: Will you dine with me tomorrow?
Goodbye!: Will you be dining with me tomorrow?

Anon!: Get thee hence.
Goodbye!: Get out of here.

Anon!: Gertrude, do not drink.
Goodbye!: Gertrude, don’t drink.

Anon!: Richmond is on the seas.
Goodbye!: Richmond is on the seas.

Anon!: As hell, Sir Topas.
Goodbye!: As hell, Sir Topas.

Anon!: I know not.
Goodbye!: I don’t know.

Anon!: No.
Goodbye!: No.

Anon!: Though the wisdom of nature can reason it thus and thus, yet nature finds itself scourged by the sequent effects.
Goodbye!: Though nature can be a good reason for it, it can be a good reason, but nature is scourged by the squeaky effects.

Anon!: Look you, the worm is not to be trusted but in the keeping of wise people, for indeed there is no goodness in the worm.
Goodbye!: Look, the worm isn’t a good thing to trust, but it’s not good.

Anon!: Good day and happiness, dear Rosalind.
Goodbye!: Good day and happiness, dear Rosalind.

Anon!: Nay, rather persuade him to hold his hands.
Goodbye!: No, don’t convince him to hold his hands.

Anon!: And what’s the news, good cousin Lodovico?
Goodbye!: And what’s the news, cousin Lodovico?

Anon!: The quarrel is between our masters and us their men.
Goodbye!: The fight is between our masters and us men.

Anon!: I am one, sir, that comes to tell you your daughter and the Moor are now making the beast with two backs.
Goodbye!: I’m one of you who comes to tell you your daughter and the Moor are making the beast with two backs.

Anon!: Show me which way.
Goodbye!: Show me which way.

Anon!: You are full of pretty answers.
Goodbye!: You’re full of pretty answers.

Anon!: O, my lord, You said that idle weeds are fast in growth.
Goodbye!: Oh, my lord, you said that idle weeds are growing fast.

Anon!: And that which spites me more than all these wants, He does it under name of perfect love, As who should say, if I should sleep or eat, 'Twere deadly sickness or else present death.
Goodbye!: And if I sleep or eat, it would be deadly sickness or else death.

Anon!: Fairly spoke.
Goodbye!: I’m right.

Anon!: Bid me tear the bond.
Goodbye!: Tell me to tear the bond.

Anon!: Good my lord, enter.
Goodbye!: Good, my lord, go inside.

Anon!: If I do not put on a sober habit, Talk with respect and swear but now and then, Wear prayer books in my pocket, look demurely— Nay more.
Goodbye!: If I don’t have a sober habit, talk with respect and swear, but now and then, wear prayer books in my pocket, look dreadfully— No more.

Anon!: What man was he talked with you yesternight Out at your window betwixt twelve and one?
Goodbye!: What man was he talking to you for a night out at your window, twelve and one?

Anon!: I never felt it till now—Two thousand ducats in that, and other precious, precious jewels.
Goodbye!: I never felt it until now—Two thousand ducats in that, and other precious, precious jewels.

Anon!: A fair woman!
Goodbye!: A fair woman!

Anon!: Therefore I took your hands, but was indeed Swayed from the point by looking down on Caesar.
Goodbye!: So I took your hands, but I was slain from the point by looking down on Caesar.

Anon!: And at her late being here She gave strange oeillades and most speaking looks To noble Edmund.
Goodbye!: And when she was here late, she gave strange oeillades and most speaking looks to noble Edmund.

Anon!: Hence, away!
Goodbye!: Go away!

Anon!: Madam, bethink you, like a careful mother, Of the young prince your son.
Goodbye!: Madam, think about the young prince your son, like a careful mother.

Anon!: Eros, Wouldst thou be windowed in great Rome and see Thy master thus with pleached arms, bending down His corrigible neck, his face subdued To penetrative shame, whilst the wheeled seat Of fortunate Caesar, drawn before him, branded His baseness that ensued?
Goodbye!: Eros, would you be hung in the great Rome and see your master like this with pleached arms, bending down his corrigible neck, his face smothered to shame, while the wheeled seat of

Anon!: I, not remembering how I cried out then, Will cry it o'er again.
Goodbye!: I’ll cry again, not remembering how I cried out then.

Anon!: As I did stand my watch upon the hill, I looked toward Birnam, and anon methought The wood began to move.
Goodbye!: As I stood my watch on the hill, I looked towards Birnam, and I thought the wood began to move.

Anon!: I gave you all— And in good time you gave it.
Goodbye!: I gave you everything— and you gave it right away.

Anon!: What, what?
Goodbye!: What?

Anon!: Let me speak proudly: tell the constable We are but warriors for the working day; Our gayness and our gilt are all besmirched With rainy marching in the painful field.
Goodbye!: Let me say proudly: tell the constable we’re only warriors for the working day.

Anon!: Now, good my lord, lie here and rest awhile.
Goodbye!: Now, my lord, lie here and rest for a while.

Anon!: Have patience, I beseech.
Goodbye!: Have patience, please.

Anon!: We doubt not of a fair and lucky war, Since God so graciously hath brought to light This dangerous treason lurking in our way To hinder our beginnings.
Goodbye!: We don’t doubt a fair and lucky war, since God has brought this dangerous treason to light.

Anon!: Woo’t fast?
Goodbye!: Wooray fast?

Anon!: So much for this, sir.
Goodbye!: So much for this, sir.

Anon!: Lord Mayor, the reason we have sent— Look back!
Goodbye!: Lord Mayor, we’ve sent you the reason— Look back!

Anon!: Master, shall I be porter at the gate?
Goodbye!: Master, should I be a porter at the gate?

Anon!: We know what belongs to a watch.
Goodbye!: We know what’s going on with a watch.

Anon!: What is the matter here?
Goodbye!: What’s the matter here?

Anon!: How likes Gremio these quick-witted folks?
Goodbye!: How are these quick-witted folks Gremio?

Anon!: Yes, you have seen Cassio and she together.
Goodbye!: Yes, you’ve seen Cassio and she together.

Anon!: Marry, sir, because silver hath a sweet sound.
Goodbye!: Sir, because silver has a sweet sound.

Anon!: Lady Beatrice, have you wept all this while?
Goodbye!: Have you wept all this while, Lady Beatrice?

Anon!: To fetch her fan, her gloves, her mask, nor nothing?
Goodbye!: To get her fan, her gloves, her mask, or anything?

Anon!: And thane of Cawdor too: went it not so?
Goodbye!: And the thane of Cawdor too: did it not work?

Anon!: Heavens shield Lysander if they mean a fray!
Goodbye!: Heavens shield Lysander if they mean a fight!

Anon!: Down with the Capulets!
Goodbye!: Down with the Capulets!

Anon!: Go to, farewell.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: Whence are you, sir?
Goodbye!: Where are you, sir?

Anon!: In those freckles live their savors.
Goodbye!: In those savors, they live in the savors.

Anon!: Fled this way, sir, when by no means he could— Pursue him, ho!
Goodbye!: Go this way, sir, when he couldn’t— Follow him, ho!

Anon!: Go hence.
Goodbye!: Go away.

Anon!: Where’s Seleucus?
Goodbye!: Where’s Seleucus?

Anon!: He lays it on.
Goodbye!: He’s laying it on.

Anon!: Think of me as you please.
Goodbye!: Think about me like you would.

Anon!: Yet he hath ever but slenderly known himself.
Goodbye!: But he has always known himself slenderly.

Anon!: That do I long to hear.
Goodbye!: I’m waiting for that.

Anon!: Ay, sweet Rosalind.
Goodbye!: Yes, sweet Rosalind.

Anon!: mutinies, in countries discord, in palaces treason, and the bond cracked ’twixt son and father.
Goodbye!: mutinies, in countries of discord, in palaces of treason, and the bond smashed son and father.

Anon!: This night I hold an old accustomed feast, Whereto I have invited many a guest Such as I love.
Goodbye!: This night I’m having a feast that’s been a long time, where I invited many guests like me to join me.

Anon!: Do as thou wilt, for I have done with thee.
Goodbye!: Do as you want, because I’ve done with you.

Anon!: Nothing, my lord.
Goodbye!: Nothing, my lord.

Anon!: Nay, an there were two such, we should have none shortly, for one would kill the other.
Goodbye!: If there were two such people, we’d have none soon, because one would kill the other.

Anon!: Though Nature hath given us wit to flout at Fortune, hath not Fortune sent in this fool to cut off the argument?
Goodbye!: Though Nature has given us wit to betray Fortune, hasn’t Fortune sent this fool into the fight to stop it?

Anon!: O' Thursday be it, then.— Go you to Juliet ere you go to bed.
Goodbye!: Oh, Thursday will be it, then.—Go to Juliet before you go to bed.

Anon!: And to run away from the Jew I should be ruled by the fiend, who, saving your reverence, is the devil himself.
Goodbye!: And to run away from the Jew, I should be ruled by the fiend, who, saving your reverence, is the devil himself.

Anon!: Prithee, my king, be quiet.
Goodbye!: Please, my king, be quiet.

Anon!: He sings at grave- making.
Goodbye!: He sings at the grave.

Anon!: Are you answered?
Goodbye!: Are you answering this question?

Anon!: I have two nights watched with you but can perceive no truth in your report.
Goodbye!: I’ve been watching you for two nights, but I can’t see any truth in your report.

Anon!: And, pretty fool, it stinted and said “ay.” Enough of this.
Goodbye!: And, pretty fool, it sat down and said “yes.” That’s enough of that.

Anon!: This, Decius Brutus.
Goodbye!: This is Decius Brutus.

Anon!: Not yet old enough for a man, nor young enough for a boy, as a squash is before ’tis a peascod, or a codling when ’tis almost an apple.
Goodbye!: Not old enough for a man, or young enough for a boy, as a squash is before it’s a peasant, or a codling when it’s almost an apple.

Anon!: Who is it?
Goodbye!: Who is it?

Anon!: Come.
Goodbye!: Come on.

Anon!: He’s dead.
Goodbye!: He’s dead.

Anon!: Please it your Grace lead on?
Goodbye!: Please, what’s your Grace doing?

Anon!: There is no more to say?
Goodbye!: There’s no more to say?

Anon!: A good soft pillow for that good white head Were better than a churlish turf of France.
Goodbye!: A good soft pillow for that white head would be better than a churlish turf in France.

Anon!: Had I but died an hour before this chance, I had lived a blessèd time, for from this instant There’s nothing serious in mortality.
Goodbye!: If I had only died an hour before this chance, I’d have lived a blessed time, because from this moment on there is nothing serious about mortality.

Anon!: You have dancing shoes With nimble soles.
Goodbye!: You’re wearing dancing shoes with nimble soles.

Anon!: Cesario, you do not keep promise with me.
Goodbye!: Cesario, you don’t keep your promise with me.

Anon!: All is the fear and nothing is the love, As little is the wisdom, where the flight So runs against all reason.
Goodbye!: Everything is fear, and nothing is love, as little is wisdom, where the flight is against all reason.

Anon!: I will kiss your hand, and so I leave you.
Goodbye!: I’ll kiss your hand, and so I’ll leave you.

Anon!: So I do.
Goodbye!: I do.

Anon!: I marry her!
Goodbye!: I’m marrying her!

Anon!: That very time I saw (but thou couldst not) Flying between the cold moon and the Earth, Cupid all armed.
Goodbye!: I saw that time (but you couldn’t) flying between the moon and the Earth, and Cupid was all armed.

Anon!: All’s cheerless, dark, and deadly.
Goodbye!: It’s a terrible thing.

Anon!: I beseech you pardon me, my lord, if I be mistaken—for my duty cannot be silent when I think your highness wronged.
Goodbye!: I beg you to pardon me if I’m mistaken—because my duty can’t be silent when I think your highness is wrong.

Anon!: He replied, “Thou unpossessing bastard!
Goodbye!: He replied, “You unpossible bastard!

Anon!: Are you good men and true?
Goodbye!: Are you good men and true?

Anon!: Look, look.
Goodbye!: Look, look.

Anon!: Approach and speak.
Goodbye!: Come and speak.

Anon!: And if you leave me so, you do me wrong.
Goodbye!: And if you leave me like that, you’re wrong.

Anon!: That’s my brave lord!
Goodbye!: That’s my brave lord!

Anon!: O inhuman dog!
Goodbye!: Oh, you inhuman dog!

Anon!: A hundred marks, my Kate does put her down.
Goodbye!: A hundred marks, my Kate puts her down.

Anon!: This sight of death is as a bell, That warns my old age to a sepulcher.
Goodbye!: This sight of death is like a bell, which warns me to be a sepulcher.

Anon!: But well and free, If thou so yield him, there is gold, and here My bluest veins to kiss—a hand that kings Have lipped, and trembled kissing.
Goodbye!: But if you give him such a gift, there’s gold and my bluest veins to kiss—a hand that kings have lipped and trembled kissing.

Anon!: What is it else?
Goodbye!: What else is it?

Anon!: Bring them before us.
Goodbye!: Bring them to us.

Anon!: And you all know, security Is mortals' chiefest enemy.
Goodbye!: And you all know, security is mortals’ chief enemy.

Anon!: Caesar hath sent— Too slow a messenger.
Goodbye!: Caesar has sent— Too slow a messenger.

Anon!: My lord, I do protest—    O, do not swear!
Goodbye!: My lord, I swear— Oh, don’t swear!

Anon!: Do you bite your thumb at us, sir?
Goodbye!: Do you bite your thumb at us?

Anon!: Give me faith, say I.
Goodbye!: Give me faith, say I.

Anon!: Young Fortinbras, with conquest come from Poland, To th' ambassadors of England gives This warlike volley.
Goodbye!: Young Fortinbras, with conquest from Poland, gives this warlike volley to the ambassadors of England.

Anon!: Hold, take my sword.
Goodbye!: Hold on, take my sword.

Anon!: We see it and will say it.
Goodbye!: We see it and will say it.

Anon!: One unperfectness shows me another, to make me frankly despise myself.
Goodbye!: One inexplicable thing shows me another, to make me despise myself.

Anon!: Let it alone.
Goodbye!: Let it be a secret.

Anon!: Thou livest.
Goodbye!: You live.

Anon!: To prayers, to prayers, all lost!
Goodbye!: To prayers, to prayers, all lost!

Anon!: Why, I pray you?
Goodbye!: Why, please?

Anon!: Our army shall In solemn show attend this funeral, And then to Rome.
Goodbye!: Our army will attend this funeral solemnly, then to Rome.

Anon!: Where art thou, proud Demetrius?
Goodbye!: Where are you, proud Demetrius?

Anon!: Thy Fates open their hands.
Goodbye!: Your Fates open their hands.

Anon!: Who would not have his wife so?
Goodbye!: Who wouldn’t have his wife like that?

Anon!: If Hamlet give the first or second hit Or quit in answer of the third exchange, Let all the battlements their ordnance fire!
Goodbye!: If Hamlet hits the first or second hit or quit in response to the third exchange, let all the battles fire their weapons!

Anon!: Oh, he’s returned, and as pleasant as ever he was.
Goodbye!: Oh, he’s returned, and he’s as pleasant as ever.

Anon!: Will you hear ’t again?
Goodbye!: Will you hear it again?

Anon!: I know her father, though I know not her, And he knew my deceasèd father well.
Goodbye!: I know her father, even though I don’t know her, and he knew my deceiving father well.

Anon!: Pray you sit still.
Goodbye!: Please sit still.

Anon!: I arrest thee of high treason, by the name of Henry, Lord Scroop of Masham.
Goodbye!: I’m arresting you for high treason, by the name of Henry, Lord Scroop of Masham.

Anon!: There’s something in ’t That is deceivable.
Goodbye!: There’s something in it that’s deceivable.

Anon!: Post-post-haste, dispatch.
Goodbye!: Post-haste, dispatch.

Anon!: So do I his.
Goodbye!: I do, too.

Anon!: Tell him my fury shall abate, and I the crowns will take.
Goodbye!: Tell him my fury will abate, and I’ll take the crowns.

Anon!: Find them out whose names are written here?
Goodbye!: Find them who have their names written here?

Anon!: That done, I will be walking on the works, Repair there to me.
Goodbye!: That’s done, I’ll walk on the works and get back to you.

Anon!: Would it not grieve a woman to be overmastered with a piece of valiant dust?
Goodbye!: Wouldn’t it be a sad thing for a woman to be overpowered with a piece of valiant dust?

Anon!: My lady bade me tell you, that, though she harbors you as her kinsman, she’s nothing allied to your disorders.
Goodbye!: My lady told me, that even though she treats you like a king, she’s nothing to do with your troubles.

Anon!: Dismiss your attendant there, look ’t be done.
Goodbye!: Go see what you’re doing.

Anon!: Put your torches out.
Goodbye!: Put your torches out.

Anon!: To wreak the love I bore my cousin Upon his body that slaughtered him!
Goodbye!: I’ll wreak the love I bore my cousin on his body that slaughtered him!

Anon!: What is your pleasure, madam?
Goodbye!: What do you want, madam?

Anon!: Thus when I shun Scylla your father, I fall into Charybdis your mother.
Goodbye!: So when I shun Scylla your father, I fall into Charybdis your mother.

Anon!: What, with worms and flies?
Goodbye!: What, with worms and flies?

Anon!: You or any man living may be drunk at a time, man.
Goodbye!: You or any man living in the city can be drunk at a time, man.

Anon!: Tis true, my brother’s daughter’s Queen of Tunis, So is she heir of Naples, ’twixt which regions There is some space.
Goodbye!: It’s true, my brother’s daughter’s Queen of Tunis, and she’s heir of Naples, a region where there’s some space.

Anon!: Nay, get thee gone.
Goodbye!: No, go away.

Anon!: You speak too bitterly.
Goodbye!: You’re talking too bitterly.

Anon!: Here comes your father.
Goodbye!: Here comes your father.

Anon!: All that follow their noses are led by their eyes but blind men, and there’s not a nose among twenty but can smell him that’s stinking.
Goodbye!: All those who follow their noses are led by their eyes, but blind men, and there’s no one in twenty who can smell him stinking.

Anon!: We’ll hear it, Antony.
Goodbye!: We’ll hear it, Antony.

Anon!: I would rather have one of your father’s getting.
Goodbye!: I’d rather get one of your father’s gifts.

Anon!: The usurer hangs the cozener.
Goodbye!: The usurer hangs the cozener.

Anon!: I’ll fetch the general’s surgeon.— Save you your labor.—He that lies slain here, Cassio, Was my dear friend.
Goodbye!: I’ll get the general’s surgeon.—Save your labor.—He who’s been killed here, Cassio, was my dear friend.

Anon!: But saying o'er what I have said before.
Goodbye!: But I’m saying something about what I’ve said before.

Anon!: Why do you send so thick?
Goodbye!: Why are you sending so much?

Anon!: I may sit in a corner and cry, “Heigh-ho for a husband!” Lady Beatrice, I will get you one.
Goodbye!: I can sit in a corner and cry, “Heigh-ho for a husband!” Lady Beatrice, I’ll get you one.

Anon!: O sweet bully Bottom!
Goodbye!: Oh sweet bully Bottom!

Anon!: Good news, good news!
Goodbye!: Good news, good news!

Anon!: Vex not his ghost.
Goodbye!: Don’t ignore his ghost.

Anon!: Why should not we Be there in person?
Goodbye!: Why shouldn’t we be there in person?

Anon!: How long within this wood intend you stay?
Goodbye!: How long do you plan to stay in this forest?

Anon!: With all my heart I’ll gossip at this feast.
Goodbye!: I’ll gossip at this feast with all my heart.

Anon!: He’s in Arthur’s bosom, if ever man went to Arthur’s bosom.
Goodbye!: He’s in Arthur’s bosom, if he ever went to Arthur’s bosom.

Anon!: Faith, none but Humfrey Hower, that called your Grace To breakfast once, forth of my company.
Goodbye!: No one except Humfrey Hower, who called your Grace to breakfast once, came out of my company.

Anon!: The higher Nilus swells The more it promises.
Goodbye!: The higher the Nile rises, the more it promises.

Anon!: Let me report to him Your sweet dependency, and you shall find A conqueror that will pray in aid for kindness Where he for grace is kneeled to.
Goodbye!: Let me tell him your sweet dependency, and you’ll find a conqueror who will pray for kindness, where he’s kneeled for grace.

Anon!: Poor Antony!
Goodbye!: Poor Antony!

Anon!: A man is master of his liberty; Time is their master, and when they see time They’ll go or come.
Goodbye!: A man is master of his freedom.

Anon!: Come thou no more for ransom, gentle herald.
Goodbye!: Don’t come out for ransom, gentle herald.

Anon!: I’ll confine myself no finer than I am.
Goodbye!: I’ll be no finer than I am.

Anon!: The spirits that know All mortal consequences have pronounced me thus: “Fear not, Macbeth.
Goodbye!: The spirits who know all mortal consequences have said that I’m not afraid, Macbeth.

Anon!: Write from us to him.
Goodbye!: Write to him.

Anon!: What company is this?
Goodbye!: What company is this?

Anon!: What, Nurse, I say!
Goodbye!: Nurse, I say what!

Anon!: Nay, let him alone.
Goodbye!: No, let him be alone.

Anon!: I call them forth to credit her.
Goodbye!: I call them out to credit her.

Anon!: And what’s to come of my despisèd time Is naught but bitterness.
Goodbye!: And what’s going on from my despising time is bitterness.

Anon!: Can no prayers pierce thee?
Goodbye!: Can’t prayers pierce you?

Anon!: Just as high as my heart.
Goodbye!: Just as high as my heart.

Anon!: I came from Corinth, my most gracious lord.
Goodbye!: I came from Corinth, my most gracious lord.

Anon!: The last she spake Was “Antony, most noble Antony!” Then in the midst a tearing groan did break The name of Antony.
Goodbye!: The last she said was “Antony, most noble Antony!” Then in the middle of a groan, she broke the name of Antony.

Anon!: Besides, old Gremio is heark'ning still, And happily we might be interrupted.
Goodbye!: Besides, old Gremio is still listening, and we’d be interrupted.

Anon!: Peace yet again.
Goodbye!: Let’s calm down.

Anon!: Anon, anon!
Goodbye!: Oh, yes!

Anon!: She that herself will sliver and disbranch From her material sap perforce must wither And come to deadly use.
Goodbye!: She who will sliver and disbranch herself must wither and come to use deadly force.

Anon!: Do but look up.
Goodbye!: Look.

Anon!: How, how I pray you?
Goodbye!: How, how do I pray for you?

Anon!: The first that there did greet my stranger-soul Was my great father-in-law, renownèd Warwick, Who spake aloud, “What scourge for perjury Can this dark monarchy afford false Clarence?” And so he vanished.
Goodbye!: The first person who came to greet me was my great father-in-law, Warwick, who said loudly, “What scourge for perjury can this dark monarchy afford to give false Clarence?” And so

Anon!: O, preposterous And frantic outrage, end thy damnèd spleen, Or let me die, to look on death no more.
Goodbye!: Oh, preposterous and frantic outrage, end your damned spleen, or let me die, to look at death no more.

Anon!: My house was at the Phoenix?
Goodbye!: My house was at the Phoenix?

Anon!: And now methinks I have a mind to it.
Goodbye!: Now I think I’m thinking about it.

Anon!: Ay, but their sense is shut.
Goodbye!: Yes, but their sense is shut.

Anon!: O God, she comes.—O honey Nurse, what news?
Goodbye!: Oh God, she comes.—Oh honey Nurse, what news do you have?

Anon!: Who’s born that day When I forget to send to Antony Shall die a beggar.
Goodbye!: Who’s born that day when I forget to send Antony will die a beggar.

Anon!: Your looks are pale and wild, and do import Some misadventure.
Goodbye!: Your looks are pale and wild, and you’re causing some misadventure.

Anon!: Good, i' faith.
Goodbye!: Good, I’m sure.

Anon!: Marry, before he fell down, when he perceived the common herd was glad he refused the crown, he plucked me ope his doublet and offered them his throat to cut.
Goodbye!: Before he fell down, when he saw the common herd was glad he refused the crown, he plucked me ope his doublet and offered them his throat to cut.

Anon!: Sir, his definement suffers no perdition in you, though I know to divide him inventorially would dizzy th' arithmetic of memory, and yet but yaw neither, in respect of his quick sail.
Goodbye!: Sir, he’s not a fool in you, even though I know that splitting him into two would dizzy his memory, and yet I’m not sure how he’s cruising.

Anon!: Well, sir, learn to jest in good time.
Goodbye!: Well, sir, learn to scold me in good time.

Anon!: What was the second noise for?
Goodbye!: What was the second noise?

Anon!: Alas, poor rogue, I think indeed she loves me.
Goodbye!: Oh, poor rogue, I think she loves me.

Anon!: He is too disputable for my company.
Goodbye!: He’s too bad for my company.

Anon!: And for the rest o' th' fleet, Which I dispersed, they all have met again And are upon the Mediterranean float, Bound sadly home for Naples, Supposing that they saw the king’s ship wracked And his great person perish.
Goodbye!: And for the rest of the fleet, which I dispersed, they all have reunited again and are on the Mediterranean float, Bound sadly home for Naples, supposing that they saw the

Anon!: I do believe that these applauses are For some new honors that are heaped on Caesar.
Goodbye!: I believe that these applauses are for some new honors that are given to Caesar.

Anon!: Look you, sir, such a one I was this present.
Goodbye!: Look, sir, I was such a person I was present.

Anon!: O love!
Goodbye!: Oh love!

Anon!: And when goes hence?
Goodbye!: And when are you going to leave?

Anon!: If you would not, it were a good sign that I should quickly have a new father.
Goodbye!: If you didn’t, it would be a good sign that I could have a new father quickly.

Anon!: Here comes the man, sir, that did rescue me.
Goodbye!: Here comes the man who saved me, sir.

Anon!: This is too long.
Goodbye!: This is too long.

Anon!: Ay, in the catalogue ye go for men, As hounds and greyhounds, mongrels, spaniels, curs, Shoughs, water-rugs, and demi-wolves are clept All by the name of dogs.
Goodbye!: Yes, you’re going to be men, as dogs and greyhounds, mongrels, spaniels, cursors, Shoughs, water-rugs, and demi-wolves are all clept

Anon!: Why, I will see thee at Philippi, then.
Goodbye!: Well, then, I’ll see you at Philippi.

Anon!: Nay, you were better speak first, and when you were graveled for lack of matter, you might take occasion to kiss.
Goodbye!: No, you’d better speak first, and when you were graveled for lack of matter, you could take occasion to kiss.

Anon!: Come on, sir.
Goodbye!: Come on, sir.

Anon!: Fear comes upon me.
Goodbye!: Fear comes on me.

Anon!: You sunburnt sicklemen of August weary, Come hither from the furrow and be merry.
Goodbye!: You sunburnt sicklemen of August are tired, come here from the furrow and be merry.

Anon!: Receive it so.
Goodbye!: Get it.

Anon!: Therefore is it most expedient for the wise, if Don Worm, his conscience, find no impediment to the contrary, to be the trumpet of his own virtues, as I am to myself.
Goodbye!: Therefore, it’s most appropriate for the wise, if Don Worm, his conscience, doesn’t find any obstacle to the contrary, to be the trumpet of his own virtues, as I am to myself.

Anon!: It is gone.
Goodbye!: It’s gone.

Anon!: Dismiss me.
Goodbye!: Dismiss me.

Anon!: And I.
Goodbye!: And I.

Anon!: My lord shall never rest, I’ll watch him tame and talk him out of patience.
Goodbye!: My lord will never rest, I’ll watch him tame and talk him out of patience.

Anon!: She for an Edward weeps, and so do I; I for a Clarence weep; so doth not she.
Goodbye!: She isn’t for Edward, and so do I. I’m not for Clarence, and she isn’t.

Anon!: O Lord, I could have stayed here all the night To hear good counsel.
Goodbye!: Oh Lord, I could have stayed here all night to hear good advice.
