Anon!: Alas, sir, it is worse for me than so, For I have bills for money by exchange From Florence, and must here deliver them.
Goodbye!: I have bills for money from Florence, and I have to deliver them here.

Anon!: Look, and thou shalt see.
Goodbye!: Look, and you’ll see.

Anon!: They know your Grace hath cause and means and might; So hath your Highness.
Goodbye!: They know that your Grace has cause and means and power, and that’s your Highness.

Anon!: Let ’t be so, good Corporal Nym.
Goodbye!: Let’s go, Corporal Nym.

Anon!: You might do much.
Goodbye!: You could do anything.

Anon!: My face I’ll grime with filth, Blanket my loins, elf all my hair in knots, And with presented nakedness outface The winds and persecutions of the sky.
Goodbye!: I’ll grime my face with filth, scolde my loins, scolde my hair in knots, and face the winds and the persecutions of the sky.

Anon!: Is ’t not denounced against us?
Goodbye!: Isn’t it being denied against us?

Anon!: Alack, my lord, what do you mean by that?
Goodbye!: What do you mean by that, my lord?

Anon!: You have too much respect upon the world.
Goodbye!: You’re too much respecting the world.

Anon!: You cannot, sir, take from me any thing that I will more willingly part withal—except my life, except my life, except my life.
Goodbye!: You can’t take from me any thing I’ll do more willingly—except my life, except my life, except my life.

Anon!: Many a man his life hath sold But my outside to behold.
Goodbye!: Many of the men who have sold their lives have only left my house to see.

Anon!: Ay, but, lady, That policy may either last so long, Or feed upon such nice and waterish diet, Or breed itself so out of circumstances, That, I being absent and my place supplied, My general will forget my love and service.
Goodbye!: Yes, but, lady, that policy may either last so long, or feed on such a nice and healthy diet, or breed itself so out of circumstances, that, if I’m absent and I’m in my place,

Anon!: Why, do not your courtier’s hands sweat?
Goodbye!: Why, don’t your courtier’s hands sweat?

Anon!: I had it of Leah when I was a bachelor.
Goodbye!: I had it from Leah when I was a bachelor.

Anon!: Let me be married to three kings in a forenoon and widow them all.
Goodbye!: Let me be married to three kings in a forenoon and widow them all.

Anon!: Come, bid me do anything for thee.
Goodbye!: Come on, ask me to do anything for you.

Anon!: Hortensio, to what end are all these words?
Goodbye!: Hortensio, what are all these words?

Anon!: I will weep for nothing, like Diana in the fountain, and I will do that when you are disposed to be merry.
Goodbye!: I’ll cry for nothing, like Diana in the fountain, and I’ll do that when you’re ready to be a good man.

Anon!: Hast thou no letters to me from the friar?
Goodbye!: Don’t you have any letters from the friar to me?

Anon!: Farewell, sweet masters both.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, sweet masters.

Anon!: Leave all the rest to me.
Goodbye!: Leave all the rest to me.

Anon!: Get me ink and paper, And hire post horses.
Goodbye!: Get me ink and paper, and hire horses to ride.

Anon!: Lysander, keep thy Hermia.
Goodbye!: Lysander, keep your Hermia.

Anon!: I never can see him but I am heartburned an hour after.
Goodbye!: I can’t see him until I’m heartburned an hour later.

Anon!: Charles, I thank thee for thy love to me, which thou shalt find I will most kindly requite.
Goodbye!: Charles, I thank you for your love for me, which you’ll find I’ll be requiting.

Anon!: Stop that, ’twill fly with the smoke out at the chimney.
Goodbye!: Stop that, it’ll blow out the chimney with the smoke.

Anon!: Show.
Goodbye!: Show.

Anon!: Now, by Apollo— Now, by Apollo, King, Thou swear’st thy gods in vain.
Goodbye!: Now, by Apollo— Now, by Apollo, King, you swear your gods are in vain.

Anon!: He speaks to me.—I am your master, Dromio.
Goodbye!: He’s talking to me.—I’m your master, Dromio.

Anon!: If your love do not persuade you to come, let not my letter.” O love, dispatch all business and be gone!
Goodbye!: If your love doesn’t convince you to come, don’t let me write my letter.” Oh love, send all your business and go away!

Anon!: Mistress, you must come away to your father.
Goodbye!: Mistress, you have to come away to your father.

Anon!: Now sir, this granted—as it is a most pregnant and unforced position—who stands so eminent in the degree of this fortune as Cassio does?
Goodbye!: Now, sir, who is so pregnant and unforced in the degree of this fortune as Cassio does?

Anon!: Good Father, I beseech you on my knees, Hear me with patience but to speak a word.
Goodbye!: Good Father, I beg you to kneel, listen to me with patience.

Anon!: Oh, the difference of man and man!
Goodbye!: Oh, the difference between man and man!

Anon!: Do you intend to stay with me tonight?
Goodbye!: Do you intend to stay with me tonight?

Anon!: Commend me to my kind lord.
Goodbye!: Give my kind lord praise.

Anon!: This is called “the countercheck quarrelsome,” and so to “the lie circumstantial” and “the lie direct.”  And how oft did you say his beard was not well cut?
Goodbye!: This is called “the counter-attack” and so to “the lie circumstantial” and “the lie direct.” And how often did you say his beard was not well cut?

Anon!: Oh weary reckoning!
Goodbye!: Oh, weary thinking!

Anon!: To her that is not here, nor doth not hear.
Goodbye!: To her who isn’t here, and doesn’t hear it.

Anon!: How dost thou?
Goodbye!: How are you?

Anon!: That ’scuse serves many men to save their gifts.
Goodbye!: That’s what many men do to save their gifts.

Anon!: Tis safer to be that which we destroy Than by destruction dwell in doubtful joy.
Goodbye!: It’s safer to be the one that we destroy than to dwell in a doubtful joy.

Anon!: I’ll bring you to him straight.
Goodbye!: I’ll bring you to him right away.

Anon!: No, by no means.
Goodbye!: No, no.

Anon!: I will be correspondent to command And do my spiriting gently.
Goodbye!: I’ll be a correspondent to command and do my spiriting gently.

Anon!: Those that with haste will make a mighty fire Begin it with weak straws.
Goodbye!: The people who rush to make a powerful fire start with weak straws.

Anon!: The earth, that’s nature’s mother, is her tomb.
Goodbye!: The earth, that’s nature’s mother, is her tomb.

Anon!: Descend.
Goodbye!: Descend.

Anon!: You are a saucy boy.
Goodbye!: You’re a savage boy.

Anon!: I’ll make division of my present with you.
Goodbye!: I’ll share my present with you.

Anon!: Hath he asked for me?
Goodbye!: Has he asked for me?

Anon!: Antony only, that would make his will Lord of his reason.
Goodbye!: Only Antony, that would make his will Lord of his reason.

Anon!: Come, good fellow, put thine iron on.
Goodbye!: Come on, good fellow, put your iron on.

Anon!: Where left we last?
Goodbye!: Where did we leave last?

Anon!: Very gladly.
Goodbye!: Very happy.

Anon!: Do not, my lord.
Goodbye!: Don’t, my lord.

Anon!: Never king of England Had nobles richer, and more loyal subjects, Whose hearts have left their bodies here in England And lie pavilioned in the fields of France.
Goodbye!: Never king of England had nobles more loyal and rich than those who left their hearts here in England and were buried in the fields of France.

Anon!: Though far more cause, yet much less spirit to curse Abides in me.
Goodbye!: Though it’s much more important to be angry, it’s much less likely to curse me.

Anon!: Oh, ’tis a gallant king!
Goodbye!: Oh, it’s a gallant king!

Anon!: Your cause of sorrow Must not be measured by his worth, for then It hath no end.
Goodbye!: Your sorrow shouldn’t be measured by his worth, because then it won’t end.

Anon!: Give me thy hand.
Goodbye!: Give me your hand.

Anon!: Ay, Desdemona.
Goodbye!: Yes, Desdemona.

Anon!: There’s no doubt his majesty Will soon recover his accustomed health.
Goodbye!: No doubt his majesty will recover his health soon.

Anon!: What not put upon His spongy officers, who shall bear the guilt Of our great quell?
Goodbye!: What’s wrong with his spongy officers, who will be guilty of our great qull?

Anon!: No further, sir.
Goodbye!: Don’t go any further, sir.

Anon!: Why did you so?
Goodbye!: Why did you do that?

Anon!: Here they’ll be, man.
Goodbye!: Here they’ll be, man.

Anon!: I fear me both are false.
Goodbye!: I’m afraid both of you are false.

Anon!: It were good that Benedick knew of it by some other, if she will not discover it.
Goodbye!: It would be good that Benedick knew about it by some other person, if she doesn’t know about it.

Anon!: Run to the Capitol, and nothing else?
Goodbye!: Run to the Capitol, and nothing else?

Anon!: Yes, I have gained my experience.
Goodbye!: Yes, I’ve gained my experience.

Anon!: Let me speak like yourself and lay a sentence Which, as a grise or step, may help these lovers.
Goodbye!: Let me speak like yourself and write a sentence that can help these lovers.

Anon!: I will have none on ’t.
Goodbye!: I won’t have any of them.

Anon!: I thank my noble lord.
Goodbye!: Thank you, my noble lord.

Anon!: Then heaven Have mercy on me!
Goodbye!: Then heaven have mercy on me!

Anon!: Here cease more questions.
Goodbye!: Let’s stop a few more questions.

Anon!: Here, sir!” You loggerheaded and unpolished grooms!
Goodbye!: Here, sir!” You snoring and unpolished grooms!

Anon!: If wolves had at thy gate howled that stern time, Thou shouldst have said, “Good porter, turn the key,” All cruèls else subscribed.
Goodbye!: If wolves had walked at your gate that night, you should have said, “Good porter, turn the key,” and all the cruèls else were a part of the conversation.

Anon!: Strumpet, I come.
Goodbye!: Strumpet, I’m coming.

Anon!: I have heard it over, And it is nothing, nothing in the world— Unless you can find sport in their intents, Extremely stretched and conned with cru 'l pain To do you service.
Goodbye!: I’ve heard it over, and it’s nothing, nothing in the world—unless you can find sport in their intentions, stretched and conned with pain to do you service.

Anon!: So may you lose your arms.
Goodbye!: You may lose your arms.

Anon!: What’s your will?
Goodbye!: What do you want?

Anon!: Here comes the furious Tybalt back again.
Goodbye!: Here comes the furious Tybalt back again.

Anon!: Think you to walk forth?
Goodbye!: Do you think you’re going to walk out?

Anon!: Ha!
Goodbye!: Ha!

Anon!: O Hamlet, thou hast cleft my heart in twain.
Goodbye!: Oh Hamlet, you’ve cleft my heart in two.

Anon!: Where is he, in his bed?
Goodbye!: Where is he, in his bed?

Anon!: Tis expressly against the law of arms.
Goodbye!: It’s expressly against the law of arms.

Anon!: Twenty crowns?
Goodbye!: Twenty crowns?

Anon!: Ah, let be, let be!
Goodbye!: Ah, let’s go, let’s go!

Anon!: But tell me yet, dost thou not know my voice?
Goodbye!: But tell me, don’t you know my voice?

Anon!: Call you me “fair”?
Goodbye!: Are you calling me “fair”?

Anon!: The most you sought was her promotion, For ’twas your heaven she should be advanced.
Goodbye!: The most you wanted was her promotion, because it was your heaven that she should be promoted.

Anon!: I hid me under the dead mooncalf’s gaberdine for fear of the storm.
Goodbye!: I hid myself under the dead mooncalf’s sand for fear of the storm.

Anon!: He hath fought today As if a god, in hate of mankind, had Destroyed in such a shape.
Goodbye!: He has fought today as if a god had destroyed his life in such a hateful way.

Anon!: Doing is activity, and he will still be doing.
Goodbye!: Doing is a job, and he will still do it.

Anon!: We’ll wait upon your lordship.
Goodbye!: We’ll wait on your lordship.

Anon!: Those that are good manners at the court are as ridiculous in the country as the behavior of the country is most mockable at the court.
Goodbye!: The people who are good at the court are as ridiculous in the country as the country is most mockable at the court.

Anon!: And thou unfit for any place but hell.
Goodbye!: And you’re not in the mood for any place except hell.

Anon!: But let me to my fortune and the caskets.
Goodbye!: But let me go to my fortune and the caskets.

Anon!: By my troth, the fool has an excellent breast.
Goodbye!: I swear, the fool has an excellent breast.

Anon!: I think I hear them.—Stand, ho!
Goodbye!: I think I hear them.—Stand, ho!

Anon!: Are you the lady of the house?
Goodbye!: Are you the lady of the house?

Anon!: Monday, my lord.
Goodbye!: Monday, my lord.

Anon!: Le chien est retourné à son propre vomissement, et la truie lavée au bourbier.” Thou mak’st use of anything.
Goodbye!: Le chien is retourné à son propre vomissement, and la truie lavée au bourbier.” You’re using anything.

Anon!: Be ’t as our gods will have ’t.
Goodbye!: Be as our gods will.

Anon!: Sure he hath killed his wife.
Goodbye!: Sure he killed his wife.

Anon!: To none but thee, no more but when to thee.
Goodbye!: No more than you, no more than when you’re coming.

Anon!: How is’t with you, sir?
Goodbye!: How are you, sir?

Anon!: It well appears.
Goodbye!: It’s good.

Anon!: Why, such is love’s transgression.
Goodbye!: Why, love is transgressing.

Anon!: And mine, to eke out hers.
Goodbye!: And mine, to eke out hers.

Anon!: Then, my queen, in silence sad, Trip we after the night’s shade.
Goodbye!: Then, my queen, we’re going to sleep in the shade of the night.

Anon!: Tis paltry to be Caesar.
Goodbye!: It’s a bit sour to be Caesar.

Anon!: This is my treasurer.
Goodbye!: This is my treasurer.

Anon!: Let’s draw our weapons.
Goodbye!: Let’s draw our weapons.

Anon!: There’s other business for thee.
Goodbye!: There’s another thing for you.

Anon!: You scarcely have the hearts to tell me so, And therefore cannot have the hearts to do it.
Goodbye!: You don’t have the hearts to tell me that, and therefore you can’t have the hearts to do it.

Anon!: A conduit, girl?
Goodbye!: A conduit, girl?

Anon!: Fair ladies, you drop manna in the way Of starvèd people.
Goodbye!: Ladies, you’re dropping manna in the way of starvation.

Anon!: Wherefore did you so?
Goodbye!: Why did you do that?

Anon!: Have at you now!
Goodbye!: Have a look at you now!

Anon!: Uncle, your Grace knows how to bear with him.
Goodbye!: Uncle, your Grace knows how to bear with him.

Anon!: My lord and brother, God save you.
Goodbye!: My lord and brother, God save you.

Anon!: Or, failing so, yet that I put the Moor At least into a jealousy so strong That judgment cannot cure.
Goodbye!: Or, if I fail, I’ll put the Moor at least in a jealousy so strong that judgment can’t cure it.

Anon!: So please you, something touching the Lord Hamlet.
Goodbye!: Please, something touching the Lord Hamlet.

Anon!: March on, march on, since we are up in arms, If not to fight with foreign enemies, Yet to beat down these rebels here at home.
Goodbye!: March on, march on, since we’re up in arms, if not to fight with foreign enemies, but to beat down these rebels here at home.

Anon!: Let him go And presently prefer his suit to Caesar.
Goodbye!: Let him go and now he prefers Caesar’s suit.

Anon!: Tis no such matter.
Goodbye!: It doesn’t matter.

Anon!: Yes, he is dead.
Goodbye!: Yes, he’s dead.

Anon!: For it is a figure in rhetoric that drink, being poured out of a cup into a glass, by filling the one doth empty the other.
Goodbye!: It’s a figure in rhetoric that drinks are poured out of a cup into a glass, filling the one with emptying the other.

Anon!: Make it no wonder.
Goodbye!: Don’t make it look like it’s been ruined.

Anon!: Not know me yet?
Goodbye!: Don’t you know me yet?

Anon!: Art thou there, Diomed?
Goodbye!: Are you there, Diomed?

Anon!: Ready, so please your grace.
Goodbye!: You’re ready, sir.

Anon!: No, sir.
Goodbye!: No, sir.

Anon!: I cannot tell.
Goodbye!: I don’t know.

Anon!: God and his angels guard your sacred throne And make you long become it.
Goodbye!: God and his angels guard your sacred throne and make you become it for a long time.

Anon!: Bring me just notice of the numbers dead On both our parts.
Goodbye!: Take care of the numbers on both sides of our lives.

Anon!: It shall to the barber’s, with your beard.—Prithee, say on.
Goodbye!: It will go to the barber’s with your beard.—Priet, tell me.

Anon!: Ha?
Goodbye!: Ha?

Anon!: Art of this house?
Goodbye!: What’s this house?

Anon!: If thou account’st it shame, lay it on me, And therefore frolic!
Goodbye!: If you’re blaming it for shame, then you’ll be blaming it on me, and then you’ll be frolicing!

Anon!: Montague!
Goodbye!: Montague!

Anon!: Sinful Macduff, They were all struck for thee!
Goodbye!: Sinful Macduff, they were all struck for you!

Anon!: Prates too.—What say you, James Soundpost?
Goodbye!: What do you say, James Soundpost?

Anon!: It fell upon a little western flower, Before milk-white, now purple with love’s wound.
Goodbye!: It fell on a little western flower, before milk-white, now purple with love’s wound.

Anon!: He will do all in all as Hastings doth.
Goodbye!: He’ll do everything as Hastings does.

Anon!: O lamentable day!
Goodbye!: Oh, sad day!

Anon!: I do bite my thumb, sir.
Goodbye!: I bite my thumb.

Anon!: Though our lives— Your spirits shine through you.
Goodbye!: Though our lives— Your spirits shine through you.

Anon!: A most extracting frenzy of mine own From my remembrance clearly banished his.
Goodbye!: I’ve been reminiscing about his own remembrance.

Anon!: If this be not that you look for, I have no more to say, But bid Bianca farewell forever and a day.
Goodbye!: If this is not what you’re looking for, I’ll tell you nothing more, but please, Bianca, goodbye forever and a day.

Anon!: I am sure you are not Launcelot, my boy.
Goodbye!: I’m sure you’re not Launcelot, my boy.

Anon!: Service.
Goodbye!: Service.

Anon!: A hundred then.
Goodbye!: A hundred then.

Anon!: Oh, yet I do repent me of my fury, That I did kill them.
Goodbye!: Oh, but I’m sorry I killed them.

Anon!: I warrant it is to knight you, Captain.
Goodbye!: I’m sure it’s to knight you, Captain.

Anon!: What is ’t?
Goodbye!: What is it?

Anon!: Shall we give o'er and drown?
Goodbye!: Should we give up and drown?

Anon!: You may have very fit occasion for ’t.
Goodbye!: You may have a good occasion for it.

Anon!: Pah!
Goodbye!: Ha!

Anon!: Young man, have you challenged Charles the wrestler?
Goodbye!: Young man, have you challenged Charles the wrestler?

Anon!: I think it is.
Goodbye!: I think it is.

Anon!: By Cheshu, I think he will plow up all if there is not better directions.
Goodbye!: By Cheshu, I think he’ll plow up everything if there aren’t better directions.

Anon!: Well, we shall sift him.—Welcome, my good friends!
Goodbye!: Well, we’ll sift him.—Welcome, my good friends!

Anon!: Is not this buckled well?
Goodbye!: Isn’t this buckled well?

Anon!: I did say so When first I raised the tempest.
Goodbye!: I said that when I first raised the tempest.

Anon!: Then plainly know my heart’s dear love is set On the fair daughter of rich Capulet.
Goodbye!: Then you can tell that my dear love is set on the fair daughter of rich Capulet.

Anon!: Well, you are to call at all the alehouses and bid those that are drunk get them to bed.
Goodbye!: Well, you’re going to call all the alehouses and ask those who are drunk to get them to bed.

Anon!: Canidius and the rest That fell away have entertainment but No honorable trust.
Goodbye!: Canidius and the rest of the people who fell away have entertainment but no honorable trust.

Anon!: Safe, Antony.
Goodbye!: Stay safe, Antony.

Anon!: Abhorred villain!
Goodbye!: Abhorred villain!

Anon!: Why do they run away?
Goodbye!: Why are they running away?

Anon!: Put on your nightgown.
Goodbye!: Put on your nightgown.

Anon!: I swear by that which I will lose for thee To prove him false that says I love thee not.
Goodbye!: I swear by the fact that I’ll lose your money to prove him false, which says I don’t love you.

Anon!: Haply when I shall wed That lord whose hand must take my plight shall carry Half my love with him, half my care and duty.
Goodbye!: I’ll bet I’ll marry a lord whose hand will take my plight with me half my love, half my care and duty.

Anon!: Lie with her—that’s fulsome.
Goodbye!: Let her sleep—that’s a bit of a pain.

Anon!: Not all the dukes of waterish Burgundy Can buy this unprized precious maid of me.— Bid them farewell, Cordelia, though unkind.
Goodbye!: Not all the dukes of a sandy Burgundy can buy this precious maid from me.—By farewell, Cordelia, even if it’s unkind.

Anon!: A good wench, give it me.
Goodbye!: A good wench, give it to me.

Anon!: We took him for a coward, but he’s the very devil incardinate.
Goodbye!: We took him for a coward, but he’s the devil incardinate.

Anon!: If it assume my noble father’s person, I’ll speak to it, though Hell itself should gape And bid me hold my peace.
Goodbye!: If it’s my noble father’s person, I’ll speak to it, even though Hell itself should gape and ask me to keep my peace.

Anon!: Let me say “Amen” betimes, lest the devil cross my prayer, for here he comes in the likeness of a Jew.
Goodbye!: Let me say “Amen” in time, so that the devil can cross my prayer, because here he comes in the likeness of a Jew.

Anon!: My lord is dead.
Goodbye!: My lord is dead.

Anon!: Oh, so light a foot Will ne'er wear out the everlasting flint.
Goodbye!: Oh, a foot so light will never wear out the everlasting flint.

Anon!: Thou old unhappy traitor, Briefly thyself remember.
Goodbye!: You old traitor, remember to be a briefly.

Anon!: If not, to say to thee that I shall die is true, but for thy love, by the Lord, no.
Goodbye!: If not, to say to you that I’ll die is true, but for your love, by the Lord, no.

Anon!: Set your countenance, sir.
Goodbye!: Set your countenance, sir.

Anon!: You tell us the manner of the wrestling.
Goodbye!: You tell us the way of the wrestling.

Anon!: The motion’s good indeed and be it so.— Petruchio, I shall be your
Goodbye!: I’ll be your

Anon!: I warrant it will.
Goodbye!: I’m sure it will.

Anon!: Here’s goodly gear.
Goodbye!: Here’s a good gear.

Anon!: As if that name, Shot from the deadly level of a gun, Did murder her, as that name’s cursed hand Murdered her kinsman.
Goodbye!: As if that name, shot from the deadly level of a gun, killed her, as if that name’s cursed hand killed her kinsman.

Anon!: What would you?
Goodbye!: What do you want?

Anon!: He shall not live.
Goodbye!: He won’t live.

Anon!: The voice of Cassio.
Goodbye!: Cassio’s voice.

Anon!: Where is he?
Goodbye!: Where is he?

Anon!: My soul is heavy, and I fain would sleep.
Goodbye!: My soul is heavy, and I’m afraid I’ll sleep.

Anon!: By my troth, it is well said.
Goodbye!: I swear, it’s well said.

Anon!: To supper?
Goodbye!: To supper?

Anon!: And art thou living, Stephano?
Goodbye!: And are you living, Stephano?

Anon!: And what says My concealed lady to our canceled love?
Goodbye!: And what does my hidden lady say to our canceled love?

Anon!: Brother, I advise you to the best.
Goodbye!: Brother, I advise you to the best.

Anon!: Thus high, by thy advice And thy assistance is King Richard seated.
Goodbye!: That’s the point, by your advice and your assistance, King Richard is sitting.

Anon!: Who knocks so hard?
Goodbye!: Who’s knocking so hard?

Anon!: Wouldst thou aught with me?
Goodbye!: Are you going to be with me?

Anon!: There’s none else by.
Goodbye!: There’s no other one here.

Anon!: I see this hath a little dashed your spirits.
Goodbye!: I see this has a little slurped your spirits.

Anon!: They shall be apprehended by and by.
Goodbye!: They’ll be arrested by and by.

Anon!: What’s this?
Goodbye!: What’s this?

Anon!: Hard, hard.—O filthy traitor!
Goodbye!: Hard, hard.—O filthy traitor!

Anon!: Not if the small come first.
Goodbye!: Not if the small ones come first.

Anon!: Abhor it, fear it, do not enter it.
Goodbye!: Don’t get out of here, but don’t go.

Anon!: And mine, but it grows something stale with me.
Goodbye!: And mine, but it’s getting worse with me.

Anon!: I will none of your money.
Goodbye!: I won’t spend any of your money.

Anon!: Happy indeed, as we have spent the day.
Goodbye!: Yes, as happy as we have spent the day.

Anon!: There are no tricks in plain and simple faith.
Goodbye!: There are no tricks in simple and simple faith.

Anon!: If it be so, as ’tis, Poor lady, she were better love a dream.
Goodbye!: If it were true, as it is, Poor lady, she would be better to love a dream.

Anon!: Even just the sum that I do owe to you Is growing to me by Antipholus.
Goodbye!: Antipholus has given me just the money I owe you.

Anon!: Save you, worthy general!
Goodbye!: Save you, worthy general!

Anon!: Tybalt, the reason that I have to love thee Doth much excuse the appertaining rage To such a greeting.
Goodbye!: Tybalt, the reason I have to love you is to excuse the rage that comes with such a greeting.

Anon!: Well met here.
Goodbye!: Good morning, we’ve got a good meeting here.

Goodbye!: Her savage leas are rooting on her darnel, hemlock, and rank fumitory, while the coulter rusts to deracinate such savagery.

Goodbye!: I love you so much that I’ll send your soul to heaven soon, if heaven will take the present at our hands.

Anon!: She’s dead, deceased, she’s dead.
Goodbye!: She’s dead, dead, she’s dead.

Anon!: No, Lepidus, let him speak.
Goodbye!: No, Lepidus, let him speak.

Anon!: Toward Peloponnesus are they fled.
Goodbye!: They’ve fled towards Peloponnesus.

Anon!: I know my physic will work with him.
Goodbye!: I know my physic will work with him.

Goodbye!: You shame your shape, your love, your wit, which, like a usurer, is all over there and doesn’t use any of those true uses that should bedecked by your shape, your love, your

Anon!: Who’s there?
Goodbye!: Who’s there?

Anon!: Nay, that’s certain.
Goodbye!: No, that’s true.

Anon!: Thou art The armorer of my heart.
Goodbye!: You’re the armorer of my heart.

Anon!: It is my wretched fortune.
Goodbye!: It’s my wretched fortune.

Anon!: Write down Prince John a villain.
Goodbye!: Write down Prince John as a villain.

Anon!: If thou dost love fair Hero, cherish it, And I will break with her and with her father, And thou shalt have her.
Goodbye!: If you love a fair Hero, cherish it, and I’ll break with her and her father, and you’ll have her.

Anon!: If I had a thunderbolt in mine eye, I can tell who should down.
Goodbye!: If I had a thunderbolt in my eye, I can tell you who should down.

Anon!: Seest thou here, This is the mouth o' th' cell.
Goodbye!: You’re here, this is the mouth of your cell.

Anon!: Ha, ha.
Goodbye!: Ha, ha.

Anon!: Fight valiantly today.
Goodbye!: Fighting valiantly today.

Anon!: To thine and Albany’s issue Be this perpetual.—What says our second daughter, Our dearest Regan, wife of Cornwall?
Goodbye!: To your and Albany’s issue, be this perpetual.—What’s the news about our second daughter, Regan, wife of Cornwall?

Goodbye!: Go inside and don’t cry.

Goodbye!: Edmund, seek him out, turn me into him, please.

Anon!: Herald, save thou thy labor.
Goodbye!: Herald, save your labor.

Anon!: She is dead.
Goodbye!: She’s dead.

Goodbye!: When you take occasions to see leeks later, please, mock them, that’s all.

Goodbye!: And all the faith, the virtue of my heart, the object and the pleasure of my eyes, is only Helena.

Anon!: Welcome, gentlemen!
Goodbye!: Welcome, gentlemen.

Anon!: Mum, then, and no more.
Goodbye!: Mum, then, and no more.

Goodbye!: He said my eyes were black and my hair was black.

Anon!: Assuredly the thing is to be sold.
Goodbye!: The thing is going to be sold.

Anon!: Tis false.
Goodbye!: It’s false.

Anon!: Marcus Luccicos, is not he in town?
Goodbye!: Marcus Luccicos, isn’t he in town?

Goodbye!: And you must make a dullard of the world if they didn’t think the profits from my death were very pregnant and potential spirits would make you seek it.” Oh, a strange and fastened villain!

Anon!: Speak, man.
Goodbye!: Speak, man.

Anon!: Say that I did all this for love of her.
Goodbye!: Say that I did all this for her love.

Anon!: Why, you speak like an ancient and most quiet watchman, for I cannot see how sleeping should offend.
Goodbye!: You’re speaking like a quiet, ancient watchman, because I can’t see how sleeping should offend me.

Anon!: I pray the gods she may, with all my heart!
Goodbye!: I pray the gods she can, with all my heart!

Anon!: Madam, good night.
Goodbye!: Madam, good night.

Anon!: Let every man be master of his time Till seven at night.
Goodbye!: Every man should be master of his time until seven at night.

Anon!: God mark thee to his grace!
Goodbye!: God bless you to his grace!

Anon!: Oh, my heart bleeds To think o' th' teen that I have turned you to, Which is from my remembrance!
Goodbye!: Oh, my heart bleeds to think about the teen I’ve turned you to, which is from my memory!

Goodbye!: What’s the wager?

Anon!: Truly, sir, to wear out their shoes to get myself into more work.
Goodbye!: I’m going to do more work, sir.

Goodbye!: If you have any sound or voice, speak to me.

Anon!: What, are the brothers parted?
Goodbye!: What, are the brothers separated?

Anon!: What wilt thou do for her?
Goodbye!: What will you do for her?

Anon!: O, let me make the period to my curse!
Goodbye!: Oh, let me make the time for my curse!

Anon!: Why, then let’s home again.
Goodbye!: Well, then let’s go home again.

Anon!: There’s meaning in thy snores.
Goodbye!: You’re snoring.

Anon!: O woe!
Goodbye!: Oh, what a terrible thing!

Anon!: By the mass, I was about to say something.
Goodbye!: By the mass, I was about to say something.

Anon!: Take hence this jack and whip him.
Goodbye!: Take this jack away and whip him.

Anon!: His word is more than the miraculous harp.
Goodbye!: His word is more than the miraculous harp.

Anon!: And she can weep, sir, weep.
Goodbye!: And she can cry, sir, cry.

Goodbye!: By Jove, I’m not a coward for gold, and I don’t care who feeds on my cost; it doesn’t want me to wear men’s clothes; I don’t want to wear them

Goodbye!: The Moor has already changed with my poison.

Anon!: My lord, we will not.
Goodbye!: My lord, we won’t.

Anon!: What’s this to my Lysander?
Goodbye!: What’s this to my Lysander?

Anon!: And he’s gone.
Goodbye!: And he’s gone.

Anon!: Some are born great—”
Goodbye!: Some are born great—”

Anon!: Thou shouldst know There were a heart in Egypt.
Goodbye!: You should know that Egypt had a heart.

Anon!: Speak.
Goodbye!: Speak.

Anon!: Jove shield thee well for this!
Goodbye!: Good luck with this!

Anon!: Affection!
Goodbye!: Affection!

Anon!: The duke must grant me that.
Goodbye!: The duke must grant me that.

Anon!: I am glad on ’t.
Goodbye!: I’m glad about it.

Anon!: Alack, what heinous sin is it in me To be ashamed to be my father’s child!
Goodbye!: Oh, what a heinous sin I’m having to be ashamed of being my father’s child!

Anon!: Tell us what hath chanced today That Caesar looks so sad.
Goodbye!: Tell us what happened today that Caesar looks so sad.

Anon!: That from your first of difference and decay Have followed your sad steps.
Goodbye!: That you’ve followed your sad steps from your first day of decay and difference.

Anon!: And if tomorrow Our navy thrive, I have an absolute hope Our landmen will stand up.
Goodbye!: And if our navy survives tomorrow, I have a total hope that our landmen will stand up.

Anon!: Who knows he is?
Goodbye!: Who knows he is?

Anon!: Wilt thou be pleased to hearken once again to the suit I made to thee?
Goodbye!: Would you be pleased to hear again the suit I made to you?

Anon!: Marry, my child, early next Thursday morn, The gallant, young, and noble gentleman, The County Paris, at Saint Peter’s Church, Shall happily make thee there a joyful bride.
Goodbye!: My child, early Thursday morning, the gallant, young, and noble gentleman, The County Paris, at Saint Peter’s Church, will happily make you a joyful bride.

Anon!: Come, you look paler and paler.
Goodbye!: Come on, you look paler and paler.

Anon!: If he be sad, he wants money.
Goodbye!: If he’s sad, he wants money.

Anon!: Back, slave, or I will break thy pate across.
Goodbye!: Back, slave, or I’ll break your sword across.

Anon!: Why are you virtuous?
Goodbye!: Why are you virtuous?

Anon!: Away, then.
Goodbye!: Go away, then.

Anon!: Behold, there stand the caskets, noble Prince.
Goodbye!: Look, there are the caskets, noble Prince.

Goodbye!: Within an hour I was his servant, sir, but he, thank him, gnawed in two my cords.

Anon!: Beware the ides of March.
Goodbye!: Beware of March’s landslides.

Anon!: And some have greatness thrust upon them.” Heaven restore thee!
Goodbye!: And some have greatness thrust on them.” Heaven restore you!

Goodbye!: Then we’ll go in to see his embassy, which I could tell with a guess that I’d be able to tell before the Frenchman tells me a word about it.

Anon!: Let’s see these pockets.
Goodbye!: Let’s see these pockets.

Goodbye!: I hate ingratitude more than lying, vainness, babbling, drunkenness, or any other taint of evil whose corruption inflicts our frail blood— Oh heavens!

Goodbye!: Stand up.

Goodbye!: Oh, sad day, sad day!

Anon!: Half afeard to come.

Anon!: Poisoned, then.

Goodbye!: It’s not good to take the stories out of my mouth before it’s finished.

Goodbye!: I will, Pompey.

Anon!: What would you?
Goodbye!: What do you want?

Anon!: God be with you all.
Goodbye!: God be with you all.

Anon!: My father charged you in his will to give me good education.
Goodbye!: My father told you to give me a good education.

Anon!: No, my lord.
Goodbye!: No, my lord.

Anon!: Why, there was a crown offered him; and, being offered him, he put it by with the back of his hand, thus; and then the people fell a-shouting.
Goodbye!: There was a crown offered to him, and when he offered it to him, he put it by the back of his hand, so the people fell asleep.

Anon!: Make no delay.
Goodbye!: Don’t delay.

Anon!: We will persuade him, be it possible, To put on better ere he go to church.
Goodbye!: We’ll convince him, if it’s possible, to put on better things before he goes to church.

Anon!: O, well flown, bird.
Goodbye!: Oh, well flown, bird.

Anon!: Sir, he may live.
Goodbye!: Sir, he can live.

Anon!: Made it for me, sir?
Goodbye!: Did it work for me, sir?

Anon!: He did me kindness, sir, drew on my side, But in conclusion put strange speech upon me.
Goodbye!: He did me kindness, sir, drew on my side, but in conclusion he put a strange speech on me.

Anon!: No, though thou call’st thyself a hotter name Than any is in hell.
Goodbye!: No, even though you’re calling yourself a hotter name than anyone is in hell.

Anon!: I must be laughed at If or for nothing or a little, I Should say myself offended, and with you Chiefly i’ th’ world; more laughed at, that I should Once name you derogately, when to sound your name It not concerned me.
Goodbye!: I’d rather be laughed at if I were offended or for nothing or a little bit, and I’d be laughed at more than that, when I said you were insulted, when you didn’t sound like

Anon!: Sir, would she give you so much of her lips As of her tongue she oft bestows on me, You’ll have enough.
Goodbye!: Sir, if she gave you so much of her lips as much of her tongue she gives me, you’ll have enough.

Anon!: Nay, how will you do for a husband?
Goodbye!: No, how will you do for a husband?

Anon!: I say again, give out That Anne my queen is sick and like to die.
Goodbye!: Again, I say, give out that Anne, my queen, is sick and likes to die.

Anon!: But till that time Come not thou near me.
Goodbye!: But until that time, don’t come near me.

Anon!: Look where he comes.
Goodbye!: Look, he’s coming.

Anon!: Come, Antonio.
Goodbye!: Come on, Antonio.

Anon!: What Adam dost thou mean?
Goodbye!: What do you mean by Adam?

Anon!: We must incline to the king.
Goodbye!: We have to go to the king.

Anon!: Why of thy thought, Iago?
Goodbye!: Why did you think about it, Iago?

Anon!: Count Claudio?
Goodbye!: Claudio?

Anon!: Madam!
Goodbye!: Madam!

Anon!: Why, this' a heavy chance ’twixt him and you, Your ancient, trusty, pleasant servant Grumio.
Goodbye!: It’s a big chance for him and you, your noble, trusty, pleasant servant Grumio.

Anon!: Farewell.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: Bemonster not thy feature.
Goodbye!: Don’t bemonster your character.

Anon!: Thou dar’st as well be hanged.
Goodbye!: You’re as good as you are.

Anon!: But in your daughter’s womb I bury them, Where, in that nest of spicery, they will breed Selves of themselves, to your recomforture.
Goodbye!: But I bury them in your daughter’s womb, where they will grow in that nest of spice, to your recomforture.

Anon!: And did not she herself revile me there?
Goodbye!: And she scolded me there?

Anon!: I had forgot—three months.
Goodbye!: I had forgotten—three months.

Anon!: I’ll go arm myself.
Goodbye!: I’ll go arm myself.

Anon!: And here I stand, both to impeach and purge, Myself condemnèd and myself excused.
Goodbye!: And here I stand, both to impeach and purge, condemning myself and excused myself.

Anon!: Did she see thee the while, old boy?
Goodbye!: Did she see you there for a while, old boy?

Anon!: Wrench his sword from him.
Goodbye!: Wrench his sword from him.

Anon!: But when shall we set the savage bull’s horns on the sensible Benedick’s head?
Goodbye!: But when should we put the savage bull’s horns on the sensible Benedick’s head?

Anon!: Well met, my lord.
Goodbye!: Good morning, my lord.

Anon!: These Moors are changeable in their wills—fill thy purse with money.
Goodbye!: These Moors are a changeable man in their wills—fill your purse with money.

Anon!: Which is he that killed the deer?
Goodbye!: Which one of you killed the deer?

Anon!: It is an honor that I dream not of.
Goodbye!: It’s an honor that I don’t dream of.

Anon!: Tis the time’s plague when madmen lead the blind.
Goodbye!: It’s the time when madmen lead the blind.

Anon!: Farewell, dear mother.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, dear mother.

Anon!: When I wore it at your daughter’s marriage?
Goodbye!: When I wore it at your daughter’s wedding?

Anon!: But did I never speak of all that time?
Goodbye!: But I never spoke of that all the time?

Anon!: Noses, ears, and lips.
Goodbye!: Noses, ears, and lips.

Anon!: Went’st not thou to her for a purse of ducats?
Goodbye!: Don’t you go to her for a purse of ducats?

Anon!: Why then, thus it is: You must prepare your bosom for his knife.
Goodbye!: Well then, it’s the same: you have to prepare your sleeve for his knife.

Anon!: Searching the window for a flint, I found This paper, thus sealed up, and I am sure It did not lie there when I went to bed.
Goodbye!: I searched the window for a flint, and found this paper, sealed up so I can see it wasn’t there when I went to bed.

Anon!: Then swore he that he was a stranger here.
Goodbye!: Then he swore he was a stranger here.

Anon!: Oh, how I love thee!
Goodbye!: Oh, how I love you!

Anon!: When I come where he calls, then he is gone.
Goodbye!: When I come where he calls, he’s gone.

Anon!: How now?
Goodbye!: What’s going on?

Anon!: So he laughed and let me go.
Goodbye!: So he laughed and let me go.

Anon!: God speak this “amen”!
Goodbye!: God speak this “amen”!

Anon!: Why dost thou wring thy hands?
Goodbye!: Why are you wringing your hands?

Anon!: I understand thee not.
Goodbye!: I don’t understand you.

Anon!: You do advance your cunning more and more.
Goodbye!: You’re getting more and more sane.

Anon!: Her body sleeps in Capels' monument, And her immortal part with angels lives.
Goodbye!: Her body sleeps in Capels’ tomb, and her immortal part with angels lives.

Anon!: For what, I pray thee?
Goodbye!: What, please?

Anon!: Oh, a cherubim Thou wast that did preserve me.
Goodbye!: Oh, you were a cherubim who kept me.

Anon!: Look, and thou shalt see.
Goodbye!: Look, and you’ll see.

Anon!: She gave it him, and he hath given it his whore.
Goodbye!: She gave it to him, and he gave it to him.

Anon!: What, is my beaver easier than it was?
Goodbye!: Is my beaver easier than it was?

Anon!: When my tongue blabs, then let mine eyes not see.
Goodbye!: When my tongue blabs, then let my eyes not see.

Anon!: Then is there mirth in heaven When earthly things, made even, Atone together.
Goodbye!: Then there’s the sun in heaven when earthly things, made even, are together.

Anon!: Tell me but truly—but then speak the truth— Do you not love my sister?
Goodbye!: Tell me, but then tell me the truth—Do you love my sister?

Anon!: A great suspicion.
Goodbye!: A great suspicion.

Anon!: But you, sir, altered that, for some hour before you took me from the breach of the sea was my sister drowned.
Goodbye!: But you changed that, sir, for an hour before you took me from the sea, my sister drowned.

Anon!: The king’s son, Ferdinand, With hair up-staring—then, like reeds, not hair— Was the first man that leaped, cried, “Hell is empty And all the devils are here.”      Why, that’s my spirit!
Goodbye!: The king’s son Ferdinand, with his hair up-staring—and then, like reeds, not hair—was the first man to leaped, crying, “Hell is empty and all the de

Anon!: Let us quit all And give our vineyards to a barbarous people.
Goodbye!: Let’s leave everything and give our vineyards to a barbarous people.

Anon!: Where is my gracious lord of Canterbury?
Goodbye!: Where is my gracious lord of Canterbury?

Anon!: They call for dates and quinces in the pastry.
Goodbye!: They’re calling for dates and quinces in the pastry.

Anon!: Shall I deny you?
Goodbye!: Shall I deny you that?

Anon!: The whole butt, man.
Goodbye!: The whole butt, man.

Anon!: What say you?
Goodbye!: What do you say?

Anon!: Have I in conquest stretched mine arm so far To be afraid to tell graybeards the truth?
Goodbye!: Have I stretched my arm so far in the battle to be afraid to tell graybeards the truth?

Anon!: I am sure he had more hair of his tail than I have of my face when I last saw him.
Goodbye!: I’m sure he had more hair on his tail than I have on my face when I last saw him.

Anon!: What hast thou found?
Goodbye!: What have you found?

Anon!: You are a counterfeit cowardly knave.
Goodbye!: You’re a cowardly king.

Anon!: Master young gentleman, I pray you, which is the way to Master Jew’s?
Goodbye!: Dear young gentleman, what’s the way to the Jew’s house?

Anon!: Malvolio’s coming down this walk.
Goodbye!: Malvolio’s coming down this walk.

Anon!: How intend you, “practiced”?
Goodbye!: What do you think you’re doing, “practiced”?

Anon!: Let me be your servant.
Goodbye!: Let me be your servant.

Anon!: O!
Goodbye!: Oh!

Anon!: A lord to a lord, a man to a man, stuffed with all honorable virtues.
Goodbye!: A lord to a lord, a man to a man, stuffed with honorable virtues.

Anon!: I do suffer love indeed, for I love thee against my will.
Goodbye!: I suffer love, because I love you against my will.

Anon!: Kent, father, sisters!
Goodbye!: Kent, father, sisters!

Anon!: Tell me.
Goodbye!: Tell me.

Anon!: The lieutenant tonight watches on the court of guard.
Goodbye!: The lieutenant will watch on guard’s court tonight.

Anon!: To make an account of her life to a clod of wayward marl?
Goodbye!: To make a story of her life to a clod of a rotten marl?

Anon!: Brutus” will start a spirit as soon as “Caesar.” Now in the names of all the gods at once, Upon what meat doth this our Caesar feed That he is grown so great?
Goodbye!: Brutus” will start a spirit as soon as “Caesar.” Now, in the names of all the gods at once, what meat does Caesar feed that he is so great?

Anon!: Would that alone o' love he would detain, So he would keep fair quarter with his bed.
Goodbye!: He’d keep his bed in a fair quarter of his love.

Anon!: Quoth my master.
Goodbye!: Quot my master.

Anon!: The slip, sir, the slip.
Goodbye!: The slip, sir, the slip.

Anon!: Younger than you Here in Verona, ladies of esteem Are made already mothers.
Goodbye!: Younger than you here in Verona, women of esteem are already mothers.

Anon!: Hoppedance cries in Tom’s belly for two white herring.
Goodbye!: The cries in Tom’s belly for two white herrings.

Anon!: Now will he sit under a medlar tree And wish his mistress were that kind of fruit As maids call medlars when they laugh alone.— O Romeo, that she were!
Goodbye!: Now he’ll sit under a medlar tree and wish his mistress were the kind of fruit that maids call medlars when they laugh alone.—Oh Romeo, that she were!

Anon!: Happy is your Grace, That can translate the stubbornness of fortune Into so quiet and so sweet a style.
Goodbye!: Your Grace is happy, who can turn the stubbornness of fortune into so quiet and sweet.

Anon!: Here, sir, but trouble him not.
Goodbye!: Here, sir, but don’t bother him.

Anon!: Nor, I am sure, there is no force in eyes That can do hurt.
Goodbye!: I’m sure there’s no force in eyes that can hurt you.

Anon!: Therefore, my lords, omit no happy hour That may give furth'rance to our expedition; For we have now no thought in us but France, Save those to God, that run before our business.
Goodbye!: So, my lords, we can’t wait for a happy hour to give us a chance to go on our expedition.

Anon!: Go.
Goodbye!: Go.

Anon!: Is ’t come to this?
Goodbye!: Is it coming to this?

Anon!: I think he will stand very strong with us.
Goodbye!: I think he’ll stand strong with us.

Anon!: I do.
Goodbye!: I do.

Anon!: What poor an instrument May do a noble deed!
Goodbye!: What a poor instrument can do a noble deed!

Anon!: I could not find him at the Elephant.
Goodbye!: I couldn’t find him at the Elephant.

Anon!: Follow your spirit, and upon this charge Cry “God for Harry, England, and Saint George!”
Goodbye!: Follow your spirit, and on this charge, Cry “God for Harry, England, and Saint George!”

Anon!: If you do meet Horatio and Marcellus, The rivals of my watch, bid them make haste.
Goodbye!: If you meet Horatio and Marcellus, the rivals of my watch, ask them to hurry.

Anon!: O, ’tis a parlous boy, Bold, quick, ingenious, forward, capable.
Goodbye!: Oh, it’s a parlous boy, baffling, quick, ingenious, forward, capable.

Anon!: I know that virtue to be in you, Brutus, As well as I do know your outward favor.
Goodbye!: I know that you deserve that virtue, Brutus, as well as I know your outward favor.

Anon!: If swift thought break it not, a swifter mean Shall outstrike thought, but thought will do ’t, I feel.
Goodbye!: If a quick thought doesn’t break it, a faster mean won’t break it, but it won’t, I feel.

Anon!: No beast so fierce but knows some touch of pity.
Goodbye!: No beast so fierce, but he knows some bit of pity.

Anon!: What, Pindarus!
Goodbye!: Pindarus!

Anon!: What, is there such a place?
Goodbye!: Is there such a place?

Anon!: Then by your side no bed room me deny.
Goodbye!: Then I’m not in bed.

Anon!: Why, sir, what’s your conceit in that?
Goodbye!: Why, sir, what’s your opinion about that?

Anon!: The dew is raw and cold.
Goodbye!: The dew is raw and cold.

Anon!: Well pray you, father.
Goodbye!: Please, father.

Anon!: The air breathes upon us here most sweetly.
Goodbye!: The air is shining on us here very sweetly.

Anon!: Brutus speaks.
Goodbye!: Brutus is talking.

Anon!: Here Catesby comes again.
Goodbye!: Here comes Catesby again.

Anon!: Then tell me, what makes he upon the seas?
Goodbye!: Then tell me, what’s he doing on the seas?

Anon!: He did bewray his practice, and received This hurt you see striving to apprehend him.
Goodbye!: He was a victim of his behavior, and you see he was trying to arrest him.

Anon!: In good time, sir, what’s that?
Goodbye!: In good time, sir, what’s that?

Anon!: What a brazen-faced varlet art thou to deny thou knowest me!
Goodbye!: What a brazen-faced man you’re trying to deny you know me!

Anon!: This is a slight, unmeritable man, Meet to be sent on errands.
Goodbye!: This is a very small, unremarkable man who’s going to be sent on errands.

Anon!: Known unto these, and to myself disguised!
Goodbye!: I’ve been known to these people, and I’ve been disguised!

Anon!: One?
Goodbye!: One?

Anon!: Be fickle, fortune, For then, I hope, thou wilt not keep him long, But send him back.
Goodbye!: Be a bit frightened, fortune, then, I hope, you won’t keep him long, but send him back.

Anon!: Let us, Lepidus, not lack your company.
Goodbye!: Let’s not be without your company, Lepidus.

Anon!: If there come truth from them— As upon thee, Macbeth, their speeches shine— Why, by the verities on thee made good, May they not be my oracles as well, And set me up in hope?
Goodbye!: If they come out of truth—as on you, Macbeth, their speeches shine—why, by the truth, they’ve made good for you, don’t they be my oracles as well, and set

Anon!: In private?
Goodbye!: In private?

Anon!: Hear it not, Duncan, for it is a knell That summons thee to heaven or to hell.
Goodbye!: Don’t listen to it, Duncan, because it’s a knell that summons you to heaven or hell.

Anon!: But, for true need— You heavens, give me that patience, patience I need.
Goodbye!: But for true need— You heavens, give me that patience, patience I need.

Anon!: I fear ’tis choleric.
Goodbye!: I’m afraid it’s choleric.

Anon!: It is meat and drink to me to see a clown.
Goodbye!: It’s meat and drink to me to see a clown.

Anon!: Thou shalt, I warrant thee.
Goodbye!: You will, I assure you.

Anon!: Is it they?
Goodbye!: Is it them?

Anon!: No, as I shall be saved.
Goodbye!: No, I’ll be saved.

Anon!: I pardon that man’s life.
Goodbye!: I pardon that man’s life.

Anon!: And may not young men die as well as old?
Goodbye!: And can’t young men die as well as old?

Anon!: By such despair I should accuse myself.
Goodbye!: I’d rather accuse myself of such despair.

Anon!: Chill pick your teeth, zir.
Goodbye!: Chill pick your teeth, sir.

Anon!: Tis far off, And rather like a dream than an assurance That my remembrance warrants.
Goodbye!: It’s far away, and it’s rather like a dream than an assurance that my memory is worthy of.

Anon!: It may be so, my lord.
Goodbye!: It may be, my lord.

Anon!: Love’s heralds should be thoughts, Which ten times faster glide than the sun’s beams, Driving back shadows over louring hills.
Goodbye!: Love’s heroes should be thoughts, which glide ten times faster than sun’s beams, driving back shadows over louring hills.

Anon!: Now civil wounds are stopped, peace lives again.
Goodbye!: Now civil wounds are stopped, and peace is back.

Anon!: O God!—O Nurse, how shall this be prevented?
Goodbye!: Oh God!—Oh Nurse, how can this be prevented?

Anon!: Set him before me.
Goodbye!: Set him up before me.

Anon!: Welcome to Rome.
Goodbye!: Welcome to Rome.

Anon!: I will say nothing.
Goodbye!: I won’t say anything.

Anon!: Well, what was yours?
Goodbye!: Well, what was yours?

Anon!: Has this fellow no feeling of his business?
Goodbye!: Has this fellow no feeling about his business?

Anon!: Well, then I shall see thee again?
Goodbye!: Well, then I’ll see you again?

Anon!: Go then, my mother; to thy daughter go.
Goodbye!: Go then, my mother; go to your daughter.

Anon!: Which do not be entreated to, but weigh What it is worth embraced.
Goodbye!: If you’re not sure what you’re saying, you’ll be able to weigh what you’re worth embracing.

Anon!: Come, father, I’ll bestow you with a friend.
Goodbye!: Come, father, I’ll give you a friend.

Anon!: Here’s the friar ready.
Goodbye!: Here’s the friar ready.

Anon!: I would give all my fame for a pot of ale, and safety.
Goodbye!: I wish I could give all my fame for a pot of beer and safety.

Anon!: He tells me flatly there is no mercy for me in heaven because I am a Jew’s daughter, and he says you are no good member of the commonwealth, for in converting Jews to Christians you raise the price of pork.
Goodbye!: He tells me that I’m a Jew’s daughter, and he says you’re not a good member of the commonwealth, because you’re converting Jews to Christians and you’re raising

Anon!: Fellow Grumio!
Goodbye!: Fellow Grumio!

Anon!: The rest shall keep as they are.
Goodbye!: The rest of us will keep their names as they are.

Anon!: Pleaseth your Grace To appoint some of your council presently To sit with us once more with better heed To resurvey them, we will suddenly Pass our accept and peremptory answer.
Goodbye!: If you ask your Grace to appoint some of your council members to sit with us once more with better attention to resurvey them, we’ll pass our acceptable and imprisoned answer suddenly.

Anon!: Tush, thou art deceived.
Goodbye!: You’re wrong.

Anon!: And though I make this marriage for my peace, I’ th’ East my pleasure lies.
Goodbye!: And even though I’m making this marriage for my peace, I’m in the East.

Anon!: I cannot believe that in her.
Goodbye!: I can’t believe that in her.

Anon!: Take thou some new infection to thy eye, And the rank poison of the old will die.
Goodbye!: Take some new poison to your eyes, and the old poison will die.

Anon!: What mercy can you render him, Antonio?
Goodbye!: What mercy can you give him, Antonio?

Anon!: But while thou livest, keep a good tongue in thy head.
Goodbye!: But while you’re alive, keep a good tongue in your head.

Anon!: They must be bound and laid in some dark room.
Goodbye!: They must be bound and laid in some dark room.

Anon!: Master, you looked so longly on the maid, Perhaps you marked not what’s the pith of all.
Goodbye!: Master, you looked so long on the maid, but you didn’t know what’s going on.

Anon!: Mine, and most of our fortunes tonight, shall be—drunk to bed.
Goodbye!: My fortune, and most of our fortunes tonight, will be—drunk to bed.

Anon!: Well, masters, we hear our charge.
Goodbye!: Well, masters, we hear our charge.

Anon!: Is Rosaline, whom thou didst love so dear, So soon forsaken?
Goodbye!: Is Rosaline, whom you loved so much, so soon forsaken?

Anon!: Our foster nurse of nature is repose, The which he lacks—that to provoke in him Are many simples operative, whose power Will close the eye of anguish.
Goodbye!: Our nurse is a good friend, and he has a good reputation for being a good nurse.

Anon!: There, take it, Prince.
Goodbye!: Take it, Prince.

Anon!: Where is Antony?
Goodbye!: Where’s Antony?

Anon!: There are the players.
Goodbye!: There are the actors.

Anon!: Why then, your other senses grow imperfect By your eyes' anguish.
Goodbye!: Well, then, your other senses are getting irritated by your eyes.

Anon!: Then hadst thou had an excellent head of hair.
Goodbye!: Then you’d have an excellent head of hair.

Anon!: Good people, enter and lay hold on him.
Goodbye!: Good people, enter and hold him.

Anon!: Then put up your pipes in your bag, for I’ll away.
Goodbye!: Then put your pipes in your bag, because I’ll leave.

Anon!: Commend me to him and tell him I will not fail him at supper, for indeed he hath made great preparation.
Goodbye!: Give him a shout and tell him I won’t fail him at dinner, because he’s really prepared.

Anon!: Self-love, my liege, is not so vile a sin As self-neglecting.
Goodbye!: Self-love, my liege, is not as vile a sin as self-neglecting.

Anon!: By Jupiter, I swear “No.” By Juno, I swear “Ay.”    They durst not do ’t.
Goodbye!: By Jupiter, I swear “No.” By Juno, I swear “Yes.” They don’t want to do it.

Anon!: I think there’s never a man in Christendom Can lesser hide his love or hate than he, For by his face straight shall you know his heart.
Goodbye!: I think there’s never a man in Christendom who can hide his love or hate more than he can hide, because you’ll know his heart by his face.

Anon!: As of a man faithful and honorable.
Goodbye!: As a faithful and honorable man.

Anon!: Crack thy frail case!—Apace, Eros, apace.
Goodbye!: Crack your fragile case!—Apace, Eros, hurry up.

Anon!: Most high, most mighty, and most puissant Caesar, Metellus Cimber throws before thy seat An humble heart—     I must prevent thee, Cimber.
Goodbye!: Most high, most powerful, and most powerful Caesar, Metellus Cimber throws a humble heart over your seat— I must stop you, Cimber.

Anon!: The queen, my lord, is dead.
Goodbye!: The queen, my lord, is dead.

Anon!: Like a drowned man, a fool and a madman.
Goodbye!: Like a drowned man, a fool and a madman.

Anon!: Ready to go, but never to return.
Goodbye!: Ready to go, but never to return.

Anon!: Draw the curtains—so, so, so.
Goodbye!: Draw the curtains—so, so, so.

Anon!: Cassio, my lord, hath killed a young Venetian Called Roderigo.
Goodbye!: Cassio, my lord, has killed a young Venetian named Roderigo.

Anon!: What, drawn, and talk of peace?
Goodbye!: What, drawn, and talk about peace?

Anon!: What should I say, sweet lady?
Goodbye!: What should I say, lady?

Anon!: O, if thou be’st the same Egeon, speak, And speak unto the same Emilia.
Goodbye!: Oh, if you’re the same Egeon, speak and speak to the same Emilia.

Anon!: Why, as a woodcock to mine own springe, Osric.
Goodbye!: Oh, I’m a woodcock to my own springe.

Anon!: If he do, sure he cannot weep ’t back again.
Goodbye!: If he does, he’ll be sure he can’t weep back again.

Anon!: Now, for I know the Breton Richmond aims At young Elizabeth, my brother’s daughter, And by that knot looks proudly on the crown, To her go I, a jolly thriving wooer.
Goodbye!: Now, because I know the Breton Richmond is looking at young Elizabeth, my brother’s daughter, and by that knot looks proudly on the crown, I’ll go to her, a jolly thriving woo

Anon!: And in good time here comes the sweating lord.
Goodbye!: And in good time here comes the sweating lord.

Anon!: Why, this is excellent.
Goodbye!: That’s excellent.

Anon!: When came this to you?
Goodbye!: When did you get this?

Anon!: There stays a husband to make you a wife.
Goodbye!: There’s a husband who can make you a wife.

Anon!: Do but now promise, Kate, you will endeavor for your French part of such a boy; and for my English moiety take the word of a king and a bachelor.
Goodbye!: But just promise, Kate, you’ll be a good boy for your French part, and for my English moiety take the word of a king and a bachelor.

Anon!: Why, look you how you storm!
Goodbye!: Look, how you storm!

Anon!: I will not say so, for fear I should be faced out of my way.
Goodbye!: I won’t say that, because I’m afraid I’ll be faced out of my way.

Anon!: That is another simple sin in you, to bring the ewes and the rams together and to offer to get your living by the copulation of cattle; to be bawd to a bellwether and to betray a she-lamb of a twelvemonth to a crooked-pated old cuckoldly ram, out of all reasonable match.
Goodbye!: That’s another simple sin for you: to bring the ewes and the rams together and offer to get your life by a copulation of cattle; to be beaten to a bellwether and bet

Anon!: Why, man?
Goodbye!: Why, man?

Anon!: What is ’t thou say’st?
Goodbye!: What do you say?

Anon!: I cannot tell.
Goodbye!: I don’t know.

Anon!: Well, keep me company but two years more, Thou shalt not know the sound of thine own tongue.
Goodbye!: Well, keep me quiet for two years, you won’t know the sound of your own tongue.

Anon!: My reputation, Iago, my reputation!
Goodbye!: My reputation, Iago, my reputation!

Anon!: I must fetch his necessaries ashore.
Goodbye!: I have to get his sane ashore.

Anon!: I can tell what thou wouldst do.
Goodbye!: I can tell you what you want.

Anon!: My lord, the first time that I ever saw him Methought he was a brother to your daughter.
Goodbye!: My lord, the first time I saw him, I thought he was your daughter’s brother.

Anon!: Though I struck him first, yet it’s no matter for that.
Goodbye!: I struck him first, but it doesn’t matter.

Anon!: He is, indeed, sir, the most skillful, bloody, and fatal opposite that you could possibly have found in any part of Illyria.
Goodbye!: He is indeed the most skillful, bloody, and fatal man you could find in any part of Illyria.

Anon!: Yet I will adventure.
Goodbye!: But I’ll go.

Anon!: It were, my lord, a hard condition for a maid to consign to.
Goodbye!: It would be a hard job for a maid to get to.

Anon!: Indeed, I never shall be satisfied With Romeo, till I behold him—dead— Is my poor heart for a kinsman vexed.
Goodbye!: I’ll never be satisfied with Romeo until I see him—dead—is my poor heart for a king.

Anon!: And terms compulsatory, those foresaid lands So by his father lost.
Goodbye!: And the terms are compulsive, the land that was lost by his father.

Anon!: Doth his Majesty Incline to it or no?
Goodbye!: Is his Majesty indifferent to it or not?

Anon!: Ah, dear, if I be so, From my cold heart let heaven engender hail, And poison it in the source, and the first stone Drop in my neck.
Goodbye!: Oh, dear, if I’m so, let heaven engender hail and poison it in the source, and the first stone drops in my neck.

Anon!: Keep your cabins.
Goodbye!: Keep your cabins.

Anon!: Come, what says Romeo?
Goodbye!: Come on, what does Romeo say?

Anon!: So the maid that stood in the way for my wish shall show me the way to my will.
Goodbye!: So the woman who stood in the way for my wish will show me the way to my will.

Anon!: Ay, now am I in Arden, the more fool I.
Goodbye!: Yes, now I’m in Arden, the more fool I’m.

Anon!: Come, there is sauce for it.
Goodbye!: Come on, there’s a sauce for it.

Anon!: Fear not, my lord.
Goodbye!: Don’t worry, my lord.

Anon!: By my holy order, I thought thy disposition better tempered.
Goodbye!: I swear by my holy order, I thought you were better prepared.

Anon!: If sanctimony and a frail vow betwixt an erring barbarian and supersubtle Venetian be not too hard for my wits and all the tribe of hell, thou shalt enjoy her.
Goodbye!: If sanctimony and a frail vow aren’t too hard for my wits and all the tribe of hell, you’ll enjoy her.

Anon!: Ay, sooth, so humbled That he hath left part of his grief with me To suffer with him.
Goodbye!: Yes, he’s so humbled that he left me with a part of his grief to suffer with him.

Anon!: Come, sir, I pray you, go.
Goodbye!: Come, sir, please, go.

Anon!: Why—after I have cut the egg i' th' middle and eat up the meat—the two crowns of the egg.
Goodbye!: After I cut the egg in the middle and eat it up, the two crowns of the egg are ruined.

Anon!: No doubt the murd'rous knife was dull and blunt Till it was whetted on thy stone-hard heart, To revel in the entrails of my lambs.
Goodbye!: No doubt the murdrous knife was dull and blunt until it was sprayed on your stone-hard heart, to revel in the entrails of my lambs.

Anon!: For, sir, It is as sure as you are Roderigo, Were I the Moor, I would not be Iago.
Goodbye!: If I were the Moor, I wouldn’t be Iago.

Anon!: Poor Tom hath been scared out of his good wits.
Goodbye!: Poor Tom has been scared out of his good intentions.

Anon!: Mistress,  Wilt thou still talk?
Goodbye!: Mistress, do you still talk?

Anon!: Some twenty of them fought in this black strife, And all those twenty could but kill one life.
Goodbye!: Some twenty of them fought in this black conflict, and all those twenty could only kill one person.

Anon!: Four days will quickly steep themselves in night.
Goodbye!: Four days will quickly break up in the night.

Anon!: My lord, I’ll tell you that self bill is urged Which in th' eleventh year of the last king’s reign Was like, and had indeed against us passed But that the scambling and unquiet time Did push it out of farther question.
Goodbye!: My lord, I’ll tell you that the king’s self-reported bill was like in the eleventh year of the last king’s reign, and that the king’s resigned against us

Anon!: Or if it did not, Your first is dead, or ’twere as good he were, As living here and you no use of him.
Goodbye!: Or if it didn’t, your first one is dead or was as good as his own, as he was living here and you didn’t use him.

Anon!: Sleep shall neither night nor day Hang upon his penthouse lid.
Goodbye!: Sleep will neither be hung on his penthouse nor on his porch.

Anon!: Where goes Cesario?
Goodbye!: Where’s Cesario going?

Anon!: Though I die for it—as no less is threatened me—the king my old master must be relieved.
Goodbye!: Though I die for it—as it threatens me no less—the king my old master must be relieved.

Anon!: But I will not stir from this place, do what they can.
Goodbye!: But I won’t go out of here, do what they can.

Anon!: I thank thee.
Goodbye!: Thank you.

Anon!: I’ll cross it though it blast me.—Stay, illusion!
Goodbye!: I’ll cross it even if it hits me.—Stay, I’m going to be fooled!

Anon!: I’ll go find a shadow and sigh till he come.
Goodbye!: I’ll go find a shadow and sigh until he comes.

Anon!: I know not.
Goodbye!: I don’t know.

Anon!: Why, my young cousin?
Goodbye!: Why, my young cousin?

Anon!: Ay, if I be alive and your mind hold and your dinner worth the eating.
Goodbye!: Yes, if I’m alive and your mind is holding and your dinner worthy of the meal.

Anon!: One minded like the weather, most unquietly.
Goodbye!: One who is minded like the weather, most unquietly.

Anon!: You do extend These thoughts of horror further than you shall Find cause in Caesar.
Goodbye!: You’ll extend these horror thoughts further than you’ll find reason for Caesar.

Anon!: We do, my lord.
Goodbye!: We do, my lord.

Anon!: Vouchsafe to wear this ring.
Goodbye!: Wear this ring.

Anon!: Evermore weeping for your cousin’s death?
Goodbye!: Ever weeping for your cousin’s death?

Anon!: I’ll make thee an example.
Goodbye!: I’ll give you an example.

Anon!: Why, how now?
Goodbye!: What’s going on?

Anon!: Follow not.
Goodbye!: Don’t follow me.

Anon!: You would lift the moon out of her sphere if she would continue in it five weeks without changing.
Goodbye!: You’d lift the moon out of her sphere if she continued in it for five weeks without changing it.

Anon!: The trick of that voice I do well remember.
Goodbye!: I remember the trick of that voice.

Anon!: Ill rest betide the chamber where thou liest!
Goodbye!: I’ll rest in the room where you’re sitting!

Anon!: You love me not.
Goodbye!: You don’t love me.

Anon!: Fiery”?
Goodbye!: Fiery”?

Anon!: Here is his Majesty.
Goodbye!: Here is his Majesty.

Anon!: Our severed navy too Have knit again, and fleet, threat’ning most sealike.
Goodbye!: Our sunk navy has knit again and flotted, threatening most sealike.

Anon!: My bounty is as boundless as the sea, My love as deep.
Goodbye!: My bounty is as boundless as the sea, my love is as deep.

Anon!: My hair doth stand an end to hear her curses.
Goodbye!: My hair is fading to hear her curses.

Anon!: Incapable and shallow innocents, You cannot guess who caused your father’s death.
Goodbye!: Innocent people, you can’t guess who caused your father’s death.

Anon!: Now are we well prepared to know the pleasure Of our fair cousin Dauphin, for we hear Your greeting is from him, not from the king.
Goodbye!: Now we’re ready to know the pleasure of our fair cousin Dauphin, because we hear your greeting is from him, not from the king.

Anon!: But, Othello, speak.
Goodbye!: But speak, Othello.

Anon!: What shall I swear by?
Goodbye!: What should I swear by?

Anon!: Why do you speak to me?
Goodbye!: Why are you talking to me?

Anon!: No.
Goodbye!: No.

Anon!: A lantern, slaughtered youth, For here lies Juliet, and her beauty makes This vault a feasting presence full of light.
Goodbye!: Juliet lies here, and her beauty makes this vault a feasting place full of light.

Anon!: And what of all this?
Goodbye!: And what about all this?

Anon!: Was not this love indeed?
Goodbye!: Wasn’t this love true?

Anon!: We will have more of this tomorrow.
Goodbye!: We’ll see more of this tomorrow.

Anon!: Prithee, put up.
Goodbye!: Please put up.

Anon!: What, shall I groan and tell thee?
Goodbye!: What, should I groan and tell you?

Anon!: Thou hast, Ventidius, that Without the which a soldier and his sword Grants scarce distinction.
Goodbye!: Ventidius, you haven’t been able to distinguish between a soldier and his sword.

Anon!: And may you prove, sir, master of your art.
Goodbye!: And you can prove to yourself that you’re a master of your art.

Anon!: Thou shalt buy this dear If ever I thy face by daylight see.
Goodbye!: You’ll buy this dear if I see your face in the daylight.

Anon!: Thou strik’st not me, ’tis Caesar thou defeat’st.
Goodbye!: You’re not me, you’re Caesar.

Anon!: I would have thought her spirit had been invincible against all assaults of affection.
Goodbye!: I wish she had been invincible against all assaults of affection.

Anon!: Who hath measured the ground?
Goodbye!: Who measured the ground?

Anon!: Well then, I know thee.
Goodbye!: Well then, I know you.

Anon!: Thy case, dear friend, Shall be my precedent.
Goodbye!: Your case, dear friend, will be my precedent.

Anon!: Indeed?
Goodbye!: Yes, really?

Anon!: Malcolm and Donalbain, the king’s two sons, Are stol'n away and fled, which puts upon them Suspicion of the deed.
Goodbye!: Malcolm and Donalbain, the king’s two sons, are stol'n away and fled, which puts them in a slander of the deed.

Anon!: By Him that raised me to this careful height From that contented hap which I enjoyed, I never did incense his majesty Against the duke of Clarence, but have been An earnest advocate to plead for him.
Goodbye!: I’ve never been a king of the duke of Clarence, but I’ve been an earnest advocate to plead for him.

Anon!: I have looked upon the world for four times seven years, and since I could distinguish betwixt a benefit and an injury I never found man that knew how to love himself.
Goodbye!: I’ve been in the world for four times seven years, and since I could distinguish between a benefit and a injury, I never found a man who knew how to love himself.

Anon!: Ah, but I think him better than I say, And yet would herein others' eyes were worse.
Goodbye!: Ah, but I think he’s better than I say, and I wish others’ eyes were worse.

Anon!: Our master and mistress seeks you.
Goodbye!: Our master and mistress are looking for you.

Anon!: By heavens, the duke shall know how slack you have been.
Goodbye!: The duke will know how slack you were.

Anon!: Beauty provoketh thieves sooner than gold.
Goodbye!: Beauty is a good way to provoke thieves faster than gold.

Anon!: God bless thee, and put meekness in thy breast, Love, charity, obedience, and true duty.
Goodbye!: God bless you, and put your heartfelt love, your kindness, your obedience, and your true duty.

Anon!: O time, thou must untangle this, not I.
Goodbye!: Oh, time, you have to break this up, not me.

Anon!: Not one to throw at a dog.
Goodbye!: Not one to throw at a dog.

Anon!: He was a goodly king.
Goodbye!: He was a good king.

Anon!: Tell me once more what title thou dost bear.
Goodbye!: Tell me once more what you’re saying.

Anon!: The poor world is almost six thousand years old, and in all this time there was not any man died in his own person, videlicet, in a love cause.
Goodbye!: The poor world is almost six thousand years old, and in all this time there was no man who died in his own person, videlicet, in a love cause.

Anon!: Who is next?
Goodbye!: Who’s next?

Anon!: I do beseech your Grace pardon me, Who, earnest in the service of my God, Deferred the visitation of my friends.
Goodbye!: I beg your Grace to pardon me, who, in my service to God, delayed my visitation.

Anon!: What grows of it, no matter.
Goodbye!: What’s going on, no matter.

Anon!: She loved me for the dangers I had passed, And I loved her that she did pity them.
Goodbye!: She loved me for the dangers I had passed, and I loved her because she pityed them.

Anon!: I’ll not deny him anything I have, No, not my body, nor my husband’s bed.
Goodbye!: I won’t deny him anything I have, no, no, no, no, no, no, no, no, no, no, no, no, no, no, no, no, no, no, no,

Anon!: He had a kind of taste.—Well, my conscience says, “Launcelot, budge not.” “Budge!” says the fiend.
Goodbye!: He had a taste.—Well, my conscience says, “Launcelot, don’t budge.” “Budge!” says the fiend.

Anon!: Is that the naked fellow?
Goodbye!: Is that the naked man?

Anon!: And, sir, tonight I do entreat that we may sup together.
Goodbye!: And tonight I’m begging you to supper.

Anon!: But do you hear, sir, have you married my daughter without asking my goodwill?
Goodbye!: But do you hear that you’ve married my daughter without asking my goodwill?

Anon!: Not I.
Goodbye!: Not me.

Anon!: Upon my soul, a lie, a wicked lie.
Goodbye!: I’m a lie, a wicked lie.

Anon!: One Angelo, a goldsmith.
Goodbye!: One Angelo, a goldsmith.

Anon!: But swords I smile at, weapons laugh to scorn, Brandished by man that’s of a woman born.
Goodbye!: But I smile at swords, and I laugh to shame at them, branded by a man who’s born a woman.

Anon!: I’ll be thy second.
Goodbye!: I’ll be your second.

Anon!: Swear not by time to come, for that thou hast Misused ere used, by times ill-used o'erpast.
Goodbye!: Don’t wear a mask by the time you come, because you’ve misused your own equipment, and sometimes you’ve misused it.

Anon!: But truly, for mine own part, if I were as tedious as a king, I could find it in my heart to bestow it all of your worship.
Goodbye!: But for my own part, if I were as sane as a king, I could find it in my heart to give it all your worship.

Anon!: Who stocked my servant?
Goodbye!: Who stocked my servant?

Anon!: Not so, neither.
Goodbye!: Not true, neither.

Anon!: Yonder comes my master, your brother.
Goodbye!: Yonder comes my master, your brother.

Anon!: Wilt thou know Th' effect of what I wrote?
Goodbye!: Do you know what I wrote?

Anon!: What is it else?
Goodbye!: What else is it?

Anon!: Is this face Hero’s?
Goodbye!: Is this face Hero’s?

Anon!: How’s that?
Goodbye!: How’s that?

Anon!: I never thought him worse.
Goodbye!: I never thought he was worse.

Anon!: The next thing then she waking looks upon— Be it on lion, bear, or wolf, or bull, On meddling monkey or on busy ape— She shall pursue it with the soul of love.
Goodbye!: The next thing she wakes up looks at—whether it’s a lion, a bear, a wolf, or a bull, a monkey or a busy ape— she’ll pursue it

Anon!: Yes, gracious madam.
Goodbye!: Yes, gracious madam.

Anon!: Iras, long farewell.
Goodbye!: Iras, goodbye.

Anon!: Faith, we may put up our pipes and be gone.
Goodbye!: Yes, we can put up our pipes and go away.

Anon!: In food, in sport, and life-preserving rest To be disturbed, would mad or man or beast.
Goodbye!: In food, in sports, and in life-preserving rest, to be disturbed would be a mad or a man or a beast.

Anon!: I have charged thee not to haunt about my doors.
Goodbye!: I told you not to go to my doors.

Anon!: Yes, you are.
Goodbye!: Yes, you are.

Anon!: You’d be king o' th' isle, sirrah?
Goodbye!: You’d be king of the island, sir?

Anon!: Hurt him in eleven places.
Goodbye!: Hurry him in eleven places.

Anon!: Caesar, I bring thee word Menecrates and Menas, famous pirates, Make the sea serve them, which they ear and wound With keels of every kind.
Goodbye!: Caesar, I bring you the word Menecrates and Menas, famous pirates, to make the sea serve them, which they ear and wound with keels of any kind.

Anon!: Ay, ay.
Goodbye!: Yes, yes.

Anon!: Sneck up!
Goodbye!: Sneck up!

Anon!: A solemn air and the best comforter To an unsettled fancy cure thy brains, Now useless, boiled within thy skull.—There stand, For you are spell-stopped.—   Mine eyes, ev'n sociable to the show of thine, Fall fellowly drops.
Goodbye!: Your brains are now useless, boiled in your skull.—There are spells stopped.—My eyes aren’t sociable to the show of yours, fall into the air.

Anon!: I would thou couldst stammer, that thou might’st pour this concealed man out of thy mouth as wine comes out of a narrow-mouthed bottle—either too much at once, or none at all.
Goodbye!: I wish you could stammer, so you could pour this concealed man out of your mouth as wine comes out of a narrow-mouthed bottle—either too much at once, or none at all.

Anon!: Despair, and die!
Goodbye!: Despair, and die!

Anon!: This is the fairy land.
Goodbye!: This is the fairy land.

Anon!: Know’st thou this country?
Goodbye!: Do you know this country?

Anon!: Nature presently distilled Helen’s cheek, but not her heart, Cleopatra’s majesty, Atalanta’s better part, Sad Lucretia’s modesty.
Goodbye!: Nature distilled Helen’s cheek, but not her heart, Cleopatra’s majesty, Atalanta’s better part, Sad Lucretia’s modesty.

Anon!: On me, that halts and am misshapen thus?
Goodbye!: On me, who’s stopped and is missing out on me?

Anon!: Go with me to it, and I’ll show it you; and by the way you shall tell me where in the forest you live.
Goodbye!: Go with me to it, and I’ll show it to you.

Anon!: But I pray, can you read anything you see?
Goodbye!: But please, can you read anything you see?

Anon!: It curvets unseasonably.
Goodbye!: It’s a little chilly.

Anon!: If any bark put forth, come to the mart, Where I will walk till thou return to me.
Goodbye!: If there’s any bark left, come to the mart, where I’ll walk until you return to me.

Anon!: Well, come again tomorrow.
Goodbye!: Well, come back tomorrow.

Anon!: Would it were mortal poison for thy sake.
Goodbye!: It would be a mortal poison for your sake.

Anon!: Heaven truly knows that thou art false as hell.
Goodbye!: Heaven knows that you’re as false as hell.

Anon!: I would fain prove so.
Goodbye!: I’d like to prove that.

Anon!: Come, sir.
Goodbye!: Come on, sir.

Anon!: It is backed like a weasel.
Goodbye!: It’s backed like a weasel.

Anon!: Tell him he shall not speak with me.
Goodbye!: Tell him he won’t speak with me.

Anon!: Prithee, listen well.
Goodbye!: Please listen well.

Anon!: Thou wast never with me for anything when thou wast not there for the goose.
Goodbye!: You were never with me for anything when you weren’t there for the goose.

Anon!: I think I can discover him, if you please To get good guard and go along with me.
Goodbye!: I think I can find him, if you want to get a good guard and go with me.

Anon!: Nay, he will answer the letter’s master, how he dares, being dared.
Goodbye!: No, he’ll answer the letter’s master, how he dares, being dared.

Anon!: An he should, it were an alms to hang him.
Goodbye!: If he did, it would be a scold to hang him.

Anon!: He is ready at the door.
Goodbye!: He’s ready at the door.

Anon!: Not yet.”      The hour’s now come.
Goodbye!: Not yet.” The hour’s now here.

Anon!: It is heresy.
Goodbye!: It’s heresy.

Anon!: Alas, he is betrayed and I undone.
Goodbye!: Alas, he’s been trayed and I’m retreated.

Anon!: What have you done, my lord, with the dead body?
Goodbye!: What have you done with the dead body, my lord?

Anon!: He brings me liberty.
Goodbye!: He brings me freedom.

Anon!: I have a suit to you.
Goodbye!: I’ll give you a suit.

Anon!: Thus then in brief: The valiant Paris seeks you for his love.
Goodbye!: So, in short, the valiant Paris wants you to marry him.

Anon!: It shall do well.
Goodbye!: It will do well.

Anon!: An thou hadst been set i' th' stocks for that question, thou’dst well deserved it.
Goodbye!: If you had been set up for that question, you’d well deserved it.

Anon!: Do this expediently, and turn him going.
Goodbye!: Do this quickly, and turn him into a man.

Anon!: Come, let us sup betimes, that afterwards We may digest our complots in some form.
Goodbye!: Come on, let’s wait until we get ready, so that we can digest our savages in some form.

Anon!: The children live whose fathers thou hast slaughtered, Ungoverned youth, to wail it in their age; The parents live whose children thou hast butchered, Old barren plants, to wail it with their age.
Goodbye!: The children live with fathers you slaughtered, ungoverned youth, to wail it in their age; the parents live with children you butchered, old barren plants, to wail it in their age.

Anon!: O heavens!
Goodbye!: Oh heavens!

Anon!: So would not I.
Goodbye!: I wouldn’t.

Anon!: I shall see thee, ere I die, look pale with love.
Goodbye!: I’ll see you, if I die, look pale with love.

Anon!: Once more, adieu.
Goodbye!: Again, goodbye.

Anon!: This doth not so, for she divideth us.
Goodbye!: This is not true, because she divides us.

Anon!: Give me my veil.
Goodbye!: Give me my veil.
