Anon!: I have sent to bid Cassio come speak with you.
Goodbye!: I sent to ask Cassio to come speak with you.

Anon!: Thou shalt not lose by it.
Goodbye!: You’ll not lose by it.

Anon!: But come, young waverer, come, go with me, In one respect I’ll thy assistant be, For this alliance may so happy prove To turn your households' rancor to pure love.
Goodbye!: But come, young waver, come with me, I’ll be your assistant in one respect, because this alliance may prove so happy to turn your households’ sanity into pure love.

Anon!: Carry me to the jail?
Goodbye!: Go to jail?

Anon!: What say you, Hermia?
Goodbye!: What do you say, Hermia?

Anon!: What else?
Goodbye!: What else?

Anon!: Beshrew his soul for me!
Goodbye!: Beshrew his soul for me!

Anon!: Edmund is dead, my lord.
Goodbye!: Edmund is dead, my lord.

Anon!: Do you consent we shall acquaint him with it, As needful in our loves, fitting our duty?
Goodbye!: Do you agree that we’ll inform him of it, as we need it to be, and as we need it?

Anon!: With this strange virtue, He hath a heavenly gift of prophecy, And sundry blessings hang about his throne, That speak him full of grace.
Goodbye!: With this strange virtue, he has a heavenly gift of prophecy, and sundry blessings hang around his throne, which speak to him full of grace.

Anon!: Small joy have I in being England’s queen.
Goodbye!: I’ve had a small joy in being England’s queen.

Anon!: What with a torch!
Goodbye!: What with a torch!

Anon!: Will it eat me?
Goodbye!: Will it eat me?

Anon!: Pronounce that sentence then on me, my liege.
Goodbye!: Tell me that sentence, my liege.

Anon!: Madam, undress you and come now to bed.
Goodbye!: Madam, undress you and come to bed now.

Anon!: This fellow doth not stand upon points.
Goodbye!: This man doesn’t stand on points.

Anon!: But, sir, such wanton, wild, and usual slips
Goodbye!: But, sir, such a wild, wild, and usual slips

Anon!: My naked weapon is out.
Goodbye!: My naked sword is out.

Anon!: And yet no matter.
Goodbye!: And yet it doesn’t matter.

Anon!: It cannot be.
Goodbye!: It can’t be.

Anon!: This was a venture, sir, that Jacob served for— A thing not in his power to bring to pass But swayed and fashioned by the hand of heaven.
Goodbye!: This was a venture, sir, for which Jacob served—something he didn’t have the power to bring to pass but swayed and fashioned by the hand of heaven.

Anon!: Truly, I think they are.
Goodbye!: I think they are.

Anon!: Go and trim her up.
Goodbye!: Go and trim her up.

Anon!: The noble duke my master, My worthy arch and patron, comes tonight.
Goodbye!: The noble duke, my master, my worthy arch and patron, is coming tonight.

Anon!: I pray you, speak not.
Goodbye!: Please don’t speak to me.

Anon!: Well, but what’s o'clock?
Goodbye!: Well, what time is it?

Anon!: Well contented.
Goodbye!: Good luck.

Anon!: Therefore  You will not pay for the glasses you have burst?
Goodbye!: So you won’t pay for the glasses you’ve burst?

Anon!: Some oracle Must rectify our knowledge.
Goodbye!: We need some oracle to correct our knowledge.

Anon!: I only speak right on.
Goodbye!: I’m only talking right on.

Anon!: We’ll keep no great ado, a friend or two.
Goodbye!: We won’t keep a great ado, a friend or two.

Anon!: My children too?
Goodbye!: My children too?

Anon!: Thanks, you the valiant of this warlike isle That so approve the Moor.
Goodbye!: Thanks, you brave man who approves the Moor.

Anon!: Sister, you know he promised me a chain.
Goodbye!: Sister, you know he promised me a necklace.

Anon!: Come, my fair Cordelia.
Goodbye!: Come, my dear Cordelia.

Anon!: The foul fiend follows me!
Goodbye!: The foul fiend follows me!

Anon!: Doth she not count her blessed, Unworthy as she is, that we have wrought So worthy a gentleman to be her bride?
Goodbye!: Doesn’t she count her blessed, unworthy, lady that we have made such a worthy gentleman to be her bride?

Anon!: Is the single man therefore blessed?
Goodbye!: Is the single man blessed?

Anon!: Do you quarrel, sir?
Goodbye!: Do you have a fight, sir?

Anon!: Here, wear this jewel for me.
Goodbye!: Here, wear this jewel for me.

Anon!: Go tell him of this.
Goodbye!: Tell him about this.

Anon!: Nay, then thou lov’st it not And all my pains is sorted to no proof.
Goodbye!: No, then you don’t love it, and all my pains are sorted to no proof.

Anon!: I have seen her die twenty times upon far poorer moment.
Goodbye!: I’ve seen her die twenty times in a far worse moment.

Anon!: Ay, madam.
Goodbye!: Yes, madam.

Anon!: Go you and prepare Aliena, for look you, here comes my Rosalind.
Goodbye!: Go ahead and prepare Aliena, for look at me, here comes my Rosalind.

Anon!: To these injunctions every one doth swear That comes to hazard for my worthless self.
Goodbye!: To these injunctions, every person swears that I’m a victim of a terrible self-destructiveness.

Anon!: I beseech you.
Goodbye!: Please.

Anon!: What, sigh for the toothache?
Goodbye!: What, sigh for the toothache?

Anon!: I remember You did supplant your brother Prospero.
Goodbye!: I remember you supplanted your brother Prospero.

Anon!: Why should she write to Edmund?
Goodbye!: Why should she write to Edmund?

Anon!: What say’st thou, noble heart?
Goodbye!: What do you say, noble heart?

Anon!: Thou canst tell why one’s nose stands i' th' middle on ’s face?
Goodbye!: You can tell why one’s nose stands in the middle of his face?

Anon!: On thy life I charge thee, hold!
Goodbye!: I’ll give you a chance to stay!

Anon!: Here at your service.
Goodbye!: Here at your service.

Anon!: Know, sir, that I am called Hortensio.
Goodbye!: I know, sir, that I’m called Hortensio.

Anon!: Go you and tell my daughter I would speak with her.
Goodbye!: Go and tell my daughter I’d like to speak with her.

Anon!: To make you answer truly to your name.
Goodbye!: To make you answer to your name.

Anon!: Then he’s a rogue, and a passy-measures pavin.
Goodbye!: Then he’s a rogue, and a savage pavin.

Anon!: Ay, my lord, an ’t please you.
Goodbye!: Yes, my lord, it’s a good idea to be.

Anon!: This I’ll report, dear lady.
Goodbye!: I’ll report this, dear lady.

Anon!: I am none of these, my lord.
Goodbye!: I’m not one of these, my lord.

Anon!: I will show myself a tyrant.
Goodbye!: I’ll be a tyrant.

Anon!: Oh, then I see that madmen have no ears.
Goodbye!: Oh, then I see that madmen have no ears.

Anon!: Call the slave again.
Goodbye!: Call the slave back.

Anon!: But do not go with it.
Goodbye!: But don’t go with it.

Anon!: Was this fair paper, this most goodly book, Made to write “whore” upon?
Goodbye!: Was this fair paper, this very good book, made to write “whore”?

Anon!: My cousin Westmoreland?
Goodbye!: My cousin Westmoreland?

Anon!: No, my lord.
Goodbye!: No, my lord.

Anon!: A proper saying!
Goodbye!: That’s a good saying!

Anon!: Our son shall win.
Goodbye!: Our son will win.

Anon!: So should he look That seems to speak things strange.
Goodbye!: He looks like he’s talking about things strangely.

Anon!: Save thee, friend, and thy music.
Goodbye!: Save you, friend, and your music.

Anon!: By a name I know not how to tell thee who I am.
Goodbye!: I don’t know who I am.

Anon!: Why, the hot-blooded France that dowerless took Our youngest born—I could as well be brought To knee his throne, and, squirelike, pension beg To keep base life afoot.
Goodbye!: Why, the hot-blooded France who took our youngest born without a doubt—I could as well be brought to kneel his throne and, squirely, beg to keep a base life

Anon!: Now, princely Buckingham, seal thou this league With thy embracements to my wife’s allies And make me happy in your unity.
Goodbye!: Now, princely Buckingham, seal this league with your embraces to my wife’s allies and make me happy in your unity.

Anon!: Here, sir!
Goodbye!: Here, sir!

Anon!: Tell me, good my friend, What torch is yond that vainly lends his light To grubs and eyeless skulls?
Goodbye!: Tell me, my friend, what is the torch that will give his light to grubs and eyeless skulls?

Anon!: Prithee, be not angry.
Goodbye!: Please, don’t be angry.

Anon!: I will bite thee by the ear for that jest.
Goodbye!: I’ll bite you by the ear for that sneezing.

Anon!: Mine’s not an idle cause.
Goodbye!: I’m not a good cause.

Anon!: Vent my folly?
Goodbye!: Vent my nonsense?

Anon!: There stays a husband to make you a wife.
Goodbye!: There’s a husband who can make you a wife.

Anon!: O me, O me!
Goodbye!: Oh, my, Oh my!

Anon!: God bless me from a challenge!
Goodbye!: God bless me from a challenge!

Anon!: Marry, sir, be better employed, and be naught awhile.
Goodbye!: You’re better employed and naughty for a while.

Anon!: No, madam, I do but read madness.
Goodbye!: No, madam, I’m only reading madness.

Anon!: It is no matter how witty, so it be eloquent and full of invention.
Goodbye!: It’s not as witty as it is, so it’s eloquent and full of invention.

Anon!: Signior, is all your family within?
Goodbye!: Is your family in the same place?

Anon!: Now all the blessings Of a glad father, compass thee about.
Goodbye!: Now all the blessings of a happy father, come on.

Anon!: I am aweary of this moon.
Goodbye!: I’m tired of this moon.

Anon!: The boy gives warning something doth approach.
Goodbye!: The boy warns that something is approaching.

Anon!: If every one knows us, and we know none, 'Tis time, I think, to trudge, pack, and be gone.
Goodbye!: If everyone knows us, and we don’t know, it’s time, I think, to trudge, pack, and go.

Anon!: I charge thee do so, as thou art my child.
Goodbye!: I’m directing you to do so, as you are my child.

Anon!: And so have I addressed me.
Goodbye!: And so have I addressed me.

Anon!: Here’s Decius Brutus.
Goodbye!: Here’s Decius Brutus.

Anon!: Be gone!
Goodbye!: Go away!

Anon!: Your voice shall be as strong as any man’s In the disposing of new dignities.
Goodbye!: Your voice will be as strong as any man can be when it comes to removing new dignities.

Anon!: Why, who would not make her husband a cuckold to make him a monarch?
Goodbye!: Why, who wouldn’t make her husband a cuckold to make him a monarch?

Anon!: My lord, most humbly on my knee I beg The leading of the vaward.
Goodbye!: My lord, I beg the leading of the vaward humbly on my knee.

Anon!: It is no mean happiness, therefore, to be seated in the mean.
Goodbye!: It’s no good to be seated in the middle of the room.

Anon!: When good manners shall lie all in one or two men’s hands, and they unwashed too, ’tis a foul thing.
Goodbye!: When one or two men are in their hands and they’re unwashed too, it’s a foul thing.

Anon!: Why, and I trust I may go too, may I not?
Goodbye!: Why, and I hope I can go too, can’t I?

Anon!: This doth not so, for she divideth us.
Goodbye!: This is not true, because she divides us.

Anon!: For naught so vile that on the earth doth live But to the earth some special good doth give.
Goodbye!: It’s so vile that on earth only some special good is given to the earth.

Anon!: Advise yourself.
Goodbye!: Ask.

Anon!: Caesar’s will?
Goodbye!: Caesar’s will?

Anon!: And never, since the middle summer’s spring, Met we on hill, in dale, forest, or mead, By pavèd fountain, or by rushy brook, Or in the beachèd margent of the sea, To dance our ringlets to the whistling wind, But with thy brawls thou hast disturbed our sport.
Goodbye!: And never, since the middle summer’s spring, we’ve been on hill, in dale, forest, or mead, by a fountain, or by a rushy brook, or in the beach, dancing

Anon!: My niece shall take note of it, and assure thyself, there is no love-broker in the world can more prevail in man’s commendation with woman than report of valor.
Goodbye!: My niece will take note of it and assure you, there is no love-broker in the world who can be more than a woman’s praise for him than a valor.

Anon!: Art thou aught else but place, degree, and form, Creating awe and fear in other men, Wherein thou art less happy, being feared, Than they in fearing?
Goodbye!: You’re less happy, being feared, than they are afraid?

Anon!: With bills on their necks: “Be it known unto all men by these presents.”  The eldest of the three wrestled with Charles, the duke’s wrestler, which Charles in a moment threw him and broke three of his ribs, that there is little hope of life in him.
Goodbye!: The eldest of the three wrestled with Charles, the duke’s wrestler, which Charles threw him in a moment and broke three of his ribs, said he has little hope of life in him

Anon!: Say I, her sovereign, am her subject low.
Goodbye!: Say I’m her sovereign, I’m her subject.

Anon!: And here stands all your state: Either be gone before the watch be set, Or by the break of day disguised from hence.
Goodbye!: And here’s all your state: either go away before the watch is set, or hide from the sun.

Anon!: My invocation Is fair and honest.
Goodbye!: I’m fair and honest.

Anon!: Show me, show me.
Goodbye!: Show me, show me.

Anon!: It is enacted in the laws of Venice, If it be proved against an alien That by direct or indirect attempts He seek the life of any citizen, The party 'gainst the which he doth contrive Shall seize one half his goods.
Goodbye!: If it is proved against an alien that he is seeking the life of any citizen by direct or indirect attempts, the party will take half of his goods.

Anon!: Know you not, master, to some kind of men Their graces serve them but as enemies?
Goodbye!: Do you know some kind of men who are worthy of their graces only serve them as enemies?

Anon!: When did she send thee?
Goodbye!: When did she send you?

Anon!: You have astonished him.
Goodbye!: You’ve surprised him.

Anon!: Therefore, I beseech your Highness pardon me.
Goodbye!: So please forgive me, your Highness.

Anon!: Come, vial.
Goodbye!: Come on, vial.

Anon!: If she find him not, To England send him or confine him where Your wisdom best shall think.
Goodbye!: If she doesn’t find him, send him to England or confine him to where you’ll think best.

Anon!: Censure me in your wisdom, and awake your senses that you may the better judge.
Goodbye!: Censure me in your wisdom, and awaken your senses so you can judge better.

Anon!: Pray you, look not sad, Nor make replies of loathness.
Goodbye!: Please, don’t be sad, and don’t respond to any complaints about loath.

Anon!: Did he not rather Discredit my authority with yours, And make the wars alike against my stomach, Having alike your cause?
Goodbye!: Didn’t he discredit my authority with yours rather than make the wars against my stomach, having the same effect on your cause?

Anon!: What is thy name?
Goodbye!: What’s your name?

Anon!: Go sleep, and hear us.
Goodbye!: Go sleep and listen to us.

Anon!: We will go together.
Goodbye!: We’ll go together.

Anon!: If you will not, come when you are next prepared for.
Goodbye!: If you don’t want to, come here when you’re ready for it.

Anon!: Bear me, good friends, where Cleopatra bides.
Goodbye!: Bear me, good friends, where Cleopatra is.

Anon!: I know not, madam.
Goodbye!: I don’t know, madam.

Anon!: I did not.
Goodbye!: I didn’t.

Anon!: Awake, awake!
Goodbye!: Wake up, wake up!

Anon!: What it is, my Caius, I shall unfold to thee as we are going To whom it must be done.
Goodbye!: I’ll tell you what it is, Caius, and how it will be done.

Anon!: It is very sultry—as ’twere—I cannot tell how.
Goodbye!: It’s very sultry—as it was—I can’t tell how.

Anon!: A most wicked Sir Oliver, Audrey, a most vile Martext.
Goodbye!: A wicked Sir Oliver, Audrey, a vile Martext.

Anon!: So you shall.
Goodbye!: You will.

Anon!: If he please To give me conquered Egypt for my son, He gives me so much of mine own as I Will kneel to him with thanks.
Goodbye!: If he wants to give me conquered Egypt for my son, he gives me so much of my own as I will kneel to him with thanks.

Anon!: Even so.
Goodbye!: That’s true.

Anon!: And so it is.
Goodbye!: And so it is.

Anon!: No pains, sir.
Goodbye!: No pain, sir.

Anon!: To have a foolish wife.
Goodbye!: To have a foolish wife.

Anon!: Shalt see thy other daughter will use thee kindly.
Goodbye!: You’ll see that your other daughter will use you kindly.

Anon!: Well, we shall see your bearing.
Goodbye!: Well, we’ll see what you’re doing.

Anon!: The king comes here tonight.
Goodbye!: The king is coming here tonight.

Anon!: Nay, I prithee now, with most petitionary vehemence, tell me who it is.
Goodbye!: No, please tell me, with most petitionary vehemence, who it is.

Anon!: Listen but speak not to ’t.
Goodbye!: Listen, but don’t speak to it.

Anon!: My master, not myself, lacks recompense.
Goodbye!: My master, not myself, has no money to pay.

Anon!: Speak this no more.
Goodbye!: Don’t say anything else.

Anon!: Fled to England?
Goodbye!: Fled to England?

Anon!: Let good Antonio look he keep his day, Or he shall pay for this.
Goodbye!: Let good Antonio look at him for his day, or he’ll pay for this.

Anon!: O Stephano, hast any more of this?
Goodbye!: Oh Stephano, isn’t that all this?

Anon!: Take what wife you will to bed, I will ever be your head.
Goodbye!: Take what wife you want to be to bed, I’ll always be your head.

Anon!: Better once than never, for never too late.
Goodbye!: Better once than never, because it’s never too late.

Anon!: Sing it tonight.
Goodbye!: Sing it tonight.

Anon!: I am bound to your niece, sir.
Goodbye!: I’m bound to your niece, sir.

Anon!: Wonder not till further warrant.
Goodbye!: Don’t wonder until you’ve got a warrant.

Anon!: Who’s there?
Goodbye!: Who’s there?

Anon!: He did not call, he’s busy in the paper.
Goodbye!: He didn’t call me, he’s busy in the paper.

Anon!: Come not in here, nuncle.
Goodbye!: Don’t come in here, uncle.

Anon!: I pray you all, If you have hitherto concealed this sight, Let it be tenable in your silence still.
Goodbye!: Please, if you’ve concealed this sight before, keep it quiet.

Anon!: Well, well, We shall thrive now.—Seest thou, my good fellow?
Goodbye!: Well, well, we’ll thrive now.—Seen you, my good fellow?

Anon!: For one thing she did They would not take her life.
Goodbye!: They didn’t take her life for one thing she did.

Anon!: For God’s love, let me hear.
Goodbye!: For God’s sake, let me hear.

Anon!: Sit you too.
Goodbye!: You can sit here too.

Anon!: Did he confess it?
Goodbye!: Did he confess?

Anon!: What, wilt thou flout me thus unto my face, Being forbid?
Goodbye!: What, will you go go to my face, being forbidden?

Anon!: Nay, I’ll help too.
Goodbye!: No, I’ll help too.

Anon!: Not so.
Goodbye!: Not true.

Anon!: We have a trifling foolish banquet towards.— Is it e'en so?
Goodbye!: We have a foolish banquet to eat.—Is it true?

Anon!: Know’st thou not That I have fined these bones of mine for ransom?
Goodbye!: Don’t you know that I’ve fined my bones for ransom?

Anon!: Double, double toil and trouble, Fire burn, and cauldron bubble.
Goodbye!: Double, double toil and trouble, Fire burn, and cauldron bubble.

Anon!: Humbly I thank your grace.
Goodbye!: I thank you, sir.

Anon!: Give me a taper, call up all my people!
Goodbye!: Give me a taper, call up all my people!

Anon!: This is the fool that lent out money gratis.
Goodbye!: This is the fool who gave out money free.

Anon!: No, but to the gate, and there will the devil meet me like an old cuckold with horns on his head, and say, “Get you to heaven, Beatrice, get you to heaven; here’s no place for you maids.” So deliver I up my apes and away to Saint Peter.
Goodbye!: No, I’ll go to the gate, and the devil will meet me like a cuckold with horns on his head, and say, “Get to heaven, Beatrice, get to heaven; here’s

Anon!: is your merry humor altered?
Goodbye!: Are you changing your humor?

Anon!: I am glad thou canst speak no better English, for if thou couldst, thou wouldst find me such a plain king that thou wouldst think I had sold my farm to buy my crown.
Goodbye!: I’m glad you can’t speak better English, because if you could find me such a plain king that you would think I’d sold my farm to buy my crown.

Anon!: Farewell!—God knows when we shall meet again.
Goodbye!: Goodbye!—God knows when we’ll meet again.

Anon!: Bring us the letter.
Goodbye!: Bring us the letter.

Anon!: Happiest of all is that her gentle spirit Commits itself to yours to be directed As from her lord, her governor, her king.
Goodbye!: The best thing about her is that she’s committed to yours, and to be directed as far as her lord, her governor, her king.

Anon!: I am changed.
Goodbye!: I’ve changed my mind.

Anon!: What thou wouldst highly, That wouldst thou holily; wouldst not play false, And yet wouldst wrongly win.
Goodbye!: You would highly, that you would holily, but you wouldn’t play falsely, and yet you wouldn’t win.

Anon!: What’s that to thee?
Goodbye!: What’s that to you?

Anon!: What infinite heart’s ease Must kings neglect that private men enjoy?
Goodbye!: What infinite heart’s ease do kings neglect that private men enjoy?

Anon!: Or I will live Or bathe my dying honor in the blood Shall make it live again.
Goodbye!: Or I’ll live or bathe my honor in the blood and make it live again.

Anon!: Great Mark Antony Is now a widower.
Goodbye!: Great Mark Antony is a widower now.

Anon!: Thou canst not speak of that thou dost not feel.
Goodbye!: You can’t speak about something you don’t feel.

Anon!: What of that?
Goodbye!: What about that?

Anon!: What, all so soon asleep?
Goodbye!: What, all of you are asleep so soon?

Anon!: He did, my gracious lord, begin that place, Which, since, succeeding ages have re-edified.
Goodbye!: He did, my gracious lord, start that place, which, since the beginning of the year, has re-edified.

Anon!: What, frighted with false fire?
Goodbye!: What, snoring with false fire?

Anon!: But take a taste of my finding him, and relish it with good observance.
Goodbye!: But take a taste of my finding him and enjoy it with good observance.

Anon!: Some are born great, some achieve greatness, and some have greatness thrust upon 'em.
Goodbye!: Some are born great, some achieve greatness, and others have greatness thrust on them.

Anon!: Because I would not see thy cruèl nails Pluck out his poor old eyes, nor thy fierce sister In his anointed flesh stick boarish fangs.
Goodbye!: Because I wouldn’t see your cruèl nails pluck out his poor old eyes, and your fierce sister would stick boarish fangs in his anointed flesh.

Anon!: Taurus!
Goodbye!: Taurus!

Anon!: But as I think—for truly would I speak, And now do I bethink me, so it is— I came with Hermia hither.
Goodbye!: But I think I’m coming with Hermia here.

Anon!: You may as well go about to turn the sun to ice with fanning in his face with a peacock’s feather.
Goodbye!: You may as well go about turning the sun to ice with fanning in his face with a peacock’s feather.

Anon!: The motions of his spirit are dull as night, And his affections dark as Erebus.
Goodbye!: His moods are dull as nighttime, and his affections are dark as Erebus.

Anon!: I think I told your lordship a year since how much I am in the favor of Margaret, the waiting gentlewoman to Hero.
Goodbye!: I think I told your lordship a year ago how much I’m in favor of Margaret, the waitress of Hero.

Anon!: Forever and a day.
Goodbye!: Forever and a day.

Anon!: Nay, I will give thee a kiss.
Goodbye!: No, I’ll kiss you.

Anon!: As I remember, this should be the house.
Goodbye!: As I remember, this should be the house.

Anon!: What, is the fellow mad?
Goodbye!: What, is the fellow mad?

Anon!: Up, up, and see The great doom’s image!
Goodbye!: Up, up, and see the great doom’s image!

Anon!: It’s true, good lieutenant.
Goodbye!: It’s true, lieutenant.

Anon!: O wherefore, Nature, didst thou lions frame?
Goodbye!: Oh, Nature, did you frame lions?

Anon!: Talk you of young Master Launcelot?
Goodbye!: Are you talking about young Master Launcelot?

Anon!: It gives me wonder great as my content To see you here before me.
Goodbye!: It’s great to see you here before me.

Anon!: Not?
Goodbye!: Not?

Anon!: Do not weep, do not weep.
Goodbye!: Don’t cry, don’t cry.

Anon!: Until I know this sure uncertainty I’ll entertain the offered fallacy.
Goodbye!: I’ll bet I’ll bet I’ll bet I’ll bet I’ve been a fool until I know this.

Anon!: Alas, what danger will it be to us, Maids as we are, to travel forth so far?
Goodbye!: What danger will we be to travel so far, as if we were the Maids as we are?

Anon!: At last I left them I' th' filthy-mantled pool beyond your cell, There dancing up to th' chins, that the foul lake O'erstunk their feet.
Goodbye!: I left them in the pool beyond your cell, dancing up to your chins, so the foul lake sunk their feet.

Anon!: No watch?
Goodbye!: No watch?

Anon!: This heavy-headed revel east and west Makes us traduced and taxed of other nations.
Goodbye!: This snoring party in the east and west makes us a snore and a taxed nation.

Anon!: No.
Goodbye!: No.

Anon!: Let’s have no more of this, let’s to our affairs.—Forgive us our sins!—Gentlemen, let’s look to our business.
Goodbye!: Let’s not have any more of this, let’s go to our affairs.—Forgive us our sins!—Gentlemen, let’s go to our business.

Anon!: It is young Orlando, that tripped up the wrestler’s heels and your heart both in an instant.
Goodbye!: It’s young Orlando who tripped up the wrestler’s heels and your heart in an instant.

Anon!: Sin from thy lips?
Goodbye!: Sin from your lips?

Anon!: If your leisure served, I would speak with you.
Goodbye!: If you’re enjoying your leisure, I’d like to speak with you.

Anon!: What’s a drunken man like, fool?
Goodbye!: What’s a drunken man like, fool?

Anon!: Mine nightingale, We have beat them to their beds.
Goodbye!: I’ve beat them to their beds.

Anon!: A substitute shines brightly as a king Until a king be by, and then his state Empties itself, as doth an inland brook Into the main of waters.
Goodbye!: A substitute shines brightly as a king until a king is here, and then his state is flooded, as if an inland brook is flooded with water.

Anon!: Comes there any more of it?
Goodbye!: Is there any more of it?

Anon!: O comfortable Friar!
Goodbye!: Oh, nice Friar!

Anon!: Tis better, sir, to be brief than tedious.—Let him see our commission, and talk no more.
Goodbye!: It’s better to be brief than to be tedious.—Let him see our commission and don’t talk anymore.

Anon!: Men’s eyes were made to look and let them gaze.
Goodbye!: Men’s eyes were made to look and let them see.

Anon!: Cancel his bond of life, dear God I pray, That I may live to say, “The dog is dead.”
Goodbye!: Can’t live his life, dear God, so I can say, “The dog is dead.”

Anon!: The watery kingdom, whose ambitious head Spits in the face of heaven, is no bar To stop the foreign spirits, but they come As o'er a brook to see fair Portia.
Goodbye!: The watery kingdom, whose ambitious head spits in the face of heaven, is no bar to stop the foreign spirits, but they come as if they were a brook to see the fair Portia.

Anon!: I think Alexander the Great was born in Macedon.
Goodbye!: I think Alexander the Great was born in Macedon.

Anon!: These are but wild and whirling words, my lord.
Goodbye!: These are just wild and whirling words, my lord.

Anon!: O most wicked fiend!
Goodbye!: Oh, what a wicked fiend!

Anon!: We will greet the time.
Goodbye!: We’ll greet you at the time.

Anon!: Do they grow rusty?
Goodbye!: Are they getting rusty?

Anon!: That’s good.
Goodbye!: That’s good.

Anon!: O me!
Goodbye!: Oh, my!

Anon!: Fiery”?
Goodbye!: Fiery”?

Anon!: Tell me, good Brutus, can you see your face?
Goodbye!: Tell me, good Brutus, can you see your face?

Anon!: Question it, Horatio.
Goodbye!: Question it, Horatio.

Anon!: What will you do with ’t, that you have been so earnest To have me filch it?
Goodbye!: What do you want to do with it, that you’ve been so diligent to have me snatch it?

Anon!: My old bones ache.
Goodbye!: My old bones are acheing.

Anon!: O horror, horror, horror!
Goodbye!: Oh, horror, horror, horror!

Anon!: Now could I drink hot blood And do such bitter business as the bitter day Would quake to look on.
Goodbye!: Now I could drink hot blood and do so bitter business as the bitter day would be to look on.

Anon!: Peace then!
Goodbye!: So, calm down!

Anon!: It seems not meet, nor wholesome to my place, To be producted (as, if I stay, I shall) Against the Moor.
Goodbye!: It seems not to be a good idea to be sane to me, or to be a good idea to be sane (if I stay, I will) against the Moor.

Anon!: How parted he with thee?
Goodbye!: How did he split with you?

Anon!: No more but e’en a woman, and commanded By such poor passion as the maid that milks And does the meanest chares.
Goodbye!: No more than a woman, and commanded by such poor passion as the maid who milks and does the smallest chares.

Anon!: Presently.
Goodbye!: Right now.

Anon!: There’s hope in ’t yet.
Goodbye!: There’s still hope.

Anon!: Pray ye, go.
Goodbye!: Please go.

Anon!: Here is a friar that trembles, sighs and weeps.
Goodbye!: Here’s a friar that trembles, sighs and weeps.

Anon!: I pray you, what is he?
Goodbye!: Please, what is he?

Anon!: How came you thus recovered?
Goodbye!: How did you recover from that?

Anon!: Well then, now Have you considered of my speeches?
Goodbye!: Well, have you thought about my speeches now?

Anon!: Good meat, sir, is common; that every churl affords.
Goodbye!: Good meat is common, sir.

Anon!: Nay, she is worse; she is the devil’s dam, and here she comes in the habit of a light wench.
Goodbye!: She’s worse than that, and here she comes in the habit of a light wench.

Anon!: Tut, I have the best armor of the world.
Goodbye!: I have the best armor in the world.

Anon!: And when the mind is quickened, out of doubt, The organs, though defunct and dead before, Break up their drowsy grave and newly move, With casted slough and fresh legerity.
Goodbye!: And when the mind is quickened out of doubt, the organs, even though they’ve been dead before, break up their drowsy grave and move slowly, with a slough and a fresh

Anon!: It is a good divine that follows his own instructions.
Goodbye!: It’s a good divine who follows his own instructions.

Anon!: Pompey Thrives in our idleness.
Goodbye!: Pompey is a tad bleak.

Anon!: Peace!
Goodbye!: Quiet!

Anon!: You shall have none ill, sir, for I’ll try if they can lick their fingers.
Goodbye!: You won’t have any bad luck, sir, because I’ll try if they can lick their fingers.

Anon!: Yes, marry, sir.
Goodbye!: Yes, I’m married, sir.

Anon!: When I am alone, why then I am Tranio; But in all places else, your master Lucentio.
Goodbye!: When I’m alone, then I’m Tranio, but in all other places, your master Lucentio.

Anon!: For even out of that will I cause these of Cyprus to mutiny, whose qualification shall come into no true taste again but by the displanting of Cassio.
Goodbye!: I’ll make these of Cyprus mutiny, whose sanity will come to life only by the displanting of Cassio.

Anon!: Thou hast obtained thy suit.
Goodbye!: You’ve got your case.

Anon!: But by and by comes back to Romeo, Who had but newly entertained revenge, And to ’t they go like lightning, for ere I Could draw to part them was stout Tybalt slain.
Goodbye!: But I’ll come back to Romeo, who had only recently gotten revenge, and to see them go like lightning, because I could draw Tybalt to kill me.

Anon!: Why, we have galls, and though we have some grace, Yet have we some revenge.
Goodbye!: We have galls, and even though we have some grace, we have some revenge.

Anon!: Come, we’ll to sleep.
Goodbye!: Come on, we’ll sleep.

Anon!: It was well done, and thou shalt sleep again.
Goodbye!: It was well done, and you’ll sleep again.

Anon!: God, God forgive us all!
Goodbye!: God, God forgive us all!

Anon!: Why, love, I say.
Goodbye!: Love, I say.

Anon!: We are in God’s hand, brother, not in theirs.
Goodbye!: We’re in God’s hand, brother, not in theirs.

Anon!: What’s the matter, think you?
Goodbye!: What’s the matter, do you think?

Anon!: By my faith, you have great reason to be sad.
Goodbye!: I swear, you have great reason to be sad.

Anon!: And tell me now, sweet friend, what happy gale Blows you to Padua here from old Verona?
Goodbye!: And tell me, dear friend, what happy gale do you have here from old Verona?

Anon!: Look to the queen there, ho!
Goodbye!: Look at the queen there, ho!

Anon!: How goes the world with thee?
Goodbye!: How is the world going with you?

Anon!: His very opinion in the letter!
Goodbye!: That’s what he said in the letter.

Anon!: The lady of the Strachy married the yeoman of the wardrobe.
Goodbye!: The lady of the Strachy married the yeoman of the wardrobe.

Anon!: What is your parentage?” “Above my fortunes, yet my state is well.
Goodbye!: What is your fatherage?” “I’m not sure what I’m doing, but my state is well.

Anon!: It hath been The untimely emptying of the happy throne And fall of many kings.
Goodbye!: It’s been the emptying of the happy throne and the fall of many kings.

Anon!: There is something else.
Goodbye!: There’s something else.

Anon!: You’ll have coursers for cousins and gennets for germans.
Goodbye!: You’ll have a pair of worms for cousins and gennets for germans.

Anon!: Heigh-ho.
Goodbye!: Oh, yes.

Anon!: The old priest at Saint Luke’s Church is at your command at all hours.
Goodbye!: The old priest at Saint Luke’s Church is at your command at all hours.

Anon!: Ay, my lord.
Goodbye!: Yes, my lord.

Anon!: Yet I hate not Orlando.
Goodbye!: But I don’t hate Orlando.

Anon!: Maintain a mourning ostentation, And on your family’s old monument Hang mournful epitaphs and do all rites That appertain unto a burial.
Goodbye!: Keep a mourning ostentation, and on your family’s old monument hang mournful epitaphs and do all the rites that are applicable to a burial.

Anon!: And will you give me leave?
Goodbye!: And will you give me permission?

Anon!: Come, thou day in night, For thou wilt lie upon the wings of night Whiter than new snow upon a raven’s back.
Goodbye!: Come, day in night, because you’ll lie on the wings of night more White than snow on a raven’s back.

Anon!: This shall determine that.
Goodbye!: This will determine that.

Anon!: One heart, one bed, two bosoms, and one troth.
Goodbye!: One heart, one bed, two bosoms, and one troth.

Anon!: Shall we sound him?
Goodbye!: Shall we sound him?

Anon!: A noble ship of Venice Hath seen a grievous wreck and sufferance On most part of their fleet.
Goodbye!: A noble ship of Venice has seen a grievous wreck and sufferance on most of their fleet.

Anon!: It is a branch and parcel of mine oath, A charitable duty of my order.
Goodbye!: It’s a charitable duty of mine.

Anon!: What mean you, sir?
Goodbye!: What do you mean, sir?

Anon!: He is unqualitied with very shame.
Goodbye!: He’s unqualified with very shameful punishment.

Anon!: Be not afraid.
Goodbye!: Don’t be afraid.

Anon!: Forbear to sleep the nights, and fast the days; Compare dead happiness with living woe; Think that thy babes were sweeter than they were, And he that slew them fouler than he is.
Goodbye!: Be quiet about the nights and the days; compare happiness to living pains; think your babes were sweeter than they were—and the one who slew them fouler than he is.

Anon!: There, take it to you, trenchers, cups, and all!
Goodbye!: Take it to you, trenchers, cups, and everything!

Anon!: He shall kill two of us, and men indeed, But that’s no matter.
Goodbye!: He’ll kill two of us, and indeed men, but that’s not the case.

Anon!: What’s thy pleasure?
Goodbye!: What’s your pleasure?

Anon!: O, yes, my lord, but very idle words.
Goodbye!: Oh yes, my lord, but very idle words.

Anon!: Thou protector of this damnèd strumpet, Talk’st thou to me of “ifs”?
Goodbye!: You’re the protector of this damned strumpet, do you talk to me about “ifs”?

Anon!: Nay, lay thee down and roar, For thou hast killed the sweetest innocent That e'er did lift up eye.
Goodbye!: No, lay down and roar, because you’ve killed the sweetest innocent who ever shook the eye.

Anon!: That’s he that was Othello.
Goodbye!: That’s the one who was Othello.

Anon!: This quarry cries on havoc.
Goodbye!: This quarry is crying on the ground.

Anon!: O woeful, woeful, woeful day!
Goodbye!: Oh, sad, sad day!

Anon!: Arise, dissembler.
Goodbye!: Get up, dissembler.

Anon!: I denied you not.
Goodbye!: I didn’t deny you anything.

Anon!: Tis a subject for a sovereign to reason on, and for a sovereign’s sovereign to ride on, and for the world, familiar to us and unknown, to lay apart their particular functions and wonder at him.
Goodbye!: It’s a subject for a sovereign to be a good man, and for a sovereign to be a good man, and for the world to be a good man and wonder at him.

Anon!: She sent for you by Dromio home to dinner.
Goodbye!: She sent Dromio home to dinner for you.

Anon!: On.
Goodbye!: On.

Anon!: Ay, marry, go, I say, and fetch him hither.— Now, afore God, this reverend holy friar!
Goodbye!: Yes, go, I say, and get him here.—Now, God, this reverend holy friar!

Anon!: We’ll bury him, and then, what’s brave, what’s noble, Let’s do ’t after the high Roman fashion And make death proud to take us.
Goodbye!: We’ll bury him, and then, what’s brave, what’s noble, let’s do it after the high Roman fashion and make death proud to take us.

Anon!: Were I my father, coz, would I do this?
Goodbye!: If I were my father, coz, would I do this?

Anon!: What sayest thou, Biondello?
Goodbye!: What do you say, Biondello?

Anon!: Or if not so, then here I hit it right: Our Romeo hath not been in bed tonight.
Goodbye!: If not, then I’ll hit it right here: Romeo hasn’t been in bed tonight.

Anon!: Come, cousin, I am sure you love the gentleman.
Goodbye!: Come on, cousin, I’m sure you love the gentleman.

Anon!: Thou shalt not have him.
Goodbye!: You won’t have him.

Anon!: Tis like a demi-cannon.
Goodbye!: It’s like a demi-cannon.

Anon!: Poor soul, thy face is much abused with tears.
Goodbye!: Poor soul, your face is abused with tears.

Anon!: Adieu, good Monsieur Melancholy.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, good Monsieur Melancholy.

Anon!: I can behold no longer.
Goodbye!: I can’t see it anymore.

Anon!: The testament!
Goodbye!: The testament!

Anon!: And then, I hope, thou wilt be satisfied.
Goodbye!: And then, I hope, you’ll be satisfied.

Anon!: Tell me that.
Goodbye!: Tell me that.

Anon!: Ere the bat hath flown His cloistered flight, ere to black Hecate’s summons The shard-borne beetle with his drowsy hums Hath rung night’s yawning peal, there shall be done A deed of dreadful note.
Goodbye!: The bat has escaped his cloistered flight, and the black Hecate’s summons the shard-borne beetle with his drowsy hums will be rung up night’s

Anon!: And her sister By her is poisoned.
Goodbye!: And her sister is poisoned by her.

Anon!: Noblest of men, woo’t die?
Goodbye!: The noblest of men, don’t you die?

Anon!: Ay, ay, the cords.
Goodbye!: Yes, yes, the cords.

Anon!: These babes for Clarence weep and so do I; I for an Edward weep; so do not they.
Goodbye!: I’m Edward’s weep, and I don’t.

Anon!: Therefore stay yet.
Goodbye!: So stay for a while.

Anon!: Besides, they all are fresh.
Goodbye!: Besides, they’re all fresh.

Anon!: The cease of majesty Dies not alone, but, like a gulf, doth draw What’s near it with it.
Goodbye!: The majesty’s death isn’t alone, but, like a gulf, it’s a way to draw the majesty out of it.

Anon!: Hark!
Goodbye!: Listen!

Anon!: So rare a wondered father and a wife Makes this place paradise.
Goodbye!: This place is so rare that a curious father and wife are making this place paradise.

Anon!: In voices well divulged, free, learned, and valiant; And in dimension and the shape of nature A gracious person.
Goodbye!: In the way of voice, well spoken, free, learned, and valiant, and in the way of nature, a gracious person.

Anon!: And I pray thee now tell me, for which of my bad parts didst thou first fall in love with me?
Goodbye!: And please tell me, for which of my bad things did you fall in love with me first?

Anon!: Commend me to thy lady.
Goodbye!: Give my praises to your lady.

Anon!: Dromio, nor thou?
Goodbye!: Dromio, or you?

Anon!: I, sir, am Dromio.
Goodbye!: I, sir, am Dromio.

Anon!: Now, where’s my wife?
Goodbye!: Now, where’s my wife?

Anon!: I durst have denied that before you were so choleric.
Goodbye!: I would have denied that before you were so choleric.

Anon!: How many things by season seasoned are To their right praise and true perfection!
Goodbye!: How many things are done by season to their praise and true perfection!

Anon!: But we both obey And here give up ourselves, in the full bent, To lay our service freely at your feet To be commanded.
Goodbye!: But we both obey and give up here, in the full bent, to lay our service free at your feet and to be commanded.

Anon!: Macbeth.
Goodbye!: Macbeth.

Anon!: Good morrow, Catesby.— You may jest on, but, by the Holy Rood, I do not like these several councils, I.
Goodbye!: Good morning, Catesby.—You can’t go on, but I don’t like these several councils, I swear.

Anon!: And your reports have set the murder on.
Goodbye!: And your reports have set the murder on.

Anon!: But wherefore, villain, didst thou kill my cousin?
Goodbye!: But why did you kill my cousin?

Anon!: Thou didst usurp my place, and dost thou not Usurp the just proportion of my sorrow?
Goodbye!: You snuck my place, and don’t you snuck my sorrow in the right proportion?

Anon!: Come, Desdemona, I have but an hour Of love, of worldly matter and direction, To spend with thee.
Goodbye!: Come, Desdemona, I have only an hour to spend with you.

Anon!: In thy foul throat thou liest.
Goodbye!: You’re in your foul throat.

Anon!: I will, lady.
Goodbye!: I will, lady.

Anon!: But, look you, Cassius, The angry spot doth glow on Caesar’s brow, And all the rest look like a chidden train.
Goodbye!: But look, Cassius, the angry spot glows on Caesar’s brow, and all the rest look like a chidden train.

Anon!: I have drunk but one cup tonight, and that was craftily qualified too, and behold what innovation it makes here.
Goodbye!: I’ve drunk only one cup tonight, and that was a good one too.

Anon!: Confess!—Handkerchief!—Oh, devil!— Work on, My medicine, work!
Goodbye!: I’m working on my medicine, my work!

Anon!: Confusion’s cure lives not In these confusions.
Goodbye!: Confusion’s cure doesn’t live in these confusions.

Anon!: What drink’st thou oft, instead of homage sweet, But poisoned flattery?
Goodbye!: What drink do you drink often instead of sweet, but poisoned flattery?

Anon!: Now, by the holy mother of our Lord, The citizens are mum, say not a word.
Goodbye!: Now, by the holy mother of our Lord, the citizens are mums, don’t say a word.

Anon!: Art thou a man?
Goodbye!: Are you a man?

Anon!: And one Deformed is one of them.
Goodbye!: And one of them is Deformed.

Anon!: Write down “Master Gentleman Conrade.”—Masters, do you serve God?
Goodbye!: Write down “Master Gentleman Conrade.”—Masters, do you serve God?

Anon!: I am very glad to see you.
Goodbye!: I’m very glad to see you.

Anon!: But, tell me, where is princely Richmond now?
Goodbye!: But tell me, where is princely Richmond now?

Anon!: Let’s ha ’t, good soldier.
Goodbye!: Let’s go, good soldier.

Anon!: I found her trimming up the diadem On her dead mistress.
Goodbye!: I found her trimming up the diadem on her dead mistress.

Anon!: Thou wouldst else have made thy tale large.
Goodbye!: You would have made your story large.

Anon!: What needs this iterance, woman?
Goodbye!: What’s the need for this remark, woman?

Anon!: I cannot hide what I am.
Goodbye!: I can’t hide what I am.

Anon!: And you by land.
Goodbye!: And you’re on land.

Anon!: Unarm, Eros.
Goodbye!: Unarm, Eros.

Anon!: Why, you speak truth.
Goodbye!: You’re telling the truth.

Anon!: What can it not?
Goodbye!: What can’t I do?

Anon!: Give me some music.
Goodbye!: Give me some music.

Anon!: My tables!—Meet it is I set it down That one may smile, and smile, and be a villain.
Goodbye!: I’m going to put it down so that one can smile and smile and be a villain.

Anon!: But if thy love were ever like to mine— As sure I think did never man love so— How many actions most ridiculous Hast thou been drawn to by thy fantasy?
Goodbye!: But if your love were like mine ever—I think never man loved so much—how many ridiculous actions have you been drawn to by your fantasy?

Anon!: Dost thou forget From what a torment I did free thee?
Goodbye!: Do you forget what a torment I freed you of?

Anon!: Who bids thee call?
Goodbye!: Who asked you to call me?

Anon!: This is the man.
Goodbye!: This is the man.

Anon!: Bondage is hoarse, and may not speak aloud, Else would I tear the cave where Echo lies, And make her airy tongue more hoarse than mine, With repetition of “My Romeo!” It is my soul that calls upon my name.
Goodbye!: I’d tear the cave where Echo lies, and make her airy tongue more hoarse than mine, with the repetition of “My Romeo!” I’m the soul who calls upon my name.

Anon!: No, forbear.
Goodbye!: No, don’t be afraid.

Anon!: Down with the Montagues!
Goodbye!: Down with the Montagues!

Anon!: O fair Katherine, if you will love me soundly with your French heart, I will be glad to hear you confess it brokenly with your English tongue.
Goodbye!: Oh, fair Katherine, if you love me in a way that’s a good way to speak, I’ll be glad to hear you confess it in a broken English language.

Anon!: No farther than the Tower, and, as I guess, Upon the like devotion as yourselves, To gratulate the gentle princes there.
Goodbye!: No farther than the Tower, and I guess you’ll be glad to the gentle princes there.

Anon!: Ay, if I know the letters and the language.
Goodbye!: Yes, if I know the letters and the language.

Anon!: The Count is neither sad, nor sick, nor merry, nor well, but civil count, civil as an orange, and something of that jealous complexion.
Goodbye!: The Count is neither sad, sick, nor merry, nor well, but civil count is as civil as an orange, and it’s something of that jealousy.

Anon!: And here my mistress.
Goodbye!: And here’s my mistress.

Anon!: Dispatch.
Goodbye!: Discord.

Anon!: There lies the man, slain by young Romeo, That slew thy kinsman, brave Mercutio.
Goodbye!: There’s the man, killed by young Romeo, who killed your kinsman, brave Mercutio.

Anon!: And so the lion vanished.
Goodbye!: And so the lion disappeared.

Anon!: Varrus and Claudio!
Goodbye!: Varrus and Claudio!

Anon!: For Pyramus therein doth kill himself.
Goodbye!: Pyramus is killing himself.

Anon!: Cesario is your servant’s name, fair princess.
Goodbye!: Cesario is your servant’s name, fair princess.

Anon!: He is in heaven, where thou shalt never come.
Goodbye!: He’s in heaven, where you’ll never come.

Anon!: Come, come away.
Goodbye!: Come on, come away.

Anon!: As long as heaven and nature lengthens it.
Goodbye!: As long as heaven and nature extend it.

Anon!: Lo, now, lo!
Goodbye!: Oh, now, lo!

Anon!: Why, for that too.
Goodbye!: Well, for that too.

Anon!: Nay, how now, where are you?
Goodbye!: No, where are you now?

Anon!: How doth the lady?
Goodbye!: How is the lady?

Anon!: When they do choose, They have the wisdom by their wit to lose.
Goodbye!: When they choose, they have the wisdom to lose.

Anon!: If he could right himself with quarreling, Some of us would lie low.
Goodbye!: If he could fight himself, some of us would lie low.

Anon!: Call Philostrate.
Goodbye!: Call Philostrate.

Anon!: If justice cannot tame you, she shall ne'er weigh more reasons in her balance.
Goodbye!: If justice doesn’t help you, she won’t be able to weigh more reasons in her balance.

Anon!: Chop off his head.
Goodbye!: Chop off his head.

Anon!: Mistress, what cheer?
Goodbye!: Mistress, what cheer?

Anon!: If thou doubt it, thou mayst slide from my shoulder to my heel with no greater a run but my head and my neck.
Goodbye!: If you doubt it, you can go from my shoulder to my heel without running more than my head and my neck.

Anon!: You shall, Mark Antony.
Goodbye!: You will, Mark Antony.

Anon!: Counterfeit, I assure you.
Goodbye!: Counterfeit, I assure you.

Anon!: Why, I am glad on ’t.
Goodbye!: Well, I’m glad about it.

Anon!: What, with the case of eyes?
Goodbye!: What, with the case of eyes?

Anon!: Oh, look!
Goodbye!: Oh, look!

Anon!: What say you?
Goodbye!: What do you say?

Anon!: Thou dost not wish more help from England, coz?
Goodbye!: You don’t want to get help from England, coz?

Anon!: The one of them imports The death of Cassio to be undertook By Roderigo.
Goodbye!: Roderigo’s death will be the one of them.

Anon!: Hold, Toby!
Goodbye!: Stop, Toby!

Anon!: To the health of our general!
Goodbye!: To the health of our general!

Anon!: And their tongues rot That speak against us!
Goodbye!: And their tongues rot, which speak against us!

Anon!: Bring thou the master to the citadel.
Goodbye!: Bring the master to the citadel.

Anon!: Her love to both Would each to other and all loves to both Draw after her.
Goodbye!: She would love both of us, and she would love both of us.

Anon!: Come, Sir Andrew, there’s no remedy.
Goodbye!: Come on, Sir Andrew, there’s no remedy.

Anon!: Alas, poor caitiff!
Goodbye!: Oh, poor caitiff!

Anon!: Why, she would hang on him As if increase of appetite had grown By what it fed on, and yet, within a month— Let me not think on ’t.
Goodbye!: She would hang on him like if it had grown by what it fed on, and yet within a month— Don’t think about it.

Anon!: The fearful passage of their death-marked love And the continuance of their parents' rage, Which, but their children’s end, naught could remove, Is now the two hours' traffic of our stage— The which, if you with patient ears attend, What here shall miss, our toil shall strive to mend.
Goodbye!: The fearful passage of their death-marked love and the continuance of their parents’ rage, which, but their children’s end, could remove, is now the two hours' traffic of our stage—the one that,

Anon!: Our whole city is much bound to him.
Goodbye!: Our whole city is bound to him.

Anon!: I have been dear to him, lad, some two thousand strong, or so.
Goodbye!: I’ve been dear to him for a while, lad, about two thousand strong.

Anon!: Saw you the king today, my lord of Derby?
Goodbye!: Did you see the king today, my lord of Derby?

Anon!: If that same demon that hath gulled thee thus Should with his lion gait walk the whole world, He might return to vasty Tartar back And tell the legions “I can never win A soul so easy as that Englishman’s.” Oh, how hast thou with jealousy infected The sweetness of affiance!
Goodbye!: If the demon who gulled you so badly would walk the whole world, he could return to the vast Tartar and tell the legions “I can never win a soul as easy as that Englishman’s.” Oh

Anon!: Leave me and do the thing I bid thee do.
Goodbye!: Leave me and do what I asked you to do.

Anon!: Away!
Goodbye!: Go away!

Anon!: Good Volumnius, Thou know’st that we two went to school together.
Goodbye!: Good Volumnius, you know that we both went to school together.

Anon!: Fie, thou dishonest Satan!
Goodbye!: You unhonest Satan!

Anon!: You shall have wine enough, my lord, anon.
Goodbye!: You’ll have enough wine, my lord.

Anon!: Now, for my life, she’s wandering to the Tower, On pure heart’s love, to greet the tender prince.— Daughter, well met.
Goodbye!: Now, for my life, she’s wandering to the Tower, on pure heart’s love, to greet the tender prince.— Daughter, well met.

Anon!: Since I have your good leave to go away, I will make haste.
Goodbye!: Since I have your good permission to go away, I’ll hurry.

Anon!: Give me leave To speak my mind, and I will through and through Cleanse the foul body of th' infected world, If they will patiently receive my medicine.
Goodbye!: Give me permission to speak my mind, and I’ll cleanse the body of the infected world if they receive my medicine.

Anon!: Are you not good?
Goodbye!: Aren’t you good?

Anon!: I do obey thee till I give thee bail.
Goodbye!: I’ll obey you until I’m free.

Anon!: And so return to you, and nothing else?
Goodbye!: And then return to you, and nothing else?

Anon!: To a nunnery, go.
Goodbye!: Go to a nunnery.

Anon!: What’s here?
Goodbye!: What’s this?

Anon!: What means that bloody knife?
Goodbye!: What’s that bloody knife?

Anon!: Tis double wrong to truant with your bed And let her read it in thy looks at board.
Goodbye!: It’s double wrong to truant with your bed and let her read it in your eyes.

Anon!: Therefore no more but to the matter.
Goodbye!: So let’s go to the matter.

Anon!: But now behold, In the quick forge and workinghouse of thought, How London doth pour out her citizens.
Goodbye!: But now you can see, in the sand of thought, how London is poured out of her citizens.

Anon!: Men that hazard all Do it in hope of fair advantages.
Goodbye!: Men who risk all do it in hope of good luck.

Anon!: You are their heir, you sit upon their throne, The blood and courage that renownèd them Runs in your veins; and my thrice-puissant liege Is in the very May-morn of his youth, Ripe for exploits and mighty enterprises.
Goodbye!: You are their heir, you sit on their throne, and the courage and blood that redeemed them are running in your veins.

Anon!: I do beseech you— Chiefly that I might set it in my prayers— What is your name?
Goodbye!: I beg you—that I could put it in my prayers—What’s your name?

Anon!: Thy thoughts I cleave to.
Goodbye!: I’m cleaving to your thoughts.

Anon!: But by immortal providence, she’s mine.
Goodbye!: But by immortality, she’s mine.

Anon!: But I will write again to Mantua, And keep her at my cell till Romeo come.
Goodbye!: But I’ll write again to Mantua, and keep her in my cell until Romeo comes.

Anon!: God keep me so.—Our heralds go with him.
Goodbye!: God keep me safe.—Our heroes go with him.

Anon!: I dare lay any money ’twill be nothing yet.
Goodbye!: I’d rather put any money in the way of it.

Anon!: Most like a gentleman.
Goodbye!: It’s almost like a gentleman.

Anon!: Ere I learn love, I’ll practice to obey.
Goodbye!: I’ll obey.

Anon!: Ay, the heads of the maids, or their maidenheads.
Goodbye!: Yes, the heads of the maids, or their maidenheads.

Anon!: Wilt thou provoke me?
Goodbye!: Do you want to provoke me?

Anon!: And what of him?
Goodbye!: And what about him?

Anon!: O rude unthankfulness!
Goodbye!: Oh, rude unthankfulness!

Anon!: Now, Catesby, what says your lord to my request?
Goodbye!: Now, Catesby, what does your lord say to my request?

Anon!: The dearest ring in Venice will I give you, And find it out by proclamation.
Goodbye!: I’ll give you the dearest ring in Venice, and I’ll find it by proclamation.

Anon!: But that my Lady Beatrice should know me, and not know me!
Goodbye!: But I’m sure my Lady Beatrice should know me, and not know me!

Anon!: You know sometimes he walks four hours together Here in the lobby.
Goodbye!: You know he sometimes walks here in the lobby for four hours.

Anon!: Thou speak’st wiser than thou art ware of.
Goodbye!: You’re wiser than you are aware of.

Anon!: Be valiant, and speed well.
Goodbye!: Be brave and speedy.

Anon!: It pleases your Worship to say so, but we are the poor duke’s officers.
Goodbye!: It’s your Worship to say that, but we’re the poor duke’s officers.

Anon!: I cry you mercy, uncle.—By your Grace’s pardon.
Goodbye!: I’m crying for mercy, uncle.—Thank you for your Grace’s pardon.

Anon!: I fear it, I promise you.
Goodbye!: I’m afraid, I promise you.

Anon!: You have served me well, And kings have been your fellows.
Goodbye!: You’ve served me well, and kings have been your fellows.

Anon!: What, my old worshipful old master?
Goodbye!: What, my worshipful old master?

Anon!: Where is he now?
Goodbye!: Where is he now?

Anon!: Go seek him out, speak fair, and bring the body Into the chapel.
Goodbye!: Go find him out, speak fair, and bring the body into the chapel.

Anon!: I shall never see my gold again.
Goodbye!: I’ll never see my gold again.

Anon!: Bianca’s love Made me exchange my state with Tranio, While he did bear my countenance in the town, And happily I have arrivèd at the last Unto the wishèd haven of my bliss.
Goodbye!: Bianca’s love made me exchange my state with Tranio while he was in the town, and I’ve stayed happily in the last place to the wishful paradise of my bliss.

Anon!: Gramercies, Tranio, well dost thou advise.
Goodbye!: Gramercies, Tranio, you’re good at helping.

Anon!: In your own kingdom, sir.
Goodbye!: In your own kingdom, sir.

Anon!: How now!
Goodbye!: What’s going on?

Anon!: Till Birnam Wood remove to Dunsinane I cannot taint with fear.
Goodbye!: I can’t stop tainting with fear until Birnam Wood leaves Dunsinane.

Anon!: For the intent and purpose of the law Hath full relation to the penalty, Which here appeareth due upon the bond.
Goodbye!: The law’s intent and purpose is to protect the penalty, which is due on the bond.

Anon!: A beast, no more.
Goodbye!: A beast, no more.

Anon!: Ay, go your ways, go your ways.
Goodbye!: Yes, go on, go on.

Anon!: To take ’t again perforce— Monster ingratitude!
Goodbye!: To take it back again— Monster ingratitude!

Anon!: Thy face is mine, and thou hast slandered it.
Goodbye!: Your face is mine, and you’ve slapped it.

Anon!: Be not you ashamed to show, he’ll not shame to tell you what it means.
Goodbye!: Don’t be ashamed to show, he won’t be ashamed to tell you what it means.

Anon!: I’ll have my bond.
Goodbye!: I’ll get my contract.

Anon!: Woo’t fight?
Goodbye!: Why do you want to fight?

Anon!: Come, come, away.
Goodbye!: Come, come, go away.

Anon!: Mechanic slaves With greasy aprons, rules, and hammers shall Uplift us to the view.
Goodbye!: Mechanic slaves with greasy aprons, rules, and hammers will lift us to the view.

Anon!: Look, with what courteous action It waves you to a more removèd ground.
Goodbye!: Look, with what kind of action it takes you to get to a more reclaimed ground.

Anon!: For when mine hours Were nice and lucky, men did ransom lives Of me for jests; but now I’ll set my teeth And send to darkness all that stop me.
Goodbye!: When my hours were nice and lucky, men ransom me for stealing my money, but now I’ll put my teeth on and send all the things that stop me.

Anon!: How much low peasantry would then be gleaned From the true seed of honor!
Goodbye!: How much low-paying would be gleaned from the true seed of honor?

Anon!: That is he.
Goodbye!: That’s him.

Anon!: You may as well say, that’s a valiant flea that dare eat his breakfast on the lip of a lion.
Goodbye!: You may as well say that’s a valiant flea who dares to eat his breakfast on the lip of a lion.

Anon!: What a night’s this!
Goodbye!: What a night this is!

Anon!: Out and alas, that was my lady’s voice.
Goodbye!: Oh, that was my lady’s voice.

Anon!: Nay, but swear ’t.
Goodbye!: No, but swear it.

Anon!: There is a river in Macedon, and there is also, moreover, a river at Monmouth.
Goodbye!: There’s a river in Macedon, and there’s a river in Monmouth.

Anon!: Heaven and yourself Had part in this fair maid.
Goodbye!: Heaven and you had part in this handsome maid.

Anon!: Thou dost thy office fairly.
Goodbye!: You’re doing your job fairly.

Anon!: Thou liest, thou shag-haired villain!
Goodbye!: You lie, you shag-haired villain!

Anon!: The storm is up and all is on the hazard.
Goodbye!: The storm is up and everything is on the way.

Anon!: Have at thee, coward!
Goodbye!: Have a good day, coward!

Anon!: Your Majesty says very true.
Goodbye!: Your Majesty is very true.

Anon!: Why are our bodies soft and weak and smooth, Unapt to toil and trouble in the world, But that our soft conditions and our hearts Should well agree with our external parts?
Goodbye!: Why are our bodies soft and weak and smooth, unsuited to toil and trouble in the world, but that our soft conditions and our hearts should be well aligned with our external parts?

Anon!: So you may put a man in your belly.
Goodbye!: So you can put a man in your belly.

Anon!: O God, did Romeo’s hand shed Tybalt’s blood?
Goodbye!: Oh God, did Romeo’s hand shed Tybalt’s blood?

Anon!: If this be so, why blame you me to love you?
Goodbye!: If that’s true, why do you blame me for love you?

Anon!: Lo, where he comes!
Goodbye!: Where he comes!

Anon!: Tell the hot duke that Lear— No, but not yet.
Goodbye!: Tell the hot duke that Lear— No, but not yet.

Anon!: Oh, by this count I shall be much in years Ere I again behold my Romeo.
Goodbye!: Oh, by this count I’ll be much older than I’ve been before.

Anon!: Go, prick thy face and over-red thy fear, Thou lily-livered boy.
Goodbye!: Go, prick your face and prick your fear over-red, you lily-livered boy.

Anon!: Whither?
Goodbye!: Where?

Anon!: But now, my lord, what say you to my suit?
Goodbye!: But what do you say to my suit?

Anon!: Lady, were you her bedfellow last night?
Goodbye!: Lady, were you asleep last night?

Anon!: And let the wise man fly.
Goodbye!: And let the wise man fly.

Anon!: Now, were not I a little pot and soon hot, my very lips might freeze to my teeth, my tongue to the roof of my mouth, my heart in my belly, ere I should come by a fire to thaw me.
Goodbye!: Now, if I were a little pot and soon hot, my lips would freeze to my teeth, my tongue to the roof of my mouth, my heart in my belly, if I were to come by a fire to

Anon!: What, thou speak’st drowsily?
Goodbye!: What, are you talking drowsy?

Anon!: You’ll cry for this, minion, if I beat the door down.
Goodbye!: You’ll cry for this if I beat the door down.

Anon!: Had she been true, If heaven would make me such another world Of one entire and perfect chrysolite, I’d not have sold her for it.
Goodbye!: If she were true, I wouldn’t have sold her for it.

Anon!: For so thou art.
Goodbye!: You are.

Anon!: I must hence to wait.
Goodbye!: I have to go wait.

Anon!: Give me your hand.
Goodbye!: Give me your hand.

Anon!: The valiant never taste of death but once.
Goodbye!: The valiant taste of death never comes only once.

Anon!: But repetition of what thou hast marred.
Goodbye!: But you’ve repeated what you’ve ruined.

Anon!: Where’s the Queen?
Goodbye!: Where’s the Queen?

Anon!: God, the best maker of all marriages, Combine your hearts in one, your realms in one.
Goodbye!: God, the best marriage maker, combine your hearts in one, your realms in one.

Anon!: Come, Friar Francis, be brief, only to the plain form of marriage, and you shall recount their particular duties afterwards.
Goodbye!: Come, Friar Francis, be brief, only to the plain form of marriage, and you’ll tell us their particular duties later.

Anon!: Then hie you hence to Friar Lawrence’s cell.
Goodbye!: Then go to Friar Lawrence’s cell.

Anon!: All that served Brutus, I will entertain them.
Goodbye!: I’ll entertain all who served Brutus.

Anon!: So the gods preserve thee!
Goodbye!: The gods will keep you!

Anon!: See where he looks out of the window.
Goodbye!: Look at him.

Anon!: What, art mad?
Goodbye!: What, is it insane?

Anon!: And the queen too, and that presently.
Goodbye!: And the queen too, and that is now.

Anon!: Read the will.
Goodbye!: Read the will.

Anon!: I can swim like a duck, I’ll be sworn.
Goodbye!: I can swim like a duck, I’ll be sworn.

Anon!: I prithee let me have it.
Goodbye!: Please let me have it.

Anon!: What, I, my lord?
Goodbye!: What, my lord?

Anon!: Thus far can I praise him: he is of a noble strain, of approved valor, and confirmed honesty.
Goodbye!: He’s a noble man, a good man, and a good man.

Anon!: Iago.
Goodbye!: Iago.

Anon!: Believe me, sir, It carries a brave form.
Goodbye!: Believe me, sir, it’s a brave man.

Anon!: Kind and dear princess!
Goodbye!: Kind and dear princess!

Anon!: Clarence still breathes; Edward still lives and reigns.
Goodbye!: Clarence still breathes, Edward still lives and reigns.

Anon!: You, constable, are to present the Prince’s own person.
Goodbye!: You, constable, are to present the Prince’s own person.

Anon!: You hear the suit.
Goodbye!: You hear the suit.

Anon!: Yet let me weep for such a feeling loss.
Goodbye!: But let me cry for such a loss.

Anon!: A greater gift than that I’ll give my cousin.
Goodbye!: I’ll give my cousin a greater gift than I’ll give.

Anon!: Sorrow breaks seasons and reposing hours, Makes the night morning, and the noontide night.
Goodbye!: Sorrow breaks the seasons and the hours of sleep, makes the night morning, and the noontide night.

Anon!: Yea, Signior, and depart when you bid me.
Goodbye!: Yes, sir, and leave when you ask me.

Anon!: Tranio, I saw her coral lips to move And with her breath she did perfume the air.
Goodbye!: Tranio, I saw her lips in coral and perfumed the air with her breath.

Anon!: Shut up your doors, my lord.
Goodbye!: Shut up your doors, my lord.

Anon!: Hast stolen it from her?
Goodbye!: Has she stolen it from her?

Anon!: Keep your purse.
Goodbye!: Keep your purse.

Anon!: I’ll not be far from you.
Goodbye!: I’ll be away from you.

Anon!: Madam?
Goodbye!: Madam?

Anon!: Better be with the dead, Whom we, to gain our peace, have sent to peace, Than on the torture of the mind to lie In restless ecstasy.
Goodbye!: We’d better be with the dead, who we sent to peace to get our peace than to lie in a restless ecstasy.

Anon!: Fare you well, sir.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, sir.

Anon!: Prithee, away.
Goodbye!: Go away.

Anon!: The saddler had it, sir; I kept it not.
Goodbye!: The saddler had it, sir, but I didn’t keep it.

Anon!: What, I will be jovial.
Goodbye!: I’ll be jovial.

Anon!: The starry welkin cover thou anon With drooping fog as black as Acheron, And lead these testy rivals so astray As one come not within another’s way.
Goodbye!: The starry welkin cover you with drooping fog as black as Acheron, and lead these testy rivals so astray as one doesn’t come within another’s way.

Anon!: Hold, sir, here’s my purse.
Goodbye!: Hold on, sir, here’s my purse.

Anon!: We now are near his cell.
Goodbye!: We’re near his cell now.

Anon!: The great rage, You see, is killed in him.
Goodbye!: The great rage is killed in him, you see.

Anon!: I did very well note him.
Goodbye!: I did very well note him.

Anon!: So, adieu.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: Is he well?
Goodbye!: Is he well?

Anon!: I am sorry thou wilt leave my father so.
Goodbye!: I’m sorry you’ll leave my father like that.

Anon!: No, truly.
Goodbye!: No, really.

Anon!: If he have the condition of a saint and the complexion of a devil, I had rather he should shrive me than wive me.
Goodbye!: If he has the condition of a saint and the complexion of a devil, I’d rather he shrive me than wive me.

Anon!: Your looks are pale and wild, and do import Some misadventure.
Goodbye!: Your looks are pale and wild, and you’re causing some misadventure.

Anon!: There is some ill a-brewing towards my rest, For I did dream of money bags tonight.
Goodbye!: I’m feeling some bad news about my sleep, because I dreamed of money bags tonight.

Anon!: Romeo shall thank thee, daughter, for us both.
Goodbye!: Romeo will thank you, daughter, for both of us.

Anon!: This fellow is wise enough to play the fool, And to do that well craves a kind of wit.
Goodbye!: This man is wise enough to play the fool, and to do that is a good thing.

Anon!: What is the matter, my lord?
Goodbye!: What’s the matter, my lord?

Anon!: Out, tawny Tartar, out!
Goodbye!: Out, tawny Tartar, out!

Anon!: Nor I neither.
Goodbye!: I don’t.

Anon!: I' faith, sir, you shall never need to fear.
Goodbye!: I’m sure you’ll never have to worry about it.

Anon!: I hope so, Lepidus.
Goodbye!: I hope so, Lepidus.

Anon!: He knows I know him well.
Goodbye!: He knows I know him well.

Anon!: Who now the price of his dear blood doth owe?
Goodbye!: Who owes the price of his dear blood now?

Anon!: But were I not the better part made mercy, I should not seek an absent argument Of my revenge, thou present.
Goodbye!: But if I were not the better part of the world, I wouldn’t seek revenge, you present.

Anon!: I do not think ’t.
Goodbye!: I don’t think so.

Anon!: I will go lose myself And wander up and down to view the city.
Goodbye!: I’ll go lose myself and wander up and down to see the city.

Anon!: Farewell, dear Father.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, dear Father.

Anon!: So all hail, Macbeth and Banquo!
Goodbye!: Oh, all hail, Macbeth and Banquo!

Anon!: What, worse and worse?— With leave, Bassanio, I am half yourself, And I must freely have the half of anything That this same paper brings you.
Goodbye!: What, worse and worse?—With permission, Bassanio, I’m half yourself, and I have to have the half of everything that this paper brings you.

Anon!: Your lord does know my mind.
Goodbye!: Your lord knows what I’m thinking.

Anon!: In spite of your heart, I think.
Goodbye!: I think you’re still in your heart.

Anon!: And yesternight, at supper, You suddenly arose and walked about, Musing and sighing, with your arms across, And when I asked you what the matter was, You stared upon me with ungentle looks.
Goodbye!: And yesternight, at supper, you suddenly arose and walked around, sighing and musing, with your arms across.

Anon!: Which is the lady I must seize upon?
Goodbye!: Which is the lady I must marry?

Anon!: Farewell, my coz.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, my coz.

Anon!: Sword” is an oath, and oaths must have their course.
Goodbye!: Sword” is an oath, and oaths must be made.

Anon!: What, Octavia?
Goodbye!: What, Octavia?

Anon!: I thank you, valiant Cassio.
Goodbye!: Thank you, valiant Cassio.

Anon!: No, my good lord.
Goodbye!: No, my good lord.

Anon!: What a sigh is there!
Goodbye!: What a sigh!

Anon!: Tis a strange serpent.
Goodbye!: It’s a strange serpent.

Anon!: What will this do?
Goodbye!: What will this do?

Anon!: Thy husband.
Goodbye!: Your husband.

Anon!: This tyrant, whose sole name blisters our tongues, Was once thought honest.
Goodbye!: This tyrant, whose sole name is a blistering tongue, was once thought to be honest.

Anon!: Not a whit, Touchstone.
Goodbye!: Not a whit, Touchstone.

Anon!: And sayst thou yet that exile is not death?
Goodbye!: And you say that exile is not death?

Anon!: I know not at whose suit he is arrested well, But he’s in a suit of buff which ’rested him; that can I tell.
Goodbye!: I don’t know who arrested him well, but he’s in a suit of sanity that reprimanded him.

Anon!: O, cry your mercy, sir.—        Tom’s a-cold.
Goodbye!: Oh, cry your mercy, sir.—Tom’s a cold.

Anon!: Where is Lysander and fair Hermia?
Goodbye!: Where are Lysander and fair Hermia?

Anon!: The day will come that thou shalt wish for me To help thee curse that poisonous bunch-backed toad.
Goodbye!: The day will come when you’ll wish to help you curse that poisonous toad.

Anon!: But yet for all that, an if she did not hate him deadly, she would love him dearly.
Goodbye!: But for all that, if she didn’t hate him deadlyly, she would love him very much.

Anon!: They are entirely welcome.
Goodbye!: They’re absolutely welcome.

Anon!: Trust to ’t, bethink you.
Goodbye!: Trust me, think about it.

Anon!: The powers of the kingdom approach apace.
Goodbye!: The kingdom’s powers are approaching.

Anon!: I will weep.
Goodbye!: I’ll cry.

Anon!: Tell him I am prompt To lay my crown at ’s feet, and there to kneel.
Goodbye!: Tell him I’m ready to lay my crown at the feet and kneel there.

Anon!: Speak.
Goodbye!: Speak.

Anon!: Give me any gage of thine, and I will wear it in my bonnet.
Goodbye!: Give me any gage of yours, and I’ll wear it in my bonnet.

Anon!: What can be avoided Whose end is purposed by the mighty gods?
Goodbye!: What can be avoided if the gods want to end the battle?

Anon!: O thou bloody prison, Fatal and ominous to noble peers!
Goodbye!: Oh, you bloody prison, ominous and fatal to noble peers!

Anon!: Right true it is your son Lucentio here Doth love my daughter and she loveth him, Or both dissemble deeply their affections.
Goodbye!: It’s true that your son Lucentio here loves my daughter, and she loves him, or both of them dissemble their affections deeply.

Anon!: Carthage?
Goodbye!: Carthage?

Anon!: She’s a beagle, true-bred, and one that adores me.
Goodbye!: She’s a beagle, a true-bred, and adores me.

Anon!: A simple countryman that brought her figs.
Goodbye!: A simple countryman who brought her figs.

Anon!: Shall I be frighted when a madman stares?
Goodbye!: Should I be scolded when a madman stares?

Anon!: As easy mayst thou the intrenchant air With thy keen sword impress as make me bleed.
Goodbye!: You can be as sane as you can be with your sword to make me bleed.

Anon!: Hold, sir, or I’ll throw your dagger o'er the house.
Goodbye!: Hold on, sir, or I’ll throw your dagger out of the house.

Anon!: That is the chain, sir, which you had of me.
Goodbye!: That’s the chain you had from me, sir.

Anon!: You would seem to know my stops.
Goodbye!: You’d be surprised to see my stops.

Anon!: Some say the lark makes sweet division.
Goodbye!: Some say the lark makes sweet division.

Anon!: Nor will you not tell me who you are?
Goodbye!: And you won’t tell me who you are?

Anon!: Dost thou think I care for a satire or an epigram?
Goodbye!: Do you think I’m looking for a satire or an epigram?

Anon!: It provokes the desire, but it takes away the performance.
Goodbye!: It’s a good idea, but it’s a bad idea to perform.

Anon!: And of women.
Goodbye!: And of women.

Anon!: Then must the Jew be merciful.
Goodbye!: Then the Jew must be merciful.

Anon!: The Count Claudio shall marry the daughter of Leonato.
Goodbye!: The Count Claudio will marry Leonato’s daughter.

Anon!: Confusion now hath made his masterpiece.
Goodbye!: He’s now making a mistake.

Anon!: I will do this, if you can bring it to any opportunity.
Goodbye!: I’ll do this if you can.

Anon!: You must have patience, madam.
Goodbye!: You have to be patient, madam.

Anon!: To one of your receiving Enough is shown.
Goodbye!: You’ll see enough to get to one of your guests.

Anon!: Very ill, too.
Goodbye!: Very sick, too.

Anon!: Bear him away.
Goodbye!: Keep him away.

Anon!: Why did he so?
Goodbye!: Why did he do that?

Anon!: I find not Myself disposed to sleep.
Goodbye!: I’m not sleepy.

Anon!: She hath good leave.
Goodbye!: She’s good enough to leave.

Anon!: Good madam.
Goodbye!: Good madam.

Anon!: I am their father’s mother.
Goodbye!: I’m their father’s mother.

Anon!: She is not worth thee, then.
Goodbye!: She’s not worth you, then.

Anon!: Nothing but songs of death.
Goodbye!: Nothing but death songs.

Anon!: My affections Are then most humble.
Goodbye!: I’m humble then.

Anon!: To have no man come over me!
Goodbye!: To have no man come over me!

Anon!: And, Kate, when France is mine and I am yours, then yours is France and you are mine.
Goodbye!: And Kate, when France is mine and I’m yours, then France is yours and you are mine.

Anon!: If then that friend demand why Brutus rose against Caesar, this is my answer: not that I loved Caesar less, but that I loved Rome more.
Goodbye!: If that friend asks why Brutus rose against Caesar, this is my answer: not that I loved Caesar less, but that I loved Rome more.

Anon!: Tis now but four o'clock.
Goodbye!: It’s only four o'clock now.

Anon!: Then like a Roman bear the truth I tell.
Goodbye!: Then bear the truth I tell you like a Roman.

Anon!: I must another way To fetch a ladder, by the which your love Must climb a bird’s nest soon when it is dark.
Goodbye!: I have to find another way to get a ladder, by which your love must climb a bird’s nest soon when it’s dark.

Anon!: He is, my lord, and safe in Leicester town, Whither, if it please you, we may now withdraw us.
Goodbye!: He is safe in Leicester, my lord, and if you want, we can now withdraw from the town.

Anon!: I thank you, sir.
Goodbye!: Thank you, sir.

Anon!: But, I’ll warrant you, when I say so, she looks as pale as any clout in the versal world.
Goodbye!: But I’ll tell you, when I say that, she looks as pale as any other clout in the versal world.

Anon!: Say, how grows it due?
Goodbye!: What’s the cost?

Anon!: Brutus hath rived my heart.
Goodbye!: Brutus has rubbed my heart.

Anon!: No, not so, villain, thou beliest thyself.
Goodbye!: No, not so, villain, you’re the one who’s cheating yourself.

Anon!: Fie upon thee!
Goodbye!: Go on!

Anon!: Let every soldier hew him down a bough And bear ’t before him.
Goodbye!: Every soldier should hew him down a bough and bear it before him.

Anon!: Shall I attend your Grace?
Goodbye!: Shall I attend your Grace?

Anon!: But sadly, tell me who.
Goodbye!: But tell me who.

Anon!: Have you importuned him by any means?
Goodbye!: Have you imported him by any means?

Anon!: Oh, she will sing the savageness out of a bear!
Goodbye!: Oh, she’ll sing the savageness of a bear!

Anon!: Why, then, ’tis none to you, for there is nothing either good or bad, but thinking makes it so.
Goodbye!: Well, then, it’s no good to you, because there’s nothing good or bad, but thinking makes it so.

Anon!: You need not fear, lady, the having any of these lords.
Goodbye!: You don’t need to worry about any of these lords, lady.

Anon!: Either thou, Macbeth, Or else my sword with an unbattered edge I sheathe again undeeded.
Goodbye!: Either you, Macbeth, or I’ll shave my sword with an unbattered edge again and again.

Anon!: This you should pity rather than despise.
Goodbye!: You should pity this, not be ashamed of it.

Anon!: Winter garments must be lined, So must slender Rosalind.
Goodbye!: Winter clothes must be lined, and slender Rosalind must be lined.

Anon!: Stay, on thy peril.
Goodbye!: Stay on your danger.

Anon!: You must awhile be patient.
Goodbye!: You have to be patient for a while.

Anon!: Yes, by Saint Patrick, but there is, Horatio, And much offense too.
Goodbye!: Yes, by Saint Patrick, but there is, Horatio, and much offense too.

Anon!: Report is changeable.
Goodbye!: Report is a changeable one.

Anon!: If he ask for me, I am ill and gone to bed.
Goodbye!: If he asks for me, I’ll be sick and go to bed.

Anon!: Provoke not battle Till we have done at sea.
Goodbye!: Don’t fight until we’ve finished at sea.

Anon!: The what?
Goodbye!: What?

Anon!: Mark, King of Scotland, mark: No sooner justice had, with valor armed, Compelled these skipping kerns to trust their heels, But the Norweyan lord, surveying vantage, With furbished arms and new supplies of men, Began a fresh assault.
Goodbye!: Mark, King of Scotland, mark: No sooner justice had forced these skipping kerns to trust their heels, but the Norweyan lord, who was snatching vantage, with furbished

Anon!: Under love’s heavy burden do I sink.
Goodbye!: I sink under love’s heavy burden.

Anon!: What, art thou drawn among these heartless hinds?
Goodbye!: What, are you drawn from these heartless men?

Anon!: The red plague rid you For learning me your language!
Goodbye!: The plague has rid you of learning me your language!

Anon!: Do not yourself such wrong, who are in this Relieved but not betrayed.
Goodbye!: Don’t do yourself such a wrong, who are in this ruined but not betrayed.

Anon!: When thou dost ask me blessing, I’ll kneel down And ask of thee forgiveness.
Goodbye!: When you ask me to give me blessing, I’ll kneel down and ask you forgiveness.

Anon!: Fetch me this herb, and be thou here again Ere the leviathan can swim a league.
Goodbye!: Get me this herb, and be here again, if the leviathan can swim in a league.

Anon!: O sirs, consider: they that set you on To do this deed will hate you for the deed.
Goodbye!: Oh, sirs, consider: those who set you up to do this deed will hate you for the deed.

Anon!: But hollow men, like horses hot at hand, Make gallant show and promise of their mettle.
Goodbye!: But hollow men, like horses at hand, make gallant promises of their mettle.

Anon!: Tis true.
Goodbye!: That’s true.

Anon!: So thrive my soul— A thousand times good night!
Goodbye!: I’m so happy, my soul— A thousand times good night!

Anon!: Your lady, sir, your lady.
Goodbye!: Your lady, sir, your lady.

Anon!: He did appoint so.
Goodbye!: He did that.
