Anon!: You shall have leave.
Goodbye!: You’ll have to leave.

Anon!: By Janus, I think no.
Goodbye!: By Janus, I don’t think so.

Anon!: How quickly the wrong side may be turned outward!
Goodbye!: How quickly the wrong side can be turned outward!

Anon!: I’ll send to one in Mantua, Where that same banished runagate doth live, Shall give him such an unaccustomed dram That he shall soon keep Tybalt company.
Goodbye!: I’ll send a man to Mantua, where the banished runagate is alive, and he’ll have a dram that he’ll keep Tybalt in the works soon.

Anon!: Ay, my liege, so please you give us leave.
Goodbye!: Yes, my liege, please let us know.

Anon!: My soul is full of sorrow.
Goodbye!: My soul is full of sorrow.

Anon!: Alack, sir, I am sand-blind.
Goodbye!: Oh, sir, I’m sand-blind.

Anon!: There’s no true drop of blood in him to be truly touched with love.
Goodbye!: There’s no true drop of blood in him to be touched with love.

Anon!: Gave it a judge’s clerk!
Goodbye!: Give it to a judge’s clerk!

Anon!: Oh, a thousand thousand times—and then of so gentle a condition!
Goodbye!: Oh, a thousand thousand times—and then that’s so gentle!

Anon!: I saw him once.
Goodbye!: I saw him once.

Anon!: This diamond he greets your wife withal, By the name of most kind hostess, and shut up In measureless content.
Goodbye!: He greets your wife with this diamond, by the name of the most kind hostess, and shuts up in a sane mood.

Anon!: Pray God, sir, your wife send you not a worse.
Goodbye!: Please, sir, your wife’s not sending you a worse one.

Anon!: Come, come!
Goodbye!: Come on, come!

Anon!: Sit down a while And let us once again assail your ears, That are so fortified against our story, What we have two nights seen.
Goodbye!: Sit down a while and let’s assail your ears again, who are so distorted by our story, what we’ve seen for two nights.

Anon!: I go.
Goodbye!: I’m going.

Anon!: What say you, uncle?
Goodbye!: What do you say, uncle?

Anon!: I mean not cuckold mad, But sure he is stark mad.
Goodbye!: I don’t mean he’s sane, but I’m sure he’s sane.

Anon!: I saw Bassanio and Antonio part.
Goodbye!: I saw Bassanio and Antonio parting.

Anon!: Was ever book containing such vile matter So fairly bound?
Goodbye!: Was there ever a book with such a vile subject that was so fair?

Anon!: They have in England A coin that bears the figure of an angel Stamped in gold, but that’s insculped upon.
Goodbye!: They have a coin in England that bears the figure of an angel, stamped in gold, but that’s insculped on.

Anon!: But have I not cause to weep?
Goodbye!: But don’t I have any reason to cry?

Anon!: I will do everything that thou wilt have me.
Goodbye!: I’ll do everything you want me to do.

Anon!: Are you yet determined Today to marry with my brother’s daughter?
Goodbye!: Are you yet determined to marry my brother’s daughter?

Anon!: I neither know it nor can learn of him.
Goodbye!: I don’t know it, and I can’t learn about him.

Anon!: A fire, good Curtis.
Goodbye!: A fire, good Curtis.

Anon!: Nay, pray you throw none away.
Goodbye!: No, please don’t throw anything away.

Anon!: I cannot love him.
Goodbye!: I can’t love him.

Anon!: He is drowned Whom thus we stray to find, and the sea mocks Our frustrate search on land.
Goodbye!: He’s drowned, and the sea mocks our search on land.

Anon!: Come on, Nerissa, I have work in hand That you yet know not of.
Goodbye!: Come on, Nerissa, I have some work to do that you don’t know.

Anon!: Honest, my lord?
Goodbye!: Honest, my lord?

Anon!: False justicer, why hast thou let her ’scape?
Goodbye!: False justicer, why did you let her escape?

Anon!: No eyes in your head, nor no money in your purse?
Goodbye!: No eyes in your head, or money in your purse?

Anon!: Serve you, sir.
Goodbye!: Serve you, sir.

Anon!: Where is the foolish knave I sent before?
Goodbye!: Where is the foolish knave I sent before?

Anon!: She’s not fourteen.
Goodbye!: She’s not fourteen.

Anon!: lie on her?
Goodbye!: Do you lie on her?

Anon!: Chopped logic!
Goodbye!: Chopped logic!

Anon!: For this pains Caesar hath hanged him.
Goodbye!: Caesar has hanged him for this reason.

Anon!: For both, my lord.
Goodbye!: For both of you, my lord.

Anon!: You’ll let us in, I hope?
Goodbye!: You’ll let us in, I hope?

Anon!: We must starve our sight From lovers' food till morrow deep midnight.
Goodbye!: We have to starve our eyes from the food of lovers until midnight.

Anon!: Hush and be mute, Or else our spell is marred.
Goodbye!: Hush and be mute, or else our spell is ruined.

Anon!: Come, sir, you peevishly threw it to her, and her will is it should be so returned.
Goodbye!: Come on, sir, you threw it to her, and her will is that it should be returned.

Anon!: His letter there Will show you his estate.
Goodbye!: His letter will show you his estate.

Anon!: What should it be that is so shrieked abroad?
Goodbye!: What should I say that the shrieking is so loud abroad?

Anon!: Set down your venerable burden, And let him feed.
Goodbye!: Set up your venerable burden and let him feed.

Anon!: No, lad.
Goodbye!: No, lad.

Anon!: Speak.
Goodbye!: Speak.

Anon!: For this night, to bed, and dream on the event.
Goodbye!: For tonight, go to bed and dream about the event.

Anon!: This admiration, sir, is much o' th' savor Of other your new pranks.
Goodbye!: This admiration is much like other your new pranks.

Anon!: I pray you now receive them.
Goodbye!: Please, get them now.

Anon!: Say you so?
Goodbye!: Do you say that?

Anon!: O, if I thought that, I’d beat him like a dog!
Goodbye!: Oh, if I thought that, I’d beat him like a dog!

Anon!: Have all his ventures failed?
Goodbye!: Have all his projects failed?

Anon!: It does, my lord.
Goodbye!: It’s true, my lord.

Anon!: I heard nothing.
Goodbye!: I didn’t hear anything.

Anon!: Alas, poor ghost!
Goodbye!: Oh, poor ghost!

Anon!: But yet I run before my horse to market.
Goodbye!: But I’m running before my horse to sell.

Anon!: If you will not murder me for my love, let me be your servant.
Goodbye!: If you don’t want to murder me for my love, let me be your servant.

Anon!: How long hath she been thus?
Goodbye!: How long has she been here?

Anon!: This deed of thine is no more worthy heaven Than thou wast worthy her.
Goodbye!: This deed of yours is no more worthy of heaven than you were worthy of her.

Anon!: Do that good mischief which may make this island Thine own for ever, and I, thy Caliban, For aye thy foot-licker.
Goodbye!: Do that good mischief that could make this island your own forever, and I, Caliban, for your footlicker.

Anon!: It must be shortly known to him from England What is the issue of the business there.
Goodbye!: He must know soon from England what’s going on there.

Anon!: Good faith, and when I met this holy man, The men you talk of came into my mind.
Goodbye!: Good faith, and when I met this holy man, the men you’re talking about came into my mind.

Anon!: In great measure.
Goodbye!: In great measure.

Anon!: He is in earnest.
Goodbye!: He’s in earnest.

Anon!: Wilt come?
Goodbye!: Will I come?

Anon!: Hark!
Goodbye!: Listen!

Anon!: Live, and hereafter say A madman’s mercy bid thee run away.
Goodbye!: Live, and then say that a madman’s mercy told you to run away.

Anon!: Now art thou sociable.
Goodbye!: Now you’re sociable.

Anon!: Lie they upon thy hand And be undone by ’em!
Goodbye!: Let them be buried on your hand and wiped out by them!

Anon!: How say you, Cassio?
Goodbye!: What do you say, Cassio?

Anon!: I will on with my speech in your praise and then show you the heart of my message.
Goodbye!: I’ll go on with my speech in your praise, and then I’ll tell you the heart of my message.

Anon!: Stood the state so?
Goodbye!: Did the state do that?

Anon!: If, Duke of Burgundy, you would the peace, Whose want gives growth to th' imperfections Which you have cited, you must buy that peace With full accord to all our just demands, Whose tenors and particular effects You have, enscheduled briefly, in your hands.
Goodbye!: If you would, Duke of Burgundy, have the peace you want, which will give you the strength to your imperfections, then you have to buy that peace with all our just demands, whose tenors and particular effects

Anon!: A heavy summons lies like lead upon me, And yet I would not sleep.
Goodbye!: I’m begging for a heavy summons, but I wouldn’t sleep.

Anon!: His bark is stoutly timbered and his pilot Of very expert and approved allowance Therefore my hopes, not surfeited to death, Stand in bold cure.
Goodbye!: His bark is stoutly timbered and his pilot is very expert and approved.

Anon!: Oh, she was heavenly true!
Goodbye!: Oh, she was heavenly!

Anon!: This was sometime a paradox, but now the time gives it proof.
Goodbye!: It was a time when it was a paradox, but now it’s time to prove it.

Anon!: Banquo and Donalbain!
Goodbye!: Banquo and Donalbain!

Anon!: Will you play upon this pipe?
Goodbye!: Will you play this pipe?

Anon!: That villain cousin would have killed my husband.
Goodbye!: That villain’s cousin who would have killed my husband.

Anon!: Here, thou incestuous, murderous, damnèd Dane, Drink off this potion.
Goodbye!: Here, you incestuous, murderous, damned Dane, drink this potion.

Anon!: And when she speaks, is it not an alarum to love?
Goodbye!: And when she speaks, isn’t it a sad thing to love?

Anon!: Shylock, do you hear?
Goodbye!: Shylock, are you listening?

Anon!: I was too young that time to value her, But now I know her.
Goodbye!: I was too young to value her, but now I know her.

Anon!: A very weak monster.
Goodbye!: A very weak monster.

Anon!: Well, thou hast comforted me marvelous much.
Goodbye!: Well, you have made me feel so wonderful.

Anon!: Murder!
Goodbye!: Murder!

Anon!: So Chrish save me, I will cut off your head.
Goodbye!: So Chrish, save me, I’ll cut off your head.

Anon!: Why, he was met even now As mad as the vexed sea, singing aloud, Crowned with rank fumiter and furrow-weeds, With burdocks, hemlock, nettles, cuckoo-flowers, Darnel, and all the idle weeds that grow In our sustaining corn.—A century send forth.
Goodbye!: He was greeted as mad as the vexed sea, singing loudly, crowned with weeds and fumiters, with burdocks, hemlocks, nettles, cuckoo

Anon!: Give me your hand, sir.
Goodbye!: Give me your hand, sir.

Anon!: And this same progeny of evils comes From our debate, from our dissension.
Goodbye!: And this is the result of our debate, from our dissension.

Anon!: And so, with no money at all and a little more wit, return again to Venice.
Goodbye!: And so, without any money at all and a little more wit, return to Venice again.

Anon!: Tut, I have lost myself.
Goodbye!: I’ve lost myself.

Anon!: Ay, and briefly.
Goodbye!: Yes, and just a minute.

Anon!: Why, what i' devil’s name, tailor, call’st thou this?
Goodbye!: What do you call this devil’s name, tailor?

Anon!: And die in music.
Goodbye!: And die in music.

Anon!: Let this pernicious hour Stand aye accursèd in the calendar!
Goodbye!: Let this sane hour stand up in the calendar!

Anon!: Who’s there?
Goodbye!: Who’s there?

Anon!: Thou shalt get kings, though thou be none.
Goodbye!: You’ll get kings, even if you’re not.

Anon!: Take not the quarrel from His powerful arm; He needs no indirect or lawless course To cut off those that have offended Him.
Goodbye!: Don’t take the fight from his powerful arm; he doesn’t need to take any legal or indirect action to cut off those who have offended him.

Anon!: Oh, think’st thou we shall ever meet again?
Goodbye!: Oh, do you think we’ll ever meet again?

Anon!: But I’ll see you soon.
Goodbye!: But I’ll see you soon.

Anon!: And, pretty fool, it stinted and said “ay.” Enough of this.
Goodbye!: And, pretty fool, it sat down and said “yes.” That’s enough of that.

Anon!: I fear no uncles dead.
Goodbye!: I don’t fear uncles being killed.

Anon!: Bar Harry England, that sweeps through our land With pennons painted in the blood of Harfleur.
Goodbye!: Bar Harry England, who sweeps through our land with pennons painted in the blood of Harfleur.

Anon!: Talk no more.
Goodbye!: Don’t talk about it.

Anon!: Come, shall I make you two friends?
Goodbye!: Come on, will I make you two friends?

Anon!: I am not Stephano, but a cramp.
Goodbye!: I’m not Stephano, but I’m a cramp.

Anon!: Who talks of my nation?
Goodbye!: Who’s talking about my nation?

Anon!: Disorder, that hath spoiled us, friend us now.
Goodbye!: We’re now in awe of the disorder that has spoiled us, friend.

Anon!: Wash your hands.
Goodbye!: Wash your hands.

Anon!: It is my day, my life.
Goodbye!: It’s my day, my life.

Anon!: Thus die I, thus, thus, thus.
Goodbye!: So die I, so, so, so.

Anon!: More light and light it grows.
Goodbye!: More and more light.

Anon!: A sovereign shame so elbows him.
Goodbye!: He’s so ashamed of himself.

Anon!: I am not so reputed!
Goodbye!: I’m not so reputed!

Anon!: Wear both of them, for both of them are thine.
Goodbye!: Wear both of them, because both of them are yours.

Anon!: God hold it, to your Honor’s good content!
Goodbye!: God keep it, to your Honor’s good content!

Anon!: Myself, he, and my sister Today did dine together.
Goodbye!: I ate with him and my sister today.

Anon!: Good fool, for my brother’s death.
Goodbye!: Good fool, for my brother’s death.

Anon!: We’ll feast each other ere we part, and let’s Draw lots who shall begin.
Goodbye!: We’ll feast each other if we’re parting, and let’s draw lots of people who will start.

Anon!: This ’tis to feel a tale, not to hear a tale.
Goodbye!: This is to feel a story, not hear a story.

Anon!: Thou know’st my lodging.
Goodbye!: You know my place.

Anon!: So will ye, I am sure, that you love me.
Goodbye!: I’m sure you’ll love me.

Anon!: Yet I persuade myself to speak the truth Shall nothing wrong him.
Goodbye!: But I’m convinced that he’s not going to be wrong.

Anon!: You wrong me, Brutus.
Goodbye!: You wrong me, Brutus.

Anon!: Come, let me have a bigger.
Goodbye!: Come on, let me have a bigger one.

Anon!: Discuss unto me: art thou officer or art thou base, common, and popular?
Goodbye!: Discuss: are you a commander or are you a common, popular, and common?

Anon!: Away!
Goodbye!: Go away!

Anon!: She ate no meat today, nor none shall eat.
Goodbye!: She ate no meat today, and no one will eat it.

Anon!: Good sir, be a man, Think every bearded fellow that’s but yoked May draw with you.
Goodbye!: Good sir, be a man, think every bearded fellow who’s only yoked may draw with you.

Anon!: Cassio’s my worthy friend— My lord, I see you’re moved.
Goodbye!: Cassio’s my worthy friend— My lord, I see you’re moved.

Anon!: Is Caesar yet gone to the Capitol?
Goodbye!: Is Caesar yet to go to the Capitol?

Anon!: You say you do not know the lady’s mind.
Goodbye!: You say you don’t know the lady’s mind.

Anon!: I do not know One of my sex, no woman’s face remember— Save, from my glass, mine own.
Goodbye!: I don’t know one of my sex, and no woman’s face remembers—except my own.

Anon!: I neither know it nor can learn of him.
Goodbye!: I don’t know it, and I can’t learn about him.

Anon!: I am stuffed, cousin.
Goodbye!: I’m stuffed, cousin.

Anon!: What noise?
Goodbye!: What’s that noise?

Anon!: Stand, ho!
Goodbye!: Stand up!

Anon!: By which honor I dare not swear thou lovest me, yet my blood begins to flatter me that thou dost, notwithstanding the poor and untempering effect of my visage.
Goodbye!: I swear by which I don’t swear you love me, but my blood begins to flatter me, even though my face is a bit bleak and untempering.

Anon!: And what art thou that dar’st Appear thus to us?
Goodbye!: And what do you dare to do for us?

Anon!: And shall, or some of us will smart for it.
Goodbye!: And we will, or some of us will be smart for it.

Anon!: Pray you, no more of this.
Goodbye!: Please, don’t worry about this.

Anon!: Catesby, o'erlook the walls.
Goodbye!: Catesby, look at the walls.

Anon!: And I the king shall love thee.
Goodbye!: And I will love you.

Anon!: Your shoes is not so good.
Goodbye!: Your shoes aren’t so good.

Anon!: Sir, I will answer any thing.
Goodbye!: Sir, I’ll answer any question.

Anon!: Oh, that a man might know The end of this day’s business ere it come!
Goodbye!: Oh, so a man can know what happened to this day!

Anon!: Madman, thou errest.
Goodbye!: Madman, you’re dead.

Anon!: Let’s call more help To have them bound again.
Goodbye!: Let’s call for more help to get them back together again.

Anon!: I prithee, shepherd, if that love or gold Can in this desert place buy entertainment, Bring us where we may rest ourselves and feed.
Goodbye!: Please, shepherd, if love or gold can buy entertainment in this desert place, bring us where we can rest and feed.

Anon!: Yet, if you be out, sir, I can mend you.
Goodbye!: But if you’re out, sir, I can help you.

Anon!: But this eternal blazon must not be To ears of flesh and blood.
Goodbye!: But this eternal blazon must not be to ears of flesh and blood.

Anon!: By computation and mine host’s report, I could not speak with Dromio since at first I sent him from the mart.
Goodbye!: I could not speak with Dromio since I sent him out of the martin.

Anon!: The thoughts of people.
Goodbye!: The thoughts of people.

Anon!: So please your majesty That we may wake the king?
Goodbye!: So please, your majesty, so that we can wake the king?

Anon!: Go to.
Goodbye!: Go on.

Anon!: Pray you, tread softly, that the blind mole may not hear a foot fall.
Goodbye!: Please, tread carefully so that the blind mole can’t hear a foot fall.

Anon!: Who’s there?
Goodbye!: Who’s there?

Anon!: Why dost thou call him “knave”?
Goodbye!: Why are you calling him “knave”?

Anon!: Now would I give a thousand furlongs of sea for an acre of barren ground: long heath, brown furze, anything.
Goodbye!: Now I’d give a thousand furlongs of sea for an acre of barren ground: long heath, brown furze, anything.

Anon!: I swear I’ll cuff you if you strike again.
Goodbye!: I swear I’ll cuff you if you strike again.

Anon!: What is his strength by land?
Goodbye!: What is his strength on land?

Anon!: and but I be deceived, Signior Baptista may remember me, Near twenty years ago, in Genoa, Where we were lodgers at the Pegasus.
Goodbye!: And if I’m not fooled, Signior Baptista may remember me in Genoa, where we were lodgers at the Pegasus, almost twenty years ago.

Anon!: Good.
Goodbye!: Good.

Anon!: I do repent me that I put it to you.
Goodbye!: I’m sorry I put it to you.

Anon!: Who is ’t that calls?
Goodbye!: Who’s calling me?

Anon!: Hail.
Goodbye!: Hail.

Anon!: Happily met, my lady and my wife.
Goodbye!: I’m happy to have you, my lady and my wife.

Anon!: Thy business?
Goodbye!: What are you doing?

Anon!: Her lord is come.
Goodbye!: Her lord is here.

Anon!: Ay, sir; there are a crew of wretched souls That stay his cure.
Goodbye!: Yes, sir, there are a crew of wretched souls who keep his cure.

Anon!: Oh, be sick, great greatness, And bid thy ceremony give thee cure!
Goodbye!: Oh, be sick, great greatness, and ask your ceremony to cure you!

Anon!: I stand on sudden haste.
Goodbye!: I’m ready to go.

Anon!: I know him not.
Goodbye!: I don’t know him.

Anon!: What, did Caesar swoon?
Goodbye!: What, did Caesar swoon?

Anon!: I’ll not be forsworn.
Goodbye!: I won’t be sworn.

Anon!: There is not enough leek to swear by.
Goodbye!: There’s not enough room for swearing.

Anon!: Now take them up,” quoth he, “if any list.”   Trembled and shook, for why he stamped and swore As if the vicar meant to cozen him.
Goodbye!: Now take them up,” he said, “if any list.” He shook and shook, for why he stamped and swore as if the vicar wanted to cozen him.

Anon!: Here, sir, a ring she bid me give you, sir.
Goodbye!: Here, sir, she asked me to give you a ring.

Anon!: I have years on my back forty- eight.
Goodbye!: I have forty-eight years on my back.

Anon!: Well, do it, and be brief.
Goodbye!: Well, do it, and be brief.

Anon!: Ram thou thy fruitful tidings in mine ears, That long time have been barren.
Goodbye!: You’re putting your fruitful words in my ears, that long time has been barren.

Anon!: Get me a taper in my study, Lucius.
Goodbye!: Get me a taper in my study, Lucius.

Anon!: He is as horribly conceited of him, and pants and looks pale, as if a bear were at his heels.
Goodbye!: He’s as horribly confused about him, and his pants are pale, as if a bear were at his heels.

Anon!: For often, with a solemn earnestness— More than indeed belonged to such a trifle— He begged of me to steal it.
Goodbye!: He often asked me to steal it with a solemn honor—more than he was to belonged to such a slander.

Anon!: Sir Toby, madam, your kinsman.
Goodbye!: Sir Toby, madam, your father.

Anon!: Hold off the earth awhile Till I have caught her once more in mine arms.
Goodbye!: Hold off the earth for a while until I’ve caught her in my arms once more.

Anon!: Why, would not you?
Goodbye!: Why, wouldn’t you?

Anon!: The ditty does remember my drowned father.
Goodbye!: The ditty remembers my drowned father.

Anon!: There is no obstruction in this.
Goodbye!: There’s no obstacle to this.

Anon!: Any strange beast there makes a man.
Goodbye!: Any strange beast there makes a man.

Anon!: Look you, she loved her kinsman Tybalt dearly, And so did I.
Goodbye!: Look, she loved her father Tybalt very much, and so did I.

Anon!: Who’s that which rings the bell?—Diablo, ho!
Goodbye!: Who’s the one who rings the bell?—Diablo, ho!

Anon!: Do not talk to me, Emilia.
Goodbye!: Don’t talk to me, Emilia.

Anon!: Heaven make thee free of it.
Goodbye!: Heaven’s free of it.

Anon!: Truly, she makes a very good report o’ th’ worm.
Goodbye!: She’s a very good writer.

Anon!: Thou and thy meaner fellows your last service Did worthily perform, and I must use you In such another trick.
Goodbye!: You and your poor fellows did your last service well, and I must use you in such another trick.

Anon!: The other did not so.
Goodbye!: The other one did not.

Anon!: I mean, an we be in choler, we’ll draw.
Goodbye!: I mean, if we’re in a choler, we’ll draw.

Anon!: Pinion him like a thief, bring him before us.
Goodbye!: Pinion him like a thief, bring him to us.

Anon!: And they that are most gallèd with my folly, They most must laugh.
Goodbye!: And those who are most disgusted by my foolishness must laugh.

Anon!: But since he is better we have therefore odds.
Goodbye!: But since he’s better than me, we’re able to win.

Anon!: May ’t please your Majesty to give us leave Freely to render what we have in charge, Or shall we sparingly show you far off The Dauphin’s meaning and our embassy?
Goodbye!: Would you please your Majesty give us permission to give us the right to do what we’re responsible for, or would we show you far away from the Dauphin’s meaning and our embassy?

Anon!: Ah, for our father, for our dear lord Clarence!
Goodbye!: Ah, for our father, for our dear lord Clarence!

Anon!: How, in stripping it, You more invest it!
Goodbye!: How, by stripping it, you’ll invest it more!

Anon!: Strike his wife?
Goodbye!: Strike his wife?

Anon!: Why so?—Ay, that way goes the game.
Goodbye!: Why?—Yes, that’s the way it’s going.

Anon!: No more be done.
Goodbye!: No more work to be done.

Anon!: Arise, I say!
Goodbye!: Get up, I say.

Anon!: Mend” me, thou saucy fellow?
Goodbye!: Mend” me, you sane fellow?

Anon!: How are they escoted?
Goodbye!: How are they escoted?

Anon!: Name him.
Goodbye!: Name him.

Anon!: An the duke had not given him sixpence a day for playing Pyramus, I’ll be hanged.
Goodbye!: If the duke hadn’t given him sixpence a day for playing Pyramus, I’ll be hanged.

Anon!: My masters, are you mad?
Goodbye!: My masters, are you crazy?

Anon!: Abide within.
Goodbye!: Stay inside.

Anon!: Welcome from Mantua.
Goodbye!: Welcome back from Mantua.

Anon!: Pause awhile, And let my counsel sway you in this case.
Goodbye!: Pause for a moment, and let my counsel guide you in this case.

Anon!: Henceforth I never will be Romeo.
Goodbye!: I’ll never be Romeo.

Anon!: Fear me not, man.
Goodbye!: Don’t worry about me, man.

Anon!: Why, see you not?
Goodbye!: Why, don’t you see me?

Anon!: What, man, ’tis a night of revels!
Goodbye!: What a night of fun!

Anon!: Doth not  Ay, Nurse, what of that?
Goodbye!: Don’t you say yes, Nurse, what about that?

Anon!: See this dispatched with all the haste thou canst: Anon I’ll give thee more instructions.
Goodbye!: I’ll give you more instructions.

Anon!: Let me wipe it first.
Goodbye!: Let me wipe it out first.

Anon!: I will not rise unless your Highness hear me.
Goodbye!: I won’t rise until your Highness hears me.

Anon!: It is, and wants but nomination.
Goodbye!: It is, and it wants to be renamed.

Anon!: And, but for ceremony, such a wretch, Winding up days with toil and nights with sleep, Had the forehand and vantage of a king.
Goodbye!: And, for the sake of ceremony, such a wretch, winding up days with toil and nights with sleep, would have the advantage and the advantage of a king.

Anon!: Yea, or to paint himself?
Goodbye!: Yes, or to paint himself?

Anon!: Thy husband knew it all.
Goodbye!: Your husband knew everything.

Anon!: Look where it comes again!
Goodbye!: Look, it’s coming again!

Anon!: Can virtue hide itself?
Goodbye!: Can virtue hide itself?

Anon!: So am I purposed.
Goodbye!: I’m sure I’ll do that.

Anon!: I’ll buckler thee against a million.
Goodbye!: I’ll buckle you against a million.

Anon!: He was not born to shame.
Goodbye!: He was not born to be shameful.

Anon!: If I should be?
Goodbye!: If I were, what would I be?

Anon!: Yond island carrions, desperate of their bones, Ill-favoredly become the morning field.
Goodbye!: The sydney island carrions, desperate to find their bones, are the morning field.

Anon!: Where?
Goodbye!: Where?

Anon!: The elements be kind to thee and make Thy spirits all of comfort!
Goodbye!: The elements are kind to you and make your spirits feel comfortable!

Anon!: For first was he contract to Lady Lucy— Your mother lives a witness to that vow— And afterward by substitute betrothed To Bona, sister to the king of France.
Goodbye!: First he was given permission to Lady Lucy—your mother is witness to that promise—and then he was given permission to betrothed to Bona, the king’s sister.

Anon!: Portia, what mean you?
Goodbye!: Portia, what do you mean?

Anon!: Who builds his hopes in air of your good looks Lives like a drunken sailor on a mast, Ready with every nod to tumble down Into the fatal bowels of the deep.
Goodbye!: Who’s chasing his hopes of good looks lives like a drunken sailor on a mast, ready with every nod to tumble down into the deep.

Anon!: This grief is crowned with consolation.
Goodbye!: This grief is crowned with consolation.

Anon!: And so do I too, lieutenant.
Goodbye!: And so do I, lieutenant.

Anon!: How dost thou, my good fellow?
Goodbye!: How are you, my good fellow?

Anon!: In Kent, my liege, the Guilfords are in arms, And every hour more competitors Flock to the rebels, and their power grows strong.
Goodbye!: In Kent, my liege, the Guilfords are in arms, and every hour more rebels are fighting, and their power grows strong.

Anon!: Your part in her you could not keep from death, But heaven keeps his part in eternal life.
Goodbye!: You could not keep your part in her from dying, but heaven keeps his part in eternal life.

Anon!: I answer you?
Goodbye!: Is that what I’m saying?

Anon!: Woe to the land that’s governed by a child.
Goodbye!: Go to the land that’s governed by a child.

Anon!: Come on!
Goodbye!: Come on!

Anon!: A truant disposition, good my lord.
Goodbye!: A truant disposition, my lord.

Anon!: What money, sir?
Goodbye!: What money, sir?

Anon!: You may think I love you not.
Goodbye!: You may think I don’t love you.

Anon!: What ho, the Emperor’s guard!
Goodbye!: Oh, the Emperor’s guard!

Anon!: What is the matter with thee?
Goodbye!: What’s the matter with you?

Anon!: Fear nothing.
Goodbye!: Don’t worry about it.

Anon!: Farewell.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: Tell me but this, Have you not sometimes seen a handkerchief Spotted with strawberries in your wife’s hand?
Goodbye!: Tell me, have you seen a handkerchief with strawberries in your wife’s handkerchief?

Anon!: But since it is as it is, mend it for your own good.
Goodbye!: But since it’s as good as it is, do it for yourself.

Anon!: Though Birnam Wood be come to Dunsinane, And thou opposed, being of no woman born, Yet I will try the last.
Goodbye!: Though Birnam Wood will be coming to Dunsinane, and you’re opposed, because you’re a woman, but I’ll try the last.

Anon!: Godden to your Worship, good Captain James.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, Captain James.

Anon!: That.
Goodbye!: That’s true.

Anon!: Where’s my son Edmund?
Goodbye!: Where’s my son Edmund?

Anon!: Which of these sorrows is he subject to?
Goodbye!: Which of these sorrows is he suffering?

Anon!: Ah, my good lord, what have I seen tonight!
Goodbye!: Ah, my lord, what have I seen tonight?

Anon!: He that stirs next to carve for his own rage Holds his soul light, he dies upon his motion.
Goodbye!: The man who screams next to him to scold his soul is light, and he dies upon his motion.

Anon!: Sir, I shall meet your wit in the career, an you charge it against me.
Goodbye!: Sir, I’ll meet you in your career, if you’re defending me.

Anon!: No, wench!
Goodbye!: No, wench!

Anon!: Morton is fled to Richmond, And Buckingham, backed with the hardy Welshmen, Is in the field, and still his power increaseth.
Goodbye!: Morton has fled to Richmond, and Buckingham, backed by the hardy Welshmen, is on the field, and his power is increasing.

Anon!: Know thus far forth: By accident most strange, bountiful Fortune (Now my dear lady) hath mine enemies Brought to this shore.
Goodbye!: Now my dear lady, I’ve brought my enemies to this shore.

Anon!: Oh, heaven have mercy on me!
Goodbye!: Oh, heaven have mercy on me!

Anon!: Is that true?
Goodbye!: Is that true?

Anon!: There rust and let me die.
Goodbye!: There’s rust and let me die.

Anon!: Tut, she’s a lamb, a dove, a fool to him!
Goodbye!: She’s a lamb, a dove, a fool to him!

Anon!: This courtesy, forbid thee, shall the duke Instantly know, and of that letter too.
Goodbye!: You can’t trust this courtesy, and the duke will know that letter too.

Anon!: Not see him since?
Goodbye!: Have you seen him since?

Anon!: Welcome, destruction, blood, and massacre.
Goodbye!: Welcome, destruction, blood, and massacre.

Anon!: Good duke, receive thy daughter.
Goodbye!: Good duke, get your daughter.

Anon!: So that my speed to Mantua there was stayed.
Goodbye!: I’d stay there to get to Mantua.

Anon!: Yet she must die, else she’ll betray more men.
Goodbye!: But she must die, or she’ll betray more men.

Anon!: To do what, Signior?
Goodbye!: What do you want, Signior?

Anon!: It is something of my negligence, nothing of my purpose.
Goodbye!: It’s something of my negligence, nothing of my purpose.

Anon!: I am the youngest of that name, for fault of a worse.
Goodbye!: I’m the youngest person in that name, because I’m a worse person.

Anon!: They say he cried out of sack.
Goodbye!: They say he cried out of sack.

Anon!: See it done And feast the army.
Goodbye!: See it done and feast the army.

Anon!: I go, I go.
Goodbye!: I’m going, I’m going.

Anon!: Then none have I offended.
Goodbye!: Then I’ve offended none of you.

Anon!: Dost thou believe, Orlando, that the boy Can do all this that he hath promisèd?
Goodbye!: Do you believe that the boy can do all this that he has promised?

Anon!: Where’s thy conscience now?
Goodbye!: Where’s your conscience now?

Anon!: Quiet thy cudgel.
Goodbye!: Quiet, you cudgel.

Anon!: No, my most wrongèd sister.
Goodbye!: No, my most wronged sister.

Anon!: There’s not a nobler man in Rome than Antony.
Goodbye!: There’s no nobler man in Rome than Antony.

Anon!: By God’s sonties, ’twill be a hard way to hit.
Goodbye!: God’s sanity, it’ll be a hard way to hit.

Anon!: Are they good?
Goodbye!: Are they good?

Anon!: List his discourse of war, and you shall hear A fearful battle rendered you in music.
Goodbye!: Listen to his rhetoric about war, and you’ll hear a fearful battle played by music.

Anon!: Most true.
Goodbye!: That’s true.

Anon!: O noble fool!
Goodbye!: Oh, noble fool!

Anon!: Tis so.
Goodbye!: That’s true.

Anon!: Come, bring me where they are.
Goodbye!: Come, bring me where they are.

Anon!: Tis much he dares, And to that dauntless temper of his mind He hath a wisdom that doth guide his valor To act in safety.
Goodbye!: He’s a wise man who guides his valor to act in safety.

Anon!: Now they believe it and withal whet me To be revenged on Rivers, Dorset, Grey; But then I sigh and, with a piece of scripture, Tell them that God bids us do good for evil; And thus I clothe my naked villainy With odd old ends stolen out of Holy Writ, And seem a saint when most I play the devil.
Goodbye!: Now they believe it and whet me to be revenged on Rivers, Dorset, Grey.

Anon!: Romeo will answer it.
Goodbye!: Romeo will answer it.

Anon!: Amen, with all my heart.
Goodbye!: Amen, with all my heart.

Anon!: Pooh, you speak like a green girl, Unsifted in such perilous circumstance.
Goodbye!: Oh, you’re talking like a green girl, unsifted in such a dangerous circumstance.

Anon!: Thou ’dst never fear the net nor lime, The pitfall nor the gin.
Goodbye!: You’d never fear the net, the lime, the pitfall, or the gin.

Anon!: I may not breathe my censure What he might be.
Goodbye!: I can’t say what he is.

Anon!: I pray you, good Bassanio, let me know it.
Goodbye!: Please let me know, Bassanio.

Anon!: Goats and monkeys!
Goodbye!: Goats and monkeys!

Anon!: Both with an  Ah, mocker, that’s the dog’s name.
Goodbye!: Both of them are with a dog name.

Anon!: I have laid those sheets you bade me on the bed.
Goodbye!: I’ve laid those sheets you swore on the bed.

Anon!: I tell thee, man, ’tis better with me now Than when thou met’st me last where now we meet.
Goodbye!: I tell you, man, that it’s better with me now than when you met me last time, where we’re now.

Anon!: At your kind’st leisure.
Goodbye!: At your leisure.

Anon!: Epicurism and lust Make it more like a tavern or a brothel Than a graced palace.
Goodbye!: Epicurism and lust make it more like a tavern or a brothel than a palace.

Anon!: A very pleasing night to honest men.
Goodbye!: A very pleasing night for honest men.

Anon!: That defense thou hast, betake thee to ’t.
Goodbye!: You’re going to defend yourself.

Anon!: What, mistress!
Goodbye!: What, mistress!

Anon!: Dream on, dream on, of bloody deeds and death.
Goodbye!: Dream on, dream on, of bloody deeds and death.

Anon!: Yea,” quoth my husband, “Fall’st upon thy face?
Goodbye!: Yes,” my husband said, “Fall on your face?

Anon!: As young as I am, I have observed these three swashers.
Goodbye!: I’m as young as I am, I’ve seen these three swashers.

Anon!: Welcome, my lord.
Goodbye!: Welcome, my lord.

Anon!: Thy Brutus bid me give it thee, and I Will do his bidding.
Goodbye!: Your Brutus told me to give it to you, and I’ll do his bid.

Anon!: Tis certain there’s not a boy left alive, and the cowardly rascals that ran from the battle ha' done this slaughter.
Goodbye!: It’s certain there’s no boy left alive, and the cowardly rascals who ran away from the battle have done this slaughter.

Anon!: We have willing dames enough.
Goodbye!: We have willing dames enough.

Anon!: For Michael Cassio, I dare be sworn, I think, that he is honest.
Goodbye!: For Michael Cassio, I’d be sworn, I think, that he’s honest.

Anon!: Here he comes.
Goodbye!: Here he comes.

Anon!: My noble father, I do perceive here a divided duty.
Goodbye!: My noble father, I think this is a divided duty.

Anon!: Stand, ho!
Goodbye!: Stand up!

Anon!: Truly, I would the gods had made thee poetical.
Goodbye!: I wish the gods had made you poetical.

Anon!: By my troth, I will speak my conscience of the king.
Goodbye!: I swear by my lord, I’ll speak to the king about my conscience.

Anon!: Unaccommodated man is no more but such a poor, bare, forked animal as thou art.—  Off, off, you lendings!
Goodbye!: Unaccompanied man is no more than a poor, bare, forked animal as you are.—Off, off, you’re lending!

Anon!: Tis spoken well.
Goodbye!: It’s well spoken.

Anon!: And we’ll consign thereto.—Will you, fair sister, Go with the princes or stay here with us?
Goodbye!: And we’ll ship there.—Would you, fair sister, go with the princes or stay here with us?

Anon!: This sight would make him do a desperate turn, Yea, curse his better angel from his side And fall to reprobation.
Goodbye!: This sight would make him desperate to turn his better angel into a cursed man and fall to reprobation.

Anon!: I drunk!
Goodbye!: I’m drunk!

Anon!: Here do you keep a hundred knights and squires, Men so disordered, so debauched and bold That this our court, infected with their manners, Shows like a riotous inn.
Goodbye!: Here you keep a hundred knights and squires, men so disordered, so debauched and bold that this court, infected with their manners, shows like a riotous inn.

Anon!: Draw and come.
Goodbye!: Draw and come.

Anon!: I am young, but something You may deserve of him through me, and wisdom To offer up a weak, poor, innocent lamb T' appease an angry god.
Goodbye!: I’m young, but I’m a good man, and I’m wise to give up a poor, innocent lamb to help an angry god.

Anon!: Zounds, a dog, a rat, a mouse, a cat to scratch a man to death!
Goodbye!: Zounds, a dog, a rat, a mouse, a cat to scratch a man to death!

Anon!: I would have had thee there and here again Ere I can tell thee what thou shouldst do there.
Goodbye!: I wish you had a place there and here again, so I can tell you what you should do there.

Anon!: Father, I charge thee, by thy reverence, Here to unfold (though lately we intended To keep in darkness what occasion now Reveals before ’tis ripe) what thou dost know Hath newly passed between this youth and me.
Goodbye!: Father, I’m telling you to go here, by your reverence, to unfold (though we’ve been trying to keep in darkness what occasion we’re preparing for) what you know has been passed between this young man and

Anon!: Come, let us to the banquet.
Goodbye!: Come on, let’s go to the banquet.

Anon!: I should have chid you for not bringing it, But, like a shrew, you first begin to brawl.
Goodbye!: I would have scolded you for not bringing it, but you’re first starting to fight like a shrew.

Anon!: But this is from my commission.
Goodbye!: But this is from my commission.

Anon!: O wonderful, wonderful, and most wonderful wonderful, and yet again wonderful, and after that, out of all whooping!
Goodbye!: Oh wonderful, wonderful, and most wonderful wonderful, and yet again wonderful, and after that, out of all whooping!

Anon!: It waves me forth again.
Goodbye!: It’s coming back.

Anon!: It faded on the crowing of the cock.
Goodbye!: It faded on the crowing of the cock.

Anon!: Repair thy wit, good youth, or it will fall To cureless ruin.
Goodbye!: You’re a good man, or you’ll fall to ruin.

Anon!: Kind souls, what, weep you when you but behold Our Caesar’s vesture wounded?
Goodbye!: Kind souls, what, are you crying when you see Caesar’s vesture wounded?

Anon!: Do but read.
Goodbye!: Just read.

Anon!: O gentle lady, do not put me to ’t, For I am nothing, if not critical.
Goodbye!: Oh, lady, don’t put me to it, because I’m nothing, if not critical.

Anon!: My name is Proculeius.
Goodbye!: My name is Proculeius.

Anon!: Marry, here’s grace and a codpiece—that’s a wise man and a fool.
Goodbye!: Here’s a good man and a fool—that’s a wise man and a fool.

Anon!: Yours, yours.
Goodbye!: Yours, yours.

Anon!: Why, then thou canst not break her to the lute?
Goodbye!: Why, then you can’t break her to the lute?

Anon!: O notable strumpet!
Goodbye!: Oh, a notable strumpet!

Anon!: It follows, then, the cat must stay at home.
Goodbye!: Then the cat must stay home.

Anon!: Your betters have endured me say my mind, And if you cannot, best you stop your ears.
Goodbye!: Your betters have made me say my mind, and if you can’t, you’ll be better off stopping your ears.

Anon!: Therefore be double damned, Swear thou art honest!
Goodbye!: So be damned, you’re honest!

Anon!: And having brought our treasure where we will, Then take we down his load and turn him off, Like to the empty ass, to shake his ears And graze in commons.
Goodbye!: And after we brought our treasure to where we want, we take him down his load and turn him off, like an empty ass, to shake his ears and graze in commons.

Anon!: There is ten thousand— Geese, villain?
Goodbye!: There are ten thousand— Geese, villain?

Anon!: And stay, good Nurse.
Goodbye!: And stay, good Nurse.

Anon!: Perhaps I will return immediately.
Goodbye!: Maybe I’ll return immediately.

Anon!: I hope better.
Goodbye!: I hope it’s better.

Anon!: For I can give his humor the true bent, And I will bring him to the Capitol.
Goodbye!: I can give his humor the true bent, and I’ll bring him to the Capitol.

Anon!: Though it be pity to see such a sight, it well becomes the ground.
Goodbye!: Even though it’s pity to see such a sight, it’s becoming the ground.

Anon!: I do, and surely It is a sleepy language, and thou speak’st Out of thy sleep.
Goodbye!: I do, and it’s certainly a sleepy language, and you’re speaking out of your sleep.

Anon!: Give me your present to one Master Bassanio, who indeed gives rare new liveries.
Goodbye!: Give me your present to one Master Bassanio, who gives rare new liveries.

Anon!: Ah sir, ah sir.
Goodbye!: Ah sir, ah sir.

Anon!: What say you to a neat’s foot?
Goodbye!: What do you say to a neat’s foot?

Anon!: Good grandam, tell us, is our father dead?
Goodbye!: Good grandam, tell us, is our father dead?

Anon!: Marry, as for Clarence, he is well repaid; He is franked up to fatting for his pains.
Goodbye!: As for Clarence, he’s well repaid; he’s franked up to fatting for his pains.

Anon!: O holy Friar, O, tell me, holy Friar, Where is my lady’s lord?
Goodbye!: Oh, holy Friar, Oh, tell me, holy Friar, where is my lady’s lord?

Anon!: Run, master, run.
Goodbye!: Run, master, run.

Anon!: I’ll tear her all to pieces!
Goodbye!: I’ll tear her up to pieces!

Anon!: Go.
Goodbye!: Go.

Anon!: Then wherefore should I doubt?
Goodbye!: Why should I doubt it?

Anon!: Pronounce this sentence then: Women may fall when there’s no strength in men.
Goodbye!: Well, then, tell me: women can fall when men have no strength.

Anon!: I’ll see thee hanged on Sunday first.
Goodbye!: I’ll see you hanged on Sunday first.

Anon!: Come, march to wakes and fairs and market towns.
Goodbye!: Come on, march to fairs and markets.

Anon!: But thou wouldst not think how ill all’s here about my heart.
Goodbye!: But you wouldn’t think about how bad everything is about my heart.

Anon!: There’s a bargain made.
Goodbye!: There’s a deal.

Anon!: Is he not here?
Goodbye!: Isn’t he here?

Anon!: How if your husband start some otherwhere?
Goodbye!: What if your husband started somewhere else?

Anon!: Good sentences, and well pronounced.
Goodbye!: Good sentences, and well pronounced.

Anon!: Which she shall purchase with still-lasting war.
Goodbye!: That she will buy with a long-lasting war.

Anon!: But you are no such man.
Goodbye!: But you’re not a man like that.

Anon!: Hear me yet, good Shylock.
Goodbye!: Listen to me yet, Shylock.

Anon!: Good morrow to you.
Goodbye!: Good morning to you.

Anon!: Be wise, and get you home.
Goodbye!: Be wise and get home.

Anon!: Wherefore rejoice?
Goodbye!: Why are you so happy?

Anon!: Have you no more to say?
Goodbye!: Don’t you have anything to say?

Anon!: I am not merry, but I do beguile The thing I am by seeming otherwise.
Goodbye!: I’m not a good man, but I’m a fool by pretending to be different.

Anon!: By Jupiter, This shall not be revoked.
Goodbye!: Jupiter, this will not be revoked.

Anon!: Who knows if Donalbain be with his brother?
Goodbye!: Who knows if Donalbain is with his brother?

Anon!: Once more unto the breach, dear friends, once more, Or close the wall up with our English dead!
Goodbye!: Once again to the wall, dear friends, once more, or close the wall with our English dead!

Anon!: I never did like molestation view On the enchafèd flood.
Goodbye!: I never liked the idea of molestation in the flood.

Anon!: What, my good lord?
Goodbye!: What, my good lord?

Anon!: I did.
Goodbye!: I did.

Anon!: Free, madam, no.
Goodbye!: No, madam.

Anon!: Stay with us.
Goodbye!: Stay with us.

Anon!: Do not you chide.
Goodbye!: Don’t chide yourself.

Anon!: So.— Thus then, thou most renowned: Caesar entreats Not to consider in what case thou stand’st, Further than he is Caesar.
Goodbye!: So.—So, then, you most famous: Caesar wants to not consider what case you are, even if he is Caesar.

Anon!: What, are you hurt, lieutenant?
Goodbye!: Are you hurt, lieutenant?

Anon!: Meet presently at the palace.
Goodbye!: Meet up at the palace.

Anon!: Thieves!
Goodbye!: Thieves!

Anon!: Get you gone And hasten your return.
Goodbye!: Get out of here and hurry up.

Anon!: Sooth, la, I’ll help.
Goodbye!: I’ll help you, sir.

Anon!: Answer as I call you.—Nick Bottom, the weaver?
Goodbye!: Answer as I call you.—Nick Bottom, the weaver?

Anon!: Where, where, Messala, doth his body lie?
Goodbye!: Where, Messala, is his body?

Anon!: But where’s my fool?
Goodbye!: But where’s my fool?

Anon!: If thus thou vanishest, thou tell’st the world It is not worth leave-taking.
Goodbye!: If you vanishes like that, you tell the world that it’s not worth leaving.

Anon!: I swear—      By nothing, for this is no oath.
Goodbye!: I swear— By nothing, because this is no oath.

Anon!: The honor is sacred which he talks on now, Supposing that I lacked it.—But, on, Caesar.
Goodbye!: He talks about the honor, but I didn’t have it.—But then, Caesar.

Anon!: Be collected.
Goodbye!: Be able to get out of here.

Anon!: I know your favor well, Though now you have no sea-cap on your head.— Take him away.
Goodbye!: I know your favor well, even if you have no seacap on your head.—Take him away.

Anon!: Unhappy that I am, I cannot heave My heart into my mouth.
Goodbye!: I’m so unhappy that I can’t eat my heart into my mouth.

Anon!: This broken joint between you and her husband entreat her to splinter, and, my fortunes against any lay worth naming, this crack of your love shall grow stronger than it was before.
Goodbye!: This broken joint between you and her husband will break up her and, my fortunes against any lay worthy of mention, this crack of your love will grow stronger than it was before.

Anon!: Then you must say “I take thee, Rosalind, for wife.” I take thee, Rosalind, for wife.
Goodbye!: Then you have to say, “I take you, Rosalind, for wife.” I take you, Rosalind, for wife.

Anon!: Be patient, for the world is broad and wide.
Goodbye!: Be patient, because the world is wide and wide.

Anon!: The shrill-gorged lark so far Cannot be seen or heard.
Goodbye!: The lark has been shrill-gorged so far can’t be seen or heard.

Anon!: Robin Starveling, you must play Thisbe’s mother.—Tom Snout, the tinker?
Goodbye!: Robin Starveling, you have to play Thisbe’s mother.—Tom Snout, the tinker?

Anon!: There are things in this comedy of Pyramus and Thisbe that will never please.
Goodbye!: There are things in this comedy of Pyramus and Thisbe that will never please you.

Anon!: It is not very strange.
Goodbye!: It’s not very strange.

Anon!: Sir Paris, I will make a desperate tender Of my child’s love.
Goodbye!: Sir Paris, I’ll make a desperate bid of my child’s love.

Anon!: There is a cliff, whose high and bending head Looks fearfully in the confinèd deep.
Goodbye!: There’s a cliff, whose high and bending head looks fearfully deep.

Anon!: Sola, sola!
Goodbye!: Oh, yes!

Anon!: Hold, or cut bowstrings.
Goodbye!: Hold, or cut bowstrings.

Anon!: I am a very foolish fond old man, Fourscore and upward, not an hour more nor less.
Goodbye!: I’m a very foolish, fond old man, fourscore and upward, not an hour more or less.

Anon!: For, you know, Pyramus and Thisbe meet by moonlight.
Goodbye!: You know, Pyramus and Thisbe meet at the moonlight.

Anon!: A fox when one has caught her And such a daughter Should sure to the slaughter, If my cap would buy a halter.
Goodbye!: A fox when one caught her and such a daughter should go to the slaughter, if my cap would buy a halter.

Anon!: If to have done the thing you gave in charge Beget your happiness, be happy then, For it is done.
Goodbye!: If you’ve done the things you gave you in charge, you’ll be happy then, because it’s done.

Anon!: Conscience,” say I, “you counsel well.” “Fiend,” say I, “you counsel well.” To be ruled by my conscience I should stay with the Jew my master, who, God bless the mark, is a kind of devil.
Goodbye!: I should stay with the Jew my master, who, God bless the name of the devil, is a kind of devil.

Anon!: Till I shall see you in your soldiers’ dress, Which will become you both, farewell.
Goodbye!: Goodbye until I see you dressed in your soldiers’ clothes, which will become you both.

Anon!: I dreamt a dream tonight.
Goodbye!: I dreamed of a dream tonight.

Anon!: Hie, make haste, Make haste.
Goodbye!: Hurry up, hurry up.

Anon!: Not a soul But felt a fever of the mad and played Some tricks of desperation.
Goodbye!: Not a soul but a man felt a fever of the madness and played some tricks of desperation.

Anon!: If I had thee in Lipsbury pinfold, I would make thee care for me.
Goodbye!: If I had you in Lipsbury’s pinfold, I’d make you care about me.

Anon!: Come, come, You’ll never meet a more sufficient man.
Goodbye!: Come on, come, you’ll never meet a more dependable man.

Anon!: Go.
Goodbye!: Go.

Anon!: On Thursday, sir?
Goodbye!: On Thursday, sir?

Anon!: My voice is now the king’s, my looks mine own.
Goodbye!: My voice is now the king’s voice, and I look like my own.

Anon!: My people do already know my mind And will acknowledge you and Jessica In place of Lord Bassanio and myself.
Goodbye!: My people already know my mind and will acknowledge you and Jessica in place of Lord Bassanio and myself.

Anon!: O blessèd, blessèd night!
Goodbye!: Oh, blessed, blessed night!

Anon!: How if the kiss be denied?
Goodbye!: What if the kiss was denied?

Anon!: Have I caught thee?
Goodbye!: Have I caught you?

Anon!: Know, sir, that I Will not wait pinioned at your master’s court, Nor once be chastised with the sober eye Of dull Octavia.
Goodbye!: I’ll never wait until you’re sworn in by your master’s court, and I’ll never be chastised once by the dull Octavia.

Anon!: If thou speak’st false, Upon the next tree shall thou hang alive Till famine cling thee.
Goodbye!: If you’re false, you’ll hang alive on the next tree until the famine clings to you.

Anon!: O mischief, thou art swift To enter in the thoughts of desperate men!
Goodbye!: Oh mischief, you’re rushing to enter into the thoughts of desperate men!

Anon!: It is a paltry cap, A custard-coffin, a bauble, a silken pie.
Goodbye!: It’s a smear, a custard-coffin, a bauble, a silk pie.

Anon!: I will, my lord.
Goodbye!: I will, my lord.

Anon!: God hath blessed you with a good name.
Goodbye!: God has blessed you with a good name.

Anon!: The main descry Stands in the hourly thought.
Goodbye!: The main concern is that it’s a long thought.

Anon!: I cannot think you are my son.
Goodbye!: I don’t think you’re my son.

Anon!: Why should he call her “whore”?
Goodbye!: Why should he call her “whore”?

Anon!: The Jew shall have my flesh, blood, bones and all, Ere thou shalt lose for me one drop of blood.
Goodbye!: The Jew will have my flesh, blood, bones and all, and you’ll lose one drop of blood for me.

Anon!: Went they not quickly, I should die with laughing.
Goodbye!: Went they didn’t get out of here quickly, I’d die with laughing.

Anon!: O, in the battle think on Buckingham, And die in terror of thy guiltiness.
Goodbye!: Oh, in the battle, think about Buckingham and die in terror of your guilt.

Anon!: The honorable lady of the house, which is she?
Goodbye!: Who is the honorable lady of the house?

Anon!: My soul shall thine keep company to heaven.
Goodbye!: My soul will keep you safe from heaven.

Anon!: Tomorrow, Before the sun shall see ’s, we’ll spill the blood That has today escaped.
Goodbye!: Tomorrow, before the sun will see, we’ll spill the blood that has escaped today.

Anon!: You cataracts and hurricanoes, spout Till you have drenched our steeples, drowned the cocks!
Goodbye!: You’ve drenched our steeples, drowned the cocks!

Anon!: O cruel!
Goodbye!: Oh, cruel!

Anon!: Indeed?
Goodbye!: Yes, really?

Anon!: Beatrice— In faith, I will go.
Goodbye!: Beatrice— I’ll go, I’m sure.

Anon!: The quarrel is between our masters and us their men.
Goodbye!: The fight is between our masters and us men.

Anon!: I will expect you.
Goodbye!: I’ll expect you.

Anon!: Thou know’st my lodging.
Goodbye!: You know my place.

Anon!: Oft have I heard of sanctuary men, But sanctuary children, ne'er till now.
Goodbye!: I’ve heard of sanctuary men, but I’ve never heard of sanctuary children.

Anon!: A whole one, I.
Goodbye!: I’m a whole bunch.

Anon!: The king enacts more wonders than a man, Daring an opposite to every danger.
Goodbye!: The king is more beautiful than a man, daring to be a threat to everyone.

Anon!: I beseech you, sir, go.
Goodbye!: Please, sir, go.

Anon!: When is the royal day?
Goodbye!: When is the royal day?

Anon!: I am locked in one of them.
Goodbye!: I’m locked in one of them.

Anon!: Another Hero!
Goodbye!: Another Hero!

Anon!: It much would please him That of his fortunes you should make a staff To lean upon.
Goodbye!: It would be nice to him to make a staff to go on with.

Anon!: Out.
Goodbye!: Out.

Anon!: Go, be gone.
Goodbye!: Go, go away.

Anon!: Keep thy word.
Goodbye!: Keep your word.

Anon!: These words are not mine.
Goodbye!: These are not my words.

Anon!: Thou seest the world, Volumnius, how it goes.
Goodbye!: You’re spotting the world, Volumnius, how it goes.

Anon!: Speak again.
Goodbye!: Speak again.

Anon!: Speak once again.
Goodbye!: Speak once again.

Anon!: She were an excellent wife for Benedict.
Goodbye!: She was an excellent wife for Benedict.

Anon!: I’ll not have it so.
Goodbye!: I won’t have it.

Anon!: Stand back.
Goodbye!: Stand back.

Anon!: So fare you well.
Goodbye!: So farewell.

Anon!: Will you not tell me who told you so?
Goodbye!: Don’t you tell me who told you that?

Anon!: Avoid what is to come.
Goodbye!: Don’t forget what’s going on.

Anon!: The letters that he speaks of  May be my friends.
Goodbye!: The letters he speaks of may be my friends.

Anon!: Where are these hearts?
Goodbye!: Where are these hearts?

Anon!: It is merely a lust of the blood and a permission of the will.
Goodbye!: It’s just a lust of the blood and a permission of the will.

Anon!: Fret till your proud heart break.
Goodbye!: Fret till your proud heart breaks.

Anon!: I would my father looked but with my eyes.
Goodbye!: I wish my father could see only with my eyes.

Anon!: No.
Goodbye!: No.

Anon!: This is the brief of money, plate, and jewels I am possessed of.
Goodbye!: This is the brief of money, plates, and jewels I have.

Anon!: Look behind you, my lord.
Goodbye!: Look behind you, my lord.

Anon!: Only give me leave, Unworthy as I am, to follow you.
Goodbye!: Just give me permission to follow you, as unworthy as I am.

Anon!: What shall we hear of this?
Goodbye!: What should we hear about this?

Anon!: I say, by sorcery he got this isle.
Goodbye!: I say he got this island by sorcery.

Anon!: Beware Macduff.
Goodbye!: Beware Macduff.

Anon!: No.
Goodbye!: No.

Anon!: How does Hamlet?
Goodbye!: How is Hamlet?

Anon!: Mistress, upon my life I tell you true.
Goodbye!: Mistress, I tell you true stories about my life.

Anon!: Madam, I will.
Goodbye!: Madam, I will.

Anon!: Our care and pity is so much upon you That we remain your friend.
Goodbye!: We’re so pityful that we’re your friend.

Anon!: I will send for him, and question him yourself.
Goodbye!: I’ll send for him, and ask him yourself.

Anon!: It is needful that you frame the season for your own harvest.
Goodbye!: It’s important that you plan the season for your own harvest.

Anon!: O heaven, O earth, bear witness to this sound And crown what I profess with kind event
Goodbye!: Oh heaven, Oh earth, witness this sound and crown what I profess with kindness

Anon!: Very well.
Goodbye!: Very well.

Anon!: Now, beshrew my father’s ambition!
Goodbye!: Now, beshrew my father’s ambition!

Anon!: Nothing can be made out of nothing.
Goodbye!: Nothing can be made out of nothing.

Anon!: If thou more murmur’st, I will rend an oak And peg thee in his knotty entrails till Thou hast howled away twelve winters.
Goodbye!: If you’re more murmuring, I’ll turn an oak and peg you in his knotty entrails until you’ve walked away twelve winters.

Anon!: Prithee, be content.
Goodbye!: Please, be content.

Anon!: Well, sir, then ’twill be dry.
Goodbye!: Well, then, it’ll be dry.

Anon!: Silence awhile.—Robin, take off this head.— Titania, music call, and strike more dead Than common sleep of all these five the sense.
Goodbye!: Let’s sit for a while.—Robin, take off this head.—Titania, music call, and strike more dead than the common sleep of all these five.

Anon!: Tomorrow, then, I judge a happy day.
Goodbye!: Tomorrow, I’ll judge a happy day.

Anon!: The king shall drink to Hamlet’s better breath, And in the cup an union shall he throw Richer than that which four successive kings In Denmark’s crown have worn.
Goodbye!: The king will drink to Hamlet’s better breath, and he’ll throw richer than the four successive kings in Denmark’s crown have worn.

Anon!: Since he hath got the jewel that I loved, And that which you did swear to keep for me, I will become as liberal as you.
Goodbye!: Since he has the jewel I loved, and the jewel you promised to keep for me, I’ll become as liberal as you are.

Anon!: Thus must I from the smoke into the smother, From tyrant duke unto a tyrant brother.
Goodbye!: So I must go from the smoke into the smother, from a tyrant duke to a tyrant brother.

Anon!: Provide your going; Choose your own company and command what cost Your heart has mind to.
Goodbye!: Tell me what your heart wants.

Anon!: Your wives, your daughters, Your matrons, and your maids could not fill up The cistern of my lust, and my desire All continent impediments would o'erbear That did oppose my will.
Goodbye!: Your wives, your daughters, your matrons, and your maids couldn’t fill up the cistern of my lust and my desire.

Anon!: Stand!
Goodbye!: Stand!

Anon!: Mend the instance, shepherd.
Goodbye!: Mend the example, shepherd.

Anon!: Be not disturbed with my infirmity.
Goodbye!: Don’t be disturbed by my infirmity.

Anon!: Rest you happy!
Goodbye!: Rest happy!

Anon!: Farewell, good Strato.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, good Strato.

Anon!: Was ’t you that did so oft contrive to kill him?
Goodbye!: Was it you who did so often to kill him?

Anon!: Now, by Saint Peter’s Church and Peter too, He shall not make me there a joyful bride.
Goodbye!: Now, by Saint Peter’s Church and Peter too, he won’t make me a joyful bride here.

Anon!: You come not Like Caesar’s sister.
Goodbye!: You don’t come like Caesar’s sister.

Anon!: Who riseth from a feast With that keen appetite that he sits down?
Goodbye!: Who’s coming from a feast with the appetite he’s sitting down?

Anon!: Dispatch.—Enobarbus!
Goodbye!: Dispatch.—Enobarbus!

Anon!: Oh, wonderful!
Goodbye!: Oh, what a wonderful thing!

Anon!: I like him very well.
Goodbye!: I like him very much.

Anon!: Here love, thou seest how diligent I am, To dress thy meat myself and bring it thee.
Goodbye!: Here love, you see how diligent I am to dress your meat myself and bring it to you.

Anon!: Make haste, lest mine be about your ears ere it be out.
Goodbye!: Hurry up, so I won’t hear your ears before it’s out.

Anon!: I beseech you, what manner of man is he?
Goodbye!: Please, what kind of man is he?

Anon!: Leave you your power to draw, And I shall have no power to follow you.
Goodbye!: Leave you your power to draw, and I won’t have any power to follow you.

Anon!: And, to inure thyself to what thou art like to be, cast thy humble slough and appear fresh.
Goodbye!: And, to get to what you’re like to be, cast your humble slough and appear fresh.

Anon!: Nor must not then be yielded to in this.
Goodbye!: And then, we shouldn’t be given up in this.

Anon!: Come.
Goodbye!: Come on.

Anon!: Tybalt, the kinsman to old Capulet, Hath sent a letter to his father’s house.
Goodbye!: Tybalt, the heir to old Capulet, sent a letter to his father’s house.

Anon!: Sblood, there is something in this more than natural, if philosophy could find it out.
Goodbye!: Sblood, there’s something more natural than that, if philosophy could find it.

Anon!: For I have seen more years, I’m sure, than ye.
Goodbye!: I’ve seen more years, I’m sure, than you.

Anon!: Are you a married man or a bachelor?
Goodbye!: Are you a married man or a bachelor?

Anon!: Pray you, sir, stand up.
Goodbye!: Please, sir, stand up.

Anon!: Do it, England, For like the hectic in my blood he rages, And thou must cure me.
Goodbye!: Do it, England, because like the hectic in my blood he rages, and you have to cure me.

Anon!: Two or three groan.
Goodbye!: Two or three groaners.

Anon!: Remember it, my lord?
Goodbye!: Remember it, my lord?

Anon!: It is but change, Titinius, for Octavius Is overthrown by noble Brutus' power, As Cassius' legions are by Antony.
Goodbye!: It’s only change, Titinius, because Octavius is overthrown by noble Brutus, as Cassius’s legions are by Antony.

Anon!: Why, sir, you know no house nor no such maid, Nor no such men as you have reckoned up, As Stephen Sly and old John Naps of Greece, And Peter Turph and Henry Pimpernell, And twenty more such names and men as these, Which never were, nor no man ever saw.
Goodbye!: You don’t know any house, no such maid, no such men as you’ve guessed, as Stephen Sly and old John Naps of Greece, Peter Turph and Henry Pimpernell, and twenty

Anon!: This it is: 'Tis better that the enemy seek us.
Goodbye!: It’s better for the enemy to seek us.

Anon!: Some villains of my court Are of consent and sufferance in this.
Goodbye!: Some villains of my court are in a position to accept this and suffer.

Anon!: A dog of that house shall move me to stand.
Goodbye!: A dog from that house will move me to stand.

Anon!: Go, go.
Goodbye!: Go, go.

Anon!: And be not jealous on me, gentle Brutus.
Goodbye!: And don’t be jealous of me, gentle Brutus.

Anon!: Show.
Goodbye!: Show.

Anon!: O conspiracy, Shamest thou to show thy dangerous brow by night When evils are most free?
Goodbye!: Oh, conspiracy, are you ashamed to show your dangerous brow by night when evils are free?

Anon!: Good Portia, go to bed.
Goodbye!: Good Portia, go to bed.

Anon!: Sweet Bassanio, my ships have all miscarried.
Goodbye!: Sweet Bassanio, my ships have all been damaged.

Anon!: And as with age his body uglier grows, So his mind cankers.
Goodbye!: And as he grows older, his mind is squeezing.

Anon!: Oh, how mine eyes do loathe his visage now!
Goodbye!: Oh, how my eyes loathe his face now!

Anon!: Do you doubt that?
Goodbye!: Do you doubt that?

Anon!: And where’s Cordelia?— Seest thou this object, Kent?
Goodbye!: And where’s Cordelia?—Do you see this object, Kent?

Anon!: The order was reversed.
Goodbye!: The order was reversed.

Anon!: This is the silliest stuff that ever I heard.
Goodbye!: This is the silliest thing I’ve ever heard.

Anon!: Alas, why gnaw you so your nether lip?
Goodbye!: Why are you so gnawing?

Anon!: Wilt thou, Strato?
Goodbye!: Do you want to, Strato?

Anon!: The strangers all are gone.
Goodbye!: The strangers are all gone.

Anon!: Why, madam, have I offered love for this, To be so flouted in this royal presence?
Goodbye!: Why, madam, have I offered love for this, to be so slanderous in this royal presence?

Anon!: Let me have open means to come to them, And soon I’ll rid you from the fear of them.
Goodbye!: Let me have the right means to come to them, and I’ll rid you of the fear of them soon.

Anon!: Adieu, noble Agrippa.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, noble Agrippa.

Anon!: And be all traitors that do so?
Goodbye!: And are all traitors doing so?

Anon!: Look, here comes a lover of mine and a lover of hers.
Goodbye!: Look, here comes a lover of mine and a lover of hers.

Anon!: I cannot go to, man, nor ’tis not very well.
Goodbye!: I can’t go to, man, and it’s not very well.

Anon!: Good madonna, why mournest thou?
Goodbye!: Hey, madonna, why are you so sad?

Anon!: Well, let it be.— What ho, Malvolio!
Goodbye!: Well, let it be.—What a ho, Malvolio!

Anon!: It was the nightingale, and not the lark, That pierced the fearful hollow of thine ear.
Goodbye!: It was the nightingale, not the lark, that pierced your fearful ear.

Anon!: I do remember well where I should be, And there I am.
Goodbye!: I remember where I should be, and I am here.

Anon!: In my school days, when I had lost one shaft, I shot his fellow of the selfsame flight The selfsame way with more advisèd watch To find the other forth—and by adventuring both, I oft found both.
Goodbye!: In my school days, when I lost one shaft, I shot his fellow out of the same way with more adolescent watches to find the other.

Anon!: I have forgot your name, but sure that part Was aptly fitted and naturally performed.
Goodbye!: I’ve forgotten your name, but I’m sure that part was properly fitted and naturally performed.

Anon!: From that place I shall no leading need.
Goodbye!: I’ll bet I’ll bet I’ll bet I’ll bet I’ll bet I’ll bet I’ll bet I’ll bet I’ll bet I’ll be

Anon!: What, Lucius!
Goodbye!: What, Lucius!

Anon!: How doth my lady?
Goodbye!: How is my lady?

Anon!: Space enough Have I in such a prison.
Goodbye!: I have enough space in such a prison.

Anon!: Silence!
Goodbye!: Quiet!

Anon!: My breath and blood!
Goodbye!: My breath and blood!

Anon!: Take away the lady.
Goodbye!: Take away the lady.

Anon!: I find it still, when I have leave to sleep.
Goodbye!: I find it still, when I’m awake.

Anon!: Besides, you grow dishonest.
Goodbye!: Besides, you’re getting dishonest.

Anon!: Give me a living reason she’s disloyal.
Goodbye!: Give me a living reason she’s disloyal.

Anon!: At home, my lord.
Goodbye!: At home, my lord.

Anon!: And joy comes well in such a needy time.
Goodbye!: And joy comes well in such a difficult time.

Anon!: Oh, how he loves Caesar!
Goodbye!: Oh, how he loves Caesar!

Anon!: Caesar, I shall.
Goodbye!: Caesar, I will.

Anon!: Life and these lips have long been separated.
Goodbye!: Life and these lips have been separated for a long time.

Anon!: It is, my lord.
Goodbye!: It is, my lord.

Anon!: Away, away, for he is coming hither!
Goodbye!: Go away, because he’s coming here!

Anon!: He’s married to Octavia.
Goodbye!: He’s married to Octavia.

Anon!: An you love me, let’s do ’t.
Goodbye!: If you love me, let’s do it.

Anon!: I have heard Your grace hath ta'en great pains to qualify His rigorous course.
Goodbye!: I’ve heard that you’ve made great efforts to qualify for his rigorous course.

Anon!: I say, remember.
Goodbye!: I say, remember.

Anon!: Now, by the world, it is a lusty wench.
Goodbye!: Now, by the world, it’s a lusty wench.

Anon!: I stretch it out for that word “broad,” which, added to the goose, proves thee far and wide a broad goose.
Goodbye!: I’ll use that word “broad,” which, added to the goose, proves you are a wide goose.

Anon!: O, now let Richmond and Elizabeth, The true succeeders of each royal house, By God’s fair ordinance conjoin together, And let their heirs, God, if thy will be so.
Goodbye!: Oh, now let Richmond and Elizabeth, the true successors of each royal house, join together, by God’s fair ordinance, and let their heirs, God, if you’ll be so.

Anon!: Think so, Iago?
Goodbye!: Think so, Iago?

Anon!: I leave my duty a little unthought of and speak out of my injury.
Goodbye!: I’m not thinking about my duties, but I’m not talking about my injuries.

Anon!: Whither goest thou?
Goodbye!: Where are you going?

Anon!: What, thou?
Goodbye!: What, you?

Anon!: It is a fault that springeth from your eye.
Goodbye!: It’s a fault that comes from your eyes.

Anon!: I will seek Some way to leave him.
Goodbye!: I’ll find some way to leave him.

Anon!: Therefore I say with noble Buckingham That it is meet so few should fetch the prince.
Goodbye!: So I tell the noble Buckingham that only a few people should get the prince.

Anon!: Highest queen of state, Great Juno, comes.
Goodbye!: Great Juno, the highest queen of state, comes.

Anon!: What will hap more tonight, safe ’scape the king!
Goodbye!: What will happen tonight, if you escape the king!

Anon!: I hope you will consider what is spoke Comes from my love.
Goodbye!: I hope you’ll consider what I’ve said about my love.

Anon!: I’ll come to thee straight.
Goodbye!: I’ll come to you right away.

Anon!: Draw the curtain straight.
Goodbye!: Draw the curtain straight.

Anon!: He is indeed a horse, and all other jades you may call beasts.
Goodbye!: He’s a horse, and you can call him beasts.

Anon!: What says Romeo?
Goodbye!: What does Romeo say?

Anon!: Tis he, that villain Romeo.
Goodbye!: He’s the villain Romeo.

Anon!: Ay, boy.
Goodbye!: Yes, boy.

Anon!: Can you tell if Rosalind, the duke’s daughter, be banished with her father?
Goodbye!: Can you tell if Rosalind, the duke’s daughter, is banished with her father?

Anon!: By heaven, it is as proper to our age To cast beyond ourselves in our opinions As it is common for the younger sort To lack discretion.
Goodbye!: I swear by God, it’s as appropriate to our age to think beyond ourselves, as it is common for younger people to be deprived of discretion.

Anon!: Things that are past are done, with me.
Goodbye!: Things that have happened before are done with me.

Anon!: Therefore with frank and with uncurbèd plainness Tell us the Dauphin’s mind.
Goodbye!: Tell us the Dauphin’s mind so clearly and honestly.

Anon!: But I pray, can you read anything you see?
Goodbye!: But please, can you read anything you see?

Anon!: He dreams.
Goodbye!: He’s dreaming.

Anon!: Do you know what you say?
Goodbye!: Do you know what you’re saying?

Anon!: What soldiers, whey-face?
Goodbye!: What soldiers, whey-face?

Anon!: Marry, that, I think, be young Petruchio.
Goodbye!: I think that’s young Petruchio.

Anon!: How far’st thou, soldier?
Goodbye!: How are you, soldier?

Anon!: Upon mine honor, Myself, my brother, and this grievèd count Did see her, hear her, at that hour last night Talk with a ruffian at her chamber window Who hath indeed, most like a liberal villain, Confessed the vile encounters they have had A thousand times in secret.
Goodbye!: I swear, my brother, and this grieving count saw her, hear her, at that hour last night talk with a ruffian at her window, who, like a liberal villain, has actually confessed

Anon!: What noise is this?
Goodbye!: What’s this noise?

Anon!: Fear comes upon me.
Goodbye!: Fear comes on me.

Anon!: How low am I, thou painted maypole?
Goodbye!: How low am I, you painted a maypole?

Anon!: For, by this light of heaven, I know not how I lost him.
Goodbye!: I don’t know how I lost him.

Anon!: You taught me language, and my profit on ’t Is I know how to curse.
Goodbye!: You taught me language, and I know how to curse.

Anon!: I long with all my heart to see the prince.
Goodbye!: I’ve been waiting for the prince to see him.

Anon!: If I had, my weapon should quickly have been out, I warrant you.
Goodbye!: If I had, my weapon would have been out quickly, I assure you.

Anon!: Calling death “banishment,” Thou cutt’st my head off with a golden ax And smilest upon the stroke that murders me.
Goodbye!: Calling death banishment, you cut my head off with a golden ax and smiled at the stroke that killed me.

Anon!: What stature is she of?
Goodbye!: What is she about?

Anon!: Let not that doctor e'er come near my house!
Goodbye!: Don’t let that doctor come near my house!

Anon!: I see the business.
Goodbye!: I see the business.

Anon!: Peace, you mumbling fool!
Goodbye!: Quiet, you mumbling fool!

Anon!: I may command where I adore, But silence, like a Lucrece knife, With bloodless stroke my heart doth gore; M.O.A.I.
Goodbye!: I can command where I love, but silence, like a knife, is going to gore with my bloodless heart.

Anon!: That I was disdainful and that I had my good wit out of The Hundred Merry Tales!
Goodbye!: I was disdainful and had my good wit out of The Hundred Merry Tales!

Anon!: Is she so hot a shrew as she’s reported?
Goodbye!: Is she as a shrew as she’s reported?

Anon!: Farewell, good Salisbury, and good luck go with thee.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, good Salisbury, and good luck go with you.

Anon!: These times of woe afford no time to woo.
Goodbye!: These times of sorrow don’t give us time to woo.

Anon!: Keep me in temper.
Goodbye!: Keep me calm.

Anon!: You do not mind the play.
Goodbye!: You don’t mind the play.

Anon!: Think’st thou I’d make a life of jealousy, To follow still the changes of the moon With fresh suspicions?
Goodbye!: Do you think I’d make a life of jealousy, to follow the moon’s changes with new suspicions?

Anon!: Now the fleeting moon No planet is of mine.
Goodbye!: Now the moon is a fleeting moon.

Anon!: Banquo!
Goodbye!: Banquo!

Anon!: I charge you, as you hope to have redemption, By Christ’s dear blood shed for our grievous sins, That you depart, and lay no hands on me.
Goodbye!: I ask you, as you hope to have redemption, that you leave and don’t lay any hands on me.

Anon!: There will she hide her To listen our propose.
Goodbye!: She’ll hide there to listen to our proposal.

Anon!: Fut, I should have been that I am, had the maidenliest star in the firmament twinkled on my bastardizing.
Goodbye!: I wish I were the one who had twinkled on my bastardizing.

Anon!: It were pity to cast them away for nothing, though between them and a great cause they should be esteemed nothing.
Goodbye!: It’s pity to cast them away for nothing, even if they’re not worthy of anything.

Anon!: I pray you, have a continent forbearance till the speed of his rage goes slower.
Goodbye!: Please, have a continent forbearance until his rage is slower.

Anon!: Trip, Audrey, trip, Audrey.—I attend, I attend.
Goodbye!: I’m here, Audrey.

Anon!: I thank you, sir.
Goodbye!: Thank you, sir.

Anon!: Scurvy knave!
Goodbye!: Scurvy knave!

Anon!: My life were better ended by their hate Than death proroguèd, wanting of thy love.
Goodbye!: I’d rather die by their hate than by dying, because I wanted to love you.

Anon!: Give me thy torch, boy.
Goodbye!: Give me your torch, boy.

Anon!: But till this afternoon his passion Ne'er brake into extremity of rage.
Goodbye!: But until today’s afternoon, his passion hasn’t risen into a rage.

Anon!: Patience, good sir.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, sir.

Anon!: Mine eyes did sicken at the sight and could not Endure a further view.
Goodbye!: I couldn’t see any further.

Anon!: There’s but one down.
Goodbye!: There’s only one down there.

Anon!: When went there by an age, since the great flood, But it was famed with more than with one man?
Goodbye!: When did it go there by an age, since the great flood, but it was famous with more than one man?

Anon!: I often came where I did hear of her, but cannot find her.
Goodbye!: I often came to the place I heard of her, but I can’t find her.

Anon!: Who wouldst thou serve?
Goodbye!: Who do you want?

Anon!: I pray thee, peace.
Goodbye!: Please, calm down.

Anon!: You must contrary me.
Goodbye!: You have to contradict me.

Anon!: Seyton!—I am sick at heart, When I behold—Seyton, I say!—This push Will cheer me ever, or disseat me now.
Goodbye!: Seyton!—I’m sick at heart when I see—Seyton, I say!—This push will cheer me ever, or disseat me now.

Anon!: He shall have merely justice and his bond.
Goodbye!: He’ll have justice and his bond.

Anon!: I am the very man— I’ll see that straight.
Goodbye!: I’m the man— I’ll see that right away.

Anon!: Say to the king I would attend his leisure For a few words.
Goodbye!: Tell the king I’d like to go to his leisure for a few words.

Anon!: Let him alone awhile.
Goodbye!: Let him rest for a while.

Anon!: I fear thou wilt once more come again for a ransom.
Goodbye!: I’m afraid you’ll come back again for a ransom.

Anon!: How should they, when that wise men have no eyes?
Goodbye!: How should they, when wise men don’t have eyes?

Anon!: Ourselves we do not owe.
Goodbye!: We’re not ourselves.

Anon!: I thought thy heart had been wounded with the claws of a lion.
Goodbye!: I thought your heart had been wounded with the claws of a lion.

Anon!: It is a poison tempered by himself.
Goodbye!: It’s a poison that’s been tempered by himself.

Anon!: Yes, I intend so.
Goodbye!: Yes, I’m going to do so.

Anon!: Let us withdraw.
Goodbye!: Let’s go.

Anon!: See not your bride in these unreverent robes.
Goodbye!: Don’t see your bride in these unreliable robes.

Anon!: Is all the counsel that we two have shared, The sisters' vows, the hours that we have spent When we have chid the hasty-footed time For parting us—oh, is it all forgot?
Goodbye!: Is all the advice we have shared, the sisters’ vows, the hours we’ve spent when we sat on the waiting table for us to join us—oh, is it all forgotten?

Anon!: The more my wrong, the more his spite appears.
Goodbye!: The more I’m wrong, the more he seems to be spiteful.

Anon!: Speak, I charge you.
Goodbye!: Speak, I’m telling you.

Anon!: O most wicked fiend!
Goodbye!: Oh, what a wicked fiend!

Anon!: How now, my hearts!
Goodbye!: What’s going on, my hearts?

Anon!: Follow me, then.
Goodbye!: Follow me, then.

Anon!: What, ho, Brabantio!
Goodbye!: Hey, Brabantio!

Anon!: I will have my bond.
Goodbye!: I’ll get my bond.

Anon!: No.
Goodbye!: No.

Anon!: It shall be to your good, for my father’s house and all the revenue that was old Sir Rowland’s will I estate upon you, and here live and die a shepherd.
Goodbye!: It will be to your benefit, because my father’s house and all the money that was Sir Rowland’s estate will be inherited from you, and here live and die a shepherd.

Anon!: Well, I’ll go hide the body in some hole Till that the duke give order for his burial.
Goodbye!: Well, I’ll go hide the body in some hole until the duke orders his burial.

Anon!: From all such devils, good Lord, deliver us!
Goodbye!: Go ahead, Lord.

Anon!: More than pertains to feats of broils and battle, And therefore little shall I grace my cause In speaking for myself.
Goodbye!: More than anything about battle, I’ll do nothing to help me speak for myself.

Anon!: Unhappy fortune!
Goodbye!: Unhappy fortune!

Anon!: I cannot hear of any that did see her.
Goodbye!: I can’t hear any of those who saw her.

Anon!: Nay, we will slink away in supper time, Disguise us at my lodging, and return, All in an hour.
Goodbye!: No, we’ll slink away at dinner time, disguise us at my house, and return in an hour.

Anon!: I am famished in his service.
Goodbye!: I’m famished by his service.

Anon!: How now?
Goodbye!: What’s going on?

Anon!: You must say “paragon.” A “paramour” is, God bless us, a thing of naught.
Goodbye!: You have to say “paragon.” A “paramour” is, God bless us, a thing of naughtyness.

Anon!: They are wise and honorable, And will, no doubt, with reasons answer you.
Goodbye!: They’re wise and honorable, and will answer you with reasons, no doubt.

Anon!: Harpier cries, “'Tis time, ’tis time.” Round about the cauldron go, In the poisoned entrails throw.
Goodbye!: Harpier cries, “It’s time, it’s time.” Round around the cauldron go, in the poisoned entrails throw.

Anon!: For the table, sir, it shall be served in.
Goodbye!: For the table, sir, it will be served in.

Anon!: How fares my Juliet?
Goodbye!: How is my Juliet?

Anon!: Yet here, Laertes?
Goodbye!: But here, Laertes?
