Anon!: Twere good you let him know, For who that’s but a queen, fair, sober, wise, Would from a paddock, from a bat, a gib, Such dear concernings hide?
Goodbye!: You’d be good to tell him, because who’s just a queen, fair, sober, wise, would hide from a paddock, from a bat, a gib, such a dear concern?

Anon!: This health to Lepidus!
Goodbye!: Give Lepidus this health!

Anon!: In some bush?
Goodbye!: In some bush?

Anon!: This is a very scurvy tune to sing at a man’s funeral.
Goodbye!: This is a very scurvy tune to sing at a man’s funeral.

Anon!: Yet here’s a spot.
Goodbye!: But here’s a spot.

Anon!: This deed I’ll do before this purpose cool.
Goodbye!: I’ll do this deed before I get to the point.

Anon!: Have I the aspic in my lips?
Goodbye!: Have I seen the aspic in my lips?

Anon!: I love thee well in that thou lik’st it not.
Goodbye!: I love you so much that you don’t like it.

Anon!: I am not for this ambling.
Goodbye!: I’m not for this ambling.

Anon!: Nor I neither, by this heavenly light.
Goodbye!: I don’t, by this heavenly light.

Anon!: I pray you, sirs, lie in my tent and sleep.
Goodbye!: Please, sirs, lie in my tent and sleep.

Anon!: My lord, whoever journeys to the prince, For God’s sake let not us two at home.
Goodbye!: My lord, whoever goes to the prince, for God’s sake, don’t let us two at home.

Anon!: Well held out, i' faith.
Goodbye!: Good, I’m sure.

Anon!: Be the Jacks fair within, the Jills fair without, the carpets laid, and everything in order?
Goodbye!: Are the Jacks in the house, the Jills in the house, the carpets laid, and everything in order?

Anon!: Master young man, you, I pray you, which is the way to Master Jew’s?
Goodbye!: You, master young man, please, which way to the Master Jew’s?

Anon!: Now by my life, Old fools are babes again and must be used With checks as flatteries, when they are seen abused.
Goodbye!: Now, by my life, old fools are babies again and must be used with checks as flatteries when they’re seen abused.

Anon!: Who was ’t came by?
Goodbye!: Who came here?

Anon!: Send thy man away.
Goodbye!: Send your man away.

Anon!: I' faith, I thank him.
Goodbye!: I’m sure he’s done well.

Anon!: Her blood is settled, and her joints are stiff.
Goodbye!: Her blood is settled, and her joints are stiff.

Anon!: No, let me know, And knowing what I am, I know what she shall be.
Goodbye!: No, let me know, and knowing what I am, I know what she will be.

Anon!: Gentleman, God save thee.
Goodbye!: Gentleman, God save you.

Anon!: It begins “Hold thy peace.” I shall never begin if I hold my peace.
Goodbye!: It starts “Hold your peace.” I’ll never begin if I hold my peace.

Anon!: Down with him, thief!
Goodbye!: Down with him, thief!

Anon!: Stay yet.
Goodbye!: Stay here.

Anon!: Very vilely in the morning, when he is sober, and most vilely in the afternoon, when he is drunk.
Goodbye!: He’s very vile in the morning, when he’s sober, and most vile in the afternoon, when he’s drunk.

Anon!: He would have deserved it.
Goodbye!: He would have deserved it.

Anon!: And we did think it writ down in our duty To let you know of it.
Goodbye!: And we thought it was our duty to tell you about it.

Anon!: What’s here?
Goodbye!: What’s this?

Anon!: But, let me see, by ten We shall have each a hundred Englishmen.
Goodbye!: But let me see, by ten we’ll have each a hundred Englishmen.

Anon!: Speak but one rhyme, and I am satisfied.
Goodbye!: Speak one rhyme, and I’m satisfied.

Anon!: I dare not drink yet, madam.
Goodbye!: I don’t dare drink yet, madam.

Anon!: Have you any further trade with us?
Goodbye!: Have you ever had any other trade with us?

Anon!: And I know not what’s spent in the search.
Goodbye!: And I don’t know what’s going on in the search.

Anon!: O Fates, come, come, Cut thread and thrum.
Goodbye!: Oh, Fates, come, come, cut thread and thrum.

Anon!: We will go walk a little in the orchard, And then to dinner.
Goodbye!: We’ll go walk a little in the orchard, then to dinner.

Anon!: That way the noise is.
Goodbye!: That’s what the noise is.

Anon!: Mistake no more.
Goodbye!: Don’t misunderstand it.

Anon!: You shall have the mustard Or else you get no beef of Grumio.
Goodbye!: You’ll have the mustard or you’ll have no beef from Grumio.

Anon!: Did you and he consent in Cassio’s death?
Goodbye!: Did you and he consent to Cassio’s death?

Anon!: And those that leave their valiant bones in France, Dying like men though buried in your dunghills, They shall be famed; for there the sun shall greet them And draw their honors reeking up to heaven, Leaving their earthly parts to choke your clime,
Goodbye!: And those who leave their valiant bones in France, buried in your dunghills, will be famous for their braveness.

Anon!: Swagger?
Goodbye!: Swagger?

Anon!: Tis age that nourisheth.
Goodbye!: It’s age that nourishes us.

Anon!: How shall that faith return again to earth, Unless that husband send it me from heaven By leaving earth?
Goodbye!: How will that faith return to earth unless my husband sends it to me by leaving the earth?

Anon!: Hillo, ho, ho, boy.
Goodbye!: Hillo, ho, ho, boy.

Anon!: Cassio did top her, ask thy husband else.
Goodbye!: Cassio did top her, ask your husband else.

Anon!: My father compounded with my mother under the dragon’s tail and my nativity was under Ursa Major, so that it follows I am rough and lecherous.
Goodbye!: My father was surrounded with my mother under the dragon’s tail, and my nativity was under Ursa Major, so I’m rough and lecherous.

Anon!: You’ll not endure him!
Goodbye!: You won’t endure him!

Anon!: Pardon me, I pray you.
Goodbye!: Pardon me, please.

Anon!: My lord?
Goodbye!: My lord?

Anon!: We have here recovered the most dangerous piece of lechery that ever was known in the commonwealth.
Goodbye!: We’ve recovered the most dangerous piece of lechery ever known in the commonwealth.

Anon!: Upon the right hand I.
Goodbye!: I’m right on the right hand.

Anon!: Why would you be so fond to overcome The bonny prizer of the humorous duke?
Goodbye!: Why would you be so fond of beating the bonny prizer of the humorous duke?

Anon!: Be not offended.
Goodbye!: Don’t be offended.

Anon!: Corinth first.
Goodbye!: Corinth first.

Anon!: For what advancement may I hope from thee That no revenue hast but thy good spirits, To feed and clothe thee?
Goodbye!: What can I hope for you that no one has any revenue except your good spirits, to feed and clothe you?

Anon!: But here my father comes.
Goodbye!: But here comes my father.

Anon!: Alas, what ignorant sin have I committed?
Goodbye!: What kind of ignorant sin have I committed?

Anon!: By the eighth hour.
Goodbye!: By the eighth hour.

Anon!: The Lord protect him from that kingly title!
Goodbye!: The Lord protect him from that kingly title!

Anon!: I am now in great haste, as it may appear unto you.
Goodbye!: I’m in great hurry now, as it may appear to you.

Anon!: O Ratcliffe, I have dreamed a fearful dream!
Goodbye!: Oh Ratcliffe, I’ve dreamed of a fearful dream!

Anon!: Shall we go send them dinners and fresh suits, And give their fasting horses provender, And after fight with them?
Goodbye!: Should we go send them dinners and fresh suits, and give their fasting horses a provender, and fight with them after that?

Anon!: What do you think Of marching to Philippi presently?
Goodbye!: What do you think of marching to Philippi now?

Anon!: Conception is a blessing, but, as your daughter may conceive—Friend, look to ’t.
Goodbye!: It’s a blessing to think about it, but as your daughter may think—Friend, look at it.

Anon!: So young, my lord, and true.
Goodbye!: That’s so young, my lord, and true.

Anon!: Nay, but hear me.
Goodbye!: No, but listen to me.

Anon!: Now, darting Parthia, art thou struck, and now Pleased fortune does of Marcus Crassus’ death Make me revenger.
Goodbye!: Now, Parthia, you’ve been struck, and now the fortune of Marcus Crassus’ death makes me revenger.

Anon!: I must have liberty Withal, as large a charter as the wind, To blow on whom I please, for so fools have.
Goodbye!: I have to have the freedom to blow on anyone I want, as fools have.

Anon!: They have their exits and their entrances, And one man in his time plays many parts, His acts being seven ages.
Goodbye!: They have their exits and their entrances, and one man has played many parts of his life, his actions being seven ages.

Anon!: The king is mad.
Goodbye!: The king is crazy.

Anon!: Let me go, sir, or I’ll knock you o'er the mazzard.
Goodbye!: Let me go, sir, or I’ll knock you out of the maze.

Anon!: For this, be sure, tonight thou shalt have cramps, Side-stitches that shall pen thy breath up.
Goodbye!: For this, be sure, tonight you’ll have cramps, side-stitches that will hold your breath up.

Anon!: Know’st thou Fluellen?
Goodbye!: Do you know Fluellen?

Anon!: One knocks.
Goodbye!: One knocks.

Anon!: Either be patient and entreat me fair, Or with the clamorous report of war Thus will I drown your exclamations.
Goodbye!: Either be patient and be fair, or I’ll drown your exclamations with the clamorous report of war.

Anon!: I do confess my fault, And do submit me to Your Highness' mercy.
Goodbye!: I confess my fault and submit myself to your Highness’s mercy.

Anon!: Henceforward do your messages yourself.
Goodbye!: Now, do your messages yourself.

Anon!: Piece out our imperfections with your thoughts.
Goodbye!: Take out our imperfections with your thoughts.

Anon!: Why, how now, Count, wherefore are you sad?
Goodbye!: Why, how are you sad now, count?

Anon!: You must note beside, That we have tried the utmost of our friends, Our legions are brim-full, our cause is ripe.
Goodbye!: You must note that we’ve tried all our friends, our army is full of brims, and our cause is ripe.

Anon!: Give me my principal, and let me go.
Goodbye!: Give me my principal, and let me go.

Anon!: He passes some humors and careers.
Goodbye!: He’s going to do some humor and career.

Anon!: At land indeed Thou dost o’ercount me of my father’s house, But since the cuckoo builds not for himself, Remain in ’t as thou mayst.
Goodbye!: You’re in the land, indeed, and you’re letting me know of my father’s house, but since the cuckoo doesn’t build for himself, you can stay in the land as you can.

Anon!: God rest you merry, sir.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, sir.

Anon!: Amen.
Goodbye!: Amen.

Anon!: I know you by the waggling of your head.
Goodbye!: I know you by the wiggle of your head.

Anon!: Thou shalt not from this grove Till I torment thee for this injury.— My gentle Puck, come hither.
Goodbye!: You won’t leave this grove until I’m tormenting you for this injury.—My gentle Puck, come here.

Anon!: I am glad thy father’s dead, Thy match was mortal to him, and pure grief Shore his old thread in twain.
Goodbye!: I’m glad your father’s dead, your match was mortal to him, and pure grief smothered his old thread in two.

Anon!: I will none.
Goodbye!: I won’t.

Anon!: Fare you well.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: Good night, good night.
Goodbye!: Good night, good night.

Anon!: My master, and my lord!
Goodbye!: My master, and my lord!

Anon!: I know not.
Goodbye!: I don’t know.

Anon!: What hast thou found?
Goodbye!: What have you found?

Anon!: Here.
Goodbye!: Here.

Anon!: Robin Starveling, the tailor?
Goodbye!: Robin Starveling, the tailor?

Anon!: Nay, very pale.
Goodbye!: No, very pale.

Anon!: I pray you, keep it in.
Goodbye!: Please, keep it in.

Anon!: My arm is sore.
Goodbye!: My arm is sore.

Anon!: Over thy wounds now do I prophesy— Which, like dumb mouths, do ope their ruby lips To beg the voice and utterance of my tongue— A curse shall light upon the limbs of men.
Goodbye!: I’m telling you that over your wounds, you’re oping their lips like dumb mouths, to beg my voice and speak my tongue—that curse will be a curse on the limbs of men.

Anon!: But I have cause to pry into this pedant.
Goodbye!: But I have reason to pry into this pedant.

Anon!: How!
Goodbye!: How!

Anon!: But I remember now I am in this earthly world, where to do harm Is often laudable, to do good sometime Accounted dangerous folly.
Goodbye!: But now I remember I’m in this earthly world, where it’s often laudable to do harm, and to do good in a moment, I’m a dangerous man.

Anon!: Why, sir, her name’s a word, and to dally with that word might make my sister wanton.
Goodbye!: Why, sir, her name’s a word, and to dally that word might make my sister want to be a bit more sane.

Anon!: Why then, thou hast it.
Goodbye!: Well then, you have it.

Anon!: The gods are just, and of our pleasant vices Make instruments to plague us.
Goodbye!: The gods are just, and our good vices make us plagued.

Anon!: What beard were I best to play it in?
Goodbye!: What beard would I use to play it in?

Anon!: I rather choose To wrong the dead, to wrong myself and you, Than I will wrong such honorable men.
Goodbye!: I’d rather choose to wrong the dead, to wrong myself and you than I will wrong such honorable men.

Anon!: Is this a dagger which I see before me, The handle toward my hand?
Goodbye!: Is this a dagger I see before me, the handle toward my hand?

Anon!: Kill!
Goodbye!: Kill!

Anon!: Good night to you.
Goodbye!: Good night to you.

Anon!: The iron tongue of midnight hath told twelve.
Goodbye!: The iron tongue of midnight has told twelve.

Anon!: Call you?
Goodbye!: Do you call me?

Anon!: Is it answered?
Goodbye!: Is that the answer?

Anon!: Her husband, knave.
Goodbye!: Her husband, knave.

Anon!: O, I die, Horatio.
Goodbye!: Oh, I die, Horatio.

Anon!: I will have nothing else but only this.
Goodbye!: I’ll only have this.

Anon!: He would not take the crown.
Goodbye!: He wouldn’t take the crown.

Anon!: That I ask again, For nothing can be ill if she be well.
Goodbye!: I ask again, because nothing can be bad if she’s well.

Anon!: Directly, I am going to Caesar’s funeral.
Goodbye!: I’m going to Caesar’s funeral.

Anon!: Sir, in good faith, or in sincere verity, Under th' allowance of your great aspect, Whose influence, like the wreath of radiant fire On flickering Phoebus' front—      What mean’st by this?
Goodbye!: Sir, in good faith or in sincere reassurance, under your great influence, whose influence, like the wreath of radiant fire on flickering Phoebus’s front— What do you mean by this?

Anon!: The forfeit, sovereign, of my servant’s life, Who slew today a riotous gentleman Lately attendant on the duke of Norfolk.
Goodbye!: The forfeit of my servant’s life, sovereign, who slew today a riotous gentleman who was waiting for the duke of Norfolk.

Anon!: But upon the fairest boughs, Or at every sentence end, Will I “Rosalinda” write, Teaching all that read to know The quintessence of every sprite Heaven would in little show.
Goodbye!: But I’ll write “Rosalinda” on the fairest boughs or at every sentence, teaching all who read to know the quintessence of every sprite Heaven would be in a

Anon!: But, sir, forgive me, Since my becomings kill me when they do not Eye well to you.
Goodbye!: But forgive me, sir, since my becomings kill me when they don’t look good to you.

Anon!: If you shall cleave to my consent, when ’tis, It shall make honor for you.
Goodbye!: If you cleave to my consent, when it’s time, it’ll honor you.

Anon!: Come now, what masques, what dances shall we have To wear away this long age of three hours Between our after-supper and bedtime?
Goodbye!: What dances should we have to wear away this long time of three hours between our dinner and bedtime?

Anon!: Am I in France?
Goodbye!: Am I in France?

Anon!: Disloyal?
Goodbye!: Disloyal?

Anon!: Who does he accuse?
Goodbye!: Who is he accusing?

Anon!: But fare you well.
Goodbye!: But goodbye.

Anon!: Towards him I made, but he was 'ware of me And stole into the covert of the wood.
Goodbye!: I made him to him, but he was ware of me and stole into the woods.

Anon!: No, my fair cousin.
Goodbye!: No, my fair cousin.

Anon!: What, not a whore?
Goodbye!: What, not a whore?

Anon!: Alas, my lord, Your wisdom is consumed in confidence.
Goodbye!: Oh, my lord, your wisdom is consumed in confidence.

Anon!: But you and I And honest Casca, we have the falling sickness.
Goodbye!: But you and I, and honest Casca, we’re suffering from the falling sickness.

Anon!: Stay not to answer me, but get thee gone.
Goodbye!: Don’t stay to answer me, but get out of here.

Anon!: She has robbed me of my sword.
Goodbye!: She has robbed me of my sword.

Anon!: Some god direct my judgment!
Goodbye!: Some god will direct my judgment!

Anon!: Why, sir, you know this is your wedding day.
Goodbye!: You know that this is your wedding day.

Anon!: Come forth.
Goodbye!: Come out.

Anon!: I have performed Your pleasure and my promise.
Goodbye!: I’ve done your pleasure and my promise.

Anon!: Therefore this project
Goodbye!: So this project

Anon!: In faith, lady, you have a merry heart.
Goodbye!: You’re a good man, lady.

Anon!: I can see yet without spectacles, and I see no such matter.
Goodbye!: I can see without spectacles, and I can’t see anything like that.

Anon!: I should sin To think but nobly of my grandmother.
Goodbye!: I’d sin to think a little bit about my grandmother.

Anon!: Good shepherd, tell this youth what ’tis to love.
Goodbye!: Good shepherd, tell this young man what it means to love.

Anon!: The wisdom of your duty, fair Bianca, Hath cost me an hundred crowns since suppertime.
Goodbye!: Your wisdom has cost me an hundred crowns since dinnertime.

Anon!: What is the success?
Goodbye!: What’s the success?

Anon!: Beshrew my very heart, I think you are happy in this second match, For it excels your first.
Goodbye!: I think you’re happy in this second match, because it’s your first match.

Anon!: And make him with fair Ægles break his faith, With Ariadne and Antiopa?
Goodbye!: And make him break his faith with a fair gle, with Ariadne and Antiopa?

Anon!: I would he knew that I had saved his brother.
Goodbye!: I wish he knew I saved his brother.

Anon!: Thy love?
Goodbye!: Your love?

Anon!: By my knavery (if I had it), then I were.
Goodbye!: I swear by my knavery (if I had it), then I were.

Anon!: You are my elder.
Goodbye!: You’re my older man.

Anon!: What an eye she has!
Goodbye!: What an eye she has!

Anon!: Too old by heaven.
Goodbye!: Too old by heaven.

Anon!: The love that follows us sometime is our trouble, Which still we thank as love.
Goodbye!: The love that follows us may be our problem, which we still thank as love.

Anon!: Look where she comes.
Goodbye!: Look, she comes.

Anon!: Oh, think’st thou we shall ever meet again?
Goodbye!: Oh, do you think we’ll ever meet again?

Anon!: We do not come as minding to contest you, Our true intent is.
Goodbye!: We don’t come as a fool to contest you, but we’re not going to be.

Anon!: Be not too tame neither, but let your own discretion be your tutor.
Goodbye!: Don’t be too tame, but let your own discretion be your tutor.

Anon!: Committed?
Goodbye!: Have you been told?

Anon!: I knew it would be your answer.
Goodbye!: I knew it would be your answer.

Anon!: Holy Franciscan Friar!
Goodbye!: Holy Franciscan Friar!

Anon!: Oh, these men, these men!
Goodbye!: Oh, these men, these men!

Anon!: Friends, Romans, countrymen, lend me your ears.
Goodbye!: Friends, Romans, countrymen, give me your ears.

Anon!: Why, may one ask?
Goodbye!: Why, can I ask?

Anon!: Thou art thy father’s daughter.
Goodbye!: You’re your father’s daughter.

Anon!: And let him ply his music.
Goodbye!: And let him ply his music.

Anon!: Why, bride!
Goodbye!: Hey, bride!

Anon!: And this, Metellus Cimber.
Goodbye!: And this is Metellus Cimber.

Anon!: I thank you for your pains.
Goodbye!: Thank you for your efforts.

Anon!: You know that you are Brutus that speak this, Or, by the gods, this speech were else your last.
Goodbye!: You know that you’re Brutus who speak this, or, by the gods, this speech was your last.

Anon!: I have.
Goodbye!: I have.

Anon!: If I do prove her haggard, Though that her jesses were my dear heartstrings, I’d whistle her off and let her down the wind To prey at fortune.
Goodbye!: If I prove her haggard, even though her jesses were my dear heartstrings, I’d whistle her off and let her down the wind to take revenge.

Anon!: How died my master, Strato?
Goodbye!: How did my master die, Strato?

Anon!: Come, let me wipe thy face.
Goodbye!: Come on, let me wipe your face.

Anon!: He himself Calls her a nonpareil.
Goodbye!: He himself calls her a nonpareil.

Anon!: Madam, you must come to your uncle.
Goodbye!: Madam, you have to come to your uncle.

Anon!: For gazing on your beams, fair sun, being by.
Goodbye!: You’re just gazing on your beams, a fair sun, and being near.

Anon!: I’ll bring you to him.
Goodbye!: I’ll bring you to him.

Anon!: Tyrants themselves wept when it was reported.
Goodbye!: Tyrants were crying when it was reported.

Anon!: Plucks off my beard and blows it in my face?
Goodbye!: Plucks off my beard and blows it in my face?

Anon!: I do not well know, my lord.
Goodbye!: I don’t know, my lord.

Anon!: My noble lord— What dost thou say, Iago?
Goodbye!: My noble lord— What do you say, Iago?

Anon!: Sir, pardon me in what I have to say.
Goodbye!: Sir, pardon me for what I’m saying.

Anon!: Excellent.
Goodbye!: Excellent.

Anon!: Yes.
Goodbye!: Yes.

Anon!: Come between us, good Benvolio.
Goodbye!: Come between us, Benvolio.

Anon!: He finished indeed his mortal act That day that made my sister thirteen years.
Goodbye!: He finished his mortal act on the day my sister was thirteen.

Anon!: No more.
Goodbye!: Don’t worry.

Anon!: Why, so didst thou.
Goodbye!: Why, so did you.

Anon!: The skies are painted with unnumbered sparks.
Goodbye!: The skies are painted with unnumbered sparks.

Anon!: Ascend her chamber, hence, and comfort her.
Goodbye!: Ascend her room and comfort her.

Anon!: Send out more horses.
Goodbye!: Send out more horses.

Anon!: Yes, madam, he was of that consort.
Goodbye!: Yes, madam, he was from that consort.

Anon!: What features?
Goodbye!: What features?

Anon!: Do you not hear it ring?
Goodbye!: Don’t you hear it ring?

Anon!: And in this habit Met I my father with his bleeding rings, Their precious stones new lost, became his guide, Led him, begged for him, saved him from despair.
Goodbye!: And in this way, I became my father with his bleeding rings, their precious stones lost, and became his guide, led him, begged for him, and saved him from despair.

Anon!: Yet you have all the vantage of her wrong.
Goodbye!: But you have all the advantages of her wrong.

Anon!: Is he come home yet?
Goodbye!: Is he coming home yet?

Anon!: Give me leave awhile.
Goodbye!: Give me permission for a while.

Anon!: And I another So weary with disasters, tugged with fortune, That I would set my life on any chance, To mend it or be rid on ’t.
Goodbye!: And I’m so tired of disasters, tugged with fortune, that I’d give my life any chance to do it or get rid of it.

Anon!: One face, one voice, one habit, and two persons!
Goodbye!: One face, one voice, one habit, and two people!

Anon!: One of them rates All that is won and lost.
Goodbye!: One of them is the one who wins and loses all the money.

Anon!: Father, what news?
Goodbye!: Father, what news do you have?

Anon!: In the meantime, let me be that I am, and seek not to alter me.
Goodbye!: In the meantime, let me be that I am, and not try to change me.

Anon!: Thou changèd and self-covered thing, for shame!
Goodbye!: You’re changing and self-covered, for shame!

Anon!: I’ll devil-porter it no further.
Goodbye!: I won’t take it any further.

Anon!: Alas, I took great pains to study it, and ’tis poetical.
Goodbye!: I took great pains to study it, and it’s poetic.

Anon!: I am a gentleman, sir, and my name is Conrade.
Goodbye!: I’m a gentleman, sir, and my name is Conrade.

Anon!: And in good time, Here comes Sir Richard Ratcliffe and the duke.
Goodbye!: And in good time, here comes Sir Richard Ratcliffe and the duke.

Anon!: Sebastian are you?
Goodbye!: Are you Sebastian?

Anon!: Besides, there is no king, be his cause never so spotless, if it come to the arbitrament of swords, can try it out with all unspotted soldiers.
Goodbye!: Besides, there is no king, if he’s not so sane, that if he’s going to fight with all unreliable soldiers.

Anon!: You’re fall’n into a princely hand.
Goodbye!: You’re falling into a princely hand.

Anon!: Stones have been known to move, and trees to speak.
Goodbye!: Stones have been known to move, and trees to speak.

Anon!: Hover about her; say that right for right Hath dimmed your infant morn to agèd night.
Goodbye!: Go ahead and say right for right has dimmed your infant to a night.

Anon!: We three are married, but you two are sped.
Goodbye!: We three are married, but you two are sped.

Anon!: What, has this thing appeared again tonight?
Goodbye!: Has this thing appeared again tonight?

Anon!: Cheerly, boys.
Goodbye!: Cheers, boys.

Anon!: Never trust me, then.
Goodbye!: Don’t trust me, then.

Anon!: Thou never shalt hear herald anymore.
Goodbye!: You’ll never hear herald again.

Anon!: Sir, the Queen.
Goodbye!: Sir, the Queen.

Anon!: Go ask his name.—If he be married.
Goodbye!: Go ask his name.—If he’s married.

Anon!: What’s the matter?
Goodbye!: What’s the matter?

Anon!: Brutus killed me.
Goodbye!: Brutus killed me.

Anon!: Who chooseth me shall have as much as he deserves”!
Goodbye!: Who chooses me will have as much as he deserves”!

Anon!: Or I do forget myself?
Goodbye!: Or I forget myself?

Anon!: I know this is a joyful trouble to you, But yet ’tis one.
Goodbye!: I know this is a joyful thing to do for you, but it’s not a problem.

Anon!: What’s the matter, dear?
Goodbye!: What’s the matter, dear?

Anon!: All may be well enough.
Goodbye!: All could be good enough.

Anon!: Most like.
Goodbye!: I’m very happy.

Anon!: Wrinkles forbid!
Goodbye!: Wrinkles forbid!

Anon!: Faith, her privates we.
Goodbye!: Yes, we are her privates.

Anon!: Pray, then, foresee me one.
Goodbye!: Please, then, tell me one.

Anon!: Let him come when he will, I will deny thee nothing.
Goodbye!: Let him come when he wants, I won’t deny you anything.

Anon!: You might have saved me my pains to have taken it away yourself.
Goodbye!: You could have saved me my pains to take it away yourself.

Anon!: If good, thou shamest the music of sweet news By playing it to me with so sour a face.
Goodbye!: If it’s good, you’re shameful of the sweet news by playing it to me with so sour a face.

Anon!: Why, this is an arrant counterfeit rascal.
Goodbye!: Why, this is an arrant fake rascal.

Anon!: Then, in God’s name, march.
Goodbye!: Then, in God’s name, march.

Anon!: To th' church take the priest, clerk, and some sufficient honest witnesses.
Goodbye!: Take the priest, the clerk, and some honest witnesses to the church.

Anon!: Henceforth I never will be Romeo.
Goodbye!: I’ll never be Romeo.

Anon!: Here she comes, cursed and sad.
Goodbye!: Here she comes, cursed and sad.

Anon!: I am sorry to find you thus.
Goodbye!: I’m sorry to see you here.

Anon!: I do beseech your lordship, call her back.
Goodbye!: Please, your lord, call her back.

Anon!: The mariners all under hatches stowed, Who, with a charm joined to their suffered labor, I have left asleep.
Goodbye!: The mariners were all stowed under hatches, and I’ve left asleep with a charm that accompanied them to their labor.

Anon!: I think it was to see my mother’s wedding.
Goodbye!: I think it was to see my mother’s wedding.

Anon!: The Lady Beatrice hath a quarrel to you.
Goodbye!: The Lady Beatrice has a fight with you.

Anon!: Your charm so strongly works 'em That if you now beheld them, your affections Would become tender.
Goodbye!: Your charm is so strong that if you saw them now, your affections would become tender.

Anon!: A pox of drowning thyself!
Goodbye!: A pox of drowning yourself!

Anon!: But for the whole world?
Goodbye!: But for the whole world?

Anon!: Of what your reverence shall incite us to.
Goodbye!: What you’re inciteing us to do.

Anon!: No, my good lord.
Goodbye!: No, my good lord.

Anon!: I am dumb.
Goodbye!: I’m dumb.

Anon!: What answer, sir?
Goodbye!: What do you think?

Anon!: A very fine one.
Goodbye!: A very fine one.

Anon!: Let me embrace with old Vincentio, And wander we to see thy honest son, Who will of thy arrival be full joyous.
Goodbye!: Let me embrace old Vincentio and go see your honest son, who will be happy with your arrival.

Anon!: Pox on ’t!
Goodbye!: Pox on it!

Anon!: So thou mayst say the king lies by a beggar if a beggar dwell near him, or the church stands by thy tabor, if thy tabor stand by the church.
Goodbye!: You can say the king is lying by a beggar if a beggar dwells near him, or the church stands by your tabor, if your tabor stands by the church.

Anon!: Give you good night.
Goodbye!: Good night.

Anon!: Madam, he’s married to Octavia.
Goodbye!: Madam, he’s married to Octavia.

Anon!: Mark Antony is in your tents, my lord.
Goodbye!: Mark Antony is in your tents, my lord.

Anon!: Also King Lewis the Tenth, Who was sole heir to the usurper Capet, Could not keep quiet in his conscience, Wearing the crown of France, till satisfied That fair Queen Isabel, his grandmother, Was lineal of the Lady Ermengare, Daughter to Charles the foresaid duke of Lorraine, By the which marriage the line of Charles the Great Was reunited to the crown of France.
Goodbye!: King Lewis the Tenth, who was the sole heir to the usurper Capet, couldn’t keep quiet in his conscience, wearing the crown of France, until he satisfied that fair Queen Isabel, his grandmother, was the

Anon!: There is more in it.—Cousin Ganymede.
Goodbye!: There’s more to it.—Cousin Ganymede.

Anon!: Cassio knows you not.
Goodbye!: Cassio doesn’t know you.

Anon!: Look you for any other issue?
Goodbye!: Do you have any other issue?

Anon!: I hear a knocking At the south entry.
Goodbye!: I hear a knocking at the south entrance.

Anon!: She loves me, sure!
Goodbye!: She loves me, sure!

Anon!: I am tied to th' stake, and I must stand the course.
Goodbye!: I’m tied to the stake, and I have to stand up.

Anon!: I will ask him for my place again, he shall tell me I am a drunkard.
Goodbye!: I’ll ask him for my place again, and he’ll tell me I’m a drunk.

Anon!: Then I’ll be brief.
Goodbye!: Then I’ll be brief.

Anon!: I would have him nine years a-killing.
Goodbye!: I wish he had nine years of killing.

Anon!: Most reverend signior, do you know my voice?
Goodbye!: Most reverend signior, do you know my voice?

Anon!: Treason has done his worst; nor steel nor poison, Malice domestic, foreign levy, nothing Can touch him further.
Goodbye!: He’s not a victim of a crime, nor is he a victim of poison, domestic, foreign, or anything else.

Anon!: My noble brother!
Goodbye!: My noble brother!

Anon!: And they have conspired together.
Goodbye!: And they’ve conspired together.

Anon!: Who’s there?
Goodbye!: Who’s there?

Anon!: A man, young lady!
Goodbye!: A man, young lady!

Anon!: That he might not beteem the winds of heaven Visit her face too roughly.—Heaven and earth, Must I remember?
Goodbye!: I wish he could not bet the winds of heaven on her face too much.—Heaven and earth, do I remember?

Anon!: We must out and talk.
Goodbye!: We have to go out and talk.

Anon!: Furthermore, I pray you show my youth old Shylock’s house.
Goodbye!: Besides, please show my youth old Shylock’s house.

Anon!: Of anything the image tell me that Hath kept with thy remembrance.
Goodbye!: Everything I’ve seen tells me that you remember me.

Anon!: Refuse not, mighty lord, this proffered love.
Goodbye!: Don’t refuse this profane love, mighty lord.

Anon!: And when you do them—     Cassius, be content.
Goodbye!: And when you do them— Cassius, be content.

Anon!: Trust me, I fear it has.
Goodbye!: Trust me, I’m afraid it’s.

Anon!: Why, sir, cobble you.
Goodbye!: Why, sir, cobble you.

Anon!: Let me go.
Goodbye!: Let me go.

Anon!: Ay, sir.
Goodbye!: Yes, sir.

Anon!: I do believe it, and I ask your pardon.
Goodbye!: I believe it, and I ask you to pardon me.

Anon!: Therefore no marvel though Demetrius Do, as a monster, fly my presence thus.
Goodbye!: So I can’t imagine any marvel though Demetrius, as a monster, fly my presence like this.

Anon!: I will hence tonight.
Goodbye!: I’ll leave here tonight.

Anon!: We shall be much unfurnished for this time.
Goodbye!: We’ll be unprepared for this time.

Anon!: Why, this it is when men are ruled by women.
Goodbye!: Why, this is when men are ruled by women.

Anon!: You.
Goodbye!: You.

Anon!: It is.
Goodbye!: It is.

Anon!: Let’s mock the midnight bell.
Goodbye!: Let’s mock midnight bell.

Anon!: Advise your fellows so.
Goodbye!: Tell your fellows so.

Anon!: Thither must I, and here I leave you, sir.
Goodbye!: I must, and here I leave you, sir.

Anon!: I think nobly of the soul, and no way approve his opinion.
Goodbye!: I think he’s not a good soul, and I don’t approve his opinion.

Anon!: One ever near thee.
Goodbye!: Someone ever near you.

Anon!: My sword, I say!
Goodbye!: My sword, I say!

Anon!: How?
Goodbye!: How?

Anon!: Can you inquire him out and be edified by report?
Goodbye!: Can you ask him out and be edified by a report?

Anon!: Tomorrow, sir, I wrestle for my credit, and he that escapes me without some broken limb shall acquit him well.
Goodbye!: Tomorrow, sir, I’ll fight for my credit, and the one who escapes me without a broken limb will acquit him well.

Anon!: All but Metellus Cimber, and he’s gone To seek you at your house.
Goodbye!: All except Metellus Cimber, and he’s gone to find you at your house.

Anon!: What, with my tongue in your tail?
Goodbye!: What, with my tongue in your tail?

Anon!: Be assured you may.
Goodbye!: You can.

Anon!: Am I the motive of these tears, my lord?
Goodbye!: Am I the reason for these tears, my lord?

Anon!: Sans fable, she herself reviled you there.
Goodbye!: She’s smothered you there.

Anon!: The heavens forbid But that our loves and comforts should increase, Even as our days do grow.
Goodbye!: The heavens forbid that our love and comforts should grow even as our days grow.

Anon!: Pompey is strong at sea, And it appears he is beloved of those That only have feared Caesar.
Goodbye!: Pompey is strong at sea, and it seems he is beloved by those who only feared Caesar.

Anon!: As plain as I see you now.
Goodbye!: As plain as I see you now.

Anon!: Farewell!
Goodbye!: Goodbye!

Anon!: How do you, sir?
Goodbye!: How are you, sir?

Anon!: The sorrow that I have by right is yours, And all the pleasures you usurp are mine.
Goodbye!: I have a sorrow that I have rightly, and all the pleasures you usurp are mine.

Anon!: I hear some noise within.
Goodbye!: I hear some noise inside.

Anon!: I crave the law, The penalty, and forfeit of my bond.
Goodbye!: I’m asking for the law, the penalty, and the forfeit of my bond.

Anon!: Not her that chides, sir, at any hand, I pray.
Goodbye!: I’m not the one who chides you at any hand, sir.

Anon!: What is her mother?
Goodbye!: Who is her mother?

Anon!: Saw’st thou him enter at the abbey here?
Goodbye!: Did you see him enter the abbey here?

Anon!: Yea, by Mass, that it is.
Goodbye!: Yes, by Mass, that it is.

Anon!: You must sing  This nothing’s more than matter.
Goodbye!: You must sing this thing more than matter.

Anon!: I’ll tell you, there is good men porn at Monmouth.
Goodbye!: I’ll tell you, there are good men in Monmouth.

Anon!: Five-and-twenty, sir.
Goodbye!: Five and twenty, sir.

Anon!: Come.
Goodbye!: Come on.

Anon!: Let 'em enter.
Goodbye!: Let’s go.

Anon!: Follow me and receive ’t.
Goodbye!: Follow me and get it.

Anon!: Not in love neither?
Goodbye!: Are you not in love, neither?

Anon!: Feed him with apricoks and dewberries, With purple grapes, green figs, and mulberries.
Goodbye!: Feed him with apricots and dewberries, with purple grapes, green figs, and mulberries.

Anon!: Who’s there?
Goodbye!: Who’s there?

Anon!: And never could maintain his part but in the force of his will.
Goodbye!: And he could never keep his part until he was willing to.

Anon!: Be aidant and remediate In the good man’s distress.
Goodbye!: Be helpful and help the good man in his distress.

Anon!: Tis his fashion.
Goodbye!: It’s his style.

Anon!: I am content.
Goodbye!: I’m satisfied.

Anon!: When Caesar lived, he durst not thus have moved me.
Goodbye!: When Caesar lived, he wouldn’t have moved me like that.

Anon!: Strato, thou hast been all this while asleep.
Goodbye!: Strato, you’ve been asleep all this time.

Anon!: I’ll not meddle with him.
Goodbye!: I won’t talk to him.

Anon!: Be merciful, say “death,” For exile hath more terror in his look, Much more than death.
Goodbye!: Be merciful, say “death,” because exile has more terror in his eyes than death.

Anon!: Tis a vile thing to die, my gracious lord, When men are unprepared and look not for it.
Goodbye!: It’s a vile thing to die, my gracious lord, when men aren’t prepared and don’t look for it.

Anon!: He therefore sends you, meeter for your spirit, This tun of treasure, and, in lieu of this, Desires you let the dukedoms that you claim Hear no more of you.
Goodbye!: He sends you, meeter for your spirit, this treasure, and, instead of this, he wants you to let the dukedoms that you claim to have no more than you.

Anon!: I have so often blushed to acknowledge him that now I am brazed to it.
Goodbye!: I’ve been so often blushed to acknowledge him that now I’m brazed about it.

Anon!: Then will two at once woo one.
Goodbye!: Then two of us will woo one.

Anon!: Take thou some new infection to thy eye, And the rank poison of the old will die.
Goodbye!: Take some new poison to your eyes, and the old poison will die.

Anon!: But in respect of that, I would fain think it were not.
Goodbye!: But I’d rather think it weren’t.

Anon!: Marry, for my part, I think the duke hath lost never a man, but one that is like to be executed for robbing a church, one Bardolph, if your Majesty know the man.
Goodbye!: I think the duke has never lost a man, but a man who is like to be executed for robbing a church, one Bardolph, if your Majesty knows the man.

Anon!: Some others search.
Goodbye!: Some others are searching.

Anon!: Oh, here’s a wit of cheveril, that stretches from an inch narrow to an ell broad!
Goodbye!: Oh, here’s a wit of cheveril, that’s all from an inch narrow to an ell broad!

Anon!: Jove and my stars be praised!
Goodbye!: I’ll praise Jove and my stars!

Anon!: Presently away, For to strange sores strangely they strain the cure.— Come, lady, die to live.
Goodbye!: Now, I’m away, because strange sores are causing the cure to be ruined.—Come, lady, let’s die to live.

Anon!: Pleaseth your Majesty to give me leave, I’ll muster up my friends and meet your Grace Where and what time your Majesty shall please.
Goodbye!: If your Majesty wants to leave, I’ll meet my friends and meet your Grace, where and when your Majesty will please.

Anon!: There thou speak’st reason.
Goodbye!: There you speak about reason.

Anon!: Alas, poor country!
Goodbye!: Oh, poor country!

Anon!: Either heaven with lightning strike the murderer dead, Or earth gape open wide and eat him quick, As thou dost swallow up this good king’s blood, Which his hell-governed arm hath butcherèd!
Goodbye!: Either heaven strikes the murderer dead with lightning, or the earth opens wide and eats him quick, as you swallow up this good king’s blood, which his hell-governed arm has butcherched!

Anon!: Arise, arise, Awake the snorting citizens with the bell Or else the devil will make a grandsire of you.
Goodbye!: Rise up, wake up, wake up the snorting citizens with the bell, or the devil will make a grandsire of you.

Anon!: You have a daughter called Elizabeth, Virtuous and fair, royal and gracious.
Goodbye!: You have a daughter called Elizabeth, who is virtuous and fair, royal and gracious.

Anon!: Well, I am not fair, and therefore I pray the gods make me honest.
Goodbye!: Well, I’m not fair, and therefore I beg the gods to make me honest.

Anon!: Get you to bed on th' instant, I will be returned Forthwith.
Goodbye!: I’ll go back to bed soon.

Anon!: Here I’ll sit i' th' midst.
Goodbye!: I’ll sit here in the middle.

Anon!: What masque, what music?
Goodbye!: What music, what music?

Anon!: With no sauce that can be devised to it.
Goodbye!: With no sauce to it.

Anon!: Then Edgar was abused.
Goodbye!: Then Edgar was abused.

Anon!: The world affords no law to make thee rich.
Goodbye!: The world doesn’t have any law to make you rich.

Anon!: Where is thy instrument?
Goodbye!: Where is your instrument?

Anon!: Is he not jealous?
Goodbye!: Isn’t he jealous?

Anon!: No, no, we will hold it as a dream till it appear itself.
Goodbye!: No, no, we’ll keep it as a dream until it’s a reality.

Anon!: Here.
Goodbye!: Here.

Anon!: Say boldly.
Goodbye!: Say boldly.

Anon!: Son, I’ll be your half Bianca comes.
Goodbye!: Son, I’ll be your half Bianca comes.

Anon!: He is enamored on Hero.
Goodbye!: He’s enamored by Hero.

Anon!: You are welcome, sir, to Cyprus.
Goodbye!: You’re welcome to Cyprus, sir.

Anon!: Moon and stars!
Goodbye!: Moon and stars!

Anon!: Look, in this place ran Cassius' dagger through.
Goodbye!: Look, in this place ran Cassius’s dagger through.

Anon!: I have seen you both.
Goodbye!: I’ve seen you both.

Anon!: Master, knock the door hard.
Goodbye!: Master, knock the door hard.

Anon!: Trebonius knows his time.
Goodbye!: Trebonius knows his time.

Anon!: Fairer than tongue can name thee, let me have Some patient leisure to excuse myself.
Goodbye!: If you’re a little bit a little sane, let me excuse myself.

Anon!: Then have at you with my wit.
Goodbye!: Then have my wit at you.

Anon!: Our posts shall be swift and intelligent betwixt us.—Farewell, dear sister.
Goodbye!: Our posts will be swift and intelligent.—Goodbye, dear sister.

Anon!: Do we trouble you?
Goodbye!: Do we bother you?

Anon!: How fares my noble lord?
Goodbye!: How is my noble lord?

Anon!: What I can do I will, and more I will Than for myself I dare.
Goodbye!: I will do what I can, and I will do more than I dare for myself.

Anon!: Sole monarch of the universal earth, Oh, what a beast was I to chide at him!
Goodbye!: I was a beast to scold at him!

Anon!: I take my leave at once.
Goodbye!: I’ll leave you immediately.

Anon!: I have told him, Lepidus was grown too cruel, That he his high authority abused And did deserve his change.
Goodbye!: I told him that Lepidus was grown too cruel, that he abused his high authority and did deserve his change.

Anon!: They that stand high have many blasts to shake them, And if they fall, they dash themselves to pieces.
Goodbye!: They’re thrown out of their hands, and if they fall, they’ll die to pieces.

Anon!: Tis well thou art not fish.
Goodbye!: It’s good you’re not a fisherman.

Anon!: I would have none but knaves follow it since a fool gives it.
Goodbye!: I’d rather have a fool follow it, since he gives it to me.

Anon!: It may be his enemy is a gentleman of great sort, quite from the answer of his degree.
Goodbye!: It may be his enemy is a gentleman of great kind, even if he’s not a man.

Anon!: Therefore, queen of all, Katherine, break thy mind to me in broken English.
Goodbye!: Therefore, Katherine, you’ll break your mind to me in broken English.

Anon!: Ay, you did wish that I would make her turn.
Goodbye!: Yes, you wish I could make her turn.

Anon!: Will you go?
Goodbye!: Will you go?

Anon!: Nothing certainer.
Goodbye!: Nothing more than that.

Anon!: I am old now, And these same crosses spoil me.
Goodbye!: I’m old now, and these same crosses spoil me.

Anon!: Do I look like a cudgel or a hovel-post, a staff or a prop?
Goodbye!: Do I look like a cudgel or a hovel-post, a staff or a prop?

Anon!: But, like a misbehaved and sullen wench, Thou pout’st upon thy fortune and thy love.
Goodbye!: But like a misbehaved and sullen wench, you’re poutching on your fortune and your love.

Anon!: Yare, lower, lower!
Goodbye!: Yare, lower, lower!

Anon!: No greater heart in thee?
Goodbye!: No more heart in you?

Anon!: Do not go forth today.
Goodbye!: Don’t go out today.

Anon!: Ah, Juliet, if the measure of thy joy Be heaped like mine, and that thy skill be more To blazon it, then sweeten with thy breath This neighbor air, and let rich music’s tongue Unfold the imagined happiness that both Receive in either by this dear encounter.
Goodbye!: Ah, Juliet, if you’re a little more happy than mine, and you’re more capable of blazoning it, then you’ll sweeten this neighbor with your breath, and let the rich music’

Anon!: Twill be a good way, and tomorrow the wrestling is.
Goodbye!: It’ll be a good way to fight, and tomorrow the fight will be.

Anon!: These are news indeed!
Goodbye!: Yes, these are news!

Anon!: Tush, Gremio.
Goodbye!: Tush, Gremio.

Anon!: How now, friend Eros!
Goodbye!: What’s going on, friend Eros?

Anon!: My honored lord!
Goodbye!: My dear lord!

Anon!: Then, good my liege, mistake me not so much To think my poverty is treacherous.
Goodbye!: Then, my good liege, don’t mistake me so much to think my poverty is treacherous.

Anon!: I am your host.
Goodbye!: I’m your host.

Anon!: Even he, madam.
Goodbye!: Oh, he’s right, madam.

Anon!: I have seen you gleeking and galling at this gentleman twice or thrice.
Goodbye!: I’ve seen you gleeking and galling at this gentleman twice or twice.

Anon!: I will be gone, sir, and not trouble you.
Goodbye!: I’ll go, sir, and I won’t bother you.

Anon!: My words would bandy her to my sweet love, And his to me.
Goodbye!: My words would give her my sweet love, and his words would give her my sweet love.

Anon!: Alack, alack!
Goodbye!: Oh, no!

Anon!: I have used it, nuncle, ever since thou madest thy daughters thy mothers.
Goodbye!: I’ve used it, uncle, since you made your daughters your mothers.

Anon!: My prayers, minx?
Goodbye!: My prayers, minx?

Anon!: Not poppy nor mandragora Nor all the drowsy syrups of the world, Shall ever medicine thee to that sweet sleep Which thou owedst yesterday.
Goodbye!: I’ll never give you the sweet sleep that you owed yesterday.

Anon!: A very even way, but no such friend.
Goodbye!: A very fair way, but no friend like that.

Anon!: Come, trusty sword.
Goodbye!: Come on, trusty sword.

Anon!: What would you?
Goodbye!: What do you want?

Anon!: Two of them have the very bent of honor, And if their wisdoms be misled in this, The practice of it lives in John the Bastard, Whose spirits toil in frame of villainies.
Goodbye!: Two of them have the same honor, and if they’re misled, they’ll be able to do it in John the Bastard, who’s a man who’s a villain.

Anon!: Marry, sir, lullaby to your bounty till I come again.
Goodbye!: I’ll go back to you, sir.

Anon!: Thou liest.
Goodbye!: You lie.

Anon!: Do you know me, Father?
Goodbye!: Do you know me, Father?

Anon!: The bark is ready and the wind at help, Th' associates tend, and everything is bent For England.
Goodbye!: The bark is ready and the wind is at help, your associates tend to tend to, and everything is bent for England.

Anon!: In honored love.
Goodbye!: In honor of love.

Anon!: Have at you with a proverb: shall I set in my staff?
Goodbye!: Have you heard a proverb: Should I put my staff in my ranks?

Anon!: Faith, niece, you tax Signor Benedick too much, but he’ll be meet with you, I doubt it not.
Goodbye!: Oh, niece, you’re taxing Signor Benedick too much, but he’ll be meeting you, I don’t doubt it.

Anon!: I know thou wilt say “ay,” And I will take thy word.
Goodbye!: I know you’ll say “Yes,” and I’ll take your word.

Anon!: Break an hour’s promise in love?
Goodbye!: Break an hour’s promise in love?

Anon!: Well, my lord.
Goodbye!: Well, my lord.

Anon!: Brought to this town by that most famous warrior Duke Menaphon, your most renownèd uncle.
Goodbye!: Brought to this town by that famous warrior Duke Menaphon, your most respected uncle.

Anon!: Content, in faith.
Goodbye!: Good-bye.

Anon!: Canst thou hold up thy heavy eyes awhile, And touch thy instrument a strain or two?
Goodbye!: Can you hold your eyes up for a while and touch your instrument a bit?

Anon!: O, for my beads!
Goodbye!: Oh, for my beads!

Anon!: Be this the whetstone of your sword.
Goodbye!: Be the slur of your sword.

Anon!: Tis best to give him way.
Goodbye!: It’s best to give him the way.

Anon!: Very well took, i' faith, wisely, wisely.
Goodbye!: I think it’s very well done, wisely, wisely.

Anon!: And be a happy mother by the deed.
Goodbye!: And be a happy mother by the act.

Anon!: Do you bite your thumb at us, sir?
Goodbye!: Do you bite your thumb at us?

Anon!: Where is that viper?
Goodbye!: Where is that viper?

Anon!: Beshrew him for ’t!
Goodbye!: Besoil him for it!

Anon!: This disease is beyond my practice.
Goodbye!: This disease is beyond my practice.

Anon!: Proceed, Moon.
Goodbye!: Go ahead, Moon.

Anon!: Full half an hour.
Goodbye!: For a full half hour.

Anon!: The man grows mad.
Goodbye!: The man is crazy.

Anon!: What years, i' faith?
Goodbye!: What years, I’m sure?

Anon!: Go you and tell her of it.
Goodbye!: Go and tell her about it.

Anon!: We must die, Messala.
Goodbye!: We have to die, Messala.

Anon!: I think it be, sir.
Goodbye!: I think it is, sir.

Anon!: What sayst thou to me now?
Goodbye!: What do you say to me now?

Anon!: Who hath relieved you?
Goodbye!: Who has relieved you?

Anon!: To die, to sleep.
Goodbye!: To die, to sleep.

Anon!: Tarry, Petruchio, I must go with thee, For in Baptista’s keep my treasure is.
Goodbye!: I’ll go with you, Petruchio, because in Baptista’s house, my treasure is.

Anon!: O vassal!
Goodbye!: Oh, vassal!

Anon!: Whose house?
Goodbye!: Whose house?

Anon!: The wine she drinks is made of grapes.
Goodbye!: She drinks the wine from grapes.

Anon!: Thou art a fool.
Goodbye!: You’re a fool.

Anon!: Nor in thine, lord.
Goodbye!: No, I’m not in yours, lord.

Anon!: Sir?
Goodbye!: Sir?

Anon!: Be thou familiar but by no means vulgar.
Goodbye!: Be familiar, but not vulgar.

Anon!: What, man, there are ways to recover the general again.
Goodbye!: There are ways to recover the general again.

Anon!: It is the lark that sings so out of tune, Straining harsh discords and unpleasing sharps.
Goodbye!: It’s the lark that sings so out of tune, preventing harsh discords and unpleasing sharps.

Anon!: Father, what news?
Goodbye!: Father, what news do you have?

Anon!: Farewell.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: Come, temperate nymphs, and help to celebrate A contract of true love.
Goodbye!: Come, temperate nymphs, and help celebrate a true love contract.

Anon!: Saw you my lord?
Goodbye!: Have you seen me, my lord?

Anon!: Fie, there is no such man.
Goodbye!: No, there’s no such man.

Anon!: Grieve not that I am fall'n to this for you, For herein Fortune shows herself more kind Than is her custom.
Goodbye!: Don’t be sorry that I’m falling to this for you, because herein Fortune is more kind than hers.

Anon!: Ay, millstones, as he lessoned us to weep.
Goodbye!: Yes, he’s a millstone, as he taught us to cry.

Anon!: Madam wife, they say that I have dreamed And slept above some fifteen year or more.
Goodbye!: Madam wife, they say I’ve dreamed and slept more than fifteen years.

Anon!: Ne'er a fantastical knave of them all shall flout me out of my calling.
Goodbye!: I’ll bet that they’re all fantastically scolded.

Anon!: Therefore go with me.
Goodbye!: So go with me.

Anon!: So do our vulgar drench their peasant limbs In blood of princes, and the wounded steeds Fret fetlock deep in gore, and with wild rage Yerk out their armèd heels at their dead masters, Killing them twice.
Goodbye!: Then our vulgar drench their peasants in blood of princes, and the wounded steeds Fret fetlock deep in gore, and with wild rage, Yerk

Anon!: Not for the wide world.
Goodbye!: Not for the wide world.

Anon!: It is a great price for a small vice.
Goodbye!: It’s a great price for a small snub.

Anon!: But by sea he is an absolute master.
Goodbye!: But he’s an absolute master.

Anon!: How now?
Goodbye!: What’s going on?

Anon!: I have received a hurt.
Goodbye!: I’ve received a hurt.

Anon!: Dear Duff, I prithee, contradict thyself, And say it is not so.
Goodbye!: Dear Duff, please, contradict yourself and say it’s not true.

Anon!: If they do see thee they will murder thee.
Goodbye!: If they see you, they’ll murder you.

Anon!: We are resolved, my lord.
Goodbye!: We’re ready, my lord.

Anon!: Let me see.
Goodbye!: Let me see.

Anon!: And indeed, my lord, The wretched animal heaved forth such groans That their discharge did stretch his leathern coat Almost to bursting, and the big round tears Coursed one another down his innocent nose In piteous chase.
Goodbye!: And indeed, my lord, the wretched animal heaved such groans that their groans sped up his leathern coat almost to bursting, and the big round tears slowed

Anon!: Hail to your grace.
Goodbye!: Hail to your grace.

Anon!: How goes it now?
Goodbye!: How is it going now?

Anon!: By this marriage, All little jealousies, which now seem great, And all great fears, which now import their dangers, Would then be nothing.
Goodbye!: By this marriage, all the little jealousies, which now seem great, and all the great fears, which now threaten their lives, would be nothing.

Anon!: Get you gone, And at the pit of Acheron Meet me i' th' morning.
Goodbye!: Get out of here and meet me in the pit of Acheron early in the morning.

Anon!: And you by land.
Goodbye!: And you’re on land.

Anon!: For us, we will resign During the life of this old majesty To him our absolute power.
Goodbye!: For us, we’ll resign to him for our absolute power during this time of life.

Anon!: Cleopatra, Do not abuse my master’s bounty by Th’ undoing of yourself.
Goodbye!: Cleopatra, don’t abuse my master’s bounty by removing yourself.

Anon!: Complain unto the Duke of this indignity.
Goodbye!: Tell the Duke of this indignity.

Anon!: A noble prisoner!
Goodbye!: A noble prisoner!

Anon!: They that add, moreover, he’s drunk nightly in your company.
Goodbye!: The ones who add that he’s drunk nightly in your company.

Anon!: How silver-sweet sound lovers' tongues by night, Like softest music to attending ears!
Goodbye!: The sound of lovers’ tongues by night is silver-sweet, like the softest music to listen to!

Anon!: I prithee, Strato, stay thou by thy lord.
Goodbye!: Please, Strato, stay by your lord.

Anon!: The minute of their plot Is almost come.—Well done.
Goodbye!: The moment they plotted is almost here.—Well done.

Anon!: Romeo is coming.
Goodbye!: Romeo is coming.

Anon!: They all do hate him As rootedly as I.
Goodbye!: They all hate him as rootedly as I hate him.

Anon!: Out, you baggage!
Goodbye!: You’re out of luck!

Anon!: My deeds upon my head.
Goodbye!: I’ve done my deeds on my head.

Anon!: I will make fast the doors and gild myself With some more ducats, and be with you straight.
Goodbye!: I’ll make the doors fast and gild myself with some more ducats, and I’ll be with you straight away.

Anon!: How say you by the French lord, Monsieur le Bon?
Goodbye!: What do you say by the French lord, Monsieur le Bon?

Anon!: Do not you love me?
Goodbye!: Don’t you love me?

Anon!: I am strong-framed.
Goodbye!: I’m strong-framed.

Anon!: Not sad, my lord.
Goodbye!: Not sad, my lord.

Anon!: My letters say a hundred and seven galleys.
Goodbye!: My letters say a hundred and seven galleys.

Anon!: We’ll set thee to school to an ant to teach thee there’s no laboring i' th' winter.
Goodbye!: We’ll send you to school to teach you that winter isn’t laboring.

Anon!: Did we, my lord?
Goodbye!: Did we, my lord?

Anon!: Oh, God defend me!
Goodbye!: Oh, God protect me!

Anon!: Tis very like.
Goodbye!: It’s very similar.

Anon!: It is not day.
Goodbye!: It’s not daybreak.

Anon!: I cannot but remember such things were That were most precious to me.
Goodbye!: I can’t remember what I was doing.

Anon!: What dost thou profess?
Goodbye!: What do you say?

Anon!: He hath neither Latin, French, nor Italian, and you will come into the court and swear that I have a poor pennyworth in the English.
Goodbye!: He’s neither Latin, French, or Italian, and you’ll come into the court to swear that I’m a poor man.

Anon!: Meantime we thank you for your well-took labor.
Goodbye!: We’ve been grateful for your hard work.

Anon!: Twas you we laughed at.
Goodbye!: We laughed at you.

Anon!: Ready.
Goodbye!: Ready.

Anon!: What of that?
Goodbye!: What about that?

Anon!: The gods defend her!—hear him hence awhile.
Goodbye!: The gods defend her!—Watch him leave for a while.

Anon!: I must discontinue your company.
Goodbye!: I have to stop your company.

Anon!: O most bloody sight!
Goodbye!: Oh, what a bloody sight!

Anon!: They’re busy within.
Goodbye!: They’re busy inside.

Anon!: Though to have her and death were both one thing.
Goodbye!: Though having her and death were both one thing.

Anon!: When that the poor have cried, Caesar hath wept.
Goodbye!: When the poor have cried, Caesar has wept.

Anon!: Yes, that the king is dead.
Goodbye!: Yes, the king is dead.

Anon!: The cowslips tall her pensioners be.
Goodbye!: The cowslips are tall enough to be her pensioners.

Anon!: My father is not dead, for all your saying.
Goodbye!: My father is not dead, for all your words.

Anon!: Not in a grave, To lay one in, another out to have.
Goodbye!: Not in a grave, to lay one in a grave, another out to have.

Anon!: Hence, Lest that th' infection of his fortune take Like hold on thee.
Goodbye!: So, if he’s a savage, he’ll be able to keep your fortune from slipping away.

Anon!: God’s bodykins, man, much better.
Goodbye!: God’s bodykins are much better, man.

Anon!: When were you wont to use my sister thus?
Goodbye!: When were you going to use my sister like that?

Anon!: I could not for my heart deny it him.
Goodbye!: I couldn’t say anything about him.

Anon!: For what purpose, love?
Goodbye!: What purpose, love?

Anon!: O no, my reasons are too deep and dead— Too deep and dead, poor infants, in their graves.
Goodbye!: Oh no, my reasons are too deep and dead— Too deep and dead, poor infants, in their graves.

Anon!: Is she not proud?
Goodbye!: Isn’t she proud?

Anon!: We are such stuff As dreams are made on, and our little life Is rounded with a sleep.
Goodbye!: We’re like things that dream about, and our little life is rounded with a sleep.

Anon!: Cassio shall have my place.
Goodbye!: Cassio will have my place.

Anon!: At nine i' th' morning here we’ll meet again.
Goodbye!: At nine o'clock we’ll meet again.

Anon!: His flight was madness.
Goodbye!: His flight was insane.

Anon!: And I as I love Hastings with my heart.
Goodbye!: And I love Hastings with my heart.

Anon!: I must talk a word with you.
Goodbye!: I have to talk a word with you.

Anon!: What devil art thou that dost torment me thus?
Goodbye!: What devil are you who torture me like this?

Anon!: This is the foul fiend Flibbertigibbet.
Goodbye!: This is the foul fiend Flibbertigibbet.

Anon!: Pardon, sweet father.
Goodbye!: Pardon me, sweet father.

Anon!: Will you yield and this avoid Or, guilty in defense, be thus destroyed?
Goodbye!: Will you surrender and avoid this, or be so destroyed, guilty in defense?

Anon!: Most noble sir, arise.
Goodbye!: Most noble sir, come on.

Anon!: I doubt some danger does approach you nearly.
Goodbye!: I doubt some danger is approaching you.

Anon!: Did you never see the picture of “We Three”?
Goodbye!: Did you never see the picture of “We Three”?

Anon!: A rarer spirit never Did steer humanity, but you gods will give us Some faults to make us men.
Goodbye!: A rarer spirit never helped guide humanity, but you gods will give us some faults to make us men.

Anon!: Of one not easily jealous, but being wrought, Perplexed in the extreme.
Goodbye!: I’m not sure of someone who’s jealous, but who’s wrought it.

Anon!: She that was ever fair and never proud, Had tongue at will and yet was never loud, Never lacked gold and yet went never gay, Fled from her wish and yet said “Now I may,” She that being angered, her revenge being nigh, Bade her wrong stay and her displeasure fly, She that in wisdom never was so frail To change the cod’s head for the salmon’s tail, She that could think and ne'er disclose her mind, See suitors following and not look behind, She was a wight, if ever such wights were— To do what?
Goodbye!: She was always fair and never proud, had tongue at will and was never loud, never lacked gold and yet went never gay, fled from her wish and said “Now I can,” she was angry, her revenge being

Anon!: Not mad, but bound more than a madman is, Shut up in prison, kept without my food, Whipped and tormented and—Good e'en, good fellow.
Goodbye!: Not insane, but bound more than a madman is, Shut up in prison, kept without food, whipped and tormented and—Good e'en, good fellow.

Anon!: But ships are but boards, sailors but men.
Goodbye!: But ships are only boards, sailors are only men.

Anon!: Of that there’s none, or little.
Goodbye!: Of that there’s no, or little.

Anon!: This is some fellow, Who, having been praised for bluntness, doth affect A saucy roughness and constrains the garb Quite from his nature.
Goodbye!: This is some man, who, after being praised for his bluntness, affects a saucy roughness and constrains the snoring from his nature.

Anon!: He received them Of him that brought them.
Goodbye!: He received them from the man who brought them.

Anon!: The Dauphin longs for morning.
Goodbye!: The Dauphin is waiting for morning.

Anon!: Words, words, words.
Goodbye!: Words, words, words.

Anon!: There’s no art To find the mind’s construction in the face.
Goodbye!: There’s no way to find the mind’s shape in the face.

Anon!: Now Lord be thanked for my good amends!
Goodbye!: Now Lord, thank you for my good work!

Anon!: The little strength that I have, I would it were with you.
Goodbye!: I wish I could have the little strength I have with you.

Anon!: Nay then, I will not.
Goodbye!: No, then, I won’t.

Anon!: I pity you.
Goodbye!: I’m sorry you were.

Anon!: I was born free as Caesar.
Goodbye!: I was born as free as Caesar.

Anon!: One, sir, that for his love dares yet do more Than you have heard him brag to you he will.
Goodbye!: I’m saying that he dares to do more than you’ve heard him brag about you.

Anon!: At the duke’s oak we meet.
Goodbye!: We’re at the duke’s oak.

Anon!: If his fitness speaks, mine is ready, now or whensoever, provided I be so able as now.
Goodbye!: If he’s a good man, I’ll be ready, either now or when I’m ready, if I’m as capable as I am now.

Anon!: Hie to high fortune!
Goodbye!: Go to high fortune!

Anon!: I am not married, Caesar.
Goodbye!: I’m not married, Caesar.

Anon!: So smooth he daubed his vice with show of virtue That, his apparent open guilt omitted— I mean his conversation with Shore’s wife— He lived from all attainder of suspects.
Goodbye!: He swore his innocence so well that he escaped his guilt—I mean his conversation with Shore’s wife—and lived from all angles as a suspect.

Anon!: Your Honor’s players, hearing your amendment, Are come to play a pleasant comedy, For so your doctors hold it very meet, Seeing too much sadness hath congealed your blood, And melancholy is the nurse of frenzy.
Goodbye!: Your Honor’s players are coming to play a pleasant comedy, because your doctors are very happy with it, and Seeing too much sadness has congealed your blood, and melancholy is the nurse of frenzy

Anon!: O perdurable shame!
Goodbye!: Oh, shameful!

Anon!: O, train me not, sweet mermaid, with thy note To drown me in thy sister’s flood of tears.
Goodbye!: Oh, don’t train me, sweet mermaid, to drown me in your sister’s tears.

Anon!: Twas a rough night.
Goodbye!: It was a rough night.

Anon!: A messenger from the galleys.
Goodbye!: A messenger from the galleys.

Anon!: Say, what?
Goodbye!: What?

Anon!: Is he married?
Goodbye!: Is he married?

Anon!: What kind of woman is’t?
Goodbye!: What kind of woman is she?

Anon!: For what purpose, love?
Goodbye!: What purpose, love?

Anon!: Nay, then, thou mock’st me.
Goodbye!: No, then, you’re mocking me.

Anon!: A charge we bear i’ th’ war, And as the president of my kingdom will Appear there for a man.
Goodbye!: We’re fighting for a man, and as the president of my kingdom, we’ll be there for a man.

Anon!: Yet, coming from him, that great med’cine hath With his tinct gilded thee.
Goodbye!: But coming from him, that great med’cine has gilded you with his tincture.

Anon!: Graces will appear, and there’s an end.
Goodbye!: Graces will appear, and there’s an end.

Anon!: Why, God will send more, if the man will be thankful.
Goodbye!: God will send more people, if he’s thankful.

Anon!: When we are born, we cry that we are come To this great stage of fools.
Goodbye!: When we’re born, we cry that we’re coming to this great stage of fools.

Anon!: One, gentlewoman, that God hath made, himself to mar.
Goodbye!: God has made himself a man, gentlewoman, to be a martyr.

Anon!: This night—wherein the cub-drawn bear would couch, The lion and the belly-pinchèd wolf Keep their fur dry—unbonneted he runs, And bids what will take all.
Goodbye!: This night—where the cub-drawn bear would couch, the lion and the belly-pinched wolf would keep their fur dry—he runs unbeaten and asks what will take all of it.

Anon!: Hark, they roar.
Goodbye!: Listen, they roar.

Anon!: His own unkindness That stripped her from his benediction turned her To foreign casualties, gave her dear rights To his dog-hearted daughters.
Goodbye!: His unkindness that stripped her of his benediction turned her to foreign casualties, gave her dear rights to his dog-hearted daughters.

Anon!: Have you got leave to go to shrift today?
Goodbye!: Have you got permission to go to shrift today?

Anon!: Can heaven be so envious?
Goodbye!: Can heaven be so envious?

Anon!: You call me misbeliever, cutthroat dog, And spet upon my Jewish gaberdine— And all for use of that which is mine own.
Goodbye!: You call me a misbeliever, a cutthroat dog, and scold my Jewish lord—and all for using what I own.

Anon!: Approach the chamber, and destroy your sight With a new Gorgon.
Goodbye!: Take the chamber and destroy your sight with a new Gorgon.

Anon!: Despised, distressèd, hated, martyred, killed!
Goodbye!: Despised, distressed, hated, martyred, killed!

Anon!: Stand far off.
Goodbye!: Stand far away.

Anon!: Behold and see.
Goodbye!: Look and see.

Anon!: I pray you, pardon me.
Goodbye!: Please pardon me.

Anon!: Here comes the man you mean.
Goodbye!: Here comes the man you mean.

Anon!: Pray God it be, sir.
Goodbye!: Please, sir.

Anon!: A wandering knight?
Goodbye!: A wandering knight?

Anon!: The lamentable change is from the best; The worst returns to laughter.
Goodbye!: The worst changes are coming to laughter.

Anon!: But what prevention?
Goodbye!: But what’s going on?

Anon!: If there be truth in sight, you are my Rosalind.
Goodbye!: If there’s truth in sight, you’re my Rosalind.

Anon!: That head, my lord?
Goodbye!: That head, my lord?

Anon!: Whate'er thou art, for thy good caution, thanks.
Goodbye!: Thank you, for your good advice.

Anon!: They call it Agincourt.
Goodbye!: They call it Agincourt.

Anon!: Oh, here’s a wit of cheveril, that stretches from an inch narrow to an ell broad!
Goodbye!: Oh, here’s a wit of cheveril, that’s all from an inch narrow to an ell broad!

Anon!: Therefore love moderately.
Goodbye!: So love it moderately.

Anon!: Though it appear a little out of fashion, There is much care and valor in this Welshman.
Goodbye!: Even though it’s a little out of fashion, this Welshman has a lot of care and courage.

Anon!: Some innocents ’scape not the thunderbolt.
Goodbye!: Some innocents don’t escape the thunderbolt.

Anon!: Do as I bid you.
Goodbye!: Do what I told you.

Anon!: It shall be seven ere I go to horse.
Goodbye!: It will be seven years before I go to horse.

Anon!: O thou good Kent, how shall I live and work To match thy goodness?
Goodbye!: Oh, Kent, how will I live and work to match your goodness?

Anon!: If it be man’s work, I’ll do ’t.
Goodbye!: If it’s a man’s work, I’ll do it.

Anon!: There was more foolery yet, if I could remember it.
Goodbye!: There was more foolery to do, if I could remember it.

Anon!: Oh, was she so?
Goodbye!: Oh, was she?

Anon!: I saw Othello’s visage in his mind, And to his honors and his valiant parts Did I my soul and fortunes consecrate.
Goodbye!: I saw Othello’s face in his mind, and I swore my soul and my fortunes to his honors and his valiant parts.

Anon!: I will hide me in the arbor.
Goodbye!: I’ll hide in the arbor.

Anon!: Away, go!
Goodbye!: Go!

Anon!: Then if we lose this battle You are contented to be led in triumph Thorough the streets of Rome?
Goodbye!: Then if we lose this battle, you’re contented to be led in triumph in the streets of Rome?

Anon!: Methinks you are too much of late i' th' frown.
Goodbye!: I think you’re getting too angry late.

Anon!: Follow”?
Goodbye!: Follow”?

Anon!: Pardon, my lord.
Goodbye!: Pardon me, my lord.

Anon!: Count the clock.
Goodbye!: Count the clock.

Anon!: News from Verona!—How now, Balthasar?
Goodbye!: News from Verona!—How are you, Balthasar?

Anon!: Worse and worse.
Goodbye!: Worse and worse.

Anon!: In happy time, Iago.
Goodbye!: I’m here, Iago.

Anon!: But what see I?
Goodbye!: But what do you see?

Anon!: Imperious Caesar, dead and turned to clay, Might stop a hole to keep the wind away.
Goodbye!: Imperious Caesar, dead and turned to clay, could stop a hole to keep the wind away.

Anon!: Ay, that Petruchio came.
Goodbye!: Yes, Petruchio.

Anon!: Give you good morrow.
Goodbye!: Good morning.

Anon!: Tis torture and not mercy.
Goodbye!: It’s torture and not mercy.

Anon!: If thou follow him, thou must needs wear my coxcomb.—How now, nuncle?
Goodbye!: If you follow him, you’ll have to wear my coxcomb.—How are you, uncle?

Anon!: Let us to the field.
Goodbye!: Let’s go to the field.

Anon!: I would she were in heaven, so she could Entreat some power to change this currish Jew.
Goodbye!: I wish she were in heaven so she could take some power to change this currish Jew.

Anon!: Cross him in nothing.
Goodbye!: Don’t cross him in nothing.

Anon!: There be some such, no question.
Goodbye!: There are some such things, no question.

Anon!: Ha, ha!
Goodbye!: Ha, ha!

Anon!: Me, poor man, my library Was dukedom large enough.
Goodbye!: My library was large enough to be dukedom.

Anon!: Let me have surgeons.
Goodbye!: Let me have surgeons.

Anon!: Oh, that’s a brave man.
Goodbye!: Oh, that’s a brave man.

Anon!: I’ll grow a talker for this gear.
Goodbye!: I’ll become a talker for this gear.

Anon!: Meantime I writ to Romeo, That he should hither come as this dire night, To help to take her from her borrowed grave, Being the time the potion’s force should cease.
Goodbye!: I writ to Romeo, if he came here as a terrible night, to help take her from her borrowed grave, as soon as the potion’s force stopped.

Anon!: I take this offer then: pay the bond thrice And let the Christian go.
Goodbye!: I’ll give you this offer: pay the debt three times and let the Christian go.

Anon!: What would my lord, but that he may not have, Wherein Olivia may seem serviceable?
Goodbye!: What would my lord do, but he may not have, where Olivia might seem to be a good friend?

Anon!: Why, love, I say.
Goodbye!: Love, I say.

Anon!: Some good I mean to do Despite of mine own nature.
Goodbye!: I’m going to do some good, even though I’m not.

Anon!: Fie, sir, fie!
Goodbye!: Oh, sir, sir!

Anon!: I would therefore my sister had no name, sir.
Goodbye!: So I wish my sister had no name, sir.

Anon!: Spoke like an officer!
Goodbye!: Spoke like an officer!

Anon!: Hadst thou no poison mixed, no sharp-ground knife, No sudden mean of death, though ne'er so mean, But “banishèd” to kill me?—“Banishèd”!
Goodbye!: If you had no poison mixed, no sharp knife, no sudden death, even though it’s not so mean, but “banished” to kill me?—“Banished”!

Anon!: No?
Goodbye!: No?

Anon!: I made no such report.
Goodbye!: I didn’t make any such report.

Anon!: Oh, misery!
Goodbye!: Oh, misfortune!

Anon!: But what say you to Thursday?
Goodbye!: But what do you say to Thursday?

Anon!: Tis almost morning.
Goodbye!: It’s almost morning.

Anon!: By the world, I think my wife be honest and think she is not.
Goodbye!: I think my wife is honest and doesn’t think she is.

Anon!: What’s this?
Goodbye!: What’s this?

Anon!: Touch me not so near.
Goodbye!: Don’t touch me so close to me.

Anon!: But are you sure That Benedick loves Beatrice so entirely?
Goodbye!: But are you sure that Benedick loves Beatrice so much?

Anon!: I will seek him, sir, presently, convey the business as I shall find means, and acquaint you withal.
Goodbye!: I’ll seek him, sir, and tell you what I’ll do.

Anon!: I will be deaf to pleading and excuses.
Goodbye!: I’ll be deaf to pleading and excuses.

Anon!: And fixed his eyes upon you?
Goodbye!: And he fixed his eyes on you?

Anon!: By no means” what?
Goodbye!: No, “what?

Anon!: There are my keys.—But wherefore should I go?
Goodbye!: There are my keys.—But why should I go?

Anon!: Use it for my love some other way than swearing by it.
Goodbye!: Use it for my love some other way than swear by it.

Anon!: But do not look for further recompense Than thine own gladness that thou art employed.
Goodbye!: But don’t look for more compensation than your own happiness.

Anon!: Tis a shrewd doubt, though it be but a dream.
Goodbye!: It’s a shrewd doubt, even though it’s just a dream.

Anon!: Dissolve, thick cloud, and rain, that I may say The gods themselves do weep!
Goodbye!: Dissolve, thick cloud, and rain so I can say the gods themselves weep!

Anon!: What shall become of this?
Goodbye!: What will happen from this?

Anon!: Mark me.
Goodbye!: Mark me.

Anon!: But I pray you, who is his companion?
Goodbye!: But please, who is his companion?

Anon!: Ask for me tomorrow, and you shall find me a grave man.
Goodbye!: Ask for me tomorrow, and you’ll find me in a grave.

Anon!: Why, i' faith, methinks she’s too low for a high praise, too brown for a fair praise, and too little for a great praise.
Goodbye!: I think she’s too low for a high praise, too brown for a fair praise, and too little for a great praise.

Anon!: Caesar is sad, and Lepidus, Since Pompey’s feast, as Menas says, is troubled With the greensickness.
Goodbye!: Caesar is sad, and Lepidus is troubled since Pompey’s feast, Menas says, is plagued with greensickness.

Anon!: I long that we were safe and sound aboard.
Goodbye!: I’ve been waiting for you to be safe and sound aboard.

Anon!: The bloody proclamation to escape, That followed me so near—O our lives' sweetness,
Goodbye!: The bloody proclamation to escape, that followed me so close—Once we’re in our lives,

Anon!: I’ll talk with this good fellow.
Goodbye!: I’ll talk to this good man.

Anon!: Why, sir, I brought you word an hour since that the bark  The fellow is distract, and so am I, And here we wander in illusions.
Goodbye!: I’ve brought you a word an hour ago that the bark of the fellow is distracting, and so am I, and here we wander in illusions.

Anon!: Our power is ready; Our lack is nothing but our leave.
Goodbye!: Our power is ready; our lack is nothing but our leave.

Anon!: God be wi' you and keep you and heal your pate.
Goodbye!: God be quiet and keep you and heal your wounds.

Anon!: Then, window, let day in and let life out.
Goodbye!: Then, window, let day in and let life go.

Anon!: She knows the heat of a luxurious bed.
Goodbye!: She knows the heat of a luxurious bed.

Anon!: In such a night as this!
Goodbye!: In such a night as this!

Anon!: Nothing, my lord.
Goodbye!: Nothing, my lord.

Anon!: Speak.
Goodbye!: Speak.

Anon!: Hast thou met with him?
Goodbye!: Have you met him?

Anon!: Followed the old man forth.
Goodbye!: Followed the old man out.

Anon!: The heavens themselves blaze forth the death of princes.
Goodbye!: The heavens themselves have blazed up the death of princes.

Anon!: Three times today my foot-cloth horse did stumble, And started when he looked upon the Tower, As loath to bear me to the slaughterhouse.
Goodbye!: Three times today my foot-cloth horse stumbled, and started when he looked at the Tower, as if he was loathed to bring me to the slaughterhouse.

Anon!: Good, good.
Goodbye!: Good, good.

Anon!: With anger, with sickness, or with hunger, my lord, not with love.
Goodbye!: With anger, with sickness, or with hunger, my lord, not with love.

Anon!: Dead.
Goodbye!: Dead.

Anon!: You are almost come to part almost a fray.
Goodbye!: You’ve almost come to a fight.

Anon!: If his cause be wrong, our obedience to the king wipes the crime of it out of us.
Goodbye!: If he’s wrong, we’re ignoring the king’s crime.

Anon!: Live a little, comfort a little, cheer thyself a little.
Goodbye!: Live a little, comfort a little, and cheer yourself a little.

Anon!: Macbeth!
Goodbye!: Macbeth!

Anon!: I think thou art an ass.
Goodbye!: I think you’re an ass.

Anon!: I pray you, let me see it.
Goodbye!: Please let me see it.

Anon!: The arbitrament is like to be bloody.
Goodbye!: The arbitrament is like a bloody battle.

Anon!: Go thrust him out at gates, and let him smell His way to Dover.
Goodbye!: Go thrust him out of the gates and let him smell his way to Dover.

Anon!: I’ll rather kill myself.
Goodbye!: I’d rather kill myself.

Anon!: Your Grace does me as great honors as can be desired in the hearts of his subjects.
Goodbye!: Your Grace honors me as much as it can be desired in his subjects’ hearts.

Anon!: So I, to find a mother and a brother, In quest of them, unhappy, lose myself.
Goodbye!: So I lose myself, to find a mother and a brother, and to find them unhappy, and find them.

Anon!: Believe me, lord, I think he cannot choose.
Goodbye!: Believe me, lord, I think he can’t choose.

Anon!: Thus I mend it: Time himself is bald and therefore, to the world’s end, will have bald followers.
Goodbye!: I’ll do it again.

Anon!: But ’tis a spirit.
Goodbye!: But it’s a spirit.

Anon!: These things sting His mind so venomously that burning shame Detains him from Cordelia.
Goodbye!: He’s so sane that he’s stealing from Cordelia.

Anon!: How if I answer “No”?
Goodbye!: What if I answered “No”?

Anon!: Why, how now, cousin!
Goodbye!: What’s going on, cousin?

Anon!: If love have touched you, naught remains but so:   Gramercies, lad, go forward.
Goodbye!: If love has touched you, nothing remains as good as that: Gramercies, lad, go ahead.

Anon!: Her father’s brother Would be her lord?
Goodbye!: Her father’s brother would be her lord?

Anon!: I’ll follow thee and make a heaven of hell, To die upon the hand I love so well.
Goodbye!: I’ll follow you and make a heaven of hell, to die on the hand I love so much.

Anon!: Now heaven walks on earth.
Goodbye!: Now heaven’s on earth.

Anon!: Fortune and Antony part here.
Goodbye!: Fortune and Antony are part of this group.

Anon!: I had rather than forty pound I were at home.
Goodbye!: I’d rather be than forty pounds at home.

Anon!: News, lads, Our wars are done!
Goodbye!: News, boys, our wars are over!

Anon!: Stop it, Marcellus.
Goodbye!: Stop it, Marcellus.

Anon!: How, will she none?
Goodbye!: How, will she ever be?

Anon!: Thou wilt fall backward when thou comest to age.
Goodbye!: You’ll fall backward when you get older.

Anon!: I will be strange, stout, in yellow stockings, and cross-gartered, even with the swiftness of putting on.
Goodbye!: I’ll be strange, stout, in yellow stockings, and cross-gartered, even with the rapidness of putting on.

Anon!: Shall I believe That unsubstantial death is amorous, And that the lean abhorrèd monster keeps Thee here in dark to be his paramour?
Goodbye!: Shall I believe that death is amorous, and that the evil monster keeps you here in dark to be his paramour?

Anon!: He and Lepidus are at Caesar’s house.
Goodbye!: He and Lepidus are at Caesar’s house.
