Anon!: My heart is thirsty for that noble pledge.
Goodbye!: My heart is thirsty for that noble promise.

Anon!: His taints and honors Waged equal with him.
Goodbye!: His taints and honors were equal to him.

Anon!: Why, true, he means to make a puppet of thee.
Goodbye!: Yes, he’s going to make you a puppet.

Anon!: I’ll lay fourteen of my teeth—and yet, to my teen be it spoken, I have but four—she is not fourteen.
Goodbye!: I’ll lay fourteen of my teeth—and yet, to my teen, I have only four—she’s not fourteen.

Anon!: Warrant thee, my man’s as true as steel.
Goodbye!: Yes, my man’s as true as steel.

Anon!: My lord?
Goodbye!: My lord?

Anon!: How I dote on thee!
Goodbye!: How I do it!

Anon!: I am the greatest, able to do least, Yet most suspected, as the time and place Doth make against me, of this direful murder.
Goodbye!: I’m the greatest, capable of the least, but I’ve been suspected, as time and place as I am against me, of this terrible murder.

Anon!: But come thy ways.
Goodbye!: But come on.

Anon!: Why, what are you?
Goodbye!: What are you doing?

Anon!: But it is true, without any slips of prolixity or crossing the plain highway of talk, that the good Antonio, the honest Antonio—oh, that I had a title good enough to keep his name company!—  Come, the full stop.
Goodbye!: But it’s true that the good Antonio, the honest Antonio—oh, I had a title good enough to keep his name company!—Come on, the full stop.

Anon!: Oh, much I fear some ill unthrifty thing.
Goodbye!: Oh, I’m afraid some ill-looking thing.

Anon!: I do not find that thou deal’st justly with me.
Goodbye!: I don’t think you’re dealing with me justly.

Anon!: Then comes the time, who lives to see ’t, That going shall be used with feet.
Goodbye!: Then comes the time, who lives to see it, that going will be used with feet.

Anon!: Twice then the trumpets sounded, And there I left him tranced.
Goodbye!: Then the trumpets sounded twice, and I left him tranced.

Anon!: Therefore all hearts in love use their own tongues.
Goodbye!: Therefore, all lovers use their own tongues.

Anon!: I see you do not mean to part with her, Or else you like not of my company.
Goodbye!: I see you don’t want to join her, or else you don’t like my company.

Anon!: Tis hot, it smokes.
Goodbye!: It’s hot, it’s smokey.

Anon!: I slept the next night well, fed well, was free and merry.
Goodbye!: I slept the next night well, fed well, was free and merry.

Anon!: Both which, Master Constable— You have.
Goodbye!: Both of which, Master Constable— You have.

Anon!: But sure I fear we shall not win him to it.
Goodbye!: But I’m sure we won’t win him to it.

Anon!: And death, not Romeo, take my maidenhead!
Goodbye!: And death, not Romeo, take my bridehead!

Anon!: This house is little.
Goodbye!: This house is little.

Anon!: What is ’t you say?
Goodbye!: What do you say?

Anon!: Doth she not count her blessed, Unworthy as she is, that we have wrought So worthy a gentleman to be her bride?
Goodbye!: Doesn’t she count her blessed, unworthy, lady that we have made such a worthy gentleman to be her bride?

Anon!: And died so?
Goodbye!: And that’s what happened?

Anon!: And now I’ll do ’t.
Goodbye!: And now I’ll do it.

Anon!: Upon mine honor, sir, I heard a humming, And that a strange one too, which did awake me.
Goodbye!: I heard a humming, and a strange one, which awakened me.

Anon!: Had he a hand to write this, a heart and brain to breed it in?
Goodbye!: Had he a hand to write this, a heart and a brain to make it into?

Anon!: I never may believe These antique fables nor these fairy toys.
Goodbye!: I can’t believe any of these antique fables or fairy toys.

Anon!: I would the fool were married to her grave!
Goodbye!: I wish the fool were married to her grave!

Anon!: He cannot live, I hope, and must not die Till George be packed with post-horse up to heaven.
Goodbye!: He can’t live, I hope, and he can’t die until George’s packed with a savage savage up to heaven.

Anon!: Then comes my fit again.
Goodbye!: Then I’ll be back.

Anon!: Nothing.
Goodbye!: Nothing.

Anon!: He is well paid that is well satisfied.
Goodbye!: He’s well paid and is well satisfied.

Anon!: Ay, and the time seems thirty unto me, Being all this time abandoned from your bed.
Goodbye!: Yes, and the time seems to be thirty years old, since you’ve been left out of your bed all this time.

Anon!: While he was yet in Rome His power went out in such distractions as Beguiled all spies.
Goodbye!: While he was still in Rome, his power was out of control, as if he had snorted all spies.

Anon!: And I must Rid all the sea of pirates, then, to send Measures of wheat to Rome.
Goodbye!: And then I must go to the sea to send me wheat to Rome.

Anon!: For your father’s remembrance, be at accord.
Goodbye!: For your father’s memory, be patient.

Anon!: Thou didst drink The stale of horses and the gilded puddle Which beasts would cough at.
Goodbye!: You drank the stale of horses and the gilded puddle that beasts would cough at.

Anon!: Prepare we for our marriage; on which day, My Lord of Burgundy, we’ll take your oath, And all the peers', for surety of our leagues.
Goodbye!: We’ll be ready for our marriage, my Lord of Burgundy, and all the other men’s wives, for sure of our marriage.

Anon!: Pray you, keep seat.
Goodbye!: Please, keep your seat.

Anon!: Tis strange, strange.
Goodbye!: It’s strange, strange.

Anon!: If she convey Letters to Richmond, you shall answer it.
Goodbye!: If she sends letters to Richmond, you’ll answer it.

Anon!: Ay, marry, why was he sent into England?
Goodbye!: Yes, marry, why was he sent into England?

Anon!: I’ll go and chat with Paris.
Goodbye!: I’ll go and chat with Paris.

Anon!: I am not I if there be such an  Or those eyes shut that makes thee answer “ay.” If he be slain, say “ay,” or if not, “no.” Brief sounds determine of my weal or woe.
Goodbye!: I don’t know if there’s a man like that or those eyes shut that make you answer “yes.” If he’s killed, say “yes,” or if not, “no.” Brief sounds determine

Anon!: Some that will evermore peep through their eyes And laugh like parrots at a bagpiper, And other of such vinegar aspect That they’ll not show their teeth in way of smile Though Nestor swear the jest be laughable.
Goodbye!: Some people who will peep through their eyes and laugh like parrots at a bagpiper, and other of such vinegar that they won’t smile with their teeth, even though Nestor swears the jest is

Anon!: Is thy name William?
Goodbye!: Is your name William?

Anon!: And, you know, his means, If he improve them, may well stretch so far As to annoy us all; which to prevent, Let Antony and Caesar fall together.
Goodbye!: And you know, if he improves his skills, he’ll be able to make us all angry.

Anon!: Two of the fairest stars in all the heaven, Having some business, do entreat her eyes To twinkle in their spheres till they return.
Goodbye!: Two of the fairest stars in all the heavens, who have some business, are begging her eyes to twinkle in their spheres until they return.

Anon!: Therefore my merchandise makes me not sad.
Goodbye!: So my clothes don’t make me sad.

Anon!: I humbly take my leave.
Goodbye!: I’m humbly leaving.

Anon!: I have ever held my cap off to thy fortunes.
Goodbye!: I’ve always been able to keep my cap off to your fortunes.

Anon!: Now to you.
Goodbye!: Now go to you.

Anon!: Hear me, recreant!
Goodbye!: Listen to me, recreant!

Anon!: Grief of my son’s exile hath stopped her breath.
Goodbye!: My son’s exile has stopped her breath.

Anon!: He that is robbed, not wanting what is stol'n, Let him not know’t, and he’s not robbed at all.
Goodbye!: If he’s been robbed, don’t let him know what he’s doing, and he’s not robbed at all.

Anon!: The watchdogs bark.
Goodbye!: The watchdogs bark.

Anon!: As the cony that you see dwell where she is kindled.
Goodbye!: As the cony you see, she’s smothered.

Anon!: That did I, my lord, and was accounted a good actor.
Goodbye!: I did, my lord, and I was a good actor.

Anon!: What judgment shall I dread, doing no wrong?
Goodbye!: What judgment should I do if I didn’t do anything wrong?

Anon!: Is ’t true?
Goodbye!: Is that true?

Anon!: No, sir, I say his horse comes, with him on his back.
Goodbye!: No, sir, I say his horse comes with him on his back.

Anon!: Methinks I see my cousin’s ghost Seeking out Romeo, that did spit his body Upon a rapier’s point.
Goodbye!: I think I see my cousin’s ghost looking for Romeo, who spit his body on a rapier’s point.

Anon!: Locked in her monument.
Goodbye!: Locked in her tomb.

Anon!: Come out o' th' storm.
Goodbye!: Come out of the storm.

Anon!: You have no stomach, Signior.
Goodbye!: You don’t have any stomach, sir.

Anon!: Well, sir.
Goodbye!: Well, sir.

Anon!: Before God, and in my mind, very wise.
Goodbye!: I think God is very wise.

Anon!: Alas, poor Harry of England!
Goodbye!: Oh, poor Harry of England!

Anon!: No such jade as you, if me you mean.
Goodbye!: No one like you, if you mean me.

Anon!: I am glad to see you well.— Horatio?
Goodbye!: I’m glad to see you well.—Horatio?

Anon!: Then shall we find tomorrow they have only stomachs to eat and none to fight.
Goodbye!: Then tomorrow we’ll find that they have only stomachs to eat and none to fight.

Anon!: It was.
Goodbye!: It was.

Anon!: It shall be called “Bottom’s Dream” because it hath no bottom.
Goodbye!: It’s not a bottom.

Anon!: Some dungeon.
Goodbye!: A little dungeon.

Goodbye!: So we grew together like a double cherry—she’s seen dividing up, but still dividing up—two lovely berries on one stem;

Anon!: A right fair mark, fair coz, is soonest hit.
Goodbye!: Then the right one is hit the most quickly.

Anon!: Is it so nominated in the bond?
Goodbye!: Is it so nominated in the contract?

Anon!: To find out you.
Goodbye!: To find you.

Goodbye!: I would like you to leave these sad plans to him who has more reason to be a mourner, and to repair it to Crosby House, where, after I have solemnly interred at Chertsey

Anon!: Oh, villain!
Goodbye!: Oh, villain!

Anon!: But there’s no bottom, none, In my voluptuousness.
Goodbye!: But I’m not a fan of the bottom line, and I’m not.

Anon!: What art thou, fellow?
Goodbye!: What are you, fellow?

Anon!: Too long a pause for that which you find there.
Goodbye!: It’s too long for the things you’re looking for.

Anon!: What, ho!
Goodbye!: Oh, what!

Anon!: May not one speak?
Goodbye!: Can’t one speak?

Goodbye!: What soldiers, patch?

Goodbye!: Oh sir, pardon me!

Goodbye!: Why should he stay, whom love wants to go?

Anon!: Signor Bassanio, hear me.
Goodbye!: Signor Bassanio, listen to me.

Anon!: Company is coming here.
Goodbye!: Company is coming.

Anon!: Vile earth, to earth resign.
Goodbye!: Let’s go to earth.

Anon!: But heavenly Rosalind!
Goodbye!: But heavenly Rosalind!

Anon!: I marvel your ladyship takes delight in such a barren rascal.

Anon!: There will we dine.
Goodbye!: We’ll eat there.

Goodbye!: It’s not for gravity to play at the cherry-pit with Satan.

Anon!: Wherefore!
Goodbye!: Why?

Anon!: And stay, good Nurse.
Goodbye!: And stay, good Nurse.

Goodbye!: Come on, bring me to my chance.

Goodbye!: It’s something, nothing: it was mine, it’s his, and has been slave to thousands.

Goodbye!: Oh, that you bore the mind that I do, what a sleep you had for your advancement!

Anon!: If we are like you in the rest, we will resemble you in that.
Goodbye!: If we’re like you in the rest of the world, we’ll look like you in that.

Anon!: Fie on her!
Goodbye!: Go on her!

Anon!: What is your tidings?

Anon!: If this young gentleman Have done offence, I take the fault on me.
Goodbye!: If this young gentleman has offended me, I’ll blame you.

Anon!: Fear not, Baptista, we will content you.
Goodbye!: Don’t worry, Baptista, we’ll be happy to help you.

Goodbye!: Your brother is only young and tender, and I’d be loath to foil him for your love, as I must for my own honor if he came in.

Anon!: Ay, and I’ll give them him without a fee.
Goodbye!: Yes, and I’ll give them him free of charge.

Goodbye!: A woman’s voice may do some good when she is begging for something too good.

Anon!: Nod to him, elves, and do him courtesies.
Goodbye!: Go to him, elves, and do him courtesies.

Goodbye!: Upon your sword, win the laurel and be beaten up before your feet.

Anon!: And you must cut this flesh from off his breast.
Goodbye!: And you have to cut this flesh from his breast.

Anon!: Let her alone.
Goodbye!: Leave her alone.

Goodbye!: Our fears in Banquo are deep, and his nature’s royalty is reigning the fear that would be feared.

Anon!: For if thou dost intend Never so little show of love to her, Thou shalt aby it.
Goodbye!: If you want to never show her so much love, you’ll be surprised by it.

Anon!: Fine, i' faith!
Goodbye!: Good, I’m sure!

Anon!: Teach it but how, And thou shalt see how apt it is to learn Any hard lesson that may do thee good.
Goodbye!: Teach it only how, and you’ll see how apt it is to learn any hard lesson that can do you good.

Anon!: Now do I see ’tis true.
Goodbye!: Now I see it’s true.

Anon!: Signior Lodovico?
Goodbye!: Signior Lodovico?

Anon!: Where do I dwell?
Goodbye!: Where do I live?

Anon!: A friend.
Goodbye!: A friend.

Goodbye!: If you’re going on this journey, you’ll kill yourself.

Anon!: The meat was well, if you were so contented.
Goodbye!: The meat was good if you were so happy.

Goodbye!: Death and damnation!

Anon!: God 'ild you for your last company.

Anon!: I pray thee, overname them.

Anon!: Therefore I do advise you, take this note.

Anon!: Indeed, upon my sword, indeed.

Anon!: But though we think it so, it is no matter.

Anon!: But all this did I know before.
Goodbye!: But I knew all this before.

Anon!: No, it is struck.

Goodbye!: Lucentio!

Anon!: Thanks for that.
Goodbye!: Thanks for that.

Anon!: Ay, that he did.
Goodbye!: Yes, that’s what he did.

Anon!: Go, good Tubal.
Goodbye!: Go, Tubal.

Anon!: She lives.
Goodbye!: She lives.

Goodbye!: We took this mattock and this spade from him as he was coming from this churchyard’s side.

Anon!: Content.
Goodbye!: Content.

Anon!: Not tonight, good Iago.
Goodbye!: Not tonight, Iago.

Anon!: Give me a torch.
Goodbye!: Give me a torch.

Anon!: Thy name is Gloucester.
Goodbye!: Your name is Gloucester.

Anon!: Spirits, which by mine art I have from their confines called to enact My present fancies.
Goodbye!: Spirits, which I have called to act from their confines, are the ones I have called to act on my current fancies.

Anon!: I can tell your Majesty, the duke is a prave man.
Goodbye!: I can tell your Majesty, the duke is a prave man.

Anon!: Therefore get you on and give him his desire.
Goodbye!: So hurry on and give him his desire.

Anon!: My dear master, My captain, and my emperor, let me say, Before I strike this bloody stroke, farewell.
Goodbye!: My dear master, my captain, and my emperor, let me say, before I strike this bloody stroke, goodbye.

Anon!: Belike Some things—I know not what.
Goodbye!: I don’t know what.

Anon!: I cannot say “whore,” It does abhor me now I speak the word.
Goodbye!: I can’t say “whore,” but it’s a shame I’m speaking the word now.

Anon!: Some there be that shadows kiss.
Goodbye!: There are some people who kiss.

Goodbye!: We’ll give them the opportunity to speak.

Anon!: They are.
Goodbye!: They are.

Anon!: Would I were in an alehouse in London!
Goodbye!: I wish I were in a pub in London!

Goodbye!: Then ask for adieu and say the tears are coming to Egypt.

Goodbye!: But I can learn, he hears after prophecies and dreams, and he plucks the letter from the crossrow and says a wizard told him that his issue should be disinherited by “G”.

Anon!: Is my father well?
Goodbye!: Is my father well?

Anon!: My liege, here is a villain and a traitor, that, look your Grace, has struck the glove which your Majesty is take out of the helmet of Alençon.
Goodbye!: My liege, here is a villain and a traitor, who, look at your Grace, has struck the glove that your Majesty is taking out of Alençon’s helmet.

Anon!: Dolabella, I shall remain your debtor.
Goodbye!: Dolabella, I’ll remain your debtor.

Anon!: Come, come, wrestle with thy affections.
Goodbye!: Come, come, fight with your affections.

Anon!: Do all men kill the things they do not love?
Goodbye!: Do all men kill the things they don’t love?

Anon!: Enough, Captain.
Goodbye!: Enough, Captain.

Anon!: Smatter with your gossips, go.
Goodbye!: Smatter with your gossips, go.

Anon!: If not, the Fates with traitors do contrive.
Goodbye!: If not, the Fates are threatening to fight with traitors.

Anon!: Oh, I die for food.
Goodbye!: Oh, I die for food.

Goodbye!: I’m a perfumer, as I was smoking a musty room, and I’m the Prince and Claudio, hand in hand, in a sad conference.

Anon!: He bears him like a portly gentleman, And, to say truth, Verona brags of him To be a virtuous and well-governed youth.
Goodbye!: He’s like a handsome gentleman, and, to say the truth, Verona is brags about him as a virtuous and well-governed young man.

Anon!: This is his sword.
Goodbye!: This is his sword.

Anon!: Have patience and endure.
Goodbye!: Have patience and endure.

Anon!: Or if it did not, Your first is dead, or ’twere as good he were, As living here and you no use of him.
Goodbye!: Or if it didn’t, your first one is dead or was as good as his own, as he was living here and you didn’t use him.

Anon!: Speak your office.
Goodbye!: Tell me your job.

Anon!: Calls my lord?
Goodbye!: Is that my lord?

Anon!: No, I will not cast away my physic but on those that are sick.
Goodbye!: No, I won’t give my physic advice to those who are sick.

Anon!: Amen!
Goodbye!: Amen!

Anon!: Come with a thought.
Goodbye!: Come with a thought.

Anon!: But on thy side I may not be too forward, Lest, being seen, thy brother, tender George, Be executed in his father’s sight.
Goodbye!: But I can’t be too far away, so I can’t be executed in his father’s sight.

Anon!: A friendly eye could never see such faults.
Goodbye!: A friendly eye could never see such faults.

Anon!: And what have kings that privates have not too, Save ceremony, save general ceremony?
Goodbye!: And what are kings that privates haven’t too, except ceremony, except general ceremony?

Goodbye!: And for his cowardly attitude, ask Fabian.

Anon!: I was hurt under your arm.
Goodbye!: I was hurt under your arm.

Anon!: Villains, you did not so when your vile daggers Hacked one another in the sides of Caesar.

Anon!: Tis very true.
Goodbye!: That’s very true.

Anon!: Where lies your text?
Goodbye!: Where is your text?

Anon!: All with me’s meet that I can fashion fit.
Goodbye!: I’ll meet you all with you so I can make it fit.

Anon!: But one fiend at a time, I’ll fight their legions o'er.
Goodbye!: I’ll fight their legions one at a time.

Anon!: An you be mine, I’ll give you to my friend.
Goodbye!: If you’re mine, I’ll give you to my friend.

Anon!: Cousins, I hope the days are near at hand That chambers will be safe.
Goodbye!: Cousins, I hope the days are near here that the rooms will be safe.

Anon!: My lord, I have news to tell you.
Goodbye!: My lord, I have news to tell you.

Anon!: Go seek the traitor Gloucester.
Goodbye!: Go find the traitor Gloucester.

Anon!: That shall she.
Goodbye!: That will be her.

Anon!: Before the time be out?
Goodbye!: Before the time comes out?

Anon!: First, forward to the temple.
Goodbye!: First, go to the temple.

Anon!: Oh, these flaws and starts, Impostors to true fear, would well become A woman’s story at a winter’s fire, Authorized by her grandam.
Goodbye!: Oh, these flaws and starts, which are a real threat, would well be a woman’s story in a winter’s fire, authorized by her grandma.

Anon!: All three Now marry in an instant.
Goodbye!: All three of us are married now in a moment.

Anon!: Quickly let me have it.
Goodbye!: Let me have it quickly.

Anon!: I am not in a sportive humor now.
Goodbye!: I’m not in a sporty mood now.

Anon!: Peaseblossom.
Goodbye!: Peaseblossom.

Anon!: I saw her laid low in her kindred’s vault And presently took post to tell it you.

Anon!: O, do not swear, my lord of Buckingham!
Goodbye!: Oh, don’t swear, my lord of Buckingham!

Anon!: To his father, that so tenderly and entirely loves him.
Goodbye!: He’s so sweet and loving to him.

Anon!: As I suck blood, I will some mercy show.
Goodbye!: As I suck blood, I’ll show some mercy.

Anon!: Crystal is muddy.
Goodbye!: Crystal is muddy.

Anon!: That will I, for I must bear answer back How you excuse my brother, Rosalind.
Goodbye!: I will, because I have to answer back how you excuse my brother, Rosalind.

Anon!: Cousin, you apprehend passing shrewdly.
Goodbye!: Cousin, you’re apprehending shrewdly.

Anon!: Send him but hither and I’ll fashion him.
Goodbye!: Send him here, and I’ll make him look like a man.

Anon!: Why, would that have mended my hair?
Goodbye!: Why, would that have ruined my hair?

Anon!: That’s the end.
Goodbye!: That’s the end.

Anon!: He’s now in Florence.
Goodbye!: He’s in Florence now.

Anon!: I dreamt a dream tonight.
Goodbye!: I dreamed of a dream tonight.

Anon!: Be wary, then.

Anon!: It was wont to hold me but while one tells twenty.

Goodbye!: Is this the Prince?

Anon!: I might have saved her.
Goodbye!: I could have saved her.

Goodbye!: Why did you send me out, brave Cassius?

Anon!: What, in our house?
Goodbye!: What, in our house?

Anon!: Ay.
Goodbye!: Yes.

Anon!: Shall Kate be my wife?
Goodbye!: Shall Kate be my wife?

Anon!: If love be rough with you, be rough with love.
Goodbye!: If love is rough with you, be rough with love.

Anon!: And ask no other dowry with her but such another jest.
Goodbye!: And ask no other dowry with her except such a dowry.

Anon!: Peace, ho!
Goodbye!: Quiet!

Anon!: I’ll tell thee ere thou ask it me again.
Goodbye!: I’ll tell you before you ask me again.

Anon!: Whither are you going?
Goodbye!: Where are you going?

Goodbye!: Fourscore ducats at a time!

Anon!: O cousin, cousin!
Goodbye!: Oh cousin, cousin!

Goodbye!: Signior Leonato, let the friar advise you.

Anon!: What noise?

Anon!: I would I could see this taborer.

Anon!: Receive what cheer you may.

Anon!: As he was fortunate, I rejoice at it.

Anon!: That she’s the chosen of Signior Hortensio.
Goodbye!: That she’s the chosen signior Hortensio.

Goodbye!: If I had known this young man before, I would have given him tears to a couple of sex, and he would have ventured.

Anon!: They say he has been fencer to the Sophy.
Goodbye!: They say he’s been a fencer to the Sophy.

Anon!: Adieu, Till your return at night.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, until you return at night.

Anon!: Nay, I’ll conjure too!

Goodbye!: I won’t expostulate with her, so my body and beauty will never be able to express my mind again—This night, Iago!

Anon!: She cannot deny it.
Goodbye!: She can’t deny it.

Anon!: A dear happiness to women.
Goodbye!: A dear happiness to women.

Anon!: Ha' to thee, lad!
Goodbye!: Ha' to you, lad!

Anon!: Handkerchief—confessions—handkerchief!
Goodbye!: Handkerchief—confessions—handkerchief!

Anon!: O, let us have him, for his silver hairs Will purchase us a good opinion And buy men’s voices to commend our deeds.
Goodbye!: Oh, let’s have him, because his silver hairs will buy us a good opinion and buy men’s voices to praise our actions.

Anon!: This in the public eye?
Goodbye!: Is this public opinion?

Anon!: Here comes the count.
Goodbye!: Here comes the count.

Anon!: What wicked and dissembling glass of mine Made me compare with Hermia’s sphery eyne?
Goodbye!: What wicked and dissembling glass of mine made me compare to Hermia’s spherical eyne?

Anon!: Uncle, this is a Montague, our foe, A villain that is hither come in spite To scorn at our solemnity this night.
Goodbye!: Uncle, this is a Montague, our enemy, a villain who has come here to scorn our solemnity this night.

Anon!: How goes it here?
Goodbye!: How is it going here?

Anon!: Who can impress the forest, bid the tree Unfix his earthbound root?
Goodbye!: Who can impress the forest and ask the tree to remove his earthbound root?

Anon!: I saw thee late at the Count Orsino’s.
Goodbye!: I saw you at Count Orsino’s late.

Anon!: Not now, sweet Desdemona.
Goodbye!: Not now, sweet Desdemona.

Anon!: When shall we come to th' top of that same hill?
Goodbye!: When should we come to the top of that hill?

Anon!: A segregation of the Turkish fleet.
Goodbye!: A segregation of the Turkish fleet.

Anon!: Return to her, and fifty men dismissed?
Goodbye!: Return to her, and fifty men were dismissed?

Anon!: In faith, he’s penitent, And yet his trespass, in our common reason (Save that, they say, the wars must make example Out of her best) is not, almost, a fault T' incur a private check.
Goodbye!: He’s incompetent, and yet his trespass, in our common reason (save that, they say, the wars must make example out of her best) is not a fault for a private

Anon!: I know not, sir.
Goodbye!: I don’t know, sir.

Anon!: Were we not born under Taurus?
Goodbye!: Weren’t we born under Taurus?

Anon!: And made your other love, Demetrius— Who even but now did spurn me with his foot— To call me goddess, nymph, divine, and rare, Precious, celestial?
Goodbye!: And made your other love Demetrius—who even spurned me with his foot—to call me goddess, nymph, divine, and rare, Precious, celestial?

Anon!: To flatter Caesar, would you mingle eyes With one that ties his points?
Goodbye!: To flatter Caesar, would you go get one who ties his points together?

Anon!: Light, I say, light!
Goodbye!: Light, I say, light!

Anon!: He is a sick man that would speak with you.
Goodbye!: He’s a sick man who wants to speak with you.

Anon!: The mind I sway by and the heart I bear Shall never sag with doubt nor shake with fear.
Goodbye!: I’ll never shake my mind and my heart with fear or doubt.

Anon!: Trust to ’t, bethink you.
Goodbye!: Trust me, think about it.

Anon!: List a word.
Goodbye!: Listen a minute.

Anon!: Make it so known.
Goodbye!: Tell me.

Anon!: Edmund and I have talked, And more convenient is he for my hand Than for your lady’s.
Goodbye!: Edmund and I have talked, and he’s more convenient for my hand than for your lady’s.

Anon!: Who am I, sir?
Goodbye!: Who am I, sir?

Anon!: Kill Claudio.
Goodbye!: Kill Claudio.

Anon!: If you grow foul with me, Pistol, I will scour you with my rapier, as I may, in fair terms.
Goodbye!: If you’re getting angry with me, Pistol, I’ll scour you with my rapier, as I can, in fair terms.

Anon!: Sir, in Argier.
Goodbye!: Sir, in Argier.

Anon!: Mine was not bridled.
Goodbye!: Mine wasn’t bridled.

Anon!: And how long is that, think you?
Goodbye!: And how long is that, do you think?

Anon!: Is it possible that any villainy should be so dear?
Goodbye!: Is it possible that any villainy is so dear?

Anon!: Well, we will leave you then till dinnertime.
Goodbye!: Well, we’ll leave you until dinnertime.

Anon!: Now we speak upon our cue, and our voice is imperial.
Goodbye!: Now we’re talking about our intentions, and our voice is imperial.

Anon!: Beyond imagination is the wrong That she this day hath shameless thrown on me.
Goodbye!: She’s thrown shamelessly on me today.

Anon!: Is that the chain you promised me today?
Goodbye!: Is that the necklace you promised me today?

Anon!: But a harsh hearing when women are froward.
Goodbye!: But a harsh hearing when women are froward.

Anon!: You saw they speak us fair, give us gold.
Goodbye!: You saw them speak us fair, give us gold.

Anon!: By my fay, a goodly nap.
Goodbye!: I swear, a good nap.

Anon!: You have among you many a purchased slave, Which—like your asses and your dogs and mules— You use in abject and in slavish parts Because you bought them.
Goodbye!: You have many of the slaves you bought, which—like your asses and your dogs and mules—you use in abject and slavish parts because you bought them.

Anon!: Come, some music!
Goodbye!: Come on, listen to some music!

Anon!: How?
Goodbye!: How?

Anon!: Why rail’st thou on thy birth, the heaven, and earth?
Goodbye!: Why are you scolding your birth, the heavens, and the earth?

Anon!: Ay, the heads of the maids, or their maidenheads.
Goodbye!: Yes, the heads of the maids, or their maidenheads.

Anon!: Say thou but “ay,” And that bare vowel  Than the death-darting eye of cockatrice.
Goodbye!: Say “Yes,” and that bare vowel is more than the death-darking eye of cockatrice.

Anon!: Stay, dog, for thou shalt hear me.
Goodbye!: Stay, dog, because you’ll hear me.

Anon!: Why, then, take no note of him, but let him go and presently call the rest of the watch together and thank God you are rid of a knave.
Goodbye!: So don’t take note of him, but let him go and call the rest of the watch together and thank God you’ve been rid of a knave.

Anon!: I guess at it.
Goodbye!: I guess at it.

Anon!: I pray you, father, being weak, seem so.
Goodbye!: Please, father, because you’re weak, you seem to be so.

Anon!: Ay, and he’ll tame her.
Goodbye!: Yes, and he’ll tame her.

Anon!: Come, go with me.
Goodbye!: Come with me.

Anon!: Hold you the watch tonight?
Goodbye!: Do you have the watch tonight?

Anon!: Gremio, ’tis now no time to vent our love.
Goodbye!: Gremio, it’s no time to express our love.

Anon!: If you do not, if I be left alone, Now, by mine honor—which is yet mine own— I’ll have that doctor for my bedfellow.
Goodbye!: If you don’t, if I’m left alone, now, I’ll have that doctor for my bedfellow.

Anon!: I would it might be hangers till then.
Goodbye!: I wish it were hangers until then.

Anon!: The French is gone off, look you, and there is gallant and most prave passages.
Goodbye!: The French are gone, look, and there are gallant and prave passages.

Anon!: how am I beset!— What kind of catechizing call you this?
Goodbye!: How am I snuck up!—What kind of catechizing call you this?

Anon!: Do, with like timorous accent and dire yell As when, by night and negligence, the fire Is spied in populous cities.
Goodbye!: Do, with a timorous accent and a dire yell, as when, by night and negligence, the fire is spied in populous cities.

Anon!: That will never be.
Goodbye!: That’s never true.

Anon!: Therefore this letter, being so excellently ignorant, will breed no terror in the youth.
Goodbye!: Therefore, this letter, being so ignorant, won’t cause any terror in the youth.

Anon!: From my house, if I had it— The sixth of July.
Goodbye!: From my house, if I had it— The sixth of July.

Anon!: Go to, I’ll no more on ’t.
Goodbye!: Go on, I won’t go on it again.

Anon!: I will go call the watch.
Goodbye!: I’ll go call the watch.

Anon!: Why, it hath bay windows transparent as barricadoes, and the clerestories toward the south-north are as lustrous as ebony.
Goodbye!: It’s as transparent as barricadoes, and the clerestories toward the south-north are as lustrous as ebony.

Anon!: Witness, you ever-burning lights above, You elements that clip us round about, Witness that here Iago doth give up The execution of his wit, hands, heart, To wronged Othello’s service.
Goodbye!: Witness, you ever burning lights above, you elements that clip us roundabout, Witness that Iago gives up his wit, hands, heart, to wronged Othello’s service.

Anon!: Thou look’st like him that knows a warlike charge.
Goodbye!: You look like a man who knows a warlike charge.

Anon!: Down on your knees And thank heaven, fasting, for a good man’s love, For I must tell you friendly in your ear, Sell when you can; you are not for all markets.
Goodbye!: I’ll tell you in your ear that you can sell when you can; you’re not for all markets.

Anon!: Th' affair cries haste And speed must answer it.
Goodbye!: Your affair is hurrying, and you have to hurry up.

Anon!: You have spoken truer than you purposed.
Goodbye!: You’ve spoken more than you intended.

Anon!: For I will make him tell the tale anew Where, how, how oft, how long ago, and when He hath, and is again to cope your wife.
Goodbye!: I’ll tell him the story again, where, how often, how long ago, and when he’s gone, and is again to help your wife.

Anon!: No.
Goodbye!: No.

Anon!: Come, sit on me.
Goodbye!: Come on, sit on me.

Anon!: Ah, he is young, and his minority Is put unto the trust of Richard Gloucester, A man that loves not me nor none of you.
Goodbye!: Ah, he’s young, and his minority is backed by Richard Gloucester, a man who doesn’t love me or you.

Anon!: Acquaint her here of my son Paris' love, And bid her, mark you me, on Wednesday next— But, soft!
Goodbye!: Tell her about my son Paris’s love here and tell her, please, to come see me on Wednesday— But soft!

Anon!: It were a better death than die with mocks, Which is as bad as die with tickling.
Goodbye!: It would be better to die than to die with mocks, which is as bad as dying with tickling.

Anon!: And ere I take this charm from of her sight— As I can take it with another herb— I’ll make her render up her page to me.
Goodbye!: And if I take this charm from her sight—I can take it with another herb—I’ll make her render her page to me.

Anon!: And let those that play your clowns speak no more than is set down for them, for there be of them that will themselves laugh to set on some quantity of barren spectators to laugh too, though in the meantime some necessary question of the play be then to be considered.
Goodbye!: And let those who play your clowns speak no more than they are set up for them.

Anon!: I have done the deed.
Goodbye!: I’ve done the deed.

Anon!: You know not why we came to visit you— Thus out of season, threading dark-eyed night.
Goodbye!: You don’t know why we came to visit you— So out of season, a dark night.

Anon!: The Lord Mayor knocks.
Goodbye!: The Lord Mayor is knocking.

Anon!: It is not moonlight now.
Goodbye!: It’s not moonlight now.

Anon!: Is it a custom?
Goodbye!: Is it a custom?

Anon!: Almost afraid to know itself.
Goodbye!: I’m almost afraid to know itself.

Anon!: Even then this forkèd plague is fated to us When we do quicken.
Goodbye!: And then this plague is fated to us when we get ready.

Anon!: A thousand, sir, Early though ’t be, have on their riveted trim And at the port expect you.
Goodbye!: A thousand, sir, even if it’s early, have riveted their hats and at the port expect you.

Anon!: Advantage is a better soldier than rashness.
Goodbye!: Advantage is a better soldier than rashness.

Anon!: One word more, honest neighbors.
Goodbye!: One more thing, honest neighbors.

Anon!: O my dear niece, welcome thou art to me, Even daughter, welcome in no less degree.
Goodbye!: Oh, my dear niece, welcome to me, even my daughter, welcome in no less than a degree.

Anon!: So, Dolabella, It shall content me best.
Goodbye!: So, Dolabella, I’ll be happy.

Anon!: The point envenomed too!—Then, venom, to thy work.
Goodbye!: Then, venom, you’re going to work.

Anon!: Thou but rememberest me of mine own conception.
Goodbye!: You’re only reminded of my own conception.

Anon!: And for my name of George begins with  It follows in his thought that I am he.
Goodbye!: And for my name of George begins with the idea that I am him.

Anon!: Most monsterlike be shown For poor’st diminutives, for dolts, and let Patient Octavia plow thy visage up With her preparèd nails!
Goodbye!: You can see the monsters for poor, poor, and dolts, and let Patient Octavia plow your face with her pre-made nails!

Anon!: If thou hast her not i' the end, call me “Cut.”  If I do not, never trust me, take it how you will.
Goodbye!: If she doesn’t have her in the end, call me “Cut.” If I don’t, never trust me, take it like you want.

Anon!: A sister I bequeath you whom no brother Did ever love so dearly.
Goodbye!: I beg you a sister whom no brother ever loved so much.

Anon!: I have ’t.
Goodbye!: I have.

Anon!: If thou wilt weep my fortunes, take my eyes.
Goodbye!: If you’re weeping my fortunes, take my eyes.

Anon!: Why look you strange on me?
Goodbye!: Why are you looking strange on me?

Anon!: Let’s follow it, and after do our work.
Goodbye!: Let’s follow it, and after we do our work.

Anon!: And so farewell.—Katherina, you may stay, For I have more to commune with Bianca.
Goodbye!: And goodbye.—Katherina, you can stay, because I have more to share with Bianca.

Anon!: Do it quickly.
Goodbye!: Do it quickly.

Anon!: They are in the very wrath of love, and they will together.
Goodbye!: They’re in the wrath of love, and they’ll fight together.

Anon!: Though he be as good a gentleman as the devil is, as Lucifer and Beelzebub himself, it is necessary, look your Grace, that he keep his vow and his oath.
Goodbye!: Although he’s as good a gentleman as the devil is, as Lucifer and Beelzebub himself, it’s necessary, look your Grace, that he keep his vow and oath.

Anon!: Give me my sin again.
Goodbye!: Give me my sin back.

Anon!: That he hath not.
Goodbye!: That he hasn’t.

Anon!: I know thy quality.
Goodbye!: I know your quality.

Anon!: No, sir.
Goodbye!: No, sir.

Anon!: Tis not the first time you were overshot.
Goodbye!: It’s not the first time you’ve been overshot.

Anon!: How now, daughter?
Goodbye!: What’s going on, daughter?

Anon!: For what is he they follow?
Goodbye!: What are they doing?

Anon!: The selfsame name, but one of better nature.
Goodbye!: The same name, but one of better nature.

Anon!: Poor soul!
Goodbye!: Poor soul!

Anon!: Not I, my lord, by heaven.
Goodbye!: Not me, my lord, by heaven.

Anon!: What wilt thou do?
Goodbye!: What will you do?

Anon!: O proud death, What feast is toward in thine eternal cell, That thou so many princes at a shot So bloodily hast struck?
Goodbye!: Oh, proud death, what feast is your eternal cell, that you have so many princes killed at a shot so bloodyly?

Anon!: Let me entreat you.
Goodbye!: Let me ask you.

Anon!: The labor we delight in physics pain.
Goodbye!: We’re wasting our time on physics.

Anon!: Didst hear her speak?
Goodbye!: Did you hear her speak?

Anon!: The concernancy, sir?
Goodbye!: What’s the problem, sir?

Anon!: If we, with thrice such powers left at home, Cannot defend our own doors from the dog, Let us be worried, and our nation lose The name of hardiness and policy.
Goodbye!: If we can’t defend our own doors against the dog, let’s be worried, and our nation loses the name of hardness and policy.

Anon!: Farewell.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: Methought I heard a voice cry, “Sleep no more!
Goodbye!: I thought I heard a voice cry, “Don’t let it go!

Anon!: You said the enemy would not come down But keep the hills and upper regions.
Goodbye!: You said the enemy wouldn’t come down but keep the hills and upper regions.

Anon!: He is as disproportioned in his manners As in his shape.— Take with you your companions.
Goodbye!: He’s as disproportioned in his manners as in his shape.—Take with you your companions.

Anon!: I hate the Moor, And it is thought abroad that ’twixt my sheets He’s done my office.
Goodbye!: I hate the Moor, and it’s thought abroad that he’s done my job.

Anon!: I would forget it fain, But oh, it presses to my memory, Like damnèd guilty deeds to sinners' minds.
Goodbye!: I’d forget it, but it presses to my memory like damned guilty deeds to sinners’ minds.

Anon!: Thus have I politicly begun my reign, And ’tis my hope to end successfully.
Goodbye!: I’ve begun my reign politicly, and I hope to end it with a successful end.

Anon!: To him, Sir Topas.
Goodbye!: To him, Sir Topas.

Anon!: Well, I have done.
Goodbye!: Well, I’ve done it.

Anon!: Stand, an you be a man.
Goodbye!: Stand up, if you’re a man.

Anon!: Go to, away.
Goodbye!: Go away.

Anon!: The business of this man looks out of him.
Goodbye!: The business of this man looks out of him.

Anon!: Tis just.
Goodbye!: It’s just me.

Anon!: Thou think’st ’tis much that this contentious storm Invades us to the skin.
Goodbye!: You think it’s much that this violent storm invades us to the skin.

Anon!: For Hamlet and the trifling of his favor, Hold it a fashion and a toy in blood, A violet in the youth of primy nature, Forward, not permanent, sweet, not lasting, The perfume and suppliance of a minute.
Goodbye!: For Hamlet and his slur of favor, keep it in a fashion and a toy in blood, a violet in the youth of primy nature, forward, not permanent, sweet, not lasting, and the

Anon!: Faith, I’ll home tomorrow, Sir Toby.
Goodbye!: I’ll go home tomorrow, Sir Toby.

Anon!: To get his place and to plume up my will In double knavery.
Goodbye!: To get his place and to plume up my will in double knavery.

Anon!: Orsino, noble sir, Be pleased that I shake off these names you give me.
Goodbye!: Orsino, noble sir, be pleased that I’m scolded by the names you give me.

Anon!: She had a song of “Willow,” An old thing ’twas, but it expressed her fortune And she died singing it.
Goodbye!: She had a song called “Willow,” a thing she remembers as a child, but it said her fortune and she died singing it.

Anon!: You are an ass, you are an ass!
Goodbye!: You’re an ass, you’re an ass!

Anon!: Know’st thou the youth that spoke to me erewhile?
Goodbye!: Do you know the young man who spoke to me before?

Anon!: Methoughts that I had broken from the Tower And was embarked to cross to Burgundy, And in my company my brother Gloucester, Who from my cabin tempted me to walk Upon the hatches.
Goodbye!: I thought I had broken from the Tower and was embarked on a journey to Burgundy, and in my company my brother Gloucester, who tempted me to walk on the hatches from my cabin.

Anon!: Now, good Metellus, go along by him.
Goodbye!: Now, good Metellus, go with him.

Anon!: Adieu, adieu!
Goodbye!: Goodbye, goodbye!

Anon!: Thou know’st we work by wit and not by witchcraft, And wit depends on dilatory time.
Goodbye!: You know that we’re working by wit and not by witchcraft, and wit depends on dilatory time.

Anon!: We have sworn, my lord, already.
Goodbye!: We’ve already sworn, my lord.

Anon!: What do you mean To dote thus on such luggage?
Goodbye!: What do you mean to dote on such luggage?

Anon!: Say “a day” without the “ever.” No, no, Orlando, men are April when they woo, December when they wed. Maids are May when they are maids, but the sky changes when they are wives.
Goodbye!: No, Orlando, men are April when they woo, December when they wed.

Anon!: Defend thee!
Goodbye!: Do it!

Anon!: If I could win a lady at leapfrog or by vaulting into my saddle with my armor on my back, under the correction of bragging be it spoken, I should quickly leap into a wife.
Goodbye!: If I could win a lady at leapfrog or by vaulting into my saddle with my armor on my back, under the slack of bragging, I would quickly leap into a wife.

Anon!: Unwilling, I agreed.
Goodbye!: I was unwilling.

Anon!: I do love it better than laughing.
Goodbye!: I love it better than laughing.

Anon!: Why then, my cousin, Margaret, and Ursula Are much deceived, for they did swear you did.
Goodbye!: Well then, my cousin Margaret, and Ursula are very wrong, because they swear you did.

Anon!: Now to that name my courage prove my title!
Goodbye!: Now I’ll prove my title to you with my courage!

Anon!: Sirs, I will practice on this drunken man.
Goodbye!: Sirs, I’ll practice on this drunken man.

Anon!: Nay, gentle Romeo, we must have you dance.
Goodbye!: No, gentle Romeo, we have to dance.

Anon!: Oh, relation Too nice and yet too true!
Goodbye!: Oh, relation is too nice and yet true!

Anon!: Enter, sir, the castle.
Goodbye!: Enter the castle, sir.

Anon!: Go off.
Goodbye!: Go away.

Anon!: Is she to be buried in Christian burial when she willfully seeks her own salvation?
Goodbye!: Is she going to be buried in a Christian burial when she will seek her own salvation?

Anon!: Lysander, speak again!
Goodbye!: Lysander, speak again!

Anon!: Knock, knock!
Goodbye!: Knock, knock!

Anon!: Oh, rare for Antony!
Goodbye!: Oh, that’s rare for Antony!

Anon!: You must translate.
Goodbye!: You have to translate.

Anon!: How is the man esteemed here in the city?
Goodbye!: How is the man who’s been honored here in the city?

Anon!: I say you are not.
Goodbye!: I say you aren’t.

Anon!: Bear with my weakness.
Goodbye!: Keep up with my weakness.

Anon!: I am qualmish at the smell of leek.
Goodbye!: I’m scolded at the smell of leek.

Anon!: There’s a time for all things.
Goodbye!: There’s a time for everything.

Anon!: But, sir, I will deliver his challenge by word of mouth, set upon Aguecheek a notable report of valor, and drive the gentleman (as I know his youth will aptly receive it) into a most hideous opinion of his rage, skill, fury, and impetuosity.
Goodbye!: But I’ll deliver his challenge by word of mouth, write a notable report of valor, and drive the gentleman (as I know his youth will aptly receive it) into a hideous opinion of his rage

Anon!: Prates too.—What say you, James Soundpost?
Goodbye!: What do you say, James Soundpost?

Anon!: Music, moody food Of us that trade in love.
Goodbye!: Music, moody food from us who are in love.

Anon!: But, Audrey, there is a youth here in the forest lays claim to you.
Goodbye!: But Audrey, there’s a young man in the forest who claims to you.

Anon!: You do but dally.
Goodbye!: You’re only dallying.

Anon!: My mind is changed.
Goodbye!: My mind has changed.

Anon!: Good Maria, let this fellow be looked to.
Goodbye!: Good Maria, let this fellow be looked at.

Anon!: Write loyal cantons of contemned love And sing them loud even in the dead of night.
Goodbye!: Write loyal cantons of contemned love and sing them loud even in the dead of the night.

Anon!: They have tied me to a stake.
Goodbye!: They’ve tied me to a stake.

Anon!: The more my prayer, the lesser is my grace.
Goodbye!: The more I pray, the lesser I am.

Anon!: Your loss is as yourself, great, and you bear it As answering to the weight.
Goodbye!: Your loss is as good as yours, and you bear it as you’re answering to the weight.

Anon!: Cannot my Lord Stanley sleep these tedious nights?
Goodbye!: Can’t Lord Stanley sleep these tedious nights?

Anon!: For all the rest, They’ll take suggestion as a cat laps milk.
Goodbye!: For all the rest of the rest, they’ll take suggestions as a cat laps milk.

Anon!: I will kiss thy lips.
Goodbye!: I’ll kiss your lips.

Anon!: Enobarbus, Antony Hath after thee sent all thy treasure, with His bounty overplus.
Goodbye!: Enobarbus, Antony has sent you all your treasure, with his bounty overplus.

Anon!: Look!
Goodbye!: Look!

Anon!: This is Lucentio’s house.
Goodbye!: This is Lucentio’s house.

Anon!: Hold, take these keys, and fetch more spices, Nurse.
Goodbye!: Hold, take these keys and get more spices, Nurse.

Anon!: Bid him levy straight The greatest strength and power that he can make And meet me suddenly at Salisbury.
Goodbye!: Ask him to give him the greatest strength and power he can make and meet me suddenly at Salisbury.

Anon!: Tis not the king that sends you to the Tower.
Goodbye!: It’s not the king who sends you to the Tower.

Anon!: Why should Titania cross her Oberon?
Goodbye!: Why should Titania cross her Oberon?

Anon!: Wilt thou be gone?
Goodbye!: Are you going?

Anon!: He that is giddy thinks the world turns round.
Goodbye!: The man who’s giddy thinks the world turns around.

Anon!: It is, it is.
Goodbye!: It is, it is.

Anon!: Fulvia is dead.
Goodbye!: Fulvia is dead.

Anon!: And doth affection breed it?
Goodbye!: And is it a breed of affection?

Anon!: And, as the jest did glance away from me, 'Tis ten to one it maimed you two outright.
Goodbye!: And as the jest looked away from me, it’s ten to one that killed you two completely.

Anon!: Didst thou not hear a noise?
Goodbye!: Didn’t you hear a noise?

Anon!: Yonder sure they are coming.
Goodbye!: I’m sure they’re coming.

Anon!: Should be”—should buzz!
Goodbye!: Should be”—should buzz!

Anon!: You, Pyramus' father.—Myself, Thisbe’s father.—Snug the joiner, you, the lion’s part.—And I hope here is a play fitted.
Goodbye!: You, Pyramus’s father.—Myself, Thisbe’s father.—Snug the joiner, you, the lion’s part.—And I hope this is a play.

Anon!: Because, look you, you do not love it, nor your affections and your appetites and your digestions does not agree with it, I would desire you to eat it.
Goodbye!: Because, look, you don’t love it, and your affections and appetites and your digestion don’t agree with it, I’d like you to eat it.

Anon!: Sweet Moon, I thank thee for thy sunny beams.
Goodbye!: Sweet Moon, thank you for your sunny beams.

Anon!: Let that appear hereafter, and aim better at me by that I now will manifest.
Goodbye!: Let that appear later, and I’ll see that I’ll see better at me.

Anon!: And when please you to say so?
Goodbye!: And when do you want to say that?

Anon!: I know you are of her bosom.
Goodbye!: I know you’re a man who’s a king.

Anon!: Bring him, dead or living, Within this twelvemonth or turn thou no more To seek a living in our territory.
Goodbye!: Bring him, dead or living, within this twelve month or turn to seek a living in our territory.

Anon!: I was about to protest I loved you.
Goodbye!: I was about to protest that I loved you.

Anon!: Believe none of us.
Goodbye!: Don’t believe any of us.

Anon!: Tybalt is gone, and Romeo banishèd.
Goodbye!: Tybalt is gone, and Romeo has been banned.

Anon!: He, sir.
Goodbye!: He, sir.

Anon!: Every one prepare To follow this fair corse unto her grave.
Goodbye!: Everybody wants to follow this beautiful corse to her grave.

Anon!: So to most noble Caesar.
Goodbye!: So to most noble Caesar.

Anon!: Fare thee well.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: But now, I tell thee—keep it to thyself— This day those enemies are put to death, And I in better state than e'er I was.
Goodbye!: But now I tell you—keep it to yourself—that these enemies are put to death, and I’m better off than I was before.

Anon!: I cannot bid you bid my daughter live— That were impossible—but, I pray you both, Possess the people in Messina here How innocent she died.
Goodbye!: I can’t tell you to live my daughter—that’s impossible—but please, both of you, tell the people of Messina how innocent she died.

Anon!: I would have made it short, for I was come to the whole depth of my tale, and meant, indeed, to occupy the argument no longer.
Goodbye!: I would have made it short, since I was able to tell the whole story and to stop the argument.

Anon!: Where is your sister, and Hortensio’s wife?
Goodbye!: Where are your sister and Hortensio’s wife?

Anon!: Tonight she is mewed up to her heaviness.
Goodbye!: Tonight she’s mewed up to her heaviness.

Anon!: Only be patient till we have appeased The multitude, beside themselves with fear, And then we will deliver you the cause, Why I, that did love Caesar when I struck him, Have thus proceeded.
Goodbye!: We’ll give you the reason why I, who loved Caesar when I struck him, have now proceeded.

Anon!: Oh, ay, Curtis, ay, and therefore fire, fire.
Goodbye!: Oh, yes, Curtis, yes, and therefore fire, fire.

Anon!: Sit then and talk with her.
Goodbye!: Sit down and talk to her.

Anon!: Come, let’s all take hands Till that the conquering wine hath steeped our sense In soft and delicate Lethe.
Goodbye!: Come on, let’s all take care of our hands until we’ve soaked our sense in a soft and delicate Lethe.

Anon!: For love I followed him.
Goodbye!: I followed him for love.

Anon!: Oh yes, I saw sweet beauty in her face Such as the daughter of Agenor had, That made great Jove to humble him to her hand When with his knees he kissed the Cretan strand.
Goodbye!: Oh yes, I saw sweet beauty in her face as the daughter of Agenor had in her face.

Anon!: Having once this juice, I’ll watch Titania when she is asleep And drop the liquor of it in her eyes.
Goodbye!: I’ll watch Titania when she’s asleep and drop the liquor in her eyes.

Anon!: Susan and she—God rest all Christian souls!— Were of an age.
Goodbye!: Susan and she—God rest all Christian souls—were born in an age.

Anon!: I think ’twas Soto that your Honor means.
Goodbye!: I think it was Soto, which your Honor means.

Anon!: He needs as many, sir, as Caesar has, Or needs not us.
Goodbye!: He’s not as many, sir, or not as many as Caesar has.

Anon!: Farewell the plumèd troops and the big wars That makes ambition virtue!
Goodbye!: Farewell to the mighty troops and the big wars that make ambition virtue!

Anon!: Your lady mother is coming to your chamber.
Goodbye!: Your mother is coming to your room.

Anon!: O comfortable Friar!
Goodbye!: Oh, nice Friar!

Anon!: I have too grieved a heart To take a tedious leave.
Goodbye!: I’ve too grieved a heart to take a tedious leave.

Anon!: So are those crispèd snaky golden locks Which maketh such wanton gambols with the wind, Upon supposèd fairness, often known To be the dowry of a second head, The skull that bred them in the sepulcher.
Goodbye!: The same are the crisp, snaky golden locks that make such a gambols with the wind, if they’re fair, known to be the dowry of a second head, the skull that

Anon!: By my troth, ’s not so good, and I warrant your cousin will say so.
Goodbye!: I swear it’s not so good, and I assure your cousin will say that.

Anon!: I have none.
Goodbye!: I don’t have any.

Anon!: Be not afraid, though you do see me weaponed.
Goodbye!: Don’t be afraid, even if you see me being armed.

Anon!: Go and say We purpose her no shame.
Goodbye!: Go and say we’re not ashamed of her.

Anon!: It did bass my trespass.
Goodbye!: It did sound like a trespass.

Anon!: Take heed, sirrah—the whip.
Goodbye!: Take care of it, sir—the whip.

Anon!: Nay, for a need, thus far come near my person: Tell them when that my mother went with child Of that insatiate Edward, noble York My princely father then had wars in France, And, by true computation of the time, Found that the issue was not his begot, Which well appearèd in his lineaments, Being nothing like the noble duke my father.
Goodbye!: No, for a need, come near my person so far: tell them when my mother went with a child of that insatiable Edward, noble York, then, my princely father had wars in France, and, by

Anon!: I was hurt under your arm.
Goodbye!: I was hurt under your arm.

Anon!: The prayers of holy saints and wrongèd souls, Like high-reared bulwarks, stand before our faces.
Goodbye!: The prayers of holy saints and wronged souls, like high-recommended bulwarks, stand before our faces.

Anon!: He may show what outward courage he will, but I believe, as cold a night as ’tis, he could wish himself in Thames up to the neck; and so I would he were, and I by him, at all adventures, so we were quit here.
Goodbye!: He may show what he will be courageous, but I think he could wish himself in the Thames up to the neck as cold as it is.

Anon!: Content thee, gentle coz.
Goodbye!: Let’s go, gentle coz.

Anon!: Sir Toby, I must be round with you.
Goodbye!: Sir Toby, I have to be round with you.

Anon!: Could beauty, my lord, have better commerce than with honesty?
Goodbye!: Could beauty have better business than honesty, my lord?

Anon!: Hear my soul speak.
Goodbye!: Listen to my soul.

Anon!: My child is yet a stranger in the world.
Goodbye!: My child is still a stranger in the world.

Anon!: Away, old man.
Goodbye!: Go away, old man.

Anon!: Therefore, hear me, Hermia.
Goodbye!: So listen to me, Hermia.

Anon!: Look, how she rubs her hands.
Goodbye!: Look, how she rubs her hands.

Anon!: Tis called the evil.
Goodbye!: It’s called the evil.

Anon!: Oh, defend me!
Goodbye!: Oh, defend me!

Anon!: Will you go, coz?
Goodbye!: Will you go, coz?

Anon!: O dainty duck!
Goodbye!: Oh, dainty duck!

Anon!: Spirit, We must prepare to meet with Caliban.
Goodbye!: Spirit, we have to prepare to meet with Caliban.

Anon!: His royal grace, Whom God preserve better than you would wish, Cannot be quiet scarce a breathing while But you must trouble him with lewd complaints.
Goodbye!: His royal grace, who is better preserved than you would wish, can’t be quiet and quiet, but you have to trouble him with a few lewd complaints.

Anon!: Where’s Romeo?
Goodbye!: Where’s Romeo?

Anon!: How canst thou try them so?
Goodbye!: How can you try them like that?

Anon!: We pray you for your own sake to embrace your own safety and give over this attempt.
Goodbye!: Please, for your own sake, embrace your own safety and give up on this attempt.

Anon!: Go, Eros, send his treasure after.
Goodbye!: Eros, send his treasure back to him.

Anon!: First he denied you had in him no right.
Goodbye!: First he denied you had no right in him.

Anon!: Oh, look, sir, look, sir!
Goodbye!: Oh, look, sir, look, sir!

Anon!: His very genius hath taken the infection of the device, man.
Goodbye!: He’s taken the infection, man.

Anon!: Thou hadst need send for more money.
Goodbye!: You’d have to send for more money.

Anon!: Not a false gallop.
Goodbye!: Not a false gallop.

Anon!: I am your spaniel.
Goodbye!: I’m your spaniel.

Anon!: One way I like this well.
Goodbye!: One way I like this.

Anon!: A plague o' both your houses!
Goodbye!: A plague kills both your houses!

Anon!: Die when thou hast lived.
Goodbye!: Die when you’ve lived.

Anon!: Is it good e'en?
Goodbye!: Is it good?

Anon!: He had a fever when he was in Spain, And when the fit was on him, I did mark How he did shake.
Goodbye!: He had a fever when he was in Spain, and when he was fit, I noticed how he shook.

Anon!: Thou hast killed my child.
Goodbye!: You’ve killed my child.

Anon!: I’ll follow you.
Goodbye!: I’ll follow you.

Anon!: Nothing extenuate, Nor set down aught in malice.
Goodbye!: Nothing will stop you from letting your lord be abused.

Anon!: What, To kiss in private?
Goodbye!: What, to kiss in private?

Anon!: O wicked Wall through whom I see no bliss!
Goodbye!: Oh, a wicked wall that I don’t see bliss!

Anon!: I cannot speak your England.
Goodbye!: I can’t speak your England.

Anon!: Here comes the good Macduff.
Goodbye!: Here comes the good Macduff.

Anon!: Stay, you imperfect speakers, tell me more.
Goodbye!: Stay, you imperfect speakers, tell me more.

Anon!: For there is not a more fearful wildfowl than your lion living.
Goodbye!: There’s no more fearful wildfowl than your lion.

Anon!: Good night, good night!
Goodbye!: Good night, good night!

Anon!: Here comes a messenger.
Goodbye!: Here comes a messenger.

Anon!: Good sir, I do in friendship counsel you To leave this place.
Goodbye!: Good sir, I advise you to leave this place.

Anon!: Fie, fie on all tired jades, on all mad masters, and all foul ways!
Goodbye!: I’m a savage man, I’m a savage man!

Anon!: Tis but an hour ago since it was nine, And after one hour more ’twill be eleven.
Goodbye!: It’s only an hour ago, when it was nine, and after an hour more it’ll be eleven.

Anon!: Come, go in.
Goodbye!: Come in.

Anon!: While we reason here, A royal battle might be won and lost.
Goodbye!: While we’re here, a royal battle might be won and lost.

Anon!: One aloof stand sentinel.
Goodbye!: One aloof man is a sentinel.

Anon!: My life upon ’t, young though thou art, thine eye Hath stay’d upon some favor that it loves.
Goodbye!: I’m still alive, even if you’re young, and I’m still looking for some favor that it loves.

Anon!: He will find it comes from a clodpole.
Goodbye!: He’ll find it comes from a clodpole.

Anon!: Scurvy knave!
Goodbye!: Scurvy knave!

Anon!: Here, madam:     Conster them.
Goodbye!: Here, madam: Conster them.

Anon!: Up to some scaffold, there to lose their heads.
Goodbye!: Up to some scaffold, to lose their heads.

Anon!: This is above all strangeness.
Goodbye!: This is a strange thing.

Anon!: Have you not set mine honor at the stake, And baited it with all the unmuzzled thoughts That tyrannous heart can think?
Goodbye!: Have you not set my honor on the stake and baited it with all the unmuzzled thoughts that tyrannous heart can think?

Anon!: Oh, he is gone indeed.
Goodbye!: Oh, he’s gone.

Anon!: What satisfaction canst thou have tonight?
Goodbye!: What satisfaction can you have tonight?

Anon!: No, for I hold him to be unworthy of his place that does those things.
Goodbye!: No, because I think he’s not worthy of the place he’s doing those things.

Anon!: Thereby shall we shadow The numbers of our host and make discovery Err in report of us.
Goodbye!: So we’ll shadow the numbers of our host and make a mistake in our report.

Anon!: There were none principal.
Goodbye!: There were no principals.

Anon!: Thy wit is a very bitter sweeting.
Goodbye!: Your wit is a very bitter sweetener.

Anon!: Or, if you borrow one another’s love for the instant, you may, when you hear no more words of Pompey, return it again.
Goodbye!: Or, if you borrow one another’s love for the moment, you can return it again when you don’t hear any more about Pompey.

Anon!: Let not my worser spirit tempt me again To die before you please.
Goodbye!: Don’t let my worse spirit tempt me to die again before you please.

Anon!: Is thy union here?
Goodbye!: Is your union here?

Anon!: That’s a question.
Goodbye!: That’s a question.

Anon!: Gloucester, ’tis true that we are in great danger.
Goodbye!: Gloucester, it’s true that we’re in great danger.

Anon!: We did keep time, sir, in our catches.
Goodbye!: We kept our time, sir, in our catches.

Anon!: Marry, and did.
Goodbye!: Well, and I did.

Anon!: I am mightily abused.
Goodbye!: I’m abused.

Anon!: Briefly, sir.
Goodbye!: I’m talking a bit.

Anon!: O ill-starred wench, Pale as thy smock!
Goodbye!: Oh, ill-starred wench, pale as your smock!

Anon!: What should he be?
Goodbye!: What should he be?

Anon!: That we should, with joy, pleasance revel and applause, transform ourselves into beasts!
Goodbye!: We should, with joy, joy, and applause, transform ourselves into beasts!

Anon!: Why, Gloucester, Gloucester, I’d speak with the Duke of Cornwall and his wife.
Goodbye!: Gloucester, Gloucester, I’d like to speak with the Duke of Cornwall and his wife.

Anon!: Your Dane, your German, and your swag-bellied Hollander—Drink, ho!—are nothing to your English.
Goodbye!: Your Dane, your German, and your swag-bellied Hollander—Drink, ho!—are nothing to your English.

Anon!: To horse, you gallant princes, straight to horse.
Goodbye!: You gallant princes, you’re right to horse.

Anon!: I will be near to second your attempt, and he shall fall between us.
Goodbye!: I’ll be near to second your attempt, and he’ll fall between us.

Anon!: They have made worms' meat of me.
Goodbye!: They’ve made me worms' meat.

Anon!: Indeed, I should have asked thee that before.
Goodbye!: I wish I had asked you before.

Anon!: Do not answer me.
Goodbye!: Don’t answer me.

Anon!: Why, what else?
Goodbye!: What else?

Anon!: Here in these confines slyly have I lurked To watch the waning of mine enemies.
Goodbye!: I’ve lurked here in these confines to watch the waning of my enemies.

Anon!: Here’s our own hands against our hearts.
Goodbye!: Here’s our own hands against our hearts.

Anon!: So I am free.
Goodbye!: So I’m free.

Anon!: This is open.
Goodbye!: This is open.

Anon!: Flat burglary as ever was committed.
Goodbye!: The burglary was as flat as ever.

Anon!: Oh, the world hath not a sweeter creature, she might lie by an emperor’s side and command him tasks.
Goodbye!: Oh, the world doesn’t have a sweeter creature, she might lie by the side of an emperor and command him to do his job.

Anon!: Need and oppression starveth in thine eyes.
Goodbye!: You’re starving in your eyes.

Anon!: Susan and she—God rest all Christian souls!— Were of an age.
Goodbye!: Susan and she—God rest all Christian souls—were born in an age.

Anon!: For what, I pray thee?
Goodbye!: What, please?

Anon!: Get you all three into the boxtree.
Goodbye!: Get all three of you in the boxtree.

Anon!: And, good night, sweet friend.
Goodbye!: Good night, my sweet friend.

Anon!: I have known when there was no music with him but the drum and the fife, and now had he rather hear the tabor and the pipe.
Goodbye!: I’ve known when he had no music with him except the drum and the fife, and now he’d rather hear the pipe and the tabor.

Anon!: Shall I vent to her that thou art coming?
Goodbye!: Should I tell her that you’re coming?

Anon!: O life!
Goodbye!: Oh life!

Anon!: Demand.
Goodbye!: Demand.

Anon!: And we’ll wear out In a walled prison packs and sects of great ones That ebb and flow by the moon.
Goodbye!: And we’ll wear out in a walled prison of great ones that ebb and flow by the moon.

Anon!: Thou sayest his sports were hinderd by thy brawls.
Goodbye!: You say your fights hindered his sports.

Anon!: Why, we are still handling our ewes, and their fells, you know, are greasy.
Goodbye!: We’re still sane about our ewes, and their fells, you know, are greasy.

Anon!: Thy evil spirit, Brutus.
Goodbye!: Your evil spirit, Brutus.

Anon!: But the rarity of it is—which is indeed almost beyond credit—  As many vouched rarities are.
Goodbye!: But the rarity of it is—which is certainly beyond credit—as many rarities are.

Anon!: They cannot budge till your release.
Goodbye!: They can’t budge until you release them.

Anon!: Ay, amen!
Goodbye!: Yes, amen!

Anon!: Yes, madam.
Goodbye!: Yes, madam.

Anon!: No, not till a hot January.
Goodbye!: No, not until a hot January.

Anon!: I can say little more than I have studied, and that question’s out of my part.
Goodbye!: I can say nothing more than I’ve studied, and that’s out of my mind.

Anon!: He wore his beaver up.
Goodbye!: He wore his beaver up.

Anon!: Metellus Cimber?
Goodbye!: Metellus Cimber?

Anon!: Let me alone.
Goodbye!: Let me go.

Anon!: Your lips will feel them the sooner.
Goodbye!: Your lips will feel them the sooner.

Anon!: Stay, then.
Goodbye!: Wait, then.

Anon!: I will come again.
Goodbye!: I’ll come back.

Anon!: Here’s drink.
Goodbye!: Here’s a drink.

Anon!: Am not I your Rosalind?
Goodbye!: Amn’t I your Rosalind?

Anon!: I shaked you, sir, and cried.
Goodbye!: I shaked you, sir, and cried.

Anon!: Well, honor is the subject of my story.
Goodbye!: Well, honor is the subject of my story.

Anon!: Mark me.
Goodbye!: Mark me.

Anon!: I am afraid this great lubber, the world, will prove a cockney.
Goodbye!: I’m afraid this great lubber, the world, will be a cockney.

Anon!: And your horse now would make him an ass.
Goodbye!: And now your horse would make him an ass.

Anon!: Peace, you were best.
Goodbye!: You were the best.

Anon!: I have some business.
Goodbye!: I have some business.

Anon!: Even so.
Goodbye!: That’s true.

Anon!: Go, girl, seek happy nights to happy days.
Goodbye!: Go, girl, look for happy nights to happy days.

Anon!: And so fare thee well.
Goodbye!: And so farewell.

Anon!: My sword is drawn.
Goodbye!: My sword is drawn.

Anon!: Ay, my lord.
Goodbye!: Yes, my lord.

Anon!: We have not spoke us yet of torchbearers.
Goodbye!: We haven’t spoken to anyone about torchbearers yet.

Anon!: Sir, no.
Goodbye!: No, sir.

Anon!: Well praised!
Goodbye!: Well praised!

Anon!: I am so lated in the world that I Have lost my way forever.
Goodbye!: I’m so late in the world that I’ve lost my way forever.

Anon!: Farewell!
Goodbye!: Goodbye!

Anon!: No words can that woe sound.
Goodbye!: No words can sound like that.

Anon!: Be brief, lest that the process of thy kindness Last longer telling than thy kindness' date.
Goodbye!: Be brief, so that your kindness will last longer than your kindness date.

Anon!: Fear not, Cesario.
Goodbye!: Don’t worry, Cesario.

Anon!: Not I, sir.
Goodbye!: Not me, sir.

Anon!: Will Caesar speak?
Goodbye!: Will Caesar speak?

Anon!: Oh, then, I see Queen Mab hath been with you.
Goodbye!: Oh, then, I see that Queen Mab has been with you.

Anon!: Though it be honest, it is never good To bring bad news.
Goodbye!: Even if it’s honest, it’s never good to bring bad news.

Anon!: You may think perchance that I think you are in love.
Goodbye!: You may think I’m in love with you.

Anon!: What you have spoke, it may be so perchance.
Goodbye!: What you’ve said may be so perchanceous.

Anon!: O masters, if I were disposed to stir Your hearts and minds to mutiny and rage, I should do Brutus wrong, and Cassius wrong— Who, you all know, are honorable men.
Goodbye!: Oh, masters, if I were willing to stir your hearts and minds to mutiny and rage, I would do Brutus wrong, and Cassius wrong—who, you all know, are honorable men

Anon!: Is ’t good or bad?
Goodbye!: Is it good or bad?

Anon!: Tis well thou art not fish.
Goodbye!: It’s good you’re not a fisherman.

Anon!: Take no note of him.
Goodbye!: Don’t take any notice of him.

Anon!: Doth thy other mouth call me?
Goodbye!: Do you hear your other mouth call me?

Anon!: Had he his hurts before?
Goodbye!: Had he suffered his injuries before?

Anon!: Am not I Christopher Sly, old Sly’s son of Burton Heath, by birth a peddler, by education a cardmaker, by transmutation a bearherd, and now by present profession a tinker?
Goodbye!: I’m Christopher Sly, old Sly’s son of Burton Heath, by birth a peddler, by education a cardmaker, by transmutation a bearherd, and now by profession a

Anon!: Hark!
Goodbye!: Listen!

Anon!: Why, this is evident to any formal capacity.
Goodbye!: Well, this is evident to any formal capacity.

Anon!: Antonio never yet was thief or pirate, Though, I confess, on base and ground enough, Orsino’s enemy.
Goodbye!: Antonio never was a thief or a pirate, though, I confess, on ground and ground enough, Orsino’s enemy.

Anon!: But did’st thou see them dead?
Goodbye!: But did you see them dead?

Anon!: He hath slept long.
Goodbye!: He’s slept long.

Anon!: Though news be sad, yet tell them merrily.
Goodbye!: Even though news is sad, tell them merrily.

Anon!: Tide life, tide death, I come without delay.
Goodbye!: I’ll come immediately, and I’ll kill you.

Anon!: They are sick?
Goodbye!: They’re sick?

Anon!: Kate like the hazel-twig Is straight and slender and as brown in hue As hazel nuts, and sweeter than the kernels.
Goodbye!: Kate likes the hazel-twig, straight and slender, and brown as hazelnuts, and sweeter than the kernels.

Anon!: Nay then, I’ll run.
Goodbye!: No, then, I’ll run.

Anon!: Well then, sustain me.
Goodbye!: Well then, keep me alive.

Anon!: The laws are mine, not thine.
Goodbye!: The laws are mine, not yours.

Anon!: Not I, believe me.
Goodbye!: Not me, believe me.

Anon!: Well, I will thither.
Goodbye!: Well, I’ll go.

Anon!: Hush, Thou think’st there is no more such shapes as he, Having seen but him and Caliban.
Goodbye!: You think there are no more shapes like him, despite seeing him and Caliban.

Anon!: Nurse, commend me to thy lady and mistress.
Goodbye!: Nurse, please give my praise to your lady and mistress.

Anon!: Here comes my noble gull-catcher.
Goodbye!: Here comes my noble gull-catcher.

Anon!: And buried, gentle Tyrrel?
Goodbye!: And buried, gentle Tyrrel?

Anon!: Within the infant rind of this small flower Poison hath residence and medicine power.
Goodbye!: The small flower is ripe and has medicinal power.

Anon!: There is tears for his love, joy for his fortune, honor for his valor, and death for his ambition.
Goodbye!: There are tears for his love, joy for his fortune, honor for his valor, and death for his ambition.

Anon!: Go to my chamber, put on clothes of mine.
Goodbye!: Go to my room and put on my clothes.

Anon!: May not one speak?
Goodbye!: Can’t one speak?

Anon!: And hath given countenance to his speech, my lord, With almost all the holy vows of heaven.
Goodbye!: And he has given up his speech with almost all the holy vows of heaven.

Anon!: If thou entertainest my love, let it appear in thy smiling.
Goodbye!: If you entertain my love, let it appear in your smiling face.

Anon!: No, as I am a Christian.
Goodbye!: No, as I am a Christian.

Anon!: I have Immortal longings in me.
Goodbye!: I have immortal longings in me.

Anon!: The tyrannous and bloody act is done, The most arch deed of piteous massacre That ever yet this land was guilty of.
Goodbye!: The tyrannous and bloody act is done, the most cruel massacre this country has ever committed.

Anon!: Methinks the ground is even.
Goodbye!: I think the ground is even.

Anon!: You are a lover.
Goodbye!: You’re a lover.

Anon!: Thieves!
Goodbye!: Thieves!

Anon!: The fault of it I’ll answer.
Goodbye!: I’ll answer the question.

Anon!: That’s her torment.
Goodbye!: That’s her torment.

Anon!: Thou, my slave, As thou report’st thyself, wast then her servant.
Goodbye!: You, my slave, was her servant when you reported yourself.

Anon!: Teach me.
Goodbye!: Tell me.

Anon!: I think he only loves the world for him.
Goodbye!: I think he loves the world only for him.

Anon!: O good Antonio, forgive me your trouble.
Goodbye!: Oh, Antonio, forgive me for your trouble.

Anon!: And you, fair sister.
Goodbye!: And you, fair sister.

Anon!: Who shall begin?
Goodbye!: Who should start?

Anon!: Didst thou see any thing?
Goodbye!: Did you see anything?

Anon!: Good my lord, give me thy favor still.
Goodbye!: Please, my lord, give me your favor.

Anon!: Have you done yet?
Goodbye!: Have you done something yet?

Anon!: Let her have your voice.
Goodbye!: Let her have your voice.

Anon!: Well shone, Moon!—Truly, the moon shines with a good grace.
Goodbye!: Well, moon!—Truly, the moon shines with a good grace.

Anon!: Therefore love moderately.
Goodbye!: So love it moderately.

Anon!: Bid them come near.
Goodbye!: Tell them to come near.

Anon!: I’ll pay thy pleasure then.
Goodbye!: I’ll pay you for it then.

Anon!: Thou shall present me as an eunuch to him.
Goodbye!: You’ll give him an eunuch to me.

Anon!: I prithee now, lead the way without any more talking.— Trinculo, the king and all our company else being drowned, we will inherit here.—Here, bear my bottle.—Fellow Trinculo, we’ll fill him by and by again.
Goodbye!: I urge you to lead the way without any more talking.—Trinculo, the king and all our other friends being drowned, we’ll inherit here.—Here, bear my bottle.—Trincul

Anon!: I will be hanged, if some eternal villain, Some busy and insinuating rogue, Some cogging, cozening slave, to get some office, Have not devised this slander.
Goodbye!: I’ll be hanged if some evil villain, some rogue, some cogging, a cozening slave, haven’t devised this slander.

Anon!: First, Pyramus must draw a sword to kill himself, which the ladies cannot abide.
Goodbye!: First, Pyramus must draw a sword to kill himself, which the ladies can’t follow.

Anon!: Say, my spirit, How fares the king and ’s followers?
Goodbye!: My spirit, how are the king and his followers doing?

Anon!: Hugh Capet also, who usurped the crown Of Charles the duke of Lorraine, sole heir male Of the true line and stock of Charles the Great, To find his title with some shows of truth, Though in pure truth it was corrupt and naught, Conveyed himself as th' heir to th' Lady Lingare, Daughter to Charlemagne, who was the son To Lewis the Emperor, and Lewis the son Of Charles the Great.
Goodbye!: Hugh Capet, who inherited the crown of Charles the duke of Lorraine, the sole heir of Charles the Great, was able to find his title with some proof of truth, even though it was corrupt and naught

Anon!: Our instruments to melancholy bells, Our wedding cheer to a sad burial feast.
Goodbye!: Our wedding cheers for a sad burial feast.

Anon!: Confirmed, confirmed!
Goodbye!: Confirmed, confirmed!

Anon!: Trust not to rotten planks.
Goodbye!: Don’t trust rotten planks.

Anon!: Faith, e'en with losing his wits.
Goodbye!: Yes, he’s losing his wits.

Anon!: Pleaseth you walk with me down to his house, I will discharge my bond and thank you too.
Goodbye!: Please walk with me down to his house, I’ll pay my debt and thank you too.

Anon!: I doubt not of your wisdom.
Goodbye!: I don’t doubt your wisdom.

Anon!: The wood of Birnam.
Goodbye!: The woods of Birnam.

Anon!: Now go thy way.
Goodbye!: Now go on your way.

Anon!: You rub the sore When you should bring the plaster.
Goodbye!: You rub the sore when you should bring the plaster.

Anon!: Tis certain he hath passed the river Somme.
Goodbye!: He’s sure he’s passed the river Somme.

Anon!: Cried he?
Goodbye!: He’s been killed?

Anon!: He taught me how to know a man in love, in which cage of rushes I am sure you are not prisoner.
Goodbye!: He taught me how to know a man in love, in which you’re not a prisoner.

Anon!: Go, you cot-quean, go.
Goodbye!: Go, you cot-quean, go.

Anon!: You are resolute, then?
Goodbye!: You’re resolute, then?

Anon!: O come, Ventidius.
Goodbye!: Oh, come, Ventidius.

Anon!: This is a stem Of that victorious stock, and let us fear The native mightiness and fate of him.
Goodbye!: This is a stem from that victorious stock, and let’s fear the native mightiness and fate of him.

Anon!: These tidings will well comfort Cassius.
Goodbye!: These tidings will comfort Cassius.

Anon!: Strike, drum.
Goodbye!: Beat the drum.

Anon!: Do so.
Goodbye!: Do so.

Anon!: Now shall you see the other.
Goodbye!: Now you’ll see the other.

Anon!: So is the fame.
Goodbye!: That’s what I’m calling fame.

Anon!: Let me go.
Goodbye!: Let me go.

Anon!: Wilt thou show the whole wealth of thy wit in an instant?
Goodbye!: Do you want to show your wits in a moment?

Anon!: My dismal scene I needs must act alone.
Goodbye!: I have to act alone in my terrible situation.

Anon!: I would do much T' atone them, for the love I bear to Cassio.
Goodbye!: I’d do much to help them, because I love Cassio.

Anon!: Lord, what though?
Goodbye!: Lord, what?

Anon!: O dolt!
Goodbye!: Oh, you dolt!

Anon!: Need you my help?
Goodbye!: Do you need my help?

Anon!: I your servant.
Goodbye!: I your servant.

Anon!: By my troth, it is well said.
Goodbye!: I swear, it’s well said.

Anon!: An please your Worship, Brakenbury, You may partake of anything we say.
Goodbye!: Please, Brakenbury, you can take care of anything we say.

Anon!: And let us do it with no show of fear, No, with no more than if we heard that England Were busied with a Whitsun morris-dance.
Goodbye!: And let’s do it without any fear, no, with no more than if we heard that England was busied with a Whitsun morris-dance.

Anon!: Brought you Caesar home?
Goodbye!: Have you brought Caesar home?

Anon!: Come, you deceive yourself.
Goodbye!: Come on, you’re fooling yourself.

Anon!: Now is it time to arm.
Goodbye!: Now it’s time to arm.

Anon!: None that I know will be; much that I fear may chance.
Goodbye!: I know nothing about it, but I’m afraid it will happen.

Anon!: Therefore should every soldier in the wars do as every sick man in his bed: wash every mote out of his conscience.
Goodbye!: So every soldier in the war should do as every sick man in his bed should: wash every sneeze out of his conscience.

Anon!: Observe his construction of it.
Goodbye!: Watch his work.

Anon!: I thank thee for thy care and honest pains.
Goodbye!: Thank you for your patience and your honest pains.

Anon!: Very well,” “go to”!
Goodbye!: Very well,” “go to”!

Anon!: They follow the king’s pleasure.
Goodbye!: They follow the king’s wishes.

Anon!: Put them to motion.
Goodbye!: Put them to motion.

Anon!: Hear a little further And then I’ll bring thee to the present business Which now ’s upon ’s, without the which this story Were most impertinent.
Goodbye!: Listen a little further and then I’ll bring you to the business that’s now on the rise, without the ones that this story would be most impertinent.

Anon!: Yet I cannot choose but laugh To think it should leave crying and say “ay.” And yet, I warrant, it had upon its brow A bump as big as a young cockerel’s stone, A perilous knock, and it cried bitterly.
Goodbye!: But I can’t help laughing to think it should leave crying and say “yes.” And yet, I’m sure it had a bump on its forehead as big as a young cockerel’s stone, a

Anon!: But we are spirits of another sort.
Goodbye!: But we’re spirits of another kind.

Anon!: What a blunt fellow is this grown to be!
Goodbye!: What a blunt man this man has grown to be!

Anon!: Let me shun that.
Goodbye!: Let me stop that.

Anon!: Ay, marry, are they, sir.
Goodbye!: Yes, they are, sir.

Anon!: Oh, ay.
Goodbye!: Oh, yes.

Anon!: Now counterfeit to swoon, why, now fall down; Or if thou canst not, Oh, for shame, for shame, Lie not, to say mine eyes are murderers.
