Goodbye!: Now, if you can’t, Oh, for shame, for shame, don’t lie, to say my eyes are murderers.

Anon!: You stand amazed, But be of comfort.
Goodbye!: You’re amazed, but be comforting.

Anon!: Where hast thou sent the king?
Goodbye!: Where have you sent the king?

Anon!: Get thee to bed.
Goodbye!: Go to bed.

Anon!: Shine out, fair sun, till I have bought a glass, That I may see my shadow as I pass.
Goodbye!: Shine out, fair sun, until I’ve bought a glass, so I can see my shadow as I pass.

Anon!: Bear me forthwith unto his creditor, And, knowing how the debt grows, I will pay it.— Good Master Doctor, see him safe conveyed Home to my house.
Goodbye!: Take me to his creditor and, knowing how the debt grows, I’ll pay it.—Good Master Doctor, take him home safely to my house.

Anon!: And when I have stol'n upon these sons-in-law, Then, kill, kill, kill, kill, kill, kill!
Goodbye!: And when I’m stolping on these sons-in-law, kill, kill, kill, kill, kill, kill!

Anon!: Oh, my pardon!
Goodbye!: Oh, my pardon!

Anon!: Come, go we to the king.
Goodbye!: Come on, we’ll go to the king.

Anon!: My words would bandy her to my sweet love, And his to me.
Goodbye!: My words would give her my sweet love, and his words would give her my sweet love.

Anon!: Why, madam, if I were your father’s dog, You should not use me so.
Goodbye!: If I were your father’s dog, you wouldn’t use me like that.

Anon!: Ride thou unto the horsemen on yond hill.
Goodbye!: Ride to the horsemen on another hill.

Anon!: Caesar, thy thoughts Touch their effects in this.
Goodbye!: Caesar, your thoughts are affecting this.

Anon!: If you swear, my lord, you shall not be forsworn.
Goodbye!: If you swear, my lord, you won’t be swore.

Anon!: If any, speak—for him have I offended.
Goodbye!: If there are any, speak—for he has offended me.

Anon!: When you shall please to play the thieves for wives, I’ll watch as long for you then.
Goodbye!: When you want to play the thieves for wives, I’ll watch as long as you want.

Anon!: Whether he was combined With those of Norway, or did line the rebel With hidden help and vantage, or that with both He labored in his country’s wrack, I know not; But treasons capital, confessed and proved, Have overthrown him.
Goodbye!: I don’t know whether he was a king of Norway or a rebel of Norway, or that he fought both sides in the wrack of his country, I don’t know.

Anon!: It would be spoke to.
Goodbye!: It would be a question.

Anon!: A sleeve?
Goodbye!: A sleeve?

Anon!: Sirrah young gamester, your father were a fool To give thee all and in his waning age Set foot under thy table.
Goodbye!: Sirrah young gamester, your father was a fool to give you everything and in his waning age set foot under your table.

Anon!: And yet I wish but for the thing I have.
Goodbye!: And yet I only wish for what I have.

Anon!: Besides, the knave is handsome, young, and hath all those requisites in him that folly and green minds look after.
Goodbye!: Besides, the knave is handsome, young, and has all the requisites in him that folly and green minds are responsible for.

Anon!: That’s two of his weapons.
Goodbye!: That’s two of his weapons.

Anon!: Would you praise Caesar, say “Caesar.” Go no further.
Goodbye!: You would praise Caesar, say “Caesar.” Don’t go any further.

Anon!: Tis Banquo’s then.
Goodbye!: That’s Banquo’s then.

Anon!: Welcome, Signior.
Goodbye!: Welcome, Signior.

Anon!: Ay, my lord.
Goodbye!: Yes, my lord.

Anon!: The tempest in my mind Doth from my senses take all feeling else Save what beats there—filial ingratitude.
Goodbye!: The tempest in my mind is to take all the other feeling except what’s going on—ingratitude.

Anon!: Not I, unless the breath of heartsick groans, Mistlike, infold me from the search of eyes.
Goodbye!: I won’t, unless the groans’ breath is a mist that screams me away from the search of eyes.

Anon!: And only in that safety died her brothers.
Goodbye!: And only in that safe way died her brothers.

Anon!: I would to God all strifes were well compounded.
Goodbye!: I wish all the fights were well resolved.

Anon!: If her breath were as terrible as her terminations, there were no living near her; she would infect to the north star.
Goodbye!: If her breath were as terrible as her snoring, there would be no living near her; she would infect the north star.

Anon!: Very easily possible.
Goodbye!: It’s very easy.

Anon!: Arise.
Goodbye!: Get up.

Anon!: Your servants ever Have theirs, themselves, and what is theirs in compt, To make their audit at your highness' pleasure, Still to return your own.
Goodbye!: Your servants have their own, and what they have in their hands, to make their own decisions at your highness's expense, and to return your own.

Anon!: Gentlemen, rise.
Goodbye!: Gentlemen, rise up.

Anon!: Amaze the welkin with your broken staves—
Goodbye!: Amaze the welkin with your broken staves—

Anon!: Go off, I discard you.
Goodbye!: Go off, I’ll take you away.

Anon!: In practice let us put it presently.
Goodbye!: Let’s put it in practice now.

Anon!: All schooldays' friendship, childhood innocence?
Goodbye!: Friendship of schooldays, innocence of childhood?

Anon!: Tie up the libertine in a field of feasts, Keep his brain fuming.
Goodbye!: Put the libertine in a field of feasts, keep his brain snoring.

Anon!: Know of your youth.
Goodbye!: Know about your youth.

Anon!: My remedy is then to pluck it out.
Goodbye!: I’ll throw it out.

Anon!: Oh, if it prove, Tempests are kind and salt waves fresh in love!
Goodbye!: Oh, if it turns out, the tastiest tastiest safts are kind and love is fresh!

Anon!: He’ll never yield to that.
Goodbye!: He’ll never give up on that.

Anon!: I tell you, ’twill sound harshly in her ears.
Goodbye!: I tell you, it’ll sound harshly in her ears.

Anon!: Rest you merry!
Goodbye!: Have a good day!

Anon!: I but believe it partly, For I am fresh of spirit and resolved To meet all perils very constantly.
Goodbye!: I’m not sure, because I’m very happy and determined to face all dangers very quickly.

Anon!: My lady is within, sir.
Goodbye!: My lady is inside, sir.

Anon!: Why, there, there, there, there!
Goodbye!: Oh, there, there, there, there!

Anon!: How art thou out of breath when thou hast breath To say to me that thou art out of breath?
Goodbye!: How are you out of breath when you have breath to tell me that you’re out of breath?

Anon!: He speaks well.
Goodbye!: He’s very good.

Anon!: Shylock, albeit I neither lend nor borrow By taking nor by giving of excess, Yet to supply the ripe wants of my friend, I’ll break a custom.
Goodbye!: Shylock, even if I don’t lend or borrow by taking or giving out excess, I’ll break a custom to give my friend the ripe wishes.

Anon!: Yours in the ranks of death.
Goodbye!: You’re in the ranks of death.

Anon!: I have seen nothing.
Goodbye!: I haven’t seen anything.

Anon!: Tarry a little.
Goodbye!: Be quiet.

Anon!: Sound them, it doth become the mouth as well.
Goodbye!: Sound them, it’s becoming the mouth as well.

Anon!: No, I protest, I know not the contents.
Goodbye!: No, I swear, I don’t know what’s going on.

Anon!: I will so.
Goodbye!: I will.

Anon!: Such a one Am I to fear, or none.
Goodbye!: I’m afraid of such a person, or I’m not afraid of it.

Anon!: Thou'rt i' the right.
Goodbye!: You’re right.

Anon!: The count himself here hard by woos her.
Goodbye!: The count himself is wooing her.

Anon!: Good love, call him back.
Goodbye!: Good love, call him back.

Anon!: Speak yet again.
Goodbye!: Speak again.

Anon!: Most certain.
Goodbye!: Yes, I’m sure.

Anon!: I must believe my master; else, I promise you, I should be arguing still upon that doubt.
Goodbye!: I must believe my master, but I promise you, I’ll be arguing on that.

Anon!: God and our good cause fight upon our side.
Goodbye!: God and our good cause fight on our side.

Anon!: Search, seek, and know how this foul murder comes.
Goodbye!: Search, search, and know how this horrible murder comes about.

Anon!: On, lusty gentlemen.
Goodbye!: On, lusty gentlemen.

Anon!: Most constantly.
Goodbye!: Every single day.

Anon!: Sir, I shall study deserving.
Goodbye!: Sir, I’ll do something worthy of studying.

Anon!: The gain I seek is quiet in the match.
Goodbye!: I’m looking for a win in the match.

Anon!: O Caesar!
Goodbye!: Oh, Caesar!

Anon!: There rust and let me die.
Goodbye!: There’s rust and let me die.

Anon!: Oh, excellent!
Goodbye!: Oh, excellent!

Anon!: But how long fairly shall her sweet life last?
Goodbye!: But how long will her sweet life last?

Anon!: My lord!
Goodbye!: My lord!

Anon!: I say gudday, Captain Fluellen.
Goodbye!: I say gudday, Captain Fluellen.

Anon!: Come on.
Goodbye!: Come on.

Anon!: There let him sink, and be the seas on him!
Goodbye!: Let him sink there and be the seas on him!

Anon!: Next, Cleopatra does confess thy greatness, Submits her to thy might, and of thee craves The circle of the Ptolemies for her heirs, Now hazarded to thy grace.
Goodbye!: Next, Cleopatra confesses your greatness, gives her your power, and asks the Ptolemies to give her heirs, now hazarded by your grace.

Anon!: Be your tears wet?
Goodbye!: Are your tears wet?

Anon!: Let’s not consort with them.
Goodbye!: Don’t go get them.

Anon!: Tis true, my lords, he did.
Goodbye!: It’s true, my lords, he did.

Anon!: What, man, courage yet!
Goodbye!: Oh, man, courage is still in place!

Anon!: Oh, what a world is this when what is comely Envenoms him that bears it!
Goodbye!: Oh, what a world this is when something strange has envested the man who bears it!

Anon!: The princes both make high account of you—  I know they do, and I have well deserved it.
Goodbye!: The princes both make good accounts of you— I know they do, and I’ve deserved it.

Anon!: Casca, be sudden, for we fear prevention —Brutus, what shall be done?
Goodbye!: Casca, be sudden, because we’re afraid of prevention.

Anon!: Go thou with me, and let me counsel thee.
Goodbye!: Go with me, and let me advise you.

Anon!: To be once in doubt Is to be resolved.
Goodbye!: I’ll be able to be sure I’m not sure.

Anon!: Francis Flute, the bellows-mender?
Goodbye!: Francis Flute, the bellows-mender?

Anon!: The wren goes to ’t, and the small gilded fly does lecher in my sight.
Goodbye!: The wren goes to it, and the small gilded fly is a lecher in my sight.

Anon!: Most mischievous foul sin in chiding sin, For thou thyself hast been a libertine, As sensual as the brutish sting itself, And all th' embossèd sores and headed evils That thou with license of free foot hast caught Wouldst thou disgorge into the general world.
Goodbye!: You’re a libertine, as sensual as the sting itself, and all your savages and headed evils that you’ve caught would disgorge into the general world.

Anon!: To answer that, I should confess to you.
Goodbye!: To answer that question, I’d confess to you.

Anon!: I’ll call upon you ere you go to bed And tell you what I know.
Goodbye!: I’ll call you before you go to bed and tell you what I know.

Anon!: Thou must not take my former sharpness ill.
Goodbye!: You shouldn’t take my sharpness off.

Anon!: For if the Jew do cut but deep enough, I’ll pay it presently with all my heart.
Goodbye!: If the Jew cuts deep enough, I’ll pay it now with all my heart.

Anon!: Draw, you rogue, for though it be night yet the moon shines.
Goodbye!: Draw your sword, because even if it’s night yet the moon shines.

Anon!: He’s coming hither—now, i' th' night, i' th' haste, And Regan with him.
Goodbye!: He’s coming here—now, i’m in the rush, and Regan’s with him.

Anon!: Sir, my good friend, I’ll change that name with you.
Goodbye!: Sir, my good friend, I’ll change that name with you.

Anon!: Neglected, rather, And then when poisoned hours had bound me up From mine own knowledge.
Goodbye!: I was poisoned, rather, and then I was deprived of my own knowledge.

Anon!: O sun, thy uprise shall I see no more.
Goodbye!: Oh, sun, I won’t see any more.

Anon!: My fool usurps my body.
Goodbye!: My fool sourps my body.

Anon!: If he, compact of jars, grow musical, We shall have shortly discord in the spheres.
Goodbye!: If he’s a musical genius, we’ll have a few sexy things to do.

Anon!: Tis from your sister.
Goodbye!: It’s your sister.

Anon!: Comfort me.
Goodbye!: Be calm.

Anon!: Good heaven, the souls of all my tribe defend From jealousy!
Goodbye!: Good heaven, the souls of my tribe are protecting themselves from jealousy!

Anon!: Tis but thy name that is my enemy.
Goodbye!: It’s only your name that is my enemy.

Anon!: Why, what an ass am I!
Goodbye!: What an ass I am!

Anon!: Give me thy hand.
Goodbye!: Give me your hand.

Anon!: Now your jest is earnest.
Goodbye!: Now you’re in a good mood.

Anon!: Nay, we will all of us be there to fetch him.
Goodbye!: No, we’ll all be there to fetch him.

Anon!: Did you not speak to it?
Goodbye!: Didn’t you speak to it?

Anon!: If he be perjured, see you now, his reputation is as arrant a villain and a Jack Sauce as ever his black shoe trod upon God’s ground and His earth, in my conscience, la.
Goodbye!: If he’s been perjured, see now, his reputation is as arrant as a villain and a Jack Sauce as ever, he’s thrown on God’s ground and earth, in my conscience

Anon!: She will be pleased.
Goodbye!: She’ll be happy.

Anon!: What news more?
Goodbye!: What news do you have more?

Anon!: I’ll have this knot knit up tomorrow morning.
Goodbye!: I’ll have this knot knit up tomorrow morning.

Anon!: So bless thee, master.
Goodbye!: Well, please, master.

Anon!: And I am sick when I look not on you.
Goodbye!: And I’m sick when I don’t look at you.

Anon!: What’s Antony?
Goodbye!: What’s Antony?

Anon!: What says Lord Stanley?
Goodbye!: What does Lord Stanley say?

Anon!: Come hither, neighbor Seacole.
Goodbye!: Come here, Seacole.

Anon!: His excellence did earn it, ere he had it.
Goodbye!: He did, if he had it.

Anon!: We are sent To give thee from our royal master thanks, Only to herald thee into his sight, Not pay thee.
Goodbye!: We’re sent to give you a thank you from our royal master, only to show you his vision, and not pay you.

Anon!: I have watched ere now All night for lesser cause, and ne'er been sick.
Goodbye!: I’ve been watching a lot all night for a lesser reason, and I’ve never been sick.

Anon!: My old friend Grumio and my good friend Petruchio?
Goodbye!: My old friend Grumio and my good friend Petruchio?

Anon!: So is mine.—Do you hear, monster?
Goodbye!: So is mine.—Do you hear, monster?

Anon!: What is the matter?
Goodbye!: What’s the matter?

Anon!: Is not this Stephano, my drunken butler?
Goodbye!: Isn’t Stephano, my drunken butler?

Anon!: Oh ho, are you there with me?
Goodbye!: Oh ho, are you with me?

Anon!: The sight is dismal, And our affairs from England come too late.
Goodbye!: The sight is dismal, and our affairs from England come too late.

Anon!: So please you, he is here at the door and importunes access to you.
Goodbye!: Please, he’s here at the door and has access to you.

Anon!: And yon tall anchoring bark,
Goodbye!: And a tall barking

Anon!: There is no fear in him.
Goodbye!: He’s not afraid.

Anon!: This is the air, that is the glorious sun.
Goodbye!: This is the air, that’s the glorious sun.

Anon!: Where’s my cousin Toby?
Goodbye!: Where’s my cousin Toby?

Anon!: They’ll kill us.
Goodbye!: They’ll kill us.

Anon!: If there be any good thing to be done That may to thee do ease and grace to me, Speak to me.
Goodbye!: If there’s anything good to do that can help you, speak to me.

Anon!: Art thou so bare and full of wretchedness, And fear’st to die?
Goodbye!: Are you so wretched and wretched, and you’re afraid to die?

Anon!: Why, man?
Goodbye!: Why, man?

Anon!: He always loved our sister most, and with what poor judgment he hath now cast her off appears too grossly.
Goodbye!: He loved our sister most, and his judgment has now cast her off as a whole is too gross.

Anon!: What do you mean?
Goodbye!: What do you mean?

Anon!: I shall deliver so.
Goodbye!: I’ll deliver it.

Anon!: Would you not have me honest?
Goodbye!: Don’t you want me to be honest?

Anon!: By this, I think, the dial points at five.
Goodbye!: I think the dial is five.

Anon!: Ha, Portia?
Goodbye!: Ha, Portia?

Anon!: My husband?
Goodbye!: My husband?

Anon!: When all’s done, You look but on a stool.
Goodbye!: When everything’s done, you’ll only look on a stool.

Anon!: Make all the money thou canst.
Goodbye!: Make all the money you can.

Anon!: Is there division ’twixt my lord and Cassio?
Goodbye!: Is there a division between my lord and Cassio?

Anon!: All is lost!
Goodbye!: All is lost!

Anon!: Lo, where it comes again.
Goodbye!: Oh, here it comes again.

Anon!: Speak no more of him; you’ll be whipped for taxation one of these days.
Goodbye!: Don’t talk about him anymore, you’ll be whipped for taxation one of these days.

Anon!: Hast thou not a word of joy?
Goodbye!: Don’t you have a word of joy?

Anon!: For Oberon is passing fell and wrath Because that she, as her attendant hath A lovely boy stolen from an Indian king.
Goodbye!: For Oberon is falling and wrathing because she, as her attendant, has stolen a lovely boy from an Indian king.

Anon!: Marry, well said, very well said.
Goodbye!: Well said, well said.

Anon!: Hear you, my lords—     We have some haste, Leonato.
Goodbye!: Listen, my lords— We’re ready, Leonato.

Anon!: Lay thy finger thus, and let thy soul be instructed.
Goodbye!: Lay your finger on your finger and let your soul be instructed.

Anon!: I would entreat you rather to put on Your boldest suit of mirth, for we have friends That purpose merriment.
Goodbye!: I’d rather put on your boldest suit of sex, because we have friends who want to be a merriment.

Anon!: What’s the noise?
Goodbye!: What’s the noise?

Anon!: Help!
Goodbye!: Help!

Anon!: Well, Susan is with God.
Goodbye!: Well, Susan is with God.

Anon!: Foolish wench, To th' most of men this is a Caliban And they to him are angels.
Goodbye!: Foolish wench, to most of men this is a Caliban, and they to him are angels.

Anon!: Twill be heavier soon by the weight of a man.
Goodbye!: It’ll be heavier soon than a man’s weight.

Anon!: But sup them well and look unto them all.
Goodbye!: But suppose them well and look at them all.

Anon!: I’ll not fight with thee.
Goodbye!: I won’t fight with you.

Anon!: Come your ways.
Goodbye!: Come on.

Anon!: Didst thou not fall out with a tailor for wearing his new doublet before Easter?
Goodbye!: Didn’t you fall out with a tailor for wearing his new doublet before Easter?

Anon!: Keep peace, upon your lives.
Goodbye!: Keep your life peaceful.

Anon!: So our leader’s led, And we are women’s men.
Goodbye!: That’s the way our leader is, and we’re women’s men.

Anon!: Farewell, everyone.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, everyone.

Anon!: They are natural.” For I believe they are portentous things Unto the climate that they point upon.
Goodbye!: They’re natural.” I believe they’re a threat to the climate they’re pointing at.

Anon!: My love is thine to teach.
Goodbye!: I’m going to teach you my love.

Anon!: I must attend on Caesar.
Goodbye!: I’ll be there on Caesar.

Anon!: Make assay.
Goodbye!: Be sure to.

Anon!: Come, how wouldst thou praise me?
Goodbye!: Come on, how would you praise me?

Anon!: Hast thou no care of me?
Goodbye!: Don’t you care about me?

Anon!: Away with us to Athens.
Goodbye!: Take us to Athens.

Anon!: Look, sir, here comes the lady toward my cell.
Goodbye!: Look, sir, here comes the lady toward my cell.

Anon!: Look you, sad friends, The gods rebuke me, but it is tidings To wash the eyes of kings.
Goodbye!: Look, sad friends, the gods rebuke me, but it’s a good idea to wash the eyes of kings.

Anon!: O my lord, my lord, Forgive my fearful sails!
Goodbye!: Oh, my lord, my lord, forgive my fearful sails!

Anon!: O monstrous, monstrous!
Goodbye!: Oh, monstrous, monstrous!

Anon!: Need you my help?
Goodbye!: Do you need my help?

Anon!: And he did bid us follow to the temple.
Goodbye!: And he told us to go to the temple.

Anon!: Tears seven times salt, Burn out the sense and virtue of mine eye!
Goodbye!: Tears seven times salt, burn out the sense and virtue of my eye!

Anon!: Scape being drunk for want of wine.
Goodbye!: Scape being drunk for wanting to drink.

Anon!: There lies that Tybalt.
Goodbye!: Tybalt lies there.

Anon!: Death of one person can be paid but once, And that she has discharged.
Goodbye!: One person can only pay death once, and she has been paid.

Anon!: He cannot flatter, he.
Goodbye!: He can’t flatter himself, he says.

Anon!: This is the motley-minded gentleman that I have so often met in the forest.
Goodbye!: This is the sluggish gentleman I’ve met so often in the forest.

Anon!: Oh, woe the day!
Goodbye!: Oh, what a sad day!

Anon!: And maidens call it “love-in-idleness.” Fetch me that flower.
Goodbye!: And the kings call it “love-in-idleness.” Give me that flower.

Anon!: All other devils that suggest by treasons Do botch and bungle up damnation With patches, colors, and with forms being fetched From glist'ring semblances of piety.
Goodbye!: All other devils who suggest treason do botch and scold up damnation with patches, colors, and forms being fetched from glisting semblances of piety.

Anon!: I am sick and sullen.
Goodbye!: I’m sick and sullen.

Anon!: Lend me thy cloak, Sir Thomas.
Goodbye!: Lend me your cloak, Sir Thomas.

Anon!: Pray, set it down and rest you.
Goodbye!: Please put it down and rest.

Anon!: Praised be God, and not our strength, for it!
Goodbye!: Please be God, not our strength, for it!

Anon!: No, I warrant your Grace you shall not entreat him to a second, that have so mightily persuaded him from a first.
Goodbye!: No, I assure your Grace you won’t bet he’s going to be a second, who has so kindly persuaded him to be a second.

Anon!: Come, come, you are a fool, And turned into the extremity of love.
Goodbye!: Come on, you’re a fool, and you’ve turned it into the extreme love of love.

Anon!: The text is foolish.
Goodbye!: The text is foolish.

Anon!: But I am much to blame.
Goodbye!: But I’m a big blame.

Anon!: Well, the beginning that is dead and buried.
Goodbye!: Well, that’s the beginning that’s dead and buried.

Anon!: But manhood is melted into curtsies, valor into compliment, and men are only turned into tongue, and trim ones too.
Goodbye!: But manhood is melted into curtsies, valor is melted into compliments, and men are only turned into tongues, and trim ones too.

Anon!: Ay, and a subtle, as he most learnedly delivered.
Goodbye!: Yes, and he’s a subtle man, as he learned.

Anon!: Madam, yond young fellow swears he will speak with you.
Goodbye!: Madam, he’s swearing he’ll speak with you.

Anon!: I' faith, he’ll have a lusty widow now That shall be wooed and wedded in a day.
Goodbye!: I’m sure he’ll have a lusty widow who’ll be wooed and wedded in a day.

Anon!: No?
Goodbye!: No?

Anon!: Nor none that live, I hope.
Goodbye!: I hope there aren’t any people who live there.

Anon!: And I’ll still stay, to have thee still forget, Forgetting any other home but this.
Goodbye!: And I’ll stay, to have you forget, forgeing any other home except this.

Anon!: Bid her come hither.
Goodbye!: Tell her to come here.

Anon!: An unauthorized kiss!
Goodbye!: An illegal kiss!

Anon!: You take your pennyworths now.
Goodbye!: You’re taking your pennyworths now.

Anon!: I pray you all, stand up.
Goodbye!: Please, all, stand up.

Anon!: Come, tailor, let us see ’t.
Goodbye!: Come on, tailor, let’s see it.

Anon!: Everything is well.
Goodbye!: Everything is fine.

Anon!: We follow thee.—Juliet, the county stays.
Goodbye!: We follow you.—Juliet, the county is still alive.

Anon!: Dispute it like a man.
Goodbye!: Disput it like a man.

Anon!: But you must learn to know such slanders of the age, or else you may be marvelously mistook.
Goodbye!: But you have to learn to know such slanders of the age, or else you may be mistook.

Anon!: Tis pity of him.
Goodbye!: It’s pity for him.

Anon!: Long stayed he so.
Goodbye!: He’s been there for a long time.

Anon!: They mean this night in Sardis to be quartered.
Goodbye!: They want to be sane this night in Sardis.

Anon!: Make me a willow cabin at your gate And call upon my soul within the house.
Goodbye!: Make me a willow cabin at your gate and call upon my soul inside the house.

Anon!: Cleopatra Hath nodded him to her.
Goodbye!: Cleopatra has nodded him to her.

Anon!: Oh, thou art deceived.
Goodbye!: Oh, you’re wrong.

Anon!: Jove, I thank thee!
Goodbye!: Thank you, sir!

Anon!: Meet me and Gratiano At Gratiano’s lodging some hour hence.
Goodbye!: Meet me and Gratiano at Gratiano’s house in an hour.

Anon!: Ha!
Goodbye!: Ha!

Anon!: Good your highness, patience.
Goodbye!: Good your highness, patience.

Anon!: He is welcome hither.
Goodbye!: He’s welcome here.

Anon!: Suffer love!
Goodbye!: Suffer love!

Anon!: Alas, he is too young.
Goodbye!: Alas, he’s too young.

Anon!: They say there’s but five upon this isle.
Goodbye!: They say there’s only five on this island.

Anon!: Have not saints lips, and holy palmers too?
Goodbye!: Don’t saints have lips, and holy palmers too?

Anon!: I’ll send my prayers with him.
Goodbye!: I’ll send my prayers to him.

Anon!: What fool is this?
Goodbye!: What fool is this?

Anon!: But though they jump not on a just account— As in these cases, where the aim reports 'Tis oft with difference—yet do they all confirm A Turkish fleet, and bearing up to Cyprus.
Goodbye!: But even if they don’t jump on a just account—as in these cases, where the aim is often a little different—they all confirm a Turkish fleet, and carrying up to Cyprus.

Anon!: Most monstrous, oh!
Goodbye!: What a terrible thing, oh!

Anon!: Strives in his little world of man to outscorn The to-and-fro–conflicting wind and rain.
Goodbye!: He’s trying to outscorn the wind and rain that’s causing him to scold him.

Anon!: But for the handkerchief— By heaven, I would most gladly have forgot it.
Goodbye!: But for the handkerchief— I wish I had forgotten it.

Anon!: And can you by no drift of conference Get from him why he puts on this confusion, Grating so harshly all his days of quiet With turbulent and dangerous lunacy?
Goodbye!: And can you get out of him without a scolding of anger why he’s causing this confusion, grating so harshly all his quiet days with a scolding and dangerous lunacy

Anon!: But for which of my good parts did you first suffer love for me?
Goodbye!: But for which of my good things did you suffer love first for me?

Anon!: The sky, it seems, would pour down stinking pitch, But that the sea, mounting to th' welkin’s cheek, Dashes the fire out.
Goodbye!: The sky would pour down a stinking pitch, but the sea, soaring to the welkin’s cheek, dashes the fire out.

Anon!: That’s not so good.
Goodbye!: That’s not good.

Anon!: Be it so.
Goodbye!: Be it.

Anon!: Notwithstanding, use your pleasure.
Goodbye!: Regardless, use your pleasure.

Anon!: Yea, and I will weep a while longer.
Goodbye!: Yes, and I’ll cry for a while longer.

Anon!: I will carry no crotchets.
Goodbye!: I won’t carry any crotches.

Anon!: I’ll not answer that But say it is my humour.
Goodbye!: I’ll not answer that question, but I’ll say it’s my humour.

Anon!: You must to Parthia.
Goodbye!: You have to go to Parthia.

Anon!: I’ll have this knot knit up tomorrow morning.
Goodbye!: I’ll have this knot knit up tomorrow morning.

Anon!: Conceit in weakest bodies strongest works.
Goodbye!: Conceit the weakest bodies in the strongest works.

Anon!: O Tranio, till I found it to be true, I never thought it possible or likely.
Goodbye!: Oh Tranio, until I found it true, I never thought it possible or likely.

Anon!: Save you, gentleman.
Goodbye!: Save you, gentleman.

Anon!: I would not be the villain that thou think’st For the whole space that’s in the tyrant’s grasp, And the rich East to boot.
Goodbye!: I wouldn’t be the villain you think you’re a villain for the entire space that’s in the tyrant’s grasp, and the rich East to boot.

Anon!: Thou sing’st sweet music.
Goodbye!: You sing sweet music.

Anon!: Ay, good my lord.
Goodbye!: Yes, my lord.

Anon!: As ignorant as dirt!
Goodbye!: As ignorant as dirt!

Anon!: Never to speak of this that you have seen.
Goodbye!: Never to speak about what you’ve seen.

Anon!: Leonato and his brother.
Goodbye!: Leonato and his brother.

Anon!: Peace!
Goodbye!: Quiet!

Anon!: Nay, you were a fragment Of Gneius Pompey’s, besides what hotter hours, Unregistered in vulgar fame, you have Luxuriously picked out.
Goodbye!: No, you were a fragment of Gneius Pompey’s, and you’ve picked out the hotter hours, unregistered in vulgar fame.

Anon!: For I am sure, Though you can guess what temperance should be, You know not what it is.
Goodbye!: I’m sure you know what temperance should be, but you don’t know what temperance is.

Anon!: Ere he do leave this grove, Thou shalt fly him and he shall seek thy love.
Goodbye!: If he leaves this grove, you’ll fly him, and he’ll seek your love.

Anon!: When it is paid, bring your true friend along.
Goodbye!: When it’s paid, bring your true friend along.

Anon!: Fulvia thy wife is dead.
Goodbye!: Your wife Fulvia is dead.

Anon!: Thou hast a sister by the mother’s side, Admired Octavia.
Goodbye!: You have a sister by the mother’s side, Admired Octavia.

Anon!: Kind gentlemen, your pains Are registered where every day I turn The leaf to read them.
Goodbye!: Kind gentlemen, I’m going to read them every day.

Anon!: O noble lord, bethink thee of thy birth, Call home thy ancient thoughts from banishment, And banish hence these abject lowly dreams.
Goodbye!: Oh, noble lord, think about your birth, call home your ancient thoughts from banishment, and banish from leaving these lowly dreams.

Anon!: Hamlet, thou art slain.
Goodbye!: Hamlet, you’re dead.

Anon!: Hence, be gone, away!
Goodbye!: So go away!

Anon!: Perchance?
Goodbye!: Perchance?

Anon!: She hath spied him already with those sweet eyes.
Goodbye!: She’s spied him with those sweet eyes already.

Anon!: Slight, will you make an ass o' me?
Goodbye!: Is it a little a bit a bit a bit a bit a bit?

Anon!: Let still the woman take An elder than herself.
Goodbye!: Let the woman take an older woman than herself.

Anon!: A vengeance on your crafty withered hide!
Goodbye!: A vengeance on your crafty hide!

Anon!: Look to your house, your daughter, and your bags!
Goodbye!: Look at your house, your daughter, and your bags!

Anon!: No, madam, no.
Goodbye!: No, madam, no.

Anon!: I am sorry for my cousin.
Goodbye!: I’m sorry for my cousin.

Anon!: How?
Goodbye!: How?

Anon!: God grant him health.
Goodbye!: God give him health.

Anon!: Here comes two of the banished duke’s pages.
Goodbye!: Here comes two of the duke’s pages.

Anon!: She’s not well married that lives married long, But she’s best married that dies married young.
Goodbye!: She’s not well married, who lives married long, but she’s best married, who dies young.

Anon!: And for my means, I’ll husband them so well, They shall go far with little.
Goodbye!: And for my reason, I’ll eat them so well, they’ll go far with little.

Anon!: I anger her sometimes and tell her that Paris is the properer man.
Goodbye!: I anger her sometimes and tell her that Paris is the better man.

Anon!: Look, my lord, it comes!
Goodbye!: Look, my lord, it’s coming!

Anon!: Where wilt thou lead me?
Goodbye!: Where will you lead me?

Anon!: Why, so he doth, when he delivers you From this earth’s thralldom to the joys of heaven.
Goodbye!: He’ll do that when he delivers you from this earth’s throne to the joys of heaven.

Anon!: Good Margaret, run thee to the parlor.
Goodbye!: Good Margaret, run to the parlor.

Anon!: Shed thou no blood, nor cut thou less nor more But just a pound of flesh.
Goodbye!: You didn’t have any blood, or cut you less or more than a pound of flesh.

Anon!: His indignation derives itself out of a very competent injury.
Goodbye!: His indignation is caused by a very competent injury.

Anon!: Here comes the furious Tybalt back again.
Goodbye!: Here comes the furious Tybalt back again.

Anon!: But one word more— He will not be commanded.
Goodbye!: But one more thing— He won’t be commanded.

Anon!: Signior Gremio, came you from the church?
Goodbye!: Signior Gremio, did you come from the church?

Anon!: As ever you come of women, come in quickly to Sir John.
Goodbye!: As you always do, come in quickly to Sir John.

Anon!: Where I have learned me to repent the sin Of disobedient opposition To you and your behests, and am enjoined By holy Lawrence to fall prostrate here To beg your pardon.
Goodbye!: I’ve learned to repent the sin of disobedient opposition to you and your begests, and I’ve been told by the holy Lawrence to fall prostrate here to beg your pardon.

Anon!: I have a beard coming.
Goodbye!: I’ve got a beard coming.

Anon!: Meantime God grants that we have need of you.
Goodbye!: God grants us the support we need from you.

Anon!: Look to her, Moor, if thou hast eyes to see.
Goodbye!: Look at her, Moor, if you have eyes to see.

Anon!: Yea,” quoth he, “Dost thou fall upon thy face?
Goodbye!: Yes,” he said, “Do you fall on your face?

Anon!: So is Lysander.
Goodbye!: Lysander is the same.

Anon!: About!
Goodbye!: About!

Anon!: He hath an argosy bound to Tripolis, another to the Indies.
Goodbye!: He’s bound to Tripolis, another to the Indies.

Anon!: Gone?
Goodbye!: Gone?

Anon!: Did you perceive how he laughed at his vice?
Goodbye!: Did you see how he laughed at his vice?

Anon!: is ’t not perfect conscience To quit him with this arm?
Goodbye!: Isn’t it perfect to let him leave with this arm?

Anon!: This, by his voice, should be a Montague.—   What, dares the slave Come hither, covered with an antic face, To fleer and scorn at our solemnity?
Goodbye!: This, by his voice, should be a Montague.—What, why would the slave come here, covered with antic face, to flee and scorn our solemnity?

Anon!: Well thought upon.
Goodbye!: Good thought.

Anon!: Know you any, count?
Goodbye!: Do you know any, count?

Anon!: Thyself do grace to them, and bring them in.
Goodbye!: You’re a good man to them, and bring them in.

Anon!: Lovers, make moan.
Goodbye!: Lovers, make a moan.

Anon!: Away, I do beseech you, both away.
Goodbye!: Go away, I beg you, both of you.

Anon!: My dear’st sister!
Goodbye!: My dearest sister!

Anon!: Go carry them and smear The sleepy grooms with blood.
Goodbye!: Go carry them and smear the sleepy grooms with blood.

Anon!: I' faith, I am sorry that thou art not well.
Goodbye!: I’m sorry you’re not well.

Anon!: Shall I be plain?
Goodbye!: Shall I be plain?

Anon!: I’ll board him presently.
Goodbye!: I’ll take him here now.

Anon!: The hearts of old gave hands, But our new heraldry is hands, not hearts.
Goodbye!: The hearts of old gave hands, but our new heraldry is hands, not hearts.

Anon!: Tis since the earthquake now eleven years, And she was weaned—I never shall forget it— Of all the days of the year, upon that day.
Goodbye!: It’s been eleven years since the earthquake, and she was weaned—I’ll never forget it—of all the days of the year, on that day.

Anon!: I tell him we shall stay here at the least a month, and he heartily prays some occasion may detain us longer.
Goodbye!: I tell him we’ll stay here for at least a month, and he asks that some occasion may prolong our stay.

Anon!: He hath, my lord, but be you well assured No more than he’ll unswear.
Goodbye!: He’s not wearing anything more than he’ll wear.

Anon!: Why, she defies me Like Turk to Christian.
Goodbye!: Why, she defies me like a Turk to a Christian.

Anon!: If love be rough with you, be rough with love.
Goodbye!: If love is rough with you, be rough with love.

Anon!: And even now, but now, This house, these servants, and this same myself Are yours, my lord’s.
Goodbye!: And now, but now, this house, these servants, and this same myself are yours, my lord’s.

Anon!: Why, she is within.
Goodbye!: She’s inside.

Anon!: God give your Grace good rest.
Goodbye!: God give your Grace good rest.

Anon!: Through the house give glimmering light, By the dead and drowsy fire.
Goodbye!: By the dead and drowsy fire, give glimmering light through the house.

Anon!: If my heart’s dear love— Well, do not swear.
Goodbye!: If my heart’s dear love— Well, don’t swear.

Anon!: For I am sure mine nails Are stronger than mine eyes.
Goodbye!: I’m sure my nails are stronger than my eyes.

Anon!: The time is very short.
Goodbye!: The time is very short.

Anon!: Is it your dear friend that is thus in trouble?
Goodbye!: Is it your dear friend who’s in trouble?

Anon!: If by your art, my dearest father, you have Put the wild waters in this roar, allay them.
Goodbye!: If you’ve put the wild waters in this roar, my dearest father, you’ll allay them.

Anon!: Now, gods, stand up for bastards!
Goodbye!: Now, gods, stand up for bastards!

Anon!: My naked weapon is out.
Goodbye!: My naked sword is out.

Anon!: And so I shall catch the fly, your cousin, in the latter end and she must be blind too.
Goodbye!: And so I’ll catch the fly, your cousin, in the latter end, and she must be blind too.

Anon!: Michael Cassio, Lieutenant to the warlike Moor Othello, Is come on shore.
Goodbye!: Michael Cassio, Lieutenant of the Moor Othello, is coming on shore.

Anon!: But forbear, I say.
Goodbye!: But don’t be afraid, I say.

Anon!: Where is my lord?
Goodbye!: Where is my lord?

Anon!: I have a salt and sorry rheum offends me.
Goodbye!: I have a salty and sorry rheum that offends me.

Anon!: Myself have to mine own turned enemy.
Goodbye!: I’m the enemy I’ve been.

Anon!: If she sustain him and his hundred knights When I have showed th' unfitness— Here, madam.
Goodbye!: If she supports him and his hundred knights when I show you aren’t fit— Here, madam.

Anon!: Come, Menas.
Goodbye!: Come on, Menas.

Anon!: Thus it remains, and the remainder thus.
Goodbye!: It’s still alive, and the rest is still alive.

Anon!: My Lord Bassanio gave his ring away Unto the judge that begged it and indeed Deserved it too.
Goodbye!: Bassanio gave his ring to the judge who pleaded for it and deserved it too.

Anon!: Awake, sir, awake.
Goodbye!: Wake up, sir, wake up.

Anon!: What dost thou with thy best apparel on?
Goodbye!: What are you wearing your best clothes?

Anon!: Most sweet lady— A comfortable doctrine, and much may be said of it.
Goodbye!: Most sweet lady— It’s a good doctrine, and it’s much to say about it.

Anon!: Hast thou forgot The foul witch Sycorax, who with age and envy Was grown into a hoop?
Goodbye!: Have you forgotten the evil witch Sycorax, who was born with age and envy?

Anon!: I am sick in displeasure to him, and whatsoever comes athwart his affection ranges evenly with mine.
Goodbye!: I’m sick about him, and whatever happens to be his affections, he’s equally suited to me.

Anon!: A pack of blessings light upon thy back, Happiness courts thee in her best array,
Goodbye!: A pack of blessings is shining on your back, and Happiness is the best thing for you.

Anon!: I’ll fetch my sister to get her goodwill.
Goodbye!: I’ll get my sister to get her goodwill.

Anon!: I can hardly forbear hurling things at him.
Goodbye!: I can’t resist throwing things at him.

Anon!: Upon what bargain do you give it me?
Goodbye!: What bargain do you give me?

Anon!: Romeo, Romeo, Romeo!
Goodbye!: Romeo, Romeo, Romeo!

Anon!: What else?
Goodbye!: What else?

Anon!: Shall we rouse the night owl in a catch that will draw three souls out of one weaver?
Goodbye!: Should we rouse the nightowl in a catch that will draw three souls out of one weaver?

Anon!: No more a soldier.
Goodbye!: No more soldier.

Anon!: I am here already, sir.
Goodbye!: I’m already here, sir.

Anon!: Thou hast wronged Caius Ligarius.
Goodbye!: You’ve wronged Caius Ligarius.

Anon!: Farewell, sweet lord, and sister.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, sweet lord, and sister.

Anon!: Are you so gospeled To pray for this good man and for his issue, Whose heavy hand hath bowed you to the grave And beggared yours forever?
Goodbye!: Are you so evangelized to pray for this good man and for his issue, who has bowed you to the grave and begged you forever?

Anon!: But now I was the lord Of this fair mansion, master of my servants, Queen o'er myself.
Goodbye!: But now I was the lord of this fair mansion, master of my servants, and Queen o'er myself.

Anon!: The moon?
Goodbye!: The moon?

Anon!: Pluck but his name out of his heart and turn him going.
Goodbye!: Put his name out of his heart and turn him into a man.

Anon!: Tomorrow with your earliest Let me have speech with you.— Come, my dear love, The purchase made, the fruits are to ensue: That profit’s yet to come ’tween me and you.
Goodbye!: Tomorrow, with your earliest words, let me speak with you.—Come on, my dear love, the money you’ve made is going to be the fruit of the purchase.

Anon!: Let sorrow split my heart if ever I Did hate thee or thy father.
Goodbye!: Let my sorrow split my heart if I hated you or your father ever.

Anon!: Is there any cause in nature that makes these hard hearts?
Goodbye!: Is there any reason to make these hard hearts so hard?

Anon!: Which dreams indeed are ambition, for the very substance of the ambitious is merely the shadow of a dream.
Goodbye!: Which dreams are indeed ambition, because the essence of the ambitious is just the shadow of a dream.

Anon!: And now, I pray you, sir— For still ’tis beating in my mind—your reason For raising this sea storm?
Goodbye!: And now, please—because it’s still beating my mind—your reason for raising this storm?

Anon!: I will not long be troubled with you.
Goodbye!: I won’t be troubled long enough to be with you.

Anon!: O, what men dare do!
Goodbye!: Oh, what men dare to do!

Anon!: There is no other way, Unless thou couldst put on some other shape And not be Richard, that hath done all this.
Goodbye!: There’s no other way, unless you could put on some other form and not be Richard, who’s done all this.

Anon!: You, as your business and desire shall point you— For every man has business and desire, Such as it is—and for my own poor part, Look you, I’ll go pray.
Goodbye!: You, as your business and desire will point you—for every man has business and desire, as it is—and for my own poor part, look, I’ll go pray.

Anon!: Is he come?
Goodbye!: Is he coming?

Anon!: Don Pedro is approached.
Goodbye!: Don Pedro is approaching.

Anon!: Stand you both forth now: stroke your chins and swear by your beards that I am a knave.
Goodbye!: Stand both of you up now: stroke your chins and swear by your beards that I’m a knave.

Anon!: Look to ’t.
Goodbye!: Look at it.

Anon!: Why, no.
Goodbye!: No.

Anon!: Are you ready, sir?
Goodbye!: Are you ready, sir?

Anon!: Madman and beggar too.
Goodbye!: Madman and beggar too.

Anon!: My thanes and kinsmen, Henceforth be earls, the first that ever Scotland In such an honor named.
Goodbye!: My thanes and kinsmen, now they’ll be earls, the first Scotland to be named in such an honor.

Anon!: Come, away!
Goodbye!: Come on, get out of here!

Anon!: For me, with sorrow I embrace my fortune.
Goodbye!: For me, I embrace my fortune with sorrow.

Anon!: Live, Brutus!
Goodbye!: Live, Brutus!

Anon!: How canst thou woo her?
Goodbye!: How can you get her?

Anon!: That would I, were I of all kingdoms king.
Goodbye!: I wish I were king of all kingdoms.

Anon!: Now must your conscience my acquaintance seal, And you must put me in your heart for friend, Sith you have heard, and with a knowing ear, That he which hath your noble father slain Pursued my life.
Goodbye!: Now you must be my friend, and you must put me in your heart for a friend, and you’ve heard, and with a knowing ear, that the man who killed your noble father has sworn in my life

Anon!: I am given, sir, secretly to understand that your younger brother Orlando hath a disposition to come in disguised against me to try a fall.
Goodbye!: I’ve been told secretly that your younger brother Orlando has the right to come in disguise against me to try a fall.

Anon!: Be witness to me, O thou blessèd moon, When men revolted shall upon record Bear hateful memory, poor Enobarbus did Before thy face repent.
Goodbye!: Be witness to me, oh, you blessed moon, when men revolted upon the record will bear hateful memories, poor Enobarbus did before your face repent.

Anon!: Fierce fiery warriors fought upon the clouds In ranks and squadrons and right form of war, Which drizzled blood upon the Capitol.
Goodbye!: The fiery warriors fought on the clouds in ranks and squadrons and in the right form of war, which drizzled blood on the Capitol.

Anon!: Saddle my horses.
Goodbye!: Saddle my horses.

Anon!: Hear the ambassadors.
Goodbye!: Listen to the ambassadors.

Anon!: I prithee, Remember I have done thee worthy service, Told thee no lies, made thee no mistakings, served Without or grudge or grumblings.
Goodbye!: Please, remember I’ve done you worthy service, didn’t tell you anything, didn’t make you mistakes, served without or grudge or grumblings.

Anon!: An I do not— Come, let’s see the event.
Goodbye!: If I don’t— Come on, let’s see the event.

Anon!: Peace!
Goodbye!: Quiet!

Anon!: Hath an argosy cast away coming from Tripolis.
Goodbye!: I’m a man who’s thrown away from Tripolis.

Anon!: And so they are.
Goodbye!: And so they are.

Anon!: Marry, now I can tell.
Goodbye!: Now I can tell.

Anon!: Our arms in strength of malice and our hearts Of brothers' temper do receive you in With all kind love, good thoughts, and reverence.
Goodbye!: Our arms are in awe of sorrow and our hearts are in love with our brothers.

Anon!: Shall I go fetch your nightgown?
Goodbye!: Should I go fetch your nightgown?

Anon!: Did he never make you laugh?
Goodbye!: Didn’t he ever make you laugh?

Anon!: Good sir, to the purpose.
Goodbye!: Good sir, to the purpose.

Anon!: What is the matter there?
Goodbye!: What’s the matter?

Anon!: Lorenzo certain, and my love indeed— For who love I so much?
Goodbye!: Lorenzo, and my love indeed— Who love I so much?

Anon!: Oh, thou art deceived.
Goodbye!: Oh, you’re wrong.

Anon!: Had I plantation of this isle, my lord— He’d sow ’t with nettle seed.
Goodbye!: If I had planted this island, my lord— He’d sneezed it with nettle seed.

Anon!: He’s coming, madam; but in very strange manner.
Goodbye!: He’s coming, madam, but he’s very strange.

Anon!: to fool) Is thy lady within?
Goodbye!: Is your lady inside?

Anon!: There, where the torch doth burn.
Goodbye!: There, where the torch is burning.

Anon!: My mistress, sir,” quoth I.
Goodbye!: My mistress,” I said.

Anon!: The Hyrcanian deserts and the vasty wilds Of wide Arabia are as thoroughfares now For princes to come view fair Portia.
Goodbye!: The horcanian deserts and the vast wilds of Arabia are as thoroughfares for princes to come to see Portia.

Anon!: I will make your peace with him if I can.
Goodbye!: I’ll make peace with him if I can.

Anon!: Now, Signior, what news?
Goodbye!: Now, Signior, what news do you have?

Anon!: Ne'er may I look on day, nor sleep on night But she tells to your Highness simple truth.
Goodbye!: I can’t see the day, nor sleep the night, but she tells you the truth.

Anon!: You, mistress, all this coil is long of you.
Goodbye!: You, mistress, all this slut is long.

Anon!: Hark!
Goodbye!: Listen!

Anon!: Mistress, your father prays you leave your books And help to dress your sister’s chamber up.
Goodbye!: Mistress, your father asks you leave your books and help dress your sister’s room up.

Anon!: What is the news?
Goodbye!: What’s the news?

Anon!: Here, sir!
Goodbye!: Here, sir!

Anon!: Besides, I have some business in the town.
Goodbye!: Besides, I have some business in the town.

Anon!: When were you wont to be so full of songs, sirrah?
Goodbye!: When were you going to be so full of songs, sir?

Anon!: Yet fortune cannot recompense me better Than to die well, and not my master’s debtor.
Goodbye!: But fortune can’t pay me better than to die well, and not my master’s debtor.

Anon!: I did so, and went further, which is now Our point of second meeting.
Goodbye!: I did so, and I went further, which is now our point of second meeting.

Anon!: That courtesy would be uncleanly if courtiers were shepherds.
Goodbye!: That courtesy would be unclean if courtiers were shepherds.

Anon!: Lord Alexas, sweet Alexas, most anything Alexas, almost most absolute Alexas, where’s the soothsayer that you praised so to th’ Queen?
Goodbye!: Lord Alexas, sweet Alexas, most anything Alexas, almost absolute Alexas, where’s the soothsayer you praised so much to the Queen?

Anon!: He, when he hears of her, cannot refrain From the excess of laughter.
Goodbye!: When he hears about her, he can’t refrain from laughing.

Anon!: I will challenge him.
Goodbye!: I’ll challenge him.

Anon!: Are our eyes our own?
Goodbye!: Are our eyes our own?

Anon!: Is my lord well, that he doth speak so wide?
Goodbye!: Is my lord well, that he’s speaking so wide?

Anon!: Yes, a dozen, and as many to th' vantage as would store the world they played for.
Goodbye!: Yes, a dozen, and as many as they would store the world they played for.

Anon!: Didst not mark that?
Goodbye!: Didn’t you mention that?

Anon!: Gentlemen, you are welcome to Elsinore.
Goodbye!: Gentlemen, welcome to Elsinore.

Anon!: My father’s bears more toward the marketplace.
Goodbye!: My father’s going toward the marketplace.

Anon!: What work is here, Charmian?
Goodbye!: What’s going on here, Charmian?

Anon!: Though I am mad, I will not bite him.
Goodbye!: Though I’m mad, I won’t bite him.

Anon!: Hast thou met with him?
Goodbye!: Have you met him?

Anon!: O, reason not the need!
Goodbye!: Oh, don’t reason the need!

Anon!: I am afeard, Being in night, all this is but a dream, Too flattering sweet to be substantial.
Goodbye!: I’m afeard, because it’s night, all this is just a dream, too sweet to be substantial.

Anon!: But near him thy angel Becomes afeard, as being o’erpowered.
Goodbye!: But near him, your angel is afeasant, as if he’s a feasant.

Anon!: How now, mistress?
Goodbye!: What’s going on, mistress?

Anon!: Many a morning hath he there been seen, With tears augmenting the fresh morning’s dew, Adding to clouds more clouds with his deep sighs.
Goodbye!: He’s been seen there many times a morning, with tears sighing over the dew, adding to clouds more clouds.

Anon!: Calling death “banishment,” Thou cutt’st my head off with a golden ax And smilest upon the stroke that murders me.
Goodbye!: Calling death banishment, you cut my head off with a golden ax and smiled at the stroke that killed me.

Anon!: Richard yet lives, hell’s black intelligencer, Only reserved their factor to buy souls And send them thither.
Goodbye!: Richard still lives, hell’s black intelligencer, only reserved their power to buy souls and send them to the world.

Anon!: Is that my prize?
Goodbye!: Is that my prize?

Anon!: My dukedom to a beggarly denier, I do mistake my person all this while!
Goodbye!: I’m mistaken for my dukedom to a beggarly denier.

Anon!: Most heartily I do beseech the court To give the judgment.
Goodbye!: I beg the court to give the verdict.

Anon!: My lord, I know not what the matter is, but to my judgment your highness is not entertained with that ceremonious affection as you were wont.
Goodbye!: My lord, I don’t know what the matter is, but I’m sure your highness won’t be treated with the ceremonious affection you were wont.

Anon!: I must employ you in some business Against our nuptial and confer with you Of something nearly that concerns yourselves.
Goodbye!: I have to work with you in some way to fight our marriage and talk about something that matters to you.

Anon!: Now forth, Lord Constable and princes all, And quickly bring us word of England’s fall.
Goodbye!: Now go out, Lord Constable and all princes, and quickly tell us about England’s fall.

Anon!: All men’s faces are true, whatsome’er their hands are.
Goodbye!: All men’s faces are true, what they’re doing.

Anon!: I rather will subject me to the malice Of a diverted blood and bloody brother.
Goodbye!: I’d rather be subjected to the malice of a bloody brother and a bloody brother.

Anon!: I said so, dear Katherine; and I must not blush to affirm it.
Goodbye!: I said that, dear Katherine, and I can’t blush to say it.

Anon!: Accursed, unhappy, wretched, hateful day!
Goodbye!: Accursed, unhappy, wretched, hateful day!

Anon!: And for my love I pray you wrong me not.
Goodbye!: And for my love, I beg you to not wrong me.

Anon!: In Sicyon.
Goodbye!: In Sicyon.

Anon!: It were a tedious difficulty, I think, To bring them to that prospect.
Goodbye!: It would be a tedious task to bring them to that prospect, I think.

Anon!: I am very proud, revengeful, ambitious, with more offences at my beck than I have thoughts to put them in, imagination to give them shape, or time to act them in.
Goodbye!: I’m very proud, revengeful, ambitious, with more offences at my beck than I have thoughts to put them in, imagination to give them shape, or time to act in.

Anon!: Good Enobarbus!
Goodbye!: Good Enobarbus!

Anon!: Therefore, you clown, abandon—which is, in the vulgar, “leave”—the society—which in the boorish is “company”—of this female—which in the common is “woman”; which together is, abandon the society of this female, or, clown, thou perishest; or, to thy better understanding, diest; or, to wit, I kill thee, make thee away, translate thy life into death, thy liberty into bondage.
Goodbye!: So, you clown, abandon—which is in the vulgar, “leave”—the society—which in the vulgar is “company”—of this female—which in the common is “woman”—which together is, abandon

Anon!: I’ll tell the news.
Goodbye!: I’ll tell you the news.

Anon!: Under a compelling occasion, let women die.
Goodbye!: Let women die under a compelling occasion.

Anon!: And speak ’t again, my lord.
Goodbye!: And speak it again, my lord.

Anon!: My master stays in the street.
Goodbye!: My master is staying in the street.

Anon!: Give me another horse!
Goodbye!: Give me another horse!

Anon!: Some five or six and thirty of his knights, Hot questrists after him, met him at gate, Who with some other of the lord’s dependants Are gone with him towards Dover, where they boast To have well-armèd friends.
Goodbye!: Five or six and thirty of his knights, who followed him as hot questrists, met him at the gate, and with some other of the lord’s relatives, they’re going with him to Dover,

Anon!: Let not the heavens hear these telltale women Rail on the Lord’s anointed.
Goodbye!: Don’t let the heavens hear these sexy women scold the Lord’s scolded lord.

Anon!: I arrest thee of high treason, by the name of Thomas Grey, knight, of Northumberland.
Goodbye!: I’m arresting you for high treason, by the name of Thomas Grey, knight, of Northumberland.

Anon!: We hope to make the sender blush at it.
Goodbye!: We hope to make the sender blush at it.

Anon!: Because they are not eight?
Goodbye!: Because they’re not eight?

Anon!: Shut that, and ’twill out at the keyhole.
Goodbye!: Shut that up, and it’ll go out of the keyhole.

Anon!: I never looked for better at his hands After he once fell in with Mistress Shore.
Goodbye!: I never looked for better at his hands after he fell in with Mistress Shore.

Anon!: I know thee not.
Goodbye!: I don’t know you.

Anon!: Do you think I meant country matters?
Goodbye!: Do you think I meant country matters?

Anon!: It is good to grow.
Goodbye!: It’s good to grow.

Anon!: And I do believe your Majesty takes no scorn to wear the leek upon Saint Tavy’s day.
Goodbye!: And I believe your Majesty doesn’t take any scorn to wear the leek on Saint Tavy’s day.

Anon!: The life”?
Goodbye!: The life”?

Anon!: Here’s more news.
Goodbye!: Here’s more news.

Anon!: I would thou couldst.
Goodbye!: I wish you could.

Anon!: Farewell.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: He’s a very fool and a prodigal.
Goodbye!: He’s a very fool and a prodigal.

Anon!: Here I am.
Goodbye!: Here I am.

Anon!: What proof shall I make of that?
Goodbye!: What do I need to do about that?

Anon!: I alone will go.
Goodbye!: I’ll go alone.

Anon!: Oh, that my prayers could such affection move!
Goodbye!: Oh, I wish I could see such a king!

Anon!: Spake you of Caesar?
Goodbye!: Have you spoken of Caesar?

Anon!: If we offend, it is with our good will.
Goodbye!: If we’re wrong, it’s with our good will.

Anon!: So shall you quietly enjoy your hope And marry sweet Bianca with consent.
Goodbye!: So you’ll enjoy your hope and marry sweet Bianca with your consent.

Anon!: For many miles about There’s scarce a bush.
Goodbye!: There’s a little bush for many miles.

Anon!: I fear thee not.
Goodbye!: I don’t fear you.

Anon!: Thy asses are gone about 'em.
Goodbye!: Your asses are gone about them.

Anon!: No, it begins again.
Goodbye!: No, it’s back.

Anon!: Fury, Fury!—There, Tyrant, there.
Goodbye!: Fury, Fury!—There, Tyrant, there.

Anon!: And out of doubt you do me now more wrong In making question of my uttermost Than if you had made waste of all I have.
Goodbye!: And you’re more wrong now when you’re asking me what I’m saying than if you’d scolded all I have.

Anon!: Read thou this challenge.
Goodbye!: Read this challenge.

Anon!: Let’s see.
Goodbye!: Let’s see.

Anon!: I thank you; and be blessed for your good comfort.
Goodbye!: Thank you, and be blessed for your good comfort.

Anon!: Whither away?
Goodbye!: Where are you going?

Anon!: Yet I have known those which have walked in their sleep who have died holily in their beds.
Goodbye!: But I’ve known those who have walked in their sleep who have died in their beds.

Anon!: Your plantain leaf is excellent for that.
Goodbye!: Your plantain leaf is excellent for that.

Anon!: No, make it two more.
Goodbye!: No, make it two more.

Anon!: Poor Turlygod!” “Poor Tom!”— That’s something yet.
Goodbye!: That’s something.

Anon!: Else the Puck a liar call.
Goodbye!: The Puck’s a liar call.

Anon!: Sir Paris, I will make a desperate tender Of my child’s love.
Goodbye!: Sir Paris, I’ll make a desperate bid of my child’s love.

Anon!: This jack of Caesar’s shall Bear us an errand to him.
Goodbye!: This jack of Caesar’s will give us an error to him.

Anon!: For God’s sake, take a house.
Goodbye!: For God’s sake, take a house.

Anon!: The thrice three Muses mourning for the death  Of learning, late deceased in beggary.” That is some satire, keen and critical, Not sorting with a nuptial ceremony.
Goodbye!: The three muses mourning the death of learning, late deceased in beggary.” That’s some satire, keen and critical, not sorting with a nuptial ceremony.

Anon!: My lord, the mayor of London comes to greet you.
Goodbye!: My lord, the mayor of London comes to greet you.

Anon!: She is damned for it.
Goodbye!: She’s damned for it.

Anon!: Sir, I cannot.
Goodbye!: I can’t, sir.

Anon!: How shall we try it?
Goodbye!: How can we try it?

Anon!: Have I, Malvolio?
Goodbye!: Have I, Malvolio?

Anon!: I like you lads.
Goodbye!: I like you guys.

Anon!: Prithee, go in thyself.
Goodbye!: Go inside.

Anon!: Dear love, adieu.— Anon, good Nurse!—Sweet Montague, be true.
Goodbye!: Dear love, adieu.—Aon, good Nurse!—Sweet Montague, be true.

Anon!: What, ho?
Goodbye!: What, you?

Anon!: I think our country sinks beneath the yoke.
Goodbye!: I think our country is sinking under the yoke.

Anon!: Didst thou not fall out with a tailor for wearing his new doublet before Easter?
Goodbye!: Didn’t you fall out with a tailor for wearing his new doublet before Easter?

Anon!: Kneel to the duke before he pass the abbey.
Goodbye!: Kneel to the duke before he passes the abbey.

Anon!: Dost thou know the difference, my boy, between a bitter fool and a sweet fool?
Goodbye!: Do you know the difference, my boy, between a bitter fool and a sweet fool?

Anon!: I love thee not.
Goodbye!: I don’t love you.

Anon!: It is the bright day that brings forth the adder And that craves wary walking.
Goodbye!: It’s the bright day that brings the adder back to the house and that craves a quiet walk.

Anon!: Here is the man.
Goodbye!: Here is the man.

Anon!: Therefore go.
Goodbye!: So go.

Anon!: But hear thee, Gratiano.
Goodbye!: But listen, Gratiano.

Anon!: Nay, and I will.
Goodbye!: No, and I will.

Anon!: Ere I ope his letter, I pray you tell me how my good friend doth.
Goodbye!: I’m sorry, I’m telling you how my good friend is doing.

Anon!: Fare you well.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: Horns?
Goodbye!: Horns?

Anon!: O Iago, the pity of it, Iago!
Goodbye!: Oh, Iago, it’s a terrible thing, Iago!

Anon!: Tonight I’ll mourn with Hero.
Goodbye!: Tonight I’ll mourn Hero.

Anon!: Why, that’s spoken like an honest drover; so they sell bullocks.
Goodbye!: That’s what’s spoken like an honest drover.

Anon!: Nay, by 'r Lady, that I think he cannot.
Goodbye!: No, by my Lady, I think he can’t.

Anon!: There’s beggary in the love that can be reckoned.
Goodbye!: There’s a beggar in the love that can be reckoned.

Anon!: Yet, forgive me, God, That I do brag thus.
Goodbye!: But forgive me, God, that I’m braging like this.

Anon!: Thou canst not choose but know who I am.
Goodbye!: You can’t choose but know who I am.

Anon!: Did he not say my brother was fled?
Goodbye!: Didn’t he say my brother was leaving?

Anon!: What did he when thou saw’st him?
Goodbye!: What did he do when you saw him?

Anon!: But ’tis not so.
Goodbye!: But it’s not true.

Anon!: Yet it was said It should not stand in thy posterity, But that myself should be the root and father Of many kings.
Goodbye!: But it was said that it shouldn’t stand in your post-war, but that I should be the root and father of many kings.

Anon!: My lord, the enemy is past the marsh.
Goodbye!: My lord, the enemy is past the marsh.

Anon!: I am not taught to make anything.
Goodbye!: I’ve never been taught to make anything.

Anon!: No masque tonight.
Goodbye!: There’s no masquerade tonight.

Anon!: I can stand well enough, and I speak well enough.
Goodbye!: I can stand well enough, and I can speak well enough.

Anon!: Rather on Nilus’ mud Lay me stark naked and let the waterflies Blow me into abhorring.
Goodbye!: Instead, lay me naked on Nilus’s mud and let the waterflies blow me into abhorring.

Anon!: Dost thou hear, Iago?
Goodbye!: Do you hear it, Iago?

Anon!: I am bound to the Count Orsino’s court.
Goodbye!: I’m bound to the court of Count Orsino.

Anon!: Out o' th' moon, I do assure thee.
Goodbye!: I swear you’re out of the moon.

Anon!: And is it physical To walk unbracèd and suck up the humors Of the dank morning?
Goodbye!: And is it physically possible to walk unbracened and suck up the humor of the morning?

Anon!: It may be, very like.
Goodbye!: It may be, very similar.

Anon!: Well, tell me now what lady is the same To whom you swore a secret pilgrimage, That you today promised to tell me of?
Goodbye!: Well, tell me what lady you’ve been to whom you swore a secret pilgrimage, that you promised to tell me today?

Anon!: Illo, ho, ho, my lord!
Goodbye!: Illo, ho, ho, my lord!

Anon!: Sweet men, come to him.
Goodbye!: Sweet men, come to him.

Anon!: I wonder what it bodes.
Goodbye!: I wonder what it’s going to do.

Anon!: I have stayed for thee, God knows, in torment and in agony.
Goodbye!: God knows, I’ve been waiting for you in pain and agony.

Anon!: I shall do ’t.
Goodbye!: I’ll do it.

Anon!: What’s the matter with thee now?
Goodbye!: What’s the matter with you now?

Anon!: Now he importunes him To tell it o'er.
Goodbye!: Now he’s importing him to tell him what he’s doing.

Anon!: An if he be not fought withal, my lord, Let us not live in France.
Goodbye!: If he’s not fought with him, my lord, let’s not live in France.

Anon!: I am very comptible, even to the least sinister usage.
Goodbye!: I’m very receptive, even to the least sinister use.

Anon!: Welcome, my good Alexas.
Goodbye!: Welcome, my good Alexas.

Anon!: Why, because he was mad.
Goodbye!: Why, because he was insane.

Anon!: With what persuasion did he tempt thy love?
Goodbye!: What do you think he’s doing to tempt your love?

Anon!: Sir, a word ere you go.
Goodbye!: Sir, you’re going to say a word.

Anon!: Nothing, my lord.
Goodbye!: Nothing, my lord.

Anon!: What’s the matter?
Goodbye!: What’s the matter?

Anon!: Her vestal livery is but sick and green, And none but fools do wear it.
Goodbye!: Her robes are sick and green, and no fools wear it.

Anon!: For them all together, which maintained so politic a state of evil that they will not admit any good part to intermingle with them.
Goodbye!: They all agreed to be together, who maintained a state of evil so politicically that they won’t admit any good thing to fight with them.

Anon!: Why dost thou spit at me?
Goodbye!: Why are you spiting at me?

Anon!: And, hark!
Goodbye!: Listen!

Anon!: Then tell me, if I get your daughter’s love, What dowry shall I have with her to wife?
Goodbye!: Then tell me, if I get your daughter’s love, what dowry will I have with her to marry?

Anon!: No, Antony, take the lot.
Goodbye!: No, Antony, take the lot.

Anon!: Have mercy, Jesu!—Soft, I did but dream.
Goodbye!: Have mercy, Jesu!—Soft, I only dreamed.

Anon!: Obey you, love you, and most honor you.
Goodbye!: Be patient, love you, and most honor you.

Anon!: The merchandise which thou hast brought from Rome Are all too dear for me.
Goodbye!: The merchandise you’ve brought from Rome are all too dear for me.

Anon!: Ah, my tender babes, My unblown flowers, new-appearing sweets, If yet your gentle souls fly in the air And be not fixed in doom perpetual, Hover about me with your airy wings And hear your mother’s lamentation.
Goodbye!: Ah, my sweet babes, my unblown flowers, my sweets, if your gentle souls are still flying in the air and aren’t stuck in a perpetual curse, go over over me with your air

Anon!: Will you think so?
Goodbye!: Will you think so?

Anon!: The king and queen and all are coming down.
Goodbye!: The king and queen are coming down.

Anon!: So much was his pleasure should be proclaimed.
Goodbye!: He was so happy to be a part of the party.

Anon!: Follow the noise so far as we have quarter; Let’s see how it will give off.
Goodbye!: Follow the noise so far as we have quarters.

Anon!: Gilded tombs do worms enfold.
Goodbye!: Gilded tombs are worms that enfold.

Anon!: An if you plead as well for them As I can say “nay” to thee for myself, No doubt we bring it to a happy issue.
Goodbye!: If you plead as well for them as I can say “nay” to you, then we’ll make it a happy issue.

Anon!: Caesar’s sister is called Octavia.
Goodbye!: Caesar’s sister is called Octavia.

Anon!: What man is that?
Goodbye!: Who is that man?

Anon!: In her consists my happiness and thine.
Goodbye!: She’s my happiness and yours.

Anon!: Your answer to that?
Goodbye!: What’s your answer?

Anon!: I had as lief have a reed that will do me no service as a partisan I could not heave.
Goodbye!: I had a reed that won’t do me anything like a partisan I couldn’t heave.

Anon!: Ay, past all surgery.
Goodbye!: Yes, I’ve gone through all surgery.

Anon!: And I’ll go to bed at noon.
Goodbye!: And I’ll go to bed at noon.

Anon!: We wait upon your Grace.
Goodbye!: We’ll wait on your Grace.

Anon!: Nay, come, let’s go together.
Goodbye!: No, come on, let’s go together.

Anon!: I' faith, or I either?
Goodbye!: I’m sure, or I either?

Anon!: And so she doth, cousin.
Goodbye!: And so she does, cousin.

Anon!: You were kneeled to and importuned otherwise By all of us, and the fair soul herself Weighed between loathness and obedience, at Which end o' th' beam should bow.
Goodbye!: You were kneeled to and imported otherwise by all of us, and the fair soul herself was weighed between loath and obedience, at which end the beam should bow.

Anon!: Why, at her father’s.
Goodbye!: She’s at her father’s.

Anon!: No messenger but thine, and all alone Tonight we’ll wander through the streets and note The qualities of people.
Goodbye!: No messenger except you, and we’ll wander through the streets tonight and see the people.

Anon!: Your son shall have my daughter with consent.
Goodbye!: Your son will have my daughter with consent.

Anon!: Or do you play the flouting jack, to tell us Cupid is a good hare-finder and Vulcan a rare carpenter?
Goodbye!: Or are you playing the jack, to tell us Cupid is a good hare-finder and Vulcan is a rare carpenter?

Anon!: Ay, my good lord.
Goodbye!: Yes, my good lord.

Anon!: Quail, crush, conclude, and quell!
Goodbye!: Quiet, crush, conclude, and quell!

Anon!: And, being done, thus Wall away doth go.
Goodbye!: And, after you’ve done it, Wall’s going away.

Anon!: Romeo can, Though heaven cannot.
Goodbye!: Romeo can, even though heaven can.

Anon!: Why, one that swears and lies.
Goodbye!: Why, one who swears and lies.

Anon!: Next month with us.
Goodbye!: Next month, we’ll meet.

Anon!: And that’s but unwholesome food, they say.
Goodbye!: And that’s just unwholesome food, they say.

Anon!: Many times, madam.
Goodbye!: Many times, madam.

Anon!: His son is elder, sir.
Goodbye!: His son is older than that, sir.

Anon!: Not that Adam that kept the Paradise, but that Adam that keeps the prison; he that goes in the calf’s skin that was killed for the Prodigal; he that came behind you, sir, like an evil angel, and bid you forsake your liberty.
Goodbye!: Not that Adam who kept the Paradise, but that Adam who keeps the prison; that guy who goes in the calf’s skin that was killed for the Prodigal; that guy who came behind you, sir

Anon!: By Chrish, la, ’tish ill done.
Goodbye!: By Chrish, la, it’s ill done.

Anon!: There comes an old man and his three sons— I could match this beginning with an old tale.
Goodbye!: There comes a man and his three sons— I could match this beginning with an old story.

Anon!: Well, my good fellows, wait on me tonight.
Goodbye!: Well, my good fellows, wait on me tonight.

Anon!: Yes, truly, for look you, the sins of the father are to be laid upon the children.
Goodbye!: Yes, for look, the children are being punished for the sins of the father.

Anon!: The terms of our estate may not endure Hazard so dangerous as doth hourly grow Out of his lunacies.
Goodbye!: The terms of our estate may not be as dangerous as the slanders of his slanders.

Anon!: Your servants tend.
Goodbye!: Your servants are going to do that.

Anon!: Thus hath the course of justice whirled about And left thee but a very prey to time, Having no more but thought of what thou wast To torture thee the more, being what thou art.
Goodbye!: So justice has whirled around you and left you a very prey to time, despite no more thought about what you were to torture you more, being what you are.

Anon!: Saving your merry humor, here’s the note How much your chain weighs to the utmost carat, The fineness of the gold, and chargeful fashion, Which doth amount to three-odd ducats more Than I stand debted to this gentleman.
Goodbye!: You’re saving your merry humor, here’s the note how much your chain weighs to the utmost carat, how fine the gold is, and how it’s a good, and that’s

Anon!: Do not you love me?
Goodbye!: Don’t you love me?

Anon!: I’ll not be strucken, my lord.
Goodbye!: I won’t be struck, my lord.

Anon!: Why is my lord enraged against his love?
Goodbye!: Why is my lord angry about his love?

Anon!: Or came it by request and such fair question As soul to soul affordeth?
Goodbye!: Or did it come with such a fair question as soul to soul?

Anon!: His horse is slain, and all on foot he fights, Seeking for Richmond in the throat of death.
Goodbye!: His horse is dead, and he fights all on foot, looking for Richmond in the throat of death.

Anon!: Let me alone.
Goodbye!: Let me go.

Anon!: If you saw yourself with your eyes or knew yourself with your judgment, the fear of your adventure would counsel you to a more equal enterprise.
Goodbye!: If you saw yourself with your eyes or knew yourself with your judgment, the fear of your adventure would help you to pursue a more equal enterprise.

Anon!: Will you stay awhile?
Goodbye!: Will you stay for a while?

Anon!: Legged like a man and his fins like arms!
Goodbye!: Legged like a man and his fins like arms!

Anon!: Ring the alarum bell.
Goodbye!: Ring the bell.

Anon!: What is amiss?
Goodbye!: What’s wrong?

Anon!: My Lord of Cambridge, and my kind Lord of Masham, And you, my gentle knight, give me your thoughts.
Goodbye!: My Lord of Cambridge, my kind Lord of Masham, and you, my gentle knight, give me your thoughts.

Anon!: Lead him to my bower.
Goodbye!: Lead him to my bower.

Anon!: On each side her Stood pretty dimpled boys, like smiling Cupids, With divers-colored fans, whose wind did seem To glow the delicate cheeks which they did cool, And what they undid did.
Goodbye!: On each side her savage, savage, savage boys, like smiling Cupids, with colorful fans, whose wind seemed to glow the delicate cheeks they cooled, and what they und

Anon!: Where is my mother?
Goodbye!: Where is my mother?

Anon!: Were ’t my fitness To let these hands obey my blood, They are apt enough to dislocate and tear Thy flesh and bones.
Goodbye!: If I were able to keep my hands in my blood, they would be able to displace and tear your flesh and bones.

Anon!: Where’s Antonio, then?
Goodbye!: Where’s Antonio, then?

Anon!: Meantime I writ to Romeo, That he should hither come as this dire night, To help to take her from her borrowed grave, Being the time the potion’s force should cease.
Goodbye!: I writ to Romeo, if he came here as a terrible night, to help take her from her borrowed grave, as soon as the potion’s force stopped.

Anon!: Madam?
Goodbye!: Madam?

Anon!: My master calls me.
Goodbye!: My master calls me.

Anon!: If thou art she, tell me where is that son That floated with thee on the fatal raft?
Goodbye!: If you’re she, tell me where is that son who floated with you on the fatal raft?

Anon!: A king, a king!
Goodbye!: A king, a king!

Anon!: Be brisk 0awhile, and the longer liver take all.
Goodbye!: Be brisk for a while, and the longer the liver takes everything.

Anon!: But it sufficeth that the day will end, And then the end is known.—Come, ho!
Goodbye!: But it’s enough that the day will end, and then the end will be known.—Come on!

Anon!: If you will watch his going thence (which I will fashion to fall out between twelve and one) you may take him at your pleasure.
Goodbye!: If you watch him go from here (which I’ll make up for to fall out between twelve and one), you can take him to your satisfaction.

Anon!: You shall hear me.
Goodbye!: You’ll hear me.

Anon!: What is it, my good friends?
Goodbye!: What’s it, my good friends?

Anon!: Peace, ho, for shame!
Goodbye!: Quiet, for shame!

Anon!: Nay, he will answer the letter’s master, how he dares, being dared.
Goodbye!: No, he’ll answer the letter’s master, how he dares, being dared.

Anon!: Observe how Antony becomes his flaw, And what thou think’st his very action speaks In every power that moves.
Goodbye!: Watch how Antony is a man, and what you think his actions are telling you in every power that moves.

Anon!: No woman’s heart So big, to hold so much.
Goodbye!: No woman’s heart is so big, to hold so much.

Anon!: I know not what ’twas but distraction.
Goodbye!: I don’t know what was just distraction.

Anon!: Well then, no more but this: go, gentle Catesby, And, as it were far off, sound thou Lord Hastings How he doth stand affected to our purpose And summon him tomorrow to the Tower To sit about the coronation.
Goodbye!: Well then, no more than this: go, gentle Catesby, and, as far as it were, you Lord Hastings would tell you how he’s positioned in our mission and summon him tomorrow to the Tower to

Anon!: O, then it moved her?
Goodbye!: Oh, then it moved her?

Anon!: Better it were they all came by his father, Or by the father there were none at all, For emulation who shall now be nearest Will touch us all too near if God prevent not.
Goodbye!: If they were all coming from his father, or if they were none at all, the emulation who will be closest will touch us all too close if God doesn’t prevent it.

Anon!: Hark, boy!
Goodbye!: Listen, boy!

Anon!: Marry, I saw your niece do more favors to the Count’s servingman than ever she bestowed upon me.
Goodbye!: I saw your niece do more favors to the Count’s servant than she ever gave to me.

Anon!: Commend me to thy lady, And bid her hasten all the house to bed, Which heavy sorrow makes them apt unto.
Goodbye!: Give my praise to your lady, and ask her to hurry up to bed, which makes them apt to do.

Anon!: Fare thee well, nymph.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, nymph.

Anon!: Alack, for mercy!
Goodbye!: Oh, for mercy!

Anon!: Farewell.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: No, sir.
Goodbye!: No, sir.

Anon!: True, noble prince.
Goodbye!: True, noble prince.

Anon!: What’s he that now is going out of door?
Goodbye!: Who’s going out of the door now?

Anon!: It is my fashion, when I see a crab.
Goodbye!: It’s my style when I see a crab.

Anon!: But come, your Bergomask.
Goodbye!: But come on, Bergomask.

Anon!: See, Caesar!
Goodbye!: See, Caesar!

Anon!: Then love me, Rosalind.
Goodbye!: Then love me, Rosalind.

Anon!: Here’s that shall drive some of them to a noncome.
Goodbye!: Here’s the one who will drive some of them to a noncome.

Anon!: Who’s there, in th' other devil’s name?
Goodbye!: Who’s there, in the other devil’s name?

Anon!: Caesar’s.
Goodbye!: Caesar’s.

Anon!: A heavy sight!
Goodbye!: A heavy sight!

Anon!: Sir, most heedfully.
Goodbye!: Sir, I’m very careful.

Anon!: Bear’st thou her face in mind?
Goodbye!: Have your face in mind?

Anon!: All is but toys.
Goodbye!: Everything is just toys.

Anon!: O vengeance!
Goodbye!: Oh, revenge!

Anon!: I, gentle mistress.
Goodbye!: I, gentle mistress.

Anon!: As thou got’st Milan, I’ll come by Naples.
Goodbye!: As you got Milan, I’ll come by Naples.

Anon!: Methinks sometimes I have no more wit than a Christian or an ordinary man has.
Goodbye!: Sometimes I think I’m not a Christian or a normal man.

Anon!: I have undone three tailors.
Goodbye!: I’ve wiped three tailors out.

Anon!: Good gentlemen, look fresh and merrily.
Goodbye!: Good gentlemen, look fresh and merrily.

Anon!: Where’s Monsieur Cobweb?
Goodbye!: Where’s Monsieur Cobweb?

Anon!: Now, fair befall thee, good Petruchio!
Goodbye!: Now, please, good Petruchio!

Anon!: Then would to Heaven that I had never seen ’t!
Goodbye!: Then I wish I had never seen it!

Anon!: I pray thee, good Horatio, wait upon him.
Goodbye!: Please, Horatio, wait on him.

Anon!: Thy mother’s poisoned.
Goodbye!: Your mother’s been poisoned.

Anon!: She did indeed.
Goodbye!: She did.

Anon!: He is then a giant to an ape; but then is an ape a doctor to such a man.
Goodbye!: He’s a giant to an ape, but he’s a doctor to such a man.

Anon!: Thy drugs are quick.
Goodbye!: Your drugs are quick.

Anon!: em all three all ready.
Goodbye!: All three of them are ready.

Anon!: Look like th' innocent flower, But be the serpent under ’t.
Goodbye!: Look like a innocent flower, but be the serpent under it.

Anon!: You are not, Cassius.
Goodbye!: You aren’t, Cassius.

Anon!: Ha!
Goodbye!: Ha!

Anon!: It is an honor that I dream not of.
Goodbye!: It’s an honor that I don’t dream of.

Anon!: I pray thee, moralize them.
Goodbye!: Please, moralize them.

Anon!: My lord is not my lord, nor should I know him Were he in favor as in humor altered.
Goodbye!: My lord is not my lord, and I shouldn’t know him if he was as favorable as he was in humor.

Anon!: For England his approaches makes as fierce As waters to the sucking of a gulf.
Goodbye!: England’s approach is as fierce as waters to the savage of a gulf.

Anon!: I will, my Hermia.
Goodbye!: I will, my Hermia.

Anon!: O Julius Caesar, thou art mighty yet!
Goodbye!: Oh, Julius Caesar, you’re still mighty!

Anon!: For they shall yet belie thy happy years That say thou art a man.
Goodbye!: They’ll beg you to be happy with your life, because you’re a man.
