Anon!: But next day I told him of myself, which was as much As to have asked him pardon.
Goodbye!: But the next day I told him about myself, which was as much as asking him to pardon.

Anon!: How fares my gracious sir?
Goodbye!: How is my gracious sir?

Anon!: Let me be ta'en.
Goodbye!: Let me be taint.

Anon!: Wast ever in court, shepherd?
Goodbye!: Was it ever in court, shepherd?

Anon!: Good gentle youth, tempt not a desperate man.
Goodbye!: Good gentle young man, don’t tempt a desperate man.

Anon!: In the corrupted currents of this world Offense’s gilded hand may shove by justice, And oft ’tis seen the wicked prize itself Buys out the law.
Goodbye!: In the corrupted world, the gilded hand of the offense may be shoved by justice, and it’s often seen that the wicked prize itself buys out the law.

Anon!: Then God be blessed, it is the blessèd sun.
Goodbye!: Then God be blessed, it’s the blessed sun.

Anon!: By my faith, he is very swift and sententious.
Goodbye!: I swear he’s very swift and sententious.

Anon!: An oath of mickle might, and fury shall abate.
Goodbye!: A oath of sanity will be made, and the fury will abate.

Anon!: My good lords both, with all the heed I can.
Goodbye!: My lords, I’m all right.

Anon!: Tis he.
Goodbye!: That’s him.

Anon!: Then we are rid of Litio.
Goodbye!: Then we’re rid of Litio.

Anon!: Seest thou this sweet sight?
Goodbye!: Are you seeing this sweet sight?

Anon!: If thou hast slain Lysander in his sleep, Being o'er shoes in blood, plunge in the deep, And kill me too.
Goodbye!: If you’ve killed Lysander in his sleep, you’re a man who’s soaked in blood, and you’re going to plunge in the deep, and kill me too.

Anon!: Art thou contented, Jew?
Goodbye!: Are you happy, Jew?

Anon!: Fear’st thou that, Antonio?
Goodbye!: Do you fear that, Antonio?

Anon!: Sirs, take up the corse.
Goodbye!: Sirs, take up the corse.

Anon!: By my troth, my lord, I cannot tell what to think of it, but that she loves him with an enraged affection, it is past the infinite of thought.
Goodbye!: I can’t tell you what to think of it, my lord, but she loves him with a raged affection, and it’s beyond the infinite of thought.

Anon!: I’ll none of it.
Goodbye!: I won’t do anything about it.

Anon!: Nay, I am the very pink of courtesy.
Goodbye!: No, I’m the very pink of courtesy.

Anon!: And so swear I.
Goodbye!: And so I swear.

Anon!: Perchance she cannot meet him.
Goodbye!: She can’t meet him.

Anon!: How hath your lordship brooked imprisonment?
Goodbye!: How did your lord be jailed?

Anon!: What, are you busy, ho?
Goodbye!: Are you busy?

Anon!: Fare you well.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: Go bid the priests do present sacrifice And bring me their opinions of success.
Goodbye!: Go ask the priests to sacrifice and bring me their opinions on success.

Anon!: Let us hear, sweet Bottom.
Goodbye!: Let’s hear, Bottom.

Anon!: Or shall I say her uncle?
Goodbye!: Or should I say her uncle?

Anon!: I grant I am a woman, but withal A woman that Lord Brutus took to wife.
Goodbye!: I’m sure I’m a woman, but I’m a woman Lord Brutus took to wife.

Anon!: Then you will bring the chain to her yourself.
Goodbye!: Then you’ll bring the necklace to her yourself.

Anon!: Then ’tis like the breath of an unfee’d lawyer.
Goodbye!: Then it’s like a sigh of relief from a frightened lawyer.

Anon!: His eyes are humbler than they used to be.
Goodbye!: His eyes are humbler than they used to be.

Anon!: Done to death by slanderous tongues Was the Hero that here lies.
Goodbye!: The Hero who died here was slanderous.

Anon!: Nor tears nor prayers shall purchase out abuses, Therefore use none.
Goodbye!: So don’t use tears or prayers to make money.

Anon!: Here’s Romeo’s man.
Goodbye!: Here’s Romeo’s man.

Anon!: You are naught, you are naught.
Goodbye!: You’re naughty, you’re naughty.

Anon!: When Nature hath made a fair creature, may she not by Fortune fall into the fire?
Goodbye!: When Nature has made a fair creature, can’t she fall into the fire by Fortune?

Anon!: John Duke of Norfolk, Walter, Lord Ferrers, Sir Robert Brakenbury, and Sir William Brandon.
Goodbye!: John Duke of Norfolk, Walter, Lord Ferrers, Sir Robert Brakenbury, and Sir William Brandon.

Anon!: Then do but say to me what I should do That in your knowledge may by me be done, And I am pressed unto it.
Goodbye!: Then just say to me what I should do so that I can do it in your knowledge, and I’m pressed to do it.

Anon!: For, meeting her of late behind the wood, Seeking sweet favors from this hateful fool, I did upbraid her and fall out with her.
Goodbye!: I met her late in the evening, looking for sweet favors from this hateful fool, and I scolded her and fell out with her.

Anon!: One kiss, and I’ll descend.
Goodbye!: I’ll kiss you, and I’ll descend.

Anon!: Now Romeo is beloved and loves again, Alike bewitchèd by the charm of looks, But to his foe supposed he must complain, And she steal love’s sweet bait from fearful hooks.
Goodbye!: Romeo is now beloved and loves again, as if he was beaten by the charm of looks, but he’s supposed to complain to his foe, and she steals love’s sweet bait from fearful hook

Anon!: Tis noble spoken.
Goodbye!: It’s noble.

Anon!: I bleed, sir, but not killed.
Goodbye!: I’m bleeding, sir, but I’m not killed.

Anon!: What are these faces?
Goodbye!: What are these faces?

Anon!: Are they not now upon the western shore, Safe-conducting the rebels from their ships?
Goodbye!: Aren’t they now on the western shore, securing the rebels from their ships?

Anon!: Are not these woods More free from peril than the envious court?
Goodbye!: Aren’t these forests more protected from danger than the envious court?

Anon!: Why, that is nothing.
Goodbye!: That’s nothing.

Anon!: Is this the poultice for my aching bones?
Goodbye!: Is this the sneezing for my aching bones?

Anon!: I hope thou art not mad.
Goodbye!: I hope you’re not insane.

Anon!: The queen your mother, in most great affliction of spirit, hath sent me to you.
Goodbye!: Your mother, in a great affliction of spirit, sent me to you.

Anon!: Lord, Lord, she will be a joyful woman.
Goodbye!: Lord, Lord, she will be a joyful woman.

Anon!: Truly, a peck of provender.
Goodbye!: That’s a peck of provender.

Anon!: I feared he did but trifle And meant to wreck thee.
Goodbye!: I feared he only scolded you and wanted to wreck you.

Anon!: Have done, have done.
Goodbye!: Have done, have done.

Anon!: There he is.
Goodbye!: Here he is.

Anon!: The heads of the maids?
Goodbye!: The heads of the maids?

Anon!: Hide it in smiles and affability.
Goodbye!: Be patient and smiley.

Anon!: How long hath he been there?
Goodbye!: How long has he been there?

Anon!: He is already named and gone to Scone To be invested.
Goodbye!: He’s already been named and went to Scone to be invested.

Anon!: Alas, alas!
Goodbye!: Oh, sorry!

Anon!: I am not in the giving vein today.
Goodbye!: I’m not in the giving mood today.

Anon!: And when I do, I swear It shall be Romeo, whom you know I hate, Rather than Paris.
Goodbye!: And when I do, I swear it will be Romeo, whom you know I hate, rather than Paris.

Anon!: What manner of man?
Goodbye!: What kind of man are you?

Anon!: A friend.
Goodbye!: A friend.

Anon!: Yet there he was, and there I found this credit, That he did range the town to seek me out.
Goodbye!: But there he was, and I found this credit, that he went to the town to find me.

Anon!: I nursed her daughter that you talked withal.
Goodbye!: I nursed her daughter, whom you talked to.

Anon!: But passion lends them power, time means, to meet, Tempering extremities with extreme sweet.
Goodbye!: But passion gives them power, and time gives them the opportunity to meet, tying extremities with sweetness.

Anon!: Alack, sir, you cannot see your way.
Goodbye!: You can’t see your way, sir.

Anon!: Ay, you would beg, Were you in my distress.
Goodbye!: Yes, you would beg, if you were in my distress.

Anon!: Make we our march towards Birnam.
Goodbye!: Make us our march towards Birnam.

Anon!: Mark, I say, instantly, and carry it so As I have set it down.
Goodbye!: Mark it instantly, and carry it as I have set it down.

Anon!: A miracle!
Goodbye!: A miracle!

Anon!: Trust me, I take him for the better dog.
Goodbye!: Trust me, I’m taking him for the better dog.

Anon!: Captain Jamy is a marvelous falorous gentleman, that is certain, and of great expedition and knowledge in th' aunchient wars, upon my particular knowledge of his directions.
Goodbye!: Captain Jamy is a marvelous falorous gentleman, that’s true, and he’s a great soldier and a great expert in the wars, based on my particular knowledge of his direction.

Anon!: O Lord, I could have stayed here all the night To hear good counsel.
Goodbye!: Oh Lord, I could have stayed here all night to hear good advice.

Anon!: By Cheshu, he is an ass, as in the world.
Goodbye!: By Cheshu, he is an ass, as in the world.

Anon!: Go to your rest.
Goodbye!: Go to sleep.

Anon!: Come, sweet Audrey.
Goodbye!: Come on, sweet Audrey.

Anon!: Tell him there’s a post come from my master with his horn full of good news.
Goodbye!: Tell him that I’ve got a post from my master with a horn full of good news.

Anon!: Sound, music!—Come, my queen, take hands with me, And rock the ground whereon these sleepers be.
Goodbye!: Sound, music!—Come, my queen, take my hands with me and rock the ground where these sleepers are.

Anon!: Is it upon record, or else reported Successively from age to age, he built it?
Goodbye!: Is it a record, or has he rewritten it from time to time?

Anon!: A thing for me?
Goodbye!: What’s going on for me?

Anon!: Well, I’ll end the song.—Sirs, cover the while; the duke will drink under this tree.—He hath been all this day to look you.
Goodbye!: Well, I’ll end the song.—Sirs, cover the time; the duke will drink under this tree.—He’s been looking at you all day.

Anon!: Believe me, I had rather have lost my purse Full of crusadoes.
Goodbye!: Believe me, I’d rather have lost my purse full of crusadoes.

Anon!: I have been worth the whistle.
Goodbye!: I’ve been worth the whistle.

Anon!: One fairer than my love?
Goodbye!: One more fair man than my love?

Anon!: You best know the place.
Goodbye!: You know the place best.

Anon!: Oh, it is monstrous, monstrous.
Goodbye!: Oh, it’s monstrous, monstrous.

Anon!: Swounds, show me what thou'lt do.
Goodbye!: Swounds, tell me what you’re doing.

Anon!: When you sued staying, Then was the time for words.
Goodbye!: When you sued for staying, it was time for words.

Anon!: I myself heard the king say he would not be ransomed.
Goodbye!: I myself heard the king say he wouldn’t be ransomed.

Anon!: Seek it out.
Goodbye!: Look at it.

Anon!: I make not, but foresee.
Goodbye!: I don’t make it, but I’m going to see it.

Anon!: It would become me As well as it does you, and I should do it With much more ease, for my good will is to it And yours it is against.
Goodbye!: I’d like to do it with more ease, since my good will is to it and yours is against it.

Anon!: Say I will love her everlastingly.
Goodbye!: Say I will love her everlastingly.

Anon!: I tell you, he that can lay hold of her Shall have the chinks.
Goodbye!: I tell you, the man who can hold her will have the chinks.

Anon!: Cheerly, good Adam.
Goodbye!: Cheers, good Adam.

Anon!: Virtue is beauty, but the beauteous evil Are empty trunks o'erflourished by the devil.
Goodbye!: Virtue is beauty, but evil is empty trunks o'erflourished by the devil.

Anon!: His backward voice is to utter foul speeches and to detract.
Goodbye!: His voice is uttering foul words and retracing them.

Anon!: I’ll be at charges for a looking glass And entertain a score or two of tailors To study fashions to adorn my body.
Goodbye!: I’ll be at the expense of a glass and perform a few tailors to study fashions to adorn my body.

Anon!: Macbeth doth come.
Goodbye!: Macbeth is coming.

Anon!: Ay, mother, but I would not have it so.
Goodbye!: Yes, mother, but I wouldn’t have it.

Anon!: How now!
Goodbye!: What’s going on?

Anon!: I spoke with some of the sailors that escaped the wrack.
Goodbye!: I spoke to some of the sailors who escaped the wrack.

Anon!: What, you look merrily.
Goodbye!: You look merrily.

Anon!: To him in thine own voice, and bring me word how thou findest him.
Goodbye!: Tell him in your own voice, and tell me how you find him.

Anon!: I shall break The cause of our expedience to the Queen And get her leave to part.
Goodbye!: I’ll break the law to the Queen and get her permission to join.

Anon!: Set we our squadrons on yond side o’ th’ hill, In eye of Caesar’s battle, from which place We may the number of the ships behold And so proceed accordingly.
Goodbye!: We’ll put our squadrons on the hill, in the eye of Caesar’s battle, and then we can see the number of ships and proceed accordingly.

Anon!: You must contrary me.
Goodbye!: You have to contradict me.

Anon!: What do I see on thee?
Goodbye!: What do you see on you?

Anon!: Some tender money to me; some invite me; Some other give me thanks for kindnesses; Some offer me commodities to buy.
Goodbye!: Some of you give me some money, some invite me, some give me thanks for kindness, some offer me commodities to buy.

Anon!: In the same figure like the king that’s dead.
Goodbye!: In the same figure as the king who’s dead.

Anon!: That is some good.
Goodbye!: That’s good.

Anon!: No, that you shall not till you take her hand Before this friar and swear to marry her.
Goodbye!: No, you won’t be able to wait until you take her hand before this friar and swear to marry her.

Anon!: You are now within a foot Of th' extreme verge.
Goodbye!: You’re just a foot away from the extreme point.

Anon!: I do know, When the blood burns, how prodigal the soul Lends the tongue vows.
Goodbye!: I know when the blood burns, how prodigal the soul is to be a vow.

Anon!: Ay, that he was.
Goodbye!: Yes, that he was.

Anon!: Do we but find the tyrant’s power tonight, Let us be beaten if we cannot fight.
Goodbye!: We’ll only find the power of the tyrant tonight, so we can be beaten if we can’t fight.

Anon!: Wilt thou lay hands on me, villain?
Goodbye!: Will you give me the hand, villain?

Anon!: It is the cry of women, my good lord.
Goodbye!: It’s the cry of women, my good lord.

Anon!: Vile earth, to earth resign.
Goodbye!: Let’s go to earth.

Anon!: The Lord Grandpré.
Goodbye!: The Lord Grandpré.

Anon!: To move is to stir, and to be valiant is to stand.
Goodbye!: To move is to stir, and to be brave is to stand.

Anon!: Look up a-height.
Goodbye!: Look up a horn.

Anon!: Tis all one.
Goodbye!: It’s all one thing.

Anon!: What will you give me now For the same handkerchief?
Goodbye!: What do you want to give me for the same handkerchief?

Anon!: Drink thou.
Goodbye!: Drink.

Anon!: Sir, do you know me?
Goodbye!: Sir, do you know me?

Anon!: And so am I for Rosalind.
Goodbye!: And so am I for Rosalind.

Anon!: Peace!
Goodbye!: Quiet!

Anon!: Go, good partner, go, get you to Francis Seacole.
Goodbye!: Go, good partner, go get to Francis Seacole.

Anon!: The man is innocent.
Goodbye!: The man is innocent.

Anon!: Look in upon me then and speak with me, Or, naked as I am, I will assault thee.
Goodbye!: Look in on me and speak with me, or I’ll assault you, naked as I am.

Anon!: And, good lieutenant, I think you think I love you.
Goodbye!: And, lieutenant, I think you think I love you.

Anon!: Demetrius thinks not so.
Goodbye!: Demetrius doesn’t think so.

Anon!: And do you now strew flowers in his way That comes in triumph over Pompey’s blood?
Goodbye!: And have you strew flowers in Pompey’s way now?

Anon!: How is it, general?
Goodbye!: What’s that, general?

Anon!: Ay, madam.
Goodbye!: Yes, madam.

Anon!: Hold him in safety till the Prince come hither.
Goodbye!: Keep him safe until the Prince comes here.

Anon!: Grief of my son’s exile hath stopped her breath.
Goodbye!: My son’s exile has stopped her breath.

Anon!: Is this the poultice for my aching bones?
Goodbye!: Is this the sneezing for my aching bones?

Anon!: Awake!
Goodbye!: Wake up!

Anon!: tis not so now.
Goodbye!: It’s not true now.

Anon!: How do you, Malvolio?
Goodbye!: How are you, Malvolio?

Anon!: Before my God, I might not this believe Without the sensible and true avouch Of mine own eyes.
Goodbye!: I wouldn’t believe this without my own eyes.

Anon!: I assure you, Carthage.
Goodbye!: I assure you, Carthage.

Anon!: Thou art the best o' th' cutthroats: Yet he’s good that did the like for Fleance.
Goodbye!: You’re the best cutthroat, but he did the same for Fleance.

Anon!: Swear by my sword.
Goodbye!: Swear by my sword.

Anon!: Master, if you do, expect spoon meat; or bespeak a long spoon.
Goodbye!: Master, if you do, expect a spoon of meat; or bespeak a long spoon.

Anon!: Say’st me so, friend?
Goodbye!: Tell me that, friend?

Anon!: And here will rest me.
Goodbye!: And here will rest me.

Anon!: Feeling so the loss, Cannot choose but ever weep the friend.
Goodbye!: If you feel the loss, you can’t choose but weep the friend ever.

Anon!: Farewell.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: Now, if thou wert a poet, I might have some hope thou didst feign.
Goodbye!: Now, if you’re a poet, I’d have some hope you feigned.

Anon!: You have said now.
Goodbye!: You’ve said what you’re saying now.

Anon!: If you desire the spleen, and will laugh yourself into stitches, follow me.
Goodbye!: If you want the spleen to laugh and get a laugh, follow me.

Anon!: Seek him, bid him come hither.
Goodbye!: Seek him, ask him to come here.

Anon!: Tis true, most worthy signior.
Goodbye!: It’s true, and it’s a worthy signior.

Anon!: So do the kings of France unto this day, Howbeit they would hold up this Salic law To bar your Highness claiming from the female And rather choose to hide them in a net Than amply to imbar their crooked titles Usurped from you and your progenitors.
Goodbye!: The kings of France would hold up this Salic law to stop your Highness from claiming the female and rather hide them in a net than to imbar their crooked titles from you and your descendants.

Anon!: Therefore, dear Isis, keep decorum, and fortune him accordingly.
Goodbye!: So keep him from being greedy, Isis.

Anon!: There is, there is.
Goodbye!: There is, there is.

Anon!: That light we see is burning in my hall.
Goodbye!: The light we see is burning in my hall.

Anon!: What were his marks?
Goodbye!: What were his marks?

Anon!: True, madam.
Goodbye!: True, madam.

Anon!: You shall have some part of your will.
Goodbye!: You’ll have some part of your will.

Anon!: There is an old poor man Who after me hath many a weary step Limped in pure love.
Goodbye!: There’s a poor old man who, after me, has a long, savage step smothered in pure love.

Anon!: I will to Venice.
Goodbye!: I’ll go to Venice.

Anon!: Then say they were not slain.
Goodbye!: Then say they were not killed.

Anon!: Tomorrow night look that thou lie alone.
Goodbye!: Tomorrow night, look for yourself to lie alone.

Anon!: This way, my lord.
Goodbye!: This way, my lord.

Anon!: May be she doth but counterfeit.
Goodbye!: She may be just fake.

Anon!: This is a dear manikin to you, Sir Toby.
Goodbye!: This is a dear manikin to you, Sir Toby.

Anon!: Where is he?
Goodbye!: Where is he?

Anon!: The pound of flesh which I demand of him Is dearly bought.
Goodbye!: I’ve bought the pound of flesh I want from him.

Anon!: What’s this?
Goodbye!: What’s this?

Anon!: Go then and muster men, but leave behind Your son George Stanley.
Goodbye!: Go and pick men, but leave behind your son George Stanley.

Anon!: Comfort me.
Goodbye!: Be calm.

Anon!: About the wood go swifter than the wind, And Helena of Athens look thou find— All fancy-sick she is and pale of cheer, With sighs of love, that costs the fresh blood dear.
Goodbye!: The wind is faster than the wind, and Helena of Athens looks like you— She’s all savage and pale of cheer, with sighs of love, which cost the fresh blood dearly.

Anon!: Hope I may choose, sir.
Goodbye!: I hope I can choose, sir.

Anon!: No passage?
Goodbye!: No way?

Anon!: Yet I’ll not shed her blood, Nor scar that whiter skin of hers than snow And smooth as monumental alabaster.
Goodbye!: But I won’t shed her blood, nor scar her whiter skin than snow and smooth as monumental alabaster.

Anon!: No, by mine honor, madam.
Goodbye!: No, by my honor, madam.

Anon!: How now, you dog?
Goodbye!: What’s going on, you dog?

Anon!: The word is too good to paint out her wickedness.
Goodbye!: The word is too good to paint out her wickedness.

Anon!: Let husbands know Their wives have sense like them.
Goodbye!: Let’s see how their wives feel.

Anon!: Your lordship speaks most infallibly of him.
Goodbye!: Your lordship speaks infallibly of him.

Anon!: Go charge my goblins that they grind their joints With dry convulsions, shorten up their sinews With agèd cramps, and more pinch-spotted make them Than pard or cat o' mountain.
Goodbye!: Go charge my goblins to grind their joints with dry convulsions, shorten their sinews with agèd cramps, and make them more pinch-spotted than pard or cat o' mountain.

Anon!: Now, herald, are the dead numbered?
Goodbye!: Now, herald, are the dead dead?

Anon!: It looks a little paler.
Goodbye!: It looks a little paler.

Anon!: A ripe age.
Goodbye!: A ripe age.

Anon!: I know you not.
Goodbye!: I don’t know you.

Anon!: The less they deserve, the more merit is in your bounty.
Goodbye!: The less they deserve, the more you deserve.

Anon!: Thus with imagined wing our swift scene flies In motion of no less celerity Than that of thought.
Goodbye!: So, with a wing that’s imagined, our swift scene is a little more cliche than thought.

Anon!: It is written, that the shoemaker should meddle with his yard and the tailor with his last, the fisher with his pencil and the painter with his nets.
Goodbye!: It’s written that shoemaker should go with his yard and tailor with his last, the fisherman with his pencil and the painter with his nets.

Anon!: Such wind as scatters young men through the world To seek their fortunes farther than at home, Where small experience grows.
Goodbye!: The wind is spreading through the world, and young men are looking for their fortunes farther than they are at home, where small experiences grow.

Anon!: There’s my hand.
Goodbye!: Here’s my hand.

Anon!: O Jupiter, how weary are my spirits!
Goodbye!: Oh Jupiter, how tired my spirits are!

Anon!: Quarrel, sir?
Goodbye!: Quiet, sir?

Anon!: Then you are a better than the king.
Goodbye!: Then you’re better than the king.

Anon!: It weeps, it bleeds, and each new day a gash Is added to her wounds.
Goodbye!: It weeps, it bleeds, and every day she’s slain.

Anon!: For my brother, I think he holds you well, and in dearness of heart hath holp to effect your ensuing marriage—surely suit ill spent and labor ill bestowed.
Goodbye!: My brother, I think he’s good at you, and he’s a good man to help you get married.

Anon!: They did, Fluellen.
Goodbye!: They did, Fluellen.

Anon!: Madam, how like you this play?
Goodbye!: Madam, how are you doing this play?

Anon!: Would all the world but he had quite forsworn!
Goodbye!: I wish the whole world had a chance to swear he had!

Anon!: Ebbing men indeed Most often do so near the bottom run By their own fear or sloth.
Goodbye!: In fact, stealing men often do so near the bottom run by fear or a sluggish sluggish.

Anon!: You should for that have reprehended him.
Goodbye!: You should have reprehended him for that.

Anon!: I do.
Goodbye!: I do.

Anon!: You nimble lightnings, dart your blinding flames Into her scornful eyes!
Goodbye!: You nimble lightnings, dart your blinding flames into her scornful eyes!

Anon!: Tis worse than murder To do upon respect such violent outrage.
Goodbye!: It’s worse than murder to do if you respect such violent outrage.

Anon!: And Cassio killed!
Goodbye!: Cassio was killed!

Anon!: Then is he more beholding to you than I.
Goodbye!: Then he’s more loyal to you than I am.

Anon!: The galleys Have sent a dozen sequent messengers This very night at one another’s heels, And many of the consuls, raised and met, Are at the Duke’s already.
Goodbye!: The galleys have sent a dozen sequent messengers this night at one another’s heels, and many of the consuls raised and met are at the Duke’s already.

Anon!: See, they encounter thee with their hearts' thanks.
Goodbye!: They’re greeted with their hearts' thanks.

Anon!: Not a jot more, my lord.
Goodbye!: Don’t jot more, my lord.

Anon!: And I have been all this day to avoid him.
Goodbye!: And I’ve been to avoid him all day.

Anon!: I am glad of it.
Goodbye!: I’m glad about it.

Anon!: See how they kiss and court!
Goodbye!: See how they kiss and court!

Anon!: Give me thy arm.
Goodbye!: Give me your arm.

Anon!: It is, my lord.
Goodbye!: It is, my lord.

Anon!: that claims marriage of me, i could find in my heart to stay here still, and turn witch.
Goodbye!: I could find it in my heart to stay here still and turn a witch.

Anon!: But if you have a stomach, to ’t, i' God’s name: You shall have me assisting you in all.
Goodbye!: But if you have a stomach, then I’ll help you.

Anon!: Wouldst thou give 'em all?
Goodbye!: Do you want to give them all?

Anon!: Ay, and twenty such.
Goodbye!: Yes, and twenty such.

Anon!: But, God be thanked, there is no need of me, And much I need to help you, were there need.
Goodbye!: But, thank God, I wouldn’t need to help you, and I’d be able to help you if there were no need.

Anon!: Thou bring’st me out of tune.
Goodbye!: You’re bringing me out of tune.

Anon!: This cannot anger him.
Goodbye!: This can’t anger him.

Anon!: I’ll bear thy blame And take thy office from thee, on my peril.
Goodbye!: I’ll blame you and take your job from you, on my own risk.

Anon!: Yours, if you talk of tales.
Goodbye!: You, if you talk about stories.

Anon!: Hie you, make haste, for it grows very late.
Goodbye!: Hurry up, because it’s getting late.

Anon!: Open ’t, and read it.
Goodbye!: Open it, and read it.

Anon!: My master’s.
Goodbye!: My master’s house.

Anon!: Hark, canst thou hear me?
Goodbye!: Can you hear me?

Anon!: Why, go to then.
Goodbye!: Well, then.

Anon!: You know tomorrow is the wedding day.
Goodbye!: You know tomorrow is the wedding day.

Anon!: Thou hast seen a farmer’s dog bark at a beggar?
Goodbye!: Have you seen a farmer’s dog bark at a beggar?

Anon!: They’ll have me whipped for speaking true, thou'lt have me whipped for lying, and sometimes I am whipped for holding my peace.
Goodbye!: They’ll whip me for speaking true, you’ll whip me for lying, and sometimes I’ll whip me for holding my peace.

Anon!: About your years, my lord.
Goodbye!: About your years, my lord.

Anon!: But why, why, why?
Goodbye!: But why, why, why?

Anon!: The duke of Gloucester, to whom the order of the siege is given, is altogether directed by an Irishman, a very valiant gentleman, i' faith.
Goodbye!: The duke of Gloucester, whom the siege orders, is entirely directed by an Irishman, a valiant gentleman, I believe.

Anon!: If you choose that wherein I am contained, Straight shall our nuptial rites be solemnized.
Goodbye!: If you choose the place where I am, then we’ll be solemnized.

Anon!: What, must our mouths be cold?
Goodbye!: What, should our mouths be cold?

Anon!: What should such fellows as I do crawling between earth and heaven?
Goodbye!: What should I do for fellows crawling between earth and heaven?

Anon!: What now, Lucillius?
Goodbye!: What’s going on, Lucillius?

Anon!: Maud, Bridget, Marian, Ciceley, Gillian, Ginn!
Goodbye!: Maud, Bridget, Marian, Ciceley, Gillian, Ginn!

Anon!: Come down, behold no more.
Goodbye!: Come down, see no more.

Anon!: That’s strange.
Goodbye!: That’s strange.

Anon!: Stay, though thou kill me, sweet Demetrius.
Goodbye!: Stay, even though you kill me, sweet Demetrius.

Anon!: My lord, the queen would speak with you, and presently.
Goodbye!: My lord, the queen wants to speak with you now.

Anon!: What say you to a piece of beef and mustard?
Goodbye!: What do you say to a piece of beef and mustard?

Anon!: As the ox hath his bow, sir, the horse his curb, and the falcon her bells, so man hath his desires; and as pigeons bill, so wedlock would be nibbling.
Goodbye!: As the ox has his bow, sir, the horse’s curb, and the falcon’s bells, as the man has his desires, and as pigeons bill, as wedlock would be

Anon!: I will bite my thumb at them, which is a disgrace to them, if they bear it.
Goodbye!: I’ll bite my thumb at them, which is a shame to them, if they bear it.

Anon!: Sweet Sir Andrew!
Goodbye!: Sweet Sir Andrew!

Anon!: Claudio!
Goodbye!: Claudio!

Anon!: How many times shall Caesar bleed in sport, That now on Pompey’s basis lies along No worthier than the dust!
Goodbye!: How many times will Caesar bleed in sport, that now on Pompey’s basis is no worthier than the dust!

Anon!: Or any of your faction?
Goodbye!: Or any of your factions?

Anon!: And so, good Capulet—which name I tender As dearly as my own—be satisfied.
Goodbye!: And so, good Capulet—which is the name I’m tender as dearly as my own—will be satisfied.

Anon!: And you shall speak In the same pulpit whereto I am going, After my speech is ended.
Goodbye!: And you’ll speak in the same pulpit where I’m going, after my speech has ended.

Anon!: Of her society Be not afraid.
Goodbye!: Don’t be afraid of her.

Anon!: If she and I be pleased, what’s that to you?
Goodbye!: If she and I are happy, what’s that to you?

Anon!: Will you sup with me tonight, Casca?
Goodbye!: Will you sup with me tonight, Casca?

Anon!: If you should die before him, where’s her dower?
Goodbye!: If you’re going to die before him, where’s her snoring?

Anon!: I am their mother.
Goodbye!: I’m their mother.

Anon!: Since that respects and fortunes are his love, I shall not be his wife.
Goodbye!: Since respects and fortunes are his love, I won’t be his wife.

Anon!: This tempest will not give me leave to ponder On things would hurt me more.
Goodbye!: This time of year won’t give me time to think about things that would hurt me more.

Anon!: Therefore prepare thee to cut off the flesh.
Goodbye!: So prepare yourself to cut off the flesh.

Anon!: And, dying so, death is to him advantage; or not dying, the time was blessedly lost wherein such preparation was gained.
Goodbye!: And dying like that is to him.

Anon!: Let go his arm.
Goodbye!: Let go of his arm.

Anon!: I confess two sleeves.
Goodbye!: I confess two sleeves.

Anon!: She desires to speak with you in her closet ere you go to bed.
Goodbye!: She wants to speak with you in her closet before you go to bed.

Anon!: Strike!
Goodbye!: Strike!

Anon!: You are a fool.
Goodbye!: You’re a fool.

Anon!: Nay, if our wits run the wild-goose chase, I am done, for thou hast more of the wild-goose in one of thy wits than, I am sure, I have in my whole five.
Goodbye!: No, if we’re chasing wildgoose, I’m done, because you have more wildgoose in one of your wits than I have in five of my whole five.

Anon!: Is ’t possible, my lord?
Goodbye!: Is it possible, my lord?

Anon!: It is my birthday.
Goodbye!: It’s my birthday.

Anon!: Truly, the lady fathers herself.—Be happy, lady, for you are like an honorable father.
Goodbye!: You’re like an honorable father.

Anon!: Go, keep us company, And we shall make full satisfaction.— Thirty-three years have I but gone in travail Of you, my sons, and till this present hour My heavy burden ne'er deliverèd.— The Duke, my husband, and my children both, And you, the calendars of their nativity, Go to a gossips' feast, and go with me.
Goodbye!: I’ve only been working with you, my sons for thirty-three years, and until this time I’ve never delivered my burden.—The Duke, my husband, and my children both, and you, the calendars of

Anon!: Sola!
Goodbye!: Sola!

Anon!: But brother Anthony—     Come, ’tis no matter.
Goodbye!: But brother Anthony— Come on, it doesn’t matter.

Anon!: How “wear the garland”?
Goodbye!: How do you “wear the garland”?

Anon!: O true, good Catesby.
Goodbye!: Oh, true, good Catesby.

Anon!: And so far blameless proves my enterprise, That I have 'nointed an Athenian’s eyes.
Goodbye!: And so far I’ve proved my actions so far, that I’ve snorted an Athenian’s eyes.

Anon!: Your servant Kent.
Goodbye!: Your servant Kent.

Anon!: Let’s stab ourselves.
Goodbye!: Let’s stab ourselves.

Anon!: Twas this flesh begot Those pelican daughters.
Goodbye!: It was flesh that shook the pelican daughters.

Anon!: Worthy gentleman!
Goodbye!: What a worthy gentleman!

Anon!: Not I, believe me.
Goodbye!: Not me, believe me.

Anon!: My name’s Macbeth.
Goodbye!: My name’s Macbeth.

Anon!: Gracious Olivia— What do you say, Cesario?—Good my lord— My lord would speak.
Goodbye!: Gracious Olivia— What do you say, Cesario?—Good, my lord— My lord would speak.

Anon!: But for the bloody napkin?
Goodbye!: But for the bloody napkin?

Anon!: Thy garments are not spotted with our blood, Nor thou within the compass of my curse.
Goodbye!: Your clothes aren’t spotted with our blood, and you’re not in the compass of my curse.

Anon!: We are undone, lady, we are undone!
Goodbye!: We’re gone, lady, we’re gone!

Anon!: Thou villain Capulet!
Goodbye!: Capulet, you villain!

Anon!: A wretched soul, bruised with adversity We bid be quiet when we hear it cry, But were we burdened with like weight of pain, As much or more we should ourselves complain.
Goodbye!: We’re a wretched soul, bruised by adversity.

Anon!: Is not this man jealous?
Goodbye!: Isn’t this man jealous?

Anon!: Nay, pray be covered.
Goodbye!: No, please be covered.

Anon!: Take thou the bill, give me thy mete- yard, and spare not me.
Goodbye!: Take the bill, give me your yard, and don’t spare me.

Anon!: O Bottom, thou art changed!
Goodbye!: Oh Bottom, you’ve changed!

Anon!: So you walk softly, and look sweetly, and say nothing, I am yours for the walk, and especially when I walk away.
Goodbye!: So you walk softly, look sweetly, and say nothing, I’m yours for the walk, and especially when I walk away.

Anon!: Go make thyself like a nymph o' th' sea.
Goodbye!: Go make yourself like a nymph on the sea.

Anon!: Tis a hooded valor, and when it appears, it will bate.
Goodbye!: It’s a brave man, and when it appears, it’ll be a savage.

Anon!: I your commission will forthwith dispatch, And he to England shall along with you.
Goodbye!: I’ll send you your order immediately, and he’ll go to England with you.

Anon!: Therefore, patiently and yielding.
Goodbye!: So, patiently and yielding.

Anon!: Gratiano speaks an infinite deal of nothing, more than any man in all Venice.
Goodbye!: Gratiano is talking about nothing infinitely more than any man in Venice.

Anon!: Let us not leave him out.
Goodbye!: Don’t leave him out.

Anon!: Then certifies your Lordship that this night He dreamt the boar had razèd his helm Besides, he says there are two councils kept, And that may be determined at the one Which may make you and him to rue at th' other.
Goodbye!: Then you can confirm your Lordship that this night he dreamed that the boar had razed his helm.

Anon!: O perjured woman!
Goodbye!: Oh, perjured woman!

Anon!: Good.
Goodbye!: Good.

Anon!: Is ’t true, is ’t true?
Goodbye!: Is it true, is it true?

Anon!: Question enrages him.
Goodbye!: Questioning is a big deal for him.

Anon!: In Caesar’s fleet Are those that often have ’gainst Pompey fought.
Goodbye!: Caesar’s fleet are those who have often fought against Pompey.

Anon!: Therefore thou must be hanged at the state’s charge.
Goodbye!: So you have to be hanged at the state’s charge.

Anon!: Eros, thou yet behold’st me?
Goodbye!: Eros, do you see me yet?

Anon!: If you pardon, we will mend.
Goodbye!: If you pardon us, we’ll change.

Anon!: Your name, I pray you, friend?
Goodbye!: Your name, please, friend?

Anon!: There’s the cunning of it.
Goodbye!: There’s the snub of it.

Anon!: I know this, and thus I challenge it.
Goodbye!: I know this, and I’m challenging it.

Anon!: All the world desires her.
Goodbye!: The whole world wants her.

Anon!: I have been your tenant and your father’s tenant these fourscore years.
Goodbye!: I’ve been your tenant and your father’s tenant for four years.

Anon!: Fare you well.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: So shall you feel the loss, but not the friend Which you weep for.
Goodbye!: You’ll feel the loss, but not the friend you weep for.

Anon!: O, would to God that the inclusive verge Of golden metal that must round my brow Were red-hot steel to sear me to the brains!
Goodbye!: Oh, God would have the ring of golden metal that must round my brow if it were red-hot steel to get me to the brains!

Anon!: We all expect a gentle answer, Jew.
Goodbye!: We all expect a gentle answer, Jew.

Anon!: I need not to be ashamed of your Majesty, praised be God, so long as your Majesty is an honest man.
Goodbye!: I don’t need to be ashamed of your Majesty, because I’m praised as God, as long as your Majesty is an honest man.

Anon!: My lady would not lose him for more than I’ll say.
Goodbye!: My lady wouldn’t lose him for more than I’ll say.

Anon!: More, I prithee, more.
Goodbye!: More, please, more.

Anon!: I have already.
Goodbye!: I have already.

Anon!: You are a fishmonger.
Goodbye!: You’re a fish-monger.

Anon!: Well this was Signor Benedick that said so.
Goodbye!: Well, this was Signor Benedick who said that.

Anon!: In his livery Walked crowns and crownets.
Goodbye!: He walked in his livery with crowns and crownets.

Anon!: Tis now near night.
Goodbye!: It’s near night.

Anon!: There’s something else to do.
Goodbye!: There’s something else to do.

Anon!: I remember a mass of things, but nothing distinctly.
Goodbye!: I remember a lot of things, but nothing distinct.

Anon!: To anger him, we’ll have the bear again, and we will fool him black and blue.
Goodbye!: We’ll have the bear again to anger him, and we’ll fool him black and blue.

Anon!: Is ’t so, indeed?
Goodbye!: Is that true?

Anon!: Well thought on.
Goodbye!: Good idea.

Anon!: I have full cause of weeping, but this heart Shall break into a hundred thousand flaws, Or ere I’ll weep.—O Fool, I shall go mad!
Goodbye!: I have full reason to cry, but this heart will break into a hundred thousand flaws, or if I cry, I’ll cry.—O Fool, I’ll go crazy!

Anon!: No doubt but he hath got a quiet catch.
Goodbye!: No doubt he’s got a quiet catch.

Anon!: It should be—But he is drowned, and these are devils.
Goodbye!: It should be—But he’s drowned, and these are devils.

Anon!: I’ll to him.
Goodbye!: I’ll go to him.

Anon!: Another hit.
Goodbye!: Another hit.

Anon!: Burn but his books.
Goodbye!: Burn his books.

Anon!: Doth he not deserve well?
Goodbye!: Doesn’t he deserve a good deal?

Anon!: My sickness grows upon me.
Goodbye!: My sickness is getting worse.

Anon!: Shall I strike now?
Goodbye!: Should I strike now?

Anon!: We both have fed as well, and we can both Endure the winter’s cold as well as he.
Goodbye!: We both have sex as well, and we can both end up soaking up the cold winter as well as he.

Anon!: Prithee, if thou lovest me, tell me.
Goodbye!: Please tell me if you love me.

Anon!: More validity, More honorable state, more courtship lives In carrion flies than Romeo.
Goodbye!: More validity, more honorable state, more courtship lives in carrion flies than Romeo.

Anon!: Excellent good.
Goodbye!: Good.

Anon!: Go you and maintain talk with the duke, that my charity be not of him perceived.
Goodbye!: Go and talk to the duke so that my charity doesn’t be perceived by him.

Anon!: And trust me, love, in my eye so do you.
Goodbye!: And trust me, love, you do.

Anon!: Sir, you say well, and well you do conceive.
Goodbye!: Sir, you’re right, and you’re right.

Anon!: Will you speak well of him that killed your cousin?
Goodbye!: Will you speak well about the man who killed your cousin?

Anon!: Alas, he faints!
Goodbye!: Oh, he’s fainting!

Anon!: Richard loves Richard; that is, I and I.
Goodbye!: Richard loves Richard, that’s me and I.

Anon!: If it be so as so ’tis put on me— And that in way of caution—I must tell you, You do not understand yourself so clearly As it behooves my daughter and your honor.
Goodbye!: If it’s as bad as it is put on me—and that’s a caution—I must tell you, you don’t understand yourself so clearly as it is on my daughter and your honor.

Anon!: O brave new world, That has such people in ’t!
Goodbye!: Oh, brave new world, that has such people in it!

Anon!: My father Is hard at study.
Goodbye!: My father is hard at work.

Anon!: I must leave them and seek some better service.
Goodbye!: I have to leave them and seek some better service.

Anon!: And in assemblies too.
Goodbye!: And in the same way as in the same assemblies.

Anon!: This accident is not unlike my dream, Belief of it oppresses me already.
Goodbye!: This accident is not unlike my dream, because I’m already convinced that it’s happening.

Anon!: Who did strike out the light?
Goodbye!: Who did strike the light?

Anon!: This would have seemed a period To such as love not sorrow, but another To amplify too much would make much more And top extremity.
Goodbye!: This would have been a period of love, not sorrow, but another to make it even more difficult to make it even more difficult.

Anon!: But I will tarry.
Goodbye!: But I’ll tarry.

Anon!: O bitter consequence That Edward still should live “true noble prince”!
Goodbye!: Oh, it’s a bitter consequence that Edward still has to live as a “true noble prince”!

Anon!: If our eyes had authority, here they might take two thieves kissing.
Goodbye!: If our eyes had authority, they could take two thieves kissing here.

Anon!: M.O.A.I.” This simulation is not as the former, and yet to crush this a little, it would bow to me, for every one of these letters are in my name.
Goodbye!: M.O.A.I.” This is not the first one, and yet to crush this little, it would bow to me, because every one of these letters is in my name.

Anon!: Whither away?
Goodbye!: Where are you going?

Anon!: Horatio says ’tis but our fantasy And will not let belief take hold of him Touching this dreaded sight twice seen of us.
Goodbye!: Horatio says it’s only our fantasy and won’t let the belief take hold of him once he saw this dreaded sight of us.

Anon!: And for my sister and her princely sons, Be satisfied, dear God, with our true blood, Which, as thou know’st, unjustly must be spilt.
Goodbye!: And for my sister and her princely sons, be satisfied, dear God, with our true blood, which, as you know, must be spilt in unjust fashion.

Anon!: My dear lord, You know the fiery quality of the duke, How unremoveable and fixed he is In his own course.
Goodbye!: My dear lord, you know the fiery qualities of the duke, how unremoveable and stable he is in his own way.

Anon!: I will not fail.
Goodbye!: I won’t fail.

Anon!: There is your money that I had to keep.
Goodbye!: I had to keep your money.

Anon!: How say you, Signior Gremio?
Goodbye!: What do you say, Signior Gremio?

Anon!: My money is almost spent, I have been tonight exceedingly well cudgeled, and I think the issue will be I shall have so much experience for my pains.
Goodbye!: I’ve been cudgeled over tonight, and I think I’ll have so much experience for my pains.

Anon!: Thou stickest a dagger in me.
Goodbye!: You’re sticking a dagger in me.

Anon!: Had we done so at first, we had droven them home With clouts about their heads.
Goodbye!: If we did it at first, we’d drove them home with clouts about their heads.

Anon!: Let me dispute with thee of thy estate.
Goodbye!: Let me dispute your fate.

Anon!: Gentlemen, forward to the bridal dinner.
Goodbye!: Gentlemen, go ahead to the bridal dinner.

Anon!: I heard thee say even now thou lik’st not that When Cassio left my wife.
Goodbye!: I heard you say you didn’t like Cassio’s wife.

Anon!: Here comes the lady.
Goodbye!: Here comes the lady.

Anon!: But wherefore do you hold me here so long?
Goodbye!: But why are you keeping me here so long?

Anon!: Shortly shall all my labors end, and thou Shalt have the air at freedom.
Goodbye!: I’ll leave my work soon, and you’ll have the air at freedom.

Anon!: I’ll bring you thither, my lord, if you’ll vouchsafe me.
Goodbye!: I’ll bring you there, my lord, if you’re vouching for me.

Anon!: That is hot ice and wondrous strange snow.
Goodbye!: That’s hot ice and strange snow.

Anon!: How does my royal lord?
Goodbye!: How is my royal lord?

Anon!: Nothing.
Goodbye!: Nothing.

Anon!: Whither?
Goodbye!: Where?

Anon!: My mistress here lies murdered in her bed— Oh, heavens forfend!
Goodbye!: My mistress is murdered in her bed— Oh, heavens forbid!

Anon!: Who could refrain, That had a heart to love, and in that heart Courage to make ’s love known?
Goodbye!: Who could refrain from a man who had a heart to love, and who could be a good man to make the love known?

Anon!: Scurvy knave!
Goodbye!: Scurvy knave!

Anon!: I love you the better; the hearers may cry “Amen.” God match me with a good dancer!
Goodbye!: I love you the better; the listeners can cry “Amen.” God match me with a good dancer!

Anon!: Perish the man whose mind is backward now!
Goodbye!: Perish the man who’s backward now!

Anon!: No more than my residing here at Rome Might be to you in Egypt.
Goodbye!: No more than my residing here in Rome could be to you in Egypt.

Anon!: Amen, amen to that fair prayer, say I.
Goodbye!: Amen, amen to that fair prayer, say I.

Anon!: Be not so hasty to confound my meaning.
Goodbye!: Don’t be so hurry to confuse my meaning.

Anon!: If all the wine in my bottle will recover him, I will help his ague.
Goodbye!: If all the wine in my bottle will recover him, I’ll help his ague.

Anon!: Not to be endured.
Goodbye!: Not to be endured.

Anon!: Give me thy hand, Messala.
Goodbye!: Give me your hand, Messala.

Anon!: Flower of this purple dye, Hit with Cupid’s archery, Sink in apple of his eye.
Goodbye!: The purple flower, hit with Cupid’s archery, sinks in the apple of his eye.

Anon!: Fair Katherine, and most fair, Will you vouchsafe to teach a soldier terms Such as will enter at a lady’s ear And plead his love suit to her gentle heart?
Goodbye!: Oh, and I’m fair Katherine, and I’m fair, will you be tempted to teach a soldier what to say, like to say at a lady’s ear and plead to her gentle heart?

Anon!: Give me your hand.
Goodbye!: Give me your hand.

Anon!: Be it so.
Goodbye!: Be it.

Anon!: Shall, Antipholus, Even in the spring of love thy love-springs rot?
Goodbye!: Should you rot even in your love-springs?

Anon!: Thou thinkest I am in sport.
Goodbye!: You think I’m in sport.

Anon!: He is drunk now.
Goodbye!: He’s drunk now.

Anon!: I will o'erlook thy paper.
Goodbye!: I’ll look at your paper.

Anon!: You shall be soon dispatched with fair conditions.
Goodbye!: You’ll be sent soon with fair conditions.

Anon!: Where’s Antony?
Goodbye!: Where’s Antony?

Anon!: By my troth, well met.
Goodbye!: I swear, I’m very happy.

Anon!: Let us go sit here upon the church bench till two, and then all to bed.
Goodbye!: Let’s go sit here on the church bench until two, then go to bed.

Anon!: These are news indeed!
Goodbye!: Yes, these are news!

Anon!: O my daughter, Fled with a Christian!
Goodbye!: Oh, my daughter, Fled with a Christian!

Anon!: As good a gentleman as the emperor.
Goodbye!: As good a gentleman as the emperor.

Anon!: Beseech you, father.
Goodbye!: Please, father.

Anon!: There is time enough.
Goodbye!: There’s enough time.

Anon!: The  I thank you.
Goodbye!: Thank you.

Anon!: Were you by when it began?
Goodbye!: Did you come here when it started?

Anon!: Alas the day!
Goodbye!: Oh, that’s the day!

Anon!: Oh, thy vile lady!
Goodbye!: Oh, your vile lady!

Anon!: Where is she now?—What, will these hands ne'er be clean?—No more o' that, my lord, no more o' that.
Goodbye!: Where is she now?—What, will these hands never be clean?—No more than that, my lord, no more than that.

Anon!: If you would know your wronger, look on me.
Goodbye!: If you want to know what happened, look at me.

Anon!: I think He told me Paris should have married Juliet.
Goodbye!: I think he told me Paris would have married Juliet.

Anon!: Ay, my good lord.
Goodbye!: Yes, my good lord.

Anon!: I will, my liege.
Goodbye!: I will, my liege.

Anon!: Come, vial.
Goodbye!: Come on, vial.

Anon!: Go to, woman, Throw your vile guesses in the devil’s teeth From whence you have them.
Goodbye!: Go to the devil’s teeth, woman.

Anon!: For she his hairy temples then had rounded With a coronet of fresh and fragrant flowers, And that same dew, which sometime on the buds Was wont to swell like round and orient pearls, Stood now within the pretty flowerets' eyes Like tears that did their own disgrace bewail.
Goodbye!: She had rounded his hairy temples with a coronet of fresh and fragrant flowers, and that dew, which swelled around the buds like round and orientated pearls, was swollen

Anon!: The general and his wife are talking of it, And she speaks for you stoutly.
Goodbye!: The general and his wife are talking about it, and she speaks for you stoutly.

Anon!: What will I do, think’st thou?
Goodbye!: What do you think I’ll do?

Anon!: I may say “thrusting” it, For piercing steel and darts envenomèd Shall be as welcome to the ears of Brutus As tidings of this sight.
Goodbye!: I can say “thrusting” it, because piercing steel and darts envenomed will be as welcome to Brutus’s ears as the sightings.

Anon!: Not having that which, having, makes them short.
Goodbye!: Not having the one that makes them short.

Anon!: Benedicite.
Goodbye!: Benedicite.

Anon!: I prithee, foolish Greek, depart from me.
Goodbye!: Please, foolish Greek, come out of me.

Anon!: An’t please your Majesty, ’tis the gage of one that I should fight withal, if he be alive.
Goodbye!: If you’re not your Majesty, it’s the gage of one I should fight with, if he’s alive.

Anon!: Be of good cheer, youth.
Goodbye!: Be cheerful, young man.

Anon!: I am a fool To weep at what I am glad of.
Goodbye!: I’m a fool to cry at what I’m glad about.

Anon!: In such a night as this, When the sweet wind did gently kiss the trees And they did make no noise, in such a night Troilus methinks mounted the Trojan walls And sighed his soul toward the Grecian tents Where Cressid lay that night.
Goodbye!: In such a night as this, when the wind kissed the trees and didn’t make noise, in such a night, Troilus thinks the Trojan walls were mounted and sighed his soul toward the Grecia

Anon!: Ay, so I think.
Goodbye!: Yes, I think so.

Anon!: Make haste.
Goodbye!: Hurry up.

Anon!: I would he had boarded me.
Goodbye!: I wish he had sailed me.

Anon!: Far more, far more, to you do I decline.
Goodbye!: I’m refusing to do anything much more to you.

Anon!: Happily, amen!
Goodbye!: Happily, amen!

Anon!: Cassio’s a proper man.
Goodbye!: Cassio’s a good man.

Anon!: Worthily spoken, Maecenas.
Goodbye!: That’s a good thing, Maecenas.

Anon!: Twas he informed against him, And quit the house on purpose that their punishment Might have the freer course.
Goodbye!: He was told against him, and he quit the house on purpose that their punishment could be freer.

Anon!: How now?
Goodbye!: What’s going on?

Anon!: I must eat my dinner.
Goodbye!: I have to eat my dinner.

Anon!: By my troth, niece, thou wilt never get thee a husband if thou be so shrewd of thy tongue.
Goodbye!: By my side, niece, you’ll never get a husband if you’re so shrewd of your tongue.

Anon!: Sit down and rest.
Goodbye!: Sit down and rest.

Anon!: I know thee, Roderigo.
Goodbye!: I know you, Roderigo.

Anon!: But of that tomorrow, When therewithal we shall have cause of state Craving us jointly.
Goodbye!: But we’ll have to fight for the state to condemn us.

Anon!: Why, here begins his morning story right; These two Antipholuses, these two so like, And these two Dromios, one in semblance— Besides her urging of her wreck at sea— These are the parents to these children, Which accidentally are met together.
Goodbye!: Here begins his morning story.

Anon!: The sweet and bitter fool Will presently appear— The one in motley here, The other found out there.
Goodbye!: The sweet and bitter fool will appear now— The one who’s in a sleeve here, the other found out there.

Anon!: Here comes Brabantio and the valiant Moor.
Goodbye!: Here comes Brabantio and the valiant Moor.

Anon!: What says Romeo?
Goodbye!: What does Romeo say?

Anon!: First, if all obstacles were cut away And that my path were even to the crown As the ripe revenue and due of birth, Yet so much is my poverty of spirit, So mighty and so many my defects, That I would rather hide me from my greatness, Being a bark to brook no mighty sea, Than in my greatness covet to be hid And in the vapor of my glory smothered.
Goodbye!: First, if all obstacles were cut away and my path would be to the crown as the ripe income and due of birth, so much is my lack of spirit, so powerful and so many my defects, that I would rather hide

Anon!: Hang him, Jack!
Goodbye!: Hang him, Jack!

Anon!: Unbutton here.
Goodbye!: Unbutton here.

Anon!: All which time Before the gods my knee shall bow my prayers To them for you.
Goodbye!: I’ll be praying for you all the time before the gods.

Anon!: O nuncle, court holy water in a dry house is better than this rainwater out o' door.
Goodbye!: Oh, nuncle, courting holy water in a dry house is better than letting this rain out of the door.

Anon!: Do this suddenly, And let not search and inquisition quail To bring again these foolish runaways.
Goodbye!: Do this suddenly, and don’t go search and inquisition to bring back these foolish runaways.

Anon!: A noble duke, in nature As in name.
Goodbye!: A noble duke, as nature as in name.

Anon!: No?
Goodbye!: No?

Anon!: The sun will not be seen today.
Goodbye!: The sun will not be seen today.

Anon!: Ay, forsooth.
Goodbye!: Yes, forsooth.

Anon!: He did, and from my finger snatched that ring.
Goodbye!: He did, and he snatched that ring from my finger.

Anon!: Blistered be thy tongue For such a wish!
Goodbye!: You’ve been beaten up for such a wish!

Anon!: Well, I would you did like me.
Goodbye!: Well, I wish you liked me.

Anon!: What, did they never whisper?
Goodbye!: Didn’t they ever whisper?

Anon!: Peace, fool.
Goodbye!: Be quiet, fool.

Anon!: He is as full of valor as of kindness, Princely in both.
Goodbye!: He’s as brave as a kind man, Princely in both of them.

Anon!: Then be thou jocund.
Goodbye!: Then be a jocund.

Anon!: We must have your doublet and hose plucked over your head and show the world what the bird hath done to her own nest.
Goodbye!: We have to have your hose and doublets plucked over your head and show the world what the bird has done to her own nest.

Anon!: The spirit of my father grows strong in me, and I will no longer endure it.
Goodbye!: My father’s spirit is strong in me, and I won’t endure it anymore.

Anon!: The fearful passage of their death-marked love And the continuance of their parents' rage, Which, but their children’s end, naught could remove, Is now the two hours' traffic of our stage— The which, if you with patient ears attend, What here shall miss, our toil shall strive to mend.
Goodbye!: The fearful passage of their death-marked love and the continuance of their parents’ rage, which, but their children’s end, could remove, is now the two hours' traffic of our stage—the one that,

Anon!: They must take it in sense that feel it.
Goodbye!: They must take it in the sense that they feel it.

Anon!: He died As one that had been studied in his death To throw away the dearest thing he owed As ’twere a careless trifle.
Goodbye!: He died as a man who had been taught to throw away the most precious thing he owed as a savage king.

Anon!: So will it fare with Claudio.
Goodbye!: And it will do with Claudio.

Anon!: I never saw the chain, so help me heaven, And this is false you burden me withal.
Goodbye!: I never saw the necklace, so help me heaven, and this is false you’re burdening me with.

Anon!: I will set down what comes from her, to satisfy my remembrance the more strongly.
Goodbye!: I’ll tell you what she’s saying, to make sure I remember her more deeply.

Anon!: I shall return before your Lordship thence.
Goodbye!: I’ll go back to your Lordship.

Anon!: In truth, I know it is a sin to be a mocker, but he!—why, he hath a horse better than the Neapolitan’s, a better bad habit of frowning than the Count Palatine.
Goodbye!: I know it’s a sin to be a mocker, but he!—why, he’s a better horse than the Neapolitan’s, a better bad habit of frowning than

Anon!: Did you know him?
Goodbye!: Did you know him?

Anon!: What’s the news with thee?
Goodbye!: What’s the news with you?

Anon!: Then I salute you with this royal title: Long live Richard, England’s worthy king!
Goodbye!: Then I salute you with this royal title: long live Richard, England’s worthy king!

Anon!: What would you have?
Goodbye!: What do you want?

Anon!: Tell thou the tale!
Goodbye!: Tell me the story!

Anon!: Is my lord angry?
Goodbye!: Is my lord angry?

Anon!: We have beat him to his camp.
Goodbye!: We’ve beat him to his camp.

Anon!: Tom, away!
Goodbye!: Tom, let’s go!

Anon!: Master, master, look about you.
Goodbye!: Master, master, look at you.

Anon!: If that thou be’st a devil, I cannot kill thee.
Goodbye!: If you’re a devil, I can’t kill you.

Anon!: If she will stir hither, I shall seem to notify unto her.
Goodbye!: If she’s going to stir up here, I’ll tell her.

Anon!: Eyes, do you see?
Goodbye!: Eyes, do you see?

Anon!: Kind Tyrrel, am I happy in thy news?
Goodbye!: Kind Tyrrel, am I happy with your news?

Anon!: But that, forsooth, the bouncing Amazon, Your buskined mistress and your warrior love, To Theseus must be wedded, and you come To give their bed joy and prosperity.
Goodbye!: But forsooth, the bouncing Amazon, your savage mistress and your warrior love, Theseus must be wedded and you come to give them joy and prosperity.

Anon!: I was not angry since I came to France Until this instant.
Goodbye!: I was not angry since I came to France until this moment.

Anon!: Or as ’twere perfumed by a fen.
Goodbye!: Or as if it were perfumed by a fen.

Anon!: He should, for that, commit your godfathers.
Goodbye!: He should, for that, commit your godfathers.

Anon!: I speak in understanding.
Goodbye!: I’m talking about it.

Anon!: Young son, it argues a distempered head So soon to bid good morrow to thy bed.
Goodbye!: Young son, it’s a slur of a distempered head so soon to give you a good morning to your bed.

Anon!: Within my tent his bones tonight shall lie Most like a soldier, ordered honorably.
Goodbye!: I’ll lay his bones in my tent tonight, like a soldier, or ordered honorably.

Anon!: What you know, you know.
Goodbye!: You know what you know, you know.

Anon!: Why came I hither but to that intent?
Goodbye!: Why did I come here to do that?

Anon!: How is it else the “man i' th' moon”?
Goodbye!: How is it the “man in the moon”?

Anon!: That’s all.
Goodbye!: That’s all.

Anon!: Why grow the branches when the root is gone?
Goodbye!: Why are the branches growing when the root is gone?

Anon!: Why, I am sure, if he forfeit thou wilt not take his flesh.
Goodbye!: I’m sure if he loses his flesh, you won’t take it.

Anon!: No more light answers.
Goodbye!: No more light answers.

Anon!: Bliss be upon you!
Goodbye!: Bliss be on you!

Anon!: Masters, the duke is coming from the temple, and there is two or three lords and ladies more married.
Goodbye!: Master, the duke is coming from the temple, and there are two or three more lords and ladies married.

Anon!: Swear by my sword Never to speak of this that you have heard.
Goodbye!: Swear by my sword never to speak about what you’ve heard.

Anon!: He hath a heart as sound as a bell, and his tongue is the clapper, for what his heart thinks, his tongue speaks.
Goodbye!: He has a heart as sound as a bell, and his tongue is the clapper, because what his heart thinks, his tongue speaks.

Anon!: Stop in your wind, sir.
Goodbye!: Stop in the wind, sir.

Anon!: No?
Goodbye!: No?

Anon!: Let’s make us med'cines of our great revenge, To cure this deadly grief.
Goodbye!: Let’s make us med’cines of our great revenge, to cure this deadly grief.

Anon!: Return with her?
Goodbye!: Come with her?

Anon!: Tybalt, my cousin!
Goodbye!: Tybalt, my cousin!

Anon!: Though this island seem to be desert—
Goodbye!: Though this island seems to be deserted—

Anon!: Give to a gracious message An host of tongues, but let ill tidings tell Themselves when they be felt.
Goodbye!: Give a gracious message to a host of tongues, but let ill-tipped tidbits tell Themselves when they feel.

Anon!: Within this three mile may you see it coming; I say, a moving grove.
Goodbye!: Within a mile you can see it coming, I say, a moving grove.

Anon!: Marry, before your ladyship, I grant, She puts her tongue a little in her heart And chides with thinking.
Goodbye!: I swear, before your ladyship, she puts her tongue in her heart and chides her with thinking.

Anon!: But no more deep will I endart mine eye Than your consent gives strength to make it fly.
Goodbye!: But I won’t let my eyes go deeper than your consent gives you strength to make it fly.

Anon!: Nay, yet there’s more in this.
Goodbye!: But there’s more to this.

Anon!: Tempt him not so too far.
Goodbye!: Don’t get him so far.

Anon!: I mean in singing.
Goodbye!: I mean singing.

Anon!: What day is this?
Goodbye!: What day is this?

Anon!: All these old witnesses—I cannot err— Tell me thou art my son Antipholus.
Goodbye!: All these old witnesses—I can’t err—tell me you’re my son Antipholus.

Anon!: Prithee bear some charity to my wit.
Goodbye!: Please give me some charity.

Anon!: To express the like kindness, myself, that have been more kindly beholding to you than any, freely give unto you this young scholar
Goodbye!: I’ve been more generous to you than any other person, and I’ll give this young scholar to you.

Anon!: For our losses, his exchequer is too poor; for th' effusion of our blood, the muster of his kingdom too faint a number; and for our disgrace, his own person, kneeling at our feet but a weak and worthless satisfaction.
Goodbye!: For our losses, his savage is too poor, for our blood savage, the savage of his kingdom too faint, and for our disgrace, his own person kneeling at our feet only with

Anon!: How wilt thou do for a father?
Goodbye!: How are you going to do for a father?

Anon!: I pray you, dissuade him from her.
Goodbye!: Please, dissuade him from her.

Anon!: Doth it?
Goodbye!: Is it?

Anon!: I can read.
Goodbye!: I can read.

Anon!: Speak it again and, even with the word, This hand, which for thy love did kill thy love, Shall for thy love kill a far truer love.
Goodbye!: Speak it again and, even with the word, this hand, which kills your love for you, will kill your truer love for you.

Anon!: He says, my lord, your daughter is not well.
Goodbye!: He says your daughter is not well, my lord.

Anon!: Ah, women, women!
Goodbye!: Ah, women, women!

Anon!: Why, go to bed, and sleep.
Goodbye!: Go to bed and sleep.

Anon!: Sir, fare you well.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, sir.

Anon!: I think withal There would be hands uplifted in my right; And here from gracious England have I offer Of goodly thousands.
Goodbye!: I think I’d be uplifted to my right, and I’d offer thousands of dollars here from gracious England.

Anon!: Our fortune on the sea is out of breath And sinks most lamentably.
Goodbye!: Our fortune on the sea is out of breath and sinks in a terrible way.

Anon!: What say you?
Goodbye!: What do you say?

Anon!: And is he a man to encounter Tybalt?
Goodbye!: And is he a man who wants to meet Tybalt?

Anon!: Marry, come up, I trow.
Goodbye!: Come on, I’ll trow.

Anon!: Madam, in Rome.
Goodbye!: Madam, in Rome.

Anon!: Content with Hermia?
Goodbye!: What’s the difference between Hermia and her?

Anon!: Come on.
Goodbye!: Come on.

Anon!: How comes it now, my husband, O, how comes it That thou art thus estranged from thyself?
Goodbye!: How are you getting so upset, husband, how are you?

Anon!: Tis here.
Goodbye!: It’s here.

Anon!: But Oh, how bitter a thing it is to look into happiness through another man’s eyes.
Goodbye!: But how bitter it is to look at happiness through another man’s eyes.

Anon!: I would not hear your enemy say so, Nor shall you do mine ear that violence, To make it truster of your own report Against yourself.
Goodbye!: I wouldn’t hear your enemy say that, and you won’t hear that violence, to make it trust you’re a victim of your own report.

Anon!: But for the stuffing—well, we are all mortal.
Goodbye!: But for the stuffing—well, we’re all mortal.

Anon!: If Caesar had stabbed their mothers they would have done no less.
Goodbye!: If Caesar had stabbed their mothers, they would have done nothing less.

Anon!: What did thy song bode, lady?
Goodbye!: What did your song do, lady?

Anon!: You say not right, old man.
Goodbye!: You’re not saying that, old man.

Anon!: The clerk is answered.
Goodbye!: The clerk is answering.

Anon!: I will deserve your pains.
Goodbye!: I’ll deserve your help.

Anon!: Think not I love him, though I ask for him.
Goodbye!: Don’t think I love him, even if I ask for him.

Anon!: Return you to my sister.
Goodbye!: Return to my sister.

Anon!: He attendeth here hard by To know your answer whether you’ll admit him.
Goodbye!: He’s waiting here hard to tell you whether you’ll accept him.

Anon!: She has deceived her father, and may thee.
Goodbye!: She’s fooled her father, and you may.

Anon!: I’ll serve you, sir, five hundred at the rate.
Goodbye!: I’ll serve you five hundred.

Anon!: What he hath lost, noble Macbeth hath won.
Goodbye!: What he lost, noble Macbeth has won.

Anon!: What’s your name, friend?
Goodbye!: What’s your name, friend?

Anon!: How fares my Juliet?
Goodbye!: How is my Juliet?

Anon!: There’s a division betwixt the dukes.
Goodbye!: There’s a division between the dukes.

Anon!: My lord, when at their home I did commend your highness' letters to them.
Goodbye!: My lord, when I arrived at their home I gave them your highness’ letters.

Anon!: Then he shall have no odds.
Goodbye!: Then he’ll have no chance.

Anon!: What “quality”?
Goodbye!: What “quality”?

Anon!: Well, I know not What counts harsh Fortune casts upon my face, But in my bosom shall she never come To make my heart her vassal.
Goodbye!: Well, I don’t know what the harsh Fortune casts on my face, but I’ll never come to make my heart cry.

Anon!: In debating which was best, we shall part with neither.
Goodbye!: We’ll not discuss what was best for us.

Anon!: Show me the place.
Goodbye!: Show me the place.

Anon!: Ah, my back, my back!
Goodbye!: Oh, my back, my back!

Anon!: The business of the state does him offence, And he does chide with you.
Goodbye!: The state’s business makes him offended, and he’s scolding you.

Anon!: No, no.
Goodbye!: No, no.

Anon!: Am I a married man or a bachelor?
Goodbye!: Am I a married man or a bachelor?

Anon!: But there’s no goodness in thy face—if Antony Be free and healthful, so tart a favor To trumpet such good tidings!
Goodbye!: But there’s no good in your face—if Antony is free and healthy, he’ll do a good favor to trumpet such good news!

Anon!: O sir, fly this place.
Goodbye!: Oh, sir, go fly this place.

Anon!: With an eye of green in ’t.
Goodbye!: With a green eye in it.

Anon!: I know not, Menas, How lesser enmities may give way to greater.
Goodbye!: I don’t know how lesser enmities can give way to greater.

Anon!: All this is so, but what of this, my lord?
Goodbye!: All this is true, but what about it, my lord?

Anon!: Under what title shall I woo for thee, That God, the law, my honor and her love Can make seem pleasing to her tender years?
Goodbye!: What title should I give you, so God, the law, my honor and her love can make her tender years look like a joy?

Anon!: Who comes here?
Goodbye!: Who’s coming?

Anon!: Who governs here?
Goodbye!: Who’s going to govern here?

Anon!: Say what you will, sir, but I know what I know.
Goodbye!: Say what you want, sir, but I know what I know.

Anon!: Or like a whale.
Goodbye!: Or like a whale.

Anon!: Content you, gentlemen.
Goodbye!: Let’s go, gentlemen.

Anon!: But what of that?
Goodbye!: But what about that?

Anon!: I thank his Grace.
Goodbye!: Thank his Grace.

Anon!: Come, my sweet Kate.
Goodbye!: Come on, my sweet Kate.

Anon!: I saw him put down the other day with an ordinary fool that
Goodbye!: I saw him put down the other day with a fool

Anon!: But will my Rosalind do so?
Goodbye!: But will my Rosalind do that?

Anon!: If thou say so, villain, Thou kill’st thy mistress.
Goodbye!: If you say that, villain, you’ll kill your mistress.

Anon!: Music, hark.
Goodbye!: Listen to music.

Anon!: Returned so soon?
Goodbye!: Returned so soon?

Anon!: Now, Antony, our hopes are answerèd.
Goodbye!: Now, Antony, we’re ready to do what we want.

Anon!: I told you, sir, they were red-hot with drinking, So full of valor that they smote the air For breathing in their faces, beat the ground For kissing of their feet—yet always bending Towards their project.
Goodbye!: I told you, sir, they were red-hot with drinking, so full of valor that they smote the air for breathing in their faces, beat the ground for kissing their feet—and always bend towards their project

Anon!: But we are prevented.
Goodbye!: But we’re not allowed.

Anon!: Why, how now, Charmian?
Goodbye!: What’s going on, Charmian?

Anon!: Signor Antonio Commends him to you.
Goodbye!: Signor Antonio praises you.

Anon!: Now, unto thy bones good night!
Goodbye!: Now, good night to your bones!

Anon!: Tis death to me to be at enmity; I hate it, and desire all good men’s love.
Goodbye!: I hate it, and I want all good men’s love.

Anon!: Where is Metellus Cimber?
Goodbye!: Where is Metellus Cimber?

Anon!: My words are dull.
Goodbye!: My words are dull.

Anon!: Here was a Caesar!
Goodbye!: Here was a Caesar!

Anon!: No, no, no, no!
Goodbye!: No, no, no, no!

Anon!: Dear, they durst not, So dear the love my people bore me, nor set A mark so bloody on the business, but With colors fairer painted their foul ends.
Goodbye!: Dear, they wouldn’t, and I didn’t, because my people bore me, or put a mark on the business so bloody, but with more fairness, they painted their ugly ends.

Anon!: That is done, sir.
Goodbye!: That’s done, sir.

Anon!: What is yond gentleman?
Goodbye!: What do you mean by gentleman?

Anon!: When the moon shone we did not see the candle.
Goodbye!: When the moon shone, we didn’t see the candle.

Anon!: Caesar, all hail!
Goodbye!: Caesar, all hail!

Anon!: How sound is she asleep!
Goodbye!: How sound asleep she is!

Anon!: But who comes here?
Goodbye!: But who’s coming?

Anon!: Stand up.
Goodbye!: Stand up.

Anon!: I do not understand.
Goodbye!: I don’t understand.

Anon!: May we do so?
Goodbye!: Can we do that?

Anon!: The tyranny of the open night’s too rough For nature to endure.
Goodbye!: The night’s too rough for nature to endure.

Anon!: Let him alone.
Goodbye!: Leave him alone.

Anon!: How does my good Lord Hamlet?
Goodbye!: How is my good Lord Hamlet?

Anon!: O thou pernicious caitiff!
Goodbye!: Oh, you sane caitiff!

Anon!: Of lusty earls: Grandpré and Roussi, Faulconbridge and Foix, Beaumont and Marle, Vaudemont and Lestrale.
Goodbye!: Of lusty earls: Grandpré and Roussi, Faulconbridge and Foix, Beaumont and Marle, Vaudemont and Lestrale.

Anon!: Let me deal in this.
Goodbye!: Let me deal with this.

Anon!: Yea, very force entangles Itself with strength.
Goodbye!: Yes, very force forces itself.

Anon!: Go, then, for ’tis in vain To seek him here that means not to be found.
Goodbye!: Go, then, because it’s in vain to find him here that doesn’t mean to be found.

Anon!: O’er my spirit Thy full supremacy thou knew’st, and that Thy beck might from the bidding of the gods Command me.
Goodbye!: Oh, my spirit, you knew your full power, and that you could command me from the gods’ bid.

Anon!: The Queen shall then have courtesy, so she Will yield us up?
Goodbye!: The Queen will be kindly, so she’ll give us up?

Anon!: His son was but a ward two years ago.
Goodbye!: His son was only a ward two years ago.

Anon!: Speak, speak!
Goodbye!: Speak, speak!

Anon!: Is not this true?
Goodbye!: Isn’t that true?

Anon!: Therefore give me no counsel.
Goodbye!: So don’t give me any advice.

Anon!: The cords That Romeo bid thee fetch?
Goodbye!: The cords Romeo told you to get?

Anon!: Wipe thine eyes.
Goodbye!: Wipe your eyes.

Anon!: Do you know me, my lord?
Goodbye!: Do you know me, my lord?

Anon!: Hast thou slain Tybalt?
Goodbye!: Have you killed Tybalt?

Anon!: My lord, I have considered in my mind The late request that you did sound me in.
Goodbye!: My lord, I’ve been thinking about the late request you made for me to be in.

Anon!: O these deliberate fools!
Goodbye!: Oh, these deliberate fools!

Anon!: But Macbeth is.
Goodbye!: But Macbeth is.

Anon!: Vouchsafe, divine perfection of a woman, Of these supposèd crimes to give me leave By circumstance but to acquit myself.
Goodbye!: I’m not allowed to acquit myself, but to be a woman.

Anon!: May one be pardoned and retain th' offense?
Goodbye!: Can one be pardoned and keep the offense alive?

Anon!: Have you no more to say?
Goodbye!: Don’t you have anything to say?

Anon!: Benvolio, who began this bloody fray?
Goodbye!: Benvolio, who started this bloody fight?

Anon!: Welcome.
Goodbye!: Welcome.

Anon!: I pray you leave me.
Goodbye!: Please leave me.

Anon!: Who was it?
Goodbye!: Who was it?

Anon!: And so perchance may he be.
Goodbye!: And so perchance can he be.

Anon!: Tush, thou art deceived.
Goodbye!: You’re wrong.

Anon!: What may I call your name?
Goodbye!: What can I call your name?

Anon!: The fire seven times tried this, Seven times tried that judgment is, That did never choose amiss.
Goodbye!: The fire has tried this seven times, seven times the judgment is, and never the fire has been a bad one.

Anon!: Why, he shall never wake until the great Judgment Day.
Goodbye!: Why, he’ll never wake up until the great Judgment Day.

Anon!: Tis good we do so.
Goodbye!: It’s good we do so.

Anon!: Added to these, Of knights, esquires, and gallant gentlemen, Eight thousand and four hundred, of the which, Five hundred were but yesterday dubbed knights.
Goodbye!: Eight thousand and four hundred knights, esquires, and gallant gentlemen, among which five hundred were dubbed knights yesterday.

Anon!: I promise you, my soul is very jocund In the remembrance of so fair a dream.
Goodbye!: I promise you, my soul is very sluggish in the memory of such a fair dream.

Anon!: You are not Pinch’s patient, are you, sir?
Goodbye!: You’re not Pinch’s patient, are you, sir?

Anon!: How now, my lord!
Goodbye!: What’s going on, my lord?

Anon!: No, my dearest love, I would not for the world.
Goodbye!: No, my dearest love, I wouldn’t want to go for the world.

Anon!: Amen!
Goodbye!: Amen!

Anon!: Tis in ourselves that we are thus or thus.
Goodbye!: We’re either here or here.

Anon!: I pray you, choose another subject.
Goodbye!: Please, choose another subject.

Anon!: This is a fellow of the selfsame color Our sister speaks of.—Come, bring away the stocks!
Goodbye!: This is a fellow of the same color that our sister speaks of.—Come, bring away the stocks!

Anon!: Never make denial.
Goodbye!: Don’t make denial.

Anon!: Adieu.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: My services to your lordship.
Goodbye!: My services to your lordship.

Anon!: Ay me, what news?
Goodbye!: Yes, what news do you have?

Anon!: But stop my house’s ears—I mean my casements— Let not the sound of shallow foppery enter My sober house.
Goodbye!: But stop my house’s ears—I mean my casements—and let the sound of a shallow foppery not enter my sober house.

Anon!: He never did harm that I heard of.
Goodbye!: He never did harm that I heard of.

Anon!: She’s desperate.
Goodbye!: She’s desperate.

Anon!: It is, my lord.
Goodbye!: It is, my lord.

Anon!: From Silvius, sir.
Goodbye!: From Silvius, sir.

Anon!: I will run.
Goodbye!: I’ll run.

Anon!: I’ll put ’t in proof.
Goodbye!: I’ll put it in proof.

Anon!: Come, come, dispatch.
Goodbye!: Come, come, dispatch.

Anon!: Your crown’s awry.
Goodbye!: Your crown is wry.

Anon!: Go to, they are not men o' their words.
Goodbye!: Go, they’re not men.

Anon!: Thou shalt be lord of it and I’ll serve thee.
Goodbye!: You’ll be the lord of it, and I’ll serve you.

Anon!: The gray-eyed morn smiles on the frowning night, Checkering the eastern clouds with streaks of light, And fleckled darkness like a drunkard reels From forth day’s path and Titan’s fiery wheels.
Goodbye!: The gray-eyed morn smiles on the frowning night, checking the eastern clouds with streaks of light, and fleckled darkness like a drunken reels from the day’s path and Titan’s fier

Anon!: Yea, marry, that’s the eftest way.—Let the watch come forth.
Goodbye!: Yes, marry, that’s the eftest way.—Let the watch come out.

Anon!: So I am—to let him live.
Goodbye!: I am—to let him live.

Anon!: He, of all the men that ever my foolish eyes looked upon, was the best deserving a fair lady.
Goodbye!: He was the best lady to be able to be a fair lady.

Anon!: Be thy mouth or black or white,  Do-de, de-de.
Goodbye!: Be your mouth or black or white, Do-de, de-de.

Anon!: May we be gone?
Goodbye!: Can we go?

Anon!: Madam, the young gentleman of the Count Orsino’s is returned.
Goodbye!: Madam, the young gentleman of the Count Orsino’s is back.

Anon!: If I do so, it will be of more price Being spoke behind your back than to your face.
Goodbye!: If I do so, it’ll be more expensive to be slammed behind your back than to your face.

Anon!: Who chooseth me must give and hazard all he hath.” You shall look fairer ere I give or hazard.
Goodbye!: Who chooses me must give and hazard all he has.” You’ll look more fair when I give or hazard.

Anon!: That high All-seer which I dallied with Hath turned my feignèd prayer on my head And given in earnest what I begged in jest.
Goodbye!: That high all-seer I dallied with turned my feigny prayer on my head and gave me the skepticism I begged.

Anon!: Now Romeo is beloved and loves again, Alike bewitchèd by the charm of looks, But to his foe supposed he must complain, And she steal love’s sweet bait from fearful hooks.
Goodbye!: Romeo is now beloved and loves again, as if he was beaten by the charm of looks, but he’s supposed to complain to his foe, and she steals love’s sweet bait from fearful hook

Anon!: Let’s all sink wi' th' king.
Goodbye!: Let’s all sink into the king’s seat.

Anon!: Not for Cadwallader and all his goats.
Goodbye!: Not for Cadwallader and all his goats.

Anon!: Away with the joint-stools, remove the court-cupboard, look to the plate.
Goodbye!: Take the stools away, remove the stools on the courtboard, and look at the plate.

Anon!: I’ll bury thee in a triumphant grave.
Goodbye!: I’ll bury you in a triumphant grave.

Anon!: I must attend mine office, Or would have done ’t myself.
Goodbye!: I must attend my office or would have done it myself.

Anon!: Not I.
Goodbye!: Not me.

Anon!: Take up those cords.—Poor ropes, you are beguiled, Both you and I, for Romeo is exiled.
Goodbye!: Take up those cords.—Poor ropes, you are beguiled, both you and I, because Romeo is exiled.

Anon!: You come with letters against the king and take Vanity the puppet’s part against the royalty of her father.
Goodbye!: You’re coming with letters against the king and you’re taking the puppet’s part against the royalty of her father.

Anon!: Alas, too soon We came aboard.
Goodbye!: Oh, we came aboard too soon.

Anon!: Could you not take some occasion without giving?
Goodbye!: Don’t you have to give up?

Anon!: His eyes were green as leeks.
Goodbye!: His eyes were green as leeks.

Anon!: Oh, no.
Goodbye!: Oh no.

Anon!: To what end?
Goodbye!: What do you want?

Anon!: Contending with the fretful elements.
