Goodbye!: Contending with the fretful elements.

Anon!: But ere they came,–O, let me say no more!
Goodbye!: But they came, let me say no more!

Anon!: Perdition catch my soul But I do love thee!
Goodbye!: Perdition will catch my soul, but I love you!

Anon!: Upon what cause?
Goodbye!: What cause?

Anon!: Out upon her!
Goodbye!: Out on her!

Anon!: Even so quickly may one catch the plague?
Goodbye!: Can one catch the plague so quickly?

Anon!: Signior Baptista, will you be so strange?
Goodbye!: Signior Baptista, will you be so strange?

Anon!: And from hence I go To make these doubts all even.
Goodbye!: And now I’m going to make sure all these doubts are resolved.

Anon!: For the heavens, rouse up a brave mind,” says the fiend, “and run.” Well, my conscience, hanging about the neck of my heart, says very wisely to me, “My honest friend Launcelot, being an honest man’s son”—or rather an honest woman’s son, for indeed my father did something smack, something grow to.
Goodbye!: For the heavens, rouse a brave mind,” says the fiend, “and run.” Well, my conscience, hanging around my heart, says very wisely to me, “My honest friend Launcelot, being an

Anon!: Romeo must not live.
Goodbye!: Romeo must not live.

Anon!: Pish!
Goodbye!: Pish!

Anon!: I dare not, dear, Dear my lord, pardon, I dare not, Lest I be taken.
Goodbye!: I don’t dare, dear, dear, dear lord, pardon me, I don’t dare, so I won’t be taken.

Anon!: Ay, two hours together.
Goodbye!: Yes, we’re talking for two hours.

Anon!: As if that name, Shot from the deadly level of a gun, Did murder her, as that name’s cursed hand Murdered her kinsman.
Goodbye!: As if that name, shot from the deadly level of a gun, killed her, as if that name’s cursed hand killed her kinsman.

Anon!: Most gracious majesty!
Goodbye!: Most gracious majesty!

Anon!: If consequence do but approve my dream My boat sails freely, both with wind and stream.
Goodbye!: If I’m not happy with my dream, my boat will sail freely, both with wind and stream.

Anon!: Help me into some house, Benvolio, Or I shall faint.
Goodbye!: Help me get some house, Benvolio, or I’ll faint.

Anon!: You think I’ll weep?
Goodbye!: You think I’ll cry?

Anon!: Plain and not honest is too harsh a style.
Goodbye!: Plain and not honest is too harsh.

Anon!: Hero thinks surely she will die, for she says she will die if he love her not, and she will die ere she make her love known, and she will die if he woo her rather than she will bate one breath of her accustomed crossness.
Goodbye!: Hero thinks she will die, because she says she will die if he doesn’t love her, and she will die if she tells her her love, and she will die if he woos her rather

Anon!: Did ever Dian so become a grove As Kate this chamber with her princely gait?
Goodbye!: Did Dian ever become a grove as a grove as Kate in this chamber with her princely gait?

Anon!: Captain Macmorris, I think, look you, under your correction, there is not many of your nation—  Of my nation?
Goodbye!: Captain Macmorris, I think, look, under your correction, there aren’t many of your nation—of my nation?

Anon!: You make me study of that.
Goodbye!: You’re making me study that.

Anon!: Ye say honestly.
Goodbye!: You’re right.

Anon!: Open the tomb.
Goodbye!: Open the tomb.

Anon!: Well said, old mole!
Goodbye!: Well said, old mole!

Anon!: Mutton?
Goodbye!: Mutton?

Anon!: Out on her, hilding!
Goodbye!: She’s out of here, hilding!

Anon!: Do you smell a fault?
Goodbye!: Do you smell a fault?

Anon!: What is the matter, husband?
Goodbye!: What’s the matter, husband?

Anon!: Good morrow, Father.
Goodbye!: Good morning, Father.

Anon!: Those uncles which you want were dangerous.
Goodbye!: The uncles you want were dangerous.

Anon!: Know’st thou not any whom corrupting gold Will tempt unto a close exploit of death?
Goodbye!: Don’t you know anyone who’ll kill you by stealing gold?

Anon!: Be it as you shall privately determine, Either for her stay or going.
Goodbye!: Whatever you decide privately, whether it’s for her stay or for her trip.

Anon!: The odds is gone, And there is nothing left remarkable Beneath the visiting moon.
Goodbye!: The odds are gone, and nothing remarkable has been left over the moon.

Anon!: If any be Trinculo’s legs, these are they.
Goodbye!: If any of them are Trinculo’s legs, these are.

Anon!: Let him command, And to obey shall be in me remorse, What bloody business ever.
Goodbye!: Let him command, and obeying will be my remorse, what bloody business he’s ever had.

Anon!: It seems he hath great care to please his wife.
Goodbye!: It seems he’s taken great care of his wife.

Anon!: He dies!
Goodbye!: He dies!

Anon!: Wrong hath but wrong, and blame the due of blame.
Goodbye!: It’s wrong, but it’s wrong.

Anon!: I pray you, pass with your best violence.
Goodbye!: Please, pass with your best violence.

Anon!: This did I fear, but thought he had no weapon, For he was great of heart.
Goodbye!: I was afraid of this, but I thought he had no weapon, because he was very hearty.

Anon!: It does, my boy.
Goodbye!: It’s true, my boy.

Anon!: He’s no standard.
Goodbye!: He’s not a standard.

Anon!: Had my lips that power, Thus would I wear them out.
Goodbye!: If my lips were so powerful, I would wear them out.

Anon!: Had you such leisure in the time of death To gaze upon the secrets of the deep?
Goodbye!: Have you been able to relax in the moment of death to look at the deep secrets?

Anon!: Tell me, and dally not: where is the money?
Goodbye!: Tell me, and don’t dally: where is the money?

Anon!: This is the very ecstasy of love, Whose violent property fordoes itself And leads the will to desperate undertakings As oft as any passion under heaven That does afflict our natures.
Goodbye!: This is the ecstasy of love, who has fordoes violent property and leads the will to desperate undertakings as often as any passion under heaven that affects our nature.

Anon!: Do not fear our person.
Goodbye!: Don’t worry about our person.

Anon!: Hark thee, Dardanius.
Goodbye!: Listen, Dardanius.

Anon!: Go, sirrah, trudge about Through fair Verona.
Goodbye!: Go, sir, trudge around through fair Verona.

Anon!: Besides, it should appear that if he had The present money to discharge the Jew, He would not take it.
Goodbye!: Besides, it should appear that if he had the money to pay the Jew, he wouldn’t take it.

Anon!: Tomorrow will it please you to be crowned?
Goodbye!: Will it be yours to be crowned tomorrow?

Anon!: Like to the time o’ th’ year between the extremes Of hot and cold, he was nor sad nor merry.
Goodbye!: He was neither sad nor merry at all.

Anon!: What say you then to Falconbridge, the young baron of England?
Goodbye!: What do you say then to Falconbridge, the young baron of England?

Anon!: Is ink and paper ready?
Goodbye!: Is ink and paper ready?

Anon!: Yea, wherefore should she not?
Goodbye!: Yes, why shouldn’t she?

Anon!: An I may hide my face, let me play Thisbe too!
Goodbye!: If I can hide my face, let me play Thisbe too!

Anon!: She is indeed perfection.
Goodbye!: She’s really perfection.

Anon!: You are to blame, my lord, to rate her so.
Goodbye!: You’re to blame for not telling her to.

Anon!: By the fire That quickens Nilus’ slime, I go from hence Thy soldier, servant, making peace or war As thou affects.
Goodbye!: By the fire that makes Nilus’s slime, I’m going from here to your soldier, servant, making peace or war as you affect.

Anon!: What shall I swear by?
Goodbye!: What should I swear by?

Anon!: O, sixpence, that I had o' Wednesday last To pay the saddler for my mistress' crupper?
Goodbye!: Oh, sixpence, that I had o'clock last Wednesday to pay the saddler for my mistress’s crupper?

Anon!: Why, Antony.
Goodbye!: Antony.

Anon!: Let’s meet him and receive him.
Goodbye!: Let’s meet him and get him.

Anon!: You see me here, you gods, a poor old man, As full of grief as age, wretched in both.
Goodbye!: You see me here, gods, a poor old man, as wretched in both of them as old.

Anon!: I would speak with Clarence, and I came hither on my legs.
Goodbye!: I’d like to speak with Clarence, and I came here on my legs.

Anon!: The duke and senators of Venice greet you.
Goodbye!: The duke and senators of Venice greet you.

Anon!: And from her womb children of divers kind We sucking on her natural bosom find, Many for many virtues excellent, None but for some and yet all different.
Goodbye!: And from her womb we’re sucking on her natural bosom, many for many virtues excellent, none but for some and yet all different.

Anon!: Think yourself a baby That you have ta'en these tenders for true pay, Which are not sterling.
Goodbye!: Think of yourself as a baby that you’ve gotten these tenders for true pay, which aren’t sterling.

Anon!: There thou mayst brain him, Having first seized his books; or with a log Batter his skull; or paunch him with a stake; Or cut his weasand with thy knife.
Goodbye!: You can scold him, after you’ve seized his books first, or batter his skull with a log, or paunch him with a stake, or cut his weass with your knife

Anon!: He is sure possessed, madam.
Goodbye!: He’s sure to be possessed, madam.

Anon!: Go tread the path that thou shalt ne'er return.
Goodbye!: Go on the path you won’t return.

Anon!: Of us must Pompey presently be sought, Or else he seeks out us.
Goodbye!: Pompey is now seeking us, or he’ll seek us.

Anon!: O dear!
Goodbye!: Oh dear!

Anon!: Faith, there has been much to do on both sides, and the nation holds it no sin to tar them to controversy.
Goodbye!: Yes, there’s been a lot to do on both sides, and the nation doesn’t believe it’s a sin to tarnish them.

Anon!: Still am I called.—Unhand me, gentlemen.
Goodbye!: I’m still called.—Unhand me, gentlemen.

Anon!: They would not have you to stir forth today.
Goodbye!: They wouldn’t want you to scold you today.

Anon!: What news, Borachio?
Goodbye!: What news, Borachio?

Anon!: You’re sad, Signior Balthasar.
Goodbye!: You’re sad, Signior Balthasar.

Anon!: He is a good one, and his worthiness Does challenge much respect.—Come, Desdemona, Once more, well met at Cyprus.
Goodbye!: He’s a good man, and his worth is challenging much respect.—Come again, Desdemona, I’m sure you’ve met him at Cyprus.

Anon!: Fortune, that arrant whore,  Ne'er turns the key to th' poor.
Goodbye!: Fortune, that arrant whore, Neer turns the key to the poor.

Anon!: Every one prepare To follow this fair corse unto her grave.
Goodbye!: Everybody wants to follow this beautiful corse to her grave.

Anon!: Alas, what is the matter?
Goodbye!: What’s the matter?

Anon!: Bestow it at your pleasure, and believe Caesar’s no merchant, to make prize with you Of things that merchants sold.
Goodbye!: Give it to you, and don’t believe Caesar’s not a merchant, to make a prize for the things that merchants sold.

Anon!: I found them on a tree.
Goodbye!: I found them on a tree.

Anon!: See how yon justice rails upon yon simple thief.
Goodbye!: Look how justice is defending a simple thief.

Anon!: Is ’t possible, friend Litio, that mistress Bianca Doth fancy any other but Lucentio?
Goodbye!: Is it possible, Litio, that mistress Bianca isn’t a good friend, but he’s not Lucentio?

Anon!: I cannot tell, except they are busied about a counterfeit assurance.
Goodbye!: I can’t tell, except they’re busied about a fake assurance.

Anon!: You may light on a husband that hath no beard.
Goodbye!: You can light up a husband who has no beard.

Anon!: My lord, I will use them according to their desert.
Goodbye!: My lord, I’ll use them like a desert.

Anon!: It is a theme as fluent as the sea.
Goodbye!: It’s a theme as fluent as the sea.

Anon!: Believe what?
Goodbye!: What?

Anon!: Couple it with something.
Goodbye!: Add it to something.

Anon!: I knew you at the first You were a moveable.
Goodbye!: I knew you were moving at the first time.

Anon!: Urchins Shall, forth at vast of night that they may work, All exercise on thee.
Goodbye!: Urchins will go out of the night to work, and all of them will be on you.

Anon!: But we have reason to cool our raging motions, our carnal stings, our unbitted lusts.
Goodbye!: But we have reason to cool our raging motions, our carnal stings, our unbitted lusts.

Anon!: We charge you, in the Prince’s name, stand!
Goodbye!: We’ll charge you, in the Prince’s name, to stand!

Anon!: All which the Moor is defective in.
Goodbye!: All the Moor is defective in.

Anon!: If die, be brief, That our swift-wingèd souls may catch the king’s, Or, like obedient subjects, follow him To his new kingdom of ne'er-changing night.
Goodbye!: If we die, be brief so that our swift-winged souls can catch the king’s life, or, like obedient subjects, follow him to his new kingdom of neo-changing night.

Anon!: Why, your lieutenant, Cassio.
Goodbye!: Why, your lieutenant, Cassio?

Anon!: They are afoot.
Goodbye!: They’re on the ground.

Anon!: Give him tending.
Goodbye!: Give him a job.

Anon!: Oh, she is lame!
Goodbye!: Oh, she’s lame!

Anon!: That handkerchief Which I so loved and gave thee, thou gav’st To Cassio.
Goodbye!: You gave me that handkerchief I loved and gave you, to Cassio.

Anon!: And his kissing is as full of sanctity as the touch of holy bread.
Goodbye!: And his kissing is as sanctious as the touch of holy bread.

Anon!: Are they all ready?
Goodbye!: Are they all ready?

Anon!: I know thou canst not choose.
Goodbye!: I know you can’t choose.

Anon!: Madam, I am not well.
Goodbye!: Madam, I’m not well.

Anon!: You have heard him swear downright he was.
Goodbye!: You heard him swear that he was.

Anon!: Friends, come hither.
Goodbye!: Friends, come here.

Anon!: Come the next sabbath, and I will content you.
Goodbye!: Come on the next sabbath, and I’ll be happy to help you.

Anon!: Where shall we go?
Goodbye!: Where should we go?

Anon!: Come in, tailor.
Goodbye!: Come in, tailor.

Anon!: Hath any man seen him at the barber’s?
Goodbye!: Has anyone seen him at the barber’s?

Anon!: Is Clarence dead?
Goodbye!: Is Clarence dead?

Anon!: Romeo!
Goodbye!: Romeo!

Anon!: Fie, how my bones ache!
Goodbye!: Oh, how my bones ache!

Anon!: You are not ignorant of what excellence Laertes is—
Goodbye!: You don’t know what excellence Laertes is—

Anon!: A spirit?
Goodbye!: A spirit?

Anon!: I by bargain should Wear it myself.
Goodbye!: I should wear it myself.

Anon!: Impart.
Goodbye!: Take it.

Anon!: I’ll be your foil, Laertes.
Goodbye!: I’ll be your foil, Laertes.

Anon!: We talk here in the public haunt of men.
Goodbye!: We’re talking here in the public haunt of men.

Anon!: A gentle scroll.
Goodbye!: A gentle scroll.

Anon!: I hope this passionate humor of mine will change.
Goodbye!: I hope my passion for humor will change.

Anon!: Woe, woe are we, sir, you may not live to wear All your true followers out.
Goodbye!: We’re sorry, sir, you can’t live to wear all your true followers out.

Anon!: Oh, horrible, oh, horrible, most horrible!
Goodbye!: Oh, horrible, horrible, most horrible!

Anon!: O, teach me how I should forget to think!
Goodbye!: Oh, teach me how to forget to think!

Anon!: See thou dissemble not.
Goodbye!: Don’t see you’re dissembling me.

Anon!: Fellow, wilt thou bestow thy time with me?
Goodbye!: Do you have time with me?

Anon!: I’ll go alone.
Goodbye!: I’ll go alone.

Anon!: Why are you silent?
Goodbye!: Why are you still?

Anon!: Romeo!
Goodbye!: Romeo!

Anon!: Her waspish-headed son has broke his arrows, Swears he will shoot no more, but play with sparrows And be a boy right out.
Goodbye!: Her spooky son has broken his arrows, and he’s afraid he’ll shoot no more than sparrows and be a boy right out of here.

Anon!: Therein, ye gods, you make the weak most strong.
Goodbye!: You make the weak strongest.

Anon!: How now, Sir Toby Belch!
Goodbye!: What’s going on, Sir Toby Belch?

Anon!: Look you here, Here is himself, marred, as you see, with traitors.
Goodbye!: Look, here is the man who is surrounded, as you see, by traitors.

Anon!: Draw, you rascal.
Goodbye!: Draw, you rascal.

Anon!: Ay, but not frighted me.
Goodbye!: Yes, but I didn’t cry.

Anon!: So swift a pace hath thought that even now You may imagine him upon Blackheath, Where that his lords desire him to have borne His bruisèd helmet and his bended sword Before him through the city.
Goodbye!: He’s so fast thought that you can imagine him on Blackheath, where his lords want him to have his bruise helmet and his sword before him through the city.

Anon!: They are, my lord.
Goodbye!: They are, my lord.

Anon!: O Hamlet, what a falling off was there!
Goodbye!: Oh Hamlet, what a fall there was!

Anon!: Thou almost makest me waver in my faith To hold opinion with Pythagoras That souls of animals infuse themselves Into the trunks of men.
Goodbye!: You’re almost making me angry to say that animals are infusing themselves into men’s trunks.

Anon!: Let me tell you, Cassius, you yourself Are much condemned to have an itching palm, To sell and mart your offices for gold To undeservers.
Goodbye!: Cassius, you’re too much condemned to have a slur of palms, to sell and martin your offices for gold to unservers.

Anon!: Say our pleasure, To such whose place is under us, requires Our quick remove from hence.
Goodbye!: We’ll have to leave here quickly.

Anon!: Howling attends it.
Goodbye!: I’m a howling.

Anon!: I’ll answer that.
Goodbye!: I’ll answer that question.

Anon!: Doth my simple feature content you?
Goodbye!: Does my simple feature help you?

Anon!: No, I will not.
Goodbye!: No, I won’t.

Anon!: Three kings I had newly feasted, and did want Of what I was i’ th’ morning.
Goodbye!: Three kings I had recently feasted and wanted to be the one I was in the morning.

Anon!: Mark well Metellus Cimber.
Goodbye!: Mark well Metellus Cimber.

Anon!: Shall they hoist me up And show me to the shouting varletry Of censuring Rome?
Goodbye!: Shall they hoist me up and show me the clinging screams of Rome?

Anon!: They that reap must sheaf and bind, Then to cart with Rosalind.
Goodbye!: The people who reap must sheaf and bind, then to cart with Rosalind.

Anon!: Why, now, blow wind, swell billow, and swim bark!
Goodbye!: Now, blow wind, swell billow, and swim bark!

Anon!: It shall advantage more than do us wrong.
Goodbye!: It will benefit more than do us wrong.

Anon!: At seventeen years, many their fortunes seek, But at fourscore, it is too late a week.
Goodbye!: At seventeen years old, many of them are looking for their fortunes, but at fourscore, it’s too late a week.

Anon!: There is some strange thing toward, Edmund.
Goodbye!: Edmund, there’s something strange about it.

Anon!: In troth, I think thou wouldst not.
Goodbye!: I don’t think you would.

Anon!: I should ev'n die with pity To see another thus.
Goodbye!: I’d rather see another like that.

Anon!: With him I sent the queen, My reason all the same, and they are ready Tomorrow or at further space t' appear Where you shall hold your session.
Goodbye!: I sent the queen with him, my reason for that, and they’re ready tomorrow or at the next stage where you’ll be sitting.

Anon!: Fool, I say!
Goodbye!: Fool, I say!

Anon!: See, your wife’s with him.
Goodbye!: Look, your wife’s with him.

Anon!: We are, my lord, and come to have the warrant That we may be admitted where he is.
Goodbye!: We are, my lord, and we’ve come to have the warrant that we can be admitted to where he is.

Anon!: I am sure the duke Will never grant this forfeiture to hold.
Goodbye!: I’m sure the duke will never grant this forfeiture to hold.

Anon!: God keep your Worship!
Goodbye!: God keep your Worship!

Anon!: Both our remedies Within thy help and holy physic lies.
Goodbye!: Both our remedies are lies in your help and your holy physicy.

Anon!: Turn melancholy forth to funerals.
Goodbye!: Turn melancholy away to funerals.

Anon!: No, it is Casca, one incorporate To our attempts.
Goodbye!: No, it’s Casca, one who’s a part of our efforts.

Anon!: Tis monstrous.
Goodbye!: It’s monstrous.

Anon!: Three words, dear Romeo, and good night indeed.
Goodbye!: Three words, dear Romeo, and good night indeed.

Anon!: Are you yet living?
Goodbye!: Are you still alive?

Anon!: Brother— Content yourself.
Goodbye!: Brother— Be content.

Anon!: I am in my condition A prince, Miranda—I do think, a king; I would, not so!—and would no more endure This wooden slavery than to suffer The flesh-fly blow my mouth.
Goodbye!: I’m a prince, Miranda—I think I’m a king; I wouldn’t, not so!—and I wouldn’t have to endure this wooden slavery more than to suffer the flesh-fly blow

Anon!: Harder, harder.
Goodbye!: Harder, harder.

Anon!: Do not torment me, prithee.
Goodbye!: Don’t torture me, please.

Anon!: Nor no one here, for curses never pass The lips of those that breathe them in the air.
Goodbye!: There’s no one here, because curses never pass the lips of those who breathe them in the air.

Anon!: If the enemy is an ass and a fool and a prating coxcomb, is it meet, think you, that we should also, look you, be an ass and a fool and a prating coxcomb, in your own conscience, now?
Goodbye!: If the enemy is an ass and a fool and a prating coxcomb, is it possible, you think, that we should also, look at you, be an ass and a fool and a prating

Anon!: And I do not doubt but to hear them say, “It is a sweet comedy.” No more words.
Goodbye!: And I don’t doubt that they say, “It’s a sweet comedy.” No more words.

Anon!: Fool, fool, fool, I say!
Goodbye!: Fool, fool, fool, I say!

Anon!: False face must hide what the false heart doth know.
Goodbye!: False face must hide what the false heart knows.

Anon!: I do bite my thumb, sir.
Goodbye!: I bite my thumb.

Anon!: Ay, Celia, we stayed her for your sake.
Goodbye!: Yes, Celia, we stayed her for your sake.

Anon!: For half thy wealth, it is Antonio’s.
Goodbye!: For half your wealth, it’s Antonio’s.

Anon!: O Lord, he will hang upon him like a disease!
Goodbye!: Oh Lord, he’ll hang on to him like a disease!

Anon!: He says his name is Master Fer.
Goodbye!: He says his name is Master Fer.

Anon!: What of that?
Goodbye!: What about that?

Anon!: Shall I hear from you anon?
Goodbye!: Should I hear from you soon?

Anon!: Ay, do you fear it?
Goodbye!: Yes, do you fear it?

Anon!: So say I. Methinks you are sadder.
Goodbye!: I think you’re sadder.

Anon!: A soothsayer bids you beware the ides of March.
Goodbye!: A soothsayer asks you to beware of March’s landslides.

Anon!: Call!
Goodbye!: Call me!

Anon!: But yet, alas, stood I within his grace, I would prefer him to a better place.
Goodbye!: But I’d rather him be a better place to live.

Anon!: I will be bitter with him and passing short.
Goodbye!: I’ll be bitter with him and pass short.

Anon!: Have mind upon your health, tempt me no further.
Goodbye!: Don’t worry about your health, but don’t tempt me any further.

Anon!: I have not ’scaped drowning to be afeard now of your four legs.
Goodbye!: I’ve never drowned in the water, so I’m not afraid to be afeaded of your four legs now.

Anon!: Speak, Pyramus.—Thisbe, stand forth.
Goodbye!: Speak, Pyramus.—Thisbe, stand up.

Anon!: And so had I, but yet, for fashion sake, I thank you too for your society.
Goodbye!: And so did I, but for the sake of fashion, I thank you too for your society.

Anon!: What impossible matter will he make easy next?
Goodbye!: What kind of matter will he make easy next?

Anon!: Take their examination yourself and bring it me.
Goodbye!: Take their examination yourself and bring it to me.

Anon!: Marvelous sweet music!
Goodbye!: What a wonderful music!

Anon!: That cannot be, since I am still possessed Of those effects for which I did the murder: My crown, mine own ambition, and my queen.
Goodbye!: That can’t be true, since I’m still possessed of the effects for which I killed myself: my crown, my own ambition, and my queen.

Anon!: Error i' the bill, sir, error i' the bill!
Goodbye!: I’m wrong about the bill, sir, I’m wrong about the bill!

Anon!: I do, truly, for thou swear’st to me thou art honest.
Goodbye!: I swear to you that you’re honest.

Anon!: Let me go.
Goodbye!: Let me go.

Anon!: Your eyes drop millstones, when fools' eyes drop tears.
Goodbye!: Your eyes drop millstones when fools’ eyes drop tears.

Anon!: Sayest thou so?
Goodbye!: Do you say that?

Anon!: The world is grown so bad That wrens make prey where eagles dare not perch.
Goodbye!: The world is so bad that wrens make prey where eagles don’t dare perch.

Anon!: Die and be damned, and  It is well.
Goodbye!: Die and be damned, and it’s good.

Anon!: I pray you, jest, sir, as you sit at dinner.
Goodbye!: Please, sir, as you sit at dinner.

Anon!: Because that I familiarly sometimes Do use you for my fool and chat with you, Your sauciness will jest upon my love And make a common of my serious hours.
Goodbye!: Because I often use you as a fool and chat with you, your sanity will scold my love and make me a common part of my serious hours.

Anon!: Great God of heaven, say amen to all!
Goodbye!: God of heaven, say amen to all!

Anon!: Why, what you will.
Goodbye!: What do you want?

Anon!: A man, young lady!
Goodbye!: A man, young lady!

Anon!: What life is in that to be the death of this marriage?
Goodbye!: What life does that mean to be the death of this marriage?

Anon!: For me, three thousand ducats.
Goodbye!: For me, three thousand ducats.

Anon!: So, thanks to all at once and to each one, Whom we invite to see us crowned at Scone.
Goodbye!: So, thanks to everyone at once and to each other, who we invite to see crowned at Scone.

Anon!: What, dost thou make us minstrels?
Goodbye!: What, are you making us minstrels?

Anon!: What’s this?
Goodbye!: What’s this?

Anon!: I hope they will not come upon us now.
Goodbye!: I hope they won’t come to us now.

Anon!: I will give treason his payment into plows, I warrant you.
Goodbye!: I’ll give him treason for his actions in plows, I assure you.

Anon!: Thanks, sir: the like to you!
Goodbye!: Thanks, sir: thank you for your kindness!

Anon!: To ’t, luxury, pell-mell—for I lack soldiers.
Goodbye!: I’m not a soldier.

Anon!: Is the chair empty?
Goodbye!: Is the chair empty?

Anon!: What is your will?
Goodbye!: What do you want?

Anon!: I’ll leave you, lady.
Goodbye!: I’ll leave you, lady.

Anon!: I shall find time, Cassius, I shall find time.
Goodbye!: I’ll find time, Cassius, I’ll find time.

Anon!: Pass!
Goodbye!: Go!

Anon!: Ho, let the door be locked.
Goodbye!: Ho, lock the door.

Anon!: Read it.
Goodbye!: Read it.

Anon!: Unfold it.
Goodbye!: Take it away.

Anon!: Would he have stolen away From sleeping Hermia?
Goodbye!: Would he have stolen from sleeping Hermia?

Anon!: What think’st thou, will our friends prove all true?
Goodbye!: What do you think, will our friends prove to be true?

Anon!: Hear me, my lord.
Goodbye!: Listen to me, my lord.

Anon!: But out of question, ’tis Maria’s hand.
Goodbye!: But out of question, it’s Maria’s hand.

Anon!: The earth, that’s nature’s mother, is her tomb.
Goodbye!: The earth, that’s nature’s mother, is her tomb.

Anon!: I’ll yield him thee asleep, Where thou mayst knock a nail into his head.
Goodbye!: I’ll give him to sleep, where you can knock a nail into his head.

Anon!: I will hear that play.
Goodbye!: I’ll hear that play.

Anon!: Yet would I knew That stroke would prove the worst!
Goodbye!: But I wish I could know that stroke would be the worst!

Anon!: I bear no hatred, blessèd man, for, lo, My intercession likewise steads my foe.
Goodbye!: I don’t have hatred, blessed man, because my intercession is like a foe.

Anon!: The king rises.
Goodbye!: The king is up.

Anon!: Let me see.
Goodbye!: Let me see.

Anon!: Say that I slew them not.
Goodbye!: Say I didn’t slew them.

Anon!: Do it.
Goodbye!: Do it.

Anon!: Here, sir, as foolish as I was before.
Goodbye!: Here, sir, as foolish as I was before.

Anon!: Perchance till after Theseus' wedding day.
Goodbye!: Perchance until after Theseus’s wedding day.

Anon!: Alas, good Cassio!
Goodbye!: Oh, good Cassio!

Anon!: This I wonder at, That he, unknown to me, should be in debt.
Goodbye!: I’m wondering, that he’s in debt, and I don’t know.

Anon!: Thou didst smile Infusèd with a fortitude from heaven, When I have decked the sea with drops full salt, Under my burthen groaned; which raised in me An undergoing stomach to bear up Against what should ensue.
Goodbye!: You smiled with a fortitude from heaven when I sprayed the sea with a full sea of drops of salt, groaned under my stomach, which raised me in a stomach to bear up against what should happen.

Anon!: Not being the worst Stands in some rank of praise.
Goodbye!: Not being the worst is a good example.

Anon!: She has spoke what she should not, I am sure of that.
Goodbye!: She’s said what she shouldn’t have said, I’m sure of that.

Anon!: What, rouse thee, man!
Goodbye!: What, please, man!

Anon!: An adder did it, for with doubler tongue Than thine, thou serpent, never adder stung.
Goodbye!: An adder did it, because you serpent, never stung an adder.

Anon!: I would cure you if you would but call me Rosalind and come every day to my cote and woo me.
Goodbye!: I’d cure you if you only called me Rosalind and come to my cote every day and woo me.

Anon!: I know it by their pale and deadly looks.
Goodbye!: I know it by their pale and deadly looks.

Anon!: If you offend him, I for him defy you.
Goodbye!: If you’re insulting him, I’ll defend you for him.

Anon!: Sailors, my lord, they say.
Goodbye!: Sailors, my lord, they say.

Anon!: Good now, hold thy tongue.
Goodbye!: Now, speak your tongue.

Anon!: She’s a most triumphant lady, if report be square to her.
Goodbye!: She’s a triumphant lady, if she’s a good friend.

Anon!: Did I not tell you she was innocent?
Goodbye!: Didn’t I tell you she was innocent?

Anon!: Be choked with such another emphasis!
Goodbye!: Be choked with another accent!

Anon!: What a fearful night is this!
Goodbye!: What a fearful night this is!

Anon!: Let me hear from you.
Goodbye!: Let me hear from you.

Anon!: Sir, this should be answered.
Goodbye!: Sir, this should be answered.

Anon!: I thank thee.
Goodbye!: Thank you.

Anon!: Now, Catesby, what says his grace?
Goodbye!: Now, Catesby, what does his grace say?

Anon!: If you be gentlemen, Do me this right: hear me with patience.
Goodbye!: If you’re gentlemen, do me this right: listen to me with patience.

Anon!: Oh, heaven forgive us!
Goodbye!: Oh, heaven forgive us!

Anon!: O, ’twas the foulest deed to slay that babe, And the most merciless that e'er was heard of!
Goodbye!: Oh, it was the worst thing to kill that babe, and the merciless thing that ever happened to me!

Anon!: No more.

Anon!: No, truly.

Goodbye!: God defend his grace should say no to us!

Goodbye!: Day, night, hour, tide, time, work, play, alone, in company, I’ve always been a good friend to have her matched.

Anon!: Your way is shorter.
Goodbye!: You’re getting shorter.

Anon!: I charge thee, speak!

Anon!: But I know none, and therefore am no beast.
Goodbye!: But I don’t know anything, and I’m not a beast.

Goodbye!: So come, help me.

Goodbye!: A strange fish!

Goodbye!: Don’t, Phoebe.

Anon!: And so, adieu.

Goodbye!: I wish I could copy it.

Goodbye!: Please, pardon me for this.

Goodbye!: Is Caesar coming to the Capitol tomorrow?

Anon!: Art thou my son?
Goodbye!: Are you my son?

Goodbye!: What villains have done this?

Goodbye!: Your cake inside is warm, and you’re standing here in the cold.

Goodbye!: I know her by her gait.

Goodbye!: Our general’s wife is now the general.

Anon!: Dead?
Goodbye!: Dead?

Goodbye!: Why, she was dead when you were born.

Goodbye!: Why, our battalia trebles that.

Goodbye!: You’re too wrong in this king.

Goodbye!: I’ll give out a lot of beauty plans.

Anon!: They swore you did.
Goodbye!: They swore you did.

Goodbye!: I now think it was not your brother’s bad behavior that made him seek his death, but a provoking merit that was wrought by a reproachable badness in himself.

Anon!: Let me be satisfied.
Goodbye!: Let me be satisfied.

Goodbye!: You’ll heat my blood.

Goodbye!: How can the Duke be satisfied with that, whose messengers are here about my side when they’re in the process of bringing me to him?

Anon!: They were traitors!
Goodbye!: They were traitors!

Anon!: Here he is, here he is.
Goodbye!: Here he is, here he is.

Goodbye!: Sir, they’re spoken, and these things are true.

Goodbye!: He can’t prevail with me.

Goodbye!: If every of your wishes had a womb, and fertile every wish, a million.

Anon!: No.
Goodbye!: No.

Anon!: O cousin, cousin!
Goodbye!: Oh cousin, cousin!

Anon!: Do you not see that I am out of breath?
Goodbye!: Don’t you see that I’m out of breath?

Anon!: At Pembroke, or at Ha'rfordwest in Wales.
Goodbye!: At Pembroke, or at Ha'rfordwest in Wales.

Goodbye!: Give me a calendar.

Goodbye!: He doesn’t know what he says, and it’s vain that we present him to him.

Goodbye!: Love’s not love when it’s mingled with regards that stands Aloof from the whole point.

Anon!: What is your name?
Goodbye!: What’s your name?

Anon!: It makes me mad.

Goodbye!: Oh, treason of the blood!

Anon!: doth sway my life.” Nay, but first, let me see, let me see, let me see.

Goodbye!: Sweets to the sweet.

Goodbye!: Amen.

Goodbye!: Lord Hamlet— Heaven secure him!

Goodbye!: Is Brutus sick?

Anon!: I do not like her name.
Goodbye!: I don’t like her name.

Anon!: Well, if you were but an inch of fortune better than I, where would you choose it?
Goodbye!: Well, if you were only an inch better than me, where would you choose it?

Anon!: Come, come and take a queen Worth many babes and beggars!
Goodbye!: Come, take a queen who has many babies and beggars!

Anon!: To have a thousand with red burning spits Come hissing in upon 'em!
Goodbye!: To have a thousand of spits come in with them!

Anon!: This Caesar was a tyrant.
Goodbye!: This Caesar was a tyrant.

Anon!: Master, for my hand, Both our inventions meet and jump in one.
Goodbye!: Master, for my hand, both of our inventions are able to meet and jump in one.

Anon!: There’s no composition in this news That gives them credit.
Goodbye!: There’s no way this news gives them credit.

Anon!: Now is the day we long have lookèd for.
Goodbye!: Now is the day we’ve long been looking for.

Anon!: You shall have none ill, sir, for I’ll try if they can lick their fingers.
Goodbye!: You won’t have any bad luck, sir, because I’ll try if they can lick their fingers.

Anon!: I know they are in Rome together Looking for Antony.
Goodbye!: I know they’re in Rome looking for Antony.

Anon!: With naught but truth.
Goodbye!: With no truth.

Anon!: Ye gods, it doth amaze me A man of such a feeble temper should So get the start of the majestic world And bear the palm alone.
Goodbye!: Yes, gods, it amazes me that a man with such a poor temper should start the majestic world and bear the palm alone.

Anon!: That’s my sister.
Goodbye!: That’s my sister.

Anon!: You break jests as braggarts do their blades, which, God be thanked, hurt not.—My lord, for your many courtesies I thank you.
Goodbye!: You break a jest like braggarts do their blades, which, God be thanked, won’t hurt.—My lord, I thank you for your many courtesies.

Anon!: If I do live, I will be good to thee.
Goodbye!: If I live, I’ll be good to you.

Anon!: The king, His brother, and yours, abide all three distracted, And the remainder mourning over them, Brimful of sorrow and dismay.
Goodbye!: The king, his brother, and yours are all distracted, and the rest of them are mourning, scolding sorrow and dismay.

Anon!: Unmerciful lady as you are, I’m none.
Goodbye!: I’m not a good lady as you are.

Anon!: My uncle?
Goodbye!: My uncle?

Anon!: When you have spoken your speech, enter into that brake.—And so everyone according to his cue.
Goodbye!: When you’ve spoken, enter that brake.—And so everyone will be able to obey his cue.

Anon!: Can you not stay awhile?
Goodbye!: Can’t you stay for a while?

Anon!: And so of men.
Goodbye!: And so of men.

Anon!: Nay, I have done.
Goodbye!: No, I’ve done it.

Anon!: Zounds, he dies!
Goodbye!: He’s dying!

Anon!: Ay, my lord.
Goodbye!: Yes, my lord.

Anon!: Be not lost So poorly in your thoughts.
Goodbye!: Don’t be so bad about your thoughts.

Anon!: They are all but stomachs, and we all but food.
Goodbye!: They’re all except stomachs, and we’re all except food.

Anon!: Vanish, or I shall give thee thy deserving, And blemish Caesar’s triumph.
Goodbye!: I’ll give you your merits, and I’ll blemish Caesar’s triumph.

Anon!: Let the doors be shut upon him, that he may play the fool no where but in ’s own house.
Goodbye!: Let the doors be shut on him so he can play the fool no matter where he is.

Anon!: Well moused, Lion!
Goodbye!: Good luck, Lion!

Anon!: Where should Othello go?— Now, how dost thou look now?
Goodbye!: Where should Othello go?—Now, how are you looking now?

Anon!: And now you know my meaning.
Goodbye!: Now you know my meaning.

Anon!: Young Romeo is it?
Goodbye!: Is it young Romeo?

Anon!: Knock, knock, knock!
Goodbye!: Knock, knock, knock!

Anon!: The messenger Came on my guard, and at thy tent is now Unloading of his mules.
Goodbye!: The messenger arrived on my guard and is now unloading his mules in your tent.

Anon!: Wherefore speaks he this To her he hates?
Goodbye!: Why is he speaking about this to her he hates?

Anon!: His death’s upon him, but not dead.
Goodbye!: He’s dead, but not dead.

Anon!: What says he of our marriage?
Goodbye!: What does he say about our marriage?

Anon!: And when I shall die, Take him and cut him out in little stars, And he will make the face of heaven so fine That all the world will be in love with night And pay no worship to the garish sun.
Goodbye!: And when I die, take him and cut him out in tiny stars, and he’ll make the face of heaven so fine that the whole world will be in love with night and not worship the sun.

Anon!: Now is the time of help.
Goodbye!: Now is the time for help.

Anon!: There’s another garment for ’t.
Goodbye!: There’s another garment for it.

Anon!: Which I take to be either a fool or a cipher.
Goodbye!: I think it’s a fool or a cipher.

Anon!: A beggar, brother?
Goodbye!: A beggar, brother?

Anon!: And is not the grease of a mutton as wholesome as the sweat of a man?
Goodbye!: And isn’t the grease of a mutton as wholesome as the sweat of a man?

Anon!: Thou art not by mine eye, Lysander, found.
Goodbye!: You’re not by my eye, Lysander, found you.

Anon!: Dost thou mean the crown?
Goodbye!: Do you mean the crown?

Anon!: Baptista is a noble gentleman, To whom my father is not all unknown, And were his daughter fairer than she is, She may more suitors have, and me for one.
Goodbye!: Baptista is a noble gentleman, to whom my father is not all unknown.

Anon!: Good morrow to you both.
Goodbye!: Good morning to you both.

Anon!: If there be more, more woeful, hold it in.
Goodbye!: If there’s more, more sorrowful, keep it in.

Anon!: Renownèd duke, vouchsafe to take the pains To go with us into the abbey here And hear at large discoursed all our fortunes, And all that are assembled in this place That by this sympathizèd one day’s error Have suffered wrong.
Goodbye!: Renowned duke, please take the pains to go with us here and hear at large all our fortunes, and all the people who are assembled in this place that have suffered wrong by this sympathizated one day.

Anon!: A braggart, a rogue, a villain that fights by the book of arithmetic!
Goodbye!: A braggart, a rogue, a villain who fights by the book of arithmetic!

Anon!: Villain, thou didst deny the gold’s receipt And told’st me of a mistress and a dinner, For which, I hope, thou felt’st I was displeased.
Goodbye!: Villain, you denied the gold’s receipt and told me about a mistress and a dinner, for which, I hope, you felt displeased.

Anon!: So shall I, love, And so, I pray, be you.
Goodbye!: I’ll love you, and I’ll be you.

Anon!: How sweet is love itself possessed When but love’s shadows are so rich in joy!
Goodbye!: How sweet is love itself when only love’s shadows are so rich in joy!

Anon!: A piece of work that will make sick men whole.
Goodbye!: A piece of work that will make sick men whole.

Anon!: Full half an hour.
Goodbye!: For a full half hour.

Anon!: How oddly thou repliest!
Goodbye!: How oddly you respond!

Anon!: Nay, if you be an undertaker, I am for you.
Goodbye!: No, if you’re an undertaker, I’ll be for you.

Anon!: Most certain, sir.
Goodbye!: Yes, sir.

Anon!: Let me still take away the harms I fear, Not fear still to be taken.
Goodbye!: Let me take away the harms I’m afraid, not take fear.

Anon!: Good gentlemen, let me have leave to speak.
Goodbye!: Good gentlemen, let me speak.

Anon!: Ay, on mine honor.
Goodbye!: Yes, I’m honored.

Anon!: Here, here will I remain With worms that are thy chamber maids.
Goodbye!: Here, here I’ll remain with worms that are your chambermaids.

Anon!: And, gentle friends, Let’s kill him boldly but not wrathfully.
Goodbye!: And, gentle friends, let’s kill him boldly, but not wrathfully.

Anon!: Signor Bassanio!
Goodbye!: Signor Bassanio!

Anon!: Pyramus draws near the wall.
Goodbye!: Pyramus is near the wall.

Anon!: Where runn’st thou so fast?
Goodbye!: Where are you running so fast?

Anon!: E'en so, my lord.
Goodbye!: That’s true, my lord.

Anon!: All-seeing heaven, what a world is this!
Goodbye!: All-seeing heaven, what a world this is!

Anon!: Who alone suffers, suffers most i' th' mind, Leaving free things and happy shows behind.
Goodbye!: Who suffers alone, suffers most, leaving free things behind and happy shows behind.

Anon!: Why, I think so.
Goodbye!: I think so.

Anon!: You must not, sir, mistake my niece.
Goodbye!: You shouldn’t mistake my niece, sir.

Anon!: Ah, Desdemona, away, away, away!
Goodbye!: Ah, Desdemona, away, away, away!

Anon!: I would have such a fellow whipped for o'erdoing Termagant.
Goodbye!: I wish I could have a fellow like that whipped for o'erdoing Termagant.

Anon!: You strike my people, and your disordered rabble Make servants of their betters.
Goodbye!: You’re hitting my people, and your rabble makes servants of their betters.

Anon!: I am very ill at ease, Unfit for mine own purposes.
Goodbye!: I’m very poor at ease, and I’m not suitable for my own purposes.

Anon!: In thunder, lightning, or in rain?
Goodbye!: In thunder, lightning, or in rain?

Anon!: His majesty, Tend'ring my person’s safety, hath appointed This conduct to convey me to the Tower.
Goodbye!: His majesty, who’s threatening my person’s safety, has appointed this act to send me to the Tower.

Anon!: I loved Ophelia.
Goodbye!: I loved Ophelia.

Anon!: Then saw you not his face?
Goodbye!: Then didn’t you see his face?

Anon!: O noble Caesar!
Goodbye!: Oh, noble Caesar!

Anon!: How if he will not stand?
Goodbye!: What if he doesn’t stand up?

Anon!: I do not know what “poetical” is.
Goodbye!: I don’t know what “poetical” means.

Anon!: We shall further think on ’t.
Goodbye!: We’ll think about it further.

Anon!: To supper?
Goodbye!: To supper?

Anon!: You have been nobly borne.
Goodbye!: You’ve been borne with nobility.

Anon!: Come, sit, sit, and a song.
Goodbye!: Come on, sit, sit, and sing a song.

Anon!: These griefs and losses have so bated me, That I shall hardly spare a pound of flesh Tomorrow to my bloody creditor.— Well, jailer, on.—Pray God Bassanio come To see me pay his debt, and then I care not.
Goodbye!: I’ve lost so much grief and loss that I’ll barely spare a pound of flesh tomorrow to my bloody creditor.—Well, jailer, let’s go.—God Bassanio come to see

Anon!: For when rich villains have need of poor ones, poor ones may make what price they will.
Goodbye!: When rich villains need poor villains, poor villains can pay what they want.

Anon!: If he cannot, let the botcher mend him.
Goodbye!: If he doesn’t want to, let the witch mend him.

Anon!: My language!
Goodbye!: My language!

Anon!: And so, my lord, adieu.
Goodbye!: And so, my lord, adieu.

Anon!: O, let me not be mad, not mad, sweet heaven!
Goodbye!: Oh, don’t let me be mad, not mad, sweet heaven!

Anon!: Nor will do none tomorrow.
Goodbye!: And I won’t do anything tomorrow.

Anon!: What, and my old Venetian friend Salerio?
Goodbye!: What, and my old Venetian friend Salerio?

Anon!: Come by and by to my chamber.
Goodbye!: Come by and by to my room.

Anon!: Nay, do not pause; for I did kill King Henry— But ’twas thy beauty that provokèd me.
Goodbye!: No, don’t stop, because I killed King Henry— But you’ve been your beauty who shook me.

Anon!: What do you think of me?
Goodbye!: What do you think of me?

Anon!: The question of Cordelia and her father Requires a fitter place.
Goodbye!: Cordelia and her father have to have a better place.

Anon!: No marvel, lord, though it affrighted you.
Goodbye!: No wonder, sir, it ruined you.

Anon!: Would thou and those thy scars had once prevailed To make me fight at land!
Goodbye!: You and those who have fought once would have made me fight on land!

Anon!: God save the king.
Goodbye!: God save the king.

Anon!: Good old knight, Collect them all together at my tent.
Goodbye!: Good old knight, gather them all together in my tent.

Anon!: Who’s there?
Goodbye!: Who’s there?

Anon!: We’ll speak to them, and tonight I’ll force The wine peep through their scars.—Come on, my Queen, There’s sap in ’t yet.
Goodbye!: We’ll speak to them, and tonight I’ll force the wine to peep through their scars.—Come on, my Queen, there’s still sap in it.

Anon!: This same is she, and I do give you her.
Goodbye!: That’s her, and I give you her.

Anon!: Take it in what sense thou wilt.
Goodbye!: Take it in what sense you want.

Anon!: I have forgot why I did call thee back.
Goodbye!: I’ve forgotten why I called you back.

Anon!: With his eyes full of anger.
Goodbye!: He’s scolded.

Anon!: When are you married, madam?
Goodbye!: When are you married, madam?

Anon!: Yea, the same.
Goodbye!: Yes, that’s the same.

Anon!: He hath not touched you yet.
Goodbye!: He hasn’t touched you yet.

Anon!: But be thou armed for some unhappy words.
Goodbye!: But be prepared for some unhappy words.

Anon!: Wherefore’s this noise?
Goodbye!: Why are you making this noise?

Anon!: Where should I lose that handkerchief, Emilia?
Goodbye!: Where should I lose that handkerchief, Emilia?

Anon!: Let me but meet you ladies one hour hence, And I’ll salute your Grace of York as mother And reverend looker-on, of two fair queens.
Goodbye!: I’ll meet you ladies one hour later, and I’ll salute you, your Grace of York, as a mother and reverend looker-on, of two fair queens.

Anon!: How “seventh cause”?—Good my lord, like this fellow.
Goodbye!: How “seventh cause”?—Good, my lord, like this fellow.

Anon!: Alack, alack!
Goodbye!: Oh, no!

Anon!: The one is too like an image and says nothing, and the other too like my lady’s eldest son, evermore tattling.
Goodbye!: The one is too like an image and doesn’t say anything, and the other is too like my lady’s eldest son, always tattling.

Anon!: What’s he?
Goodbye!: What’s he?

Anon!: Tis pity that thou liv’st To walk where any honest men resort.
Goodbye!: It’s pity you’re walking around where any honest men are resorting.

Anon!: I spoke with his man.
Goodbye!: I spoke to his man.

Anon!: The hurt cannot be much.
Goodbye!: The hurt can’t be anything.

Anon!: Three thousand ducats, well.
Goodbye!: Three thousand ducats, well.

Anon!: Nurse?
Goodbye!: Nurse?

Anon!: Tis not in the bond.
Goodbye!: It’s not in the contract.

Anon!: Beguiled, divorcèd, wrongèd, spited, slain!
Goodbye!: Beguiled, divorced, wronged, spited, killed!

Anon!: Well, Jessica, go in.
Goodbye!: Well, Jessica, go inside.

Anon!: Dry up in her the organs of increase, And from her derogate body never spring A babe to honor her.
Goodbye!: Dry up her body and never give her a baby to honor her.

Anon!: I’ll not trust your word.
Goodbye!: I won’t trust your words.

Anon!: We took this mattock and this spade from him As he was coming from this churchyard’s side.
Goodbye!: We took this mattock and this spade from him as he was coming from this churchyard’s side.

Anon!: But he that filches from me my good name Robs me of that which not enriches him And makes me poor indeed.
Goodbye!: But whoever steals my good name from me steals everything that doesn’t enrich him and makes me poor.

Anon!: He’s a good fellow, I can tell you that.
Goodbye!: He’s a good fellow, I can tell you that.

Anon!: Not he that himself is not so, which is Mark Antony.
Goodbye!: Not the one who isn’t, Mark Antony.

Anon!: Where is the Master, Boatswain?
Goodbye!: Where is the Master, Boatswain?

Anon!: I will unto Venice To buy apparel 'gainst the wedding day.
Goodbye!: I’ll go to Venice to buy clothes for the wedding day.

Anon!: It is almost morning, And yet I am sure you are not satisfied Of these events at full.
Goodbye!: It’s almost morning, and yet I’m sure you’re not satisfied with all of these events.

Anon!: But sure the bravery of his grief did put me Into a towering passion.
Goodbye!: But I’m sure his bravery put me into a mighty passion.

Anon!: He thinks he still is at his instrument.
Goodbye!: He thinks he’s still at his instrument.

Anon!: For by the way I’ll sort occasion, As index to the story we late talked of, To part the queen’s proud kindred from the prince.
Goodbye!: I’ll sort out the occasion, as a reference to the story we talked about late, to make the queen proudly kindred from the prince.

Anon!: I am to pray you not to strain my speech To grosser issues nor to larger reach Than to suspicion.
Goodbye!: I’m going to pray you don’t want to strain my speech to more serious issues or to more serious issues than to suspicion.

Anon!: I thank you for your company, but, good faith, I had as lief have been myself alone.
Goodbye!: Thank you for your service, but I wish I had been alone.

Anon!: Hero itself can blot out Hero’s virtue.
Goodbye!: Hero can blot out Hero’s virtue.

Anon!: This is the penthouse under which Lorenzo Desired us to make stand.
Goodbye!: This is the penthouse under which Lorenzo wanted us to stand.

Anon!: It is shaped, sir, like itself, and it is as broad as it hath breadth.
Goodbye!: It’s as broad as it has.

Anon!: Sir, sir, that cannot be.
Goodbye!: Sir, sir, that can’t be.

Anon!: The constable of France.
Goodbye!: The constable of France.

Anon!: How came these things to pass?
Goodbye!: How did this happen?

Anon!: A jealous hood, a jealous hood!
Goodbye!: A jealous hood, a jealous hood!

Anon!: Let me not stay a jot for dinner.
Goodbye!: Don’t let me stay a jot for dinner.

Anon!: Had you been as wise as bold, Young in limbs, in judgment old, Your answer had not been inscrolled.
Goodbye!: If you were as wise as bold, young in limbs, old in judgment, you wouldn’t have been able to answer it.

Anon!: Ask her forgiveness?
Goodbye!: Ask her forgiveness?

Anon!: Oh, are you come, Iago?
Goodbye!: Oh, are you here, Iago?

Anon!: Who’s there?
Goodbye!: Who’s there?

Anon!: As proper men as ever trod upon neat’s leather have gone upon my handiwork.
Goodbye!: As proper men as ever have walked on neat leather, I’ve gone on my handiwork.

Anon!: Will you walk in to see their gossiping?
Goodbye!: Will you walk in to see their gossiping?

Anon!: I’ll make a sop o' th' moonshine of you.
Goodbye!: I’ll make a sop on the moonshine of you.

Anon!: It hath no tongue to vex you.
Goodbye!: It doesn’t have any tongue to vex you.

Anon!: With what addition?
Goodbye!: What’s the difference?

Anon!: We look for you tomorrow.
Goodbye!: We’ll see you tomorrow.

Anon!: If you had known the virtue of the ring, Or half her worthiness that gave the ring, Or your own honor to contain the ring, You would not then have parted with the ring.
Goodbye!: If you had known the virtue of the ring, or half the worth of the ring that gave it to you, or your own honor to contain the ring, you wouldn’t have parted with the ring.

Anon!: I had rather break mine own.
Goodbye!: I’d rather break my own rules.

Anon!: I reasoned with a Frenchman yesterday, Who told me, in the narrow seas that part The French and English, there miscarried A vessel of our country richly fraught.
Goodbye!: I told a Frenchman yesterday that in the narrow seas between the French and English, there was a ship carrying a rich ship from our country.

Anon!: Come, shall we go and kill us venison?
Goodbye!: Come on, should we go and kill us venison?

Anon!: I will indeed no longer endure it, nor am I yet persuaded to put up in peace what already I have foolishly suffered.
Goodbye!: I won’t endure it anymore, and I’m not convinced to put up in peace what I’ve already suffered foolishly.

Anon!: I do remember me, Henry the Sixth Did prophesy that Richmond should be king, When Richmond was a little peevish boy.
Goodbye!: I remember that Henry the Sixth prophesied that Richmond should be king when Richmond was a little peevey boy.

Anon!: I partly know the man.
Goodbye!: I know the man partly.

Anon!: The more fool, madonna, to mourn for your brother’s soul being in heaven.
Goodbye!: The more fool to mourn for your brother’s soul being in heaven, madonna.

Anon!: Thus says my king: an if your father’s Highness Do not, in grant of all demands at large, Sweeten the bitter mock you sent his Majesty, He’ll call you to so hot an answer of it That caves and womby vaultages of France Shall chide your trespass and return your mock In second accent of his ordinance.
Goodbye!: My king says that if your father’s Highness doesn’t sweeten the bitter mock you sent his Majesty, he’ll call you to so hot an answer of it that the caves and caves of

Anon!: The captain that did bring me first on shore Hath my maid’s garments.
Goodbye!: The captain who brought me first on shore has my maid’s clothes.

Anon!: And wherefore are you gentle, strong, and valiant?
Goodbye!: Why are you gentle, strong, and valiant?

Anon!: Ay, my lord.
Goodbye!: Yes, my lord.

Anon!: I am more an antique Roman than a Dane.
Goodbye!: I’m more an antique Roman than a Dane.

Anon!: I’ll about And drive away the vulgar from the streets.
Goodbye!: I’ll go out and drive away the vulgar from the streets.

Anon!: What’s your grace’s will?
Goodbye!: What will you do to your grace?

Anon!: Let him not come near me.
Goodbye!: Don’t let him come near me.

Anon!: Like her?
Goodbye!: Like her?

Anon!: And look to have it yielded with all kindness.
Goodbye!: And look for it to be delivered with kindness.

Anon!: And that most deeply to consider is The beauty of his daughter.
Goodbye!: And that’s what I’m going to consider most deeply is the beauty of his daughter.

Anon!: To the mines?
Goodbye!: To the mines?

Anon!: I am right loath to go.
Goodbye!: I’m right about to go.

Anon!: Come, my lord, and in our flight Tell me how it came this night That I sleeping here was found With these mortals on the ground.
Goodbye!: Come on, my lord, and tell me in our flight how it came this night that I was found sleeping here with these mortals on the ground.

Anon!: The Prince and Claudio promised by this hour To visit me.—You know your office, brother.
Goodbye!: The Prince and Claudio promised by this hour to visit me.—You know your office, brother.

Anon!: Faith, I can tell her age unto an hour.
Goodbye!: Yes, I can tell her age to an hour.

Anon!: Whither, my lord?—Cesario, husband, stay.
Goodbye!: Where are you, my lord?—Cesario, husband, stay.

Anon!: What’s the matter?
Goodbye!: What’s the matter?

Anon!: I have done.
Goodbye!: I’ve done it.

Anon!: A tailor made thee.
Goodbye!: A tailor made you.

Anon!: Ay me!
Goodbye!: Yes, I’m!

Anon!: Wherein we saw thee quietly interred, Hath oped his ponderous and marble jaws To cast thee up again.
Goodbye!: Where we saw you quietly interred, he oped his ponderous and marble jaws to cast you up again.

Anon!: You gentle Romans—     Peace, ho!
Goodbye!: You gentle Romans— Be quiet!

Anon!: No matter, since They have left their viands behind, for we have stomachs.
Goodbye!: No matter, since they left their sneezes behind, because we have stomachs.

Anon!: It is but trash.
Goodbye!: It’s just trash.

Anon!: Up and down, up and down,  I will lead them up and down.
Goodbye!: I’ll lead them up and down, up and down.

Anon!: How, my lord, I may be censured, that nature thus gives way to loyalty, something fears me to think of.
Goodbye!: I’m afraid to think about how I can be saned, my lord.

Anon!: I’ll know thy thoughts.
Goodbye!: I’ll know your thoughts.

Anon!: How cheerest thou, Jessica?
Goodbye!: How are you cheering, Jessica?

Anon!: For lead?
Goodbye!: For lead?

Anon!: Where we lay, Our chimneys were blown down and, as they say, Lamentings heard i' th' air, strange screams of death, And prophesying with accents terrible Of dire combustion and confused events New hatched to the woeful time.
Goodbye!: Where we lay, our chimneys were blown down and, as they say, lamentings heard in the air, strange screams of death, and prophesied with accents terrible of dire combustion and confused events

Anon!: The time is free.
Goodbye!: The time is free.

Anon!: Very well mended.
Goodbye!: Very well mended.

Anon!: Get you to your lord.
Goodbye!: Get to your lord.

Anon!: He followed you.
Goodbye!: He followed you.

Anon!: Out.
Goodbye!: Out.

Anon!: What, not a word?
Goodbye!: What, not a word?

Anon!: Go in with me.
Goodbye!: Go in with me.

Anon!: A stoup of wine!
Goodbye!: A stoup of wine!

Anon!: I hear him mock The luck of Caesar, which the gods give men To excuse their after wrath.—Husband, I come!
Goodbye!: I hear him mock Caesar’s luck, which the gods give men to excuse their wrath.—Husband, I’m coming!

Anon!: He lies not like the living.
Goodbye!: He’s not living like a living man.

Anon!: Do you love me?
Goodbye!: Do you love me?

Anon!: If you would take the pains but to examine the wars of Pompey the Great, you shall find, I warrant you, that there is no tiddle toddle nor pibble babble in Pompey’s camp.
Goodbye!: If you’re only trying to examine the wars of Pompey the Great, I assure you, there’s no tiddle toddle or pibble babble in Pompey’s camp.

Anon!: Ay, there it is.
Goodbye!: Yes, here it is.

Anon!: Time is come round, And where I did begin, there shall I end.
Goodbye!: Time has come round, and where I started, I’ll end up.

Anon!: Why, you were with him, were you not?
Goodbye!: Why, you were with him, didn’t you?

Anon!: Where’s Dolabella, To second Proculeius?
Goodbye!: Where’s Dolabella, to second Proculeius?

Anon!: Tut, tut, thou art all ice; thy kindness freezes.
Goodbye!: Oh, you’re iced, your kindness freezes.

Anon!: Ay.
Goodbye!: Yes.

Anon!: A ring he hath of mine worth forty ducats, And for the same he promised me a chain.
Goodbye!: He has a ring worth forty ducats, and for the same reason he promised me a necklace.

Anon!: I would have daffed all other respects and made her half myself.
Goodbye!: I wish I had done all other things and made her half myself.

Anon!: A gentleman, Nurse, that loves to hear himself talk, and will speak more in a minute than he will stand to in a month.
Goodbye!: Nurse, a gentleman who loves to hear himself talk, and will speak more in a minute than he will stand to speak in a month.

Anon!: And his kinsman too.
Goodbye!: And his father too.

Anon!: How did you find the quarrel on the seventh cause?
Goodbye!: How did you find the fight on the seventh cause?

Anon!: And, being men, bearing the will of Caesar, It will inflame you, it will make you mad.
Goodbye!: And being men, with the will of Caesar, it will inflame you, it will make you crazy.

Anon!: The other half comes to the general state, Which humbleness may drive unto a fine.
Goodbye!: The other half comes to the general state, which is a fine.

Anon!: Come, instance.
Goodbye!: Come, example.

Anon!: Is ’t come to this?
Goodbye!: Is it coming to this?

Anon!: Fly?
Goodbye!: Fly?

Anon!: Help to dress me, good coz, good Meg, good Ursula.
Goodbye!: Help me dress up, good coz, good Meg, good Ursula.

Anon!: Oh, that woman that cannot make her fault her husband’s occasion, let her never nurse her child herself, for she will breed it like a fool.
Goodbye!: Oh, the woman who can’t make her fault her husband’s occasion, will never nurse her child herself, because she’ll make it look like a fool.

Anon!: Didst thou not hear somebody?
Goodbye!: Didn’t you hear someone?

Anon!: I would they were, that I might die at once, For now they kill me with a living death.
Goodbye!: I wish they were, so I could die instantly, because now they kill me with a living death.

Anon!: Messala!
Goodbye!: Messala!

Anon!: Good morrow, both.
Goodbye!: Good morning, both of you.

Anon!: I’ll not believe ’t.
Goodbye!: I don’t believe it.

Anon!: What is it she does now?
Goodbye!: What’s she doing now?

Anon!: How is ’t?
Goodbye!: How is it?

Anon!: Shall we do that?
Goodbye!: Should we do that?

Anon!: Here comes your father.
Goodbye!: Here comes your father.

Anon!: Time, thou anticipat’st my dread exploits.
Goodbye!: Time, you’re anticipating my terrible exploits.

Anon!: Yes, in truth it is, sir.
Goodbye!: Yes, it’s true, sir.

Anon!: Urge the necessity and state of times, And be not peevish found in great designs.
Goodbye!: Tell us the necessity and the situation of times, and don’t be peeved in great designs.

Anon!: Ah, soldier!
Goodbye!: Ah, soldier!

Anon!: Thou hast me, if thou hast me, at the worst, and thou shalt wear me, if thou wear me, better and better.
Goodbye!: You have me, if you have me, at the worst, and you’ll wear me better and better if you have me.

Anon!: Oh, noble weakness!
Goodbye!: Oh, noble weakness!

Anon!: Husband?
Goodbye!: Husband?

Anon!: And welcome more common, for that’s nothing but words.
Goodbye!: And welcome is more common, because that’s nothing but words.

Anon!: I will bring you thither.
Goodbye!: I’ll bring you there.

Anon!: Go get some water, And wash this filthy witness from your hand.
Goodbye!: Go get some water and wash this dirty witness from your hand.

Anon!: There was none such in the army of any sort.
Goodbye!: There was no such army in any way.

Anon!: Fie, Fie, lieutenant, You’ll be ashamed for ever.
Goodbye!: You’ll be ashamed for being here forever, sir.

Anon!: I am sorry For your displeasure, but all will sure be well.
Goodbye!: I’m sorry for your dissatisfaction, but everything will be good.

Anon!: Begone.— On, officer, to prison till it come.
Goodbye!: Go on.—Onward, officer, to prison until it comes.

Anon!: As I discern, It burneth in the Capels' monument.
Goodbye!: As I see, it’s burning in the Capels’ tomb.

Anon!: What man dost thou dig it for?
Goodbye!: What man do you dig it for?

Anon!: What Tranio did, myself enforced him to.
Goodbye!: What Tranio did, I told him to do that.

Anon!: Oh!
Goodbye!: Oh!

Anon!: More of this hereafter.
Goodbye!: More about this later.

Anon!: Death lies on her like an untimely frost Upon the sweetest flower of all the field.
Goodbye!: Death is on her like a frost on the sweetest flower in the world.

Anon!: Up so.
Goodbye!: That’s right.

Anon!: I’ll go alone.
Goodbye!: I’ll go alone.

Anon!: Conceit, more rich in matter than in words, Brags of his substance, not of ornament.
Goodbye!: Conceit, more rich in matter than in words, Brags of his substance, not of ornament.

Anon!: I will depart in quiet And, in despite of mirth, mean to be merry.
Goodbye!: I’ll leave in quiet, and I’ll be a merry man, despite my sanity.

Anon!: I will bite my thumb at them, which is a disgrace to them, if they bear it.
Goodbye!: I’ll bite my thumb at them, which is a shame to them, if they bear it.

Anon!: I can tell you it will serve you to mend your shoes.
Goodbye!: I can tell you that it will help you to wear your shoes.

Anon!: I am not what I am.
Goodbye!: I am not what I am.

Anon!: Lead me on.
Goodbye!: Lead me on.

Anon!: Poison, I see, hath been his timeless end.— O churl, drunk all, and left no friendly drop To help me after?
Goodbye!: I see, it’s been his lifelong end.—Oh, if you’re drunk, you’re drunk, and you’ve left no friendly drop to help me after that?

Anon!: I am thy father’s spirit, Doomed for a certain term to walk the night And for the day confined to fast in fires, Till the foul crimes done in my days of nature Are burnt and purged away.
Goodbye!: I’m your father’s spirit, doomed for a certain period to walk the night and for the day to be confined to fires until the terrible crimes I’ve committed in my days of nature are burnt and

Anon!: Ay, when the special thing is well obtained, That is, her love, for that is all in all.
Goodbye!: Yes, when the special thing is well obtained, that’s her love, because that’s all in all.

Anon!: Fears and scruples shake us.
Goodbye!: Fears and scruples shake us.

Anon!: You must not stay here longer.
Goodbye!: You can’t stay here longer.

Anon!: I cannot tell.
Goodbye!: I don’t know.

Anon!: It is so.
Goodbye!: It is.

Anon!: Use Desdemona well.
Goodbye!: Use Desdemona well.

Anon!: Go, get thee hence.
Goodbye!: Go, get out of here.

Anon!: Beggar that I am, I am even poor in thanks; but I thank you, and sure, dear friends, my thanks are too dear a halfpenny.
Goodbye!: I’m so sorry I’m not, but I thank you, and I’m sure, dear friends, my thanks are too dear.

Anon!: Now fare you well, good sir.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, good sir.

Anon!: He stays upon your will.
Goodbye!: He’s still in your will.

Anon!: And to that place the sharp Athenian law Cannot pursue us.
Goodbye!: And to that point, the athenian law can’t pursue us.

Anon!: I do but stay till your marriage be consummate, and then go I toward Aragon.
Goodbye!: I’ll wait until you’re married, and then I’ll go to Aragon.

Anon!: My present business calls me from you now.
Goodbye!: My business is calling me away from you now.

Anon!: That the soul of our grandam might haply inhabit a bird.
Goodbye!: That the soul of our grandam could inhabit a bird.

Anon!: She that makes dainty, She, I’ll swear, hath corns.
Goodbye!: She’s a dainty woman, I’ll swear, she’s a corn.

Anon!: Where do you dwell?
Goodbye!: Where do you live?

Anon!: Ay, mistress, and Petruchio is the master, That teacheth tricks eleven and twenty long To tame a shrew and charm her chattering tongue.
Goodbye!: Yes, mistress, and Petruchio is the master, who has taught you eleven and twenty tricks to tame a shrew and charm her chattering tongue.

Anon!: That is the sum of all, Leonato.—Signior Claudio and Signior Benedick, my dear friend Leonato hath invited you all.
Goodbye!: That’s the sum of everything, Leonato.—Signior Claudio and Signior Benedick, my dear friend Leonato has invited you all.

Anon!: Though all the world could see, None could be so abused in sight as he.
Goodbye!: Though all the world could see, none could be as abused in sight as he did.

Anon!: You know I gave it you half an hour since.
Goodbye!: You know I gave it to you for a half hour now.

Anon!: Utter my thoughts?
Goodbye!: What are my thoughts?

Anon!: But chiefly Him that you termed, sir, “the good old Lord Gonzalo,” His tears run down his beard like winter’s drops From eaves of reeds.
Goodbye!: But he’s tearing down his beard, like winter’s drops from reeds.

Anon!: Oh, did he so?
Goodbye!: Oh, did he?

Anon!: Although I joy in thee, I have no joy of this contract tonight.
Goodbye!: Even though I’m happy with you, I’m not happy with this contract tonight.

Anon!: Truly then I fear you are damned both by father and mother.
Goodbye!: I’m afraid you’re both damned by father and mother.

Anon!: Come, night.
Goodbye!: Come, night.

Anon!: Bellario greets your grace.
Goodbye!: Bellario greets you.

Anon!: Stand fast together, lest some friend of Caesar’s Should chance— Talk not of standing.—Publius, good cheer.
Goodbye!: Stand fast together, so some friend of Caesar’s can’t talk about standing.

Anon!: Where the devil should this Romeo be?
Goodbye!: Where the devil should Romeo be?

Anon!: Saint Davy’s day is past.
Goodbye!: Saint Davy’s day has passed.

Anon!: You’ll ask me why I rather choose to have A weight of carrion flesh than to receive Three thousand ducats.
Goodbye!: You’ll ask me why I prefer to have a weight of carrion flesh than to receive three thousand ducats.

Anon!: I hear some noise.
Goodbye!: I hear some noise.

Anon!: I am glad of your departure.
Goodbye!: I’m glad you’ve left.

Anon!: Murder most foul, as in the best it is.
Goodbye!: Murder is most foul, as it is in the best way possible.

Anon!: O bear me witness, night— What man is this?
Goodbye!: Oh, bear me witness, night— What man is this?

Anon!: O, farewell, honest soldier.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, honest soldier.

Anon!: Thou shalt not die.
Goodbye!: You won’t die.

Anon!: He would not have spoke such a word.
Goodbye!: He wouldn’t have spoken such a word.

Anon!: Let him be the devil, an he will, I care not.
Goodbye!: Let him be the devil, if he will, I don’t care.

Anon!: Adieu.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: Know I these men that come along with you?
Goodbye!: Do I know the men who come with you?

Anon!: Upon my honor— Then came each actor on his ass—
Goodbye!: Then each actor came on his ass.

Anon!: Where may we set our horses?
Goodbye!: Where can we put our horses?

Anon!: But it shall not be so long; this wrestler shall clear all.
Goodbye!: But it won’t take so long.

Anon!: How goes it with my brave Mark Antony?
Goodbye!: How is it with my brave Mark Antony?

Anon!: Be fickle, fortune, For then, I hope, thou wilt not keep him long, But send him back.
Goodbye!: Be a bit frightened, fortune, then, I hope, you won’t keep him long, but send him back.

Anon!: Invoke his warlike spirit And your great-uncle’s, Edward the Black Prince, Who on the French ground played a tragedy, Making defeat on the full power of France Whiles his most mighty father on a hill Stood smiling to behold his lion’s whelp Forage in blood of French nobility.
Goodbye!: Invoke his warlike spirit and your great-uncle’s Edward the Black Prince, who played a tragedy on the French ground, making France’s full power while his mighty father on a hill Stood smiling

Anon!: We did, my lord, weeping and commenting Upon the sobbing deer.
Goodbye!: We did, my lord, weeping and commenting on the sobbing deer.

Anon!: Not shine today?
Goodbye!: Don’t shine today?

Anon!: I take it your own business calls on you And you embrace th' occasion to depart.
Goodbye!: I think your own business demands you to leave, and you accept the occasion to leave.

Anon!: Lives my sweet son?
Goodbye!: Is my sweet son alive?

Anon!: But how, but how?
Goodbye!: But how?

Anon!: Good heart, at what?
Goodbye!: Good heart, what?

Anon!: Who can arraign me for ’t?
Goodbye!: Who can arraign me for it?

Anon!: I was always plain with you, and so now I speak my agitation of the matter.
Goodbye!: I was always in touch with you, and now I’m talking about my anger.

Anon!: How is ’t, my noble lord?
Goodbye!: How is it, my noble lord?

Anon!: Peace, you rogue, no more o' that.
Goodbye!: You rogue, don’t worry about that.

Anon!: I will not sleep, Hortensio, till I see her, And therefore let me be thus bold with you To give you over at this first encounter, Unless you will accompany me thither.
Goodbye!: I won’t sleep until I see her, Hortensio.

Anon!: We shall, my lord.
Goodbye!: We will, my lord.

Anon!: The morn is fair.
Goodbye!: The morning is fair.

Anon!: Woo’t thou fight well?
Goodbye!: Do you want to fight well?

Anon!: Most noble brother, you have done me wrong.
Goodbye!: Most noble brother, you’ve done me wrong.

Anon!: Goodman Verges, sir, speaks a little off the matter.
Goodbye!: Goodman Verges, sir, speaks a little about the matter.

Anon!: What would you with her, sir?
Goodbye!: What do you want with her, sir?

Anon!: Not in a grave, To lay one in, another out to have.
Goodbye!: Not in a grave, to lay one in a grave, another out to have.

Anon!: Therefore heaven nature charged That one body should be filled With all graces wide-enlarged.
Goodbye!: So nature wanted to fill one body with all the graces.

Anon!: Oh, it is my love.
Goodbye!: Oh, it’s my love.

Anon!: Dromio, go bid the servants spread for dinner.
Goodbye!: Dromio, go ask the servants to spread for dinner.

Anon!: Go waken Juliet.
Goodbye!: Go wake Juliet.

Anon!: Are you of good or evil?
Goodbye!: Are you good or evil?

Anon!: Can you make no use of your discontent?
Goodbye!: Can’t you use your discontent to make money?

Anon!: I may not, madam.
Goodbye!: I can’t, madam.

Anon!: Yet hear me speak.
Goodbye!: But listen to me.

Anon!: Being so frustrate, tell him, he mocks The pauses that he makes.
Goodbye!: Being so frustrate, tell him, he mocks the pauses he makes.

Anon!: With sweetest touches pierce your mistress' ear, And draw her home with music.
Goodbye!: The sweetest touches are piercing your mistress’s ear and bringing her home with music.

Anon!: Lady, shall I lie in your lap?
Goodbye!: Lady, should I lie in your lap?

Anon!: You keep by land The legions and the horse whole, do you not?
Goodbye!: You keep the legions and the horse whole, don’t you?

Anon!: Marry, I will, and this is wisely done.
Goodbye!: I will, and this is wisely done.

Anon!: The little dogs and all, Tray, Blanch, and Sweetheart—see, they bark at me.
Goodbye!: The little dogs and all, Tray, Blanch, and Sweetheart—see, they bark at me.

Anon!: What doth she say, my lord of Buckingham?
Goodbye!: What does she say, my lord of Buckingham?

Anon!: Then brook abridgment, and your eyes advance After your thoughts, straight back again to France.
Goodbye!: Then brook abridgment, and your eyes are coming back to France after your thoughts.

Anon!: Lead, monster; we’ll follow.
Goodbye!: Lead, monster; we’ll follow.

Anon!: And I for Ganymede.
Goodbye!: And I for Ganymede.

Anon!: Why hath thy queen Summoned me hither to this short-grassed green?
Goodbye!: Why have you sung me to this green green?

Anon!: Oh, this is the poison of deep grief.
Goodbye!: Oh, this is the poison of deep grief.

Anon!: Nay, it is.
Goodbye!: No, it is.

Anon!: Here’s one, a friend, and one that knows you well.
Goodbye!: Here’s one, a friend, and one who knows you well.

Anon!: Is this your speeding?
Goodbye!: Is this your speeding?

Anon!: My lady charged my duty in this business.
Goodbye!: My lady was responsible for this business.

Anon!: We cannot fight for love as men may do.
Goodbye!: We can’t fight for love as men can.

Anon!: Go back again, thou slave, and fetch him home.
Goodbye!: Go back again, you slave, and bring him home.

Anon!: What country, friends, is this?
Goodbye!: What country is this, friends?

Anon!: It hath the primal eldest curse upon ’t, A brother’s murder.
Goodbye!: It’s the eldest curse on it, a brother’s murder.

Anon!: If thou beest not immortal, look about you.
Goodbye!: If you’re not immortal, look at you.

Anon!: No further, sir.
Goodbye!: Don’t go any further, sir.

Anon!: My back a' t' other side.
Goodbye!: My back is on the other side.

Anon!: Therefore the moon, the governess of floods, Pale in her anger, washes all the air, That rheumatic diseases do abound.
Goodbye!: So the moon, the ruler of floods, is savaged in her anger, so that rheumatic diseases are everywhere.

Anon!: Whither?
Goodbye!: Where?

Anon!: Arise, you shall not kneel.
Goodbye!: You’re not going to kneel.

Anon!: By heaven, I charge thee, speak.
Goodbye!: I swear, by heaven, I’ll tell you.

Anon!: There lies the duke asleep, and there the keys.
Goodbye!: There’s the duke asleep, and there’s the keys.

Anon!: Farewell, farewell.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, goodbye.

Anon!: Remember me.” I have sworn ’t.
Goodbye!: Remember me.” I’ve sworn it.

Anon!: I know not.
Goodbye!: I don’t know.

Anon!: Not I, my lord.
Goodbye!: Not me, my lord.

Anon!: Here’s no knavery!
Goodbye!: Here’s no knathing!

Anon!: That’s a certain text.
Goodbye!: That’s a certain text.

Anon!: What said he when he came unto himself?
Goodbye!: What did he say when he came to himself?

Anon!: No disgrace Shall fall you for refusing him at sea, Being prepared for land.
Goodbye!: You won’t be ashamed of refusing him at sea, even if you’re ready for land.

Anon!: Tell me, that I may sack The hateful mansion.
Goodbye!: Tell me, so I can sack the hateful mansion.

Anon!: You have some cause; they have not.
Goodbye!: You have some reason, they don’t.

Anon!: Marry, come up, I trow.
Goodbye!: Come on, I’ll trow.

Anon!: Oh, much I fear some ill unthrifty thing.
Goodbye!: Oh, I’m afraid some ill-looking thing.

Anon!: Rest you merry!
Goodbye!: Have a good day!

Anon!: Whether this be Or be not, I’ll not swear.
Goodbye!: I won’t swear if this is or not.

Anon!: God for Thy mercy, they are loose again!
Goodbye!: God for your mercy, they’re loose again!

Anon!: But where was this?
Goodbye!: But where was this?

Anon!: Mercutio’s kinsman, noble County Paris.
Goodbye!: Mercutio’s heir, noble Count Paris.

Anon!: Will you dispatch us here under this tree, or shall we go with you to your chapel?
Goodbye!: Will you send us here under this tree, or will we go with you to your chapel?

Anon!: By my troth, sir, no—though it please you to be one of my friends.
Goodbye!: No—though it’s good to be one of my friends.

Anon!: Vent my folly!
Goodbye!: Stop my nonsense!

Anon!: List'ning their fear I could not say “Amen,” When they did say “God bless us!” Consider it not so deeply.
Goodbye!: I couldn’t say “Amen,” when they said “God bless us!” Don’t think about it so deeply.

Anon!: I’ll in to counsel them.
Goodbye!: I’ll come in to counsel them.

Anon!: In bed asleep while they do dream things true.
Goodbye!: They’re asleep in bed while they dream about it.

Anon!: Then is the world one.
Goodbye!: Then the world is one.

Anon!: I take no pleasure In aught an eunuch has.
Goodbye!: I don’t like the way an eunuch is.

Anon!: No, to Whitefriars.
Goodbye!: No, to Whitefriars.

Anon!: O all you host of heaven!
Goodbye!: Oh, all you host of heaven!

Anon!: I’ll be before thee.
Goodbye!: I’ll be there.

Anon!: Thy conceit is nearer death than thy powers.
Goodbye!: Your conceit is closer to death than your powers are.

Anon!: Is ’t not Hortensio?
Goodbye!: Isn’t Hortensio?

Anon!: O God, your only jig-maker.
Goodbye!: Oh God, you’re the only jig-maker.

Anon!: There is no more but so.
Goodbye!: There’s nothing else than that.

Anon!: Fly, good Fleance, fly, fly, fly!
Goodbye!: Fly, good Fleance, fly, fly, fly!

Anon!: My villainy?
Goodbye!: My villainy?

Anon!: Their course of love, the tidings of her death.
Goodbye!: Their love course, the tidal of her death.

Anon!: But, alas, Caesar must bleed for it.
Goodbye!: But, alas, Caesar must bleed for it.

Anon!: Witless else her son.
Goodbye!: She’s a witty son.

Anon!: My dagger, little cousin?
Goodbye!: My dagger, little cousin?

Anon!: I have used thee, Filth as thou art, with human care, and lodged thee In mine own cell till thou didst seek to violate The honor of my child.
Goodbye!: I’ve used you, as you are, with human care, and I’ve put you in my own cell until you’ve tried to violate the honor of my child.

Anon!: And so say I.
Goodbye!: And so say I.

Anon!: I am amazed and know not what to say.
Goodbye!: I’m amazed and don’t know what to say.

Anon!: Confusion’s cure lives not In these confusions.
Goodbye!: Confusion’s cure doesn’t live in these confusions.

Anon!: Which soon he granted, Being an obstruct ’tween his lust and him.
Goodbye!: He gave it soon, because he was a obstructing his lust and his lust.

Anon!: A single thing, as I am now, that wonders To hear thee speak of Naples.
Goodbye!: I’m not a single thing that wonders to hear you speak of Naples.

Anon!: I have done ill, Of which I do accuse myself so sorely That I will joy no more.
Goodbye!: I’ve done a bad thing, and I’m so angry that I won’t rejoice anymore.

Anon!: Do you find some occasion to anger Cassio, either by speaking too loud, or tainting his discipline, or from what other course you please, which the time shall more favorably minister.
