Goodbye!: You’re tempted to anger Cassio either by speaking too loud or tainting his discipline, or by letting him go, and you’ll be more likely to minister.

Anon!: Get thee gone.
Goodbye!: Go away.

Anon!: At Sardis once, And this last night here in Philippi fields.
Goodbye!: At Sardis once, and this last night here in Philippi fields.

Anon!: There’s another.
Goodbye!: There’s another.

Anon!: Cleopatra— Think you there was or might be such a man As this I dreamt of?
Goodbye!: Cleopatra— Do you think there was or could be such a man as this I dreamed of?

Anon!: I pray you, sir, my ring or else the chain.
Goodbye!: Please, sir, my ring or the other one.

Anon!: Fortune pursue thee!
Goodbye!: Good luck!

Anon!: Words without thoughts never to heaven go.
Goodbye!: Words without thoughts never go to heaven.

Anon!: And for mine own part, I durst not laugh for fear of opening my lips and receiving the bad air.
Goodbye!: And for my own part, I wouldn’t laugh for fear of opening my lips and receiving the bad air.

Anon!: These three world-sharers, these competitors, Are in thy vessel.
Goodbye!: These three world-sharers, these competitors, are in your vessel.

Anon!: Since the torch is out, Lie down and stray no farther.
Goodbye!: Since the torch is out, don’t lie down and go no further.

Anon!: The knave counterfeits well.
Goodbye!: The knave is good.

Anon!: Tis very grievous to be thought upon.
Goodbye!: It’s very sad to think about it.

Anon!: Of fighting men they have full threescore thousand.
Goodbye!: Of fighting men they have full threescore thousand.

Anon!: Ask me not what I know.
Goodbye!: Don’t ask me what I know.

Anon!: Too swift arrives as tardy as too slow.
Goodbye!: Too fast is as late as too slow.

Anon!: In praising Antony, I have dispraised Caesar.
Goodbye!: In praising Antony, I’ve dispraised Caesar.

Anon!: A guiltless death I die.
Goodbye!: I’m dying a sinless death.

Anon!: A damnèd death!
Goodbye!: A damned death!

Anon!: What should we say, my lord?
Goodbye!: What should we say, my lord?

Anon!: His absence, sir, Lays blame upon his promise.
Goodbye!: His absence, sir, blames his promise.

Anon!: Naught that I am, Not for their own demerits, but for mine, Fell slaughter on their souls.
Goodbye!: I’m not a victim of their own crimes, but a victim of mine.

Anon!: Let him alone, for I remember now How he’s employed.
Goodbye!: Let him be alone, because I remember how he’s employed.

Anon!: Hast any philosophy in thee, shepherd?
Goodbye!: Has anyone else taught you anything, shepherd?

Anon!: Oh, that I were a man for his sake!
Goodbye!: Oh, I wish I were a man for his sake!

Anon!: No, no, I am as ugly as a bear, For beasts that meet me run away for fear.
Goodbye!: No, no, I’m as ugly as a bear, because beasts who meet me run away from me for fear.

Anon!: Why then, you are in love.
Goodbye!: Well then, you’re in love.

Anon!: I am sorry for her, as I have just cause, being her uncle and her guardian.
Goodbye!: I’m sorry for her, as I have just reason to be her uncle and guardian.

Anon!: I saw no man use you at his pleasure.
Goodbye!: I didn’t see any man use you to do his job.

Anon!: But what is your affair in Elsinore?
Goodbye!: But what’s your affair in Elsinore?

Anon!: You received no gold?
Goodbye!: You didn’t receive any gold?

Anon!: Therefore weep.
Goodbye!: So cry.

Anon!: Use your authority.
Goodbye!: Use your authority.

Anon!: Fare you well, my lord.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, my lord.

Anon!: Give me a cup of wine.
Goodbye!: Give me a cup of wine.

Anon!: While then, God be with you!
Goodbye!: Until then, God be with you!

Anon!: How oft tonight Have my old feet stumbled at graves!—Who’s there?
Goodbye!: How often tonight have my old feet stumbled at graves!—Who’s there?

Anon!: My spirits are nimble.
Goodbye!: My spirits are nimble.

Anon!: Huntsman, I charge thee, tender well my hounds.
Goodbye!: Huntsman, I charge you, tender my hounds.

Anon!: Or, if thou wilt, swear by thy gracious self, Which is the god of my idolatry, And I’ll believe thee.
Goodbye!: Or, if you want to swear by your gracious self, which is the god of my idolatry, and I’ll believe you.

Anon!: Dost thou know me, fellow?
Goodbye!: Do you know me, fellow?

Anon!: My lord and master loves you.
Goodbye!: My lord and master love you.

Anon!: Cassius from bondage will deliver Cassius.
Goodbye!: Cassius will deliver Cassius from the bondage.

Anon!: Much castigation, exercise devout, For here’s a young and sweating devil here, That commonly rebels.
Goodbye!: I’m a young, sweating devil here, who rebels.

Anon!: Therefore thou liest.
Goodbye!: So you’re dead.

Anon!: Ay, you have been a mouse-hunt in your time, But I will watch you from such watching now.
Goodbye!: Yes, you’ve been a mouse hunter in your time, but I’ll watch you out now.

Anon!: Very like a whale.
Goodbye!: Very similar to a whale.

Anon!: Wherefore are these things hid?
Goodbye!: Why are these things hiding?

Anon!: He ran this way and leapt this orchard wall.
Goodbye!: He ran this way and leapt over this orchard wall.

Anon!: He has deserved it, were it carbuncled Like holy Phoebus’ car.
Goodbye!: He deserves it, if it were sprayed like a holy Phoebus’ car.

Anon!: The gray-eyed morn smiles on the frowning night, Checkering the eastern clouds with streaks of light, And fleckled darkness like a drunkard reels From forth day’s path and Titan’s fiery wheels.
Goodbye!: The gray-eyed morn smiles on the frowning night, checking the eastern clouds with streaks of light, and fleckled darkness like a drunken reels from the day’s path and Titan’s fier

Anon!: Nay, I know not.
Goodbye!: No, I don’t know.

Anon!: O gull!
Goodbye!: Oh, oh, oh!

Anon!: Yet I will adventure.
Goodbye!: But I’ll go.

Anon!: Happy be Theseus, our renownèd duke.
Goodbye!: Happy be Theseus, our renowned duke.

Anon!: For then I’ll marry Warwick’s youngest daughter.
Goodbye!: I’ll marry Warwick’s youngest daughter.

Anon!: My child, my only life, Revive, look up, or I will die with thee!— Help, help!
Goodbye!: My child, my only life, go look up, or I’ll die with you!—Help!

Anon!: Kent, sir, the banished Kent, who in disguise Followed his enemy king and did him service Improper for a slave.
Goodbye!: Kent, sir, the banished Kent, who disguisedly followed his enemy king and did him service as a slave.

Anon!: I heard the owl scream and the crickets cry.
Goodbye!: I heard the owl scream and the crickets cry.

Anon!: Come, warble, come.
Goodbye!: Come, warble, come.

Anon!: While we were interchanging thrusts and blows, Came more and more and fought on part and part, Till the Prince came, who parted either part.
Goodbye!: While we were fighting, we fought on both sides, until the Prince came, who parted either of them.

Anon!: That is because the traitor murderer lives.
Goodbye!: That’s because the murderer of the traitors lives.

Anon!: Such news, my lord, as grieves me to report.
Goodbye!: That’s what I’m grieving to report, my lord.

Anon!: Ah, where’s my man?—Give me some aqua vitae.— These griefs, these woes, these sorrows make me old.
Goodbye!: Ah, where’s my man?—Give me some vitae.—These griefs, these sorrows, these sorrows make me old.

Anon!: She is too big, I hope, for me to compass.
Goodbye!: She’s too big for me to compass.

Anon!: Who’s that?
Goodbye!: Who’s that?

Anon!: It’s suppertime, my lord.
Goodbye!: It’s dinnertime, my lord.

Anon!: You shall never take her without her answer unless you take her without her tongue.
Goodbye!: You’ll never take her without her answer unless you take her without her tongue.

Anon!: Seal then, and all is done.— Eros!—I come, my Queen.—Eros!—Stay for me.
Goodbye!: Seal then, and everything is done.—Eros!—I’m coming, my Queen.—Eros!—Stay for me.

Anon!: If your Majesties is remembered of it, the Welshmen did good service in a garden where leeks did grow, wearing leeks in their Monmouth caps, which, your Majesty know, to this hour is an honorable badge of the service.
Goodbye!: If your Majesties remember it, the Welshmen did good service in a garden where leeks grew, wearing leeks in their Monmouth caps, which, you know, is an honorable badge of service to you.

Anon!: Out, alas!
Goodbye!: Out, sorry!

Anon!: I am but hurt.
Goodbye!: I’m only hurt.

Anon!: And wilt thou have me?
Goodbye!: And do you want to have me?

Anon!: Sunday comes apace.
Goodbye!: Sunday comes quickly.

Anon!: My good lord.
Goodbye!: My good lord.

Anon!: All things in common nature should produce Without sweat or endeavor.
Goodbye!: All things in common should be produced without sweat or effort.

Anon!: And you too, sir.
Goodbye!: And you too, sir.

Anon!: That I did for him.
Goodbye!: I did that for him.

Anon!: Groan!
Goodbye!: Groan!

Anon!: That’s my office.
Goodbye!: That’s my job.

Anon!: To wreak the love I bore my cousin Upon his body that slaughtered him!
Goodbye!: I’ll wreak the love I bore my cousin on his body that slaughtered him!

Anon!: And then he offered it the third time.
Goodbye!: And then he offered it the third time.

Anon!: What counterfeit did I give you?
Goodbye!: What counterfeit did I give you?

Anon!: I hate the word, As I hate hell, all Montagues, and thee.
Goodbye!: I hate the word, as I hate hell, all Montagues, and you.

Anon!: I.
Goodbye!: I.

Anon!: So be gone.
Goodbye!: So go away.

Anon!: Have at the very eye of that proverb with “A pox of the devil.”  You are the better at proverbs, by how much “A fool’s bolt is soon shot.”  You have shot over.
Goodbye!: You’re better at saying something, because you’re a fool’s bolt that’s soon shot.” You’ve shot over.

Anon!: Then does he say he lent me Some shipping, unrestored.
Goodbye!: Then he says he gave me some shipping, unrestored.

Anon!: This feather stirs.
Goodbye!: This feather is a squeak.

Anon!: Then weep no more.
Goodbye!: Then don’t cry.

Anon!: I wonder at it.
Goodbye!: I’m wondering.

Anon!: If not to answer, you might haply think Tongue-tied ambition, not replying, yielded To bear the golden yoke of sovereignty, Which fondly you would here impose on me.
Goodbye!: If you don’t answer, you might think that a thorny ambition, not a reply, yielded to bear the golden yoke of sovereignty, which you would impose on me with a fond

Anon!: They swore that you were almost sick for me.
Goodbye!: They swore that you were almost sick for me.

Anon!: Go, prepare for dinner.
Goodbye!: Go ahead and prepare for dinner.

Anon!: Our instruments to melancholy bells, Our wedding cheer to a sad burial feast.
Goodbye!: Our wedding cheers for a sad burial feast.

Anon!: Well, as time shall try.
Goodbye!: Well, as time will tell.

Anon!: Go, bid the huntsmen wake them with their horns.
Goodbye!: Go, tell the huntsmen to wake them up with their horns.

Anon!: When they are in great danger, I recover them.
Goodbye!: When they’re in danger, I’ll recover them.

Anon!: Work, work your thoughts, and therein see a siege.
Goodbye!: Work, work your thoughts, and there you go see a siege.

Anon!: Then tell me If this might be a brother.
Goodbye!: Then tell me if this brother is a brother.

Anon!: And what other oath Than honesty to honesty engaged, That this shall be, or we will fall for it?
Goodbye!: And what other oath than honesty is owed to honesty, that this will be, or we’ll fall for it?

Anon!: Sooth, but you must.
Goodbye!: You must, but you must.

Anon!: Those that “Hobgoblin” call you, and “sweet Puck,” You do their work, and they shall have good luck.
Goodbye!: You’re doing their work, and they’ll have good luck.

Anon!: Know, Claudio, to thy head, Thou hast so wronged mine innocent child and me That I am forced to lay my reverence by, And with gray hairs and bruise of many days Do challenge thee to trial of a man.
Goodbye!: Claudio, you’ve wronged my innocent child and me so badly that I’ve been forced to give my reverence to you.

Anon!: Sir, he’s rash and very sudden in choler, and haply may strike at you.
Goodbye!: Sir, he’s rash and very sudden in choler, and he may strike at you.

Anon!: I thank you.
Goodbye!: Thank you.

Anon!: Any man that can write may answer a letter.
Goodbye!: Any man who can write can answer a letter.

Anon!: E'en so.
Goodbye!: That’s true.

Anon!: I do not think there is any such woman.
Goodbye!: I don’t think there’s any woman like that.

Anon!: That’s more than we know.
Goodbye!: That’s more than we know.

Anon!: Oh, you are sick of self-love, Malvolio, and taste with a distempered appetite.
Goodbye!: Oh, you’re sick of self-love, Malvolio, and you’re hungry.

Anon!: Will you mock at an ancient tradition begun upon an honorable respect and worn as a memorable trophy of predeceased valor, and dare not avouch in your deeds any of your words?
Goodbye!: Do you want to mock an ancient tradition that began with honorable respect and worn as a memorable trophy of valor, and don’t dare avouch in your actions any of your words?

Anon!: Well, Juliet, I will lie with thee tonight.
Goodbye!: Well, Juliet, I’ll lie with you tonight.

Anon!: Thou art translated.
Goodbye!: You’re translated.

Anon!: Not Cassio killed!
Goodbye!: Not Cassio killed!

Anon!: You have among you killed a sweet and innocent lady.
Goodbye!: You killed a sweet and innocent lady among you.

Anon!: Saw you him today?
Goodbye!: Did you see him today?

Anon!: Oh, I could weep My spirit from mine eyes.
Goodbye!: Oh, I could weep my spirit from my eyes.

Anon!: But this reasoning is not in the fashion to choose me a husband.
Goodbye!: But this isn’t the way to choose me for a husband.

Anon!: Budge not,” says my conscience.
Goodbye!: Don’t be afraid,” says my conscience.

Anon!: Let us come in, that we may bind him fast And bear him home for his recovery.
Goodbye!: Let’s come in so we can bind him fast and bring him home for his recovery.

Anon!: O Cleopatra!
Goodbye!: Oh Cleopatra!

Anon!: Reserve them till a merrier hour than this.
Goodbye!: Reserve them until a merrier hour than this.

Anon!: And nothing is at a like goodness still.
Goodbye!: And nothing is still at a good level.

Anon!: Question: why, an hour in clamor and a quarter in rheum.
Goodbye!: Question: why, an hour in a clamor and a quarter in rheum.

Anon!: Take thou that.
Goodbye!: Take that.

Anon!: Sure ones, then.
Goodbye!: Sure ones, then.

Anon!: I could do more to do Antonius good, But ’twould offend him, and in his offense Should my performance perish.
Goodbye!: I could do more to do Antonius good, but it would offend him, and if I perished, I’d be punished.

Anon!: Me they shall feel while I am able to stand, and ’tis known I am a pretty piece of flesh.
Goodbye!: I’ll feel like a pretty piece of flesh while I stand.

Anon!: I’ll not endure it.
Goodbye!: I won’t endure it.

Anon!: He does make our fire, Fetch in our wood, and serves in offices That profit us.—What, ho!
Goodbye!: He’s making our fires, fetching in our woods, and serves as a profitor.—What, ho!

Anon!: So that, conclusions to be as kisses, if your four negatives make your two affirmatives, why then the worse for my friends and the better for my foes.
Goodbye!: So, if your four negatives make your two affirmatives, then I’ll be worse for my friends and better for my enemies.

Anon!: Knock at the gate?
Goodbye!: Knock at the gate?

Anon!: Inquire the Jew’s house out.
Goodbye!: Ask the Jew’s house.

Anon!: Do the boys carry it away?
Goodbye!: Do the boys carry it away?

Anon!: You see how easily she may be surprised.
Goodbye!: You see how easily she might be surprised.

Anon!: The gold I gave to Dromio is laid up Safe at the Centaur, and the heedful slave Is wandered forth, in care to seek me out.
Goodbye!: The gold I gave Dromio is safe at the Centaur, and the heedful slave has wandered out, looking for me.

Anon!: If Signor Leonato be her father, she would not have his head on her shoulders for all Messina, as like him as she is.
Goodbye!: If Signor Leonato is her father, she wouldn’t have his head on her shoulders for all Messina, as like him as she is.

Anon!: Bonos dies, Sir Toby.
Goodbye!: Bonos dies, Sir Toby.

Anon!: Draw thy sword.
Goodbye!: Draw your sword.

Anon!: The broken rancor of your high-swoll'n hates, But lately splintered, knit, and joined together, Must gently be preserved, cherished, and kept.
Goodbye!: The broken rancor of your high-swoll's hates, but lately splintered, knitted, and joined together, must be preserved, cherished, and kept.

Anon!: Call 'em.
Goodbye!: Call them.

Anon!: Oh ho, oh ho!
Goodbye!: Oh ho, oh ho!

Anon!: My father’s spirit in arms.
Goodbye!: My father’s spirit is in arms.

Anon!: Who hath made this havoc with them?
Goodbye!: Who’s made this havoc with them?

Anon!: It stops me here, it is too much of joy.
Goodbye!: It’s too much joy to see you here.

Anon!: But I beseech your Grace pardon me.
Goodbye!: But please forgive me for pardoning your Grace.

Anon!: That’s my fear.
Goodbye!: That’s what I’m afraid of.

Anon!: Do not swear at all.
Goodbye!: Don’t swear at all.

Anon!: Yonder, sir, he walks.
Goodbye!: Yonder, sir, he’s walking.

Anon!: O my good master!
Goodbye!: Oh, my good master!

Anon!: And in the morn and liquid dew of youth, Contagious blastments are most imminent.
Goodbye!: And in the morning and in the morning of young men, deadly blasts are imminent.

Anon!: There’s not, I think, a subject That sits in heart-grief and uneasiness Under the sweet shade of your government.
Goodbye!: I don’t think there’s a subject that’s sane and unasinessless under the sweet shade of your government.

Anon!: And every object that might make me fear Misfortune to my ventures out of doubt Would make me sad.
Goodbye!: And every object that could make me fear misfortune to my ventures out of doubt would make me sad.

Anon!: Some food we had and some fresh water that A noble Neapolitan, Gonzalo, Out of his charity, who being then appointed Master of this design, did give us, with Rich garments, linens, stuffs, and necessaries, Which since have steaded much.
Goodbye!: We had some food and some fresh water that a noble Neapolitan, Gonzalo, who was appointed master of this design, gave us, with rich clothes, linens, stuffs, and necessaries,

Anon!: I can, Petruchio, help thee to a wife With wealth enough, and young and beauteous, Brought up as best becomes a gentlewoman.
Goodbye!: Petruchio, I can help you find a wife with enough wealth, young and wise, and he’s the best woman to become.

Anon!: Adieu.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: Tis time we twain Did show ourselves i’ th’ field, and to that end Assemble we immediate council.
Goodbye!: It’s time we threw out the field and assembled ourselves to the ground.

Anon!: Out, you green sickness, carrion!
Goodbye!: You green sickness, carrion!

Anon!: Am I come near ye now?— Welcome, gentlemen!
Goodbye!: Am I coming near you now?— Welcome, gentlemen!

Anon!: One is too poor, too weak for my revenge.
Goodbye!: One of us is too poor, too weak for my revenge.

Anon!: And whatsoever else shall hap tonight, Give it an understanding, but no tongue.
Goodbye!: And whatever else will happen tonight, give it a sense, but not a tongue.

Anon!: Declare thine office.
Goodbye!: Declare your job.

Anon!: The games are done and Caesar is returning.
Goodbye!: The games are finished and Caesar is returning.

Anon!: For if the sun breed maggots in a dead dog, being a good kissing carrion— Have you a daughter?
Goodbye!: If the sun breeds maggots in a dead dog, being a good kissing carrion— Have you a daughter?

Anon!: Tis no less, I tell you, for the bawdy hand of the dial is now upon the prick of noon.
Goodbye!: It’s no less, I tell you, because the sluggish hand of the dial is now on the prick of noon.

Anon!: My lord, I would that Thursday were tomorrow.
Goodbye!: My lord, I wish Thursday were tomorrow.

Anon!: Who does beguile you?
Goodbye!: Who’s guiling you?

Anon!: I prithee, hear me speak.
Goodbye!: Please, listen to me.

Anon!: So did you me, my liege.
Goodbye!: I did, my liege.

Anon!: Go forth, Agrippa, and begin the fight.
Goodbye!: Go out, Agrippa, and start the fight.

Anon!: You told me so.
Goodbye!: You told me that.

Anon!: Now must I to the monument alone.
Goodbye!: Now I have to go to the monument alone.

Anon!: I will possess you of that ship and treasure.
Goodbye!: I’ll take you from that ship and treasure.

Anon!: Why, it stood by her.
Goodbye!: Well, it stood by her.

Anon!: Thou hast forspoke my being in these wars And sayst it is not fit.
Goodbye!: You’ve told me I’m in these wars and said it’s not right.

Anon!: Down with the Capulets!
Goodbye!: Down with the Capulets!

Anon!: You are well fleshed.
Goodbye!: You’re well-prepared.

Anon!: It is the part of men to fear and tremble When the most mighty gods by tokens send Such dreadful heralds to astonish us.
Goodbye!: It’s the part of men to fear and tremble when the mighty gods send such terrible heralds to amaze us.

Anon!: Tis past, and so am I.
Goodbye!: It’s past, and so am I.

Anon!: Richard except, those whom we fight against Had rather have us win than him they follow.
Goodbye!: Richard, except those who fight against us would rather win than follow him.

Anon!: If not, why then this parting was well made.
Goodbye!: If not, then this parting was well done.

Anon!: They are loves I bear to you.
Goodbye!: I’m glad to see you.

Anon!: Thou art a cobbler, art thou?
Goodbye!: Are you a cobbler?

Anon!: He would make but a sport of it and torment the poor lady worse.
Goodbye!: He’d make it a sport and torment the poor lady.

Anon!: Alexas!
Goodbye!: Alexas!

Anon!: We see how mortal an unkindness is to them.
Goodbye!: We see how mortal and unkind they are.

Anon!: No.
Goodbye!: No.

Anon!: I do know him by his gait.
Goodbye!: I know him by his gait.

Anon!: Soft!
Goodbye!: Get out of here!

Anon!: Even those you were wont to take delight in, the tragedians of the city.
Goodbye!: The tragedians of the city are the ones you were willing to delight in.

Anon!: Even so.
Goodbye!: That’s true.

Anon!: An’t please your Honor, players That offer service to your Lordship.
Goodbye!: You can’t please your Honor, players who offer service to your Lordship.

Anon!: The article of my oath?
Goodbye!: What’s the article of my oath?

Anon!: You may be pleased to catch at mine intent By what did here befall me.
Goodbye!: You may be pleased to see what happened here.

Anon!: I think that one of them is hereabout, And cannot make away.
Goodbye!: I think one of them is here, and I can’t make it away.

Anon!: O Brutus!
Goodbye!: Oh, Brutus!

Anon!: Thy father!
Goodbye!: Your father!

Anon!: What think you on ’t?
Goodbye!: What do you think about it?

Anon!: Brutus, a word with you.
Goodbye!: Brutus, let’s talk to you.

Anon!: No, let the candied tongue lick absurd pomp, And crook the pregnant hinges of the knee Where thrift may follow fawning.
Goodbye!: No, let the candied tongue lick absurd pomp and crook the pregnant knees where the fawning can be ruined.

Anon!: Friends, begone.
Goodbye!: Friends, go.

Anon!: To whose hands You have sent the lunatic king.
Goodbye!: To those who sent the king to hell.

Anon!: Then yield thee, coward, And live to be the show and gaze o' th' time.
Goodbye!: Then give up, coward, and live to be the show and the gaze at you.

Anon!: How now, sirrah!
Goodbye!: What’s going on, sir!

Anon!: Oh, what learning is!
Goodbye!: What a good idea!

Anon!: What, will you have them weep our horses' blood?
Goodbye!: What, will you have them weep our horses' blood?

Anon!: Then she is well, and nothing can be ill.
Goodbye!: Then she’s well, and nothing can be bad.

Anon!: Me, uncle?
Goodbye!: Me, uncle?

Anon!: Come on.
Goodbye!: Come on.

Anon!: He that has the two fair daughters—is ’t he you mean?
Goodbye!: Who has the two fair daughters—is that what you mean?

Anon!: A right good markman!
Goodbye!: A good markman!

Anon!: The meantime, lady, I’ll raise the preparation of a war Shall stain your brother.
Goodbye!: In the meantime, lady, I’ll raise the question of the preparation for a war that will stain your brother.

Anon!: With Rosaline, my ghostly Father?
Goodbye!: With Rosaline, my ghostly Father?

Anon!: What’s the matter?
Goodbye!: What’s the matter?

Anon!: Thy life hath had some smatch of honor in it.
Goodbye!: Your life has had some honor in it.

Anon!: Speak not.
Goodbye!: Don’t say anything.

Anon!: Now I arise.
Goodbye!: Now I’m coming.

Anon!: It is a business of some heat.
Goodbye!: It’s a business that’s a bit sane.

Anon!: For, as it is a heartbreaking to see a handsome man loose-wived, so it is a deadly sorrow to behold a foul knave uncuckolded.
Goodbye!: It’s a deadly sorrow to see a foul knave uncuckolded.

Anon!: Ambassadors from Harry King of England Do crave admittance to your Majesty.
Goodbye!: Ambassadors from Harry King of England want to admit to your Majesty.

Anon!: You have known what you should not.
Goodbye!: You’ve already heard what you shouldn’t.

Anon!: All but mariners Plunged in the foaming brine and quit the vessel, Then all afire with me.
Goodbye!: All the sailors were plung in the foaming brine and left the vessel, then all afire with me.

Anon!: This ring, good sir—alas, it is a trifle.
Goodbye!: This ring, good sir—it’s a trifle.

Anon!: Ascend her chamber, hence, and comfort her.
Goodbye!: Ascend her room and comfort her.

Anon!: Four legs and two voices—a most delicate monster.
Goodbye!: Four legs and two voices—a very delicate monster.

Anon!: A foe to tyrants, and my country’s friend.
Goodbye!: A foe to tyrants, and my country’s friend.

Anon!: What, were you snarling all before I came, Ready to catch each other by the throat, And turn you all your hatred now on me?
Goodbye!: What, were you snarling all before I arrived, ready to catch each other by the throat and turn all your hatred on me now?

Anon!: False, false.
Goodbye!: False, false.

Anon!: I am bid forth to supper, Jessica.
Goodbye!: I’m going to supper, Jessica.

Anon!: Wash they his wounds with tears?
Goodbye!: Are they washing his wounds with tears?

Anon!: Know’st thou not the duke Hath banished me, his daughter?
Goodbye!: Don’t you know the duke has banished me, his daughter?

Anon!: She hath, and in that sparing makes huge waste, For beauty, starved with her severity, Cuts beauty off from all posterity.
Goodbye!: She has, and in that way she’s making huge wastes, because she’s starved with her severity, she’s cutting her beauty off from all the posterity.

Anon!: How many goodly creatures are there here!
Goodbye!: How many good creatures are there here!

Anon!: How now, my sweet Bianca!
Goodbye!: What’s going on, my sweet Bianca?

Anon!: It then draws near the season Wherein the spirit held his wont to walk.
Goodbye!: It’s coming near the season, when the spirit waited for him to walk.

Anon!: In the wars.
Goodbye!: In the wars.

Anon!: We, ignorant of ourselves, Beg often our own harms, which the wise powers Deny us for our good, so find we profit By losing of our prayers.
Goodbye!: We’re often committing our own harms, which the wise powers refuse to do for our good, and we’re so lucky by losing our prayers.

Anon!: Mock not, Enobarbus.
Goodbye!: Don’t bother, Enobarbus.

Anon!: Safe in a ditch he bides, With twenty trenchèd gashes on his head, The least a death to nature.
Goodbye!: He’s safe in a ditch, with twenty trenched gashes on his head, which is the least death to nature.

Anon!: Bruisèd pieces, go.
Goodbye!: Bruisèd pieces, go.

Anon!: Lie thou there (throwing down a letter), for here comes the trout that must be caught with tickling.
Goodbye!: You’re here (throwing down a letter), because here comes the trout that must be caught with tickling.

Anon!: These both put off, a poor petitioner, A care-crazed mother to a many sons, A beauty-waning and distressèd widow, Even in the afternoon of her best days, Made prize and purchase of his wanton eye, Seduced the pitch and height of his degree To base declension and loathed bigamy.
Goodbye!: Both of them put off, a poor petitioner, a care-giving mother to many sons, a beauty-waning and distressed widow, even in the afternoon of her best days, made prize and purchase his

Anon!: Borrow Cupid’s wings And soar with them above a common bound.
Goodbye!: Borrow Cupid’s wings and soar with them above a common bound.

Anon!: Tis such another fitchew.
Goodbye!: That’s another savage.

Anon!: Is your name Goneril?
Goodbye!: Is your name Goneril?

Anon!: Madam, good hope.
Goodbye!: Madam, good hope.

Anon!: Well, Syracusian, say in brief the cause Why thou dep-artedst from thy native home And for what cause thou camest to Ephesus.
Goodbye!: Well, Syracusian, tell us in brief the reason why you dep-arted from your native home and for what reason you came to Ephesus.

Anon!: Murder!
Goodbye!: Murder!

Anon!: Do not you hear a cry?
Goodbye!: Don’t you hear a cry?

Anon!: Yonder they lie, the poor old man their father making such pitiful dole over them that all the beholders take his part with weeping.
Goodbye!: They lie, the poor old man their father making such a pitiful dole over them that all the beholders take his part in weeping.

Anon!: Do not presume too much upon my love.
Goodbye!: Don’t presume I’m my love.

Anon!: Well, well, thou hast a careful father, child.
Goodbye!: Well, well, you have a careful father, child.

Anon!: Your ear is good.
Goodbye!: Your ear is good.

Anon!: As Caesar loved me, I weep for him.
Goodbye!: As Caesar loved me, I cry for him.

Anon!: He did comply, sir, with his dug before he sucked it.
Goodbye!: He did, sir, get his dug before he sucked it.

Anon!: Doth it therefore ensue that you should love his son dearly?
Goodbye!: So, is it going to be that you should love his son?

Anon!: Me they shall feel while I am able to stand, and ’tis known I am a pretty piece of flesh.
Goodbye!: I’ll feel like a pretty piece of flesh while I stand.

Anon!: Thou art not conquered.
Goodbye!: You’ve never been conquered.

Anon!: What a long night is this!
Goodbye!: What a long night this is!

Anon!: Orlando.
Goodbye!: Orlando.

Anon!: He no more shall see my face.
Goodbye!: He won’t see my face again.

Anon!: Excellent well.
Goodbye!: Good.

Anon!: It should seem then that Dobbin’s tail grows backward.
Goodbye!: It should seem then that Dobbin’s tail is getting backward.

Anon!: It is the best horse of Europe.
Goodbye!: It’s the best horse in Europe.

Anon!: A goodly one, in which there are many confines, wards, and dungeons, Denmark being one o' th' worst.
Goodbye!: It’s a good place, where there are many wards, and dungeons, Denmark being the worst.

Anon!: I say I will make him eat some part of my leek, or I will peat his pate four days.—Bite, I pray you.
Goodbye!: I say I’ll make him eat some part of my leek or I’ll peat his pate for four days.—Bite, please.

Anon!: Cupid is a knavish lad  Thus to make poor females mad.
Goodbye!: Cupid is a knavish man who makes poor females mad.

Anon!: Caesar, I shall.
Goodbye!: Caesar, I will.

Anon!: Are his wits safe?
Goodbye!: Are his wits safe?

Anon!: But you shall find the band that seems to tie their friendship together will be the very strangler of their amity.
Goodbye!: But you’ll find that the band that seems to tie their friendships together will be the stricken force of their friendship.

Anon!: I saw no man use you at his pleasure.
Goodbye!: I didn’t see any man use you to do his job.

Anon!: Well, thou dost best.
Goodbye!: Well, you do the best.

Anon!: Come, we’ll have him in a dark room and bound.
Goodbye!: Come on, we’ll have him in a dark room and bound him.

Anon!: Methinks our garments are now as fresh as when we put them on first in Afric, at the marriage of the king’s fair daughter Claribel to the King of Tunis.
Goodbye!: I think our clothes are as fresh as they were when we put them on first in Afric, at the marriage of the king’s fair daughter Claribel to the King of Tunis.

Anon!: So will I turn her virtue into pitch And out of her own goodness make the net That shall enmesh them all.
Goodbye!: I’ll turn her virtue into a pitch and make her a net that will send them all out of her own goodness.

Anon!: We are their parents and original.
Goodbye!: We’re their parents and originals.

Anon!: Thus the bowl should run, And not unluckily against the bias.
Goodbye!: So the bowl should run, and not unluckily against the bias.

Anon!: And that same vengeance doth He hurl on thee For false forswearing and for murder too.
Goodbye!: And he’s hurling on you for false forswearing and murdering.

Anon!: Come, my spade.
Goodbye!: Come on, my words.

Anon!: A brave vessel Who had, no doubt, some noble creature in her Dashed all to pieces.
Goodbye!: A brave vessel with some noble creature in her was thrown to pieces.

Anon!: Alas, what cry is that?
Goodbye!: What’s that cry?

Anon!: And but my noble Moor Is true of mind and made of no such baseness As jealous creatures are, it were enough To put him to ill thinking.
Goodbye!: And if my noble Moor is true of mind and made of no baseness as jealous creatures are, it would be enough to put him into ill thinking.

Anon!: I say she shall.—And first begin with her.
Goodbye!: I say she will.—And first start with her.

Anon!: I kiss his dirty shoe, and from heartstring I love the lovely bully.
Goodbye!: I kiss his dirty shoe, and I love the lovely bully.

Anon!: Call to me All my sad captains.
Goodbye!: Call me all my sad captains.

Anon!: We shall, my liege.
Goodbye!: We will, my liege.

Anon!: But yet you draw not iron, for my heart Is true as steel.
Goodbye!: But you don’t draw iron, because my heart is as true as steel.

Anon!: But lend it rather to thine enemy, Who, if he break, thou mayst with better face Exact the penalty.
Goodbye!: But give it to your enemy, who, if he breaks, you can face better with the penalty.

Anon!: I have a head, sir, that will find out logs, And never trouble Peter for the matter.
Goodbye!: I have a head that will find logs, and I’ll never bother Peter for the matter.

Anon!: These things are beyond all use, And I do fear them.
Goodbye!: These things are beyond their use, and I’m afraid of them.

Anon!: Must I bite?
Goodbye!: Should I bite?

Anon!: And, in conclusion, she shall watch all night, And if she chance to nod I’ll rail and brawl, And with the clamor keep her still awake.
Goodbye!: And, in conclusion, she’ll watch all night, and if she’s a good friend, I’ll be arguing and scolding her with the clamor, keeping her awake.

Anon!: If I should speak, She would mock me into air.
Goodbye!: If I’d say something, she’d mock me in the air.

Anon!: I’ll meet you at that place some hour hence.
Goodbye!: I’ll meet you at that place sometime in the morning.

Anon!: Hush!
Goodbye!: Hush!

Anon!: Tis certain.
Goodbye!: It’s certain.

Anon!: There be fools alive, iwis, Silvered o'er—and so was this.
Goodbye!: There are fools alive, iwis, Silvered o'er—and so was this.

Anon!: Let’s see for means.
Goodbye!: Let’s see what’s going on.

Anon!: Nay, had I power, I should Pour the sweet milk of concord into hell, Uproar the universal peace, confound All unity on earth.
Goodbye!: If I were my power, I’d put the sweet milk of concord into hell, bring the universal peace to life, and scolde all the unity on earth.

Anon!: Music i’ th’ air.
Goodbye!: Music in the air.

Anon!: But all this did I know before.
Goodbye!: But I knew all this before.

Anon!: He is welcome too.
Goodbye!: He’s welcome too.

Anon!: Madam, so thrive I in my enterprise And dangerous success of bloody wars As I intend more good to you and yours Than ever you or yours were by me harmed!
Goodbye!: Madam, I’m so successful in my work and in my bloody wars that I’m going to do more good to you and yours than you or yours were harmed by me!

Anon!: We’ll hear him.—Noble Antony, go up.
Goodbye!: We’ll hear him.—Noble Antony, go up.

Anon!: No, you unnatural hags,
Goodbye!: No, you snore hags.

Anon!: Perchance, Iago, I will ne'er go home.
Goodbye!: I’ll never go home, Iago.

Anon!: O illegitimate construction!
Goodbye!: Oh, illegitimate construction!

Anon!: I’ll look to like if looking liking move.
Goodbye!: I’ll look at it if I’m looking for something to like.

Anon!: Saint Francis be my speed!
Goodbye!: Saint Francis, be my speed!

Anon!: Do so, and bid my sweet prepare to chide.
Goodbye!: Do so, and tell my sweet to prepare to scold me.

Anon!: Let’s away And get our jewels and our wealth together, Devise the fittest time and safest way To hide us from pursuit that will be made After my flight.
Goodbye!: Let’s go and get our jewels and our wealth together, and then make the best choice and safest way to hide us from the pursuit that will be made after my flight.

Anon!: Trust not Trebonius.
Goodbye!: Don’t trust Trebonius.

Anon!: I have done.
Goodbye!: I’ve done it.

Anon!: In cunning I must draw my sword upon you.
Goodbye!: I’ll have to draw my sword on you.

Anon!: What, art thou come?—On, gentlemen, away!
Goodbye!: What, are you coming?—Only, gentlemen, let’s go!

Anon!: Where be these knaves?
Goodbye!: Where are these knaves?

Anon!: How say you, then?
Goodbye!: What do you say, then?

Anon!: Ay, marry, sir, now it begins to work.
Goodbye!: Yes, sir, now it’s starting to work.

Anon!: They murder Caesar!”—Who’s within?
Goodbye!: They murder Caesar!”Who’s inside?

Anon!: Madam, I had rather— I know your lady does not love her husband.
Goodbye!: Madam, I’d rather— I know your lady doesn’t love her husband.

Anon!: Why, man, what is the matter?
Goodbye!: What’s the matter, man?

Anon!: I had a wound here that was like a “T,” But now ’tis made an “H.” They do retire.
Goodbye!: I had a wound here that was like a “T,” but now it’s become a “H.” They’re retiring.

Anon!: Be of good cheer.
Goodbye!: Be cheerful.

Anon!: My wife killed too?
Goodbye!: My wife was killed too?

Anon!: Indeed, he is so.
Goodbye!: Yes, he is.

Anon!: I do beseech you That are of suppler joints, follow them swiftly And hinder them from what this ecstasy May now provoke them to.
Goodbye!: I beg you, who are suppler, to follow them swiftly and stop them from doing what this ecstasy may provoke them to do.

Anon!: Here comes the lady.
Goodbye!: Here comes the lady.

Anon!: Therefore perpend, my princess, and give ear.
Goodbye!: So stop, my princess, and listen to me.

Anon!: This avarice Sticks deeper, grows with more pernicious root Than summer-seeming lust, and it hath been The sword of our slain kings.
Goodbye!: This avarice grows deeper, more pernicious than summer-seeming lust, and it’s been the sword of our slain kings.

Anon!: I hate a drunken rogue.
Goodbye!: I hate a drunken rogue.

Anon!: I humbly beseech you, proceed to th' affairs of state.
Goodbye!: Please, proceed to the state affairs.

Anon!: To make society The sweeter welcome, we will keep ourself Till suppertime alone.
Goodbye!: To make the society more welcome, we’ll keep ourselves alone until dinnertime.

Anon!: Lead me on.
Goodbye!: Lead me on.

Anon!: My lord and you were then at Mantua.— Nay, I do bear a brain.—But, as I said, When it did taste the wormwood on the nipple Of my dug and felt it bitter, pretty fool, To see it tetchy and fall out with the dug!
Goodbye!: My lord and you were at Mantua.—No, I have a brain.—But I said that when it tasted the wormwood on the nipple of my dug and felt it

Anon!: I humbly thank you for’t.
Goodbye!: Thank you very much.

Anon!: Let me stand here till thou remember it.
Goodbye!: Let me stand here until you remember it.

Anon!: And I would I could find in my heart that I had not a hard heart, for truly I love none.
Goodbye!: And I wish I could find out that I had no hard heart, because I really don’t love anyone.

Anon!: Is it four o'clock?
Goodbye!: Is it four o'clock?

Anon!: Canst thou so daff me?
Goodbye!: Can you help me so badly?

Anon!: Let’s tonight Be bounteous at our meal.
Goodbye!: Let’s be happy tonight at our meal.

Anon!: I do beseech you, sir, trouble yourself no further.
Goodbye!: I beg you, sir, to not bother yourself any more.

Anon!: I’ll able 'em.
Goodbye!: I’ll see them.

Anon!: This course I fittest choose, For forty ducats is too much to lose.
Goodbye!: I’m choosing this course, because forty ducats are too much to lose.

Anon!: Oh, I am slain!
Goodbye!: Oh, I’m dead!

Anon!: Enough.
Goodbye!: Enough.

Anon!: And yesterday the bird of night did sit Even at noon-day upon the marketplace, Hooting and shrieking.
Goodbye!: And yesterday the night bird was sitting on the marketplace at noon, shrieking and choking.

Anon!: You lie up to the hearing of the gods.
Goodbye!: You lie up to the gods’ hearing.

Anon!: Let us be satisfied!
Goodbye!: Let’s be satisfied!

Anon!: Oh, my soul’s joy!
Goodbye!: Oh, my soul’s joy!

Anon!: The third o’ th’ world is yours, which with a snaffle You may pace easy, but not such a wife.
Goodbye!: The third world is yours, which you can do with a snaffle, but not with such a wife.

Anon!: My dearest love, Duncan comes here tonight.
Goodbye!: My dearest love, Duncan is coming here tonight.

Anon!: We are spoiled and yonder he is!
Goodbye!: We’re spoiled and he is!

Anon!: I must another way To fetch a ladder, by the which your love Must climb a bird’s nest soon when it is dark.
Goodbye!: I have to find another way to get a ladder, by which your love must climb a bird’s nest soon when it’s dark.

Anon!: Petruchio is my name, Antonio’s son, A man well known throughout all Italy.
Goodbye!: Petruchio is my name, Antonio’s son, a man well known in all Italy.

Anon!: But now I’ll tell thee joyful tidings, girl.
Goodbye!: But now I’ll tell you joyous stories, girl.

Anon!: Meet me by and by at the citadel.
Goodbye!: Meet me at the citadel.

Anon!: Where are the vile beginners of this fray?
Goodbye!: Where are the vile men who are starting this fight?

Anon!: Use me well.
Goodbye!: Use me well.

Anon!: You lie.
Goodbye!: You lie.

Anon!: The time is come.
Goodbye!: The time is coming.

Anon!: Exchange forgiveness with me, noble Hamlet.
Goodbye!: Give me forgiveness, noble Hamlet.

Anon!: Rather make My country’s high pyramides my gibbet And hang me up in chains!
Goodbye!: Instead, make my country’s high pyramids my gibbet and hang me in chains!

Anon!: Mercy, mercy!
Goodbye!: Mercy, mercy!

Anon!: O my lord!
Goodbye!: Oh, my lord!

Anon!: Give me your blessing.
Goodbye!: Give me your blessing.

Anon!: This done, he took the bride about the neck And kissed her lips with such a clamorous smack That at the parting all the church did echo.
Goodbye!: He took the bride around the neck and kissed her lips with such a smack that at the parting the church all the screamed.

Anon!: I have possessed your grace of what I purpose, And by our holy Sabbath have I sworn To have the due and forfeit of my bond.
Goodbye!: I’ve possessed your grace of what I intended, and by our holy Sabbath I’ve sworn to have the due and forfeit my bond.

Anon!: Tomorrow will I send.
Goodbye!: Tomorrow I’ll send you.

Anon!: None but the fool, who labors to outjest His heart-struck injuries.
Goodbye!: He’s not the fool, who’s trying to hurt his heart.

Anon!: Come hither, Fabian.
Goodbye!: Come here, Fabian.

Anon!: They’ll tell all.
Goodbye!: They’ll tell you all.

Anon!: Surely I do believe your fair cousin is wronged.
Goodbye!: I don’t believe your fair cousin is wronged.

Anon!: And I another.
Goodbye!: And I’m another.

Anon!: Tis very true.
Goodbye!: That’s very true.

Anon!: I had rather have my horse to my mistress.
Goodbye!: I’d rather have my horse to my mistress.

Anon!: No wonder, my lord.
Goodbye!: It’s no wonder, my lord.

Anon!: Say either, and I’ll stay the circumstance.
Goodbye!: Say either, and I’ll keep the situation.

Anon!: Asses are made to bear, and so are you.
Goodbye!: Asses are made to bear, and so are you.

Anon!: Good my mouse of virtue, answer me.
Goodbye!: Good my mouse of virtue, answer me.

Anon!: Here, sir!
Goodbye!: Here, sir!

Anon!: Fare you well at once.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: Banquo, thy soul’s flight, If it find heaven, must find it out tonight.
Goodbye!: Banquo, if your soul finds heaven, she’ll find it tonight.

Anon!: O most pernicious woman!
Goodbye!: Oh, the most dangerous woman!

Anon!: Seal up the mouth of outrage for a while, Till we can clear these ambiguities And know their spring, their head, their true descent, And then will I be general of your woes, And lead you even to death.
Goodbye!: Wait a while until we can clear these ambiguities and know their origin, their head, their true descent.

Anon!: Nor I, my lord.
Goodbye!: I’m not, my lord.

Anon!: He that has a house to put ’s head in has a good headpiece.
Goodbye!: The person who has a house to put his head in has a good headpiece.

Anon!: She hath prevented me.
Goodbye!: She has stopped me.

Anon!: No cause, no cause.
Goodbye!: No reason, no reason.

Anon!: I held the sword and he did run on it.
Goodbye!: I held the sword and he ran on it.

Anon!: Well met, honest gentleman.
Goodbye!: Good morning, honest gentleman.

Anon!: Sister, you’ll go with us?
Goodbye!: Sister, you’ll go with us?

Anon!: Farewell till then.
Goodbye!: Goodbye until then.

Anon!: He bounds from the earth, as if his entrails were hairs, le cheval volant, the Pegasus, qui a les narines de feu.
Goodbye!: He’s bound from the earth, as if his entrails were hairs, le cheval volant, the Pegasus, qui a les narines de feu.

Anon!: There’s strange news come, sir.
Goodbye!: There’s strange news coming, sir.

Anon!: What a pretty thing man is when he goes in his doublet and hose and leaves off his wit!
Goodbye!: What a pretty thing man is when he goes in his doublet and hose and leaves off his wit!

Anon!: How can that be?
Goodbye!: How can that be?

Anon!: I will live in thy heart, die in thy lap, and be buried in thy eyes—and moreover, I will go with thee to thy uncle’s.
Goodbye!: I’ll live in your heart, die in your lap, and be buried in your eyes—and, besides, I’ll go with you to your uncle’s.

Anon!: Oh, ten times faster Venus' pigeons fly To seal love’s bonds new made than they are wont To keep obligèd faith unforfeited.
Goodbye!: Oh, ten times faster the pigeons of Venus fly to seal love’s bonds, new ones, than they are wont keep their faith unforfeited.

Anon!: I think it freely, and betimes in the morning I will beseech the virtuous Desdemona to undertake for me.
Goodbye!: I think it is freely, and I’ll beg the virtuous Desdemona to do it for me.

Anon!: In the meantime I will draw a bill of properties such as our play wants.
Goodbye!: In the meantime, I’ll draw a list of properties that we want to play.

Anon!: I will forget my nature.
Goodbye!: I’ll forget my nature.

Anon!: Am I in earth, in heaven, or in hell?
Goodbye!: Am I in heaven, in heaven, or in hell?

Anon!: Grace go with you, sir.
Goodbye!: Grace will go with you, sir.

Anon!: You look as you had something more to say.
Goodbye!: You look like you had something more to say.

Anon!: And for that I promised you, I’ll be as good as my word.
Goodbye!: And for what I promised you, I’ll be as good as my word.

Anon!: The morning comes upon ’s.
Goodbye!: The morning is approaching.

Anon!: Therefore, fair Hermia, question your desires.
Goodbye!: So ask, fair Hermia, what do you want?

Anon!: This is she—    Peace, peace, Mercutio, peace!
Goodbye!: This is her— Peace, peace, Mercutio, peace!

Anon!: Call the messenger.
Goodbye!: Call the messenger.

Anon!: We must both give and take, my loving lord.
Goodbye!: We must both give and take, my loving lord.

Anon!: For as thou urgest justice, be assured Thou shalt have justice more than thou desirest.
Goodbye!: As long as you want to get justice, be assured you’ll get justice more than you want.

Anon!: I am ready now.
Goodbye!: I’m ready now.

Anon!: Here lies the east.
Goodbye!: Here lies the east.

Anon!: Do thou meet me presently at the harbor.—Come hither.
Goodbye!: You’re meeting me at the harbor.—Come here.

Anon!: That would hang us, every mother’s son.
Goodbye!: That would hang us, every mother’s son.

Anon!: Call thyself “sister,” sweet, for I am thee.
Goodbye!: Call yourself “sister,” because I’m you.

Anon!: I am very glad to see you, signior.
Goodbye!: I’m very glad to see you, sir.

Anon!: It was.
Goodbye!: It was.

Anon!: And lawfully by this the Jew may claim A pound of flesh to be by him cut off Nearest the merchant’s heart.—Be merciful.
Goodbye!: And by law, the Jew may claim a pound of flesh to be cut off by him near the merchant’s heart.—Be merciful.

Anon!: Belong you to the Lady Olivia, friends?
Goodbye!: Do you belong to the Lady Olivia, friends?

Anon!: Lovers can see to do their amorous rites By their own beauties, or, if love be blind, It best agrees with night.
Goodbye!: Lovers can see that they’re doing their rites by their own beauties, or if love is blind, it’s best to agree with night.

Anon!: Who wrongs him?
Goodbye!: Who’s wrong with him?

Anon!: Twas a fault unwilling.
Goodbye!: It was a fault that was unwilling to.

Anon!: As long as hell and Richard likes of it.
Goodbye!: As long as hell and Richard like it.

Anon!: They say you are a melancholy fellow.
Goodbye!: They say you’re a melancholy fellow.

Anon!: Wouldst thou do such a deed for all the world?
Goodbye!: Would you do such a thing for all the world?

Anon!: Room!
Goodbye!: There’s room!

Anon!: I never saw an action of such shame.
Goodbye!: I never saw such a shameful act.

Anon!: Were I a common laugher, or did use To stale with ordinary oaths my love To every new protester, if you know That I do fawn on men and hug them hard And, after, scandal them, or if you know That I profess myself in banqueting To all the rout, then hold me dangerous.
Goodbye!: If I were a common laugher, or if I were a stale man, or if I were a stale man, or if I were a stale man, or if you

Anon!: If the matter of this paper be certain, you have mighty business in hand.
Goodbye!: If the matter of this paper is true, you have a lot of business to do.

Anon!: Some grief shows much of love, But much of grief shows still some want of wit.
Goodbye!: Some grief shows much of love, but some grief shows some desire for wit.

Anon!: Where I have come, great clerks have purposèd To greet me with premeditated welcomes, Where I have seen them shiver and look pale, Make periods in the midst of sentences, Throttle their practiced accent in their fears, And in conclusion dumbly have broke off, Not paying me a welcome.
Goodbye!: Where I’ve come, great clerks have said they’d greet me with premeditated welcomes, where I saw them shiver and look pale, make periods in the middle of sentences, and throttle their

Anon!: Yea, art thou there?
Goodbye!: Yes, are you there?

Anon!: O my son, what theme?
Goodbye!: Oh, my son, what’s the theme?

Anon!: Wherefore do you come?
Goodbye!: Why are you coming?

Anon!: For, I am sure, you have your hands full all In this so sudden business.
Goodbye!: I’m sure you’re all in the right mood for this sudden business.

Anon!: Hastings and Edward’s children, Grey and Rivers, Holy King Henry and thy fair son Edward, Vaughan, and all that have miscarrièd By underhand, corrupted, foul injustice, If that your moody, discontented souls Do through the clouds behold this present hour, Even for revenge mock my destruction.— This is All Souls' Day, fellow, is it not?
Goodbye!: Hastings and Edward’s children, Grey and Rivers, Holy King Henry and your fair son Edward, Vaughan, and all who have miscarriaged by underhand, corrupted, foul injustice, if your

Anon!: Ay, madam, it is common.
Goodbye!: Yes, madam, it’s common.

Anon!: I tell you, he that can lay hold of her Shall have the chinks.
Goodbye!: I tell you, the man who can hold her will have the chinks.

Anon!: Give me your hands if we be friends,  And Robin shall restore amends.
Goodbye!: Give me your hands if we’re friends, and Robin will make some changes.

Anon!: Good night, Lord Brutus.
Goodbye!: Good night, Lord Brutus.

Anon!: Doth he not mend?
Goodbye!: Don’t he re-empower him?

Anon!: And not a jot of “Tranio” in your mouth.
Goodbye!: And don’t jot a jot of “Tranio” in your mouth.

Anon!: Whisper her ear and tell her I and Ursula Walk in the orchard, and our whole discourse Is all of her.
Goodbye!: Whisper her ear and tell her I and Ursula walk in the orchard, and our entire discourse is about her.

Anon!: Were we before our armies, and to fight, I should do thus.
Goodbye!: If we were in front of our army, and I were going to fight, I would do that.

Anon!: This mortal house I’ll ruin, Do Caesar what he can.
Goodbye!: I’ll ruin this mortal house, do Caesar what he can.

Anon!: Black night o'ershade thy day, and death thy life.
Goodbye!: The night is dark, and death is your life.

Anon!: Why, lady!
Goodbye!: Why, lady!

Anon!: Proceed, Solinus, to procure my fall, And by the doom of death end woes and all.
Goodbye!: Solinus, go get my fall and end all the suffering and all.

Anon!: My love, my life, my soul, fair Helena!
Goodbye!: My love, my life, my soul, fair Helena!

Anon!: Once more, what news?
Goodbye!: Once more, what’s the news?

Anon!: This is a sleepy tune.
Goodbye!: This is a sleepy tune.

Anon!: A sweeter and a Lovellier gentleman, Framed in the prodigality of nature, Young, valiant, wise, and, no doubt, right royal, The spacious world cannot again afford.
Goodbye!: A sweeter and a sweeter gentleman, framed in the spirit of nature, young, valiant, wise, and, without doubt, right royal, the vast world cannot afford it again.

Anon!: Here’s a night pities neither wise man nor fool.
Goodbye!: Here’s a night of pity that neither wise man nor fool.

Anon!: And what art thou, thou idol ceremony?
Goodbye!: And what are you doing, idol ceremony?

Anon!: Say thou but “ay,” And that bare vowel  Than the death-darting eye of cockatrice.
Goodbye!: Say “Yes,” and that bare vowel is more than the death-darking eye of cockatrice.

Anon!: Tomorrow dinner, then?
Goodbye!: Tomorrow dinner?

Anon!: First let us go to dinner.
Goodbye!: Let’s go to dinner first.

Anon!: I’ll set a bourn how far to be beloved.
Goodbye!: I’ll tell you how far to be beloved.

Anon!: Prithee, do not turn me about.
Goodbye!: Please don’t turn me around.

Anon!: Thou dost snore distinctly.
Goodbye!: You’re snoring.

Anon!: But life, being weary of these worldly bars, Never lacks power to dismiss itself.
Goodbye!: But life, because we’re tired of these worldly bars, never has the power to dismiss itself.

Anon!: I myself.
Goodbye!: I myself.

Anon!: O, reform it altogether!
Goodbye!: Oh, reform it altogether!

Anon!: The heads of the maids?
Goodbye!: The heads of the maids?

Anon!: Am I like such a fellow?
Goodbye!: Am I like such a man?

Anon!: But, as they say, to hear music the general does not greatly care.
Goodbye!: But as they say, the general doesn’t care about listening to music.

Anon!: My sword, I say!
Goodbye!: My sword, I say!

Anon!: And what have I to give you back whose worth May counterpoise this rich and precious gift?
Goodbye!: And what do I have to give you back, whose worth may counterpoenase this rich and precious gift?

Anon!: Farewell!
Goodbye!: Goodbye!

Anon!: How lush and lusty the grass looks!
Goodbye!: How lush and lusty the grass looks!

Anon!: Ay, to a niggardly host and more sparing guest.
Goodbye!: Yes, to a niggly host and a more sparing guest.

Anon!: Good counsel, marry.
Goodbye!: Good advice, marry.

Anon!: It makes me mad.
Goodbye!: It makes me mad.

Anon!: Nay, guiltiness Will speak, though tongues were out of use.
Goodbye!: No, guilt will speak, even if the tongues were out of use.

Anon!: O earth!
Goodbye!: Oh earth!

Anon!: And look, where Publius is come to fetch me.
Goodbye!: Look, where Publius is coming to fetch me.

Anon!: Come, let’s away.
Goodbye!: Let’s go.

Anon!: I have a good eye, uncle.
Goodbye!: I’m very happy, uncle.

Anon!: No, pray thee, let it serve for table talk.
Goodbye!: No, please, let it serve as a table talk.

Anon!: Is ’t not strange?
Goodbye!: Isn’t it strange?

Anon!: My lord, I am for you, though it cost me ten nights' watchings.
Goodbye!: My lord, I’m for you, even though it cost me ten nights to watch.

Anon!: Good night, honest Iago.
Goodbye!: Good night, honest Iago.

Anon!: Draw, you rascal!
Goodbye!: Draw, you rascal!

Anon!: This may prove food to my displeasure.
Goodbye!: This may be a food for my dissatisfaction.

Anon!: I am for thee straight.
Goodbye!: I’m for you right now.

Anon!: My heart is sorry for your daughter’s death, But, on my honor, she was charged with nothing But what was true and very full of proof.
Goodbye!: My heart is sorry for your daughter’s death, but I was honoured to say she was charged with nothing but what was true and very proofful.

Anon!: Mine and my father’s death come not upon thee, Nor thine on me.
Goodbye!: My father and I’ve never killed you, and neither of you have killed me.

Anon!: Do you like this haste?
Goodbye!: Do you like this rush?

Anon!: Even he, sir.
Goodbye!: He’s just that, sir.

Anon!: It beckons you to go away with it, As if it some impartment did desire To you alone.
Goodbye!: It’s a good idea to go away with it, as if it were a gift to you alone.

Anon!: Come, poor remains of friends, rest on this rock.
Goodbye!: Come, poor friends, rest on this rock.

Anon!: O lamentable day!
Goodbye!: Oh, sad day!

Anon!: Tis time to part.
Goodbye!: It’s time to get out of here.

Anon!: Good my lord, tell it.
Goodbye!: My lord, tell me.

Anon!: All springs reduce their currents to mine eyes, That I, being governed by the watery moon, May send forth plenteous tears to drown the world.
Goodbye!: I can send out plenteous tears to drown the world, because I’m governed by the watery moon.

Anon!: A parlous boy!
Goodbye!: A terrible boy!

Anon!: Why then, can one desire too much of a good thing?— Come, sister, you shall be the priest and marry us.—Give me your hand, Orlando.—What do you say, sister?
Goodbye!: Well then, can one want too much of a good thing?—Come, sister, you’ll be the priest and marry us.—Give me your hand, Orlando.—What do you say, sister?

Anon!: Drones hive not with me.
Goodbye!: Drones aren’t coming with me.

Anon!: Come, go with me apart.
Goodbye!: Come with me.

Anon!: I will not sup tonight.
Goodbye!: I won’t sup tonight.

Anon!: Myself the man i' th' moon do seem to be— This is the greatest error of all the rest.
Goodbye!: I’m the man in the moon— This is the greatest error of all the rest.

Anon!: My sweet mistress Weeps when she sees me work, and says such baseness Had never like executor.
Goodbye!: My sweet mistress weeps when she sees me work, and says such a sanity would never have been like executor.

Anon!: None but friends.
Goodbye!: No one except friends.

Anon!: Oh, is this he?
Goodbye!: Oh, is this he?

Anon!: Meantime, have patience.
Goodbye!: Until now, have patience.

Anon!: Shall we not?
Goodbye!: Shall we?

Anon!: Go, And with your speediest bring us what she says And how you find of her.
Goodbye!: Go, and bring us with your best friend what she says and how you find her.

Anon!: Therefore away, to get our stuff aboard.
Goodbye!: So go away to get our stuff on board.

Anon!: We love him highly And shall continue our graces towards him.
Goodbye!: We love him very much, and we’ll continue to give him our grace.

Anon!: See him delivered, Fabian; bring him hither.
Goodbye!: See him delivered, Fabian; bring him here.

Anon!: Every subject’s duty is the king’s, but every subject’s soul is his own.
Goodbye!: Every subject’s duty is the king’s, but every subject’s soul is his own.

Anon!: O mistress, villainy hath made mocks with love!
Goodbye!: Oh, mistress, villainy has made mocks with love!

Anon!: What have I kept back?
Goodbye!: What did I keep back from that?

Anon!: And so they parted.
Goodbye!: And so they sat down.

Anon!: With him is Gratiano gone along.
Goodbye!: Gratiano has gone with him.

Anon!: My men should call me “lord.” I am your goodman.
Goodbye!: My men should call me “lord.” I’m your goodman.

Anon!: How now, my love?
Goodbye!: What’s going on, my love?

Anon!: Where we are, There’s daggers in men’s smiles.
Goodbye!: Where we are, men’s smiles are filled with daggers.

Anon!: By the apostle Paul, shadows tonight Have struck more terror to the soul of Richard Than can the substance of ten thousand soldiers Armed in proof and led by shallow Richmond.
Goodbye!: By the apostle Paul, shadows have struck more terror to the soul of Richard than can the ten thousand soldiers who were armed in proof and led by Richmond.

Anon!: Be ruled by me.
Goodbye!: Be ruled by me.

Anon!: Was ever book containing such vile matter So fairly bound?
Goodbye!: Was there ever a book with such a vile subject that was so fair?

Anon!: The Moor replies That he you hurt is of great fame in Cyprus And great affinity, and that in wholesome wisdom He might not but refuse you.
Goodbye!: The Moor says that he’s famous in Cyprus and has a great affinity for Cyprus, and that he’s not only able to refuse you.

Anon!: Throw some of them at me.
Goodbye!: Throw some of them at me.

Anon!: Bespeak him a fortnight before.—I will have the heart of him if he forfeit, for were he out of Venice I can make what merchandise I will.—Go, go, Tubal, and meet me at our synagogue.
Goodbye!: Be quiet for a fortnight before.—I’ll have the heart of him if he wins, because if he’s out of Venice I’d make what I want.—Go, Tubal,

Anon!: Speak, nephew.
Goodbye!: Speak, nephew.

Anon!: Say I am sick.
Goodbye!: Say I’m sick.

Anon!: Now art thou sociable.
Goodbye!: Now you’re sociable.

Anon!: You are a spirit, I know.
Goodbye!: You’re a spirit, I know.

Anon!: Free from the bondage you are in, Messala.
Goodbye!: Free from the bondage you’re in, Messala.

Anon!: Not to his father’s.
Goodbye!: Not to his father’s house.

Anon!: So white, and such a traitor?
Goodbye!: Is that white and a traitor?

Anon!: If there were no more women but Fulvia, then had you indeed a cut, and the case to be lamented.
Goodbye!: If there were no more women than Fulvia, then you would have a cut, and the case to be ruined.

Anon!: Thou’dst shun a bear, But if thy flight lay toward the raging sea Thou’dst meet the bear i' th' mouth.
Goodbye!: You’d shun a bear, but if you were flying toward the sea, you’d meet the bear in your mouth.

Anon!: Charmian!
Goodbye!: Charmian!

Anon!: No.
Goodbye!: No.

Anon!: She speaks, yet she says nothing.
Goodbye!: She’s talking, but she’s not saying anything.

Anon!: I will walk up and down here and I will sing, that they shall hear I am not afraid.
Goodbye!: I’ll walk up and down here and sing, so they can hear I’m not afraid.

Anon!: You cram these words into mine ears against The stomach of my sense.
Goodbye!: You’re craming these words into my ears against my sense.

Anon!: Whose noise is this that ones on murder?
Goodbye!: Whose noise is this that is causing murder?

Anon!: That young swain that you saw here but erewhile, That little cares for buying anything.
Goodbye!: That young man you saw here only a few times, that little man doesn’t care about buying anything.

Anon!: Therefore the sadness is without limit.
Goodbye!: So the sadness is without limits.

Anon!: Come, my young soldier, put up your iron.
Goodbye!: Come on, my young soldier, put up your iron.

Anon!: Why, thou say’st true.
Goodbye!: Why, you say that’s true.

Anon!: He waxes desperate with imagination.
Goodbye!: He’s desperate with imagination.

Anon!: Master, master!
Goodbye!: Master, master!

Anon!: We talk with goblins, owls, and sprites: If we obey them not, this will ensue: They’ll suck our breath, or pinch us black and blue.
Goodbye!: We talk with goblins, owls, and sprites: If we don’t obey them, this will happen: they’ll suck our breath or pinch us black and blue.

Anon!: Thou’dst thank me but a little for my counsel; And yet I’ll promise thee she shall be rich, And very rich.
Goodbye!: You’d thank me only a little for my advice.

Anon!: Peter, stay at the gate.
Goodbye!: Peter, stay at the gate.

Anon!: My royal lord, You do not give the cheer.
Goodbye!: My lord, you don’t give the cheer.

Anon!: Follow, follow!
Goodbye!: Follow, follow!

Anon!: But soft you, let me be.
Goodbye!: But please, let me be.

Anon!: A merry whoreson, ha!
Goodbye!: A merry whoreson, ha!

Anon!: Tunis was never graced before with such a paragon to their queen.
Goodbye!: Tunis was never graced before with such a paragon to their queen.

Anon!: Goneril with a white beard?
Goodbye!: Goneril with a white beard?

Anon!: Give me,”      quoth I.
Goodbye!: Give me,” I said.

Anon!: By th' mass, and ’tis like a camel indeed.
Goodbye!: By the way, it’s like a camel.

Anon!: It is not day.
Goodbye!: It’s not daybreak.

Anon!: Lucentio, gentle sir.
Goodbye!: Lucentio, gentle sir.

Anon!: Till he come home again, I would forbear.
Goodbye!: I’d beg him to stay here until he comes back home.

Anon!: For us, we will consider of this further.
Goodbye!: For us, we’ll look at this further.

Anon!: I think of as many matters as he, but I give heaven thanks and make no boast of them.
Goodbye!: I think of as many things as he does, but I thank heaven and don’t boast about them.

Anon!: If ever he go alone again, I’ll never wrestle for prize more.
Goodbye!: If he ever goes alone again, I’ll never fight for more prize.

Anon!: He that plays the king shall be welcome.
Goodbye!: The man who plays the king will be welcome.

Anon!: My stomach is not constant.
Goodbye!: My stomach isn’t constant.

Anon!: I had thought t’ have held it poor; but since my lord Is Antony again, I will be Cleopatra.
Goodbye!: I thought it was poor, but since my lord is Antony again, I’ll be Cleopatra.

Anon!: Hast thou slain him then?
Goodbye!: Have you killed him then?

Anon!: Hark, hark!
Goodbye!: Listen, listen!

Anon!: That’s my noble master!
Goodbye!: That’s my noble master!

Anon!: O deadly sin!
Goodbye!: Oh, deadly sin!

Anon!: Take note, take note, O world, To be direct and honest is not safe.
Goodbye!: Take note, take note, O world, to be honest and direct is not safe.

Anon!: Moreover that we much did long to see you, The need we have to use you did provoke Our hasty sending.
Goodbye!: Moreover, since we had to wait so long to see you, the need we have to use you caused our rush.

Anon!: Brief let me be.
Goodbye!: Let me be brief.

Anon!: This is old Ninny’s tomb.
Goodbye!: This is old Ninny’s tomb.

Anon!: The reason why the seven stars are no more than seven is a pretty reason.
Goodbye!: The reason why the seven stars aren’t more than seven is pretty.

Anon!: O woeful sympathy, Piteous predicament!
Goodbye!: Oh, sorry, terrible sympathy!

Anon!: Come, thou day in night, For thou wilt lie upon the wings of night Whiter than new snow upon a raven’s back.
Goodbye!: Come, day in night, because you’ll lie on the wings of night more White than snow on a raven’s back.

Anon!: The ancient saying is no heresy.
Goodbye!: The ancient saying is no king.

Anon!: My being in Egypt, Caesar, what was ’t to you?
Goodbye!: What did I do to you when I was in Egypt, Caesar?

Anon!: Come, blade, my breast imbrue.
Goodbye!: Come, blade, my breast imbrue.

Anon!: And with the juice of this I’ll streak her eyes And make her full of hateful fantasies.
Goodbye!: And with the juice of this I’ll streak her eyes and make her full of hateful fantasies.

Anon!: Nurse, will you go with me into my closet To help me sort such needful ornaments As you think fit to furnish me tomorrow?
Goodbye!: Nurse, will you go with me into my closet to help me sort out the needy ornaments you think I’ll need tomorrow?

Anon!: No, my lord, unless I might have another for working days.
Goodbye!: No, my lord, unless I could have another for work days.

Anon!: If their purgation did consist in words, They are as innocent as grace itself.
Goodbye!: If they were merely a word, they would be as innocent as the grace itself.

Anon!: Anon we’ll drink a measure The table round.
Goodbye!: We’ll drink a measure round the table.

Anon!: How fares our cousin, noble Lord of York?
Goodbye!: How is our cousin, noble Lord of York?

Anon!: What a pestilent knave is this same!
Goodbye!: What a pestilent knave this is!

Anon!: You shall not go, my lord.
Goodbye!: You won’t go, my lord.

Anon!: Ah, for my husband, for my dear lord Edward!
Goodbye!: Ah, for my husband, for my dear Edward!

Anon!: Caesar did write for him to come to Rome.
Goodbye!: Caesar wrote for him to come to Rome.

Anon!: Oh, that your frowns would teach my smiles such skill!
Goodbye!: Oh, that your frowns would teach my smiles such skill!

Anon!: Made I him king for this?
Goodbye!: Did I make him king for this?

Anon!: Ay, but not enough.
Goodbye!: Yes, but not enough.

Anon!: Yet that is but a crushed necessity, Since we have locks to safeguard necessaries And pretty traps to catch the petty thieves.
Goodbye!: But that’s a ruined necessity, since we have locks to protect our precious treasures and pretty traps to catch the petty thieves.

Anon!: It is my duty, sir.
Goodbye!: It’s my duty, sir.

Anon!: O Romeo, Romeo, brave Mercutio is dead!
Goodbye!: Oh, Romeo, Romeo, brave Mercutio is dead!

Anon!: And is it thus?
Goodbye!: And is it that?

Anon!: Perhaps some merchant hath invited him, And from the mart he’s somewhere gone to dinner.
Goodbye!: Maybe some merchant invited him, and he’s gone somewhere to dinner.

Anon!: Benvolio, who began this bloody fray?
Goodbye!: Benvolio, who started this bloody fight?

Anon!: For the love of God, your help!
Goodbye!: For the love of God, help!

Anon!: All for your delight We are not here.
Goodbye!: We’re not here for your pleasure.

Anon!: On Tuesday noon, or night, or Wednesday morn.
Goodbye!: On Tuesday noon, or night, or Wednesday morning.

Anon!: You shall see anon how the murderer gets the love of Gonzago’s wife.
Goodbye!: You’ll see how the murderer gets the love of Gonzago’s wife.

Anon!: Let not the Nurse lie with thee in thy chamber.
Goodbye!: Don’t let the Nurse lie with you in your room.

Anon!: Tell her the king, that may command, entreats— That, at her hands, which the king’s King forbids.
Goodbye!: Tell her the king, who can command her, scolds—that she’s able to do, which the king’s King forbids.

Anon!: Swear your love.
Goodbye!: Swear your love.

Anon!: What concern they?
Goodbye!: What are they worried about?

Anon!: That’s a fault.
Goodbye!: That’s a fault.

Anon!: How now?
Goodbye!: What’s going on?

Anon!: Take comfort.
Goodbye!: Take comfort.

Anon!: Well, be it so.
Goodbye!: Well, it’s true.

Anon!: And that you would have me to do!
Goodbye!: And that’s what you want me to do!

Anon!: The beds i’ th’ East are soft, and thanks to you, That called me timelier than my purpose hither, For I have gained by ’t.
Goodbye!: The beds in the East are soft, and thanks to you, who called me more time-consuming than my intended purpose here, because it’s been a good thing.

Anon!: Nor will not.
Goodbye!: And he won’t.

Anon!: But fare ye well.
Goodbye!: But goodbye.

Anon!: He’ll fright you up, i' faith.
Goodbye!: He’ll frighten you up, I’m sure.

Anon!: You know not how to choose a man.
Goodbye!: You don’t know how to choose a man.

Anon!: Let her witness it.
Goodbye!: Let her witness it.

Anon!: Nor I.
Goodbye!: I’m not.

Anon!: Is ’t gone?
Goodbye!: Is it gone?

Anon!: Judgment?
Goodbye!: Judgment?

Anon!: If ever I return to you again, I’ll bring you comfort.
Goodbye!: If I ever return to you again, I’ll bring you comfort.

Anon!: My mistress showed me thee and thy dog and thy bush.
Goodbye!: My mistress showed me you and your dog and your bush.

Anon!: Dear sovereign, hear me speak.
Goodbye!: Dear sovereign, listen to me.

Anon!: You will be schoolmaster And undertake the teaching of the maid: That’s your device.
Goodbye!: You’ll be a schoolmaster and teach the maid: that’s your device.

Anon!: My master is the great rich Capulet, and if you be not of the house of Montagues, I pray come and crush a cup of wine.
Goodbye!: My master is the great rich Capulet, and if you don’t belong to the house of Montagues, please come and crush a cup of wine.

Anon!: But if you do refuse to marry me, You’ll give yourself to this most faithful shepherd?
Goodbye!: But if you refuse to marry me, you’ll give yourself to this faithful shepherd?

Anon!: What the goodyear, my lord, why are you thus out of measure sad?
Goodbye!: What good year is it, my lord?

Anon!: Silenced with that, In viewing o'er the rest o' the selfsame day, He finds thee in the stout Norweyan ranks, Nothing afeard of what thyself didst make, Strange images of death.
Goodbye!: He’s still silent with that, watching the rest of the day as if it were the same day, and finds you in the Norweyan ranks, nothing afeated of what you did, strange images of death

Anon!: This to be true I do engage my life.
Goodbye!: I’m a part of my life.

Anon!: How smooth and even they do bear themselves, As if allegiance in their bosoms sat Crownèd with faith and constant loyalty.
Goodbye!: They’re so smooth and even happy, as if they were sat in their robes with faith and constant loyalty.

Anon!: If we do meet again, we’ll smile indeed.
Goodbye!: If we meet again, we’ll smile.

Anon!: I not doubt He came alive to land.
Goodbye!: I don’t doubt he came alive to land.

Anon!: O Cassius, I am sick of many griefs.
Goodbye!: Oh Cassius, I’m sick of many griefs.

Anon!: Riddling confession finds but riddling shrift.
Goodbye!: A raging confession is only a riddling shrift.

Anon!: What’s his offense?
Goodbye!: What’s his offense?

Anon!: The four strangers seek for you, madam, to take their leave.
Goodbye!: The four strangers want you to leave, madam.

Anon!: If thy speech be sooth, I care not if thou dost for me as much.
Goodbye!: If your speech is sooth, I don’t care if you do it for me as much.

Anon!: How chance thou art returned so soon?
Goodbye!: How could you get back so soon?

Anon!: O Cassius, Brutus gave the word too early, Who, having some advantage on Octavius, Took it too eagerly.
Goodbye!: Oh Cassius, Brutus gave the word too early, who, having some advantage over Octavius, rushed it too eagerly.

Anon!: His dishonesty appears in leaving his friend here in necessity and denying him.
Goodbye!: He’s wrong about leaving his friend here in a hurry and refusing him.

Anon!: There.
Goodbye!: There.

Anon!: Good morrow, Father.
Goodbye!: Good morning, Father.

Anon!: This was but as a fly by an eagle.
Goodbye!: This was just like a fly by an eagle.

Anon!: Fare you well.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: Here it is.
Goodbye!: Here it is.

Anon!: Farewell, my lords.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, my lords.

Anon!: I know he would not be a wolf But that he sees the Romans are but sheep.
Goodbye!: I know he wouldn’t be a wolf, but I see that the Romans are sheep.

Anon!: I thank you.
Goodbye!: Thank you.

Anon!: Why, how now, Juliet?
Goodbye!: What’s going on, Juliet?

Anon!: Have you had quiet guard?
Goodbye!: Have you had a quiet guard?

Anon!: So, fare thee well.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: And my heart too.
Goodbye!: And my heart too.

Anon!: Well, look unto it.
Goodbye!: Well, look at it.

Anon!: Ha, ha, heard in Genoa.
Goodbye!: Ha, ha, heard in Genoa.

Anon!: No, my good lord.
Goodbye!: No, my good lord.

Anon!: Ay, dread Queen.
Goodbye!: Yes, dreadful Queen.

Anon!: If it be mine, Keep it not from me.
Goodbye!: If it’s mine, don’t keep it from me.

Anon!: Heaven and yourself Had part in this fair maid.
Goodbye!: Heaven and you had part in this handsome maid.

Anon!: What, girl, though gray Do something mingle with our younger brown, yet ha’ we A brain that nourishes our nerves and can Get goal for goal of youth.
Goodbye!: What, girl, even though gray do something to mingle with our younger brown, we’re a brain that nourishes our nerves and can get goal for goal for youth.

Anon!: What shall we do, Enobarbus?
Goodbye!: What should we do, Enobarbus?

Anon!: What news from Genoa?
Goodbye!: What news did Genoa have?

Anon!: Such duty as the subject owes the prince, Even such a woman oweth to her husband.
Goodbye!: The prince owes the subject such a duty, and even a woman owes her husband such a duty.

Anon!: Tyrrel, I mean those bastards in the Tower.
Goodbye!: Tyrrel, I mean those bastards in the Tower.

Anon!: I am out of all other tune, methinks.
Goodbye!: I’m out of all other tunes, I think.

Anon!: For several virtues Have I liked several women.
Goodbye!: I’ve liked several women.

Anon!: Doth this news hold of good King Edward’s death?
Goodbye!: Is this news of good King Edward’s death?

Anon!: So please you.
Goodbye!: Please.

Anon!: Why do people love you?
Goodbye!: Why do people love you?

Anon!: At once, good night.
Goodbye!: Good night, at once.

Anon!: O Harry’s wife, triumph not in my woes!
Goodbye!: Oh, Harry’s wife, don’t triumph in my sorrows!

Anon!: When last I was at Exeter, The mayor in courtesy showed me the castle And called it Rougemont, at which name I started, Because a bard of Ireland told me once I should not live long after I saw Richmond.
Goodbye!: When I was last at Exeter, the mayor showed me the castle and called it Rougemont, which I started to name, because a bard of Ireland told me I should not live long after I saw Richmond.

Anon!: Dispatch.—O love, That thou couldst see my wars today, and knew’st The royal occupation!
Goodbye!: Dispatch.—O love, that you could see my wars today, and that you knew the royal occupation!

Anon!: It is Captain Macmorris, is it not?
Goodbye!: It’s Captain Macmorris, isn’t it?

Anon!: I protest unto thee— Good heart, and i' faith, I will tell her as much.
Goodbye!: I’m telling her that I’m good, and I’m sure she’ll tell her as much.

Anon!: I drew to part them.
Goodbye!: I drew my sword to part them.

Anon!: If you mark Alexander’s life well, Harry of Monmouth’s life is come after it indifferent well, for there is figures in all things.
Goodbye!: If you mark Alexander’s life well, Harry of Monmouth’s life is coming after it well, because there are figures in everything.

Anon!: I will, my lord, with all convenient haste.
Goodbye!: I will, my lord, with all the convenient rush.

Anon!: I would she had bestowed this dotage on me.
Goodbye!: I wish she had given me this slander.

Anon!: Death is the fairest cover for her shame That may be wished for.
Goodbye!: Death is the fairest cover for her shame that could be wished for.

Anon!: By my troth, he’ll yield the crow a pudding one of these days.
Goodbye!: I swear he’ll give the crow a pudding of this day.

Anon!: In thee there is not half an hour of life.
Goodbye!: There’s not a half hour of life in you.

Anon!: Denmark’s a prison.
Goodbye!: Denmark’s a prison.

Anon!: I have sent twenty out to seek for you.
Goodbye!: I’ve sent twenty people out to search for you.

Anon!: The gentleman will, for his honor’s sake, have one bout with you.
Goodbye!: The gentleman will fight you for his honor.

Anon!: Be trusty, and I’ll quit thy pains.
Goodbye!: Be confident, and I’ll leave you alone.

Anon!: But if I had wit enough to get out of this wood, I have enough to serve mine own turn.
Goodbye!: But if I had enough wit to get out of this forest, I would have enough wit to serve my own purpose.

Anon!: How can this be?
Goodbye!: How can this be?

Anon!: Come thee on.
Goodbye!: Come on.

Anon!: The king is not to answer it.
Goodbye!: The king isn’t going to answer it.

Anon!: Live, and hereafter say A madman’s mercy bid thee run away.
Goodbye!: Live, and then say that a madman’s mercy told you to run away.

Anon!: Take him up gently, and to bed with him, And each one to his office when he wakes.
Goodbye!: Take him up gently, and to bed with him, and each one of them will go to his office when he wakes up.

Anon!: Make us thy ministers of chastisement, That we may praise thee in the victory!
Goodbye!: Make us your ministers of chastisement so we can praise you for your victory!

Anon!: I know a wench of excellent discourse, Pretty and witty, wild and yet, too, gentle.
