Goodbye!: I know a wench of excellent discourse, pretty and witty, wild and yet, too, gentle.

Anon!: I pray you, give me leave to go from hence.
Goodbye!: Please, give me permission to go away.

Anon!: Where I have learned me to repent the sin Of disobedient opposition To you and your behests, and am enjoined By holy Lawrence to fall prostrate here To beg your pardon.
Goodbye!: I’ve learned to repent the sin of disobedient opposition to you and your begests, and I’ve been told by the holy Lawrence to fall prostrate here to beg your pardon.

Anon!: Well, sir, for want of other idleness, I’ll bide your proof.
Goodbye!: Well, sir, I’ll tell you, because I’m not idle.

Anon!: For what offence?
Goodbye!: What crime?

Anon!: The man is notwithstanding sufficient.
Goodbye!: The man is notwithstanding enough.

Anon!: No.
Goodbye!: No.

Anon!: Her hedges, even-pleached, Like prisoners wildly overgrown with hair, Put forth disordered twigs.
Goodbye!: Her hedges, even-pleached, like prisoners wildly overgrown with hair, put forth disordered twigs.

Anon!: What say’st thou, my fair flower de luce?
Goodbye!: What do you say, my beautiful flower de luce?

Anon!: Neither good nor bad.
Goodbye!: Neither good nor bad.

Anon!: Well, Petruchio, this has put me in heart.
Goodbye!: Well, Petruchio, this has put me in the heart.

Anon!: The French have reinforced their scattered men.
Goodbye!: The French have reinforced their scattered men.

Anon!: Since no man of aught he leaves knows, what is ’t to leave betimes?
Goodbye!: Since no man who leaves knows what to do, what can I do to leave early?

Anon!: Tis no matter how it be in tune, so it make noise enough.
Goodbye!: It doesn’t matter how it’s in tune, so it’s making enough noise.

Anon!: Is it not Hero?
Goodbye!: Isn’t it Hero?

Anon!: Seek!
Goodbye!: Seek!

Anon!: Well, sir?
Goodbye!: Well, sir?

Anon!: Hold you content.
Goodbye!: Hold on.

Anon!: Give me the gown.
Goodbye!: Give me the gown.

Anon!: Uncomfortable time, why camest thou now To murder, murder our solemnity?
Goodbye!: Why are you coming to murder us?

Anon!: Even now, sir.
Goodbye!: Now, sir.

Anon!: There was a pretty redness in his lip, A little riper and more lusty red Than that mixed in his cheek: ’twas just the difference Betwixt the constant red and mingled damask.
Goodbye!: He had a pretty red lip, a little more riper and more lusty red than that mixed in his cheek.

Anon!: Then I will give you the serving creature.
Goodbye!: Then I’ll give you the serving creature.

Anon!: Tigers, not daughters, what have you performed?
Goodbye!: Tigers, not daughters, what have you done?

Anon!: Well, I say no.
Goodbye!: Well, I don’t say no.

Anon!: Alas, my liege, my wife is dead tonight.
Goodbye!: Oh, my liege, my wife is dead tonight.

Anon!: How lost you company?
Goodbye!: How did you lose your company?

Anon!: Friends am I with you all and love you all Upon this hope: that you shall give me reasons Why and wherein Caesar was dangerous.
Goodbye!: Friends are with you all and I love you all.

Anon!: No, truly, for the truest poetry is the most feigning, and lovers are given to poetry, and what they swear in poetry may be said as lovers they do feign.
Goodbye!: No, really, because the truest poetry is the most feigning, and lovers are given to poetry, and what they swear in poetry can be said as lovers they feign.

Anon!: Upon her landing, Antony sent to her, Invited her to supper.
Goodbye!: Upon her landing, Antony sent to her and invited her to supper.

Anon!: O, welcome, father!
Goodbye!: Oh, welcome, father!

Anon!: If thou say so, withdraw and prove it too.
Goodbye!: If you say that, then you can go back and prove it too.

Anon!: When I did make thee free, swor’st thou not then To do this when I bade thee?
Goodbye!: When I freed you, don’t you want to do this when I baded you?

Anon!: Feed and regard him not.
Goodbye!: Feed him and don’t regard him.

Anon!: I am peppered, I warrant, for this world.
Goodbye!: I’m scolded for this world, I swear.

Anon!: O heavens!
Goodbye!: Oh heavens!

Anon!: O lamentable day!
Goodbye!: Oh, sad day!

Anon!: Five shillings to one on ’t, with any man that knows the statutes, he may stay him—marry, not without the Prince be willing, for indeed the watch ought to offend no man, and it is an offense to stay a man against his will.
Goodbye!: Five shillings to one on it, with any man who knows the laws, he can keep him—marry, not without the Prince be willing, because the guard should not offend any man, and it’s

Anon!: My mistress, dearest, and I thus humble ever.
Goodbye!: My dearest mistress, and I’m humble ever.

Anon!: For certain, sir, he is not.
Goodbye!: Yes, he isn’t.

Anon!: Let him speak, my lord, Upon his peril, that I have reserved To myself nothing.
Goodbye!: Let him speak, my lord, if he’s ill, that I haven’t reserved to myself anything.

Anon!: I must be cruel only to be kind.
Goodbye!: I must be cruel only to be kind.

Anon!: Do so.
Goodbye!: Do so.

Anon!: Think you I am no stronger than my sex, Being so fathered and so husbanded?
Goodbye!: Do you think I’m no stronger than my sex, because I’m so fathered and so married?

Anon!: This seen, Orlando did approach the man And found it was his brother, his elder brother.
Goodbye!: Orlando approached the man and found it was his brother, his elder brother.

Anon!: Marry them to your heirs!
Goodbye!: Give them to your heirs!

Anon!: I will fetch up your goats, Audrey.
Goodbye!: I’ll fetch your goats, Audrey.

Anon!: What would she have?
Goodbye!: What would she have?

Anon!: What prisoners of good sort are taken, uncle?
Goodbye!: What prisoners of good sort are taken, uncle?

Anon!: Indeed, indeed, sirs, but this troubles me.
Goodbye!: Yes, sirs, but this is a problem for me.

Anon!: Ready to go, but never to return.
Goodbye!: Ready to go, but never to return.

Anon!: It is not nor it cannot come to good, But break, my heart, for I must hold my tongue.
Goodbye!: It isn’t, and it can’t come to good, but break my heart, because I have to hold my tongue.

Anon!: Do you go back dismayed?
Goodbye!: Are you back feeling dismayed?

Anon!: Our duties, and the pledge.
Goodbye!: We’re doing our duties, and we’re giving them the pledge.

Anon!: Or neither?
Goodbye!: Or neither?

Anon!: If this fall into thy hand, revolve.
Goodbye!: If this fall into your hand, turn your hand.

Anon!: Leave holloaing, man.
Goodbye!: Leave holloaing, man.

Anon!: Write them together, yours is as fair a name.
Goodbye!: Write them together, yours is as fair as yours.

Anon!: What was the last cry for?
Goodbye!: What was the last cry for?

Anon!: Marry, I remember it well.
Goodbye!: I remember it well.

Anon!: Do not say so, Lysander.
Goodbye!: Don’t say that, Lysander.

Anon!: He faints!—My lord, my lord!
Goodbye!: He’s fainting!—My lord, my lord!

Anon!: Thou shalt not stir one foot to seek a foe.
Goodbye!: You won’t have to scold one foot to find a foe.

Anon!: Lechery, sir, it provokes and unprovokes.
Goodbye!: It’s a slander, sir.

Anon!: Soft!
Goodbye!: Get out of here!

Anon!: Therefore another prologue must tell he is not a lion.
Goodbye!: So another prologue must tell him he’s not a lion.

Anon!: Besides, she uses me with a more exalted respect than anyone else that follows her.
Goodbye!: Besides, she uses me more than anyone else who follows her.

Anon!: It is perchance that you yourself were saved.
Goodbye!: It’s a danger that you were saved yourself.

Anon!: I shall the effect of this good lesson keep As watchman to my heart.
Goodbye!: I’ll keep this good lesson as a watchman to my heart.

Anon!: And here much Orlando.
Goodbye!: And here’s much Orlando.

Anon!: Farewell!—God knows when we shall meet again.
Goodbye!: Goodbye!—God knows when we’ll meet again.

Anon!: And this may help to thicken other proofs That do demonstrate thinly.
Goodbye!: And this may help to thicken other proofs that show little.

Anon!: Better cheer may you have, but not with better heart.
Goodbye!: You may have better cheer, but not with a better heart.

Anon!: Come.
Goodbye!: Come on.

Anon!: Things have fall'n out, sir, so unluckily, That we have had no time to move our daughter.
Goodbye!: It’s so bad, sir, that we haven’t had time to move our daughter.

Anon!: What man is that?
Goodbye!: Who is that man?

Anon!: Let it alone, thou fool.
Goodbye!: Don’t let it alone, you fool.

Anon!: What should I think on ’t?
Goodbye!: What should I think about it?

Anon!: Let me not hinder, Cassius, your desires.
Goodbye!: Don’t let me hinder your desires, Cassius.

Anon!: How now?
Goodbye!: What’s going on?

Anon!: Let’s to bed, knight.
Goodbye!: Let’s go to bed, knight.

Anon!: Nay, send in time!
Goodbye!: No, send me in time!

Anon!: Bind him, I say.
Goodbye!: Bind him, I say.

Anon!: I love to cope him in these sullen fits, For then he’s full of matter.
Goodbye!: I love to help him with these sane fits, because then he’s full of matter.

Anon!: Now is it Rome indeed, and room enough, When there is in it but one only man.
Goodbye!: Now it’s Rome, and there’s enough room to go, when there’s only one man in it.

Anon!: Invest me in my motley.
Goodbye!: Get me out of my bed.

Anon!: Round, even to faultiness.
Goodbye!: Round, even to faultiness.

Anon!: It may be worth thy pains, for I can sing And speak to him in many sorts of music That will allow me very worth his service.
Goodbye!: It may be worth your pains, because I can sing and speak to him in many different ways that will make me very worthy of his service.

Anon!: Nay, good my fellows, do not please sharp fate To grace it with your sorrows.
Goodbye!: No, my good fellows, don’t please sharp fate to grace it with your sorrows.

Anon!: Tis time I should inform thee farther.
Goodbye!: It’s time I’ll tell you more.

Anon!: His fault concludes but what the law should end, The life of Tybalt.
Goodbye!: He’s only guilty of what the law should end, Tybalt’s life.

Anon!: Would I had met my dearest foe in heaven Or ever I had seen that day, Horatio.
Goodbye!: I wish I had met my dearest enemy in heaven or ever seen that day, Horatio.

Anon!: Fare thee well awhile.
Goodbye!: Goodbye for a while.

Anon!: Tis a very excellent piece of work, madam lady.
Goodbye!: It’s a very excellent piece of work, madam lady.

Anon!: Spakest thou of Juliet?
Goodbye!: Are you complaining about Juliet?

Anon!: You shall have anything.
Goodbye!: You’ll have anything.

Anon!: Farewell.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: Conceit upon her father.
Goodbye!: Ask her father.

Anon!: Teach me, dear creature, how to think and speak.
Goodbye!: Tell me how to think and speak, dear creature.

Anon!: She is never sad but when she sleeps, and not ever sad then, for I have heard my daughter say she hath often dreamed of unhappiness and waked herself with laughing.
Goodbye!: She’s never sad, but when she sleeps, and not ever sad then, because I’ve heard my daughter say she’s dreamed of unhappiness and woke up laughing.

Anon!: For better might we Have loved without this mean, if on both parts This be not cherished.
Goodbye!: For better, we could have loved without this mean, if we didn’t love this on both sides.

Anon!: Almost at odds with morning, which is which.
Goodbye!: It’s almost morning, which is what.

Anon!: There was a noise, That’s verily.
Goodbye!: There was a noise, that’s true.

Anon!: Was ever woman in this humor wooed?
Goodbye!: Was a woman ever wooed by this humor?

Anon!: Ha!
Goodbye!: Ha!

Anon!: It was my duty, sir.
Goodbye!: It was my duty, sir.

Anon!: Thou dost speak masterly.
Goodbye!: You speak masterfully.

Anon!: I speak but in the figures and comparisons of it.
Goodbye!: I’m only talking about the figures and the comparisons.

Anon!: And then the boy, his clerk, That took some pains in writing, he begged mine.
Goodbye!: And then the boy, his clerk, who took some pains in writing, begged me.

Anon!: Come, sit down, every mother’s son, and rehearse your parts.—Pyramus, you begin.
Goodbye!: Come, sit down, every mother’s son, and listen to your thoughts.—Pyramus, you start.

Anon!: Shall we see this wrestling, cousin?
Goodbye!: Shall we see this wrestling, cousin?

Anon!: But wherefore could not I pronounce “Amen”?
Goodbye!: But why couldn’t I say “Amen”?

Anon!: I came hither to tell you; and, circumstances shortened, for she has been too long a-talking of, the lady is disloyal.
Goodbye!: I came here to tell you, and, since she’s been talking about for too long, the lady is disloyal.

Anon!: Good heart, at what?
Goodbye!: Good heart, what?

Anon!: It is the quality o' th' climate.
Goodbye!: It’s the quality of the climate.

Anon!: There, My music playing far off, I will betray Tawny-finned fishes.
Goodbye!: I’ll betray fishes, whose music is playing far away.

Anon!: Why, sir, a carpenter.
Goodbye!: You’re a carpenter, sir.

Anon!: Give me thy hand.
Goodbye!: Give me your hand.

Anon!: And then he drew a dial from his poke And, looking on it with lackluster eye, Says very wisely, “It is ten o'clock.
Goodbye!: And then he pulled a dial from his poke and, looking at it with a lackluster eye, says wisely, “It’s ten o'clock.

Anon!: I shall.
Goodbye!: I will.

Anon!: I wonder at this haste, that I must wed Ere he, that should be husband, comes to woo.
Goodbye!: I wonder at this moment that I have to marry him, who should be husband, and come to woo me.

Anon!: And with my hand I seal my true heart’s love.
Goodbye!: And with my hand, I’m sure I’ll love you.

Anon!: If they do see thee they will murder thee.
Goodbye!: If they see you, they’ll murder you.

Anon!: A lady, sir, though it was said she much resembled me, was yet of many accounted beautiful.
Goodbye!: A lady, sir, though it was said she resembled me, was still a beautiful woman.

Anon!: This Lodovico is a proper man.
Goodbye!: This Lodovico is a good man.

Anon!: Good night, good Captain Blunt.
Goodbye!: Good night, Captain Blunt.

Anon!: That thing you speak of, I took it for a man.
Goodbye!: I took it for a man.

Anon!: What, up and down, carved like an apple tart?
Goodbye!: What, up and down, carved like an apple tart?

Anon!: With good acceptance of his Majesty— Save that there was not time enough to hear, As I perceived his Grace would fain have done, The severals and unhidden passages Of his true titles to some certain dukedoms, And generally to the crown and seat of France, Derived from Edward, his great-grandfather.
Goodbye!: With good acceptance of his Majesty—Seven years ago, I didn’t have time to hear the passages of his true titles to some certain dukedoms, and generally to the crown and seat of France, which were

Anon!: But have you both forsworn me?
Goodbye!: But have you both denied to swear me?

Anon!: My liberty.
Goodbye!: My freedom.

Anon!: O, remember, God, To hear her prayer for them, as now for us!
Goodbye!: Oh, God, remember to hear her prayer for them, as for us now!

Anon!: Nay, then indeed she cannot choose but hate thee, Having bought love with such a bloody spoil.
Goodbye!: No, then she can’t choose but hate you, if she bought love with such a bloody spoil.

Anon!: Who is it that can tell me who I am?
Goodbye!: Who can tell me who I am?

Anon!: Would it be better, madam, than I am?
Goodbye!: Would it be better, madam, than I am?

Anon!: When he is gone I would on great occasion speak with you.
Goodbye!: When he’s gone, I’d like to speak with you.

Anon!: But who comes here?
Goodbye!: But who’s coming?

Anon!: They stumble that run fast.
Goodbye!: They’re scolded when they run fast.

Anon!: Give me thy hand.
Goodbye!: Give me your hand.

Anon!: One thing more rests, that thyself execute, to make one among these wooers.
Goodbye!: One more thing is to make one of these wooers.

Anon!: A foolish heart, that I leave here behind.
Goodbye!: I’m a foolish man, who I leave behind here.

Anon!: I will requite your loves.
Goodbye!: I’ll requite your love.

Anon!: Madam, he’s well.
Goodbye!: Madam, he’s well.

Anon!: Conceit, more rich in matter than in words, Brags of his substance, not of ornament.
Goodbye!: Conceit, more rich in matter than in words, Brags of his substance, not of ornament.

Anon!: Not I, believe me.
Goodbye!: Not me, believe me.

Anon!: Do you triumph?
Goodbye!: Do you win?

Anon!: Fled to his house amazed.
Goodbye!: He fled to his house amazed.

Anon!: The law that threatened death becomes thy friend And turns it to exile—there art thou happy.
Goodbye!: The law that threatened death becomes your friend and turns it into exile—there are you happy.

Anon!: As the time, the place, and the condition of this country stands, I could heartily wish this had not befallen.
Goodbye!: As the time, the place, and the situation of this country are approaching, I wish this hadn’t happened.

Anon!: And where the worser is predominant, Full soon the canker death eats up that plant.
Goodbye!: And where the worser is predominant, death soon kills that plant.

Anon!: How now, you secret, black, and midnight hags?
Goodbye!: What’s going on, you secretly hags, black, and midnight?

Anon!: I heard myself proclaimed, And by the happy hollow of a tree Escaped the hunt.
Goodbye!: I heard myself proclaiming, and by the happy hollow of a tree, I escaped the hunt.

Anon!: He was furnished like a hunter.
Goodbye!: He was furnished like a hunter.

Anon!: Lady, you know no rules of charity, Which renders good for bad, blessings for curses.
Goodbye!: Lady, you don’t know the rules of charity, which make good for bad, and blessings for curses.

Anon!: What, is this so?
Goodbye!: Is that true?

Anon!: Ay, if the fool could find it where it lies.
Goodbye!: Yes, if the fool could find it where it lies.

Anon!: Send for him, good uncle.
Goodbye!: Send for him, uncle.

Anon!: I’ll play the housewife for this once.
Goodbye!: I’ll play the housewife for this once.

Anon!: And his unbookish jealousy must construe Poor Cassio’s smiles, gestures, and light behavior Quite in the wrong.—How do you now, lieutenant?
Goodbye!: And his jealousy is a mistake.—How are you, lieutenant?

Anon!: O, how we joy to see your wit restored!
Goodbye!: Oh, how wonderful it is to see your wit restored!

Anon!: These fifteen years you have been in a dream Or, when you waked, so waked as if you slept.
Goodbye!: In the past fifteen years you’ve been in a dream or, when you wake up, you’ve been so awake as if you slept.

Anon!: Now my spirit is going.
Goodbye!: Now I’m going.

Anon!: Thyself art coming To see performed the dreaded act which thou So sought’st to hinder.
Goodbye!: You’re coming to see the dreaded act you wanted to stop.

Anon!: My name is Edgar, and thy father’s son.
Goodbye!: My name is Edgar, and your father’s son.

Anon!: Silence that dreadful bell, it frights the isle From her propriety.
Goodbye!: Silence that dreadful bell, it’s a frightening for the island to be reliant on her own merit.

Anon!: Judge me, you gods!
Goodbye!: Judge me, you gods!

Anon!: Do you mark that?
Goodbye!: Do you remember that?

Anon!: All dead.
Goodbye!: All dead.

Anon!: Not this, but troubles of the marriage bed.
Goodbye!: Not this, but the marriage bed.

Anon!: If thou canst love a fellow of this temper, Kate, whose face is not worth sunburning, that never looks in his glass for love of anything he sees there, let thine eye be thy cook.
Goodbye!: If you can love a fellow of this temper, Kate, whose face isn’t worth sunburning, who never looks in his glass for love of anything he sees there, let your eyes be your cook.

Anon!: Hold then my sword and turn away thy face While I do run upon it.
Goodbye!: Hold my sword and turn your face away while I run on it.

Anon!: You have taken it wiselier than I meant you should.
Goodbye!: You’ve taken it wiser than I thought you should.

Anon!: Good thou, save me a piece of marchpane, and, as thou loves me, let the porter let in Susan Grindstone and Nell.—Antony and Potpan!
Goodbye!: You, save me a piece of sand, and, as you love me, let the porter let in Susan Grindstone and Nell.—Antony and Potpan!

Anon!: Good time of day unto my gracious lord.
Goodbye!: Good day to my gracious lord.

Anon!: And art thou changed?
Goodbye!: And you’ve changed?

Anon!: O, in the duke of Gloucester’s purse.
Goodbye!: Oh, in the duke of Gloucester’s purse.

Anon!: Thou hast seen these signs.
Goodbye!: You’ve seen these signs.

Anon!: Send thy man away.
Goodbye!: Send your man away.

Anon!: My duty, madam, and most humble service.
Goodbye!: My duty, madam, and my humble service.

Anon!: Thou know’st that Banquo, and his Fleance, lives.
Goodbye!: You know that Banquo and his Fleance are alive.

Anon!: Here, here comes Master Signior Leonato, and the Sexton too.
Goodbye!: Here comes Master Signior Leonato, and the Sexton too.

Anon!: If I owe you anything, I will pay you in cudgels.
Goodbye!: If I owe you anything, I’ll pay you in a cudgel.

Anon!: What, shall one of us That struck the foremost man of all this world But for supporting robbers, shall we now Contaminate our fingers with base bribes, And sell the mighty space of our large honors For so much trash as may be graspèd thus?
Goodbye!: What, should one of us who struck the foremost man in this world only for supporting robbers, now we’ll be tempted to bribe our fingers with mighty bribes and sell the mighty space of

Anon!: What villain touched his body, that did stab, And not for justice?
Goodbye!: What villain touched his body, who stabbed him, and not for justice?

Anon!: By this leek, I will most horribly revenge.
Goodbye!: By this leek, I’ll be terribly revenged.

Anon!: I have it, And soundly too.
Goodbye!: I have it, and it’s sound too.

Anon!: What shall I say?
Goodbye!: What should I say?

Anon!: Romeo!
Goodbye!: Romeo!

Anon!: Prithee, nuncle, be contented.
Goodbye!: Please, my mother, be content.

Anon!: Take no note of him.
Goodbye!: Don’t take any notice of him.

Anon!: What dost thou say?
Goodbye!: What do you say?

Anon!: Is Decius Brutus and Trebonius there?
Goodbye!: Are Decius Brutus and Trebonius there?

Anon!: White-livered runagate, what doth he there?
Goodbye!: What’s he doing there?

Anon!: Canst thou, when thou command’st the beggar’s knee, Command the health of it?
Goodbye!: Can you command the beggar’s knee when you’re kneeling?

Anon!: Thy gown?
Goodbye!: Your gown?

Anon!: Oh, that that earth, which kept the world in awe, Should patch a wall t' expel the winter’s flaw!
Goodbye!: Oh, that the earth, which kept the world in awe, should patch a wall to expel the winter’s flaw!

Anon!: No, my lord, not I. Alas, it is the baseness of thy fear That makes thee strangle thy propriety.
Goodbye!: No, my lord, not me.

Anon!: He has no children.
Goodbye!: He has no children.

Anon!: Tis most true, And he beseeched me to entreat your Majesties To hear and see the matter.
Goodbye!: It’s true, and he asked me to ask your Majesties to hear and see the matter.

Anon!: Barnardo has my place.
Goodbye!: Barnardo has my place.

Anon!: Soldier, thou art; but his whole action grows Not in the power on ’t.
Goodbye!: Soldier, you’re a soldier, but his entire action isn’t in the power of it.

Anon!: This is the man.
Goodbye!: This is the man.

Anon!: Up.
Goodbye!: Up.

Anon!: He saves my labor by his own approach.
Goodbye!: He saves my time by avoiding my own mistakes.

Anon!: If our father carry authority with such dispositions as he bears, this last surrender of his will but offend us.
Goodbye!: If our father has authority with the same dispositions he bears, this last surrender of his will only offend us.

Anon!: I pray thee, get us some excellent music, for tomorrow night we would have it at the Lady Hero’s chamber window
Goodbye!: Please, get us some excellent music, because tomorrow night we’ll have it at Lady Hero’s bedroom window.

Anon!: Whip me, ye devils, From the possession of this heavenly sight!
Goodbye!: Whip me, your devils, from the possession of this heavenly sight!

Anon!: How sound is she asleep!
Goodbye!: How sound asleep she is!

Anon!: Nor tears nor prayers shall purchase out abuses, Therefore use none.
Goodbye!: So don’t use tears or prayers to make money.

Anon!: Well, sir, get you in.
Goodbye!: Well, sir, get in.

Anon!: I would the lightning had Burnt up those logs that you are enjoined to pile!
Goodbye!: I wish the lightning had burned up those logs you’ve been invited to pile up!

Anon!: My wayward husband hath a hundred times
Goodbye!: My lord

Anon!: Come, put mine armor on.
Goodbye!: Come on, put my armor on.

Anon!: No, believe me.
Goodbye!: No, don’t believe me.

Anon!: The most exquisite Claudio?
Goodbye!: The most exquisite Claudio?

Anon!: Why, Belman is as good as he, my lord.
Goodbye!: Why, Belman is as good as he is, my lord.

Anon!: Od’s lifelings, here he is!—You broke my head for nothing, and that that I did, I was set on to do ’t by Sir Toby.
Goodbye!: I was set to do it by Sir Toby.

Anon!: Never fear that.
Goodbye!: Don’t worry about that.

Anon!: God and your arms be praised, victorious friends!
Goodbye!: God and your arms will be praised, victorious friends!

Anon!: But to read his right wits is to read thus.
Goodbye!: But read his right wits is to read like this.

Anon!: Now Edmund, where’s the villain?
Goodbye!: Edmund, where’s the villain?

Anon!: Stand!
Goodbye!: Stand!

Anon!: But come, young waverer, come, go with me, In one respect I’ll thy assistant be, For this alliance may so happy prove To turn your households' rancor to pure love.
Goodbye!: But come, young waver, come with me, I’ll be your assistant in one respect, because this alliance may prove so happy to turn your households’ sanity into pure love.

Anon!: Dost thou not bring me letters from the friar?
Goodbye!: Don’t you bring me letters from the friar?

Anon!: A lantern, slaughtered youth, For here lies Juliet, and her beauty makes This vault a feasting presence full of light.
Goodbye!: Juliet lies here, and her beauty makes this vault a feasting place full of light.

Anon!: Oh, widow Dido?
Goodbye!: Oh, the widow Dido?

Anon!: Go, write it in a martial hand.
Goodbye!: Go, write it in a martial hand.

Anon!: You should then have accosted her, and with some excellent jests, fire-new from the mint, you should have banged the youth into dumbness.
Goodbye!: You should have accosted her, and you should have thrown the youth into a dumbness with some excellent sneezes.

Anon!: Oh, sweet England!
Goodbye!: Oh, sweet England!

Anon!: This interchange of love, I here protest, Upon my part shall be inviolable.
Goodbye!: I swear that love will be inviolable.

Anon!: Stay and speak!
Goodbye!: Stay and speak!

Anon!: Riotous madness, To be entangled with those mouth-made vows Which break themselves in swearing!
Goodbye!: I’m a rooster, to be engulfed with those mouth-made vows that break themselves in swearing!

Anon!: Let me ask you one word in private.
Goodbye!: Let me ask you one word in private.

Anon!: I look down towards his feet, but that’s a fable.
Goodbye!: I look down towards his feet, but that’s a fable.

Anon!: Well, well, away.
Goodbye!: Well, well, let’s go.

Anon!: Then, window, let day in and let life out.
Goodbye!: Then, window, let day in and let life go.

Anon!: Tis a naughty night to swim in.
Goodbye!: It’s a naughty night to swim in.

Anon!: If he have caught the Benedick, it will cost him a thousand pound ere a be cured.
Goodbye!: If he caught the Benedick, it will cost him a thousand pounds before he can be cured.

Anon!: You are merry, my lord.
Goodbye!: You’re a good man, my lord.

Anon!: These foolish drops do something drown my manly spirit.
Goodbye!: These foolish drops drown my manly spirit.

Anon!: Leave me and do the thing I bid thee do.
Goodbye!: Leave me and do what I asked you to do.

Anon!: Demetrius, I will keep my word with thee.
Goodbye!: Demetrius, I’ll keep my word with you.

Anon!: Father, and wife, and gentlemen, adieu.
Goodbye!: Father, wife, and gentlemen, adieu.

Anon!: Read.
Goodbye!: Read.

Anon!: No more, cousin.
Goodbye!: No more, cousin.

Anon!: Indeed!
Goodbye!: Yes!

Anon!: I am ready.
Goodbye!: I’m ready.

Anon!: This prince hath neither claimed it nor deserved it And therefore, in mine opinion, cannot have it.
Goodbye!: This prince has neither claimed or deserved it, and therefore, I think, I can’t have it.

Anon!: Hold, hold, my heart, And you, my sinews, grow not instant old, But bear me stiffly up.
Goodbye!: Hold my heart, and you, my sinews, don’t grow old instantly, but hold me up.

Anon!: My Lord High Constable, the English lie within fifteen hundred paces of your tents.
Goodbye!: My Lord High Constable, the English are within fifteen hundred paces of your tents.

Anon!: My best way is to creep under his gaberdine.
Goodbye!: My best way is to creep under his sleeve.

Anon!: Oh, help!
Goodbye!: Help!

Anon!: You touched my vein at first.
Goodbye!: You touched my heart first.

Anon!: I am sent before to make a fire, and they are coming after to warm them.
Goodbye!: I’ve been sent before to make a fire, and they’re coming after to warm them up.

Anon!: Thrice within this hour I saw him down, thrice up again and fighting.
Goodbye!: I saw him down in an hour, down again and fighting.

Anon!: But yet do I believe The origin and commencement of his grief Sprung from neglected love.—How now, Ophelia?
Goodbye!: But I don’t believe that his grief is a result of neglected love.—How are you, Ophelia?

Anon!: Goblin, lead them up and down.
Goodbye!: Goblin, lead them up and down.

Anon!: Not yet quite dead?
Goodbye!: Not yet quite dead?

Anon!: Hark, now I hear them.
Goodbye!: Listen, now I hear them.

Anon!: He brushes his hat o' mornings.
Goodbye!: He brushes his hat over the mornings.

Anon!: Ay, my commander.
Goodbye!: Yes, my commander.

Anon!: Master Fer.
Goodbye!: Master Fer.

Anon!: That I did love the Moor to live with him, My downright violence and storm of fortunes May trumpet to the world.
Goodbye!: I wish I had loved the Moor to live with him, and my terrible violence and storm of fortunes may make the world more powerful.

Anon!: O, then, dear saint, let lips do what hands do.
Goodbye!: Oh, then, dear saint, let lips do what hands do.

Anon!: Why, man, they did make love to this employment.
Goodbye!: They did make love for this job, man.

Anon!: I cry your worships' mercy, heartily.—I beseech your worship’s name.
Goodbye!: I beg your worship’s name.

Anon!: A bird of my tongue is better than a beast of yours.
Goodbye!: A bird of my tongue is better than a beast of yours.

Anon!: O, never Shall sun that morrow see!
Goodbye!: Oh, never will sun shine that morning!

Anon!: Ay, ’tis strong, and it does indifferent well in a dun-colored stock.
Goodbye!: Yes, it’s strong, and it’s indifferent in a dun-colored stock.

Anon!: I speak not to disprove what Brutus spoke, But here I am to speak what I do know.
Goodbye!: I don’t say anything to disprove what Brutus said, but here I am to say what I know.

Anon!: Where is thy power, then, to beat him back?
Goodbye!: Where is your power to beat him back?

Anon!: And there she shall at Friar Lawrence' cell Be shrived and married.
Goodbye!: And she’ll be married at Friar Lawrence’s cell.

Anon!: Nay, then you lie.
Goodbye!: No, then you lie.

Anon!: If that her breath will mist or stain the stone, Why then, she lives.
Goodbye!: If her breath will mist or stain the stone, then she’ll live.

Anon!: Whither will you that I go To answer this your charge?
Goodbye!: Where will you go to answer this question?

Anon!: I have done my work ill, friends.
Goodbye!: I’ve done my work poorly, friends.

Anon!: I wot well where he is.
Goodbye!: I’m glad he’s here.

Anon!: It were well The general were put in mind of it.
Goodbye!: It was a good idea for the general.

Anon!: I thought all for the best.
Goodbye!: I thought everything was the best.

Anon!: Why, how now, Dromio.
Goodbye!: What’s going on, Dromio?

Anon!: Answer to that.
Goodbye!: Answer that question.

Anon!: Nay, I’ll go with thee, cheek by jowl.
Goodbye!: No, I’ll go with you, cheek by cheek.

Anon!: But, I’ll warrant you, when I say so, she looks as pale as any clout in the versal world.
Goodbye!: But I’ll tell you, when I say that, she looks as pale as any other clout in the versal world.

Anon!: Was that done like Cassius?
Goodbye!: Was that done like Cassius?

Anon!: Good my lord, enter here.
Goodbye!: Please, my lord, come here.

Anon!: Trouble us not.
Goodbye!: Don’t bother us.

Anon!: Thou 'rt kind.
Goodbye!: You’re kind.

Anon!: Six or seven thousand is their utmost power.
Goodbye!: Six or seven thousand are their greatest powers.

Anon!: Well.
Goodbye!: Well, that’s right.

Anon!: But no more deep will I endart mine eye Than your consent gives strength to make it fly.
Goodbye!: But I won’t let my eyes go deeper than your consent gives you strength to make it fly.

Anon!: Good Ursula, wake my cousin Beatrice and desire her to rise.
Goodbye!: Good Ursula, wake up my cousin Beatrice and want her to rise.

Anon!: Tis so strange That, though the truth of it stands off as gross As black and white, my eye will scarcely see it.
Goodbye!: It’s so strange that even though the truth is as gross as black and white, my eyes will see it.

Anon!: Tis gone.
Goodbye!: It’s gone.

Anon!: And by how much she strives to do him good She shall undo her credit with the Moor.
Goodbye!: And by how much she wants to do him good, she will undo her credit with the Moor.

Anon!: Would you buy her, that you enquire after her?
Goodbye!: Would you buy her so you can ask for her?

Anon!: Cunning.
Goodbye!: Cunningham.

Anon!: Hast thou the flower there?
Goodbye!: Are you the flower here?

Anon!: One from the Lord Stanley.
Goodbye!: One from the Lord Stanley.

Anon!: Here’s to thee, Menas!
Goodbye!: Here’s to you, Menas!

Anon!: We wish your peace.
Goodbye!: We wish you peace.

Anon!: And it is very much lamented, Brutus, That you have no such mirrors as will turn Your hidden worthiness into your eye That you might see your shadow.
Goodbye!: And it’s very sad, Brutus, that you don’t have any mirrors that will turn your hidden worth into your eyes so you can see your shadow.

Anon!: But, I pray you, let none of your people stir me.
Goodbye!: But please, don’t let any of your people disturb me.

Anon!: Thus bad begins and worse remains behind.
Goodbye!: That’s bad, and worse still remains behind.

Anon!: Give me up the truth.
Goodbye!: Give me up the truth.

Anon!: Thy truth then be thy dower.
Goodbye!: Your truth will be your king.

Anon!: She speaks.
Goodbye!: She’s talking.

Anon!: Now you talk of a sheet of paper, I remember a pretty jest your daughter told.
Goodbye!: Now you’re talking about a sheet of paper, I remember a pretty joke your daughter told me.

Anon!: Methought the billows spoke and told me of it, The winds did sing it to me, and the thunder, That deep and dreadful organ pipe, pronounced The name of Prosper.
Goodbye!: I thought the billows were talking and telling me about it, the winds sang it to me, and the thunder, that deep and dreadful organ pipe, pronounced Prosper’s name.

Anon!: Nor I neither.
Goodbye!: I don’t.

Anon!: Know you any, Hero?
Goodbye!: Do you know any, Hero?

Anon!: What night-rule now about this haunted grove?
Goodbye!: What’s the news about this haunted grove?

Anon!: Wouldst thou do such a deed for all the world?
Goodbye!: Would you do such a thing for all the world?

Anon!: God ye good e'en, fair gentlewoman.
Goodbye!: Good-bye, fair lady.

Anon!: That if you be honest and fair, your honesty should admit no discourse to your beauty.
Goodbye!: If you’re honest and fair, you shouldn’t admit anything to your beauty.

Anon!: But other of your insolent retinue Do hourly carp and quarrel, breaking forth In rank and not-to-be-endurèd riots.
Goodbye!: But other of your resentful men do hourly carp and fight, breaking out of riots and rioting.

Anon!: Whose tongue?
Goodbye!: Whose tongue?

Anon!: Madam, with all my heart.
Goodbye!: Madam, with all my heart.

Anon!: My fair Rosalind, I come within an hour of my promise.
Goodbye!: My dear Rosalind, I’m coming within an hour of my promise.

Anon!: Ay, pilgrim, lips that they must use in prayer.
Goodbye!: Yes, pilgrim, they have lips that they need to pray for.

Anon!: Let life be short, else shame will be too long.
Goodbye!: Let life be short, and shame will be too long.

Anon!: You have heard much.
Goodbye!: You’ve heard so much.

Anon!: I pray you, rise.
Goodbye!: Please, come on.

Anon!: It harrows me with fear and wonder.
Goodbye!: It’s harrowing me with fear and wonder.

Anon!: Oh, he has given example for our flight Most grossly by his own!
Goodbye!: Oh, he’s given us an example for our flight, most grossly by his own words!

Anon!: Too well what love women to men may owe.
Goodbye!: Too well what women can owe men.

Anon!: I do but beg a little changeling boy, To be my henchman.
Goodbye!: I beg a little boy to be my king.

Anon!: I am that merry wanderer of the night.
Goodbye!: I’m that merry wanderer of the night.

Anon!: I am no fighter.
Goodbye!: I’m not a fighter.

Anon!: But soft!
Goodbye!: But wait!

Anon!: O Lord, I must laugh.
Goodbye!: Oh Lord, I have to laugh.

Anon!: Speak’st thou in sober meanings?
Goodbye!: Do you speak in sober terms?

Anon!: The oars were silver, Which to the tune of flutes kept stroke, and made The water which they beat to follow faster, As amorous of their strokes.
Goodbye!: The oars were silver, which, to the tune of flutes, kept the stroke, and made the water they beat to follow faster, as amorous as their strokes.

Anon!: What villain, madam?
Goodbye!: What villain, madam?

Anon!: O my dear Orlando, how it grieves me to see thee wear thy heart in a scarf.
Goodbye!: Oh, Orlando, I’m so sad to see you wear your heart in a scarf.

Anon!: Shall I abide In this dull world, which in thy absence is No better than a sty?
Goodbye!: Shall I live in this dull world, which isn’t better than a sty?

Anon!: True or false, it hath made thee Earl of Gloucester.
Goodbye!: True or false, it’s made you Earl of Gloucester.

Anon!: Meantime, but think how I may do thee good, And be inheritor of thy desire.
Goodbye!: I’ve been able to do you good, and be the inheritor of your desire.

Anon!: Where virtue is, these are more virtuous.
Goodbye!: Where virtue is, these are more virtuous.

Anon!: Now, by my mother’s son, and that’s myself, It shall be moon, or star, or what I list, Or e'er I journey to your father’s house.
Goodbye!: Now, by my mother’s son, and that’s me, it will be moon, or star, or whatever I list, or if I’ll go to your father’s house.

Anon!: Do what you will, dishonor shall be humor.
Goodbye!: Do what you want, and you’ll be dishonored by humor.

Anon!: I am armed and well prepared.— Give me your hand, Bassanio.
Goodbye!: I’m well prepared and armed.—Don’t give me your hand, Bassanio.

Anon!: I believe drink gave thee the lie last night.
Goodbye!: I believe drink gave you the lie last night.

Anon!: For what had he to do to chide at me?
Goodbye!: What did he do to scold me?

Anon!: I have perceived a most faint neglect of late, which I have rather blamed as mine own jealous curiosity than as a very pretense and purpose of unkindness.
Goodbye!: I’ve seen a very faint neglect of my life recently, which I’d rather blame as my jealous curiosity than as a very foolish and unkindness.

Anon!: Then she bears some breadth?
Goodbye!: Then she has some depth?

Anon!: For these fellows of infinite tongue, that can rhyme themselves into ladies' favors, they do always reason themselves out again.
Goodbye!: For those who can rhyme themselves into ladies' favors, they always reason themselves out again.

Anon!: The English force, so please you.
Goodbye!: The English force, please.

Anon!: Our will is Antony be took alive.
Goodbye!: Our will is to take Antony alive.

Anon!: We cannot call her winds and waters sighs and tears.
Goodbye!: We can’t call her sighs and tears.

Anon!: He is much changed.
Goodbye!: He’s been a lot changed.

Anon!: I hear The strain of strutting chanticleer Cry “Cock-a-diddle-dow.” Where should this music be?
Goodbye!: I hear the strutting chanticleer cry “Cock-a-diddle-dow.” Where should this music be?

Anon!: Then let thy love be younger than thyself, Or thy affection cannot hold the bent.
Goodbye!: Then let your love be younger than you are, or your affection can’t hold the bent.

Anon!: I did not give the lie.
Goodbye!: I didn’t give the lie.

Anon!: How say you now?
Goodbye!: What do you think?

Anon!: Pray thee, go seek him, and bring him to my tent.
Goodbye!: Please go find him, and bring him to my tent.

Anon!: Neither to you nor any one, having no witness to confirm my speech.
Goodbye!: I’m not to you or any one, but I’m not sure what I’m saying.

Anon!: I crave your highness’ pardon.
Goodbye!: I’m asking your highness’ pardon.

Anon!: Tell us where ’tis, that we may take it thence And bear it to the chapel.
Goodbye!: Tell us where it is, so we can take it from here and carry it to the chapel.

Anon!: Ay, master.
Goodbye!: Yes, master.

Anon!: When thou once Wast beaten from Modena, where thou slew’st Hirtius and Pansa, consuls, at thy heel Did famine follow, whom thou fought’st against, Though daintily brought up, with patience more Than savages could suffer.
Goodbye!: When you were once beaten from Modena, where you slew Hirtius and Pansa, consuls, followed famine at your heel, whom you fought against, even though you were

Anon!: I had a Richard too, and thou did’st kill him; I had a Rutland too; thou holp’st to kill him.
Goodbye!: I had a Richard too, and you killed him; I had a Rutland too; you holp to kill him.

Anon!: Tell me where it is.
Goodbye!: Tell me where it is.

Anon!: My invocation Is fair and honest.
Goodbye!: I’m fair and honest.

Anon!: Thou dost see I eat.
Goodbye!: You see I eat.

Anon!: Rather your eyes must with his judgment look.
Goodbye!: You’re more likely to see him with his judgment.

Anon!: I have forsworn his bed and company.
Goodbye!: I’ve sworn he’s sleeping and sleeping.

Anon!: Our good old friend, Lay comforts to your bosom, and bestow Your needful counsel to our business, Which craves the instant use.
Goodbye!: Our good old friend, give us comfort and advice for our business, which demands immediate use.

Anon!: I give it you.
Goodbye!: I give it to you.

Anon!: I would try, if I could cry “hem” and have him.
Goodbye!: I’d try to get him to cry “hem” and have him.

Anon!: In troth, ’tis morning.
Goodbye!: It’s morning.

Anon!: We speak no treason, man.
Goodbye!: We don’t speak of treason, man.

Anon!: Away, slight man!
Goodbye!: Go away, a little man!

Anon!: Nothing but this: your true love for my master.
Goodbye!: Nothing but this: you’re true to me.

Anon!: I will preach to thee.
Goodbye!: I’ll preach to you.

Anon!: Forget to think of her.
Goodbye!: Don’t think about her.

Anon!: Take the fool away.
Goodbye!: Take the fool away.

Anon!: Tarry, good Beatrice.
Goodbye!: Be sorry, good Beatrice.

Anon!: If th' other two be brained like us, the state totters.
Goodbye!: If the other two are brained like us, the state will get worse.

Anon!: Not too fast!
Goodbye!: Not too fast!

Anon!: Oh, most lame and impotent conclusion!
Goodbye!: Oh, most lame and impotent conclusion!

Anon!: I peseech you heartily, scurvy, lousy knave, at my desires, and my requests, and my petitions, to eat, look you, this leek.
Goodbye!: I ask you to eat, look, this leek.

Anon!: This fellow’s of exceeding honesty And knows all quantities, with a learnèd spirit, Of human dealings.
Goodbye!: This fellow is a man who’s very honest and knows all the things about human affairs.

Anon!: Lead the way.
Goodbye!: Lead the way.

Anon!: And he is a very paramour for a sweet voice.
Goodbye!: And he’s a paramour for a sweet voice.

Anon!: What is your will?
Goodbye!: What do you want?

Anon!: I am fire and air, my other elements I give to baser life.—So, have you done?
Goodbye!: I’m fire and air, my other elements I give to basers.—So, have you done that?

Anon!: Do not you wear your dagger in your cap that day, lest he knock that about yours.
Goodbye!: Don’t wear your dagger in your cap that day, so he won’t knock that over yours.

Anon!: He shall taste of my bottle.
Goodbye!: He’ll taste my bottle.

Anon!: One side will mock another—th' other too.
Goodbye!: One side will mock another—the other will.

Anon!: Thyself a queen, for me that was a queen, Outlive thy glory, like my wretched self.
Goodbye!: You’re a queen, for I was a queen, and you’re outlived your glory, like my wretched self.

Anon!: Yet I suppose him virtuous, know him noble, Of great estate, of fresh and stainless youth.
Goodbye!: But I suppose he’s virtuous, and he’s noble, and he’s a fresh, and dependable young man.

Anon!: Yet you will be hanged for being so long absent.
Goodbye!: But you’ll be hanged for being so long absent.

Anon!: What, are you busy, ho?
Goodbye!: Are you busy?

Anon!: Pray, sir, be patient.
Goodbye!: Please, sir, be patient.

Anon!: Bid him Report the feature of Octavia: her years, Her inclination.
Goodbye!: Tell him to tell me the story of Octavia: her years, her desire to be a woman.

Anon!: The Prince will doom thee death If thou art taken.
Goodbye!: The Prince will punish you for death if you’re taken.

Anon!: Here will we sit and let the sounds of music Creep in our ears.
Goodbye!: Here we sit and listen to the music in our ears.

Anon!: Dear my lord, if you in your own proof Have vanquished the resistance of her youth And made defeat of her virginity— I know what you would say: if I have known her, You will say she did embrace me as a husband, And so extenuate the forehand sin.
Goodbye!: Dear lord, if you’ve defended her youth and defeated her virginity—I know what you would say: if I knew her, you’ll say she embraces me as a husband, and so ex

Anon!: The old cock.
Goodbye!: The old cock.

Anon!: God made him and therefore let him pass for a man.
Goodbye!: God made him, and so he let him pass for a man.

Anon!: If I cut my finger, I shall make bold with you.— Your name, honest gentleman?
Goodbye!: If I cut my finger, I’ll make bold with you.—Your name, honest gentleman?

Anon!: Flatterers?—Now, Brutus, thank yourself.
Goodbye!: Flatterers?—Now, Brutus, thank you.

Anon!: How much better is it to weep at joy than to joy at weeping!
Goodbye!: How much better it is to weep at joy than to rejoice at weeping!

Anon!: Do thy duty, and have thy duty, for my master and mistress are almost frozen to death.
Goodbye!: Do your duty, and do your duty, because my master and mistress are almost dead.

Anon!: O dear father, It is thy business that I go about.
Goodbye!: Oh, father, I’m going to do your business.

Anon!: Then burst his mighty heart, And, in his mantle muffling up his face, Even at the base of Pompey’s statue, Which all the while ran blood, great Caesar fell.
Goodbye!: Then he burst his mighty heart and, in his mantle muffling up his face, even at the base of Pompey’s statue, which ran blood all the while, great Caesar fell.

Anon!: I did so, and take heed on ’t, Make it a darling like your precious eye.
Goodbye!: I did that, and I’m sure you’ll see it as a darling like your precious eye.

Anon!: What, have you dined at home?
Goodbye!: Have you eaten at home?

Anon!: Return, good Catesby, to the gracious duke.
Goodbye!: Return to the gracious duke, good Catesby.

Anon!: You forget yourself To hedge me in.
Goodbye!: You forget to hide me.

Anon!: The court awards it, and the law doth give it.
Goodbye!: The court awards it, and the law gives it to him.

Anon!: Sick, oh, sick!
Goodbye!: Oh, sick!

Anon!: Answer every man directly.
Goodbye!: Answer every man directly.

Anon!: Marry, this is miching
Goodbye!: This is a snobby.

Anon!: Too well, too well.
Goodbye!: Too well, too well.

Anon!: Wherefore this ghastly looking?
Goodbye!: Why are you looking so gloomy?

Anon!: Great Dunsinane he strongly fortifies.
Goodbye!: Great Dunsinane is strong enough to be a soldier.

Anon!: Can you tell me whether one Launcelot that dwells with him, dwell with him or no?
Goodbye!: Can you tell me whether one Launcelot who lives with him, or not, is living with him?

Anon!: Tis marvel, but that you are but newly come, You might have heard it else proclaimed about.
Goodbye!: It’s marvellous, but you’re only coming soon, you might have heard it else.

Anon!: We will spare for no wit, I warrant you.
Goodbye!: We won’t spare for any wit, I assure you.

Anon!: Not in deed, madam, for I can do nothing But what indeed is honest to be done.
Goodbye!: I can’t do anything but what is actually honest.

Anon!: Why do you dress me In borrowed robes?
Goodbye!: Why do you dress me in borrowed robes?

Anon!: Be patient, for the prize I’ll bring thee to Shall hoodwink this mischance.
Goodbye!: Be patient, because the prize I’ll bring you to Shall wink this mischance.

Anon!: what mistress, slave, hast thou?
Goodbye!: What mistress, slave, are you?

Anon!: Tis sport to maul a runner.
Goodbye!: It’s a sport to make a runner.

Anon!: Their ships are yare, yours, heavy.
Goodbye!: Their ships are heavy, yours.

Anon!: I have heard of some kind of men that put quarrels purposely on others, to taste their valor.
Goodbye!: I’ve heard of some kind of men who put quarrels on others to taste their valor.

Anon!: God 'ild you, sir.
Goodbye!: God bless you, sir.

Anon!: Lord, how art thou changed!
Goodbye!: Lord, how have you changed!

Anon!: Come, sisters, cheer we up his sprites, And show the best of our delights.
Goodbye!: Come, sisters, cheer him up and show us the best of our delights.

Anon!: But who is with him?
Goodbye!: But who is he?

Anon!: If you call me Jephthah, my lord, I have a daughter that I love passing well.
Goodbye!: If you call me Jephthah, my lord, I have a daughter I love passing well.

Anon!: Write to me very shortly, And you shall understand from me her mind.
Goodbye!: Write to me very soon, and you’ll understand her thoughts from me.

Anon!: I owe you much, and, like a willful youth, That which I owe is lost.
Goodbye!: I owe you much, and, like a willful young man, I’m losing everything I owe.

Anon!: If we are marked to die, we are enough To do our country loss; and if to live, The fewer men, the greater share of honor.
Goodbye!: If we’re marked to die, we’re enough to do our country’s loss.

Anon!: Ride, ride, Messala.
Goodbye!: Ride, ride, Messala.

Anon!: My friend, thy husband, honest, honest Iago.
Goodbye!: My friend, your husband, honest, honest Iago.

Anon!: Their hands and faces were all badged with blood.
Goodbye!: Their hands and faces were all covered with blood.

Anon!: For besides these beneficial news, it is the celebration of his nuptial.
Goodbye!: And besides these good news, it’s the celebration of his wedding.

Anon!: The king his master needs must take it ill, That he, so slightly valued in his messenger, Should have him thus restrained.
Goodbye!: The king’s master has to take it seriously, so he should restrain him from being so a little valued in his messenger.

Anon!: I am not guilty of Lysander’s blood.
Goodbye!: I’m not guilty of Lysander’s blood.

Anon!: Oh, by no means.
Goodbye!: Oh, no.

Anon!: But I am sent to find those persons whose names are here writ, and can never find what names the writing person hath here writ.
Goodbye!: But I’m sent to find those people who have written this letter, and I can’t find what the author has written.

Anon!: The devil himself could not pronounce a title More hateful to mine ear.
Goodbye!: The devil himself couldn’t pronounce a title more hateful to me than a title I’d like to hear.

Anon!: I could not forget you, for I never saw you before in all my life.
Goodbye!: I couldn’t forget you, because I never saw you before in my life.

Anon!: This is his second fit.
Goodbye!: This is his second fit.

Anon!: Verona’s summer hath not such a flower.
Goodbye!: Summer in Verona hasn’t been such a beautiful flower.

Anon!: He is not the flower of courtesy, but, I’ll warrant him, as gentle as a lamb.
Goodbye!: He’s not the flower of courtesy, but I’ll bet he’s as gentle as a lamb.

Anon!: Tis true indeed, so your daughter says.
Goodbye!: It’s true, your daughter says.

Anon!: I once more take my leave.
Goodbye!: I’ll leave again.

Anon!: Therefore confess thee freely of thy sin, For to deny each article with oath Cannot remove nor choke the strong conception That I do groan withal.
Goodbye!: So confess freely to your sin, because to deny each article with oath can’t remove or choke the strong conception that I’m groaning with.

Anon!: I pray thee, do not mock me, fellow student.
Goodbye!: Please, don’t mock me, fellow student.

Anon!: By this kind of chase I should hate him, for my father hated his father dearly.
Goodbye!: I’d hate him by this kind of chase, because my father hated his father very much.

Anon!: Answer my life my judgment, Thy youngest daughter does not love thee least, Nor are those empty-hearted whose low sound Reverbs no hollowness.
Goodbye!: I’ll answer my life’s judgment, your youngest daughter doesn’t love you the least, and neither are those emptyhearted who don’t listen to you.

Anon!: That’s not so.
Goodbye!: That’s not true.

Anon!: Had I as many sons as I have hairs, I would not wish them to a fairer death.
Goodbye!: If I had as many sons as I have hairs, I wouldn’t wish them a better death.

Anon!: And yet complainest thou of obstruction?
Goodbye!: And yet you’re complaining of obstruction?

Anon!: And unrespective boys.
Goodbye!: And unrespective boys.

Anon!: Away, then!
Goodbye!: Go away, then!

Anon!: Soft, comes he not here?
Goodbye!: Isn’t he here?

Anon!: She was here even now.
Goodbye!: She was here right now.

Anon!: I know not, lady.
Goodbye!: I don’t know, lady.

Anon!: Sometimes from her eyes I did receive fair speechless messages.
Goodbye!: Sometimes she saw me receiving speechless messages from her eyes.

Anon!: How now, Horatio?
Goodbye!: What’s going on, Horatio?

Anon!: I have a daughter.
Goodbye!: I have a daughter.

Anon!: He is no less than a stuffed man.
Goodbye!: He’s not less than a stuffed man.

Anon!: Thus it must be.
Goodbye!: That’s what it must be.

Anon!: Monday, my lord.
Goodbye!: Monday, my lord.

Anon!: Madam, with much ado.
Goodbye!: Madam, with much ado.

Anon!: I said thou hadst a fine wit.
Goodbye!: I said you had a good wit.

Anon!: Twas no need, I trow, To bid me trudge.
Goodbye!: There was no need to tell me to trudge.

Anon!: For, of my heart, those charms, thine eyes, are blotted.
Goodbye!: My heart is full of charms, your eyes, and your eyes.

Anon!: O infinite virtue, com’st thou smiling from The world’s great snare uncaught?
Goodbye!: Oh, infinite virtue, are you smiling from the world’s great snare uncaught?

Anon!: Alas, sir, be patient.
Goodbye!: Oh, sir, be patient.

Anon!: Hath she made her affection known to Benedick?
Goodbye!: Has she told Benedick about her love?

Anon!: For aught that I could ever read, Could ever hear by tale or history, The course of true love never did run smooth.
Goodbye!: For a story I could ever read, hear by story or history, the course of true love never ran smoothly.

Anon!: Why, this fellow has banished two on ’s daughters, and did the third a blessing against his will.
Goodbye!: Why, this man has banished two of his daughters and gave the third a blessing against his will.

Anon!: If I do find him fit, I’ll move your suit And seek to effect it to my uttermost.
Goodbye!: If I find him right, I’ll move your suit and try to make it to my fullest.

Anon!: Apollo plays, And twenty cagèd nightingales do sing: Or wilt thou sleep?
Goodbye!: Apollo plays, and twenty cagèd nightingales sing: Or are you going to sleep?

Anon!: But for a fine, quaint, graceful, and excellent fashion, yours is worth ten on ’t.
Goodbye!: But for a fine, charming, graceful, and excellent manner, yours is worth ten.

Anon!: And so, without more circumstance at all, I hold it fit that we shake hands and part.
Goodbye!: And so, without any more circumstance, I’m sure we’ll shake hands and part.

Anon!: I want more uncles here to welcome me.
Goodbye!: I want more uncles here to welcome me.

Anon!: These be good humors.
Goodbye!: These are good humors.

Anon!: Ay.
Goodbye!: Yes.

Anon!: Idle old man That still would manage those authorities That he hath given away!
Goodbye!: Idle old man who still wants to manage the powers he has given away!

Anon!: The tender prince Would fain have come with me to meet your Grace, But by his mother was perforce withheld.
Goodbye!: The tender prince would have come with me to meet you, but his mother was unable to help him.

Anon!: I have drunk poison whiles he uttered it.
Goodbye!: I’ve drunk poison while he said it.

Anon!: Monday!
Goodbye!: Monday!

Anon!: Nay, by Saint Jamy, I hold you a penny, A horse and a man Is more than one And yet not many.
Goodbye!: No, by Saint Jamy, I hold you a penny, a horse and a man are more than one, but not many.

Anon!: Sir, sir, be patient.
Goodbye!: Sir, sir, be patient.

Anon!: Serve God, love me, and mend.
Goodbye!: Serve God, love me, and heal me.

Anon!: It comes upon me.—Art thou any thing?
Goodbye!: It’s coming to me.—Do you have any thing?

Anon!: The fault, dear Brutus, is not in our stars But in ourselves, that we are underlings.
Goodbye!: The fault, dear Brutus, is not in our stars, but in ourselves, that we are underlings.

Anon!: Is love a tender thing?
Goodbye!: Is love a tender thing?

Anon!: Hence!
Goodbye!: Let’s go!

Anon!: Yes, something you can deny for your own safety: you have been a great thief by sea.
Goodbye!: Yes, something you can’t say for your own safety: you’ve been a great thief by sea.

Anon!: He is justly served.
Goodbye!: He’s served a good job.

Anon!: I come but in as others do, to try with him the strength of my youth.
Goodbye!: I’m just coming in as others do, trying to convince him to be my strength.

Anon!: Speak to me what thou art.
Goodbye!: Tell me what you’re doing.

Anon!: How is ’t, Laertes?
Goodbye!: How is it, Laertes?

Anon!: Of so high and plenteous wit and invention!
Goodbye!: Of so high and plenuous wit and invention!

Anon!: Say, if th' hadst rather hear it from our mouths, Or from our masters'.
Goodbye!: Say, if you’d rather hear it from our mouths or from our masters’.

Anon!: I repent me much That so I harried him.
Goodbye!: I’m sorry I harried him so much.

Anon!: Should not upbraid our course.
Goodbye!: Don’t jump on our course.

Anon!: These times of woe afford no time to woo.
Goodbye!: These times of sorrow don’t give us time to woo.

Anon!: My lord?
Goodbye!: My lord?

Anon!: A good lenten answer.
Goodbye!: A good answer.

Anon!: No, I’ll not weep.
Goodbye!: No, I won’t cry.

Anon!: But there where I have garnered up my heart, Where either I must live or bear no life, The fountain from the which my current runs Or else dries up—to be discarded thence!
Goodbye!: But there I have gotten my heart out of here, where I must live or have no life, the fountain from which my current runs or else dries up—to be discarded from here!

Anon!: Stand not amazed.
Goodbye!: Don’t stand up surprised.

Anon!: These fellows have some soul,
Goodbye!: These men are a bit sane,

Anon!: Hem them away.
Goodbye!: Hem them away.

Anon!: To fly the boar before the boar pursues Were to incense the boar to follow us And make pursuit where he did mean no chase.
Goodbye!: If the boar were flying before the boar pursued, the boar would incense the boar to follow us and make pursuit where he didn’t mean any chase.

Anon!: What is the matter?
Goodbye!: What’s the matter?

Anon!: Come.
Goodbye!: Come on.

Anon!: Let us hear him.
Goodbye!: Let’s hear him.

Anon!: Since he went into France, I have been in continual practice.
Goodbye!: Since he left France, I’ve been practicing constant.

Anon!: I must hence to wait.
Goodbye!: I have to go wait.

Anon!: What sayst thou?
Goodbye!: What do you say?

Anon!: He goes forth gallantly.
Goodbye!: He’s going out of his way.

Anon!: What sum owes he the Jew?
Goodbye!: What sum does he owe the Jew?

Anon!: Your wife and brother Made wars upon me, and their contestation Was theme for you.
Goodbye!: Your wife and brother made wars against me, and their contestation was the theme for you.

Anon!: What tell’st thou me of robbing?
Goodbye!: What do you say about robbing?

Anon!: If till the expiration of your month, You will return and sojourn with my sister, Dismissing half your train, come then to me.
Goodbye!: If you leave until the end of your month, you’ll return and stay with my sister, leaving half your train, then I’ll come to me.

Anon!: At least two glasses.
Goodbye!: At least two glasses.

Anon!: You come to me and you say, “Shylock, we would have moneys.” You say so!— You, that did void your rheum upon my beard And foot me as you spurn a stranger cur Over your threshold!
Goodbye!: You come to me and you say, “Shylock, we would have money.” You say that!—You, who ripped your beard and shook me as you shook a stranger over your threshold!

Anon!: I will resolve you herein presently.
Goodbye!: I’ll resolve you here in the meantime.

Anon!: She said so.
Goodbye!: She said that.

Anon!: Not for all this land Would I be guilty of so deep a sin.
Goodbye!: I wouldn’t be guilty of such a serious sin for all this land.

Anon!: I am not drunk now.
Goodbye!: I’m not drunk now.

Anon!: What a pestilent knave is this same!
Goodbye!: What a pestilent knave this is!

Anon!: I have heard my father name him.
Goodbye!: I’ve heard my father name him.

Anon!: The royal tree hath left us royal fruit, Which, mellowed by the stealing hours of time, Will well become the seat of majesty, And make, no doubt, us happy by his reign.
Goodbye!: The royal tree has left us with royal fruit, which, mellowed by the stealing hours of time, will be the seat of majesty and make us happy by his reign.

Anon!: Are you native of this place?
Goodbye!: Are you native of this place?

Anon!: Expound unto me, boy.
Goodbye!: Expound to me, boy.

Anon!: Thus from my lips, by thine, my sin is purged.
Goodbye!: So my sin is purged from my lips by yours.

Anon!: Two things provided more: that for this favor He presently become a Christian; The other, that he do record a gift Here in the court, of all he dies possessed, Unto his son Lorenzo and his daughter.
Goodbye!: He’s got two things more than that: that he’s now a Christian, and that he’s a gift from the court of justice for all the money he’s possessed, to his son Lo

Anon!: Your plainness and your shortness please me well.
Goodbye!: Your plainness and your shortness please me.

Anon!: Be that thou know’st thou art, and then thou art As great as that thou fear’st.
Goodbye!: Be that you know you’re doing, and then you’re as great as you fear.

Anon!: Here’s one, a friend, and one that knows you well.
Goodbye!: Here’s one, a friend, and one who knows you well.

Anon!: My very hairs do mutiny, for the white Reprove the brown for rashness, and they them For fear and doting.
Goodbye!: My hairs are muted, because the whites are reaffirming the brown for rashness, and they’re afraid and doting.

Anon!: Come, my lord.
Goodbye!: Come on, my lord.

Anon!: And most dear actors, eat no onions nor garlic, for we are to utter sweet breath.
Goodbye!: And most dear actors, don’t eat any onions or garlic, because we’re utterly sweet.

Anon!: Not having that which, having, makes them short.
Goodbye!: Not having the one that makes them short.

Anon!: Out, alas!
Goodbye!: Out, sorry!

Anon!: Not altogether so, sir.
Goodbye!: Not altogether, sir.

Anon!: I put it in the pocket of my gown.
Goodbye!: I put it in my pocket.

Anon!: I see thou know’st me not.
Goodbye!: I see you don’t know me.

Anon!: Leave me, I say.
Goodbye!: Leave me alone, I say.

Anon!: Death makes no conquest of this conqueror, For now he lives in fame, though not in life.
Goodbye!: He’s still alive, though he’s not alive.

Anon!: A greater power than we can contradict Hath thwarted our intents.
Goodbye!: A greater power than we can contradict has ruined our intentions.

Anon!: I hope, for my brother’s justification, he wrote this but as an essay or taste of my virtue.
Goodbye!: I hope for my brother’s reason he wrote this as a taste of my virtue.

Anon!: My tongue and soul in this be hypocrites.
Goodbye!: I’m a hypocrit.

Anon!: I long To hear the story of your life, which must Take the ear strangely.
Goodbye!: I’m waiting to hear the story of your life, which must take the ear strangely.

Anon!: Cast on no water.
Goodbye!: Don’t cast on water.

Anon!: Thou'rt a scholar.
Goodbye!: You’re a scholar.

Anon!: Nay, if you strive— But half an hour!
Goodbye!: No, if you’re trying— But wait a half hour!

Anon!: We will meet, and there we may rehearse most obscenely and courageously.
Goodbye!: We’ll meet, and we can listen courageously and obscenely.

Anon!: This is not yet an Alexandrian feast.
Goodbye!: This isn’t yet an Alexandrian feast.

Anon!: I am your own for ever.
Goodbye!: I’m your own for forever.

Anon!: O, name him not.
Goodbye!: Don’t name him.

Anon!: Give me, give me!
Goodbye!: Give me, give me!

Anon!: And, friends, disperse yourselves.
Goodbye!: And, friends, disperse yourself.

Anon!: Well, let him go.
Goodbye!: Well, let him go.

Anon!: Nay, that’s not so.
Goodbye!: No, that’s not true.

Anon!: Tis one Iago, ancient to the general.
Goodbye!: It’s one Iago, old to the general.

Anon!: I’ll to my charge.
Goodbye!: I’ll go to my job.

Anon!: With cunning hast thou filched my daughter’s heart, Turned her obedience (which is due to me) To stubborn harshness.—And, my gracious duke, Be it so she will not here before your grace Consent to marry with Demetrius, I beg the ancient privilege of Athens.
Goodbye!: I beg the ancient privilege of Athens, my gracious duke, if she doesn’t want to marry Demetrius, I beg her to be a good man.

Anon!: You cannot feed capons so.
Goodbye!: You can’t feed capons like that.

Anon!: Nay, that’s not your way.
Goodbye!: No, that’s not your way.

Anon!: Be factious for redress of all these griefs, And I will set this foot of mine as far As who goes farthest.
Goodbye!: Be honest about all these griefs, and I’ll go as far as anyone who goes farthest.

Anon!: I leave him to your gracious acceptance, whose trial shall better publish his commendation.” You hear the learned Bellario, what he writes.
Goodbye!: I’ll give him your gracious acceptance, whose trial will better publish his praise.” You hear the learned Bellario, what he writes.

Anon!: Well, what was yours?
Goodbye!: Well, what was yours?

Anon!: All’s hushed as midnight yet.
Goodbye!: It’s still as hushed as midnight.

Anon!: I must leave you.
Goodbye!: I have to leave you.

Anon!: Why, she comes to borrow nothing of them.
Goodbye!: Why, she’s not borrowing anything from them.

Anon!: He is a very proper man.
Goodbye!: He’s a very good man.

Anon!: Tell me what more thou know’st.
Goodbye!: Tell me what you know more.

Anon!: No, nor mine now.
Goodbye!: No, and I’m not.

Anon!: Two of both kinds make up four.
Goodbye!: Two of both kinds make four.

Anon!: Farewell.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: And there were drawn Upon a heap a hundred ghastly women, Transformèd with their fear, who swore they saw Men all in fire walk up and down the streets.
Goodbye!: And there were a hundred ghastly women, dressed with their fear, who swore they saw men in fire walk up and down the streets.

Anon!: Therefore prepare you.
Goodbye!: So prepare yourself.

Anon!: What was he, sad or merry?
Goodbye!: What was he sad or merry?

Anon!: Now he is a-praying.
Goodbye!: Now he’s a praying.

Anon!: Alas, gentlemen— Help, ho!— Lieutenant—sir, Montano— Help, masters!—Here’s a goodly watch indeed!
Goodbye!: Oh, gentlemen— Help, ho!—Loyal—sir, Montano— Help, masters!—Here’s a good watch!

Anon!: As a friend or an enemy?
Goodbye!: As a friend or an enemy?

Anon!: If not, ’tis true this parting was well made.
Goodbye!: If not, it’s true that this parting was well done.

Anon!: I’ll not be made a soft and dull-eyed fool To shake the head, relent and sigh, and yield To Christian intercessors.
Goodbye!: I won’t be a dull-eyed fool to shake the head, sigh and give away to Christian intercessors.

Anon!: Oh, but she’ll keep her word.
Goodbye!: Oh, but she’ll keep her word.

Anon!: And mine, two hundred.
Goodbye!: And mine, two hundred.

Anon!: A match!
Goodbye!: A match!

Anon!: Here comes one.
Goodbye!: Here comes one.

Anon!: I pray thee, hold thy peace.
Goodbye!: Please, keep your peace.

Anon!: We’ll away tonight, And be a day before our husbands home.
Goodbye!: We’ll leave tonight, and we’ll be a day before our husbands return home.

Anon!: You know that I held Epicurus strong And his opinion.
Goodbye!: You know that I held Epicurus strong and his opinion.

Anon!: Here comes your father.
Goodbye!: Here comes your father.

Anon!: Command him away.
Goodbye!: Command him away.

Anon!: What, we have many goodly days to see!
Goodbye!: We have many good days to see!

Anon!: If they speak but truth of her, These hands shall tear her; if they wrong her honor, The proudest of them shall well hear of it.
Goodbye!: If they say nothing about her, they’ll tear her up.

Anon!: Iago beckons me.
Goodbye!: Iago is coming.

Anon!: Heaven doth truly know it.
Goodbye!: Heaven knows it.

Anon!: He’s a conspirator.
Goodbye!: He’s a conspirator.

Anon!: What, Curio?
Goodbye!: What, Curio?

Anon!: I trouble thee too much, but thou art willing.
Goodbye!: I’m bothering you too much, but you’re willing.

Anon!: The king and prince at prayers.
Goodbye!: The king and prince are at prayers.

Anon!: Demetrius loves her, and he loves not you.
Goodbye!: Demetrius loves her, and he doesn’t love you.

Anon!: We’ll teach you to drink deep ere you depart.
Goodbye!: We’ll teach you to drink deep before you leave.

Anon!: Dear master, I can go no further.
Goodbye!: Dear master, I can’t go any further.

Anon!: There’s few or none will entertain it.
Goodbye!: There are few or none of them who will entertain it.

Anon!: Truly, she must be given, or the marriage is not lawful.
Goodbye!: Yes, she must be given a marriage, or the marriage is not legal.

Anon!: No, by this hand.
Goodbye!: No, by this hand.

Anon!: Phoebe did write it.
Goodbye!: Phoebe wrote it.

Anon!: The even mead, that erst brought sweetly forth The freckled cowslip, burnet, and green clover, Wanting the scythe, withal uncorrected, rank, Conceives by idleness, and nothing teems But hateful docks, rough thistles, kecksies, burrs, Losing both beauty and utility.
Goodbye!: The even mead, who brought sweetly the freckled cowslip, burnet, and green clover, who wanted the scythe, withal uncorrected, rank, is a man

Anon!: What, are we cuckolds ere we have deserved it?
Goodbye!: What, are we scolding the kings if we deserve it?

Anon!: Fed with the same food, hurt with the same weapons, subject to the same diseases, healed by the same means, warmed and cooled by the same winter and summer as a Christian is?
Goodbye!: Are you fed with the same food, hurt with the same weapons, subject to the same diseases, healed by the same means, warmed and cooled by the same winter and summer as a Christian?

Anon!: How can that be, when you have the voice of the king himself for your succession in Denmark?
Goodbye!: How can that be, when you have the voice of the king himself for your succession in Denmark?

Anon!: The will!
Goodbye!: The will!

Anon!: That eye my daughter lent her; ’tis most true.
Goodbye!: That eye was a sign my daughter gave her.

Anon!: Show.
Goodbye!: Show.

Anon!: It is not yet near day.
Goodbye!: It’s not yet day.

Anon!: Wake her not.
Goodbye!: Don’t wake her up.

Anon!: I am sped.
Goodbye!: I’m sped.

Anon!: If this be known, Cassius or Caesar never shall turn back, For I will slay myself.
Goodbye!: If this is known, Cassius or Caesar will never turn back, because I’ll kill myself.

Anon!: Suffolk first died, and York, all haggled over, Comes to him where in gore he lay insteeped And takes him by the beard, kisses the gashes That bloodily did yawn upon his face.
Goodbye!: Suffolk died first, and York, all haggled over, comes to him where he lay in a gore and takes him by the beard, kisses the gashes that bloody yawn on

Anon!: There is none of my uncle’s marks upon you.
Goodbye!: There’s no sign of my uncle’s calling you.

Anon!: Seafaring men, sir.
Goodbye!: Seafaring men, sir.

Anon!: I pray you, sir, hold your hand.
Goodbye!: Please, sir, hold your hand.

Anon!: Let me stay the growth of his beard, if thou delay me not the knowledge of his chin.
Goodbye!: Let me keep the growth of his beard if you don’t delay me to know his chin.

Anon!: A most scurvy monster.
Goodbye!: A very scurvy monster.

Anon!: Well, your imprisonment shall not be long.
Goodbye!: Well, you’ll be sentenced for not long.

Anon!: Boy!
Goodbye!: Boy!

Anon!: Prithee, see there!
Goodbye!: Please, see there!

Anon!: What, to perverseness?
Goodbye!: What, to perverseness?

Anon!: My husband!
Goodbye!: My husband!

Anon!: Let them affright thee.
Goodbye!: Let them scolde you.

Anon!: God’s arm strike with us!
Goodbye!: God’s arm strikes with us!

Anon!: I sent for thee upon a sad occasion.
Goodbye!: I sent for you on a sad occasion.

Anon!: For the most part, too, they are foolish that are so.
Goodbye!: The majority of them are foolish.

Anon!: Sirrah, your father’s dead.
Goodbye!: Sirrah, your father’s dead.

Anon!: I do entreat your grace to pardon me.
Goodbye!: I’m asking you to pardon me.

Anon!: You wrong me, Signior Gremio.
Goodbye!: You wrong me, Signior Gremio.

Anon!: What is ’t you seek?
Goodbye!: What do you want?

Anon!: From this time forth I never will speak word.
Goodbye!: From now on I’ll never speak to you.

Anon!: And she’s fair I love.
Goodbye!: And she’s fair, I love her.

Anon!: Speak, hands, for me!
Goodbye!: Speak, hands, for me!

Anon!: Can you not stay awhile?
Goodbye!: Can’t you stay for a while?

Anon!: The same.
Goodbye!: That’s the same.

Anon!: For if such actions may have passage free, Bond-slaves and pagans shall our statesmen be.
Goodbye!: If such actions are free, our statemen will be slaves and pagans.

Anon!: Do not deny to him that you love me.
Goodbye!: Don’t deny to him that you love me.

Anon!: Yea, my good lord.
Goodbye!: Yes, my good lord.

Anon!: Yet bend not all the harm upon yourself.
Goodbye!: But don’t bend all the harm on yourself.

Anon!: You are a merry man, sir.
Goodbye!: You’re a merry man, sir.

Anon!: Cold, cold, my girl, Even like thy chastity.
Goodbye!: Cold, cold, my girl, even like your chastity.

Anon!: Do not answer me.
Goodbye!: Don’t answer me.

Anon!: Talk no more.
Goodbye!: Don’t talk about it.

Anon!: Draw thy tool!
Goodbye!: Draw your tool!

Anon!: We shall chide downright, if I longer stay.
Goodbye!: We’ll scold you for letting me stay.

Anon!: I will reward thee Once for thy sprightly comfort and tenfold For thy good valor.
Goodbye!: I’ll reward you once for your sprightly comfort and tenfold for your good valor.

Anon!: Where’s the Master?
Goodbye!: Where’s the Master?

Anon!: It is concluded.
Goodbye!: It’s been concluded.

Anon!: By my hand I swear, and my father’s soul, the work ish ill done.
Goodbye!: I swear by my hand, and my father’s soul, that the work is ill done.

Anon!: Do thy office.
Goodbye!: Do your job.

Anon!: Thou art a lady.
Goodbye!: You’re a lady.

Anon!: Young men’s love then lies Not truly in their hearts, but in their eyes.
Goodbye!: Then young men’s love isn’t true in their hearts, but in their eyes.

Anon!: She In th’ habiliments of the goddess Isis That day appeared, and oft before gave audience, As ’tis reported, so.
Goodbye!: She appeared in the habiliments of the goddess Isis that day, and then gave the audience, as it’s reported.

Anon!: And in good time here the lieutenant comes.— Master Lieutenant, pray you, by your leave, How doth the prince and my young son of York?
Goodbye!: And in good time, the lieutenant comes.—Meister Lieutenant, please, by your permission, how are the prince and my young son of York?

Anon!: From forth the fatal loins of these two foes A pair of star-crossed lovers take their life, Whose misadventured piteous overthrows Doth with their death bury their parents' strife.
Goodbye!: Then a pair of star-crossed lovers take their lives from the fare of these two foes.

Anon!: Stand, ho!
Goodbye!: Stand up!

Anon!: For this present, I would not, so with love I might entreat you, Be any further moved.
Goodbye!: For now, I wouldn’t be moved any further, so I could be with you.

Anon!: Your daughter spent in Genoa, as I heard, in one night fourscore ducats.
Goodbye!: Your daughter spent one night in Genoa, as I heard, in fourscore ducats.

Anon!: Soft!
Goodbye!: Get out of here!

Anon!: For us, you know Whose he is we are, and that is Caesar’s.
Goodbye!: For us, you know who he is, and that’s Caesar’s.

Anon!: How shall we then behold their natural tears?
Goodbye!: How can we see their natural tears?

Anon!: We defy augury.
Goodbye!: We’re not afraid of augury.

Anon!: Brief, I recovered him, bound up his wound, And after some small space, being strong at heart,
Goodbye!: I recovered him, bound up his wound, and after some small space, being strong at heart,

Anon!: Not a jot, not a jot.
Goodbye!: Not a joke, not a joke.

Anon!: So long?
Goodbye!: So long?

Anon!: Were ’t twenty of the greatest tributaries That do acknowledge Caesar, should I find them So saucy with the hand of she here—what’s her name Since she was Cleopatra?
Goodbye!: If there were twenty of the greatest tributaries who acknowledge Caesar, would I find them so sour with the hand of her here—what’s her name since she was Cleopatra?

Anon!: How came she by that light?
Goodbye!: How did she get that light?

Anon!: He prays you to save his life.
Goodbye!: He asks you to save his life.

Anon!: Stand, you neat slave, strike!
Goodbye!: Stand up, you neat slave, strike!

Anon!: Who?
Goodbye!: Who?

Anon!: Banquo and Macbeth, all hail!
Goodbye!: Banquo and Macbeth, all hail!

Anon!: Where is Montjoy the herald?
Goodbye!: Where is Montjoy the herald?

Anon!: Now let thy friendly hand Put strength enough to ’t.
Goodbye!: Now let your friendly hand put strength enough to do it.

Anon!: Drown cats and blind puppies!
Goodbye!: Drowning cats and blind puppies!

Anon!: Trail’st thou the puissant pike?
Goodbye!: Are you the powerful pike?

Anon!: She is protectress of her honor too.
Goodbye!: She’s a protector of her honor, too.

Anon!: Madam.
Goodbye!: Madam.

Anon!: The world affords no law to make thee rich.
Goodbye!: The world doesn’t have any law to make you rich.

Anon!: Ay, marry, go, I say, and fetch him hither.— Now, afore God, this reverend holy friar!
Goodbye!: Yes, go, I say, and get him here.—Now, God, this reverend holy friar!

Anon!: Were you made the messenger?
Goodbye!: Did you make the messenger?

Anon!: Lend thine ear.
Goodbye!: Let’s hear your ear.

Anon!: And Trinculo is reeling ripe.
Goodbye!: Trinculo is reeling ripe.

Anon!: I doubt not of his temperance.
Goodbye!: I don’t doubt his temper.

Anon!: But if it were, doubt not her care should be To comb your noddle with a three-legged stool And paint your face and use you like a fool.
Goodbye!: But if it were, she wouldn’t care if she combped your noddle with a three-legged stool and painted your face and used you like a fool.

Anon!: So frowned he once when, in an angry parle, He smote the sledded Polacks on the ice.
Goodbye!: He smashed the sledded Polacks on the ice once.

Anon!: No, no.
Goodbye!: No, no.

Anon!: Go, go, dispatch.
Goodbye!: Go, go, dispatch.

Anon!: Lechery!
Goodbye!: Lechery!

Anon!: I cannot hope Caesar and Antony shall well greet together.
Goodbye!: I can’t hope Caesar and Antony will greet together.
