Anon!: A gallant curtal-axe upon my thigh, A boar-spear in my hand, and in my heart Lie there what hidden woman’s fear there will, We’ll have a swashing and a martial outside— As many other mannish cowards have That do outface it with their semblances.
Goodbye!: I’ll have a swashing and a martial outside— As many other mannish cowards have, they’re swashing it with their semblances.

Anon!: They smile at me that shortly shall be dead.
Goodbye!: They smile at me, who will be dead soon.

Anon!: All this”?
Goodbye!: All this”?

Anon!: Sir, being his knave, I will.
Goodbye!: Sir, I will, being his king.

Anon!: Shall I be married then tomorrow morning?
Goodbye!: Should I be married tomorrow morning?

Anon!: I will, my lord.
Goodbye!: I will, my lord.

Anon!: Most absolute lord, My mistress Cleopatra sent me to thee.
Goodbye!: My absolute lord, my mistress Cleopatra sent me to you.

Anon!: Tis certain so, the Prince woos for himself.
Goodbye!: It’s certain that the Prince is wooing for himself.

Anon!: She’s the worse for all this.
Goodbye!: She’s the worse for all this.

Anon!: This dream is all amiss interpreted.
Goodbye!: This dream is all wrong.

Anon!: The town will rise.
Goodbye!: The town will rise.

Anon!: If I quench thee, thou flaming minister, I can again thy former light restore Should I repent me.
Goodbye!: If I stop you, you flaming minister, I can restore your old light again if I repent.

Anon!: If I were bound to divine of this unity, I would not prophesy so.
Goodbye!: If I were to be a divine servant of this unity, I wouldn’t say that.

Anon!: As sweet repose and rest Come to thy heart as that within my breast.
Goodbye!: You’ll feel as calm and restful as I am in my breast.

Anon!: No, not an oath.
Goodbye!: No, not an oath.

Anon!: A stone-cutter or painter could not have made him so ill though they had been but two years o' th' trade.
Goodbye!: A stone-cutter or painter could not have made him so sick as they were only two years old.

Anon!: The west yet glimmers with some streaks of day.
Goodbye!: The west still glimmes with some streaks of day.

Anon!: Faith, I know not what to say.
Goodbye!: I don’t know what to say.

Anon!: Therefore give out you are of Epidamnum, Lest that your goods too soon be confiscate.
Goodbye!: So give out your belongings to Epidamnum, so you don’t have to confiscate your goods too soon.

Anon!: Ha?
Goodbye!: Ha?

Anon!: It is too heavy for your Grace to wear.
Goodbye!: It’s too heavy for your Grace to wear it.

Anon!: I tell you, ’tis incredible to believe How much she loves me.
Goodbye!: I tell you, it’s incredible to believe how much she loves me.

Anon!: O Romeo, Romeo, brave Mercutio is dead!
Goodbye!: Oh, Romeo, Romeo, brave Mercutio is dead!

Anon!: Money by me!
Goodbye!: I’m giving you money!

Anon!: I’ll then nor give nor hazard aught for lead.
Goodbye!: I won’t give or risk anything for lead.

Anon!: Authority.
Goodbye!: Authority.

Anon!: Make you a wholesome answer.
Goodbye!: Make you a good answer.

Anon!: Is it the fashion that discarded fathers Should have thus little mercy on their flesh?
Goodbye!: Is it the way fathers should have so little mercy on their flesh?

Anon!: Where be thy tenants and thy followers?
Goodbye!: Where are your tenants and your followers?

Anon!: Now, by my maidenhead at twelve year old I bade her come.
Goodbye!: Now, by my mother at twelve, I told her to come.

Anon!: They were villains, murderers.
Goodbye!: They were villains, murderers.

Anon!: Still so cruel?
Goodbye!: Are you still so cruel?

Anon!: I will here shroud till the dregs of the storm be past.
Goodbye!: I’ll go here until the storm passes.

Anon!: Away!
Goodbye!: Go away!

Anon!: Madam, I am here.
Goodbye!: Madam, I’m here.

Anon!: Help, ho!
Goodbye!: Help!

Anon!: His life I gave him and did thereto add My love, without retention or restraint, All his in dedication.
Goodbye!: I gave him his life and did it to add my love, without restraint or resentment, to his dedication.

Anon!: I “an itching palm”!
Goodbye!: I’m “an itching palm”!

Anon!: About it, and write “happy” when thou’st done.
Goodbye!: Read it, and write “happy” when you’re done.

Anon!: I saw them not.
Goodbye!: I didn’t see them.

Anon!: Where’s my knave, my fool?—Go you, and call my fool hither.
Goodbye!: Where’s my knave, my fool?—Go and call my fool here.

Anon!: Art thou indeed?
Goodbye!: Are you really?

Anon!: Anything.
Goodbye!: Anything.

Anon!: If there be any impediment, I pray you discover it.
Goodbye!: If there’s any obstacle, please find out.

Anon!: I’ll not budge an inch, boy.
Goodbye!: I won’t budge an inch, boy.

Anon!: The madly used Malvolio.”  Did he write this?
Goodbye!: The madly used Malvolio.” Did he write this?

Anon!: And for I know she taketh most delight In music, instruments, and poetry, Schoolmasters will I keep within my house, Fit to instruct her youth.
Goodbye!: And because I know she enjoys music, music, and poetry, I’ll keep my house full of schoolmasters who will teach her youth.

Anon!: Well, peace be with you.
Goodbye!: Well, let’s go.

Anon!: Look in my face.
Goodbye!: Look in my face.

Anon!: Speak.
Goodbye!: Speak.

Anon!: Art thou a churchman?
Goodbye!: Are you a churchman?

Anon!: Then to have seen much and to have nothing is to have rich eyes and poor hands.
Goodbye!: Then to have seen much and to have nothing is to have rich eyes and poor hands.

Anon!: Madam, madam— Antonio’s dead!
Goodbye!: Madam, madam— Antonio’s dead!

Anon!: O piteous spectacle!
Goodbye!: Oh, what a terrible spectacle!

Anon!: He may command me as my sovereign, But you have power in me as in a kinsman.
Goodbye!: He may command me as my sovereign, but you have power in me as a kinsman.

Anon!: Make me to see ’t, or at the least so prove it That the probation bear no hinge nor loop To hang a doubt on, or woe upon thy life!
Goodbye!: Make me see it, or at least prove it so that the probation doesn’t have any sleeve or loop to hang a doubt on your life or to be angry!

Anon!: Your fortunes are alike.
Goodbye!: Your fortunes are alike.

Anon!: We first address towards you, who with this king Hath rivaled for our daughter.
Goodbye!: We’ll first speak to you, who, with this king, rivaled for our daughter.

Anon!: But here’s a villain that would face me down He met me on the mart, and that I beat him And charged him with a thousand marks in gold, And that I did deny my wife and house.— Thou drunkard, thou, what didst thou mean by this?
Goodbye!: But here’s a villain who would face me down, he met me on the martin, and I beat him and charged him with a thousand marks in gold, and I denied my wife and house.—You drunk

Anon!: Mercutio’s kinsman, noble County Paris.
Goodbye!: Mercutio’s heir, noble Count Paris.

Anon!: Oh, I have heard him speak of that same brother, And he did render him the most unnatural That lived amongst men.
Goodbye!: Oh, I’ve heard him speak of that brother, and he made him the most unnatural man who lived among men.

Anon!: My dearest cousin and my dearer lord?
Goodbye!: My dearest cousin and my dearer lord?

Anon!: Let them begin.
Goodbye!: Let them start.

Anon!: Make her amends, she weeps.
Goodbye!: She weeps.

Anon!: So is the bargain.
Goodbye!: That’s the deal.

Anon!: But all the story of the night told over, And all their minds transfigured so together, More witnesseth than fancy’s images And grows to something of great constancy, But, howsoever, strange and admirable.
Goodbye!: But all the stories of the night were told and all their minds were rearranged together, more vivid than fancy’s images, and more vividly, but, whatever it is, strange and admirable.

Anon!: Thou told’st me they were stol'n unto this wood.
Goodbye!: You told me they were stolping into this wood.

Anon!: Tis dangerous when the baser nature comes Between the pass and fell incensèd points Of mighty opposites.
Goodbye!: It’s dangerous when the mighty opposites are surrounded by a sand.

Anon!: I have professed me thy friend, and I confess me knit to thy deserving with cables of perdurable toughness.
Goodbye!: I’ve told you to be your friend, and I confess I’m a man who’s a man who’s a man of a saneness.

Anon!: Is he gone and hath nothing?
Goodbye!: Is he gone and has nothing to do with?

Anon!: Well, well.
Goodbye!: Well, well.

Anon!: Have an eye to Cinna.
Goodbye!: Have a look at Cinna.

Anon!: Stay here.
Goodbye!: Stay here.

Anon!: Troth, sir, I can yield you none without words, and words are grown so false, I am loath to prove reason with them.
Goodbye!: I can’t give you any without words, and words are so false that I’m loath to prove that I’m not able to do anything wrong with them.

Anon!: I’m out of patience.
Goodbye!: I’m out of patience.

Anon!: I go to take my stand To see him pass on to the Capitol.
Goodbye!: I’ll stand to see him pass on to the Capitol.

Anon!: But one cup.
Goodbye!: Only one cup.

Anon!: Be happy.
Goodbye!: Be happy.

Anon!: We’ll have thee, as our rarer monsters are, Painted on a pole, and underwrit, “Here may you see the tyrant.”      I will not yield, To kiss the ground before young Malcolm’s feet, And to be baited with the rabble’s curse.
Goodbye!: We’ll have you, as our rarer monsters are, sprayed on a pole and underwrit, “Here may you see the tyrant.” I won’t give up, to kiss the

Anon!: Calphurnia here, my wife, stays me at home.
Goodbye!: Calphurnia here, my wife, stays at home.

Anon!: Nay, as they dare.
Goodbye!: No, they dare.

Anon!: Hark!
Goodbye!: Listen!

Anon!: His name, my lord, is Tyrrel.
Goodbye!: His name is Tyrrel, my lord.

Anon!: I am sorry that I am deceived in him.
Goodbye!: I’m sorry I’ve been fooled by him.

Anon!: What is the reason of this terrible summons?
Goodbye!: What’s the reason for this terrible summons?

Anon!: Taste your legs, sir.
Goodbye!: Taste your legs, sir.

Anon!: It droppeth as the gentle rain from heaven Upon the place beneath.
Goodbye!: It drops as gentle as the rain from heaven on the ground.

Anon!: Now a little fire in a wild field were like an old lecher’s heart—a small spark, all the rest on ’s body cold.
Goodbye!: Now a little fire in a wild field would look like an old lecher’s heart—a small spark, all the rest of the body cold.

Anon!: Now all labor Mars what it does.
Goodbye!: Now all the work is going on.

Anon!: The people knows it, and have now received His accusations.
Goodbye!: The people know it, and now he’s been accused.

Anon!: My duty to you both, on equal love, Great kings of France and England.
Goodbye!: I’m going to both of you, the great kings of France and England.

Anon!: He speaks not true.
Goodbye!: He’s not saying anything.

Anon!: Ay, and brought off the field.
Goodbye!: Yes, and he’s been brought off the field.

Anon!: I say, O Caesar, Antony is dead.
Goodbye!: Oh, Caesar, Antony is dead.

Anon!: Honest Iago Hath ta'en order for ’t.
Goodbye!: Honest Iago has ordered it.

Anon!: By the mess, ere theise eyes of mine take themselves to slomber, ay’ll de gud service, or I’ll lig i' th' grund for it, ay, or go to death.
Goodbye!: By the mess, my eyes are smuggling, and I’ll de-gud service, or I’ll smuggling the smuggling, or go to death.

Anon!: Upon condition Publius shall not live, Who is your sister’s son, Mark Antony.
Goodbye!: Upon condition that Publius will not live, who is your sister’s son, Mark Antony.

Anon!: I chose her when I could not ask my father For his advice, nor thought I had one.
Goodbye!: I chose her when I couldn’t ask my father for his advice, and I didn’t think I had one.

Anon!: Tis a wild night.
Goodbye!: It’s a wild night.

Anon!: Lay her a-hold, a-hold!
Goodbye!: Hold her on her, hold her on!

Anon!: Welcome.
Goodbye!: Welcome.

Anon!: I have a head, sir, that will find out logs, And never trouble Peter for the matter.
Goodbye!: I have a head that will find logs, and I’ll never bother Peter for the matter.

Anon!: Have I thought long to see this morning’s face, And doth it give me such a sight as this?
Goodbye!: Have I thought I’d be watching this morning for a long time, and does it give me such a sight as this?

Anon!: But I am sent to find those persons whose names are here writ, and can never find what names the writing person hath here writ.
Goodbye!: But I’m sent to find those people who have written this letter, and I can’t find what the author has written.

Anon!: Your overkindness doth wring tears from me.
Goodbye!: Your overkindness wringes tears from me.

Anon!: Drunk?
Goodbye!: Drunk?

Anon!: Your cousin, my lady, takes great exceptions to your ill hours.
Goodbye!: Your cousin, my lady, makes great exceptions to your poor hours.

Anon!: A man may see how this world goes with no eyes.
Goodbye!: A man can see how this world goes without any eyes.

Anon!: I’ll not to bed tonight.
Goodbye!: I won’t go to bed tonight.

Anon!: But, good Laertes, Will you do this, keep close within your chamber.
Goodbye!: But, good Laertes, you’ll do this, keep close to your room.

Anon!: With all my heart, good youth.
Goodbye!: With all my heart, good young man.

Anon!: We’ll revenge his death.
Goodbye!: We’ll revenge his death.

Anon!: Is Romeo slaughtered, and is Tybalt dead?
Goodbye!: Is Romeo killed, and Tybalt dead?

Anon!: I am satisfied.
Goodbye!: I’m satisfied.

Anon!: And here stands all your state: Either be gone before the watch be set, Or by the break of day disguised from hence.
Goodbye!: And here’s all your state: either go away before the watch is set, or hide from the sun.

Anon!: I shall answer that better to the commonwealth than you can the getting up of the Negro’s belly.
Goodbye!: I’ll answer that question to the commonwealth better than you can get up the Negro’s belly.

Anon!: He were a brave monster indeed, if they were set in his tail.
Goodbye!: He would be a brave monster if they were set in his tail.

Anon!: Farewell, fair cruelty.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, fair cruelty.

Anon!: He smiled and said “The better for our purpose.” He was in the right, and so indeed it is.
Goodbye!: He smiled and said, “The better for our purpose.” He was in the right place, and so is it.

Anon!: When I like your favor, for God defend the lute should be like the case!
Goodbye!: When I like your favor, because God defend the lute should be like the case!

Anon!: Would I could answer This comfort with the like.
Goodbye!: I wish I could answer this comfort with the like.

Anon!: Away, away, be gone.
Goodbye!: Go away, go away.

Anon!: I’ll leave thee Now like a man of steel.
Goodbye!: I’ll leave you now like a man of steel.

Anon!: Give me thy hand.
Goodbye!: Give me your hand.

Anon!: Ha, ha, ha!
Goodbye!: Ha, ha, ha!

Anon!: Sweet Prince, why speak not you?
Goodbye!: Sweet Prince, why don’t you say something?

Anon!: Of love?
Goodbye!: Of love?

Anon!: Dost thou love me?
Goodbye!: Do you love me?

Anon!: Get thee to a nunnery.
Goodbye!: Get to a nunnery.

Anon!: Full oft ’tis seen, Our means secure us and our mere defects Prove our commodities.
Goodbye!: We’ve got everything to do, and our simple defects are proof of our goods.

Anon!: Your features, Lord warrant us!
Goodbye!: Your features, Lord, warrant us!

Anon!: Dead, dead?
Goodbye!: Dead, dead?

Anon!: Filths savor but themselves.
Goodbye!: Filths only savor themselves.

Anon!: And begged he pardon?
Goodbye!: And asked him to pardon?

Anon!: Dolabella!
Goodbye!: Dolabella!

Anon!: For Falstaff, he is dead, and we must earn therefore.
Goodbye!: Falstaff, he’s dead, and we have to earn it.

Anon!: O, serve me well, and teach yourselves that duty!
Goodbye!: Oh, please, serve me well, and teach yourself that duty!

Anon!: I will not hear thee speak.
Goodbye!: I won’t hear you speak.

Anon!: Iago keeps his word.
Goodbye!: Iago keeps his word.

Anon!: Shall I strike at it with my partisan?
Goodbye!: Should I strike at it with my partisan?

Anon!: Ay, if I know the letters and the language.
Goodbye!: Yes, if I know the letters and the language.

Anon!: Nor know I aught But that he’s well and will be shortly here.
Goodbye!: I don’t know that he’s well and will be here soon.

Anon!: Farewell.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: I will not come.
Goodbye!: I won’t come.

Anon!: I dare make his answer, none.
Goodbye!: I dare tell him, no.

Anon!: Come, gentlemen, let’s go.
Goodbye!: Come on, gentlemen, let’s go.

Anon!: Marry, sir, by a rule as plain as the plain bald pate of Father Time himself.
Goodbye!: Sir, you’re a rule as plain as the plain bald pate of Father Time himself.

Anon!: But she is now the wife of Marcus Antonius.
Goodbye!: But she’s now Marcus Antonius’s wife.

Anon!: I pray thee, let us go and find him out And quicken his embracèd heaviness With some delight or other.
Goodbye!: Please, let’s go find him and quicken his heaviness with some or all of his delight.

Anon!: My sister may receive it much more worse To have her gentleman abused, assaulted For following her affairs.—Put in his legs.
Goodbye!: My sister might get it much worse to have her gentleman abused and assaulted for following her affairs.—Put in his legs.

Anon!: I loved him, friend— No father his son dearer.
Goodbye!: I loved him, friend— No father his son is dearer.

Anon!: Thither I must, although against my will, For servants must their masters' minds fulfill.
Goodbye!: I must, even if I do, because servants must be satisfied with their masters' minds.

Anon!: One word, sir.
Goodbye!: One word, sir.

Anon!: By heaven, I’ll have ’t.
Goodbye!: I’ll have it.

Anon!: Lo, yonder, and Titinius mourning it.
Goodbye!: Lo, you’re dead, and Titinius mourning it.

Anon!: Twenty crowns.
Goodbye!: Twenty crowns.

Anon!: If only to go warm were gorgeous, Why, nature needs not what thou gorgeous wear’st, Which scarcely keeps thee warm.
Goodbye!: If only to go warm were beautiful, then nature doesn’t need what you’re wearing, which isn’t enough to keep you warm.

Anon!: Tut, there’s life in ’t, man.
Goodbye!: You’re a man.

Anon!: Thou knowest that the fashion of a doublet, or a hat, or a cloak, is nothing to a man.
Goodbye!: You know that a man can’t wear a doublet, a hat, or a cloak.

Anon!: Dolor comes to him, indeed.
Goodbye!: Dolor comes to him, indeed.

Anon!: Such was the very armour he had on When he the ambitious Norway combated.
Goodbye!: That was the armour he had on his side when he was fighting the ambitious Norway.

Anon!: The man i' th' moon!
Goodbye!: The man in the moon!

Anon!: Who calls so loud?
Goodbye!: Who’s calling so loud?

Anon!: Adieu.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: Thou wast the prettiest babe that e'er I nursed.
Goodbye!: You were the prettiest baby I ever nursed.

Anon!: Tomorrow We’ll hear ourselves again.
Goodbye!: Tomorrow we’ll hear ourselves again.

Anon!: Pindarus, Bid our commanders lead their charges off A little from this ground.
Goodbye!: Pindarus, ask our commanders to lead their charges a little off this ground.

Anon!: Thou’st spoken right.
Goodbye!: You’ve spoken right.

Anon!: Hold, take these keys, and fetch more spices, Nurse.
Goodbye!: Hold, take these keys and get more spices, Nurse.

Anon!: Then I will kiss your lips, Kate.
Goodbye!: Then I’ll kiss your lips, Kate.

Anon!: Let us go.
Goodbye!: Let’s go.

Anon!: Come, I’ll dispose of thee Among a sisterhood of holy nuns.
Goodbye!: Come on, I’ll leave you with a sisterhood of holy nuns.

Anon!: Take it, brave York.
Goodbye!: Take it, brave York.

Anon!: I am not well in health, and that is all.
Goodbye!: I’m not well in health, and that’s all.

Anon!: Nay, good goose, bite not.
Goodbye!: No, good goose, don’t bite me.

Anon!: His knights grow riotous, and himself upbraids us On every trifle.
Goodbye!: His knights are rioting, and he’s upbraiding us on every corner.

Anon!: To be Count Malvolio!
Goodbye!: To be Count Malvolio!

Anon!: A deed without a name.
Goodbye!: A deed without a name.

Anon!: I pray you, sir, take patience.
Goodbye!: Please, sir, take patience.

Anon!: Think you of a worse title, and I will fit her to it.
Goodbye!: Think about a worse title, and I’ll fit her to it.

Anon!: Go, fetch me something: I’ll break ope the gate.
Goodbye!: Go get me something: I’ll break the gate.

Anon!: I speak but as I find.
Goodbye!: I’m only speaking as I find out.

Anon!: Rebellious dead, rise never till the wood Of Birnam rise, and our high-placed Macbeth Shall live the lease of nature, pay his breath To time and mortal custom.
Goodbye!: Rebellious dead, never rise until the woods of Birnam rise, and our high-placed Macbeth will live the life of nature, pay his breath to time and mortal custom.

Anon!: Good Romeo, hide thyself.
Goodbye!: Good Romeo, hide yourself.

Anon!: Strike!
Goodbye!: Strike!

Anon!: Well, thou hast comforted me marvelous much.
Goodbye!: Well, you have made me feel so wonderful.

Anon!: A sight most pitiful in the meanest wretch, Past speaking of in a king.
Goodbye!: It’s a terrible sight to see in a king’s eyes.

Anon!: Will you grant with me That Ferdinand is drowned?
Goodbye!: Will you grant me that Ferdinand was drowned?

Anon!: Would none but I might venge my cousin’s death!
Goodbye!: I wish I could venge my cousin’s death.

Anon!: Cicero one?
Goodbye!: Cicero one?

Anon!: I do,  This touches me in reputation.
Goodbye!: I do, this is a good thing for me.

Anon!: Thy face is mine, and thou hast slandered it.
Goodbye!: Your face is mine, and you’ve slapped it.

Anon!: Fool!
Goodbye!: Fool!

Anon!: What unaccustomed cause procures her hither?
Goodbye!: What unaccustomed reason did she get here?

Anon!: Get thee a wife, get thee a wife.
Goodbye!: Get a wife, get a wife.

Anon!: Why, so didst thou.
Goodbye!: Why, so did you.

Anon!: O God!—O Nurse, how shall this be prevented?
Goodbye!: Oh God!—Oh Nurse, how can this be prevented?

Anon!: His ceremonies laid by, in his nakedness he appears but a man, and though his affections are higher mounted than ours, yet when they stoop, they stoop with the like wing.
Goodbye!: He’s not a man, and even though his affections are higher than ours, when they stoop, they stoop with the same wing.

Anon!: Arise, and say how thou camest here.
Goodbye!: Get up and tell me how you came here.

Anon!: Why, thy godhead laid apart, Warr’st thou with a woman’s heart?
Goodbye!: Why, your godhead laid apart, are you a woman?

Anon!: I cannot make you what amends I would; Therefore accept such kindness as I can.
Goodbye!: I can’t make you what I want.

Anon!: We learn no other but the confident tyrant Keeps still in Dunsinane and will endure Our setting down before ’t.
Goodbye!: We’ll be able to learn from the confident tyrant who’s still in Dunsinane and will endure our battle before it.

Anon!: You lie.
Goodbye!: You lie.

Anon!: Thank you.
Goodbye!: Thank you.

Anon!: Search, seek, and know how this foul murder comes.
Goodbye!: Search, search, and know how this horrible murder comes about.

Anon!: What are you?
Goodbye!: Who are you?

Anon!: How then, sick?
Goodbye!: What then, sick?

Anon!: I pray you, remember the porter.
Goodbye!: Please, remember the porter.

Anon!: But the great one that goes up the hill, let him draw thee after.
Goodbye!: But the great man who goes up the hill, let him draw you after you.

Anon!: Armed, say you?
Goodbye!: Armed, do you say?

Anon!: To tell you where he lodges is to tell you where I lie.
Goodbye!: Telling you where he’s lodged is telling you where I’m lying.

Anon!: Come, come.
Goodbye!: Come on, come on.

Anon!: Tis much.—Servants, leave me and her alone.
Goodbye!: It’s much.—Servants, leave me and her alone.

Anon!: That you do love me, I am nothing jealous.
Goodbye!: I’m not jealous of you.

Anon!: What is he at the gate, cousin?
Goodbye!: What’s he at the gate, cousin?

Anon!: A man no mightier than thyself or me In personal action, yet prodigious grown, And fearful as these strange eruptions are.
Goodbye!: A man no more powerful than you or me, but he’s grown as a man, and as fearful as these strange eruptions are.

Anon!: Unless the master were the man.
Goodbye!: Unless the master were the man.

Anon!: Thou wilt quarrel with a man for cracking nuts, having no other reason but because thou hast hazel eyes.
Goodbye!: You’ll fight with a man for cracking nuts, just because you have hazelnut eyes.

Anon!: Ah, thou spell!
Goodbye!: Ah, you spell!

Anon!: Thus have you heard me severed from my bliss; That by misfortunes was my life prolonged To tell sad stories of my own mishaps.
Goodbye!: So you’ve heard me smothered from my bliss.

Anon!: Look who comes here.
Goodbye!: Look who’s coming here.

Anon!: Now fear I this will give it start again.
Goodbye!: Now I’m afraid I’ll start again.

Anon!: You jig and amble, and you lisp, you nickname God’s creatures and make your wantonness your ignorance.
Goodbye!: You jig and amble, and you lisp, you nickname God’s creatures and make your ignorance a bad thing.

Anon!: Amen, if you love her, for the lady is very well worthy.
Goodbye!: Amen, if you love her, because the lady is very worthy of her.

Anon!: I have a ship Laden with gold.
Goodbye!: I have a ship Laden with gold.

Anon!: You speak not as you think.
Goodbye!: You don’t speak as you think.

Anon!: I know thy constellation is right apt For this affair.
Goodbye!: I know your constellation is right for this matter.

Anon!: This is the fruits of whoring.
Goodbye!: This is the fruit of whoring.

Anon!: Is it possible?
Goodbye!: Is it possible?

Anon!: Even or odd, of all days in the year, Come Lammas Eve at night shall she be fourteen.
Goodbye!: Even or oddly, of all days in the year, Come Lammas Eve at night she’ll be fourteen.

Anon!: Pleasure and action make the hours seem short.
Goodbye!: The time is short.

Anon!: O God!
Goodbye!: Oh God!

Anon!: Will he tell us what this show meant?
Goodbye!: Will he tell us what this show meant?

Anon!: And yet, by the very fangs of malice I swear, I am not that I play.
Goodbye!: And yet I swear by the screams of malice, I’m not that I’m playing.

Anon!: Thieves!
Goodbye!: Thieves!

Anon!: When comes such another?
Goodbye!: When’s that another?

Anon!: Made she no verbal question?
Goodbye!: Didn’t she ask any questions?

Anon!: No more, I pray thee.
Goodbye!: Don’t wait, please.

Anon!: The son of Clarence have I pent up close, His daughter meanly have I matched in marriage, The sons of Edward sleep in Abraham’s bosom, And Anne my wife hath bid this world goodnight.
Goodbye!: I’ve been a close friend of Clarence’s son, his daughter has been a sex lover, the sons of Edward sleep in Abraham’s robe, and Anne, my wife, has promised this world

Anon!: They, for their truth, might better wear their heads Than some that have accused them wear their hats.
Goodbye!: They might better wear their heads than some people who have accused them of wearing their hats.

Anon!: I’ll do ’t, but it dislikes me.
Goodbye!: I’ll do it, but it doesn’t like me.

Anon!: Thou art a fellow of a good respect.
Goodbye!: You’re a good man.

Anon!: Till then, think of the world.
Goodbye!: Now, think about the world.

Anon!: Thy eyes are almost set in thy head.
Goodbye!: Your eyes are almost set in your head.

Anon!: What profane wretch art thou?
Goodbye!: What kind of wretch are you?

Anon!: Tybalt would kill thee, But thou slew’st Tybalt—there art thou happy.
Goodbye!: Tybalt would kill you, but you slew Tybalt—there are you happy.

Anon!: Have by some surgeon, Shylock, on your charge, To stop his wounds lest he do bleed to death.
Goodbye!: You can have some surgeon, Shylock, on your charge to stop his wounds so he can’t bleed to death.

Anon!: Ask for me tomorrow, and you shall find me a grave man.
Goodbye!: Ask for me tomorrow, and you’ll find me in a grave.

Anon!: Your castle is surprised, your wife and babes Savagely slaughtered.
Goodbye!: Your castle is surprised, your wife and babes were slaughtered in a savage manner.

Anon!: A very honest-hearted fellow, and as poor as the king.
Goodbye!: A very honest, and as poor as the king.

Anon!: This will prove a brave kingdom to me, where I shall have my music for nothing.
Goodbye!: This will be a brave kingdom for me, where I’ll have my music for nothing.

Anon!: God defend me from these two!
Goodbye!: God protect me from these two!

Anon!: They stared, and were distracted.
Goodbye!: They stared and were distracted.

Anon!: I have, when you have heard what I can say.
Goodbye!: I have, when you heard what I can say.

Anon!: And then, sir, does he this, he does— What was I about to say?
Goodbye!: And then, sir, does he this, he does— What was I about to say?

Anon!: An I might live to see thee married once, I have my wish.
Goodbye!: If I could live to see you marry once, I have my wish.

Anon!: Yes, bring me word, boy, if thy lord look well, For he went sickly forth.
Goodbye!: Yes, tell me, boy, if your lord looks well, because he went sickly out of here.

Anon!: Look to my chattels and my movables.
Goodbye!: Look at my hats and my furniture.

Anon!: You are idle, shallow things.
Goodbye!: You’re idle, shallow things.

Anon!: Bring him away.
Goodbye!: Bring him away.

Anon!: He was a man.
Goodbye!: He was a man.

Anon!: All hell shall stir for this.
Goodbye!: All hell will stir for this.

Anon!: The “fiery” duke?
Goodbye!: The “fiery” duke?

Anon!: What might import my sister’s letter to him?
Goodbye!: What could I do to send my sister’s letter to him?

Anon!: All this my sister is, or else should be.
Goodbye!: My sister is all this, or else she should be.

Anon!: Where America, the Indies?
Goodbye!: Where are America, the Indies?

Anon!: But not with such familiar instances Nor with such free and friendly conference As he hath used of old.
Goodbye!: But not with such familiar situations as this, or with such free and friendly meetings as he used to.

Anon!: The other did not so.
Goodbye!: The other one did not.

Anon!: He calls to horse, but will I know not whither.
Goodbye!: He’s calling to horse, but I don’t know what to do.

Anon!: I speak not this that you should bear a good opinion of my knowledge, insomuch I say I know you are.
Goodbye!: I don’t say that you should be a good opinion of my knowledge, as long as I say I know you are.

Anon!: But your news is not true.
Goodbye!: But your news is not true.

Anon!: I warrant her rags and the
Goodbye!: I’m sure she’s a rag.

Anon!: Tis very much.
Goodbye!: That’s very much.

Anon!: Natures of such deep trust we shall much need.
Goodbye!: We’ll need to know the truth.

Anon!: I’ll wait upon your Lordship.
Goodbye!: I’ll wait on your Lordship.

Anon!: Nay, and most like.
Goodbye!: No, and I’m very much.

Anon!: Tedious” and “brief”?
Goodbye!: Are you stupid” and “brief”?

Anon!: For he partly begs To be desired to give.
Goodbye!: He begs to be desired to give.

Anon!: Younger than she are happy mothers made.
Goodbye!: Younger than she is, happy mothers.

Anon!: And then the moon, like to a silver bow New bent in heaven, shall behold the night Of our solemnities.
Goodbye!: And then the moon, like a silver bow, will behold the night of our solemnity.

Anon!: This morning, like the spirit of a youth That means to be of note, begins betimes.
Goodbye!: This morning, like a young man who wants to be a good man, begins early.

Anon!: If not, your pardon and my return shall be the end of my business.
Goodbye!: If not, your pardon and my return will be the end of my business.

Anon!: Is she not proud?
Goodbye!: Isn’t she proud?

Anon!: I’ll pheeze you, in faith.
Goodbye!: I’ll pheeze you, in faith.

Anon!: And this cuff was but to knock at your ear and beseech list'ning.
Goodbye!: And this cuff was just to knock at your ear and beg you to see what’s going on.

Anon!: Let me not burst in ignorance, but tell Why thy canonized bones, hearsed in death, Have burst their cerements; why the sepulcher,
Goodbye!: Don’t burst in ignorance, but tell me why your canonized bones, heard in death, have burst in their cerebrations.

Anon!: Before my body I throw my warlike shield.
Goodbye!: I’ll throw my shield before my body is thrown.

Anon!: That “fair” again unsay.
Goodbye!: That “fair” is again unremarkable.

Anon!: He was a bachelor then.
Goodbye!: He was a bachelor then.

Anon!: Wast born i' th' forest here?
Goodbye!: Was it born in the forest here?

Anon!: If ever I live to see it, I will challenge it.
Goodbye!: If I ever live to see it, I’ll challenge it.

Anon!: I stand for judgment.
Goodbye!: I’m standing for judgment.

Anon!: Tis mightiest in the mightiest.
Goodbye!: It’s the best thing to do.

Anon!: But know that I have tonight wooed Margaret, the Lady Hero’s gentlewoman, by the name of Hero.
Goodbye!: But you know that I’ve wooed Margaret, the Lady Hero’s gentlewoman, by the name Hero.

Anon!: Say, how is that?
Goodbye!: What’s that?

Anon!: There’s Dolabella sent from Caesar.
Goodbye!: There’s Dolabella sent from Caesar.

Anon!: Who knows the Lord Protector’s mind herein?
Goodbye!: Who knows the Lord Protector’s mind herein?

Anon!: My countrymen—     Peace, silence!
Goodbye!: My countrymen— Let’s calm down!

Anon!: He’s married.
Goodbye!: He’s married.

Anon!: Go, go, up to the leads.
Goodbye!: Go, go, up to the leads.

Anon!: Mistress, both man and master is possessed.
Goodbye!: Mistress, both man and master are possessed.

Anon!: Knock, sir?
Goodbye!: Knock, sir?

Anon!: Com’st thou again for ransom?
Goodbye!: Do you have to pay for ransom again?

Anon!: God keep your Lordship in that gracious mind.
Goodbye!: God keep your Lordship in that gracious mind.

Anon!: An eagle, madam, Hath not so green, so quick, so fair an eye As Paris hath.
Goodbye!: An eagle, madam, is not as green, as quick, as a man is.

Anon!: Eight wild boars roasted whole at a breakfast—and but twelve persons there!
Goodbye!: Eight wild boars roasted whole at a breakfast—and only twelve people there!

Anon!: O Lord, Lord, it is a hard matter for friends to meet, but mountains may be removed with earthquakes and so encounter.
Goodbye!: Oh Lord, Lord, it’s hard for friends to meet, but mountains can be removed by earthquakes and so encounters.

Anon!: Would I were assured Of my condition.
Goodbye!: I wish I were assured of my condition.

Anon!: Clubs cannot part them.
Goodbye!: Clubs can’t break them.

Anon!: I pant for life.
Goodbye!: I’m waiting for life.

Anon!: For himself to mar,” quoth he?
Goodbye!: For himself to be a savage,” he said.

Anon!: Beat—
Goodbye!: Beat—

Anon!: Another way I have to man my haggard, To make her come and know her keeper’s call.
Goodbye!: Another way I have to man my lord is to make her come and know her keeper’s call.

Anon!: Tis sweating labor To bear such idleness so near the heart As Cleopatra this.
Goodbye!: It’s hard to bear such idleness in the heart as Cleopatra this.

Anon!: We must obey the time.
Goodbye!: We have to obey the time.

Anon!: Let her send it.
Goodbye!: Let her send it.

Anon!: Nay, that’s certain.
Goodbye!: No, that’s true.

Anon!: The British powers are marching hitherward.
Goodbye!: The British forces are marching here.

Anon!: I know you are not ignorant— I would you did, sir.
Goodbye!: I know you’re not ignorant— I wish you did, sir.

Anon!: She should have died hereafter.
Goodbye!: She should have died later.

Anon!: Went he hence now?
Goodbye!: Did he leave now?

Anon!: I will show you such a necessity in his death that you shall think yourself bound to put it on him.
Goodbye!: I’ll show you such a necessity in his death that you’ll think you’re going to put it on him.

Anon!: And friends with Caesar.
Goodbye!: And friends with Caesar.

Anon!: They do me wrong, and I will not endure it!
Goodbye!: They’re doing me wrong, and I won’t endure it!

Anon!: I’ll to England.
Goodbye!: I’ll go to England.

Anon!: When I was with him I have heard him swear To Tubal and to Chus, his countrymen, That he would rather have Antonio’s flesh Than twenty times the value of the sum That he did owe him.
Goodbye!: When I was with him, I heard him swear to Tubal and Chus, his countrymen, that Antonio would rather have his flesh than twenty times the sum he owed him.

Anon!: Ay, sir, I thank God.
Goodbye!: Yes, sir, I thank God.

Anon!: Liberty!
Goodbye!: Liberty!

Anon!: Here is the place, my lord.
Goodbye!: Here’s the place, my lord.

Anon!: I’ll do the service of a younger man In all your business and necessities.
Goodbye!: I’ll do the job of a younger man in all your business and necessities.

Anon!: No, no, forsooth, I dare not for my life.
Goodbye!: No, no, I don’t dare for my life.

Anon!: No, faith, die by attorney.
Goodbye!: No, please, die by a lawyer.

Anon!: Oh, by whom?
Goodbye!: Oh, by whom?

Anon!: What is, my lord?
Goodbye!: What is, my lord?

Anon!: He is not doubted.—A word, Lucillius.
Goodbye!: He’s not doubted.—A word, Lucillius.

Anon!: Tarry, rash wanton.
Goodbye!: Tarry, rash wanton.

Anon!: Ah, that’s a foul fault.
Goodbye!: Ah, that’s a bad fault.

Anon!: What are his words?
Goodbye!: What are his words?

Anon!: Yes, I am.
Goodbye!: Yes, I am.

Anon!: Whip him.
Goodbye!: Whip him.

Anon!: I think oxen and wainropes cannot hale them together.
Goodbye!: I think oxen and wainropes can’t hale them together.

Anon!: What’s he that wishes so?
Goodbye!: Who wants that?

Anon!: Armed, brother?
Goodbye!: Armed, brother?

Anon!: The princess is the better Englishwoman.—I' faith, Kate, my wooing is fit for thy understanding.
Goodbye!: The princess is the better Englishwoman.—I’m sure my wooing is fit for your understanding, Kate.

Anon!: Go, and bring them.
Goodbye!: Go and bring them.

Anon!: But, first or last, Your fine Egyptian cookery shall have The fame.
Goodbye!: But first or last, your fine Egyptian cookery will have the fame.

Anon!: Fare you well, sir.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, sir.

Anon!: Come, you and I will thither presently.
Goodbye!: Come on, you and I will go here now.

Anon!: Oh, he’s a lovely gentleman.
Goodbye!: Oh, he’s a lovely gentleman.

Anon!: It shall be done.
Goodbye!: It will be done.

Anon!: Nothing that I respect, my gracious lord.
Goodbye!: Nothing I respect, my gracious lord.

Anon!: It is a creature That dotes on Cassio, as ’tis the strumpet’s plague To beguile many and be beguiled by one.
Goodbye!: It’s a creature that drew on Cassio, as it’s the plague of the strumpets to beguile many and beguiled by one.

Anon!: And stand indebted, over and above, In love and service to you evermore.
Goodbye!: And be indebted over and above, in love and service to you evermore.

Anon!: You are looked for and called for, asked for and sought for, in the great chamber.
Goodbye!: You’re in the great chamber looking for and called for, asked and sought for.

Anon!: Is there any ships put forth tonight?
Goodbye!: Is there any ships on board tonight?

Anon!: If it were so, it was a grievous fault, And grievously hath Caesar answered it.
Goodbye!: If it were true, it was a grievous fault, and Caesar has answered it.

Anon!: Am I not stayed for, Cinna?
Goodbye!: I’m not staying for, Cinna?

Anon!: Let him not leave out The color of her hair.
Goodbye!: Don’t let him leave out the color of her hair.

Anon!: And so, I pray thee, call Beatrice.
Goodbye!: And so, please, call Beatrice.

Anon!: And yet to win her, all the world to nothing!
Goodbye!: And yet to win her, the whole world has to be destroyed!

Anon!: Hold off thy hand.
Goodbye!: Hold off your hand.

Anon!: Come, I’ll go in with you.
Goodbye!: Come on, I’ll go in with you.

Anon!: My liege.
Goodbye!: My liege.

Anon!: If more thou dost perceive, let me know more.
Goodbye!: If you see more, let me know more.

Anon!: God give us leisure for these rites of love!
Goodbye!: God give us time to celebrate these love rites!

Anon!: I am none of his skains-mates.
Goodbye!: I’m not one of his sains-mates.

Anon!: Hush!
Goodbye!: Hush!

Anon!: Well, think of marriage now.
Goodbye!: Well, think about marriage now.

Anon!: The wiser, the waywarder.
Goodbye!: The wiser the man, the wiser the man.

Anon!: Therefore you must needs play Pyramus.
Goodbye!: So you have to play Pyramus.

Anon!: Now, Iras, what think’st thou?
Goodbye!: Now, Iras, what do you think?

Anon!: And sayst thou yet that exile is not death?
Goodbye!: And you say that exile is not death?

Anon!: My young master doth expect your reproach.
Goodbye!: My young master is expecting your remark.

Anon!: No, that same wicked bastard of Venus that was begot of thought, conceived of spleen, and born of madness, that blind rascally boy that abuses everyone’s eyes because his own are out, let him be judge how deep I am in love.
Goodbye!: No, let me judge how deep I am in love.

Anon!: O, let me think on Hastings and be gone To Brecknock, while my fearful head is on!
Goodbye!: Oh, let me think about Hastings and go to Brecknock while my fearful head is on!

Anon!: Will ’t please your Honor taste of these conserves?
Goodbye!: Will your Honor enjoy these conserved goods?

Anon!: Now quit you well.—             Torches, torches!
Goodbye!: Now you’re dead.—Torches, torches!

Anon!: In faith, my lord, not I.
Goodbye!: I swear, my lord, not me.

Anon!: I hear him.
Goodbye!: I hear him.

Anon!: Soft and fair, Friar.—Which is Beatrice?
Goodbye!: Is it Beatrice?

Anon!: Here is a friar that trembles, sighs and weeps.
Goodbye!: Here’s a friar that trembles, sighs and weeps.

Anon!: That’s a certain text.
Goodbye!: That’s a certain text.

Anon!: Cry the man mercy, love him, take his offer.
Goodbye!: Give the man mercy, love him, and take his offer.

Anon!: Fly, my lord, fly.
Goodbye!: Fly, my lord, fly.

Anon!: Well.— Now come, my Ariel!
Goodbye!: Well, now come, my Ariel!

Anon!: In time we hate that which we often fear.
Goodbye!: We hate things that we often fear.

Anon!: Madam, I come to whet your gentle thoughts On his behalf.
Goodbye!: Madam, I’m coming to ask you to think about his behalf.

Anon!: Caesar!
Goodbye!: Caesar!

Anon!: This speed of Caesar’s Carries beyond belief.
Goodbye!: This speed of Caesar’s reigns beyond belief.

Anon!: Or, if you do not, make the bridal bed In that dim monument where Tybalt lies.
Goodbye!: Or, if you don’t, make the bridal bed in the dim tomb where Tybalt lies.

Anon!: Why, what is that to you?
Goodbye!: What’s that to you?

Anon!: Have with you.
Goodbye!: Have with you.

Anon!: Not so, sir, I do care for something.
Goodbye!: Not so, sir, I care about something.

Anon!: One speech in it I chiefly loved.
Goodbye!: I loved one speech in the first place.

Anon!: I am full of pleasure.
Goodbye!: I’m full of pleasure.

Anon!: Her length of sickness, with what else more serious Importeth thee to know, this bears.
Goodbye!: She’s suffering with what else you need to know more about, and this is what she’s doing.

Anon!: For, hark you, Tybalt being slain so late, It may be thought we held him carelessly, Being our kinsman, if we revel much.
Goodbye!: If you’re a king, you can think that Tybalt was killed so late that we thought we held him a sane man, as our kinsman.

Anon!: And so she did.
Goodbye!: And so she did.

Anon!: Was ever man so 'rayed?
Goodbye!: Was a man ever so rayed?

Anon!: Spare not for the cost.
Goodbye!: Don’t worry about the cost.

Anon!: And since the quarrel Will bear no color for the thing he is, Fashion it thus: that what he is, augmented, Would run to these and these extremities.
Goodbye!: And since the fight won’t bear any color for what he is, it’s time to be a logical way to say that what he is is, augmented, would run to these and these extremities.

Anon!: Is not tomorrow, boy, the ides of March?
Goodbye!: Isn’t tomorrow the ides of March, boy?

Anon!: Favors?
Goodbye!: Favors?

Anon!: Sirs, let ’t alone.
Goodbye!: Don’t let it alone.

Anon!: Go, by this token.
Goodbye!: Go, by this token.

Anon!: Caesar?
Goodbye!: Caesar?

Anon!: Now, by yon marble heaven, In the due reverence of a sacred vow I here engage my words.
Goodbye!: Now, by the time I’m in heaven, I swear to you in the respect of a sacred vow.

Anon!: That you did fear is done.
Goodbye!: You’ve been afraid of it.

Anon!: M”—Malvolio.
Goodbye!: M”—Malvolio.

Anon!: As much unto my good Lord Chamberlain.
Goodbye!: As much to my good Lord Chamberlain.

Anon!: Demetrius loves your fair.
Goodbye!: Demetrius loves you.

Anon!: If you tickle us, do we not laugh?
Goodbye!: If you tickle us, don’t we laugh?

Anon!: There were none fine but Adam, Rafe, and Gregory.
Goodbye!: There were no good except Adam, Rafe, and Gregory.

Anon!: He’s worth no more.
Goodbye!: He’s not worth any more than that.

Anon!: Is your man secret?
Goodbye!: Is your man secret?

Anon!: The very instant that I saw you did My heart fly to your service, there resides To make me slave to it, and for your sake Am I this patient log-man.
Goodbye!: I saw you in the instant I saw you, my heart was flying to your service, and there is a place to make me slave to it, and for your sake I am this patient log-man.

Anon!: That she is worthy, I know.
Goodbye!: I know that she is worthy of her work.

Anon!: What?
Goodbye!: What?

Anon!: Oh, she knew well Thy love did read by rote, that could not spell.
Goodbye!: Oh, she knew well that your love was written by a man who couldn’t spell it.

Anon!: It is even so.
Goodbye!: It’s true.

Anon!: Good cheer, Antonio!
Goodbye!: Good cheer, Antonio!

Anon!: We should have else desired your good advice— Which still hath been both grave and prosperous— In this day’s council, but we’ll take tomorrow.
Goodbye!: We’d like to see you in the council today, but we’ll take it tomorrow.

Anon!: And after that he came thus sad away?
Goodbye!: And then he came so sad away?

Anon!: Behold, I have a weapon.
Goodbye!: Look, I have a weapon.

Anon!: Madam, I am not well.
Goodbye!: Madam, I’m not well.

Anon!: It is impossible.
Goodbye!: It’s impossible.

Anon!: Madam, what should I do?
Goodbye!: Madam, what should I do?

Anon!: Then let them use us well, else let them know, The ills we do, their ills instruct us so.
Goodbye!: Then let them use us well, and then let them know what we do, what they do.

Anon!: A Roman.
Goodbye!: A Roman.

Anon!: Ah, sirrah, a body would think this was well-counterfeited.
Goodbye!: Ah, sir, a body would think this was well-required.

Anon!: Stay but a little.
Goodbye!: Stay a little longer.

Anon!: Oh, so light a foot Will ne'er wear out the everlasting flint.
Goodbye!: Oh, a foot so light will never wear out the everlasting flint.

Anon!: But no metal can— No, not the hangman’s axe—bear half the keenness Of thy sharp envy.
Goodbye!: But no metal can—no, not the hangman’s axe—bear half your sharp envy.

Anon!: Believe me, I cannot.
Goodbye!: Believe me, I can’t.

Anon!: I say she never did invent this letter.
Goodbye!: I say she never wrote this letter.

Anon!: Farewell both.
Goodbye!: Goodbye to both of you.

Anon!: I can no more.
Goodbye!: I can’t do anything else.

Anon!: Were they not forced with those that should be ours, We might have met them dareful, beard to beard, And beat them backward home.
Goodbye!: If they weren’t forced to marry those who should be ours, we could have met them with courage, beard to beard, and beat them back home.

Anon!: What, will you not suffer me?
Goodbye!: What, won’t you suffer me?

Anon!: Alas, poor Romeo!
Goodbye!: Oh, poor Romeo!

Anon!: Hang him, Jack!
Goodbye!: Hang him, Jack!

Anon!: Virtue itself turns vice, being misapplied, And vice sometime by action dignified.
Goodbye!: Virtue itself turns vice, being misapplied, and vice may be a mistake.

Anon!: Let floods o'erswell and fiends for food howl on!
Goodbye!: Let floods o'clock and fiends for food howl on!

Anon!: Shall we call in th' ambassador, my liege?
Goodbye!: Should we call in the ambassador, my liege?

Anon!: O spite of spites!
Goodbye!: Oh spite of spites!

Anon!: Where art thou, Pindarus?
Goodbye!: Where are you, Pindarus?

Anon!: Oh, ay, as summer flies are in the shambles, That quicken even with blowing.
Goodbye!: Oh, yes, as summer flies are in the shambles, that’s just like blowing.

Anon!: Farewell till then.
Goodbye!: Goodbye until then.

Anon!: Hie you, make haste, for it grows very late.
Goodbye!: Hurry up, because it’s getting late.

Anon!: This case of that huge spirit now is cold.
Goodbye!: This is cold now.

Anon!: What might be toward, that this sweaty haste Doth make the night joint laborer with the day?
Goodbye!: What would it be like to see that this sweaty rush makes the night work together with the day?

Anon!: He’s dead and rotten.
Goodbye!: He’s dead and rotten.

Anon!: I dare not confess that lest I should compare with him in excellence, but to know a man well were to know himself.
Goodbye!: I don’t dare admit that, if I could compare him to him in excellence, I’d rather know a man well than know himself.

Anon!: Then I’ll be brief.
Goodbye!: Then I’ll be brief.

Anon!: Let him fly far.
Goodbye!: Let him fly far.

Anon!: Come, stir, stir, stir!
Goodbye!: Come on, stir up, stir up, stir up!

Anon!: The villain shall not ’scape.
Goodbye!: The villain won’t escape.

Anon!: But if that I am I, then well I know Your weeping sister is no wife of mine, Nor to her bed no homage do I owe.
Goodbye!: But if I am, then I know that your weeping sister isn’t my wife, and I’m not a homage to her bed.

Anon!: Speak to me.
Goodbye!: Speak to me.

Anon!: What should it be that is so shrieked abroad?
Goodbye!: What should I say that the shrieking is so loud abroad?

Anon!: Oh, let the heavens Give him defense against the elements, For I have lost him on a dangerous sea.
Goodbye!: Oh, let the heavens defend him against the elements, because I’ve lost him on a dangerous sea.

Anon!: Go with me To bless this twain that they may prosperous be, And honored in their issue.
Goodbye!: Go with me to bless this two of them so they can be prosperous and be honored in their fight.

Anon!: If I can recover him and keep him tame, I will not take too much for him.
Goodbye!: If I can recover him and keep him tame, I won’t take too much for him.

Anon!: It is so.
Goodbye!: It is.

Anon!: You look pale, and gaze, And put on fear, and cast yourself in wonder To see the strange impatience of the heavens.
Goodbye!: You look pale, look, and stare, and put on fear, and you’re in awe of the strange impatience of the heavens.

Anon!: Farewell, my lord.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, my lord.

Anon!: List, list, O, list!
Goodbye!: Listen, listen, listen!

Anon!: Well, think of marriage now.
Goodbye!: Well, think about marriage now.

Anon!: But she is none.
Goodbye!: But she isn’t.

Anon!: O Tybalt, Tybalt, the best friend I had!
Goodbye!: Oh Tybalt, Tybalt, I had the best friend I had!

Anon!: I do entreat you, not a man depart, Save I alone, till Antony have spoke.
Goodbye!: I’m telling you, not a man, except I’m alone, until Antony has spoken.

Anon!: My lord, I think I saw him yesternight.
Goodbye!: My lord, I think I saw him there for the first time.

Anon!: Nay, indeed if you had your eyes, you might fail of the knowing me.
Goodbye!: If you had your eyes, you could not see me.

Anon!: Or if thou follow me, do not believe But I shall do thee mischief in the wood.
Goodbye!: Or if you follow me, I’ll do you mischief in the woods.

Anon!: In this last tempest.
Goodbye!: In this last moment.

Anon!: Who does do you wrong?
Goodbye!: Who did you wrong?

Anon!: And therefore haste away, For we must measure twenty miles today.
Goodbye!: So hurry away, because we have to measure twenty miles today.

Anon!: What art thou?
Goodbye!: What are you doing?

Anon!: Come hither, good Volumnius.
Goodbye!: Come here, good Volumnius.

Anon!: Adieu!
Goodbye!: Goodbye!

Anon!: Your Highness told me I should post before.
Goodbye!: Your Highness told me I should post before.

Anon!: Hence, be gone, away!
Goodbye!: So go away!

Anon!: Best safety lies in fear.
Goodbye!: Fear is the best way to protect yourself.

Anon!: You shall have gold To pay the petty debt twenty times over.
Goodbye!: You’ll have gold to pay the debt twenty times over.

Anon!: That is the voice, Or I am much deceived, of Portia.
Goodbye!: That’s Portia’s voice, or I’m much deceived.

Anon!: Whereon I do beseech thee, grant me this, To leave me but a little to myself.
Goodbye!: Wherever I beg you, grant me this, to leave me to myself only a little.

Anon!: Tell me, thou villain-slave, where are my children?
Goodbye!: Tell me, you villain-slave, where are my children?

Anon!: An evil soul producing holy witness Is like a villain with a smiling cheek, A goodly apple rotten at the heart.
Goodbye!: An evil soul who is a holy witness is like a villain with a smiling cheek, a good apple rotten at the heart.

Anon!: Yet Edmund was beloved.
Goodbye!: But Edmund was beloved.

Anon!: He hath confessed.
Goodbye!: He’s confessed.

Anon!: Forbear me.
Goodbye!: Be quiet.

Anon!: O excellent motion!
Goodbye!: Oh, what an excellent motion!

Anon!: Well, sir, my mistress is the sweetest lady.—Lord, Lord!
Goodbye!: Well, sir, my mistress is the sweetest lady.—Lord, Lord!

Anon!: All my reports go with the modest truth, Nor more, nor clipped, but so.
Goodbye!: All my reports are based on the modest truth, and neither more, nor clipped, but so.

Anon!: Is my master and his wife coming, Grumio?
Goodbye!: Is my master and his wife coming, Grumio?

Anon!: Well, heaven’s above all, and there be souls must be saved, and there be souls must not be saved.
Goodbye!: Well, heaven’s foremost, and there are souls to be saved, and there are souls to be saved.

Anon!: But is this law?
Goodbye!: But is this law?

Anon!: Let him go up into the public chair.
Goodbye!: Let him go up to the public seat.

Anon!: But life itself, my wife, and all the world Are not with me esteemed above thy life.
Goodbye!: But life itself, my wife, and the whole world aren’t with me as worthy of your life.

Anon!: And I for no woman.
Goodbye!: And I don’t want to be a woman.

Anon!: Justice, most sacred duke, against the Abbess.
Goodbye!: Justice, most sacred duke, against the Abbess.

Anon!: Kings it makes gods, and meaner creatures kings.
Goodbye!: It’s kings, and kings are kings of more mean creatures.

Anon!: But my uncle-father and aunt-mother are deceived.
Goodbye!: But my uncle-father and aunt-mother are fooled.

Anon!: Who serv’st thou under?
Goodbye!: Who are you?

Anon!: Fare you well.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: Peace, ho!
Goodbye!: Quiet!

Anon!: By my troth, thou hast an open hand.
Goodbye!: I swear, you have a good hand.

Anon!: I must remove Some thousands of these logs and pile them up, Upon a sore injunction.
Goodbye!: I have to remove some thousand of these logs and pile them up, if I have a sore injunction.

Anon!: He bears him like a portly gentleman, And, to say truth, Verona brags of him To be a virtuous and well-governed youth.
Goodbye!: He’s like a handsome gentleman, and, to say the truth, Verona is brags about him as a virtuous and well-governed young man.

Anon!: For heaven’s sake, help me!
Goodbye!: For heaven’s sake, help me!

Anon!: Time travels in diverse paces with diverse persons.
Goodbye!: Time travels in different ways with diverse people.

Anon!: They see and smell And have their palates both for sweet and sour, As husbands have.
Goodbye!: They see and smell and have their palates both sweet and sour, as husbands have.

Anon!: Satan, avoid!
Goodbye!: Satan, don’t worry!

Anon!: Here, kiss the book.
Goodbye!: Here, kiss the book.

Anon!: God send you joy, Petruchio.
Goodbye!: God send you joy, Petruchio.

Anon!: Nothing, Messala.
Goodbye!: Nothing, Messala.

Anon!: He that shall see this day, and live old age, Will yearly on the vigil feast his neighbors And say, “Tomorrow is Saint Crispian.” Then will he strip his sleeve and show his scars, And say, “These wounds I had on Crispin’s day.”
Goodbye!: He who will see this day and live old age will yearly feast on the feast with his neighbors and say, “Tomorrow is Saint Crispian.” Then he’ll strip his sleeve and show his

Anon!: Montague!
Goodbye!: Montague!

Anon!: What, will my daughter prove a good musician?
Goodbye!: What, will my daughter be a good musician?

Anon!: This is Illyria, lady.
Goodbye!: This is Illyria, lady.

Anon!: Well, I will marry one day, but to try.
Goodbye!: Well, I’ll marry one day, but I’ll try.

Anon!: Tell me in sadness, who is that you love.
Goodbye!: Tell me in sadness who you love.

Anon!: Fly And make your peace with Caesar.
Goodbye!: Fly and make peace with Caesar.

Anon!: Take them in.
Goodbye!: Take them in.

Anon!: After dinner Your hazard shall be made.
Goodbye!: After dinner, you’ll be warned.

Anon!: Do, if it will not stand.
Goodbye!: Do, if it doesn’t stand.

Anon!: A right fair mark, fair coz, is soonest hit.
Goodbye!: Then the right one is hit the most quickly.

Anon!: I pray you, will you take him by the arm?
Goodbye!: Please, will you take him by the arm?

Anon!: Bring him with triumph home unto his house!
Goodbye!: Bring him with triumph back to his house!

Anon!: Prison, my lord?
Goodbye!: Prison, my lord?

Anon!: He bears The third part of the world, man.
Goodbye!: He’s the third person in the world.

Anon!: Would thou’dst be ruled by me!
Goodbye!: I wish you were ruled by me!

Anon!: For she is wise, if I can judge of her.
Goodbye!: She’s wise, if I can judge her.

Anon!: And so good morrow to you every one.
Goodbye!: And so good morning to you every one of you.

Anon!: There is a man haunts the forest that abuses our young plants with carving “Rosalind” on their barks, hangs odes upon hawthorns and elegies on brambles, all, forsooth, deifying the name of Rosalind.
Goodbye!: There’s a man in the forest who sneezes our young plants by carving “Rosalind” on their barks, hangs odes on hawthorns and elegies

Anon!: My Lord Bassanio, let him have the ring.
Goodbye!: Bassanio, let him have the ring.

Anon!: Why, there then!
Goodbye!: Well, then!

Anon!: Good night, Penthesilea.
Goodbye!: Good night, Penthesilea.

Anon!: This night methinks is but the daylight sick.
Goodbye!: This night I think it’s just the daylight sick.

Anon!: This is the man, this is Antonio, To whom I am so infinitely bound.
Goodbye!: This is the man, this is Antonio, to whom I’m so bound.

Anon!: Use lenity, sweet chuck.
Goodbye!: Use lenity, sweet chuck.

Anon!: In faith, she’s too curst.
Goodbye!: She’s too scolded.

Anon!: That our garments, being, as they were, drenched in the sea, hold notwithstanding their freshness and glosses, being rather new-dyed than stained with salt water.
Goodbye!: Our clothes, as they were, are drenched in the sea, but they are still fresh and shiny, rather than stained with salt.

Anon!: Marry, ’tis enough.
Goodbye!: It’s enough.

Anon!: Let me be put to death.
Goodbye!: Let me be put to death.

Anon!: Still did I tell him it was vile and bad.
Goodbye!: I told him it was vile and bad.

Anon!: For when thou gavest them the rod, and put’st down thine own breeches,            Prithee, nuncle, keep a schoolmaster that can teach thy fool to lie.
Goodbye!: When you gave them the rod and put down your own breeches, please, nuncle, keep a schoolmaster who can teach your fool to lie.

Anon!: What I should think of this I cannot tell, But this I think: there’s no man is so vain That would refuse so fair an offered chain.
Goodbye!: I don’t know what I should think of this, but I think that’s true: there’s no man so vain that would refuse such a fair offer.

Anon!: I dare, and do defy thee for a villain.
Goodbye!: I dare, and I’m defying you for a villain.

Anon!: Two such opposèd kings encamp them still, In man as well as herbs—grace and rude will.
Goodbye!: Two such opposing kings still encamp them in man as well as in herbs—grace and rude will.

Anon!: Romeo is banishèd.” There is no end, no limit, measure, bound, In that word’s death.
Goodbye!: Romeo is banned.” There’s no end, no limit, no measure, no bound, in the word’s death.

Anon!: Yes, Captain, but with this acknowledgement: That God fought for us.
Goodbye!: Yes, Captain, but with this acknowledgement: God fought for us.

Anon!: His name!
Goodbye!: His name!

Anon!: Queen Margaret saw Thy murd'rous falchion smoking in his blood, The which thou once didst bend against her breast, But that thy brothers beat aside the point.
Goodbye!: Queen Margaret saw your murdrous falchion smoking in his blood, the one you bended against her breast once, but your brothers beat aside the point.

Anon!: Sir, Octavius is already come to Rome.
Goodbye!: Sir, Octavius has already come to Rome.

Anon!: Hang him instantly.
Goodbye!: Hang him immediately.

Anon!: Though you have put me into darkness and given your drunken cousin rule over me, yet have I the benefit of my senses as well as your Ladyship.
Goodbye!: Though you’ve put me in darkness and given your drunken cousin control over me, I’ve got the benefit of my senses as well as your Ladyship.

Anon!: I take pleasure in singing, sir.
Goodbye!: I enjoy singing, sir.

Anon!: Call in the messengers.
Goodbye!: Call in the messengers.

Anon!: Wonder not Nor be grieved.
Goodbye!: Don’t wonder or be grieved.

Anon!: My lord, I take my leave.
Goodbye!: My lord, I’m leaving.

Anon!: They are his shards, and he
Goodbye!: He

Anon!: But what talk I of this?
Goodbye!: But what do I say about this?

Anon!: I have, my lord.
Goodbye!: I have, my lord.

Anon!: Ho, open the door.
Goodbye!: Open the door.

Anon!: Tucket Once more I come to know of thee, King Harry, If for thy ransom thou wilt now compound, Before thy most assurèd overthrow.
Goodbye!: Once again, I’ll come to know you, King Harry, if you’re going to get your ransom, before you’re finally overthrown.

Anon!: Signor, you are very near my brother in his love.
Goodbye!: Signor, you’re very close to my brother in his love.

Anon!: Saint Francis be my speed!
Goodbye!: Saint Francis, be my speed!

Anon!: I have a letter guessingly set down, Which came from one that’s of a neutral heart, And not from one opposed.
Goodbye!: I have a letter written down in a way that’s a neutral heart, and not a opposed one.

Anon!: Fare thee well at once.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: Even since you left it.
Goodbye!: Since you left it.

Anon!: Hear me, good brother— Under your pardon.
Goodbye!: Listen to me, good brother— Under your pardon.

Anon!: And doubt not, sir, but she will well excuse Why at this time the doors are made against you.
Goodbye!: And she won’t doubt her, but she’ll excuse why the doors are closed against you.

Anon!: Would he not be a comfort to our travel?
Goodbye!: Wouldn’t he be a comfort to our travels?

Anon!: No shame but mine.
Goodbye!: No shame except mine.

Anon!: My books and instruments shall be my company, On them to look and practice by myself.
Goodbye!: My books and instruments will be my company, so I can look and practice them myself.

Anon!: Only this commendation I can afford her, that were she other than she is, she were unhandsome, and being no other but as she is, I do not like her.
Goodbye!: I can afford her, because if she were other than she is, she would be unhandsome, and since she is as beautiful as she is, I don’t like her.

Anon!: Brutus, bait not me.
Goodbye!: Brutus, don’t bait me.

Anon!: Therefore your Grace may well say I have lost it.
Goodbye!: So your Grace may say I’ve lost it.

Anon!: The competitors enter.
Goodbye!: The competitors are entering.

Anon!: I am bound to thee forever.
Goodbye!: I’m bound to you forever.

Anon!: Great happiness!
Goodbye!: Great happiness!

Anon!: Oh, now you weep, and, I perceive, you feel The dint of pity.
Goodbye!: Oh, now you cry, and I think you feel the pity of pity.

Anon!: Oh, that his fault should make a knave of thee, That art not what th’ art sure of!
Goodbye!: Oh, that his fault should make you a king, that’s not what you’re sure of!

Anon!: Nay, we must think men are not gods, Nor of them look for such observances As fit the bridal.
Goodbye!: No, we must think men are not gods, and not look for anything that suits the bridal.

Anon!: You must leave this.
Goodbye!: You have to leave this.

Anon!: Twas full two years ere I could get a tooth.
Goodbye!: It was a long time before I could get a tooth.

Anon!: Tell him his fears are shallow, without instance.
Goodbye!: Tell him his fears are shallow, without a sense of instance.

Anon!: Well, fare you well, my lord.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, my lord.

Anon!: Smile you my speeches as I were a fool?
Goodbye!: Do you smile at my speeches as I were a fool?

Anon!: And what’s her history?
Goodbye!: And what’s her history?

Anon!: Thou art a strange fellow.
Goodbye!: You’re a strange man.

Anon!: Let me see 'em.
Goodbye!: Let me see them.

Anon!: Mend when thou canst.
Goodbye!: Mend when you can.

Anon!: Your wife would give you little thanks for that If she were by to hear you make the offer.
Goodbye!: Your wife would give you little thanks for that if she were there to hear you make the offer.

Anon!: She rendered life, Thy name so buried in her.
Goodbye!: She gave her life, your name was so buried in her.

Anon!: If it were now to die, 'Twere now to be most happy, for I fear My soul hath her content so absolute That not another comfort like to this Succeeds in unknown fate.
Goodbye!: If it were to die now, then I’d be most happy now, because I’m afraid my soul has a content that doesn’t make me feel like this.

Anon!: All ports I’ll bar.
Goodbye!: I’ll stop all ports.

Anon!: I’ll put myself in poor and mean attire And with a kind of umber smirch my face.
Goodbye!: I’ll wear poor and mean attire and smirch my face with a smirch.

Anon!: My most dear lord!
Goodbye!: My dear lord!

Anon!: Find them out whose names are written here?
Goodbye!: Find them who have their names written here?

Anon!: I pray you, tell my lord and father, madam, I will not marry yet.
Goodbye!: Please tell my lord and father, madam, I won’t marry yet.

Anon!: Lie with her?
Goodbye!: Do you have a seat with her?

Anon!: There lies that Tybalt.
Goodbye!: Tybalt lies there.

Anon!: Get you a place.
Goodbye!: Get a place.

Anon!: And true she is, as she hath proved herself.
Goodbye!: And she is, as she has proved herself.

Anon!: Now the witch take me if I meant it thus!
Goodbye!: Now the witch will take me if I meant it like that!

Anon!: Commend me to your daughter.
Goodbye!: Give my praises to your daughter.

Anon!: Ay, thou poor ghost, whiles memory holds a seat In this distracted globe.
Goodbye!: Yes, you poor ghost, while your memory holds a seat in this distracted globe.

Anon!: Grieved I I had but one?
Goodbye!: Is it sad I had only one?

Anon!: O, O, O, O.
Goodbye!: Oh, Oh, Oh, Oh, Oh, Oh, Oh.

Anon!: Your worship’s friend and Launcelot, sir.
Goodbye!: Your worship’s friend and Launcelot, sir.

Anon!: Is your Englishman so expert in his drinking?
Goodbye!: Is your Englishman so expert in his drinking?

Anon!: You take my house when you do take the prop That doth sustain my house.
Goodbye!: You take my house when you take the prop that sustains my house.

Anon!: Home, you idle creatures get you home!
Goodbye!: Home, you idle creatures get you home!

Anon!: No?
Goodbye!: No?

Anon!: I fear your disposition.
Goodbye!: I’m afraid you’re going to do that.

Anon!: Is it no more but this—a tardiness in nature Which often leaves the history unspoke That it intends to do?—My lord of Burgundy, What say you to the lady?
Goodbye!: Isn’t it all that important to say about this—a long time in nature that leaves the history unspoken that it intends to do?—My lord of Burgundy, what do you say to the

Anon!: Come, for the third, Laertes.
Goodbye!: Come, for the third time, Laertes.

Anon!: Take heed of Cassius.
Goodbye!: Take care of Cassius.

Anon!: I am in this commanded to deliver The noble duke of Clarence to your hands.
Goodbye!: I’m ordered to deliver the noble duke of Clarence to your hands.

Anon!: You!
Goodbye!: You!

Anon!: Lear’s shadow.
Goodbye!: Lear’s shadow.

Anon!: Amen.
Goodbye!: Amen.

Anon!: Since that my beauty cannot please his eye, I’ll weep what’s left away, and weeping die.
Goodbye!: Since my beauty can’t please his eyes, I’ll weep what’s left away and weep and die.

Anon!: Then one of you will prove a shrunk panel and, like green timber, warp, warp.
Goodbye!: Then one of you will be a shrunk panel and, like green timber, warp, warp.

Anon!: Cassio hath here been set on in the dark By Roderigo and fellows that are ’scaped.
Goodbye!: Cassio has been set on here in the dark by Roderigo and fellows who have escaped.

Anon!: Strangle her in her bed, even the bed she hath contaminated.
Goodbye!: Strangle her in her bed, even the bed she’s contaminated.

Anon!: Do not run away.
Goodbye!: Don’t run away.

Anon!: Thy spirit walks abroad and turns our swords In our own proper entrails.
Goodbye!: Your spirit walks out of here and turns our swords into our own entrails.

Anon!: But where hast thou been, then?
Goodbye!: But where have you been, then?

Anon!: Come, come, good wine is a good familiar creature, if it be well used.
Goodbye!: Come on, good wine is a good familiar creature, if it’s well used.

Anon!: Twas a shame no less Than was his loss, to course your flying flags And leave his navy gazing.
Goodbye!: It was a shame no less than his loss, to get your flying flags and leave his navy gazing.

Anon!: What villain, madam?
Goodbye!: What villain, madam?

Anon!: One word more Shall make me chide thee, if not hate thee.
Goodbye!: One more word will make me remark on you, if not hate you.

Anon!: What news?
Goodbye!: What news do you have?

Anon!: Good or bad news, that thou com’st in so bluntly?
Goodbye!: Good or bad news, that you’re compelled to speak so bluntly?

Anon!: No, my profound heart.
Goodbye!: No, my profound heart.

Anon!: Here all eyes gaze on us.
Goodbye!: Here all eyes are on us.

Anon!: Yes indeed.
Goodbye!: Yes, indeed.

Anon!: I’ll beat the knave into a twiggen bottle.
Goodbye!: I’ll beat the knave into a twiggen bottle.

Anon!: Now God in heaven bless thee!
Goodbye!: Now God in heaven bless you!

Anon!: I’d have thee live, For in my sense ’tis happiness to die.
Goodbye!: I wish you could live, because it’s happiness to die.

Anon!: I will, my lord.
Goodbye!: I will, my lord.

Anon!: If not, he foams at mouth and by and by Breaks out to savage madness.
Goodbye!: If not, he’s foaming at his mouth and he’s breaking out of a savage madness.

Anon!: Dost thou squiny at me?
Goodbye!: Are you squinting at me?

Anon!: Here is a wonder, if you talk of a wonder.
Goodbye!: Here’s a wonder, if you talk about it.

Anon!: This is a man’s invention, and his hand.
Goodbye!: This is a man’s invention, and his handwriting.

Anon!: Please you, farther.
Goodbye!: Please, go further.

Anon!: It is a high-wrought flood.
Goodbye!: It’s a flood.

Anon!: You have of late stood out against your brother, and he hath ta'en you newly into his grace, where it is impossible you should take true root but by the fair weather that you make yourself.
Goodbye!: You’ve stood out against your brother, and he has gotten you into his grace, where it’s impossible to take true root only by the weather that you’re making yourself.

Anon!: Bless us!
Goodbye!: Bless us!

Anon!: How should that be?
Goodbye!: How should that be?

Anon!: Who’s there?
Goodbye!: Who’s there?

Anon!: Nay, if they lead to any ill, I will leave them at the next turning.
Goodbye!: If they cause any illness, I’ll leave them at the next turn.

Anon!: Oh, Oh, Oh!
Goodbye!: Oh, Oh, Oh!

Anon!: And yet I would not be thee, nuncle.
Goodbye!: And yet I wouldn’t be you, uncle.

Anon!: What sense had I in her stol'n hours of lust?
Goodbye!: What sense did I have in her lust-filled hours?

Anon!: Who knows not he is dead!
Goodbye!: Who doesn’t know he’s dead!

Anon!: This concurs directly with the letter.
Goodbye!: This is exactly what I said.

Anon!: First, there is the Neapolitan prince.
Goodbye!: First, there’s the Neapolitan prince.

Anon!: By foul play, as thou sayst, were we heaved thence, But blessedly holp hither.
Goodbye!: We were heaved from here, but we were blessed to be holp here.

Anon!: What are you?
Goodbye!: Who are you?

Anon!: That I have, lady.
Goodbye!: I have, lady.

Anon!: Under love’s heavy burden do I sink.
Goodbye!: I sink under love’s heavy burden.

Anon!: To move is to stir, and to be valiant is to stand.
Goodbye!: To move is to stir, and to be brave is to stand.

Anon!: What, jealous Oberon?—Fairies, skip hence.
Goodbye!: What, jealous Oberon?—Fairies, skip out of here.

Anon!: With all my heart, so thou canst get a wife.
Goodbye!: With all my heart, you can get a wife.

Anon!: Ay, or drinking, fencing, swearing, Quarreling, drabbing—you may go so far.
Goodbye!: Yes, or drinking, fencing, swearing, arguing, drabbing—you can go so far.

Anon!: I’ll put a girdle round about the Earth In forty minutes.
Goodbye!: I’ll put a girdle around the Earth in forty minutes.

Anon!: And I trow this is his house.
Goodbye!: And I trow this is his house.

Anon!: Shall I be married then tomorrow morning?
Goodbye!: Should I be married tomorrow morning?

Anon!: Let it be so.
Goodbye!: Let it be.

Anon!: Nor what I have done by water.
Goodbye!: I’m not doing anything by water.

Anon!: Lady, amen.
Goodbye!: Amen, lady.

Anon!: For a taste: If a hart do lack a hind, Let him seek out Rosalind.
Goodbye!: For a taste: If a sleeve has a hind, let him find Rosalind.

Anon!: As I descended?
Goodbye!: As I walked down?

Anon!: They stay upon your patience.
Goodbye!: They’re waiting for you.

Anon!: Give me your arm.
Goodbye!: Give me your arm.

Anon!: Well, you temporize with the hours.
Goodbye!: Well, you’re rushing around with the hours.

Anon!: Tis good.
Goodbye!: It’s good.

Anon!: Find you out a bed, For I upon this bank will rest my head.
Goodbye!: Find a bed, because I’ll rest my head on this bank.

Anon!: The dram of evil Doth all the noble substance of a doubt To his own scandal.
Goodbye!: The evil dram is the most noble thing to doubt his own scandal.

Anon!: I will frown as I pass by, and let them take it as they list.
Goodbye!: I’ll frown as I pass by, and let them take it as they list it.

Anon!: I take some joy to say you are because I would be talking of her.
Goodbye!: I’m glad you’re here, because I’d like to talk about her.

Anon!: Henry the Sixth, in infant bands crowned king Of France and England, did this king succeed, Whose state so many had the managing That they lost France and made his England bleed, Which oft our stage hath shown.
Goodbye!: Henry the Sixth, crowned king of France and England, succeeded this king, who had the power to manage so many of them that they lost France and made his England bleed, which we have shown on stage.

Anon!: Will not the mayor then and his brethren come?
Goodbye!: Willn’t the mayor and his brethren come then?

Anon!: Here comes the lady.
Goodbye!: Here comes the lady.

Anon!: Pray heavens he be, For I have served him, and the man commands Like a full soldier.
Goodbye!: I’ve served him, and the man commands him like a full soldier.

Anon!: How comes this trick upon him?
Goodbye!: How does he get this trick?

Anon!: Heaven knows what she has known.
Goodbye!: Heaven knows what she has known.

Anon!: Alack the day!
Goodbye!: Let’s go!

Anon!: Or rather, do thy pleasure.
Goodbye!: Or rather, do your pleasure.

Anon!: By day and night he wrongs me.
Goodbye!: He’s wronged me by night and day.

Anon!: Some good man bear him carefully from hence.
Goodbye!: Some good man should take him away from here.

Anon!: A spirit I am indeed, But am in that dimension grossly clad Which from the womb I did participate.
Goodbye!: I’m a spirit, but I’m in that womb that I was a part of.

Anon!: See” ’t shalt thou never.—Fellows, hold the chair.— Upon these eyes of thine I’ll set my foot.
Goodbye!: You’ll never see” if you’re ever.—Fellows, hold the chair.—I’ll set my foot on your eyes.

Anon!: Is not this something more than fantasy?
Goodbye!: Isn’t this something more than fantasy?

Anon!: I dreamt there was an emperor Antony.
Goodbye!: I dreamed there was an emperor Antony.

Anon!: O my Christian ducats!
Goodbye!: Oh my Christian ducats!

Anon!: Brother of Gloucester, you mistake the matter.
Goodbye!: Brother of Gloucester, you’re wrong about this.

Anon!: How now, daughter and cousin?
Goodbye!: What’s going on, daughter and cousin?

Anon!: Your Majesty came not like yourself.
Goodbye!: Your Majesty didn’t come like yourself.

Anon!: For indeed, who would set his wit to so foolish a bird?
Goodbye!: Who would do that to be so foolish?

Anon!: Only to despite them, I will endeavor anything.
Goodbye!: I’ll do anything to keep them from being beaten.

Anon!: Was I with you there for the goose?
Goodbye!: Was I with you there for the goose?

Anon!: I know you what you are, And like a sister am most loath to call Your faults as they are named.
Goodbye!: I know what you are, and like a sister I’m afraid to call your faults as they’re named.

Anon!: Let me be put to death.
Goodbye!: Let me be put to death.

Anon!: He is a gentleman of a good house, and for his ransom he will give you two hundred crowns.
Goodbye!: He’s a gentleman of a good house, and for his ransom he’ll give you two hundred crowns.

Anon!: Against my will I am sent to bid you come in to dinner.” There’s a double meaning in that.
Goodbye!: I’ve been sent to ask you to come in to dinner.

Anon!: And so am I revenged.—That would be scanned.
Goodbye!: And so am I revenged.—That would be scanned.

Anon!: I have heard it said so.
Goodbye!: I’ve heard it said so.

Anon!: But such officers do the king best service in the end.
Goodbye!: But such officers do the king best in the end.

Anon!: Be quiet, people.
Goodbye!: Be quiet, people.

Anon!: Sweet friends, to bed.
Goodbye!: Sweet friends, go to bed.

Anon!: Boy!
Goodbye!: Boy!

Anon!: He was not merry, Which seemed to tell them his remembrance lay In Egypt with his joy, but between both.
Goodbye!: He was not a merry man, which seemed to tell them his memory was in Egypt with his joy, but between both.

Anon!: I know by that same eye there’s some good news.
Goodbye!: I know that there’s some good news.

Anon!: But where hast thou been, then?
Goodbye!: But where have you been, then?

Anon!: And therefore ’tis called a sensible tale.
Goodbye!: So it’s called a sensible tale.

Anon!: And did not I in rage depart from thence?
Goodbye!: And I didn’t leave here in rage?

Anon!: Give me audience, good madam.
Goodbye!: Give me a crowd, good madam.

Anon!: Two things are to be done: My wife must move for Cassio to her mistress.
Goodbye!: Two things are to be done: My wife must move for Cassio to her mistress.

Anon!: Unto the dignity and height of fortune, The high imperial type of this earth’s glory.
Goodbye!: The high imperial type of this earth’s glory is to the dignity and height of fortune.

Anon!: What is the matter?
Goodbye!: What’s the matter?

Anon!: The second cock hath crowed.
Goodbye!: The second cock has crowed.

Anon!: Look, he wears cruel garters.
Goodbye!: Look, he’s wearing cruel garters.

Anon!: You knew—none so well, none so well as you—of my daughter’s flight.
Goodbye!: You knew—no one knew as well, no one knew as well about my daughter’s flight.

Anon!: Go hence.
Goodbye!: Go away.

Anon!: Andrew Aguecheek”
Goodbye!: Andrew Aguecheek”

Anon!: Go, girl.
Goodbye!: Go, girl.

Anon!: No.
Goodbye!: No.

Anon!: Excellent well!
Goodbye!: Good luck!

Anon!: Hold, worthy lady, hold!
Goodbye!: Hold on, dear lady, hold on!

Anon!: Hark ye, your Romeo will be here at night.
Goodbye!: Listen, your Romeo will be here at night.

Anon!: How hast thou offended?
Goodbye!: How have you offended me?

Anon!: Oh, the more angel she, And you the blacker devil!
Goodbye!: Oh, the more angel she is, and you the blacker devil!

Anon!: This is well.
Goodbye!: That’s good.

Anon!: You wrong me every way.
Goodbye!: You wrong me in every way.

Anon!: His beard was grizzled, no?
Goodbye!: He was grizzled, no?

Anon!: All the power of his wits have given way to his impatience.
Goodbye!: His wits have given way to his impatience.

Anon!: If much you note him, You shall offend him and extend his passion.
