Goodbye!: If you notice him, you’ll offend him and extend his passion.

Anon!: The will!
Goodbye!: The will!

Anon!: You do mistake me, sir.
Goodbye!: You’re wrong, sir.

Anon!: When he stands where I am and sees you there.
Goodbye!: When he stands where I am and sees you there.

Anon!: By this sword, I will.
Goodbye!: I will, by this sword.

Anon!: Thanks, Guildenstern and gentle Rosencrantz.
Goodbye!: Thanks, Guildenstern and gentle Rosencrantz.

Anon!: Think’st thou that duty shall have dread to speak When power to flattery bows?
Goodbye!: Do you think that you’ll have to be afraid to speak when the power to flattery bows?

Anon!: If it please the eye of one, it is with me as the very true sonnet is, “Please one, and please all.”  Why, how dost thou, man?
Goodbye!: If it’s the eye of one, it’s with me as true as the sonnet is, “Please one, and please all.” Why, how are you, man?

Anon!: Lo, here upon thy cheek the stain doth sit Of an old tear that is not washed off yet.
Goodbye!: Oh, on your cheek, the stain is a tear that hasn’t been washed off yet.

Anon!: Is ’t good or bad?
Goodbye!: Is it good or bad?

Anon!: Or docks, or mallows.
Goodbye!: Or docks, or mallows.

Anon!: Here comes Sir Toby halting.
Goodbye!: Here comes Sir Toby halting.

Anon!: Ill spirit, I would hold more talk with thee.
Goodbye!: I’d like to talk more about you.

Anon!: O most happy hour!
Goodbye!: Oh, what a happy hour!

Anon!: Sojourn in Mantua.
Goodbye!: Sojourn in Mantua.

Anon!: Though it pass your patience and mine to endure her loud alarums, why, man, there be good fellows in the world, an a man could light on them, would take her with all faults, and money enough.
Goodbye!: Even though you’re begging me to endure her loud alarums, there are good fellows in the world, a man could light on them, would take her with all the faults and money.

Anon!: I drink to thee.
Goodbye!: I drink to you.

Anon!: By my count, I was your mother much upon these years That you are now a maid.
Goodbye!: I swear, I was your mother in the years you have been a maid.

Anon!: Orlando doth commend him to you both, And to that youth he calls his Rosalind He sends this bloody napkin.
Goodbye!: Orlando is recommending him to you both, and he sends this bloody napkin to the young man he calls his Rosalind.

Anon!: Twas I indeed thou promised’st to strike, And thou hast given me most bitter terms.
Goodbye!: I was actually promised to strike, and you’ve given me the most bitter terms.

Anon!: Thus hath the candle singed the moth.
Goodbye!: So the candle has singed the moth.

Anon!: I shall have glory by this losing day More than Octavius and Mark Antony By this vile conquest shall attain unto.
Goodbye!: I’ll have glory by this loss day more than Octavius and Mark Antony will have to achieve by this vile conquest.

Anon!: Never, my lord.
Goodbye!: Never, my lord.

Anon!: Hark!
Goodbye!: Listen!

Anon!: Love is merely a madness and, I tell you, deserves as well a dark house and a whip as madmen do, and the reason why they are not so punished and cured is that the lunacy is so ordinary that the whippers are in love, too.
Goodbye!: Love is just a madness, and I tell you, it deserves as much a dark house and a whip as madmen do.

Anon!: He doth, for he did bid Antonius Send word to you he would be there tomorrow.
Goodbye!: He’s doing it, because he asked Antonius to send you a message saying he’ll be there tomorrow.

Anon!: I remember the story.
Goodbye!: I remember the story.

Anon!: And I with him.
Goodbye!: And I’m with him.

Anon!: What?
Goodbye!: What?

Anon!: Why, what an intricate impeach is this!
Goodbye!: What an intricate impeach this is!

Anon!: A plague upon you, murderers, traitors all!
Goodbye!: You all have a plague!

Anon!: Souls and bodies hath he divorced three, and his incensement at this moment is so implacable that satisfaction can be none but by pangs of death and sepulchre.
Goodbye!: He has separated three souls and bodies, and his incensement is so unreliable that it can only be a result of death and sepulchre.

Anon!: See what a rent the envious Casca made.
Goodbye!: See what a rent the envious Casca made.

Anon!: Here’s yet some liquor left.
Goodbye!: Here’s some liquor left.

Anon!: This night I hold an old accustomed feast, Whereto I have invited many a guest Such as I love.
Goodbye!: This night I’m having a feast that’s been a long time, where I invited many guests like me to join me.

Anon!: Leave me with haste.
Goodbye!: Leave me in the rush.

Anon!: Leave her to heaven And to those thorns that in her bosom lodge To prick and sting her.
Goodbye!: Leave her to heaven and to those thorns that prick and sting her in her bosom lodge.

Anon!: What claim lays she to thee?
Goodbye!: What claim does she make to you?

Anon!: Hoo!
Goodbye!: Hooray!

Anon!: Give me, give me!
Goodbye!: Give me, give me!

Anon!: Did you converse, sir, with this gentlewoman?
Goodbye!: Did you have a conversation with this lady, sir?

Anon!: Let me be satisfied.
Goodbye!: Let me be satisfied.

Anon!: She, dying, as it must so be maintained, Upon the instant that she was accused, Shall be lamented, pitied and excused Of every hearer.
Goodbye!: She’ll be lamented, pitied and excused from every hearer, if she dies, as it must be.

Anon!: O me, O me!
Goodbye!: Oh, my, Oh my!

Anon!: Oh, the heavens!
Goodbye!: Oh, the heavens!

Anon!: What had he done to you?
Goodbye!: What did he do to you?

Anon!: I will be deaf to pleading and excuses.
Goodbye!: I’ll be deaf to pleading and excuses.

Anon!: Why then, God forgive me.
Goodbye!: Well then, God forgive me.

Anon!: Didst thou not hear their shouts?
Goodbye!: Didn’t you hear their shouts?

Anon!: Three thousand ducats for three months, and Antonio bound.
Goodbye!: Three thousand ducats for three months, and Antonio bound.

Anon!: But let her live.
Goodbye!: But let her live.

Anon!: She is thine own.— What, Ariel!
Goodbye!: She’s your own.—What, Ariel!

Anon!: He hath, my lord.
Goodbye!: He has, my lord.

Anon!: I have no way, and therefore want no eyes.
Goodbye!: I have no way, and therefore I don’t want to see.

Anon!: Lie thou there.
Goodbye!: Go there.

Anon!: Or blessè was ’t we did?
Goodbye!: Or was it a blessing that we did?

Anon!: For this time I will leave you.
Goodbye!: For now I’ll leave you.

Anon!: Rumor it abroad That Anne my wife is very grievous sick.
Goodbye!: I’m telling you abroad that Anne, my wife, is very sick.

Anon!: Your houses!
Goodbye!: Your houses!

Anon!: Nurse, where’s my daughter?
Goodbye!: Nurse, where’s my daughter?

Anon!: Take up the bodies.
Goodbye!: Take up the bodies.

Anon!: If he be, he knows how to turn his girdle.
Goodbye!: If he is, he knows how to turn his girdle.

Anon!: I will o’ertake thee, Cleopatra, and Weep for my pardon.
Goodbye!: I’ll take you, Cleopatra, and weep for my pardon.

Anon!: Is Banquo gone from court?
Goodbye!: Has Banquo gone to court?

Anon!: Who can be wise, amazed, temp'rate, and furious, Loyal and neutral, in a moment?
Goodbye!: Who can be wise, amazed, temp'rate, furious, loyal and neutral in a moment?

Anon!: If ever thou wilt thrive, bury my body.
Goodbye!: If you ever want to grow, bury my body.

Anon!: This is the excellent foppery of the world that when we are sick in fortune—often the surfeit of our own behavior—we make guilty of our disasters the sun, the moon, and the stars, as if we were villains by necessity, fools by heavenly compulsion, knaves, thieves, and treachers by spherical predominance, drunkards, liars, and adulterers by an enforced obedience of planetary influence, and all that we are evil in by a divine thrusting-on.
Goodbye!: This is the excellent foppery of the world that when we’re sick in fortune—often because of our own behavior—we make guilty of our disasters the sun, the moon, and the stars, as if we were

Anon!: Where is she?
Goodbye!: Where is she?

Anon!: Go thy ways, wench.
Goodbye!: Go on, wench.

Anon!: Give me the letter, sir.
Goodbye!: Give me the letter, sir.

Anon!: Who ever knew the heavens menace so?
Goodbye!: Who ever knew the heavens were so dangerous?

Anon!: You rise to play and go to bed to work.
Goodbye!: You’re up to play and go to bed to work.

Anon!: Eternity was in our lips and eyes, Bliss in our brows’ bent, none our parts so poor But was a race of heaven.
Goodbye!: Eternity was in our lips and eyes, a bliss in our brows’ bent bent, and none of our parts were so poor, but it was a race of heaven.

Anon!: Unknit that threat'ning unkind brow And dart not scornful glances from those eyes To wound thy lord, thy king, thy governor.
Goodbye!: Don’t scold your lord, your king, your governor.

Anon!: Of all the days i' the year, I came to ’t that day that our last King Hamlet overcame Fortinbras.
Goodbye!: Of all the days of the year, I came to the day our last King Hamlet overcame Fortinbras.

Anon!: Nay, then— Well, well, th' event.
Goodbye!: Well, well, well, that’s what happened.

Anon!: That very hour, and in the selfsame inn, A meaner woman was deliverèd Of such a burden, male twins, both alike.
Goodbye!: In the same hour, and in the same inn, a meaner woman was delivered from such a burden, male twins, both alike.

Anon!: I prithee, do so.
Goodbye!: Please, do so.

Anon!: Thou art sensible in nothing but blows, and so is an ass.
Goodbye!: You’re a man who’s just a blow, and so is an ass.

Anon!: Neither, my lord.
Goodbye!: No, my lord.

Anon!: Ay, my good lord.
Goodbye!: Yes, my good lord.

Anon!: What, is he angry?
Goodbye!: Is he angry?

Anon!: Hear his speech but say thou nought.
Goodbye!: Listen to his speech but say you’re not.

Anon!: Thou art Dromio, thou art my man, thou art thyself.
Goodbye!: You’re Dromio, you’re my man, you’re yourself.

Anon!: Upon the talk of the poisoning?
Goodbye!: When I heard about the poisoning?

Anon!: What from the cape can you discern at sea?
Goodbye!: What can you see from the cape at sea?

Anon!: Mark Antony In Egypt sits at dinner, and will make No wars without doors.
Goodbye!: Mark Antony is sitting in Egypt at dinner and won’t make wars without doors.

Anon!: Go and trim her up.
Goodbye!: Go and trim her up.

Anon!: What, my lord?
Goodbye!: What, my lord?

Anon!: I shall be pinched to death.
Goodbye!: I’ll be pinched to death.

Anon!: Now, I’ll stand to it, the pancakes were naught and the mustard was good, and yet was not the knight forsworn.
Goodbye!: Now I’ll stand to it, the pancakes were naughty and the mustard was good, and the knight wasn’t forsworn.

Anon!: Then plainly to her tell my loving tale.
Goodbye!: Then tell her my loving story.

Anon!: The wind sits in the shoulder of your sail And you are stayed for.
Goodbye!: The wind is sitting in your sail and you’re waiting for it.

Anon!: Love give me strength, and strength shall help afford.
Goodbye!: Love will give me strength, and strength will help me.

Anon!: As much to him, else is his thanks too much.
Goodbye!: As much to him as I do, and his thanks are too much.

Anon!: Oh, banish me, my lord, but kill me not!
Goodbye!: Oh, banish me, my lord, but don’t kill me!

Anon!: Those of his chamber, as it seemed, had done ’t.
Goodbye!: The people of his room, as it seemed, had done it.

Anon!: This is a practise As full of labor as a wise man’s art, For folly that he wisely shows is fit.
Goodbye!: This is a practice as full of work as a wise man’s art, because he shows a good example of folly.

Anon!: We cannot be here and there too.
Goodbye!: We can’t be both here and there.

Anon!: Leave, gentle wax, and, manners, blame us not.
Goodbye!: Leave, gentle wax, and, please, don’t blame us.

Anon!: This man hath had good counsel—a hundred knights!
Goodbye!: This man has had good advice—a hundred knights!

Anon!: We are blest that Rome is rid of him.
Goodbye!: We’re so sad that Rome has rid of him.

Anon!: How fares my lord?
Goodbye!: How is my lord doing?

Anon!: You shall confess that you are both deceived.
Goodbye!: You’ll admit that you both have been fooled.

Anon!: Oh, thou art wise!
Goodbye!: Oh, you’re wise!

Anon!: Thou must know, ’Tis not my profit that does lead mine honor; Mine honor, it.
Goodbye!: You must know, I’m not the one who leads me to honor me, but my honor.

Anon!: Give me some wine and let me speak a little.
Goodbye!: Give me some wine and let me speak a little.

Anon!: I will confess to you that I love him.
Goodbye!: I’ll confess to you that I love him.

Anon!: If we know him to be a thief, shall we not lay hands on him?
Goodbye!: If we know him as a thief, shouldn’t we give him hands?

Anon!: This is as strange a maze as e'er men trod, And there is in this business more than nature Was ever conduct of.
Goodbye!: This is as strange a maze as a gang of men, and there is more in this business than nature ever did.

Anon!: You see how full of changes his age is.
Goodbye!: You see how old he is.

Anon!: And as our vineyards, fallows, meads, and hedges, Defective in their natures, grow to wildness, Even so our houses and ourselves and children Have lost, or do not learn for want of time, The sciences that should become our country, But grow like savages, as soldiers will
Goodbye!: And as our vineyards, fallows, meads, and hedges grow to wildness, as our houses and our children have lost or not learn to learn for a long time the sciences that should become our country,

Anon!: I know not what to say.
Goodbye!: I don’t know what to say.

Anon!: I’ll drink for you.
Goodbye!: I’ll drink for you.

Anon!: Madam, with all my heart.
Goodbye!: Madam, with all my heart.

Anon!: My father was no traitor.
Goodbye!: My father was no traitor.

Anon!: Why might not you, my lord, receive attendance From those that she calls servants, or from mine?
Goodbye!: Why wouldn’t you, my lord, be able to attend from those who she calls servants, or from mine?

Anon!: O fortune, fortune!
Goodbye!: Oh luck, luck!

Anon!: Well, sir, we will not.
Goodbye!: Well, sir, we won’t.

Anon!: Was not that Cassio parted from my wife?
Goodbye!: Didn’t Cassio break from my wife?

Anon!: To this, add defiance, and tell him, for conclusion, he hath betrayed his followers, whose condemnation is pronounced.” So far my king and master; so much my office.
Goodbye!: To this, add defiance, and tell him, for the sake of conclusion, he has betrayed his followers, whose condemnation is pronounced.” So far my king and master, so much my job.

Anon!: I know not where he lodges, and for me to devise a lodging and say he lies here, or he lies there, were to lie in mine own throat.
Goodbye!: I don’t know where he’s staying, and if I wanted to find a place to stay and say he’s here or there, I’d lie in my own throat.

Anon!: Sir, I bade them take away you.
Goodbye!: Sir, I told them to take you away.

Anon!: All is confirmed, my lord, which was reported.
Goodbye!: All this is confirmed, my lord.

Anon!: Come, I will bring thee to thy bridal chamber.
Goodbye!: Come on, I’ll bring you to your bridal chamber.

Anon!: But, room, fairy!
Goodbye!: But, room, fairy!

Anon!: I tell thee true.
Goodbye!: I’m telling you that.

Anon!: Dost thou hear?
Goodbye!: Do you hear it?

Anon!: Away with the dotard!
Goodbye!: Get out of here with the dotard!

Anon!: Oh, thou wilt speak again of banishment.
Goodbye!: Oh, you’re going to talk about banishment again.

Anon!: How much I had to do to calm his rage!
Goodbye!: How much I had to do to calm his rage!

Anon!: Where is kind Hastings?
Goodbye!: Where is kind Hastings?

Anon!: Myself?
Goodbye!: Myself?

Anon!: To the Elephant.
Goodbye!: To the Elephant.

Anon!: I know the glove is a glove.
Goodbye!: I know the glove is a glove.

Anon!: And therefore, like herself—wise, fair and true— Shall she be placèd in my constant soul.
Goodbye!: So she’ll be placated in my constant soul like herself—wise, fair and true.

Anon!: My comfort is that old age, that ill layer-up of beauty, can do no more spoil upon my face.
Goodbye!: I’m glad that old age, that ill-tempered layer of beauty, can’t spoil my face more.

Anon!: Alas, poor shepherd, searching of thy wound, I have by hard adventure found mine own.
Goodbye!: I’ve found my own wounds, poor shepherd.

Anon!: Upon the stroke of four.
Goodbye!: Upon four strokes.

Anon!: You are welcome for his sake.
Goodbye!: You’re welcome for his sake.

Anon!: I will give thee mine.
Goodbye!: I’ll give you mine.

Anon!: This day, great duke, she shut the doors upon me While she with harlots feasted in my house.
Goodbye!: This day, great duke, she shut the doors on me while she feasted with harlots in my house.

Anon!: My father, poorly led?
Goodbye!: My father, led by a poor leadership?

Anon!: Who is ’t you mean?
Goodbye!: Who are you talking about?

Anon!: Or, if his mind be writ, give me his letter.
Goodbye!: Or, if his mind is written, give me his letter.

Anon!: Tis vile, unless it may be quaintly ordered, And better in my mind not undertook.
Goodbye!: It’s vile, unless it’s a little quaint, and I’m not sure what to do.

Anon!: Revenges burn in them, for their dear causes Would to the bleeding and the grim alarm Excite the mortified man.
Goodbye!: Revenges burn in them, because their dear causes would cause the bleeding and the grim alarm to excite the mortified man.

Anon!: She well instructs me.
Goodbye!: She’s very helpful.

Anon!: I had rather be any kind o' thing than a fool.
Goodbye!: I’d rather be any kind of thing than a fool.

Anon!: O you gods!
Goodbye!: Oh gods!

Anon!: I would not for the world they saw thee here.
Goodbye!: I wouldn’t want to see them here in the world.

Anon!: Lovers can see to do their amorous rites By their own beauties, or, if love be blind, It best agrees with night.
Goodbye!: Lovers can see that they’re doing their rites by their own beauties, or if love is blind, it’s best to agree with night.

Anon!: What eye but such an eye would spy out such a quarrel?
Goodbye!: What eye would spy out such a fight?

Anon!: Will they pursue the quality no longer than they can sing?
Goodbye!: Will they not sing the same thing as you can?

Anon!: The lady is dead upon mine and my master’s false accusation.
Goodbye!: The lady is dead after my master and my false accusation.

Anon!: We are enough yet living in the field To smother up the English in our throngs, If any order might be thought upon.
Goodbye!: We’re still enough to smother the English in our throngs, if any order could be thought of.

Anon!: Here, sirrah Grumio.
Goodbye!: Here, sirah Grumio.

Anon!: A friend.
Goodbye!: A friend.

Anon!: I had rather be a canker in a hedge than a rose in his grace, and it better fits my blood to be disdained of all than to fashion a carriage to rob love from any.
Goodbye!: I’d rather be a canker in a hedge than a rose in his grace, and it’s better for me to be disdained of all than to make a carriage to steal love from anyone.

Anon!: Go to, well said, well said.
Goodbye!: Go on, well said, well said.

Anon!: Come, go with me; Under our tents I’ll play the eavesdropper To see if any mean to shrink from me.
Goodbye!: Come with me.

Anon!: What, with Lysander?
Goodbye!: What, with Lysander?

Anon!: Good my lord, If I have any grace or power to move you His present reconciliation take.
Goodbye!: My lord, if I have any grace or power to make you take his reconciliation.

Anon!: Why, what’s the matter?
Goodbye!: What’s the matter?

Anon!: No.
Goodbye!: No.

Anon!: I humbly thank your ladyship.
Goodbye!: Thank you very much.

Anon!: Look, he stirs.
Goodbye!: Look, he’s scolded.

Anon!: Hath it not, boy?
Goodbye!: Isn’t that true, boy?

Anon!: Look how our partner’s rapt.
Goodbye!: Look at how our partner’s rapt.

Anon!: Then your hose should be ungartered, your bonnet unbanded, your sleeve unbuttoned, your shoe untied, and everything about you demonstrating a careless desolation.
Goodbye!: Then your hose should be ungartered, your bonnet should be unbanded, your sleeve should be unbuttoned, your shoe should be untied, and everything about you should be

Anon!: Lips, do not move; No man must know.”
Goodbye!: Lips, don’t move; no man must know.”

Anon!: I say it is the moon.
Goodbye!: I say it’s the moon.

Anon!: Is thy news good, or bad?
Goodbye!: Is your news good or bad?

Anon!: And neither man nor master would take aught But the two rings.
Goodbye!: And neither man nor master would take a savage but the two rings.

Anon!: Be attentive.
Goodbye!: Be attentive.

Anon!: So shalt thou show me friendship.
Goodbye!: You’ll show me friendship.

Anon!: But, were you wedded, you would bear some sway.
Goodbye!: But if you were wedded, you’d have some influence.

Anon!: You kill me to deny it.
Goodbye!: You kill me to deny it.

Anon!: Now show the wound mine eye hath made in thee.
Goodbye!: Now show me the wound my eye has made in you.

Anon!: Have patience, madam.
Goodbye!: Have patience, madam.

Anon!: He doth entreat your Grace, my noble lord, To visit him tomorrow or next day.
Goodbye!: He’ll ask your Grace to visit him tomorrow or the next day, my noble lord.

Anon!: Ambition should be made of sterner stuff.
Goodbye!: Ambition should be made of sterner stuff.

Anon!: Makest thou this shame thy pastime?
Goodbye!: Are you making this shameful day your day?

Anon!: Sure, Luciana, it is two o'clock.
Goodbye!: Sure, Luciana, it’s two o'clock.

Anon!: I think the world’s asleep.
Goodbye!: I think the world’s asleep.

Anon!: What’s that?
Goodbye!: What’s that?

Anon!: We’ll send Mark Antony to the senate house, And he shall say you are not well today.
Goodbye!: We’ll send Mark Antony to the senate house, and he’ll say you’re not well today.

Anon!: There’s magic in the web of it.
Goodbye!: There’s magic in it.

Anon!: Then he is dead?
Goodbye!: Then he’s dead?

Anon!: You know he does.
Goodbye!: You know he does.

Anon!: But, my good lord, your Graces' words shall serve As well as I had seen and heard him speak; And do not doubt, right noble princes both, But I’ll acquaint our duteous citizens With all your just proceedings in this case.
Goodbye!: But I’ll tell you all your sanity in this case.

Anon!: Welcome, lady.
Goodbye!: Welcome, lady.

Anon!: I will walk by.
Goodbye!: I’ll walk by.

Anon!: Launcelot and I are out.
Goodbye!: Launcelot and I are out.

Anon!: Fall to ’t yarely, or we run ourselves aground.
Goodbye!: Fall to it, or we’re running away.

Anon!: Do it at once, Or thy precedent services are all But accidents unpurposed.
Goodbye!: Do it immediately, or your services are only a result of accidents.

Anon!: For mine own good, All causes shall give way.
Goodbye!: For my own good, all causes will give way.

Anon!: Cicero is dead, And by that order of proscription.
Goodbye!: Cicero is dead, and he’s a proscription.

Anon!: Our yoke and sufferance show us womanish.
Goodbye!: Our yoke and suffering show us that we’re womanish.

Anon!: This purse of ducats I received from you, And Dromio my man did bring them me.
Goodbye!: I received this purse of ducats from you, and Dromio, my man, brought them to me.

Anon!: Away!
Goodbye!: Go away!

Anon!: Come, Grey.
Goodbye!: Come, Grey.

Anon!: Cool it with a baboon’s blood, Then the charm is firm and good.
Goodbye!: Cool it with a baboon’s blood, then the charm is firm and good.

Anon!: Make the doors upon a woman’s wit, and it will out at the casement.
Goodbye!: Make the doors open on a woman’s wit, and it’ll be out of the casement.

Anon!: So.
Goodbye!: That’s true.

Anon!: Sblood, an arrant traitor as any ’s in the universal world, or in France, or in England!
Goodbye!: Sblood, an arrant traitor as any other in the universal world, or in France, or in England!

Anon!: Where’s the king?
Goodbye!: Where’s the king?

Anon!: But small to greater matters must give way.
Goodbye!: But small to larger matters must give way to them.

Anon!: A dry jest, sir.
Goodbye!: A dry sneeze, sir.

Anon!: For, my good liege, she is so idly kinged, Her scepter so fantastically borne By a vain, giddy, shallow, humorous youth, That fear attends her not.
Goodbye!: My good liege, she’s so kinged, her scepter is so fantastically borne by a vain, giddy, shallow, humorous youth that she doesn’t have any fear.

Anon!: Let us score their backs And snatch ’em up, as we take hares, behind!
Goodbye!: Let’s score their backs and snatch them up, as we take hares, behind!

Anon!: Thou 'lt be afraid to hear it.
Goodbye!: You shouldn’t be afraid to hear it.

Anon!: Brother, good night.
Goodbye!: Brother, good night.

Anon!: O villainy!
Goodbye!: Oh, bad luck!

Anon!: But old folks, many feign as they were dead, Unwieldy, slow, heavy, and pale as lead.
Goodbye!: But old people, many feign as they were dead, unwieldy, slow, heavy, and pale as lead.

Anon!: What say you?
Goodbye!: What do you say?

Anon!: Come away.
Goodbye!: Come on.

Anon!: When I spoke that, I was ill-tempered too.
Goodbye!: When I said that, I was too ill-tempered.

Anon!: Ay, to me.
Goodbye!: Yes, to me.

Anon!: What’s the matter here?
Goodbye!: What’s the matter here?

Anon!: I was a gentleman, And then I told you true.
Goodbye!: I was a gentleman, and then I told you that.

Anon!: And this.
Goodbye!: And that’s it.

Anon!: I do require them of you, so to use them As we shall find their merits and our safety May equally determine.
Goodbye!: I’ll ask you to use them, as we’ll find that their merits and our safety may be equally determined.

Anon!: Come like shadows; so depart!
Goodbye!: Come like shadows, so depart!

Anon!: The worst fault you have is to be in love.
Goodbye!: The worst fault you have is being in love.

Anon!: Give the word, ho, and stand.
Goodbye!: Give the word, go, and stand.

Anon!: Fie on thee!
Goodbye!: Go on!

Anon!: To me it is a prison.
Goodbye!: It’s a prison for me.

Anon!: Why, how now, monsieur?
Goodbye!: What’s going on, monsieur?

Anon!: A husband?
Goodbye!: A husband?

Anon!: Thou makest me merry.
Goodbye!: You make me happy.

Anon!: Kiss him for that, good widow.
Goodbye!: Kiss him for that, good widow.

Anon!: Zounds, a dog, a rat, a mouse, a cat to scratch a man to death!
Goodbye!: Zounds, a dog, a rat, a mouse, a cat to scratch a man to death!

Anon!: A plague upon the tyrant that I serve!
Goodbye!: I’m a plague on the tyrant I serve!

Anon!: O, she would laugh me Out of myself, press me to death with wit.
Goodbye!: Oh, she would laugh me out of myself, press me to death with wit.

Anon!: Pay him six thousand and deface the bond!
Goodbye!: Pay him six thousand and deface the bond!

Anon!: Who knows not where a wasp does wear his sting?
Goodbye!: Who doesn’t know where a wasp is wearing his sting?

Anon!: I think it is in Macedon where Alexander is porn.
Goodbye!: I think it’s in Macedon where Alexander is porno.

Anon!: Hath not else his eye Stray’d his affection in unlawful love, A sin prevailing much in youthful men Who give their eyes the liberty of gazing?
Goodbye!: He’s a sin that is prevalent in young men who give their eyes the freedom to gaze?

Anon!: And though we lay these honors on this man To ease ourselves of divers slanderous loads, He shall but bear them as the ass bears gold, To groan and sweat under the business, Either led or driven, as we point the way.
Goodbye!: And even though we’re giving this man these honors to ease ourselves from slanderous charges, he’ll only bear them as the ass bears gold, to groan and sweat under the business, either led

Anon!: Even she: Leonato’s Hero, your Hero, every man’s Hero.
Goodbye!: She’s the Hero of Leonato, your Hero, every man’s Hero.

Anon!: Why, what should you fear?
Goodbye!: What do you want to fear?

Anon!: To both their deaths shalt thou be accessory.
Goodbye!: To both their deaths, you’ll be a friend.

Anon!: Cleopatra, Not what you have reserved nor what acknowledged Put we i’ th’ roll of conquest.
Goodbye!: Cleopatra, not what you’ve reserved or what you’ve acknowledged.

Anon!: Oh, bloody period!
Goodbye!: Oh, bloody period!

Anon!: I would have my bond.
Goodbye!: I want my bond.

Anon!: Merciful heaven!
Goodbye!: Merciful heaven!

Anon!: Go with me to a notary, seal me there Your single bond, and—in a merry sport— If you repay me not on such a day, In such a place, such sum or sums as are Expressed in the condition, let the forfeit Be nominated for an equal pound Of your fair flesh, to be cut off and taken In what part of your body pleaseth me.
Goodbye!: If you don’t repay me on such a day, in such a place, in such a place, in such a place, in such a place, in such a place, in such a place,

Anon!: After so long grief, such nativity!
Goodbye!: After so long grief, such a nativity!

Anon!: We’ll speak with thee at sea.
Goodbye!: We’ll talk to you at sea.

Anon!: Is he of God’s making?
Goodbye!: Is he God’s making?

Anon!: Dry sorrow drinks our blood.
Goodbye!: We drink our blood with dry sorrow.

Anon!: The third part, then, is drunk.
Goodbye!: The third part is drunk.

Anon!: We say that Shore’s wife hath a pretty foot, A cherry lip, a bonny eye, a passing pleasing tongue, And that the queen’s kindred are made gentlefolks.
Goodbye!: We say Shore’s wife has a pretty foot, a cherry lip, a bonny eye, a pleasing tongue, and that the queen’s kindred is made gentlefolks.

Anon!: All comfort that the dark night can afford Be to thy person, noble father-in-law.
Goodbye!: You can give all comfort in the dark night to your person, noble father-in-law.

Anon!: Alack the day!
Goodbye!: Let’s go!

Anon!: Brother, my lord the duke, Stand to and do as we.
Goodbye!: Brother, my lord the duke, stand up and do as we do.

Anon!: Nor you, as we are, loyal.
Goodbye!: You are not loyal, as we are.

Anon!: But, for certain, He cannot buckle his distempered cause Within the belt of rule.
Goodbye!: But he can’t buckle his sane cause in the belt of rule.

Anon!: Madam, sleeps still.
Goodbye!: Madam, still sleeps.

Anon!: The goodness of the night upon you, friends!
Goodbye!: You’re in the dark, friends!

Anon!: Tis done.
Goodbye!: It’s done.

Anon!: He brings you figs.
Goodbye!: He brings you figs.

Anon!: Good countrymen, let me depart alone.
Goodbye!: Good countrymen, let me leave alone.

Anon!: Nay, pursue him now, lest the device take air and taint.
Goodbye!: No, follow him now, so that the device doesn’t take air and taint.

Anon!: Be quiet and depart.
Goodbye!: Be quiet and leave.

Anon!: Who is here so vile that will not love his country?
Goodbye!: Who is here so vile that he won’t love his country?

Anon!: Yes, my conscience, He did us great good.
Goodbye!: Yes, my conscience, he did great good for us.

Anon!: You have good judgment in horsemanship.
Goodbye!: You’re good at horsemanship.

Anon!: Caesar and Lepidus Are in the field.
Goodbye!: Caesar and Lepidus are on the field.

Anon!: No, coz, I rather weep.
Goodbye!: No, coz, I’d rather cry.

Anon!: And, I think, if my breast had not been made of faith, and my heart of steel, She had transformed me to a curtal dog and made me turn i' th' wheel.
Goodbye!: And I think if my breast hadn’t been made of faith and my heart of steel, she would have transformed me into a curty dog and made me turn the wheel.

Anon!: The great contention of the sea and skies Parted our fellowship—   But, hark!
Goodbye!: The great battle of the sea and the skies shook our friendship— But listen!

Anon!: Oh, you are men of stones.
Goodbye!: Oh, you’re men of stones.

Anon!: Farewell.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: Twas a color he never liked.
Goodbye!: He never liked a color.

Anon!: Some dear cause Will in concealment wrap me up awhile.
Goodbye!: Some dear cause will wrap me up in concealment for a while.

Anon!: Goes Fleance with you?
Goodbye!: Is Fleance coming with you?

Anon!: She returns this ring to you, sir.
Goodbye!: She’s sending this ring to you, sir.

Anon!: Send to his brother.
Goodbye!: Send to his brother.

Anon!: Ay, ay.
Goodbye!: Yes, yes.

Anon!: I have much to do But to go hang my head all at one side And sing it like poor Barbary.
Goodbye!: I have to do much to go hang my head all over one side and sing it like poor Barbary.

Anon!: Both our remedies Within thy help and holy physic lies.
Goodbye!: Both our remedies are lies in your help and your holy physicy.

Anon!: Well, what worst?
Goodbye!: Well, what worst thing?

Anon!: Thou troublest me; I am not in the vein.
Goodbye!: You’re upset me, I’m not in the mood.

Anon!: Should I have answered Caius Cassius so?
Goodbye!: Should I have answered Caius Cassius like that?

Anon!: This, by his voice, should be a Montague.—   What, dares the slave Come hither, covered with an antic face, To fleer and scorn at our solemnity?
Goodbye!: This, by his voice, should be a Montague.—What, why would the slave come here, covered with antic face, to flee and scorn our solemnity?

Anon!: This castle hath a pleasant seat.
Goodbye!: This castle has a nice seat.

Anon!: In such a time as this it is not meet That every nice offense should bear his comment.
Goodbye!: In such a time as this, it’s not possible to make a comment on every nice offense.

Anon!: What should a man do but be merry?
Goodbye!: What should a man do only to be cheerful?

Anon!: Well, sir, I thank you.
Goodbye!: Well, sir, thank you.

Anon!: Come, hang them on this line.
Goodbye!: Come on, hang them on this line.

Anon!: Fair lady, by your leave, I come by note to give and to receive.
Goodbye!: Dear lady, I’m coming by your permission to give and receive.

Anon!: Bliss be upon you!
Goodbye!: Bliss be on you!

Anon!: I’ll to him.
Goodbye!: I’ll go to him.

Anon!: Fare thee well, dame.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, sir.

Anon!: Let our officers Have notice what we purpose.
Goodbye!: Let our officers know what we’re doing.

Anon!: This bond doth give thee here no jot of blood.
Goodbye!: This bond doesn’t give you any blood.

Anon!: And he’s gone.
Goodbye!: And he’s gone.

Anon!: More shall they speak, for now I am bent to know, By the worst means, the worst.
Goodbye!: They’ll speak more, because I’m determined to know the worst by the worst means.

Anon!: The moon is down.
Goodbye!: The moon is down.

Anon!: I am glad on ’t.
Goodbye!: I’m glad about it.

Anon!: Save you, friend Cassio!
Goodbye!: Save you, Cassio!

Anon!: So I do, madonna.
Goodbye!: I do, madonna.

Anon!: I must love you and sue to know you better.
Goodbye!: I must love you and sue you to know you better.

Anon!: I should not urge thy duty past thy might.
Goodbye!: I wouldn’t urge you to do your duty beyond your power.

Anon!: What ish my nation?
Goodbye!: What’s my nation?

Anon!: Can Fulvia die?
Goodbye!: Can Fulvia die?

Anon!: My voice is ragged.
Goodbye!: My voice is ragged.

Anon!: I see a voice.
Goodbye!: I see a voice.

Anon!: Pray thee, marry us.
Goodbye!: Please, marry us.

Anon!: True.
Goodbye!: True.

Anon!: If she should make tender of her love, ’tis very possible he’ll scorn it, for the man, as you know all, hath a contemptible spirit.
Goodbye!: If she’s tender about her love, it’s very possible he’ll punish it, because the man, as you know, has a contemptive spirit.

Anon!: But that I do not.
Goodbye!: But I don’t.

Anon!: You would be satisfied?
Goodbye!: You want to be satisfied?

Anon!: If not, adieu.
Goodbye!: If not, please.

Anon!: Belike some noble gentleman that means, Traveling some journey, to repose him here.
Goodbye!: Like some noble gentleman who wants to take him here, traveling some way.

Anon!: Where is this sight?
Goodbye!: Where is this sight?

Anon!: Up in the air, crowned with the golden sun, Saw his heroical seed and smiled to see him Mangle the work of nature and deface The patterns that by God and by French fathers Had twenty years been made.
Goodbye!: He sat up in the air, crowned with the golden sun, saw his heroical seed and smiled to see him mangle nature and deface the patterns that God and French fathers had made for twenty years.

Anon!: And I do think she’s thirty.
Goodbye!: And I think she’s thirty.

Anon!: Arm you, I pray you, to this speedy voyage.
Goodbye!: Please, please, help me to this fast voyage.

Anon!: Nay, but who is it?
Goodbye!: But who is it?

Anon!: You must bear with me.
Goodbye!: You have to bear with me.

Anon!: Ay; and let none enter, lest I break your pate.
Goodbye!: Yes, and don’t let anyone enter, so I won’t break your sword.

Anon!: Tomorrow, as he purposes.
Goodbye!: Tomorrow, as he wants.

Anon!: With lawyers in the vacation, for they sleep between term and term, and then they perceive not how time moves.
Goodbye!: They’re sleeping in the vacation, because they’re both asleep and not aware of how time moves.

Anon!: I would not so much as make water but in a sink-a-pace.
Goodbye!: I wouldn’t want to make water as much as I want to.

Anon!: He shall see none to fear.
Goodbye!: He won’t see any fear.

Anon!: True, my lord.
Goodbye!: Yes, my lord.

Anon!: Men must not walk too late.
Goodbye!: Men shouldn’t walk too late.

Anon!: But that I am forbid To tell the secrets of my prison house, I could a tale unfold whose lightest word Would harrow up thy soul, freeze thy young blood,
Goodbye!: But if I’m forbidden to tell the secrets of my prison house, I could tell you a story that would harrow your soul, freeze your young blood,

Anon!: And, Demetrius, The more you beat me, I will fawn on you.
Goodbye!: And Demetrius, the more you beat me, I’ll fawn on you.

Anon!: Monday!
Goodbye!: Monday!

Anon!: My mother.
Goodbye!: My mother.

Anon!: Good night—but go not to mine uncle’s bed.
Goodbye!: Good night—but don’t go to my uncle’s bed.

Anon!: Did not her kitchen maid rail, taunt, and scorn me?
Goodbye!: Didn’t her kitchenmaid scolde me, taunt me, and scorn me?

Anon!: Nay, stay.
Goodbye!: No, stay.

Anon!: You must think this, look you, that the worm will do his kind.
Goodbye!: You have to think this, look, that the worm will do his kind.

Anon!: I am aweary.
Goodbye!: I’m tired.

Anon!: Or else what follows?
Goodbye!: Or else what’s going on?

Anon!: Shall I lay perjury upon my soul?
Goodbye!: Should I die of perjury?

Anon!: Carry him gently to my fairest chamber And hang it round with all my wanton pictures.
Goodbye!: Take him to my fairest room and hang it around with all my ill-fated pictures.

Anon!: I, thus neglecting worldly ends, all dedicated To closeness and the bettering of my mind With that which, but by being so retired, O'erprized all popular rate, in my false brother Awaked an evil nature.
Goodbye!: I’ve been deprived of all the worldly ends, and I’ve been dedicated to the pursuit of closeness and the betterment of my mind, with the same thing that, only by being so retired, erpr

Anon!: Alas, Malvolio, this is not my writing, Though, I confess, much like the character.
Goodbye!: Malvolio, this is not my writing, though, I confess, I’m much like the character.

Anon!: The thane of Fife had a wife.
Goodbye!: The thane of Fife had a wife.

Anon!: Being unprepared, Our will became the servant to defect, Which else should free have wrought.
Goodbye!: Being unprepared, we became the servant to defect, which else we should have freed.

Anon!: Murder, murder!
Goodbye!: Murder, murder!

Anon!: I have been to seek you.
Goodbye!: I’ve been looking for you.

Anon!: Even here Do we shake hands.
Goodbye!: We’re shaking hands here.

Anon!: But I pray you commend my counterfeiting to him.
Goodbye!: But please tell him I’m counterfeiting.

Anon!: So was I when your Highness took his dukedom.
Goodbye!: I was the one who took your Highness’s dukedom.

Anon!: I must to the barber’s, monsieur, for methinks I am marvelous hairy about the face.
Goodbye!: I’ll go to the barber’s, monsieur, because I think I’m beautiful about the face.

Anon!: The sweeter rest was mine.
Goodbye!: The sweeter rest was mine.

Anon!: I will debate this matter at more leisure And teach your ears to list me with more heed.
Goodbye!: I’ll discuss this more at leisure and teach you to listen to me.

Anon!: What, art thou afraid?
Goodbye!: What, are you afraid?

Anon!: Lo, here upon thy cheek the stain doth sit Of an old tear that is not washed off yet.
Goodbye!: Oh, on your cheek, the stain is a tear that hasn’t been washed off yet.

Anon!: No, ’twas the vane on the house.
Goodbye!: No, it was the vane on the house.

Anon!: Oh, he’s a lovely gentleman.
Goodbye!: Oh, he’s a lovely gentleman.

Anon!: By this hand, I’ll have that gown.
Goodbye!: I’ll wear that gown with this hand.

Anon!: I have yet Room for six scotches more.
Goodbye!: I have room for six scotches more.

Anon!: Modo he’s called, and Mahu.
Goodbye!: Modo he’s called, and Mahu.

Anon!: Friends to this ground.
Goodbye!: Friends to this ground.

Anon!: Sure, her offense Must be of such unnatural degree That monsters it (or your fore-vouched affection Fall into taint), which to believe of her Must be a faith that reason without miracle Could never plant in me.
Goodbye!: Sure, her offense must be so unnatural that monsters it (or your sane affections fall into a trap), which to believe in her must be a faith that no miracle could ever bring me.

Anon!: Nothing is good, I see, without respect.
Goodbye!: Nothing is good, I see, without respect.

Anon!: Give me your neaf, Monsieur Mustardseed.
Goodbye!: Give me your neaf, Monsieur Mustardseed.

Anon!: In such a night Did pretty Jessica, like a little shrew, Slander her love, and he forgave it her.
Goodbye!: In such a night, pretty Jessica, like a little shrew, slander her love, and he forgave it for her.

Anon!: Stands he or sits he?
Goodbye!: Is he standing or sitting?

Anon!: You swore to me when I did give it you That you would wear it till your hour of death, And that it should lie with you in your grave.
Goodbye!: You swore to me when I gave it to you that you would wear it until you died, and that it should lie with you in your grave.

Anon!: Did Cicero say anything?
Goodbye!: Did Cicero say anything?

Anon!: Leave you!
Goodbye!: Leave you alone!

Anon!: Happy were England would this virtuous prince Take on his grave the sovereignty thereof.
Goodbye!: If England were happy, this virtuous prince would take on his grave the sovereignty of his grave.

Anon!: The cockerel.
Goodbye!: The cockerel.

Anon!: You are, and do not know ’t.
Goodbye!: You are, and you don’t know it.

Anon!: Some say the Earth Was feverous and did shake.
Goodbye!: Some say the Earth was feverous and shaken.

Anon!: Come, “The croaking raven doth bellow for revenge—”
Goodbye!: Come on, “The croaking raven bellows for revenge—”

Anon!: I was, but I do find more pain in banishment Than death can yield me here by my abode.
Goodbye!: I was, but I find more pain in banishment than death can give me here by my abode.

Anon!: I have a file Of all the gentry.
Goodbye!: I have a file of all the gentry.

Anon!: I go, my lord.
Goodbye!: I’m going, my lord.

Anon!: If Echo were as fleet, I would esteem him worth a dozen such.
Goodbye!: If Echo were as fleet as Echo, I’d be a good value for a dozen such.

Anon!: Truly, the tree yields bad fruit.
Goodbye!: The tree is a bad fruit.

Anon!: Give every man thy ear but few thy voice.
Goodbye!: Give every man your ear only a few words.

Anon!: He grows worse and worse.
Goodbye!: He’s getting worse and worse.

Anon!: Life and these lips have long been separated.
Goodbye!: Life and these lips have been separated for a long time.

Anon!: Here, Signior Tranio, This bird you aimed at, though you hit her not.— Therefore a health to all that shot and missed.
Goodbye!: Here, Signior Tranio, you aimed at this bird, though you didn’t hit her.—So, it’s a good thing to all those who shot and missed.

Anon!: Honest Nurse, farewell.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, Nurse.

Anon!: The most infectious pestilence upon thee!
Goodbye!: The most infectious pestilence on you!

Anon!: Cousin of Buckingham, a word with you.
Goodbye!: Cousin of Buckingham, let’s talk to you.

Anon!: The duke my father loved his father dearly.
Goodbye!: The duke, my father, loved his father very much.

Anon!: We thank your Honor.
Goodbye!: We thank your Honor.

Anon!: If I myself, there is no hour so fit As Caesar’s death’s hour, nor no instrument Of half that worth as those your swords, made rich With the most noble blood of all this world.
Goodbye!: If I myself, there’s no hour as good as Caesar’s death hour, or half that worth as your swords, made rich with the most noble blood of all this world.

Anon!: In this, though I cannot be said to be a flattering honest man, it must not be denied but I am a plain-dealing villain.
Goodbye!: I’m a slanderous, honest man, but I can’t be denied that I’m a slanderous villain.

Anon!: My lord, what is your will?
Goodbye!: My lord, what will you do?

Anon!: Let’s follow.
Goodbye!: Let’s follow them.

Anon!: Give me a torch.
Goodbye!: Give me a torch.

Anon!: Commend me to thy mistress.
Goodbye!: Give my praise to your mistress.

Anon!: You say very true, scald knave, when God’s will is.
Goodbye!: You’re very true, scald king, when God’s will is.

Anon!: So art thou to revenge when thou shalt hear.
Goodbye!: You’re going to revenge when you hear them.

Anon!: No Thisbe do I see.
Goodbye!: No Thisbe I see.

Anon!: Pardon me.
Goodbye!: Pardon me.

Anon!: Ah keeper, keeper, I have done those things, That now give evidence against my soul, For Edward’s sake, and see how he requites me.— O God, if my deep prayers cannot appease thee, But thou wilt be avenged on my misdeeds, Yet execute thy wrath in me alone!
Goodbye!: Oh, God, if my prayers can’t appease you, but you’ll be avenged on my misdeeds, but you’ll be avenged on my misdeeds!

Anon!: So Caesar may.
Goodbye!: So Caesar may.

Anon!: Once more, Cesario, Get thee to yond same sovereign cruelty.
Goodbye!: Once again, Cesario, get out of the same cruelty that is committed by the sovereigns.

Anon!: Come, mistress Kate, I’ll bear you company.
Goodbye!: Come on, mistress Kate, I’ll keep you safe.

Anon!: This is an aspic’s trail, and these fig leaves Have slime upon them, such as th’ aspic leaves Upon the caves of Nile.
Goodbye!: This is an aspic’s trail, and these fig leaves have slimed on them, like the aspic leaves on the caves of the Nile.

Anon!: What manner of man?
Goodbye!: What kind of man are you?

Anon!: Help, help, O, help!
Goodbye!: Help, help, Oh, help!

Anon!: Wouldst thou not be glad to have the niggardly rascally sheep-biter come by some notable shame?
Goodbye!: Wouldn’t you be glad to see the niggardly rascally sheep-biter come by some notable shame?

Anon!: Prithee, friend, Pour out the pack of matter to mine ear, The good and bad together.
Goodbye!: Please, friend, listen to me, the good and bad together.

Anon!: Up, princes, and, with spirit of honor edged More sharper than your swords, hie to the field: Charles Delabreth, High Constable of France; You dukes of Orléans, Bourbon, and of Berri, Alençon, Brabant, Bar, and Burgundy; Jacques Chatillon, Rambures, Vaudemont, Beaumont, Grandpré, Roussi, and Faulconbridge, Foix, Lestrale, Bouciqualt, and Charolois; High dukes, great princes, barons, lords, and knights, For your great seats now quit you of great shames.
Goodbye!: You dukes of Orléans, Bourbon, Berri, Alençon, Brabant, Bar, and Burgundy, Jacques Chatillon, Rambures, Vaudemont, Beaumont, Grandpré

Anon!: I cry you mercy.
Goodbye!: I’m crying for mercy.

Anon!: Then I will give you the serving creature.
Goodbye!: Then I’ll give you the serving creature.

Anon!: Does any here know me?
Goodbye!: Does anyone here know me?

Anon!: I fear it is too choleric a meat.
Goodbye!: I’m afraid it’s too choleric.

Anon!: Tis very strange.
Goodbye!: It’s very strange.

Anon!: But first I will release the fairy queen.
Goodbye!: But first I’ll release the fairy queen.

Anon!: Yea, dost thou jeer and flout me in the teeth?
Goodbye!: Yes, do you scolde and scolde me in the teeth?

Anon!: Up to the breach, you dogs!
Goodbye!: Up to the breach, you dogs!

Anon!: Thy half o' th' kingdom hast thou not forgot, Wherein I thee endowed.
Goodbye!: You’ve never forgotten your half of your kingdom, where I have gotten you.

Anon!: A more unhappy lady, If this division chance, ne’er stood between, Praying for both parts.
Goodbye!: A more unhappy lady, if this division is possible, she’ll be begging for both of them.

Anon!: My lord, he’s going to his mother’s closet.
Goodbye!: My lord, he’s going to his mother’s closet.

Anon!: Are they married, think you?
Goodbye!: Are they married, don’t you think?

Anon!: Well, bawd I’ll turn, And something lean to cutpurse of quick hand.
Goodbye!: Well, I’ll turn and have something lean to cut the hand out.

Anon!: Sir Toby will be sworn that I am no fox, but he will not pass his word for two pence that you are no fool.
Goodbye!: Sir Toby will be sworn that I’m not a fox, but he won’t say two pence that you’re not a fool.

Anon!: Fire!
Goodbye!: Fire!

Anon!: Only I here importune death awhile, until Of many thousand kisses the poor last I lay upon thy lips.
Goodbye!: I’ll wait for a moment to die, until I’ve gotten over many thousand kisses from the poor.

Anon!: A spirit, a spirit.
Goodbye!: A spirit, a spirit.

Anon!: Past all expressing.
Goodbye!: All of us were talking.

Anon!: Canst thou blame him?
Goodbye!: Can you blame him?

Anon!: Here comes newer comfort.
Goodbye!: Here comes more comfort.

Anon!: For Edward, for my brother, for his sake.
Goodbye!: For Edward, for my brother, for his sake.

Anon!: In faith, they are as true of heart as we.
Goodbye!: They’re as heartfelt as we are.

Anon!: What further woe conspires against mine age?
Goodbye!: What further troubles do you have to face against me?

Anon!: Then there is the County Palatine.
Goodbye!: Then there’s the County Palatine.

Anon!: He has brave utensils—for so he calls them— Which when he has a house, he’ll deck withal.
Goodbye!: He has brave utensils—for he calls them—that he’ll be able to carry when he’s in a house.

Anon!: For his bounty, There was no winter in ’t, an autumn ’twas That grew the more by reaping.
Goodbye!: For his bounty, there wasn’t any winter in it, and an autumn was the one that grew more by reaping.

Anon!: Then she is well, and nothing can be ill.
Goodbye!: Then she’s well, and nothing can be bad.

Anon!: And I’ll still stay, to have thee still forget, Forgetting any other home but this.
Goodbye!: And I’ll stay, to have you forget, forgeing any other home except this.

Anon!: As mine on hers, so hers is set on mine, And all combined, save what thou must combine By holy marriage.
Goodbye!: As mine on her, as mine on her, as mine on hers, and all together, except what you must combine by holy marriage.

Anon!: How answer you that?
Goodbye!: How do you respond to that?

Anon!: I have locked the letter in my closet.
Goodbye!: I’ve locked the letter in my closet.

Anon!: How that might change his nature, there’s the question.
Goodbye!: What could change his nature, there’s the question.

Anon!: Begin these woodbirds but to couple now?
Goodbye!: Do you want to start a relationship with these birds only now?

Anon!: Was that mine?
Goodbye!: Was that my?

Anon!: What, are you mad?
Goodbye!: Are you crazy?

Anon!: That villain cousin would have killed my husband.
Goodbye!: That villain’s cousin who would have killed my husband.

Anon!: Give them way till he take leave, and presently after him.
Goodbye!: Give them the way until he leaves, and then after him.

Anon!: I am glad to see you.
Goodbye!: I’m glad to see you.

Anon!: I’ll tell thee more of this another time.
Goodbye!: I’ll tell you more about this another time.

Anon!: Gracious England hath Lent us good Siward and ten thousand men; An older and a better soldier none That Christendom gives out.
Goodbye!: Gracious England has Lent us good Siward and ten thousand men; an older and better soldier than Christendom gives out.

Anon!: Come, shall we fall to work?
Goodbye!: Come on, should we fall to work?

Anon!: Keep your word, Silvius, that you’ll marry her If she refuse me.
Goodbye!: Keep your word, Silvius, that you’ll marry her if she refuses me.

Anon!: Then take him up and manage well the jest.
Goodbye!: Then take him up and manage the sneeze.

Anon!: Till then, lead thou first.
Goodbye!: So, lead the first step.

Anon!: What is the opinion of Pythagoras concerning wildfowl?
Goodbye!: What do Pythagoras think about wildfowl?

Anon!: What noise is this?—Not dead?
Goodbye!: What’s this noise?—Not dead?

Anon!: Where dost thou hide thy head?
Goodbye!: Where are you hiding your head?

Anon!: I know him; he wears a lock.
Goodbye!: I know him, he’s wearing a lock.

Anon!: I am come To bid my king and master aye good night.
Goodbye!: I’m coming to tell my king and master to have a good night.

Anon!: Look, here she comes.
Goodbye!: Look, here she comes.

Anon!: No matter.
Goodbye!: No matter.

Anon!: You shall have letters from me to my son In your behalf, to meet you on the way.
Goodbye!: You’ll have letters from me to my son in your behalf, to meet you on the way.

Anon!: By sea, what else?
Goodbye!: What else?

Anon!: Vengeance, plague, death, confusion!
Goodbye!: Vengeance, plague, death, confusion!

Anon!: Relent, and save your souls.
Goodbye!: Relent, and save your souls.

Anon!: Infect her beauty, You fen-sucked fogs drawn by the powerful sun, To fall and blister!
Goodbye!: Infect her beauty, you fen-sucked fog drawn by the powerful sun to fall and blister!

Anon!: Have I not heard the sea, puffed up with winds, Rage like an angry boar chafèd with sweat?
Goodbye!: Have I heard the sea puffed up with winds, raging like a snoring boar chafed with sweat?

Anon!: What, ho!
Goodbye!: Oh, what!

Anon!: By Hercules, I think I am i’ th’ right.
Goodbye!: By Hercules, I think I’m right.

Anon!: Yet once again proclaim it publicly, If any friend will pay the sum for him, He shall not die; so much we tender him.
Goodbye!: But once again, publicly proclaim it, if any friend will pay the sum for him, he won’t die.

Anon!: Basting.
Goodbye!: Basting.

Anon!: What, art thou hurt?
Goodbye!: What, are you hurt?

Anon!: How yet resolves the governor of the town?
Goodbye!: How is the governor of the town still doing?

Anon!: Our time does call upon ’s.
Goodbye!: Our time is right now.

Anon!: Lord, what fools these mortals be!
Goodbye!: Lord, what fools these mortals are!

Anon!: And lovers' absent hours More tedious than the dial eightscore times!
Goodbye!: And lovers’ absences are more tedious than the dial eightscore times!

Anon!: And you.
Goodbye!: And you.

Anon!: Then ’tis he: the rest That are within the note of expectation Already are i' th' court.
Goodbye!: Then he’s dead: the rest of the people who are already in the midst of the expectation are already in the court.

Anon!: I’ll write to him a very taunting letter, And thou shalt bear it.
Goodbye!: I’ll write to him a very taunting letter, and you’ll bear it.

Anon!: How now, masters?
Goodbye!: What’s going on, masters?

Anon!: And what hope is that, I pray thee?
Goodbye!: And what hope is that, please?

Anon!: I pause for a reply.
Goodbye!: I’ll wait for a reply.

Anon!: Who is ’t that cried?
Goodbye!: Who’s crying?

Anon!: Now I’ll tell you without asking.
Goodbye!: Now I’ll tell you without asking.

Anon!: Made you my guardians, my depositaries, But kept a reservation to be followed With such a number.
Goodbye!: I made you my guardians, my guardians, but I kept a reservation to follow with such a number.

Anon!: Let us sit and mock the good housewife Fortune from her wheel, that her gifts may henceforth be bestowed equally.
Goodbye!: Let’s sit and mock the good housewife Fortune from her wheel so that her gifts can be given equally.

Anon!: Come on, gentle my lord, Sleek o'er your rugged looks.
Goodbye!: Come on, my lord, look good and look good.

Anon!: Sin from thy lips?
Goodbye!: Sin from your lips?

Anon!: It was, as I have seen it in his life, A sable silvered.
Goodbye!: It was, as I’ve seen it in his life, a sable silvered sword.

Anon!: Horatio, thou art e'en as just a man As e'er my conversation coped withal.
Goodbye!: Horatio, you’re just as a man as I’ve been.

Anon!: This villain of mine comes under the prediction—there’s son against father.
Goodbye!: This villain of mine is under the prediction—there’s son against father.

Anon!: Though all things foul would wear the brows of grace, Yet grace must still look so.
Goodbye!: Even though all things foul would wear the brows of grace, grace must look like that.

Anon!: The consequence is, then, thy jealous fits Have scared thy husband from the use of wits.
Goodbye!: Then you’ve scared your husband from using wits.

Anon!: He looks gentler than he did.
Goodbye!: He looks gentler than he did.

Anon!: Tis cowardly and womanish.
Goodbye!: It’s cowardly and womanish.

Anon!: Well, as you guess?
Goodbye!: Well, you guess?

Anon!: But fare you well.
Goodbye!: But goodbye.

Anon!: Is there any man has rebused your Worship?
Goodbye!: Is there any man who has rebused your Worship?

Anon!: I have no ambition To see a goodlier man.
Goodbye!: I don’t want to see a better man.

Anon!: If with myself I hold intelligence Or have acquaintance with mine own desires, If that I do not dream or be not frantic— As I do trust I am not—then, dear uncle, Never so much as in a thought unborn Did I offend your Highness.
Goodbye!: If I have intelligence or know my own desires, if I don’t dream or be frantic—I don’t trust I am—and I’m not, dear uncle, I’ve never been as intelligent as I

Anon!: The weakest kind of fruit Drops earliest to the ground, and so let me.
Goodbye!: The weakest fruit drops to the ground early, and so let me.

Anon!: But he hath chid me hence and threatened me To strike me, spurn me—nay, to kill me too.
Goodbye!: But he has pushed me away and threatened me to strike me, spurn me—no, to kill me too.

Anon!: Pitiful sight!
Goodbye!: A pitiful sight!

Anon!: The better for thy friends.
Goodbye!: The better for your friends.

Anon!: Methinks, mistress, you should have little reason for that.
Goodbye!: I think you should have little reason for that, my mistress.

Anon!: For the heavens, he shows me where the bachelors sit, and there live we as merry as the day is long.
Goodbye!: For the heavens, he shows me where the bachelors sit, and there live we as merry as the day is long.

Anon!: Fill, Lucius, till the wine o'erswell the cup.
Goodbye!: Fill the cup, Lucius, until the wine o'clock.

Anon!: What’s this?
Goodbye!: What’s this?

Anon!: His answer was, the people were not used To be spoke to but by the recorder.
Goodbye!: He said that the people were not used to speak to only by the recorder.

Anon!: Sitting on a bank, Weeping again the king my father’s wrack, This music crept by me upon the waters, Allaying both their fury and my passion With its sweet air.
Goodbye!: Sitting on a bank, weeping the king again in my father’s wrack, this music screamed by me on the waters, blaming both my fury and my passion with its

Anon!: Faith, sir, so-so.
Goodbye!: Yes, sir, so-so.

Anon!: I did hear him groan, Ay, and that tongue of his that bade the Romans Mark him and write his speeches in their books— “Alas,” it cried, “give me some drink, Titinius,” As a sick girl.
Goodbye!: I heard him groaning, yes, and the tongue of his that told the Romans to mark him and write his speeches in their books— “Alas,” it cried, “give me some drink, Titi

Anon!: When Jacob grazed his uncle Laban’s sheep— This Jacob from our holy Abram was, As his wise mother wrought in his behalf, The third possessor, ay, he was the third— And what of him?
Goodbye!: Jacob grazed his uncle Laban’s sheep when Jacob grazed— Jacob from our holy Abram was, as his wise mother wrought in his behalf, the third possessor, yes, he was the third

Anon!: How sweet is love itself possessed When but love’s shadows are so rich in joy!
Goodbye!: How sweet is love itself when only love’s shadows are so rich in joy!

Anon!: Come forth, thou fearful man.
Goodbye!: Come out, you fearful man.

Anon!: How doth the prince?
Goodbye!: How is the prince?

Anon!: Is there no respect of place, persons, nor time in you?
Goodbye!: Isn’t there any respect for you, people, or time?

Anon!: Oh, there has been much throwing about of brains.
Goodbye!: Oh, there’s been a lot of slurping of brains.

Anon!: I cannot find it.
Goodbye!: I can’t find it.

Anon!: Make no compare Between that love a woman can bear me And that I owe Olivia.
Goodbye!: Don’t compare that love a woman can bear me with my love for Olivia.

Anon!: O most unhappy day!
Goodbye!: Oh, what a sad day!

Anon!: Well then, Legitimate Edgar, I must have your land.
Goodbye!: Well then, Legitimate Edgar, I have to have your land.

Anon!: Come from thy ward, For I can here disarm thee with this stick And make thy weapon drop.
Goodbye!: Come from your ward, because I can disarm you with this stick and make your weapon drop.

Anon!: How much more elder art thou than thy looks!
Goodbye!: You’re so much older than you look!

Anon!: Good Father, how foolish are our minds!
Goodbye!: Good Father, how foolish we are!

Anon!: And therefore will come.
Goodbye!: So I’ll come.

Anon!: Here he comes.
Goodbye!: Here he comes.

Anon!: Who keeps her company?
Goodbye!: Who’s keeping her company?

Anon!: Octavia weeps To part from Rome.
Goodbye!: Octavia weeps to take part from Rome.

Anon!: I am not sick if Brutus have in hand Any exploit worthy the name of honor.
Goodbye!: I’m not sick if Brutus has any exploit worthy of the name of honor.

Anon!: No, It is thyself, mine own self’s better part, Mine eye’s clear eye, my dear heart’s dearer heart, My food, my fortune, and my sweet hope’s aim, My sole earth’s heaven, and my heaven’s claim.
Goodbye!: No, it’s yours, my self’s better part, my eyes’ clear eye, my dear heart’s dearer heart, my food, my fortune, and my sweet hope’s aim, my earth’s heaven

Anon!: Tis well I am found by you.
Goodbye!: It’s good you found me.

Anon!: Oh, do not wish one more!
Goodbye!: Oh, don’t wish one more!

Anon!: Sir John Falstaff.
Goodbye!: Sir John Falstaff.

Anon!: And this our life, exempt from public haunt, Finds tongues in trees, books in the running brooks, Sermons in stones, and good in everything.
Goodbye!: And this life, exempt from public haunts, finds tongues in trees, books in the running brooks, Sermons in stones, and good in everything.

Anon!: To this chair bind him.—Villain, thou shalt find— By the kind gods, ’tis most ignobly done To pluck me by the beard.
Goodbye!: To this chair, bind him.—Villain, you’ll find— By the kind gods, it’s most ignobly done to pluck me by the beard.

Anon!: God make your Majesty joyful, as you have been.
Goodbye!: God make your Majesty joyful, as you have been.

Anon!: Patience, gentle Audrey.
Goodbye!: Be calm, gentle Audrey.

Anon!: Under the earth.
Goodbye!: Under the earth.

Anon!: Though his bark cannot be lost, Yet it shall be tempest-tossed.
Goodbye!: Though his bark can’t be lost, it will be tossed in the mud.

Anon!: I pray you mar no more trees with writing love songs in their barks.
Goodbye!: Please don’t leave any more trees with writing love songs in their barks.

Anon!: Princes have but their titles for their glories, An outward honor for an inward toil,
Goodbye!: Princes have only their titles for their glories, an honor for an inward toil.

Anon!: Ay, better than him I am before knows me.
Goodbye!: Yes, I’m better than him, who knows me.

Anon!: Foul words is but foul wind, and foul wind is but foul breath, and foul breath is noisome.
Goodbye!: Foul words are only foul, and foul words are only foul breath, and foul breath is naive.

Anon!: Where is he now?
Goodbye!: Where is he now?

Anon!: How do you mean, removing of him?
Goodbye!: What do you mean, remove him?

Anon!: Tush, tush, man, never fleer and jest at me.
Goodbye!: Oh, hey, man, never flee and jest at me.

Anon!: Change you color?
Goodbye!: Do you change your color?

Anon!: Interrupt the monster one word further, and, by this hand, I’ll turn my mercy out o' doors and make a stockfish of thee.
Goodbye!: I’ll turn my mercy out of the door and make a stockfish of you.

Anon!: Approach, Sir Andrew.
Goodbye!: Take me, Sir Andrew.

Anon!: It is to be all made of fantasy, All made of passion and all made of wishes, All adoration, duty, and observance, All humbleness, all patience and impatience, All purity, all trial, all observance, And so am I for Phoebe.
Goodbye!: It’s to be all made of fantasy, all made of passion and all made of wishes, all adoration, duty, and respect, all humbleness, all patience and impatience, all purity, all trial, all respect

Anon!: Thou hadst, and more, Miranda.
Goodbye!: You had, and more, Miranda.

Anon!: I pray you, leave me.
Goodbye!: Please leave me.

Anon!: Yes, one, and in this manner.
Goodbye!: Yes, one, and in this way.

Anon!: Then cursed she Hastings.
Goodbye!: Then she cursed Hastings.

Anon!: What, all my pretty chickens and their dam At one fell swoop?
Goodbye!: What, all my pretty chickens and their dams were swooping at one fell swoop?

Anon!: I do fear, the people Choose Caesar for their king.
Goodbye!: I’m afraid the people choose Caesar for their king.

Anon!: I eat the air, promise-crammed.
Goodbye!: I eat the air, I’m promised.

Anon!: Alas, good gentleman!
Goodbye!: Oh, good gentleman!

Anon!: Early tomorrow will we rise and hence.
Goodbye!: We’ll rise and leave early tomorrow.

Anon!: You cannot revel into dukedoms there.
Goodbye!: You can’t revel in dukedoms here.

Anon!: You cannot better be employed, Bassanio, Than to live still and write mine epitaph.
Goodbye!: Bassanio, you can’t be better employed than to live still and write my epitaph.

Anon!: Thou art a soldier only.
Goodbye!: You’re only a soldier.

Anon!: And a good soldier too, lady.
Goodbye!: And a good soldier too, lady.

Anon!: Then follow me and give me audience, friends.
Goodbye!: Then follow me and give me a crowd, friends.

Anon!: As he was valiant, I honor him.
Goodbye!: As he was brave, I honor him.

Anon!: He is a god and knows What is most right.
Goodbye!: He’s a god and knows what’s right.

Anon!: That you should here repent you, The actors are at hand, and by their show You shall know all that you are like to know.
Goodbye!: You should be punished here, the actors are at hand, and you’ll know everything you’re like to know.

Anon!: Peter!
Goodbye!: Peter!

Anon!: Think on Lord Hastings.
Goodbye!: Think about Lord Hastings.

Anon!: Kneel not, gentle Portia.
Goodbye!: Don’t scold me, Portia.

Anon!: The sun doth gild our armor.
Goodbye!: The sun gilds our armor.

Anon!: Moody?
Goodbye!: Moody?

Anon!: God send you, sir, a speedy infirmity, for the better increasing your folly!
Goodbye!: God send you a quick infirmity, for the better to increase your folly!

Anon!: Why, for that too.
Goodbye!: Well, for that too.

Anon!: Ah, good Demetrius, wilt thou give him me?
Goodbye!: Ah, good Demetrius, will you give him me?

Anon!: I will not give my part of this sport for a pension of thousands to be paid from the Sophy.
Goodbye!: I won’t give my part of this sport for a pension of thousands to be paid from the Sophy.

Anon!: Duke Frederick, hearing how that every day Men of great worth resorted to this forest, Addressed a mighty power, which were on foot In his own conduct, purposely to take His brother here and put him to the sword.
Goodbye!: Duke Frederick, hearing how men of great worth retreated to this forest every day, addressed a powerful power, who were on foot in his own way, to take his brother here and put him to the sword.

Anon!: Front to front Bring thou this fiend of Scotland and myself.
Goodbye!: Bring this fiend of Scotland and myself to front.

Anon!: Had our general Been what he knew himself, it had gone well.
Goodbye!: If our general had been what he knew himself, it would have been good.

Anon!: The sun was not so true unto the day As he to me.
Goodbye!: The sun was not as true to the day as it was to me.

Anon!: And cries aloud, “Tarry, my cousin Suffolk.
Goodbye!: And he cries, “Tarry, my cousin Suffolk.

Anon!: No.
Goodbye!: No.

Anon!: Harp not on that string, madam; that is past.
Goodbye!: Don’t listen to that string, madam.

Anon!: The time has been my senses would have cooled To hear a night-shriek, and my fell of hair Would at a dismal treatise rouse and stir As life were in ’t.
Goodbye!: I’d rather hear a nightshriek, and my hair would rouse and stir as much as life would be.

Anon!: No child but Hero; she’s his only heir.
Goodbye!: Hero is his only child.

Anon!: Good night, good brother.
Goodbye!: Good night, good brother.

Anon!: Now, Cinna.—Now, Metellus.—What, Trebonius, I have an hour’s talk in store for you.
Goodbye!: Now, Cinna.—Now, Metellus.—What, Trebonius, I have an hour to talk about you.

Anon!: O, no!
Goodbye!: Oh, no!

Anon!: Pluck them asunder.
Goodbye!: Pluck them asunder.

Anon!: Tis torture and not mercy.
Goodbye!: It’s torture and not mercy.

Anon!: There’s a strong fellow, Menas.
Goodbye!: There’s a strong fellow, Menas.

Anon!: I have a venturous fairy that shall seek The squirrel’s hoard and fetch thee new nuts.
Goodbye!: I have a fairy who will hunt for the squirrel’s hoard and fetch you new nuts.

Anon!: But I hope you have no intent to turn husband, have you?
Goodbye!: But I hope you don’t want to turn your husband into a husband, have you?

Anon!: Oh well done!
Goodbye!: Oh, well done!

Anon!: How shall we beguile The lazy time if not with some delight?
Goodbye!: How can we beguiled by the lazy time if not with some delight?

Anon!: The venom clamors of a jealous woman Poisons more deadly than a mad dog’s tooth.
Goodbye!: The venom clamors of a jealous woman are deadly than a mad dog’s tooth.

Anon!: Think on thy sins.
Goodbye!: Think about your sins.

Anon!: Where hast thou been, my heart?
Goodbye!: Where have you been, my heart?

Anon!: What is thy name?
Goodbye!: What’s your name?

Anon!: The duke’s to blame in this.
Goodbye!: The duke’s to blame in this.

Anon!: Speak not.
Goodbye!: Don’t say anything.

Anon!: Sir, will you, with those infirmities she owes— Unfriended, new adopted to our hate, Dowered with our curse and strangered with our oath— Take her or leave her?
Goodbye!: Sir, will you take her or leave her with those infirmities she owes—unfriended, adopted to our hatred, beaten with our curse and strangely oath—with her?

Anon!: Oh, let their bodies follow, my dear liege, With blood and sword and fire to win your right, In aid whereof we of the spiritualty Will raise your Highness such a mighty sum As never did the clergy at one time Bring in to any of your ancestors.
Goodbye!: Oh, let their bodies follow, my dear liege, with blood and sword and fire to win your right, and we will raise your Highness as much as the clergy brought in to any of your ancestors at once.

Anon!: That’s certain.
Goodbye!: That’s true.

Anon!: You peers, continue this united league.
Goodbye!: You, friends, continue this united league.

Anon!: What need you five and twenty, ten, or five To follow in a house where twice so many Have a command to tend you?
Goodbye!: What do you need to be five and twenty, ten or five to follow in a house where twice as many people have a command to take care of you?

Anon!: I know you could not lack, I am certain on ’t, Very necessity of this thought, that I, Your partner in the cause ’gainst which he fought, Could not with graceful eyes attend those wars Which fronted mine own peace.
Goodbye!: I know you couldn’t be so confident about this, I’m sure, that I, your partner in the cause he fought, couldn’t attend the wars that fronted me.

Anon!: Here comes my man.
Goodbye!: Here comes my man.

Anon!: Away!
Goodbye!: Go away!

Anon!: What is thy news then?
Goodbye!: What’s your news then?

Anon!: Do you not remember, lady, in your father’s time a Venetian, a scholar and a soldier, that came hither in company of the Marquess of Montferrat?
Goodbye!: Don’t you remember, lady, that in your father’s time you were a Venetian, a scholar and a soldier who came here in the company of the Marquess of Montferrat?

Anon!: Thy wild acts denote The unreasonable fury of a beast.
Goodbye!: Your wild actions are like the fury of a beast.

Anon!: Oh, the cry did knock Against my very heart!
Goodbye!: Oh, the cry knocked on my heart!

Anon!: Oh, God 'i' good e'en.
Goodbye!: Oh, God 'i’m good.

Anon!: Mine eyes do itch, Doth that bode weeping?
Goodbye!: I’m itching, is that a good sign of weeping?

Anon!: Take thy face hence.
Goodbye!: Take your face away.

Anon!: I know her answer.
Goodbye!: I know her answer.

Anon!: That “banishèd,” that one word “banishèd” Hath slain ten thousand Tybalts.
Goodbye!: That banishment, that one word banishment, has killed ten thousand Tybalts.

Anon!: Why should you fall into so deep an O?
Goodbye!: Why should you fall into such a deep hole?

Anon!: They have dispatched with Pompey; he is gone.
Goodbye!: They’ve dispatched Pompey, and Pompey is gone.

Anon!: I shall obey you.
Goodbye!: I’ll obey you.

Anon!: I dare avouch it, sir.
Goodbye!: I’m going to say that, sir.

Anon!: Run to the Capulets.
Goodbye!: Run to the Capulets.

Anon!: If in thy wisdom thou canst give no help, Do thou but call my resolution wise, And with this knife I’ll help it presently.
Goodbye!: If you can’t give any help, then you can’t help but call me wise, and I’ll help it with this knife.

Anon!: He’s a traitor.
Goodbye!: He’s a traitor.

Anon!: Thou shalt have nothing but the forfeiture To be so taken at thy peril, Jew.
Goodbye!: You’ll have nothing but the forfeiture to be taken at your risk, Jew.

Anon!: Am I not stayed for?
Goodbye!: Isn’t that what I’m waiting for?

Anon!: Dido and her Aeneas shall want troops, And all the haunt be ours.—Come, Eros, Eros!
Goodbye!: Dido and her Aeneas will want troops, and all the haunts will be ours.—Come, Eros, Eros!

Anon!: May you stead me?
Goodbye!: Can you help me?

Anon!: Thus was I, sleeping, by a brother’s hand Of life, of crown, of queen at once dispatched, Cut off even in the blossoms of my sin,
Goodbye!: I was asleep, by a brother’s hand, of life, of crown, of queen, and cut off my sins in the blossoms.

Anon!: As it ebbs, the seedsman Upon the slime and ooze scatters his grain, And shortly comes to harvest.
Goodbye!: As it ebbs, the seedman oozes on the slime and scatters his grain, and soon comes to harvest.

Anon!: Is this true?
Goodbye!: Is this true?

Anon!: My noble girls!
Goodbye!: My noble girls!

Anon!: And I have met a gentleman Hath promised me to help me to another, A fine musician to instruct our mistress.
Goodbye!: And I’ve met a gentleman who promised me to help me to another musician, who instructed our mistress.

Anon!: Naked in bed, Iago, and not mean harm!
Goodbye!: I’m asleep, Iago, and don’t mean anything!

Anon!: About a hoop of gold, a paltry ring That she did give me, whose posy was For all the world like cutler’s poetry Upon a knife, “Love me and leave me not.” What talk you of the posy or the value?
Goodbye!: She gave me a ring of gold, a paltry ring that she gave me, whose posy was for all the world like a knife’s poetry, “Love me and don’t leave me.”

Anon!: I had as lief be wooed of a snail.
Goodbye!: I had to be wooed by a snail.

Anon!: We have done our course.
Goodbye!: We’ve done our job.

Anon!: Only I say Things have been strangely borne.
Goodbye!: Only I’m saying things have been borne strangely.

Anon!: Now art thou my lieutenant.
Goodbye!: Now you’re my lieutenant.

Anon!: Did you confer with him?
Goodbye!: Did you talk to him?

Anon!: O my brother’s child!
Goodbye!: Oh, my brother’s child!

Anon!: God mark thee to his grace!
Goodbye!: God bless you to his grace!

Anon!: Hie thee, gentle Jew.
Goodbye!: Hie, gentle Jew.

Anon!: Nay, I’ll ne'er believe a madman till I see his brains.
Goodbye!: No, I’ll never believe a madman until I see his brains.

Anon!: No, we’ll reason with him.
Goodbye!: No, we’ll have to be adamant with him.

Anon!: Mean you his majesty?
Goodbye!: Do you mean his majesty?

Anon!: I am the greatest, able to do least, Yet most suspected, as the time and place Doth make against me, of this direful murder.
Goodbye!: I’m the greatest, capable of the least, but I’ve been suspected, as time and place as I am against me, of this terrible murder.

Anon!: Did this in Caesar seem ambitious?
Goodbye!: Did this in Caesar seem ambitious?

Anon!: Although I hate her, I’ll not harm her so.
Goodbye!: Although I hate her, I won’t harm her.

Anon!: Where hast thou been, sister?
Goodbye!: Where have you been, sister?

Anon!: What you would have I’ll stay to know at your abandoned cave.
Goodbye!: I’ll stay here to see what you want in your cave.

Anon!: That is the very defect of the matter, sir.
Goodbye!: That’s the reason for this, sir.

Anon!: Three or four wenches where I stood cried, “Alas, good soul!” and forgave him with all their hearts.
Goodbye!: Three or four wenches where I stood cried, “Alas, good soul!” and forgave him with all their hearts.

Anon!: Wherefore?
Goodbye!: Why?

Anon!: I have within my mind A thousand raw tricks of these bragging jacks Which I will practice.
Goodbye!: I have a thousand raw tricks of these bragging jacks that I’ll use.

Anon!: He hath assembled Bocchus, the King of Libya; Archelaus, Of Cappadocia; Philadelphos, King Of Paphlagonia; the Thracian king, Adallas; King Manchus of Arabia; King of Pont; Herod of Jewry; Mithridates, King Of Comagen; Polemon and Amyntas, The Kings of Mede and Lycaonia, With a more larger list of scepters.
Goodbye!: He’s assembled Bocchus, the King of Libya, Archelaus, of Cappadocia, Philadelphos, King of Paphlagonia, the Thracian king, Adallas,

Anon!: Now, my dearest Queen— Pray you, stand farther from me.
Goodbye!: Now, my dearest Queen— Please, stand farther away from me.

Anon!: We do not know.
Goodbye!: We don’t know.

Anon!: You know no Centaur?
Goodbye!: You don’t know Centaur?

Anon!: Give first admittance to th' ambassadors.
Goodbye!: Give your ambassadors the first admittance.

Anon!: These English woes will make me smile in France.
Goodbye!: These English problems will make me smile in France.

Anon!: Here comes the noble Antony.
Goodbye!: Here comes the noble Antony.

Anon!: Most sincerely.
Goodbye!: I’m very happy.

Anon!: Not possible.
Goodbye!: Not possible.

Anon!: I care not.
Goodbye!: I don’t care.

Anon!: Very well.
Goodbye!: Very well.

Anon!: Soldier, why wear’st thou that glove in thy cap?
Goodbye!: Soldier, why do you wear that glove in your cap?

Anon!: Indeed, I am no mourner for that news, Because they have been still my adversaries.
Goodbye!: I’m not a mourner for that news, because they’ve been my adversaries.

Anon!: The triplex, sir, is a good tripping measure, or the bells of Saint Bennet, sir, may put you in mind—one, two, three.
Goodbye!: The triplex is a good tripping measure, or the bells of Saint Bennet may remind you—one, two, three.

Anon!: I shall be constrained in ’t to call thee knave, knight.
Goodbye!: I’ll be forced to call you a king, knight.

Anon!: You, Roderigo!
Goodbye!: You, Roderigo!

Anon!: Adieu.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: So, it will make us mad.
Goodbye!: That’s what’s going on.

Anon!: We would have all such offenders so cut off, and we give express charge that in our marches through the country there be nothing compelled from the villages, nothing taken but paid for, none of the French upbraided or abused in disdainful language; for when lenity and cruelty play for a kingdom, the gentler gamester is the soonest winner.
Goodbye!: We want all of these crimes to be cut off so quickly, and we give express charge that in our marchs through the country there is nothing forced out of the villages, nothing taken but paid for, none of the French upbraided

Anon!: How now, general?
Goodbye!: What’s going on, general?

Anon!: It is with a good will.
Goodbye!: It’s good.

Anon!: Helen, to you our minds we will unfold.
Goodbye!: Helen, we’ll go ahead to you.
