Anon!: You shall mark Many a duteous and knee-crooking knave That (doting on his own obsequious bondage) Wears out his time much like his master’s ass For naught but provender, and when he’s old, cashiered.
Goodbye!: You’ll see a duteous, knee-crooking knave who (doing his own sanity) wears out his time like his master’s ass for naught but

Anon!: Welcome, ass.
Goodbye!: Welcome, ass.

Anon!: I think it is the weakness of mine eyes That shapes this monstrous apparition.
Goodbye!: I think it’s my weakness in my eyes that shapes this monstrous apparition.

Anon!: Therefore I promise ye I fear you.
Goodbye!: So I promise you’re afraid.

Anon!: I am bound by oath, and therefore pardon me.
Goodbye!: I’m bound by oath, and I’ll pardon him.

Anon!: Our fraughtage, sir, I have conveyed aboard, and I have bought The oil, the balsamum and aqua vitae.
Goodbye!: I’ve sat on our ship, sir, and I’ve bought the oil, the balsamum and the aqua vitae.

Anon!: Fetch me an iron crow.
Goodbye!: Give me an iron crow.

Anon!: The world is not thy friend nor the world’s law.
Goodbye!: The world is not your friend, and neither is the law.

Anon!: But what say you to Thursday?
Goodbye!: But what do you say to Thursday?

Anon!: I pray, sir, can you read?
Goodbye!: Please, sir, can you read?

Anon!: Wherefore storm you so?
Goodbye!: Why are you so angry?

Anon!: Alas, that they are so, To die even when they to perfection grow!
Goodbye!: Oh, they’re so old, to die even when they grow to perfection!

Anon!: What name, fair lady?
Goodbye!: What name, fair lady?

Anon!: Who is ’t that cried?
Goodbye!: Who’s crying?

Anon!: Am I not an inch of fortune better than she?
Goodbye!: Isn’t she a better man than me?

Anon!: I’ll not to bed tonight.
Goodbye!: I won’t go to bed tonight.

Anon!: Acquaint her here of my son Paris' love, And bid her, mark you me, on Wednesday next— But, soft!
Goodbye!: Tell her about my son Paris’s love here and tell her, please, to come see me on Wednesday— But soft!

Anon!: Then I beat my tabor, At which, like unbacked colts, they pricked their ears, Advanced their eyelids, lifted up their noses As they smelt music.
Goodbye!: Then I beat my thorn, where they pricked their ears, advanced their eyelids, lifted up their noses as they smelt music.

Anon!: Let me not, Since I have my dukedom got And pardoned the deceiver, dwell In this bare island by your spell, But release me from my bands With the help of your good hands.
Goodbye!: I don’t want to dwell on this bare island by your spell, since my dukedom has been pardoned by the deceiver, but release me from my band with the help of your good hands.

Anon!: Foul weather?
Goodbye!: Weather?

Anon!: I would not be mad.
Goodbye!: I wouldn’t be mad.

Anon!: Hold, take thou that and that.
Goodbye!: Hold on to that and that.

Anon!: Dishonor not your mothers.
Goodbye!: Don’t be ashamed of your mothers.

Anon!: Hear me, good friends—
Goodbye!: Listen to me, good friends—

Anon!: Victory sits on our helms.
Goodbye!: Victory is on our helms.

Anon!: Why, how now, Hecate!
Goodbye!: Hecate!

Anon!: Be a child o’ th’ time.
Goodbye!: Be a child at the same time.

Anon!: I’ll keep my oath Patiently to bear my wroth.”
Goodbye!: I’ll keep my oath for a long time to bear my wrath.”

Anon!: But, hold thee, take this garland on thy brow.
Goodbye!: But, hold on, take this garland on your brow.

Anon!: Arms, take your last embrace.
Goodbye!: Arms, take your last embrace.

Anon!: I will be brief, for my short date of breath Is not so long as is a tedious tale.
Goodbye!: I’ll be brief, because my short time of breath is not as long as a tedious tale.

Anon!: Upon his royal face there is no note How dread an army hath enrounded him, Nor doth he dedicate one jot of color Unto the weary and all-watchèd night, But freshly looks and overbears attaint With cheerful semblance and sweet majesty, That every wretch, pining and pale before, Beholding him, plucks comfort from his looks.
Goodbye!: He’s not a man who’s dreadfully rounded him, and he’s not a man who’s jokingly dressed up in a dark night, but he’s a

Anon!: Wherefore to Dover?
Goodbye!: Why Dover?

Anon!: Thanks, good Egeus.
Goodbye!: Thanks, good Egeus.

Anon!: Thus we are agreed.
Goodbye!: So we’re agreeing.

Anon!: My bounty is as boundless as the sea, My love as deep.
Goodbye!: My bounty is as boundless as the sea, my love is as deep.

Anon!: There, gentle Hermia, may I marry thee.
Goodbye!: Here, gentle Hermia, I can marry you.

Anon!: Death lies on her like an untimely frost Upon the sweetest flower of all the field.
Goodbye!: Death is on her like a frost on the sweetest flower in the world.

Anon!: Call my guard, I prithee.
Goodbye!: Call my guard, please.

Anon!: Both he loves.
Goodbye!: He loves both of them.

Anon!: And to deal plainly I fear I am not in my perfect mind.
Goodbye!: And I’m afraid I’m not in my perfect mind.

Anon!: Thence we looked toward England And cited up a thousand fearful times, During the wars of York and Lancaster That had befall'n us.
Goodbye!: From there we looked toward England and cited a thousand fearful times during the wars of York and Lancaster that had killed us.

Anon!: Do we so.
Goodbye!: Do so.

Anon!: Come, brands, ho, firebrands.
Goodbye!: Come, firebrands, firebrands.

Anon!: They do offend our sight.
Goodbye!: They’re offended by our sight.

Anon!: If there be any in this assembly, any dear friend of Caesar’s, to him I say that Brutus' love to Caesar was no less than his.
Goodbye!: If there’s any in this assembly, any dear friend of Caesar’s, I say to him that Brutus’s love for Caesar was not less than his.

Anon!: That would I, had I kingdoms to give with her.
Goodbye!: I wish I had kingdoms to give with her.

Anon!: Bring a corollary, Rather than want a spirit.
Goodbye!: Bring a corollary, rather than want a spirit.

Anon!: Then thus: Baptista is safe, talking with the deceiving father of a deceitful son.
Goodbye!: Then Baptista is safe talking with the deceiving father of a deceiving son.

Anon!: Why, then All Souls' Day is my body’s doomsday.
Goodbye!: Well, then, All Souls’ Day is my body’s doomsday.

Anon!: Be ruled by me; depart in patience, And let us to the Tiger all to dinner, And about evening come yourself alone To know the reason of this strange restraint.
Goodbye!: Be ruled by me, leave with patience, and let us go to the Tiger all to dinner, and come alone in the evening to know the reason for this strange restraint.

Anon!: Well, ’tis not so, my Lord High Constable.
Goodbye!: Well, it’s not true, my Lord High Constable.

Anon!: This was not counterfeit.
Goodbye!: This was not a fake.

Anon!: When our actions do not, Our fears do make us traitors.
Goodbye!: When we’re not doing anything, our fears make us traitors.

Anon!: We’ll keep no great ado, a friend or two.
Goodbye!: We won’t keep a great ado, a friend or two.

Anon!: No doubt, no doubt.
Goodbye!: No doubt, no doubt.

Anon!: But was not this nigh shore?
Goodbye!: But was this near shore?

Anon!: The son and heir of old Tiberio.
Goodbye!: The son and heir of old Tiberio.

Anon!: Their battles are at hand.
Goodbye!: Their battles are at hand.

Anon!: The wall, methinks, being sensible, should curse again.
Goodbye!: The wall, I think, should curse again.

Anon!: My more particular, And that which most with you should safe my going, Is Fulvia’s death.
Goodbye!: My particular concern is Fulvia’s death, and that you should protect me from the worst.

Anon!: For murder, though it have no tongue, will speak With most miraculous organ.
Goodbye!: For murder, though it doesn’t speak, will speak miraculously.

Anon!: The cause is in my will.
Goodbye!: The reason is in my will.

Anon!: Very well.
Goodbye!: Very well.

Anon!: What, must I hold a candle to my shames?
Goodbye!: What, must I hold a candle to my shames?

Anon!: I shifted him away And laid good ’scuses upon your ecstasy,
Goodbye!: I shifted him away and laid good scuses on your ecstasy.

Anon!: Scratching could not make it worse an ’twere such a face as yours were.
Goodbye!: Scratching couldn’t make it worse if it were as beautiful as yours were.

Anon!: Ready.
Goodbye!: Ready.

Anon!: Fly hence and leave me.
Goodbye!: Go away and leave me.

Anon!: Hail, king!
Goodbye!: Hail, king!

Anon!: Here, master.
Goodbye!: Here, master.

Anon!: And fair words to them.
Goodbye!: And fair words to them.

Anon!: Informed them”?
Goodbye!: Did they know”?

Anon!: Shall I speak a word in your ear?
Goodbye!: Should I speak a word in your ear?

Anon!: My voice is in my sword.
Goodbye!: My voice is in my sword.

Anon!: Lord of lords!
Goodbye!: Lord of lords!

Anon!: But these offers, Which serve not for his vantage, he shakes off, And so should you.
Goodbye!: But he’s shaken off these offers, which don’t serve his purpose, and so should you.

Anon!: We’ll hear the will.
Goodbye!: We’ll hear the will.

Anon!: Yes, just.
Goodbye!: Yes, just.

Anon!: What o'clock tomorrow Shall I send to thee?
Goodbye!: What time tomorrow will I send you?

Anon!: Ay, be so, good Touchstone.
Goodbye!: Yes, be good Touchstone.

Anon!: Yet you, the murderer, look as bright, as clear, As yonder Venus in her glimmering sphere.
Goodbye!: But you, the murderer, look as bright, as clear as Venus in her glimmering sphere.

Anon!: Therefore turn and draw.
Goodbye!: So turn and draw.

Anon!: Nay then, come on, and take the chance of anger.
Goodbye!: No, come on, and take the chance to get angry.

Anon!: What do you think?
Goodbye!: What do you think?

Anon!: Such a one is a natural philosopher.
Goodbye!: That’s a natural philosopher.

Anon!: Who’s there?
Goodbye!: Who’s there?

Anon!: Turn thy complexion there, Patience, thou young and rose-lipped cherubin,— Ay, there, look grim as hell!
Goodbye!: Look, there, as grim as hell!

Anon!: Tell me this, I pray: Where have you left the money that I gave you?
Goodbye!: Tell me this, please: Where have you left the money I gave you?

Anon!: Hail, Caesar, and my lord!
Goodbye!: Hail, Caesar, and my lord!

Anon!: Do you know them?
Goodbye!: Do you know them?

Anon!: Fourscore ducats!
Goodbye!: Fourscore ducats!

Anon!: Pray you, if it be, give it me, for I am slow of study.
Goodbye!: Please, if it’s true, give it to me, because I’m too slow to study.

Anon!: No more perchance does mine, nor his, nor hers.
Goodbye!: No more sex is possible for mine, his, and hers.

Anon!: And I serve the fairy queen  To dew her orbs upon the green.
Goodbye!: And I’m helping the fairy queen to dew her orbs on the green.

Anon!: Fie, for shame!
Goodbye!: Shame on you!

Anon!: Did he ask for me?
Goodbye!: Did he ask for me?

Anon!: You have been hotly called for.
Goodbye!: You’ve been called for.

Anon!: A play there is, my lord, some ten words long, Which is as brief as I have known a play.
Goodbye!: There’s a play there, my lord, about ten words long, which is as brief as I’ve known.

Anon!: I am content.
Goodbye!: I’m satisfied.

Anon!: Apothecary!
Goodbye!: Apothecary!

Anon!: Is he arrayed?
Goodbye!: Is he a man?

Anon!: The English power is near, led on by Malcolm, His uncle Siward and the good Macduff.
Goodbye!: The English power is near, led by Malcolm, his uncle Siward and the good Macduff.

Anon!: Either withdraw unto some private place, And reason coldly of your grievances, Or else depart.
Goodbye!: Either go to some private place, and explain your grievances coldly, or else go away.

Anon!: Buy food, and get thyself in flesh.— Come, cordial and not poison, go with me To Juliet’s grave, for there must I use thee.
Goodbye!: Get food and get yourself in flesh.—Come with me, cordial and not poison, to Juliet’s grave, because I have to use you there.

Anon!: Wash they his wounds with tears?
Goodbye!: Are they washing his wounds with tears?

Anon!: Is it for him you do envy me so?
Goodbye!: Is it for him you envy me so much?

Anon!: As willingly as e'er I came from school.
Goodbye!: I’m as willing as I am to come from school.

Anon!: My wits faints.
Goodbye!: My wits are faint.

Anon!: What services canst thou do?
Goodbye!: What services can you do?

Anon!: Note this before my notes: There’s not a note of mine that’s worth the noting.
Goodbye!: Note this before my notes: I don’t have a note of mine that’s worthy of mention.

Anon!: I stretch it out for that word “broad,” which, added to the goose, proves thee far and wide a broad goose.
Goodbye!: I’ll use that word “broad,” which, added to the goose, proves you are a wide goose.

Anon!: The more pity that fools may not speak wisely what wise men do foolishly.
Goodbye!: It’s a little sad that fools can’t speak wisely about what wise men do foolishly.

Anon!: Why so earnestly seek you to put up that letter?
Goodbye!: Why are you asking so seriously to write that letter?

Anon!: And what to?
Goodbye!: And what do you mean?

Anon!: What does this mean, my lord?
Goodbye!: What does this mean, my lord?

Anon!: You have said, but whether wisely or no, let the forest judge.
Goodbye!: You’ve said something, but if you’re wise or not, let the forest judge.

Anon!: I shall obey you in all fair commands.
Goodbye!: I’ll obey you in all fair commands.

Anon!: Melt Egypt into Nile, and kindly creatures Turn all to serpents.
Goodbye!: Melt Egypt into the Nile, and kindly creatures turn everything into serpents.

Anon!: These are portents, but yet I hope, I hope They do not point on me.
Goodbye!: These are a thorn, but I hope they don’t point to me.

Anon!: I have done no more to Caesar than you shall do to Brutus.
Goodbye!: I’ve done nothing more to Caesar than you’ll do to Brutus.

Anon!: Death is my heir.
Goodbye!: Death is my heir.

Anon!: He shall in time be ready.
Goodbye!: He’ll be ready in time.

Anon!: Indeed?
Goodbye!: Yes, really?

Anon!: For the one, I have neither words nor measure; and for the other, I have no strength in measure, yet a reasonable measure in strength.
Goodbye!: For the one, I have neither words nor measure; for the other, I have no measure, but a reasonable measure.

Anon!: Where art thou, keeper?
Goodbye!: Where are you, keeper?

Anon!: O Setebos, these be brave spirits indeed!
Goodbye!: Oh Setebos, these are brave spirits!

Anon!: Good morrow, masters.
Goodbye!: Good morning, masters.

Anon!: Or have we eaten on the insane root That takes the reason prisoner?
Goodbye!: Or have we eaten on the insane root that takes the reason for prisoner?

Anon!: No, thou proud dream, That play’st so subtly with a king’s repose.
Goodbye!: No, you proud dream, that play is so subtly played with a king’s repose.

Anon!: Prithee say true!
Goodbye!: Please say true!

Anon!: If it be that— If it be that, or any that was hers, It speaks against her with the other proofs.
Goodbye!: If it’s that— If it’s that, or any one that was hers, it’s not against her with the other proofs.

Anon!: Oh, me, lieutenant!
Goodbye!: Oh, my lieutenant!

Anon!: All thy other titles thou hast given away that thou wast born with.
Goodbye!: All your other titles you’ve given away that you were born with.

Anon!: We have used our throats in Egypt.
Goodbye!: We’ve used our throats in Egypt.

Anon!: Thy Edward he is dead, that killed my Edward, Thy other Edward dead, to quit my Edward; Young York, he is but boot, because both they Matched not the high perfection of my loss.
Goodbye!: Your Edward is dead, who killed my Edward, your other Edward, to quit my Edward.

Anon!: What if I strayed no further, but chose here?
Goodbye!: What if I didn’t go any further, but decided to go here?

Anon!: Why the devil came you between us?
Goodbye!: Why the devil came you between us?

Anon!: Give order to my servants that they take No note at all of our being absent hence.— Nor you, Lorenzo.—Jessica, nor you.
Goodbye!: I’ll give my servants the order to ignore all the fact that we’re absent from here.—No, Lorenzo.—Jessica, no.

Anon!: I say amen, Gonzalo.
Goodbye!: I say amen, Gonzalo.

Anon!: The date is out of such prolixity.
Goodbye!: The date is out of such a bad mood.

Anon!: Then bring me to their sights.
Goodbye!: Then bring me to their sights.

Anon!: O most dear mistress, The sun will set before I shall discharge What I must strive to do.
Goodbye!: Oh, my dear mistress, I’ll be ready to go.

Anon!: What further woe conspires against mine age?
Goodbye!: What further troubles do you have to face against me?

Anon!: I pray thee, chide not.
Goodbye!: Please don’t chide me.

Anon!: O Dardanius!
Goodbye!: Oh Dardanius!

Anon!: Heaven preserve you!
Goodbye!: Heaven keep you!

Anon!: Did I not bid thee meet me in the park And bring along these rascal knaves with thee?
Goodbye!: Didn’t I ask you to meet me in the park and bring these rascal knaves with you?

Anon!: Welcome, my friends all.
Goodbye!: Welcome, my friends.

Anon!: There are more things in heaven and earth, Horatio, Than are dreamt of in your philosophy.
Goodbye!: There are more things in heaven and earth than you dream about in your philosophy.

Anon!: And then the justice, In fair round belly with good capon lined, With eyes severe and beard of formal cut, Full of wise saws and modern instances; And so he plays his part.
Goodbye!: And then the justice, in a fair round belly with a good capon lined, with eyes severe and beard of formal cut, full of wise saws and modern instances; and so he plays his part.

Anon!: I pray now, keep below.
Goodbye!: Please, keep below.

Anon!: In cash, most justly paid.
Goodbye!: In cash, most just paid.

Anon!: I told him what I thought, and told no more Than what he found himself was apt and true.
Goodbye!: I told him what I thought, and I didn’t tell him anything more than what he found true.

Anon!: Will you hear the letter?
Goodbye!: Will you hear the letter?

Anon!: Where be the sacred vials thou shouldst fill With sorrowful water?
Goodbye!: Where are the sacred waterways you should fill with sorrowful water?

Anon!: O noble judge!
Goodbye!: Oh, noble judge!

Anon!: Good morrow, neighbor, whither away so fast?
Goodbye!: Good morning, neighbor, whither away so fast?

Anon!: Romeo, will you come to your father’s?
Goodbye!: Romeo, will you come to your father’s house?

Anon!: Hence with your little ones.
Goodbye!: Come with your little ones.

Anon!: Revenge.
Goodbye!: Revenge.

Anon!: Farewell.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: O heavenly mingle!
Goodbye!: Oh, heavenly lord!

Anon!: Tis twenty year till then.
Goodbye!: It’s twenty years until then.

Anon!: Yea, my lord.
Goodbye!: Yes, my lord.

Anon!: This is the sergeant Who like a good and hardy soldier fought 'Gainst my captivity.
Goodbye!: This is the sergeant who, like a good and hardy soldier, fought to protect me.

Anon!: Put on my crown.
Goodbye!: Put on my crown.

Anon!: Nurse!
Goodbye!: Nurse!

Anon!: Sweet, sweet, sweet Nurse, tell me, what says my love?
Goodbye!: Sweet, sweet, sweet Nurse, tell me, what does my love say?

Anon!: Ding, dong, bell.
Goodbye!: Ding, dong, bell.

Anon!: The Moor hath killed my mistress!
Goodbye!: The Moor has killed my mistress!

Anon!: If without peril it be possible, Sweet Blunt, make some good means to speak with him, And give him from me this most needful note.
Goodbye!: If it’s possible, Sweet Blunt, make some good means to speak with him and give him this very important note.

Anon!: Did not you tell me I should know the man By the Athenian garment he had on?
Goodbye!: Didn’t you tell me I should know the man he had on his clothes?

Anon!: The transgression is in the stealer.
Goodbye!: The gang is stealing.

Anon!: We’ll along ourselves, and meet them at Philippi.
Goodbye!: We’ll go along ourselves and meet them at Philippi.

Anon!: But make amends now.
Goodbye!: But make some changes now.

Anon!: There thou shouldst be; By this great clatter, one of the greatest note Seems bruited.
Goodbye!: You should be there.

Anon!: We would be resolved, Before we hear him, of some things of weight That task our thoughts concerning us and France.
Goodbye!: Before we hear him, we’d be able to decide some things that matter to us and France.

Anon!: Bind up my wounds!
Goodbye!: Bind up my wounds!

Anon!: In his bosom?
Goodbye!: In his throne?

Anon!: From both, my lord.
Goodbye!: From both of them, my lord.

Anon!: See, it stalks away.
Goodbye!: Look, it’s stalking away.

Anon!: Behind the abbey wall Within this hour my man shall be with thee And bring thee cords made like a tackled stair, Which to the high top-gallant of my joy Must be my convoy in the secret night.
Goodbye!: I’ll be with you behind the abbey wall within an hour and bring you cords made like a stair, which must be my convoy in the secret night.

Anon!: Cursed be I that did so!
Goodbye!: I’m sorry I did!

Anon!: Then I know My answer must be made.
Goodbye!: Then I know that my answer must be made.

Anon!: To what end did I bid thee hie thee home?
Goodbye!: To what end did I ask you to go home?

Anon!: Be merciful, say “death,” For exile hath more terror in his look, Much more than death.
Goodbye!: Be merciful, say “death,” because exile has more terror in his eyes than death.

Anon!: Alone, it was the subject of my theme; In company I often glancèd it.
Goodbye!: I was alone, it was the subject of my theme.

Anon!: O Phoebe, Phoebe, Phoebe!
Goodbye!: Oh, Phoebe, Phoebe, Phoebe!

Anon!: Ay, too gentle.
Goodbye!: Yes, too gentle.

Anon!: No, madam.
Goodbye!: No, madam.

Anon!: The earth hath bubbles, as the water has, And these are of them.
Goodbye!: The earth has bubbles, like the water, and these bubbles are.

Anon!: We will hence forthwith To feast and sport us at thy father’s house.
Goodbye!: We’ll leave your father’s house soon.

Anon!: If I speak true!
Goodbye!: If I’m true, then

Anon!: You talk!
Goodbye!: You’re talking!

Anon!: Cut my lace, Charmian, come!
Goodbye!: Cut my lace, Charmian, and come!

Anon!: This sword but shown to Caesar, with this tidings, Shall enter me with him.
Goodbye!: This sword, shown to Caesar, will be able to enter me with this sword.

Anon!: And, moreover, God saw him when he was hid in the garden.
Goodbye!: And, besides, God saw him when he was hid in the garden.

Anon!: Run away, I pray you!
Goodbye!: Run away, please!

Anon!: For God’s sake, a pot of small ale.
Goodbye!: For God’s sake, a pot of beer.

Anon!: Madam, I trust, not so.
Goodbye!: I’m sure, madam, not so.

Anon!: Bid that welcome Which comes to punish us, and we punish it, Seeming to bear it lightly.
Goodbye!: We’ll punish you, and we’ll bear it lightly.

Anon!: I to the world am like a drop of water That in the ocean seeks another drop, Who, falling there to find his fellow forth, Unseen, inquisitive, confounds himself.
Goodbye!: I’m like a drop of water that’s looking for another drop in the ocean, who, falling there to find his fellow, unseen, inquisitive, confounds himself.

Anon!: I beseech your pardon.
Goodbye!: Please forgive me.

Anon!: It is an accustomed action with her to seem thus washing her hands.
Goodbye!: It’s a habit for her to seem like washing her hands.

Anon!: Then you live about her waist, or in the middle of her favors?
Goodbye!: Then you’re living around her waist, or in the middle of her favors?

Anon!: To be a well-favored man is the gift of fortune, but to write and read comes by nature.
Goodbye!: To be a well-favored man is the gift of fortune, but to write and read is a natural gift.

Anon!: What foul play had we that we came from thence?
Goodbye!: What kind of play did we play that we came from here?

Anon!: Who, Hero?
Goodbye!: Who, Hero?

Anon!: A sweet woman!
Goodbye!: A sweet woman!

Anon!: I hope your Majesty is pear me testimony and witness, and will avouchment that this is the glove of Alençon that your Majesty is give me, in your conscience now.
Goodbye!: I hope your Majesty is bringing me testimony and testimony, and I’ll tell you that this is Alençon’s glove, given to me by your Majesty now.

Anon!: What is this?
Goodbye!: What’s this?

Anon!: Oh, when she had writ it and was reading it over, she found “Benedick” and “Beatrice” between the sheet?
Goodbye!: Oh, when she wrote it and read it over, she found “Benedick” and “Beatrice” between the sheets?

Anon!: The spring, the summer, The childing autumn, angry winter change Their wonted liveries, and the mazèd world, By their increase, now knows not which is which.
Goodbye!: Spring, summer, childing autumn, angry winter change their lives, and the mazed world, by their rise, now doesn’t know which one is.

Anon!: Pitiful sight!
Goodbye!: A pitiful sight!

Anon!: I am hurt.
Goodbye!: I’m hurt.

Anon!: Sometime she gallops o'er a courtier’s nose, And then dreams he of smelling out a suit.
Goodbye!: Sometimes she gallops up a courtier’s nose, and then dreams of smelling out a suit.

Anon!: Why, stay and hear me speak.
Goodbye!: Why, stay and hear me speak.

Anon!: O, fear me not.
Goodbye!: Oh, don’t worry about me.

Anon!: I was born to speak all mirth and no  matter.
Goodbye!: I was born to speak a whole lot, no matter what.

Anon!: Why, how now, Stephano?
Goodbye!: Why, how are you, Stephano?

Anon!: Sir, sooth to say, you did not dine at home.
Goodbye!: Sir, I’m sure you didn’t eat at home.

Anon!: Shame itself!
Goodbye!: Shame on you!

Anon!: Methinks the wind hath spoke aloud at land, A fuller blast ne'er shook our battlements.
Goodbye!: I think the wind has spoken loudly at land, and a fuller blast hasn’t shook our battlements.

Anon!: Is thy master coming?
Goodbye!: Is your master coming?

Anon!: Madam, I will.
Goodbye!: Madam, I will.

Anon!: Though I wish thy death, I will not be the executioner.
Goodbye!: Even though I wish you were dead, I won’t be the executioner.

Anon!: Will you two help to hasten them?
Goodbye!: Will you two help them get ready?

Anon!: O happy fair!
Goodbye!: Oh, happy, fair!

Anon!: It waves me still.
Goodbye!: It’s still a wave.

Anon!: You wronged yourself to write in such a case.
Goodbye!: You wronged yourself to write in such a case.

Anon!: Marry, it is your brother’s right hand.
Goodbye!: It’s your brother’s right hand.

Anon!: Question your Grace the late ambassadors With what great state he heard their embassy, How well supplied with noble counselors, How modest in exception, and withal How terrible in constant resolution, And you shall find his vanities forespent Were but the outside of the Roman Brutus, Covering discretion with a coat of folly, As gardeners do with ordure hide those roots That shall first spring and be most delicate.
Goodbye!: Your Grace, the late ambassadors, ask how great he heard their embassy, how well he was able to provide noble counselors, how modest in exception, and how terrible in constant resolution, and you’ll find his

Anon!: I saw him not.
Goodbye!: I didn’t see him.

Anon!: He is very near by this.
Goodbye!: He’s very close to this.

Anon!: He has broke my head across and has given Sir Toby a bloody coxcomb too.
Goodbye!: He broke my head and gave Sir Toby a bloody sneeze too.

Anon!: All the world’s a stage, And all the men and women merely players.
Goodbye!: The whole world is a stage, and all the men and women are just actors.

Anon!: A sailor’s wife had chestnuts in her lap, And munched, and munched, and munched.
Goodbye!: A sailor’s wife had chestnuts in her lap and munched, munched, and munched.

Anon!: Amen to that, sweet powers!
Goodbye!: Amen to that, sweet powers!

Anon!: Hie therefore, Robin, overcast the night.
Goodbye!: So, Robin, overcast the night.

Anon!: How goes ’t?
Goodbye!: How is it?

Anon!: Come, let us to the castle.
Goodbye!: Come on, let’s go to the castle.

Anon!: The English are embattled, you French peers.
Goodbye!: The English are embattled, you French peers.

Anon!: Your Highness bade me ask for it today.
Goodbye!: Your Highness told me to ask for it today.

Anon!: Dost thou lie so low?
Goodbye!: Do you lie so low?

Anon!: You will not then?
Goodbye!: You won’t, then?

Anon!: Go thou to Juliet, help to deck up her.
Goodbye!: Go to Juliet and help her get dressed.

Anon!: They that have done this deed are honorable.
Goodbye!: The people who have done this deed are honorable.

Anon!: Let go thy hold when a great wheel runs down a hill, lest it break thy neck with following it.
Goodbye!: Let go of your sleeve when a great wheel runs down a hill, so it won’t break your neck with following it.

Anon!: Rome, thou hast lost the breed of noble bloods!
Goodbye!: Rome, you’ve lost the breed of noble bloods!

Anon!: No, unpin me here.
Goodbye!: No, don’t bother me here.

Anon!: I pray you tell Benedick of it and hear what he will say.
Goodbye!: Please tell Benedick about it and hear what he’ll say.

Anon!: I know not, madam.
Goodbye!: I don’t know, madam.

Anon!: How long have you been a sectary astronomical?
Goodbye!: How long have you been a astronomical astronom?

Anon!: Therefore the Dukes of Berri and of Brittany, Of Brabant and of Orléans, shall make forth, And you, Prince Dauphin, with all swift dispatch, To line and new-repair our towns of war With men of courage and with means defendant.
Goodbye!: So the Dukes of Berri and Brittany, of Brabant and of Orléans, will come out and you, Prince Dauphin, will dispatch you quickly to line and return our towns of war with men of

Anon!: Yet I insisted; yet you answered not, But with an angry wafture of your hand Gave sign for me to leave you.
Goodbye!: But I insisted.

Anon!: I was not born to die on Brutus' sword.
Goodbye!: I was not born to die on Brutus’s sword.

Anon!: I shall do my friends no wrong, for I have none to lament me; the world no injury, for in it I have nothing.
Goodbye!: I won’t do my friends any wrong, because I don’t have any to lament me; the world won’t hurt me, because I don’t have anything to do with it.

Anon!: He is coming.
Goodbye!: He’s coming.

Anon!: Your reasons are too shallow and too quick.
Goodbye!: Your reasons are too shallow and too quick.

Anon!: It is a hint That wrings mine eyes to ’t.
Goodbye!: It’s a hint that wrings my eyes to it.

Anon!: She shall not.
Goodbye!: She won’t.

Anon!: I’ll give ’t him.
Goodbye!: I’ll give it to him.

Anon!: Go, call him hither, boy   No more shall be the neighbor to my counsels Hath he so long held out with me, untired, And stops he now for breath?
Goodbye!: Go call him here, boy, no more will be the neighbor to my counsels.

Anon!: The murmuring surge That on th' unnumbered idle pebbles chafes Cannot be heard so high.
Goodbye!: The squeak surge that screams on the idle pebbles can’t be heard so high.

Anon!: Never excuse—for when the players are all dead, there needs none to be blamed.
Goodbye!: Don’t excuse—when the players are all dead, there’s no reason to blame.

Anon!: And I.
Goodbye!: And I.

Anon!: Tis known before.
Goodbye!: It’s been known before.

Anon!: I remember when I was in love I broke my sword upon a stone and bid him take that for coming a- night to Jane Smile.
Goodbye!: I remember when I was in love, I broke my sword on a stone and told him to take that for coming to Jane Smile night.

Anon!: Good my lord, vouchsafe me a word with you.
Goodbye!: Please, my lord, please tell me a word.

Anon!: Now, my lord.
Goodbye!: Now, my lord.

Anon!: I’ll drink to her as long as there is a passage in my throat and drink in Illyria.
Goodbye!: I’ll drink to her as long as there’s a passage in my throat and drink in Illyria.

Anon!: She’s dead too, our sovereign.
Goodbye!: She’s dead too, our sovereign.

Anon!: Withdraw thee, wretched Margaret.
Goodbye!: Withdraw your sword, wretched Margaret.

Anon!: Will you have some more sauce to your leek?
Goodbye!: Will you have some more sauce to eat?

Anon!: If it be thus to dream, still let me sleep!
Goodbye!: If it’s like dreaming, let me sleep!

Anon!: Besides, the king’s name is a tower of strength Which they upon the adverse party want.
Goodbye!: Besides, the king’s name is a tower of strength that they want to build upon the adverse party.

Anon!: Our sex, as well as I, may chide you for it, Though I alone do feel the injury.
Goodbye!: Our sex as well as I may chide you for it, even though I feel the injury alone.

Anon!: Are they returned?
Goodbye!: Are they back?

Anon!: These time ambles withal.
Goodbye!: This time is a long amble.

Anon!: Then must you speak Of one that loved not wisely, but too well.
Goodbye!: Then you must speak of someone who loved nothing wisely, but too well.

Anon!: You know I say nothing to him, for he understands not me, nor I him.
Goodbye!: You know I’m not saying anything to him, because he doesn’t understand me, and neither does he understand me.

Anon!: Call him in.
Goodbye!: Call him in.

Anon!: She cannot be so much without true judgment, Having so swift and excellent a wit As she is prized to have, as to refuse So rare a gentleman as Signior Benedick.
Goodbye!: She can’t be as good as a man, even if she’s as intelligent and witful as she is prized to have, as to refuse a gentleman as rare as Signior Benedick.

Anon!: I am much bound to you.
Goodbye!: I’m very close to you.

Anon!: Hark, Petruchio: she says she’ll see thee hanged first.
Goodbye!: Listen, Petruchio: she says she’ll see you hanged first.

Anon!: Longer, longer.
Goodbye!: Longer, longer.

Anon!: Do Poor Tom some charity, whom the foul fiend vexes.
Goodbye!: Do Poor Tom some charity, whom the foul fiend vexes.

Anon!: But thus, I trust, you will not marry her.
Goodbye!: But you won’t marry her, I trust.

Anon!: Therefore great France My mourning and importuned tears hath pitied.
Goodbye!: So great France has pitied me for my grief and my tears.

Anon!: Myself and what is mine to you and yours Is now converted.
Goodbye!: I’m now converted to what I’m doing to you and yours.

Anon!: My dearest cousin and my dearer lord?
Goodbye!: My dearest cousin and my dearer lord?

Anon!: I can keep honest counsel, ride, run, mar a curious tale in telling it, and deliver a plain message bluntly.
Goodbye!: I can keep a good counsel, ride, run, tell a curious story, and deliver a clear message.

Anon!: How fine my master is!
Goodbye!: How fine my master is!

Anon!: Make it a word and a blow.
Goodbye!: Make it a word and a blow.

Anon!: Tis thus: Who tells me true, though in his tale lie death, I hear him as he flattered.
Goodbye!: That’s the one: I hear him flattered, even though he’s dead.

Anon!: Then is courtesy a turncoat.
Goodbye!: Then he’s a nice man.

Anon!: So he does indeed.
Goodbye!: That’s true.

Anon!: If you shall send them word you will not come, Their minds may change.
Goodbye!: If you send them a message that you won’t come, their minds may change.

Anon!: See, see, our honored hostess!
Goodbye!: See, see, our honored hostess!

Anon!: Peace there!
Goodbye!: Quiet!

Anon!: Me believe it?
Goodbye!: Do you believe it?

Anon!: Come, boy, with me.
Goodbye!: Come with me, boy.

Anon!: Who, he?
Goodbye!: Who, he?

Anon!: And Cassius too.
Goodbye!: And Cassius too.

Anon!: Caesar, I go.
Goodbye!: Caesar, I’m going.

Anon!: I warrant you, you shall find the ceremonies of the wars and the cares of it and the forms of it and the sobriety of it and the modesty of it to be otherwise.
Goodbye!: I assure you, you’ll find that the ceremonies of war and the cares of it and the forms of it and the sobriety of it and the modesty of it are otherwise.

Anon!: With patience, noble lord, as prisoners must.
Goodbye!: With patience, noble lord, as prisoners must.

Anon!: I had rather have a handful or two of dried peas.
Goodbye!: I’d rather have a handful or two of dried peas.

Anon!: I think thou dost.
Goodbye!: I think you do.

Anon!: I’ll make so bold to call, For ’tis my limited service.
Goodbye!: I’ll make it so bold to call, because it’s my limited service.

Anon!: Gentlemen, can any of you tell me where I may find the young Romeo?
Goodbye!: Gentlemen, can any of you tell me where I can find young Romeo?

Anon!: Here’s neither bush nor shrub to bear off any weather at all.
Goodbye!: There’s no bush or shrub to keep away from the weather.

Anon!: You shall not gauge me By what we do tonight.
Goodbye!: You won’t see me by what we do tonight.

Anon!: Thou told’st me Thou didst hold him in thy hate.
Goodbye!: You told me you hated him.

Anon!: Art rich?
Goodbye!: Are you rich?

Anon!: And when I shall die, Take him and cut him out in little stars, And he will make the face of heaven so fine That all the world will be in love with night And pay no worship to the garish sun.
Goodbye!: And when I die, take him and cut him out in tiny stars, and he’ll make the face of heaven so fine that the whole world will be in love with night and not worship the sun.

Anon!: No, but she let it drop by negligence And, to th' advantage, I being here, took ’t up.
Goodbye!: No, but she let it drop by negligence and, to my advantage, I was here, took it up.

Anon!: Bate, I beseech you, widow Dido.
Goodbye!: Bate, please, Dido.

Anon!: There’s money for thee.
Goodbye!: There’s money for you.

Anon!: Therefore beware my censure, and keep your promise.
Goodbye!: So beware of my censure and keep your promise.

Anon!: No jewel is like Rosalind.
Goodbye!: No jewel is like Rosalind.

Anon!: An if I could, what should I get therefore?
Goodbye!: If I could, what should I get from that?

Anon!: I remember.
Goodbye!: I remember.

Anon!: Oh, you and I have heard our fathers say, There was a Brutus once that would have brooked Th' eternal devil to keep his state in Rome As easily as a king.
Goodbye!: Oh, you and I have heard our fathers say that Brutus once was the one who would have fought for your eternal devil to keep his state in Rome as easily as a king.

Anon!: No marvel though she pause; They can be meek that have no other cause.
Goodbye!: She can’t be a miracle, but they can be a savage, if there’s no other reason to do that.

Anon!: Have you not read, Roderigo, Of some such thing?
Goodbye!: Didn’t you read about anything like that, Roderigo?

Anon!: And you, sir.
Goodbye!: And you, sir.

Anon!: By heaven, thy madness shall be paid by weight, Till our scale turn the beam.
Goodbye!: By heaven, your madness will be paid by weight until our scale turns the beam.

Anon!: Answer me in one word.
Goodbye!: Answer me in one word.

Anon!: The “why” is plain as way to parish church: He that a fool doth very wisely hit Doth very foolishly, although he smart, Not to seem senseless of the bob.
Goodbye!: The “why” is as simple as it is to go to the parish church: whoever is a fool who is very wisely hit is very foolish, even though he’s smart, and doesn’t seem to be

Anon!: O nature, what hadst thou to do in hell When thou didst bower the spirit of a fiend In moral paradise of such sweet flesh?
Goodbye!: Oh nature, what did you do in hell when you bowed to the spirit of a fiend in such a sweet flesh?

Anon!: I fly, Biondello.
Goodbye!: I’m flying, Biondello.

Anon!: What private griefs they have, alas, I know not, That made them do it.
Goodbye!: I don’t know what private grief they have, and that made them do it.

Anon!: Not in my house, Lucentio, for you know Pitchers have ears, and I have many servants.
Goodbye!: Not in my house, Lucentio, because you know Pitchers have ears, and I have many servants.

Anon!: Go, Pindarus, get higher on that hill.
Goodbye!: Go, Pindarus, get up on that hill.

Anon!: I am agreed, and would I had given him the best horse inv Padua to begin his wooing that would thoroughly woo her, wed her, and bed her, and rid the house of her!
Goodbye!: I agree, and I wish I had given him the best horse in Padua to start his wooing that would woo her thoroughly, wed her, and bed her, and rid the house of her!

Anon!: Ah, my poor princes!
Goodbye!: Ah, my poor princes!

Anon!: Night hangs upon mine eyes.
Goodbye!: I’m hanging out of my eyes for night.

Anon!: I shall be reconciled to him again.
Goodbye!: I’ll be reconciled with him again.

Anon!: Ay, but not rough enough.
Goodbye!: Yes, but not rough enough.

Anon!: My brother and thy uncle, called Antonio— I pray thee, mark me (that a brother should Be so perfidious!
Goodbye!: My brother and your uncle, Antonio— I beg you, mark me (that a brother should be so perfidious!

Anon!: What are you there?
Goodbye!: What are you doing?

Anon!: Hold, then.
Goodbye!: Stop, then.

Anon!: Good Norfolk, hie thee to thy charge.
Goodbye!: Good Norfolk, please tell me what you’re doing.

Anon!: In this time of the night?
Goodbye!: In this time of the night?

Anon!: As he shall smile, Othello shall go mad.
Goodbye!: As he smiles, Othello will go crazy.

Anon!: How now, Captain Macmorris, have you quit the mines?
Goodbye!: How are you, Captain Macmorris, leaving the mines?

Anon!: Post back with speed, and tell him what hath chanced.
Goodbye!: Go back to him quickly and tell him what he’s going to do.

Anon!: But I can tell you that of late this duke Hath ta'en displeasure 'gainst his gentle niece, Grounded upon no other argument But that the people praise her for her virtues And pity her for her good father’s sake; And, on my life, his malice 'gainst the lady Will suddenly break forth.
Goodbye!: But I can tell you that this duke has a bad reputation for his gentle niece, and that the people praise her for her virtues and pity her for her father’s sake.

Anon!: Cry “holla” to thy tongue, I prithee.
Goodbye!: Please, cry “holla” to your tongue.

Anon!: What is ’t, Ophelia, he hath said to you?
Goodbye!: What did he say to you, Ophelia?

Anon!: The boy was the very staff of my age, my very prop.
Goodbye!: The boy was the person I was, my prop.

Anon!: Nay, I am sure it is, Volumnius.
Goodbye!: No, I’m sure it is, Volumnius.

Anon!: Do you see this, O God?
Goodbye!: Do you see this, God?

Anon!: I pray you bring me on the way a little And say if I shall see you soon at night.
Goodbye!: Please bring me on the way a little and tell me if I’ll see you soon at night.

Anon!: Most mighty Caesar, let me know some cause, Lest I be laughed at when I tell them so.
Goodbye!: Most mighty Caesar, let me know some reason, so I won’t be laughed at when I tell them so.

Anon!: I do so, I confess it.
Goodbye!: I do, I confess.

Anon!: Do not then walk too open.
Goodbye!: Don’t walk too open.

Anon!: I do think there is mettle in death, which commits some loving act upon her, she hath such a celerity in dying.
Goodbye!: I think there’s a stalemate in death, which is a loving act on her, and she’s so stale in dying.

Anon!: Help me, my women!
Goodbye!: Help me, my women!

Anon!: Yet but three?
Goodbye!: But only three?

Anon!: You know me well.
Goodbye!: You know me well.

Anon!: You shall not in your funeral speech blame us, But speak all good you can devise of Caesar, And say you do ’t by our permission.
Goodbye!: You won’t blame us in your funeral speech, but you can tell us everything you can do about Caesar and say you do it by our permission.

Anon!: Reproach and everlasting shame Sits mocking in our plumes.
Goodbye!: Reproach and everlasting shame sits in our bushes.

Anon!: More, I prithee, more.
Goodbye!: More, please, more.

Anon!: If Caesar please, our master Will leap to be his friend.
Goodbye!: If Caesar wants, our master will leap to be his friend.

Anon!: I’ll not meddle with it.
Goodbye!: I won’t betray it.

Anon!: Ah sir, ah sir.
Goodbye!: Ah sir, ah sir.

Anon!: Peace, Grumio.
Goodbye!: Quiet, Grumio.

Anon!: Marry, sir, to bid my old master the Jew to sup tonight with my new master the Christian.
Goodbye!: Dear, sir, to ask my old master the Jew to suppose tonight with my new master the Christian.

Anon!: He is the only man of Italy, Always excepted my dear Claudio.
Goodbye!: He’s the only man in Italy, excepted my dear Claudio.

Anon!: Tis well consented.
Goodbye!: It’s well agreed.

Anon!: No noise, and enter.
Goodbye!: Don’t make noise, and enter.

Anon!: Horn mad, thou villain!
Goodbye!: Horn mad, you villain!

Anon!: And here’s another, whose warped looks proclaim What store her heart is made on.
Goodbye!: And here’s another, whose sane looks proclaim what she’s making of her heart.

Anon!: Since the youth of the count’s was today with thy lady, she is much out of quiet.
Goodbye!: Since the count’s youth was today with your lady, she’s still out of quiet.

Anon!: That face of his I do remember well.
Goodbye!: I remember his face well.

Anon!: What kind of help?
Goodbye!: What kind of help do you need?

Anon!: But, for mine own part, it was Greek to me.
Goodbye!: But for my own part, it was Greek to me.

Anon!: Tis not to me she speaks.
Goodbye!: She’s not talking to me.

Anon!: Thou shouldst rather ask if it were possible any villainy should be so rich.
Goodbye!: You should ask if it’s possible any villainy should be so rich.

Anon!: Why, a horse.
Goodbye!: What a horse!

Anon!: Whilst he stood up and spoke, He was my master, and I wore my life To spend upon his haters.
Goodbye!: While he stood up and spoke, he was my master, and I wore my life to spend on his haters.

Anon!: Let him take thee And hoist thee up to the shouting plebeians!
Goodbye!: Let him take you and hoist you up to the shouting plebeians!

Anon!: Hold, there’s expenses for thee.
Goodbye!: Hold on, there’s money for you.

Anon!: Virtue itself turns vice, being misapplied, And vice sometime by action dignified.
Goodbye!: Virtue itself turns vice, being misapplied, and vice may be a mistake.

Anon!: It hath not appeared.
Goodbye!: It hasn’t appeared.

Anon!: He leads himself.
Goodbye!: He’s leading himself.

Anon!: Thou may ’st revenge —O slave!
Goodbye!: You may revenge — Oh, slave!

Anon!: Which way ran he that killed Mercutio?
Goodbye!: Which way did he kill Mercutio?

Anon!: I know into what straits of fortune she is driven, and it is not impossible to me, if it appear not inconvenient to you, to set her before your eyes tomorrow, human as she is, and without any danger.
Goodbye!: I know what she’s going to do, and it’s not impossible for me to see her tomorrow, as human as she is, and without any danger.

Anon!: I’ll sell all my land.
Goodbye!: I’ll sell all my land.

Anon!: They have made worms' meat of me.
Goodbye!: They’ve made me worms' meat.

Anon!: Till noon?
Goodbye!: Till noon?

Anon!: Do you not hear him?
Goodbye!: Don’t you hear him?

Anon!: Good troth, you do me wrong, good sooth, you do, In such disdainful manner me to woo.
Goodbye!: Good luck, you’re wrong, good sooth, you do, and I’m so disdainful to woo.

Anon!: Then both, or one, or anything thou wilt.
Goodbye!: Then both, or one, or anything you want.

Anon!: For your desire to know what is between us, O'ermaster ’t as you may.
Goodbye!: For your desire to know what’s going on between us, please, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, o

Anon!: thee aloud “England is thine, Ireland is thine, France is thine, and Harry Plantagenet is thine,” who, though I speak it before his face, if he be not fellow with the best king, thou shalt find the best king of good fellows.
Goodbye!: You said, “England is yours, Ireland is yours, France is yours, and Harry Plantagenet is yours,” who, even though I speak before his face, if he isn’t the

Anon!: Observe him, for the love of mockery, for I know this letter will make a contemplative idiot of him.
Goodbye!: Watch him, because I love mockery, because I know this letter will make him a contemplative idiot.

Anon!: Rapier and dagger.
Goodbye!: Rapier and dagger.

Anon!: So farewell to you both.
Goodbye!: Goodbye to you both.

Anon!: I took him sleeping—that is finished too— And the Athenian woman by his side, That, when he waked, of force she must be eyed.
Goodbye!: I took him to sleep—that’s finished too—and the Athenian woman by his side, that when he wakes up, she must be seen.

Anon!: Shame come to Romeo!
Goodbye!: Shame on Romeo!

Anon!: I stay too long from her.
Goodbye!: I’m staying away from her for too long.

Anon!: I left no ring with her.
Goodbye!: I didn’t leave any ring with her.

Anon!: Come you to make confession to this Father?
Goodbye!: Do you come to make confession to this Father?

Anon!: The note lies in ’s throat, if he say I said so.
Goodbye!: The note is in the throat, if he says I said that.

Anon!: As I am Egypt’s queen, Thou blushest, Antony, and that blood of thine Is Caesar’s homager.
Goodbye!: As I am Egypt’s queen, you blushest, Antony, and that blood of yours is Caesar’s homage.

Anon!: What mean’st thou by that?
Goodbye!: What do you mean by that?

Anon!: Oh, Caesar, This Charmian lived but now.
Goodbye!: Oh, Caesar, this Charmian lived only now.

Anon!: Cheerly, boys.
Goodbye!: Cheers, boys.

Anon!: How like you the young German, the Duke of Saxony’s nephew?
Goodbye!: How are you, the German young man, the Duke of Saxony’s nephew?

Anon!: That’s our offer.
Goodbye!: That’s what we’re offering.

Anon!: Another general shout!
Goodbye!: Another shout!

Anon!: Be clamorous, and leap all civil bounds, Rather than make unprofited return.
Goodbye!: Be clamorous and leap all civil bounds, rather than make unprofited return.

Anon!: That you do think you are not what you are.
Goodbye!: You don’t think you’re what you’re.

Anon!: What says he of our marriage?
Goodbye!: What does he say about our marriage?

Anon!: How hast thou the heart, Being a divine, a ghostly confessor, A sin-absolver, and my friend professed, To mangle me with that word “banishèd”?
Goodbye!: How have you been a divine, a ghostly confessor, a sin-absolver, and my friend said you’re trying to fool me with that word banishment?

Anon!: Even such a husband Hast thou of me as she is for a wife.
Goodbye!: You’re a husband like her for a wife.

Anon!: He’s a coward and a coistrel that will not drink to my niece till his brains turn o' th' toe like a parish top.
Goodbye!: He’s a coward and a coistrel who won’t drink to my niece until his brains turn toe like a parish top.

Anon!: Where’s Potpan, that he helps not to take away?
Goodbye!: Where’s Potpan, that he doesn’t help take away?

Anon!: He dares not come there for the candle.
Goodbye!: He doesn’t dare come here to drink the candle.

Anon!: If you prove a mutineer, the next tree.
Goodbye!: If you’re a mutineer, the next tree will be the tree.

Anon!: And this report Hath so exasperated the king that he Prepares for some attempt of war.
Goodbye!: And this report has exasperated the king so much that he’s ready for some war.

Anon!: Well, And well am like to do, for I perceive, Four feasts are toward.
Goodbye!: Well, and I’m like to do, because I see, four feasts are coming.

Anon!: And shall I couple hell?
Goodbye!: And should I just marry hell?

Anon!: What do you here alone?
Goodbye!: What are you doing alone?

Anon!: Sir, I have not you by the hand.
Goodbye!: Sir, I haven’t seen you.

Anon!: At five o'clock I shall receive the money for the same.
Goodbye!: At five o'clock I’ll receive the money for the same.

Anon!: You minion, you, are these your customers?
Goodbye!: You, you, are these your customers?

Anon!: Your love says, like an honest gentleman, and a courteous, and a kind, and a handsome, and, I warrant, a virtuous— Where is your mother?
Goodbye!: Your love says, like an honest gentleman, a courteous, kind, handsome, and, I’m sure, virtuous— Where is your mother?

Anon!: Marry, this it is, sir.
Goodbye!: That’s it, sir.

Anon!: Who will go with me?
Goodbye!: Who will go with me?

Anon!: Ay, I do.
Goodbye!: Yes, I do.

Anon!: What, would you make me mad?
Goodbye!: What, would you make me mad?

Anon!: The what?
Goodbye!: What?

Anon!: Sure we thank you.
Goodbye!: Thank you.

Anon!: I think thou art in mind, and so am I. Nay, master, both in mind and in my shape.
Goodbye!: I think you’re thinking, and so am I.

Anon!: Give me some ink and paper.
Goodbye!: Give me some ink and paper.

Anon!: That sir which serves and seeks for gain,  And follows but for form,  Will pack when it begins to rain  And leave thee in the storm.
Goodbye!: The sir who serves and seeks for profit, and follows only for form, will pack when it begins to rain and leave you in the storm.

Anon!: He has killed me, mother.
Goodbye!: He’s killed me, mother.

Anon!: At my lodging.
Goodbye!: I’m here.

Anon!: O Thou, whose captain I account myself, Look on my forces with a gracious eye.
Goodbye!: Oh, you, whose captain I’m referring to myself, look at my forces with a gracious eye.

Anon!: Sir, I lack advancement.
Goodbye!: Sir, I’m not getting any progress.

Anon!: Every man look o'er his part.
Goodbye!: Every man looks at his part.

Anon!: Friends, begone.
Goodbye!: Friends, go.

Anon!: Let heaven and men and devils, let them all, All, all cry shame against me, yet I’ll speak.
Goodbye!: Let heaven and men and devils, let them all cry shame against me, but I’ll speak.

Anon!: Nay, I am the very pink of courtesy.
Goodbye!: No, I’m the very pink of courtesy.

Anon!: You envy my advancement, and my friends'.
Goodbye!: You envy my advancement, and my friends’.

Anon!: Well, daughter, and you gentlewomen all, Withdraw into a chamber by yourselves, And when I send for you, come hither masked.
Goodbye!: Well, daughter, and you ladies, all get out of here and come dressed.

Anon!: She’s gone forever.
Goodbye!: She’s gone forever.

Anon!: Dead art thou!
Goodbye!: You’re dead!

Anon!: Wife!
Goodbye!: Wife!

Anon!: Call in the messengers sent from the Dauphin.
Goodbye!: Call in the messengers sent from the Dauphin.

Anon!: I am half afeard Thou wilt say anon he is some kin to thee, Thou spend’st such high-day wit in praising him.— Come, come, Nerissa, for I long to see Quick Cupid’s post that comes so mannerly.
Goodbye!: I’m half afeard that you’ll say that he’s a kin to you, and you’re so witful of praising him.—Come on, Nerissa, for

Anon!: Aunchient Pistol, I do partly understand your meaning.
Goodbye!: Aunchient Pistol, I understand a lot about your meaning.

Anon!: Hast thou forgot thyself?
Goodbye!: Have you forgotten yourself?

Anon!: If it prove lawful prize, he’s made for ever.
Goodbye!: If it’s a good prize, he’s always made for you.

Anon!: Oh, she doth teach the torches to burn bright!
Goodbye!: Oh, she’s teaching the torches to burn bright!

Anon!: Most royal majesty, I crave no more than hath your highness offered.
Goodbye!: Most royal majesty, I don’t want to do anything more than you’ve offered.

Anon!: No, I am a Welshman.
Goodbye!: No, I’m a Welshman.

Anon!: Thee and thy virtues here I seize upon, Be it lawful I take up what’s cast away.
Goodbye!: I’ll take your virtues here, whether it’s legal or not I’ll take up what’s left out.

Anon!: I have no more sons of the royal blood For thee to slaughter.
Goodbye!: I have no more royal sons for you to slaughter.

Anon!: O my good lord, Believe not all, or, if you must believe, Stomach not all.
Goodbye!: Oh, my good lord, don’t believe everything, or if you have to believe it, don’t shake everything.

Anon!: Well, then, that’s the humor of ’t.
Goodbye!: Well, then, that’s the humor of it.

Anon!: Set me the stoups of wine upon that table.
Goodbye!: Put the stoups of wine on that table.

Anon!: The wager thou hast won, and I will add Unto their losses twenty thousand crowns, Another dowry to another daughter, For she is changed as she had never been.
Goodbye!: The wager you’ve won, and I’ll add twenty thousand crowns to their losses, another dowry to another daughter, because she’s changed as she never had.

Anon!: While we were interchanging thrusts and blows, Came more and more and fought on part and part, Till the Prince came, who parted either part.
Goodbye!: While we were fighting, we fought on both sides, until the Prince came, who parted either of them.

Anon!: In the meantime, Let me be thought too busy in my fears— As worthy cause I have to fear I am— And hold her free, I do beseech your honor.
Goodbye!: In the meantime, let me be thought too busy about my fears—as worthy reason I have to fear myself—and hold her free, I beg your honor.

Anon!: It would make a man mad as a buck to be so bought and sold.
Goodbye!: It would make a man insane to be bought and sold so quickly.

Anon!: Knock you here, sir?
Goodbye!: Knock you here, sir?

Anon!: I wish you well, and so I take my leave.
Goodbye!: I wish you well, and so I’ll leave.

Anon!: None, man.
Goodbye!: No, man.

Anon!: I am not a slut, though I thank the gods I am foul.
Goodbye!: I’m not a slut, even though I thank the gods for being foul.

Anon!: Light, gentlemen, I’ll bind it with my shirt.
Goodbye!: I’ll tie it up with my shirt.

Anon!: See me no more, whether he be dead or no.
Goodbye!: Don’t see me anymore, whether he’s dead or not.

Anon!: Farewell, hostess.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, hostess.

Anon!: You’re welcome, sir, and he for your good sake.
Goodbye!: You’re welcome, sir, and he’s for your good sake.

Anon!: Here’s such a coil.
Goodbye!: Here’s a slew of sleeves.

Anon!: Behold the ordnance on their carriages, With fatal mouths gaping on girded Harfleur.
Goodbye!: Look at the munitions on their carriages, with fatal mouths gaping on the girded Harfleur.

Anon!: But, Lepidus, go you to Caesar’s house.
Goodbye!: But Lepidus, go to Caesar’s house.

Anon!: Go to, go to.
Goodbye!: Go to, go to.

Anon!: Nerissa teaches me what to believe.
Goodbye!: Nerissa’s telling me what to believe.

Anon!: Yea,” quoth my husband, “Fall’st upon thy face?
Goodbye!: Yes,” my husband said, “Fall on your face?

Anon!: Neither rhyme nor reason can express how much.
Goodbye!: No rhyme or reason can tell how much.

Anon!: So I, being young, till now ripe not to reason.
Goodbye!: So I’m young, and I’m not ready to be a good reasoner.

Anon!: Utter your gravity o'er a gossip’s bowl, For here we need it not.
Goodbye!: Don’t let your gravity go into a gossip’s bowl, because here we don’t need it.

Anon!: Let’s ha' ’t, good Grumio.
Goodbye!: Let’s do it, good Grumio.

Anon!: No.
Goodbye!: No.

Anon!: There, sir, stop.
Goodbye!: Stop there, sir.

Anon!: Have not saints lips, and holy palmers too?
Goodbye!: Don’t saints have lips, and holy palmers too?

Anon!: And tell the Dauphin His jest will savor but of shallow wit When thousands weep more than did laugh at it.
Goodbye!: And tell the Dauphin his wit will savor only when thousands of people cry more than they laughed at it.

Anon!: The cunning of her passion Invites me in this churlish messenger.
Goodbye!: The sanity of her passion invites me to join this churlish messenger.

Anon!: He lives that loves thee better than he could.
Goodbye!: He’s a man who loves you better than he could.

Anon!: You shall Have letters from me to some friends that will Sweep your way for you.
Goodbye!: You’ll have letters from me to some friends who will go to you.

Anon!: Shall I tell you why?
Goodbye!: Shall I tell you why?

Anon!: Without his roe, like a dried herring.
Goodbye!: Without his roe, like a dried herring.

Anon!: I am quickly ill, and well, So Antony loves.
Goodbye!: I’m ill quickly, and I love it.

Anon!: Win me and wear me!
Goodbye!: Win me and wear me!

Anon!: Farewell, my Desdemona.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, Desdemona.

Anon!: No, boy.
Goodbye!: No, boy.

Anon!: Wit shall not go unrewarded while I am king of this country.
Goodbye!: I won’t betray you while I’m king of this country.

Anon!: If you went in pain, master, this knave would go sore.
Goodbye!: If you went in pain, master, this knave would go sore.

Anon!: Why should you fall into so deep an O?
Goodbye!: Why should you fall into such a deep hole?

Anon!: O you sir, you, come you hither, sir.
Goodbye!: Oh, sir, you, come here, sir.

Anon!: Ely with Richmond troubles me more near Than Buckingham and his rash-levied strength.
Goodbye!: Richmond’s rash-stricken strength makes me more upset with him than Buckingham’s.

Anon!: Neighbors, God speed.
Goodbye!: Neighbors, God hurry.

Anon!: Therefore we’ll have some half a dozen friends, And there an end.
Goodbye!: So we’ll have about half a dozen friends, and that’s the end.

Anon!: But in my conscience, sir, I do not care for you.
Goodbye!: But I don’t care about you, sir.

Anon!: I would forget it fain, But oh, it presses to my memory, Like damnèd guilty deeds to sinners' minds.
Goodbye!: I’d forget it, but it presses to my memory like damned guilty deeds to sinners’ minds.

Anon!: I would these dewy tears were from the ground.
Goodbye!: I wish these tears were from the ground.

Anon!: But she perforce withholds the lovèd boy, Crowns him with flowers, and makes him all her joy.
Goodbye!: But she keeps the lovable boy from being beaten, and she makes him happy.

Anon!: My name is Roderigo.
Goodbye!: My name is Roderigo.

Anon!: Parted you in good terms?
Goodbye!: Have you been pitying in good terms?

Anon!: Malcolm!
Goodbye!: Malcolm!

Anon!: If not, when you have stomachs.
Goodbye!: If not, when you have stomachs.

Anon!: If thy revengeful heart cannot forgive, Lo, here I lend thee this sharp-pointed sword, Which if thou please to hide in this true breast And let the soul forth that adoreth thee, I lay it naked to the deadly stroke And humbly beg the death upon my knee.
Goodbye!: If you can’t forgive your revenge, Lo, here I give you this sharp-pointed sword, which if you want to hide in this true breast and let the soul of you go, I lay it naked to the deadly

Anon!: Madam, I heard her speak.
Goodbye!: Madam, I heard her speak.

Anon!: But I have, sir, a son by order of law, some year older than this, who yet is no dearer in my account.
Goodbye!: But I have a son, sir, who is a little older than this, who is still no dearer than me.

Anon!: Oh, here Will I set up my everlasting rest, And shake the yoke of inauspicious stars From this world-wearied flesh.
Goodbye!: Oh, I’ll rest here forever and shake the yoke of savage stars from this world-wearied flesh.

Anon!: Search every acre in the high-grown field, And bring him to our eye.
Goodbye!: Search every acre in the high-growth field and bring him to our eyes.

Anon!: Thus Rosalind of many parts By heavenly synod was devised, Of many faces, eyes, and hearts To have the touches dearest prized.
Goodbye!: So Rosalind was created in a heavenly synod, with many faces, eyes, and hearts, to have the most precious touches.

Anon!: Ay, springes to catch woodcocks.
Goodbye!: Yes, it’s springing to catch woodcocks.

Anon!: Kill Brutus, and be honored in his death.
Goodbye!: Kill Brutus and be honored in his death.

Anon!: Is this the monument of Leonato?
Goodbye!: Is this the monument of Leonato?

Anon!: This wind you talk of, blows us from ourselves.
Goodbye!: This wind you’re talking about blows us away from ourselves.

Anon!: Some bloody passion shakes your very frame.
Goodbye!: You’re in a mood of bloody anger.

Anon!: Who chooseth me shall get as much as he deserves.” “As much as he deserves!”—pause there, Morocco, And weigh thy value with an even hand.
Goodbye!: Who chooses me will get as much as he deserves.” “As much as he deserves!”—Go back there, Morocco, and weigh your value with a fair hand.

Anon!: But I am constant as the northern star, Of whose true-fixed and resting quality There is no fellow in the firmament.
Goodbye!: But I’m always the northern star, of whom I’m a true-fixed and resting star, and I don’t have any other person in the firmament.

Anon!: The fool will stay.
Goodbye!: The fool will stay.

Anon!: But, like a misbehaved and sullen wench, Thou pout’st upon thy fortune and thy love.
Goodbye!: But like a misbehaved and sullen wench, you’re poutching on your fortune and your love.

Anon!: No, by my life and soul!
Goodbye!: No, by my life and soul!

Anon!: I will physic your rankness and yet give no thousand crowns neither.—Holla, Dennis!
Goodbye!: I’ll physicize your rank and give no thousand crowns.—Holla, Dennis!

Anon!: Catesby, fly to the duke.
Goodbye!: Catesby, go to the duke.

Anon!: Now is the winter of our discontent Made glorious summer by this son of York, And all the clouds that loured upon our house In the deep bosom of the ocean buried.
Goodbye!: Now we’ve been ruined by this son of York, and all the clouds that shook our house in the deep ocean are buried.

Anon!: Go.
Goodbye!: Go.

Anon!: Here lies the county slain, And Juliet bleeding, warm and newly dead, Who here hath lain these two days buried.— Go, tell the Prince.
Goodbye!: Here lies the slain county, and Juliet is bleeding, warm and newly dead, who has been buried here for two days.—Go, tell the Prince.

Anon!: There’s hell, there’s darkness, there’s the sulfurous pit— burning, scalding, stench, consumption!
Goodbye!: There’s hell, darkness, the sulfurous pit— burning, scalding, stench, consumption!

Anon!: Upon my life, she finds, although I cannot, Myself to be a marv'lous proper man.
Goodbye!: I’m sure she’s a sane, sane man.

Anon!: Yea, but so I am apt to do myself wrong.
Goodbye!: Yes, but I’m apt to do myself wrong.

Anon!: Well, you are gone both ways.
Goodbye!: Well, you’re going both ways.

Anon!: Remember thee!
Goodbye!: Remember you!

Anon!: This ’greed upon To part with unhacked edges and bear back Our targes undinted.
Goodbye!: This was the first time we’ve gotten together to break with unharmed edges and bear back our targes uninted.

Anon!: How now?
Goodbye!: What’s going on?

Anon!: Good night, good night!
Goodbye!: Good night, good night!

Anon!: We were Christians eno' before, e'en as many as could well live one by another.
Goodbye!: We were Christians before, and we could live as many as we could.

Anon!: No port is free, no place That guard and most unusual vigilance Does not attend my taking.
Goodbye!: No port is free, no place that guards and vigilance isn’t watching me take.

Anon!: More validity, More honorable state, more courtship lives In carrion flies than Romeo.
Goodbye!: More validity, more honorable state, more courtship lives in carrion flies than Romeo.

Anon!: No slander.
Goodbye!: No slander.

Anon!: I will survey th' inscriptions back again.
Goodbye!: I’ll look at the inscriptions back again.

Anon!: Will it never be morning?
Goodbye!: Will it never be morning?

Anon!: O noble prince, I can discover all The unlucky manage of this fatal brawl.
Goodbye!: Oh, noble prince, I can see all the unfortunate consequences of this fatal brawl.

Anon!: My lord.
Goodbye!: My lord.

Anon!: Think and die.
Goodbye!: Think and die.

Anon!: For youth is bought more oft than begged or borrow’d.
Goodbye!: Young people are more expensive to buy than to begged or borrow.

Anon!: Post to Salisbury.
Goodbye!: Post to Salisbury.

Anon!: My lord, I do not know that I did cry.
Goodbye!: My lord, I don’t know that I cried.

Anon!: Let us bear him To th’ court of guard.
Goodbye!: Let’s take him to the court of guard.

Anon!: Amen.
Goodbye!: Amen.

Anon!: Therefore I pray you lead me to the caskets To try my fortune.
Goodbye!: So please lead me to the caskets to try my luck.

Anon!: So let him land, And solemnly see him set on to London.
Goodbye!: Let him land and solemnly see him set off to London.

Anon!: If it be found so, some will dear abide it.
Goodbye!: If it’s found, some will be happy with it.

Anon!: No, sir, I live by the church.
Goodbye!: No, sir, I’m living by the church.

Anon!: Good night, lieutenant, I must to the watch.
Goodbye!: Good night, lieutenant, I have to watch.

Anon!: Come, stir, stir, stir!
Goodbye!: Come on, stir up, stir up, stir up!

Anon!: We are three of them.
Goodbye!: We’re three of them.

Anon!: Come hither, Leonato.
Goodbye!: Come here, Leonato.

Anon!: Is this the Prince’s brother?
Goodbye!: Is this the Prince’s brother?

Anon!: Friendship is constant in all other things Save in the office and affairs of love.
Goodbye!: Friendship is constant in all other things except in the office and affairs of love.

Anon!: O my son, my son!
Goodbye!: Oh, my son, my son!

Anon!: Sweet-heart!
Goodbye!: Sweetheart!

Anon!: O Lord, methought what pain it was to drown, What dreadful noise of waters in my ears, What sights of ugly death within my eyes.
Goodbye!: Oh Lord, I thought about how painful it was to drown, how dreadful sound of water in my ears, and how ugly death in my eyes.

Anon!: My gracious sovereign.
Goodbye!: My gracious sovereign.

Anon!: And ever will—though he do shake me off To beggarly divorcement—love him dearly, Comfort forswear me!
Goodbye!: And if he shakes me off to beg me to divorce me, I’ll always love him.

Anon!: It came even from the heart of—oh, she’s dead!
Goodbye!: It came from the heart of—oh, she’s dead!

Anon!: I will be flesh and blood, For there was never yet philosopher That could endure the toothache patiently, However they have writ the style of gods And made a push at chance and sufferance.
Goodbye!: I’ll be flesh and blood, because there was never a philosopher who could endure the toothache patiently, even if they writ the style of gods and made a push at chance and suffer.

Anon!: The violet smells to him as it doth to me.
Goodbye!: The violet smells to him as it smells to me.

Anon!: Adieu.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: Thus we may see,” quoth he, “how the world wags.
Goodbye!: So we can see,” he said, “how the world is doing.

Anon!: Never, my lord.
Goodbye!: Never, my lord.

Anon!: Or would you have me speak after my custom, as being a professed tyrant to their sex?
Goodbye!: Or would you want me to speak like a tyrant to their sex?

Anon!: Strike, drum.
Goodbye!: Beat the drum.

Anon!: These wise men that give fools money get themselves a good report—after fourteen years' purchase.
Goodbye!: These wise men who give fools money get themselves a good report—after fourteen years’ purchase.

Anon!: Poor Tom shall lead thee.
Goodbye!: Poor Tom will lead you.

Anon!: O thou foul thief, where hast thou stowed my daughter?
Goodbye!: Oh, you thief, where have you stowed my daughter?

Anon!: Madam, I had rather seal my lips Than to my peril speak that which is not.
Goodbye!: Madam, I’d rather seal my lips than speak to my own danger.

Anon!: The duke of York commends him to your Majesty.
Goodbye!: The duke of York recommends him to your Majesty.

Anon!: Temperance was a delicate wench.
Goodbye!: Temperance was a delicate wench.

Anon!: When I am known aright you shall not grieve Lending me this acquaintance.
Goodbye!: When I’m known as a good man, you won’t grieve letting me know this.

Anon!: An we do not, it is pity of our lives.
Goodbye!: If we don’t, it’s a pity of our lives.

Anon!: Dismayed not this our captains, Macbeth and Banquo?
Goodbye!: Don’t you think this is the captains Macbeth and Banquo?

Anon!: I’ll go along, no such sight to be shown, But to rejoice in splendor of mine own.
Goodbye!: I’ll go along, no one can see that, but I’ll rejoice in my own splendor.

Anon!: For I tell you, father, I am as peremptory as she proud-minded; And where two raging fires meet together, They do consume the thing that feeds their fury.
Goodbye!: I tell you, father, I’m as ill-tempered as she is proud.

Anon!: Well get you gone.
Goodbye!: Well, go away.

Anon!: The door is open, sir.
Goodbye!: The door is open, sir.

Anon!: Gower is a good captain, and is good knowledge and literatured in the wars.
Goodbye!: Gower is a good captain, and he has good knowledge and literature in the wars.

Anon!: Where is she?
Goodbye!: Where is she?

Anon!: Of this discourse we more will hear anon.— Egeus, I will overbear your will.
Goodbye!: We’ll hear more about this.—Egeus, I’ll overbear your will.

Anon!: O God’s lady dear, Are you so hot?
Goodbye!: Oh God’s lady, are you so hot?

Anon!: My good knave Eros, now thy captain is Even such a body.
Goodbye!: My good king Eros, now your captain is even such a body.

Anon!: We will be witnesses.
Goodbye!: We’ll be witnesses.

Anon!: Tender yourself more dearly, Or—not to crack the wind of the poor phrase, Running it thus—you’ll tender me a fool.
Goodbye!: Give yourself more money or—not to crack the wind of the poor phrase, running it like this—you’ll give me a fool.

Anon!: Looks he as freshly as he did the day he wrestled?
Goodbye!: Is he as young as he did the day he wrestled?

Anon!: Come, civil night, Thou sober-suited matron, all in black, And learn me how to lose a winning match Played for a pair of stainless maidenhoods.
Goodbye!: Come, civil night, you handsome matron, all in black, and learn how to lose a winning match played for a pair of stainless-steel-trained women.

Anon!: Go, Biondello, bid your mistress come to me.
Goodbye!: Go, Biondello, tell your mistress to come to me.

Anon!: Ah, where’s my man?—Give me some aqua vitae.— These griefs, these woes, these sorrows make me old.
Goodbye!: Ah, where’s my man?—Give me some vitae.—These griefs, these sorrows, these sorrows make me old.

Anon!: Truly, and I hold ambition of so airy and light a quality that it is but a shadow’s shadow.
Goodbye!: I’m sure it’s a shadow’s shadow.

Anon!: You tallow face!
Goodbye!: You tallow face!

Anon!: Oh, what a rogue and peasant slave am I!
Goodbye!: Oh, what a rogue and peasant slave I am!

Anon!: Then will I lay the serving creature’s dagger on your pate.
Goodbye!: Then I’ll lay the servant creature’s dagger on your pate.

Anon!: Marry, if he that writ it had played Pyramus and hanged himself in Thisbe’s garter, it would have been a fine tragedy.
Goodbye!: If the one who wrote this book had played Pyramus and hanged himself in Thisbe’s robe, it would have been a fine tragedy.

Anon!: Let it fall rather, though the fork invade The region of my heart.
Goodbye!: Let it fall, even though the fork invades my heart.

Anon!: I know thee well—a serviceable villain, As duteous to the vices of thy mistress As badness would desire.
Goodbye!: I know you—a sane villain, as a villain as he is a sane, as he is a villain, as he is a villain, as a villain as bad as

Anon!: Pray you, sir, do you know of this matter?
Goodbye!: Do you know about this?

Anon!: Let us swear That you are worth your breeding, which I doubt not,
Goodbye!: Let’s swear that you’re worthy of your breeding, which I don’t doubt.

Anon!: You peasant swain!
Goodbye!: You swain a peasant!

Anon!: A dog of that house shall move me to stand.
Goodbye!: A dog from that house will move me to stand.

Anon!: Pisa, renownèd for grave citizens, Gave me my being and my father first, A merchant of great traffic through the world, Vincentio, come of the Bentivolii.
Goodbye!: Pisa, renamed for grave citizens, gave me my father and my being first, a merchant of great traffic through the world, Vincentio, come from the Bentivolii.

Anon!: Princes and counties!
Goodbye!: Princes and counties!

Anon!: Thy threats have no more strength than her weak prayers.— Helen, I love thee.
Goodbye!: Your threats don’t have any more strength than her weak prayers.—Henry, I love you.

Anon!: Age cannot wither her, nor custom stale Her infinite variety.
Goodbye!: Age can’t wither her, and her infinite variety can’t be stale.

Anon!: Give me mine angle.
Goodbye!: Give me my angle.

Anon!: Portia, forgive me this enforcèd wrong, And in the hearing of these many friends I swear to thee, even by thine own fair eyes Wherein I see myself—     Mark you but that!
Goodbye!: Portia, forgive me this imposed wrong, and I swear to you, even by your own fair eyes, wherein I see myself— don’t be afraid to do that!

Anon!: Our queen and all our elves come here anon.
Goodbye!: Our queen and all our elves come here.

Anon!: Or that I had any friend would be a man for my sake!
Goodbye!: Or that any friend I had would be a man for my sake!

Anon!: So the fool follows after.
Goodbye!: The fool follows him.

Anon!: Sir, there is especial commission come from Venice to depute Cassio in Othello’s place.
Goodbye!: Sir, there’s a special commission coming from Venice to depute Cassio in Othello’s place.

Anon!: My noble uncle, do you know the cause?
Goodbye!: My uncle, do you know the cause?

Anon!: That will I do.
Goodbye!: I’ll do that.

Anon!: What should I do?
Goodbye!: What should I do?

Anon!: Send for the county.
Goodbye!: Send for the county.

Anon!: If he do resist, Subdue him at his peril!
Goodbye!: If he resists, please forgive him for his sins!

Anon!: Come hither, captain.
Goodbye!: Come here, captain.

Anon!: If you choose that, then I am yours withal.
Goodbye!: If you choose that, then I’ll be yours withal.

Anon!: Nay, press not so upon me.
Goodbye!: Don’t press on me.

Anon!: We cannot all be masters, nor all masters Cannot be truly followed.
Goodbye!: We can’t all be masters, and we can’t be followed.

Anon!: Even so.
Goodbye!: That’s true.

Anon!: Wrong not her birth.
Goodbye!: Don’t mistake her birth.

Anon!: And another storm brewing, I hear it sing i' th' wind.
Goodbye!: And another storm is coming, I hear it sing in the wind.

Anon!: Some wine, ho!
Goodbye!: Get some wine!

Anon!: And so it is, truly, and very notably discharged.
Goodbye!: That’s true, and it’s very well discharged.

Anon!: Mercutio, thou consort’st with Romeo.
Goodbye!: Mercutio, you’re consorting with Romeo.

Anon!: O, what more favor can I do to thee, Than with that hand that cut thy youth in twain To sunder his that was thine enemy?
Goodbye!: Oh, what more favor can I do to you than to sunder his enemy with the hand that cut your youth in two ways?

Anon!: I’ll have this crown of mine cut from my shoulders Before I’ll see the crown so foul misplaced.
Goodbye!: I’ll have this crown of mine cut from my shoulders before I see the crown so badly misplaced.

Anon!: If, sir, perchance She have restrained the riots of your followers, 'Tis on such ground and to such wholesome end As clears her from all blame.
Goodbye!: If she has resisted the riots of your followers, she’ll be on such a solid ground as to protect her from all blame.

Anon!: Oh!
Goodbye!: Oh!

Anon!: Good sir, draw near to me.
Goodbye!: Good sir, come near to me.

Anon!: In sooth, I know not why I am so sad.
Goodbye!: I don’t know why I’m so sad.

Anon!: Meseemeth good that with some little train Forthwith from Ludlow the young prince be fet Hither to London, to be crowned our king.
Goodbye!: It’s good that the young prince will be fet to London with some little train to be crowned our king.

Anon!: This is the day which, in King Edward’s time, I wished might fall on me when I was found False to his children and his wife’s allies.
Goodbye!: This is the day I wished I could fall on me when I was found to be false to his children and his wife’s allies.

Anon!: Good night.
Goodbye!: Good night.

Anon!: Speak, Agrippa.
Goodbye!: Speak, Agrippa.

Anon!: Those that were your father’s enemies Have steeped their galls in honey, and do serve you With hearts create of duty and of zeal.
Goodbye!: The people who were your father’s enemies have sprayed their galls with honey, and serve you with hearts that create a sense of duty and zeal.

Anon!: Go fetch it, sister.
Goodbye!: Go get it, sister.

Anon!: I’ll fight till from my bones my flesh be hacked.
Goodbye!: I’ll fight until my flesh is hacked from my bones.

Anon!: The blow thou hadst Shall make thy peace for moving me to rage, And I will boot thee with what gift beside Thy modesty can beg.
Goodbye!: The blow you had will make me feel better when you move me to rage, and I’ll bet you what you can beg.

Anon!: He’s bound unto Octavia.
Goodbye!: He’s bound to Octavia.

Anon!: Good morrow, Benedick.
Goodbye!: Good morning, Benedick.

Anon!: Take thy forfeiture.
Goodbye!: Take your forfeiture.

Anon!: What handkerchief?
Goodbye!: What handkerchief?

Anon!: One inch of delay more is a South Sea of discovery.
Goodbye!: One inch of delay is more than a South Sea discovery.

Anon!: Where’s thy drum?
Goodbye!: Where’s your drum?

Anon!: Yet marked I where the bolt of Cupid fell.
Goodbye!: But I was pointing to where Cupid fell.

Anon!: How comes that?
Goodbye!: How is that?

Anon!: And the business you have broached here cannot be without you, especially that of Cleopatra’s, which wholly depends on your abode.
Goodbye!: And the business you’ve done here can’t be without you, especially the business of Cleopatra’s, which is entirely dependent on your home.

Anon!: You shall be more beloving than beloved.
Goodbye!: You’ll be more beloving than you’ll be beloved.
