Anon!: For you know, nuncle, The hedge-sparrow fed the cuckoo so long, That it’s had it head bit off by it young.
Goodbye!: You know, uncle, the hedge-sparrow fed the cuckoo so long, that it had it bit off its head young.

Anon!: They shall have none, I swear, but these my joints, Which, if they have, as I will leave 'em them, Shall yield them little.
Goodbye!: I swear they won’t have any, but my joints, which, if they have, as I’ll leave them, will yield them little.

Anon!: Go fetch fire.
Goodbye!: Go get fire.

Anon!: Who are the late commissioners?
Goodbye!: Who are the late commissioners?

Anon!: I have more care to stay than will to go.
Goodbye!: I’m more concerned about staying than I want to go.

Anon!: Ay, a tailor, sir.
Goodbye!: Yes, a tailor, sir.

Anon!: Had she affections and warm youthful blood, She would be as swift in motion as a ball.
Goodbye!: If she had affections and youthful blood, she would be as swift in motion as a ball.

Anon!: Let this be so.
Goodbye!: Let this be.

Anon!: Barren my wit?
Goodbye!: Do you have my wit?

Anon!: Decius, go tell them Caesar will not come.
Goodbye!: Decius, tell them that Caesar won’t come.

Anon!: Men at some time are masters of their fates.
Goodbye!: Some men are masters of their fates.

Anon!: Why should that name be sounded more than yours?
Goodbye!: Why should that name be sounded more than yours?

Anon!: Ay me, most wretched, That have my heart parted betwixt two friends That does afflict each other!
Goodbye!: Yes, I’m wretched, and I’ve been beaten up by two friends who are fighting each other!

Anon!: Hortensio, have you told him all her faults?
Goodbye!: Hortensio, have you told him all her faults?

Anon!: Shall I know your answer?
Goodbye!: Shall I know your answer?

Anon!: What’s that, my lord?
Goodbye!: What’s that, my lord?

Anon!: And seemed I ever otherwise to you?
Goodbye!: And did I ever seem to be like that to you?

Anon!: Yea, Richard, when I know, for I protest As yet I do not.
Goodbye!: Yes, Richard, when I know, because I’m not protesting yet.

Anon!: This lanthorn doth the hornèd moon present.
Goodbye!: This lanthorn is the horned moon present.

Anon!: The time to come.
Goodbye!: The time to come.

Anon!: O wife, look how our daughter bleeds!
Goodbye!: Oh wife, look at how our daughter bleeds!

Anon!: He uses his folly like a stalking-horse, and under the presentation of that he shoots his wit.
Goodbye!: He’s a stalking-horse, and he’s a wit-strength.

Anon!: She gives it out that you shall marry her.
Goodbye!: She tells you to marry her.

Anon!: Mark his condition and the event.
Goodbye!: Mark his condition and the event.

Anon!: You will never run mad, niece.
Goodbye!: You’ll never run crazy, niece.

Anon!: Ay, husband.
Goodbye!: Yes, husband.

Anon!: Exclaim no more against it.
Goodbye!: Don’t say anything else.

Anon!: Yet you began rudely.
Goodbye!: But you started to be rude.

Anon!: Now, Signior, where’s the Count?
Goodbye!: Now, Signior, where’s the Count?

Anon!: Here the street is narrow.
Goodbye!: Here the street is narrow.

Anon!: All the perfumes of Arabia will not sweeten this little hand.
Goodbye!: All the Arabian perfumes won’t sweeten this little hand.

Anon!: Your father got excellent husbands, if a maid could come by them.
Goodbye!: Your father had excellent husbands, if a maid could come by them.

Anon!: Good lords, make all the speedy haste you may.
Goodbye!: Good lords, hurry up quickly.

Anon!: I do beseech you, take it not amiss; I cannot, nor I will not, yield to you.
Goodbye!: Please, don’t take it off the ground.

Anon!: Ay, on the front.
Goodbye!: Yes, on the front.

Anon!: I love you with so much of my heart that none is left to protest.
Goodbye!: I love you so much that none of you is left to protest.

Anon!: My leisure serves me, pensive daughter, now.— My lord, we must entreat the time alone.
Goodbye!: My leisure is for me now, my pensive daughter.—My lord, we have to wait for the time alone.

Anon!: My lord, the roinish clown, at whom so oft Your Grace was wont to laugh, is also missing.
Goodbye!: My lord, the roinish clown, at whom you were so often tempted to laugh, is also missing.

Anon!: O, gentlemen, see, see dead Henry’s wounds Open their congealed mouths and bleed afresh!— Blush, blush, thou lump of foul deformity, For ’tis thy presence that exhales this blood From cold and empty veins where no blood dwells.
Goodbye!: Oh, gentlemen, see, see dead Henry’s wounds open their mouths and bleed afresh!—Blush, blush, you lump of foul deformity, because your presence exhilades this

Anon!: he whom next thyself Of all the world I loved and to him put The manage of my state, as at that time Through all the signories it was the first, And Prospero the prime duke, being so reputed In dignity, and for the liberal arts Without a parallel.
Goodbye!: I loved him, and I was the first man to be the first man to be the prime duke, and Prospero was so reputed in dignity, and for the liberal arts without a parallel.

Anon!: That lord that counseled thee To give away thy land, Come place him here by me.
Goodbye!: That lord who advised you to give away your land, come place him here by me.

Anon!: Then shall the sighs of Octavia blow the fire up in Caesar, and, as I said before, that which is the strength of their amity shall prove the immediate author of their variance.
Goodbye!: Then Octavia’s sighs will blow the fire in Caesar, and, like I said before, the strength of their amity will prove the author of their disagreement.

Anon!: Shall I have some water?— Come, Kate, and wash, and welcome heartily.— You whoreson villain!
Goodbye!: Should I have some water?— Come, Kate, and wash, and welcome heartily.—You whoreson villain!

Anon!: I arrest thee of high treason, by the name of Richard, Earl of Cambridge.
Goodbye!: I’m arresting you for high treason, by the name of Richard, Earl of Cambridge.

Anon!: Here, madam.
Goodbye!: Here, madam.

Anon!: He hath an uncle here in Messina will be very much glad of it.
Goodbye!: He has an uncle here in Messina who will be very happy of it.

Anon!: I had rather be a peddler.
Goodbye!: I’d rather be a peddler.

Anon!: So-so” is good, very good, very excellent good.
Goodbye!: So-so” is good, very good, very excellent.

Anon!: Not till you have slept.
Goodbye!: Not until you’ve slept.

Anon!: Caius Ligarius doth bear Caesar hard, Who rated him for speaking well of Pompey.
Goodbye!: Caius Ligarius is a man who rated him for speaking well about Pompey.

Anon!: But didst thou hear without wondering how thy name should be hanged and carved upon these trees?
Goodbye!: But did you hear that without wondering how your name should be hanged and carved on these trees?

Anon!: I conjure thee by all the saints in heaven.
Goodbye!: I swear to you by all the saints in heaven.

Anon!: The law allows it, and the court awards it.
Goodbye!: The law allows it, and the court awards it.

Anon!: It is the devil.
Goodbye!: It’s the devil.

Anon!: Farewell.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: And death, not Romeo, take my maidenhead!
Goodbye!: And death, not Romeo, take my bridehead!

Anon!: The capon burns; the pig falls from the spit; The clock hath strucken twelve upon the bell; My mistress made it one upon my cheek.
Goodbye!: The capon burns, the pig falls from the spit, the clock has struck twelve on the bell, and my mistress made it one on my cheek.

Anon!: By Jeshu, I am your Majesty’s countryman, I care not who know it.
Goodbye!: By Jeshu, I’m your Majesty’s countryman, I don’t care who knows it.

Anon!: Who bare my letter, then, to Romeo?
Goodbye!: Who bared my letter to Romeo?

Anon!: O God, I have an ill-divining soul.
Goodbye!: Oh God, I have a bad-divining soul.

Anon!: Pray you, let Cassio be received again.
Goodbye!: Please, let Cassio be received again.

Anon!: I have as much of this in art as you, But yet my nature could not bear it so.
Goodbye!: I have as much of this in art as you do, but I can’t bear it.

Anon!: Woo’t weep?
Goodbye!: Wooh, cry?

Anon!: Sound, trumpet!
Goodbye!: Sound, trumpet!

Anon!: Tis true, this god did shake!
Goodbye!: It’s true, this god shook!

Anon!: Tis time that I were gone.
Goodbye!: It’s time for me to go.

Anon!: He can report, As seemeth by his plight, of the revolt The newest state.
Goodbye!: He can tell you, as he appears by his plight, that the revolt is the latest state.

Anon!: The contents, as in part I understand them, are to blame.
Goodbye!: The content, as I understand it, is to blame.

Anon!: You have lost no reputation at all unless you repute yourself such a loser.
Goodbye!: You haven’t lost any reputation unless you’re a man who’s a loser.

Anon!: O, but one word.
Goodbye!: Oh, just one word.

Anon!: You say well.
Goodbye!: You’re right.

Anon!: Why did you laugh then, when I said “man delights not me”?
Goodbye!: Why did you laugh when I said “man doesn’t delight me”?

Anon!: Sawst thou the melancholy Lord Northumberland?
Goodbye!: Did you see the melancholy Lord Northumberland?

Anon!: If you will let your lady know I am here to speak with her, and bring her along with you, it may awake my bounty further.
Goodbye!: If you tell your lady I’m here to speak with her, and bring her with you, it’ll awaken my bounty.

Anon!: This is old.
Goodbye!: This is old.

Anon!: A better instance, I say.
Goodbye!: A better example, I say.

Anon!: The one the other poisoned for my sake, And after slew herself.
Goodbye!: The one poisoned for my sake, and then slammed herself.

Anon!: Why dost thou wring thy hands?
Goodbye!: Why are you wringing your hands?

Anon!: With another, for tying his new shoes with old ribbon?
Goodbye!: With another, for tying his new shoes with old ribbon?

Anon!: Say that they slack their duties
Goodbye!: Say they’re not doing their jobs.

Anon!: Sleeping and waking, O, defend me still!
Goodbye!: Sleeping and waking, Oh, keep me safe!

Anon!: We’ll bring him to his house with shouts and clamors.
Goodbye!: We’ll bring him to his house with shouts and clamors.

Anon!: My lord, I shall reply amazèdly, Half sleep, half waking.
Goodbye!: My lord, I’ll reply amazingly, half sleep, half wake up.

Anon!: Will you have me, lady?
Goodbye!: Will you have me, lady?

Anon!: He sees thee not.
Goodbye!: He doesn’t see you.

Anon!: Remember what I have said.
Goodbye!: Remember what I’ve said.

Anon!: Why, what a king is this!
Goodbye!: What a king this is!

Anon!: That now I will have—that’s the humor of it.
Goodbye!: I’ll have it now—that’s the humor of it.

Anon!: And second father This lady makes him to me.
Goodbye!: And second father, this lady, makes him to me.

Anon!: I strike quickly, being moved.
Goodbye!: I’m stricken, being moved.

Anon!: Think you but that I know our state secure, I would be so triumphant as I am?
Goodbye!: Isn’t that you think I’m a good man, but I know that our state is secure, I’d be as triumphant as I am?

Anon!: Speak.
Goodbye!: Speak.

Anon!: Why, man, he’s a very devil.
Goodbye!: He’s a very devil.

Anon!: You might have come before.
Goodbye!: You might have come before.

Anon!: Nay, gentlemen, prepare not to be gone.
Goodbye!: No, gentlemen, don’t prepare to go.

Anon!: Pray you come in.
Goodbye!: Please come in.

Anon!: God 'i' good e'en.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: Why, right, you are in the right.
Goodbye!: You’re right, you’re right.

Anon!: May I with right and conscience make this claim?
Goodbye!: Can I make this claim with good and good conscience?

Anon!: Come you, sir.
Goodbye!: Come on, sir.

Anon!: Cassius, what night is this!
Goodbye!: Cassius, what night is this?

Anon!: But I’ll catch thine eyes, Though they had wings.
Goodbye!: But I’ll catch your eyes, even if they had wings.

Anon!: When time shall serve, let but the herald cry, And I’ll appear again.
Goodbye!: When the time comes, let the herald cry, and I’ll appear again.

Anon!: If a bloody coxcomb be a hurt, you have hurt me.
Goodbye!: If a bloody coxcomb is a hurt, you’ve hurt me.

Anon!: Drink, servant-monster, when I bid thee.
Goodbye!: Drink when I asked you, servant-monster.

Anon!: My father—methinks I see my father.
Goodbye!: My father—I think I see my father.

Anon!: Wine loved I deeply, dice dearly, and in woman outparamoured the Turk.
Goodbye!: I loved wine, and I diced dearly, and a woman outprettyly spoiled the Turk.

Anon!: My door is lock’d.
Goodbye!: My door is locked.

Anon!: He cries for you, and vows, if he can take you, To scorch your face and to disfigure you.
Goodbye!: He cries for you, and vows, if he can take you, to scorch your face and disfigure you.

Anon!: For thy escape would teach me tyranny, To hang clogs on them.—I have done, my lord.
Goodbye!: You’d teach me to hang clogs on them.—I’ve done it, my lord.

Anon!: You have me, have you not?
Goodbye!: You have me, don’t you?

Anon!: Roderigo killed?
Goodbye!: Roderigo?

Anon!: Most noble Antony!
Goodbye!: Most noble Antony!

Anon!: Do you misdoubt This sword and these my wounds?
Goodbye!: Do you misdoubt this sword and these wounds?

Anon!: I thank thee, good Tubal.
Goodbye!: Thank you, Tubal.

Anon!: My charge was but to fetch you from the mart Home to your house, the Phoenix, sir, to dinner.
Goodbye!: I only wanted to get you from the martin’s home to your house, the Phoenix, sir, to dinner.

Anon!: Or, if sour woe delights in fellowship And needly will be ranked with other griefs, Why followed not, when she said “Tybalt’s dead,” “Thy father” or “thy mother,” nay, or both, Which modern lamentations might have moved?
Goodbye!: Or, if sour sorrows are in fellowship and are ranked with other griefs, why not, when she said “Tybalt’s dead,” “your father” or “your mother,” no, or both

Anon!: Caesar himself has work, and our oppression Exceeds what we expected.
Goodbye!: Caesar himself has work, and our oppression is more than what we expected.

Anon!: My lord.
Goodbye!: My lord.

Anon!: I have a reasonable good ear in music.
Goodbye!: I have a good ear for music.

Anon!: The ears are senseless that should give us hearing, To tell him his commandment is fulfilled, That Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are dead.
Goodbye!: The ears are so stupid that we should hear him, and to tell him that his command is fulfilled, that Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are dead.

Anon!: Then, by myself—      Thyself is self-misused.
Goodbye!: Then, by myself— You’re self-misused.

Anon!: All?
Goodbye!: All right?

Anon!: Romans, countrymen, and lovers!
Goodbye!: Romans, countrymen, and lovers!

Anon!: Speak softly.
Goodbye!: Speak softly.

Anon!: When shall we three meet again?
Goodbye!: When will we three meet again?

Anon!: He is not lolling on a lewd love bed, But on his knees at meditation; Not dallying with a brace of courtesans, But meditating with two deep divines; Not sleeping, to engross his idle body, But praying, to enrich his watchful soul.
Goodbye!: He’s not sleeping, engrossing his idle body, but praying, to enrich his soul.

Anon!: Oh, that exceeds, they say.
Goodbye!: Oh, that’s what they say.

Anon!: A messenger from Caesar.
Goodbye!: A messenger from Caesar.

Anon!: My master will be here ere morning.
Goodbye!: My master will be here early morning.

Anon!: Be subject To no sight but thine and mine, invisible To every eyeball else.
Goodbye!: You can’t see anything but mine and my eyes, and you can’t see anything else.

Anon!: The fellow has good judgment.
Goodbye!: The fellow is good at judgment.

Anon!: Who?
Goodbye!: Who?

Anon!: Such a mad marriage never was before.
Goodbye!: That marriage was like never before.

Anon!: I think I did, sir.
Goodbye!: I think I did, sir.

Anon!: Never talk to me.
Goodbye!: Don’t talk to me.

Anon!: Good, yet remember whom thou hast aboard.
Goodbye!: Good, remember who you’re aboard.

Anon!: But woo her, gentle Paris, get her heart.
Goodbye!: But woo her, gentle Paris, get her heart.

Anon!: For my uncle is King of Denmark, and those that would make mouths at him while my father lived give twenty, forty, fifty, a hundred ducats apiece for his picture in little.
Goodbye!: My uncle is King of Denmark, and those who would make mouths at him while my father lived give twenty, forty, fifty, a hundred ducats apiece for his picture in little detail.

Anon!: I am no traitor.
Goodbye!: I’m not a traitor.

Anon!: Come, in what key shall a man take you to go in the song?
Goodbye!: Come, what key should a man take you to go in the song?

Anon!: Take my sword.
Goodbye!: Take my sword.

Anon!: The fold stands empty in the drownèd field, And crows are fatted with the murrain flock.
Goodbye!: The crows are stuffed with the murrain flock.

Anon!: Fear not my government.
Goodbye!: Don’t worry about my government.

Anon!: You thought because he could not speak English in the native garb, he could not therefore handle an English cudgel.
Goodbye!: You thought because he couldn’t speak English in the native language, he couldn’t handle an English cudgel.

Anon!: Of this my letters Before did satisfy you.
Goodbye!: I’d like to say that I’d like to say that I’d like to say that I’d like to say that I’d like to say that I’d like to say that I’d like to say that

Anon!: Many good morrows to my noble lord.
Goodbye!: Good morning to my noble lord.

Anon!: Let me but move one question to your daughter, And by that fatherly and kindly power That you have in her, bid her answer truly.
Goodbye!: Let me send one question to your daughter, and ask her to answer it by the fatherly and kindly power you have in her.

Anon!: Oh, that the slave had forty thousand lives!
Goodbye!: Oh, that the slave had forty thousand lives!

Anon!: God save your Majesty.
Goodbye!: God save your Majesty.

Anon!: Certain ones, then.
Goodbye!: Some, then.

Anon!: I pray thee, mark me.
Goodbye!: Please, mark me.

Anon!: I do not see them bleed.
Goodbye!: I don’t see them bleeding.

Anon!: Look, where she comes.
Goodbye!: Look, where she comes.

Anon!: All thy tediousness on me, ah?
Goodbye!: Is it all your tediousness, ah?

Anon!: What do you here?
Goodbye!: What are you doing here?

Anon!: Your Emperor Continues still a Jove.
Goodbye!: Your Emperor is still a Jove.

Anon!: Old Cassius still.
Goodbye!: Old Cassius still.

Anon!: O, how this mother swells up toward my heart!
Goodbye!: Oh, how this mother swells up toward my heart!

Anon!: Belike this is a man of that quirk.
Goodbye!: Look, this is a man who’s a savage.

Anon!: Come on.
Goodbye!: Come on.

Anon!: Ay, marry, was ’t, and he put it by thrice, every time gentler than other, and at every putting-by mine honest neighbors shouted.
Goodbye!: Yes, I was, and he put it by three times, every time more gentle than any other, and at every putting-by my honest neighbors shouted.

Anon!: Alack, alack, Edmund, I like not this unnatural dealing.
Goodbye!: Oh, I don’t like this unnatural deal.

Anon!: For I am he am born to tame you, Kate, And bring you from a wild Kate to a Kate Conformable as other household Kates.
Goodbye!: I’m born to tame you, Kate, and bring you from a wild Kate to a Kate that’s as suited to other household Kates.

Anon!: Marry, sir, they have committed false report; moreover, they have spoken untruths; secondarily, they are slanders; sixth and lastly, they have belied a lady; thirdly, they have verified unjust things; and, to conclude, they are lying knaves.
Goodbye!: They’ve been slandering a lady, and a third of them have verified unjust things, and, to conclude, they’re lying knaves.

Anon!: But dead they are, and devilish slave, by thee.
Goodbye!: But they’re dead, and they’re a devilish slave.

Anon!: We have been praying for our husbands' welfare, Which speed, we hope, the better for our words.
Goodbye!: We’ve been praying for our husbands’ welfare, which, we hope, will make us better.

Anon!: Do you believe his “tenders,” as you call them?
Goodbye!: Do you think his “tenders,” like you call them?

Anon!: How sweet the moonlight sleeps upon this bank!
Goodbye!: How sweet the moonlight sleeps on this bank!

Anon!: Come, woo me, woo me, for now I am in a holiday humor, and like enough to consent.
Goodbye!: Come on, listen to me, listen to me, because now I’m in a holiday mood, and I’m like enough to consent.

Anon!: He is arrived.
Goodbye!: He’s arrived.

Anon!: He longs to eat the English.
Goodbye!: He’s eager to eat the English.

Anon!: That chain will I bestow— Be it for nothing but to spite my wife— Upon mine hostess there.
Goodbye!: I’ll give that necklace to my hostess here—whether it’s for spiteing my wife.

Anon!: Y' have ungently, Brutus, Stole from my bed.
Goodbye!: You’ve sat in my bed, Brutus.

Anon!: Here I am.
Goodbye!: Here I am.

Anon!: Why should the poor be flattered?
Goodbye!: Why should the poor be flattered?

Anon!: Come, boy.
Goodbye!: Come on, boy.

Anon!: Help, ho, help!
Goodbye!: Help!

Anon!: O sweet Portia, Here are a few of the unpleasant’st words That ever blotted paper.
Goodbye!: Oh, Portia, here are some of the unpleasant words that ever blotted paper.

Anon!: God will revenge it, whom I will importune With earnest prayers, all to that effect.
Goodbye!: God will revenge it, whom I’ll make with my serenity, all to that effect.

Anon!: Alack the day!
Goodbye!: Let’s go!

Anon!: Why, he that cuts off twenty years of life Cuts off so many years of fearing death.
Goodbye!: Why, the man who cuts off twenty years of life cuts off so many years of fearing death.

Anon!: No money, on my faith, but the gleek.
Goodbye!: No money, I swear.

Anon!: Downy windows, close,
Goodbye!: Close, sluggish windows.

Anon!: I must and will have Katherine to my wife.
Goodbye!: I must and will have Katherine to marry my wife.

Anon!: What sayst thou, my dear Nurse?
Goodbye!: What do you say, my dear Nurse?

Anon!: Beware the ides of March.
Goodbye!: Beware of March’s landslides.

Anon!: There is no power in Venice Can alter a decree establishèd.
Goodbye!: There is no power in Venice that can change a decree.

Anon!: Wouldst thou betray me?
Goodbye!: Are you going to betrayed by me?

Anon!: Heavens thank you for ’t!
Goodbye!: Thank you!

Anon!: Dispatch, I say, and find the forester.
Goodbye!: Dispose, I say, and find the forester.

Anon!: Most noble Caesar!
Goodbye!: Most noble Caesar!

Anon!: Hath he provided this music?
Goodbye!: Has he done this?

Anon!: Come, come.
Goodbye!: Come on, come on.

Anon!: That will I make before I let thee go.
Goodbye!: I’ll make that decision before I let you go.

Anon!: One dead, or drunk?
Goodbye!: One dead, or drunk?

Anon!: Cowards die many times before their deaths.
Goodbye!: Cowards die many times before their deaths.

Anon!: Where have you hid yourself?
Goodbye!: Where have you hid yourself?

Anon!: Be brisk 0awhile, and the longer liver take all.
Goodbye!: Be brisk for a while, and the longer the liver takes everything.

Anon!: Thou art too like the spirit of Banquo.
Goodbye!: You’re too like the spirit of Banquo.

Anon!: I will tell you why.
Goodbye!: I’ll tell you why.

Anon!: If it had been painful, I would not have come.
Goodbye!: If it had been painful, I wouldn’t have come.

Anon!: I’ll see no more.
Goodbye!: I won’t see anything else.

Anon!: Herein I see thou lov’st me not with the full weight that I love thee.
Goodbye!: Here I see you don’t love me with the full weight that I love you.

Anon!: Thus ornament is but the guilèd shore To a most dangerous sea, the beauteous scarf Veiling an Indian beauty—in a word, The seeming truth which cunning times put on To entrap the wisest.
Goodbye!: The ornament is only the guilled shore to a dangerous sea, the beauteous scarf showcasing an Indian beauty—in a word, the seemingly savage truth that has been put on by the

Anon!: Nay, by 'r Lady, I am not such a fool to think what I list, nor I list not to think what I can, nor indeed I cannot think, if I would think my heart out of thinking, that you are in love or that you will be in love or that you can be in love.
Goodbye!: No, by my Lady, I’m not a fool to think what I list, nor I list it to think what I can, and I can’t think, if I want to think my heart out of thinking, that

Anon!: If thou and nature can so gently part, The stroke of death is as a lover’s pinch, Which hurts, and is desired.
Goodbye!: If you and nature can make such a difference, death is like a lover’s pinch, which hurts and is desired.

Anon!: Farewell, kind master.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, kind master.

Anon!: Give him this money and these notes, Reynaldo.
Goodbye!: Give him this money and these notes, Reynaldo.

Anon!: Lady, will you walk a bout with your friend?
Goodbye!: Lady, will you walk a bout with your friend?

Anon!: Hence will I to my ghostly friar’s close cell, His help to crave and my dear hap to tell.
Goodbye!: I’ll go to my ghostly friar’s cell, where he’ll help me, and tell me what I’m doing.

Anon!: I’ll be your purse-bearer and leave you For an hour.
Goodbye!: I’ll be your purse-bearer and leave you for an hour.

Anon!: Therefore take heed how you impawn our person, How you awake our sleeping sword of war.
Goodbye!: So listen to how you implode our person, how you awaken our sword of war.

Anon!: Madam!
Goodbye!: Madam!

Anon!: Truly, sir, in respect of a fine workman, I am but, as you would say, a cobbler.
Goodbye!: I’m just a cobbler, sir.

Anon!: Let him look to his bond.
Goodbye!: Let him look at his contract.

Anon!: Oh peace, Prince Dauphin!
Goodbye!: Oh, let’s go, Prince Dauphin!

Anon!: Thou shalt hold the opinion of Pythagoras ere I will allow of thy wits, and fear to kill a woodcock lest thou dispossess the soul of thy grandam.
Goodbye!: You’ll hold the opinion of Pythagoras, if I allow you to be wits, and you’ll be afraid to kill a woodcock, so you can’t get rid of your grand

Anon!: I hear the news, my lord.
Goodbye!: I hear the news, my lord.

Anon!: Jailer, look to him.
Goodbye!: Jailer, look at him.

Anon!: Think upon these gone.
Goodbye!: Think about the ones who have died.

Anon!: I am for you.
Goodbye!: I’m for you.

Anon!: Tis noble Kent, your friend.
Goodbye!: It’s noble Kent, your friend.

Anon!: And a true lover of the holy Church.
Goodbye!: And a true lover of the holy Church.

Anon!: Pray you, be careful.
Goodbye!: Please, be careful.

Anon!: Why the devil came you between us?
Goodbye!: Why the devil came you between us?

Anon!: So when he opens his purse to give us our reward, thy conscience flies out.
Goodbye!: When he opens his purse to give us our reward, your conscience flies out.

Anon!: On, lusty gentlemen.
Goodbye!: On, lusty gentlemen.

Anon!: Ha, banishment!
Goodbye!: Ha, banishment!

Anon!: And I, most jocund, apt, and willingly, To do you rest, a thousand deaths would die.
Goodbye!: And if I were apt and willing to rest, a thousand deaths would die.

Anon!: This is thy office.
Goodbye!: This is your job.

Anon!: What was it you told me of today, that your niece Beatrice was in love with Signor Benedick?
Goodbye!: What did you tell me today, that your niece Beatrice was in love with Signor Benedick?

Anon!: I have many enemies in Orsino’s court, Else would I very shortly see thee there.
Goodbye!: I have many enemies in Orsino’s court, and I’d be very soon there.

Anon!: What men daily do, not knowing what they do!
Goodbye!: What men do daily, not knowing what they do!

Anon!: Hold, there is forty ducats.
Goodbye!: There are forty ducats.

Anon!: And what should I do in Illyria?
Goodbye!: And what should I do in Illyria?

Anon!: But that it would be double-dealing, sir, I would you could make it another.
Goodbye!: But if it’s a double-deal, sir, I wish you could make it another.

Anon!: And they have been grand-jurymen since before Noah was a sailor.
Goodbye!: And they’ve been grand-jurymen since Noah was a sailor.

Anon!: Why, fare thee well.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: Tomorrow will I send.
Goodbye!: Tomorrow I’ll send you.

Anon!: Indeed, my lord, it followed hard upon.
Goodbye!: Yes, my lord, it followed hard.

Anon!: Well, let them rest.—Come hither, Catesby.
Goodbye!: Well, let them rest.—Come here, Catesby.

Anon!: Now God in heaven bless thee!
Goodbye!: Now God in heaven bless you!

Anon!: Alexander, God knows and you know, in his rages and his furies and his wraths and his cholers and his moods and his displeasures and his indignations, and also being a little intoxicates in his prains, did, in his ales and his angers, look you, kill his best friend, Cleitus.
Goodbye!: Alexander, God knows and you know, in his rages and his furies and his wraths and his cholers and his moods and his displeasures and his indignations, and even

Anon!: Never was seen so black a day as this.
Goodbye!: Never was this black day as this.

Anon!: Thou art armed, Gloucester.
Goodbye!: You’re armed, Gloucester.

Anon!: Upon the crown o' th' cliff, what thing was that Which parted from you?
Goodbye!: What was the thing that sank on the cliff?

Anon!: Live a thousand years, I shall not find myself so apt to die.
Goodbye!: I’ll live a thousand years, but I won’t find myself so apt to die.

Anon!: Do ’t, knight.
Goodbye!: Do it, knight.

Anon!: I will plant you two, and let the fool make a third, where he shall find the letter.
Goodbye!: I’ll put you two, and let the fool make a third, where he’ll find the letter.

Anon!: But where unbruisèd youth with unstuffed brain Doth couch his limbs, there golden sleep doth reign.
Goodbye!: But when unloved young men with unstuffed brains sleep in their arms, there’s golden sleep.

Anon!: By providence divine.
Goodbye!: By divine grace.

Anon!: A man, sir.
Goodbye!: A man, sir.

Anon!: Not a word of me.
Goodbye!: Not a word from me.

Anon!: But, soft!
Goodbye!: But, wait!

Anon!: But if you know not this my manners tell me We have your wrong rebuke.
Goodbye!: But if you don’t know this, my manners tell me we’ve got your wrong rebuke.

Anon!: I’ll rest.
Goodbye!: I’ll rest.

Anon!: Farewell.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: The pale companion is not for our pomp.
Goodbye!: The pale companion isn’t for our pomp.

Anon!: By my troth, I would not undertake her in this company.
Goodbye!: I’m not going to take her to this company.

Anon!: She turned to folly, and she was a whore.
Goodbye!: She turned to a frightening, and she was a whore.

Anon!: On, to the field!
Goodbye!: Go on, to the field!

Anon!: Oh, in this love, you love your child so ill That you run mad, seeing that she is well.
Goodbye!: Oh, in this love, you love your child so badly that you run crazy, seeing that she’s well.

Anon!: It is a pretty youth—not very pretty— But sure he’s proud—and yet his pride becomes him.
Goodbye!: It’s a pretty young man—not very pretty—but he’s sure he’s proud—and yet his pride becomes him.

Anon!: It touches you, my lord, as much as me.
Goodbye!: It’s touching you as much as me, my lord.

Anon!: Be simple-answered, for we know the truth.
Goodbye!: Be quick to answer, because we know the truth.

Anon!: Double, double toil and trouble, Fire burn and cauldron bubble.
Goodbye!: Double, double toil and trouble, Fire burn and cauldron bubble.

Anon!: Their mastiffs are of unmatchable courage.
Goodbye!: Their savages are unmatched courage.

Anon!: Good Master Peaseblossom, I shall desire you of more acquaintance too.— Your name, I beseech you, sir?
Goodbye!: Good Master Peaseblossom, I’ll want you to get more acquainted too.—Your name, please, sir?

Anon!: Welcome, Iago.
Goodbye!: Welcome, Iago.

Anon!: And how besides thyself?
Goodbye!: And how are you doing?

Anon!: Fare thee well.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: Soldier, you must come to the king.
Goodbye!: Soldier, you have to come to the king.

Anon!: Master Malvolio?
Goodbye!: Master Malvolio?

Anon!: If that may be then all is well.
Goodbye!: If that’s true, then everything is fine.

Anon!: Here comes Lorenzo.
Goodbye!: Here comes Lorenzo.

Anon!: My sight was ever thick.
Goodbye!: My eyes were always thick.

Anon!: Is ’t not enough, is ’t not enough, young man, That I did never, no, nor never can, Deserve a sweet look from Demetrius' eye, But you must flout my insufficiency?
Goodbye!: Isn’t it enough, isn’t it enough, young man?

Anon!: Hark, hark!
Goodbye!: Listen, listen!

Anon!: What’s the matter?
Goodbye!: What’s the matter?

Anon!: And have you mercy too!
Goodbye!: And you have mercy too!

Anon!: In him there is a hope of government, Which, in his nonage, council under him, And, in his full and ripened years, himself, No doubt shall then, and till then, govern well.
Goodbye!: He has a hope of government, which, in his absence, will be governed by him, and he will, in his full and ripened years, never be afraid to govern.

Anon!: A most manly wit, Margaret, it will not hurt a woman.
Goodbye!: It’s a manly wit, Margaret, that won’t hurt a woman.

Anon!: Now, by my hood, a gentle and no Jew.
Goodbye!: Now, by my hood, I’m a gentle, no Jew.

Anon!: Not for thy fairy kingdom.—Fairies, away!
Goodbye!: Not for your fairy kingdom.—Fairies, let’s go!

Anon!: Know then I came before you here a man prepared To take this offer, but Mark Antony Put me to some impatience.
Goodbye!: I know that I came before you here, and that a man was prepared to take this offer, but Mark Antony put me to some impatience.

Anon!: I have not heard the clock.
Goodbye!: I haven’t heard the clock.

Anon!: We will ourselves provide.
Goodbye!: We’ll do what we want.

Anon!: I greet thy love Not with vain thanks but with acceptance bounteous, And will upon the instant put thee to ’t.
Goodbye!: I’ll greet you immediately with my thanks, and I’ll put you to it.

Anon!: Death is my son-in-law.
Goodbye!: Death is my son-in-law.

Anon!: She will indite him to some supper.
Goodbye!: She’ll indite him to some supper.

Anon!: Do I entice you?
Goodbye!: Do I invite you?

Anon!: So help me every spirit sanctified As I have spoken for you all my best And stood within the blank of his displeasure For my free speech.
Goodbye!: Help me every spirit I have sanctified, as I’ve spoken for you all my best and stood in the blank of his displeasure for my free speech.

Anon!: First, madam, he is well.
Goodbye!: First, madam, he’s well.

Anon!: I did, my lord.
Goodbye!: I did, my lord.

Anon!: Dost thou prate, rogue?
Goodbye!: Are you scolding, rogue?

Anon!: Come, thou tortoise!
Goodbye!: Come on, you tortoise!

Anon!: I was contracted to them both.
Goodbye!: I was contacted by both of them.

Anon!: Miscreant!
Goodbye!: Miscreant!

Anon!: I would thou hadst my bones and I thy news.
Goodbye!: I wish you had my bones and I had your news.

Anon!: Ay, it stands so that I may hardly tarry so long.
Goodbye!: Yes, it’s so good that I can’t tarry so long.

Anon!: I say he shall go to prison.
Goodbye!: I say he’ll go to prison.

Anon!: At first And last, the hearty welcome.
Goodbye!: At first and last, the hearty welcome.

Anon!: What, is Brutus sick, And will he steal out of his wholesome bed, To dare the vile contagion of the night And tempt the rheumy and unpurgèd air To add unto his sickness?
Goodbye!: Is Brutus sick, and will he steal out of his wholesome bed, to dare the vile nightfall and tempt the rheumy and unpurgised air to add to his sickness

Anon!: Therefore thy kinsmen are no stop to me.
Goodbye!: Therefore, your parents aren’t stopping me.

Anon!: Nay, then, thus: We came into the world like brother and brother, And now let’s go hand in hand, not one before another.
Goodbye!: No, then, so we came into the world like brother and brother, and now let’s go hand in hand, not one before another.

Anon!: Even so lies she, Blubbering and weeping, weeping and blubbering.
Goodbye!: She lies in that she’s Blubbering and weeping, weeping and blubbering.

Anon!: He calls us back.
Goodbye!: He’s calling us back.

Anon!: Come, come away.
Goodbye!: Come on, come away.

Anon!: Motley’s the only wear.
Goodbye!: Motley’s the only wear.

Anon!: And the tears of it are wet.
Goodbye!: And the tears of it are wet.

Anon!: Oh, let me see thee walk!
Goodbye!: Oh, let me see you walk!

Anon!: Now, by my troth, if I had been remembered, I could have given my uncle’s grace a flout To touch his growth nearer than he touched mine.
Goodbye!: I wish I had a chance to remember my uncle’s growth, even if he touched mine.

Anon!: It struck mine ear most terribly.
Goodbye!: It struck my ear most terribly.

Anon!: He that commends me to mine own content Commends me to the thing I cannot get.
Goodbye!: The one who praises me for my own content, praises me for what I can’t get.

Anon!: Well be with you, gentlemen.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, gentlemen.

Anon!: And so adieu, good madam.
Goodbye!: And so, good madam.

Anon!: Have I, my lord?
Goodbye!: Have I, my lord?

Anon!: Tis some mischance, the cry is very direful.
Goodbye!: It’s a bit misching, but the cry is very dire.

Anon!: He started one poor heart of mine in thee.
Goodbye!: He started one poor heart in you.

Anon!: Ha, art thou bedlam?
Goodbye!: Are you a bedlam?

Anon!: You’ll bear me a bang for that, I fear.
Goodbye!: You’ll be a bang for that, I’m afraid.

Anon!: Tis a good dullness, And give it way.
Goodbye!: It’s a good dullness, and give it away.

Anon!: So, let me hear you speak.
Goodbye!: So let me hear you speak.

Anon!: But I pray you, ergo, old man, ergo, I beseech you, talk you of young Master Launcelot?
Goodbye!: But please, old man, please, talk to him about young Master Launcelot?

Anon!: Remember March, the ides of March remember.
Goodbye!: Remember March, remember March’s lands.

Anon!: O mighty Caesar!
Goodbye!: Oh, mighty Caesar!

Anon!: Ay, my lord, this same.
Goodbye!: Yes, my lord, that’s the same thing.

Anon!: It must be your imagination then, and not theirs.
Goodbye!: It must be your imagination, not theirs.

Anon!: Edward Plantagenet, why art thou dead?
Goodbye!: Edward Plantagenet, why are you dead?

Anon!: O, give me leave.
Goodbye!: Oh, let me go.

Anon!: Nay, ’tis twice two months, my lord.
Goodbye!: No, it’s twice two months, my lord.

Anon!: And I for no woman.
Goodbye!: And I don’t want to be a woman.

Anon!: Come, let’s do so.
Goodbye!: Let’s do so.

Anon!: Oh, withered is the garland of the war.
Goodbye!: Oh, the war has gotten rid of you.

Anon!: The best news is that we have safely found Our king and company.
Goodbye!: The best news is that we have found our king and company safely.

Anon!: There’s the point.
Goodbye!: That’s the point.

Anon!: Tell me, thou villain, where is my son Lucentio?
Goodbye!: Tell me, you villain, where is my son Lucentio?

Anon!: Why Doth it not then our eyelids sink?
Goodbye!: Why aren’t our eyes sink then?

Anon!: Signior Baptista, my business asketh haste, And every day I cannot come to woo.
Goodbye!: Signior Baptista, my business is urgent, and I can’t come to woo every day.

Anon!: I have slept, my lord, already.
Goodbye!: I’ve already slept, my lord.

Anon!: A good swift simile, but something currish.
Goodbye!: A good quick simile, but something currish.

Anon!: Who, I?
Goodbye!: Who, I?

Anon!: If thou beest as poor for a subject as he’s for a king, thou'rt poor enough.
Goodbye!: If you’re as poor as a king, you’re poor enough.

Anon!: And what says My concealed lady to our canceled love?
Goodbye!: And what does my hidden lady say to our canceled love?

Anon!: Ay me!
Goodbye!: Yes, I’m!

Anon!: Thou hast some suit to Caesar, hast thou not?
Goodbye!: You’re getting some money from Caesar, don’t you?

Anon!: But ’tis strange.
Goodbye!: But it’s strange.

Anon!: Support him by the arm.
Goodbye!: Support him by the arm.

Anon!: You have seen cruel proof of this man’s strength.
Goodbye!: You’ve seen a cruel proof of this man’s strength.

Anon!: Thy dæmon—that thy spirit which keeps thee—is Noble, courageous, high, unmatchable Where Caesar’s is not.
Goodbye!: Your dmon—that you are a noble, courageous, high, unmatched, where Caesar’s not.

Anon!: For the love o' God, peace!
Goodbye!: For the love of God, please, be quiet!

Anon!: Peter, stay at the gate.
Goodbye!: Peter, stay at the gate.

Anon!: But what’s the matter, Clarence?
Goodbye!: But what’s the matter, Clarence?

Anon!: If you have poison for me, I will drink it.
Goodbye!: If you have poison for me, I’ll drink it.

Anon!: Pluck out his eyes.
Goodbye!: Pluck out his eyes.

Anon!: That song tonight Will not go from my mind.
Goodbye!: That song will not go out of my mind tonight.

Anon!: He may win, And what is music then?
Goodbye!: He can win, and what’s music?

Anon!: Our solemn hymns to sullen dirges change, Our bridal flowers serve for a buried corse, And all things change them to the contrary.
Goodbye!: Our solemn hymns to sullen dirges change, our bridal flowers serve as a burial corse, and everything changes them to the contrary.

Anon!: To bed, to bed.
Goodbye!: To bed, to bed.

Anon!: Tis well blown, lads.
Goodbye!: It’s good, lads.

Anon!: Come on, assay.
Goodbye!: Come on, tell me.

Anon!: He was my friend, faithful and just to me.
Goodbye!: He was my friend, faithful and just to me.

Anon!: Why should you think that I should woo in scorn?
Goodbye!: Why do you think I should be wooing in a bad way?

Anon!: I’ll tell thee, Aliena, I cannot be out of the sight of Orlando.
Goodbye!: I’ll tell you, Aliena, I can’t be out of sight of Orlando.

Anon!: Tell me, that I may sack The hateful mansion.
Goodbye!: Tell me, so I can sack the hateful mansion.

Anon!: Touch her soft mouth, and march.
Goodbye!: Touch her soft mouth and march.

Anon!: For divers unknown reasons, I beseech you, Grant me this boon.
Goodbye!: For unknown reasons, please, grant me this boon.

Anon!: Due for a chain your husband had of him.
Goodbye!: You’re due for a necklace your husband had with him.

Anon!: Forbear, and eat no more.
Goodbye!: Be quiet, and don’t eat anymore.

Anon!: The second cock hath crowed.
Goodbye!: The second cock has crowed.

Anon!: My talk to thee must be how Benedick Is sick in love with Beatrice.
Goodbye!: I’ll talk to you about how Benedick is sick in love with Beatrice.

Anon!: A gentleman, Nurse, that loves to hear himself talk, and will speak more in a minute than he will stand to in a month.
Goodbye!: Nurse, a gentleman who loves to hear himself talk, and will speak more in a minute than he will stand to speak in a month.

Anon!: I wish it might, for now I am your fool.
Goodbye!: I wish it could, because now I’m your fool.

Anon!: We will, my noble lord.
Goodbye!: We will, my noble lord.

Anon!: As sweet repose and rest Come to thy heart as that within my breast.
Goodbye!: You’ll feel as calm and restful as I am in my breast.

Anon!: God be with my old master.
Goodbye!: God be with my old master.

Anon!: Nearest his heart”—those are the very words.
Goodbye!: Then the words are the ones that are near his heart.”

Anon!: Transform me, then, and to your power I’ll yield.
Goodbye!: So I’ll get to your power.

Anon!: Nor I, my lord, in faith.
Goodbye!: I’m not, my lord.

Anon!: He comes upon a wish.
Goodbye!: He’s coming on a wish.

Anon!: What?
Goodbye!: What?

Anon!: Nay, he hath but a little beard.
Goodbye!: No, he has a little beard.

Anon!: We should profane the service of the dead To sing a requiem and such rest to her As to peace-parted souls.
Goodbye!: We should profane the service of the dead to sing a requiem and rest to her as to peace-stressed souls.

Anon!: Hear, Nature, hear, dear goddess, hear!
Goodbye!: Listen to Nature, listen to you, dear goddess, listen to me!

Anon!: He hath not told his thought to the king?
Goodbye!: He hasn’t told the king his thoughts?

Anon!: What shall I do?
Goodbye!: What should I do?

Anon!: But though I am a daughter to his blood, I am not to his manners.
Goodbye!: But even though I’m a daughter to his blood, I’m not to his manners.

Anon!: I’ll have her, but I will not keep her long.
Goodbye!: I’ll have her, but I won’t keep her long.

Anon!: What committed?
Goodbye!: What have you done?

Anon!: How canst thou cross this marriage?
Goodbye!: How can you cross this marriage?

Anon!: Here is thy fee.
Goodbye!: Here’s your fee.

Anon!: This is a slave whose easy borrowed pride Dwells in the fickle grace of her he follows.— Out, varlet, from my sight!
Goodbye!: This is a slave whose sanity is fading in the sanity of her he follows.—I’m out of sight, varlet!

Anon!: Edgar I nothing am.
Goodbye!: I’m nothing.

Anon!: What men may do!
Goodbye!: What men can do!

Anon!: I shall win at the odds.
Goodbye!: I’ll win at the odds.

Anon!: Set it by a while.
Goodbye!: Wait a minute.

Anon!: Bid him bring his pen and inkhorn to the jail.
Goodbye!: Tell him to bring his pen and his inkhorn to the jail.

Anon!: Pray, what do you think is his name?
Goodbye!: Please, what do you think is his name?

Anon!: Art thou some god, some angel, or some devil That makest my blood cold and my hair to stare?
Goodbye!: Are you a god, an angel, or a devil who makes my blood cold and my hair to stare?

Anon!: Her eye discourses.
Goodbye!: Her eyes are talking.

Anon!: Here I stand, your slave— A poor, infirm, weak, and despised old man.
Goodbye!: Here I am, your slave— A poor, infirm, weak, and despised old man.

Anon!: An there be any matter of weight chances, call up me.
Goodbye!: If there’s any matter of weight chances, call me.

Anon!: Here lay Duncan, His silver skin laced with his golden blood, And his gashed stabs looked like a breach in nature For ruin’s wasteful entrance; there, the murderers, Steeped in the colors of their trade, their daggers Unmannerly breeched with gore.
Goodbye!: Here lay Duncan, his silver skin laced with his golden blood, and his gashed stabs looked like a breach in nature for ruin’s wasteful entrance.

Anon!: Then are our beggars bodies, and our monarchs and outstretched heroes the beggars' shadows.
Goodbye!: Then we’re beggars, and our monarchs and outstretched heroes are the beggars’ shadows.

Anon!: Captain Macmorris, I beseech you now, will you voutsafe me, look you, a few disputations with you as partly touching or concerning the disciplines of the war, the Roman wars?
Goodbye!: Captain Macmorris, I beg you now, will you scolde me, look at me, some disagreements with you as a part of the war, the Roman wars?

Anon!: Can you smell him out by that?
Goodbye!: Can you smell him out of that?

Anon!: Come, come, we fear the worst.
Goodbye!: Come on, come, we’re afraid of the worst.

Anon!: You have my consent.
Goodbye!: You have my consent.

Anon!: Dost thou not see my baby at my breast, That sucks the nurse asleep?
Goodbye!: Don’t you see my baby at my breast, that’s the nurse who sleeps?

Anon!: Do not believe That, from the sense of all civility, I thus would play and trifle with your reverence.
Goodbye!: Don’t believe that I would play and trifle with your reverence.

Anon!: I say, we will have no more marriages.
Goodbye!: I say we won’t have any more marriages.

Anon!: Give me.
Goodbye!: Give me a call.

Anon!: Are you a comedian?
Goodbye!: Are you a comedian?

Anon!: If there be truth in sight, you are my daughter.
Goodbye!: If there’s truth in sight, you’re my daughter.

Anon!: Set down, set down your honorable load, If honor may be shrouded in a hearse, Whilst I awhile obsequiously lament Th' untimely fall of virtuous Lancaster.
Goodbye!: Set down your honorable duty, if you can shroude your honor in a hearse, while I obsessively lament the untimely fall of virtuous Lancaster.

Anon!: Indeed, my lord, you made me believe so.
Goodbye!: Yes, my lord, you made me believe that.

Anon!: They have all stomachs.
Goodbye!: They’re all stomachs.

Anon!: Pronounce it for me, sir, to all our friends, For my heart speaks they are welcome.
Goodbye!: Tell all our friends to do it for me, sir, because my heart says they’re welcome.

Anon!: Sir, you speak nobly.
Goodbye!: Sir, you’re talking nobly.

Anon!: Look, here comes the duke.
Goodbye!: Look, here comes the duke.

Anon!: But how, my lord, shall we resist it now?
Goodbye!: But how, my lord, should we resist it now?

Anon!: Time hath not yet so dried this blood of mine Nor age so eat up my invention Nor fortune made such havoc of my means Nor my bad life reft me so much of friends But they shall find, awaked in such a kind, Both strength of limb and policy of mind, Ability in means and choice of friends, To quit me of them throughly.
Goodbye!: I’ve never been so sick of this blood, nor did I age so much, nor did my fortune make me so bad about my friends, and I’ll be so bad about my life.

Anon!: I commend your pains, And every one shall share i' th' gains.
Goodbye!: I’ll give you the best advice.

Anon!: Hast thou found my daughter?
Goodbye!: Have you found my daughter?

Anon!: I fear you have sold your own lands to see other men’s.
Goodbye!: I’m afraid you’ve sold your own land to see other men’s.

Anon!: Look where the youngest wren of nine comes.
Goodbye!: Look, where the youngest wren of nine comes.

Anon!: Pish!
Goodbye!: Pish!

Anon!: I am a gentleman of blood and breeding, And from some knowledge and assurance offer This office to you.
Goodbye!: I’m a gentleman of blood and breeding, and I’ve gained some knowledge and assurance to give this job to you.

Anon!: What is the time o' th' day?
Goodbye!: What time is it?

Anon!: I do beseech you.
Goodbye!: I beg you.

Anon!: Let us leave him.
Goodbye!: Let’s leave him.

Anon!: I tell thee, Litio, this is wonderful!
Goodbye!: Litio, I tell you that this is wonderful!

Anon!: O, if thou wert the noblest of thy strain, Young man, thou couldst not die more honorable.
Goodbye!: Oh, if you count the noblest of your strain, young man, you wouldn’t die honorably.

Anon!: I thank thee for that jest.
Goodbye!: Thank you for that.

Anon!: Go to, go to.
Goodbye!: Go to, go to.

Anon!: He sought my life, But lately, very late.
Goodbye!: He’s been searching for my life, but lately, very late.

Anon!: But thy vile race, Though thou didst learn, had that in ’t which good natures Could not abide to be with.
Goodbye!: But your vile race, even though you learned, had something that good natures couldn’t be able to be with.

Anon!: All for our vantage.
Goodbye!: All for our advantage.

Anon!: First let me talk with this philosopher.—
Goodbye!: First let me talk with this philosopher.—

Anon!: Against my brother Lucius?
Goodbye!: Against my brother Lucius?

Anon!: Ay, ay.
Goodbye!: Yes, yes.

Anon!: It was my turquoise.
Goodbye!: It was my turquoise.

Anon!: We will here part.
Goodbye!: We’ll be here.

Anon!: O monstrous world!
Goodbye!: Oh, what a monstrous world!

Anon!: Nay, gentlemen, prepare not to be gone.
Goodbye!: No, gentlemen, don’t prepare to go.

Anon!: Riddling confession finds but riddling shrift.
Goodbye!: A raging confession is only a riddling shrift.

Anon!: We will not fail.
Goodbye!: We won’t fail.

Anon!: Let her live To join our kingdoms and our hearts, and never Fly off our loves again!
Goodbye!: Let her live to join our kingdoms and our hearts, and never flee off our love again!

Anon!: how, I pray?
Goodbye!: How, please?

Anon!: What wound did ever heal but by degrees?
Goodbye!: What wound did you heal only by degrees?

Anon!: How will this fadge?
Goodbye!: How will this fadge?

Anon!: The heavens do lour upon you for some ill. Move them no more by crossing their high will.
Goodbye!: The heavens are lurching on you for some ill, and you’ll never move them again by crossing their high will.

Anon!: Descend, brother, I say.
Goodbye!: Descend, brother, I say.

Anon!: Not life, but love in death.
Goodbye!: Not life, but love in death.

Anon!: And you, sir.
Goodbye!: And you, sir.

Anon!: Here, sir!
Goodbye!: Here, sir!

Anon!: Saw you the weird sisters?
Goodbye!: Did you see the weird sisters?

Anon!: Use them after your own honor and dignity.
Goodbye!: Use them after your own honor and dignity.

Anon!: Then, world, thou hast a pair of chaps, no more, And throw between them all the food thou hast, They’ll grind the one the other.
Goodbye!: Then, in the world, you have a pair of chaps, no more, and throw all the food you have between them, they’ll grind the one one.

Anon!: Eyes, look your last.
Goodbye!: Eyes, look at your last sight.

Anon!: The law hath yet another hold on you.
Goodbye!: The law has another hold on you.

Anon!: They were suborned.
Goodbye!: They were smothered.

Anon!: I will not leave him now till Cassio Be called to him.—How is ’t with you, my lord?
Goodbye!: I won’t leave him until Cassio gets called to him.—How are you, my lord?

Anon!: A fine woman!
Goodbye!: A fine woman!

Anon!: Thou, wretched boy, that didst consort him here Shalt with him hence.
Goodbye!: You, wretched boy, who consorted him here will go with him.

Anon!: O Lord!
Goodbye!: Oh Lord!

Anon!: No, my good knight.
Goodbye!: No, my good knight.

Anon!: O brother Montague, give me thy hand.
Goodbye!: Oh, brother Montague, give me your hand.

Anon!: Up.
Goodbye!: Up.

Anon!: Remember that you call on me today.
Goodbye!: Remember that you call on me today.

Anon!: My lord, you nod.
Goodbye!: My lord, you nod.

Anon!: Come thy ways, Signior Fabian.
Goodbye!: Come on, Signior Fabian.

Anon!: Nurse, where’s my daughter?
Goodbye!: Nurse, where’s my daughter?

Anon!: Is not your lord honorable without marriage?
Goodbye!: Isn’t your lord honorable without marriage?

Anon!: Heavens keep him from these beasts!
Goodbye!: Heavens keep him from these beasts!

Anon!: Here comes the Prince and Claudio hastily.
Goodbye!: Here comes the Prince and Claudio in the rush.

Anon!: Thou wouldst else have made thy tale large.
Goodbye!: You would have made your story large.

Anon!: But adieu.
Goodbye!: But goodbye.

Anon!: Hie you to the cell.
Goodbye!: Go to the cell.

Anon!: Thou shouldst not have been old till thou hadst been wise.
Goodbye!: You wouldn’t have been old until you had been wise.

Anon!: Sole monarch of the universal earth, Oh, what a beast was I to chide at him!
Goodbye!: I was a beast to scold at him!

Anon!: The gods make this a happy day to Antony!
Goodbye!: The gods make this a happy day for Antony!

Anon!: At night we’ll feast together.
Goodbye!: At night we’ll feast together.

Anon!: Give ear, sir, to my sister.
Goodbye!: Give a ear to my sister, sir.

Anon!: The orchard walls are high and hard to climb, And the place death, considering who thou art, If any of my kinsmen find thee here.
Goodbye!: The orchard walls are high and hard to climb, and death is the place, considering who you are, if any of my relatives find you here.

Anon!: To lend me arms and aid when I required them, The which you both denied.
Goodbye!: I’d give them to me when I needed them, which you both denied.

Anon!: Wot you what, my lord?
Goodbye!: What are you doing, my lord?

Anon!: Say you?
Goodbye!: What do you say?

Anon!: Perhaps you have learned it without book.
Goodbye!: Maybe you’ve learned it without a book.

Anon!: Fool, I’ll requite it in the highest degree.
Goodbye!: Fool, I’ll requite it in the highest degree.

Anon!: When ’s god’s asleep, he’ll rob his bottle.
Goodbye!: When the god sleeps, he’ll rob his bottle.

Anon!: All men call thee fickle.
Goodbye!: All men call you a fickle man.

Anon!: I prithee, put them off.
Goodbye!: Please, put them off.

Anon!: Hark, hark!
Goodbye!: Listen, listen!

Anon!: Content thee, gentle coz.
Goodbye!: Let’s go, gentle coz.

Anon!: You bid me make it orderly and well, According to the fashion and the time.
Goodbye!: You asked me to make it right and well, according to the fashion and the time.

Anon!: A dollar.
Goodbye!: A dollar.

Anon!: Alack, my lord, that fault is none of yours.
Goodbye!: Oh, my lord, that’s not your fault.

Anon!: But I might see young Cupid’s fiery shaft Quenched in the chaste beams of the watery moon, And the imperial votaress passèd on, In maiden meditation, fancy-free.
Goodbye!: But I could see the fiery shaft of young Cupid sunk in the chaste beams of the moon, and the imperial votaress was thrown on, in a king’s meditation, and

Anon!: No epilogue, I pray you, for your play needs no excuse.
Goodbye!: I’m not going to write an epilogue, please, because your play doesn’t need to be excused.

Anon!: We’ll no more meet, no more see one another.
Goodbye!: We’ll never meet again, we’ll never see each other again.

Anon!: I speak too loud.— Where’s Malvolio?
Goodbye!: I’m talking too loud.—Where’s Malvolio?

Anon!: Go with me and see What I can show in this.
Goodbye!: Go with me and see what I can show you in this.

Anon!: My lord, this would not be believed in Venice, Though I should swear I saw ’t.
Goodbye!: My lord, this would not be true in Venice, even though I’d swear I saw it.

Anon!: To Brutus', to Cassius', burn all.
Goodbye!: To Brutus’s, to Cassius’s, burn everything.

Anon!: Why, this would make a man a man of salt, To use his eyes for garden water-pots, Ay, and laying autumn’s dust.
Goodbye!: That would make a man a man of salt, to use his eyes to make garden water-pots, and to lay autumn’s dust.

Anon!: I pray thee, tell me then that he is well.
Goodbye!: Please tell me that he’s well.

Anon!: Hold little faith, though thou hast too much fear.
Goodbye!: Don’t be afraid, even if you’re afraid.

Anon!: The gentleman that danced with her told her she is much wronged by you.
Goodbye!: The gentleman who danced with her told her you’re wronged.

Anon!: It hath made me mad.
Goodbye!: It’s made me mad.

Anon!: Tranio, you jest.
Goodbye!: Tranio, you scolded me.

Anon!: I tell you true.
Goodbye!: I’m telling you that.

Anon!: We’ll go to supper i' th' morning.
Goodbye!: We’ll go to supper in the morning.

Anon!: No words can that woe sound.
Goodbye!: No words can sound like that.

Anon!: They will surely do us no harm.
Goodbye!: They won’t do anything to us.

Anon!: Was ever match clapped up so suddenly?
Goodbye!: Was there ever a match clapped up so suddenly?

Anon!: Tis in my memory locked, And you yourself shall keep the key of it.
Goodbye!: It’s locked in my memory, and you’ll keep the key of it.

Anon!: Ay.
Goodbye!: Yes.

Anon!: A ship you sent me to, to hire waftage.
Goodbye!: A ship you sent me to, to hire a waftage.

Anon!: Chopped logic!
Goodbye!: Chopped logic!

Anon!: Come, come with me, and we will make short work.
Goodbye!: Come with me, and we’ll make a short work.

Anon!: Our knocking has awaked him.
Goodbye!: Our knocking has awakened him.

Anon!: Look in the calendar and bring me word.
Goodbye!: Look in the calendar and bring me word.

Anon!: We have consented to all terms of reason.
Goodbye!: We have agreed to all terms of reason.

Anon!: What wouldst thou now?
Goodbye!: What do you want now?

Anon!: Ay, and to wage this battle at Pharsalia, Where Caesar fought with Pompey.
Goodbye!: Yes, and to wage this battle at Pharsalia, where Caesar fought with Pompey.

Anon!: How dost thou, Benedick, the married man?
Goodbye!: How are you, Benedick, the married man?

Anon!: I have heard him read many lectures against it, and I thank God I am not a woman, to be touched with so many giddy offenses as he hath generally taxed their whole sex withal.
Goodbye!: I’ve heard him read many lectures against it, and I thank God I’m not a woman, to be touched with so many giddy offenses as he sexed them withal.

Anon!: My remembrance is very free and clear from any image of offense done to any man.
Goodbye!: I’m free and clear from any offense committed to any man.

Anon!: I will stop your mouth.
Goodbye!: I’ll stop your mouth.

Anon!: I never saw you in my life till now.
Goodbye!: I never saw you in my life until now.

Anon!: The herb I showed thee once.
Goodbye!: I showed you the herb once.

Anon!: Back do I toss these treasons to thy head, With the hell-hated lie o'erwhelm thy heart—
Goodbye!: I’ll throw these treasons back to your head with the hell-hated lie that’s causing your heart to fall asleep—

Anon!: Most royal sir, Fleance is ’scaped.
Goodbye!: Most royal sir, Fleance is scaped.

Anon!: It cannot be that she hath done thee wrong.
Goodbye!: It can’t be that she has done you wrong.

Anon!: Most welcome home!
Goodbye!: Welcome home!

Anon!: You are passing welcome, And so I pray you all to think yourselves.
Goodbye!: You’re coming, and I beg you all to think yourself.

Anon!: Didst thou not say he comes?
Goodbye!: Didn’t you say he’s coming?

Anon!: See where she comes from shrift with merry look.
Goodbye!: Look, she’s coming from shrift with a merry look.

Anon!: Husband, let’s follow to see the end of this ado.
Goodbye!: Husband, let’s follow to see the end of this ado.

Anon!: I care not for good life.
Goodbye!: I don’t care about good life.

Anon!: O, my poor brother!
Goodbye!: Oh, my poor brother!

Anon!: Even what it please my lord that shall become him.
Goodbye!: I’ll do whatever I want, my lord.

Anon!: Tis even so, For let our finger ache and it endues Our other healthful members even to that sense Of pain.
Goodbye!: It’s even so, because let our fingerache go away and it’s causing our other healthful members to feel pain.

Anon!: Oh, she doth teach the torches to burn bright!
Goodbye!: Oh, she’s teaching the torches to burn bright!

Anon!: I did nothing.
Goodbye!: I didn’t do anything.

Anon!: Where is he?
Goodbye!: Where is he?

Anon!: Where is that damnèd villain, Tranio, That faced and braved me in this matter so?
Goodbye!: Where is that damned villain Tranio, who faced and braved me in this matter?

Anon!: Life, living, all is Death’s.
Goodbye!: Life, living, everything is Death’s.

Anon!: But that they call “compliment” is like th' encounter of two dog- apes.
Goodbye!: But the word “compliment” is like two dog apes.

Anon!: Thus do they, sir: they take the flow o’ th’ Nile By certain scales i’ th’ Pyramid.
Goodbye!: They’re taking the flow of the Nile by certain scales in the Pyramid.

Anon!: And is it not well served into a sweet goose?
Goodbye!: And isn’t it good served as a sweet goose?

Anon!: But, alas the while!
Goodbye!: But wait a minute!

Anon!: That thou dost love my daughter from thy soul.
Goodbye!: You love my daughter from your soul.

Anon!: I do beseech your Grace to pardon me, and withal Forbear your conference with the noble duke.
Goodbye!: I beg your Grace to pardon me, and I’ll beg you to stop your conference with the noble duke.

Anon!: He hath been a courtier, he swears.
Goodbye!: He’s been a courtier, he swears.

Anon!: I will not hurt him.
Goodbye!: I won’t hurt him.

Anon!: Ha, ha, are you honest?
Goodbye!: Are you honest?

Anon!: Thou villain, what sayest thou?
Goodbye!: You villain, what do you say?

Anon!: Madam, here comes my lord.
Goodbye!: Madam, here comes my lord.

Anon!: What might you think?
Goodbye!: What do you think?

Anon!: Time shall unfold what plighted cunning hides, Who covers faults at last with shame derides.
Goodbye!: Time will tell what pranks are, and who’s defending faults with shame lasts forever.

Anon!: No more of that.
Goodbye!: Don’t worry about that.

Anon!: Zounds, sir, you’re robbed!
Goodbye!: You’re robbed, sir!

Anon!: Now is he for the numbers that Petrarch flowed in.
Goodbye!: Now he’s a man for the numbers Petrarch flies in.

Anon!: I am weary of you.
Goodbye!: I’m tired of you.

Anon!: Madam, in happy time, what day is that?
Goodbye!: Madam, what day is that?

Anon!: My Lord— Ay, what’s o'clock?
Goodbye!: Oh, what time is it?

Anon!: I will not choose what many men desire Because I will not jump with common spirits And rank me with the barbarous multitudes.
Goodbye!: I won’t choose what many men want because I won’t jump with common spirits and rank myself with the barbarous multitudes.

Anon!: Be patient till the last.
Goodbye!: Be patient until the last minute.

Anon!: And I will sing it in the latter end of a play before the duke.
Goodbye!: And I’ll sing it in the latter end of a play before the duke.

Anon!: Dorset is fled to Richmond.
Goodbye!: Dorset has fled to Richmond.

Anon!: I hope the king made peace with all of us; And the compact is firm and true in me.
Goodbye!: I hope the king made peace with us all.

Anon!: And why, my Lady Wisdom?
Goodbye!: And why, my Lady Wisdom?

Anon!: Wherefore art thou Romeo?
Goodbye!: Why are you Romeo?

Anon!: Let me yet know of you whither you are bound.
Goodbye!: Let me know what you’re doing.

Anon!: Thou shalt not live, That I may tell pale-hearted fear it lies, And sleep in spite of thunder.
Goodbye!: You won’t live, so I can tell you the truth, and sleep in spite of thunder.

Anon!: If I could make that resemble something in me—Softly!
Goodbye!: If I could make that look like something in me—Softly!

Anon!: No, truly not, although until last night I have this twelvemonth been her bedfellow.
Goodbye!: No, I’m not, even though I’ve been her bedtime for twelve months.

Anon!: Appear thou in the likeness of a sigh!
Goodbye!: Show yourself in the same way as a sigh!

Anon!: These late eclipses in the sun and moon portend no good to us.
Goodbye!: These late eclipses in the sun and the moon don’t bring us any good.

Anon!: Then, good my lord, teach your cousin to consent winking.
Goodbye!: Then, my lord, teach your cousin to consent to winking.

Anon!: Caesar, I shall.
Goodbye!: Caesar, I will.

Anon!: Art thou gone so, love, lord?
Goodbye!: Are you gone, love, lord?

Anon!: How chance the roses there do fade so fast?
Goodbye!: What chance the roses there are to fade so quickly?

Anon!: My life were better ended by their hate Than death proroguèd, wanting of thy love.
Goodbye!: I’d rather die by their hate than by dying, because I wanted to love you.

Anon!: Go in, and tell my lady I am gone, Having displeased my father, to Lawrence’s cell To make confession and to be absolved.
Goodbye!: Go inside and tell my lady I’m gone, displeased by my father, to Lawrence’s cell to confess and be absolved.

Anon!: What then?
Goodbye!: What then?

Anon!: Tis now near night.
Goodbye!: It’s near night.

Anon!: Good Sir Toby!
Goodbye!: Good Sir Toby!

Anon!: No, hath not?
Goodbye!: No, hasn’t it?

Anon!: Shall we clap into ’t roundly, without hawking or spitting or saying we are hoarse, which are the only prologues to a bad voice?
Goodbye!: Should we clap into it roundly, without hawking or spitting or saying we’re hoarsing, which are the only prologues to a bad voice?

Anon!: So shall you feel the loss, but not the friend Which you weep for.
Goodbye!: You’ll feel the loss, but not the friend you weep for.

Anon!: Oh, it came o'er my ear like the sweet sound, That breathes upon a bank of violets, Stealing and giving odor.
Goodbye!: Oh, it came to me like a sweet sound, which breathes on a bank of violets, smelling and giving odor to the ear.

Anon!: I’ll ride home tomorrow, Sir Toby.
Goodbye!: I’ll ride home tomorrow, Sir Toby.

Anon!: Peace, Smulkin.
Goodbye!: Quiet, Smulkin.

Anon!: O heavy deed!
Goodbye!: Oh, what a terrible deed!

Anon!: Therefore, good Emilia, Give me my nightly wearing, and adieu.
Goodbye!: So, good Emilia, give me my nightly clothes and adieu.

Anon!: Now, for my life, Hortensio fears his widow.
Goodbye!: Hortensio is worried about his widow for my life.

Anon!: By thee; and this thou didst return from him: That he did buffet thee and, in his blows, Denied my house for his, me for his wife.
Goodbye!: By you; and this was the reason you returned from him: that he shook you and, in his blows, denied my house for his, and I was for his wife.

Anon!: It is no boast, being asked, to say we are.
Goodbye!: It’s not a joke to say we’re.

Anon!: I hoped there was no need to trouble himself with any such thoughts yet.
Goodbye!: I hoped he didn’t have to bother with any such thoughts yet.

Anon!: Into what dangers would you lead me, Cassius, That you would have me seek into myself For that which is not in me?
Goodbye!: What dangers would you lead me, Cassius, that you’d have me to seek out for something that doesn’t belong to me?

Anon!: Let their heads be slickly combed, their blue coats brushed, and their garters of an indifferent knit.
Goodbye!: Let their heads be slickly combed, their blue coats brushed, and their shins of a different knit.

Anon!: For the Dauphin, I stand here for him.
Goodbye!: For the Dauphin, I’m here for him.

Anon!: Prepare you, generals.
Goodbye!: Prepare yourself, generals.

Anon!: Will it be ever thus?
Goodbye!: Will it ever be like that?

Anon!: How now, what news?
Goodbye!: What’s the news?

Anon!: Speak, if you can: what are you?
Goodbye!: Speak, if you can: what are you?

Anon!: Love, and be friends as two such men should be.
Goodbye!: Love, and be friends as two such men should be.

Anon!: Proceed.
Goodbye!: Go ahead.

Anon!: O proper stuff!
Goodbye!: Oh, what a good thing!

Anon!: Come hither, man.
Goodbye!: Come here, man.

Anon!: O, sir, I will not be so hard-hearted.
Goodbye!: Oh, sir, I won’t be so hard-hearted.

Anon!: No man must know.” If this should be thee, Malvolio?
Goodbye!: No man must know.” If this is you, Malvolio?

Anon!: I lay with Cassio lately And, being troubled with a raging tooth, I could not sleep.
Goodbye!: I lay with Cassio lately, and I couldn’t sleep because of a raging tooth.

Anon!: If I did take the kingdom from your sons, To make amends I’ll give it to your daughter.
Goodbye!: If I took the kingdom from your sons, I’ll give it to your daughter.

Anon!: But now they rise again With twenty mortal murders on their crowns And push us from our stools.
Goodbye!: But now they’re back with twenty mortal murders on their crowns and push us out of our stools.

Anon!: Why, very well then.
Goodbye!: Well then, very well.

Anon!: In my stars I am above thee, but be not afraid of greatness.
Goodbye!: I’m above you in my stars, but don’t be afraid of greatness.

Anon!: I grant him bloody, Luxurious, avaricious, false, deceitful, Sudden, malicious, smacking of every sin That has a name.
Goodbye!: I give him bloody, adversity, false, deceitful, smacking of every sin that has a name.

Anon!: Right, I mean you.
Goodbye!: Right, I mean you.

Anon!: Who would be jealous, then, of such a one?
Goodbye!: Who would be jealous of such a man?

Anon!: The fee simple?
Goodbye!: The fee is simple?

Anon!: Hark!
Goodbye!: Listen!

Anon!: Hortensio, hark.
Goodbye!: Hortensio, listen.

Anon!: I hope he is much grown since last I saw him.
Goodbye!: I hope he’s grown much since I saw him last time.

Anon!: I’ll after him, and see the event of this.
Goodbye!: I’ll follow him and see what happened.

Anon!: Why, I pray you, is not “pig” great?
Goodbye!: Why, please, isn’t “pig” great?

Anon!: On thy love, I charge thee.
Goodbye!: I’m directing you on your love.

Anon!: James Tyrrel, and your most obedient subject.
Goodbye!: James Tyrrel, and your most obedient subject.

Anon!: So should we you, if you should be our king.
Goodbye!: We should, if you were our king, do so.

Anon!: In nothing am I changed But in my garments.
Goodbye!: I’ve changed everything except my clothes.

Anon!: He seems to have a foreknowledge of that too, and therefore comes to speak with you.
Goodbye!: He seems to know about that too, and so he’s coming to speak with you.

Anon!: No, nor I neither, but most wonderful that she should so dote on Signor Benedick, whom she hath in all outward behaviors seemed ever to abhor.
Goodbye!: No, nor I neither, but it’s wonderful that she’s so sane about Signor Benedick, whom she has always seemed to abhorted.

Anon!: My lady will hang thee for thy absence.
Goodbye!: My lady will hang you for your absence.

Anon!: No.
Goodbye!: No.

Anon!: Marry, my child, early next Thursday morn, The gallant, young, and noble gentleman, The County Paris, at Saint Peter’s Church, Shall happily make thee there a joyful bride.
Goodbye!: My child, early Thursday morning, the gallant, young, and noble gentleman, The County Paris, at Saint Peter’s Church, will happily make you a joyful bride.

Anon!: I’ll lay fourteen of my teeth—and yet, to my teen be it spoken, I have but four—she is not fourteen.
Goodbye!: I’ll lay fourteen of my teeth—and yet, to my teen, I have only four—she’s not fourteen.

Anon!: Between who?
Goodbye!: Who?

Anon!: I wish him joy of her.
Goodbye!: I wish him joy to her.

Anon!: What promise, chuck?
Goodbye!: What promise, chuck?

Anon!: Dove-feathered raven, wolvish-ravening lamb!
Goodbye!: A raven, ravening lamb, feathered by doves!

Anon!: Why doth the Jew pause?
Goodbye!: Why is the Jew paused?

Anon!: O noble prince, I can discover all The unlucky manage of this fatal brawl.
Goodbye!: Oh, noble prince, I can see all the unfortunate consequences of this fatal brawl.

Anon!: Well, Brutus, thou art noble.
Goodbye!: Well, Brutus, you’re noble.

Anon!: Ay, but (by your leave) not before me.
Goodbye!: Yes, but you can’t stand before me.

Anon!: Here’s the smell of the blood still.
Goodbye!: Here’s the smell of blood still alive.

Anon!: When being not at your lodging to be found The Senate hath sent about three several guests To search you out.
Goodbye!: When you’re not at your house to find out, the Senate has sent about three different guests to search you.

Anon!: Look, where thy love comes.
Goodbye!: Look, where your love comes from.

Anon!: What is your will?
Goodbye!: What do you want?

Anon!: Yes, that thou didst.
Goodbye!: Yes, you did.

Anon!: There’s not a one of them but in his house I keep a servant fee’d.
Goodbye!: There’s not one of them, but I’m keeping a servant in his house.

Anon!: If not, an it would please you to take leave of her, she is very willing to bid you farewell.
Goodbye!: If not, if you would like to leave her, she’s very willing to offer you farewell.

Anon!: If she will return me my jewels I will give over my suit and repent my unlawful solicitation.
Goodbye!: If she returns me my jewels, I’ll give up my suit and repent my unlawful solicitation.

Anon!: They could be content To visit other places, and come down With fearful bravery, thinking by this face To fasten in our thoughts that they have courage.
Goodbye!: They could be happy to visit other places and come down with fearful bravery, thinking by this face to be able to say that they have courage.

Anon!: If the heavens had been pleased, would we had so ended!
Goodbye!: If the heavens were happy, we’d have ended so soon!

Anon!: Tut, I have lost myself.
Goodbye!: I’ve lost myself.

Anon!: Sent he to Macduff?
Goodbye!: Sent him to Macduff?

Anon!: My brother killed no man; his fault was thought, And yet his punishment was bitter death.
Goodbye!: My brother didn’t kill any man, but he thought he was wrong, and yet he was a bitter death.

Anon!: I should have known no less.
Goodbye!: I should have known it.

Anon!: Consider how it stands upon my credit.
Goodbye!: Think about how it stands for me.

Anon!: Fair lovers, you are fortunately met.
Goodbye!: Good lovers, you’ve been blessed to have you.

Anon!: I can tell you, but young Romeo will be older when you have found him than he was when you sought him.
Goodbye!: I can tell you, but young Romeo will be older when you find him than he was when you found him.

Anon!: These are now the fashion, and so berattle the common stages—so they call them—that many wearing rapiers are afraid of goose quills and dare scarce come thither.
Goodbye!: These are the clothes that are now in fashion, and they’re so sane—they’re called them—that many rapiers are afraid of goose quills and dare to come here.

Anon!: I led them on in this distracted fear And left sweet Pyramus translated there.
Goodbye!: I led them on in this distracted fear and left sweet Pyramus translated there.

Anon!: Kent, on thy life, no more.
Goodbye!: Kent, on your life, don’t worry.

Anon!: Since Cleopatra died I have lived in such dishonor that the gods Detest my baseness.
Goodbye!: Since Cleopatra died, I have lived in such a dishonor that the gods detest my sanity.

Anon!: Is this the madman?
Goodbye!: Is this the madman?

Anon!: He doth indeed show some sparks that are like wit.
Goodbye!: He’s really showing some sparks that are like wit.

Anon!: No, none that thou hast wit enough to make.
Goodbye!: No, none that you have enough wit to make.

Anon!: Some to the common pulpits, and cry out, “Liberty, freedom, and enfranchisement!” People and senators, be not affrighted.
Goodbye!: Some people go to the common pulpits and cry out, “Liberty, freedom, and enfranchisement!” People and senators, don’t be afraid.

Anon!: What mar you then, sir?
Goodbye!: What do you mean, sir?

Anon!: Macbeth Is ripe for shaking, and the powers above Put on their instruments.
Goodbye!: Macbeth is ready for shaking, and the powers above are on their instruments.

Anon!: Come on and kiss me, Kate.
Goodbye!: Come on and kiss me, Kate.

Anon!: Did this companion with the saffron face Revel and feast it at my house today Whilst upon me the guilty doors were shut And I denied to enter in my house?
Goodbye!: Did this companion with the saffron face Revel and feast it at my house today while the guilty doors were shut and I refused to enter in my house?

Anon!: Of thirty sail.
Goodbye!: Of thirty people.

Anon!: Who can come in and say that I mean her, When such a one as she such is her neighbor?
Goodbye!: Who can come in and say I mean her, when such a person as she is her neighbor?

Anon!: Men should be what they seem, Or those that be not, would they might seem none!
Goodbye!: Men should be what they seem, or those who don’t seem to be, they wouldn’t seem to be any!

Anon!: Let me stand here till thou remember it.
Goodbye!: Let me stand here until you remember it.

Anon!: Is all our company here?
Goodbye!: Is all our company here?

Anon!: Behold, sir.
Goodbye!: Look, sir.

Anon!: He swore he would never marry, and yet now, in despite of his heart, he eats his meat without grudging.
Goodbye!: He swore he wouldn’t marry, and yet despite his heart, he eats his meat without grudging.

Anon!: Well, happiness to their sheets!
Goodbye!: Well, happy to their sheets!

Anon!: Come, therefore, and to Thasos send his body.
Goodbye!: So come, and send his body to Thasos.

Anon!: God’s benison go with you and with those That would make good of bad and friends of foes.
Goodbye!: God’s benison will go with you and with those who would make good of bad and friends of foes.

Anon!: The hour of death is expiate.
Goodbye!: The hour of death is gone.

Anon!: Her body sleeps in Capels' monument, And her immortal part with angels lives.
Goodbye!: Her body sleeps in Capels’ tomb, and her immortal part with angels lives.

Anon!: Romeo!— Alack, alack, what blood is this, which stains The stony entrance of the sepulcher?
Goodbye!: Romeo!—Oh, what’s this blood that stains the stony entrance of the sepulcher?

Anon!: Wouldst thou withdraw it?
Goodbye!: Would you withdraw it?

Anon!: Bad news, my lord.
Goodbye!: Good news, my lord.

Anon!: Tut, I like it not.
Goodbye!: I don’t like it.

Anon!: To do thus I learned of thee.
Goodbye!: I learned about you.

Anon!: I’ll attend her here And woo her with some spirit when she comes.
Goodbye!: I’ll attend her here and woo her with some spirit when she comes.

Anon!: Forty thousand brothers Could not with all their quantity of love Make up my sum.
Goodbye!: Forty thousand brothers couldn’t make my sum with all their love.

Anon!: She doth well.
Goodbye!: She’s good.

Anon!: When you are gentle, you shall have one too, And not till then.
Goodbye!: When you’re gentle, you’ll have one too, and not until then.

Anon!: They would be better if well followed.
Goodbye!: They would be better if they were followed.

Anon!: What’s the matter?
Goodbye!: What’s the matter?

Anon!: What’s done is done.
Goodbye!: What’s done is done.

Anon!: How dost thou like the Lord Bassanio’s wife?
Goodbye!: How are you like Lord Bassanio’s wife?

Anon!: You sulfurous and thought-executing fires, Vaunt-couriers of oak-cleaving thunderbolts, Singe my white head!
Goodbye!: You sulphurous fires, savage savage thunderbolts, singe my white head!

Anon!: Spout, rain!
Goodbye!: Rain!

Anon!: Tear him to pieces.
Goodbye!: Tear him to pieces.

Anon!: Now die, die, die, die, die.
Goodbye!: Now die, die, die, die, die.

Anon!: What?
Goodbye!: What?

Anon!: Indeed he is not fit.
Goodbye!: He’s not fit.

Anon!: Let us rather Hold fast the mortal sword and, like good men, Bestride our downfall'n birthdom.
