Goodbye!: Let’s hold the mortal sword and, like good men, beg our downfall’s birthdom.

Anon!: It was great ignorance, Gloucester’s eyes being out, To let him live.
Goodbye!: It was a great ignorance to let Gloucester live, with his eyes out.

Anon!: Your plantain leaf is excellent for that.
Goodbye!: Your plantain leaf is excellent for that.

Anon!: Go in, and tell my lady I am gone, Having displeased my father, to Lawrence’s cell To make confession and to be absolved.
Goodbye!: Go inside and tell my lady I’m gone, displeased by my father, to Lawrence’s cell to confess and be absolved.

Anon!: Bear him my head.
Goodbye!: Keep him my head.

Anon!: Ay, good fool.
Goodbye!: Yes, good fool.

Anon!: Go fetch My best attires.
Goodbye!: Go get my best clothes.

Anon!: Does she so?
Goodbye!: Does she?

Anon!: And for three months.
Goodbye!: And for three months.

Anon!: Forever and forever farewell, Brutus.
Goodbye!: Farewell for forever, Brutus.

Anon!: What dost thou know me for?
Goodbye!: What do you know about me?

Anon!: We must do something, and i' th' heat.
Goodbye!: We have to do something, and it’s time to get out of here.

Anon!: What, wilt thou hear some music, my sweet love?
Goodbye!: Do you want to hear some music, my sweet love?

Anon!: Your case is better.
Goodbye!: Your case is better.

Anon!: Go look after him.
Goodbye!: Go look after him.

Anon!: My matter hath no voice, lady, but to your own most pregnant and vouchsafed ear.
Goodbye!: My matter has no voice, lady, but to your own pregnant and vouchsafed ear.

Anon!: Then know that from my soul I love thy daughter.
Goodbye!: Then know that from my soul I love your daughter.

Anon!: Then have at you with my wit.
Goodbye!: Then have my wit at you.

Anon!: So, I am satisfied.
Goodbye!: So, I’m satisfied.

Anon!: Farewell.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: To leave his wife, to leave his babes, His mansion and his titles in a place From whence himself does fly?
Goodbye!: To leave his wife, to leave his babes, his mansion and his titles in a place from where he’s flying?

Anon!: My brother’s love, the devil, and my rage.
Goodbye!: My brother’s love, the devil, and my rage.

Anon!: Whereon old Norway, overcome with joy,
Goodbye!: In Norway, overcome with joy,

Anon!: She made good view of me, indeed so much That sure methought her eyes had lost her tongue, For she did speak in starts distractedly.
Goodbye!: She looked at me so much that I thought her eyes had lost her tongue, because she was distracted.

Anon!: Alack the day.
Goodbye!: Let’s go.

Anon!: It is not friendly, ’tis not maidenly.
Goodbye!: It’s not friendly, it’s not a girl.

Anon!: And what said he?
Goodbye!: And what did he say?

Anon!: O, thou well-skilled in curses, stay awhile, And teach me how to curse mine enemies.
Goodbye!: Oh, you well-skilled in curses, stay for a while and teach me how to curse my enemies.

Anon!: In sadness, cousin, I do love a woman.
Goodbye!: I’m sad, cousin, I love a woman.

Anon!: O simple!
Goodbye!: Oh, that’s simple!

Anon!: I prithee name the time, but let it not Exceed three days.
Goodbye!: Please tell me the time, but don’t let it take three days.

Anon!: Best of comfort, And ever welcome to us.
Goodbye!: I’m always happy to see you.

Anon!: For naught so vile that on the earth doth live But to the earth some special good doth give.
Goodbye!: It’s so vile that on earth only some special good is given to the earth.

Anon!: What bloody man is that?
Goodbye!: What kind of man is that bloody man?

Anon!: But I feel not This deity in my bosom.
Goodbye!: But I don’t feel this deity in my heart.

Anon!: Lord, how it looks about!
Goodbye!: Lord, what a beautiful story it looks like!

Anon!: This way will I. Disrobe the images If you do find them decked with ceremonies.
Goodbye!: I’ll do this.

Anon!: Peace, you dull fool.
Goodbye!: Be quiet, you dull fool.

Anon!: I would have all well betwixt you.
Goodbye!: I wish I could bet you.

Anon!: Your love says, like an honest gentleman, and a courteous, and a kind, and a handsome, and, I warrant, a virtuous— Where is your mother?
Goodbye!: Your love says, like an honest gentleman, a courteous, kind, handsome, and, I’m sure, virtuous— Where is your mother?

Anon!: Yet you are withered.
Goodbye!: But you’re withered.

Anon!: The wine of life is drawn, and the mere lees Is left this vault to brag of.
Goodbye!: The wine of life is drawn, and the mere lees have left this vault to be sprayed.

Anon!: There is no terror, Cassius, in your threats, For I am armed so strong in honesty That they pass by me as the idle wind, Which I respect not.
Goodbye!: You’re not terrorizing me, Cassius, because I’m so strong in honesty that they pass by me like a windy wind, which I don’t respect.

Anon!: Good morrow, Prince; good morrow, Claudio.
Goodbye!: Good morning, Prince; good morning, Claudio.

Anon!: Well, sir, my mistress is the sweetest lady.—Lord, Lord!
Goodbye!: Well, sir, my mistress is the sweetest lady.—Lord, Lord!

Anon!: Can he be angry?
Goodbye!: Can he be angry?

Anon!: Hail!
Goodbye!: Hail!

Anon!: And yet no further than a wanton’s bird, That lets it hop a little from his hand Like a poor prisoner in his twisted gyves, And with a silken thread plucks it back again, So loving-jealous of his liberty.
Goodbye!: And yet it’s not far from a bird, who lets it hop a little from his hand like a poor prisoner in his twisted gyves, and plucks it back with a silky

Anon!: And I’ll sleep.
Goodbye!: And I’ll sleep.

Anon!: Romeo’s a dishclout to him.
Goodbye!: Romeo’s a dishclout to him.

Anon!: For that he dares us to ’t.
Goodbye!: He dares us to do that.

Anon!: If in thy wisdom thou canst give no help, Do thou but call my resolution wise, And with this knife I’ll help it presently.
Goodbye!: If you can’t give any help, then you can’t help but call me wise, and I’ll help it with this knife.

Anon!: Caesar, I never stood on ceremonies, Yet now they fright me.
Goodbye!: Caesar, I never stood on ceremonies, but now they’re frightening me.

Anon!: In brief, for so the season bids us be, Prepare thy battle early in the morning, And put thy fortune to the arbitrament Of bloody strokes and mortal-staring war.
Goodbye!: In short, since the season is approaching, prepare your battle early in the morning and put your fortune into the battle of bloody strokes and mortal-staring war.

Anon!: O my heart!
Goodbye!: Oh, my heart!

Anon!: Glance at my credit with Hippolyta, Didst thou not lead him through the glimmering night From Perigouna, whom he ravishèd?
Goodbye!: Didn’t you lead him through the glimmering night from Perigouna, whom he ravished?

Anon!: What wouldst thou do, old man?
Goodbye!: What do you want, old man?

Anon!: Why, then, some be of laughing, as, ah, ha, he!
Goodbye!: Well, then, some people are laughing, as he is!

Anon!: I shall obey, my lord.
Goodbye!: I’ll obey, my lord.

Anon!: Put money enough in your purse.
Goodbye!: Put enough money in your purse.

Anon!: And that’s true too.
Goodbye!: And that’s true too.

Anon!: Biondello, what of that?
Goodbye!: Biondello, what about that?

Anon!: My gentleman, Cesario?
Goodbye!: My gentleman, Cesario?

Anon!: Is ’t lost?
Goodbye!: Is it lost?

Anon!: Can you blame her then, being a maid yet rosed over with the virgin crimson of modesty, if she deny the appearance of a naked blind boy in her naked seeing self?
Goodbye!: Can you blame her for being a maid who rose over with the virgin crimson of modesty, if she denies the appearance of a naked blind boy in her naked eyes?

Anon!: And let no man abide this deed But we the doers.
Goodbye!: And don’t let anyone do this except us, the doers.

Anon!: Hence, get thee gone, and follow me no more.
Goodbye!: Go away, and don’t follow me anymore.

Anon!: I pray thee, hear me speak.
Goodbye!: Please, listen to me.

Anon!: Your letters did withhold our breaking forth Till we perceived both how you were wrong led And we in negligent danger.
Goodbye!: Your letters prevented us from breaking up until we saw both how you were wronged and how we were in danger.

Anon!: How fares your grace?
Goodbye!: How are you?

Anon!: A trade, sir, that I hope I may use with a safe conscience, which is, indeed, sir, a mender of bad soles.
Goodbye!: I hope I can use it with a safe conscience, which is, indeed, a mender of bad soles.

Anon!: It is not lost, but what and if it were?
Goodbye!: It’s not lost, but what if it were?

Anon!: What’s that?
Goodbye!: What’s that?

Anon!: There is not chastity enough in language, Without offense, to utter them.—Thus, pretty lady, I am sorry for thy much misgovernment.
Goodbye!: I’m sorry for your poor government.

Anon!: Do not fret yourself too much in the action, monsieur.
Goodbye!: Don’t fret yourself too much about the action, monsieur.

Anon!: I would not have such a heart in my bosom for the dignity of the whole body.
Goodbye!: I wouldn’t have a heart like this in my heart for the dignity of the whole body.

Anon!: I thought the king had more affected the Duke of Albany than Cornwall.
Goodbye!: I thought the king had more impact on the Duke of Albany than on Cornwall.

Anon!: I cannot tell; I think not.
Goodbye!: I don’t think so.

Anon!: But are you so much in love as your rhymes speak?
Goodbye!: But are you so in love with me as your rhymes say?

Anon!: The early village cock Hath twice done salutation to the morn.
Goodbye!: The early village cock has twice saluted the morne.

Anon!: God almighty, There is some soul of goodness in things evil, Would men observingly distill it out.
Goodbye!: God almighty, there’s some soul of goodness in evil, and men would be able to do it.

Anon!: Beshrew me, if I would do such a wrong For the whole world.
Goodbye!: I’d do a wrong for the whole world.

Anon!: Unreal mockery, hence!
Goodbye!: This is a terrible mockery!

Anon!: Or else it stood upon the choice of friends— O hell, to choose love by another’s eyes!
Goodbye!: Or else it stood for friends to choose— Oh hell, to choose love by another’s eyes!

Anon!: How well my comfort is revived by this!
Goodbye!: How good I feel about this!

Anon!: Stay the friar too.
Goodbye!: Stay the friar too.

Anon!: But all so soon as the all-cheering sun Should in the farthest east begin to draw The shady curtains from Aurora’s bed, Away from light steals home my heavy son,
Goodbye!: But so soon as the sun’s fading in the farthest east begins to draw the shady curtains from Aurora’s bed, away from light, steals my heavy son home.

Anon!: How now, lady?
Goodbye!: What’s going on, lady?

Anon!: Safer than trust too far.
Goodbye!: I’m safer than I’m going to trust you too far.

Anon!: I have said.
Goodbye!: I’ve said what I’ve said.

Anon!: Look, he recovers.
Goodbye!: Look, he’s recovering.

Anon!: But if she cannot love you, sir?
Goodbye!: But if she can’t love you, sir?

Anon!: In both my eyes he doubly sees himself— In each eye, one.
Goodbye!: He sees himself in both my eyes—in each eye, one.

Anon!: It is my lady.
Goodbye!: It’s my lady.

Anon!: This night I’ll spend Unto a dismal and a fatal end.
Goodbye!: I’ll spend the night in a terrible and fatal way.

Anon!: Oh, in this love, you love your child so ill That you run mad, seeing that she is well.
Goodbye!: Oh, in this love, you love your child so badly that you run crazy, seeing that she’s well.

Anon!: Marry, my uncle Clarence' angry ghost.
Goodbye!: My uncle Clarence’s angry ghost.

Anon!: The clock hath stricken three.
Goodbye!: The clock has stricken three.

Anon!: I’ll warrant him for drowning though the ship were no stronger than a nutshell and as leaky as an unstanched wench.
Goodbye!: I’ll bet he drowned even if the ship were as slick and leaky as a wench.

Anon!: What’s your will?
Goodbye!: What do you want?

Anon!: Would you desire lime and hair to speak better?
Goodbye!: Would you like to see more of lime and hair?

Anon!: My way is now to hie home to his house And tell his wife that, being lunatic, He rushed into my house and took perforce My ring away.
Goodbye!: I’m going to go home to his house and tell his wife that, being a lunatic, he rushed into my house and took my ring away.

Anon!: Signor Antonio, many a time and oft In the Rialto you have rated me About my moneys and my usances.
Goodbye!: Signor Antonio, you’ve rated me over my money and my money.

Anon!: What’s the matter?
Goodbye!: What’s the matter?

Anon!: Look whe'e he has not turned his color and has tears in ’s eyes.—Prithee, no more.
Goodbye!: Look, he hasn’t turned his color and has tears in his eyes.—Prie, don’t worry.

Anon!: It was in place where I could not breed no contention with him, but I will be so bold as to wear it in my cap till I see him once again, and then I will tell him a little piece of my desires.
Goodbye!: I didn’t want to fight with him, but I’ll be so bold as to wear it in my cap until I see him again, and then I’ll tell him a little piece of my desires.

Anon!: We’ll hear a play tomorrow.
Goodbye!: We’ll hear a play tomorrow.

Anon!: I’ll have no halves.
Goodbye!: I won’t have any halves.

Anon!: O woe!
Goodbye!: Oh, what a terrible thing!

Anon!: Those that have known the earth so full of faults.
Goodbye!: The people who have known the earth so full of faults.

Anon!: As I discern, It burneth in the Capels' monument.
Goodbye!: As I see, it’s burning in the Capels’ tomb.

Anon!: Why, then he’ll say we stabbed him sleeping.
Goodbye!: Well, then he’ll say we stabbed him asleep.

Anon!: Are you a suitor to the maid you talk of, yea or no?
Goodbye!: Are you a suitor to the woman you’re talking about, yes or no?

Anon!: Do you know him?
Goodbye!: Do you know him?

Anon!: Go to.
Goodbye!: Go on.

Anon!: To thee, that hast nor honesty nor grace.
Goodbye!: You, who haven’t been a good man or a good man.

Anon!: Have you no wit, manners, nor honesty but to gabble like tinkers at this time of night?
Goodbye!: Do you have any wit, manners, or honesty but to slam like tinkers at this time of night?

Anon!: This island’s mine, by Sycorax my mother, Which thou takest from me.
Goodbye!: This island is mine, by Sycorax, my mother, which you take from me.

Anon!: Sweet, so would I.
Goodbye!: Sweet, so would I.

Anon!: Your hands, come then.
Goodbye!: Your hands, come then.

Anon!: Why, how now, Adam?
Goodbye!: What’s going on, Adam?

Anon!: Nay, I beseech you, sir, be not out with me.
Goodbye!: No, please, sir, don’t be out with me.

Anon!: Seek thine own ease.
Goodbye!: Seek your own ease.

Anon!: Be gentle to her.
Goodbye!: Be gentle to her.

Anon!: I take my leave of you.
Goodbye!: I’ll leave you alone.

Anon!: A touch, a touch, I do confess ’t.
Goodbye!: I confess.

Anon!: Seek, seek for him, Lest his ungoverned rage dissolve the life That wants the means to lead it.
Goodbye!: Look for him, so that his rage will dissolve the life that wants to lead it.

Anon!: My heart prays for him, though my tongue do curse.
Goodbye!: My heart prays for him, even though my tongue curses him.

Anon!: He’s as good at anything and yet a fool.
Goodbye!: He’s as good at anything as a fool, but he’s still a fool.

Anon!: It is indifferent cold, my lord, indeed.
Goodbye!: It’s a cold, my lord, indeed.

Anon!: Sir, are not you my father?
Goodbye!: Sir, aren’t you my father?

Anon!: My Lord of Warwick and my brother Gloucester, Follow Fluellen closely at the heels.
Goodbye!: My Lord of Warwick and my brother Gloucester, follow Fluellen closely at the heels.

Anon!: Romeo must not live.
Goodbye!: Romeo must not live.

Anon!: Did I, Charmian, Ever love Caesar so?
Goodbye!: Did I ever love Caesar like that, Charmian?

Anon!: No, no, the bell.
Goodbye!: No, no, the bell.

Anon!: I shall grow jealous of you shortly, Launcelot, if you thus get my wife into corners.
Goodbye!: I’ll get jealous of you soon, Launcelot, if you get my wife into corners.

Anon!: He said the truth.
Goodbye!: He said the truth.

Anon!: On a trice, so please you, Even in a dream were we divided from them And were brought moping hither.
Goodbye!: On a trice, please, even in a dream we were separated from them and brought to mop here.

Anon!: And let her speak of me before her father.
Goodbye!: And let her speak of me before her father.

Anon!: He speaks not true.
Goodbye!: He’s not saying anything.

Anon!: Not that I know.
Goodbye!: Not that I know.

Anon!: Take your place.
Goodbye!: Take your place.

Anon!: This the Dauphin speaks.
Goodbye!: The Dauphin speaks about this.

Anon!: Or does he walk?
Goodbye!: Or is he walking?

Anon!: I’ll to the throng.
Goodbye!: I’ll go to the throng.

Anon!: I say a devil.
Goodbye!: I’m a devil.

Anon!: Will you give thanks, sweet Kate, or else shall I?— What’s this?
Goodbye!: Will you give thanks, sweet Kate, or else will I?—What’s this?

Anon!: Soundly, my lord.
Goodbye!: Good, my lord.

Anon!: Relent?
Goodbye!: Relent?

Anon!: Then, in the name of God and all these rights, Advance your standards.
Goodbye!: Then, in the name of God and all these rights, you’ll be able to follow your standards.

Anon!: And thou, all-shaking thunder, Smite flat the thick rotundity o' th' world, Crack nature’s molds, all germens spill at once That make ingrateful man!
Goodbye!: And you, all-shaking thunder, smit the thick rotundity of the world, crack nature’s molds, and all germens spill at once that make a sane man!

Anon!: Good night, my lord.
Goodbye!: Good night, my lord.

Anon!: I tell you ’tis not very well.
Goodbye!: I tell you that it’s not very well.

Anon!: I am afraid, methinks, to hear you tell it.
Goodbye!: I’m afraid to hear you tell me.

Anon!: Lives he?
Goodbye!: Is he alive?

Anon!: Famine is in thy cheeks.
Goodbye!: Hunger is in your cheeks.

Anon!: His soldiership Is twice the other twain.
Goodbye!: His army is twice the other two.

Anon!: Oh, it is my love.
Goodbye!: Oh, it’s my love.

Anon!: You shall play it in a mask, and you may speak as small as you will.
Goodbye!: You’ll play it in a mask, and you can speak as small as you want.

Anon!: Then shall we be news-crammed.
Goodbye!: Then we’ll be crammed with news.

Anon!: For I mine own gained knowledge should profane If I would time expend with such a snipe But for my sport and profit.
Goodbye!: I’d rather spend time with such a snipe than for my sport and my profit.

Anon!: The duke of Exeter has very gallantly maintained the pridge.
Goodbye!: The duke of Exeter has maintained the pridge very gallantly.

Anon!: Would ’t had been done!
Goodbye!: I wish it had been done!

Anon!: This wind you talk of, blows us from ourselves.
Goodbye!: This wind you’re talking about blows us away from ourselves.

Anon!: Thou baggage, let me in.
Goodbye!: You’re a baggage, let me in.

Anon!: Take no offense that I would not offend you.
Goodbye!: Don’t be offended by the fact that I wouldn’t offend you.

Anon!: Who comes here?
Goodbye!: Who’s coming?

Anon!: Two nights together had these gentlemen, Marcellus and Barnardo, on their watch, In the dead waste and middle of the night, Been thus encountered: a figure like your father, Armed at point exactly, cap-à-pie, Appears before them and with solemn march Goes slow and stately by them.
Goodbye!: Two nights together, these gentlemen Marcellus and Barnardo were on their watch, in the dead waste and middle of the night, and were seen as if you were your father, who was armed at point-to-point

Anon!: Ay, at Philippi.
Goodbye!: Yes, at Philippi.

Anon!: Madam, I wish it may.
Goodbye!: Madam, I wish it could.

Anon!: How chances it they travel?
Goodbye!: How are they going?

Anon!: Look in the almanac.
Goodbye!: Look in the almanac.

Anon!: Dearly my delicate Ariel.
Goodbye!: Dearly, my delicate Ariel.

Anon!: Certainly, sir, I can.
Goodbye!: Yes, sir, I can.

Anon!: It is twice blessed: It blesseth him that gives and him that takes.
Goodbye!: It blesses the man who gives and the man who takes.

Anon!: What man art thou that, thus bescreened in night, So stumblest on my counsel?
Goodbye!: What man are you, who stumbles on my advice, so be screened in the night?

Anon!: And so do I.
Goodbye!: And so do I.

Anon!: He is slain.
Goodbye!: He’s been killed.

Anon!: O thou public commoner!
Goodbye!: Oh, you’re a public servant!

Anon!: Bear thee well in it and leave us alone.
Goodbye!: Keep your heart in it and leave us alone.

Anon!: Fare you well.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: I fight against thee?
Goodbye!: I’m fighting against you?

Anon!: You see an ass head of your own, do you?
Goodbye!: You’re seeing an ass head like you, do you?

Anon!: Will you know them then?
Goodbye!: Will you know them then?

Anon!: I have watched ere now All night for lesser cause, and ne'er been sick.
Goodbye!: I’ve been watching a lot all night for a lesser reason, and I’ve never been sick.

Anon!: All of us have cause To wail the dimming of our shining star, But none can help our harms by wailing them.— Madam, my mother, I do cry you mercy; I did not see your Grace.
Goodbye!: We all have reason to wail the dimming of our shining star, but none of us can help our harms by wailing them.—Mame, my mother, I cry you mercy; I didn’t see

Anon!: Room, ho!
Goodbye!: There’s room!

Anon!: Let me enjoy my private.
Goodbye!: Let me enjoy my private life.

Anon!: Why do you infect yourself with them?
Goodbye!: Why are you infecting yourself with them?

Anon!: Is it a man?
Goodbye!: Is it a man?

Anon!: Are you acquainted with the difference That holds this present question in the court?
Goodbye!: Are you familiar with the difference that holds this question in the court?

Anon!: The glowworm shows the matin to be near, And 'gins to pale his uneffectual fire.
Goodbye!: The glowworm shows the matin to be near, and he’s starting to pale his uneffectual fire.

Anon!: Sure, these are but imaginary wiles, And lapland sorcerers inhabit here.
Goodbye!: Sure, these are only imaginary wiles, and savages are living here.

Anon!: I prithee, vent thy folly somewhere else.
Goodbye!: Please, go somewhere else to avoid your slander.

Anon!: You are a lover.
Goodbye!: You’re a lover.

Anon!: What is your will that I shall do with this?
Goodbye!: What will I do with this?

Anon!: Othello’s occupation’s gone.
Goodbye!: Othello’s occupation has gone.

Anon!: O, what more favor can I do to thee, Than with that hand that cut thy youth in twain To sunder his that was thine enemy?
Goodbye!: Oh, what more favor can I do to you than to sunder his enemy with the hand that cut your youth in two ways?

Anon!: My mind hath been as big as one of yours, My heart as great, my reason haply more, To bandy word for word and frown for frown.
Goodbye!: My mind has been as big as one of yours, my heart as great, and my reason is haply more important, to bandy word for word and frown for frown.

Anon!: Do you hear, masters?
Goodbye!: Do you hear them, masters?

Anon!: Off, pluck off!
Goodbye!: Get off, get off!

Anon!: Do not deny.
Goodbye!: Don’t deny that.

Anon!: By my head, here comes the Capulets.
Goodbye!: I swear, here come the Capulets.

Anon!: I will do any thing, Nerissa, ere I’ll be married to a sponge.
Goodbye!: I’ll do anything, Nerissa, if I’ll be married to a sponge.

Anon!: The folly of this island.
Goodbye!: The fright of this island.

Anon!: They could not, would not do ’t.
Goodbye!: They couldn’t, wouldn’t.

Anon!: I speak but brotherly of him, but should I anatomize him to thee as he is, I must blush and weep, and thou must look pale and wonder.
Goodbye!: I’m talking about him only brotherly, but if I anatomize him to you as he is, I’ll blush and weep, and you’ll look pale and wonder.

Anon!: What less than doomsday is the Prince’s doom?
Goodbye!: What less is the Prince’s doom than doomsday?

Anon!: Your rye-straw hats put on, And these fresh nymphs encounter every one In country footing.
Goodbye!: Your rye-straw hats are put on, and these fresh nymphs are all in the country.

Anon!: No, not he, though his face be better than any man’s, yet his leg excels all men’s, and for a hand and a foot and a body, though they be not to be talked on, yet they are past compare.
Goodbye!: No, he’s not, even though his face is better than any man’s, but his leg is more than any man’s, and for a hand and a foot and a body, even though they’

Anon!: Sir Topas, Sir Topas, good Sir Topas, go to my lady— Out, hyperbolical fiend!
Goodbye!: Sir Topas, Sir Topas, good Sir Topas, go to my lady— Out, hyperbolic fiend!

Anon!: Best you safed the bringer Out of the host.
Goodbye!: You’d better get the bringer out of the host.

Anon!: My excellent good friends!
Goodbye!: My excellent good friends!

Anon!: And so, his knell is knolled.
Goodbye!: And so, his knell is snuck.

Anon!: O, no, he loves me, and he holds me dear.
Goodbye!: Oh, no, he loves me, and he loves me.

Anon!: Domestic fury and fierce civil strife Shall cumber all the parts of Italy.
Goodbye!: The civil war will ravaged all parts of Italy.

Anon!: Oh, strange!
Goodbye!: Oh, strange!

Anon!: Thou liest.
Goodbye!: You lie.

Anon!: Cassius, go you into the other street And part the numbers.
Goodbye!: Cassius, go to the other street and part the numbers.

Anon!: Came they not by you?
Goodbye!: Didn’t they come by you?

Anon!: Good Master Mustardseed, I know your patience well.
Goodbye!: Good Master Mustardseed, I know your patience well.

Anon!: A good old commander and a most kind gentleman.
Goodbye!: A good old commander and a very kind gentleman.

Anon!: What’s thy passion?
Goodbye!: What’s your passion?

Anon!: But come what sorrow can, It cannot countervail the exchange of joy That one short minute gives me in her sight.
Goodbye!: But if you come to see what sorrow can do, it can’t counteract the joy I’ve had in her sight for a minute.

Anon!: Not a mouse stirring.
Goodbye!: Not a mouse.

Anon!: Here, under leave of Brutus and the rest— For Brutus is an honorable man; So are they all, all honorable men— Come I to speak in Caesar’s funeral.
Goodbye!: Here, under the permission of Brutus and the rest—for Brutus is an honorable man; so are they all, all honorable men— Come to speak in Caesar’s funeral.

Anon!: But how should Prospero Be living and be here?
Goodbye!: But how should Prospero live and be here?

Anon!: Now art thou Romeo.
Goodbye!: Now you’re Romeo.

Anon!: Where is your husband?
Goodbye!: Where is your husband?

Anon!: Give me your hand.
Goodbye!: Give me your hand.

Anon!: Nay, let them go, a couple of quiet ones.
Goodbye!: No, let them go, a couple of quiet ones.

Anon!: God’s my life, where’s the Sexton?
Goodbye!: Where’s the Sexton?

Anon!: The enemy comes on in gallant show.
Goodbye!: The enemy is coming on in a gallant show.

Anon!: I’ll ride your horse as well as I ride you.
Goodbye!: I’ll ride your horse as well as I ride you.

Anon!: Ay, madam.
Goodbye!: Yes, madam.

Anon!: He’s worth more sorrow, And that I’ll spend for him.
Goodbye!: He’s worth more sorrow than I’m going to spend for him.

Anon!: It is proved my Lady Hero hath been falsely accused, the Prince and Claudio mightily abused, and Don John is the author of all, who is fled and gone.
Goodbye!: It’s been proved that my Lady Hero has been falsely accused, the Prince and Claudio have been abused, and Don John is the author of all, who has fled and gone.

Anon!: How fearful And dizzy ’tis to cast one’s eyes so low!
Goodbye!: How fearful and dizzy it is to see one’s eyes so low!

Anon!: Beware Of entrance to a quarrel, but being in, Bear ’t that th' opposèd may beware of thee.
Goodbye!: Beware of the entrance to a fight, but beware of being in, so that the opposing may beware of you.

Anon!: What treasure, uncle?
Goodbye!: What treasure, uncle?

Anon!: Who is so gross That cannot see this palpable device?
Goodbye!: Who is so gross that he can’t see this palpable device?

Anon!: Pat, pat.
Goodbye!: Let’s go.

Anon!: Why sweat they under burdens?
Goodbye!: Why are they sweating under the burdens?

Anon!: Shall I do such a deed?
Goodbye!: Should I do such a thing?

Anon!: I am glad to see you in this merry vein.
Goodbye!: I’m glad to see you in this merry way.

Anon!: The gods do this in shame of cowardice.
Goodbye!: The gods do this in shame of cowardice.

Anon!: When holy and devout religious men Are at their beads, ’tis much to draw them thence, So sweet is zealous contemplation.
Goodbye!: When holy and devout religious men are at their beads, it’s much to draw them from there, so sweet is zealous contemplation.

Anon!: I believe we must leave the killing out, when all is done.
Goodbye!: I believe we have to leave out the killing until everything is done.

Anon!: Welcome hither.
Goodbye!: Welcome here.

Anon!: But art thou not drowned, Stephano?
Goodbye!: But you’re not drowned, Stephano?

Anon!: He’ll say ’twas done cowardly, when he wakes.
Goodbye!: He’ll say he’s been done cowardly when he wakes up.

Anon!: It is some meteor that the sun exhales To be to thee this night a torchbearer, And light thee on thy way to Mantua.
Goodbye!: It’s some meteor that the sun is telling you to be a torchbearer this night and light you on your way to Mantua.

Anon!: She is persuaded I will marry her, out of her own love and flattery, not out of my promise.
Goodbye!: She’s convinced I’ll marry her out of her own love and flattery, not out of my promise.

Anon!: What’s that, I pray?
Goodbye!: What’s that, please?

Anon!: It is not meet you know how Caesar loved you.
Goodbye!: It’s not true that you know how much Caesar loved you.

Anon!: There’s husbandry in heaven; Their candles are all out.
Goodbye!: There’s a man’s house in heaven, and their candles are all out.

Anon!: Do I speak you fair?
Goodbye!: Do I speak to you fairly?

Anon!: If then they chanced to slack you, We could control them.
Goodbye!: If they were able to slack you, we could control them.

Anon!: Your father was ever virtuous, and holy men at their death have good inspirations.
Goodbye!: Your father was always virtuous, and holy men at their death have good inspirations.

Anon!: Let us hear what Antony can say.
Goodbye!: Let’s hear what Antony can say.

Anon!: Not we.
Goodbye!: Not us.

Anon!: My back a' t' other side.
Goodbye!: My back is on the other side.

Anon!: Signior Fabian, stay you by this gentleman till my return.
Goodbye!: Signior Fabian, stay with this gentleman until I return.

Anon!: But saying o'er what I have said before.
Goodbye!: But I’m saying something about what I’ve said before.

Anon!: Though I look old, yet I am strong and lusty, For in my youth I never did apply Hot and rebellious liquors in my blood Nor did not with unbashful forehead woo The means of weakness and debility.
Goodbye!: Though I look old, I’m strong and lusty, since I never used hot and rebellious liquors in my blood in my youth, and I didn’t woo with unbashful foreheads to make weakness

Anon!: How is ’t, brother!
Goodbye!: How is it, brother?

Anon!: All hail, Macbeth!
Goodbye!: All hail, Macbeth!

Anon!: Peter Quince— What sayest thou, bully Bottom?
Goodbye!: Peter Quince— What do you say, bully Bottom?

Anon!: But, by your favor, how near’s the other army?
Goodbye!: But, by your favor, how close is the other army?

Anon!: But all the charms of love, Salt Cleopatra, soften thy wanned lip!
Goodbye!: But all the charms of love, Salt Cleopatra, soften your wanned lip!

Anon!: A most ridiculous monster, to make a wonder of a poor drunkard.
Goodbye!: A ridiculous monster, to make a wonder of a poor drunkard.

Anon!: As birds do, Mother.
Goodbye!: As birds do, Mother.

Anon!: Ye say honestly.
Goodbye!: You’re right.

Anon!: Go put on thy defenses.
Goodbye!: Go put on your defenses.

Anon!: Sit thee down, Clitus.
Goodbye!: Sit down, Clitus.

Anon!: You think of him too much.
Goodbye!: You think about him too much.

Anon!: My husband say that she was false!
Goodbye!: My husband said she was false!

Anon!: Think, when we talk of horses, that you see them Printing their proud hoofs i' th' receiving earth, For ’tis your thoughts that now must deck our kings, Carry them here and there, jumping o'er times,
Goodbye!: When we talk about horses, you see them putting their proud hoofs on the earth, because your thoughts must be a part of our kings, and carry them here and there, jumping a little more often.

Anon!: Wisely and slow.
Goodbye!: Be wise and slow.

Anon!: Stay till I have read the letter.
Goodbye!: Wait until I read the letter.

Anon!: That love i begged for you he begged of me.
Goodbye!: I begged for you, and he begged for me.

Anon!: Up with my tent!—Here will I lie tonight.
Goodbye!: I’ll lie here tonight.

Anon!: Ride, ride, Messala, ride, and give these bills Unto the legions on the other side.
Goodbye!: Ride, ride, Messala, ride, and give these bills to the legions on the other side.

Anon!: In my mind’s eye, Horatio.
Goodbye!: I’m in my mind, Horatio.

Anon!: In such a night To shut me out!
Goodbye!: In such a night, shut me out!

Anon!: She was, good Curtis, before this frost.
Goodbye!: She was, good Curtis, before this frost.

Anon!: Treachery!
Goodbye!: Treachery!

Anon!: There is time enough.
Goodbye!: There’s enough time.

Anon!: Each heart in Rome does love and pity you.
Goodbye!: Every heart in Rome loves and pitys you.

Anon!: Would I were sleep and peace, so sweet to rest.
Goodbye!: I wish I were sleep and quiet, so I could rest.

Anon!: Why should calamity be full of words?
Goodbye!: Why should calamity be full of words?

Anon!: Is ’t so, indeed.
Goodbye!: Is that true?

Anon!: No, sir.
Goodbye!: No, sir.

Anon!: What do you see?
Goodbye!: What do you see?

Anon!: Thus have I, Wall, my part dischargèd so.
Goodbye!: I’ve dischargaged my part, Wall.

Anon!: With one fool’s head I came to woo, But I go away with two.— Sweet, adieu.
Goodbye!: I came with one fool’s head to woo, but I’ll go away with two.—Sweet, adieu.

Anon!: Her blood is settled, and her joints are stiff.
Goodbye!: Her blood is settled, and her joints are stiff.

Anon!: Now tell me how long you would have her after you have possessed her.
Goodbye!: Now tell me how long you want her to live after you have possessed her.

Anon!: As if time were in debt.
Goodbye!: As if time were in debt.

Anon!: Ay, Biddy, come with me.—What, man!
Goodbye!: Yes, Biddy, come with me.—What, man!

Anon!: What is it?
Goodbye!: What’s it?

Anon!: In saying so, you shall but say the truth.
Goodbye!: If you say that, you’ll only say the truth.

Anon!: If I do not usurp myself, I am.
Goodbye!: If I don’t usurp myself, I’m.

Anon!: Wast thou mad, That thus so madly thou didst answer me?
Goodbye!: Was you mad, that you answered me so madly?

Anon!: What passion hangs these weights upon my tongue?
Goodbye!: What’s the passion that hangs on my tongue?

Anon!: Grim-visaged war hath smoothed his wrinkled front; And now, instead of mounting barbèd steeds To fright the souls of fearful adversaries, He capers nimbly in a lady’s chamber To the lascivious pleasing of a lute.
Goodbye!: He’s snuck up his face and snuck up his face, and instead of putting his sneezes on the souls of fearful adversaries, he’s sne

Anon!: What should I answer you?
Goodbye!: What should I do for you?

Anon!: That a maiden’s heart hath burned?
Goodbye!: That a woman’s heart has burned?

Anon!: Here were the servants of your adversary, And yours, close fighting ere I did approach.
Goodbye!: Here were the servants of your adversary, and yours, I was fighting close to you.

Anon!: Can you not conceive?
Goodbye!: Can’t you imagine?

Anon!: Was not Charles, the duke’s wrestler, here to speak with me?
Goodbye!: Didn’t Charles, the duke’s wrestler, speak to me?

Anon!: I confess it is my shame to be so fond, but it is not in my virtue to amend it.
Goodbye!: I admit it’s my shame to be so fond, but it’s not my virtue to change it.

Anon!: Oh, monstrous!
Goodbye!: Oh, monstrous!

Anon!: But, soft!
Goodbye!: But, wait!

Anon!: What say you, Bottom?
Goodbye!: What do you say, Bottom?

Anon!: Most detestable Death, by thee beguiled, By cruel, cruel thee quite overthrown!
Goodbye!: You’re ruined by cruel, cruel Death!

Anon!: Hold, my hand.
Goodbye!: Hold my hand.

Anon!: Let’s follow the old earl, and get the Bedlam To lead him where he would.
Goodbye!: Let’s follow the old earl and get the Bedlam to lead him where he would.

Anon!: Hence!
Goodbye!: Let’s go!

Anon!: Let him kill one first.
Goodbye!: Let him kill one of them first.

Anon!: What’s his fault?
Goodbye!: What’s his fault?

Anon!: Welcome, dear madam.
Goodbye!: Welcome, dear madam.

Anon!: Then there were two cousins laid up, when the one should be lamed with reasons and the other mad without any.
Goodbye!: Then there were two cousins laid up, one of whom should be slashed with a few reasons, and the other would be mad without any.

Anon!: There’s little of the melancholy element in her, my lord.
Goodbye!: She’s not a melancholy girl, my lord.

Anon!: Let us go in, And charge us there upon interr'gatories, And we will answer all things faithfully.
Goodbye!: Let’s go in, and take us there with us, and we’ll answer all the questions faithfully.

Anon!: For Antony, I have no ears to his request.
Goodbye!: I don’t have any ears to his request for Antony.

Anon!: I am content you shall entreat me stay, But yet not stay, entreat me how you can.
Goodbye!: I’m happy you’ll keep me, but don’t stay, keep me as you can.

Anon!: My lord.
Goodbye!: My lord.

Anon!: Therefore, since brevity is the soul of wit And tediousness the limbs and outward flourishes, I will be brief: your noble son is mad.
Goodbye!: Therefore, since brevity is the soul of wit and tediousness the limbs and outward flourishes, I’ll be brief: your noble son is insane.

Anon!: Good madam, patience.
Goodbye!: Good madam, patience.

Anon!: Thou still hast been the father of good news.
Goodbye!: You’ve been the father of good news.

Anon!: Me, a groat?
Goodbye!: Me, a groat?

Anon!: His breeding, sir, hath been at my charge.
Goodbye!: His breeding, sir, has been my responsibility.

Anon!: He’s gone.
Goodbye!: He’s gone.

Anon!: Where be these bloody thieves?
Goodbye!: Where are these bloody thieves?

Anon!: True!
Goodbye!: True!

Anon!: And then give them great meals of beef and iron and steel, they will eat like wolves and fight like devils.
Goodbye!: And then give them great meals of beef and iron and steel, they will eat like wolves and fight like devils.

Anon!: Even such delight Among fresh fennel buds shall you this night Inherit at my house.
Goodbye!: You’ll be here tonight at my house.

Anon!: What, dead, my dove?
Goodbye!: What, dead, my dove?

Anon!: All eyes!
Goodbye!: All eyes!

Anon!: Had he done so?
Goodbye!: Had he done that?

Anon!: Alas the day, it did.
Goodbye!: It did.

Anon!: O, you are novices!
Goodbye!: Oh, you’re novices!

Anon!: Doth not the gentleman Deserve as full as fortunate a bed As ever Beatrice shall couch upon?
Goodbye!: Doesn’t the gentleman deserve as much a bed as ever as Beatrice will sleep?

Anon!: O, teach me how you look and with what art You sway the motion of Demetrius' heart.
Goodbye!: Oh, teach me how you look and how you’re swaying Demetrius’s heart.

Anon!: By Isis, I will give thee bloody teeth If thou with Caesar paragon again My man of men.
Goodbye!: Isis, I’ll give you bloody teeth if you’re again with Caesar paragon my man of men.

Anon!: Come, no matter vor your foins.
Goodbye!: Come, no matter what you’re doing.

Anon!: Farewell.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: It must be thought on.
Goodbye!: It must be thought about.

Anon!: Mercy but murders, pardoning those that kill.
Goodbye!: Mercy is only about murders, pardoning those who kill.

Anon!: What unaccustomed cause procures her hither?
Goodbye!: What unaccustomed reason did she get here?

Anon!: They would else have been troubled with a pernicious suitor.
Goodbye!: They would have been troubled with a dangerous suitor.

Anon!: How now, fellow?
Goodbye!: What’s going on, fellow?

Anon!: Yes, it is apparel.
Goodbye!: Yes, it’s a garment.

Anon!: I saw her laid low in her kindred’s vault And presently took post to tell it you.
Goodbye!: I saw her laid in her kindred’s vault and took the post to tell you.

Anon!: Ay, those attires are best.
Goodbye!: Yes, those are the best clothes.

Anon!: Dismount thy tuck, be yare in thy preparation, for thy assailant is quick, skillful and deadly.
Goodbye!: Take your tuck away, be prepared, because your assailant is quick, skillful and deadly.

Anon!: What’s the matter?
Goodbye!: What’s the matter?

Anon!: He hath done good service, lady, in these wars.
Goodbye!: He’s done good service in these wars, lady.

Anon!: Weigh it but with the grossness of this age, You break not sanctuary in seizing him.
Goodbye!: You’re not a sanctuary in taking him.

Anon!: I saw the handkerchief.
Goodbye!: I saw the handkerchief.

Anon!: He takes on him to understand so much, and therefore comes to speak with you.
Goodbye!: He takes on him to understand so much, and so he comes to speak with you.

Anon!: I think he bought his doublet in Italy, his round hose in France, his bonnet in Germany, and his behavior everywhere.
Goodbye!: I think he bought his doublet in Italy, his round hose in France, his bonnet in Germany, and his behavior everywhere.

Anon!: If that will not suffice, I will be bound to pay it ten times o'er, On forfeit of my hands, my head, my heart.
Goodbye!: If that doesn’t suffice, I’ll be forced to pay it ten times more for my hands, my head, my heart.

Anon!: I bring no overture of war, no taxation of homage.
Goodbye!: I don’t bring any war or homage to you.

Anon!: Pardon, master.
Goodbye!: Pardon me, master.

Anon!: She did show favor to the youth in your sight only to exasperate you, to awake your dormouse valor, to put fire in your heart and brimstone in your liver.
Goodbye!: She showed favor to the young man in your sight only to exasperate you, awaken your dormouse valor, put fire in your heart and brimstone in your liver.

Anon!: What if a man bring him a hundred pound or two to make merry withal?
Goodbye!: What if a man brought him a hundred pounds or two to make a happy day?

Anon!: Nay, an you be a cursing hypocrite once, you must be looked to.
Goodbye!: No, if you’re a cursed hypocrite once, you have to be careful.

Anon!: O, spare my guiltless wife and my poor children!— Keeper, I prithee sit by me awhile.
Goodbye!: Oh, spare my guiltless wife and my poor children!—Keeper, please sit by me for a while.

Anon!: Till thou canst rail the seal from off my bond, Thou but offend’st thy lungs to speak so loud.
Goodbye!: You can only offend your lungs to speak so loud until you can get the seal off my contract.

Anon!: From seventeen years till now almost fourscore Here livèd I, but now live here no more.
Goodbye!: From seventeen years ago, almost fourscore here livèd me, but now I don’t live here anymore.

Anon!: But here comes Antony.—Welcome, Mark Antony.
Goodbye!: But here comes Antony.—Welcome, Mark Antony.

Anon!: How came he mad?
Goodbye!: How did he get mad?

Anon!: This making Christians will raise the price of hogs.
Goodbye!: This makes Christians raise the price of hogs.

Anon!: Is his head worth a hat or his chin worth a beard?
Goodbye!: Is his head worth a hat or his chin worth a beard?

Anon!: I’ll make one too.
Goodbye!: I’ll make one too.

Anon!: For Christian shame, put by this barbarous brawl.
Goodbye!: For Christian shame, put by this barbarous brawl.

Anon!: What good is covered with the face of heaven, To be discovered, that can do me good?
Goodbye!: What good is covered with the face of heaven, to be discovered, that can do me good?

Anon!: Not very well, but I have met him oft, And he hath bought the cottage and the bounds That the old carlot once was master of.
Goodbye!: Not very well, but I’ve met him often, and he’s bought the cottage and the bounds that the old carlot once was master of.

Anon!: Ay, ay.
Goodbye!: Yes, yes.

Anon!: Fabian can scarce hold him yonder.
Goodbye!: Fabian can’t hold him back.

Anon!: I pray you, know me when we meet again.
Goodbye!: Please, know me when we meet again.

Anon!: Weeping and wailing over Tybalt’s corse.
Goodbye!: Weeping and wailing over Tybalt’s corse.

Anon!: I here do give thee that with all my heart Which, but thou hast already, with all my heart I would keep from thee.
Goodbye!: I give you that with all my heart, which, but you have already, I want to keep from you with all my heart.

Anon!: A proper man.
Goodbye!: A good man.

Anon!: Is ’t so, indeed?
Goodbye!: Is that true?

Anon!: Upon his brow shame is ashamed to sit, For ’tis a throne where honor may be crowned.
Goodbye!: He’s ashamed to sit on his forehead, because it’s a throne where honor can be crowned.

Anon!: If that be all, masters, I hear no harm.
Goodbye!: If that’s all, my masters, I won’t hear anything wrong.

Anon!: Or shall we on without apology?
Goodbye!: Or should we go on without apology?

Anon!: Well, all’s one for that.
Goodbye!: Well, it’s all for that.

Anon!: Then meet me forthwith at the notary’s.
Goodbye!: Then meet me at the notary’s.

Anon!: The barbarous Scythian, Or he that makes his generation messes To gorge his appetite, shall to my bosom Be as well neighbored, pitied, and relieved As thou my sometime daughter.
Goodbye!: The barbarous Scythian, or the man who makes his generation messes to gorge his appetite, will be as well neighbored, pitied, and relieved as you, my sometime daughter.

Anon!: Saw you anything?
Goodbye!: Have you seen anything?

Anon!: Where is the fellow?
Goodbye!: Where is the man?

Anon!: The like is on her arm.
Goodbye!: The same thing happens on her arm.

Anon!: Abominable villain!
Goodbye!: Abominable villain!

Anon!: You have killed a sweet lady, and her death shall fall heavy on you.
Goodbye!: You’ve killed a sweet lady, and her death will be heavy on you.

Anon!: The last was I that felt thy tyranny.
Goodbye!: The last thing I saw was that I felt your tyranny.

Anon!: How now?
Goodbye!: What’s going on?

Anon!: With what, i' th' name of God?
Goodbye!: What, God’s name?

Anon!: Dexterously, good madonna.
Goodbye!: Dexterously, good madonna.

Anon!: No warmth, no breath shall testify thou livest.
Goodbye!: No warmth, no breath will test your life.

Anon!: Why, mistress, sure my master is horn mad.
Goodbye!: Oh, my master, my lord, I’m sure he’s insane.

Anon!: Adieu, Lest our old robes sit easier than our new!
Goodbye!: Goodbye, so our old robes are easier to sit than our new ones!

Anon!: Thou art like one of those fellows that, when he enters the confines of a tavern, claps me his sword upon the table and says “God send me no need of thee!” and, by the operation of the second cup, draws it on the drawer when indeed there is no need.
Goodbye!: You’re like one of those men who, when he enters the confines of a tavern, claps me his sword on the table and says, “God send me no need of you

Anon!: True, sir.
Goodbye!: Yes, sir.

Anon!: Why no, no more than reason.
Goodbye!: No, no more than reason.

Anon!: So, so, so.
Goodbye!: So, so, so.

Anon!: My husband!
Goodbye!: My husband!

Anon!: Or I’ll deliver thy indignation to him by word of mouth.
Goodbye!: Or I’ll give him your indignation by word of mouth.

Anon!: Uncle!
Goodbye!: Uncle!

Anon!: She that makes dainty, She, I’ll swear, hath corns.
Goodbye!: She’s a dainty woman, I’ll swear, she’s a corn.

Anon!: He sends to know if your pleasure hold to play with Laertes, or that you will take longer time.
Goodbye!: He asks if you want to play with Laertes, or if you want to take longer.

Anon!: What devil art thou that dost torment me thus?
Goodbye!: What devil are you who torture me like this?

Anon!: I pray you, is my master yet returned?
Goodbye!: Please, is my master yet returned?

Anon!: Read it, great Caesar.
Goodbye!: Read it, great Caesar.

Anon!: Your Grace, we think, should soonest know his mind.
Goodbye!: We think your Grace should know his mind quickly.

Anon!: I deny it not.
Goodbye!: I don’t deny it.

Anon!: Then, prophetlike, They hailed him father to a line of kings.
Goodbye!: Then they hailed him father to a line of kings.

Anon!: Base Trojan, thou shalt die.
Goodbye!: You’ll die from a Trojan.

Anon!: To the selfsame tune and words.
Goodbye!: To the same tune and words.

Anon!: Help, Charmian, help, Iras, help!
Goodbye!: Help, Charmian, help, Iras, help!

Anon!: The moon methinks looks with a watery eye.
Goodbye!: The moon looks like a watery eye.

Anon!: But you’ll lie like dogs, and yet say nothing neither.
Goodbye!: But you’ll lie like dogs, and you’ll say nothing.

Anon!: Because we come to do you service and you think we are ruffians, you’ll have your daughter covered with a Barbary horse.
Goodbye!: Because we come to do you service and you think we’re ruffians, you’ll have your daughter covered with a barbary horse.

Anon!: It was the nightingale, and not the lark, That pierced the fearful hollow of thine ear.
Goodbye!: It was the nightingale, not the lark, that pierced your fearful ear.

Anon!: Madam, I am most apt to embrace your offer.
Goodbye!: Madam, I’m very happy to accept your offer.

Anon!: Let our reciprocal vows be remembered.
Goodbye!: Let’s remember our reciprocal vows.

Anon!: Father, ’tis thus: yourself and all the world That talked of her have talked amiss of her.
Goodbye!: Father, it’s like this: you and all the world who talked about her have talked about her.

Anon!: What gentleman?
Goodbye!: What gentleman?

Anon!: But there’s more work.
Goodbye!: But there’s more work to be done.

Anon!: Every inordinate cup is unblessed and the ingredient is a devil.
Goodbye!: Every inordinate cup is unblessed and the ingredient is a devil.

Anon!: Let him be Caesar!
Goodbye!: Let him be Caesar!

Anon!: I’ll venture so much of my hawk or hound, But twenty times so much upon my wife.
Goodbye!: I’ll venture so much of my hawk or hound, but twenty times so much on my wife.

Anon!: I am scarce in breath, my lord.
Goodbye!: I’m not breathing, my lord.

Anon!: Yes, faith, and all his lords, the Duke of Milan And his brave son being twain.
Goodbye!: Yes, and all his lords, the Duke of Milan and his brave son being twain.

Anon!: What is ’t o'clock?
Goodbye!: What time is it?

Anon!: This deed will be well welcome to Lorenzo.
Goodbye!: Lorenzo will be welcome to do this.

Anon!: And God forbid, my dear and faithful lord, That you should fashion, wrest, or bow your reading, Or nicely charge your understanding soul With opening titles miscreate, whose right Suits not in native colors with the truth; For God doth know how many now in health Shall drop their blood in approbation
Goodbye!: And God forbid, my dear and faithful lord, that you fashion, wrest, bow, or bow your reading, or nicely charge your understanding soul with opening titles miscreated, whose right doesn’t suit in

Anon!: Tis so—but Edward lives.
Goodbye!: It’s true—but Edward’s alive.

Anon!: But get thee back.
Goodbye!: But get back.

Anon!: We shall, my lord, Perform what you command us.
Goodbye!: We’ll do what you command us, my lord.

Anon!: She creeps.
Goodbye!: She creeps.

Anon!: My babes were destined to a fairer death If grace had blessed thee with a fairer life.
Goodbye!: My babes were destined for a better death if you had blessed you with a better life.

Anon!: My lord, he is but even now gone hence.
Goodbye!: My lord, he’s just gone away.

Anon!: John Duke of Norfolk, Thomas Earl of Surrey, Shall have the leading of this foot and horse.
Goodbye!: John Duke of Norfolk, Thomas Earl of Surrey, will have the lead of this foot and horse.

Anon!: And leave out thee?
Goodbye!: And leave you out?

Anon!: But say, my lord, it were not registered, Methinks the truth should live from age to age, As ’twere retailed to all posterity, Even to the general all-ending day.
Goodbye!: But if it were not registered, I think the truth should live from age to age, as it would be marketed to all people, even to the end of the day.

Anon!: Art thou learned?
Goodbye!: Have you learned something?

Anon!: It is the rival of my love.
Goodbye!: It’s the rival of my love.

Anon!: When?
Goodbye!: When?

Anon!: Sometime she gallops o'er a courtier’s nose, And then dreams he of smelling out a suit.
Goodbye!: Sometimes she gallops up a courtier’s nose, and then dreams of smelling out a suit.

Anon!: How now shall this be compassed?
Goodbye!: How can I get this done?

Anon!: I have not art to reckon my groans, but that I love thee best, oh, most best, believe it.
Goodbye!: I don’t have the art to think about my groans, but I love you best, oh, best, and I’m not.

Anon!: Fare thee well.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: Send Thy token of reprieve.
Goodbye!: Send your token of reprieve.

Anon!: What, Grumio!
Goodbye!: What, Grumio!

Anon!: Twas a sweet marriage, and we prosper well in our return.
Goodbye!: It was a sweet marriage, and we’re going to be happy.

Anon!: So young and so untender?
Goodbye!: So young and so rotten?

Anon!: I could play Ercles rarely, or a part to tear a cat in to make all split.
Goodbye!: I could play Ercles rarely, or a part to tear a cat in and make everything split.

Anon!: Or image of that horror?
Goodbye!: Or image of that horror?

Anon!: A thousand times the worse to want thy light.
Goodbye!: A thousand times worse to want your light.

Anon!: Lady, come from that nest Of death, contagion, and unnatural sleep.
Goodbye!: Lady, come from that nest of death, contagion, and unnatural sleep.

Anon!: But for your words, they rob the Hybla bees And leave them honeyless.
Goodbye!: But for your words, they rob the Hybla bees and leave them honeyless.

Anon!: Now shall my friend Petruchio do me grace, And offer me disguised in sober robes To old Baptista as a schoolmaster Well seen in music, to instruct Bianca, That so I may, by this device at least, Have leave and leisure to make love to her And, unsuspected, court her by herself.
Goodbye!: Now my friend Petruchio will give me grace and offer me disguised in sober robes to old Baptista as a schoolmaster who is well seen in music, to instruct Bianca, so I can, by this

Anon!: Is he not approved in the height a villain, that hath slandered, scorned, dishonored my kinswoman?
Goodbye!: Isn’t he a villain who has slandered, scorned, dishonored my mother?

Anon!: With all my heart, and much it joys me too To see you are become so penitent.— Tressel and Berkeley, go along with me.
Goodbye!: With all my heart, and it’s great to see you’re so penitent.—Tressel and Berkeley, go with me.

Anon!: O happy dagger, This is thy sheath.
Goodbye!: Oh, happy dagger, this is your sheath.

Anon!: Not so, my lord.
Goodbye!: Not true, my lord.

Anon!: I like it not.
Goodbye!: I don’t like it.

Anon!: Open the tomb.
Goodbye!: Open the tomb.

Anon!: Take but good note, and you shall see in him The triple pillar of the world transformed Into a strumpet’s fool.
Goodbye!: Take good care of him, and you’ll see that the triple pillar of the world has transformed into a strumpet’s fool.

Anon!: I understand a fury in your words, But not the words.
Goodbye!: I understand your words are furious, but not the words.

Anon!: We’ll beat ’em into bench-holes.
Goodbye!: We’ll beat ’em into a hole.

Anon!: I now repent I told the pursuivant, As too triumphing, how mine enemies Today at Pomfret bloodily were butchered, And I myself secure in grace and favor.
Goodbye!: I’m sorry I told the king, as if I were too triumphant, how my enemies were killed at Pomfret today, and I myself was secure in grace and favor.

Anon!: Or shall I think in silver she’s immured, Being ten times undervalued to tried gold?
Goodbye!: Or should I think she’s immured in silver, being ten times undervalued to gold?

Anon!: An now tell me, how doth your cousin?
Goodbye!: Tell me, how is your cousin?

Anon!: But wherefore art not in thy shop today?
Goodbye!: But why aren’t you in your shop today?

Anon!: We are yet but young in deed.
Goodbye!: We’re still young in the matter of things.

Anon!: Marry, that he had received a thousand ducats of Don John for accusing the Lady Hero wrongfully.
Goodbye!: He’d received a thousand ducats from Don John for accusing the Lady Hero of wrong doing.

Anon!: Yet here she is allowed her virgin crants, Her maiden strewments, and the bringing home Of bell and burial.
Goodbye!: But here she is allowed to eat her virgin strewns, her maiden strewments, and the bringing home of bell and burial.

Anon!: What is thy will with her?
Goodbye!: What will you do with her?

Anon!: Whip him, fellows, Till like a boy, you see him cringe his face And whine aloud for mercy.
Goodbye!: Whip him up, fellows, until you see him cringe his face and whine for mercy.

Anon!: Oh, wonder!
Goodbye!: Oh, wonder!

Anon!: I have it ready for thee.
Goodbye!: I have it ready for you.

Anon!: On the ground  Sleep sound.
Goodbye!: On the ground sleep sound.

Anon!: Sir!
Goodbye!: Sir!

Anon!: Presently?
Goodbye!: Presently?

Anon!: What?
Goodbye!: What?

Anon!: Rude ragged nurse, old sullen playfellow For tender princes, use my babies well.
Goodbye!: A ragged nurse, old sullen playfellow, for tender princes, use my babies well.

Anon!: Not I, I must be found.
Goodbye!: Not me, I have to find him.

Anon!: Never, till Caesar’s three and thirty wounds Be well avenged, or till another Caesar Have added slaughter to the sword of traitors.
Goodbye!: Never, until Caesar’s three and thirty wounds are well avenged, or until another Caesar has added a sword to the sword of traitors.

Anon!: Lend me thy handkerchief.
Goodbye!: Lend me your handkerchief.

Anon!: This is not altogether fool, my lord.
Goodbye!: This is not a fool altogether, my lord.

Anon!: Why had I not with charitable hand Took up a beggar’s issue at my gates, Who, smirchèd thus, and mired with infamy, I might have said, “No part of it is mine; This shame derives itself from unknown loins”?
Goodbye!: Why wouldn’t I have smirked a beggar’s issue at my gates, who, smirchended so, and mired in a famy, I could have said, “

Anon!: Give me the cups.
Goodbye!: Give me the cups.

Anon!: This savors not much of distraction.
Goodbye!: This isn’t a good thing to do.

Anon!: No.
Goodbye!: No.

Anon!: Go in with me, and I will tell you my drift.
Goodbye!: Go inside with me, and I’ll tell you my story.

Anon!: All’s well, sweeting, Come away to bed.— Myself will be your surgeon.
Goodbye!: All right, sweetening, come to bed.—I’ll be your surgeon.

Anon!: Oh, ’twas a din to fright a monster’s ear, To make an earthquake!
Goodbye!: Oh, it was a scream to frighten a monster’s ear, to make an earthquake!

Anon!: Did your letters pierce the queen to any demonstration of grief?
Goodbye!: Did your letters pierce the queen to any demonstration of grief?

Anon!: He is not the flower of courtesy, but, I’ll warrant him, as gentle as a lamb.
Goodbye!: He’s not the flower of courtesy, but I’ll bet he’s as gentle as a lamb.

Anon!: Then there’s hope a great man’s memory may outlive his life half a year.
Goodbye!: Then there’s hope that a great man’s memory will outlive his life for half a year.

Anon!: It is not for your health thus to commit Your weak condition to the raw, cold morning.
Goodbye!: It’s not your health to commit your weak condition to the cold morning.

Anon!: I’ll serve this duke.
Goodbye!: I’ll serve this duke.

Anon!: Alas, why would you heap this care on me?
Goodbye!: Why would you heap this attention on me?

Anon!: At first the infant, Mewling and puking in the nurse’s arms.
Goodbye!: The first child was born, swung and puking in the nurse’s arms.

Anon!: The gods reward your kindness!
Goodbye!: The gods reward your kindness!

Anon!: O God, she comes.—O honey Nurse, what news?
Goodbye!: Oh God, she comes.—Oh honey Nurse, what news do you have?

Anon!: Are my deserts no better?
Goodbye!: Are my deserts no better than mine?

Anon!: Not so young, sir, to love a woman for singing, nor so old to dote on her for anything.
Goodbye!: I’m not so young, sir, to love a woman for singing, or so old to dote on her for anything.

Anon!: How oddly he is suited!
Goodbye!: How odd he is!

Anon!: Such unconstant starts are we like to have from him as this of Kent’s banishment.
Goodbye!: We like to see such unconstant starts from him as this of Kent’s banishment.

Anon!: I dare pawn down my life for him that he hath wrote this to feel my affection to your honor and to no other pretense of danger.
Goodbye!: I dare pawn down my life for him, because he wrote this letter to feel my affection for you and to no other reason.

Anon!: And I have built Two chantries where the sad and solemn priests Sing still for Richard’s soul.
Goodbye!: And I’ve built two chantries where the sad and solemn priests sing still for Richard’s soul.

Anon!: An old Italian fox is not so kind, my boy.
Goodbye!: An old Italian fox is not so kind, my boy.

Anon!: The duke be here tonight?
Goodbye!: The duke will be here tonight?

Anon!: Comes not that blood as modest evidence To witness simple virtue?
Goodbye!: Isn’t that blood as modest as it is to witness simple virtue?

Anon!: What are you?
Goodbye!: Who are you?

Anon!: Why, thy horn is a foot, and so long am I, at the least.
Goodbye!: You’re a foot, and I’m so long, at least.

Anon!: Marry, th' athversary was have possession of the pridge, but he is enforced to retire, and the duke of Exeter is master of the pridge.
Goodbye!: The duke of Exeter is the master of the pridge.

Anon!: I cannot drink too much of Brutus' love.
Goodbye!: I can’t drink too much of Brutus’s love.

Anon!: That, sir, which I will not report after her.
Goodbye!: That, sir, which I won’t report after her.

Anon!: Will you be married, motley?
Goodbye!: Will you be married, scold?

Anon!: Much is breeding Which, like the courser’s hair, hath yet but life, And not a serpent’s poison.
Goodbye!: There’s a lot of breeding that, like the courser’s hair, has only life, and not a serpent’s poison.

Anon!: Borachio.
Goodbye!: Borachio.

Anon!: Why not, my lord?
Goodbye!: Why not, my lord?

Anon!: Consider then we come but in despite.
Goodbye!: So let’s look at the fact that we’re only coming in spite of it.

Anon!: Most mighty sovereign, You have no cause to hold my friendship doubtful.
Goodbye!: Most mighty sovereign, you have no reason to doubt my friendship.

Anon!: Therefore he that cannot lick his fingers goes not with me.
Goodbye!: So anyone who can’t lick his fingers doesn’t go with me.

Anon!: Look where they come.
Goodbye!: Look, they come.

Anon!: He was quick mettle when he went to school.
Goodbye!: He was quick and sane when he went to school.

Anon!: Now he denies it faintly, and laughs it out.
Goodbye!: Now he denies it faintly, and laughs it out.

Anon!: Mine speak of seventy senators that died By their proscriptions, Cicero being one.
Goodbye!: I’m talking about seventy senators who died by their proscriptions, Cicero being one.

Anon!: I will not budge for no man’s pleasure, I.
Goodbye!: I won’t budge for anyone’s pleasure, I swear.

Anon!: These couchings and these lowly courtesies Might fire the blood of ordinary men And turn preordinance and first decree Into the law of children.
Goodbye!: These slurreds and slurred courtesies could fire ordinary men’s blood and turn preordinance and first decree into children’s law.

Anon!: Out, treacherous villain!
Goodbye!: Out, treacherous villain!

Anon!: The Turk with a most mighty preparation makes for Cyprus.
Goodbye!: The Turk is ready for Cyprus.

Anon!: I will to Egypt.
Goodbye!: I’ll go to Egypt.

Anon!: Gentlemen both, you will mistake each other.
Goodbye!: Gentlemen, you’ll mistake each other.

Anon!: I am not gamesome.
Goodbye!: I’m not a game-player.

Anon!: Things must be as they may.
Goodbye!: Everything must be as good as it may be.

Anon!: He’s friends with Caesar, In state of health, thou say’st, and, thou say’st, free.
Goodbye!: He’s friends with Caesar, you say you’re in good health, and you say you’re free.

Anon!: The sweeter rest was mine.
Goodbye!: The sweeter rest was mine.

Anon!: Deny to speak with me?
Goodbye!: Don’t you refuse to speak with me?

Anon!: Fair princess, you have lost much good sport.
Goodbye!: You’ve lost a lot of good sport.

Anon!: One draught above heat makes him a fool, the second mads him, and a third drowns him.
Goodbye!: A man who’s draught over the heat makes him a fool, the second is mad, and a third drowns him.

Anon!: And as I wooed for thee to obtain her, I will join with thee to disgrace her.
Goodbye!: And as I wooed for you to get her, I’ll join you to shame her.

Anon!: Nor would we deign him burial of his men Till he disbursed at Saint Colme’s Inch Ten thousand dollars to our general use.
Goodbye!: We wouldn’t deign him until he was buried at Saint Colme’s Inch for ten thousand dollars.

Anon!: Come, more, another stanzo.
Goodbye!: Come on, more, another stanzo.

Anon!: Speak but one rhyme, and I am satisfied.
Goodbye!: Speak one rhyme, and I’m satisfied.

Anon!: I did not see you since you sent me hence, Home to the Centaur with the gold you gave me.
Goodbye!: I didn’t see you since you sent me home to the Centaur with the gold you gave me.

Anon!: Grace grow where those drops fall!
Goodbye!: Grace grows where those drops fall!

Anon!: There’s one at the gate.
Goodbye!: There’s one at the gate.

Anon!: If thou dost love me Show me thy thought.
Goodbye!: If you love me, show me your thoughts.

Anon!: Yearly will I do this rite.
Goodbye!: I’ll do this rite every year.

Anon!: Beg another of thy daughters.
Goodbye!: Begin another of your daughters.

Anon!: She’s not fourteen.
Goodbye!: She’s not fourteen.

Anon!: And good monsieur, have a care the honey bag break not.
Goodbye!: And good monsieur, don’t break the honey bag.

Anon!: Sweet masters, be patient.
Goodbye!: Sweet masters, be patient.

Anon!: Bring me to Octavius.
Goodbye!: Bring me to Octavius.

Anon!: I do attend here on the general And think it no addition, nor my wish, To have him see me womaned.
Goodbye!: I’m not a fan of the general and I don’t think it’s any more than my wish to have him see me womaned.

Anon!: Apothecary!
Goodbye!: Apothecary!

Anon!: What then?
Goodbye!: What then?

Anon!: I can write very like my lady your niece: on a forgotten matter we can hardly make distinction of our hands.
Goodbye!: I can write very like your niece, my lady: on a forgotten matter, we can’t make distinction between our hands.

Anon!: Good your grace, pardon me.
Goodbye!: Please pardon me.

Anon!: I shall fall.
Goodbye!: I’ll fall.

Anon!: But first I’ll turn yon fellow in his grave And then return lamenting to my love.
Goodbye!: But first I’ll turn a fellow in his grave and then return to my love, chanting.

Anon!: Who doth he gallop withal?
Goodbye!: Who’s he scolding?

Anon!: Will you, I pray, demand that demi-devil Why he hath thus ensnared my soul and body?
Goodbye!: Will you ask the demi-devil why he has ensnared my soul and body?

Anon!: I hold you but a subject of this war, Not as a brother.
Goodbye!: I’m not a brother, but a subject of this war.

Anon!: Tis true.
Goodbye!: That’s true.

Anon!: I come not, friends, to steal away your hearts.
Goodbye!: I don’t come to steal your hearts, friends.

Anon!: Why, so I did, but looked for no reply.
Goodbye!: I did, but I didn’t look for a reply.

Anon!: Are you not well?
Goodbye!: Aren’t you well?

Anon!: You know the character to be your brother’s?
Goodbye!: You know the character is your brother’s?

Anon!: Here.
Goodbye!: Here.

Anon!: I hear my father coming.
Goodbye!: I hear my father coming.

Anon!: The enemy increaseth every day.
Goodbye!: The enemy is growing every day.

Anon!: By Jupiter, Were I the wearer of Antonio’s beard, I would not shave ’t today.
Goodbye!: By Jupiter, if I were the wearer of Antonio’s beard, I wouldn’t shave it today.

Anon!: Perchance 'Twill walk again.
Goodbye!: I’ll walk again.

Anon!: Those his goodly eyes, That o’er the files and musters of the war Have glowed like plated Mars, now bend, now turn The office and devotion of their view Upon a tawny front.
Goodbye!: The good eyes of the war have glowed like a tawny Mars, and now they’re turning their eyes on a tawny front.

Anon!: Your  It is not a fashion for the maids in France to kiss before they are married, would she say?
Goodbye!: You don’t want the maids in France to kiss before they are married, would she say?

Anon!: What must be shall be.
Goodbye!: What must be will be.

Anon!: Hold!
Goodbye!: Stop!

Anon!: These happy masks that kiss fair ladies' brows, Being black, puts us in mind they hide the fair.
Goodbye!: These happy masks that kiss fair ladies' brows, being black, tell us they hide the fair.

Anon!: Thou hast hit it.
Goodbye!: You’ve hit it.

Anon!: Nay, that would be as great a soil in the new gloss of your marriage as to show a child his new coat and forbid him to wear it.
Goodbye!: No, that would be as important as showing a child his new coat and forbid him to wear it.

Anon!: Where’s the king?
Goodbye!: Where’s the king?

Anon!: What means your lordship?
Goodbye!: What’s your lordship doing?

Anon!: Oh, that I served that lady And might not be delivered to the world, Till I had made mine own occasion mellow, What my estate is.
Goodbye!: Oh, I wouldn’t be able to serve that lady and be delivered to the world until I had made my own occasion, what my estate is.

Anon!: Yea, my lord, but I can cross it.
Goodbye!: Yes, my lord, but I can do it.

Anon!: Will you help?—An ass-head, and a coxcomb, and a knave, a thin-faced knave, a gull!
Goodbye!: Will you help me?—An ass-head, a coxcomb, and a knave, a thin-faced knave, a gull!

Anon!: You have put him down, lady, you have put him down.
Goodbye!: You’ve put him down, lady, you’ve put him down.

Anon!: I will not swear these are my hands.
Goodbye!: I won’t swear that these are my hands.

Anon!: Come, come, we know your meaning, brother Gloucester.
Goodbye!: Come, come, we know what you mean, brother Gloucester.

Anon!: Go, take it up unto thy master’s use.
Goodbye!: Go, take it up to your master’s use.

Anon!: Hear me, Queen: The strong necessity of time commands Our services awhile, but my full heart Remains in use with you.
Goodbye!: Listen to me, Queen: The need for time is important for us to wait a while, but my full heart is still in use with you.

Anon!: But soft!
Goodbye!: But wait!

Anon!: Bloody constraint, for if you hide the crown Even in your hearts, there will he rake for it.
Goodbye!: He’ll be squeezing for it if you hide the crown in your hearts.

Anon!: Farewell, and if my fortune be not crost, I have a father, you a daughter, lost.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, and if my fortune doesn’t go away, I’ve lost a father, you a daughter.

Anon!: There is a fair behavior in thee, captain, And though that nature with a beauteous wall Doth oft close in pollution, yet of thee I will believe thou hast a mind that suits With this thy fair and outward character.
Goodbye!: You have a fair behavior, captain, and even though the nature of the wall is a bit rotten, I’ll believe you have a good mind to do with this kind of character.

Anon!: Where shall we dine?—O me!
Goodbye!: Where should we eat?—Oh, I’m!

Anon!: There’s no clock in the forest.
Goodbye!: There’s no clock in the forest.

Anon!: Where died she?
Goodbye!: Where did she die?

Anon!: I will compound this strife.
Goodbye!: I’ll fight this.

Anon!: I have said.
Goodbye!: I’ve said what I’ve said.

Anon!: No man that’s born of woman Shall e'er have power upon thee.” Then fly, false thanes, And mingle with the English epicures.
Goodbye!: No man born from a woman will have power on you.” Then fly, false thanes, and mingle with the English epicures.

Anon!: Is it so brave a lass?
Goodbye!: Is it so brave?

Anon!: He hath, my lord, of late made many tenders Of his affection to me.
Goodbye!: He has, my lord, made many tenders of his affection to me lately.

Anon!: You advise me well.
Goodbye!: You’re right.

Anon!: I think he be angry indeed.
Goodbye!: I think he’s really angry.

Anon!: Why, bride!
Goodbye!: Hey, bride!

Anon!: Here he comes with your niece.
Goodbye!: Here he comes with your niece.

Anon!: Something have you heard Of Hamlet’s “transformation”—so call it Since nor th' exterior nor the inward man Resembles that it was.
Goodbye!: You’ve heard about Hamlet’s “transformation”—so call it because neither the exterior nor the inside man are similar to what it was.

Anon!: I would have sworn it had, my lord, especially against Benedick.
Goodbye!: I wish I had sworn it had, my lord, especially against Benedick.

Anon!: My lord, we were sent for.
Goodbye!: My lord, we were sent for.

Anon!: Stay, stand apart.
Goodbye!: Stay, stand apart.

Anon!: I cannot fly, But, bearlike, I must fight the course.
Goodbye!: I can’t fly, but I have to fight the course.

Anon!: Strike!
Goodbye!: Strike!

Anon!: Let me question more in particular.
Goodbye!: Let me ask more questions in particular.

Anon!: And by all means stir on the youth to an answer.
Goodbye!: And by all means, encourage the youth to get a reply.

Anon!: Hast thou forgot her?
Goodbye!: Have you forgotten her?

Anon!: The plainsong” is most just, for humors do abound.
Goodbye!: The plainsong” is just, because humor is everywhere.

Anon!: Art thou not Romeo, and a Montague?
Goodbye!: Aren’t you Romeo, and a Montague?

Anon!: Why, no.
Goodbye!: No.

Anon!: Then half Signor Benedick’s tongue in Count John’s mouth, and half Count John’s melancholy in Signor Benedick’s face— With a good leg and a good foot, uncle, and money enough in his purse, such a man would win any woman in the world, if he could get her goodwill.
Goodbye!: Then half of Signor Benedick’s tongue in Count John’s mouth, and half of Count John’s melancholy in Signor Benedick’s face—with a good leg and

Anon!: Are they like to take dust, like Mistress Mall’s picture?
Goodbye!: Are they like to take dust like Mistress Mall’s picture?

Anon!: It was some fiend.
Goodbye!: It was some savage.

Anon!: I owe you none till I receive the chain.
Goodbye!: I owe you nothing until I receive the necklace.

Anon!: Why, so.
Goodbye!: Well, that’s true.

Anon!: Discern’st thou aught in that?
Goodbye!: Are you a bit sceptical about that?

Anon!: And smelt so?
Goodbye!: And smelt so?

Anon!: Then walk we forth, even to the marketplace, And waving our red weapons o'er our heads Let’s all cry, “Peace, freedom, and liberty!” Stoop, then, and wash.
Goodbye!: Then we’ll walk out to the marketplace, and waving our red weapons over our heads, let’s all cry, “Peace, freedom, and liberty!” Stoop, then, and wash.

Anon!: What, Brutus?
Goodbye!: What, Brutus?

Anon!: The foul practice Hath turned itself on me.
Goodbye!: The foul practice has turned itself on me.

Anon!: Oh, the heavens!
Goodbye!: Oh, the heavens!

Anon!: I am very sorry that you are not well.
Goodbye!: I’m very sorry you’re not well.

Anon!: I had most need of blessing, and “Amen” Stuck in my throat.
Goodbye!: I had the most need for blessing, and “Amen” suck in my throat.

Anon!: Sir, my liege, Do not infest your mind with beating on The strangeness of this business.
Goodbye!: Sir, my liege, don’t attack your mind with beating on the strangeness of this business.

Anon!: Tis figured in my tongue.
Goodbye!: It’s figured out in my tongue.

Anon!: No, Messala.
Goodbye!: No, Messala.

Anon!: Cessez!
Goodbye!: Cessez!

Anon!: Nay, I prithee, put on this gown and this beard.
Goodbye!: No, please, put on this gown and this beard.

Anon!: No matter.
Goodbye!: No matter.

Anon!: There I deny my land service.
Goodbye!: I’m refusing my land service.

Anon!: I’ll go another way to work with him.
Goodbye!: I’ll go another way to work with him.

Anon!: And so I am, I am.
Goodbye!: And I am, I am.

Anon!: If but as well I other accents borrow, That can my speech diffuse, my good intent May carry through itself to that full issue For which I razed my likeness.
Goodbye!: If I borrow other accents as well, that can make my speech diffuse, my good intentions can carry through to the full issue for which I razed my likeness.

Anon!: Why, gentle sweet, you shall see no such thing.
Goodbye!: You won’t see anything like that, sweetheart.

Anon!: Fear nothing.
Goodbye!: Don’t worry about it.

Anon!: Oh!
Goodbye!: Oh!

Anon!: Let me have audience for a word or two.
Goodbye!: Let me have a listener for a word or two.

Anon!: O God’s lady dear, Are you so hot?
Goodbye!: Oh God’s lady, are you so hot?

Anon!: No, not till Thursday.
Goodbye!: No, not until Thursday.

Anon!: I think so, Charmian.
Goodbye!: I think so, Charmian.

Anon!: Well, here’s my comfort.
Goodbye!: Well, here’s my comfort.

Anon!: Is ’t so saucy?
Goodbye!: Is it so sane?

Anon!: But he sleeps.
Goodbye!: But he’s asleep.

Anon!: Truly, the more to blame he.
Goodbye!: The more he’s to blame.

Anon!: I will have it all mine.
Goodbye!: I’ll have it all mine.

Anon!: Good Father, I beseech you on my knees, Hear me with patience but to speak a word.
Goodbye!: Good Father, I beg you to kneel, listen to me with patience.

Anon!: Both, both, my lord.— This letter, madam, craves a speedy answer.
Goodbye!: Both, both, my lord.—This letter, madam, wants a quick answer.

Anon!: Away with it!
Goodbye!: Get out of here!

Anon!: Even he that makes her queen.
Goodbye!: The one who makes her queen.

Anon!: We’ll wait upon your lordship.
Goodbye!: We’ll wait on your lordship.

Anon!: Pursue him and entreat him to a peace.
Goodbye!: Go ahead and get him to a peace.

Anon!: Some dear friend dead, else nothing in the world Could turn so much the constitution Of any constant man.
Goodbye!: Some dear friend is dead, but nothing in the world could turn any man’s constitution into a constant man.

Anon!: The rarer action is In virtue than in vengeance.
Goodbye!: The rarer action is in virtue than in vengeance.

Anon!: Who, Sir Andrew Aguecheek?
Goodbye!: Who, Sir Andrew Aguecheek?

Anon!: Good friend,” quoth he, “Say the firm Roman to great Egypt sends This treasure of an oyster, at whose foot, To mend the petty present, I will piece Her opulent throne with kingdoms.
Goodbye!: “Say the Romans to great Egypt send this treasure of an oyster, at whose feet, to mend the petty present, I’ll put her throne in the kingdoms.

Anon!: Though that the queen on special cause is here, Her army is moved on.
Goodbye!: Though the queen is here for a special cause, her army has moved on.

Anon!: I passed, methought, the melancholy flood, With that sour ferryman which poets write of, Unto the kingdom of perpetual night.
Goodbye!: I passed the melancholy flood, with the sour ferryman, poets write about, to the kingdom of perpetual night.

Anon!: I know not what you mean by that, but I am sure Caesar fell down.
Goodbye!: I don’t know what you mean by that, but I’m sure Caesar fell down.

Anon!: They are all welcome.
Goodbye!: They’re all welcome.

Anon!: What, you mean my face?
Goodbye!: What, you mean my face?

Anon!: Had she affections and warm youthful blood, She would be as swift in motion as a ball.
Goodbye!: If she had affections and youthful blood, she would be as swift in motion as a ball.

Anon!: My determinate voyage is mere extravagancy.
Goodbye!: My sane voyage is just a matter of extravagance.

Anon!: Wherefore storm you so?
Goodbye!: Why are you so angry?

Anon!: I’ll help you, Sir Toby, because we’ll be dressed together.
Goodbye!: I’ll help you, Sir Toby, because we’ll be dressed together.

Anon!: The earth sings when he touches it.
Goodbye!: The earth sings when he touches it.

Anon!: Why do you speak, too, “Why blame you me to love you?”?
Goodbye!: Why do you say, too, “Why do you blame me for love you?”?

Anon!: Indeed she’s a most fresh and delicate creature.
Goodbye!: She’s a very fresh and delicate creature.

Anon!: Help to bear this away where my hogshead of wine is, or I’ll turn you out of my kingdom.
Goodbye!: Help me get this out of my hogshead of wine, or I’ll take you out of my kingdom.

Anon!: Fail not our feast.
Goodbye!: Don’t miss our feast.
