Anon!: What, shall I be appointed hours as though, belike, I knew not what to take and what to leave, ha?
Goodbye!: What, should I be notified hours like if I didn’t know what to take and what to leave, ha?

Anon!: Infer fair England’s peace by this alliance.
Goodbye!: Infer that this alliance will give England fair peace.

Anon!: There remain And fortify it strongly 'gainst the French.
Goodbye!: There are still some people here, and it’s strong against the French.

Anon!: Your wife Octavia, with her modest eyes And still conclusion, shall acquire no honor Demuring upon me.
Goodbye!: Your wife Octavia, with her modest eyes and still conclusion, won’t be honored to be Demuring me.

Anon!: Have not you love enough to bear with me, When that rash humor which my mother gave me Makes me forgetful?
Goodbye!: Don’t you love me enough to bear with me when my rash humor that my mother gave me makes me forgetful?

Anon!: Will you sup there?
Goodbye!: Will you go there?

Anon!: Here comes Sir Oliver.—Sir Oliver Martext, you are well met.
Goodbye!: Here comes Sir Oliver.—Sir Oliver Martext, you’re well met.

Anon!: Oh, devil, devil!
Goodbye!: Oh, devil, devil!

Anon!: But here comes Antony.
Goodbye!: But here comes Antony.

Anon!: Now she’s gone for ever.— Cordelia, Cordelia, stay a little.
Goodbye!: Now she’s gone for forever.—Curtelia, Cordelia, stay a little longer.

Anon!: Thy master and his man are here, And that is false thou dost report to us.
Goodbye!: Your master and his man are here, and that’s false news that you’re reporting to us.

Anon!: Or I, I promise thee.
Goodbye!: Or I, I promise you.

Anon!: Ay, my good lord.
Goodbye!: Yes, my good lord.

Anon!: Give the word through.
Goodbye!: Give the word out.

Anon!: God be at your table.
Goodbye!: God be at your table.

Anon!: My life, sir!
Goodbye!: My life, sir!

Anon!: Or is your gold and silver ewes and rams?
Goodbye!: Or are your ewes and rams in gold and silver?

Anon!: Are those my tents where I perceive the fire?
Goodbye!: Are those my tents where I see the fire?

Anon!: Thou hast served me with much faith.
Goodbye!: You’ve served me with great faith.

Anon!: And thus it may be.
Goodbye!: That’s what it may be.

Anon!: Oh, couldst thou speak, That I might hear thee call great Caesar ass Unpolicied!
Goodbye!: Oh, could you speak, so I could hear you call the great Caesar ass unpolicied!

Anon!: Hence will I to my ghostly friar’s close cell, His help to crave and my dear hap to tell.
Goodbye!: I’ll go to my ghostly friar’s cell, where he’ll help me, and tell me what I’m doing.

Anon!: But who comes here?
Goodbye!: But who’s coming?

Anon!: He cannot by the duello avoid it.
Goodbye!: He can’t avoid it by the duello.

Anon!: Cry mercy, lords and watchful gentlemen, That you have ta'en a tardy sluggard here.
Goodbye!: Please, lords and gentlemen, that you’re a tardy sluggard here.

Anon!: I gave him the stuff.
Goodbye!: I gave him the stuff.

Anon!: I doubt not but his friends will turn to us.
Goodbye!: I don’t doubt his friends will come to us.

Anon!: To the breach, to the breach!
Goodbye!: To the breach, to the breach!

Anon!: I will be here again, even with a thought.
Goodbye!: I’ll be here again, even with a thought.

Anon!: My Lord of Warwick, here is, praised be God for it, a most contagious treason come to light, look you, as you shall desire in a summer’s day.
Goodbye!: My Lord of Warwick, here comes a contagious treason to light, look at you, as you’ll want in a summer’s day.

Anon!: What a blow was there given!
Goodbye!: What a blow it was!

Anon!: Did I not meet thy friends?
Goodbye!: Didn’t I meet your friends?

Anon!: Let it go.
Goodbye!: Let it go.

Anon!: I could be sad.
Goodbye!: I could be sad.

Anon!: Poor Ophelia Divided from herself and her fair judgment, Without the which we are pictures, or mere beasts.
Goodbye!: Poor Ophelia was separated from herself and her judgment, even if we were mere beasts.

Anon!: I say, this house is as dark as ignorance, though ignorance were as dark as hell.
Goodbye!: I say this house is as dark as ignorance, even though ignorance was as dark as hell.

Anon!: Would the night were come!
Goodbye!: I wish the night were here!

Anon!: Beshrew me but I love her heartily.
Goodbye!: I’m a shrewd woman, but I love her very much.

Anon!: Very well took, i' faith, wisely, wisely.
Goodbye!: I think it’s very well done, wisely, wisely.

Anon!: So was I when your Highness banished him.
Goodbye!: I was the one who banished him from your Highness.

Anon!: Utter your gravity o'er a gossip’s bowl, For here we need it not.
Goodbye!: Don’t let your gravity go into a gossip’s bowl, because here we don’t need it.

Anon!: Cassio, my lord?
Goodbye!: Cassio, my lord?

Anon!: None, Brutus, none.
Goodbye!: No, Brutus, no.

Anon!: One of them showed me a ring that he had of your daughter for a monkey.
Goodbye!: One of them showed me a ring that he had of your daughter for a monkey.

Anon!: Other women cloy The appetites they feed, but she makes hungry Where most she satisfies, for vilest things Become themselves in her, that the holy priests Bless her when she is riggish.
Goodbye!: Other women cloy their appetites, but she makes hungry wherever she satisfies most, because the vilest things are in her, that the holy priests Bless her when she is rigging.

Anon!: So doth the greater glory dim the less.
Goodbye!: The greater glory dim the less.

Anon!: I would I knew thy heart.
Goodbye!: I wish I knew your heart.

Anon!: No, I am promised forth.
Goodbye!: No, I’ve been promised to go.

Anon!: Wisely and slow.
Goodbye!: Be wise and slow.

Anon!: Know you where you are, sir?
Goodbye!: Do you know where you are, sir?

Anon!: Weeping and wailing over Tybalt’s corse.
Goodbye!: Weeping and wailing over Tybalt’s corse.

Anon!: What, not to pray?
Goodbye!: What, don’t you want to pray?

Anon!: See, doth he breathe?
Goodbye!: Is he breathing?

Anon!: And I mine.
Goodbye!: And I’m mine.

Anon!: Cambio is changed into Lucentio.
Goodbye!: Cambio is transformed into Lucentio.

Anon!: Villainous whore!
Goodbye!: A vile whore!

Anon!: It ripens towards it.
Goodbye!: It’s ripening towards it.

Anon!: I would your duty were as foolish too.
Goodbye!: I wish your duties were as foolish as you were.

Anon!: I wis, your grandam had a worser match.
Goodbye!: I swear, your grandma had a worse match.

Anon!: Your mistress sent to have me home to dinner?
Goodbye!: Your mistress sent to bring me home to dinner?

Anon!: You shall read us the will, Caesar’s will.
Goodbye!: You’ll read the will, Caesar’s will.

Anon!: Tis even so.
Goodbye!: That’s true.

Anon!: Ill will never said well.
Goodbye!: Ill will never say anything well.

Anon!: What woman’s man?
Goodbye!: What woman’s man?

Anon!: He is now as valiant as Hercules that only tells a lie and swears it.
Goodbye!: He’s as brave now as Hercules, who only tells a lie and swears it.

Anon!: Old fashions please me best.
Goodbye!: Old fashions please me best.

Anon!: Nothing?
Goodbye!: Nothing?

Anon!: Good morrow to my sovereign king and queen, And, princely peers, a happy time of day.
Goodbye!: Good morning to my sovereign king and queen, and, princely peers, a happy day.

Anon!: That’s one of them.
Goodbye!: That’s one of them.

Anon!: Therefore be out of hope, of question, of doubt.
Goodbye!: So be out of hope, of question, of doubt.

Anon!: O soft, sir!
Goodbye!: Oh, you’re soft, sir!

Anon!: How dost thou, Charles?
Goodbye!: How are you, Charles?

Anon!: For the meat, sir, it shall be covered.
Goodbye!: For the meat, sir, it will be covered.

Anon!: Welcome, good Cambio.
Goodbye!: Welcome, good Cambio.

Anon!: No, not much moved.
Goodbye!: No, not much moved.

Anon!: In sadness, cousin, I do love a woman.
Goodbye!: I’m sad, cousin, I love a woman.

Anon!: I loved you ever.
Goodbye!: I always loved you.

Anon!: Nay, but his jesting spirit, which is now crept into a lute string and now governed by stops— Indeed, that tells a heavy tale for him.
Goodbye!: No, but his stinging spirit, which has now crept into a lute and now is governed by stops—that’s a heavy tale for him.

Anon!: Believe me, no.
Goodbye!: No, don’t believe me.

Anon!: And we understand him well, How he comes o'er us with our wilder days, Not measuring what use we made of them.
Goodbye!: And we understand him well, how he comes to us with our wilder days, not how we used them.

Anon!: What, the chain?
Goodbye!: What, the necklace?

Anon!: I prithee, be gone.
Goodbye!: Please, go away.

Anon!: Then shall I bleed to death.
Goodbye!: Then I’ll bleed to death.

Anon!: God save you, sir!
Goodbye!: God save you, sir!

Anon!: Conduct me to mine host.
Goodbye!: Go to my host.

Anon!: What is the matter?
Goodbye!: What’s the matter?

Anon!: Why ask you this?
Goodbye!: Why do you ask this?

Anon!: A gentleman?
Goodbye!: A gentleman?

Anon!: If you come slack of former services, You shall do well.
Goodbye!: If you’re not able to do anything like that, you’ll do well.

Anon!: Give her the right you should have given her cousin, And so dies my revenge.
Goodbye!: Give her the right you should have given her cousin, and so dies my revenge.

Anon!: Richard!
Goodbye!: Richard!

Anon!: How is ’t with me when every noise appals me?
Goodbye!: How is it with me when every noise strikes me?

Anon!: Mercutio, thou consort’st with Romeo.
Goodbye!: Mercutio, you’re consorting with Romeo.

Anon!: But yet hie you to Egypt again.
Goodbye!: But you’re still going to Egypt again.

Anon!: Prithee, peace.
Goodbye!: Please, calm down.

Anon!: Is the day so young?
Goodbye!: Is the day so young?

Anon!: I dare assure thee that no enemy Shall ever take alive the noble Brutus.
Goodbye!: I’m sure no enemy will ever take the noble Brutus alive.

Anon!: Tell him I have moved my lord on his behalf, and hope all will be well.
Goodbye!: Tell him I’ve moved my lord on his behalf, and I hope everything will be well.

Anon!: How?
Goodbye!: How?

Anon!: Remember me.
Goodbye!: Remember me.

Anon!: Were it not better, Because that I am more than common tall, That I did suit me all points like a man?
Goodbye!: Isn’t it better to be taller than a man, because I’m more than common tall, and that I would fit me all the points like a man?

Anon!: Mark Antony shall say I am not well, And for thy humor I will stay at home.
Goodbye!: Mark Antony will say I’m not well, and I’ll stay at home for your humor.

Anon!: You, you, sirrah, where’s my daughter?
Goodbye!: You, you, sir, where’s my daughter?

Anon!: Call my train together.— Degenerate bastard, I’ll not trouble thee.
Goodbye!: Call my train together.—Degenerate bastard, I won’t bother you.

Anon!: Moonshine and Lion are left to bury the dead.
Goodbye!: Moonshine and Lion are left to bury the dead.

Anon!: Marian, I say!
Goodbye!: Marian, I say!

Anon!: My Lord of Norfolk— Here, most gracious liege.
Goodbye!: My Lord of Norfolk— Here, most gracious liege.

Anon!: How appears the fight?
Goodbye!: How is the fight going?

Anon!: So the life that died with shame Lives in death with glorious fame.
Goodbye!: So the life that died with shame lives in death with glorious fame.

Anon!: O murderous slumber, Layst thou thy leaden mace upon my boy That plays thee music?—Gentle knave, good night.
Goodbye!: Oh, murderous slumber, are you putting your lead mace on my boy who plays you music?—Gentle knave, good night.

Anon!: You heard her say herself it was not I.
Goodbye!: You heard her say it wasn’t me.

Anon!: It is the green-eyed monster which doth mock The meat it feeds on.
Goodbye!: It’s the green-eyed monster who mocks the meat it feeds.

Anon!: For that goes hard.
Goodbye!: That’s hard.

Anon!: Advise the duke where you are going, to a most festinate preparation.
Goodbye!: Ask the duke where you’re going, to prepare for the worst.

Anon!: Here, Peter Quince.
Goodbye!: Here, Peter Quince.

Anon!: Lay hand on heart, advise.
Goodbye!: Give me a hand on heart and advise me.

Anon!: I found it thrown in at the casement of my closet.
Goodbye!: I found it in my closet.

Anon!: What, art thou waking?
Goodbye!: What, are you awake?

Anon!: What, shall we toward the Tower?
Goodbye!: What, should we go to the Tower?

Anon!: Here comes Baptista.
Goodbye!: Here comes Baptista.

Anon!: The day, my friends, and all things stay for me.
Goodbye!: The day, my friends, and everything is going on for me.

Anon!: Minion, your dear lies dead, And your unblest fate hies.
Goodbye!: Minion, your dear lies dead, and your unblest fate is coming.

Anon!: Marry, I would not do such a thing for a joint-ring, nor for measures of lawn, nor for gowns, petticoats, nor caps, nor any petty exhibition.
Goodbye!: I wouldn’t do such a thing for a ring, for lawn measures, for gowns, petticoats, caps, or any other small exhibition.

Anon!: Is she shrill-tongued or low?
Goodbye!: Is she shrill-tongued or low?

Anon!: O mercy, God!
Goodbye!: Oh mercy, God!

Anon!: Who ambles time withal?
Goodbye!: Who ambles time with him?

Anon!: Speakest thou from thy heart?
Goodbye!: Do you speak from your heart?

Anon!: More light and light, more dark and dark our woes!
Goodbye!: More and more light and dark and dark our sorrows!

Anon!: And since you know you cannot see yourself So well as by reflection, I, your glass, Will modestly discover to yourself That of yourself which you yet know not of.
Goodbye!: And since you know you can’t see yourself as well as by reflection, I’ll be able to find out what you’re not aware of.

Anon!: I say to you this house is dark.
Goodbye!: I say this house is dark.

Anon!: Come on, then.
Goodbye!: Come on, then.

Anon!: Tis wonderful.
Goodbye!: It’s wonderful.

Anon!: Believe me for mine honor, and have respect to mine honor that you may believe.
Goodbye!: Believe me for my honor, and have respect for my honor that you may believe.

Anon!: A devil!
Goodbye!: A devil!

Anon!: Poor I am but his stale.
Goodbye!: I’m only a poor man.

Anon!: I am called.
Goodbye!: I’m called.

Anon!: Expose thyself to feel what wretches feel, That thou mayst shake the superflux to them And show the heavens more just.
Goodbye!: Expose yourself to what wretches feel, so you can shake the superflux to them and show the heavens more just.

Anon!: Yet hear me, countrymen.
Goodbye!: But listen to me, countrymen.

Anon!: I warrant you, my lord.
Goodbye!: I’m sure you, my lord.

Anon!: What, wouldst thou have me go and beg my food, Or with a base and boist'rous sword enforce A thievish living on the common road?
Goodbye!: What, would you have me go and beg my food, or do you want to force a thiev on the common road with a sword and a base?

Anon!: The world’s a huge thing.
Goodbye!: The world is huge.

Anon!: It shall not need.
Goodbye!: It won’t need it.

Anon!: We had like to have had our two noses snapped off with two old men without teeth.
Goodbye!: We wish we had two noses snapped off with two old men without teeth.

Anon!: We have a trifling foolish banquet towards.— Is it e'en so?
Goodbye!: We have a foolish banquet to eat.—Is it true?

Anon!: An you lie, sirrah, we’ll have you whipped.
Goodbye!: If you lie, sir, we’ll have you whipped.

Anon!: First, he commends him to your noble self.
Goodbye!: First, he recommends him to your noble self.

Anon!: Fly hence and leave me.
Goodbye!: Go away and leave me.

Anon!: I could say she were worse.
Goodbye!: I could say she was worse.

Anon!: Honest, my lord?
Goodbye!: Honest, my lord?

Anon!: I will dispatch it straight.
Goodbye!: I’ll send it straight.

Anon!: Sit.
Goodbye!: Sit down.

Anon!: It is impossible you should see this, Were they as prime as goats, as hot as monkeys, As salt as wolves in pride, and fools as gross As ignorance made drunk.
Goodbye!: It’s impossible to see this, if they were as prime as goats, as hot as monkeys, as salt as wolves in pride, and fools as gross as drunken ignorance.

Anon!: I am an ass; else it could never be But I should know her as well as she knows me.
Goodbye!: I’m an ass, but I’d like to know her as well as she knows me.

Anon!: A cup, closed in my true love’s hand?
Goodbye!: A cup, closed in my true love’s hand?

Anon!: Yea, is the worst well?
Goodbye!: Is the worst well?

Anon!: I know,” quoth he, “no house, no wife, no mistress.” So that my errand, due unto my tongue, I thank him, I bare home upon my shoulders, For, in conclusion, he did beat me there.
Goodbye!: I know,” he said, “no house, no wife, no mistress.” So that my errand, due to my tongue, I thank him, I bare home on my shoulders, because, in conclusion,

Anon!: Tis strange.
Goodbye!: It’s strange.

Anon!: One cried, “God bless us!” and “Amen” the other, As they had seen me with these hangman’s hands.
Goodbye!: One cried, “God bless us!” and “Amen” the other, as they had seen me with these hangman’s hands.

Anon!: I tell thee, I, that thou hast marred her gown.
Goodbye!: I tell you that you’ve ruined her gown.

Anon!: For he loves to hear That unicorns may be betrayed with trees, And bears with glasses, elephants with holes, Lions with toils, and men with flatterers.
Goodbye!: He loves to hear that unicorns can be betrayed by trees, bears with glasses, elephants with holes, Lions with toils, and men with flatterers.

Anon!: This contents.
Goodbye!: That’s what I’m saying.

Anon!: What you have charged me with, that have I done— And more, much more.
Goodbye!: What you’ve charged me with, that I’ve done—and more, much more.

Anon!: The better for the King of heaven that hath him.
Goodbye!: The better for the King of heaven who has him.

Anon!: Oh, then I see that madmen have no ears.
Goodbye!: Oh, then I see that madmen have no ears.

Anon!: Maybe he is not well.
Goodbye!: Maybe he’s not well.

Anon!: Wilt thou change fathers?
Goodbye!: Do you want to change fathers?

Anon!: There’s not a piece of feather in our host— Good argument, I hope, we will not fly— And time hath worn us into slovenry.
Goodbye!: We don’t have a feather in our host—I hope we won’t fly, I hope—and time has ruined us.

Anon!: Alack, what noise is this?
Goodbye!: What’s this noise?

Anon!: If it please His Majesty, ’tis the breathing time of day with me.
Goodbye!: If it pleases His Majesty, it’s the time of day for me to breathe.

Anon!: Thou art in a parlous state, shepherd.
Goodbye!: You’re in a miserable state, shepherd.

Anon!: Now, by my maidenhead at twelve year old I bade her come.
Goodbye!: Now, by my mother at twelve, I told her to come.

Anon!: Well, to our work alive.
Goodbye!: Well, we’re alive.

Anon!: Hear my excuse.
Goodbye!: Listen to my excuse.

Anon!: These happy masks that kiss fair ladies' brows, Being black, puts us in mind they hide the fair.
Goodbye!: These happy masks that kiss fair ladies' brows, being black, tell us they hide the fair.

Anon!: But do not stain The even virtue of our enterprise, Nor th' insuppressive mettle of our spirits, To think that or our cause or our performance Did need an oath, when every drop of blood That every Roman bears—and nobly bears— Is guilty of a several bastardy If he do break the smallest particle Of any promise that hath passed from him.
Goodbye!: But don’t stain the virtue of our enterprise, nor the insuppressive mettle of our spirits, to think that or our cause or our performance had to be oath, when every drop of blood that every Roman

Anon!: Your Honor wins bad humors.
Goodbye!: Your Honor wins bad humor.

Anon!: My daughter’s mother thinks it with her soul.
Goodbye!: My daughter’s mother thinks about it.

Anon!: We shall have a rare letter from him: but you’ll not deliver ’t?
Goodbye!: We’ll get a rare letter from him, but you won’t deliver it?

Anon!: Well, I am sorry for your niece.
Goodbye!: Well, I’m sorry for your niece.

Anon!: Poor venomous fool Be angry and dispatch.
Goodbye!: Poor venomous fool, be angry and be ready.

Anon!: Fortune now To my heart’s hope!
Goodbye!: I hope I’ll have luck now!

Anon!: My hour is almost come When I to sulfurous and tormenting flames Must render up myself.
Goodbye!: I’m almost here when I’ll be forced to burn myself to the flames.

Anon!: What make you from home?
Goodbye!: What do you mean by leaving home?

Anon!: This is the night That either makes me or fordoes me quite.
Goodbye!: This is the night that makes me feel like it’s a bad night.

Anon!: Belike his wife, acquainted with his fits, On purpose shut the doors against his way.
Goodbye!: As his wife, who knows his sleeves, shut the doors against his way.

Anon!: This is not the way To win your daughter.
Goodbye!: This is not the way to win your daughter.

Anon!: The obscure bird Clamored the livelong night.
Goodbye!: The obscure bird screamed livelong night.

Anon!: And therefore, I pray thee, news.
Goodbye!: So please, tell me, news.

Anon!: When could they say till now, that talked of Rome, That her wide walks encompassed but one man?
Goodbye!: When could they say that he talked about Rome, that his long walks included only one man?

Anon!: Awake, I say!
Goodbye!: Wake up, I say.

Anon!: But speak, Egeus.
Goodbye!: But speak, Egeus.

Anon!: Will you withdraw?
Goodbye!: Will you come back?

Anon!: By no means, sir.
Goodbye!: No, I don’t.

Anon!: Laugh to scorn The power of man, for none of woman born Shall harm Macbeth.
Goodbye!: Don’t Laugh to dissuade the power of man, because none of the women born will harm Macbeth.

Anon!: But Brutus says he was ambitious, And Brutus is an honorable man.
Goodbye!: But Brutus says he was ambitious, and Brutus is an honorable man.

Anon!: Hid’st thou that forehead with a golden crown Where should be branded, if that right were right, The slaughter of the prince that owed that crown And the dire death of my poor sons and brothers?
Goodbye!: Are you a man who’s a golden crown?

Anon!: Will you lead, lords?
Goodbye!: Will you lead, lords?

Anon!: The carriages, sir, are the hangers.
Goodbye!: The carriages, sir, are the hangers.

Anon!: His eyes are red as fire with weeping.
Goodbye!: His eyes are as red as fire with weeping.

Anon!: But I have spoke With one that saw him die, who did report That very frankly he confessed his treasons, Implored your highness' pardon, and set forth A deep repentance.
Goodbye!: But I’ve spoken with one who saw him die, who said he confessed his crimes very frankly, implored your highness’ pardon and made a deep repentance.

Anon!: I do believe ’twas he.
Goodbye!: I think he was.

Anon!: Captain Fluellen.
Goodbye!: Captain Fluellen.

Anon!: If I lose a scruple of this sport, let me be boiled to death with melancholy.
Goodbye!: If I lose a fight over this sport, let me be boiled to death with melancholy.

Anon!: So, slave, hence!
Goodbye!: So, slave, let’s go!

Anon!: The handkerchief!
Goodbye!: The handkerchief!

Anon!: What does the tyrant?
Goodbye!: What’s the tyrant doing?

Anon!: What means your grace?
Goodbye!: What’s your grace?

Anon!: Stands Scotland where it did?
Goodbye!: Is Scotland the same as it did?

Anon!: Who calls?
Goodbye!: Who’s calling me?

Anon!: Thou shouldst be honest.
Goodbye!: You should be honest.

Anon!: And my help.
Goodbye!: And my help.

Anon!: I know when one is dead and when one lives.
Goodbye!: I know when one is dead and when one is alive.

Anon!: Sir, I am vexed.
Goodbye!: Sir, I’m a slander.

Anon!: Why, sir, he comes not.
Goodbye!: Why, sir, he doesn’t come.

Anon!: I know no answer.
Goodbye!: I don’t know what to say.

Anon!: By the pricking of my thumbs, Something wicked this way comes.
Goodbye!: I swear by the pricking of my thumbs, something wicked is coming.

Anon!: Farewell, for I must leave you.
Goodbye!: Farewell, because I have to leave you.

Anon!: Ready.
Goodbye!: Ready.

Anon!: Suppose th' Ambassador from the French comes back, Tells Harry that the king doth offer him
Goodbye!: The French Ambassador returns to tell Harry that the king offers him

Anon!: Oh, quick, or I am gone.
Goodbye!: Oh, quick, or I’m gone.

Anon!: Thou wilt fall backward when thou comest to age.
Goodbye!: You’ll fall backward when you get older.

Anon!: What else, fellow?
Goodbye!: What else, fellow?

Anon!: No offense i' th' world.
Goodbye!: No offense in the world.

Anon!: We say the king Is wise and virtuous, and his noble queen Well struck in years, fair, and not jealous.
Goodbye!: We say the king is wise and virtuous, and his noble queen has been struck in years, fair, and not jealous.

Anon!: My father had a daughter loved a man As it might be, perhaps, were I a woman, I should your lordship.
Goodbye!: My father had a daughter who loved a man as much as it could be, perhaps if I were a woman, then you should be your lord.

Anon!: Put on what weary negligence you please, You and your fellow servants.
Goodbye!: Put on what you’re a savage man, you and your fellow servants.

Anon!: I may do that I shall be sorry for.
Goodbye!: I may do something I’ll be sorry for.

Anon!: But did you ever tell him she was false?
Goodbye!: But did you ever tell him she was false?

Anon!: But it would warm his spirits To hear from me you had left Antony And put yourself under his shroud, The universal landlord.
Goodbye!: But it would warm his spirits to hear from me that you left Antony and put yourself under his shattered shroud, the universal landlord.

Anon!: Trouble him no more Till further settling.
Goodbye!: Don’t bother him anymore until he’s settled.

Anon!: Thou hast done a deed— I care not for thy sword, I’ll make thee known
Goodbye!: You’ve done a deed— I don’t care about your sword, I’ll tell you.

Anon!: You are my true and honorable wife, As dear to me as are the ruddy drops That visit my sad heart.
Goodbye!: You’re my true and honorable wife, as dear to me as the ruddy drops that make me sad.

Anon!: No, Caesar, we will answer on their charge.
Goodbye!: No, Caesar, we’ll answer to their charge.

Anon!: Go to, then!
Goodbye!: Go on, then!

Anon!: There’s warrant in that theft Which steals itself when there’s no mercy left.
Goodbye!: There’s a warrant in that theft that steals itself when there’s no mercy left.

Anon!: If a Christian do not play the knave and get thee, I am much deceived.
Goodbye!: If a Christian doesn’t play the knave and get you, I’m very wrong.

Anon!: What shall be our sport, then?
Goodbye!: What should we do, then?

Anon!: I am afeard there are few die well that die in a battle, for how can they charitably dispose of anything, when blood is their argument?
Goodbye!: I’m afraid there are few people who die well in a battle, because how can they charitably dispose of anything when they’re fighting?

Anon!: Would it not make one weep?
Goodbye!: Wouldn’t it make one cry?

Anon!: In your bad strokes, Brutus, you give good words.
Goodbye!: In your bad strokes, Brutus, you give good words.

Anon!: Dispatch us with all speed, lest that our king Come here himself to question our delay, For he is footed in this land already.
Goodbye!: Let’s get to the point, so that our king will come here to ask about our delay, because he’s already landed in this land.

Anon!: Madam!
Goodbye!: Madam!

Anon!: Good morrow, cousin.
Goodbye!: Good morning, cousin.

Anon!: The servants of the Duke and my lieutenant?
Goodbye!: The servants of the Duke and my lieutenant?

Anon!: Shall ’t be tonight at supper?
Goodbye!: Shall it be tonight at supper?

Anon!: He’s in yellow stockings.
Goodbye!: He’s in yellow stockings.

Anon!: My words are as full of peace as matter.
Goodbye!: My words are as peaceful as matter.

Anon!: Were the world mine, Demetrius being bated, The rest I’d give to be to you translated.
Goodbye!: If I were in the world, Demetrius being bated, I’d give you the rest of my time to be translated.

Anon!: Do so.
Goodbye!: Do so.

Anon!: O villain, villain!
Goodbye!: Oh, villain, villain!

Anon!: The greater part, the horse in general, Are come with Cassius.
Goodbye!: The greater part, the horse in general, are coming with Cassius.

Anon!: The devil speaks in him.
Goodbye!: The devil speaks in him.

Anon!: Have done thy charm, thou hateful, withered hag.
Goodbye!: Have done your charm, you hateful, withered hag.

Anon!: Briefly, I dwell by the Capitol.
Goodbye!: I’m here.

Anon!: Please you, sir, Do not omit the heavy offer of it.
Goodbye!: Please, sir, don’t omit the heavy offer.

Anon!: Let them come in.
Goodbye!: Let them come in.

Anon!: What simple thief brags of his own attaint?
Goodbye!: What simple thief is brags about his own achievement?

Anon!: More will I do— Though all that I can do is nothing worth, Since that my penitence comes after all, Imploring pardon.
Goodbye!: I’ll do more— Though I can’t do anything worth it, since my penitence is over, imploring pardon.

Anon!: Follow that lord, and look you mock him not.
Goodbye!: Follow that lord, and don’t look at him.

Anon!: Men, wives, and children stare, cry out, and run As it were doomsday.
Goodbye!: Men, wives, and children stare, cry out, and run as if it were doomsday.

Anon!: Hark further.
Goodbye!: Listen.

Anon!: Let him bless thee too.
Goodbye!: Let him bless you too.

Anon!: Your brother the Bastard is fled from Messina.
Goodbye!: Your brother the Bastard has fled from Messina.

Anon!: We are men, my liege.
Goodbye!: We’re men, my liege.

Anon!: Believe me, sir, had I such venture forth, The better part of my affections would Be with my hopes abroad.
Goodbye!: If I had such a venture, I’d have better hoped for my future abroad.

Anon!: The king would speak with Cornwall.
Goodbye!: The king would speak with Cornwall.

Anon!: Sit, sir.
Goodbye!: Sit down, sir.

Anon!: I swear ’tis better to be much abused Than but to know ’t a little.
Goodbye!: I swear it’s better to be abused than to just know a little.

Anon!: Forget to think of her.
Goodbye!: Don’t think about her.

Anon!: They stand and would have parley.
Goodbye!: They’re standing and would have a parley.

Anon!: Would Katherine had never seen him, though!
Goodbye!: I wish Katherine had never seen him, though!

Anon!: In verity you did.—My bones bear witness, That since have felt the vigour of his rage.
Goodbye!: You did.—My bones show that since then he has felt the vigour of his rage.

Anon!: Faith, here’s an English tailor come hither for stealing out of a French hose.
Goodbye!: Yes, here’s an English tailor who’s come here for stealing a French hose.

Anon!: If I should say, I saw such islanders— For, certes, these are people of the island— Who, though they are of monstrous shape, yet note, Their manners are more gentle-kind than of Our human generation you shall find Many—nay, almost any.
Goodbye!: If I said that, I saw such islanders—for, certes, these are people of the island—who, even though they are monstrous, but you can see, their manners are gentler than many of us

Anon!: Come, one for me.
Goodbye!: Come on, one for me.

Anon!: Now Antony must leave her utterly.
Goodbye!: Now Antony must leave her completely.

Anon!: But doth he know that I am in this forest and in man’s apparel?
Goodbye!: But does he know that I’m in this forest and in the man’s clothing?

Anon!: When these prodigies Do so conjointly meet, let not men say, “These are their reasons.
Goodbye!: When these prodigies meet together, don’t say, “These are their reasons.

Anon!: Have more than thou showest, Speak less than thou knowest, Lend less than thou owest, Ride more than thou goest, Learn more than thou trowest, Set less than thou throwest, Leave thy drink and thy whore And keep in-a-door, And thou shalt have more Than two tens to a score.
Goodbye!: Have more than you show, speak less than you know, Lend less than you owest, Ride more than you go, Learn more than you trowest, Set less than you throw, Leave your drink and your whore and keep

Anon!: If you deny it, let the danger light Upon your charter and your city’s freedom.
Goodbye!: If you refuse, let the danger light your charter and your city’s freedom.

Anon!: The sun not yet thy sighs from heaven clears, Thy old groans ring yet in my ancient ears.
Goodbye!: The sun still doesn’t clear your sighs from heaven, and your old groans still ring in my old ears.

Anon!: She hath not seen the change of fourteen years.
Goodbye!: She hasn’t seen the change of fourteen years.

Anon!: Good madam, do.
Goodbye!: Good madam, do.

Anon!: But, as he was ambitious, I slew him.
Goodbye!: But as he was ambitious, I slew him.

Anon!: I afeard of him!
Goodbye!: I’ve scolded him!

Anon!: She, dying, gave it me And bid me, when my fate would have me wived, To give it her.
Goodbye!: She gave it to me, dying, and told me to give it to her when my fate would have me.

Anon!: Nature wants stuff To vie strange forms with fancy, yet t’ imagine An Antony were nature’s piece ’gainst fancy, Condemning shadows quite.
Goodbye!: Nature wants things to be strange and fancy, but imagine an Antony would be the piece of nature’s own, conjuring shadows perfectly.

Anon!: Hadst thou no poison mixed, no sharp-ground knife, No sudden mean of death, though ne'er so mean, But “banishèd” to kill me?—“Banishèd”!
Goodbye!: If you had no poison mixed, no sharp knife, no sudden death, even though it’s not so mean, but “banished” to kill me?—“Banished”!

Anon!: Well, let that rest.
Goodbye!: Well, let that rest.

Anon!: Draw up your powers.
Goodbye!: Draw up your powers.

Anon!: Fellow, I know thee.
Goodbye!: Hello, I know you.

Anon!: For taking one’s part that’s out of favor.
Goodbye!: For taking part in something that’s out of favor.

Anon!: Now, where’s your master?
Goodbye!: Now, where’s your master?

Anon!: Fa, sol, la, mi.
Goodbye!: Fa, sol, la, mi.

Anon!: You spoke not with her since?
Goodbye!: You’ve not spoken to her since then?

Anon!: Then, if ever thou dar’st acknowledge it, I will make it my quarrel.
Goodbye!: Then if you dare to acknowledge it, I’ll make it my fight.

Anon!: Tis but thy name that is my enemy.
Goodbye!: It’s only your name that is my enemy.

Anon!: Madam!
Goodbye!: Madam!

Anon!: After the battle let George Stanley die.
Goodbye!: After the battle let George Stanley die.

Anon!: But woo her, gentle Paris, get her heart.
Goodbye!: But woo her, gentle Paris, get her heart.

Anon!: What error drives our eyes and ears amiss?
Goodbye!: What’s wrong with our eyes and ears?

Anon!: I’ll tell thee, friend, I am almost mad myself.
Goodbye!: I’ll tell you, friend, I’m almost mad myself.

Anon!: There’s not a man I meet but doth salute me As if I were their well-acquainted friend, And every one doth call me by my name.
Goodbye!: I’m not a man who greets me, but who greets me like if I were a well-known friend, and everyone calls me my name.

Anon!: When I do name him, let it be thy part To praise him more than ever man did merit.
Goodbye!: When I name him, let it be your job to praise him more than any man deserves.

Anon!: The sun!
Goodbye!: The sun!

Anon!: But cheer thy heart, and be thou not dismayed.
Goodbye!: But please be calm and don’t be dismayed.

Anon!: Hear me for my cause, and be silent that you may hear.
Goodbye!: Listen to me for my cause, and be silent so you can hear me.

Anon!: Or here, or at the Capitol.
Goodbye!: Or here, or at the Capitol.

Anon!: Do thou for him stand.
Goodbye!: Do you stand for him.

Anon!: You come most carefully upon your hour.
Goodbye!: You’re coming very carefully at your hour.

Anon!: Wherefore, bold peasant, Darest thou support a published traitor?
Goodbye!: Why, bold peasant, do you support a published traitor?

Anon!: My niece is already in the belief that he’s mad.
Goodbye!: My niece already believes he’s insane.

Anon!: Fare you well, Jessica.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, Jessica.

Anon!: In bed asleep while they do dream things true.
Goodbye!: They’re asleep in bed while they dream about it.

Anon!: Good morrow, cousin.
Goodbye!: Good morning, cousin.

Anon!: I wear it for a memorable honor, For I am Welsh, you know, good countryman.
Goodbye!: I wear it for a memorable honor, because I am Welsh, you know, good countryman.

Anon!: Will you go?
Goodbye!: Will you go?

Anon!: He’s of the color of the nutmeg.
Goodbye!: He’s the color of the nutmeg.

Anon!: What tributaries follow him to Rome To grace in captive bonds his chariot wheels?
Goodbye!: What tributaries are he going to Rome to make his chariot wheels captive?

Anon!: Here’s France and Burgundy, my noble lord.
Goodbye!: Here’s France and Burgundy, my noble lord.

Anon!: The money that you owe me for the chain.
Goodbye!: The money you owe me for the necklace.

Anon!: Go a little before.
Goodbye!: Go a little earlier.

Anon!: A trusty villain, sir, that very oft, When I am dull with care and melancholy, Lightens my humor with his merry jests.
Goodbye!: A trusty villain, sir, that often, when I’m dull and dull, he’s bringing me joy with his merry screams.

Anon!: Well, I will forget the condition of my estate to rejoice in yours.
Goodbye!: Well, I’ll forget the condition of my estate to rejoice in yours.

Anon!: But if he had not been in drink, he would have tickled you othergates than he did.
Goodbye!: But if he hadn’t been drinking, he would have thrown you out of the way than he did.

Anon!: Pale or red?
Goodbye!: Pale or red?

Anon!: But being widow, and my Gloucester with her, May all the building in my fancy pluck Upon my hateful life.
Goodbye!: But being a widow, and my Gloucester with her, I’ll leave the entire building in my fancy to spit on my hateful life.

Anon!: What of that?
Goodbye!: What about that?

Anon!: If it were done when ’tis done, then ’twere well It were done quickly.
Goodbye!: If it were done when it was done, then it would be done quickly.

Anon!: Yet at the first I saw the treasons planted.
Goodbye!: But I saw the treasons planted at the first.

Anon!: And if I cannot, I’ll find those that shall.
Goodbye!: And if I can’t, I’ll find those who can.

Anon!: I do not think so.
Goodbye!: I don’t think so.

Anon!: Nay, forward, old man.
Goodbye!: No, go ahead, old man.

Anon!: I hope he is, but yet let mothers doubt.
Goodbye!: I hope he is, but mothers should be afraid.

Anon!: The breaking of so great a thing should make A greater crack.
Goodbye!: The breaking of such a thing should make a bigger crack.

Anon!: Never was monarch better feared and loved Than is your Majesty.
Goodbye!: Never was a monarch better feared and loved than your Majesty.

Anon!: Through the sharp hawthorn blows the cold wind.
Goodbye!: The wind blows through the hawthorn.

Anon!: More light and light, more dark and dark our woes!
Goodbye!: More and more light and dark and dark our sorrows!

Anon!: Why, so I did.
Goodbye!: Well, I did.

Anon!: From Athens is her house remote seven leagues, And she respects me as her only son.
Goodbye!: She’s a little shy from Athens, and she respects me as her only son.

Anon!: Poor lady, she’ll run mad When she shall lack it.
Goodbye!: Poor lady, she’ll run crazy when she’ll have it.

Anon!: What is your name?
Goodbye!: What’s your name?

Anon!: The more I hate, the more he follows me.
Goodbye!: The more I hate him, the more he follows me.

Anon!: How now, Malvolio?
Goodbye!: What’s going on, Malvolio?

Anon!: Love, therefore, and tongue-tied simplicity In least speak most, to my capacity.
Goodbye!: So love and tongue-tied simplicity are all in my capacity.

Anon!: Wisdom!
Goodbye!: Wisdom!

Anon!: Belike ’tis but a rumor.
Goodbye!: It’s just a rumor.

Anon!: But it would better fit your honor to change your mind.
Goodbye!: But it’s better for you to change your mind.

Anon!: O, then be bold to say Bassanio’s dead!
Goodbye!: Oh, then be bold to say Bassanio’s dead!

Anon!: Where’s the cook?
Goodbye!: Where’s the cook?

Anon!: The rest are princes, barons, lords, knights, squires, And gentlemen of blood and quality.
Goodbye!: The rest are princes, barons, lords, knights, squires, and gentlemen of blood and quality.

Anon!: What’s the matter?
Goodbye!: What’s the matter?

Anon!: I am bound to hear.
Goodbye!: I’m bound to hear.

Anon!: Yet leave our cousin Katherine here with us.
Goodbye!: But leave our cousin Katherine here with us.

Anon!: O, tell me, Friar, tell me, In what vile part of this anatomy Doth my name lodge?
Goodbye!: Oh, tell me, Friar, tell me, in what part of my anatomy is my name?

Anon!: Thy sister’s sister.
Goodbye!: Your sister’s sister.

Anon!: Only I yield to die.
Goodbye!: I’ll only give up to die.

Anon!: Oh, that’s well said—the chair!
Goodbye!: Oh, that’s well said—the chair!

Anon!: Very good, my lord.
Goodbye!: Very good, my lord.

Anon!: Long since thy husband served me in my wars, And I to thee engaged a prince’s word, When thou didst make him master of thy bed, To do him all the grace and good I could.
Goodbye!: I’ve been waiting for your husband to serve me in my wars, and I told you to speak with a prince when you made him master of your bed, to do him all the grace and good I could.

Anon!: Besides, his cote, his flocks, and bounds of feed Are now on sale, and at our sheepcote now, By reason of his absence, there is nothing That you will feed on.
Goodbye!: Besides, his cote, his flocks, and his feed bounds are now on sale, and now, because of his absence, there’s nothing you can feed on at our sheepcote.

Anon!: For God’s sake, hold your hands.
Goodbye!: For God’s sake, hold your hands.

Anon!: Reply not.
Goodbye!: Don’t reply.

Anon!: By and by.
Goodbye!: By and by.

Anon!: Well, well, well.
Goodbye!: Well, well, well.

Anon!: I prithee, boy, run to the senate house.
Goodbye!: Please, boy, run to the senate house.

Anon!: I found it in my chamber, And he himself confessed but even now That there he dropped it for a special purpose Which wrought to his desire.
Goodbye!: I found it in my room, and he himself confessed that there he dropped it for a special purpose that he wanted.

Anon!: There, my blessing with thee.
Goodbye!: Here, I’ll give you my blessing.

Anon!: Yon ribaudred nag of Egypt— Whom leprosy o’ertake!—i’ th’ midst o’ th’ fight, When vantage like a pair of twins appeared Both as the same, or rather ours the elder, The breeze upon her, like a cow in June, Hoists sails and flies.
Goodbye!: The ribaudred nag of Egypt—Whom leprosy o’ertakes!—in the middle of the fight, when a pair of twins appeared both as the same, or rather ours

Anon!: Make your vaunting true, And it shall please me well.
Goodbye!: Make your vows true, and it will please me.

Anon!: Your love says, like an honest gentleman, 'Where is your mother?
Goodbye!: Your love says, like an honest gentleman, 'Where is your mother?

Anon!: Farewell, and thanks.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, and thanks.

Anon!: I did her wrong— Canst tell how an oyster makes his shell?
Goodbye!: I did her wrong— Can’t tell how an oyster makes his shell?

Anon!: Soon may I hear and see him.
Goodbye!: I’ll hear him and see him soon.

Anon!: Now I must To the young man send humble treaties, dodge And palter in the shifts of lowness, who With half the bulk o’ th’ world played as I pleased, Making and marring fortunes.
Goodbye!: Now I have to send humble treaties to the young man, who dodges and scolds the sluggish world, making and sluggish fortunes.

Anon!: Stand still.
Goodbye!: Stand still.

Anon!: Twas no need, I trow, To bid me trudge.
Goodbye!: There was no need to tell me to trudge.

Anon!: Give him the cup.
Goodbye!: Give him the cup.

Anon!: Let me see your eyes.
Goodbye!: Let me see your eyes.

Anon!: And weep ye now, seeing she is advanced Above the clouds, as high as heaven itself?
Goodbye!: And now you cry, seeing she’s up above the clouds, as high as heaven itself?

Anon!: For the which I hear what they say of him.
Goodbye!: I hear what they say about him.

Anon!: My will, not all the world.
Goodbye!: I will, not all the world.

Anon!: I would not deny you, but, by this good day, I yield upon great persuasion, and partly to save your life, for I was told you were in a consumption.
Goodbye!: I wouldn’t deny you anything, but I’ll give you a great warning, and partly to save your life, because I was told you were in a good mood.

Anon!: Here I am Antony, Yet cannot hold this visible shape, my knave.
Goodbye!: Here I am Antony, but I can’t hold this visible shape, my king.

Anon!: I pray you call them in.
Goodbye!: Please call them in.

Anon!: I will not shame myself to give you this.
Goodbye!: I won’t shame myself to give you this.

Anon!: No, not a denier.
Goodbye!: No, not a denier.

Anon!: I give him curses, yet he gives me love.
Goodbye!: I curse him, but he gives me love.

Anon!: You are unkind, Demetrius.
Goodbye!: You’re unkind, Demetrius.

Anon!: If such a one be fit to govern, speak.
Goodbye!: If such a person is right to govern, speak.

Anon!: Methinks I do.
Goodbye!: I think I do.

Anon!: Howe'er thou art a fiend, A woman’s shape doth shield thee.
Goodbye!: If you’re a fiend, you’re shielded by a woman’s shape.

Anon!: Be near me, that I may remember you.
Goodbye!: Be near me so I can remember you.

Anon!: So call the field to rest, and let’s away To part the glories of this happy day.
Goodbye!: So call the field to rest, and let’s go to part the glories of this happy day.

Anon!: Be it so, Lysander.
Goodbye!: Be it, Lysander.

Anon!: God ye good morrow, gentlemen.
Goodbye!: Good morning, gentlemen.

Anon!: She shall, Lucentio.
Goodbye!: She will, Lucentio.

Anon!: Her name is Katherina Minola, Renowned in Padua for her scolding tongue.
Goodbye!: Her name is Katherina Minola, known in Padua for her scolding tongue.

Anon!: Oh, I have read it.
Goodbye!: Oh, I’ve read it.

Anon!: True.
Goodbye!: True.

Anon!: Good fool, help me to some light and some paper.
Goodbye!: Good fool, help me to get some light and some paper.

Anon!: If you do love me you will find me out.— Nerissa and the rest, stand all aloof.
Goodbye!: If you love me, you’ll find me.—Nerissa and the rest of you, stay quiet.

Anon!: I durst not!
Goodbye!: I don’t want to!

Anon!: Ah, how much might the man deserve of me that would right her!
Goodbye!: Ah, how much would the man deserve from me who would right her!

Anon!: Look upon Caesar.
Goodbye!: Look at Caesar.

Anon!: By my holy order, I thought thy disposition better tempered.
Goodbye!: I swear by my holy order, I thought you were better prepared.

Anon!: Fortune forbid my outside have not charmed her!
Goodbye!: Fortune forbid that my outsiders haven’t charmed her!

Anon!: And I.
Goodbye!: And I.

Anon!: Moneys is your suit.
Goodbye!: Money is your suit.

Anon!: A greater power than we can contradict Hath thwarted our intents.
Goodbye!: A greater power than we can contradict has ruined our intentions.

Anon!: What should I do with him?
Goodbye!: What should I do with him?

Anon!: She is not, madam.
Goodbye!: She isn’t, madam.

Anon!: Ah, this thou shouldst have done And not have spoke on ’t!
Goodbye!: Ah, you should have done this, and not have spoken about it!

Anon!: We have been up and down to seek him.
Goodbye!: We’ve been looking for him all over the place.

Anon!: I’ll run from thee and hide me in the brakes, And leave thee to the mercy of wild beasts.
Goodbye!: I’ll run away from you and hide in the brakes, and leave you to the mercy of wild animals.

Anon!: You know, he brought me out o' favor with my lady about a bear-baiting here.
Goodbye!: You know, he brought me out of favor with my lady about a bear-baiting here.

Anon!: He did in some sort, indeed, handle women, but then he was rheumatic, and talked of the Whore of Babylon.
Goodbye!: He did in some way handle women, but then he was rheumatic and talked about the Whore of Babylon.

Anon!: All’s but naught.
Goodbye!: It’s just a naughty thing.

Anon!: If you’ll come to supper tonight, you may.
Goodbye!: If you’re going to supper tonight, you may.

Anon!: We will yet do well.
Goodbye!: We’ll do well yet.

Anon!: Was it not yesterday we spoke together?
Goodbye!: Wasn’t it yesterday that we spoke to each other?

Anon!: Hear me, good madam.
Goodbye!: Listen to me, good madam.

Anon!: If you’ll patch a quarrel, As matter whole you have to make it with, It must not be with this.
Goodbye!: If you’re going to fight, you have to fight it together, but it won’t be with this.

Anon!: Farewell.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: Ay, ay, three thousand ducats.
Goodbye!: Yes, yes, three thousand ducats.

Anon!: Hang not on my garments.
Goodbye!: Don’t hang on my clothes.

Anon!: Carry this mad knave to the jail.—Father Baptista, I charge you see that he be forthcoming.
Goodbye!: Go to jail for this mad man.—Father Baptista, I’m telling you that he’s ready.

Anon!: Most rightful judge!
Goodbye!: The most rightful judge!

Anon!: Thou sayst his meat was sauced with thy upbraidings.
Goodbye!: You say his meat was smothered with your sour creams.

Anon!: Tell the clock there.
Goodbye!: Tell the clock there.

Anon!: Who is that calls so coldly?
Goodbye!: Who’s calling so coldly?

Anon!: Impudent strumpet!
Goodbye!: I’m a snub!

Anon!: For his thoughts, Would they were blanks, rather than fill’d with me.
Goodbye!: For his thoughts, would they be blanks instead of filling with me?

Anon!: We see yonder the beginning of the day, but I think we shall never see the end of it.—Who goes there?
Goodbye!: We see the beginning of the day, but I think we’ll never see the end of it.—Who’s there?

Anon!: Even or odd, of all days in the year, Come Lammas Eve at night shall she be fourteen.
Goodbye!: Even or oddly, of all days in the year, Come Lammas Eve at night she’ll be fourteen.

Anon!: but you see my finger Hath not the ring upon it.
Goodbye!: But you see my finger doesn’t have the ring on it.

Anon!: Thy love ne'er alter till thy sweet life end!
Goodbye!: Your love will never change until your sweet life ends!

Anon!: God shield I should disturb devotion!— Juliet, on Thursday early will I rouse ye.
Goodbye!: I’ll bet I’ll disturb devotion!— Juliet, I’ll rouse you on Thursday.

Anon!: Alas, she hath from France too long been chased, And all her husbandry doth lie on heaps, Corrupting in its own fertility.
Goodbye!: She’s been chased from France too long, and her husbandry is lying on heaps, causing her to be ill.

Anon!: Touching this vision here, It is an honest ghost, that let me tell you.
Goodbye!: I’m telling you this, it’s an honest ghost.

Anon!: How, how, how, how?
Goodbye!: How, how, how, how?

Anon!: Marry, I remember it well.
Goodbye!: I remember it well.

Anon!: Is not, sir, my doublet as fresh as the first day I wore it?
Goodbye!: Isn’t my doublet as fresh as the first day I wore it?

Anon!: For I ne'er saw true beauty till this night.
Goodbye!: I’ve never seen true beauty until tonight.

Anon!: To show an unfelt sorrow is an office Which the false man does easy.
Goodbye!: To show a sad man is a job that the false man is easy to do.

Anon!: Do not torment me.
Goodbye!: Don’t torture me.

Anon!: Good friend, I prithee, take him in thy arms.
Goodbye!: Please, my friend, take him in your arms.

Anon!: Oh, fie upon thee, strumpet!
Goodbye!: Oh, fie on you, strumpet!

Anon!: Good morrow, masters.
Goodbye!: Good morning, masters.

Anon!: Yet in faith, if you did, it would not much approve me.
Goodbye!: But if you did, it wouldn’t approve me much.

Anon!: How hast thou lost thy breath?
Goodbye!: How have you lost your breath?

Anon!: Caesar’s better parts Shall be crowned in Brutus!
Goodbye!: Caesar’s better parts will be crowned in Brutus!

Anon!: Why, you gave no gold to me!
Goodbye!: You didn’t give me any gold!

Anon!: The all-seeing sun Ne'er saw her match since first the world begun.
Goodbye!: The sun in the sky has been watching her match since the world began.

Anon!: Now, what news on the Rialto?
Goodbye!: Now, what’s the news on the Rialto?

Anon!: I would it might prove the end of his losses.
Goodbye!: I wish it could prove the end of his losses.

Anon!: I do beseech you, sir, have patience.
Goodbye!: Please, sir, have patience.

Anon!: Murder and treason!
Goodbye!: Murder and treason!

Anon!: By heaven, I will acquaint his majesty With those gross taunts that oft I have endured.
Goodbye!: I’ll tell his majesty I’ve been taunting him for a long time.

Anon!: My clerk hath some good comforts too for you.
Goodbye!: My clerk has some good comforts for you too.

Anon!: Run to your houses, fall upon your knees, Pray to the gods to intermit the plague That needs must light on this ingratitude.
Goodbye!: Run to your houses, fall on your knees, and pray to the gods to stop the plague that needs to be eradicated.

Anon!: A sick man in sadness makes his will, A word ill urged to one that is so ill.
Goodbye!: A sick man in sadness makes his will, a word ill for a man who is so sick.

Anon!: This bud of love, by summer’s ripening breath, May prove a beauteous flower when next we meet.
Goodbye!: This bud of love, by the ripening breath of summer, may turn out to be a beauteous flower when we meet next.

Anon!: They mean to warn us at Philippi here, Answering before we do demand of them.
Goodbye!: They’re going to warn us at Philippi here, answering questions before we ask them.

Anon!: Hence, horrible shadow!
Goodbye!: So, horrible shadow!

Anon!: Your name, sir, truly.
Goodbye!: Your name is truly true, sir.

Anon!: I, sir, am Dromio.
Goodbye!: I, sir, am Dromio.

Anon!: Into a thousand parts divide one man, And make imaginary puissance.
Goodbye!: Divide one man into a thousand pieces and make a sanity.

Anon!: For I have neither wit nor words nor worth, Action nor utterance nor the power of speech, To stir men’s blood.
Goodbye!: I have no wit, no words, no worth, no action, no speech, no power to stir men’s blood.

Anon!: Minion, thou liest.
Goodbye!: You’re a man, minion.

Anon!: Fie upon ’t, foh!
Goodbye!: Go on, foh!

Anon!: Caesar sits down in Alexandria, where I will oppose his fate.
Goodbye!: Caesar sits down in Alexandria, where I’ll fight against his fate.

Anon!: Good dawning to thee, friend.
Goodbye!: Good morning, friend.

Anon!: Thus from my lips, by thine, my sin is purged.
Goodbye!: So my sin is purged from my lips by yours.

Anon!: Tell me, heavenly bow, If Venus or her son, as thou dost know, Do now attend the queen?
Goodbye!: Tell me, heavenly bow, if Venus or her son, as you know, are visiting the queen now?

Anon!: I could never better stead thee than now.
Goodbye!: I couldn’t stand for you better than now.

Anon!: Poor heart, adieu.
Goodbye!: Poor heart, adieu.

Anon!: Why is your cheek so pale?
Goodbye!: Why is your cheek so pale?

Anon!: Now, out of doubt Antipholus is mad; Else would he never so demean himself.
Goodbye!: Now, out of doubt, Antipholus is insane.

Anon!: God’s bread!
Goodbye!: God’s bread!

Anon!: My lord, I warrant you we will play our part As he shall think by our true diligence He is no less than what we say he is.
Goodbye!: My lord, I assure you that we’ll play our part as he thinks by our true diligence he’s not less than what we say he is.

Anon!: Then fly!
Goodbye!: Then fly!

Anon!: They pray; grant thou, lest faith turn to despair.
Goodbye!: They ask, please, so that your faith doesn’t turn to despair.

Anon!: And I, my royal sovereign.
Goodbye!: And I, my royal sovereign.

Anon!: If one knight give a— Would you have a love song or a song of good life?
Goodbye!: If one knight gives a gift— Would you like to sing a love song or a song of good life?

Anon!: What, is the man lunatic?
Goodbye!: What, is the man a savage?

Anon!: Niece, will you look to those things I told you of?
Goodbye!: Niece, will you look at what I told you about?

Anon!: You may as well do anything most hard, As seek to soften that—than which what’s harder?— His Jewish heart.
Goodbye!: You may as well do anything most hard as try to soften that—which is harder than that?—his Jewish heart.

Anon!: Swallows have built In Cleopatra’s sails their nests.
Goodbye!: Swallows have built nests in Cleopatra’s sails.

Anon!: And how does your content Tender your own good fortune?
Goodbye!: And how do you feel about your own good fortune?

Anon!: Marry, ’tis enough.
Goodbye!: It’s enough.

Anon!: Will you go hear this news, Signior?
Goodbye!: Will you go hear this news, Signior?

Anon!: Tomorrow morning come you to my house, And since you could not be my son-in-law, Be yet my nephew.
Goodbye!: Tomorrow morning, come to my house, and since you couldn’t be my son-in-law, be my nephew.

Anon!: And have not we affections, Desires for sport, and frailty, as men have?
Goodbye!: And don’t we have affections, desire for sport, and frailty, as men have?

Anon!: I pray you mar no more of my verses with reading them ill- favoredly.
Goodbye!: Please don’t forget to read my verses ill- suited.

Anon!: God grant that some, less noble and less loyal, Nearer in bloody thoughts, and not in blood, Deserve not worse than wretched Clarence did, And yet go current from suspicion.
Goodbye!: God grant that some, less noble and less loyal, are more likely to be in a bloody mood than wretched Clarence did, and yet they’ll be thrown away from suspicion.

Anon!: Come hither, Nurse.
Goodbye!: Come here, Nurse.

Anon!: But, oh, vain boast!
Goodbye!: But, oh, I’m not a fool!

Anon!: You were best go in.
Goodbye!: You’d better go in.

Anon!: Stand close and list him.
Goodbye!: Stand close and list him.

Anon!: I shall be saved by my husband.
Goodbye!: My husband will save me.

Anon!: What watchful cares do interpose themselves Betwixt your eyes and night?
Goodbye!: What kind of attention do you have to be careful about your eyes and night?

Anon!: The children thus disposed, my wife and I, Fixing our eyes on whom our care was fixed, Fastened ourselves at either end the mast And, floating straight, obedient to the stream, Was carried towards Corinth, as we thought.
Goodbye!: The children who were so disposed of, my wife and I, whose eyes were fixed on whom we were concerned, fixed our eyes on each other at either end of the mast and, floating straight, obedient to the stream

Anon!: I drink to thee.
Goodbye!: I drink to you.

Anon!: Alive in triumph—and Mercutio slain!
Goodbye!: You’re alive in triumph—and Mercutio’s dead!

Anon!: By the hour of nine.
Goodbye!: By nine o'clock.

Anon!: He that knows better how to tame a shrew, Now let him speak; ’tis charity to show.
Goodbye!: He who knows better how to tame a shrew, let him speak.

Anon!: It is.
Goodbye!: It is.

Anon!: No, if without more words you will get you hence.
Goodbye!: No, if you don’t have any more words, you’ll get out of here.

Anon!: Do you not know I am a woman?
Goodbye!: Don’t you know I’m a woman?

Anon!: Come, lords, will you go To comfort Edward with our company?
Goodbye!: Do you want to comfort Edward with our company?

Anon!: No.
Goodbye!: No.

Anon!: That I disdain.
Goodbye!: I’m disdaining you.

Anon!: But note me, signor—
Goodbye!: But watch me, signor—

Anon!: But now, my lord, what say you to my suit?
Goodbye!: But what do you say to my suit?

Anon!: O dear Phoebe, If ever—as that ever may be near— You meet in some fresh cheek the power of fancy, Then shall you know the wounds invisible That love’s keen arrows make.
Goodbye!: Oh, Phoebe, if you ever meet in a fresh cheek the power of fancy, you’ll know the wounds invisible that love’s keen arrows make.

Anon!: My master is grown quarrelsome.
Goodbye!: My master is getting angry.

Anon!: There is but one hope in it that can do you any good, and that is but a kind of bastard hope neither.
Goodbye!: There’s only one hope in it that can do you any good, and that’s just a bastard hope.

Anon!: I am glad on ’t.
Goodbye!: I’m glad about it.

Anon!: The captain— Give it the captain.
Goodbye!: The captain— Give it to the captain.

Anon!: Who is it in the press that calls on me?
Goodbye!: Who’s calling on me in the press?

Anon!: Night’s candles are burnt out, and jocund day Stands tiptoe on the misty mountain tops.
Goodbye!: Night’s candles are burned out, and day is a slut on the misty mountain tops.

Anon!: But not, as I am, royal.
Goodbye!: But not royal, as I am.

Anon!: That is enough to satisfy the senate.
Goodbye!: That’s enough to satisfy the senate.

Anon!: No, trust me, sir, nor I. I am sure thou dost.
Goodbye!: No, don’t trust me, sir, and I’m sure you do.

Anon!: What dost thou mean?
Goodbye!: What do you mean?

Anon!: I have no great devotion to the deed And yet he hath given me satisfying reasons.
Goodbye!: I have no great devotion to the deed, but he has given me good reasons to do that.

Anon!: I have had four quarrels, and like to have fought one.
Goodbye!: I’ve had four fights, and I’d like to have fought one.

Anon!: I am sure you both of you remember me.
Goodbye!: I’m sure you both remember me.

Anon!: Give him heedful note.
Goodbye!: Give him a note.

Anon!: Thy dukedom I resign and do entreat Thou pardon me my wrongs.
Goodbye!: I’m leaving your dukedom and you’re begging you to pardon me my wrongs.

Anon!: I must away this night toward Padua, And it is meet I presently set forth.
Goodbye!: I’ll go away this night to Padua, and I’ll meet it.

Anon!: I will follow.
Goodbye!: I’ll follow.

Anon!: Our general cast us thus early for the love of his Desdemona—who let us not therefore blame.
Goodbye!: Our general swore so early for the love of Desdemona—who let us not blame him.

Anon!: Yet is this no charm for the toothache.—Old Signior, walk aside with me.
Goodbye!: But this isn’t a charm for the toothache.—Old Signior, walk aside with me.

Anon!: I commanded the sleeves should be cut out and sewed up again, and that I’ll prove upon thee, though thy little finger be armed in a thimble.
Goodbye!: I commanded that the sleeves should be cut out and sewed up again, and that I’ll prove that I’ll be able to help you, even if your little finger is armed in a thim

Anon!: My husband, then?
Goodbye!: My husband, then?

Anon!: So Fulvia told me.
Goodbye!: That’s what Fulvia told me.

Anon!: These injuries the king now bears will be revenged home.
Goodbye!: The injuries the king bears will be revenged home.

Anon!: By my heel, I care not.
Goodbye!: I don’t care.

Anon!: Bid your friends welcome, show a merry cheer.
Goodbye!: Tell your friends to welcome you, show a merry cheer.

Anon!: Faith, stay here this night.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, stay here tonight.

Anon!: By your patience, I needs must rest me.
Goodbye!: You’re a good man, so I’ll have to rest.

Anon!: Stars, my lord.
Goodbye!: Stars, my lord.

Anon!: I will not do them wrong.
Goodbye!: I won’t do them wrong.

Anon!: Marry, once before he won it of me with false dice.
Goodbye!: He won it from me once before, with false dice.

Anon!: I’ll carry it to the pile.
Goodbye!: I’ll carry it to the pile.

Anon!: Say what, is Horatio there?
Goodbye!: Is Horatio there?

Anon!: He lies tonight within seven leagues of Rome.
Goodbye!: He’s lying tonight within seven lands of Rome.

Anon!: Are you full of them?
Goodbye!: Are you full of them?

Anon!: Then have at thee, boy!
Goodbye!: Then have at you, boy!

Anon!: I dreamt last night of the three weird sisters: To you they have showed some truth.
Goodbye!: I dreamed last night of the three weird sisters: they’ve shown some truth to you.

Anon!: Give me thy hand, And let me see thee in thy woman’s weeds.
Goodbye!: Give me your hand, and let me see you in your woman’s weeds.

Anon!: And she as much in love, her means much less To meet her new beloved anywhere.
Goodbye!: And she’s as much in love as she is, and she’s less likely to meet her new lover anywhere.

Anon!: But all remember What you have said, and show yourselves true Romans.
Goodbye!: But remember what you’ve said and show yourself true Romans.

Anon!: So all.
Goodbye!: That’s all.

Anon!: Here we.
Goodbye!: Here we go.

Anon!: The excuse that thou dost make in this delay Is longer than the tale thou dost excuse.
Goodbye!: The excuse you make for this delay is longer than the story you’re telling.

Anon!: An if he hear thee, thou wilt anger him.
Goodbye!: If he hears you, you’ll anger him.

Anon!: Pluck up, my heart, and be sad.
Goodbye!: Pluck up, my heart, and be sad.

Anon!: Tomorrow night look that thou lie alone.
Goodbye!: Tomorrow night, look for yourself to lie alone.

Anon!: Your will?
Goodbye!: Your will?

Anon!: So do you too, where you perceive them thick.
Goodbye!: You do, too, where you see them thick.

Anon!: Let it be so.
Goodbye!: Let it be.

Anon!: Because my name is George.
Goodbye!: Because my name is George.

Anon!: Who shall stay you?
Goodbye!: Who will stay you?

Anon!: And to see how he prizes the foolish woman your wife!
Goodbye!: And to see how he treats the foolish woman your wife!

Anon!: A flatterer’s would not, though they do appear As huge as high Olympus.
Goodbye!: A flatterer’s would not, even though they appear as huge as high Olympus.

Anon!: Is your name Shylock?
Goodbye!: Is your name Shylock?

Anon!: The greater cantle of the world is lost With very ignorance.
Goodbye!: The greater cantle of the world is lost with very little ignorance.

Anon!: Alive in triumph—and Mercutio slain!
Goodbye!: You’re alive in triumph—and Mercutio’s dead!

Anon!: Nay, if our wits run the wild-goose chase, I am done, for thou hast more of the wild-goose in one of thy wits than, I am sure, I have in my whole five.
Goodbye!: No, if we’re chasing wildgoose, I’m done, because you have more wildgoose in one of your wits than I have in five of my whole five.

Anon!: O holy Friar, O, tell me, holy Friar, Where is my lady’s lord?
Goodbye!: Oh, holy Friar, Oh, tell me, holy Friar, where is my lady’s lord?

Anon!: Where got’st thou that goose look?
Goodbye!: Where did you look like a goose?

Anon!: Good gentlemen, give him a further edge, And drive his purpose on to these delights.
Goodbye!: Good gentlemen, give him a further edge and drive his purpose to these delights.

Anon!: Fast bind, fast find.
Goodbye!: Fasten up, fast find.

Anon!: I never sued to friend, nor enemy; My tongue could never learn sweet smoothing word.
Goodbye!: I never sued a friend or an enemy, but I could never learn a sweet, sweet word.

Anon!: Ay, madam, but returns again tonight.
Goodbye!: Yes, madam, but he’ll return again tonight.

Anon!: When and where and how We met, we wooed and made exchange of vow, I’ll tell thee as we pass, but this I pray: That thou consent to marry us today.
Goodbye!: When and where and how we met, we wooed and made exchange of vows, I’ll tell you as soon as we pass, but please: you agree to marry us today.

Anon!: Hear you the news abroad?
Goodbye!: Do you hear the news from abroad?

Anon!: As with the meat, some undeservèd fault I’ll find about the making of the bed, And here I’ll fling the pillow, there the bolster, This way the coverlet, another way the sheets.
Goodbye!: I’ll fling the pillow, the bolster, the coverlet, the sheets.

Anon!: Dar’st thou resolve to kill a friend of mine?
Goodbye!: Do you want to kill a friend of mine?

Anon!: His reason well I know.
Goodbye!: I know his reason.

Anon!: Friar!
Goodbye!: Friar!

Anon!: The will, the will!
Goodbye!: The will, the will!

Anon!: I had rather to adopt a child than get it.— Come hither, Moor.
Goodbye!: I’d rather adopt a child than get it.—Come here, Moor.

Anon!: Do you think I’ll be forsworn?
Goodbye!: Do you think I’ll be sworn?

Anon!: Good madam, stay a while.
Goodbye!: Good madam, stay a while.

Anon!: Ay, madam.
Goodbye!: Yes, madam.

Anon!: How say you, lady?
Goodbye!: What do you say, lady?

Anon!: Go on before.
Goodbye!: Go on ahead.

Anon!: When did I see thee so put down?
Goodbye!: When did I see you put down so badly?

Anon!: Tis proper I obey him, but not now.
Goodbye!: It’s appropriate I obey him, but not now.

Anon!: Proud,” and “I thank you,” and “I thank you not,” And yet “not proud”?
Goodbye!: “Good,” and “I thank you,” and “I don’t thank you,” and yet “not proud”?

Anon!: So should the murdered look, and so should I, Pierced through the heart with your stern cruelty.
Goodbye!: I should look like the murdered, and I should look like you, and I’m smothered by your cruelness.

Anon!: My life will be too short, And every measure fail me.
Goodbye!: My life will be too short, and I’ll fail every single thing.

Anon!: Nay, an thou canst not smile as the wind sits, thou'lt catch cold shortly.
Goodbye!: No, if you can’t smile as the wind sits, you’ll catch cold in the near future.

Anon!: Though we have spent our harvest of this king, We are to reap the harvest of his son.
Goodbye!: Though we’ve spent our harvest on this king, we’re going to harvest the harvest of his son.

Anon!: Let but the commons hear this testament— Which, pardon me, I do not mean to read— And they would go and kiss dead Caesar’s wounds And dip their napkins in his sacred blood, Yea, beg a hair of him for memory, And, dying, mention it within their wills, Bequeathing it as a rich legacy Unto their issue.
Goodbye!: But the commons should hear this testament—which, pardon me, I don’t want to read—and they’d go and kiss dead Caesar’s wounds and dip their napkins in his sacred blood, Yea,

Anon!: Oh, thereby hangs a tail.
Goodbye!: Oh, so it hangs a tail.

Anon!: Let me be ta'en.
Goodbye!: Let me be taint.

Anon!: For shame, you generals!
Goodbye!: You generals!

Anon!: Not to be abed after midnight is to be up betimes, and  Nay, my troth, I know not.
Goodbye!: I don’t know.

Anon!: Master, I am here entered in bond for you.
Goodbye!: Master, I’m here to pay you a bond.

Anon!: Tis pity of him.
Goodbye!: It’s pity for him.

Anon!: Fetch that gallant hither.
Goodbye!: Get that gallant here.

Anon!: We must be married, or we must live in bawdry.—Farewell, good Master Oliver, not               'Tis no matter.
Goodbye!: We must be married, or we must live in a sane.—Goodbye, good Master Oliver, it doesn’t matter.

Anon!: If he distaste it, let him to our sister, Whose mind and mine I know in that are one, Not to be overruled.
Goodbye!: If he distastes it, let him go to our sister, who I know is one, and not to be overruled.

Anon!: And how doth she?
Goodbye!: And how is she?

Anon!: And yet it is danger To make him even o'er the time he has lost.
Goodbye!: And yet it’s dangerous to make him even more prone to losing his time.

Anon!: I will not have to do with you.
Goodbye!: I won’t have to deal with you.

Anon!: Her blush is guiltiness, not modesty.
Goodbye!: Her blush is guilt, not modesty.

Anon!: Why, may one ask?
Goodbye!: Why, can I ask?

Anon!: I am only sorry  He had no other death’s-man.
Goodbye!: I’m only sorry he didn’t have any other man to kill himself.

Anon!: But who dare tell her so?
Goodbye!: But who’s going to tell her that?

Anon!: Give him direction for this merry bond, And I will go and purse the ducats straight, See to my house left in the fearful guard Of an unthrifty knave, and presently I will be with you.
Goodbye!: Give him directions for this merry bond, and I’ll go and get the ducats back to my house, leaving in the fearful guard of an unthrifty knave, and I’ll be with

Anon!: We two, my lord, Will guard your person while you take your rest And watch your safety.
Goodbye!: We two will guard your person while you rest and watch your safety.

Anon!: It is the most impenetrable cur That ever kept with men.
Goodbye!: It’s the most impenetrable curfew ever kept by men.

Anon!: Is this the king we sent to for his ransom?
Goodbye!: Is this the king we sent to for his ransom?

Anon!: Romeo, come forth.
Goodbye!: Romeo, come out.

Anon!: Caesar, ’tis strucken eight.
Goodbye!: Caesar, it’s struck eight.

Anon!: Who is ’t that calls?
Goodbye!: Who’s calling me?

Anon!: Is ’t possible you will away tonight?
Goodbye!: Is it possible you’ll leave tonight?

Anon!: Thou art sure of me.
Goodbye!: You’re sure of me.

Anon!: Now ’mongst this flock of drunkards Am I to put our Cassio in some action That may offend the isle.
Goodbye!: Now I’m going to put Cassio in some action that could offend the island.

Anon!: You were to blame, I must be plain with you, To part so slightly with your wife’s first gift, A thing stuck on with oaths upon your finger And so riveted with faith unto your flesh.
Goodbye!: You were to blame, I must be clear with you, to part so slightly with your wife’s first gift, a thing that was stuck on your finger with oaths and so riveted with faith to your flesh

Anon!: No, not till Thursday.
Goodbye!: No, not until Thursday.

Anon!: My lord, my lord, I’ll prove it on his body if he dare, Despite his nice fence and his active practice, His May of youth and bloom of lustihood.
Goodbye!: My lord, my lord, I’ll prove it on his body if he dares, despite his nice fence and his active practice, his youth’s May and his lustihood.

Anon!: Here’s too much “out upon thee!” I pray thee, let me in.
Goodbye!: Here’s too much “out on you!” Please, let me in.

Anon!: Of what kind should this cock come of?
Goodbye!: What kind of cock should this cock come from?

Anon!: Hark, how these instruments summon to supper.
Goodbye!: Listen, how these instruments summon to supper.

Anon!: Who dead?
Goodbye!: Who’s dead?

Anon!: There may as well be amity and life 'Tween snow and fire, as treason and my love.
Goodbye!: There may be as much amity and life as treason and my love.

Anon!: Whither indeed, before thy here-approach, Old Siward, with ten thousand warlike men, Already at a point, was setting forth.
Goodbye!: Then, before you arrived here, Old Siward, with ten thousand war-like men, was already at a point.

Anon!: Ish a villain and a basterd and a knave and a rascal.
Goodbye!: I’m a villain and a basterd and a knave and a rascal.

Anon!: I am ashamed that women are so simple To offer war where they should kneel for peace; Or seek for rule, supremacy and sway When they are bound to serve, love, and obey.
Goodbye!: I’m ashamed that women are so simple to offer war where they should kneel for peace; or seek for rule, supremacy, and sway when they are bound to serve, love, and obey.

Anon!: Madam!
Goodbye!: Madam!

Anon!: O Clitus!
Goodbye!: Oh Clitus!

Anon!: Ninus' tomb,” man.
Goodbye!: Ninus’s tomb,” man.

Anon!: Withdraw, my lord.
Goodbye!: Withdraw, my lord.

Anon!: This is she—    Peace, peace, Mercutio, peace!
Goodbye!: This is her— Peace, peace, Mercutio, peace!

Anon!: Our purposes God justly hath discovered, And I repent my fault more than my death, Which I beseech Your Highness to forgive, Although my body pay the price of it.
Goodbye!: God has discovered our purpose, and I’m more sorry for my fault than for my death, which I ask your Highness to forgive, even though my body pays the price of it.

Anon!: This hand of yours requires A sequester from liberty, fasting, and prayer,
Goodbye!: This hand is yours.

Anon!: Call Burgundy.—    Cornwall and Albany, With my two daughters' dowers digest this third.
Goodbye!: Call Burgundy.— Cornwall and Albany, with my two daughters’ dowers, digest this third.

Anon!: Well, I will hie, And so bestow these papers as you bade me.
Goodbye!: Well, I’ll go, and I’ll give them to you as you bade me.

Anon!: You’ve strange serpents there?
Goodbye!: You’ve got strange serpents there?

Anon!: Not a dump, we.
Goodbye!: Not a dump, we’re not.

Anon!: Come, go we to the king.
Goodbye!: Come on, we’ll go to the king.

Anon!: What, household stuff?
Goodbye!: What, household stuff?

Anon!: Thrice hath Calphurnia in her sleep cried out, “Help, ho!
Goodbye!: Three times Calphurnia has cried out, “Help!

Anon!: She mocks all her wooers out of suit.
Goodbye!: She mocks all her wooers out of court.

Anon!: I will carry no crotchets.
Goodbye!: I won’t carry any crotches.

Anon!: I humbly thank you.
Goodbye!: Thank you very much.

Anon!: I never saw my father in my life.
Goodbye!: I never saw my father in my life.

Anon!: We are for you.
Goodbye!: We’re for you.

Anon!: If not, he’s plain.
Goodbye!: If not, he’s plain.

Anon!: Down with the topmast!
Goodbye!: Down with the topmast!

Anon!: If he come tomorrow, I’ll give him his payment.
Goodbye!: If he’s coming tomorrow, I’ll pay him.

Anon!: Swell, bosom, with thy fraught, For ’tis of aspics' tongues!
Goodbye!: Swell, bosom, with your fraughtness, because it’s like aspics’ tongues!

Anon!: Why is this “impawned,” as you call it?
Goodbye!: Why is this “impawned”?

Anon!: Bid them achieve me and then sell my bones.
Goodbye!: Tell them to get me and then sell my bones.

Anon!: Tis my picture.
Goodbye!: That’s my picture.

Anon!: So will you say when you have seen the sequel.
Goodbye!: You’ll tell me when you’ve seen the sequel.

Anon!: This jest shall cost me some expense.
Goodbye!: This slut will cost me some money.

Anon!: I fear my Thisbe’s promise is forgot!— And thou, O Wall, O sweet, O lovely Wall, That stand’st between her father’s ground and mine.
Goodbye!: I’m afraid my Thisbe’s promise is forgotten!—And you, Wall, sweet, lovely Wall, that stand between her father’s ground and mine.

Anon!: Sblood, do you think I am easier to be played on than a pipe?
Goodbye!: Sblood, do you think I’m easier to play than a pipe?

Anon!: A lioness hath whelpèd in the streets, And graves have yawned and yielded up their dead.
Goodbye!: A lioness has whelped in the streets, and graves have yawned and yielded their dead.

Anon!: Go hence with diligence.
Goodbye!: Go on to the airport with a vigor.

Anon!: Indeed, I should have asked thee that before.
Goodbye!: I wish I had asked you before.

Anon!: It is as easy as lying.
Goodbye!: It’s as easy as lying.

Anon!: If he come not, then the play is marred.
Goodbye!: If he doesn’t come, then the play is ruined.

Anon!: Thou hast.
Goodbye!: You have.

Anon!: If you would conjure in her, you must make a circle; if conjure up Love in her in his true likeness, he must appear naked and blind.
Goodbye!: If you want to conjure her, you have to make a circle.

Anon!: I durst, my lord, to wager she is honest, Lay down my soul at stake.
Goodbye!: I’d like to wager that she’s honest, and put my soul on the stake.

Anon!: Unkindness may do much, And his unkindness may defeat my life, But never taint my love.
Goodbye!: Unkindness can do much, and his unkindness can defeat my life, but never taint my love.

Anon!: Farewell, good Signior Love.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, good Signior Love.

Anon!: There is no way but this, Sir Andrew.
Goodbye!: There’s no way to do this, Sir Andrew.

Anon!: Well, in that hit you miss.
Goodbye!: Well, you’re missing out on that hit.

Anon!: Harry le Roy.
Goodbye!: Harry le Roy.

Anon!: I will not change my horse with any that treads but on four pasterns.
Goodbye!: I won’t change my horse with any horse that treads only on four pasterns.

Anon!: Such and so finely bolted didst thou seem.
Goodbye!: You were so finely smashed that you were.

Anon!: Look, here I have you.
Goodbye!: Look, here I have you.

Anon!: But he loves Caesar best; yet he loves Antony.
Goodbye!: But he loves Caesar best, but he loves Antony.

Anon!: Peace.
Goodbye!: Quiet.

Anon!: I make all use of it, for I use it only.
Goodbye!: I’m all about to use it, because I only use it.

Anon!: Your graces are right welcome.
Goodbye!: Your graces are right welcome.

Anon!: I will give you the minstrel.
Goodbye!: I’ll give you the minstrel.

Anon!: Courage, man.
Goodbye!: Be calm, man.

Anon!: Where is my love?
Goodbye!: Where is my love?

Anon!: Remain thou still in darkness.
Goodbye!: Stay in the darkness.

Anon!: For women are as roses, whose fair flower Being once displayed, doth fall that very hour.
Goodbye!: Women are like roses, whose beautiful flower was once displayed, fall that hour.

Anon!: If ever thou come to me and say, after tomorrow, “This is my glove,” by this hand I will take thee a box on the ear.
Goodbye!: If you come to me and say, after tomorrow, “This is my glove,” I’ll take you a box on the ear.

Anon!: What enterprise, Popillius?
Goodbye!: What is the business, Popillius?

Anon!: The Queen, my lord, the Queen.
Goodbye!: The Queen, my lord, the Queen.

Anon!: Fly, masters!
Goodbye!: Fly, masters!

Anon!: I cannot be so partial, Goneril, To the great love I bear you—      Pray you, content.
Goodbye!: Goneril, I can’t be so partial to the great love I bear you— Please, calm down.

Anon!: You have stayed me in a happy hour.
Goodbye!: You’ve stayed with me for a happy hour.
