Anon!: At land, thou know’st How much we do o’ercount thee.
Goodbye!: At land, you know how much we’re doing to you.

Anon!: Thou hast railed on thyself.
Goodbye!: You’ve railed on yourself.

Anon!: But, my good lord— Wherefore should you do this?
Goodbye!: But, my good lord— Why should you do this?

Anon!: This thou shalt answer.
Goodbye!: You’ll answer this question.

Anon!: Katherine his daughter and with her, to dowry, Some petty and unprofitable dukedoms.
Goodbye!: Katherine’s daughter and with her, to dowry, some petty and unprofitable dukedoms.

Anon!: No more with me.
Goodbye!: Don’t wait with me.

Anon!: My master’s a very Jew.
Goodbye!: My master’s a very Jew.

Anon!: The desperate tempest hath so banged the Turks, That their designment halts.
Goodbye!: The desperate weather has banged the Turks so much that their plans are halting.

Anon!: Go apart, Adam, and thou shalt hear how he will shake me up.
Goodbye!: Go apart, Adam, and you’ll hear how he’ll shake me up.

Anon!: Art thou mad?
Goodbye!: Are you crazy?

Anon!: I can live no longer by thinking.
Goodbye!: I can’t live by thinking anymore.

Anon!: I will do ’t, my lord.
Goodbye!: I’ll do it, my lord.

Anon!: If it will not be, I’ll leave you.
Goodbye!: If it doesn’t, I’ll leave you.

Anon!: He was the wretched’st thing when he was young, So long a-growing and so leisurely, That if this rule were true, he should be gracious.
Goodbye!: He was the wretched man when he was young, so long as he was growing and so leisurely, that if this rule were true, he would be gracious.

Anon!: Why, the enemy is loud.
Goodbye!: The enemy is loud.

Anon!: And therefore, since I cannot prove a lover To entertain these fair well-spoken days, I am determinèd to prove a villain And hate the idle pleasures of these days.
Goodbye!: So since I can’t prove a lover to entertain these fair-spoken days, I’m determined to prove a villain and hate the idle pleasures of these days.

Anon!: I would I were at home.
Goodbye!: I wish I were at home.

Anon!: It was mine art, When I arrived and heard thee, that made gape The pine and let thee out.
Goodbye!: When I arrived and heard you, I saw you making a gap between the pines and let you out.

Anon!: Alack, sir, he is mad.
Goodbye!: He’s insane, sir.

Anon!: Why, all our ranks are broke.
Goodbye!: Why, all our ranks are broken.

Anon!: Hot, hot, and moist.
Goodbye!: Hot, hot, and moist.

Anon!: She that doth call me husband, even my soul Doth for a wife abhor.
Goodbye!: I’m not a wife, but I’m a wife.

Anon!: I will follow you.
Goodbye!: I’ll follow you.

Anon!: Believe me, sir, they butt together well.
Goodbye!: Believe me, sir, they smother well together.

Anon!: Where’s Potpan, that he helps not to take away?
Goodbye!: Where’s Potpan, that he doesn’t help take away?

Anon!: To threaten me with death is most unlawful.
Goodbye!: To threaten me with death is most unlawful.

Anon!: Marry, sir, in her buttocks.
Goodbye!: She’s in her buttocks, sir.

Anon!: Go to, carry this.
Goodbye!: Go on, carry this.

Anon!: Why, so didst thou.
Goodbye!: Why, so did you.

Anon!: Now am I dead.
Goodbye!: Now I’m dead.

Anon!: And I have reason for it.
Goodbye!: And I have reason for it.

Anon!: Your reason?
Goodbye!: Why?

Anon!: Hence!
Goodbye!: Let’s go!

Anon!: My other self, my council’s consistory, My oracle, my prophet, my dear cousin, I, as a child, will go by thy direction Toward Ludlow then, for we’ll not stay behind.
Goodbye!: My other self, my council’s consistory, my oracle, my prophet, my dear cousin, I’ll go, as a child, to Ludlow, then, because we won’t stay behind.

Anon!: It seldom visits sorrow.
Goodbye!: It’s rarely a victim of sorrow.

Anon!: Art thou the slave that with thy breath hast killed Mine innocent child?
Goodbye!: Are you the slave who, with your breath, killed my innocent child?

Anon!: The sight of lovers feedeth those in love.
Goodbye!: The sight of lovers feeds those in love.

Anon!: Give me your hand.
Goodbye!: Give me your hand.

Anon!: A most poor credulous monster.—Well drawn, monster, in good sooth!
Goodbye!: A poor, credulous monster.—Well drawn, monster, in good sooth!

Anon!: I will, my lord.
Goodbye!: I will, my lord.

Anon!: Who knows not that the gentle duke is dead?
Goodbye!: Who doesn’t know that the gentle duke is dead?

Anon!: As you are old and reverend, should be wise.
Goodbye!: As old as you are reverend, you should be wise.

Anon!: Why, Fool?
Goodbye!: Why, Fool?

Anon!: My powers are crescent, and my auguring hope Says it will come to th’ full.
Goodbye!: My powers are growing, and my savage hope is that it will come to full power.

Anon!: O woeful sympathy, Piteous predicament!
Goodbye!: Oh, sorry, terrible sympathy!

Anon!: Do you not see that I am out of breath?
Goodbye!: Don’t you see that I’m out of breath?

Anon!: Tis heavy night, These may be counterfeits.
Goodbye!: It’s a heavy night, but these may be fakes.

Anon!: I cannot tell.
Goodbye!: I don’t know.

Anon!: Give me leave, Caesar.
Goodbye!: Give me permission, Caesar.

Anon!: And so in me, and so, I think, in all.
Goodbye!: And so in me, and so, I think, in all.

Anon!: Why, then, I care not for thee.
Goodbye!: Well then, I don’t care about you.

Anon!: More knocking.
Goodbye!: More knocking.

Anon!: Ay, and said nothing but what I protest intendment of doing.
Goodbye!: Yes, and I’ve only said what I’m planning to do.

Anon!: Bring the villain forth.
Goodbye!: Bring the villain out.

Anon!: Take up the body.
Goodbye!: Take up the body.

Anon!: So is my horse, Octavius, and for that I do appoint him store of provender.
Goodbye!: I’m a horse, Octavius, and for that I’m a good guy.

Anon!: Courage, man.
Goodbye!: Be calm, man.

Anon!: Nay, I shall ne'er be ware of mine own wit till I break my shins against it.
Goodbye!: No, I won’t be able to be careful of my own wit until I break my shins against it.

Anon!: Nay, then.
Goodbye!: No, then.

Anon!: Pray you, tell him I am his fortune’s vassal, and I send him The greatness he has got.
Goodbye!: Please tell him I’m a vassal of his fortune, and I’ll send him the greatness he has.

Anon!: How fares our cousin Hamlet?
Goodbye!: How is our cousin Hamlet doing?

Anon!: How can these things in me seem scorn to you, Bearing the badge of faith to prove them true?
Goodbye!: How can I seem to be a slander to you, if I have the proof that they’re true?

Anon!: Thou wilt write to Antony?
Goodbye!: You’re going to write to Antony?

Anon!: Tell me not, Friar, that thou hear’st of this, Unless thou tell me how I may prevent it.
Goodbye!: Don’t tell me that you hear about this, Friar, unless you tell me how I can prevent it.

Anon!: World, world, O world!
Goodbye!: Oh, oh, oh!

Anon!: I wonder if the lion be to speak.
Goodbye!: I wonder if the lion will speak.

Anon!: Let me lick thy shoe.
Goodbye!: Let me lick your shoe.

Anon!: Nor I.
Goodbye!: I’m not.

Anon!: You men of Cyprus, let her have your knees.
Goodbye!: You, men of Cyprus, let her have your knees.

Anon!: What’s he that speaks for Edmund, Earl of Gloucester?
Goodbye!: Who’s talking for Edmund, Earl of Gloucester?

Anon!: His company must do his minions grace, Whilst I at home starve for a merry look.
Goodbye!: His company must do his best to his servants while I’m starving at home for a happy look.

Anon!: Touching our person, seek we no revenge, But we our kingdom’s safety must so tender, Whose ruin you have sought, that to her laws We do deliver you.
Goodbye!: We must be so sane, whose ruin you’ve sought, that we can deliver you to her law.

Anon!: Now he begins the story.
Goodbye!: Now he’s starting the story.

Anon!: What, shall I find you here?
Goodbye!: What, will I find you here?

Anon!: And when that time comes, Afflict me with thy mocks, pity me not, As till that time I shall not pity thee.
Goodbye!: And when that time comes, make me mock, don’t pity me, as I won’t pity you until that time.

Anon!: There is some strange misprision in the princes.
Goodbye!: The princes are snoring.

Anon!: I hear it by the way; but I will send.
Goodbye!: I hear it by the way, but I’ll send it.

Anon!: Brown, madam, and her forehead As low as she would wish it.
Goodbye!: Brown, madam, and her forehead are as low as she would wish.

Anon!: Ay, my good lord.
Goodbye!: Yes, my good lord.

Anon!: No, not a grize.
Goodbye!: No, not a grize.

Anon!: I’ll bring my wood home faster.
Goodbye!: I’ll bring my wood home faster.

Anon!: Smilest thou?
Goodbye!: You’re smiling?

Anon!: What is she?
Goodbye!: What is she?

Anon!: Belike they had some notice of the people How I had moved them.
Goodbye!: They were a little surprised to see how I moved them.

Anon!: Besides, he brings his destiny with him.
Goodbye!: Besides, he brings his destiny with him.

Anon!: Sometime a horse I’ll be, sometime a hound, A hog, a headless bear, sometime a fire.
Goodbye!: Sometime I’ll be a horse, sometime a hound, some hog, some headless bear, sometime a fire.

Anon!: But let them measure us by what they will.
Goodbye!: But let them measure us by what they want.

Anon!: Hero that is dead!
Goodbye!: Hero who’s dead!

Anon!: God grant we never may have need of you.
Goodbye!: God grant we may never have any need for you.

Anon!: Flies may do this, but I from this must fly.
Goodbye!: Flies can do this, but I have to fly from here.

Anon!: Nor no man else.
Goodbye!: And no one else.

Anon!: Would?
Goodbye!: Would you?

Anon!: Tis more, ’tis more.
Goodbye!: It’s more, it’s more.

Anon!: Tell me at whose suit.
Goodbye!: Tell me who is the one who is in court.

Anon!: Why, now, as fast as she can marry us.
Goodbye!: Now, she can marry us as fast as she can.

Anon!: Return with her?
Goodbye!: Come with her?

Anon!: What early tongue so sweet saluteth me?
Goodbye!: What early tongue is that sweet salute for me?

Anon!: I’ll send to one in Mantua, Where that same banished runagate doth live, Shall give him such an unaccustomed dram That he shall soon keep Tybalt company.
Goodbye!: I’ll send a man to Mantua, where the banished runagate is alive, and he’ll have a dram that he’ll keep Tybalt in the works soon.

Anon!: What was he that you followed with your sword?
Goodbye!: What was the man you followed with your sword?

Anon!: Egypt, thou knew’st too well My heart was to thy rudder tied by th’ strings, And thou shouldst tow me after.
Goodbye!: Egypt, you knew too well that my heart was tied to your rudder, and you should swoop me after you.

Anon!: O, forgive me my sins!
Goodbye!: Oh, forgive me my sins!

Anon!: The king?
Goodbye!: The king?

Anon!: Ah, do not tear away thyself from me!
Goodbye!: Ah, don’t tear yourself away from me!

Anon!: I am called Dercetus.
Goodbye!: I’m called Dercetus.

Anon!: Didst thou hear these verses?
Goodbye!: Did you hear these verses?

Anon!: Here he comes, and the Scots captain, Captain Jamy, with him.
Goodbye!: Here he comes, and the Scots captain, Captain Jamy, with him.

Anon!: The king himself is rode to view their battle.
Goodbye!: The king himself rode to see their battle.

Anon!: Big Mars seems bankrupt in their beggared host And faintly through a rusty beaver peeps.
Goodbye!: Big Mars seems bankrupt in their beggared host and faintly through rusty beaver peeps.

Anon!: And fair she is, if that mine eyes be true.
Goodbye!: And she is, if my eyes are true.

Anon!: They say Edgar, his banished son, is with the Earl of Kent in Germany.
Goodbye!: They say Edgar, his banished son, is with the Earl of Kent in Germany.

Anon!: Octavius, then take him to follow thee, That did the latest service to my master.
Goodbye!: Octavius, take him to follow you, who did the latest service to my master.

Anon!: Truly, young gentlemen, though there was no great matter in the ditty, yet the note was very untunable.
Goodbye!: Yes, young gentlemen, even though there was no big thing in the ditty, the note was very untold.

Anon!: Away with the joint-stools, remove the court-cupboard, look to the plate.
Goodbye!: Take the stools away, remove the stools on the courtboard, and look at the plate.

Anon!: O excellent young man!
Goodbye!: Oh, a great young man!

Anon!: Every hour He flashes into one gross crime or other That sets us all at odds.
Goodbye!: Every hour he’s committing one crime or another that puts us all at odds.

Anon!: In which regard,
Goodbye!: In that regard,

Anon!: Good my lord, bid him welcome.
Goodbye!: My lord, welcome him.

Anon!: I am glad he’s come, howsoe'er he comes.
Goodbye!: I’m glad he’s come, howsoe's he come?

Anon!: I told him you were sick.
Goodbye!: I told him you were sick.

Anon!: Although I joy in thee, I have no joy of this contract tonight.
Goodbye!: Even though I’m happy with you, I’m not happy with this contract tonight.

Anon!: Go bear it to the Centaur, where we host, And stay there, Dromio, till I come to thee.
Goodbye!: Go take it to the Centaur, where we’re staying, and stay there, Dromio, until I come to you.

Anon!: Where art thou, Death?
Goodbye!: Where are you, Death?

Anon!: Said you so?
Goodbye!: Did you say that?

Anon!: I have it, Tranio!
Goodbye!: I have it, Tranio!

Anon!: Sirrah, come hither: ’tis no time to jest, And therefore frame your manners to the time.
Goodbye!: Sirrah, come here: it’s no time to go out and then you’ll be able to go back to the moment.

Anon!: I never heard So musical a discord, such sweet thunder.
Goodbye!: I never heard such a musical discord, such sweet thunder.

Anon!: Hereafter, in a better world than this, I shall desire more love and knowledge of you.
Goodbye!: In a better world than this, I’ll want to know more about you.

Anon!: Unto bad causes swear Such creatures as men doubt.
Goodbye!: To bad causes swear as many men as you can.

Anon!: These fifteen years!
Goodbye!: These fifteen years!

Anon!: Now let me see if I can conster it.
Goodbye!: Now let me see if I can consecrate it.

Anon!: Set your heart at rest.
Goodbye!: Rest your heart.

Anon!: I should venture purgatory for ’t.
Goodbye!: I’d rather go purgatory for it.

Anon!: What, and stake down?
Goodbye!: What, and do you stake down?

Anon!: Good.
Goodbye!: Good.

Anon!: How now, who calls?
Goodbye!: Who’s calling me?

Anon!: But were I Brutus, And Brutus Antony, there were an Antony Would ruffle up your spirits and put a tongue In every wound of Caesar that should move The stones of Rome to rise and mutiny.
Goodbye!: But if I were Brutus, and Brutus Antony, there would be an Antony who would ruffle up your spirits and put a tongue in every wound of Caesar that would move the stones of

Anon!: Think’st thou, Hortensio, though her father be very rich, any man is so very a fool to be married to hell?
Goodbye!: You, Hortensio, are you thinking that even though her father is very rich, any man is so a fool to be married to hell?

Anon!: How does the queen?
Goodbye!: How is the queen?

Anon!: I do love nothing in the world so well as you.
Goodbye!: I don’t love anything in the world as much as you.

Anon!: I will incontinently drown myself.
Goodbye!: I’ll drown myself incontinently.

Anon!: Methoughts I saw a thousand fearful wracks, A thousand men that fishes gnawed upon, Wedges of gold, great anchors, heaps of pearl, Inestimable stones, unvalued jewels, All scattered in the bottom of the sea.
Goodbye!: I saw a thousand fearful wracks, a thousand men who gnawed on fish, a heap of gold, great anchors, heaps of pearls, inestimable stones, unvalued

Anon!: It is too rough, Too rude, too boisterous, and it pricks like thorn.
Goodbye!: It’s too rough, too rude, too boisterous, and it’s pricking like a thorn.

Anon!: Disdain and scorn ride sparkling in her eyes, Misprizing what they look on, and her wit Values itself so highly that to her All matter else seems weak.
Goodbye!: She’s so angry and angry that everything else seems weak to her.

Anon!: Signior Brabantio, ho!
Goodbye!: Signior Brabantio, ho!

Anon!: O cursed, cursed slave!
Goodbye!: Oh, cursed, cursed slave!

Anon!: Talkest thou nothing but of ladies?
Goodbye!: Are you talking about ladies?

Anon!: Mark it, nuncle.
Goodbye!: Mark it, uncle.

Anon!: I think he be transformed into a beast, For I can nowhere find him like a man.
Goodbye!: I think he’s transformed into a beast, because I can’t find him like a man.

Anon!: She’s dead, deceased, she’s dead.
Goodbye!: She’s dead, dead, she’s dead.

Anon!: Whither should they come?
Goodbye!: Where should they come?

Anon!: How, will she none?
Goodbye!: How, will she ever be?

Anon!: Nor hath Love’s mind of any judgment taste— Wings and no eyes figure unheedy haste.
Goodbye!: Love’s mind doesn’t taste any judgment— Wings and no eyes are rushing.

Anon!: I’ll to the friar to know his remedy.
Goodbye!: I’ll go to the friar to find out his remedy.

Anon!: If you be not mad, be gone.
Goodbye!: If you’re not insane, go away.

Anon!: Run after that same peevish messenger, The county’s man.
Goodbye!: Run after that peeveish messenger, the county’s man.

Anon!: Who maintains 'em?
Goodbye!: Who’s holding them?

Anon!: Down with the Montagues!
Goodbye!: Down with the Montagues!

Anon!: Prince Dauphin, you shall stay with us in Rouen.
Goodbye!: Prince Dauphin, you’ll stay with us in Rouen.

Anon!: Hear Antony.
Goodbye!: Listen to Antony.

Anon!: Then so much have I heard.
Goodbye!: Then I’ve heard so much.

Anon!: Nay, you must call me Rosalind.—Come, sister, will you go?
Goodbye!: No, you have to call me Rosalind.—Come, sister, will you go?

Anon!: No, pray thee.
Goodbye!: No, please.

Anon!: Reply not.
Goodbye!: Don’t reply.

Anon!: But to my mind, though I am native here And to the manner born, it is a custom More honored in the breach than the observance.
Goodbye!: But I think that even though I’m native here and have been born, it’s a common practice more honored in the breach than the observance.

Anon!: There’s no time for a man to recover his hair that grows bald by nature.
Goodbye!: There’s no time for a man to recover his hair that grows bald by nature.

Anon!: His grace speaks cheerfully.
Goodbye!: His grace speaks cheerfully.

Anon!: I am not of many words, but I thank you.
Goodbye!: I’m not a lot of words, but I thank you.

Anon!: Your Grace attended to their sugared words But looked not on the poison of their hearts.
Goodbye!: Your Grace listened to their sugary words, but they didn’t look at the poison of their hearts.

Anon!: Then have my lips the sin that they have took.
Goodbye!: Then have my lips sinned about the sin they took.

Anon!: O, belike his majesty hath some intent That you shall be new christened in the Tower.
Goodbye!: Oh, as if his majesty had the intention of naming you in the Tower.

Anon!: Well, we were born to die.
Goodbye!: Well, we were born to die.

Anon!: An Englishman?
Goodbye!: An Englishman?

Anon!: We shall find of him A shrewd contriver.
Goodbye!: We’ll find him a shrewd man.

Anon!: Romeo, come forth.
Goodbye!: Romeo, come out.

Anon!: But if these— As I am sure they do—bear fire enough To kindle cowards and to steel with valor The melting spirits of women, then, countrymen, What need we any spur but our own cause To prick us to redress?
Goodbye!: But if these are enough fire to kindle cowards and to steel with the mighty women, then countrymen, what do we need to do to get us to redress?

Anon!: I know no touch of it, my lord.
Goodbye!: I don’t know anything about it, my lord.

Anon!: Let him cry, “Praise and glory on his head!” For forth he goes and visits all his host, Bids them good morrow with a modest smile, And calls them brothers, friends, and countrymen.
Goodbye!: He’ll cry, “Praise and glory on his head!” He’ll go back and visit all his host, he’ll give them good morning with a modest smile, and call them brothers, friends, and country

Anon!: Go to, go to.—Come hither, sir.
Goodbye!: Go to, go to.—Come here, sir.

Anon!: I am never merry when I hear sweet music.
Goodbye!: I’m never a merry person when I hear sweet music.

Anon!: Will ’t please your Mightiness to wash your hands?
Goodbye!: Will you be a good man to wash your hands?

Anon!: Puppet”?
Goodbye!: Puppet”?

Anon!: Let the old ruffian know I have many other ways to die, meantime Laugh at his challenge.
Goodbye!: Let the old ruffian know I have many other ways to die, and in the meantime, Laugh at his challenge.

Anon!: Where have I been?
Goodbye!: Where have I been?

Anon!: Am I come near ye now?— Welcome, gentlemen!
Goodbye!: Am I coming near you now?— Welcome, gentlemen!

Anon!: Let’s hear it.
Goodbye!: Let’s hear it.

Anon!: Oh, out of that “no hope” What great hope have you!
Goodbye!: Oh, out of that “no hope” you have so much hope!

Anon!: How I have thought of this and of these times I shall recount hereafter.
Goodbye!: I’ll tell you what I think of this and what happened in this time.

Anon!: Ha, banishment!
Goodbye!: Ha, banishment!

Anon!: But in my terms of honor I stand aloof, and will no reconcilement Till by some elder masters, of known honor, I have a voice and precedent of peace To keep my name ungored.
Goodbye!: But I’m not in the position of honor, and I won’t be reconciled until some elder masters, who have known me, have a voice and a precedent of peace to keep my name ungored.

Anon!: Pray, chuck, come hither.
Goodbye!: Please, chuck, come here.

Anon!: But here the lady comes.
Goodbye!: But here comes the lady.

Anon!: I mean, an we be in choler, we’ll draw.
Goodbye!: I mean, if we’re in a choler, we’ll draw.

Anon!: Then, at my farm I have a hundred milch-kine to the pail, Six score fat oxen standing in my stalls, And all things answerable to this portion.
Goodbye!: Then, at my farm, I have a hundred milch-kine to the pail, six fat oxen standing in my stalls, and all the things that are responsible for this portion.

Anon!: His passport shall be made, And crowns for convoy put into his purse.
Goodbye!: His passport will be made, and his purse will be filled with crowns for the convoy.

Anon!: Stand away, Captain Gower.
Goodbye!: Stand away, Captain Gower.

Anon!: He does hear me, And that he does I weep.
Goodbye!: He hears me, and he weeps.

Anon!: Called you, my lord?
Goodbye!: Have you called me, my lord?

Anon!: Call you this “gamut”?
Goodbye!: Are you calling this “gamut”?

Anon!: He is.
Goodbye!: He is.

Anon!: I should first tell thee how the Prince, Claudio and my master, planted and placed and possessed by my master Don John, saw afar off in the orchard this amiable encounter.
Goodbye!: I should first tell you how the Prince, Claudio and my master, planted and placed and possessed by my master Don John, saw this amiable encounter in the orchard.

Anon!: Tis a worthy governor.
Goodbye!: It’s a worthy governor.

Anon!: But now I see our lances are but straws, Our strength as weak, our weakness past compare, That seeming to be most which we indeed least are.
Goodbye!: But now I see our lances are only straws, our strength as weak, our weakness past compare, which seems to be the most which we are.

Anon!: More of this matter cannot I report.
Goodbye!: I can’t report any more of this.

Anon!: Than my Lord Hastings no man might be bolder.
Goodbye!: No man could be bolder than my Lord Hastings.

Anon!: Hail.
Goodbye!: Hail.

Anon!: It is not so expressed, but what of that?
Goodbye!: It’s not so clear, but what about that?

Anon!: Thou art a villain to impeach me thus.
Goodbye!: You’re a villain to impeach me like this.

Anon!: Very well, my lord.
Goodbye!: Very well, my lord.

Anon!: Besides, I like you not.
Goodbye!: Besides, I don’t like you.

Anon!: God save you, sir.
Goodbye!: God save you, sir.

Anon!: I am no child, no babe.
Goodbye!: I’m no child, no baby.

Anon!: Ah, Buckingham, now do I play the touch, To try if thou be current gold indeed.
Goodbye!: Oh, Buckingham, now I’m playing the touch, to try to find out if you’re indeed a goldman.

Anon!: What I should deny— As this I would, ay, though thou didst produce My very character—I’d turn it all To thy suggestion, plot, and damnèd practice.
Goodbye!: I’d say it all to your suggestion, plot, and damned practice.

Anon!: Infirmity, that decays the wise, doth ever make the better fool.
Goodbye!: Infirmity, which decays the wise, makes the better fool.

Anon!: Appear and pertly!— No tongue.
Goodbye!: Listen and listen quietly!—No tongue.

Anon!: Hear me a word, For I shall never speak to thee again.
Goodbye!: Listen to me a word, because I’ll never speak to you again.

Anon!: I’ll tell thee how Beatrice praised thy wit he other day.
Goodbye!: I’ll tell you how Beatrice praised you the other day.

Anon!: A most miraculous work in this good king, Which often since my here-remain in England I have seen him do.
Goodbye!: I’ve seen him do a miracle work in this good king since my stay here in England.

Anon!: But tell me true, are you not mad indeed?
Goodbye!: But tell me, aren’t you really insane?

Anon!: What if this mixture do not work at all?
Goodbye!: What if this mixture doesn’t work at all?

Anon!: Oh, pardon me, Signior Gremio, I would fain be doing.
Goodbye!: Oh, pardon me, Signior Gremio, I’d rather do something.

Anon!: That is my rest; that is the rendezvous of it.
Goodbye!: That’s my rest, and that’s the place to go.

Anon!: O, unpleasing news!
Goodbye!: Oh, what a terrible news!

Anon!: I am the second son of old Sir Rowland, That bring these tidings to this fair assembly.
Goodbye!: I’m Sir Rowland’s second son, who brings these tidals to this fair assembly.

Anon!: Which of them shall I take?
Goodbye!: Which of them will I take?

Anon!: I am no less in blood than thou art, Edmund.
Goodbye!: I’m no less in blood than you are, Edmund.

Anon!: Dismiss me?
Goodbye!: Dismiss me?

Anon!: You shall not stir out of your house today.
Goodbye!: You’re not going to get out of your house today.

Anon!: Den it sall also content me.
Goodbye!: That’s what I’m saying.

Anon!: Oh!
Goodbye!: Oh!

Anon!: And me too, good Lord!
Goodbye!: And me too, Lord!

Anon!: Why dost thou use me thus?
Goodbye!: Why are you using me like that?

Anon!: I am but mad north-north-west.
Goodbye!: I’m only a mad north-north-westerner.

Anon!: Think you so?
Goodbye!: Do you think so?

Anon!: I could not stay behind you.
Goodbye!: I couldn’t stay behind you.

Anon!: He will not say so.
Goodbye!: He won’t say that.

Anon!: How know you he loves her?
Goodbye!: How do you know he loves her?

Anon!: Him and his worth and our great need of him You have right well conceited.
Goodbye!: You’ve already conceived of him and his worth and our great need for him.

Anon!: She was too good for me.
Goodbye!: She was too good for me.

Anon!: Pray you Be ever known to patience.
Goodbye!: Please be patient.

Anon!: False-boding woman, end thy frantic curse, Lest to thy harm thou move our patience.
Goodbye!: If you’re a false-boding woman, stop your frantic curse, so you can’t hurt yourself.

Anon!: Very good!
Goodbye!: Very good!

Anon!: But is all this for your father?
Goodbye!: But is all this for your father?

Anon!: Let me hire him too.—Here’s my coxcomb.
Goodbye!: Let me hire him too.—Here’s my sneezing.

Anon!: You charge me most unjustly.
Goodbye!: You’re wrong to say it.

Anon!: Sit, Jessica.
Goodbye!: Sit down, Jessica.

Anon!: Most detestable Death, by thee beguiled, By cruel, cruel thee quite overthrown!
Goodbye!: You’re ruined by cruel, cruel Death!

Anon!: I never spake with her in all my life.
Goodbye!: I never spoke with her in my life.

Anon!: I know the hand.
Goodbye!: I know the handwriting.

Anon!: Twere to consider too curiously, to consider so.
Goodbye!: You’d be too curious to think about it.

Anon!: If you will patiently dance in our round And see our moonlight revels, go with us.
Goodbye!: If you’re dancing in our round and watching our moonlights, go with us.

Anon!: Ay, by my troth, the case may be amended.
Goodbye!: Yes, I’m sure the case can be amended.

Anon!: Ay, or very falsely pocket up his report.
Goodbye!: Yes, or he’s stealing his report very falsely.

Anon!: I prithee now, ungird thy strangeness and tell me what I shall vent to my lady.
Goodbye!: Now please, ungird your strangeness and tell me what I’ll send to my lady.

Anon!: O me!
Goodbye!: Oh, my!

Anon!: Monstrous!
Goodbye!: Monstrous!

Anon!: Is supper ready, the house trimmed, rushes strewed, cobwebs swept, the servingmen in their new fustian, their white stockings, and every officer his wedding garment on?
Goodbye!: Is the dinner ready, the house trimmed, the house swept, the servants swept in their new fustian, their white stockings, and every officer has his wedding garment on it?

Anon!: Come, is the bride ready to go to church?
Goodbye!: Come on, is the bride ready to go to church?

Anon!: Why, what is Tybalt?
Goodbye!: Why, what’s Tybalt?

Anon!: Tell him myself, the mayor, and aldermen, No less importing than our general good, In deep designs, and matters of great moment Are come to have some conference with his grace.
Goodbye!: Tell him, the mayor, and the aldermen, that we are not less important than our general good, in deep designs, and matters of great importance, and that we’re coming to have some conference with his grace.

Anon!: I have heard Where many of the best respect in Rome, Except immortal Caesar, speaking of Brutus And groaning underneath this age’s yoke, Have wished that noble Brutus had his eyes.
Goodbye!: I’ve heard where many of the best respects in Rome, except immortal Caesar, talking about Brutus and groaning under this age’s yoke, wish that noble Brutus had his eyes

Anon!: Rosalind of a better leer than you.
Goodbye!: Rosalind is a better leer man than you are.

Anon!: No, uncle, but our crosses on the way Have made it tedious, wearisome, and heavy.
Goodbye!: No, uncle, but our crosses on the way have made it tedious, tired, and heavy.

Anon!: It shall go hard if “Cambio” go without her.
Goodbye!: It’ll be hard if “Cambio” goes without her.

Anon!: To die, to sleep— No more—and by a sleep to say we end The heartache and the thousand natural shocks That flesh is heir to—’tis a consummation Devoutly to be wished!
Goodbye!: To die, to sleep—no more—and to say we’re ending the heartache and the thousand natural shocks that flesh is heir to—is a consummation to wish for!

Anon!: What is thy name, young man?
Goodbye!: What’s your name, young man?

Anon!: I have led you oft; carry me now, good friends, And have my thanks for all.
Goodbye!: I’ve led you often, and I’ll be with you now, my friends, and I’ll thank you for all of you.

Anon!: My child is yet a stranger in the world.
Goodbye!: My child is still a stranger in the world.

Anon!: We would so, and then go a-batfowling.
Goodbye!: We would do that, and then we’d go ashore.

Anon!: I must perforce Have shown to thee such a declining day, Or look on thine.
Goodbye!: I must have shown you such a declining day or look at you.

Anon!: But I do think it is their husbands' faults If wives do fall.
Goodbye!: But I think wives are their faults if wives fall.

Anon!: Shall Caesar send a lie?
Goodbye!: Should Caesar send a lie?

Anon!: Do you hear, you minion?
Goodbye!: Do you hear me, you minion?

Anon!: What noise is here?
Goodbye!: What’s this noise?

Anon!: Why, what’s the matter?
Goodbye!: What’s the matter?

Anon!: I will run, fiend.
Goodbye!: I’ll run, fiend.

Anon!: Hold, for your lives!
Goodbye!: Hold on, for your lives!

Anon!: Why, Fool?
Goodbye!: Why, Fool?

Anon!: Away!
Goodbye!: Go away!

Anon!: That’s a perilous shot out of an elder gun, that a poor and private displeasure can do against a monarch.
Goodbye!: That’s a dangerous shot from an elder gun, that a poor and private displeasure can do against a monarch.

Anon!: Let him alone.
Goodbye!: Leave him alone.

Anon!: I have a pain upon my forehead, here.
Goodbye!: I’m having a pain on my forehead.

Anon!: If I have killed the issue of your womb, To quicken your increase I will beget Mine issue of your blood upon your daughter.
Goodbye!: If I’ve killed the issue of your womb, I’ll beg your daughter to get my issue of your blood.

Anon!: Why, the end is he hath lost a ship.
Goodbye!: The end is he’s lost a ship.

Anon!: There’s a great abatement of kindness appears as well in the general dependants as in the duke himself also, and your daughter.
Goodbye!: There’s a great deal of kindness in the general people as well as in the duke himself and your daughter.

Anon!: You, cousin.
Goodbye!: You, cousin.

Anon!: Catesby.
Goodbye!: Catesby.

Anon!: God’s will, I pray thee wish not one man more.
Goodbye!: God’s will, please don’t wish one more man.

Anon!: Signior, it is the Moor.
Goodbye!: Signior, it’s the Moor.

Anon!: What players are they?
Goodbye!: What are they doing?

Anon!: Lay them in gore, Since you have shore With shears his thread of silk.
Goodbye!: Lay them in a gore, since you have shore with shears his thread of silk.

Anon!: Say not so, Agrippa.
Goodbye!: Don’t say that, Agrippa.

Anon!: Ay, my lord.
Goodbye!: Yes, my lord.

Anon!: What, shall this speech be spoke for our excuse?
Goodbye!: What, should we speak about this speech as a excuse?

Anon!: You shall try but one fall.
Goodbye!: You’ll only try one fall.

Anon!: I will die, And leave him all.
Goodbye!: I’ll die and leave him all.

Anon!: Haply your eye shall light upon some toy You have desire to purchase, and your store, I think, is not for idle markets, sir.
Goodbye!: You’ll see some toy you want to buy, and your store, I think, isn’t for idle markets, sir.

Anon!: Why do you speak so faintly?
Goodbye!: Why are you talking so faintly?

Anon!: O my poor Rosalind, whither wilt thou go?
Goodbye!: Oh, my poor Rosalind, do you want to go?

Anon!: Who, I, my lord?
Goodbye!: Who, my lord?

Anon!: Whence come you?
Goodbye!: When are you coming?

Anon!: Ay, if Messala will prefer me to you.
Goodbye!: Yes, if Messala prefers me to you.

Anon!: He’ll be hanged yet, though every drop of water swear against it and gape at widest to glut him.
Goodbye!: He’ll be hanged yet, even though every drop of water swears against it and gapes at the widest to get him.

Anon!: For doting, not for loving, pupil mine.
Goodbye!: I’m a pupil for doing things, not loving it.

Anon!: Welcome, then, Thou unsubstantial air that I embrace!
Goodbye!: Welcome, then, you unsubstantial air that I embrace!

Anon!: So the sins of my mother should be visited upon me.
Goodbye!: So I should be able to see the sins of my mother.

Anon!: There are no faces truer than those that are so washed.
Goodbye!: There are no faces that are truer than those who are so washed.

Anon!: No, Cassio is not killed.
Goodbye!: No, Cassio is not killed.

Anon!: Even now, now, very now, an old black ram Is tupping your white ewe.
Goodbye!: Now, very now, an old black ram is tupping your white ewe.

Anon!: Being done unknown, I should have found it afterwards well done, But must condemn it now.
Goodbye!: I wish I had done it well, but I must condemn it now.

Anon!: And may, through all the world!
Goodbye!: And you can, through all the world!

Anon!: Were you well served, you would be taught your duty.
Goodbye!: If you were well served, you would be taught your duty.

Anon!: Ay, and a bold one, that dare look on that Which might appall the devil.
Goodbye!: Yes, and a bold one, who dares to look at something that could kill the devil.

Anon!: And all my armor laid into my tent?
Goodbye!: And all my armor was put in my tent?

Anon!: For any good That I myself have done unto myself?
Goodbye!: For any good I’ve done myself to myself?

Anon!: Oh, that we then could come by Caesar’s spirit And not dismember Caesar!
Goodbye!: Oh, we could come here by Caesar’s spirit and not dismember Caesar!

Anon!: Romeo shall thank thee, daughter, for us both.
Goodbye!: Romeo will thank you, daughter, for both of us.

Anon!: Is Antony or we in fault for this?
Goodbye!: Is Antony or we responsible for this?

Anon!: Hark you, Guildenstern, and you too—at each ear a hearer.
Goodbye!: Listen to you, Guildenstern, and you too—at each ear you hear a listener.

Anon!: I will laugh like a hyena, and that when thou art inclined to sleep.
Goodbye!: I’ll laugh like a hyena when you’re awake.

Anon!: She doth stray about By holy crosses, where she kneels and prays For happy wedlock hours.
Goodbye!: She strays around by holy crosses, where she kneels and prays for happy wedlock hours.

Anon!: We wait upon your Grace.
Goodbye!: We’ll wait on your Grace.

Anon!: Ay, if a woman live to be a man.
Goodbye!: Yes, if a woman lives to be a man.

Anon!: It is the wittiest partition that ever I heard discourse, my lord.
Goodbye!: It’s the wittiest partition I’ve ever heard, my lord.

Anon!: Hang up thy mistress!
Goodbye!: Hang up your mistress!

Anon!: Your mistress bears well.
Goodbye!: Your mistress is well.

Anon!: Travelers ne'er did lie, Though fools at home condemn 'em.
Goodbye!: Travelers never lie, even though fools at home condemn them.

Anon!: I found not Cassio’s kisses on her lips.
Goodbye!: I didn’t find Cassio’s kisses on her lips.

Anon!: Abate the edge of traitors, gracious Lord, That would reduce these bloody days again, And make poor England weep in streams of blood!
Goodbye!: Abate the edge of traitors, gracious Lord, who would reduce these bloody days again and make poor England cry in streams of blood!

Anon!: Something from Cyprus as I may divine.
Goodbye!: Something from Cyprus as I can divinely do.

Anon!: Where is my wife?
Goodbye!: Where is my wife?

Anon!: And I have heard Apollodorus carried—   What, I pray you?
Goodbye!: And I’ve heard Apollodorus carry— What, please?

Anon!: This were kindness.
Goodbye!: This was kindness.

Anon!: You mean, to bear me, not to bear with me.— Uncle, my brother mocks both you and me.
Goodbye!: You mean to bear me, not to bear with me.— Uncle, my brother mocks you and me.

Anon!: You may do your will, But he’s a tried and valiant soldier.
Goodbye!: You may do your will, but he’s a tried and valiant soldier.

Anon!: Evermore weeping for your cousin’s death?
Goodbye!: Ever weeping for your cousin’s death?

Anon!: A victory is twice itself when the achiever brings home full numbers.
Goodbye!: A victory is twice as important when the winner brings home full numbers.

Anon!: Woe that too late repents!—   Is it your will?
Goodbye!: Is it your will?

Anon!: O wonderful son that can so ’stonish a mother!
Goodbye!: Oh, a wonderful son who can really amaze a mother!

Anon!: Tell him I would speak with him.
Goodbye!: Tell him I’d like to speak with him.

Anon!: On Fortune’s cap we are not the very button.
Goodbye!: On Fortune’s cap we’re not the button.

Anon!: The king’s son have I landed by himself, Whom I left cooling of the air with sighs In an odd angle of the isle, and sitting, His arms in this sad knot.
Goodbye!: I’ve landed the king’s son by himself, who left the air cooling with sighs in an odd angle of the island, and sitting in his arms in this sad knot.

Anon!: Do not approach Till thou dost hear me call.
Goodbye!: Don’t go to the hotel until you hear me call you.

Anon!: Love give me strength, and strength shall help afford.
Goodbye!: Love will give me strength, and strength will help me.

Anon!: Go to, you are too shrewd.
Goodbye!: Go on, you’re too shrewd.

Anon!: My lord?
Goodbye!: My lord?

Anon!: Will you hear me, Roderigo?
Goodbye!: Will you hear me, Roderigo?

Anon!: So says the Prince and my new-trothèd lord.
Goodbye!: That’s what the Prince and my new lord say.

Anon!: My liege, I am advisèd what I say, Neither disturbed with the effect of wine, Nor heady-rash, provoked with raging ire, Albeit my wrongs might make one wiser mad.
Goodbye!: I’m not a liege, I’m not a good person to say anything, and I’m not disturbed by the effects of wine, or by a heady rash, provoked by raging

Anon!: But there is never a fair woman has a true face.
Goodbye!: But never a woman who’s fair has a true face.

Anon!: Not so, not so.
Goodbye!: Not true, not true.

Anon!: I thought all for the best.
Goodbye!: I thought everything was the best.

Anon!: Alack, for pity!
Goodbye!: Oh, sorry!

Anon!: I partly feel thee.
Goodbye!: I feel a bit more like you.

Anon!: What says Polonius?
Goodbye!: What does Polonius say?

Anon!: To see a reverend Syracusian merchant, Who put unluckily into this bay Against the laws and statutes of this town, Beheaded publicly for his offense.
Goodbye!: To see a reverend Syracusian merchant, who put unluckily in this bay against the laws and laws of this town, beheaded publicly for his offense.

Anon!: Why call you me “love”?
Goodbye!: Why are you calling me “love”?

Anon!: Where is my lady?
Goodbye!: Where is my lady?

Anon!: To answer that, I should confess to you.
Goodbye!: To answer that question, I’d confess to you.

Anon!: I will go before, sir.— Mistress, look out at window, for all this.
Goodbye!: I’ll go before you, sir.—Mistress, look out the window for all this.

Anon!: Poor bird!
Goodbye!: Poor bird!

Anon!: It is worth the pains.
Goodbye!: It’s worth the pains.

Anon!: O, that’s the sword to it.
Goodbye!: Oh, that’s the sword to it.

Anon!: No wonder, sir, But certainly a maid.
Goodbye!: No wonder, sir, but certainly a maid.

Anon!: I will look further into ’t.
Goodbye!: I’ll look into it further.

Anon!: Turn up on your right hand at the next turning, but at the next turning of all on your left.
Goodbye!: Turn right at the next turn, but at the next turn on your left.

Anon!: Soft, sir!
Goodbye!: I’m soft, sir!

Anon!: What art thou that dost grumble there i' th' straw?
Goodbye!: What are you who grumbled there in the straw?

Anon!: So did I too, and he swore he would marry her tonight.
Goodbye!: I did, and he swore he would marry her tonight.

Anon!: Cry but “Ay me!” Pronounce but “love” and “dove.” Speak to my gossip Venus one fair word, One nickname for her purblind son and heir, Young Abraham Cupid, he that shot so true When King Cophetua loved the beggar maid.— He heareth not, he stirreth not, he moveth not.
Goodbye!: Tell me one fair word to my gossip, one nickname for her purblind son and heir, Young Abraham Cupid, who shot so true when King Cophetua loved the beggar maid.—He doesn

Anon!: The Jove of power make me most weak, most weak, Your reconciler!
Goodbye!: The power of the king makes me weak, weak, your reconciler!

Anon!: Well, my good lord, I’ll do ’t.
Goodbye!: Well, my good lord, I’ll do it.

Anon!: What said he?
Goodbye!: What did he say?

Anon!: Please it your grace, on to the state affairs.
Goodbye!: Please, please, go on to the state affairs.

Anon!: Well.
Goodbye!: Well, that’s right.

Anon!: Thisbe?
Goodbye!: Thisbe?

Anon!: But fear not yet To take upon you what is yours.
Goodbye!: But don’t worry about taking care of what’s yours.

Anon!: Tis destiny unshunnable, like death.
Goodbye!: It’s impossible to control your destiny, like death.

Anon!: Marked you not How that the guilty kindred of the queen Looked pale when they did hear of Clarence' death?
Goodbye!: Didn’t you see how the guilty of the queen looked pale when they heard of Clarence’s death?

Anon!: Zounds, I’ll entreat no more.
Goodbye!: I’ll never beg you any more.

Anon!: I will not fail.
Goodbye!: I won’t fail.

Anon!: You taught me first to beg, and now methinks You teach me how a beggar should be answered.
Goodbye!: You taught me to beg first, and now I think you teach me how to beg a beggar.

Anon!: What serious contemplation are you in?
Goodbye!: What serious contemplation are you in?

Anon!: Weapons, arms?
Goodbye!: Weapons, arms?

Anon!: By Cheshu, he will maintain his argument as well as any military man in the world in the disciplines of the pristine wars of the Romans.
Goodbye!: By Cheshu, he will defend his position as well as any military man in the world in the pristine wars of the Romans.

Anon!: She is herself a dowry.
Goodbye!: She’s a dowry.

Anon!: O Tybalt, Tybalt, the best friend I had!
Goodbye!: Oh Tybalt, Tybalt, I had the best friend I had!

Anon!: That ever I should live to see thee dead.
Goodbye!: I wish I could live forever to see you dead.

Anon!: And the rarest that e'er came there.
Goodbye!: And the rarest people who came here.

Anon!: Scratch my head, Peaseblossom.
Goodbye!: Scratch my head, Peaseblossom.

Anon!: I tell thee, Constable, my mistress wears his own hair.
Goodbye!: I tell you, Constable, my mistress wears his own hair.

Anon!: This wedding day Perhaps is but prolonged.
Goodbye!: This wedding day may be delayed.

Anon!: Well, go to.
Goodbye!: Well, go on.

Anon!: Renown and grace is dead.
Goodbye!: Renown and grace are dead.

Anon!: A sibyl, that had numbered in the world The sun to course two hundred compasses, In her prophetic fury sewed the work.
Goodbye!: A sibyl, who had numbered in the world two hundred times, sewed the work in her prophetic fury.

Anon!: Lend me your hand.
Goodbye!: Lend me your hand.

Anon!: The mighty gods defend thee!
Goodbye!: The mighty gods defend you!

Anon!: And yet my sky shall not want.
Goodbye!: And yet my sky will not want.

Anon!: But ’tis not so above.
Goodbye!: But it’s not above me.

Anon!: Read the will!
Goodbye!: Read the will!

Anon!: Know you him?
Goodbye!: Do you know him?

Anon!: Since he went from Egypt ’tis A space for farther travel.
Goodbye!: Since he left Egypt, it’s a space for more travel.

Anon!: I will speak lower.
Goodbye!: I’ll speak lower.

Anon!: I have made no fault.
Goodbye!: I haven’t made any fault.

Anon!: The gods forbid!
Goodbye!: The gods forbid!

Anon!: Nathaniel’s coat, sir, was not fully made, And Gabriel’s pumps were all unpinked i' th' heel.
Goodbye!: Nathaniel’s coat was not fully made, and Gabriel’s pumps were unpinked on the heel.

Anon!: Welcome, dear Rosencrantz and Guildenstern.
Goodbye!: Welcome, dear Rosencrantz and Guildenstern.

Anon!: The hand of death hath raught him.
Goodbye!: The hand of death has raught him.

Anon!: Therefore, my sweet Rose, my dear Rose, be merry.
Goodbye!: So, my sweet Rose, my dear Rose, be a good man.

Anon!: Ay, a thousand times.—Peter!
Goodbye!: Yes, a thousand times.—Peter!

Anon!: Well, praised be the gods for thy foulness; sluttishness may come hereafter.
Goodbye!: Well, praise the gods for your foulness; you can come here later.

Anon!: I warrant you.
Goodbye!: I’m sure you.

Anon!: Ay, those attires are best.
Goodbye!: Yes, those are the best clothes.

Anon!: She’s an excellent sweet lady, and, out of all suspicion, she is virtuous.
Goodbye!: She’s an excellent sweet lady, and, out of all suspicion, she’s virtuous.

Anon!: Why does the world report that Kate doth limp?
Goodbye!: Why is the world reporting that Kate is limping?

Anon!: I am much afeard my lady his mother played false with a smith.
Goodbye!: I’m a big fan of how my lady his mother played a false role with a smith.

Anon!: I think not of them.
Goodbye!: I don’t think about them.

Anon!: He is not yet arrived.
Goodbye!: He’s not yet arrived.

Anon!: Hath he set bounds between their love and me?
Goodbye!: Has he set boundaries between my love and their love?

Anon!: Seigneur Valentio and his cousin Tybalt; Lucio and the lively Helena.” A fair assembly.
Goodbye!: Seigneur Valentio and his cousin Tybalt, Lucio and the lively Helena.” A fair assembly.

Anon!: I would not for the world they saw thee here.
Goodbye!: I wouldn’t want to see them here in the world.

Anon!: Let us toward the king.
Goodbye!: Let’s go to the king.

Anon!: And as I say, retire with me to my lodging, from whence I will fitly bring you to hear my lord speak.
Goodbye!: And as I said, go with me to my house, and I’ll bring you to hear my lord speak.

Anon!: Antonio.
Goodbye!: Antonio.

Anon!: From France there comes a power Into this scattered kingdom, who already, Wise in our negligence, have secret feet In some of our best ports and are at point To show their open banner.
Goodbye!: From France there comes a power into this scattered kingdom, who, wisely, have secret feet in some of our best ports and are at the point to show their open banner.

Anon!: It is just so high as it is, and moves with its own organs.
Goodbye!: It’s just as high as it is, and it’s moving with its own organs.

Anon!: Let us be jocund.
Goodbye!: Let’s be jocund.

Anon!: Tis to be doubted, madam.
Goodbye!: It’s not to be doubted, madam.

Anon!: My Lord Bassanio, since you have found Antonio, We two will leave you.
Goodbye!: My Lord Bassanio, since you’ve found Antonio, we’ll leave you.

Anon!: Swear by your double self, And there’s an oath of credit!
Goodbye!: Swear by your double self, and there’s an oath of credit!

Anon!: Maybe the letter moved him, For, as I think, they do command him home, Deputing Cassio in his government.
Goodbye!: Maybe the letter moved him, because I think they command him home, deputing Cassio in his government.

Anon!: Come, help to bear thy master.
Goodbye!: Come, help your master.

Anon!: Y'are a baggage, the Slys are no rogues.
Goodbye!: The Slys are no rogues.

Anon!: Better thou Hadst not been born than not t' have pleased me better.
Goodbye!: If you hadn’t been born, then you’d have better gotten to me.

Anon!: The revelers are entering, brother.
Goodbye!: The revelers are coming, brother.

Anon!: To whom do you speak this?
Goodbye!: To whom do you say this?

Anon!: Think’st thou I jest?
Goodbye!: Do you think I’m cheating?

Anon!: Was he not born of woman?
Goodbye!: Wasn’t he born from a woman?

Anon!: Fie, that you’ll say so!
Goodbye!: I’ll tell you that!

Anon!: Trust me, I am glad on ’t.
Goodbye!: Trust me, I’m glad about it.

Anon!: Tybalt, my cousin!
Goodbye!: Tybalt, my cousin!

Anon!: I hope this reason stands for my excuse.
Goodbye!: I hope this is the reason I’m going to excuse.

Anon!: Gentle Octavia, Let your best love draw to that point which seeks Best to preserve it.
Goodbye!: Gentle Octavia, let your best love draw to the point where you want to preserve it.

Anon!: I' th' clout, i' th' clout.
Goodbye!: I’m the one who’s clout, the other.

Anon!: For they were parted With foul and violent tempest.
Goodbye!: They were split up with violent and violent forces.

Anon!: God bless you, sir.
Goodbye!: God bless you, sir.

Anon!: But I do prophesy the election lights On Fortinbras.
Goodbye!: But I’m telling you that Fortinbras will be lighted by the election.

Anon!: Ay.—Fare you well, fair gentleman.
Goodbye!: Yes.—Goodbye, fair gentleman.

Anon!: But, for your conscience?
Goodbye!: But, for your conscience?

Anon!: No, to my cabin.
Goodbye!: No, I’m going to my cabin.

Anon!: I am dying, Egypt, dying.
Goodbye!: I’m dying, Egypt, dying.

Anon!: Prithee, be cheerful.
Goodbye!: Please, be cheerful.

Anon!: Who intercepts my expedition?
Goodbye!: Who’s stopping my expedition?

Anon!: Many hot inroads They make in Italy—the borders maritime Lack blood to think on ’t—and flush youth revolt.
Goodbye!: They’re making many hot moves in Italy—the sea borders lack blood to think about it—and the youth revolt.

Anon!: Where’s Romeo?
Goodbye!: Where’s Romeo?

Anon!: It shall be done.
Goodbye!: It will be done.

Anon!: Gentle madam, no.
Goodbye!: No, gentle madam.

Anon!: No, my good lord.
Goodbye!: No, my good lord.

Anon!: Come, Nerissa.—
Goodbye!: Come, Nerissa.—

Anon!: Tut, tut, my lord, we will not stand to prate.
Goodbye!: Oh, my lord, we won’t stand to fight.

Anon!: Here comes Thisbe.
Goodbye!: Here comes Thisbe.

Anon!: What, wilt thou wash him from his grave with tears?
Goodbye!: Do you want to wash him out of his grave with tears?

Anon!: He is returned.
Goodbye!: He’s back.

Anon!: We must follow the leaders.
Goodbye!: We have to follow the leaders.

Anon!: This my mean task Would be as heavy to me as odious, but The mistress which I serve quickens what’s dead And makes my labors pleasures.
Goodbye!: I’d like to do this, but the mistress I serve quickens the dead and makes my work pleasure.

Anon!: First, as you know, my house within the city Is richly furnishèd with plate and gold, Basins and ewers to lave her dainty hands; My hangings all of Tyrian tapestry, In ivory coffers I have stuffed my crowns, In cypress chests my arras counterpoints, Costly apparel, tents, and canopies, Fine linen, Turkey cushions bossed with pearl, Valance of Venice gold in needlework, Pewter and brass, and all things that belong To house or housekeeping.
Goodbye!: First, as you know, my house in the city is richly decorated with gold, ewers and a base to lave her dainty hands; my hangings are all of Tyrian tapestry, in

Anon!: That Herod’s head I’ll have!
Goodbye!: I’ll have Herod’s head!

Anon!: General, be advised, He comes to bad intent.
Goodbye!: General, be advised, he’s coming to bad intentions.

Anon!: From me, whose love was of that dignity That it went hand in hand even with the vow I made to her in marriage, and to decline Upon a wretch whose natural gifts were poor To those of mine.
Goodbye!: From me, whose love was so dignityful that it went hand in hand even with the vow I made to her in marriage, and to decline upon a wretch whose natural gifts were poor to those of mine.

Anon!: Out of my sight!
Goodbye!: Out of my sight!

Anon!: Go armed.
Goodbye!: Be armed.

Anon!: You lack a man’s heart.
Goodbye!: You don’t have a man’s heart.

Anon!: A peevish schoolboy, worthless of such honor, Joined with a masker and a reveler!
Goodbye!: A peevish schoolboy, worthless of such honor, joined with a masker and a reveler!

Anon!: Sir, grieve not you.
Goodbye!: Sir, don’t grieve.

Anon!: He hath not told us of the captain yet.
Goodbye!: He hasn’t told us about the captain yet.

Anon!: Who is here so base that would be a bondman?
Goodbye!: Who is here so far that he wants to be a bondman?

Anon!: I’ll drain him dry as hay.
Goodbye!: I’ll drain him as much as hay.

Anon!: And speak parrot?
Goodbye!: And speak parrot?

Anon!: I am sorry to give breathing to my purpose— Help me away, dear Charmian!
Goodbye!: I’m sorry to give up my purpose— Help me out, dear Charmian!

Anon!: Enough.
Goodbye!: Enough.

Anon!: The nature of bad news infects the teller.
Goodbye!: The nature of bad news affects the teller.

Anon!: So well thy words become thee as thy wounds; They smack of honor both.
Goodbye!: Your words are as good as your wounds.

Anon!: Why, headstrong liberty is lashed with woe.
Goodbye!: Why, the king’s freedom is slashed with sorrow.

Anon!: No, monster, not I.
Goodbye!: No, monster, not me.

Anon!: Th' exchange of thy love’s faithful vow for mine.
Goodbye!: I’m glad to hear your love’s faithful vow for me.

Anon!: Your children were vexation to your youth, But mine shall be a comfort to your age.
Goodbye!: Your children were vexing your youth, but mine will be a comfort to your age.

Anon!: Then say at once what is it thou requests.
Goodbye!: Then tell me immediately what you want.

Anon!: Then plainly know my heart’s dear love is set On the fair daughter of rich Capulet.
Goodbye!: Then you can tell that my dear love is set on the fair daughter of rich Capulet.

Anon!: Give me thy torch, boy.
Goodbye!: Give me your torch, boy.

Anon!: Double, double toil and trouble, Fire burn and cauldron bubble.
Goodbye!: Double, double toil and trouble, Fire burn and cauldron bubble.

Anon!: Why, my boy?
Goodbye!: Why, my boy?

Anon!: But it is no matter.
Goodbye!: But it doesn’t matter.

Anon!: Therefore, out of my love to you, I came hither to acquaint you withal, that either you might stay him from his intendment or brook such disgrace well as he shall run into, in that it is a thing of his own search and altogether against my will.
Goodbye!: So I came here to tell you what he wants, so you can either stay him from his intentions or run away from the shame he will be facing, because it’s a thing of his own search and entirely against my will

Anon!: Thou hast not, cousin.
Goodbye!: You haven’t, cousin.

Anon!: Before the days of change, still is it so.
Goodbye!: It’s still true before the days of change.

Anon!: Has he never before sounded you in this business?
Goodbye!: Has he never heard of you before in this business?

Anon!: I muse why she’s at liberty.
Goodbye!: I’m unsure why she’s in liberty.

Anon!: To cabin, silence!
Goodbye!: Go to sleep, silence!

Anon!: Go you, call hither my fool.
Goodbye!: Go, call my fool here.

Anon!: He is wise, And, on my life, hath stol'n him home to bed.
Goodbye!: He’s wise, and I’ve stolped him home to bed.

Anon!: Tell not me.
Goodbye!: Don’t tell me.

Anon!: At this same ancient feast of Capulet’s Sups the fair Rosaline whom thou so loves With all the admired beauties of Verona.
Goodbye!: At this ancient feast of Capulet’s Supps the beautiful Rosaline whom you love so much with all the admired beauties of Verona.

Anon!: I prithee take the cork out of thy mouth, that I may drink thy tidings.
Goodbye!: I’d rather take the cork out of your mouth so I can drink your tidal.

Anon!: Of love?
Goodbye!: Of love?

Anon!: You’ve said, sir.
Goodbye!: You’ve said what you’re saying, sir.

Anon!: For that you must But say I could not help it.
Goodbye!: You must only say I couldn’t help it.

Anon!: What dost you mean by this?
Goodbye!: What do you mean by this?

Anon!: O villain, thou hast stolen both mine office and my name!
Goodbye!: Oh, villain, you’ve stolen both my job and my name!

Anon!: Yet the gold bides still That others touch, and often touching will Wear gold; yet no man that hath a name By falsehood and corruption doth it shame.
Goodbye!: But the gold is still a thing that others touch, and often wear gold.

Anon!: In himself he is.
Goodbye!: He is.

Anon!: To the tuition of God.
Goodbye!: To God’s mercy.

Anon!: He has almost supped.
Goodbye!: He’s almost supped.

Anon!: Hast thou drunk well?
Goodbye!: Are you drunk?

Anon!: Thrice noble lord, let me entreat of you To pardon me yet for a night or two, Or if not so, until the sun be set.
Goodbye!: My noble lord, let me ask you to pardon me for a night or two, or if not until the sun sets.

Anon!: A poor virgin, sir, an ill-favored thing, sir, but mine own.
Goodbye!: A poor virgin, a bad-wined thing, sir, but my own.

Anon!: I can be patient.
Goodbye!: I can be patient.

Anon!: Good morrow to you both.
Goodbye!: Good morning to you both.

Anon!: To whom in all this presence speaks your Grace?
Goodbye!: To whom is your Grace speaking in all this presence?

Anon!: With whom?
Goodbye!: With whom?

Anon!: I go, my lord.
Goodbye!: I’m going, my lord.

Anon!: Women are made to bear, and so are you.
Goodbye!: Women are made to bear, and so are you.

Anon!: The near in blood, The nearer bloody.
Goodbye!: The nearer, the nearer, the more bloody.

Anon!: Those that are in extremity of either are abominable fellows and betray themselves to every modern censure worse than drunkards.
Goodbye!: The people who are either abominable or abominable are evil men and they betray themselves to every evil punishment worse than drunkards.

Anon!: His spirits hear me And yet I needs must curse.
Goodbye!: His spirits hear me, but I have to curse him.

Anon!: The enemy, marching along by them, By them shall make a fuller number up, Come on refreshed, new-added, and encouraged, From which advantage shall we cut him off If at Philippi we do face him there, These people at our back.

Anon!: O day untowardly turned!
Goodbye!: Oh, day has turned out to be over!

Anon!: No better.
Goodbye!: No better.

Anon!: Death is my heir.
Goodbye!: Death is my heir.

Anon!: Farewell.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: And am I then revenged
Goodbye!: I’m revenged.

Anon!: No!
Goodbye!: No!

Anon!: Poor living corse, closed in a dead man’s tomb!
Goodbye!: Poor living corse, closed in a dead man’s tomb!

Anon!: Methinks she should not use a long one for such a Pyramus.
Goodbye!: I think she shouldn’t use a long one for such a Pyramus.

Anon!: Away!
Goodbye!: Go away!

Anon!: I have not seen him this two days.
Goodbye!: I haven’t seen him for two days.

Anon!: Nay, it is possible enough to judgment.
Goodbye!: No, it’s possible to judge.

Anon!: Down, therefore, and beg mercy of the Duke.
Goodbye!: So go down and beg the Duke to forgive him.

Anon!: I hate the word, As I hate hell, all Montagues, and thee.
Goodbye!: I hate the word, as I hate hell, all Montagues, and you.

Anon!: Do so, and after two days I will discharge thee.
Goodbye!: Do so, and after two days I’ll leave you.

Anon!: My decayèd fair A sunny look of his would soon repair.
Goodbye!: My decayed, fair, beautiful look would soon be repainted.

Anon!: Grandam, one night as we did sit at supper, My uncle Rivers talked how I did grow More than my brother: “Ay,” quoth my uncle Gloucester, “Small herbs have grace; great weeds do grow apace.” And since, methinks I would not grow so fast Because sweet flowers are slow and weeds make haste.
Goodbye!: My uncle Rivers said that I grew more than my brother: “Yes, my uncle Gloucester said, “Small herbs have grace; great weeds grow quickly.” And since then, I think I wouldn’t grow so

Anon!: Things at the worst will cease, or else climb upward To what they were before.—My pretty cousin, Blessing upon you.
Goodbye!: The worst things will stop, or else they’ll climb up to what they were before.—My pretty cousin, Blessing on you.

Anon!: How is ’t with you, my most fair Bianca?
Goodbye!: How are you, my fair Bianca?

Anon!: If a man’s brains were in ’s heels, were ’t not in danger of kibes?
Goodbye!: If a man’s brains were in the shin, weren’t they in danger of kibes?

Anon!: Seyton!
Goodbye!: Seyton!

Anon!: Why seek’st thou me?
Goodbye!: Why are you looking for me?

Anon!: Ah, Luciana, did he tempt thee so?
Goodbye!: Ah, Luciana, did he tempt you like that?

Anon!: I am afraid He will chastise me.
Goodbye!: I’m afraid he’ll chase me.

Anon!: If you cannot, give thanks you have lived so long and make yourself ready in your cabin for the mischance of the hour, if it so hap.—Cheerly, good hearts!—Out of our way, I say.
Goodbye!: If you can’t, give thanks to me for your long life and make yourself ready in your cabin for the hour, if it’s so hap.—Cheerly, good hearts!—Out of our way,

Anon!: Bid them all fly.
Goodbye!: Tell them to fly.

Anon!: Upon the stroke of four.
Goodbye!: Upon four strokes.

Anon!: I could tell you more news too.
Goodbye!: I could tell you more about it too.

Anon!: Come away, servant, come.
Goodbye!: Come away, servant, come.

Anon!: These hands do lack nobility that they strike A meaner than myself, since I myself Have given myself the cause.
Goodbye!: These hands are so naive that they’re a meaner than myself, since I have given myself the cause.

Anon!: Stand aside.
Goodbye!: Stand aside.

Anon!: That’s my good son.
Goodbye!: That’s my good son.

Anon!: Her mother hath many times told me so.
Goodbye!: Her mother has told me so many times.

Anon!: What, shall this speech be spoke for our excuse?
Goodbye!: What, should we speak about this speech as a excuse?

Anon!: Myself myself confound, Heaven and fortune bar me happy hours, Day, yield me not thy light, nor night thy rest, Be opposite all planets of good luck To my proceedings if, with dear heart’s love, Immaculate devotion, holy thoughts, I tender not thy beauteous princely daughter.
Goodbye!: I’m scolded, Heaven and fortune bar me happy hours, Day, I won’t give me any light, nor night rest, and I won’t be opposite all the planets of good luck to my actions

Anon!: Did he receive you well?
Goodbye!: Did he get you well?

Anon!: It is “music with her silver sound” because musicians have no gold for sounding.
Goodbye!: It’s “music with her silver sound,” because musicians don’t have gold to sound.

Anon!: Tonight I take my leave.
Goodbye!: Tonight I’ll leave.

Anon!: Well, girl, thou weep’st not so much for his death, As that the villain lives which slaughtered him.
Goodbye!: Well, girl, you’re not crying for his death, as much as for the life of the villain who killed him.

Anon!: It seemed she was a queen Over her passion, who, most rebel-like, Sought to be king o'er her.
Goodbye!: It seemed she was a queen over her passion, who, most rebel-like, strove to be king for her.

Anon!: In love?
Goodbye!: In love?

Anon!: Romeo slew him; he slew Mercutio.
Goodbye!: Romeo killed him, and Mercutio killed him.

Anon!: Fulvia is dead.
Goodbye!: Fulvia is dead.

Anon!: Let us seek out some desolate shade and there Weep our sad bosoms empty.
Goodbye!: Let’s look for some shade of shade, and weep our sad bosoms empty.

Anon!: Go, sirrah, seek him.
Goodbye!: Go, sir, find him.

Anon!: O, by your leave, I pray you, I bade you never speak again of him.
Goodbye!: Oh, please, I beg you, you’ll never talk about him again.

Anon!: I am as mad as he, If sad and merry madness equal be.
Goodbye!: I’m as mad as he is, if sad and merry madness is equal.

Anon!: The quality of mercy is not strained.
Goodbye!: The quality of mercy is not strained.

Anon!: Alas, Iago, my lord hath so bewhored her, Thrown such despite and heavy terms upon her, That true hearts cannot bear it.
Goodbye!: Iago, my lord has thrown her so despite and heavyly on her, that true hearts can’t bear it.

Anon!: She has light by her continually.
Goodbye!: She’s always lighted by her.

Anon!: Keep thou the left.
Goodbye!: Keep your head on the left.

Anon!: Am I Dromio?
Goodbye!: Am I Dromio?

Anon!: If thou didst it, thou art the nonpareil.
Goodbye!: If you did it, you’d be the nonpareil.

Anon!: What I am and what I would are as secret as maidenhead.

Anon!: Away before me to sweet beds of flowers.
Goodbye!: Take me to the sweet beds of flowers.

Anon!: O madam, my old heart is cracked, it’s cracked.
Goodbye!: Oh, madam, my old heart is cracked, it’s cracked.

Anon!: Whom thou wert sworn to cherish and defend.
Goodbye!: Whom you swore to cherish and defend.

Anon!: Your children shall be kings.

Anon!: And to sink in it, should you burthen love— Too great oppression for a tender thing.

Anon!: What news, my lord?
Goodbye!: What news do you have, my lord?

Anon!: Why ask you?

Anon!: When Prospero is destroyed.

Anon!: Oh, let us hence.

Anon!: Romeo will answer it.
Goodbye!: Romeo will answer it.

Anon!: So is the dearest o' th' loss.

Goodbye!: He has no friends except those who are afraid of him.

Anon!: I will not till I please.

Anon!: Give me your arm.
Goodbye!: Give me your arm.

Anon!: My husband!
Goodbye!: My husband!

Goodbye!: I’ll confess to you that I love him.

Goodbye!: Now, by Saint George, I’m too young for you.

Anon!: They are then excused, my lord, when they see not what they do.
Goodbye!: They’re then excused, my lord, when they don’t see what they do.

Goodbye!: If she’s alive long, and then she’ll be dead, then women will turn into monsters.

Anon!: So they are.
Goodbye!: They are.

Goodbye!: I don’t know why he’s coming.

Anon!: Choose your revenge yourself.
Goodbye!: Choose your revenge yourself.

Anon!: Hark thee, Clitus.
Goodbye!: Listen, Clitus.

Goodbye!: But let your fair eyes and gentle wishes go with me to my trial, wherein, if I’m beaten, there’s only one shamed man who never graciously died; if killed, but one dead who was

Goodbye!: If you ever held me in your heart without you from a moment of praise, and in this harsh world you’re in pain to tell my story.

Anon!: Sconce” call you it?
Goodbye!: Sconce” call you it?

Goodbye!: Does he rave?

Goodbye!: Oh, traitors, villains!

Anon!: Heaven rest them now.

Anon!: We may effect this business yet ere day.

Anon!: The fiend is rough and will not be roughly used.

Goodbye!: And even though you know my love and inwardness are very close to the Prince and Claudio, I’ll do this secretly and justly as your soul should with your body.

Anon!: But till I come again, No bed shall e'er be guilty of my stay, No rest be interposer ’twixt us twain.

Anon!: Yes, nightingales answer daws!
Goodbye!: Yes, nightingales answer daws!

Goodbye!: No one can be called deformed, but the unkind.

Goodbye!: Now Sweno, the Norwegian king, wants to be composed.

Goodbye!: Know me for Brutus!

Goodbye!: Either go to some private place, and explain your grievances coldly, or else go away.

Anon!: Haply the seas and countries different With variable objects shall expel This something-settled matter in his heart, Whereon his brains still beating puts him thus From fashion of himself.

Anon!: Goodly Lord, what a wit-snapper are you!
Goodbye!: Good Lord, what a wit-snapper you are!

Anon!: Let’s speak to him.
Goodbye!: Let’s speak to him.

Anon!: A witty mother!
Goodbye!: A witty mother!

Anon!: Well, sir.

Anon!: It is the east, and Juliet is the sun.
Goodbye!: It’s the east, and Juliet’s the sun.

Anon!: One.
Goodbye!: One.

Anon!: Both your majesties Might, by the sovereign power you have of us, Put your dread pleasures more into command Than to entreaty.
Goodbye!: Both your majesties can put your dreadful pleasures more in command than to get into the trap.

Anon!: I will tomorrow— And betimes I will—to the weird sisters.
Goodbye!: I’ll go to the weird sisters tomorrow—and it’s time to do that.

Anon!: Are you sure That we are awake?
Goodbye!: Are you sure we’re awake?

Anon!: The king is coming.
Goodbye!: The king is coming.

Anon!: As thou art to thyself.
Goodbye!: You are to yourself.

Anon!: Give me some little breath, some pause, dear lord, Before I positively speak in this.
Goodbye!: Give me some breath, my dear lord, before I speak positively about this.

Anon!: When valor preys on reason, It eats the sword it fights with.
Goodbye!: When a man is a good man, he eats the sword it fights with.

Anon!: Is not this well?
Goodbye!: Isn’t that all right?

Anon!: Take heed o' th' foul fiend.
Goodbye!: Take care of your foul fiend.

Anon!: Oh, no.
Goodbye!: Oh no.

Anon!: Let none presume To wear an undeservèd dignity.
Goodbye!: Don’t presume to wear an undeserved dignity.

Anon!: Since Cassius first did whet me against Caesar, I have not slept.
Goodbye!: Since Cassius first attacked me against Caesar, I haven’t slept.

Anon!: Tis not needed yet.
Goodbye!: It’s not needed yet.

Anon!: By and by.
Goodbye!: By and by.

Anon!: Where’s Publius?
Goodbye!: Where’s Publius?

Anon!: How now, my lord!
Goodbye!: What’s going on, my lord?

Anon!: I prithee, good Grumio, tell me, how goes the world?
Goodbye!: Please tell me, good Grumio, how is the world going?

Anon!: Leave me alone to woo him.
Goodbye!: Leave me alone to woo him.

Anon!: What, dost thou scorn me for my gentle counsel, And soothe the devil that I warn thee from?
Goodbye!: What, do you scorn me for my gentle advice, and soothe the devil I warn you from?

Anon!: Sister, it is not a little I have to say of what most nearly appertains to us both.
Goodbye!: Sister, I have to say a little about what almost matters to both of us.

Anon!: My lord, there needs no such apology.
Goodbye!: My lord, there’s no need for apology.

Anon!: Ay, very well, my lord.
Goodbye!: Yes, very well, my lord.

Anon!: Thou wilt quarrel with a man for cracking nuts, having no other reason but because thou hast hazel eyes.
Goodbye!: You’ll fight with a man for cracking nuts, just because you have hazelnut eyes.

Anon!: Thou know’st not me.
Goodbye!: You don’t know me.

Anon!: O most courageous day!
Goodbye!: Oh, what a courageous day!

Anon!: Go, get thee to thy love, as was decreed.
Goodbye!: Go, get to your love, as was decreed.

Anon!: Marry, sir, she’s the kitchen wench, and all grease, and I know not what use to put her to but to make a lamp of her and run from her by her own light.
Goodbye!: She’s the kitchen wench, and all the grease, and I don’t know what to do to make her a lamp of her and run away from her by her own light.

Anon!: I will chop her into messes!
Goodbye!: I’ll chop her into messes!

Anon!: I call thee not.
Goodbye!: I don’t call you.

Anon!: Parting is such sweet sorrow That I shall say good night till it be morrow.
Goodbye!: Parting is such sweet sorrow that I’ll say good night until it’s morrow.

Anon!: I took no more pains for those thanks than you take pains to thank me.
Goodbye!: I didn’t take any more pains for those thanks than you took pains to thank me.

Anon!: Stay, then.
Goodbye!: Wait, then.

Anon!: Why then, ’tis good to be a post.
Goodbye!: Well then, it’s good to be a post.

Anon!: And to that end we wished your Lordship here T' avoid the censures of the carping world.
Goodbye!: And to that end, we wished your Lordship would avoid the carping world.

Anon!: I do not like your faults.
Goodbye!: I don’t like your faults.

Anon!: Let her awhile be secretly kept in And publish it that she is dead indeed.
Goodbye!: Let her be kept in secret for a while and publish that she’s actually dead.

Anon!: Welcome home, Grumio.
Goodbye!: Welcome home, Grumio.

Anon!: Sport royal, I warrant you.
Goodbye!: Sport royal, I assure you.

Anon!: How art thou out of breath when thou hast breath To say to me that thou art out of breath?
Goodbye!: How are you out of breath when you have breath to tell me that you’re out of breath?

Anon!: I am glad to see your Honor.
Goodbye!: I’m glad to see your Honor.

Anon!: Amen.
Goodbye!: Amen.

Anon!: I do lack some part Of that quick spirit that is in Antony.
Goodbye!: I don’t have any part of the spirit that is in Antony.

Anon!: With drinking healths to my niece.
Goodbye!: I’m drinking healthily to my niece.

Anon!: But I shall crave your pardon.
Goodbye!: But I’ll beg your pardon.

Anon!: Demetrius is a worthy gentleman.
Goodbye!: Demetrius is a worthy gentleman.

Anon!: Justice, find the girl!
Goodbye!: Just find the girl!

Anon!: It cannot be but thou hast murdered him.
Goodbye!: It can’t be that you’ve murdered him.

Anon!: And for his dreams, I wonder he’s so simple To trust the mock'ry of unquiet slumbers.
Goodbye!: And for his dreams, I wonder he’s so simple to trust the mockery of unquiet slumbers.

Anon!: You’ll be sick tomorrow For this night’s watching.
Goodbye!: You’ll be sick tomorrow because you’re watching this night.

Anon!: Yet am I noble as the adversary I come to cope withal.
Goodbye!: But I’m noble as the adversary I come to deal with.

Anon!: To Baptista Minola.
Goodbye!: To Baptista Minola.

Anon!: My estate is very low.
Goodbye!: My estate is very low.

Anon!: And there assume some other horrible form, Which might deprive your sovereignty of reason And draw you into madness?
Goodbye!: And there’s some other horrible form of nonsense that could deprive you of your right to reason and make you mad?

Anon!: Or Charles or something weaker masters thee.
Goodbye!: Or Charles or something weaker will be mastering you.

Anon!: Thou fond mad man, hear me a little speak.
Goodbye!: You fond madman, listen to me a little bit.

Anon!: I would I had been there.
Goodbye!: I wish I had been there.

Anon!: I would lose all—ay, sacrifice them all Here to this devil—to deliver you.
Goodbye!: I’d lose everything—yes, sacrifice them all here to this devil—to deliver you.

Anon!: And I am witness with her that she did.
Goodbye!: And I’m witnessing her doing it.

Anon!: Some haste, my lord!
Goodbye!: Hurry up, my lord!

Anon!: It is not yet near day.
Goodbye!: It’s not yet day.

Anon!: Now, most noble Brutus, The gods today stand friendly that we may, Lovers in peace, lead on our days to age.
Goodbye!: Now, most noble Brutus, the gods are friendly so that we can lead our loyal servants to age.

Anon!: Lest it make you choleric and purchase me another dry basting.
Goodbye!: If you’re choleric, you’ll need to buy me another dry basting.

Anon!: If he do bleed, I’ll gild the faces of the grooms withal, For it must seem their guilt.
Goodbye!: If he bleeds, I’ll gild the faces of the grooms with a smile, because it must seem their guilt.

Anon!: Fathered he is, and yet he’s fatherless.
Goodbye!: He’s fathered, and yet he’s fatherless.

Anon!: Tis since the earthquake now eleven years, And she was weaned—I never shall forget it— Of all the days of the year, upon that day.
Goodbye!: It’s been eleven years since the earthquake, and she was weaned—I’ll never forget it—of all the days of the year, on that day.

Anon!: We think not so, my lord.
Goodbye!: We don’t think so, my lord.

Anon!: Was ever woman in this humor won?
Goodbye!: Was a woman ever won this fight?

Anon!: He goes before me and still dares me on.
Goodbye!: He’s going ahead and dares me to go.

Anon!: Ay, marry, must you.
Goodbye!: Yes, you must marry.

Anon!: I am sure you know him well enough.
Goodbye!: I’m sure you know him well enough.

Anon!: I was the man i' the moon when time was.
Goodbye!: I was the man in the moon when time was.

Anon!: I will hold friends with you, lady.
Goodbye!: I’ll be friends with you, lady.

Anon!: How now, my friend, why dost thou look so pale?
Goodbye!: Why are you so pale, my friend?

Anon!: Moreover, urge his hateful luxury And bestial appetite in change of lust, Which stretched to their servants, daughters, wives, Even where his raging eye or savage heart, Without control, lusted to make his prey.
Goodbye!: Moreover, urge his hateful luxury and bestial appetite to change his lust, which stretched to their servants, daughters, wives, even where his raging eye or savage heart, without control, lus

Anon!: Smatter with your gossips, go.
Goodbye!: Smatter with your gossips, go.

Anon!: And you, sir.
Goodbye!: And you, sir.

Anon!: And so, good Capulet—which name I tender As dearly as my own—be satisfied.
Goodbye!: And so, good Capulet—which is the name I’m tender as dearly as my own—will be satisfied.

Anon!: I saw the Duchess of Milan’s gown that they praise so.
Goodbye!: I saw the Duchess of Milan’s gown that they praise so much.

Anon!: The worms were hallowed that did breed the silk, And it was dyed in mummy which the skillful Conserved of maidens' hearts.
Goodbye!: The worms were sprayed with the silk, and it was dyed in mummy, which the skillful men of the maidens were able to keep.

Anon!: Welcome, wanderer.
Goodbye!: Welcome, wanderer.

Anon!: At this same ancient feast of Capulet’s Sups the fair Rosaline whom thou so loves With all the admired beauties of Verona.
Goodbye!: At this ancient feast of Capulet’s Supps the beautiful Rosaline whom you love so much with all the admired beauties of Verona.

Anon!: Th' ambassadors from Norway, my good lord, Are joyfully returned.
Goodbye!: The ambassadors from Norway, my good lord, are returning joyfully.

Anon!: Tis passing good.
Goodbye!: It’s good.

Anon!: Crowner’s quest law.
Goodbye!: Crowner’s quest law.

Anon!: To vail the title, as her mother doth.
Goodbye!: To go away with the title, as her mother does.

Anon!: Why let it strike?
Goodbye!: Why should it strike?

Anon!: Dear Celia, I show more mirth than I am mistress of, and would you yet I were merrier?
Goodbye!: Dear Celia, I’m more sane than I am a mistress, and would you be a bit merrier?

Anon!: Come hither, mistress.
Goodbye!: Come here, my mistress.

Anon!: Death, traitor!
Goodbye!: Death, traitor!

Anon!: For mine own part, no offence to the general nor any man of quality, I hope to be saved.
Goodbye!: I hope to save myself, neither the general nor any man of quality.

Anon!: He was wont to lend money for a Christian courtesy; let him look to his bond.
Goodbye!: He was wont lend money to a Christian, but let him look at his debt.

Anon!: The age is grown so picked that the toe of the peasant comes so near the heel of the courtier he galls his kibe.—How long hast thou been a grave-maker?
Goodbye!: The age has grown so quickly that the toe of the peasant comes so near the heel of the courtier he galles his kibe.—How long have you been a gravemaker?

Anon!: Twas yet some comfort When misery could beguile the tyrant’s rage And frustrate his proud will.
Goodbye!: It was comforting to see that misfortune could beguile the tyrant’s rage and frustrate his proud will.

Anon!: Shall we shog?
Goodbye!: Shall we shog?

Anon!: Call in my gentlewoman.
Goodbye!: Call in my lady.

Anon!: How say you by this change?
Goodbye!: What do you think about this change?

Anon!: Royal wench!
Goodbye!: Royal wench!

Anon!: That you shall surely find him, Lead to the Sagittary the raisèd search, And there will I be with him.
