Goodbye!: You’ll find him, lead the Sagittarian to the search, and I’ll be with him there.

Anon!: Have you importuned him by any means?
Goodbye!: Have you imported him by any means?

Anon!: Tennis balls, my liege.
Goodbye!: Tennis balls, my liege.

Anon!: And brief, good mother, for I am in haste.
Goodbye!: And I’m quick, good mother, because I’m in a hurry.

Anon!: How shall we find the concord of this discord?
Goodbye!: How can we find the concord between this and the discord?

Anon!: The deep of night is crept upon our talk, And nature must obey necessity, Which we will niggard with a little rest.
Goodbye!: We’re talking about the deep night, and we need to be careful, which we’ll niggard with a little rest.

Anon!: Farewell, kind lord.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, kind lord.

Anon!: God-a-mercy, Grumio!
Goodbye!: Goodbye, Grumio!

Anon!: My lord, I have.
Goodbye!: My lord, I have.

Anon!: I pray you, what thinks he of our estate?
Goodbye!: Please, what does he think of our estate?

Anon!: Thou shalt Go back, I warrant thee!
Goodbye!: You’ll go back, I promise you!

Anon!: In brief, Sorrow would be a rarity most beloved If all could so become it.
Goodbye!: I’m telling you, Sorrow would be a rarity most beloved if all could become it.

Anon!: Then leave her, sir, for by the power that made me, I tell you all her wealth.
Goodbye!: Then leave her, sir, because I tell you all her wealth by the power that made me.

Anon!: I’ll go with you.
Goodbye!: I’ll go with you.

Anon!: O my dear lord—   Nay, do not think I flatter.
Goodbye!: Oh, my dear lord— Don’t think I’m flattering you.

Anon!: I will lay trust upon thee, and thou shalt find a dearer father in my love.
Goodbye!: I’ll trust you, and you’ll find a dearer father in my love.

Anon!: Let her be thine, for we Have no such daughter, nor shall ever see That face of hers again.
Goodbye!: Let her be yours, because we don’t have any daughter like that, and we won’t see that face again.

Anon!: My lord, I have remembrances of yours That I have longèd long to redeliver.
Goodbye!: My lord, I’ve been able to remember yours for a long time.

Anon!: But I would be loath to fall into my dreams again.
Goodbye!: But I’d be loath to fall back into my dreams.

Anon!: Let me work.
Goodbye!: Let me work.

Anon!: When this burns, 'Twill weep for having wearied you.
Goodbye!: When this burns, weep for having worn you.

Anon!: Knock, knock, knock!
Goodbye!: Knock, knock, knock!

Anon!: I do not like the Tower, of any place.— Did Julius Caesar build that place, my lord?
Goodbye!: I don’t like the Tower, any place.— Did Julius Caesar build that place, my lord?

Anon!: For this slave, If there be any cunning cruelty That can torment him much and hold him long, It shall be his.
Goodbye!: If there’s any cruel cruelty that can torment him and keep him long, it will be his.

Anon!: Why will My lord do so?
Goodbye!: Why will my lord do that?

Anon!: Now follow, if thou darest, to try whose right, Of thine or mine, is most in Helena.
Goodbye!: Now, if you dare, try to find out who is most in Helena.

Anon!: If this be so, why blame you me to love you?
Goodbye!: If that’s true, why do you blame me for love you?

Anon!: Come, Romeo.
Goodbye!: Come, Romeo.

Anon!: It is some meteor that the sun exhales To be to thee this night a torchbearer, And light thee on thy way to Mantua.
Goodbye!: It’s some meteor that the sun is telling you to be a torchbearer this night and light you on your way to Mantua.

Anon!: Come, sir, I am for you.
Goodbye!: Come on, sir, I’m for you.

Anon!: No, not for Venice.
Goodbye!: No, not for Venice.

Anon!: I drew to part them.
Goodbye!: I drew my sword to part them.

Anon!: Am I myself?
Goodbye!: Am I myself?

Anon!: Here, sir, a ring she bid me give you, sir.
Goodbye!: Here, sir, she asked me to give you a ring.

Anon!: Which of you two did dine with me today?
Goodbye!: Which of you two had dinner with me today?

Anon!: Miserable England, I prophesy the fearfull’st time to thee That ever wretched age hath looked upon.— Come, lead me to the block.
Goodbye!: Miserable England, I’m telling you the fearfulst time that ever wretched age has been.—Come on, lead me to the block.

Anon!: Nay, I prithee stay a little.
Goodbye!: No, please stay a little longer.

Anon!: All this done, Repair to Pompey’s porch, where you shall find us.
Goodbye!: All this is done, and you’ll get back to Pompey’s porch, where you’ll find us.

Anon!: Nay, you must forget that.
Goodbye!: No, you have to forget that.

Anon!: Here is my journey’s end, here is my butt, And very sea-mark of my utmost sail.
Goodbye!: Here’s my journey’s end, here’s my butt, and I’m the sea-mark of my most beautiful sail.

Anon!: Marry, peace it bodes, and love, and quiet life, And awful rule, and right supremacy, And, to be short, what not that’s sweet and happy?
Goodbye!: It’s a peace, and love, and a quiet life, and awful rule, and right supremacy, and, to be short, what’s not sweet and happy?

Anon!: Good fortune, worthy soldier, and farewell.
Goodbye!: Good luck, worthy soldier, and farewell.

Anon!: You cannot, if my heart were in your hand, Nor shall not, whilst ’tis in my custody.
Goodbye!: You can’t, if my heart were in your hand, and you can’t, while I’m in my custody.

Anon!: Here is yet a postscript.
Goodbye!: Here’s a postscript.

Anon!: Good morrow to your Worship.
Goodbye!: Good morning to your Worship.

Anon!: And if thou prate of mountains let them throw Millions of acres on us, till our ground, Singeing his pate against the burning zone, Make Ossa like a wart!
Goodbye!: And if you’re a king of mountains, let them throw millions of acres on us, till our ground is sung against the burning zone, make Ossa like a wart!

Anon!: O woeful time.
Goodbye!: Oh, what a sad time.

Anon!: What had he done to make him fly the land?
Goodbye!: What did he do to make him fly the land?

Anon!: The venom of such looks, we fairly hope, Have lost their quality, and that this day Shall change all griefs and quarrels into love.
Goodbye!: We hope that such a bad look has lost their quality, and that this day all grief and conflict will turn into love.

Anon!: So can I.
Goodbye!: I can do that.

Anon!: Methinks they are such a gentle nation that, but for the mountain of mad flesh
Goodbye!: I think they’re such a gentle nation that, only for the mountain of madness

Anon!: Do it carefully.—And the noble and true-hearted Kent banished, his offense honesty!
Goodbye!: Do it carefully.—And the noble and true-hearted Kent was banished, his offense honesty!

Anon!: Sometime I’d divide, And burn in many places.
Goodbye!: Sometime I’d divide and burn in many places.

Anon!: How came you to this?
Goodbye!: How did you get to this?

Anon!: More matter for a May morning.
Goodbye!: More matters for a May morning.

Anon!: And look when I am king, claim thou of me The earldom of Hereford, and all the moveables Whereof the king my brother was possessed.
Goodbye!: And when I’m king, you’ll be king of Hereford, and all the possessions of the king my brother was.

Anon!: Is Romeo slaughtered, and is Tybalt dead?
Goodbye!: Is Romeo killed, and Tybalt dead?

Anon!: What will you do?
Goodbye!: What are you going to do?

Anon!: As I am a gentleman, I will live to be thankful to thee for ’t.
Goodbye!: As a gentleman, I’ll live to be thankful to you for it.

Anon!: Let us all embrace.
Goodbye!: Let’s all embrace it.

Anon!: As manhood shall compound.
Goodbye!: As manhood will grow.

Anon!: So thrive my soul— A thousand times good night!
Goodbye!: I’m so happy, my soul— A thousand times good night!

Anon!: Hold him in safety till the Prince come hither.
Goodbye!: Keep him safe until the Prince comes here.

Anon!: The house will be the quieter.
Goodbye!: The house will be quieter.

Anon!: I should know that voice.
Goodbye!: I’d like to hear that voice.

Anon!: How beauteous mankind is!
Goodbye!: How cruel mankind is!

Anon!: She was false as water.
Goodbye!: She was false as water.

Anon!: You are he, you are he.
Goodbye!: You’re him, you’re him.

Anon!: That same villain, Romeo.
Goodbye!: That villain, Romeo.

Anon!: But men may construe things after their fashion, Clean from the purpose of the things themselves.
Goodbye!: But men can’t do anything like that, and they can’t do anything like that.

Anon!: What should that bode?
Goodbye!: What should that mean?

Anon!: But I will tell you at some meeter season.
Goodbye!: But I’ll tell you at some meet up season.

Anon!: For, look you, how cheerfully my mother looks, and my father died within these two hours.
Goodbye!: Look, my mother looks cheerful, and my father died within two hours.

Anon!: She’s like a liar gone to burning hell.
Goodbye!: She’s like a liar who’s gone to hell.

Anon!: Wouldst thou have that Which thou esteem’st the ornament of life, And live a coward in thine own esteem, Letting “I dare not” wait upon “I would, ” Like the poor cat i' th' adage?
Goodbye!: You would have the one that you admire the ornament of life, and you would live a coward in your own esteem, if you didn’t want to wait on “I would,” like the poor cat?

Anon!: I would scarce trust myself, though I had sworn the contrary, if Hero would be my wife.
Goodbye!: I’d be tempted to trust myself, even if I had sworn that Hero would be my wife.

Anon!: I am desperate of my fortunes if they check me.
Goodbye!: I’m desperate about my fortunes if they check me.

Anon!: Peradventure, to make it the more gracious, I shall sing it at her death.
Goodbye!: I’ll sing it at her death.

Anon!: But, in faith, Kate, the elder I wax, the better I shall appear.
Goodbye!: But, in faith, Kate, the older I become, the better I will appear.

Anon!: Madam, here comes my lord.
Goodbye!: Madam, here comes my lord.

Anon!: The old man’s daughter told us all.
Goodbye!: The old man’s daughter told us everything.

Anon!: The last of all the Romans, fare thee well!
Goodbye!: The last of all the Romans, farewell!

Anon!: What wert thou if the King of Naples heard thee?
Goodbye!: What value would you have if the King of Naples heard you?

Anon!: Pray you, go with us.
Goodbye!: Please go with us.

Anon!: O wife, look how our daughter bleeds!
Goodbye!: Oh wife, look at how our daughter bleeds!

Anon!: I will bandy with thee in faction.
Goodbye!: I’ll bandy with you in a faction.

Anon!: Oh, mickle is the powerful grace that lies In herbs, plants, stones, and their true qualities.
Goodbye!: Oh, mickle is the powerful grace that lies in herbs, plants, stones, and their true qualities.

Anon!: But that still use of grief makes wild grief tame, My tongue should to thy ears not name my boys Till that my nails were anchored in thine eyes, And I, in such a desp'rate bay of death, Like a poor bark of sails and tackling reft, Rush all to pieces on thy rocky bosom.
Goodbye!: But when I’m still using grief to make wild grief tame, my tongue should not name my boys until my nails were anchored in your eyes.

Anon!: Go but with me tonight, you shall see her chamber window entered, even the night before her wedding day.
Goodbye!: You’ll see her window entered the night before her wedding day.

Anon!: Well, let’s away and say how much is done.
Goodbye!: Well, let’s go and say how much is done.

Anon!: Hark!
Goodbye!: Listen!

Anon!: O lady, speak again!
Goodbye!: Oh, lady, speak again!

Anon!: If this were true, then should I know this secret.
Goodbye!: If this were true, then I’d know this secret.

Anon!: I pray thee, if it stand with honesty, Buy thou the cottage, pasture, and the flock, And thou shalt have to pay for it of us.
Goodbye!: If it’s true, you’ll have to buy the cottage, the pasture, and the flock, and you’ll have to pay for it from us.

Anon!: The very head and front of my offending Hath this extent, no more.
Goodbye!: The head and front of my offending are in this state, no more.

Anon!: There is the playhouse now, there must you sit, And thence to France shall we convey you safe And bring you back, charming the narrow seas To give you gentle pass; for, if we may, We’ll not offend one stomach with our play.
Goodbye!: There’s the playhouse now, there must be a seat, and then we’ll bring you back to France, charming the narrow seas to give you a gentle pass.

Anon!: You shall advise me in all for Cleopatra.
Goodbye!: You’ll advise me in all of the matters for Cleopatra.

Anon!: Thou liest, abhorrèd tyrant.
Goodbye!: You lie, a tyrant.

Anon!: A traveler.
Goodbye!: A traveler.

Anon!: Then, to answer every man directly and briefly, wisely and truly—wisely I say, I am a bachelor.
Goodbye!: Then, to answer every man directly and briefly, wisely and truly—wisely I say, I am a bachelor.

Anon!: Hie to your chamber.
Goodbye!: Go to your room.

Anon!: You lie out on ’t, sir, and therefore it is not yours.
Goodbye!: You’re lying on it, sir, and therefore it’s not yours.

Anon!: If it be so, It is a chance which does redeem all sorrows That ever I have felt.
Goodbye!: If it’s true, it’s a chance to redeem all the sorrows I’ve ever felt.

Anon!: Yea, and text underneath: “Here dwells Benedick the married man”?
Goodbye!: Yes, and under the text: “Here’s Benedick the married man”?

Anon!: Good morrow, General.
Goodbye!: Good morning, General.

Anon!: No, my lord.
Goodbye!: No, my lord.

Anon!: What, my lord?
Goodbye!: What, my lord?

Anon!: Indeed, my lord, it is a most absolute and excellent horse.
Goodbye!: Indeed, my lord, it’s a very absolute and excellent horse.

Anon!: Have you writ down that they are none?
Goodbye!: Have you written down that they aren’t?

Anon!: Find out moonshine, find out moonshine!
Goodbye!: Find out moonshine, find moonshine!

Anon!: Ay, so please your Majesty.
Goodbye!: Yes, sir.

Anon!: Some comfort, Nurse.
Goodbye!: I’m feeling a little better, Nurse.

Anon!: Would she were hearsed at my foot and the ducats in her coffin!
Goodbye!: She’d be heard at my foot and the ducats in her coffin!

Anon!: I pray you, then, in love and dear alliance, Let that one article rank with the rest, And thereupon give me your daughter.
Goodbye!: So please, in love and friendship, let that one article rank with the rest, and then give me your daughter.

Anon!: That’s all one.
Goodbye!: That’s all one thing.

Anon!: And you, sir, for this chain arrested me.
Goodbye!: And you, sir, for this necklace arrested me.

Anon!: But sadly, tell me who.
Goodbye!: But tell me who.

Anon!: Tis but a little way that I can bring you, For I attend here.
Goodbye!: I can bring you a little way, because I’m here.

Anon!: Ay, madam.
Goodbye!: Yes, madam.

Anon!: Where is my lord?
Goodbye!: Where is my lord?

Anon!: Put color in thy cheek.
Goodbye!: Put color in your cheek.

Anon!: I had as lief thou didst break his neck as his finger.
Goodbye!: I had as much pain breaking his neck as his finger.

Anon!: Well then, go you into hell?
Goodbye!: Well then, go into hell?

Anon!: Addicted so and so.—” And there put on him What forgeries you please.
Goodbye!: I’ve added so much.—” And there put on him what you want to get.

Anon!: What black magician conjures up this fiend To stop devoted charitable deeds?
Goodbye!: What black magician is threatening this fiend to stop charitable acts?

Anon!: A man that had a wife with such a wit, he might say “Wit, whither wilt?”  Nay, you might keep that check for it, till you met your wife’s wit going to your neighbor’s bed.
Goodbye!: If you had a wife with such a wit, he might say, “Wit, whither wilt?” No, you might keep that check for it until you met your wife’s wit and went

Anon!: My lord Sebastian, The truth you speak doth lack some gentleness And time to speak it in.
Goodbye!: My lord Sebastian, you’re talking about the truth without a lot of patience and time to speak.

Anon!: Thither he Will come to know his destiny.
Goodbye!: He’ll come to know his destiny.

Anon!: Good repose the while!
Goodbye!: Good morning!

Anon!: O Regan, Goneril, Your old kind father, whose frank heart gave all— Oh, that way madness lies.
Goodbye!: Oh, Regan, Goneril, your old kind father, whose frank heart gave everything— Oh, that’s the way madness lies.

Anon!: Why rail’st thou on thy birth, the heaven, and earth?
Goodbye!: Why are you scolding your birth, the heavens, and the earth?

Anon!: Season your admiration for a while With an attent ear, till I may deliver, Upon the witness of these gentlemen, This marvel to you.
Goodbye!: I’ll give you this marvel, upon the witness of these gentlemen.

Anon!: I am content, so thou wilt have it so.
Goodbye!: I’m happy, you’ll get it.

Anon!: These things to hear Would Desdemona seriously incline.
Goodbye!: That’s what Desdemona wants to hear.

Anon!: Get me some poison, Iago, this night.
Goodbye!: Get me some poison tonight, Iago.

Anon!: Therefore wast thou Deservedly confined into this rock, Who hadst deserved more than a prison.
Goodbye!: So you were confined to this rock, who had deserved more than a prison.

Anon!: Tom’s a- cold.
Goodbye!: Tom’s cold.

Anon!: Is that his answer?
Goodbye!: Is that his answer?

Anon!: Horses are tied by the heads, dogs and bears by the neck, monkeys by the loins, and men by the legs.
Goodbye!: Horses are tied by the heads, dogs and bears by the neck, monkeys by the loins, and men by the legs.

Anon!: What’s he That was not born of woman?
Goodbye!: Who was born from a woman?

Anon!: And he that hath commanded is our king.
Goodbye!: And the man who has commanded is our king.

Anon!: Nay, I have ta'en you napping, gentle love, And have forsworn you with Hortensio.
Goodbye!: No, I’ve been chatting to you, my gentle love, and I’ve been begging you to marry Hortensio.

Anon!: With all my heart.
Goodbye!: With all my heart.

Anon!: Kind gentlemen, let’s go see poor Cassio dressed.— Come, mistress, you must tell ’s another tale.
Goodbye!: Kind gentlemen, let’s go see poor Cassio dressed.—Come on, mistress, you have to tell a new story.

Anon!: How?
Goodbye!: How?

Anon!: Found you no displeasure in him by word or countenance?
Goodbye!: Did you feel any dissatisfaction with him by word or countenance?

Anon!: Fear me not.— She and the duke her husband!
Goodbye!: Don’t worry about me.—She and the duke her husband!

Anon!: What sayst thou to him?
Goodbye!: What do you say to him?

Anon!: There is no other shelter hereabouts.
Goodbye!: There’s no other shelter hereabouts.

Anon!: But jealous souls will not be answered so.
Goodbye!: But jealous souls won’t be answered like that.

Anon!: Pray you, avoid it.
Goodbye!: Please, don’t worry about it.

Anon!: Edmund, farewell.
Goodbye!: Edmund, goodbye.

Anon!: Cast it off!
Goodbye!: Get it out of here!

Anon!: Thou hast a lady far more beautiful Than any woman in this waning age.
Goodbye!: You have a lady far more beautiful than any woman in this waning age.

Anon!: Remorseless, treacherous, lecherous, kindless villain!
Goodbye!: Remorseless, treacherous, lecherous, kindless villain!

Anon!: Caesar is turned to hear.
Goodbye!: Caesar is waiting to hear.

Anon!: Ay, ’twas he that told me on her first.
Goodbye!: Yes, it was the one who told me about her first.

Anon!: My heart is ten times lighter than my looks.
Goodbye!: My heart is ten times lighter than my looks.

Anon!: To the death, my lord.
Goodbye!: To death, my lord.

Anon!: Oh, say so, and so be!
Goodbye!: Oh, say that, and so be!

Anon!: Good my lord— You have been a boggler ever.
Goodbye!: My lord— You’ve been a boggler ever.

Anon!: He is or ta'en or slain.
Goodbye!: He’s been killed or killed.

Anon!: My fault, but not my body, pardon, sovereign.
Goodbye!: My fault, but not my body, pardon me, sovereign.

Anon!: In happy time.
Goodbye!: Good time.

Anon!: On what occasion God He knows, not I, The queen your mother and your brother York Have taken sanctuary.
Goodbye!: If God knows what happens, you and your brother York have taken refuge in the queen.

Anon!: Offended us you have not, but the king.
Goodbye!: You offended us, not the king.

Anon!: Ingrateful fox, ’tis he.
Goodbye!: He’s a gratifying fox.

Anon!: Do, do.
Goodbye!: Do it.

Anon!: With all my heart.—Some three or four of you Go give him courteous conduct to this place.— Meantime the court shall hear Bellario’s letter.
Goodbye!: With all my heart.—Some three or four of you go give him courteous conduct to this place.—In the meantime, the court will hear Bellario’s letter.

Anon!: Therefore be patient.
Goodbye!: So be patient.

Anon!: Of it own color too.
Goodbye!: It’s own color too.

Anon!: This guest of summer, The temple-haunting martlet, does approve, By his loved mansionry, that the heaven’s breath Smells wooingly here.
Goodbye!: This summer guest, the temple-haunting martlet, approves, by his loved mansion, that the heaven’s breath is wooing here.

Anon!: Is ’t far you ride?
Goodbye!: Is it far away you’re riding?

Anon!: Call her forth to me.
Goodbye!: Call her out to me.

Anon!: Juno and Ceres whisper seriously.
Goodbye!: Juno and Ceres whisper quietly.

Anon!: All that I will tell you is that the duke hath dined.
Goodbye!: I’ll tell you all that the duke has sat there.

Anon!: Well then, the peace which you before so urged Lies in his answer.
Goodbye!: Well then, the peace you urged you to give him is the answer he gave him.

Anon!: I am an ass, I am a woman’s man, and besides myself.
Goodbye!: I’m an ass, I’m a woman’s man, and besides myself.

Anon!: Who chooseth me shall get as much as he deserves.” And well said too—for who shall go about To cozen fortune and be honorable Without the stamp of merit?
Goodbye!: Who chooses me will get as much as he deserves.” And well said too—who will go about to be a sane man and be honorable without the stamp of merit?

Anon!: What was your dream, my lord?
Goodbye!: What was your dream, my lord?

Anon!: Good morrow, Kate—for that’s your name, I hear.
Goodbye!: Good morning, Kate—that’s your name, I hear.

Anon!: Well run, Thisbe!
Goodbye!: Good run, Thisbe!

Anon!: The Moor’s abused by some most villainous knave, Some base notorious knave, some scurvy fellow.
Goodbye!: The Moor’s been abused by some villainous knave, some notorious knave, some scurvy fellow.

Anon!: My lord.
Goodbye!: My lord.

Anon!: Ah, Juliet, if the measure of thy joy Be heaped like mine, and that thy skill be more To blazon it, then sweeten with thy breath This neighbor air, and let rich music’s tongue Unfold the imagined happiness that both Receive in either by this dear encounter.
Goodbye!: Ah, Juliet, if you’re a little more happy than mine, and you’re more capable of blazoning it, then you’ll sweeten this neighbor with your breath, and let the rich music’

Anon!: These gloves the Count sent me, they are an excellent perfume.
Goodbye!: The Count sent me these gloves, and they’re an excellent perfume.

Anon!: Where am I?
Goodbye!: Where am I?

Anon!: Fouler than heart can think thee, thou canst make No excuse current but to hang thyself.
Goodbye!: If you’re frightened than your heart can think of you, you can’t make excuses for yourself to hang yourself.

Anon!: Are these things spoken, or do I but dream?
Goodbye!: Are you talking about these things, or do I dream?

Anon!: I will go seek him.—Cassio, walk hereabout.
Goodbye!: I’ll go find him.—Cassio, walk hereabout.

Anon!: I would not for the wealth of all the town Here in my house do him disparagement.
Goodbye!: I wouldn’t punish him for the wealth of the whole town here in my house.

Anon!: Truly, I have him, but I would not be the party that should desire you to touch him, for his biting is immortal.
Goodbye!: I have him, but I wouldn’t be the party that wants you to touch him, because he’s immortal.

Anon!: I think it lacks of twelve.
Goodbye!: I think it’s not twelve.

Anon!: Most veritable, therefore look to ’t well.
Goodbye!: That’s true, so be sure to do it well.

Anon!: Let him appear that’s come from Antony.
Goodbye!: Let him appear to be from Antony.

Anon!: Your accent is something finer than you could purchase in so removed a dwelling.
Goodbye!: Your accent is something finer than you could buy in such a ruined house.

Anon!: Peter!
Goodbye!: Peter!

Anon!: Who of my people hold him in delay?
Goodbye!: Who of my people are waiting for him?

Anon!: No, faith, hate him not, for my sake.
Goodbye!: No, please don’t hate him, for my sake.

Anon!: The French might have a good prey of us if he knew of it, for there is none to guard it but boys.
Goodbye!: The French could have a good prey of us if he knew about it, because there are no guards for it except boys.

Anon!: Sir, I never loved you much, but I ha’ praised ye When you have well deserved ten times as much As I have said you did.
Goodbye!: Sir, I never loved you much, but I’ve praised you when you deserve ten times as much as I said you did.

Anon!: I would not kill thy unpreparèd spirit.
Goodbye!: I wouldn’t kill your unprepared spirit.

Anon!: He will not fight with me, Domitius?
Goodbye!: He won’t fight with me, Domitius?

Anon!: Fly, fly, my lord.
Goodbye!: Fly, fly, my lord.

Anon!: My master is the great rich Capulet, and if you be not of the house of Montagues, I pray come and crush a cup of wine.
Goodbye!: My master is the great rich Capulet, and if you don’t belong to the house of Montagues, please come and crush a cup of wine.

Anon!: Why?
Goodbye!: Why?

Anon!: What sayst thou, my dear Nurse?
Goodbye!: What do you say, my dear Nurse?

Anon!: I say amen to her.
Goodbye!: I say amen to her.

Anon!: What sights, my lord?
Goodbye!: What sights, my lord?

Anon!: I pity thy complaining.
Goodbye!: I’m sorry you’re complaining.

Anon!: Sweet Prince, you learn me noble thankfulness.— There, Leonato, take her back again.
Goodbye!: Sweet Prince, you learn how to be thankful.—Leonato, take her back again.

Anon!: Nay, you need not fear us, Lorenzo.
Goodbye!: No, you don’t need to worry about us, Lorenzo.

Anon!: Mad for thy love?
Goodbye!: Are you mad for your love?

Anon!: This was his basket.
Goodbye!: This was his basket.

Anon!: Your Grace may do your pleasure.
Goodbye!: Your Grace can do whatever you want.

Anon!: And all for nothing— For Hecuba!
Goodbye!: And for nothing— For Hecuba!

Anon!: His employment between his lord and my niece confirms no less.
Goodbye!: His relationship with my niece is no less than impressive.

Anon!: Any man that can write may answer a letter.
Goodbye!: Any man who can write can answer a letter.

Anon!: Tybalt’s death Was woe enough, if it had ended there.
Goodbye!: Tybalt’s death was a terrible one if it had ended there.

Anon!: Thus goes everyone to the world but I, and I am sunburnt.
Goodbye!: So everyone goes to the world except me, and I’m sunburnt.

Anon!: I and my sword will earn our chronicle.
Goodbye!: I and my sword will earn our chronicle.

Anon!: Well get you gone.
Goodbye!: Well, go away.

Anon!: Cleopatra— Why should I think you can be mine, and true— Though you in swearing shake the thronèd gods— Who have been false to Fulvia?
Goodbye!: Cleopatra— Why should I think you’re my true man—though you swear to shake the throne gods—who have been false to Fulvia?

Anon!: That may be, for you bear a many superfluously, and ’twere more honor some were away.
Goodbye!: That may be true, because you’re a lot too wealthy to be rewarded, and some were away.

Anon!: Go to the pulpit, Brutus.
Goodbye!: Go to the pulpit, Brutus.

Anon!: Thou art come to answer A stony adversary, an inhuman wretch Uncapable of pity, void and empty From any dram of mercy.
Goodbye!: You’ve come to answer a stony adversary, an inhuman wretch, unpityable, empty and unreliable from any dram of mercy.

Anon!: Good friend, go to him.
Goodbye!: Good friend, go to him.

Anon!: I go.
Goodbye!: I’m going.

Anon!: When good manners shall lie all in one or two men’s hands, and they unwashed too, ’tis a foul thing.
Goodbye!: When one or two men are in their hands and they’re unwashed too, it’s a foul thing.

Anon!: Be not too late.
Goodbye!: Don’t be late.

Anon!: Within my sword’s length set him; if he ’scape, Heaven forgive him too.
Goodbye!: Set him in my sword, and if he escapes, Heaven forgive him too.

Anon!: Why, Rosalind!
Goodbye!: Rosalind!

Anon!: Shall we to th' court?
Goodbye!: Should we go to court?

Anon!: Give me leave.— I am a gentleman of Verona, sir, That hearing of her beauty and her wit, Her affability and bashful modesty, Her wondrous qualities and mild behavior, Am bold to show myself a forward guest Within your house, to make mine eye the witness Of that report which I so oft have heard.
Goodbye!: I’m a gentleman of Verona, sir.

Anon!: I humbly thank you, sir.
Goodbye!: Thank you very much, sir.

Anon!: Let me hear Agrippa further speak.
Goodbye!: Let me hear Agrippa speak more.

Anon!: Where’s that mongrel?
Goodbye!: Where’s that mongrel?

Anon!: As you on him, Demetrius dote on you!
Goodbye!: As you look at him, Demetrius looks at you!

Anon!: Why, he has three thousand ducats a year.
Goodbye!: Why, he has three thousand ducats a year.

Anon!: Within these three days let me hear thee say That Cassio’s not alive.
Goodbye!: Within three days let me hear you say Cassio’s not alive.

Anon!: What says this leaden casket?
Goodbye!: What does this lead casket say?

Anon!: Why, you must not speak that yet.
Goodbye!: You haven’t heard that yet.

Anon!: I will be treble-sinewed, -hearted, -breathed, And fight maliciously.
Goodbye!: I’ll be treble-sinewed, hearted, breathed, and fight maliciously.

Anon!: Come, your answer in broken music, for thy voice is music and thy English broken.
Goodbye!: Come on, listen to your broken music, because your voice is music and your English broken.

Anon!: What if this mixture do not work at all?
Goodbye!: What if this mixture doesn’t work at all?

Anon!: Marry, sir, because silver hath a sweet sound.
Goodbye!: Sir, because silver has a sweet sound.

Anon!: Begin you to grow upon me?
Goodbye!: Do you want to grow up on me?

Anon!: And did you see the handkerchief?
Goodbye!: And did you see the handkerchief?

Anon!: O Antony, beg not your death of us.
Goodbye!: Oh Antony, don’t beg us to die.

Anon!: But let that go.
Goodbye!: But let that go.

Anon!: Very well.
Goodbye!: Very well.

Anon!: Therein our letters do not well agree.
Goodbye!: In our letters, we don’t agree well.

Anon!: I never heard a passion so confused, So strange, outrageous, and so variable, As the dog Jew did utter in the streets.
Goodbye!: I never heard a passion so confused, so strange, outrageous, and so variable, as the dog Jew uttered in the streets.

Anon!: Thou liest.
Goodbye!: You lie.

Anon!: Come let’s in all.
Goodbye!: Let’s go.

Anon!: So may it be indeed.
Goodbye!: Yes, it may be.

Anon!: She give it Cassio?
Goodbye!: She gave it to Cassio?

Anon!: You do mistake your business.
Goodbye!: You’re wrong about your business.

Anon!: Your heart’s desires be with you.
Goodbye!: Your heart desires are with you.

Anon!: Come, draw the curtain, Nerissa.
Goodbye!: Come on, draw the curtain, Nerissa.

Anon!: Wert thou not my brother, I would not take this hand from thy throat till this other had pulled out thy tongue for saying so.
Goodbye!: Don’t bet my brother, I wouldn’t take this hand from your throat until this other had pulled out your tongue for saying that.

Anon!: Fare you well.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: I would I were, to be revenged on thee.
Goodbye!: I wish I were, to be revenged on you.

Anon!: No.
Goodbye!: No.

Anon!: O treachery!
Goodbye!: Oh, treachery!

Anon!: Nay, I have offered all, I have no more, And she can have no more than all I have.
Goodbye!: No, I’ve offered everything, I have no more, and she can’t have more than everything I have.

Anon!: Tell me your mind.
Goodbye!: Tell me your thoughts.

Anon!: I wish, forbear.
Goodbye!: I wish, please.

Anon!: The gods withhold me!
Goodbye!: The gods withhold me!

Anon!: Did ever dragon keep so fair a cave?
Goodbye!: Did a dragon ever keep such a beautiful cave?

Anon!: I must needs after him, madam, with my letter.
Goodbye!: I have to follow him with my letter, madam.

Anon!: Upon that I kiss your hand, and I call you my queen.
Goodbye!: I kiss your hand and call you my queen.

Anon!: Who sued to me for him?
Goodbye!: Who sued me for him?

Anon!: I am the son of Marcus Cato, ho!
Goodbye!: I’m Marcus Cato’s son!

Anon!: Therefore tremble and depart.
Goodbye!: So hurry up and leave.

Anon!: It is the greatest admiration in the universal world when the true and aunchient prerogatifes and laws of the wars is not kept.
Goodbye!: It’s the greatest admiration in the universal world when the true and utterly utter prerogatives and laws of the wars aren’t kept.

Anon!: I had rather be a country servant-maid Than a great queen with this condition, To be so baited, scorned, and stormèd at.
Goodbye!: I’d rather be a country servant-maid than a great queen with this condition, to be so baited, scorned, and stormed.

Anon!: Shall we not, Sir Andrew?
Goodbye!: Shouldn’t we, Sir Andrew?

Anon!: Surely, a princely testimony, a goodly count, Count Comfect, a sweet gallant, surely!
Goodbye!: Yes, a good count, Count Comfect, a sweet gallant, surely!

Anon!: Make forth.
Goodbye!: Go ahead.

Anon!: I hear their drum.
Goodbye!: I hear their drum.

Anon!: I thank your lordship.
Goodbye!: Thank you, sir.

Anon!: Not I, believe me.
Goodbye!: Not me, believe me.

Anon!: I am afeard, Being in night, all this is but a dream, Too flattering sweet to be substantial.
Goodbye!: I’m afeard, because it’s night, all this is just a dream, too sweet to be substantial.

Anon!: But will you woo this wildcat?
Goodbye!: But will you woo this wildcat?

Anon!: By this hand, I love thee.
Goodbye!: By this hand, I love you.

Anon!: Look, look, a mouse!
Goodbye!: Look, look, a mouse!

Anon!: And when your honors mean to solemnize The bargain of your faith, I do beseech you Even at that time I may be married too.
Goodbye!: And when your honors mean to solemnize the deal of your faith, I beg you to marry me too.

Anon!: Here comes the little villain.
Goodbye!: Here comes the little villain.

Anon!: What meanest thou by that, Malvolio?
Goodbye!: What do you mean by that, Malvolio?

Anon!: Then stand with us.
Goodbye!: Then stand with us.

Anon!: God be wi' you, sir.
Goodbye!: God be quiet, sir.

Anon!: No, he’s a yeoman that has a gentleman to his son, for he’s a mad yeoman that sees his son a gentleman before him.
Goodbye!: No, he’s a man who has a gentleman to his son, because he’s a mad man who sees his son as a gentleman to him.

Anon!: They would have me as familiar with men’s pockets as their gloves or their handkerchers, which makes much against my manhood, if I should take from another’s pocket to put into mine, for it is plain pocketing up of wrongs.
Goodbye!: They would have me as familiar with men’s pockets as their gloves or handkerchiefs, which is much against my manhood if I took from another’s pocket to put into mine, because it’s just a pocket

Anon!: Who brought it?
Goodbye!: Who brought it?

Anon!: Come, gentlemen, Let us consult upon tomorrow’s business Into my tent.
Goodbye!: Come, gentlemen, let’s go to my tent to discuss the business of tomorrow.

Anon!: Yea, leave that labor to great Hercules, And let it be more than Alcides' twelve.
Goodbye!: Yes, leave that work to great Hercules, and let it be more than Alcides’ twelve.

Anon!: Good name in man and woman, dear my lord, Is the immediate jewel of their souls.
Goodbye!: The name of men and women, dear my lord, is the jewel of their souls.

Anon!: Therefore turn and draw.
Goodbye!: So turn and draw.

Anon!: Blessed pudding!
Goodbye!: Blessed pudding!

Anon!: In honest plainness thou hast heard me say My daughter is not for thee.
Goodbye!: You’ve heard me say my daughter isn’t for you.

Anon!: That ever I should live to see thee dead.
Goodbye!: I wish I could live forever to see you dead.

Anon!: Here it is, I think.
Goodbye!: Here it is, I think.

Anon!: You speak to Casca, and to such a man That is no fleering telltale.
Goodbye!: You speak to Casca, and to a man like that who’s not a slander.

Anon!: Content.
Goodbye!: Content.

Anon!: I saw ’t not, thought it not, it harmed not me.
Goodbye!: I didn’t see it, I didn’t think it was, it didn’t hurt me.

Anon!: What can he say in this?
Goodbye!: What does he say in this?

Anon!: If you have lost him, Why, I have lost him too.
Goodbye!: If you’ve lost him, why, I’ve lost him too.

Anon!: Could my good brother suffer you to do it— A man, a prince by him so benefited?
Goodbye!: Could my good brother suffer you to do it— A man, a prince by him so benefitted?

Anon!: It is to be all made of sighs and tears, And so am I for Phoebe.
Goodbye!: It’s all about being made of sighs and tears, and so am I for Phoebe.

Anon!: I have heard that Julius Caesar Grew fat with feasting there.
Goodbye!: I’ve heard that Julius Caesar ate there fat.

Anon!: Here’s a good world the while.
Goodbye!: Here’s a good world.

Anon!: Of Mantua.
Goodbye!: Mantua.

Anon!: Bring him silently.
Goodbye!: Bring him to rest.

Anon!: I cannot speak of this.
Goodbye!: I can’t speak of this.

Anon!: What are you?
Goodbye!: Who are you?

Anon!: I would have blowed up the town, so Chrish save me, la, in an hour.
Goodbye!: I wish I had blown up the town, so Chrish saved me in an hour.

Anon!: I understand not what you mean by this.
Goodbye!: I don’t understand what you mean by this.

Anon!: The son and heir of old Tiberio.
Goodbye!: The son and heir of old Tiberio.

Anon!: To our house.
Goodbye!: To our house.

Anon!: He is wise, And, on my life, hath stol'n him home to bed.
Goodbye!: He’s wise, and I’ve stolped him home to bed.

Anon!: O perjured woman, thou dost stone my heart, And mak’st me call what I intend to do A murder, which I thought a sacrifice!
Goodbye!: Oh, perjury woman, you stone my heart, and you’re calling what I intend to do a murder, which I thought was a sacrifice!

Anon!: O gentle lady, 'Tis not for you to hear what I can speak: The repetition, in a woman’s ear, Would murder as it fell.
Goodbye!: Oh, lady, it’s not for you to hear what I can say: I’d murder as if I were in a woman’s ear.

Anon!: Be eloquent in my behalf to her.
Goodbye!: Be eloquent to her in my behalf.

Anon!: But I confess, sir, that we were locked out.
Goodbye!: But I admit, sir, that we were locked out.

Anon!: If she be in her chamber or your house, Let loose on me the justice of the state For thus deluding you.
Goodbye!: If she’s in your house or in her room, let me get the justice of the state for deluding you.

Anon!: I could marry this wench for this device.
Goodbye!: I could marry this man for this device.

Anon!: But, brother, I can tell you strange news that you yet dreamt not of.
Goodbye!: But brother, I can tell you strange news that you haven’t dreamed of.

Anon!: If you did wed my sister for her wealth, Then for her wealth’s sake use her with more kindness.
Goodbye!: If you married my sister for her wealth, then for her wealth’s sake, use her with more kindness.

Anon!: Thou know’st the mask of night is on my face, Else would a maiden blush bepaint my cheek For that which thou hast heard me speak tonight.
Goodbye!: You know that the night mask is on my face, and you would be a maiden blushing on my cheek for the one you heard me say tonight.

Anon!: Caesar and Antony have ever won More in their officer than person.
Goodbye!: Caesar and Antony have ever won more in their officers than in their person.

Anon!: What, dost thou make us minstrels?
Goodbye!: What, are you making us minstrels?

Anon!: Speak.
Goodbye!: Speak.

Anon!: Come on then.
Goodbye!: Come on, then.

Anon!: Ay.
Goodbye!: Yes.

Anon!: This was the most unkindest cut of all.
Goodbye!: This was the most unkind cut of all.

Anon!: Beat him enough.
Goodbye!: Beat him up.

Anon!: O, she that might have intercepted thee, By strangling thee in her accursèd womb, From all the slaughters, wretch, that thou hast done.
Goodbye!: Oh, the woman who could have killed you by strangling you in her womb, from all the slaughters you’ve done, you’ve done.

Anon!: Not in the legions Of horrid hell can come a devil more damned In evils to top Macbeth.
Goodbye!: Not in the throne of horrid hell can make a devil damned more than Macbeth can make a fortune.

Anon!: So, with two seeming bodies but one heart, Two of the first, like coats in heraldry, Due but to one and crownèd with one crest.
Goodbye!: So, with two seemingly identical bodies but one heart, two of the first, like coats in heraldry, due only to one and crowned with one crest.

Anon!: And what noise is this?
Goodbye!: And what’s this noise?

Anon!: Villain, thou liest; for even her very words Didst thou deliver to me on the mart.
Goodbye!: You’re a fool, you lie.

Anon!: Let our catch be “Thou Knave.” “Hold thy peace, thou knave,” knight?
Goodbye!: Let’s catch “You knave.” “Hold your peace, you knave,” knight?

Anon!: Tis midnight.
Goodbye!: It’s midnight.

Anon!: I may command where I adore.” Why, she may command me.
Goodbye!: I can command where I love.” Why, she can command me.

Anon!: It is good for your green wound and your ploody coxcomb.
Goodbye!: It’s good for your green wound and your ploody coxcomb.

Anon!: Be these the wretches that we played at dice for?
Goodbye!: Are these the wretches we played dice for?

Anon!: What, is he dead?
Goodbye!: What, is he dead?

Anon!: Hie you, Messala, And I will seek for Pindarus the while.
Goodbye!: Hey, Messala, and I’ll look for Pindarus for a while.

Anon!: If I may trust the flattering truth of sleep, My dreams presage some joyful news at hand.
Goodbye!: If I can trust the flattering truth of sleep, my dreams are a good sign of joy.

Anon!: Where’s satisfaction?
Goodbye!: Where’s the satisfaction?

Anon!: Your bedchamber.
Goodbye!: Your bedchamber.

Anon!: One Hero died defiled, but I do live, And surely as I live, I am a maid.
Goodbye!: I live, and as I live, I’m a maid.

Anon!: I say thou hast belied mine innocent child.
Goodbye!: I say you’ve been lied to my innocent child.

Anon!: I will here be with thee presently, and if I bring thee not something to eat, I will give thee leave to die.
Goodbye!: I’ll be here with you now, and if I bring you something to eat, I’ll give you permission to die.

Anon!: An I were so apt to quarrel as thou art, any man should buy the fee simple of my life for an hour and a quarter.
Goodbye!: If I were so apt to fight like you, anyone would buy the basic wage of my life for an hour and a quarter.

Anon!: Something, sure, of state, Either from Venice, or some unhatched practice Made demonstrable here in Cyprus to him, Hath puddled his clear spirit, and in such cases Men’s natures wrangle with inferior things, Though great ones are their object.
Goodbye!: A man who’s puddled his spirit in a state, either from Venice, or from Cyprus, has puddled his spirit, and in such cases men’s nature is wrangled with inferior things,

Anon!: On my knees I beg That you’ll vouchsafe me raiment, bed, and food.” Good sir, no more.
Goodbye!: I beg you to scold me for a bit of raiment, bed, and food.” Good sir, don’t worry.

Anon!: Ay, what of that?
Goodbye!: Yes, what about that?

Anon!: I’ll fetch some flax and whites of eggs To apply to his bleeding face.
Goodbye!: I’ll get some flax and whites of eggs to apply to his bleeding face.

Anon!: Some blessed power deliver us from hence!
Goodbye!: Some blessed power will take us away from here!

Anon!: Sir, the gods Will have it thus.
Goodbye!: Sir, the gods will have it.

Anon!: It alone concerns your ear.
Goodbye!: It’s only about your ear.

Anon!: Hence “banishèd” is banished from the world, And world’s exile is death.
Goodbye!: So “banished” is banished from the world, and the world’s exile is death.

Anon!: Let the world see His nobleness well acted, which your death Will never let come forth.
Goodbye!: Let the world see how he is, and that your death will never come out.

Anon!: Thou shalt be loggerhead.—Good faith, ’tis day.
Goodbye!: You’ll be a loggerhead.—Good faith, it’s day.

Anon!: It were too gross To rib her cerecloth in the obscure grave.
Goodbye!: It was too gross to rib her cerecloth in the obscure grave.

Anon!: At this hour Lie at my mercy all mine enemies.
Goodbye!: At this hour, Lie at my mercy all my enemies.

Anon!: Sir, March is wasted fifteen days.
Goodbye!: Sir, fifteen days of March have passed.

Anon!: You may go to the devil’s dam!
Goodbye!: You can go to the devil’s dam!

Anon!: Speak, is ’t out o' th' way?
Goodbye!: Speak, is it out of the way?

Anon!: Not so, I do beseech your Majesty.
Goodbye!: Not true, I beg your Majesty.

Anon!: Be thou assured, good Cassio, I will do All my abilities in thy behalf.
Goodbye!: You can trust me, Cassio, I’ll do everything I can to help you.

Anon!: Grave sir, hail!
Goodbye!: Grave, sir!

Anon!: Why, how now, daughter Katherine?
Goodbye!: What’s going on, daughter Katherine?

Anon!: This does make some obstruction in the blood, this cross-gartering, but what of that?
Goodbye!: This is a way to block the blood, this cross-gartering, but what about that?

Anon!: Say, uncle Gloucester, if our brother come, Where shall we sojourn till our coronation?
Goodbye!: Say, uncle Gloucester, if our brother comes, where will we go until our coronation?

Anon!: I am debating of my present store, And by the near guess of my memory I cannot instantly raise up the gross Of full three thousand ducats.
Goodbye!: I’m talking about my present store, and I can’t raise up the total of three thousand ducats instantly.

Anon!: O, she tore the letter into a thousand halfpence, railed at herself that she should be so immodest to write to one that she knew would flout her.
Goodbye!: Oh, she tore the letter into a thousand halfpence, and railed at herself that she should be so cruel to write to one that she knew would frighten her.

Anon!: I do desire no more.
Goodbye!: I don’t want to do anything else.

Anon!: Without contradiction I have heard that.
Goodbye!: I’ve heard that without contradiction.

Anon!: I hear it now above me.
Goodbye!: I hear it above me.

Anon!: Therefore I’ll sleep again.
Goodbye!: So I’ll sleep again.

Anon!: For both our sakes, I would that word were true.
Goodbye!: For both of us, I wish that word were true.

Anon!: For learn this, Silius: Better to leave undone than by our deed Acquire too high a fame when him we serve’s away.
Goodbye!: If you learn this, Silius: better to leave and do something than to get a reputation for being too high when he’s away.

Anon!: Mark Antony, shall we give sign of battle?
Goodbye!: Mark Antony, should we give signs of battle?

Anon!: With all my heart.
Goodbye!: With all my heart.

Anon!: A good epithet!
Goodbye!: A good example!

Anon!: You may tell every finger I have with my ribs.
Goodbye!: You can tell me every finger I have with my ribs.

Anon!: This is nothing, Fool.
Goodbye!: This is nothing, Fool.

Anon!: Oh, such another sleep, that I might see But such another man!
Goodbye!: Oh, I’m going to sleep like this, so I could see another man like that!

Anon!: No, not for all the world.
Goodbye!: No, not for all the world.

Anon!: There’s knocking at the gate.
Goodbye!: There’s a knocking at the gate.

Anon!: His word might bear my wealth at any time.
Goodbye!: His word could bear my wealth anytime.

Anon!: I robbed his wound of it.
Goodbye!: I robbed his wound.

Anon!: Where is the number of our English dead?
Goodbye!: Where is the number of our English dead?

Anon!: The sleeping and the dead Are but as pictures.
Goodbye!: The sleeping and the dead are just as pictures.

Anon!: In the most high and palmy state of Rome, A little ere the mightiest Julius fell, The graves stood tenantless and the sheeted dead Did squeak and gibber in the Roman streets As stars with trains of fire and dews of blood, Disasters in the sun, and the moist star Upon whose influence Neptune’s empire stands Was sick almost to doomsday with eclipse.
Goodbye!: In the most high and palmy state of Rome, a little before the mightiest Julius fell, the graves stood empty and the dead squeak and gibber in the Roman streets as stars with fire and blood de

Anon!: Dat it is not be de fashion pour les ladies of France—I cannot tell wat is  To kiss.
Goodbye!: It doesn’t matter how much France loves—I can’t tell you how to kiss.

Anon!: Donalbain.
Goodbye!: Donalbain.

Anon!: The man should be put into the lanthorn.
Goodbye!: The man should be put in the ring.

Anon!: Draw thy tool!
Goodbye!: Draw your tool!

Anon!: I’ll claim that promise at your Grace’s hands.
Goodbye!: I’ll say that promise to you, your Grace.

Anon!: Faith, I know not what to say.
Goodbye!: I don’t know what to say.

Anon!: Look what I speak, or do, or think to do, You are still crossing it.
Goodbye!: Look what I’m saying, or do, or think to do, you’re still crossing it.

Anon!: Oh, whither hast thou led me, Egypt?
Goodbye!: Oh, where did you lead me, Egypt?

Anon!: Give me thy hand.
Goodbye!: Give me your hand.

Anon!: I will presently go learn their day of marriage.
Goodbye!: I’ll go learn their day of marriage.

Anon!: Hast thou not dropped from heaven?
Goodbye!: Don’t you have dropped from heaven?

Anon!: Come, will you go with me?
Goodbye!: Come on, will you come with me?

Anon!: Oh, thou wilt speak again of banishment.
Goodbye!: Oh, you’re going to talk about banishment again.

Anon!: Your honor calls you hence.
Goodbye!: Your honor is calling you here.

Anon!: Farewell, thou woeful welcomer of glory.
Goodbye!: Goodbye, you a sad welcomer of glory.

Anon!: You may be rightly just, Whatever I shall think.
Goodbye!: You may be just, whatever I think.

Anon!: Go seek him.
Goodbye!: Go find him.

Anon!: If all the devils of hell be drawn in little, and Legion himself possessed him, yet I’ll speak to him.
Goodbye!: If all the devils of hell are drawn in little, and Legion himself has possessed him, I’ll speak to him.

Anon!: Without, my lord; guarded, to know your pleasure.
Goodbye!: Without you, my lord, guarded, to know what you’re doing.

Anon!: I shall do well.
Goodbye!: I’ll do well.

Anon!: Burn!
Goodbye!: Burn!

Anon!: Sir, I commend you to your own content.
Goodbye!: Sir, I’ll tell you to be content.

Anon!: Whereby hangs a tale, sir?
Goodbye!: Where’s a story hanging, sir?

Anon!: Lepidus flatters both, Of both is flattered, but he neither loves, Nor either cares for him.
Goodbye!: Lepidus flatters both of them, but he doesn’t love him, and he doesn’t care about him.

Anon!: I am your neighbor, and was suitor first.
Goodbye!: I’m your neighbor, and I was suitor first.

Anon!: County Claudio, when mean you to go to church?
Goodbye!: County Claudio, when are you going to church?

Anon!: The sin upon my head, dread sovereign, For in the Book of Numbers is it writ: “When the man dies, let the inheritance Descend unto the daughter.” Gracious lord, Stand for your own, unwind your bloody flag, Look back into your mighty ancestors.
Goodbye!: The sin on my head, dreadful sovereign, because in the Book of Numbers it says: “When the man dies, let the inheritance be ruined by the daughter.” Gracious lord, stand for your own

Anon!: There are no tongues else for ’s turn.
Goodbye!: There are no other words for the turn.

Anon!: There’s money for your pains.
Goodbye!: There’s money for your pains.

Anon!: But tell not me.
Goodbye!: But don’t tell me.

Anon!: Your hand, Leonato.
Goodbye!: Your hand, Leonato.

Anon!: Fly not.
Goodbye!: Don’t fly.

Anon!: I think this tale would win my daughter too.
Goodbye!: I think this story would win my daughter too.

Anon!: Why he more than another?
Goodbye!: Why is he more than another?

Anon!: Why then, we are awake.
Goodbye!: Well then, we’re awake.

Anon!: I’ll come to him.
Goodbye!: I’ll come to him.

Anon!: Well, what is it?
Goodbye!: Well, what’s it?

Anon!: Do not lie so near.
Goodbye!: Don’t lie so close to me.

Anon!: Let your wedding be tomorrow.
Goodbye!: Let your wedding be tomorrow.

Anon!: Good sister, let us dine and never fret.
Goodbye!: Good sister, let’s eat and never fret.

Anon!: I have broke with her father and his goodwill obtained.
Goodbye!: I’ve broken up with her father and obtained his goodwill.

Anon!: I go.
Goodbye!: I’m going.

Anon!: Now must I to the monument alone.
Goodbye!: Now I have to go to the monument alone.

Anon!: She bids you come to her.
Goodbye!: She wants you to come to her.

Anon!: Ready.
Goodbye!: Ready.

Anon!: And from her womb children of divers kind We sucking on her natural bosom find, Many for many virtues excellent, None but for some and yet all different.
Goodbye!: And from her womb we’re sucking on her natural bosom, many for many virtues excellent, none but for some and yet all different.

Anon!: What tidings can you tell me of my lord?
Goodbye!: What advice can you tell me about my lord?

Anon!: I will watch tonight.
Goodbye!: I’ll watch tonight.

Anon!: My mind was never yet more mercenary.
Goodbye!: I never thought of more mercenary.

Anon!: What is his name?
Goodbye!: What’s his name?

Anon!: And these few precepts in thy memory Look thou character.
Goodbye!: And these little precepts in your memory look like you’re character.

Anon!: With who?
Goodbye!: With who?

Anon!: Tomorrow I intend to hunt again.
Goodbye!: Tomorrow I’ll hunt again.

Anon!: I have an humor to knock you indifferently well.
Goodbye!: I have an humor to knock you indifferently well.

Anon!: But soft, but soft a while.
Goodbye!: But it’s soft, but soft for a while.

Anon!: I myself could make A chough of as deep chat.
Goodbye!: I could make a chough of that as deep chat.

Anon!: Monster, lay to your fingers.
Goodbye!: Monster, lay to your fingers.

Anon!: I know thou wilt say “ay,” And I will take thy word.
Goodbye!: I know you’ll say “Yes,” and I’ll take your word.

Anon!: Alas Iago, What shall I do to win my lord again?
Goodbye!: Oh, Iago, what should I do to win my lord back?

Anon!: Who must hang them?
Goodbye!: Who must hang them?

Anon!: Your old smock brings forth a new petticoat, and indeed the tears live in an onion that should water this sorrow.
Goodbye!: Your old smock brings out a new petticoat, and the tears of an onion should be filled with sorrow.

Anon!: Speak to me home.
Goodbye!: Talk to me home.

Anon!: And joy comes well in such a needy time.
Goodbye!: And joy comes well in such a difficult time.

Anon!: Think, my lord?” Alas, thou echo’st me As if there were some monster in thy thought Too hideous to be shown.
Goodbye!: Think, my lord?” Oh, you’re echoing me like if you were thinking about something too hideous to be shown.

Anon!: Tis his own blame.
Goodbye!: He’s a victim.

Anon!: You shall do small respect, show too bold malice Against the grace and person of my master, Stocking his messenger.
Goodbye!: You’ll be a little disrespectful, and you’ll be a bit too bold to be a victim of my master’s grace and sanity, securing his messenger.

Anon!: If I do not love her, I am a Jew.
Goodbye!: If I don’t love her, I’m a Jew.

Anon!: I prithee, who?
Goodbye!: Please, who?

Anon!: Realms and islands were As plates dropped from his pocket.
Goodbye!: Realms and islands were dropped from his pocket as plates dropped from his pocket.

Anon!: So please my lord the duke and all the court, To quit the fine for one half of his goods I am content, so he will let me have The other half in use to render it Upon his death unto the gentleman That lately stole his daughter.
Goodbye!: I’m happy to leave the fine for half of his goods, so he’ll let me use the other half to make it available to the gentleman who stole his daughter recently.

Anon!: Why will you mew her up, Signior Baptista, for this fiend of hell And make her bear the penance of her tongue?
Goodbye!: Why will you bring her up, Signior Baptista, for this sin of hell and make her bear the penance of her tongue?

Anon!: And now forward with thy tale.
Goodbye!: Now go ahead with your story.

Anon!: Look, they weep, And I, an ass, am onion-eyed.
Goodbye!: Look, they cry, and I’m an ass.

Anon!: Excellent!
Goodbye!: Excellent!

Anon!: And if thy poor devoted servant may But beg one favor at thy gracious hand, Thou dost confirm his happiness forever.
Goodbye!: And if your poor servant can only beg one favor at your gracious hand, you’ll confirm his happiness forever.

Anon!: O, let him pass.
Goodbye!: Oh, let him pass.

Anon!: Their lips were four red roses on a stalk, And in their summer beauty kissed each other.
Goodbye!: Their lips were four red roses on a stalk, and in their summer beauty kissed each other.

Anon!: Ay, mine own fortune in my misery.
Goodbye!: Yes, I’m a good man in my mistress.

Anon!: But what will you be called?
Goodbye!: But what do you want?

Anon!: Hang there, my verse, in witness of my love.
Goodbye!: Hang here, my verse, to witness my love.

Anon!: Did not great Julius bleed for justice' sake?
Goodbye!: Didn’t great Julius bleed for justice?

Anon!: Talk not, Signior Gremio.
Goodbye!: Don’t talk, Signior Gremio.

Anon!: Even so great men great losses should endure.
Goodbye!: Even so great men should endure great losses.

Anon!: You may gather more.
Goodbye!: You can find out more.

Anon!: I will condole in some measure.—To the rest.—Yet my chief humor is for a tyrant.
Goodbye!: I’ll condole in some way.—To the rest of the world.—I’m a tyrant.

Anon!: Why, then, tomorrow I cannot serve your turn for Rosalind?
Goodbye!: So, why, then, tomorrow I won’t serve you as Rosalind?

Anon!: And, sister, as the winds give benefit And convey is assistant, do not sleep, But let me hear from you.
Goodbye!: And, sister, as the winds give benefit and convey is assistant, don’t sleep, but let me hear from you.

Anon!: Then let your will attend on their accords.
Goodbye!: Then let them take your will.

Anon!: This is a devil, and no monster.
Goodbye!: This is a devil, and no monster.

Anon!: The itch of his affection should not then Have nicked his captainship at such a point When half to half the world opposed, he being The merèd question.
Goodbye!: The itch of his affection shouldn’t have nicked his captainship at such a point when half to half the world opposed him, he being the merchandising question.

Anon!: Get thee gone, but do it.
Goodbye!: Go away, but do it.

Anon!: We will behold his death.
Goodbye!: We’ll see his death.

Anon!: Thou shalt not stir one foot to seek a foe.
Goodbye!: You won’t have to scold one foot to find a foe.

Anon!: Methinks your maw, like mine, should be your clock, And strike you home without a messenger.
Goodbye!: I think your maw should be your clock, like mine, and strike you home without a messenger.

Anon!: That dreamers often lie.
Goodbye!: Dreamers often lie.

Anon!: All myself?
Goodbye!: I’m all alone?

Anon!: I called thee then “vain flourish of my fortune.” I called thee then poor shadow, “painted queen,” The presentation of but what I was, The flattering index of a direful pageant, One heaved a-high, to be hurled down below, A mother only mocked with two fair babes, A dream of what thou wast, a garish flag To be the aim of every dangerous shot, A sign of dignity, a breath, a bubble, A queen in jest, only to fill the scene.
Goodbye!: I called you “vain of my fortune.” I called you a poor shadow, “painted queen,” the presentation of what I was, the flattering index of a direful pageant, one heaved a

Anon!: Bring her to try wi' th' main course.
Goodbye!: Bring her to try the main course.

Anon!: Ay, but these English are shrewdly out of beef.
Goodbye!: Yes, but these English are shrewdly out of beef.

Anon!: I cry thee mercy, then, for I did think That thou hadst called me all these bitter names.
Goodbye!: I’m crying for mercy, then, because I thought you had called me all these bitter names.

Anon!: Was not Count John here at supper?
Goodbye!: Didn’t Count John sit here at supper?

Anon!: No, pray thee, good Meg, I’ll wear this.
Goodbye!: No, please, good Meg, I’ll wear this.

Anon!: Where is my father and my mother, Nurse?
Goodbye!: Where are my father and my mother, Nurse?

Anon!: Why dost thou lash that whore?
Goodbye!: Why are you lashing that whore?

Anon!: A man, as you are.
Goodbye!: A man, as you are.

Anon!: Let pity not be believed.” There she shook The holy water from her heavenly eyes, And clamor moistened.
Goodbye!: She shook the holy water from her heavenly eyes and moistened her clamor.

Anon!: Since this fortune falls to you, Be content and seek no new.
Goodbye!: Since you’re losing your fortune, don’t be content and don’t seek anything new.

Anon!: Is it possible A cur can lend three thousand ducats?” Or Shall I bend low and in a bondman’s key With bated breath and whispering humbleness Say this:
Goodbye!: Is it possible a cur can lend three thousand ducats?” Or should I bend low and say this in a bondman’s key with bated breath and whispering humbleness:

Anon!: Aye, sir.
Goodbye!: Yes, sir.

Anon!: Hence, and stand aloof.
Goodbye!: Go away and stay away from me.

Anon!: This pernicious slave, Forsooth, took on him as a conjurer, And, gazing in mine eyes, feeling my pulse,
Goodbye!: This dangerous slave, Forsooth, took on him as a conjurer, and, gazeing in my eyes, feeling my pulse,

Anon!: Here, here, sir!
Goodbye!: Here, here, sir!

Anon!: Nor know I aught By me that’s said or done amiss this night, Unless self-charity be sometimes a vice, And to defend ourselves it be a sin When violence assails us.
Goodbye!: I don’t know anything about what I’m saying or doing this night, unless I’m not a good man, and to defend ourselves it’s a sin when violence kills us.

Anon!: So could I, faith, boy, to have the next wish after, That Lucentio indeed had Baptista’s youngest daughter.
Goodbye!: I could have the next wish, that Lucentio had Baptista’s youngest daughter.

Anon!: Or, if thou wilt, swear by thy gracious self, Which is the god of my idolatry, And I’ll believe thee.
Goodbye!: Or, if you want to swear by your gracious self, which is the god of my idolatry, and I’ll believe you.

Anon!: Do then, but I’ll not hear.
Goodbye!: Do then, but I won’t hear anything.

Anon!: Adieu.
Goodbye!: Goodbye.

Anon!: As mine eyes opened, I saw their weapons drawn.
Goodbye!: As my eyes opened, I saw their weapons drawn.

Anon!: Masters, play here, I will content your pains.
Goodbye!: Masters, play here, I’ll be happy to help you.

Anon!: No, indeed, my lord.
Goodbye!: No, my lord.

Anon!: How now?
Goodbye!: What’s going on?

Anon!: Plots have I laid, inductions dangerous, By drunken prophecies, libels and dreams, To set my brother Clarence and the king In deadly hate, the one against the other; And if King Edward be as true and just As I am subtle, false, and treacherous, This day should Clarence closely be mewed up About a prophecy which says that “G” Of Edward’s heirs the murderer shall be.
Goodbye!: I’ve laid out a lot of dangerous inductions, by drunken prophecies, libels and dreams, to set my brother Clarence and the king in deadly hate, the one against the other.

Anon!: I speak not yet of proof.
Goodbye!: I’m not talking about proof yet.

Anon!: Didst thou give all to thy two daughters, and art thou come to this?
Goodbye!: Did you give everything to your two daughters, and are you coming to this?

Anon!: Bring it hither to me in the orchard.
Goodbye!: Bring it here to me in the orchard.

Anon!: If she confess that she was half the wooer, Destruction on my head if my bad blame Light on the man.—Come hither, gentle mistress.
Goodbye!: If she confessed she was half the wooer, I’ll be ruined by the evil light on the man.—Come here, gentle mistress.

Anon!: That “sort” was well fished for.
Goodbye!: That “sort” was well rewarded.

Anon!: The king is full of grace and fair regard.
Goodbye!: The king is full of grace and fairness.

Anon!: So tell them, Publius.
Goodbye!: Tell them, Publius.

Anon!: Tis mine and I will have it.
Goodbye!: It’s mine, and I’ll have it.

Anon!: Her vine, the merry cheerer of the heart, Unprunèd, dies.
Goodbye!: Her vine, the merry cheerer of the heart, is unpruned.

Anon!: Thou shalt be whipped with wire and stewed in brine, Smarting in ling’ring pickle!
Goodbye!: You’ll be whipped with wire and stewed in brine, smarting in ling’ring pickle!

Anon!: Ay, and wisely.
Goodbye!: Yes, and wisely.

Anon!: There is no love in you.
Goodbye!: You don’t have any love.

Anon!: What should I stay— In this wild world?
Goodbye!: What should I do— In this wild world?

Anon!: I beseech thee, youth, Put not another sin upon my head By urging me to fury.
Goodbye!: I beg you, young man, don’t put another sin on my head by telling me to fury.

Anon!: Croak not, black angel.
Goodbye!: Don’t croak, black angel.

Anon!: To who, my lord?—Who hath the office?
Goodbye!: Who’s the office?

Anon!: Go, then, for ’tis in vain To seek him here that means not to be found.
Goodbye!: Go, then, because it’s in vain to find him here that doesn’t mean to be found.

Anon!: What hath he said?
Goodbye!: What did he say?

Anon!: I will say for you.
Goodbye!: I’ll say for you.

Anon!: The patch is kind enough, but a huge feeder, Snail-slow in profit, and he sleeps by day More than the wildcat.
Goodbye!: The patch is kind enough, but it’s a huge feeder, snail-slow in profit, and he sleeps by day more than the wildcat.

Anon!: That’s as much as to say they are fools that marry.
Goodbye!: That’s as much as to say they’re fools who marry.

Anon!: Ha?
Goodbye!: Ha?

Anon!: If the matter were good, my lord, I durst swear it were his.
Goodbye!: If the matter were good, my lord, I would swear it were his.

Anon!: O God, I have an ill-divining soul.
Goodbye!: Oh God, I have a bad-divining soul.

Anon!: Thy substance, valued at the highest rate, Cannot amount unto a hundred marks; Therefore by law thou art condemned to die.
Goodbye!: Your substance, valued at the highest rate, can’t be a hundred marks; therefore, by law you’re condemned to die.

Anon!: How hast thou the heart, Being a divine, a ghostly confessor, A sin-absolver, and my friend professed, To mangle me with that word “banishèd”?
Goodbye!: How have you been a divine, a ghostly confessor, a sin-absolver, and my friend said you’re trying to fool me with that word banishment?

Anon!: What wouldst thou have with me?
Goodbye!: What do you want with me?

Anon!: Ha, ha, ha!
Goodbye!: Ha, ha, ha!

Anon!: Silver.
Goodbye!: Silver.

Anon!: Call them again.
Goodbye!: Call them back again.

Anon!: Tis not to make me jealous To say my wife is fair, feeds well, loves company, Is free of speech, sings, plays, and dances.
Goodbye!: It’s not to make me jealous to say my wife is fair, is well fed, loves company, is free of speech, sings, plays, and dances.

Anon!: Beat me?
Goodbye!: Beat me?

Anon!: Is it a world to hide virtues in?
Goodbye!: Is it a world to hide virtues in?

Anon!: Bless the isle of Cyprus and our noble general Othello!
Goodbye!: Bless the island of Cyprus and our noble general Othello!

Anon!: Fathers that wear rags  Do make their children blind.
Goodbye!: Fathers who wear rags make their children blind.

Anon!: Follow his chariot, like the greatest spot Of all thy sex.
Goodbye!: Follow his chariot, like the greatest spot of your sex.

Anon!: Where is the rascal cook?
Goodbye!: Where is the rascal cook?

Anon!: It is here, Hamlet.
Goodbye!: It’s here, Hamlet.

Anon!: You shall do marvelous wisely, good Reynaldo, Before you visit him, to make inquire Of his behavior.
Goodbye!: You’ll do marvelous things wisely, good Reynaldo, before you visit him, to ask about his behavior.

Anon!: I am a fellow o' th' strangest mind i' th' world.
Goodbye!: I’m a fellow of the strangest minds in the world.

Anon!: Aboard, aboard, for shame!
Goodbye!: Take it on, for shame!

Anon!: Please you, draw near.—Louder the music there!
Goodbye!: Please, come near.—Louder the music there!

Anon!: Our wars are done, the Turks are drowned.
Goodbye!: Our wars are over, the Turks are drowned.

Anon!: Too familiar Is my dear son with such sour company.
Goodbye!: My dear son is too familiar with such sour company.

Anon!: Soon at five o'clock, Please you, I’ll meet with you upon the mart And afterward consort you till bedtime.
Goodbye!: Soon at five o'clock, please, I’ll meet you on the mart and then consort you till bedtime.

Anon!: Not on thy sole, but on thy soul, harsh Jew, Thou makest thy knife keen.
Goodbye!: You’re not on your sole, but on your soul, harsh Jew, you’re making your knife look like a king.

Anon!: You are too hot.
Goodbye!: You’re too hot.

Anon!: Nay, faith, I’ll see the church a' your back, and then come back to my master’s as soon as I can.
Goodbye!: No, I’ll see the church on your back, and then come back to my master’s as soon as I can.

Anon!: Come, shall we about it?
Goodbye!: Come on, should we do it?

Anon!: We’ll hear him what he says.
Goodbye!: We’ll hear what he says.

Anon!: O, teach me how I should forget to think!
Goodbye!: Oh, teach me how to forget to think!

Anon!: Prithee, peace.
Goodbye!: Please, calm down.

Anon!: For though she’s as like this as a crab’s like an apple, yet I can tell what I can tell.
Goodbye!: Even though she’s as like this as a crab’s like an apple, I can tell what I can tell.

Anon!: Oh, that I were a glove upon that hand That I might touch that cheek!
Goodbye!: Oh, I wish I were a glove on that hand so I could touch that cheek!

Anon!: See where his Grace stands, ’tween two clergymen.
Goodbye!: See where his Grace is, two clergymen.

Anon!: Ay me, what news?
Goodbye!: Yes, what news do you have?

Anon!: All’s one.
Goodbye!: It’s all one.

Anon!: Troth, my lord, I have played the part of Lady Fame.
Goodbye!: My lord, I’ve played the role of Lady Fame.

Anon!: Rub him about the temples.
Goodbye!: Rub him around the temples.

Anon!: Tis a blushing, shamefaced spirit that mutinies in a man’s bosom.
Goodbye!: It’s a blushing, shame-faced spirit that mutinies in a man’s heart.

Anon!: Therefore bear up and board 'em.—Servant- monster, drink to me.
Goodbye!: So keep up and board them.—Servant monster, drink to me.

Anon!: An thou make minstrels of us, look to hear nothing but discords.
Goodbye!: If you make a bunch of jokes about us, you’ll hear nothing but discords.

Anon!: Nay, it is true, or else I am a Turk.
Goodbye!: No, it’s true, or else I’m a Turk.

Anon!: I do beseech you To understand my purposes aright.
Goodbye!: I beg you to understand my purpose.

Anon!: Sir, have pity, I’ll be his surety.
Goodbye!: Sir, I’m sorry he’s going to be his best friend.

Anon!: Pray thee, sweet Mistress Margaret, deserve well at my hands by helping me to the speech of Beatrice.
Goodbye!: Please, sweet Mistress Margaret, I’m sure you deserve my help by helping me to speak with Beatrice.

Anon!: Good night.
Goodbye!: Good night.

Anon!: Servant-monster”?
Goodbye!: Servant-monster”?

Anon!: Could you not take some occasion without giving?
Goodbye!: Don’t you have to give up?

Anon!: So the gods keep you And make the hearts of Romans serve your ends.
Goodbye!: So the gods keep you and make the Romans’ hearts serve your purposes.

Anon!: The excuse that thou dost make in this delay Is longer than the tale thou dost excuse.
Goodbye!: The excuse you make for this delay is longer than the story you’re telling.

Anon!: No, my good lord.
Goodbye!: No, my good lord.

Anon!: They fell together all, as by consent.
Goodbye!: They all fell together, as if they were.

Anon!: One word more.
Goodbye!: One more thing.

Anon!: How now?
Goodbye!: What’s going on?

Anon!: And when I have my meed, I will away, For this will out, and then I must not stay.
Goodbye!: And when I have my sword, I’ll go away, because this will go away, and then I won’t stay.

Anon!: Truly, an obedient lady.
Goodbye!: Yes, she’s an obedient lady.

Anon!: Monster, I do smell all horse piss, at which my nose is in great indignation.
Goodbye!: Monster, I smell all horse piss, which is indigning my nose.

Anon!: Well, my good lord, I have informed them so.
Goodbye!: Well, my good lord, I’ve told them so.

Anon!: I would we were well rid of this knavery.
Goodbye!: I wish we were all rid of this snafus.

Anon!: My fairy lord, this must be done with haste.
Goodbye!: My fairy lord, this must be done quickly.

Anon!: And how was that ta'en up?
Goodbye!: And how did that get started?

Anon!: What’s thy name?
Goodbye!: What’s your name?

Anon!: O, now I need the priest that spake to me!
Goodbye!: Oh, now I need the priest who said to me!

Anon!: Thence I have followed it, Or it hath drawn me rather.
Goodbye!: I’ve followed it, or it has drawn me more.

Anon!: By our beards (if we had them), thou art.
Goodbye!: You’re a man by our beards (if we had them).

Anon!: What were I best to say?
Goodbye!: What should I say?

Anon!: Not a drop before.
Goodbye!: Not a drop before.

Anon!: Hence!
Goodbye!: Let’s go!

Anon!: Gives him three thousand crowns in annual fee And his commission to employ those soldiers, So levied as before, against the Polack, With an entreaty, herein further shown, That it might please you to give quiet pass Through your dominions for this enterprise, On such regards of safety and allowance As therein are set down.
Goodbye!: He’s given three thousand crowns annually, and his commission to hire those soldiers, as much as before, against the Polack, with an argument, herein further shown, that it would be nice to give quiet advice to your

Anon!: Why, then ’tis time to arm and give direction.
Goodbye!: Well, then it’s time to arm and give direction.

Anon!: Still live they, and forever let them last.
Goodbye!: They’re still alive, and they’ll be forever last.

Anon!: Not in this land shall he remain uncaught.
Goodbye!: He will not be killed in this land.

Anon!: Oh, dispatch me!
Goodbye!: Oh, send me!

Anon!: Why should I not?
Goodbye!: Why shouldn’t I?

Anon!: You know not what you do.
Goodbye!: You don’t know what you’re doing.

Anon!: What countryman?
Goodbye!: What countryman?

Anon!: How canst thou make me satisfaction?
Goodbye!: How can you make me happy?

Anon!: The wildest hath not such a heart as you.
Goodbye!: The wildest people don’t have such a heart as you.

Anon!: So.
Goodbye!: That’s true.

Anon!: Hear you, sir?
Goodbye!: Listen, sir?

Anon!: FOOL Oh, he’s drunk, Sir Toby, an hour agone.
Goodbye!: Oh, he’s drunk, Sir Toby, an hour old.

Anon!: News, my good lord, from Rome.
Goodbye!: News from Rome, my good lord.

Anon!: O, what cause have I, Thine being but a moiety of my moan, To overgo thy woes and drown thy cries!
Goodbye!: Oh, what reason do you have to overgo your troubles and drown your cries?

Anon!: You are both sure, and will assist me?
Goodbye!: You both are sure, and will help me?

Anon!: That’s not so.
Goodbye!: That’s not true.

Anon!: That will be ere the set of sun.
Goodbye!: That’ll be the sun.

Anon!: Wife, children, servants, all that could be found.
Goodbye!: Wife, children, servants, all that could be found.

Anon!: Young men’s love then lies Not truly in their hearts, but in their eyes.
Goodbye!: Then young men’s love isn’t true in their hearts, but in their eyes.

Anon!: He shall enlarge him.
Goodbye!: He’ll enlarge him.

Anon!: I am maimed for ever.
Goodbye!: I’ve been mutilated for a long time.

Anon!: I would not have given it for a wilderness of monkeys.
Goodbye!: I wouldn’t have given it to a monkey sanctuary.

Anon!: Our expectation hath this day an end.
Goodbye!: We’re expecting to see this day end.

Anon!: Then I, and you, and all of us fell down, Whilst bloody treason flourished over us.
Goodbye!: Then I, and you, and all of us fell down while bloody treason flourished over us.

Anon!: How many, as you guess?
Goodbye!: How many, as you guess?

Anon!: King Lear hath lost, he and his daughter ta'en.
Goodbye!: King Lear has lost his daughter and he has lost his daughter.

Anon!: Fetch me the handkerchief—my mind misgives.
Goodbye!: Give me the handkerchief—my mind is wrong.

Anon!: Good Lord for alliance!
Goodbye!: Good Lord for alliance!

Anon!: I will not go today, and ere I do It shall be what o'clock I say it is.
Goodbye!: I won’t go today, and if I do, it’ll be what time I say.

Anon!: What cursèd foot wanders this way tonight To cross my obsequies and true love’s rite?
Goodbye!: What foot is wandering this way tonight to cross my rite of love and obsequies?

Anon!: But, by 'r Lady, he must build churches then, or else shall he suffer not thinking on, with the hobby-horse, whose epitaph is “For, oh, for, oh, the hobby-horse is forgot.”      What means this, my lord?
Goodbye!: But by his Lady, he must build churches then, or else he won’t suffer thinking about it with the hobby-horse, whose epitaph is “For, oh, oh,

Anon!: Caesar, I shall.
Goodbye!: Caesar, I will.

Anon!: There, drink that for me.
Goodbye!: Here, drink that for me.

Anon!: My old brain is troubled.
Goodbye!: My old brain is troubled.

Anon!: These lily lips, This cherry nose, These yellow cowslip cheeks Are gone, are gone.
Goodbye!: These lily lips, this cherry nose, these yellow cowslip cheeks are gone.

Anon!: Scurvy knave!
Goodbye!: Scurvy knave!

Anon!: Look, sir, here comes the lady toward my cell.
Goodbye!: Look, sir, here comes the lady toward my cell.

Anon!: Well, go to, I will.
Goodbye!: Well, go to, I will.

Anon!: Half-blooded fellow, yes.
Goodbye!: Yes, a half-blooded fellow.

Anon!: And why, my Lady Wisdom?
Goodbye!: And why, my Lady Wisdom?

Anon!: I pray you, give me leave.
Goodbye!: Please, give me permission.

Anon!: Ay, and this.
Goodbye!: Yes, and this is.

Anon!: But I will punish home.
Goodbye!: But I’ll punish you home.

Anon!: I could well forbear ’t.
Goodbye!: I could bet it was.

Anon!: On a moderate pace I have since arrived but hither.
Goodbye!: I’ve only arrived here since I arrived at a moderate pace.

Anon!: All lost!
Goodbye!: All lost!

Anon!: I pray you, let me look upon the bond.
Goodbye!: Please, let me look at the contract.

Anon!: Why, how should she be murdered?
Goodbye!: Why, how should she be murdered?

Anon!: My purposes do draw me much about.
Goodbye!: My goals are a big draw for me.

Anon!: I am so much a fool, should I stay longer It would be my disgrace and your discomfort.
Goodbye!: I’m so a fool, if I stay longer, it would be my shame and your discomfort.

Anon!: Not I but my affairs have made you wait.
Goodbye!: I’ve only been there for you to wait.

Anon!: Ay, so we will.
Goodbye!: Yes, we will.

Anon!: By the Lord, madam, you wrong me, and the world shall know it.
Goodbye!: The Lord, madam, you wrong me, and the world will know it.

Anon!: Henceforward do your messages yourself.
Goodbye!: Now, do your messages yourself.

Anon!: Now entertain conjecture of a time When creeping murmur and the poring dark Fills the wide vessel of the universe.
Goodbye!: Now imagine a time when a creeping murmur and the darkening of the universe fills the vast vessel.

Anon!: Take him for all in all.
Goodbye!: Take him for everything.

Anon!: If she had been blessed, she would never have loved the Moor.
Goodbye!: If she had been blessed, she would never have loved the Moor.

Anon!: My lord!
Goodbye!: My lord!

Anon!: Alas, how shall this bloody deed be answered?
Goodbye!: How can I answer this bloody deed?

Anon!: Long love doth so.
Goodbye!: Love does that.

Anon!: Oh, that a lady of one man refused Should of another therefore be abused!
Goodbye!: Oh, that a lady of one man who refused to marry another should be abused!

Anon!: I’ll speak a prophecy ere I go.
Goodbye!: I’ll speak a prophecy before I go.

Anon!: Ay, in the temple, in the town, the field You do me mischief.
Goodbye!: Yes, you’re doing me mischief in the temple, in the town, in the field.

Anon!: Hear the noble Antony.
Goodbye!: Listen to the noble Antony.

Anon!: Nothing will come of nothing.
Goodbye!: Nothing will come from nothing.

Anon!: Now, if these men have defeated the law and outrun native punishment, though they can outstrip men, they have no wings to fly from God.
Goodbye!: Now, if these men have defeated the law and outrun native punishment, even though they can outstrip men, they have no wings to fly from God.

Anon!: Thus doth he force the swords of wicked men To turn their own points in their masters' bosoms.
Goodbye!: He’s forcing wicked men to turn their swords into their masters’ swords.

Anon!: Feel you your legs?
Goodbye!: Do you feel your legs?

Anon!: Signior?
Goodbye!: Signior?

Anon!: Think of it.
Goodbye!: Think about it.

Anon!: You must away tonight.
Goodbye!: You have to leave tonight.

Anon!: Alas, poor hurt fowl, now will he creep into sedges.
Goodbye!: Alas, poor hurt fowl, now he’ll creep into sedges.

Anon!: Oh, that brave Caesar!
Goodbye!: Oh, that brave Caesar!

Anon!: Of very ill manner.
Goodbye!: It’s very bad.

Anon!: No, not a whit.
Goodbye!: No, not a moment.

Anon!: So delicate with her needle, an admirable musician.
Goodbye!: She’s so delicate with her needle, an admirable musician.

Anon!: Oh, he hath murdered his master!
Goodbye!: Oh, he’s murdered his master!

Anon!: My niece Plantagenet Led in the hand of her kind aunt of Gloucester?
Goodbye!: My niece Plantagenet was hung in the hand by her kind aunt of Gloucester?

Anon!: It is the more like to be feigned.
Goodbye!: It’s more like being feigned.

Anon!: Nature in you stands on the very verge Of his confine.
Goodbye!: Nature in you is on the bringe of being confined to his confinement.

Anon!: It seems to me That yet we sleep, we dream.
Goodbye!: I’m sure we’re still sleeping, dreaming.

Anon!: And when the cross blue lightning seemed to open The breast of heaven, I did present myself Even in the aim and very flash of it.
Goodbye!: And when the blue lightning appeared to open the breast of heaven, I showed myself in the aim and flash of it.

Anon!: You have done well by water.
Goodbye!: You’ve done well by water.

Anon!: Therefore depart and leave him here with me.
Goodbye!: So leave and leave him here with me.

Anon!: Speak to him.
Goodbye!: Tell him.

Anon!: I, for my part, knew the tailor that made the wings she flew withal.
Goodbye!: I knew the tailor who made the wings she flew with.

Anon!: Or o' mine either?
Goodbye!: Or mine either?

Anon!: And will you, being a man of your breeding, be married under a bush like a beggar?
Goodbye!: And will you be married under a bush like a beggar?

Anon!: Ink and paper, Charmian.
Goodbye!: Ink and paper, Charmian.

Anon!: But what trade art thou?
Goodbye!: But what’s the trade you’re doing?

Anon!: Cannot a plain man live and think no harm, But thus his simple truth must be abused With silken, sly, insinuating jacks?
Goodbye!: Can’t a plain man live and think no harm, but he must be abused with silky, sly, insinuating jacks?

Anon!: Was it so late, friend, ere you went to bed, That you do lie so late?
Goodbye!: Was it so late, friend, when you went to bed, that you’re lying so late?

Anon!: Out, you green sickness, carrion!
Goodbye!: You green sickness, carrion!

Anon!: A most poor man made tame to fortune’s blows, Who by the art of known and feeling sorrows Am pregnant to good pity.
Goodbye!: A poor man who has been tame to fortune’s blows, who, by the means of being known and feeling sorrow, is pregnant to good pity.

Anon!: Thy currish spirit Governed a wolf who, hanged for human slaughter, Even from the gallows did his fell soul fleet, And whilst thou layest in thy unhallowed dam Infused itself in thee, for thy desires Are wolvish, bloody, starved, and ravenous.
Goodbye!: Your currish spirit ruled a wolf, who, hanged for human slaughter, even from the gallows, escaped his soul, and while you lay in your unhallowed dam, you infused

Anon!: That shows thou art unconfirmed.
Goodbye!: That’s what you’re not convinced of.

Anon!: Where is he?
Goodbye!: Where is he?

Anon!: He’s married, madam.
Goodbye!: He’s married, madam.
